vi_translation: “That's all there is to it,” the artist said after a while. “Two months ago I attended a crowded gathering at Mrs. Brandon's place. You know, we poor artists sometimes have to show ourselves in society, just to remind the public that we are not barbarians. Wearing a dress coat and a white tie, as you once told me, anyone, even a stockbroker, can gain the reputation of being civilized. So, after I had been in the room for about ten minutes, talking to overly ostentatious fat widows and dull academicians, I suddenly realized that someone was looking at me. I turned halfway around and saw Dorian Gray for the first time. When our eyes met, I felt that I was turning pale. A dreadful sense of curiosity took hold of me. I knew that I was face to face with someone whose mere personality was so fascinating that, if I allowed it to do so, it would absorb my whole nature, my whole soul, and even my very art. I did not want any external influence in my life. You know yourself, Harry, how independent I am by nature. I have always been able to control myself; and at least it had always been so until I met Dorian Gray. Then — but I don't know how to explain it to you. Something seemed to tell me that I was on the verge of a terrible crisis in my life. I had a strange feeling that Fate had in store for me exquisite joys and exquisite sorrows. I gradually became afraid, and turned to leave the room. It wasn't conscience that made me do so; it was something akin to cowardice. I felt no glory in trying to escape.”
tr_translation: After a pause, the painter said, "It all comes down to this." "Two months ago, I attended one of Lady Brandon's gatherings. You know, we poor artists occasionally have to show up in high society, just to remind everyone that we are not complete savages. Once, you told me; as long as one wears an evening coat and a white tie, anyone, even a stockbroker, can gain a reputation as a civilized person. Anyway, I had been in the room for about ten minutes. I was chatting with those large, overly adorned, elderly noblewomen and those tedious academy members when suddenly, I felt someone was looking at me. When I turned around, I saw Dorian Gray. I didn't know him at all. When our eyes met, I felt my face turn pale. A strange unease enveloped me. The mere presence of this person I was facing was so captivating that, if I allowed it, he could take over my entire being, my soul, even my art. I realized this immediately. Yet, I did not want any external interference in my life. You know how independent I am by nature, Harry. I have always been my own master. That is, until I met Dorian Gray. At that moment... But I don't know how to explain it to you. It was as if a voice was telling me that I was on the brink of a terrible crisis. I had a premonition that fate had prepared unparalleled joys and unparalleled sorrows for me. I got scared, turned around, and walked to the door with the intention of going outside. It wasn't the voice of my conscience that made me do this, it was a kind of cowardice. I'm not giving myself any credit for trying to escape.”
es_translation: —It's a very simple story —said the painter after some time—. Two months ago, I attended one of those parties thrown by Lady Brandon, which so many people go to. You know that we poor artists have to appear in society from time to time to remind the public that we are not savages. Dressed in formal attire and with a white tie, as you once told me, anyone, even a stockbroker, can earn a reputation for being civilized. Well, when I had been in the room for about ten minutes, chatting with imposing widows overly adorned with jewelry and tedious academics, I suddenly noticed that someone was looking at me. When I turned around, I saw Dorian Gray for the first time. When our eyes met, I felt myself turn pale. A strange sensation of terror took hold of me. I knew that I had before me someone with such a fascinating personality that, if I allowed it, he would absorb my entire existence, my whole soul, even my art. I did not want any external influence in my life. You know perfectly well how independent I am by nature. I have always done what I wanted; at least, until I met Dorian Gray. Then... although I don't know how to explain it to you. Something seemed to tell me that I was on the verge of a terrible crisis. I had the strange feeling that Fate had exquisite joys and terrible sufferings in store for me. I got scared and turned around to leave the room. It wasn't conscience that drove me to do it: rather something akin to cowardice. I don't attribute any merit to myself for having tried to escape.

en: “Conscience and cowardice are really the same things, Basil. Conscience is the trade-name of the firm. That is all.”
vi: “Lương tâm và hèn nhát thực ra là những thứ giống nhau mà, Basil. Lương tâm là tên thương mại của hãng. Chỉ vậy thôi.”
tr: “Vicdan ve ödleklik aslında aynı şeydir, Basil. Vicdan şirketin piyasada bilinen adıdır, hepsi bu.
es: —Conciencia y cobardía son en realidad lo mismo, Basil. La conciencia es la marca registrada de la empresa. Eso es todo.
vi_translation: “Conscience and cowardice are really the same thing, Basil. Conscience is the trade name of the firm. That is all.”
tr_translation: “Conscience and cowardice are really the same thing, Basil. Conscience is just the trade name of the firm, that's all.”
es_translation: —Conscience and cowardice are really the same thing, Basil. Conscience is the trade name of the firm. That is all.

en: “I don’t believe that, Harry, and I don’t believe you do either. However, whatever was my motive—and it may have been pride, for I used to be very proud—I certainly struggled to the door. There, of course, I stumbled against Lady Brandon. ‘You are not going to run away so soon, Mr. Hallward?’ she screamed out. You know her curiously shrill voice?”
vi: “Tôi không tin điều ấy đâu, Harry, và tôi không tin là anh lại thế. Tuy nhiên, dẫu mô-típ của tôi có thế nào — và nó có thể là niềm kiêu hãnh, vì tôi thường rất tự hào — tôi vẫn dứt khoát len ra cửa. Ở đó, tất nhiên, tôi lại bắt gặp bà Brandon. ‘Anh đừng bỏ về sớm vậy chứ, mít-tơ Hallward?’ bà ấy la lên. Chắc anh có biết cái giọng lanh lảnh lạ lùng của bà ta?”
tr: “Ben buna inanmıyorum, Harry; senin bu fikirde olduğuna da inanmıyorum. Her neyse, beni böyle davranmaya iten her ne idiyse... belki de gururdur, bir zamanla çok gururluydum... Gerçek şu ki kalabalığı yararak kapıya yöneldim. Ne var ki orada, Leydi Brandon’la çarpıştım doğallıkla. Leydi Brandon, ‘mr Hallward, böyle erken erken kaçıyor musunuz yoksa?’ diye yaygarayı bastı. Sesi ne tuhaf tiz çıkar, bilirsin ya!
es: —No lo creo, Harry, y me parece que tampoco lo crees tú. Fuera cual fuese mi motivo, y quizá se tratara orgullo, porque he sido siempre muy orgulloso, conseguí llegar a duras penas hasta la puerta. Pero allí, por supuesto, me tropecé con lady Brandon. «¿No irá usted a marcharse tan pronto, señor Hallward?», me gritó. ¿Recuerdas la voz tan peculiarmente estridente que tiene?
vi_translation: “I don't believe that, Harry, and I don't believe you would either. However, regardless of my motive — and it could be pride, as I am often very proud — I still resolutely made my way to the door. There, of course, I encountered Mrs. Brandon again. ‘Don't leave so early, Mr. Hallward?’ she exclaimed. Surely you know her strange, shrill voice?”
tr_translation: “I don't believe this, Harry; I don't believe you think this way either. Anyway, whatever it was that made me act this way... maybe it was pride, I used to be very proud once... The truth is, I made my way through the crowd towards the door. But there, I naturally collided with Lady Brandon. Lady Brandon exclaimed, ‘Mr. Hallward, are you running away so early?’ You know how oddly high-pitched her voice is!”
es_translation: —I don't believe it, Harry, and it seems to me that you don't believe it either. Whatever my motive was, and perhaps it was pride, because I have always been very proud, I managed to barely make it to the door. But there, of course, I ran into Lady Brandon. «You're not leaving so soon, Mr. Hallward?», she shouted at me. Do you remember the peculiarly shrill voice she has?

en: “Yes; she is a peacock in everything but beauty,” said Lord Henry, pulling the daisy to bits with his long nervous fingers.
vi: “Vâng; bà ấy là một con công trên mọi phương diện ngoại trừ sắc đẹp,” huân tước Henry vừa nói vừa bứt bông cúc thành nhiều mảnh bằng những ngón tay dài, bồn chồn của mình.
tr: Lord Henry, papatyayı o uzun, duyarlı parmaklarıyla didik didik ederek, “Evet, güzelliği dışında her şeyiyle tavuskuşudur,” dedi.
es: —Sí; es un pavo real en todo menos en la belleza —dijo lord Henry, deshaciendo la margarita con sus largos dedos nerviosos.
vi_translation: "Yes; she is a peacock in everything but beauty," said Lord Henry, tearing a daisy into pieces with his long, restless fingers.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, plucking the daisy with his long, sensitive fingers, said, "Yes, he is a peacock in everything but beauty."
es_translation: —Yes; he is a peacock in everything except beauty —said Lord Henry, undoing the daisy with his long, nervous fingers.

en: “I could not get rid of her. She brought me up to royalties, and people with stars and garters, and elderly ladies with gigantic tiaras and parrot noses. She spoke of me as her dearest friend. I had only met her once before, but she took it into her head to lionize me. I believe some picture of mine had made a great success at the time, at least had been chattered about in the penny newspapers, which is the nineteenth-century standard of immortality. Suddenly I found myself face to face with the young man whose personality had so strangely stirred me. We were quite close, almost touching. Our eyes met again. It was reckless of me, but I asked Lady Brandon to introduce me to him. Perhaps it was not so reckless, after all. It was simply inevitable. We would have spoken to each other without any introduction. I am sure of that. Dorian told me so afterwards. He, too, felt that we were destined to know each other.”
vi: “Tôi không làm sao thoát được bà ta. Bà ta đưa tôi đến gặp các hoàng thân và những người đeo sao cùng huy hiệu cấp tước Ga-tơ, rồi các quý bà lớn tuổi đội những chiếc mũ miện khổng lồ và có những cái mũi chim vẹt. Bà ta nói về tôi cứ như người bạn thân nhất của bà. Tôi chỉ mới gặp bà ta một lần trước đây, nhưng bà ta nhập tâm chuyện đó để đối đãi tôi như danh nhân. Tôi tin là có bức tranh nào đó của tôi từng có lúc tạo được thành công lớn, chí ít thì cũng từng được nói đến trong những tờ báo ba xu vốn dĩ là chuẩn mực của thế kỷ mười chín về sự bất tử. Đột nhiên tôi thấy mình đối mặt với chàng thanh niên mà cá tính cậu ấy đã kích thích tôi một cách lạ lùng làm vậy. Chúng tôi rất gần nhau, gần như chạm vào nhau. Mắt chúng tôi gặp nhau lần nữa. Là do sự khinh suất của tôi, song tôi đề nghị bà Brandon giới thiệu tôi với cậu ấy. Không chừng chuyện ấy cũng không quá khinh suất đâu, nói cho cùng. Nó chỉ là không thể tránh được. Chúng tôi lẽ ra có thể chuyện trò với nhau mà chẳng cần sự giới thiệu nào cả. Tôi tin chắc vào điều đó. Sau này Dorian đã bảo tôi như vậy. Cậu ấy cũng cảm thấy là cái số chúng tôi phải gặp nhau.”
tr: “Elinden kurtulamadım. Beni kral soyundan gelme kişilere, unvan, nişan sahibi kişilere, gaga burunlu, kocaman taçlı, yaşını başını almış hanımefendilere götürüp tanıştırdı. Çok sevgili dostum, diye söz ediyordu benden. Gerçi bundan önce yalnızca bir tek kez karşılaşmıştık ama, o beni kanatlarının altına almaya kararlıydı. Sanırım bir tablom pek ün kazanmıştı o sıralarda, daha doğrusu renkli bulvar gazetelerinde yazılıp çizilmişti ki bu, on dokuzuncu yüzyılın ölümsüzlük ölçütüdür. Kişiliği içimde öylesi tuhaf heyecanlar uyandırmış olan genç erkekle yüz yüze geliverdik. Bakışlarımız karşılaştı. Gereksiz bir gözü karalıktı, biliyorum, ama Leydi Brandon’ dan bizi tanıştırmasını istedim. Gözü karalık değildi belki de, ne bileyim. Belki de kaçınılmazdı. Tanıştırılmasak da konuşacaktık birbirimizle. Bundan eminim. Sonradan Dorian da böyle dedi. Birbirimizi tanımamızın alnımıza yazılmış olduğunu o da hissetmiş.
es: —No me pude librar de ella. Me presentó a altezas reales, a militares y aristócratas, y a señoras mayores con gigantescas diademas y narices de loro. Habló de mí como de su amigo más querido. Sólo había estado una vez con ella, pero se le metió en la cabeza convertirme en la celebridad de la velada. Creo que por entonces algún cuadro mío tuvo un gran éxito o al menos se habló de él en los periódicos sensacionalistas, que son el criterio de la inmoralidad del siglo XIX. De repente, me encontré cara a cara con el joven cuya personalidad me había afectado de manera tan extraña. Estábamos muy cerca, casi nos tocábamos. Nuestras miradas se cruzaron de nuevo. Fue una imprudencia por mi parte, pero pedí a lady Brandon que nos presentara. Quizá no fuese imprudencia, sino algo sencillamente inevitable. Nos hubiésemos hablado sin necesidad de presentación. Estoy seguro de ello. Dorian me lo confirmó después. También él sintió que estábamos destinados a conocernos.
vi_translation: "I couldn't escape her. She took me to meet the princes and those wearing stars and Garter badges, then the elderly ladies with enormous tiaras and parrot-like noses. She spoke about me as if I were her closest friend. I had only met her once before, but she internalized that encounter to treat me like a celebrity. I believe there was some painting of mine that once achieved great success, at least it was mentioned in the penny papers which were the nineteenth-century standard of immortality. Suddenly I found myself face to face with the young man whose personality had strangely intrigued me so. We were very close, almost touching. Our eyes met again. It was due to my recklessness, but I asked Mrs. Brandon to introduce me to him. Perhaps it wasn't too reckless after all, in the end. It was simply unavoidable. We could have talked to each other without any introduction at all. I'm certain of that. Dorian later told me so. He also felt that it was our fate to meet."
tr_translation: “I couldn't escape from her. She introduced me to people of royal lineage, to those with titles and decorations, to hook-nosed individuals with enormous crowns, and to elderly ladies. She would refer to me as her very dear friend. Although we had only met once before, she was determined to take me under her wing. I suppose one of my paintings had gained some fame at that time, or rather, it had been written about in the colorful boulevard newspapers, which is the measure of immortality in the nineteenth century. I came face to face with the young man who had stirred such strange emotions within me. Our eyes met. It was a reckless move, I know, but I asked Lady Brandon to introduce us. Perhaps it wasn't recklessness, who knows. Maybe it was inevitable. Even if we hadn't been introduced, we would have spoken to each other. I'm sure of it. Later, Dorian said the same thing. He also felt that it was written in our fate to know each other.”
es_translation: —I couldn't get rid of her. She introduced me to royal highnesses, military officers and aristocrats, and elderly ladies with gigantic tiaras and parrot noses. She spoke of me as her dearest friend. I had only been with her once, but she got it into her head to make me the celebrity of the evening. I believe that around that time one of my paintings had great success or at least was talked about in the sensationalist newspapers, which are the measure of immorality in the 19th century. Suddenly, I found myself face to face with the young man whose personality had affected me so strangely. We were very close, almost touching. Our gazes crossed again. It was reckless of me, but I asked Lady Brandon to introduce us. Perhaps it wasn't recklessness, but something simply inevitable. We would have spoken to each other without the need for an introduction. I'm sure of it. Dorian confirmed it to me later. He also felt that we were destined to meet.

en: “And how did Lady Brandon describe this wonderful young man?” asked his companion. “I know she goes in for giving a rapid précis of all her guests. I remember her bringing me up to a truculent and red-faced old gentleman covered all over with orders and ribbons, and hissing into my ear, in a tragic whisper which must have been perfectly audible to everybody in the room, the most astounding details. I simply fled. I like to find out people for myself. But Lady Brandon treats her guests exactly as an auctioneer treats his goods. She either explains them entirely away, or tells one everything about them except what one wants to know.”
vi: “Và bà Brandon đã mô tả chàng thanh niên tuyệt vời này thế nào?” bạn y hỏi. “Tôi biết là bà ấy thường đưa ra một bản tóm lược nhanh chóng cho mọi vị khách của mình. Tôi còn nhớ bà ấy vừa đưa tôi đến gặp một quý ông lớn tuổi hung hăng mặt đỏ phừng phừng người phủ đầy huân chương và cuống huân chương vừa rít vào tai tôi, bằng một giọng thầm thì bi kịch có thể nghe rõ với mọi người trong phòng, về các chi tiết sửng sốt nhất. Tôi trốn thẳng. Tôi muốn tự mình tìm hiểu mọi người. Nhưng bà Brandon đối xử với khách của bà chẳng khác gì một gã bán đấu giá đối xử với các món hàng của gã. Bà ta hoặc là giảng giải về họ tuốt tuột, hoặc kể cho người ta nghe tất tật về họ ngoại trừ những thứ người ta muốn biết.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Peki, ya Leydi Brandon bu harika genç erkeği nasıl tanımladı?” diye sordu. “Bütün konuklarının hızlı özetlerini çıkarmakta birebirdir, biliyorum. Hatırlıyorum, bir keresinde beni her yeri nişanlar, şeritlerle kaplı, kırmızı suratlı, huysuz bir ihtiyarın yanına götürdü; sonra da kulağıma eğilerek trajik bir fısıltıyla, insanı afallatan ayrıntılar anlatmaya girişti ki, bu fısıltıyı oradaki herkesin bal gibi duyabildiğinden hiç kuşkum yok. Zaten açık artırma çığırtkanları sattıkları mala ne gözle bakarsa, Leydi Brandon da konuklarına öyle davranır. Onları ya bir açıklamayla temelli ortadan siler ya da haklarındaki her şeyi ortaya döker, insanın öğrenmek istediği dışında her şeyi.
es: —Y, ¿cómo describió lady Brandon a ese joven maravilloso? —preguntó su amigo—. Sé que le gusta dar un rápido resumen de todos sus invitados. Recuerdo que me llevó a conocer a un anciano caballero de rostro colorado, cubierto con todas las condecoraciones imaginables, y me confió al oído, en un trágico susurro que debieron oír perfectamente todos los presentes, los detalles más asombrosos. Sencillamente huí. Prefiero desenmascarar a las personas yo mismo. Pero lady Brandon trata a sus invitados exactamente como un subastador trata a sus mercancías. O los explica completamente del revés, o cuenta todo excepto lo que uno quiere saber.
vi_translation: “And how did Mrs. Brandon describe this wonderful young man?” his friend asked. “I know she usually gives a quick summary to all her guests. I remember she once introduced me to an aggressive elderly gentleman with a flushed face covered in medals and ribbons, and she whispered in my ear, in a tragically audible voice to everyone in the room, the most astonishing details. I made a quick escape. I prefer to learn about people on my own. But Mrs. Brandon treats her guests no differently than an auctioneer treats his items. She either explains everything about them or tells people everything except what they actually want to know.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry asked, "Well, how did Lady Brandon describe this wonderful young man?" "I know she is excellent at giving quick summaries of all her guests. I remember once she took me to a red-faced, grumpy old man covered in medals and ribbons; then she leaned over and began to whisper tragic details into my ear, which I'm sure everyone there could clearly hear. Lady Brandon treats her guests the way auctioneers view the items they sell. She either dismisses them with a single remark or reveals everything about them, except what one actually wants to know."
es_translation: —And how did Lady Brandon describe that wonderful young man? —asked his friend—. I know she likes to give a quick summary of all her guests. I remember she introduced me to an elderly gentleman with a red face, covered with all imaginable decorations, and confided in my ear, in a tragic whisper that everyone present must have perfectly heard, the most astonishing details. I simply fled. I prefer to unmask people myself. But Lady Brandon treats her guests exactly like an auctioneer treats his goods. She either explains them completely backwards or tells everything except what one wants to know.

en: “Poor Lady Brandon! You are hard on her, Harry!” said Hallward listlessly.
vi: “Tội nghiệp bà Brandon! Anh đã quá khắt khe với bà ấy, Harry à!” Hallward nói, lơ đễnh.
tr: Ressam, “Zavallı Leydi Brandon! Ona insaf göstermiyorsun, Harry!” diye biraz can sıkıntısıyla konuştu.
es: —¡Pobre lady Brandon! ¡Eres muy duro con ella, Harry! —dijo Hallward lánguidamente.
vi_translation: "Poor Mrs. Brandon! You were too harsh on her, Harry!" Hallward said, absent-mindedly.
tr_translation: The painter spoke with a bit of boredom, "Poor Lady Brandon! You are not showing her any mercy, Harry!"
es_translation: —Poor Lady Brandon! You are very hard on her, Harry! —said Hallward languidly.

en: “My dear fellow, she tried to found a salon, and only succeeded in opening a restaurant. How could I admire her? But tell me, what did she say about Mr. Dorian Gray?”
vi: “Bạn tôi ơi, bà ấy cố gắng lập ra một salon1, mà chỉ thành công trong việc mở được một nhà hàng. Làm sao tôi khâm phục bà ấy được? Nhưng hãy kể tôi nghe đi, bà ấy nói gì về mít-tơ Dorian Gray?”
tr: “Sevgili dostum, bu kadın bir salon kurmaya yeltenmiş ama ancak bir lokanta kurabilmeyi başarmış. Nasıl hayranlık duyabilirim ona? Ama sen anlat, mr Dorian Gray konusunda neler söyledi?
es: —Mi querido amigo, esa buena señora trataba de fundar un salón, pero sólo ha conseguido abrir un restaurante. ¿Cómo quieres que la admire? Pero, dime, ¿qué te contó del señor Dorian Gray?
vi_translation: “My friend, she tried to establish a salon, but only succeeded in opening a restaurant. How can I admire her? But tell me, what did she say about Mr. Dorian Gray?”
tr_translation: “My dear friend, this woman attempted to establish a salon but only managed to set up a restaurant. How can I admire her? But you tell me, what did she say about Mr. Dorian Gray?”
es_translation: —My dear friend, that good lady was trying to establish a salon, but she has only managed to open a restaurant. How do you expect me to admire her? But, tell me, what did she tell you about Mr. Dorian Gray?

en: “Oh, something like, ‘Charming boy—poor dear mother and I absolutely inseparable. Quite forget what he does—afraid he—doesn’t do anything—oh, yes, plays the piano—or is it the violin, dear Mr. Gray?’ Neither of us could help laughing, and we became friends at once.”
vi: 1 Xa-lông: nơi gặp gỡ của các nghệ sỹ. “Ồ, vài thứ như là, ‘một chàng trai hấp dẫn — bà mẹ tội nghiệp của cậu ấy với tôi không bao giờ rời nhau được một bước. Quên hẳn là cậu ấy làm gì — e là cậu ấy — không làm gì cả — ồ, vâng, chơi dương cầm — hay vĩ cầm nhỉ, mít-tơ Gray?’ Cả hai chúng tôi đều không nhịn được cười, và chúng tôi kết bạn với nhau luôn.”
tr: “Şöyle bir şeyler mırıldandı: sevimli bir çocuk... Zavallı anneciğiyle içtiğimiz su ayrı gitmezdi. Dorian’ın ne yaptığı aklımda kalmamış... Korkarım hiçbir şey yapmıyor... Ha, evet, piyano çalıyor ya... Yoksa keman mıydı, sevgili mr Gray?.. İkimiz de ister istemez güldük, hemencecik de kaynaşıverdik.
es: —Algo así como «muchacho encantador, su pobre madre y yo absolutamente inseparables. He olvidado por completo a qué se dedica, me temo que..., no hace nada... Sí, sí, toca el piano, ¿o es el violín, mi querido señor Gray?» Ninguno de los dos pudimos evitar la risa, y nos hicimos amigos al instante.
vi_translation: 1 Salon: a meeting place for artists. “Oh, some things like, ‘a handsome young man — his poor mother and I can never be apart for a moment. Completely forget what he does — afraid that he — does nothing at all — oh, yes, plays the piano — or is it the violin, Mr. Gray?’ Both of us couldn't help but laugh, and we became friends immediately.”
tr_translation: “He mumbled something like: a lovely child... We were inseparable with his poor mother. I can't remember what Dorian was doing... I'm afraid he's doing nothing... Ah, yes, he plays the piano, doesn't he... Or was it the violin, dear Mr. Gray?.. We both couldn't help but laugh, and we immediately hit it off.”
es_translation: —Something like "charming young man, his poor mother and I absolutely inseparable. I've completely forgotten what he does, I'm afraid that..., he does nothing... Yes, yes, he plays the piano, or is it the violin, my dear Mr. Gray?" Neither of us could avoid laughing, and we became friends instantly.

en: “Laughter is not at all a bad beginning for a friendship, and it is far the best ending for one,” said the young lord, plucking another daisy.
vi: “Cười hoàn toàn không phải là sự khởi đầu tồi tệ cho một tình bạn, và đó còn là cái kết tốt hơn nhiều cho nó ấy chứ,” quý ngài trẻ tuổi vừa nói vừa bứt một đóa cúc khác.
tr: Genç Lord bir papatya daha kopararak, “Gülmek, dostluk için hiç de kötü bir başlangıç sayılmaz; dostluğu sona erdirme yollarınınsa en iyisidir,” dedi.
es: —La risa no es un mal principio para una amistad y, desde luego, es la mejor manera de terminarla —dijo el joven lord, arrancando otra margarita.
vi_translation: “Laughing is certainly not a bad beginning for a friendship, and it is far better as an ending for it,” the young gentleman said as he plucked another daisy.
tr_translation: The Young Lord plucked another daisy and said, "Laughter is not a bad start for friendship; it is the best way to end it."
es_translation: —Laughter is not a bad beginning for a friendship, and certainly it is the best way to end it —said the young lord, plucking another daisy.

en: Hallward shook his head. “You don’t understand what friendship is, Harry,” he murmured—“or what enmity is, for that matter. You like every one; that is to say, you are indifferent to every one.”
vi: Hallward lắc đầu. “Anh không hiểu tình bạn là gì, Harry à,” y lẩm bẩm, — “hay sự thù hằn là gì, cả vậy nữa. Anh thích tất cả mọi người; thế nghĩa là anh dửng dưng với tất cả mọi người.”
tr: Hallward başını sallayarak, “Harry, sen dostluğun ne demek olduğunu anlamıyorsun,” dedi. “Ne de düşmanlığın anlamını biliyorsun. Herkesi seversin sen, yani herkese karşı kayıtsızsın, demeye gelir bu.
es: Hallward negó con la cabeza. —No entiendes lo que es la amistad, Harry —murmuró—; ni tampoco la enemistad, si vamos a eso. Te gusta todo el mundo; es decir, todo el mundo te deja indiferente.
vi_translation: Hallward shook his head. "You don't understand what friendship is, Harry," he muttered, "nor what enmity is, either." You like everyone; that means you are indifferent to everyone."
tr_translation: Hallward shook his head, "Harry, you don't understand what friendship means," he said. "Nor do you know the meaning of enmity. You love everyone, which means you are indifferent to everyone."
es_translation: Hallward shook his head. —You don't understand what friendship is, Harry —he murmured—; nor enmity, for that matter. You like everyone; that is to say, everyone leaves you indifferent.

en: “How horribly unjust of you!” cried Lord Henry, tilting his hat back and looking up at the little clouds that, like ravelled skeins of glossy white silk, were drifting across the hollowed turquoise of the summer sky. “Yes; horribly unjust of you. I make a great difference between people. I choose my friends for their good looks, my acquaintances for their good characters, and my enemies for their good intellects. A man cannot be too careful in the choice of his enemies. I have not got one who is a fool. They are all men of some intellectual power, and consequently they all appreciate me. Is that very vain of me? I think it is rather vain.”
vi: “Anh thật bất công khinh khủng!” huân tước Henry hét lên, lật mũ ra sau và nhìn lên những đám mây nhỏ, như các cuộn tơ trắng bóng rối bời, đang trôi ngang qua sắc ngọc lam thăm thẳm của bầu trời mùa hạ. “Vâng; anh bất công kinh khủng. Tôi hiểu rõ sự khác biệt rất lớn giữa mọi người. Tôi chọn bạn bè vì họ đẹp, chọn người quen vì họ tốt, chọn kẻ thù vì họ tài. Người ta có kỹ đến mấy cũng không thừa trong việc lựa chọn kẻ thù. Tôi không chọn được một ai là kẻ ngu ngốc cả. Bọn họ toàn là những người có năng lực trí tuệ đáng kể, và do đó họ đều trân trọng tôi. Có phải điều đó là quá tự phụ về phía tôi? Tôi nghĩ đúng là khá tự phụ thật đấy.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Ne korkunç haksızlık ediyorsun bana!” diyerek şapkasını arkaya doğru itti; yaz semasının firuze kubbesi üzerinde, çözülmüş parlak ibrişim yumakları gibi uçuşan bulutlara baktı. “Evet, korkunç haksızlık ediyorsun bana. Aslında insanları birbirinden ayırırım ben. Arkadaşlarımı güzellikleri için seçerim, tanışlarımı karakterlerinin sağlamlığı için, düşmanlarımı da parlak zekâları yüzünden. Kişi düşmanını seçerken ne denli dikkatli olsa azdır. Benim bir tane bile aptal düşmanım yoktur. Tüm düşmanlarımın zihinsel melekeleri güçlüdür, bu yüzden de benim değerimi bilirler. Çok mu kibirli buluyorsun beni? Evet, oldukça kibirli sayılırım.
es: —¡Qué horriblemente injusto eres conmigo! —exclamó lord Henry, echándose el sombrero hacia atrás para mirar a las nubecillas que, como madejas enmarañadas de brillante seda blanca, vagaban por la oquedad turquesa del cielo veraniego—. Sí; horriblemente injusto. Ya lo creo que distingo entre la gente. Elijo a mis amigos por su apostura, a mis conocidos por su buena reputación y a mis enemigos por su inteligencia. No es posible excederse en el cuidado al elegir a los enemigos. No tengo ni uno solo que sea estúpido. Todos son personas de cierta talla intelectual y, en consecuencia, me aprecian. ¿Te parece demasiada vanidad por mi parte? Creo que lo es.
vi_translation: “You are terribly unfair!” Lord Henry shouted, flipping his hat back and looking up at the small clouds, like tangled, shiny white silk threads, drifting across the deep turquoise of the summer sky. “Yes; you are terribly unfair. I understand very well the great difference between people. I choose friends because they are beautiful, acquaintances because they are good, and enemies because they are talented. No matter how skilled one is, it is never excessive in the selection of enemies. I have not chosen a single fool as an enemy. They are all people with considerable intellectual abilities, and therefore they all appreciate me. Is that too conceited of me? I think it is quite conceited indeed.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "What a terrible injustice you do to me!" he said, pushing his hat back; he looked at the clouds flying like unraveled bright silk skeins over the turquoise dome of the summer sky. "Yes, you do me a terrible injustice. In fact, I do distinguish between people. I choose my friends for their beauty, my acquaintances for the solidity of their character, and my enemies for their sharp intellect. One cannot be too careful in choosing one's enemies. I do not have a single foolish enemy. All my enemies have strong mental faculties, and therefore they appreciate my worth. Do you find me very arrogant? Yes, I am quite arrogant."
es_translation: —How horribly unfair you are to me! —exclaimed Lord Henry, tipping his hat back to look at the little clouds that, like tangled skeins of bright white silk, wandered through the turquoise hollow of the summer sky—. Yes; horribly unfair. Of course I distinguish between people. I choose my friends for their good looks, my acquaintances for their good reputation, and my enemies for their intelligence. One cannot be too careful in choosing one's enemies. I don't have a single stupid one. They are all people of some intellectual stature and, consequently, they appreciate me. Do you think that's too much vanity on my part? I think it is.

en: “I should think it was, Harry. But according to your category I must be merely an acquaintance.”
vi: “Tôi cũng nghĩ thế đấy, Harry. Nhưng cứ theo như xếp hạng của anh thì tôi chắc chỉ là người quen.
tr: “Bana kalırsa da öyle, Harry. Ama sınıflandırmana göre ben yalnızca bir tanışım, senin gözünde.
es: —Coincido en eso contigo. Pero según tus categorías yo no debo de ser más que un conocido.
vi_translation: “I think so too, Harry. But according to your ranking, I'm probably just an acquaintance.”
tr_translation: “I think so too, Harry. But according to your classification, I am merely an acquaintance in your eyes.”
es_translation: —I agree with you on that. But according to your categories, I must be nothing more than an acquaintance.

en: “My dear old Basil, you are much more than an acquaintance.”
vi: “Bạn già Basil yêu quý của tôi, anh hơn hẳn người quen.
tr: “Çok sevgili dostum Basil, bir tanıştan çok ötedesin sen.
es: —Mi querido Basil: eres mucho más que un conocido.
vi_translation: “My dear old friend Basil, you are far superior to mere acquaintances.”
tr_translation: “My very dear friend Basil, you are much more than an acquaintance.”
es_translation: —My dear Basil: you are much more than an acquaintance.

en: “And much less than a friend. A sort of brother, I suppose?”
vi: “Và thua hẳn bạn. Một dạng anh em trai, tôi cho là vậy?”
tr: “Ama arkadaştan da çok beride. Bir tür kardeş miyim acaba?
es: —Y mucho menos que un amigo. Algo así como un hermano, ¿no es cierto?
vi_translation: "And definitely lost to you. A kind of brother, I suppose?"
tr_translation: “But far from being just a friend. Am I a kind of sibling, I wonder?”
es_translation: —And much less than a friend. Something like a brother, isn't that right?

en: “Oh, brothers! I don’t care for brothers. My elder brother won’t die, and my younger brothers seem never to do anything else.”
vi: “Ồ, anh em! Tôi không quan tâm đến anh em. Anh tôi sẽ không chết, và các em trai tôi dường như chẳng bao giờ làm bất cứ điều gì khác thế cả.
tr: “Of, kardeş deme bana! Kardeş denen şeyden hiç hazzetmem ben. Ağabeyim ölmek bilmiyor; küçük kardeşlerim de ölmek dışında bir şey bilmiyorlar sanki.
es: —¡Ah, los hermanos! No me gustan los hermanos. Mi hermano mayor no se muere, y los menores nunca hacen otra cosa.
vi_translation: “Oh, my brothers! I don't care about my brothers. My brother will not die, and my younger brothers seem to never do anything else at all.”
tr_translation: “Oh, don't call me brother! I don't like that word at all. My older brother doesn't seem to know how to die; and my younger siblings don't seem to know anything but dying.”
es_translation: —Ah, siblings! I don't like siblings. My older brother never dies, and the younger ones never do anything else.

en: “Harry!” exclaimed Hallward, frowning.
vi: “Harry!” Hallward la lên, nhăn mặt.
tr: Basil Hallward, “Harry!” diyerek kaşlarını çattı.
es: —¡Harry! —exclamó Hallward, frunciendo el ceño.
vi_translation: “Harry!” Hallward shouted, frowning.
tr_translation: Basil Hallward frowned and said, "Harry!"
es_translation: —Harry! —exclaimed Hallward, frowning.

en: “My dear fellow, I am not quite serious. But I can’t help detesting my relations. I suppose it comes from the fact that none of us can stand other people having the same faults as ourselves. I quite sympathize with the rage of the English democracy against what they call the vices of the upper orders. The masses feel that drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality should be their own special property, and that if any one of us makes an ass of himself, he is poaching on their preserves. When poor Southwark got into the divorce court, their indignation was quite magnificent. And yet I don’t suppose that ten per cent of the proletariat live correctly.”
vi: “Bạn tôi ơi, tôi không nghiêm túc lắm đâu. Nhưng tôi không thể nào thôi căm ghét các mối quan hệ của mình. Tôi cho rằng do thực tế là không ai trong chúng ta có thể chịu đựng được việc người khác có các lỗi lầm giống như của chính chúng ta. Tôi hết sức thông cảm với cơn thịnh nộ của nền dân chủ Anh quốc trước cái mà họ gọi là thói hư tật xấu của giai cấp thượng lưu. Quần chúng cảm thấy rằng tật nghiện rượu, sự đần độn và thói đồi bại nên là đặc tính của riêng họ, và rằng nếu bất cứ ai trong số chúng ta mà lại đi làm trò cười cho thiên hạ thì y đã xâm phạm vào cấm địa của họ. Khi Southwark đáng thương ra tòa li hôn với vợ, sự phẫn nộ của họ thật sự là kỳ diệu. Tuy nhiên tôi không nghĩ là có được mười phần trăm tầng lớp dưới sống đúng mực.”
tr: “Dostum, şaka yapıyorum. Gene de akrabalarımdan nefret etmemek elimde değil. Kendimizdeki kusurları başkalarında görmeye hiçbirimiz dayanamayız da ondan olsa gerek. İngiliz demokrasisinin, yüksek sınıfların kötü yönleri, dedikleri şeylere diş bilemesini ben çok iyi anlıyorum. Halk kitleleri ayyaşlık, aptallık, ahlaksızlık yalnızca onlara özgü olsun istiyor! Bizlerden biri kendini rezil etti mi onların özel mülküne tecavüz edilmiş gibi oluyorlar: Zavallı Southwarkcık kendini boşanma mahkemesinde bulunca halkın gösterdiği öfke harikaydı doğrusu. Oysa proletarya sınıfının onda birinin bile kusursuz yaşam sürdüğünü sanmıyorum.
es: —No hablo del todo en serio. Pero me es imposible no detestar a mi familia. Imagino que se debe a que nadie soporta a las personas que tienen sus mismos defectos. Entiendo perfectamente la indignación de la democracia inglesa ante lo que llama los vicios de las clases altas. Las masas consideran que embriaguez, estupidez e inmoralidad deben ser exclusivo patrimonio suyo, y cuando alguno de nosotros se pone en ridículo nos ven como cazadores furtivos en sus tierras. Cuando el pobre Southwark tuvo que presentarse en el Tribunal de Divorcios, la indignación de las masas fue realmente magnífica. Y, sin embargo, no creo que el diez por ciento del proletariado viva correctamente.
vi_translation: "My friend, I am not very serious. But I cannot help but hate my relationships. I suppose it is because none of us can tolerate others having the same faults as we do. I fully sympathize with the wrath of British democracy against what they call the vices of the upper class. The masses feel that alcoholism, stupidity, and depravity should be their own characteristics, and that if any of us make a fool of ourselves, we have encroached on their territory. When poor Southwark went to court to divorce his wife, their indignation was truly remarkable. However, I do not think that even ten percent of the lower class live properly."
tr_translation: “My friend, I'm joking. Still, I can't help but hate my relatives. It's probably because none of us can stand seeing our own flaws in others. I understand very well the British democracy's grudge against what they call the bad traits of the upper classes. The masses want drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality to be exclusive to them! When one of us disgraces themselves, it's as if their private property has been violated: The public's outrage was truly remarkable when poor little Southwark found himself in the divorce court. Yet, I don't think even one-tenth of the proletariat lives a flawless life.”
es_translation: —I'm not entirely serious. But it is impossible for me not to detest my family. I imagine it is because no one can stand people who have the same flaws as they do. I perfectly understand the indignation of English democracy at what it calls the vices of the upper classes. The masses believe that drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality should be their exclusive domain, and when one of us makes a fool of ourselves, they see us as poachers on their land. When poor Southwark had to appear in the Divorce Court, the indignation of the masses was truly magnificent. And yet, I don't think ten percent of the proletariat lives correctly.

en: “I don’t agree with a single word that you have said, and, what is more, Harry, I feel sure you don’t either.”
vi: “Tôi không đồng ý với dù chỉ một lời anh nói, và, hơn nữa, Harry, tôi cảm thấy chắc chắn là anh cũng vậy.”
tr: “Harry, söylediklerinin bir tek sözcüğüne bile inanmıyorum. Dahası, senin de inanmadığından eminim.
es: —No estoy de acuerdo con una sola palabra de lo que has dicho y, lo que es más, estoy seguro de que a ti te sucede lo mismo.
vi_translation: “I do not agree with even a single word you say, and, moreover, Harry, I feel certain that you don't either.”
tr_translation: “Harry, I don't believe a single word you're saying. Moreover, I'm sure you don't believe it either.”
es_translation: —I don't agree with a single word of what you have said and, what's more, I'm sure you feel the same way.

en: Lord Henry stroked his pointed brown beard and tapped the toe of his patent-leather boot with a tasselled ebony cane. “How English you are Basil! That is the second time you have made that observation. If one puts forward an idea to a true Englishman—always a rash thing to do—he never dreams of considering whether the idea is right or wrong. The only thing he considers of any importance is whether one believes it oneself. Now, the value of an idea has nothing whatsoever to do with the sincerity of the man who expresses it. Indeed, the probabilities are that the more insincere the man is, the more purely intellectual will the idea be, as in that case it will not be coloured by either his wants, his desires, or his prejudices. However, I don’t propose to discuss politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you. I like persons better than principles, and I like persons with no principles better than anything else in the world. Tell me more about Mr. Dorian Gray. How often do you see him?”
vi: Huân tước Henry vuốt bộ râu nâu nhọn, gõ cây ba-toong đen bóng có núm tua lên mũi giày ống da sơn. “Anh đúng là một người Anh, Basil! Đây là lần thứ hai anh đưa ra lời bình ấy. Nếu ai đó đề xuất một ý tưởng với một người Anh thực thụ — luôn là một việc liều lĩnh — y không bao giờ mơ đến việc suy xét xem liệu ý tưởng ấy đúng hay sai. Việc duy nhất có chút ý nghĩa mà y suy xét đến là không biết chính kẻ kia có tin vào nó hay không. Bởi chưng giá trị của một ý tưởng dẫu sao cũng chẳng có gì liên quan với sự thành thật của người phát biểu nó. Quả thật thì rất có thể là con người càng không thành thực thì ý tưởng sẽ càng trở nên thuần túy trí tuệ hơn, như thể trong trường hợp ấy thì nó sẽ không bị tô vẽ thêm bởi cả những nhu cầu, ham muốn, hoặc định kiến của y. Tuy nhiên tôi không định thảo luận về chính trị, xã hội học, hoặc siêu hình học với anh. Tôi thích con người hơn nguyên tắc, và tôi thích những người vô nguyên tắc hơn bất cứ thứ gì khác trên đời. Hãy kể thêm cho tôi nghe về mít-tơ Dorian Gray đi. Anh có hay gặp cậu ấy không?”
tr: Lord Henry sivri, kestane renkli sakalını sıvazlıyor, Püsküllü abanoz bastonuyla ayağındaki rugan pabuçlara vurup duruyordu. “Nasıl da tipik İngiliz’sin, Basil! İkinci kez aynı görüşü belirtiyorsun. Kişi gerçek bir İngilize bir fikir yürüttüğü zaman... Ki zaten tehlikeli iştir ya... Fikrinin doğru mu yanlış mı olduğunu düşünmeyi aklından bile geçirmez. Önemli saydığı tek şey bu fikre kendinin inanıp inanmadığıdır. Şimdi, bir fikrin değeri ile bunu ileri süren kişinin içtenliği arasında hiçbir bağlantı yoktur. Doğrusunu istersen, büyük bir olasılıkla, kişi ne kadar içtenlikten uzaksa, ileri sürdüğü fikir de o oranda saf bir zihinsel değer taşıyacaktır, çünkü o kişinin ihtiyaçlarının, arzularının ve de önyargılarının rengini kapmamış olacaktır. Ne var ki seninle siyaset, toplumbilim ya da metafizik tartışmaya niyetim yok benim. Ben insanları ilkelerden daha çok severim. Bana şu mr Dorian Gray’i biraz daha anlatsana. Sık sık görüşüyor musunuz?
es: Lord Henry se acarició la afilada barba castaña y se golpeó la punta de una bota de charol con el bastón de caoba. —¡Qué inglés eres, Basil! Es la segunda vez que haces hoy esa observación. Si se presenta una idea a un inglés auténtico (lo que siempre es una imprudencia), nunca se le ocurre ni por lo más remoto pararse a pensar si la idea es verdadera o falsa. Lo único que considera importante es si el interesado cree lo que dice. Ahora bien, el valor de una idea no tiene nada que ver con la sinceridad de la persona que la expone. En realidad, es probable que cuanto más insincera sea la persona, más puramente intelectual sea la idea, ya que en ese caso no estará coloreada ni por sus necesidades, ni por sus deseos, ni por sus prejuicios. No pretendo, sin embargo, discutir contigo ni de política, ni de sociología, ni de metafísica. Las personas me gustan más que los principios, y las personas sin principios me gustan más que nada en el mundo. Cuéntame más cosas acerca de Dorian Gray. ¿Lo ves con frecuencia?
vi_translation: Lord Henry stroked his sharp brown beard, tapping the glossy black cane with a tassel on the tip of his polished leather boot. “You really are an Englishman, Basil! This is the second time you've made that remark. If someone proposes an idea to a true Englishman — always a risky endeavor — he never dreams of considering whether the idea is right or wrong. The only thing of any significance that he considers is whether the other person believes in it or not. For the value of an idea has nothing to do with the sincerity of the person expressing it. Indeed, it is very likely that the less sincere a person is, the more purely intellectual the idea will be, as in that case it will not be colored by his own needs, desires, or prejudices. However, I do not intend to discuss politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you. I prefer people to principles, and I prefer those without principles to anything else in the world. Tell me more about Mr. Dorian Gray. Do you see him often?”
tr_translation: Lord Henry was stroking his sharp, chestnut-colored beard and kept tapping his patent leather shoes with his tasseled ebony cane. “How typically English you are, Basil! You are stating the same opinion for the second time. When a person presents an idea to a true Englishman... Which is already a dangerous task... He never even considers whether the idea is right or wrong. The only thing he deems important is whether he himself believes in it. Now, there is no connection between the value of an idea and the sincerity of the person presenting it. To be honest, most likely, the less sincere a person is, the purer the intellectual value of the idea will be, because it will not be tainted by that person's needs, desires, and prejudices. However, I have no intention of discussing politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you. I love people more than principles. Tell me a bit more about this Mr. Dorian Gray. Do you see him often?”
es_translation: Lord Henry stroked his sharp brown beard and tapped the tip of a patent leather boot with his mahogany cane. —How English you are, Basil! It's the second time today that you've made that observation. If an idea is presented to a genuine Englishman (which is always imprudent), it never occurs to him, even remotely, to stop and think whether the idea is true or false. The only thing he considers important is whether the person believes what they are saying. Now, the value of an idea has nothing to do with the sincerity of the person expressing it. In fact, it is likely that the more insincere the person, the more purely intellectual the idea, since in that case it will not be colored by their needs, desires, or prejudices. However, I do not intend to discuss politics, sociology, or metaphysics with you. I like people more than principles, and I like people without principles more than anything in the world. Tell me more about Dorian Gray. Do you see him often?

en: “Every day. I couldn’t be happy if I didn’t see him every day. He is absolutely necessary to me.”
vi: “Ngày nào chẳng gặp. Tôi không thể vui vẻ được nếu không gặp cậu ấy mỗi ngày. Tôi rất cần cậu ấy.”
tr: “Her gün. Onu her gün görmesem mutlu olamam ki! Onsuz edemiyorum artık.
es: —Todos los días. No sería feliz si no lo viera todos los días. Me es absolutamente necesario.
vi_translation: “We meet every day. I can't be happy without seeing him every day. I really need him.”
tr_translation: “Every day. If I don't see him every day, I can't be happy! I can't do without him anymore.”
es_translation: —Every day. I wouldn't be happy if I didn't see him every day. It's absolutely necessary for me.

en: “How extraordinary! I thought you would never care for anything but your art.”
vi: “Lạ thật! Tôi đã nghĩ là anh không để ý đến bất cứ thứ gì ngoài nghệ thuật của anh.”
tr: “Olağandışı bir şey, doğrusu! Ben seni sanatın dışında hiçbir şeyi umursamaz sanırdım.
es: —¡Extraordinario! Creía que sólo te interesaba el arte.
vi_translation: "Strange! I thought you didn't pay attention to anything except your art."
tr_translation: “An unusual thing, indeed! I thought you didn't care about anything other than art.”
es_translation: —Extraordinary! I thought you were only interested in art.

en: “He is all my art to me now,” said the painter gravely. “I sometimes think, Harry, that there are only two eras of any importance in the world’s history. The first is the appearance of a new medium for art, and the second is the appearance of a new personality for art also. What the invention of oil-painting was to the Venetians, the face of Antinous was to late Greek sculpture, and the face of Dorian Gray will some day be to me. It is not merely that I paint from him, draw from him, sketch from him. Of course, I have done all that. But he is much more to me than a model or a sitter. I won’t tell you that I am dissatisfied with what I have done of him, or that his beauty is such that art cannot express it. There is nothing that art cannot express, and I know that the work I have done, since I met Dorian Gray, is good work, is the best work of my life. But in some curious way—I wonder will you understand me?—his personality has suggested to me an entirely new manner in art, an entirely new mode of style. I see things differently, I think of them differently. I can now recreate life in a way that was hidden from me before. ‘A dream of form in days of thought’—who is it who says that? I forget; but it is what Dorian Gray has been to me. The merely visible presence of this lad—for he seems to me little more than a lad, though he is really over twenty—his merely visible presence—ah! I wonder can you realize all that that means? Unconsciously he defines for me the lines of a fresh school, a school that is to have in it all the passion of the romantic spirit, all the perfection of the spirit that is Greek. The harmony of soul and body—how much that is! We in our madness have separated the two, and have invented a realism that is vulgar, an ideality that is void. Harry! if you only knew what Dorian Gray is to me! You remember that landscape of mine, for which Agnew offered me such a huge price but which I would not part with? It is one of the best things I have ever done. And why is it so? Because, while I was painting it, Dorian Gray sat beside me. Some subtle influence passed from him to me, and for the first time in my life I saw in the plain woodland the wonder I had always looked for and always missed.”
vi: “Cậu ấy là tất cả nghệ thuật với tôi bây giờ,” họa sỹ nói, rất trang nghiêm. “Đôi khi tôi nghĩ, Harry, là chỉ hai thời kỳ có chút ý nghĩa nào đó trong lịch sử thế giới. Đầu tiên là sự xuất hiện phương tiện mới cho nghệ thuật, và thứ nhì là sự xuất hiện cá tính mới cũng cho nghệ thuật. Những thứ mà sự phát minh ra kỹ thuật vẽ sơn dầu đã mang đến cho dân Venice, bộ mặt Antinoüs đã mang đến cho nghệ thuật điêu khắc Hy Lạp sau này, và gương mặt Dorian Gray sẽ mang lại cho tôi một ngày nào đó. Chuyện không đơn thuần là tôi vẽ từ cậu ấy, dựng từ cậu ấy, phác từ cậu ấy. Dĩ nhiên tôi đã làm mọi việc đó. Nhưng cậu ấy có ý nghĩa với tôi hơn hẳn một người mẫu hoặc một người làm kiểu. Tôi sẽ không bảo anh là tôi không hài lòng với những gì tôi đã làm về cậu ấy, hoặc là vẻ đẹp của cậu ấy tuyệt vời đến nỗi mà Nghệ thuật không thể biểu lộ. Chẳng có gì mà Nghệ thuật lại không thể biểu lộ, và tôi biết là tác phẩm mà tôi đã thực hiện, từ khi tôi gặp Dorian Gray, là một tác phẩm tốt, là tác phẩm tốt nhất đời tôi. Nhưng theo một lối lạ lùng nào đó — tôi tự hỏi không biết anh có hiểu tôi không? — cá tính cậu ấy đã khơi gợi lên trong tôi một phong cách nghệ thuật hoàn toàn mới, một kiểu sáng tác hoàn toàn mới. Tôi nhìn sự vật khác hẳn, tôi nghĩ về chúng khác hẳn. Giờ đây tôi có thể tái tạo cuộc sống theo một lối từng bị che khuất đi khỏi tôi trước kia. ‘Một giấc mơ về dáng hình trong những ngày suy tưởng,’ — ai là người đã nói điều này nhỉ? Tôi quên rồi; nhưng đó chính là những gì mà Dorian Gray đã mang đến cho tôi. Chỉ sự hiện diện của cậu bé này thôi — vì dường như với tôi thì cậu ấy cũng chỉ lớn hơn chút xíu so với một cậu bé, mặc dù cậu ấy thật sự là đã ngoài hai mươi — chỉ sự hiện diện của cậu ấy — ôi! Tôi tự hỏi liệu anh có thể hiểu rõ mọi ý nghĩa mà điều ấy mang đến không? Một cách vô thức, cậu ấy định rõ cho tôi các giới hạn của một trường phái tươi mới, một trường phái có trong nó mọi đam mê của tinh thần lãng mạn, mọi sự tuyệt mỹ của cái tinh thần thuộc về Hy Lạp. Sự hài hòa của linh hồn và thể xác — điều ấy nhiều biết nhường nào! Trong cơn mất trí, chúng ta đã chia cắt hai thứ này, và đã phát minh ra một thứ chủ nghĩa hiện thực hết sức thô tục, một năng lực tưởng tượng rỗng tuếch. Harry! Nếu như anh chỉ cần biết được rằng Dorian Gray có ý nghĩa thế nào với tôi! Anh có nhớ cái bức tranh phong cảnh của tôi, mà Agnew từng trả cho tôi một cái giá rất đắt, nhưng tôi không thể xa nó được không? Đó là một trong những bức đẹp nhất mà tôi từng tạo được. Tại sao như vậy? Bởi vì khi tôi vẽ nó, Dorian Gray ngồi bên tôi. Một sự ảnh hưởng huyền ảo nào đó đã truyền từ cậu ấy qua tôi, và lần đầu tiên trong đời mình, tôi thấy trong vùng rừng đơn sơ ấy có sự diệu kỳ mà tôi luôn kiếm tìm, và luôn bỏ lỡ.”
tr: Ressam, “Benim için sanatımın tümü o demek artık,” diye ciddiyetle yanıt verdi. “Harry, kimi zaman düşünüyorum da, dünya tarihinde önemli sayılabilecek topu topu iki dönem var, bence. Birincisi yeni bir sanat ortamının belirmesi, ikincisi de gene sanat için yeni bir kişiliğin ortaya çıkması. Yağlıboyanın icadı Venedik ressamları için, Antinous’un çehresi geç dönem Yunan heykeltıraşları için ne demek olduysa, Dorian Gray’in yüzü de benim için bir gün o önemi taşıyacak. Ondan esinlenerek yalnızca resim çiziyor, boyuyor değilim. Bunları yapıyorum elbette. Gene de o benim gözümde bir modelden çok öte bir anlam taşıyor. Ondan esinlenerek yaptığım resimlerden hoşnut değilim, onun güzelliğini sanat ortaya koyamaz, falan diyecek değilim sana. Sanatın ifade edemeyeceği hiçbir şey yoktur; Dorian Gray’i tanıdığımdan bu yana yaptığım çalışmaların da iyi ürünler olduğunu biliyorum, şimdiye dek verdiğim ürünlerin en iyileri. Gene de, ne tuhaf... Bilmem anlayacak mısın beni?.. Onun kişiliği sayesinde sanatta yepyeni bir tarzın varlığını seziyorum sanki. Yepyeni bir tarz. Her şeyi bambaşka görüyorum, bambaşka algılıyorum artık. Şimdilerde yaşamı, eskiden bilmediğim, göremediğim yepyeni bir formda yaratabilir oldum. ‘Düşünce günlerinde bir form hayali.’ Kim söylemiş bunu? Anımsayamıyorum ama Dorian Gray benim gözümde bu işte. Bu çocuğun salt gözle görünen varlığı... Aslında yaşı yirminin üstünde, ama ben onu hep çocuk olarak görüyorum... Evet, salt gözle görünen varlığı bile... Of, bilmem kavrayabiliyor musun bütün bunların taşıdığı anlamı? Kendi de bilmeden bu çocuk yepyeni bir sanat ekolünün çizgilerini tanımlıyor sanki: romantik ekolün tüm ateşiyle antik Yunan ekolünün tüm kusursuzluğunu birleştirecek bir okul. Bedenle ruhun uyumu... Nasıl da önemlidir bu! Biz, beyinsizliğimiz yüzünden bunları birbirinden ayırmış, kaba bir gerçekçilik icat etmişiz, bomboş bir idealcilik. Ah, Harry, Dorian Gray’in benim gözümde neyi simgelediğini bir anlayabilsen! Hani bir peyzajım vardı, Agnew dünya kadar para verdiydi de elimden çıkarmadıydım. En iyi eserlerimden biridir o. Peki neden dersin? Çünkü o resmi yaparken Dorian Gray yanı başımda oturuyordu. Ondan bana elle tutulmaz bir etki geçiyor olsa gerek ki ömrümde ilk olarak, karşımdaki sıradan ormanlıkta hep aramış, hiç yakalayamamış olduğum büyüyü bulmuştum.
es: —Dorian es todo mi arte —dijo el pintor gravemente—. A veces pienso, Harry, que la historia del mundo sólo ha conocido dos eras importantes. La primera es la que ve la aparición de una nueva técnica artística. La segunda, la que asiste a la aparición de una nueva personalidad, también para el arte. Lo que fue la invención de la pintura al óleo para los venecianos, o el rostro de Antinoo para los últimos escultores griegos, lo será algún día para mí el rostro de Dorian Gray. No es sólo que lo utilice como modelo para pintar, para dibujar, para hacer apuntes. He hecho todo eso, por supuesto. Pero para mí es mucho más que un modelo o un tema. No te voy a decir que esté insatisfecho con lo que he conseguido, ni que su belleza sea tal que el arte no pueda expresarla. No hay nada que el arte no pueda expresar, y sé que lo que he hecho desde que conocí a Dorian Gray es bueno, es lo mejor que he hecho nunca. Pero, de alguna manera curiosa (no sé si me entenderás), su personalidad me ha sugerido una manera completamente nueva, un nuevo estilo. Veo las cosas de manera distinta, las pienso de forma diferente. Ahora soy capaz de recrear la vida de una manera que antes desconocía. «Un sueño de belleza en días de meditación». ¿Quién ha dicho eso? No me acuerdo; pero eso ha sido para mí Dorian Gray. La simple presencia de ese muchacho, porque me parece poco más que un adolescente, aunque pasa de los veinte, su simple presencia... ¡Ah! Me pregunto si puedes darte cuenta de lo que significa. De manera inconsciente define para mí los trazos de una nueva escuela, una escuela que tiene toda la pasión del espíritu romántico y toda la perfección de lo griego. La armonía del alma y del cuerpo, ¡qué maravilla! En nuestra locura hemos separado las dos cosas, y hemos inventado un realismo que es vulgar, y un idealismo hueco. ¡Harry! ¡Si supieras lo que Dorian es para mí! ¿Recuerdas aquel paisaje mío, por el que Agnew me ofreció tanto dinero, pero del que no quise desprenderme? Es una de las mejores cosas que he hecho nunca. Y, ¿por qué? Porque mientras lo pintaba Dorian Gray estaba a mi lado. Me transmitía alguna influencia sutil y por primera vez en mi vida vi en un simple bosque la maravilla que siempre había buscado y que siempre se me había escapado.
vi_translation: “He is all my art to me now,” the artist said, very seriously. “Sometimes I think, Harry, that there are only two periods that have any significance in the history of the world. The first is the appearance of a new medium for art, and the second is the appearance of a new personality also for art. The things that the invention of oil painting brought to the Venetians, the face of Antinoüs brought to later Greek sculpture, and the face of Dorian Gray will bring to me one day. It’s not simply that I paint from him, draw from him, sketch from him. Of course, I have done all that. But he means more to me than just a model or a sitter. I won’t tell you that I am not satisfied with what I have done about him, or that his beauty is so marvelous that Art cannot express it. There is nothing that Art cannot express, and I know that the work I have done since I met Dorian Gray is good work, the best work of my life. But in some strange way — I wonder if you understand me? — his personality has stirred in me a completely new manner of art, a completely new mode of style. I see things differently, I think of them differently. Now I can recreate life in a way that was hidden from me before. ‘A dream of form in days of thought,’ — who said that? I forget; but that is what Dorian Gray has brought to me. Just his mere presence — for to me he seems little more than a boy, though he is really over twenty — just his mere presence — oh! I wonder if you can realize all that that means? Unconsciously, he defines for me the limits of a fresh school, a school that has in it all the passion of the romantic spirit, all the perfection of the spirit that belongs to Greece. The harmony of soul and body — how much that is! In our madness, we have separated the two, and have invented a realism that is vulgar, an ideality that is void. Harry! If you only knew what Dorian Gray means to me! Do you remember that landscape of mine, for which Agnew offered me such a large price, but which I could not part with? It is one of the best things I have ever done. Why is that? Because while I was painting it, Dorian Gray sat beside me. Some subtle influence passed from him to me, and for the first time in my life, I saw in the plain woodland the wonder I had always looked for, and always missed.”
tr_translation: The painter replied seriously, "For me, my art means everything now." "Harry, sometimes I think there are only two periods in world history that can be considered important, in my opinion. The first is the emergence of a new art environment, and the second is the appearance of a new personality for art. The invention of oil painting was to the Venetian painters what the face of Antinous was to the late Greek sculptors, and one day, Dorian Gray's face will hold that importance for me. I'm not just drawing and painting because of him. Of course, I am doing those things. Yet, in my eyes, he means much more than just a model. I'm not going to tell you that I'm not satisfied with the paintings I made inspired by him, or that art cannot capture his beauty. There is nothing that art cannot express; I know that the works I've done since I met Dorian Gray are good products, the best I've ever produced. Still, how strange... I wonder if you'll understand me?.. Thanks to his personality, I feel as if there's a completely new style in art. A completely new style. I see everything differently, I perceive everything differently now. Nowadays, I can create life in a completely new form that I didn't know or see before. 'A form dreamt of in the days of thought.' Who said that? I can't remember, but that's what Dorian Gray is to me. The mere visible presence of this boy... Actually, he's over twenty, but I always see him as a child... Yes, even his mere visible presence... Oh, I don't know if you can grasp the full meaning of all this? Without even knowing it, this boy seems to define the lines of a completely new art school: a school that will combine all the fire of the romantic school with all the perfection of the ancient Greek school. The harmony of body and soul... How important this is! We, in our stupidity, have separated them, invented a crude realism, an empty idealism. Oh, Harry, if only you could understand what Dorian Gray symbolizes to me! You know that landscape of mine, Agnew offered a fortune for it, but I didn't let it go. It's one of my best works. And why, do you think? Because while I was painting it, Dorian Gray was sitting beside me. There must have been an intangible influence from him to me, because for the first time in my life, I found the magic I had always sought but never caught in the ordinary forest in front of me."
es_translation: —Dorian is all my art —said the painter gravely—. Sometimes I think, Harry, that the history of the world has only known two important eras. The first is the one that sees the emergence of a new artistic technique. The second, the one that witnesses the emergence of a new personality, also for art. What the invention of oil painting was for the Venetians, or the face of Antinous for the last Greek sculptors, the face of Dorian Gray will be for me someday. It's not just that I use him as a model to paint, to draw, to make sketches. I've done all that, of course. But for me, he is much more than a model or a subject. I'm not going to tell you that I'm dissatisfied with what I've achieved, nor that his beauty is such that art cannot express it. There is nothing that art cannot express, and I know that what I've done since I met Dorian Gray is good, it's the best I've ever done. But, in some curious way (I don't know if you'll understand me), his personality has suggested to me a completely new way, a new style. I see things differently, I think of them differently. Now I am able to recreate life in a way I didn't know before. «A dream of beauty in days of meditation». Who said that? I don't remember; but that has been Dorian Gray for me. The mere presence of that boy, because he seems little more than a teenager to me, although he is over twenty, his mere presence... Ah! I wonder if you can realize what it means. Unconsciously, he defines for me the outlines of a new school, a school that has all the passion of the romantic spirit and all the perfection of the Greek. The harmony of soul and body, what a marvel! In our madness, we have separated the two things, and we have invented a realism that is vulgar, and a hollow idealism. Harry! If you knew what Dorian is to me! Do you remember that landscape of mine, for which Agnew offered me so much money, but which I didn't want to part with? It is one of the best things I've ever done. And, why? Because while I was painting it, Dorian Gray was by my side. He transmitted some subtle influence to me and for the first time in my life I saw in a simple forest the wonder I had always sought and that had always eluded me.

en: “Basil, this is extraordinary! I must see Dorian Gray.”
vi: “Basil, chuyện này lạ quá! Tôi phải gặp Dorian Gray.”
tr: “Basil, duyulmadık bir şey bu! Dorian Gray’i mutlaka görmem gerek.
es: —¡Eso que cuentas es extraordinario! He de ver a Dorian Gray.
vi_translation: “Basil, this is so strange! I must meet Dorian Gray.”
tr_translation: "Basil, this is unheard of! I absolutely must see Dorian Gray."
es_translation: —What you're telling me is extraordinary! I must see Dorian Gray.

en: Hallward got up from the seat and walked up and down the garden. After some time he came back. “Harry,” he said, “Dorian Gray is to me simply a motive in art. You might see nothing in him. I see everything in him. He is never more present in my work than when no image of him is there. He is a suggestion, as I have said, of a new manner. I find him in the curves of certain lines, in the loveliness and subtleties of certain colours. That is all.”
vi: Hallward nhỏm dậy khỏi chỗ ngồi và bước tới bước lui trong vườn. Một lát sau, y quay lại. “Harry,” y nói, “Dorian Gray với tôi chỉ là một mô- típ nghệ thuật. Anh sẽ chẳng thể nào thấy gì trong cậu ấy đâu. Tôi thì thấy mọi thứ trong cậu ấy. Cậu ấy chẳng bao giờ hiện diện trong tác phẩm của tôi nhiều hơn những lúc mà không có hình ảnh cậu ấy ở đó. Cậu ấy là một gợi ý, như tôi từng nói, về phong cách mới. Tôi thấy cậu ấy trong những đoạn cong của vài nét vẽ nào đó, trong vẻ yêu kiều và sự tinh tế của vài sắc màu nào đó. Chỉ thế thôi.”
tr: Hallward ayağa kalkarak bahçede ileri geri gezinmeye başladı. Biraz sonra gene geri geldi. “Harry,” dedi. “Dorian Gray benim için yalnızca beni yaratıcılığa iten bir güdü. Ben onda her şeyi buluyorum. Sen hiçbir şey bulmayabilirsin. Onun yapıtlarımda en çok var olduğu zamanla da imgesinin görülmediği zamanlar. Dedim ya, yepyeni bir tarzın sezisi o. Ben birtakım çizgilerin yuvarlanışında buluyorum onu, kimi renklerin güzelliğinde, anlatılmaz inceliğinde. Hepsi bu.
es: Hallward se levantó del asiento y empezó a pasear por el jardín. Al cabo de unos momentos regresó. —Harry —dijo—, Dorian Gray no es para mí más que un motivo artístico. Quizá tú no veas nada en él. Yo lo veo todo. Nunca está más presente en mi trabajo que cuando no aparece en lo que pinto. Es la sugerencia, como he dicho, de una nueva manera. Lo encuentro en las curvas de ciertas líneas, en el encanto y sutileza de ciertos colores. Eso es todo.
vi_translation: Hallward got up from his seat and paced back and forth in the garden. A moment later, he returned. “Harry,” he said, “Dorian Gray is just an artistic motif to me. You will never see anything in him. I see everything in him. He is never more present in my work than when his image is not there. He is a suggestion, as I have said, of a new style. I see him in the curves of certain lines, in the grace and subtlety of certain colors. That's all.”
tr_translation: Hallward stood up and began pacing back and forth in the garden. A little later, he came back again. “Harry,” he said. “Dorian Gray is merely a motive that drives me to creativity. I find everything in him. You may find nothing. The times when he is most present in my works are also the times when his image is not seen. As I said, he is the intuition of a completely new style. I find him in the curve of some lines, in the beauty of certain colors, in their indescribable delicacy. That's all.”
es_translation: Hallward got up from his seat and began to walk around the garden. After a few moments, he returned. —Harry —he said—, Dorian Gray is nothing more to me than an artistic inspiration. Perhaps you see nothing in him. I see everything. He is never more present in my work than when he does not appear in what I paint. He is the suggestion, as I have said, of a new manner. I find him in the curves of certain lines, in the charm and subtlety of certain colors. That is all.

en: “Then why won’t you exhibit his portrait?” asked Lord Henry.
vi: “Vậy sao anh lại không trưng bày bức chân dung cậu ấy?” Huân tước Henry hỏi.
tr: Lord Henry, “Öyleyse onun portresini neden sergilemiyorsun?” diye sordu.
es: —Entonces, ¿por qué te niegas a exponer su retrato? —preguntó lord Henry.
vi_translation: “Then why don't you display his portrait?” Lord Henry asked.
tr_translation: Lord Henry asked, "Then why don't you exhibit his portrait?"
es_translation: —Then, why do you refuse to exhibit his portrait? —asked Lord Henry.

en: “Because, without intending it, I have put into it some expression of all this curious artistic idolatry, of which, of course, I have never cared to speak to him. He knows nothing about it. He shall never know anything about it. But the world might guess it, and I will not bare my soul to their shallow prying eyes. My heart shall never be put under their microscope. There is too much of myself in the thing, Harry—too much of myself!”
vi: “Bởi vì, dù không định trước, nhưng tôi đã đưa vào nó một biểu hiện nào đó về mọi sự sùng bái thần tượng kỳ lạ này trong nghệ thuật, sự sùng bái mà, đương nhiên, tôi chưa từng muốn nói về nó với cậu ấy. Cậu ấy chẳng biết gì về nó. Cậu ấy cũng sẽ chẳng bao giờ biết bất cứ điều gì về nó. Song thế giới có thể đoán ra nó; và tôi sẽ không phơi bày tâm hồn mình trước những con mắt tọc mạch nông cạn của họ. Tim tôi sẽ không bao giờ bị đặt dưới kính hiển vi của họ. Có quá nhiều thứ thuộc về tôi trong vật ấy, Harry — quá nhiều thứ thuộc về tôi!”
tr: “Şu duyduğum tuhaf sanatsal putperestliğin bir ifadesini, hiç niyetim olmadığı halde, o portreye yansıtmışım da ondan. Bu duygulardan ona hiç söz etmedim, doğallıkla. Dorian Gray’in bundan haberi yok. Olmayacak da. Gelgelelim başkaları bunu sezebilir; benim de ruhumu onların o sığ, meraklı gözlerinin önünde sergilemeye hiç niyetim yok. Yüreğimi onların mikroskoplarının altına asla sermeyeceğim. Portrede benim özbenliğimden çok şey var, Harry, gereğinden çok!
es: —Porque, sin pretenderlo, he puesto en ese cuadro la expresión de mi extraña idolatría de artista, de la que, por supuesto, nunca he querido hablar con él. Nada sabe. No lo sabrá nunca. Pero quizá el mundo lo adivine; y no quiero desnudar mi alma ante su mirada entrometida y superficial. Nunca pondré mi corazón bajo su microscopio. Hay demasiado de mí mismo en ese cuadro, Harry, ¡demasiado de mí mismo!
vi_translation: “Because, although unintentionally, I have imbued it with some expression of this strange idolatry in art, an idolatry that, of course, I never wanted to discuss with him. He knows nothing about it. He will never know anything about it. But the world might guess it; and I will not expose my soul to their shallow, prying eyes. My heart will never be placed under their microscope. There is too much of myself in that thing, Harry — too much of myself!”
tr_translation: “It is because I have unconsciously reflected in that portrait the strange artistic idolatry I have heard of. I never spoke to him about these feelings, naturally. Dorian Gray has no idea about it. Nor will he ever. However, others might sense it; and I have no intention of exposing my soul to their shallow, curious eyes. I will never lay my heart under their microscopes. There is too much of myself in the portrait, Harry, far too much!”
es_translation: —Because, without intending to, I have put in that painting the expression of my strange idolatry as an artist, which, of course, I have never wanted to talk to him about. He knows nothing. He will never know. But perhaps the world will guess it; and I do not want to bare my soul before its intrusive and superficial gaze. I will never place my heart under its microscope. There is too much of myself in that painting, Harry, too much of myself!

en: “Poets are not so scrupulous as you are. They know how useful passion is for publication. Nowadays a broken heart will run to many editions.”
vi: “Các thi sỹ cũng không đắn đo nhiều như anh. Họ biết nỗi đam mê hữu ích thế nào cho việc xuất bản. Thời nay, một trái tim tan vỡ sẽ chạy vào được nhiều bản in.”
tr: “Şairler senin kadar kılı kırk yarmazlar. Tutkunun yayınlamak için işe yarar bir şey olduğunu bilirler. Şimdilerde yanık bir yürek sayısız baskılar yapabiliyor.
es: —Los poetas no son tan escrupulosos como tú. Saben lo útil que es la pasión cuando piensan en publicar. En nuestros días un corazón roto da para muchas ediciones.
vi_translation: “Poets do not deliberate as much as you do. They know how useful passion is for publishing. These days, a broken heart will make it into many prints.”
tr_translation: “Poets do not split hairs as much as you do. They know that passion is something useful to publish. Nowadays, a burning heart can make countless impressions.”
es_translation: —Poets are not as scrupulous as you. They know how useful passion is when they think about publishing. In our days, a broken heart can lead to many editions.

en: “I hate them for it,” cried Hallward. “An artist should create beautiful things, but should put nothing of his own life into them. We live in an age when men treat art as if it were meant to be a form of autobiography. We have lost the abstract sense of beauty. Some day I will show the world what it is; and for that reason the world shall never see my portrait of Dorian Gray.”
vi: “Tôi ghét bọn họ vì chuyện đó,” Hallward kêu lên. “Một nghệ sỹ nên tạo ra những thứ đẹp đẽ, song không nên đưa gì của đời mình vào trong chúng. Ta đang sống trong một thời đại mà mọi người đối xử với nghệ thuật như thể nó nghĩa là một dạng tự truyện. Ta đã đánh mất khả năng trừu tượng để cảm nhận cái đẹp. Ngày nào đó tôi sẽ cho thế giới xem nó là gì; và vì lý do ấy mà thế giới sẽ chẳng bao giờ được thấy bức chân dung Dorian Gray của tôi.”
tr: Ressam, “Ben de onların bu yönünden tiksiniyorum!” diye bağırdı. “Sanatçı dediğin güzel şeyler yaratmalı, ama bunlara kendi özel yaşamından hiçbir şey katmamalı. Öyle bir çağda yaşıyoruz ki herkes sanata bir tür özyaşamöyküsü gözüyle bakıyor. Soyut güzellik duyusunu yitirmişiz. Günün birinde bunun ne olduğunu bütün dünyaya göstereceğim ben; işte bu nedenledir ki dünya benim yaptığım Dorian Gray portresini asla göremeyecek.
es: —Los detesto por eso —exclamó Hallward—. Un artista debe crear cosas hermosas, pero sin poner en ellas nada de su propia existencia. Vivimos en una época en la que se trata el arte como si fuese una forma de autobiografía. Hemos perdido el sentido abstracto de la belleza. Algún día mostraré al mundo lo que es eso; y ésa es la razón de que el mundo no deba ver nunca mi retrato de Dorian Gray.
vi_translation: “I hate them for that,” Hallward exclaimed. “An artist should create beautiful things, but should not put anything of his own life into them. We live in an age where people treat art as if it were some kind of autobiography. We have lost the ability to abstractly appreciate beauty. One day I will show the world what it is; and for that reason, the world will never see my portrait of Dorian Gray.”
tr_translation: The painter shouted, "I despise them for this very reason!" "An artist should create beautiful things, but should not put anything of his own life into them. We live in an age where everyone looks at art as a kind of autobiography. We have lost the sense of abstract beauty. One day I will show the world what it is; that is why the world will never see my portrait of Dorian Gray."
es_translation: —I detest them for that —exclaimed Hallward—. An artist should create beautiful things, but without putting anything of their own existence into them. We live in an age where art is treated as if it were a form of autobiography. We have lost the abstract sense of beauty. Someday I will show the world what that is; and that is the reason why the world must never see my portrait of Dorian Gray.

en: “I think you are wrong, Basil, but I won’t argue with you. It is only the intellectually lost who ever argue. Tell me, is Dorian Gray very fond of you?”
vi: “Tôi nghĩ anh sai rồi, Basil, nhưng tôi sẽ không tranh cãi với anh. Chỉ có những kẻ mất trí mới đi tranh cãi. Kể tôi đi, có phải là Dorian Gray rất mến anh?”
tr: “Bence tutumun yanlış, Basil, gene de seninle tartışacak değilim. Entelektüel yoldan çıkanlar dur durak bilmeksizin tartışır bana sorarsan. Söyle bana, Dorian Gray sana çok bağlı mı?
es: —Creo que estás equivocado, pero no voy a discutir contigo. Sólo discuten los que están perdidos intelectualmente. Dime, Dorian Gray te tiene mucho afecto?
vi_translation: “I think you are wrong, Basil, but I will not argue with you. Only fools argue. Tell me, does Dorian Gray like you very much?”
tr_translation: “I think your attitude is wrong, Basil, but I'm not going to argue with you. If you ask me, those who go astray intellectually argue incessantly. Tell me, is Dorian Gray very attached to you?”
es_translation: —I think you are mistaken, but I am not going to argue with you. Only those who are intellectually lost argue. Tell me, does Dorian Gray care about you a lot?

en: The painter considered for a few moments. “He likes me,” he answered after a pause; “I know he likes me. Of course I flatter him dreadfully. I find a strange pleasure in saying things to him that I know I shall be sorry for having said. As a rule, he is charming to me, and we sit in the studio and talk of a thousand things. Now and then, however, he is horribly thoughtless, and seems to take a real delight in giving me pain. Then I feel, Harry, that I have given away my whole soul to some one who treats it as if it were a flower to put in his coat, a bit of decoration to charm his vanity, an ornament for a summer’s day.”
vi: Họa sỹ cân nhắc vài giây. “Cậu ấy thích tôi,” y trả lời, sau một chút ngập ngừng; “tôi biết cậu ấy thích tôi. Dĩ nhiên tôi tâng cậu ấy lên mây. Tôi thấy một khoái cảm lạ lùng trong việc nói cho cậu ấy những thứ mà tôi biết là tôi sẽ hối tiếc vì đã nói ra. Theo lệ thường, cậu ấy rất dễ thương với tôi, chúng tôi ngồi trong xưởng vẽ và nói về đủ thứ chuyện. Tuy nhiên, thỉnh thoảng cậu ấy cũng khinh suất kinh khủng, và dường như nhận thấy niềm vui thực sự trong việc làm tôi đau. Lúc ấy tôi cảm thấy, Harry à, rằng tôi sẽ trao tặng cả linh hồn mình cho ai đó biết cách đối xử với nó như thể nó là một bông hoa để mà cài lên áo choàng anh ấy, một món trang sức bé mọn để mà làm đẹp cho hư danh anh ấy, một món đồ trang trí cho ngày hè.”
tr: Ressam bir süre düşündü. Bir duralamadan sonra, “Benden hoşlanıyor,” diye karşılık verdi. “Biliyorum, hoşlanıyor benden. Tabii ben de onu müthiş pohpohluyorum ya.
