Sonradan pişman olacağımı kesin bildiğim bir sürü şeyi ona söylemekten garip bir zevk alıyorum. Genellikle bana karşı çok tatlı, çok sevimli davranıyor. Stüdyoda oturup bin bir konudan konuşuyoruz. Gelgelelim arada korkunç düşüncesizlikler ediyor, bana acı vermekten gerçek bir kıvanç duyuyor sanki. Harry, o zaman da bana öyle geliyor ki ruhumun tümünü, yakasına takacak bir çiçek yerine koyan birine vermişim; kibrini okşayacak bir süs yerine koyuyor benim ruhumu, bir yaz gününde kullanılıp atılacak bir süs.
es: El pintor reflexionó durante unos instantes. —Me tiene afecto —respondió, después de una pausa—; sé que me tiene afecto. Es cierto, por otra parte, que lo halago terriblemente. Hallo un extraño placer en decirle cosas de las que sé que después voy a arrepentirme. Por regla general es encantador conmigo, y nos sentamos en el estudio y hablamos de mil cosas. De cuando en cuando, sin embargo, es terriblemente desconsiderado, y parece disfrutar haciéndome sufrir. Entonces siento que he entregado toda mi alma a alguien que la trata como si fuera una flor que se pone en el ojal, una condecoración que deleita su vanidad, un adorno para un día de verano.
vi_translation: The artist pondered for a few seconds. "He likes me," he replied, after a slight hesitation; "I know he likes me. Of course, I flatter him excessively. I find a strange pleasure in telling him things that I know I will regret saying. As usual, he is very charming to me, we sit in the studio and talk about all sorts of things. However, sometimes he is terribly reckless, and seems to find real joy in hurting me. At those times, I feel, Harry, that I would give my soul to someone who knows how to treat it as if it were a flower to pin on his cloak, a small ornament to beautify his vanity, a decoration for a summer's day."
tr_translation: The painter thought for a while. After a pause, he replied, "She likes me." "I know, she likes me. Of course, I also flatter her immensely. I take a strange pleasure in telling her a lot of things that I know I will definitely regret later. She generally behaves very sweetly and charmingly towards me. We sit in the studio and talk about a thousand different topics. However, sometimes she acts incredibly thoughtlessly, as if she takes real pleasure in causing me pain. Harry, at those times, it feels to me as if I have given my entire soul to someone who treats it like a flower to be pinned to their lapel; she treats my soul like an ornament to flatter her vanity, an ornament to be used and discarded on a summer day."
es_translation: The painter reflected for a few moments. —He is fond of me —he replied, after a pause—; I know he is fond of me. It is true, on the other hand, that I flatter him terribly. I find a strange pleasure in telling him things that I know I will regret later. Generally, he is charming with me, and we sit in the study and talk about a thousand things. From time to time, however, he is terribly inconsiderate, and he seems to enjoy making me suffer. Then I feel that I have given my whole soul to someone who treats it as if it were a flower to put in his buttonhole, a decoration that delights his vanity, an ornament for a summer's day.

en: “Days in summer, Basil, are apt to linger,” murmured Lord Henry. “Perhaps you will tire sooner than he will. It is a sad thing to think of, but there is no doubt that genius lasts longer than beauty. That accounts for the fact that we all take such pains to over-educate ourselves. In the wild struggle for existence, we want to have something that endures, and so we fill our minds with rubbish and facts, in the silly hope of keeping our place. The thoroughly well-informed man—that is the modern ideal. And the mind of the thoroughly well-informed man is a dreadful thing. It is like a bric-à-brac shop, all monsters and dust, with everything priced above its proper value. I think you will tire first, all the same. Some day you will look at your friend, and he will seem to you to be a little out of drawing, or you won’t like his tone of colour, or something. You will bitterly reproach him in your own heart, and seriously think that he has behaved very badly to you. The next time he calls, you will be perfectly cold and indifferent. It will be a great pity, for it will alter you. What you have told me is quite a romance, a romance of art one might call it, and the worst of having a romance of any kind is that it leaves one so unromantic.”
vi: “Những ngày hè, Basil, thường dễ kéo dài,” huân tước Henry lẩm bẩm. “Không chừng anh sẽ chán sớm hơn cậu ấy. Thật buồn khi nghĩ đến, song chắc chắn là Tài năng tồn tại lâu hơn Sắc đẹp. Điều đó giải thích cho sự thật là tất cả chúng ta đều bỏ biết bao công sức cho việc rèn đi rèn lại bản thân mình. Trong cuộc vật lộn cuồng điên cho cuộc sinh tồn, ta muốn có gì đó lâu dài, vậy nên ta nhồi đầy ký ức mình bằng rác rưởi và sự thật, với niềm hy vọng ngây thơ về việc giữ được chỗ của mình. Kẻ biết tuốt — đó là người lý tưởng thời nay. Và trí tuệ của kẻ biết tuốt là một thứ khủng khiếp. Nó giống như tiệm lạc xoong, toàn quái vật và bụi, với mọi thứ được kê giá cao hơn giá trị thật. Tôi nghĩ anh sẽ chán trước, dẫu có thế nào. Ngày nào đó anh sẽ nhìn bạn anh, và anh sẽ thấy cậu ấy dường như bị vẽ hơi sai, hoặc anh sẽ không thích tông màu của cậu ấy, hoặc gì đó. Anh sẽ cay đắng nhục mạ cậu ấy trong thâm tâm, và nghiêm túc nghĩ rằng cậu ấy đã cư xử rất tệ với anh. Lần sau cậu ấy ghé thăm, anh sẽ lạnh nhạt và dửng dưng như không. Đó sẽ là một điều hết sức đáng tiếc, vì nó sẽ thay đổi anh. Những gì anh đã kể cho tôi đúng là một câu chuyện lãng mạn, một câu chuyện lãng mạn về nghệ thuật như người ta có thể gọi, và điều tệ hại nhất trong việc có một câu chuyện lãng mạn bất cứ kiểu nào chính là ở chỗ nó sẽ làm cho người ta thành ra hết sức tầm thường.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Yaz günleri uzun sürer, Basil,” diye mırıldandı. “Belki de sen ondan önce bıkarsın. Hüzün verici bir düşünce, evet, ne var ki deha hiç kuşkusuz güzellikten daha uzun ömürlüdür. Hepimizin, kendimizi aşırı derecede eğitmek uğruna bunca zahmete katlanmamız da bundandır ya. Şu çılgın, kıran kırana yaşam savaşında hepimiz dayanıklı bir şeylere sahip olmak isteriz, bu yüzden de yaşam kavgasındaki yerimizden olmamak için kafamızı süprüntülerle, olgularla doldururuz. Eksiksiz bilgi sahibi adam: Çağdaş ideal işte budur. Eksiksiz bilgi sahibi adamın zihniyse ürkütücü bir şeydir. Elden düşme züccaciye satan bir dükkân gibi, baştan aşağı toz ve eciş bücüş nesneler, canavarlar. Her şeye gerçek değerinin üstünde fiyat konmuş. Evet, bana öyle geliyor ki, ilkin sen usanacaksın. Günlerden bir gün dostuna bakacaksın, çizgileri gözüne az buçuk ayarsız gözükecek ya da renginin tonunu beğenmeyeceksin ya da böyle bir şey işte. İçten içe onu acı acı kınayacaksın, onun sana karşı çok kötü davranmış olduğunu düşüneceksin. Kapına bir daha geldiğinde tümden soğuk, ilgisiz davranacaksın ona. Çok yazık olacak doğrusu, çünkü bu seni değiştirecek. Senin bana anlattığın enikonu romantik bir öykü, bir sanat romantizmi, diyebiliriz. Böyle romantik bir öykü yaşamanın en kötü yanı şudur ki bittiği zaman kişiyi romantiklikten tümüyle uzaklaştırır.
es: —En verano los días suelen ser largos, Basil —murmuró lord Henry—. Quizá te canses tú antes que él. Es triste pensarlo, pero sin duda el genio dura más que la belleza. Eso explica que nos esforcemos tanto por cultivarnos. En la lucha feroz por la existencia queremos tener algo que dure, y nos llenamos la cabeza de basura y de datos, con la tonta esperanza de conservar nuestro puesto. La persona que lo sabe todo: ése es el ideal moderno. Y la mente de esa persona que todo lo sabe es una cosa terrible, un almacén de baratillo, todo monstruos y polvo, y siempre con precios por encima de su valor verdadero. Creo que tú te cansarás primero, de todos modos. Algún día mirarás a tu amigo, y te parecerá que está un poco desdibujado, o no te gustará la tonalidad de su tez, o cualquier otra cosa. Se lo reprocharás con amargura, y pensarás, muy seriamente, que se ha portado mal contigo. La siguiente vez que te visite, te mostrarás perfectamente frío e indiferente. Será una pena, porque te cambiará. Lo que me has contado es una historia de amor, habría que llamarla historia de amor estético, y lo peor de toda historia de amor es que después tino se siente muy poco romántico.
vi_translation: “Summer days, Basil, tend to linger,” Lord Henry murmured. “You might grow bored with him sooner than he with you. It is sad to think about, but Talent undoubtedly lasts longer than Beauty. That explains why we all put so much effort into refining ourselves over and over. In the mad struggle for survival, we want something enduring, so we fill our memories with rubbish and facts, with the naive hope of maintaining our place. The know-it-all — that is the ideal of our time. And the intellect of the know-it-all is a terrible thing. It is like a curiosity shop, full of monsters and dust, with everything priced higher than its true worth. I think you will grow bored first, no matter what. One day you will look at your friend, and you will see that he seems slightly misdrawn, or you will dislike his tone, or something. You will bitterly resent him in your heart, and seriously think that he has treated you very badly. The next time he visits, you will be cold and indifferent as if nothing happened. That will be a great pity, for it will change you. What you have told me is indeed a romantic story, a romantic story about art as one might call it, and the worst thing about having any kind of romantic story is that it makes one become exceedingly ordinary.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, “Summer days are long, Basil.”“Perhaps you will tire of it before it does. A sad thought, yes, but genius undoubtedly lasts longer than beauty. That is why we all go to such lengths to educate ourselves excessively. In this mad, fierce struggle for life, we all want to possess something durable, so we fill our heads with trivia, with facts, to maintain our place in the struggle. The man with complete knowledge: This is the contemporary ideal. Yet the mind of a man with complete knowledge is a terrifying thing. Like a shop selling second-hand crockery, full of dust and misshapen objects, monsters. Everything is priced above its real value. Yes, it seems to me that you will be the first to grow weary. One day you will look at your friend, and his features will seem somewhat out of proportion to you, or you will not like the tone of his color, or something like that. Inwardly, you will bitterly reproach him, thinking he has treated you very badly. When he comes to your door again, you will behave entirely coldly and indifferently towards him. It will be a great pity, really, because it will change you. The story you told me is a thoroughly romantic one, a romance of art, we might say. The worst part of living such a romantic story is that when it ends, it completely alienates a person from romanticism.”
es_translation: —In summer, the days are usually long, Basil —murmured Lord Henry—. Perhaps you will tire before he does. It's sad to think about, but undoubtedly genius lasts longer than beauty. That explains why we strive so hard to cultivate ourselves. In the fierce struggle for existence, we want to have something that lasts, and we fill our heads with trash and data, with the foolish hope of maintaining our position. The person who knows everything: that is the modern ideal. And the mind of that person who knows everything is a terrible thing, a junk shop, all monsters and dust, and always with prices above their true value. I think you will tire first, anyway. Someday you will look at your friend, and he will seem a bit blurred, or you won't like the tone of his complexion, or something else. You will reproach him bitterly, and you will think, very seriously, that he has treated you badly. The next time he visits you, you will show yourself perfectly cold and indifferent. It will be a shame, because it will change you. What you have told me is a love story, it should be called an aesthetic love story, and the worst thing about any love story is that afterward one feels very little romantic.

en: “Harry, don’t talk like that. As long as I live, the personality of Dorian Gray will dominate me. You can’t feel what I feel. You change too often.”
vi: “Harry, đừng nói chuyện như vậy. Chừng nào tôi còn sống, cá tính của Dorian Gray còn chi phối tôi. Anh không thể cảm nhận được những gì tôi cảm nhận được. Anh thay đổi quá thường xuyên.”
tr: “Harry, böyle konuşmasana. Var olduğum sürece Dorian Gray’in etkisi bana egemen olacak. Benim hissettiklerimi sen hissedemezsin ki! Sen durmadan değişen birisin.
es: —Harry, no hables así. Mientras viva, la personalidad de Dorian Gray me dominará. No puedes sentir lo que yo siento. Tú cambias con demasiada frecuencia.
vi_translation: "Harry, don't talk like that. As long as I live, the personality of Dorian Gray will dominate me. You cannot feel what I feel. You change too often."
tr_translation: "Harry, don't talk like that. As long as I exist, the influence of Dorian Gray will dominate me. You can't feel what I feel! You are someone who is constantly changing."
es_translation: —Harry, don't talk like that. As long as I live, the personality of Dorian Gray will dominate me. You can't feel what I feel. You change too often.

en: “Ah, my dear Basil, that is exactly why I can feel it. Those who are faithful know only the trivial side of love: it is the faithless who know love’s tragedies.” And Lord Henry struck a light on a dainty silver case and began to smoke a cigarette with a self-conscious and satisfied air, as if he had summed up the world in a phrase. There was a rustle of chirruping sparrows in the green lacquer leaves of the ivy, and the blue cloud-shadows chased themselves across the grass like swallows. How pleasant it was in the garden! And how delightful other people’s emotions were!—much more delightful than their ideas, it seemed to him. One’s own soul, and the passions of one’s friends—those were the fascinating things in life. He pictured to himself with silent amusement the tedious luncheon that he had missed by staying so long with Basil Hallward. Had he gone to his aunt’s, he would have been sure to have met Lord Goodbody there, and the whole conversation would have been about the feeding of the poor and the necessity for model lodging-houses. Each class would have preached the importance of those virtues, for whose exercise there was no necessity in their own lives. The rich would have spoken on the value of thrift, and the idle grown eloquent over the dignity of labour. It was charming to have escaped all that! As he thought of his aunt, an idea seemed to strike him. He turned to Hallward and said, “My dear fellow, I have just remembered.”
vi: “Ôi, Basil yêu quý của tôi, đó đúng là lý do tôi cảm nhận được nó đấy. Những ai chung tình chỉ biết đến khía cạnh tầm thường của tình yêu; chính những kẻ bạc tình mới biết được các bi kịch tình yêu.” Và huân tước Henry bật lửa trên một cái hộp bạc xinh xắn, rồi bắt đầu hút thuốc với vẻ e dè và thỏa mãn, như thể y vừa mới tóm lược cả thế giới lại bằng một câu văn. Đâu đây có tiếng sột soạt của lũ chim sẻ ríu rít giữa những chiếc lá thường xuân xanh bóng, còn những bóng mây lam chuồn ngang thảm cỏ như những con nhạn. Trong vườn mới dễ chịu làm sao! Và cảm xúc của những người khác mới thú vị làm sao! — dễ chịu hơn nhiều so với các ý tưởng của họ,— y thấy dường như là thế. Linh hồn một con người, và các đam mê của bạn bè người ấy — đó là những thứ quyến rũ trên đời. Y tưởng tượng với sự thích thú thầm lặng về bữa tiệc trưa chán ngắt y đã bỏ lỡ do nán lại quá lâu với Basil Hallward. Giả dụ y mà đến chỗ bà dì thì chắc là y đã gặp huân tước Goodbody ở đó, và cả cuộc chuyện trò hẳn là sẽ về việc nuôi người nghèo, và sự cần thiết của các nhà trọ kiểu mẫu. Mỗi tầng lớp sẽ ra sức giảng giải về sự quan trọng của các đức tính mà việc rèn luyện chúng chẳng cần thiết trong đời chính họ. Người giàu sẽ nói về giá trị của tính tiết kiệm, còn người thất nghiệp thì lại quay ra hùng biện về chân giá trị của lao động. Thật may là đã thoát được mọi chuyện này! Lúc y nghĩ về dì mình, một ý tưởng dường như bất chợt nảy ra. Y quay qua Hallward và nói, “Bạn quý ơi, tôi vừa mới nhớ ra.”
tr: “Ah, sevgili Basil, işte tam bu nedenle hissedebilirim ya bunları. Aşkta sadık olanlar aşkın yalnızca uçarı yönlerini bilirler; aşkın trajedilerini bilenlerse vefasızdırlar.” Lord Henry zarif, gümüş bir çakmakla yaktığı sigarasını kendini bilen ve kendini beğenmiş bir edayla tüttürmeye başladı; sanki bir tek tümceyle dünyayı özetleyivermiş sanırdınız. Duvar sarmaşığının cilalı yapraklarının arasında cıvıldaşan serçelerin hışırtısı vardı ve mavi renkli bulut gölgeleri çimenlerin üzerinden kırlangıçlar gibi uçup geçiyorlardı. Ne güzeldi şu bahçede olmak! Başkalarının duyguları da nasıl zevkliydi! İnsanların duygularını düşüncelerinden çok daha zevkli buluyordu Lord Henry. Kişinin kendi ruhu ve dostlarının duyguları: Hayatta insanı saran konular bunlardı işte. Lord Henry, Basil Hallward’ın yanında böyle uzun oyalanmak sayesinde atlatmış olduğu can sıkıcı yemek davetini, gizlice gülümseyerek düşündü. Halasının davetine gitmiş olsaydı yüzde yüz Lord Goodbody ile karşılaşacak, tüm konuşma, yoksulların beslenmesi ve örnek konut yapımının gerekliliği üstüne kurulacaktı. Her sınıf, kendi yaşamları açısından bir zorunluluk olmayan erdemlerin önemi üstüne atıp tutacaktı. Zenginler tutumluluğun değerinden dem vuracak, tembeller emeğin yüceliğini övüp göklere çıkaracaklardı. Çok tatlı olmuştu bunlardan kaçabilmek! Lord Henry halasını düşündüğü sırada aklına bir şey gelmiş gibi oldu. Ressama dönerek, “Şu anda aklıma geldi,” dedi.
es: —¡Ah, mi querido Basil, precisamente por eso soy capaz de sentirlo! Los que son fieles sólo conocen el lado trivial del amor: es el infiel quien sabe de sus tragedias. Lord Henry frotó una cerilla sobre un delicado estuche de plata y empezó a fumar un cigarrillo con un aire tan pagado de sí mismo y tan satisfecho como si hubiera resumido el mundo en una frase. Los gorriones alborotaban entre las hojas lacadas de la enredadera y las sombras azules de las nubes se perseguían sobre el césped como golondrinas. ¡Qué agradable era estar en el jardín! ¡Y cuán deliciosas las emociones de otras personas! Mucho más que sus ideas, en opinión de lord Henry. Nuestra alma y las pasiones de nuestros amigos: ésas son las cosas fascinantes de la vida. Le divirtió recordar en silencio el tedioso almuerzo que se había perdido al quedarse tanto tiempo con Basil Hallward. Si hubiera ido a casa de su tía, se habría encontrado sin duda con lord Goodboy, y sólo habrían hablado de alimentar a los pobres y de la necesidad de construir alojamientos modelo. Todos los comensales habrían destacado la importancia de las virtudes que su situación en la vida les dispensaba de ejercitar. Los ricos hablarían del valor del ahorro, y los ociosos se extenderían elocuentemente sobre la dignidad del trabajo. ¡Era delicioso haber escapado a todo aquello! Mientras pensaba en su tía, algo pareció sorprenderlo. Volviéndose hacia Hallward, dijo:
vi_translation: “Oh, my dear Basil, that is exactly why I feel it. Those who are faithful know only the trivial side of love; it is the faithless who know the tragedies of love.” And Lord Henry lit a cigarette from a dainty silver box, then began to smoke with a cautious and satisfied air, as if he had just summarized the entire world in a single sentence. Somewhere, there was the rustling sound of sparrows chirping among the glossy green ivy leaves, while blue shadows flitted across the lawn like swallows. How pleasant it was in the garden! And how interesting other people's emotions were! — much more pleasant than their ideas, — it seemed to him. The soul of a man, and the passions of his friends — those were the fascinating things in life. He silently relished the thought of the dull luncheon he had missed by lingering too long with Basil Hallward. If he had gone to his aunt's, he would have met Lord Goodbody there, and the whole conversation would have been about feeding the poor and the necessity of model lodging houses. Each class would expound on the importance of virtues that they themselves did not need to practice in their own lives. The rich would talk about the value of thrift, while the unemployed would wax eloquent about the true worth of labor. How fortunate he was to have escaped all that! As he thought of his aunt, an idea seemed to suddenly occur to him. He turned to Hallward and said, “My dear fellow, I have just remembered.”
tr_translation: “Ah, dear Basil, that is precisely why I can feel these things. Those who are faithful in love only know the trivial aspects of love; those who know its tragedies are unfaithful.” Lord Henry began to puff on his cigarette, which he had lit with an elegant silver lighter, with a self-aware and self-satisfied air; you would think he had summarized the world in a single sentence. There was the rustling of sparrows chirping among the polished leaves of the ivy, and blue cloud shadows were flying over the grass like swallows. How beautiful it was to be in this garden! How delightful were the feelings of others! Lord Henry found people's feelings much more delightful than their thoughts. One's own soul and the feelings of friends: these were the matters that enveloped a person in life. Lord Henry thought with a secret smile about the tedious dinner invitation he had avoided by lingering so long beside Basil Hallward. If he had gone to his aunt's invitation, he would have undoubtedly encountered Lord Goodbody, and the entire conversation would have been about the necessity of feeding the poor and building model housing. Every class would be prattling about the importance of virtues that were not a necessity for their own lives. The rich would extol the value of thrift, and the lazy would praise the nobility of labor to the skies. It had been so sweet to escape from these! As Lord Henry thought of his aunt, something seemed to occur to him. Turning to the painter, he said, “It just came to my mind.”
es_translation: —Ah, my dear Basil, precisely because of that I am able to feel it! Those who are faithful only know the trivial side of love: it is the unfaithful who know its tragedies. Lord Henry struck a match on a delicate silver case and began to smoke a cigarette with an air so self-satisfied and so pleased with himself as if he had summarized the world in a phrase. The sparrows were chattering among the lacquered leaves of the vine, and the blue shadows of the clouds chased each other over the lawn like swallows. How pleasant it was to be in the garden! And how delightful the emotions of other people! Much more so than their ideas, in lord Henry's opinion. Our soul and the passions of our friends: those are the fascinating things in life. He amused himself by silently recalling the tedious lunch he had missed by staying so long with Basil Hallward. If he had gone to his aunt's house, he would undoubtedly have encountered lord Goodboy, and they would have only talked about feeding the poor and the need to build model housing. All the diners would have emphasized the importance of the virtues that their situation in life exempted them from practicing. The rich would speak of the value of thrift, and the idle would eloquently expound on the dignity of work. It was delightful to have escaped all that! While thinking about his aunt, something seemed to surprise him. Turning to Hallward, he said:

en: “Remembered what, Harry?”
vi: “Nhớ ra gì vậy, Harry?”
tr: “Nedir aklına gelen Harry?
es: —Acabo de acordarme. —¿Acordarte de qué, Harry?
vi_translation: “Remember what, Harry?”
tr_translation: “What comes to your mind, Harry?”
es_translation: —I just remembered. —Remember what, Harry?

en: “Where I heard the name of Dorian Gray.”
vi: “Nơi tôi nghe được cái tên của Dorian Gray.” “Là ở đâu vậy?” Hallward hỏi, hơi cau mày.
tr: “Dorian Gray’in adını nerede duymuş olduğum.
es: —De dónde he oído el nombre de Dorian Gray.
vi_translation: “The place where I heard the name of Dorian Gray.”
tr_translation: "Where I might have heard the name Dorian Gray.""
es_translation: —Where have I heard the name Dorian Gray.

en: “Where was it?” asked Hallward, with a slight frown.
vi: “Nơi tôi nghe được cái tên của Dorian Gray.” “Là ở đâu vậy?” Hallward hỏi, hơi cau mày.
tr: “Dorian Gray’in adını nerede duymuş olduğum. Hallward yüzünü belli belirsiz asarak, “Nerede?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Dónde? —preguntó Hallward, frunciendo levemente el ceño.
vi_translation: “Where was that?” Hallward asked, frowning slightly.
tr_translation: Hallward, faintly wrinkling his face, asked, "Where?"
es_translation: "Where?" asked Hallward, frowning slightly.

en: “Don’t look so angry, Basil. It was at my aunt, Lady Agatha’s. She told me she had discovered a wonderful young man who was going to help her in the East End, and that his name was Dorian Gray. I am bound to state that she never told me he was good-looking. Women have no appreciation of good looks; at least, good women have not. She said that he was very earnest and had a beautiful nature. I at once pictured to myself a creature with spectacles and lank hair, horribly freckled, and tramping about on huge feet. I wish I had known it was your friend.”
vi: “Đừng ra vẻ giận dữ thế, Basil. Đó là ở chỗ dì tôi, chỗ bà Agatha. Bà ấy bảo tôi là bà ấy đã phát hiện ra một thanh niên tuyệt vời, người sẽ đi giúp bà ấy ở vùng East End, và rằng tên anh ta là Dorian Gray. Tôi buộc phải nói rõ là bà ấy chưa bao giờ kể tôi nghe rằng cậu ấy rất đẹp trai. Đàn bà không biết đánh giá vẻ đẹp ngoại hình; chí ít thì những người đàn bà tử tế không thế. Bà nói rằng cậu ấy rất đứng đắn và tốt tính. Tôi lập tức hình dung ra một tạo vật với mục kỉnh và mái tóc rũ thẳng, tàn nhang phát gớm, và đi lang thang trên đôi chân khổng lồ. Phải chi tôi biết đấy là bạn anh.”
tr: “Basil, kızma öyle. Halam Leydi Agatha’dan duymuştum. Halam bana harika bir genç adam keşfettiğini, bu gencin ona East End’de yardım edeceğini, adının da Dorian Gray olduğunu söylemişti. Şunu da belirtmek zorundayım ki halam bu çocuğun yakışıklı olduğuna hiç değinmedi. Kadınlar güzellikten anlamaz zaten, daha doğrusu namuslu kadınlar anlamaz. Halam bana bu gencin çok ciddi, dürüst, iyi huylu olduğunu söyledi. Benim de gözümün önünde o saat yağlı saçlı, gözlüklü, feci çilli bir tip belirdi, kocaman ayaklarıyla sağda solda dolanıp duran biri. Bu gencin senin anlattığın kişi olduğunu bilseydim keşke.
es: —No es necesario que te enfades. Fue en casa de mi tía, lady Agatha. Me dijo que había descubierto a un joven maravilloso que iba a ayudarla en el East End y que se llamaba Dorian Gray. Tengo que confesar que nunca me contó que fuese bien parecido. Las mujeres no aprecian la belleza; al menos, las mujeres honestas. Me dijo que era muy serio y con muy buena disposición. Al instante me imaginé una criatura con gafas y de pelo lacio, horriblemente cubierto de pecas y con enormes pies planos. Ojalá hubiera sabido que se trataba de tu amigo.
vi_translation: “Don't look so angry, Basil. It was at my aunt's place, Lady Agatha's. She told me that she had discovered a wonderful young man who was going to help her in the East End, and that his name was Dorian Gray. I must say, she never mentioned to me that he was very handsome. Women don't appreciate physical beauty; at least, decent women don't. She said that he was very earnest and had a good nature. I immediately pictured a creature with spectacles and lank hair, freckles galore, and walking around on huge feet. If only I had known he was your friend.”
tr_translation: "Basil, don't get so angry. I had heard it from my aunt Lady Agatha. My aunt told me that she had discovered a wonderful young man, that this young man would help her in the East End, and that his name was Dorian Gray. I must also point out that my aunt never mentioned that this boy was handsome. Women don't understand beauty anyway, or rather, respectable women don't. My aunt told me that this young man was very serious, honest, and well-mannered. In my mind, I immediately pictured someone with greasy hair, glasses, and terrible freckles, wandering around with huge feet. I wish I had known that this young man was the person you were talking about."
es_translation: —There is no need for you to get angry. It was at my aunt's house, Lady Agatha. She told me that she had discovered a wonderful young man who was going to help her in the East End and that his name was Dorian Gray. I have to confess that she never told me he was good-looking. Women do not appreciate beauty; at least, honest women don't. She told me he was very serious and very well-disposed. Immediately, I imagined a creature with glasses and straight hair, horribly covered in freckles and with enormous flat feet. I wish I had known he was your friend.

en: “I am very glad you didn’t, Harry.”
vi: “Tôi rất mừng là anh không biết, Harry à.”
tr: “Bilmediğine çok sevindim, Harry.
es: —Me alegro mucho de que no fuese así, Harry.
vi_translation: “I am very glad you don't know, Harry.”
tr_translation: "I'm very glad you didn't know, Harry."
es_translation: —I'm very glad it wasn't like that, Harry.

en: “Why?”
vi: “Tại sao?”
tr: “Neden?
es: —¿Por qué?
vi_translation: "Why?"
tr_translation: “Why?”
es_translation: —Why?

en: “I don’t want you to meet him.”
vi: “Tôi chẳng muốn anh gặp cậu ấy.”
tr: “Senin onu tanımanı istemiyorum da ondan.
es: —No quiero que lo conozcas.
vi_translation: “I don't want you to meet him.”
tr_translation: “That's because I don't want you to know him.”
es_translation: —I don't want you to meet him.

en: “You don’t want me to meet him?”
vi: “Anh không muốn tôi gặp cậu ấy sao?”
tr: “Benim onu tanımamı istemiyorsun ha?
es: —¿No quieres que lo conozca?
vi_translation: “Don't you want me to meet him?”
tr_translation: "You don't want me to know him, huh?""
es_translation: —Don't you want me to meet him?

en: “No.”
vi: “Không.”
tr: “İstemiyorum.
es: —No.
vi_translation: "No."
tr_translation: "I don't want to.""
es_translation: —No.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir,” said the butler, coming into the garden.
vi: “Mít-tơ Dorian Gray ở trong xưởng vẽ, thưa ông,” quản gia vừa nói vừa đi vào vườn.
tr: “mr Dorian Gray stüdyodalar, efendim.” Erkek uşak bahçede belirmişti.
es: —El señor Dorian Gray está en el estudio —anunció el mayordomo, entrando en el jardín.
vi_translation: "Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir," the butler said as he walked into the garden.
tr_translation: "Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio, sir." The male servant had appeared in the garden.
es_translation: —Mr. Dorian Gray is in the studio —announced the butler, entering the garden.

en: “You must introduce me now,” cried Lord Henry, laughing.
vi: “Anh phải giới thiệu tôi ngay,” huân tước Henry kêu lớn và cười vang.
tr: Lord Henry gülerek, “Şimdi artık beni tanıştırmak zorundasın!” dedi.
es: —Ahora tienes que presentármelo —exclamó lord Henry, riendo.
vi_translation: “You must introduce me at once,” Lord Henry exclaimed and laughed heartily.
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed, "Now you have to introduce me!" he said.
es_translation: —Now you have to introduce him to me —exclaimed Lord Henry, laughing.

en: The painter turned to his servant, who stood blinking in the sunlight. “Ask Mr. Gray to wait, Parker: I shall be in in a few moments.” The man bowed and went up the walk.
vi: Họa sỹ quay qua anh người hầu đang đứng nhấp nháy trong nắng. “Bảo mít-tơ Gray chờ nhé, Parker: tôi sẽ tới sau vài giây.” Người đó cúi đầu chào và rảo chân bước đi.
tr: Ressam, güneşte durmuş gözlerini kırpıştıran uşağına baktı. “Parker, lütfen mr Gray’e söyle, beklesin. Birkaç dakika içinde geliyorum. Adam eğildi, sonra eve doğru yürüdü.
es: El pintor se volvió hacia su criado, a quien la luz del sol obligaba a parpadear. —Dígale al señor Gray que espere, Parker. Me reuniré con él dentro de un momento. El mayordomo hizo una inclinación y se retiró.
vi_translation: The painter turned to the servant who was standing and blinking in the sunlight. "Tell Mr. Gray to wait, Parker: I will be there in a few seconds." The servant bowed and hurried away.
tr_translation: The painter looked at his servant who was standing in the sun, blinking his eyes. “Parker, please tell Mr. Gray to wait. I am coming in a few minutes.” Adam bent down, then walked towards the house.
es_translation: The painter turned to his servant, who was forced to blink by the sunlight. —Tell Mr. Gray to wait, Parker. I will meet with him in a moment. The butler bowed and withdrew.

en: Then he looked at Lord Henry. “Dorian Gray is my dearest friend,” he said. “He has a simple and a beautiful nature. Your aunt was quite right in what she said of him. Don’t spoil him. Don’t try to influence him. Your influence would be bad. The world is wide, and has many marvellous people in it. Don’t take away from me the one person who gives to my art whatever charm it possesses: my life as an artist depends on him. Mind, Harry, I trust you.” He spoke very slowly, and the words seemed wrung out of him almost against his will.
vi: Sau đó y nhìn huân tước Henry. “Dorian Gray là bạn thân nhất của tôi,” y nói. “Tính cậu ấy đơn giản và tử tế. Dì anh đã nói rất đúng về cậu ấy. Đừng làm hỏng cậu ấy. Đừng cố tạo ảnh hưởng lên cậu ấy. Sự ảnh hưởng của anh sẽ rất tồi tệ. Thế giới rộng lớn, có rất nhiều người phi thường trong nó. Đừng lấy đi khỏi tôi cái người đã mang lại cho nghệ thuật của tôi mọi sức mê hoặc mà nó đang có; cuộc đời cá nhân tôi trên tư cách nghệ sỹ phụ thuộc hoàn toàn vào cậu ấy. Lưu ý nhé, Harry, tôi tin anh.” Y nói rất chậm, và các lời dường như bị moi ra ngoài y gần như trái với lòng y.
tr: O zaman ressam, Lord Henry’ye baktı. “Dorian Gray benim en kıymetli dostumdur,” dedi. “Sade, güzel bir kişiliği var. Halan onu çok doğru tanımlamış. Bozma onun saflığını. Onu etkilemeye kalkışma. Etkin kötü olacaktır. Dünya geniş. İçinde bir sürü harika insan var. Benim sanatıma kendince bir tutam çekicilik katan tek kişiyi elimden alma, Harry. Sanatçı olarak yaşamım Dorian Gray’e bağlı. Unutma, sana güveniyorum, Harry.” Ağır ağır konuşuyordu; sözcükleri, iradesi dışında bir güç ondan çekip koparır gibiydi.
es: Hallward se volvió después hacia lord Henry. —Dorian Gray es mi amigo más querido —dijo—. Es una persona sencilla y bondadosa. Tu tía estaba en lo cierto al describirlo. No lo eches a perder. No trates de influir en él. Tu influencia sería mala. El mundo es muy grande y encierra mucha gente maravillosa. No me arrebates la única persona que da a mi arte todo el encanto que posee: mi vida de artista depende de él. Tenlo en cuenta, Harry, confío en ti —hablaba muy despacio, y las palabras parecían salirle de la boca casi contra su voluntad.
vi_translation: Then he looked at Lord Henry. “Dorian Gray is my closest friend,” he said. “His nature is simple and kind. Your aunt was absolutely right about him. Do not spoil him. Do not try to influence him. Your influence would be disastrous. The world is vast, and it contains many extraordinary people. Do not take away from me the person who has given my art all the charm it possesses; my personal life as an artist depends entirely on him. Mark my words, Harry, I trust you.” He spoke very slowly, and the words seemed to be dragged out of him almost against his will.
tr_translation: Then the painter looked at Lord Henry. "Dorian Gray is my most precious friend," he said. "He has a simple, beautiful personality. Your aunt has described him very accurately. Do not spoil his purity. Do not try to influence him. Your influence will be bad. The world is vast. There are many wonderful people in it. Do not take away the only person who adds a touch of charm to my art, Harry. My life as an artist depends on Dorian Gray. Remember, I trust you, Harry." He spoke slowly; it was as if a force beyond his will was pulling the words out of him.
es_translation: Hallward then turned to Lord Henry. —Dorian Gray is my dearest friend —he said—. He is a simple and kind person. Your aunt was right in describing him. Do not spoil him. Do not try to influence him. Your influence would be bad. The world is very large and contains many wonderful people. Do not take away from me the only person who gives my art all the charm it possesses: my life as an artist depends on him. Keep that in mind, Harry, I trust you —he spoke very slowly, and the words seemed to come out of his mouth almost against his will.

en: “What nonsense you talk!” said Lord Henry, smiling, and taking Hallward by the arm, he almost led him into the house.
vi: “Anh nói linh tinh gì thế!” Huân tước Henry ngắt lời, mỉm cười, và, nắm lấy cánh tay Hallward, gần như dẫn y vào nhà.
tr: Lord Henry, “Neler saçmalıyorsun!” diye gülümsedi ve Basil Hallward’ı kolundan tutarak sürüklercesine eve götürdü.
es: —¡Qué tonterías dices! —respondió lord Henry, con una sonrisa. Luego, tomando a Hallward del brazo, casi lo condujo hacia la casa.
vi_translation: "What nonsense are you talking about!" Lord Henry interrupted, smiling, and, taking Hallward's arm, almost led him into the house.
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled and said, "What nonsense are you talking about!" and, grabbing Basil Hallward by the arm, dragged him into the house.
es_translation: —What nonsense you speak! —responded Lord Henry, with a smile. Then, taking Hallward by the arm, he almost led him towards the house.

en: CHAPTER II.
vi: Chương 2
tr: İkinci bölüm
es: Capítulo 2
vi_translation: Chapter 2
tr_translation: Second chapter
es_translation: Chapter 2

en: As they entered they saw Dorian Gray. He was seated at the piano, with his back to them, turning over the pages of a volume of Schumann’s “Forest Scenes.” “You must lend me these, Basil,” he cried. “I want to learn them. They are perfectly charming.”
vi: Lúc họ vào thì họ thấy Dorian Gray. Cậu ngồi bên dương cầm, lưng quay lại họ, lật trang tập Cảnh Rừng của Schumann. “Anh phải cho tôi mượn những cái này, Basil,” cậu la lên. “Tôi muốn học chúng. Chúng tuyệt đẹp.”
tr: İçeri girerken Dorian Gray’i gördüler. Genç adam arkası dönük olarak piyano başında oturmuş, Schumann’ın Orman Sahneleri’nin sayfalarını karıştırmaktaydı. “Basil, bunları ödünç versene bana!” diye seslendi. “Öğrenmek istiyorum. Çok nefis şeyler.
es: Al entrar, vieron a Dorian Gray. Estaba sentado al piano, de espaldas a ellos, pasando las páginas de Las escenas del bosque, de Schumann. —Tienes que prestármelo, Basil —exclamó—. Quiero aprendérmelas. Son encantadoras.
vi_translation: When they entered, they saw Dorian Gray. He was sitting by the piano, his back turned to them, flipping through the pages of Schumann's Forest Scenes. "You must lend these to me, Basil," he exclaimed. "I want to learn them. They are beautiful."
tr_translation: They saw Dorian Gray as they entered. The young man was sitting at the piano with his back turned, leafing through the pages of Schumann's Forest Scenes. “Basil, lend these to me!” he called out. “I want to learn. They are very exquisite things.”
es_translation: Upon entering, they saw Dorian Gray. He was seated at the piano, with his back to them, turning the pages of Schumann's Forest Scenes. —You have to lend it to me, Basil —he exclaimed—. I want to learn them by heart. They are delightful.

en: “That entirely depends on how you sit to-day, Dorian.”
vi: “Chuyện ấy phụ thuộc hoàn toàn vào việc hôm nay cậu ngồi làm mẫu ra sao đấy, Dorian.
tr: “Her şey senin bana bugün yapacağın modelliğe bağlı, Dorian.
es: —Eso depende de cómo poses hoy, Dorian.
vi_translation: "That entirely depends on how well you sit for the modeling today, Dorian."
tr_translation: "Everything depends on the modeling you will do for me today, Dorian."
es_translation: —That depends on how you pose today, Dorian.

en: “Oh, I am tired of sitting, and I don’t want a life-sized portrait of myself,” answered the lad, swinging round on the music-stool in a wilful, petulant manner. When he caught sight of Lord Henry, a faint blush coloured his cheeks for a moment, and he started up. “I beg your pardon, Basil, but I didn’t know you had any one with you.”
vi: “Ôi, tôi chán ngồi rồi, và tôi không muốn một bức chân dung to như thật về mình,” chàng trai trả lời, xoay vòng trên ghế dương cầm, tỏ vẻ bướng bỉnh, dằn dỗi. Lúc cậu nhìn thấy huân tước Henry, một chút phớt hồng ửng lên trên má cậu trong giây lát, và cậu nhỏm lên. “Tôi xin lỗi, Basil, song tôi không biết anh có khách đi cùng.”
tr: Genç adam, “Of, modellik yapmaktan bıktım, boydan portre falan da istemiyorum,” diyerek huysuz, dediğim dedik bir ifadeyle, piyano taburesinin üzerinde gelenlere döndü. Lord Henry’yi görünce yanaklarına bir an hafif bir renk yayılarak ayağa kalktı. “Özür dilerim, Basil, yanında biri olduğunu bilmiyordum.
es: —Estoy cansado de posar, y no quiero un retrato de cuerpo entero —respondió el muchacho, volviéndose sobre el taburete del piano con un gesto caprichoso y malhumorado. Al ver a lord Henry, se le colorearon las mejillas por un momento y procedió a levantarse—. Perdóname, Basil, pero no sabía que estuvieras acompañado.
vi_translation: “Oh, I'm tired of sitting, and I don't want a life-sized portrait of myself,” the young man replied, spinning on the piano stool, showing a stubborn, sulky demeanor. When he saw Lord Henry, a slight blush appeared on his cheeks for a moment, and he stood up. “I'm sorry, Basil, but I didn't know you had a guest with you.”
tr_translation: The young man, "Ugh, I'm tired of modeling, I don't want any full-length portraits either," he said grumpily, with a stubborn expression, turning to those who had come while sitting on the piano stool. When he saw Lord Henry, a slight color spread across his cheeks for a moment as he stood up. "I'm sorry, Basil, I didn't know you had someone with you."
es_translation: —I am tired of posing, and I don't want a full-body portrait —replied the young man, turning on the piano stool with a capricious and sullen gesture. Upon seeing Lord Henry, his cheeks colored for a moment and he proceeded to stand up—. Forgive me, Basil, but I didn't know you were accompanied.

en: “This is Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old Oxford friend of mine. I have just been telling him what a capital sitter you were, and now you have spoiled everything.”
vi: “Đây là huân tước Henry Wotton, Dorian à, một anh bạn cũ của tôi ở Oxford. Tôi vừa mới kể cho anh ấy nghe cậu là một người mẫu tuyệt hảo thế nào, vậy mà giờ cậu làm hỏng hết cả.
tr: “Dorian, bu Lord Henry Wotton, Oxford’dan eski bir arkadaşım. Şimdi ona senin ne eşsiz bir model olduğunu anlatıyordum, her şeyi berbat ettin.
es: —Te presento a lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, un viejo amigo mío de Oxford. Le estaba diciendo que eres un modelo muy disciplinado, y acabas de echarlo todo a perder.
vi_translation: "This is Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old friend of mine from Oxford. I was just telling him what a perfect model you are, and now you've ruined everything."
tr_translation: “Dorian, this is Lord Henry Wotton, an old friend of mine from Oxford. I was just telling him what an exceptional model you are, and you ruined everything.”
es_translation: —I present to you Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old friend of mine from Oxford. I was telling him that you are a very disciplined model, and you have just ruined everything.

en: “You have not spoiled my pleasure in meeting you, Mr. Gray,” said Lord Henry, stepping forward and extending his hand. “My aunt has often spoken to me about you. You are one of her favourites, and, I am afraid, one of her victims also.”
vi: “Cậu không làm hỏng niềm vui của tôi vì được gặp cậu đâu, mít-tơ Gray,” huân tước Henry nói, bước tới và chìa tay ra. “Dì tôi thường kể tôi nghe về cậu. Cậu là một trong những người được bà ấy mến mộ nhất, và, tôi e rằng, cũng là một trong các nạn nhân của bà ấy.”
tr: “Sizinle tanışmaktan duyduğum sevinci hiç de berbat etmediniz, mr Gray,” diyen Lord Henry ilerleyip elini uzattı. “Halam bana söz etti sizden. Onun gözdelerindensiniz. Korkarım kurbanlarından birisiniz.
es: —Excepto el placer de conocerlo a usted, señor Gray —dijo lord Henry, dando un paso al frente y extendiendo la mano—. Mi tía me ha hablado a menudo de usted. Es uno de sus preferidos y, mucho me temo, también una de sus víctimas.
vi_translation: “You haven't spoiled my pleasure in meeting you, Mr. Gray,” Lord Henry said, stepping forward and extending his hand. “My aunt often talks to me about you. You are one of her most admired people, and, I fear, also one of her victims.”
tr_translation: “You did not spoil the pleasure I felt in meeting you at all, Mr. Gray,” said Lord Henry, stepping forward and extending his hand. “My aunt spoke to me about you. You are one of her favorites. I fear you are one of her victims.”
es_translation: —Except for the pleasure of meeting you, Mr. Gray —said Lord Henry, stepping forward and extending his hand—. My aunt has often spoken of you. You are one of her favorites and, I much fear, also one of her victims.

en: “I am in Lady Agatha’s black books at present,” answered Dorian with a funny look of penitence. “I promised to go to a club in Whitechapel with her last Tuesday, and I really forgot all about it. We were to have played a duet together—three duets, I believe. I don’t know what she will say to me. I am far too frightened to call.”
vi: “Tôi đang trong sổ đen của bà Agatha đấy,” Dorian trả lời, với vẻ mặt hối lỗi tức cười. “Tôi hứa đi đến một câu lạc bộ ở Whitechapel với bà ấy hôm thứ Ba vừa rồi, và tôi thực sự quên hẳn chuyện ấy. Chúng tôi nhẽ ra phải chơi một bản song tấu cùng nhau — ba khúc song tấu, tôi nghĩ vậy. Tôi không biết bà ấy sẽ nói gì với tôi. Tôi sợ quá nên không dám ghé qua bà ấy.”
tr: Dorian gülünç bir pişmanlık ifadesiyle, “Şu sırada Leydi Agatha’nın kara listesindeyim,” dedi. “Geçen salı onunla birlikte Whitechapel’da bir kulübe gitmeye söz verdim, ama unuttum gitti. Birlikte bir düet çalacaktık, üç düet, yanılmıyorsam. Bana neler söyleyecek kimbilir! Korkumdan gidemiyorum.
es: —En el momento actual estoy en la lista negra de lady Agatha —respondió Dorian con una divertida expresión de remordimiento—. Prometí ir con ella el martes a un club de Whitechapel y lo olvidé por completo. íbamos a tocar juntos un dúo..., más bien tres, según creo. No sé qué dirá. Me da miedo ir a visitarla.
vi_translation: “I am in Mrs. Agatha's black book,” Dorian replied, with a comically apologetic look. “I promised to go to a club in Whitechapel with her last Tuesday, and I completely forgot about it. We were supposed to play a duet together — three duets, I think. I don't know what she will say to me. I'm so scared that I don't dare to visit her.”
tr_translation: Dorian said with a ridiculous expression of regret, "At the moment, I am on Lady Agatha's blacklist." "I promised to go with her to a club in Whitechapel last Tuesday, but I completely forgot. We were supposed to play a duet together, three duets, if I'm not mistaken. Who knows what she will say to me! I am too afraid to go."
es_translation: —At the moment, I am on Lady Agatha's blacklist —replied Dorian with an amused expression of remorse—. I promised to go with her on Tuesday to a club in Whitechapel and completely forgot about it. We were going to play a duet together..., or rather three, I believe. I don't know what she will say. I'm afraid to visit her.

en: “Oh, I will make your peace with my aunt. She is quite devoted to you. And I don’t think it really matters about your not being there. The audience probably thought it was a duet. When Aunt Agatha sits down to the piano, she makes quite enough noise for two people.”
vi: “Ồ, tôi sẽ dàn hòa cho anh với dì tôi. Bà ấy rất hết lòng vì anh. Và tôi không nghĩ rằng lại có vấn đề gì thật sự nghiêm trọng với chuyện anh không đến đấy. Thính giả chắc có lẽ nghĩ đó là bản song tấu. Mỗi khi dì Agatha ngồi xuống dương cầm thì bà ấy thường gây ồn đủ cho hai người.”
tr: “Ben sizin aranızı bulurum. Halam sizi çok seviyor. Sizin kulübe gitmeyişinizin de bir şey değiştirmiş olacağını hiç sanmıyorum. Orada bulunanlar söylenenin düet olduğunu sanmışlardır zaten. Agatha Halam piyano başına geçti mi iki kişilik şamata yapar.
es: —Yo me encargo de reconciliarlo con ella. Siente verdadera devoción por usted. Y no creo que importara que no fuese. El público pensó probablemente que era un dúo. Cuando tía Agatha se sienta al piano hace ruido suficiente por dos personas.
vi_translation: “Oh, I will reconcile you with my aunt. She is very devoted to you. And I don't think there's really any serious issue with you not going there. The audience probably thought it was a duet. Whenever Aunt Agatha sits down at the piano, she usually makes enough noise for two people.”
tr_translation: “I will mediate between you. My aunt likes you very much. I don't think your not going to the club would have changed anything. Those present there probably thought it was a duet anyway. When my Aunt Agatha sits at the piano, she makes a racket for two.”
es_translation: —I will take care of reconciling him with her. She feels true devotion for you. And I don't think it would matter if you didn't go. The audience probably thought it was a duet. When Aunt Agatha sits at the piano, she makes enough noise for two people.

en: “That is very horrid to her, and not very nice to me,” answered Dorian, laughing.
vi: “Nói thế thì thật quá đáng với bà ấy, và cũng không hay ho gì cho lắm với tôi,” Dorian bật cười, đáp lại.
tr: Dorian gülerek, “Halanıza hakaret bu, bana da övgü sayılmaz,” dedi.
es: —Eso es una insidia contra ella y tampoco me deja a mí en muy buen lugar —respondió Dorian, riendo.
vi_translation: “Saying that would be too harsh on her, and not very nice for me either,” Dorian laughed, responding.
tr_translation: Dorian laughed, "That's an insult to your aunt, and not much of a compliment to me," he said.
es_translation: —That is an insinuation against her and it doesn't leave me in a very good position either —replied Dorian, laughing.

en: Lord Henry looked at him. Yes, he was certainly wonderfully handsome, with his finely curved scarlet lips, his frank blue eyes, his crisp gold hair. There was something in his face that made one trust him at once. All the candour of youth was there, as well as all youth’s passionate purity. One felt that he had kept himself unspotted from the world. No wonder Basil Hallward worshipped him.
vi: Huân tước Henry nhìn cậu. Đúng, cậu thật sự là cực kỳ đẹp trai, với đôi môi đỏ thắm uốn cong tuyệt mỹ, cặp mắt xanh lam ngay thật, mái tóc quăn vàng óng. Có gì đó trên mặt cậu khiến người ta tin cậu ngay lập tức. Mọi sự vô tư xuân thì đều ở đó, cũng như mọi sự thuần khiết thiết tha xuân thì. Người ta cảm thấy rằng cậu đã giữ được mình không vương chút bụi trần. Không ngạc nhiên là Basil Hallward tôn sùng cậu.
tr: Lord Henry ona baktı. Evet, gerçekten de olağanüstü yakışıklıydı bu çocuk, ince bükümlü kıpkırmızı dudakları, açık yürekli mavi gözleri, diri altın saçları vardı. Yüzünde, insanın hemen güvenini kazanan bir şey vardı. Gençliğin ateşli saflığının yanı sıra açık yürekliliği de bu çehredeydi. Sanki kendini dünyanın kirine bulaşmaktan koruyabilirmiş gibi geliyordu. Basil Hallward’ın ona tapmasına şaşmamak gerekti.
es: Lord Henry se lo quedó mirando. Sí; no había la menor duda de que era extraordinariamente bien parecido, con labios muy rojos debidamente arqueados, ojos azules llenos de franqueza, rubios cabellos rizados. Había algo en su rostro que inspiraba inmediata confianza. Estaba allí presente todo el candor de la juventud, así como toda su pureza apasionada. Se sentía que aquel adolescente no se había dejado manchar por el mundo. No era de extrañar que Basil Hallward sintiera veneración por él.
vi_translation: Lord Henry looked at him. Yes, he was truly extremely handsome, with perfectly curved red lips, honest blue eyes, and golden curly hair. There was something about his face that made people trust him immediately. All the carefree youthfulness was there, as well as all the earnest purity of youth. One felt that he had kept himself untainted by the world. No wonder Basil Hallward worshipped him.
tr_translation: Lord Henry looked at him. Yes, this boy was indeed extraordinarily handsome, with his delicately curved bright red lips, open-hearted blue eyes, and vibrant golden hair. There was something in his face that immediately won one's trust. Alongside the passionate innocence of youth, there was also an openness in this countenance. It seemed as if he could protect himself from the world's corruption. It was no wonder Basil Hallward adored him.
es_translation: Lord Henry stared at him. Yes; there was no doubt that he was extraordinarily handsome, with properly arched very red lips, blue eyes full of frankness, and curly blond hair. There was something in his face that inspired immediate trust. All the candor of youth was present there, as well as all its passionate purity. One felt that this young man had not allowed himself to be tainted by the world. It was no wonder that Basil Hallward felt veneration for him.

en: “You are too charming to go in for philanthropy, Mr. Gray—far too charming.” And Lord Henry flung himself down on the divan and opened his cigarette-case.
vi: “Cậu quá quyến rũ để đi làm việc từ thiện, mít-tơ Gray — quá đỗi quyến rũ.” Và huân tước Henry gieo mình xuống đi-văng, rồi mở hộp thuốc lá ra.
tr: “Siz kendinizi hayır işlerine adamayacak kadar çekicisiniz, mr Gray, öyle işlere göre çok fazla çekicisiniz.” Böyle diyen Lord Henry kendini divanın üstüne bırakıp sigara tablasını açtı.
es: —Sin duda es usted demasiado encantador para dedicarse a la filantropía, señor Gray —lord Henry se dejó caer en el diván y abrió la pitillera.
vi_translation: “You are too charming to do charity work, Mr. Gray — far too charming.” And Lord Henry threw himself onto the couch, then opened his cigarette case.
tr_translation: "You are too charming to devote yourself to charity, Mr. Gray, far too charming for such things." Saying this, Lord Henry threw himself onto the sofa and opened the cigarette case.
es_translation: —Without a doubt, you are too charming to devote yourself to philanthropy, Mr. Gray —Lord Henry dropped onto the divan and opened the cigarette case.

en: The painter had been busy mixing his colours and getting his brushes ready. He was looking worried, and when he heard Lord Henry’s last remark, he glanced at him, hesitated for a moment, and then said, “Harry, I want to finish this picture to-day. Would you think it awfully rude of me if I asked you to go away?”
vi: Họa sỹ đang bận trộn màu và chuẩn bị bút vẽ. Trông y có vẻ bồn chồn, và khi y nghe thấy lời nhận xét cuối cùng của huân tước Henry thì y liếc nhìn anh này, lưỡng lự chốc lát, rồi nói, “Harry, tôi muốn xong bức tranh này hôm nay. Chẳng hay anh có nghĩ là tôi quá khiếm nhã không nếu tôi xin anh đi ra?”
tr: Ressam bu arada boyalarını birbirine karıştırıp fırçalarını hazır etmekteydi. Yüzü kaygılıydı, hele bu son sözleri duyunca Henry’den yana şöyle bir baktı, bir an duraksadı, sonra, “Harry, bu resmi bugün bitirmek istiyorum,” dedi. “Senden gitmeni dilesem çok mu kabalık etmiş olurum?
es: El pintor había estado ocupado mezclando colores y preparando los pinceles. Parecía preocupado y, al oír la última observación de lord Henry, lo miró, vaciló un instante y luego dijo: —Harry, quiero terminar hoy este retrato. ¿Me juzgarás terriblemente descortés si te pido que te vayas?
vi_translation: The painter is busy mixing colors and preparing brushes. He looks anxious, and when he hears Lord Henry's last remark, he glances at him, hesitates for a moment, then says, "Harry, I want to finish this painting today. Do you think it would be too rude of me to ask you to leave?"
tr_translation: The painter, in the meantime, was mixing his paints and preparing his brushes. His face was anxious, especially after hearing these last words, he glanced towards Henry, hesitated for a moment, then said, "Harry, I want to finish this painting today." "Would it be too rude if I asked you to leave?"
es_translation: The painter had been busy mixing colors and preparing the brushes. He seemed worried and, upon hearing Lord Henry's last remark, looked at him, hesitated for a moment, and then said: —Harry, I want to finish this portrait today. Would you think me terribly rude if I asked you to leave?

en: Lord Henry smiled and looked at Dorian Gray. “Am I to go, Mr. Gray?” he asked.
vi: Huân tước Henry cười, nhìn Dorian Gray. “Tôi đi nhé, mít-tơ Gray?” y hỏi.
tr: Lord Henry gülümseyerek Dorian Gray’e baktı. “Gitmem gerekiyor mu, mr Gray?” diye sordu.
es: Lord Henry sonrió y miró a Dorian Gray. —¿Tengo que marcharme, señor Gray? —preguntó.
vi_translation: Lord Henry smiled, looking at Dorian Gray. "Shall I go, Mr. Gray?" he asked.
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled as he looked at Dorian Gray. "Do I have to go, Mr. Gray?" he asked.
es_translation: Lord Henry smiled and looked at Dorian Gray. —Do I have to leave, Mr. Gray? —he asked.

en: “Oh, please don’t, Lord Henry. I see that Basil is in one of his sulky moods, and I can’t bear him when he sulks. Besides, I want you to tell me why I should not go in for philanthropy.”
vi: “Ôi, xin đừng, huân tước Henry. Tôi thấy là Basil đang trong tâm trạng hờn dỗi thôi; và tôi không thể chịu được anh ấy khi anh ấy hờn dỗi. Vả lại, tôi muốn anh kể cho tôi nghe vì sao mà tôi lại không nên tiếp tục đi làm từ thiện.
tr: “Aa, kuzum gitmeyin, Lord Henry. Görüyorum, Basil’in suratsızlığı üstünde; somurttuğu zamanlarda da hiç çekemiyorum onu. Hem zaten bana anlatmanızı istiyorum, hayır işleriyle niçin ilgilenmeyecekmişim?
es: —No, por favor, lord Henry. Ya veo que Basil está hoy de mal humor, y no lo soporto cuando se enfurruña. Además, quiero que me explique por qué no debo dedicarme a la filantropía.
vi_translation: “Oh, please don't, Lord Henry. I see that Basil is just in a sulky mood; and I can't stand him when he's sulking. Besides, I want you to tell me why I shouldn't continue doing charity work.”
tr_translation: “Ah, my dear, don't go, Lord Henry. I can see it, Basil is in a bad mood; I can't stand him when he sulks. Besides, I want you to tell me why I shouldn't be interested in charitable works?”
es_translation: —No, please, Lord Henry. I can see that Basil is in a bad mood today, and I can't stand him when he sulks. Besides, I want you to explain to me why I shouldn't devote myself to philanthropy.

en: “I don’t know that I shall tell you that, Mr. Gray. It is so tedious a subject that one would have to talk seriously about it. But I certainly shall not run away, now that you have asked me to stop. You don’t really mind, Basil, do you? You have often told me that you liked your sitters to have some one to chat to.”
vi: “Tôi không biết là tôi lại phải nói với cậu về chuyện ấy, mít-tơ Gray. Đó là một chủ đề tẻ nhạt đến nỗi người ta đành phải nói chuyện nghiêm túc về nó. Nhưng tôi chắc không phải chạy ra ngoài rồi, vì cậu đã xin tôi ở lại. Anh thật sự không bận tâm chứ, Basil, phải không? Anh thường bảo tôi là anh thích những người mẫu của anh có ai đó chuyện trò.”
tr: “Size bunu anlatacağımı pek sanmıyorum, mr Gray. Hayır işleri öylesine sıkıcı bir konu ki insanı ciddileşmek zorunda bırakır. Öte yandan kaçıp gidecek de değilim, mademki kalmamı istediniz. Basil, gerçekten kızmıyorsun bana, değil mi? Modellerinin yanlarında çene çalacak birileri olmasından hoşlandıklarını söylemişsindir kaç kere.
es: —No estoy seguro de que deba decírselo, señor Gray. Se trata de un asunto tan tedioso que habría que hablar en serio de ello. Pero, desde luego, no saldré corriendo después de haberme dicho usted que me quede. ¿No te importa demasiado, verdad Basil? Me has dicho muchas veces que te gusta que tus hermanas tengan a alguien con quien charlar.
vi_translation: “I didn't know I had to talk to you about that matter, Mr. Gray. It is such a tedious topic that one has to speak seriously about it. But I surely don't have to run outside, since you have asked me to stay. You really don't mind, Basil, do you? You often tell me that you like your models to have someone to talk to.”
tr_translation: “I don't really think I will tell you this, Mr. Gray. Charity work is such a boring subject that it forces one to become serious. On the other hand, I won't run away, since you want me to stay. Basil, you aren't really angry with me, are you? You've said many times that your models like having someone to chat with beside them.”
es_translation: —I'm not sure I should tell you, Mr. Gray. It's such a tedious matter that it would require serious discussion. But, of course, I won't run away after you've told me to stay. You don't mind too much, do you, Basil? You've told me many times that you like your sisters to have someone to chat with.

en: Hallward bit his lip. “If Dorian wishes it, of course you must stay. Dorian’s whims are laws to everybody, except himself.”
vi: Hallward cắn môi. “Nếu Dorian muốn thế thì dĩ nhiên anh có thể ở lại. Các ý thích bất chợt của Dorian là luật cho mọi người, trừ chính cậu ta.”
tr: Hallward dudağını ısırdı, “Dorian istiyorsa elbet kalacaksın. Dorian’ın kaprisleri, kendi dışında herkes için yasa sayılır.
es: Hallward se mordió los labios. —Si Dorian lo desea, claro que te puedes quedar. Los caprichos de Dorian son leyes para todo el mundo, excepto para él.
vi_translation: Hallward bit his lip. "If Dorian wants it that way, then of course you can stay. Dorian's whims are law for everyone, except for himself."
tr_translation: Hallward bit his lip, "If Dorian wants it, of course you will stay. Dorian's whims are considered law for everyone except himself."
es_translation: Hallward bit his lips. —If Dorian wishes, of course you can stay. Dorian's whims are laws for everyone, except for himself.

en: Lord Henry took up his hat and gloves. “You are very pressing, Basil, but I am afraid I must go. I have promised to meet a man at the Orleans. Good-bye, Mr. Gray. Come and see me some afternoon in Curzon Street. I am nearly always at home at five o’clock. Write to me when you are coming. I should be sorry to miss you.”
vi: Huân tước Henry nhặt mũ và găng tay lên. “Anh nài nỉ nhiệt tình quá, Basil, nhưng tôi e là tôi phải đi. Tôi đã hứa gặp một người ở Orleans. Tạm biệt, mít-tơ Gray. Hãy đến gặp tôi vào buổi chiều nào đó trên phố Curzon. Tôi hầu như luôn ở nhà lúc năm giờ. Biên trước cho tôi khi nào cậu đến. Tôi sẽ rất hối tiếc nếu bỏ lỡ cậu.”
tr: Lord Henry şapkasıyla eldivenlerini eline aldı. “Çok ısrar ediyorsun, ama yazık ki gitmek zorundayım, Basil. Orleans’ta birine sözüm var. Hoşça kalın, mr Gray. Bir gün öğleden sonra Curzon Sokağı’na buyurun da görüşelim. Hemen her gün akşamüzerleri beşte evde olurum. Geleceğiniz günü yazın bana. Geldiğinizde sizi görebilmek isterim.
es: Lord Henry recogió su sombrero y sus guantes. —Eres muy insistente, Basil, pero, desgraciadamente, debo irme. Prometí reunirme con una persona en el Orleans. Hasta la vista, señor Gray. Venga a verme alguna tarde a Curzon Street. Casi siempre estoy en casa a las cinco. Escríbame cuando decida ir, sentiría mucho perderme su visita.
vi_translation: Lord Henry picked up his hat and gloves. "You are very persistent, Basil, but I'm afraid I must go. I have promised to meet someone in Orleans. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Do come and see me some afternoon on Curzon Street. I am almost always at home at five o'clock. Write to me beforehand when you are coming. I would be very sorry to miss you."
tr_translation: Lord Henry took his hat and gloves in his hand. “You insist too much, but unfortunately, I have to go, Basil. I have an appointment with someone in Orleans. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Come to Curzon Street one afternoon so we can meet. I am usually home at five in the evening almost every day. Write to me the day you will come. I would like to see you when you arrive.”
es_translation: Lord Henry picked up his hat and gloves. —You are very insistent, Basil, but unfortunately, I must go. I promised to meet someone at the Orleans. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Come see me some afternoon on Curzon Street. I am almost always home at five. Write to me when you decide to come, I would hate to miss your visit.

en: “Basil,” cried Dorian Gray, “if Lord Henry Wotton goes, I shall go, too. You never open your lips while you are painting, and it is horribly dull standing on a platform and trying to look pleasant. Ask him to stay. I insist upon it.”
vi: “Basil,” Dorian Gray kêu lên, “nếu huân tước Henry Wotton mà đi thì tôi cũng sẽ đi. Anh chẳng khi nào mở miệng lúc anh đang vẽ, và chán chết đi được khi phải đứng trên bục và cố gắng để trông có vẻ vui. Xin anh ấy ở lại đi. Tôi năn nỉ đấy.”
tr: Dorian Gray, “Basil!” dedi. “Lord Henry Wotton giderse ben de giderim. Sen çizerken ağzını açmazsın; böyle, platform üstünde ayakta durup güler yüzlü görünmeye çalışmak da beni sıkıntıdan patlatıyor. Rica et ona, kalsın. Dediğim dedik.
es: —Basil —exclamó Dorian Gray—, si lord Henry Wotton se marcha, me iré yo también. Nunca despegas los labios cuando pintas, y es muy aburrido estar de pie en un estrado y tratar de parecer contento. Pídele que se quede. Insisto.
vi_translation: "Basil," Dorian Gray exclaimed, "if Lord Henry Wotton leaves, then I will also leave. You never speak while you are painting, and it is terribly boring to stand on the platform and try to look cheerful. Please ask him to stay. I beg you."
tr_translation: Dorian Gray said, "Basil!" "If Lord Henry Wotton leaves, I will leave too. You don't open your mouth while you draw; standing on the platform trying to look cheerful is driving me crazy. Ask him to stay. What I say goes."
es_translation: —Basil —exclaimed Dorian Gray—, if Lord Henry Wotton leaves, I will leave too. You never part your lips when you paint, and it is very boring to stand on a platform and try to look happy. Ask him to stay. I insist.

en: “Stay, Harry, to oblige Dorian, and to oblige me,” said Hallward, gazing intently at his picture. “It is quite true, I never talk when I am working, and never listen either, and it must be dreadfully tedious for my unfortunate sitters. I beg you to stay.”
vi: Tôi năn nỉ đấy.” “Ở lại đi, Harry, để gia ơn cho Dorian, và để gia ơn cho tôi,” Hallward vừa nói vừa chăm chú nhìn bức tranh của mình. “Thật đấy, tôi chẳng khi nào nói chuyện khi tôi đang làm việc, và cũng chẳng khi nào nghe luôn, và điều ấy hẳn là chán ngấy với những người mẫu không may của tôi. Tôi cầu xin anh ở lại.”
tr: Hallward gözlerini çizdiği resme dikkatle dikmiş olarak, “Kal, Harry, kal da Dorian’ın gönlünü yap, beni de sevindir,” dedi. “Çok doğrudur, ben çalışırken hiç konuşmam, söylenenleri de dinlemem. Zavallı modellerim için müthiş sıkıcı olsa gerek. Yalvarırım kal.
es: —Quédate, Harry, para complacer a Dorian y para complacerme a mí —dijo Hallward, sin apartar los ojos del cuadro—. Es muy cierto que nunca hablo cuando estoy trabajando, y tampoco escucho, lo que debe de ser increíblemente tedioso para mis pobres modelos. Te suplico que te quedes.
vi_translation: “Stay, Harry, to do a favor for Dorian, and to do a favor for me,” Hallward said while intently looking at his painting. “Really, I never talk when I am working, and I never listen either, and that must be terribly boring for my unfortunate models. I beg you to stay.”
tr_translation: Hallward, with his eyes fixed intently on the picture he was drawing, said, "Stay, Harry, stay and cheer up Dorian, and make me happy too." "It's very true, I never talk while I'm working, nor do I listen to what's being said. It must be terribly boring for my poor models. I beg you to stay."
es_translation: —Stay, Harry, to please Dorian and to please me —said Hallward, without taking his eyes off the painting—. It is very true that I never talk when I am working, and I do not listen either, which must be incredibly tedious for my poor models. I beg you to stay.

en: “But what about my man at the Orleans?”
vi: “Thế còn cái người của tôi ở Orleans thì sao?”
tr: “Peki, Orleans’taki adam ne olacak?
es: —¿Y qué va a ser del caballero que me espera en el Orleans?
vi_translation: "What about my man in Orleans?"
tr_translation: “So, what will happen to the man in Orleans?”
es_translation: —And what will become of the gentleman who is waiting for me in Orleans?

en: The painter laughed. “I don’t think there will be any difficulty about that. Sit down again, Harry. And now, Dorian, get up on the platform, and don’t move about too much, or pay any attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a very bad influence over all his friends, with the single exception of myself.”
vi: Họa sỹ cười. “Tôi không nghĩ sẽ có gì khó với chuyện đó đâu. Thôi ngồi lại lần nữa đi, Harry. Giờ thì, Dorian, lên bục nào, và đừng nhúc nhích nhiều quá, hoặc để ý đến những gì huân tước Henry nói. Anh ấy gây ảnh hưởng rất xấu đến mọi người bạn, trừ một mình tôi.”
tr: Ressam güldü. “Bunun bir sorun çıkartacağını hiç sanmıyorum. Otur aşağı, Harry. Sen de, Dorian, çık şu platforma. Pek kıpırdamamaya çalış; Lord Henry’nin dediklerine de kulak asma. Benim dışımda bütün dostları üzerinde çok kötü etki bırakır.
es: El pintor se echó a reír. —No creo que eso sea un problema. Siéntate otra vez, Harry. Y ahora, Dorian, sube al estrado y no te muevas demasiado ni prestes atención a lo que dice lord Henry. Tiene una pésima influencia sobre todos mis amigos, sin otra excepción que yo.
vi_translation: The artist laughed. "I don't think there will be any difficulty with that." “Now sit down again, Harry. Now then, Dorian, get on the platform, and don't move too much, or pay attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a very bad influence on all his friends, except for me.”
tr_translation: The painter laughed. "I don't think this will cause any trouble. Sit down, Harry. And you, Dorian, get up on that platform. Try not to move too much; and don't pay attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a very bad influence on all his friends except me."
es_translation: The painter burst out laughing. —I don't think that will be a problem. Sit down again, Harry. And now, Dorian, get on the platform and don't move too much or pay attention to what Lord Henry says. He has a terrible influence on all my friends, with no exception but me.

en: Dorian Gray stepped up on the dais with the air of a young Greek martyr, and made a little moue of discontent to Lord Henry, to whom he had rather taken a fancy. He was so unlike Basil. They made a delightful contrast. And he had such a beautiful voice. After a few moments he said to him, “Have you really a very bad influence, Lord Henry? As bad as Basil says?”
vi: Dorian Gray bước lên đài với phong thái một thanh niên Hy Lạp tử vì đạo, và làm bộ hơi nhăn mặt để tỏ vẻ bất mãn trước huân tước Henry, người mà cậu đã thấy khá mến mộ. Anh ấy khác hẳn Basil. Họ tạo nên một sự tương phản thú vị. Và anh ấy có giọng nói thật là hay. Sau vài giây, cậu nói với y, “Có phải anh thật sự gây ảnh hưởng xấu không, huân tước Henry? Xấu đến mức như Basil nói ấy?”
tr: Dorian Gray, antik Yunan’dan genç bir ermiş edasıyla platforma çıktı, Lord Henry’den yana bakarak yüzünü hafifçe bir yakınmayla buruşturdu. Lord Henry’den enikonu hoşlanmıştı. Basil’den öyle farklıydı ki bu adam. İki dost çok zevkli bir çelişki oluşturuyorlardı. Lord Henry’ nin sesi de ne güzeldi. Birkaç dakika sonra Dorian ona sordu: “Gerçekten de dostlarınız üzerinde etkiniz çok mu kötü oluyor, Lord Henry? Basil’in dediği kadar var mı?
es: Dorian Gray subió al estrado con el aspecto de un joven mártir griego, e hizo una ligera mueca de descontento dirigida a lord Henry, que le inspiraba ya una gran simpatía. ¡Era tan distinto de Basil! Producían un contraste muy agradable. Y tenía una voz muy bella. —¿Es cierto que ejerce usted una pésima influencia, lord Henry? —le preguntó al cabo de unos instantes—. ¿Tan mala como dice Basil?
vi_translation: Dorian Gray stepped onto the platform with the demeanor of a Greek youth martyred, and made a slight grimace to show his displeasure before Lord Henry, whom he had come to quite admire. He was entirely different from Basil. They created an interesting contrast. And he had such a wonderful voice. After a few seconds, he said to him, "Are you really a bad influence, Lord Henry? As bad as Basil says?"
tr_translation: Dorian Gray stepped onto the platform with the air of a young saint from ancient Greece, looking towards Lord Henry and slightly wrinkling his face with a hint of complaint. He had taken quite a liking to Lord Henry. This man was so different from Basil. The two friends formed a very delightful contrast. Lord Henry's voice was also beautiful. A few minutes later, Dorian asked him: “Do you really have such a bad influence on your friends, Lord Henry? Is it as bad as Basil says?”
es_translation: Dorian Gray ascended the platform with the appearance of a young Greek martyr, and made a slight grimace of discontent directed at Lord Henry, who already inspired in him a great sympathy. He was so different from Basil! They produced a very pleasant contrast. And he had a very beautiful voice. —Is it true that you exert a terrible influence, Lord Henry? —he asked after a few moments—. As bad as Basil says?

en: “There is no such thing as a good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral—immoral from the scientific point of view.”
vi: “Chẳng có gì là ảnh hưởng tốt đâu, mít-tơ Gray. Mọi ảnh hưởng đều đồi bại — đồi bại từ quan điểm khoa học.
tr: “İyi etki diye bir şey yoktur ki, mr Gray. Etki denen şey tümüyle ahlaka aykırıdır, yani bilimsel yönden ahlakdışıdır.
es: —Las buenas influencias no existen, señor Gray. Toda influencia es inmoral; inmoral desde el punto de vista científico.
vi_translation: “There is nothing like a good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral — immoral from the scientific point of view.”
tr_translation: “There is no such thing as a good influence, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral – immoral from the scientific point of view.”
es_translation: —Good influences do not exist, Mr. Gray. All influence is immoral; immoral from a scientific point of view.

en: “Why?”
vi: “Tại sao?”
tr: “Neden?
es: —¿Por qué?
vi_translation: "Why?"
tr_translation: “Why?”
es_translation: —Why?

en: “Because to influence a person is to give him one’s own soul. He does not think his natural thoughts, or burn with his natural passions. His virtues are not real to him. His sins, if there are such things as sins, are borrowed. He becomes an echo of some one else’s music, an actor of a part that has not been written for him. The aim of life is self-development. To realize one’s nature perfectly—that is what each of us is here for. People are afraid of themselves, nowadays. They have forgotten the highest of all duties, the duty that one owes to one’s self. Of course, they are charitable. They feed the hungry and clothe the beggar. But their own souls starve, and are naked. Courage has gone out of our race. Perhaps we never really had it. The terror of society, which is the basis of morals, the terror of God, which is the secret of religion—these are the two things that govern us. And yet—”
vi: “Vì tạo ảnh hưởng lên một người tức là cho hắn tâm hồn của chính ta. Hắn không còn nghĩ những suy nghĩ tự nhiên của hắn nữa, hoặc cháy với các đam mê tự nhiên của hắn nữa. Các đức tính của hắn không còn thật với hắn nữa. Các tội lỗi của hắn, nếu có cái gì đó tựa như tội lỗi, là vay mượn. Hắn trở thành một tiếng dội lại âm nhạc kẻ khác, một diễn viên đóng cái vai không được viết cho mình. Mục đích cuộc đời là tự phát triển bản thân. Nhận thức được thấu đáo bản chất của mình — đó là điều mà vì nó nên mỗi chúng ta mới ở đây. Thời nay, con người sợ chính mình. Họ đã quên đi nghĩa vụ cao nhất trong số mọi nghĩa vụ, cái nghĩa vụ mà người ta nợ chính bản thân mình. Dĩ nhiên họ rất nhân từ. Họ mang thức ăn cho người đói khát, mặc quần áo cho kẻ ăn mày. Nhưng tâm hồn chính họ thì đói khát, trần truồng. Lòng dũng cảm đã rời bỏ loài người chúng ta. Không chừng chúng ta chưa bao giờ thật sự có nó. Nỗi sợ hãi trong xã hội, ấy là nền tảng của luân lý, nỗi sợ Chúa, ấy là bí mật của tôn giáo — đó là hai cái kiềm chế chúng ta. Thế mà…”
tr: “İnsanın birini etkilemesi demek ona kendi ruhunu vermesi demektir de ondan. Bu insan kendi doğal düşünceleriyle düşünmez artık, kendi doğal ihtiraslarıyla yanmaz. Erdemleri sahici değildir. Günahları –günah diye bir şey varsa eğer– ödünçtür. Bu insan başka birinin müziğinin bir yansıması olup çıkar, kendisi için yazılmamış bir rolde oynayan bir aktör. Yaşamanın amacı kişinin kendini geliştirmesidir. Doğamızın gereğini kusursuz olarak gerçekleştirmek: İşte her birimizin burada olmamızın nedeni budur. Oysa şimdilerde insanlar özbenliklerinden korkuyorlar. Görevlerin en yücesini, yani kişinin kendi özbenliğine olan görevini unutmuşlar. Hayırseverliklerine diyecek yok. Açları doyuruyor, dilencileri giydiriyorlar. Gel gör ki kendi ruhları aç, çıplak. Soyumuzda cesaret diye bir şey kalmamış. Belki de hiçbir zaman yoktu. Toplum korkusu –ki ahlakın temelidir–, bir de dinin püf noktası olan Tanrı korkusu: Bizi yöneten iki şey işte bunlar. Öte yandan, gene de...
es: —Porque influir en una persona es darle la propia alma. Esa persona deja de pensar sus propias ideas y de arder con sus pasiones. Sus virtudes dejan de ser reales. Sus pecados, si es que los pecados existen, son prestados. Se convierte en eco de la música de otro, en un actor que interpreta un papel que no se ha escrito para él. La finalidad de la vida es el propio desarrollo. Alcanzar la plenitud de la manera más perfecta posible, para eso estamos aquí. En la actualidad las personas se tienen miedo. Han olvidado el mayor de todos los deberes, lo que cada uno se debe a sí mismo. Son caritativos, por supuesto. Dan de comer al hambriento y visten al desnudo. Pero sus almas pasan hambre y ellos mismos están desnudos. Nuestra raza ha dejado de tener valor. Quizá no lo haya tenido nunca. El miedo a la sociedad, que es la base de la moral; el miedo a Dios, que es el secreto de la religión: ésas son las dos cosas que nos gobiernan. Y, sin embargo...
vi_translation: “To influence a person is to give him one's own soul. He does not think his natural thoughts, or burn with his natural passions. His virtues are not real to him anymore. His sins, if there is such a thing as sins, are borrowed. He becomes an echo of someone else's music, an actor of a part that has not been written for him. The aim of life is self-development. To realize one's nature perfectly — that is what each of us is here for. Nowadays people are afraid of themselves. They have forgotten the highest of all duties, the duty that one owes to oneself. Of course they are charitable. They feed the hungry and clothe the beggar. But their own souls are starving and naked. Courage has left our race. Perhaps we never really had it. Fear of society, which is the basis of morality, fear of God, which is the secret of religion — these are the two things that govern us. And yet…”
tr_translation: “To influence someone means to give them your own soul. This person no longer thinks with their own natural thoughts, no longer burns with their own natural passions. Their virtues are not genuine. Their sins – if there is such a thing as sin – are borrowed. This person becomes a reflection of someone else's music, an actor playing a role not written for them. The purpose of life is for a person to develop themselves. To perfectly realize the requirements of our nature: That is why each of us is here. Yet nowadays people are afraid of their own true selves. They have forgotten the highest duty, which is the duty to one's own true self. There is nothing to say against their charity.
