He watched it with that strange interest in trivial things that we try to develop when things of high import make us afraid, or when we are stirred by some new emotion for which we cannot find expression, or when some thought that terrifies us lays sudden siege to the brain and calls on us to yield. After a time the bee flew away. He saw it creeping into the stained trumpet of a Tyrian convolvulus. The flower seemed to quiver, and then swayed gently to and fro.
vi: Dorian Gray lắng nghe, mắt mở to kinh ngạc. Cành tử đinh hương rơi từ tay cậu lên cỏ. Một con ong lù xù bay đến và vo ve vòng quanh một lát. Sau đó nó bắt đầu bò khắp quả bầu dục lấm chấm đầy sao hoa tí hon. Cậu ngắm nhìn nó với sự thích thú kỳ lạ ấy với những thứ tầm thường mà ta vẫn cố bày tỏ mỗi khi những thứ quan trọng khiến ta sợ hãi, hoặc khi ta bị xao lòng bởi xúc cảm nào đó mới mẻ mà ta không thể tìm được cách diễn đạt, hoặc khi ý tưởng nào đó làm ta kinh hãi bỗng dưng vây hãm não ta và kêu gọi ta đầu hàng. Một lát sau con ong bay đi. Cậu nhìn nó bò vào trong chiếc kèn trôm-pét hoen ố của một cây bìm bìm màu tím hoàng gia. Đóa hoa dường như run rẩy, rồi nhè nhẹ lắc lư.
tr: Dorian gözlerini açmış şaşkın, dalgın dinliyordu. Elindeki leylak yerdeki çakıl taşlarının üstüne düştü. Tüylü bir arı geldi, bir an leylağın üzerinde vızıldadı. Sonra minik çiçeklerden oluşmuş yıldız tutamının üzerine tırmandı. Dorian arıyı, önemli şeylerin bizi korkuttuğu, adını koyamadığımız yepyeni bir duygunun içimizde kıpırdadığı ya da bize dehşet veren bir düşüncenin ansızın beynimizi kuşatarak bize teslim ol çağrısı yaptığı zamanlarda önemsiz şeylere karşı duymaya çalıştığımız o tuhaf ilgiyle seyrediyordu. Arının mor bir kahkahaçiçeğinin parlak renkli borazanının içine sokulduğunu gördü. Çiçek şöyle bir titredi sanki, sonra usulca öne arkaya sallanmaya başladı.
es: Dorian Gray escuchaba, los ojos muy abiertos, asombrado. El ramillete de lilas se le cayó al suelo. Una sedosa abeja zumbó a su alrededor por un instante. Luego empezó a trepar con dificultad por los globos estrellados de cada flor. Dorian Gray la observó con el extraño interés por las cosas triviales que tratamos de fomentar cuando las más importantes nos asustan, o cuando nos embarga alguna nueva emoción que no sabemos expresar, o cuando alguna idea que nos aterra pone repentino sitio a la mente y exige nuestra rendición. Al cabo de algún tiempo la abeja alzó el vuelo. Dorian Gray la vio introducirse en la campanilla de una enredadera. La flor pareció estremecerse y luego se balanceó suavemente hacia adelante y hacia atrás.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray listened, his eyes wide with astonishment. The lilac branch fell from his hand onto the grass. A fuzzy bee flew over and buzzed around for a moment. Then it began to crawl all over the star-speckled oval gourd. He watched it with that strange fascination we often show for trivial things when important matters frighten us, or when we are distracted by some new emotion we cannot find words to express, or when some terrifying idea suddenly besieges our mind and calls for our surrender. A moment later, the bee flew away. He watched it crawl into the tarnished trumpet of a royal purple morning glory. The flower seemed to tremble, then gently sway.
tr_translation: Dorian opened his eyes, listening in a dazed and bewildered manner. The lilac in his hand fell onto the pebbles on the ground. A fuzzy bee came and buzzed over the lilac for a moment. Then it climbed onto the tuft of star-shaped tiny flowers. Dorian watched the bee with that strange interest we try to feel towards insignificant things when important things frighten us, when a brand-new feeling we cannot name stirs within us, or when a thought that terrifies us suddenly besieges our mind and calls for our surrender. He saw the bee burrow into the bright-colored trumpet of a purple laughing flower. The flower seemed to shiver slightly, then began to gently sway back and forth.
es_translation: Dorian Gray listened, his eyes wide open, astonished. The bouquet of lilacs fell to the ground. A silky bee buzzed around him for a moment. Then it began to climb laboriously over the star-shaped globes of each flower. Dorian Gray watched it with the strange interest in trivial things that we try to cultivate when the more important ones frighten us, or when we are overwhelmed by some new emotion that we do not know how to express, or when some idea that terrifies us suddenly besieges the mind and demands our surrender. After some time, the bee took flight. Dorian Gray saw it enter the bell of a vine flower. The flower seemed to shudder and then gently swayed back and forth.

en: Suddenly the painter appeared at the door of the studio and made staccato signs for them to come in. They turned to each other and smiled.
vi: Bỗng dưng họa sỹ xuất hiện trên cửa vào xưởng vẽ, và ra dấu ngắt âm mời họ vào nhà. Họ quay qua nhau và cười.
tr: Birden ressam stüdyonun kapısında belirerek el edip onları içeri çağırdı. Dorian’la Lord Henry birbirlerine bakarak gülümsediler.
es: De repente, el pintor apareció en la puerta del estudio y, con gestos bruscos, les indicó que entraran en la casa. Dorian Gray y lord Henry se miraron y sonrieron.
vi_translation: Suddenly, the artist appeared at the entrance to the studio and gestured silently to invite them inside. They turned to each other and laughed.
tr_translation: Suddenly, the painter appeared at the studio door and waved them inside. Dorian and Lord Henry looked at each other and smiled.
es_translation: Suddenly, the painter appeared at the studio door and, with brusque gestures, indicated that they should enter the house. Dorian Gray and Lord Henry looked at each other and smiled.

en: “I am waiting,” he cried. “Do come in. The light is quite perfect, and you can bring your drinks.”
vi: “Tôi chờ đây,” y kêu lên. “Vào đi nào. Ánh sáng rất hoàn hảo, và các bạn có thể mang đồ uống theo.
tr: Ressam, “Bekliyorum,” diye seslendi. “Kuzum, gelsenize. Işık şu sırada mükemmel. İçkilerinizi de getirin.
es: —Estoy esperando —exclamó Hallward—. Vengan, por favor. La luz es perfecta; tráiganse los vasos.
vi_translation: “I'm waiting here,” he shouted. “Come on in. The light is perfect, and you can bring your drinks along.”
tr_translation: The painter called out, "I'm waiting." "My dear, come on. The light is perfect right now. Bring your drinks too."
es_translation: —I am waiting —exclaimed Hallward—. Come, please. The light is perfect; bring the glasses.

en: They rose up and sauntered down the walk together. Two green-and-white butterflies fluttered past them, and in the pear-tree at the corner of the garden a thrush began to sing.
vi: “Họ đứng lên, thơ thẩn thả bộ cùng nhau. Hai con bướm xanh-và-trắng dập dờn bay ngang qua họ, và, trên cây lê ở góc vườn, một con chim hoét cất tiếng ca.
tr: Ayağa kalktılar, yolda yan yana yürümeye başladılar. Yeşilli beyazlı iki kelebek kanat çırparak yanlarından uçup geçti; bahçenin köşesindeki armut ağacında bir kuş ötmeye başladı.
es: Se levantaron y recorrieron juntos la senda. Dos mariposas verdes y blancas se cruzaron con ellos y, en el peral que ocupaba una esquina del jardín, un mirlo empezó a cantar.
vi_translation: “They stood up, wandering together. Two blue-and-white butterflies fluttered past them, and, on the pear tree in the corner of the garden, a thrush sang.
tr_translation: They stood up and started walking side by side on the road. Two butterflies, green and white, fluttered past them; a bird began to sing in the pear tree at the corner of the garden.
es_translation: They got up and walked the path together. Two green and white butterflies crossed their path, and in the pear tree that occupied a corner of the garden, a blackbird began to sing.

en: “You are glad you have met me, Mr. Gray,” said Lord Henry, looking at him.
vi: “Cậu có vui vì gặp tôi không, mít-tơ Gray,” huân tước Henry nói, nhìn cậu.
tr: Lord Henry genç adamdan yana bakarak, “Bana rastladığınıza seviniyorsunuz mr Gray,” dedi.
es: —Se alegra de haberme conocido, señor Gray—dijo lord Henry, mirándolo.
vi_translation: “Are you happy to see me, Mr. Gray,” Lord Henry said, looking at him.
tr_translation: Lord Henry looked at the young man and said, "You are glad to have met me, Mr. Gray."
es_translation: —He is glad to have met me, Mr. Gray—said Lord Henry, looking at him.

en: “Yes, I am glad now. I wonder shall I always be glad?”
vi: “Vâng, tôi đang vui. Tôi tự hỏi liệu mình có được vui mãi không?”
tr: “Evet, şimdi seviniyorum. Her zaman böyle sevinecek miyim acaba?
es: —Sí, ahora sí. Me pregunto si me alegraré siempre.
vi_translation: “Yes, I am happy. I wonder if I will always be happy?”
tr_translation: “Yes, now I am happy. Will I always be this happy, I wonder?”
es_translation: —Yes, now I do. I wonder if I will always be happy.

en: “Always! That is a dreadful word. It makes me shudder when I hear it. Women are so fond of using it. They spoil every romance by trying to make it last for ever. It is a meaningless word, too. The only difference between a caprice and a lifelong passion is that the caprice lasts a little longer.”
vi: “Mãi! Đó là một từ khủng khiếp. Nó khiến tôi rùng mình mỗi khi nghe thấy. Đàn bà rất thích dùng nó. Họ làm hỏng mọi chuyện tình lãng mạn bằng cách cố gắng làm cho chúng kéo dài vĩnh viễn. Nó cũng là một từ vô nghĩa nữa. Sự khác biệt duy nhất giữa sự tùy hứng và niềm đam mê trọn đời là ở chỗ sự tùy hứng kéo dài thêm được ít lâu.”
tr: “Her zaman! Çok çirkin bir deyim bu. Duyar duymaz kanım donar. Kadınlar bayılırlar bunu kullanmaya. Her aşkı, sonsuza dek sürdürmeye çalışarak berbat ederler. Sözcük olarak da anlamsızdır. Bir kaprisle ebedi bir aşk arasındaki tek ayrım kaprisin biraz daha uzun ömürlü olmasıdır.
es: —¡Siempre! Terrible palabra. Hace que me estremezca cuando la oigo. Las mujeres son tan aficionadas a usarla. Echan a perder todas las historias de amor intentando que duren para siempre. Es, además, una palabra sin sentido. La única diferencia entre un capricho y una pasión para toda la vida es que el capricho dura un poco más.
vi_translation: “Forever!” “That is a terrible word. It makes me shudder every time I hear it. Women love to use it. They ruin every romantic affair by trying to make it last forever. It is also a meaningless word. The only difference between a whim and a lifelong passion is that a whim lasts a little longer.”
tr_translation: “Always! It's a very ugly expression. As soon as I hear it, my blood freezes. Women love to use it. They ruin every love by trying to make it last forever. As a word, it is also meaningless. The only difference between a whim and an eternal love is that the whim lasts a little longer.”
es_translation: —Always! Terrible word. It makes me shudder when I hear it. Women are so fond of using it. They ruin all love stories by trying to make them last forever. It is, moreover, a meaningless word. The only difference between a whim and a lifelong passion is that the whim lasts a little longer.

en: As they entered the studio, Dorian Gray put his hand upon Lord Henry’s arm. “In that case, let our friendship be a caprice,” he murmured, flushing at his own boldness, then stepped up on the platform and resumed his pose.
vi: Lúc họ vào xưởng vẽ, Dorian Gray đặt bàn tay mình lên cánh tay huân tước Henry. “Nếu vậy, hãy để tình bạn của ta thành ra một sự tùy hứng,” cậu thì thầm, đỏ bừng lên vì sự bạo dạn của chính mình, rồi bước lên bục và lại tiếp tục tư thế làm mẫu.
tr: Stüdyoya girerlerken Dorian Gray elini Lord Henry’nin koluna koydu. “Öyleyse bizim dostluğumuz bir kapris olsun,” dedi ve kendi cüreti karşısında yüzü kıpkırmızı kesildi. Sonra platforma çıkarak deminki duruşunu aldı.
es: Al entrar en el estudio, Dorian Gray puso una mano en el brazo de lord Henry. —En ese caso, que nuestra amistad sea un capricho —murmuró, ruborizándose ante su propia audacia; luego subió al estrado y volvió a posar.
vi_translation: When they entered the studio, Dorian Gray placed his hand on Lord Henry's arm. "If so, let our friendship be a whim," he whispered, blushing at his own boldness, then stepped onto the platform and resumed his modeling pose.
tr_translation: As they entered the studio, Dorian Gray placed his hand on Lord Henry's arm. "Then let our friendship be a whim," he said, and his face turned crimson at his own audacity. Then he stepped onto the platform and resumed his previous pose.
es_translation: Upon entering the study, Dorian Gray placed a hand on Lord Henry's arm. —In that case, let our friendship be a whim —she murmured, blushing at her own audacity; then she stepped onto the stage and resumed posing.

en: Lord Henry flung himself into a large wicker arm-chair and watched him. The sweep and dash of the brush on the canvas made the only sound that broke the stillness, except when, now and then, Hallward stepped back to look at his work from a distance. In the slanting beams that streamed through the open doorway the dust danced and was golden. The heavy scent of the roses seemed to brood over everything.
vi: Huân tước Henry buông mình lên chiếc ghế bành liễu gai rộng rãi và ngắm cậu. Những nét quết và phết bút trên toan tạo ra thanh âm duy nhất phá vỡ sự tĩnh lặng, ngoại trừ những lúc thỉnh thoảng Hallward bước lùi lại để ngắm tác phẩm của mình từ một khoảng cách. Trong các chùm sáng xiên đang ùa vào qua ô cửa mở, bụi nhảy múa và nhuộm sắc vàng. Hương hồng ngào ngạt dường như ấp ủ lên mọi thứ.
tr: Lord Henry kendini geniş bir hasır koltuğa bırakarak, onu seyre daldı. Fırçanın tuval üzerindeki vuruş ve sürünüşleri sessizliği bozan tek sedaydı. Arada bir Hall yapıtına uzaktan bakmak için biraz geriye çekiliyordu. Kapıdan vuran eğik ışınların içinde altın renkli tozlar oynaşıyordu. Her şeyin üstüne güllerin ağır kokusu sinmişti.
es: Lord Henry se dejó caer en un gran sillón de mimbre y lo contempló. El roce del pincel sobre el lienzo era el único ruido que turbaba la quietud, excepto cuando, de tarde en tarde, Hallward retrocedía para examinar su obra desde más lejos. En los rayos oblicuos que penetraban por la puerta abierta, el polvo danzaba, convertido en oro. El intenso perfume de las rosas parecía envolverlo todo.
vi_translation: Lord Henry dropped himself into the spacious wicker armchair and observed him. The strokes and brush marks on the canvas created the only sound breaking the silence, except for the occasional moments when Hallward stepped back to view his work from a distance. In the slanting beams of light streaming through the open window, dust danced and turned golden. The fragrant scent of roses seemed to envelop everything.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, dropping himself into a wide wicker chair, began to gaze at him. The strokes and glides of the brush on the canvas were the only sounds breaking the silence. Occasionally, Hall would step back a bit to look at his work from a distance. Golden-colored dust danced in the slanting rays of light coming through the door. The heavy scent of roses had permeated everything.
es_translation: Lord Henry dropped into a large wicker armchair and watched him. The brush's stroke on the canvas was the only noise disturbing the stillness, except when, from time to time, Hallward stepped back to examine his work from a distance. In the slanting rays that penetrated through the open door, the dust danced, turned into gold. The intense fragrance of the roses seemed to envelop everything.

en: After about a quarter of an hour Hallward stopped painting, looked for a long time at Dorian Gray, and then for a long time at the picture, biting the end of one of his huge brushes and frowning. “It is quite finished,” he cried at last, and stooping down he wrote his name in long vermilion letters on the left-hand corner of the canvas.
vi: Sau khoảng phần tư giờ, Hallward dừng vẽ, ngắm rất lâu về phía Dorian Gray, sau đó lại nhìn rất lâu vào bức tranh, cắn đầu một trong những cây bút vẽ khổng lồ, chau mày. “Xong hết rồi đấy,” rốt cuộc y kêu lên và khom xuống viết tên mình bằng các chữ cái dài màu đỏ son lên góc tay trái tấm toan.
tr: Bir çeyrek saat kadar sonra Hallward fırçayı elinden bıraktı. Uzun zaman Dorian Gray’e, sonra da o kocaman fırçasının ucunu dişleyerek, çatık kaşlarla yapıtına baktı. Sonunda, “Bitti, nihayet!” diye bağırarak eğildi, tuvalin sol köşesine uzun, al renkli harflerle adını yazdı.
es: Al cabo de un cuarto de hora Hallward dejó de pintar, miró durante un buen rato a Dorian Gray, y luego durante otro buen rato al cuadro mientras mordía el extremo de uno de sus grandes pinceles y fruncía el ceño. —Está terminado —exclamó por fin; agachándose, firmó con grandes trazos rojos en la esquina izquierda del lienzo.
vi_translation: After about a quarter of an hour, Hallward stopped painting, gazed at Dorian Gray for a long time, then looked at the painting for a long time, biting the end of one of his huge paintbrushes, frowning. "It's all done," he finally exclaimed and bent down to write his name in long red letters on the bottom left corner of the canvas.
tr_translation: About a quarter of an hour later, Hallward put down the brush. For a long time, he looked at Dorian Gray, then, biting the tip of his large brush, he frowned at his work. Finally, "Finished, finally!" he shouted, bending over, and wrote his name in long, red letters in the left corner of the canvas.
es_translation: After a quarter of an hour, Hallward stopped painting, looked at Dorian Gray for a long time, and then at the painting for another long time while biting the end of one of his large brushes and frowning. —It's finished —he exclaimed at last; bending down, he signed with large red strokes in the bottom left corner of the canvas.

en: Lord Henry came over and examined the picture. It was certainly a wonderful work of art, and a wonderful likeness as well.
vi: Huân tước Henry lại gần và xem kỹ bức tranh. Nó đúng là một tác phẩm nghệ thuật phi thường, và sự tương đồng cũng phi thường.
tr: Lord Henry geldi, resmi gözden geçirdi. Hiç kuşkusuz, olağanüstü bir sanat ürünüydü, modelin tıpkısıydı.
es: Lord Henry se acercó a examinar el retrato. Era, sin duda, una espléndida obra de arte, y el parecido era excelente.
vi_translation: Lord Henry approached and examined the painting closely. It was indeed an extraordinary piece of art, and the resemblance was also remarkable.
tr_translation: Lord Henry arrived and examined the portrait. Without a doubt, it was an extraordinary work of art, exactly like the model.
es_translation: Lord Henry approached to examine the portrait. It was, without a doubt, a splendid work of art, and the likeness was excellent.

en: “My dear fellow, I congratulate you most warmly,” he said. “It is the finest portrait of modern times. Mr. Gray, come over and look at yourself.”
vi: “Bạn thân mến ơi, tôi xin nồng nhiệt chúc mừng anh,” y nói. “Đây là bức chân dung đẹp nhất đương thời. Mít-tơ Gray, hãy lại đây nhìn mình.”
tr: “Sevgili dostum, bütün kalbimle kutlarım. Çağdaş dönemin en üstün portresi bu! mr Gray, gelin de kendinize bakın.
es: —Mi querido amigo —dijo—, te felicito de todo corazón. Es el mejor retrato de nuestra época. Señor Gray, venga a comprobarlo usted mismo.
vi_translation: “Dear friend, I warmly congratulate you,” he said. “This is the most beautiful portrait of the time. Mr. Gray, come here and look at yourself.”
tr_translation: "My dear friend, I congratulate you with all my heart." "This is the finest portrait of the contemporary era! Mr. Gray, come and see yourself.""
es_translation: —My dear friend —he said—, I congratulate you with all my heart. It is the best portrait of our time. Mr. Gray, come and see for yourself.

en: The lad started, as if awakened from some dream.
vi: Chàng trai giật mình, như thể bừng tỉnh một giấc mơ nào đó.
tr: Genç adam bir düşten uyanırcasına irkildi.
es: El muchacho se sobresaltó, como despertando de un sueño.
vi_translation: The young man was startled, as if waking up from some dream.
tr_translation: The young man jolted as if waking from a dream.
es_translation: The boy started, as if waking from a dream.

en: “Is it really finished?” he murmured, stepping down from the platform.
vi: “Xong thật rồi sao?” cậu thì thầm, bước xuống bục.
tr: “Bitti mi sahiden?” diyerek platformdan indi.
es: —¿Realmente acabado? —murmuró, bajando del estrado.
vi_translation: "Is it really over?" he whispered, stepping down from the platform.
tr_translation: “Is it really over?” he said, stepping down from the platform.
es_translation: —Really finished? —he murmured, stepping down from the platform.

en: “Quite finished,” said the painter. “And you have sat splendidly to-day. I am awfully obliged to you.”
vi: “Xong hẳn rồi,” họa sỹ nói. “Và hôm nay cậu ngồi mẫu tuyệt quá. Tôi vô cùng cảm ơn cậu.”
tr: “Sahiden bitti,” dedi ressam. “Bugün nefis poz verdin. Sana candan teşekkür ederim.
es: —Totalmente —dijo el pintor—. Y hoy has posado mejor que nunca. Te estoy muy agradecido.
vi_translation: "It's completely done," the artist said. "And today you posed wonderfully. I am extremely grateful to you."
tr_translation: “It's truly finished,” said the painter. “You posed beautifully today. I sincerely thank you.”
es_translation: —Absolutely —said the painter—. And today you have posed better than ever. I am very grateful to you.

en: “That is entirely due to me,” broke in Lord Henry. “Isn’t it, Mr. Gray?”
vi: “Ấy là do tôi cả đấy,” huân tước Henry xen ngang. “Phải vậy không, mít-tơ Gray?”
tr: Lord Henry, “Tamamen benim sayemde oldu,” dedi. “Öyle değil mi mr Gray?
es: —Eso me lo debes enteramente a mí —intervino lord Henry—. ¿No es así, señor Gray?
vi_translation: "It's all my doing," Lord Henry interrupted. "Isn't that right, Mr. Gray?"
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "It was entirely thanks to me." "Isn't that right, Mr. Gray?"
es_translation: —You owe that entirely to me —interjected Lord Henry—. Isn't that right, Mr. Gray?

en: Dorian made no answer, but passed listlessly in front of his picture and turned towards it. When he saw it he drew back, and his cheeks flushed for a moment with pleasure. A look of joy came into his eyes, as if he had recognized himself for the first time. He stood there motionless and in wonder, dimly conscious that Hallward was speaking to him, but not catching the meaning of his words. The sense of his own beauty came on him like a revelation. He had never felt it before. Basil Hallward’s compliments had seemed to him to be merely the charming exaggeration of friendship. He had listened to them, laughed at them, forgotten them. They had not influenced his nature. Then had come Lord Henry Wotton with his strange panegyric on youth, his terrible warning of its brevity. That had stirred him at the time, and now, as he stood gazing at the shadow of his own loveliness, the full reality of the description flashed across him. Yes, there would be a day when his face would be wrinkled and wizen, his eyes dim and colourless, the grace of his figure broken and deformed. The scarlet would pass away from his lips and the gold steal from his hair. The life that was to make his soul would mar his body. He would become dreadful, hideous, and uncouth.
vi: Dorian không đáp lại, nhưng thờ ơ đi ngang qua trước bức tranh của mình, rồi quay về phía nó. Khi cậu nhìn thấy nó thì cậu giật lùi lại, và má cậu đỏ bừng lên một lúc vì vui sướng. Một nét hân hoan hiện lên trong mắt cậu, như thể cậu nhận ra mình lần đầu. Cậu đứng bất động trong nỗi kinh ngạc, lờ mờ biết rằng Hallward đang nói với cậu, nhưng không thể nắm được ý nghĩa những lời nói của y. Ý thức về sắc đẹp của chính mình đến với cậu như một sự khai sáng. Cậu chưa bao giờ cảm thấy điều ấy trước đây. Những lời ca tụng của Basil Hallward với cậu dường như chỉ là sự cường điệu dễ thương của tình bạn. Cậu đã nghe chúng, đã cười chúng, đã quên chúng. Chúng không ảnh hưởng đến bản chất cậu. Rồi huân tước Henry Wotton đến với bài tán tụng kỳ lạ về tuổi xuân, với lời cảnh báo khủng khiếp về sự ngắn ngủi của nó. Điều ấy đã làm cậu xao lòng lúc đó, và giờ đây, khi cậu đứng nhìn chằm chằm vào bóng hình vẻ đẹp chính mình, thì thực tại đủ đầy của sự miêu tả ấy vụt ngang qua cậu. Đúng, sẽ đến cái ngày mà mặt cậu sẽ nhăn nheo khô xác, mắt cậu sẽ mờ nhạt, dáng hình thanh nhã của cậu sẽ sổ ra và biến dạng. Sắc đỏ thắm sẽ biến khỏi môi cậu, màu vàng óng sẽ chuồn khỏi tóc cậu. Cái cuộc đời đã tạo nên tâm hồn cậu cũng sẽ làm hỏng thân xác cậu. Cậu sẽ trở nên dễ sợ, gớm guốc, cục cằn.
tr: Dorian karşılık vermeyerek isteksizce ilerledi, portresine doğru döndü. Portreyi görünce geriledi, yanakları bir an kıvançtan pembeleşti. Kendi kendini ilk kez tanımış gibi gözlerinde bir sevinç parladı. Orada, kendinden geçmiş gibi kıpırtısız duruyordu. Hallward’ın ona bir şeyler söylediğini hayal meyal fark ediyorsa da, sözcüklerin anlamlarını kavrayamıyordu. Kutsal bir gerçeğin açıklanması gibi, kendi güzelliğinin bilincine varmıştı. Bundan önce hiç duyumsamamıştı bunu. Basil Hallward’ın övgülerini dostluğunun tatlı abartıları saymıştı. Dinlemiş, gülmüş, unutmuştu. Doğasını etkilememişti bu övgüler. Derken Lord Henry ortaya çıkmıştı, gençliğe düzdüğü o tuhaf kasideyle, gençliğin kısalığı üstüne yaptığı ürkünç uyarılarla. Genç adamın dinlerken etkilendiği bu sözlerin anlamı portresinde kendi güzelliğinin yansısına bakarken birden tüm açıklığıyla beyninde çaktı. Evet, gün gelecek yüzü buruşup çökecek, gözlerinin nuru, rengi kaçacak, yapısının ince uyumu bozulup biçimsizleşecekti. Dudaklarının kızılı solacak, saçlarının altın ışıltısı uçup gidecekti. Ruhunu geliştirecek olan yaşam bedenini çirkinleştirecekti. Ürkünç, iğrenç, hantal bir şey olup çıkacaktı.
es: Dorian, sin responder, avanzó con lentitud de espaldas al cuadro y luego se volvió hacia él. Al verlo retrocedió, las mejillas encendidas de placer por un momento. Un brillo de alegría se le encendió en los ojos, como si se reconociese por vez primera. Permaneció inmóvil y maravillado, consciente apenas de que Hallward hablaba con él y sin captar el significado de sus palabras. La conciencia de su propia belleza lo asaltó como una revelación. Era la primera vez. Los cumplidos de Basil Hallward le habían parecido hasta entonces simples exageraciones agradables, producto de la amistad. Los escuchaba, se reía con ellos y los olvidaba. No influían sobre él. Luego se había presentado lord Henry Wotton con su extraño panegírico sobre la juventud, su terrible advertencia sobre su brevedad. Aquello le había conmovido y, ahora, mientras miraba fijamente la imagen de su belleza, con una claridad fulgurante captó toda la verdad. Sí, en un día no muy lejano su rostro se arrugaría y marchitaría, sus ojos perderían color y brillo, la armonía de su figura se quebraría. Desaparecería el rojo escarlata de sus labios y el oro de sus cabellos. La vida que había de formarle al alma le deformaría el cuerpo. Se convertiría en un ser horrible, odioso, grotesco.
vi_translation: Dorian did not respond, but indifferently walked past his painting, then turned towards it. When he saw it, he stepped back, and his cheeks flushed for a moment with joy. A look of delight appeared in his eyes, as if he recognized himself for the first time. He stood motionless in astonishment, vaguely aware that Hallward was speaking to him, but unable to grasp the meaning of his words. The awareness of his own beauty came to him like an enlightenment. He had never felt that before. Basil Hallward's praises seemed to him merely the charming exaggerations of friendship. He had heard them, laughed at them, and forgotten them. They did not affect his nature. Then Lord Henry Wotton came with his strange eulogy of youth, with his terrible warning of its brevity. That had unsettled him at the time, and now, as he stood staring at the image of his own beauty, the full reality of that description flashed across him. Yes, there would come a day when his face would be wrinkled and withered, his eyes would dim, and his graceful figure would become bloated and deformed. The crimson would fade from his lips, the gold would flee from his hair. The life that had made his soul would also mar his body. He would become dreadful, hideous, and coarse.
tr_translation: Dorian, without responding, reluctantly moved forward and turned towards his portrait. He recoiled when he saw the portrait, his cheeks momentarily flushed with pride. As if recognizing himself for the first time, a joy sparkled in his eyes. He stood there motionless, as if in a trance. Though he vaguely noticed Hallward saying something to him, he couldn't grasp the meaning of the words. He had become aware of his own beauty, as if a sacred truth had been revealed. He had never felt this before. He had considered Basil Hallward's praises as sweet exaggerations of friendship. He had listened, laughed, and forgotten. These praises had not affected his nature. Then Lord Henry had appeared, with that strange ode to youth and his alarming warnings about its brevity. The meaning of these words, which had impressed the young man while listening, suddenly struck him with full clarity as he looked at the reflection of his own beauty in the portrait. Yes, the day would come when his face would wrinkle and sag, the light and color of his eyes would fade, the delicate harmony of his form would become distorted and misshapen. The redness of his lips would pale, the golden sheen of his hair would vanish. The life that would develop his soul would disfigure his body. He would become something dreadful, repulsive, and cumbersome.
es_translation: Dorian, without responding, advanced slowly with his back to the painting and then turned towards it. Upon seeing it, he stepped back, his cheeks flushed with pleasure for a moment. A gleam of joy lit up in his eyes, as if he recognized himself for the first time. He remained motionless and amazed, barely aware that Hallward was speaking to him and without grasping the meaning of his words. The awareness of his own beauty struck him like a revelation. It was the first time. Basil Hallward's compliments had seemed to him until then mere pleasant exaggerations, products of friendship. He listened to them, laughed at them, and forgot them. They did not influence him. Then Lord Henry Wotton had appeared with his strange panegyric on youth, his terrible warning about its brevity. That had moved him and now, as he gazed intently at the image of his beauty, he grasped the whole truth with blinding clarity. Yes, on a not too distant day his face would wrinkle and wither, his eyes would lose color and brightness, the harmony of his figure would break. The scarlet red of his lips and the gold of his hair would disappear. The life that was to shape his soul would deform his body. He would become a horrible, hateful, grotesque being.

en: As he thought of it, a sharp pang of pain struck through him like a knife and made each delicate fibre of his nature quiver. His eyes deepened into amethyst, and across them came a mist of tears. He felt as if a hand of ice had been laid upon his heart.
vi: Trong lúc cậu nghĩ về điều ấy, một cơn đau buốt nhói đâm xuyên qua cậu như con dao, và khiến cho từng thớ mềm của bản thể cậu rung lên. Mắt cậu đậm màu tím thạch anh, và giăng ngang qua chúng — một màn lệ nhạt nhòa. Cậu cảm thấy như thể một bàn tay băng giá vừa đặt lên tim mình.
tr: Bunu düşünen genç erkeğin içine bıçak gibi saplanan keskin bir acı benliğinin incecik liflerini teker teker titretti. Gözleri koyulaşarak ametist moruna dönüştü ve gözyaşlarının sisine büründü. Sanki buzdan bir el yüreğini sıkmıştı.
es: Al pensar en ello, un dolor muy agudo lo atravesó como un cuchillo, e hizo que se estremecieran todas las fibras de su ser. El azul de sus ojos se oscureció con un velo de lágrimas. Sintió que una mano de hielo se le había posado sobre el corazón.
vi_translation: While he was thinking about it, a sharp pain pierced through him like a knife, making every soft fiber of his being tremble. His eyes were a deep amethyst color, and across them — a veil of blurred tears. He felt as if an icy hand had just been placed on his heart.
tr_translation: The sharp pain that pierced the young man's soul like a knife made the delicate fibers of his being quiver one by one. His eyes darkened and turned into amethyst purple, shrouded in a mist of tears. It was as if an icy hand had squeezed his heart.
es_translation: Thinking about it, a very sharp pain pierced him like a knife, making all the fibers of his being tremble. The blue of his eyes darkened with a veil of tears. He felt as if an icy hand had settled on his heart.

en: “Don’t you like it?” cried Hallward at last, stung a little by the lad’s silence, not understanding what it meant.
vi: “Cậu không thích nó à?” rốt cuộc Hallward kêu lên, day dứt một chút trước sự im lặng của chàng trai, không hiểu thế nghĩa là gì.
tr: Gencin, anlamını çıkartamadığı bu sessizliğine biraz alınan ressam sonunda, “Beğenmedin mi?” diye çıkıştı.
es: —¿No te gusta? —exclamó finalmente Hallward, un tanto dolido por el silencio del muchacho, sin entender su significado.
vi_translation: “You don't like it?” Hallward finally exclaimed, a bit distressed by the young man's silence, not understanding what it meant.
tr_translation: The painter, slightly offended by the young man's silence which he couldn't understand, finally burst out, "Didn't you like it?"
es_translation: —Don't you like it? —Hallward finally exclaimed, somewhat hurt by the boy's silence, not understanding its meaning.

en: “Of course he likes it,” said Lord Henry. “Who wouldn’t like it? It is one of the greatest things in modern art. I will give you anything you like to ask for it. I must have it.”
vi: “Đương nhiên là cậu ấy thích nó rồi,” huân tước Henry nói. “Ai mà không thích nó cơ chứ? Nó là một trong những tác phẩm vĩ đại nhất của nghệ thuật hiện đại. Tôi sẽ đưa anh bất cứ thứ gì anh muốn đòi cho nó. Tôi phải có nó.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Elbette beğendi,” dedi. “Kim beğenmez bunu? Çağdaş sanatın en büyük yapıtlarından biri. Sana ne istersen veririm bu resme karşılık. Benim olmalı bu.
es: —Claro que le gusta —dijo lord Henry—. ¿A quién podría no gustarle? Es una de las grandes obras del arte moderno. Te daré por él lo que quieras pedirme. Debe ser mío.
vi_translation: “Of course he likes it,” said Lord Henry. “Who wouldn't like it? It is one of the greatest works of modern art. I will give you anything you want for it. I must have it.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "Of course he liked it." "Who wouldn't like this? It's one of the greatest works of contemporary art. I'll give you whatever you want in exchange for this painting. It must be mine."
es_translation: —Of course he likes it —said Lord Henry—. Who could not like it? It is one of the great works of modern art. I will give you whatever you want for it. It must be mine.

en: “It is not my property, Harry.”
vi: “Nó không thuộc sở hữu của tôi, Harry.”
tr: “Resim bana ait değil ki, Harry.
es: —No soy yo su dueño, Harry.
vi_translation: “It does not belong to me, Harry.”
tr_translation: “The painting doesn't belong to me, Harry.”
es_translation: —I am not its owner, Harry.

en: “Whose property is it?”
vi: “Thế nó thuộc sở hữu của ai?”
tr: “Kime ait?
es: —¿Quién es el propietario?
vi_translation: "So, who owns it?"
tr_translation: "Whose is it?"
es_translation: —Who is the owner?

en: “Dorian’s, of course,” answered the painter.
vi: “Của Dorian, đương nhiên,” họa sỹ trả lời.
tr: “Elbette ki Dorian’a,” diye yanıtladı ressam.
es: —Dorian, por supuesto —respondió el pintor.
vi_translation: “Dorian's, of course,” the artist replied.
tr_translation: “Of course to Dorian,” replied the painter.
es_translation: —Dorian, of course —replied the painter.

en: “He is a very lucky fellow.”
vi: “Cậu ấy là một anh chàng rất may mắn.”
tr: “Çok şanslı çocukmuş.
es: —Es muy afortunado.
vi_translation: “He is a very lucky young man.”
tr_translation: “He was a very lucky child.”
es_translation: —He is very fortunate.

en: “How sad it is!” murmured Dorian Gray with his eyes still fixed upon his own portrait. “How sad it is! I shall grow old, and horrible, and dreadful. But this picture will remain always young. It will never be older than this particular day of June.... If it were only the other way! If it were I who was to be always young, and the picture that was to grow old! For that—for that—I would give everything! Yes, there is nothing in the whole world I would not give! I would give my soul for that!”
vi: “Buồn làm sao!” Dorian Gray thì thầm, mắt vẫn dán vào bức chân dung chính mình. “Buồn làm sao! Tôi sẽ dần dần trở nên già nua, xấu xí, kinh tởm. Nhưng bức tranh này sẽ còn trẻ mãi. Nó sẽ chẳng bao giờ bị già hơn cái ngày đặc biệt này của tháng Sáu… Giá mà còn cách khác! Giá mà tôi mới là kẻ trẻ mãi còn bức tranh ấy mới bị già đi! Vì điều ấy — vì điều ấy — tôi có thể cho đi mọi thứ! Vâng, chẳng có gì trên khắp thế gian này mà tôi không thể cho đi! Tôi sẽ cho đi cả linh hồn mình vì điều ấy!”
tr: Dorian Gray, “Ne hazin!” diye mırıldandı gözlerini kendi portresinden ayırmadan. “Ne hazin şey! İhtiyarlayıp çirkinleşeceğim, iğrenç olacağım. Oysa bu resim sonsuza dek genç kalacak. Şu haziran günündeki yaşından öteye hiç gitmeyecek... Öbür türlü olabilseydi! Sonsuza dek genç kalan ben, ihtiyarlayansa şu resim olsaydı! Bu uğurda... Bu uğurda her şeyimi verirdim! Evet, koca dünyada vermeyeceğim hiçbir şey yok! Ruhumu bile satarım bu uğurda!
es: —¡Qué triste resulta! —murmuró Dorian Gray, los ojos todavía fijos en el retrato—. Me haré viejo, horrible, espantoso. Pero este cuadro siempre será joven. Nunca dejará atrás este día de junio... ¡Si fuese al revés! ¡Si yo me conservase siempre joven y el retrato envejeciera! Daría..., ¡daría cualquier cosa por eso! ¡Daría el alma!
vi_translation: “How sad it is!” Dorian Gray whispered, his eyes still fixed on the portrait of himself. “How sad it is! I will gradually grow old, ugly, and horrible. But this picture will remain young forever. It will never be older than this particular day in June… If only there were another way! If only I could stay young and the picture would grow old! For that — for that — I would give everything! Yes, there is nothing in the whole world that I would not give! I would give my soul for that!”
tr_translation: Dorian Gray murmured, "How sad!" without taking his eyes off his own portrait. "How sad it is! I will grow old and become ugly, I will be hideous. Yet this picture will remain young forever. It will never be older than this June day... If only it could be the other way around! If I could remain young forever, and this picture would grow old! For that... I would give everything for that! Yes, there is nothing in the whole world I wouldn't give! I would even sell my soul for that!"
es_translation: —How sad it is! —murmured Dorian Gray, his eyes still fixed on the portrait—. I will grow old, horrible, dreadful. But this picture will always remain young. It will never be older than this particular day of June... If it were only the other way around! If I could always stay young and the picture grow old! I would give..., I would give anything for that! I would give my soul!

en: “You would hardly care for such an arrangement, Basil,” cried Lord Henry, laughing. “It would be rather hard lines on your work.”
vi: “Anh sẽ khó mà lo được cho một dàn xếp như thế, Basil,” huân tước Henry kêu lên, cười. “Nó sẽ thành vận rủi trong tác phẩm của anh.”
tr: Lord Henry gülerek, “Basil, böyle bir pazarlık senin işine gelmezdi,” dedi. “Yapıtına haksızlık olurdu.
es: —No creo que te gustara mucho esa solución, Basil —exclamó lord Henry, riendo—. Sería bastante inclemente con tu obra.
vi_translation: "You will hardly be able to arrange such a setup, Basil," Lord Henry exclaimed, laughing. "It will become a misfortune in your work."
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed and said, "Basil, such a bargain would not suit you." "It would be unfair to your work."
es_translation: —I don't think you would like that solution very much, Basil —exclaimed Lord Henry, laughing—. It would be quite unkind to your work.

en: “I should object very strongly, Harry,” said Hallward.
vi: “Chắc tôi sẽ phản đối đến cùng đấy, Harry,” Hallward nói.
tr: Ressam, “Var gücümle karşı çıkardım zaten, Harry,” diye yanıtladı.
es: —Me opondría con la mayor energía posible, Harry —dijo Hallward.
vi_translation: "I will probably oppose it to the end, Harry," Hallward said.
tr_translation: The painter replied, "I would have already opposed it with all my might, Harry."
es_translation: —I would oppose it with the greatest possible energy, Harry —said Hallward.

en: Dorian Gray turned and looked at him. “I believe you would, Basil. You like your art better than your friends. I am no more to you than a green bronze figure. Hardly as much, I dare say.”
vi: Dorian Gray quay qua nhìn y. “Tôi tin là anh sẽ thế, Basil. Anh thích nghệ thuật của mình hơn bạn bè anh. Anh coi tôi không hơn gì một hình nhân bằng đồng ngả màu xanh lục. Khó mà bằng được, tôi dám nói vậy.”
tr: Dorian Gray dönüp ona baktı. “İnanırım buna, Basil. Sen sanatını dostlarından üstün tutuyorsun Senin gözünde bronz bir heykelden farkım yok benim. O kadar bile değerim yoktur ya!
es: Dorian Gray se volvió para mirarlo. —Estoy seguro de que lo harías. Tu arte te importa más que los amigos. Para ti no soy más que una figurilla de bronce. Ni siquiera eso, me atrevería a decir.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray turned to look at him. "I believe you will, Basil. You love your art more than your friends. You see me as nothing more than a bronze statue turning green. It's hard to match that, I dare say."
tr_translation: Dorian Gray turned and looked at him. "I believe it, Basil. You value your art above your friends. In your eyes, I am no different from a bronze statue. I am not even worth that much!"
es_translation: Dorian Gray turned to look at him. —I am sure you would. Your art matters more to you than friends. To you, I am nothing more than a little bronze figurine. Not even that, I would dare to say.

en: The painter stared in amazement. It was so unlike Dorian to speak like that. What had happened? He seemed quite angry. His face was flushed and his cheeks burning.
vi: Họa sỹ nhìn chằm chằm kinh ngạc. Không giống như là Dorian đã nói như vậy. Chuyện gì đã xảy ra? Cậu dường như khá giận. Mặt cậu đỏ bừng và má cậu rực lên.
tr: Ressam şaşkınlıklar içinde bakakalmıştı. Böyle bir konuşma Dorian Gray’den hiç umulmayacak bir şeydi. Ne olmuştu? Delikanlı enikonu öfkeli görünüyordu Yüzüne kan basmış, yanakları yanıyordu.
es: El pintor se lo quedó mirando, asombrado. Dorian no hablaba nunca así. ¿Qué había sucedido? Parecía muy enfadado. Tenía el rostro encendido y le ardían las mejillas.
vi_translation: The artist stared in astonishment. It did not seem like Dorian had said that. What had happened? You seemed quite angry. Your face was flushed and your cheeks were glowing.
tr_translation: The painter was left staring in astonishment. Such a conversation was something completely unexpected from Dorian Gray. What had happened? The young man looked quite angry. Blood had rushed to his face, and his cheeks were burning.
es_translation: The painter stared at him, astonished. Dorian never spoke like that. What had happened? He seemed very angry. His face was flushed and his cheeks were burning.

en: “Yes,” he continued, “I am less to you than your ivory Hermes or your silver Faun. You will like them always. How long will you like me? Till I have my first wrinkle, I suppose. I know, now, that when one loses one’s good looks, whatever they may be, one loses everything. Your picture has taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton is perfectly right. Youth is the only thing worth having. When I find that I am growing old, I shall kill myself.”
vi: “Vâng,” cậu nói tiếp, “Anh coi tôi không bằng thần Hermes ngà voi hoặc thần Faun bạc trắng của anh. Anh sẽ thích chúng mãi. Anh sẽ thích tôi được bao lâu? Cho đến khi tôi có nếp nhăn đầu tiên, tôi cho là thế. Giờ thì tôi đã biết là khi người ta mất đi các nét đẹp của mình, dẫu chúng có thế nào, thì người ta cũng sẽ mất hết mọi thứ. Bức tranh của anh dạy tôi thế. Huân tước Henry Wotton hoàn toàn đúng. Tuổi xuân là thứ duy nhất đáng giá. Khi tôi thấy mình già đi, tôi sẽ tự sát.”
tr: “Evet,” diye konuşmasını sürdürdü. “Senin gözünde ben o fildişi Hermes’inden, o gümüş Fauna’ndan bile daha önemsizim. Onları ömür boyu seveceksin. Ya beni ne kadar seveceksin? Yüzümde ilk kırışık belirinceye kadar, herhalde. Şimdi öğrendim artık: Kişi güzelliğini yitirince her şeyi yitirmiş oluyor. Senin çizdiğin portre öğretti bunu bana. Lord Henry Wotton yüzde yüz haklı. Sahip olunmaya değer tek şey gençliktir. İhtiyarlamaya başladığımı gördüğüm zaman kendimi öldüreceğim.
es: —Sí —continuó el joven—: para ti soy menos que tu Hermes de marfil o tu fauno de plata. Ésos te gustarán siempre. ¿Hasta cuándo te gustaré yo? Hasta que me salga la primera arruga. Ahora ya sé que cuando se pierde la belleza, mucha o poca, se pierde todo. Tu cuadro me lo ha enseñado. Lord Henry Wotton tiene razón. La juventud es lo único que merece la pena. Cuando descubra que envejezco, me mataré.
vi_translation: “Yes,” he continued, “You regard me as less than your ivory Hermes or your silver Faun. You will always like them. How long will you like me? Until I get my first wrinkle, I suppose. Now I know that when one loses their beauty, whatever it may be, they lose everything. Your painting taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton was absolutely right. Youth is the only thing worth having. When I see myself growing old, I will kill myself.”
tr_translation: “Yes,” he continued speaking. “In your eyes, I am even less important than that ivory Hermes, that silver Faun. You will love them for a lifetime. How long will you love me? Probably until the first wrinkle appears on my face. Now I have learned: When a person loses their beauty, they lose everything. Your portrait taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton is absolutely right. The only thing worth having is youth. When I see that I am starting to age, I will kill myself.”
es_translation: —Yes —continued the young man—: to you, I am less than your ivory Hermes or your silver faun. Those you will always like. How long will you like me? Until I get my first wrinkle. Now I know that when beauty is lost, whether much or little, everything is lost. Your painting has taught me that. Lord Henry Wotton is right. Youth is the only thing worth having. When I discover that I am aging, I will kill myself.

en: Hallward turned pale and caught his hand. “Dorian! Dorian!” he cried, “don’t talk like that. I have never had such a friend as you, and I shall never have such another. You are not jealous of material things, are you?—you who are finer than any of them!”
vi: Hallward tái mặt, nắm lấy tay cậu. “Dorian! Dorian!” y kêu lên, “đừng nói vậy. Tôi chưa bao giờ có người bạn nào như cậu, và tôi sẽ không bao giờ có người khác như thế. Cậu không ghen với những vật hữu hình đấy chứ, phải không? — cậu đẹp hơn bất cứ cái nào trong số chúng!”
tr: Hallward sapsarı kesilerek gencin elini tuttu. “Dorian!” diye bağırdı. “Dorian, konuşma böyle. Benim daha önce senin gibi arkadaşım olmadı, bundan sonra da olmayacak. Maddi, dünyevî şeyleri kıskanmaya kalkışmıyorsun, değil mi? Sen ki onların hepsinden daha üstünsün.
es: Hallward palideció y le tomó la mano. —¡Dorian! ¡Dorian! —exclamó—, no hables así. Nunca he tenido un amigo como tú, ni tendré nunca otro. No me digas que sientes celos de las cosas materiales. ¡Tú estás por encima de todas ellas!
vi_translation: Hallward turned pale, grasping his hand. "Dorian! Dorian!" he cried, "don't say that. I've never had a friend like you, and I never will have another like that. You're not jealous of those tangible things, are you? — you're more beautiful than any of them!”
tr_translation: Hallward turned pale and grasped the young man's hand. “Dorian!” he cried. “Dorian, don't talk like that. I've never had a friend like you before, and I never will again. You're not trying to envy material, worldly things, are you? You are above all of them.”
es_translation: Hallward paled and took his hand. —Dorian! Dorian! —he exclaimed—, don't speak like that. I've never had a friend like you, nor will I ever have another. Don't tell me you're jealous of material things. You are above all of them!

en: “I am jealous of everything whose beauty does not die. I am jealous of the portrait you have painted of me. Why should it keep what I must lose? Every moment that passes takes something from me and gives something to it. Oh, if it were only the other way! If the picture could change, and I could be always what I am now! Why did you paint it? It will mock me some day—mock me horribly!” The hot tears welled into his eyes; he tore his hand away and, flinging himself on the divan, he buried his face in the cushions, as though he was praying.
vi: “Tôi ghen với mọi thứ có sắc đẹp bất tử. Tôi ghen với bức chân dung anh đã vẽ tôi. Tại sao nó có thể giữ lại được những gì tôi phải mất đi? Mỗi khoảnh khắc trôi qua sẽ lấy cái gì đó khỏi tôi, và cho nó cái gì đó. Ôi, giá như có cách khác! Nếu bức tranh có thể thay đổi, còn tôi có thể mãi là tôi lúc này! Tại sao anh lại vẽ nó? Nó sẽ chế nhạo tôi vào một ngày nào đó — chế nhạo tôi một cách khủng khiếp!” Những giọt lệ nóng hổi dâng lên mắt cậu; cậu giật tay ra, và, buông mình xuống đi-văng, cậu vùi mặt vào nệm, như thể đang cầu nguyện.
tr: “Güzelliği ölmeyen her şeyi kıskanıyorum. Senin çizdiğin portremi kıskanıyorum. Benim yitirdiğim şeyi o neden saklasın ki! Geçen her dakika benden bir şey eksiltirken ona bir şeyler ekliyor. Ah, öbür türlü olabilseydi! Değişen şu resim olsaydı da ben olduğum gibi kalabilseydim! Neden yaptın sanki bunu? Gün gelecek benimle alay edecek bu resim, feci şekilde alay edecek!” Gözlerine sıcacık yaşlar dolmuştu. Elini koparırcasına çekti, kendini divanın üstüne atarak yüzünü, dua eder gibi, yastıklara gömdü.
es: —Tengo celos de todo aquello cuya belleza no muere. Tengo celos de mi retrato. ¿Por qué ha de conservar lo que yo voy a perder? Cada momento que pasa me quita algo para dárselo a él. ¡Ah, si fuese al revés! ¡Si el cuadro pudiera cambiar y ser yo siempre como ahora! ¿Para qué lo has pintado? Se burlará de mí algún día, ¡se burlará despiadadamente! Los ojos se le llenaron de lágrimas ardientes; retiró bruscamente la mano y, arrojándose sobre el diván, enterró el rostro entre los cojines, como si estuviera rezando.
vi_translation: “I am jealous of everything that has immortal beauty. I am jealous of the portrait you painted of me. Why can it retain what I must lose? Every passing moment takes something from me and gives something to it. Oh, if only there were another way! If the painting could change, and I could remain as I am now! Why did you paint it? One day it will mock me — mock me terribly!” Hot tears welled up in his eyes; he pulled his hand away, and, throwing himself onto the couch, he buried his face in the cushion, as if in prayer.
tr_translation: “I envy everything whose beauty does not die. I envy the portrait you drew. Why should it keep what I have lost! Every passing minute takes something away from me while adding something to it. Ah, if only it could be the other way around! If only the picture changed and I could remain as I am! Why did you do this? One day this picture will mock me, mock me terribly!” Tears filled his eyes. He pulled his hand away as if tearing it off, threw himself onto the couch, and buried his face in the pillows as if praying.
es_translation: —I am jealous of everything whose beauty does not die. I am jealous of my portrait. Why should it keep what I am going to lose? Every moment that passes takes something from me to give it to him. Ah, if it were the other way around! If the painting could change and I could always remain as I am now! Why did you paint it? It will mock me someday, it will mock me mercilessly! His eyes filled with burning tears; he abruptly withdrew his hand and, throwing himself onto the divan, buried his face among the cushions, as if he were praying.

en: “This is your doing, Harry,” said the painter bitterly.
vi: “Chuyện này là do anh gây ra đấy, Harry,” họa sỹ nói, cay đắng.
tr: Ressam acı acı, “Bu senin marifetin, Harry!” dedi.
es: —Esto es obra tuya, Harry —dijo el pintor con amargura.
vi_translation: "This is your doing, Harry," the artist said bitterly.
tr_translation: The painter bitterly said, "This is your doing, Harry!"
es_translation: —This is your doing, Harry —said the painter bitterly.

en: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “It is the real Dorian Gray—that is all.”
vi: Huân tước Henry nhún vai. “Đó là Dorian Gray thật — đấy chỉ có vậy thôi.
tr: Lord Henry omuz silkti. “Karşımızdaki gerçek Dorian Gray... Hepsi bu.
es: Lord Henry se encogió de hombros. —Es el verdadero Dorian Gray, eso es todo.
vi_translation: Lord Henry shrugged. "That is Dorian Gray — that's all."
tr_translation: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “The real Dorian Gray before us... That's all.”
es_translation: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. —It is the real Dorian Gray, that's all.

en: “It is not.”
vi: “Không phải.”
tr: “Değil işte!
es: —No lo es.
vi_translation: "No."
tr_translation: “It is not!”
es_translation: —It is not.

en: “If it is not, what have I to do with it?”
vi: “Nếu không phải, thì tôi liên quan gì?”
tr: “Değilse ne peki?
es: —Si no lo es, ¿qué tengo yo que ver con eso?
vi_translation: “If not, then what do I have to do with it?”
tr_translation: “If not, then what?”
es_translation: —If it isn't, what do I have to do with that?

en: “You should have gone away when I asked you,” he muttered.
vi: “Lẽ ra anh nên đi khi tôi xin anh,” y lẩm bẩm.
tr: Ressam, “Rica ettiğim zaman gidecektin,” diye söylendi.
es: —Deberías haberte marchado cuando te lo pedí —murmuró.
vi_translation: “You should have left when I asked you,” he muttered.
tr_translation: The painter muttered, "You were supposed to leave when I asked."
es_translation: —You should have left when I asked you to —he murmured.

en: “I stayed when you asked me,” was Lord Henry’s answer.
vi: “Tôi đã ở lại khi anh xin tôi,” là câu trả lời của huân tước Henry.
tr: Lord Henry, “Rica ettiğinde kaldım,” diye yanıtladı.
es: —Me quedé cuando me lo pediste —fue la respuesta de lord Henry.
vi_translation: “I stayed when you asked me,” was Lord Henry's reply.
tr_translation: Lord Henry replied, "I stayed when you asked."
es_translation: —I stayed when you asked me to —was Lord Henry's reply.

en: “Harry, I can’t quarrel with my two best friends at once, but between you both you have made me hate the finest piece of work I have ever done, and I will destroy it. What is it but canvas and colour? I will not let it come across our three lives and mar them.”
vi: “Harry, tôi không thể cãi cọ với hai người bạn thân nhất của mình cùng lúc, những nói riêng giữa hai người các anh thôi nhé, các anh đã khiến tôi ghét tác phẩm đẹp nhất mà tôi từng thực hiện được, và tôi sẽ hủy nó. Nó có là gì đâu ngoài toan và màu? Tôi sẽ không để nó xen vào ba cuộc đời của chúng ta và làm hỏng chúng.”
tr: “Harry, en iyi iki dostumun ikisiyle birden kavgaya tutuşamam, ne var ki ikiniz birlik oldunuz, en iyi yapıtımdan beni soğuttunuz; ben de bu resmi ortadan kaldıracağım. Ne ki zaten, tuvalle boyadan ibaret değil mi? Üçümüzün birden hayatımıza gölge düşürüp yara açmasına izin veremem.
es: —Harry, no me puedo pelear al mismo tiempo con mis dos mejores amigos, pero entre los dos me habéis hecho odiar la más perfecta de mis obras, y voy a destruirla. ¿Qué es, después de todo, excepto lienzo y color? No voy a permitir que un retrato se interponga entre nosotros.
vi_translation: "Harry, I can't argue with my two best friends at the same time, but just between the two of you, you have made me hate the most beautiful work I have ever created, and I will destroy it. What is it but canvas and paint? I will not let it interfere with our three lives and ruin them."
tr_translation: “Harry, I can't get into a fight with both of my best friends at once, but you two have teamed up and made me lose my passion for my best work; so I will destroy this painting. But after all, isn't it just canvas and paint? I can't allow it to cast a shadow and wound all three of our lives.”
es_translation: —Harry, I can't fight with my two best friends at the same time, but between the two of you, you have made me hate the most perfect of my works, and I am going to destroy it. What is it, after all, except canvas and color? I will not allow a portrait to come between us.

en: Dorian Gray lifted his golden head from the pillow, and with pallid face and tear-stained eyes, looked at him as he walked over to the deal painting-table that was set beneath the high curtained window. What was he doing there? His fingers were straying about among the litter of tin tubes and dry brushes, seeking for something. Yes, it was for the long palette-knife, with its thin blade of lithe steel. He had found it at last. He was going to rip up the canvas.
vi: Dorian Gray nhấc mái đầu vàng óng lên khỏi gối, và, với khuôn mặt tái nhợt cùng đôi mắt hoen lệ, nhìn y, trong lúc y bước đến cái bàn vẽ gỗ thông kê dưới ô cửa sổ cao buông màn. Y đang làm gì ở đó? Các ngón tay y lang thang giữa đống bề bộn tuýp thiếc và bút khô, tìm kiếm gì đó. Vâng, tìm con dao trộn màu dài thượt, với lưỡi mảnh và thép mềm. Rốt cuộc y tìm được nó. Y sẽ rạch nát tấm toan.
tr: Dorian Gray o altın başını yastıktan kaldırdı, solgun yüzü, ıslanmış gözleriyle Basil’in pencerenin önünde duran çam tuvaline doğru yürümesine baktı. Ne yapıyordu ressam orada? Parmakları, karman çorman duran teneke tüplerin, kuru fırçaların arasında bir şeyler arayarak dolaşıyordu. Evet, esnek, ince çelikten yapılma o uzun falçatayı aramaktaydı. İşte, bulmuştu sonunda. Tuvali kesip doğrayacaktı.
es: Dorian Gray alzó la rubia cabeza del cojín y, con el rostro pálido y los ojos enrojecidos por las lágrimas lo miró, mientras Hallward se dirigía hacia la mesa de madera situada bajo la alta ventana con cortinas. ¿Qué había ido a hacer allí? Los dedos se perdían entre el revoltijo de tubos de estaño y pinceles secos, buscando algo. Sí, el largo cuchillo apaletado, con su delgada hoja de acero flexible. Una vez encontrado, se disponía a rasgar la tela.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray lifted his golden head from the pillow, and, with a pale face and tear-stained eyes, looked at him, while he walked to the pine drawing table under the tall, curtained window. What was he doing there? His fingers wandered among the clutter of tin tubes and dry brushes, searching for something. Yes, searching for the long palette knife, with its thin, soft steel blade. At last he found it. He would slash the canvas.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray lifted his golden head from the pillow and watched with his pale face and tearful eyes as Basil walked towards the pine easel standing by the window. What was the painter doing there? His fingers were moving around, searching for something among the tangled tin tubes and dry brushes. Yes, he was looking for that long palette knife made of flexible, thin steel. There, he had finally found it. He was going to cut and slice the canvas.
es_translation: Dorian Gray lifted his blond head from the cushion and, with a pale face and eyes red from tears, looked at him as Hallward walked towards the wooden table situated under the high curtained window. What had he gone there to do? His fingers got lost among the jumble of tin tubes and dry brushes, searching for something. Yes, the long palette knife, with its thin, flexible steel blade. . Once found, he was about to slash the canvas.

en: With a stifled sob the lad leaped from the couch, and, rushing over to Hallward, tore the knife out of his hand, and flung it to the end of the studio. “Don’t, Basil, don’t!” he cried. “It would be murder!”
vi: Với tiếng nức nở nghẹn ngào, chàng trai nhảy khỏi đi-văng, và, lao đến Hallward, giật con dao khỏi tay y, quăng nó qua đầu bên kia xưởng vẽ. “Đừng, Basil, đừng!” cậu hét lên. “Thế là tội sát nhân!”
tr: Dorian boğuk bir hıçkırıkla yerinden fırladı, Hallward’ın üstüne atılarak bıçağı elinden kaptığı gibi stüdyonun karşı köşesine fırlattı. “Yapma, Basil, yapma!” diye bağırıyordu. “Cinayet olur bu!
es: Ahogando un gemido, el muchacho saltó del diván y, corriendo hacia Hallward, le arrancó el cuchillo de la mano, arrojándolo al otro extremo del estudio. —¡No, Basil, no lo hagas! —exclamó—. ¡Sería un asesinato!
vi_translation: With a sobbing cry, the young man jumped off the couch, and, rushing to Hallward, snatched the knife from his hand, throwing it to the other side of the studio. "Don't, Basil, don't!" he shouted. "That's murder!"
tr_translation: Dorian sprang up with a choked sob, leaping onto Hallward and snatching the knife from his hand, then hurling it to the opposite corner of the studio. "Don't do it, Basil, don't do it!" he was shouting. "This would be murder!"
es_translation: Stifling a groan, the boy jumped off the divan and, running towards Hallward, snatched the knife from his hand, throwing it to the other end of the studio. —No, Basil, don't do it! —he exclaimed—. It would be murder!

en: “I am glad you appreciate my work at last, Dorian,” said the painter coldly when he had recovered from his surprise. “I never thought you would.”
vi: “Tôi vui vì rốt cuộc cậu đã đánh giá cao tác phẩm của tôi, Dorian,” họa sỹ nói, lạnh lùng, khi y trấn tĩnh lại sau cơn bất ngờ. “Tôi không bao giờ nghĩ là cậu lại thế.”
tr: Ressam, şaşkınlığı geçtiği zaman soğuk soğuk, “Sonunda yaptığım resmin değerini bilmene sevindim, Dorian,” dedi. “Hiç bilmeyeceksin sanmıştım.
es: —Me alegro de que por fin aprecies mi obra, Dorian —dijo fríamente el pintor, una vez recuperado de la sorpresa—. Había perdido la esperanza.
vi_translation: "I am glad that you have finally appreciated my work, Dorian," the artist said coldly, as he calmed down after the surprise. "I never thought you would."
tr_translation: When the painter's astonishment passed, he said coldly, "I'm glad you finally appreciate the value of the painting I made, Dorian." "I thought you would never know.""
es_translation: —I'm glad that you finally appreciate my work, Dorian —said the painter coldly, once he had recovered from the surprise—. I had lost hope.

en: “Appreciate it? I am in love with it, Basil. It is part of myself. I feel that.”
vi: “Đánh giá cao ư? Tôi phải lòng nó, Basil. Nó là một phần của chính tôi. Tôi cảm thấy thế.”
tr: “Değerini bilmek mi? Ben bu resme vurgunum, Basil. Benim varlığımın bir parçası bu. Öyle geliyor bana.
es: —¿Apreciarla? Me fascina. Es parte de mí mismo. Lo noto.
vi_translation: "Appreciate it? I am in love with it, Basil. It is a part of myself. That's how I feel."
tr_translation: "Appreciate its value? I'm infatuated with this painting, Basil. It's a part of my existence. That's how it feels to me. "
es_translation: —Appreciate it? It fascinates me. It's part of myself. I notice it.

en: “Well, as soon as you are dry, you shall be varnished, and framed, and sent home. Then you can do what you like with yourself.” And he walked across the room and rang the bell for tea. “You will have tea, of course, Dorian? And so will you, Harry? Or do you object to such simple pleasures?”
vi: “Được rồi, ngay khi cậu đã khô, cậu sẽ được phủ véc-ni, lên khung, và gửi về nhà. Sau đó cậu có thể làm gì cậu thích với chính mình.” Và y bước ngang qua phòng rồi rung chuông gọi trà. “Cậu sẽ dùng trà chứ, Dorian? Và anh cũng sẽ vậy chứ, Harry? Hay anh phản đối cả những niềm vui đơn sơ như vậy?”
tr: “Peki öyleyse, boyalarım kurur kurumaz üstüne bir cila geçeceğim, sonra çerçeveleyip evine yollayacağım. O zaman istediğini yaparsın kendine.” Böyle diyen ressam kapıya doğru yürüdü, çay istemek için çıngırağı çaldı. “Çaya kalacaksın, değil mi, Dorian? Sen de kalır mısın, Harry? Yoksa böyle küçük keyiflere karşı mı çıkarsın?
es: —Bien; tan pronto como estés seco, serás barnizado y enmarcado y enviado a tu casa. Una vez allí, podrás hacer contigo lo que quieras —cruzando la estancia tocó la campanilla para pedir té—. ¿Tomarás té, como es lógico, Dorian? ¿Y tú también, Harry? ¿O estás en contra de placeres tan sencillos?
vi_translation: "Alright, as soon as you are dry, you will be varnished, framed, and sent home. After that, you can do whatever you like with yourself." And he walked across the room and rang the bell for tea. "Will you have some tea, Dorian? And you too, Harry? Or do you object to even such simple pleasures?"
tr_translation: “Well then, as soon as my paints dry, I will apply a varnish over it, then frame it and send it to your home. Then you can do whatever you want with it.” Saying this, the painter walked towards the door and rang the bell to ask for tea. “You will stay for tea, won't you, Dorian? Will you stay too, Harry? Or do you object to such small pleasures?”
es_translation: —Alright; as soon as you are dry, you will be varnished and framed and sent to your home. Once there, you can do with yourself whatever you want —crossing the room, he rang the bell to order tea—. Will you have tea, as is logical, Dorian? And you too, Harry? Or are you against such simple pleasures?

en: “I adore simple pleasures,” said Lord Henry. “They are the last refuge of the complex. But I don’t like scenes, except on the stage. What absurd fellows you are, both of you! I wonder who it was defined man as a rational animal. It was the most premature definition ever given. Man is many things, but he is not rational. I am glad he is not, after all—though I wish you chaps would not squabble over the picture. You had much better let me have it, Basil. This silly boy doesn’t really want it, and I really do.”
vi: “Tôi ngưỡng mộ những niềm vui đơn sơ,” huân tước Henry nói. “Chúng là nơi ẩn náu cuối cùng của sự rắc rối. Nhưng tôi không thích cảnh cãi cọ, không kể trên sân khấu. Các anh là những kẻ lố bịch làm sao, cả hai anh! Tôi tự hỏi ai đã định nghĩa con người là sinh vật có lý trí. Đó là định nghĩa vội vã nhất từng được đưa ra. Con người là rất nhiều thứ, nhưng nó không phải là có lý trí. Tôi vui vì rốt cuộc thì nó không thế: mặc dù tôi mong hai gã các anh không cãi lộn vì bức tranh. Anh nên để tôi sở hữu nó thì hơn, Basil. Cậu bé ngờ nghệch này không thật sự muốn nó, còn tôi thì thật sự muốn.”
tr: “Küçük keyiflere bayılırım ben,” dedi Lord Henry. “Karmaşık ruhların son sığınağıdır onlar. Yalnız ben, sahne dışında oynanan tiyatro sahnelerini sevmem. Ne gülünç çocuklarsınız, ikiniz de! İnsana mantıklı hayvan, tanımını yakıştıran kimdi acaba? Dünyanın en zamansız aceleyle yakıştırılmış tanımı bu. İnsanoğlu şöyle ya da böyle olabilir, gelgelelim mantıklı değildir. Olmadığına da seviniyorum aslında; gene de bu resmin başında çekişmenizi istemiyorum. Basil, en iyisi sen bana ver şunu. Bu sersem portreyi istemiyor aslında, oysa ben gerçekten istiyorum.
es: —Adoro los placeres sencillos —dijo lord Henry—. Son el último refugio de las almas complicadas. Pero no me gustan las escenas, excepto en el teatro. ¡Qué personas tan absurdas sois los dos! Me pregunto quién definió al hombre como animal racional. Fue la definición más prematura que se ha dado nunca. El hombre es muchas cosas, pero no racional. Y me alegro de ello después de todo: aunque me gustaría que no os pelearais por el cuadro. Será mucho mejor que me lo des a mí, Basil. Este pobre chico no lo quiere en realidad, y yo en cambio sí.
vi_translation: “I admire simple pleasures,” Lord Henry said. “They are the last refuge of the complex. But I do not like scenes, except on the stage. How ridiculous you both are! I wonder who defined man as a rational animal. It was the most hasty definition ever given. Man is many things, but he is not rational. I am glad he is not, after all: though I wish you two would not quarrel over the picture. You had better let me have it, Basil. This silly boy doesn’t really want it, and I really do.”
tr_translation: “I adore small pleasures,” said Lord Henry. “They are the last refuge of complex souls. But I do not like theater scenes played offstage. How ridiculous you both are! I wonder who first called man a rational animal? It is the most premature definition ever given. Man can be many things, but rational is not one of them. And I am glad he is not; still, I do not want you quarreling over this painting. Basil, you better give it to me. He does not actually want this silly portrait, whereas I truly do.”
es_translation: —I adore simple pleasures —said Lord Henry—. They are the last refuge of complex souls. But I do not like scenes, except in the theater. How absurd you both are! I wonder who defined man as a rational animal. It was the most premature definition ever given. Man is many things, but not rational. And I am glad of it after all: although I would like you not to fight over the painting. It would be much better if you gave it to me, Basil. This poor boy doesn't really want it, and I do.

en: “If you let any one have it but me, Basil, I shall never forgive you!” cried Dorian Gray; “and I don’t allow people to call me a silly boy.”
vi: “Nếu anh để cho bất cứ ai có nó ngoài tôi, Basil, tôi sẽ không bao giờ tha thứ cho anh!” Dorian Gray kêu lên; “và tôi không cho phép mọi người gọi tôi là một cậu bé ngờ nghệch.
tr: Dorian Gray, “Basil, bunu benden başkasına verirsen seni dünyada affetmem!” diye bağırdı. “Kimsenin bana, sersem demesine de izin vermem!
es: —¡Si se lo das a otra persona, no te lo perdonaré nunca! —exclamó Dorian Gray—; y no permito que nadie me llame pobre chico.
vi_translation: “If you let anyone else have it besides me, Basil, I will never forgive you!” Dorian Gray exclaimed; “and I do not allow people to call me a foolish boy.”
tr_translation: Dorian Gray shouted, "Basil, if you give this to anyone else, I will never forgive you in this world!" "I also won't allow anyone to call me a fool!"
es_translation: —If you give it to another person, I will never forgive you! —exclaimed Dorian Gray—; and I do not allow anyone to call me poor boy.

en: “You know the picture is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it existed.”
vi: “Cậu biết là bức tranh là của cậu mà, Dorian. Tôi đã tặng nó cho cậu trước khi nó tồn tại.”
tr: “Bu resim senin, Dorian, biliyorsun. Daha ortada yokken verdim onu sana.
es: —Ya sabes que el cuadro es tuyo, Dorian. Te lo di antes de que existiera.
vi_translation: "You know the painting is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it even existed."
tr_translation: "This painting is yours, Dorian, you know that. I gave it to you before it even existed."
es_translation: —You know that the painting is yours, Dorian. I gave it to you before it even existed.

en: “And you know you have been a little silly, Mr. Gray, and that you don’t really object to being reminded that you are extremely young.”
vi: “Và cậu biết cậu từng là một thằng bé ngờ nghệch, mít-tơ Gray, và rằng cậu không thật sự cảm thấy khó chịu vì bị nhắc rằng cậu cực kỳ trẻ.”
tr: “Biraz saçma davrandığınızı da biliyorsunuz mr Gray. Çok genç olduğunuzun vurgulanmasına da itirazınız yok aslında.
es: —Y también sabe usted, señor Gray, que se ha dejado llevar por los sentimientos y que en realidad no le parece mal que se le recuerde cuán joven es.
vi_translation: “And you know you used to be a naive boy, Mr. Gray, and that you don't really feel upset about being reminded that you are extremely young.”
tr_translation: “You also know that you are acting a bit silly, Mr. Gray. You actually have no objection to the emphasis on your youth.”
es_translation: —And you also know, Mr. Gray, that you have let yourself be carried away by your feelings and that, in reality, you do not mind being reminded of how young you are.

en: “I should have objected very strongly this morning, Lord Henry.”
vi: “Lẽ ra tôi nên cảm thấy vô cùng khó chịu sáng nay, huân tước Henry.”
tr: “Bu sabah olsa şiddetle itiraz ederdim, Lord Henry.
es: —Me hubiera parecido francamente mal esta mañana, lord Henry.
vi_translation: "I should have felt extremely uncomfortable this morning, Lord Henry."
tr_translation: “If it were this morning, I would strongly object, Lord Henry.”
es_translation: —It would have seemed frankly wrong to me this morning, Lord Henry.

en: “Ah! this morning! You have lived since then.”
vi: “Ôi! Sáng nay! Cậu đã sống qua cái lúc ấy.”
tr: “Ha! Bu sabah! O zamandan beri bir ömür yaşadınız.
es: —¡Ah, esta mañana! Ha vivido usted mucho desde entonces.
vi_translation: "Oh! This morning! You lived through that moment."
tr_translation: “Ha! This morning! You have lived a lifetime since then.”
es_translation: —Ah, this morning! You have lived a lot since then.

en: There came a knock at the door, and the butler entered with a laden tea-tray and set it down upon a small Japanese table. There was a rattle of cups and saucers and the hissing of a fluted Georgian urn. Two globe-shaped china dishes were brought in by a page. Dorian Gray went over and poured out the tea. The two men sauntered languidly to the table and examined what was under the covers.
vi: Có tiếng gõ cửa, quản gia bước vào với khay trà nặng trĩu và đặt nó xuống chiếc bàn Nhật nhỏ. Có tiếng tách đĩa lách cách và tiếng huýt gió của bình trà cổ xẻ rãnh thời George. Hai thố sứ hình cầu được một chú bồi mang vào. Dorian Gray lại gần và rót trà ra. Hai người thơ thẩn lại gần bàn và nhìn xem cái gì dưới nắp.
tr: Kapıya vuruldu, uşak elinde dolu bir çay tepsisiyle içeri girdi, tepsiyi ufak bir Japon masasının üstüne bıraktı. Bir fincan, tabak şıngırtısı oldu, oluklu antika çaydanlığın ıslığı duyuldu. Genç bir uşak yamağı iki porselen tabak getirdi. Üzerlerinde yarımküre biçiminde kapaklar vardı. Dorian tepsinin başına geçerek çayları koydu. İki erkek tembel adımlarla masaya yaklaşarak kapakların altında neler olduğuna baktılar.
es: Se oyó llamar a la puerta, entró el mayordomo con la bandeja del té y la colocó sobre una mesita japonesa. Se oyó un tintineo de tazas y platillos y el silbido de una tetera georgiana. Entró un paje llevando dos fuentes con forma de globo. Dorian Gray se acercó a la mesa y sirvió el té. Los otros dos se acercaron lánguidamente y examinaron lo que había bajo las tapaderas.
vi_translation: There was a knock on the door, the butler entered with a heavy tray of tea and placed it on the small Japanese table. There was the clinking of cups and the whistling of the antique George-era grooved teapot. Two spherical porcelain bowls were brought in by a young servant. Dorian Gray approached and poured the tea. The two of them wandered closer to the table and looked to see what was under the lid.
tr_translation: There was a knock at the door, the servant entered with a full tea tray in his hand, and placed the tray on a small Japanese table. There was the clinking of a cup and saucer, and the whistle of an antique grooved teapot was heard. A young servant's assistant brought two porcelain plates. They had dome-shaped covers on them. Dorian took his place at the tray and poured the tea. The two men approached the table with lazy steps and looked at what was under the covers.
es_translation: The door was heard knocking, the butler entered with the tea tray and placed it on a Japanese table. The clinking of cups and saucers and the whistle of a Georgian teapot were heard. A page entered carrying two globe-shaped dishes. Dorian Gray approached the table and served the tea. The other two approached languidly and examined what was under the covers.

en: “Let us go to the theatre to-night,” said Lord Henry. “There is sure to be something on, somewhere. I have promised to dine at White’s, but it is only with an old friend, so I can send him a wire to say that I am ill, or that I am prevented from coming in consequence of a subsequent engagement. I think that would be a rather nice excuse: it would have all the surprise of candour.”
vi: “Đêm nay ta đi xem hát đi,” huân tước Henry nói. “Chắc phải có gì đó đang diễn, ở đâu đó. Tôi đã hứa dùng bữa ở chỗ White, nhưng chỉ với một anh bạn cũ, nên tôi có thể đánh một bức điện cho y để báo rằng tôi ốm, hoặc rằng tôi bị ngăn cản không đến được do một lời mời đến sau. Tôi nghĩ rằng đó sẽ là lời xin lỗi khá hay: nó sẽ có tất cả sự bất ngờ thẳng thắn.
tr: Lord Henry, “Tiyatroya gidelim bu gece,” dedi. “Bir yerlerde bir şeyler vardır elbet. White’ta akşam yemeği sözüm var çok eski bir dostumla. Hasta olduğumu ya da bir işim çıktığını söylerim. Böyle bir özür ileri sürmek çok hoş olur, bence: Açıksözlülüğün sürprizini yaratır.
es: —Vayamos esta noche al teatro —propuso lord Henry—. Habrá algo que ver en algún sitio. He quedado para cenar en White's, pero sólo se trata de un viejo amigo, de manera que le puedo mandar un telegrama diciendo que estoy enfermo o que no puedo ir en razón de un compromiso ulterior. Creo que sería una excusa bastante simpática, ya que contaría con la sorpresa de la sinceridad.
vi_translation: “Let's go watch a play tonight,” Lord Henry said. “There must be something showing, somewhere. I had promised to have dinner at White's, but it's just with an old friend, so I can send him a telegram saying that I'm ill, or that I'm prevented from coming due to a later invitation. I think that would be a rather good excuse: it will have all the straightforward surprise.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "Let's go to the theater tonight." "There must be something going on somewhere. I have a dinner appointment at White's with a very old friend. I'll tell him that I'm sick or that something came up. It would be very pleasant to offer such an excuse, I think: It creates the surprise of candor."
es_translation: —Let's go to the theater tonight —proposed Lord Henry—. There will be something to see somewhere. I have a dinner appointment at White's, but it's just with an old friend, so I can send him a telegram saying that I'm sick or that I can't go due to a prior commitment. I think it would be a rather nice excuse, as it would come with the surprise of sincerity.

en: “It is such a bore putting on one’s dress-clothes,” muttered Hallward. “And, when one has them on, they are so horrid.”
vi: “Thật là chán ngán khi phải bận lễ phục,” Hallward lẩm bẩm. “Và, khi người ta bận chúng vào người, họ mới kinh khủng làm sao.”
tr: Hallward, “Resmi kılık giymek öyle can sıkıcı ki!” diye söylendi. “Giyince üstte de öyle kötü duruyor ki.
es: —¡Es tan aburrido ponerse de etiqueta! —murmuró Hallward—. Y, cuando ya lo has hecho, ¡se tiene un aspecto tan horroroso!
vi_translation: “It is really tedious to have to wear formal attire,” Hallward muttered. “And, when people put them on, they look so dreadful.”
tr_translation: Hallward grumbled, "Wearing formal attire is so annoying!" "And it looks so bad when you put it on."
es_translation: —It's so boring to dress formally! —murmured Hallward—. And, once you've done it, you look so awful!

en: “Yes,” answered Lord Henry dreamily, “the costume of the nineteenth century is detestable. It is so sombre, so depressing. Sin is the only real colour-element left in modern life.”
vi: “Đúng rồi,” huân tước Henry nói, mơ màng, “trang phục thế kỷ mười chín thật đáng tởm. Nó quá u sầu, quá chán chường. Tội lỗi là yếu tố sắc màu chân thật duy nhất còn lại trong đời sống hiện đại.”
tr: Lord Henry dalgın dalgın, “Evet,” diye yanıtladı. “On dokuzuncu yüzyılın kılığı gerçekten iğrenç. Öylesine iç karartıcı, öyle karamsar ki! Bugünün yaşantısına renk katan tek şey olarak günah kaldı.
es: —Sí —respondió lord Henry distraídamente—, la ropa del siglo XIX es detestable. Tan sombría, tan deprimente. El pecado es el único elemento de color que queda en la vida moderna.
vi_translation: “That's right,” Lord Henry said dreamily, “nineteenth-century clothing is truly disgusting. It is too gloomy, too dreary. Sin is the only real color left in modern life.”
