tr_translation: Lord Henry replied absentmindedly, "Yes." "The attire of the nineteenth century is truly disgusting. So dreary, so gloomy! The only thing that adds color to today's life is sin."
es_translation: —Yes —replied Lord Henry distractedly—, the clothing of the 19th century is detestable. So gloomy, so depressing. Sin is the only element of color left in modern life.

en: “You really must not say things like that before Dorian, Harry.”
vi: “Anh thật ra không nên nói những điều như vậy trước mặt Dorian, Harry.”
tr: “Harry, Dorian’ın önünde böyle konuşmamalısın, sahi söylüyorum.
es: —No deberías decir cosas como ésa delante de Dorian, Harry.
vi_translation: "You really shouldn't say things like that in front of Dorian, Harry."
tr_translation: “Harry, you shouldn't talk like that in front of Dorian, I'm serious.”
es_translation: —You shouldn't say things like that in front of Dorian, Harry.

en: “Before which Dorian? The one who is pouring out tea for us, or the one in the picture?”
vi: “Trước mặt Dorian nào? Người đang rót trà cho chúng ta, hay người trong tranh?”
tr: “Hangi Dorian’ın önünde? Çaylarımızı koyan mı, yoksa portredeki mi?
es: —¿Delante de qué Dorian? ¿El que nos está sirviendo el té o el del cuadro?
vi_translation: “Which Dorian are you talking about? The one pouring tea for us, or the one in the painting?”
tr_translation: “In front of which Dorian? The one who served our tea, or the one in the portrait?”
es_translation: —In front of which Dorian? The one serving us tea or the one in the painting?

en: “Before either.”
vi: “Trước mặt cả hai.”
tr: “Her ikisi de.
es: —De ninguno de los dos.
vi_translation: "In front of both of them."
tr_translation: "Both of them.""
es_translation: —Neither of them.

en: “I should like to come to the theatre with you, Lord Henry,” said the lad.
vi: “Tôi những muốn đi xem hát với anh, huân tước Henry,” chàng trai nói.
tr: Delikanlı, “Ben sizinle tiyatroya gelmek istiyorum, Lord Henry,” dedi.
es: —Me gustaría ir al teatro con usted, lord Henry —dijo el muchacho.
vi_translation: “I would like to go see the play with you, Lord Henry,” the young man said.
tr_translation: The young man said, "I want to go to the theater with you, Lord Henry."
es_translation: —I would like to go to the theater with you, Lord Henry —said the boy.

en: “Then you shall come; and you will come, too, Basil, won’t you?”
vi: “Vậy thì cậu cứ đi thôi; còn anh cũng sẽ đi chứ, Basil, phải không?”
tr: “Gel öyleyse. Sen de gelirsin değil mi, Basil?
es: —Venga, entonces; y tú también, Basil.
vi_translation: “Then you just go; and you will go too, Basil, won't you?”
tr_translation: “Come then. You will come too, won't you, Basil?”
es_translation: —Come, then; and you too, Basil.

en: “I can’t, really. I would sooner not. I have a lot of work to do.”
vi: “Tôi thật sự không thể. Tôi thích ở nhà hơn. Tôi có quá nhiều việc phải làm.
tr: “İnan, gelemem. Canım da istemiyor. Çok işim var.
es: —La verdad es que no puedo. Será mejor que no. Tengo muchísimo trabajo.
vi_translation: “I really can't. I prefer staying at home. I have too much work to do.”
tr_translation: “Believe me, I can't come. I don't feel like it. I have a lot of work.”
es_translation: —The truth is that I can't. It would be better not to. I have a lot of work.

en: “Well, then, you and I will go alone, Mr. Gray.”
vi: “Vậy sao, thế thì cậu với tôi sẽ đi riêng vậy, mít-tơ Gray.”
tr: “Peki öyleyse. Siz ve ben baş başa gidiyoruz, mr Gray.
es: —Bien; en ese caso, iremos usted y yo, señor Gray.
vi_translation: “Is that so? Then you and I will go separately, Mr. Gray.”
tr_translation: "Well then. You and I are going alone, Mr. Gray."
es_translation: —Well; in that case, you and I will go, Mr. Gray.

en: The painter bit his lip and walked over, cup in hand, to the picture. “I shall stay with the real Dorian,” he said, sadly.
vi: Họa sỹ cắn môi và đi, với tách trong tay, tới chỗ bức tranh. “Tôi sẽ ở lại với Dorian thật,” y nói, buồn rầu.
tr: Ressam, dudağını dişleyerek, elinde çay bardağıyla resmin yanına gitti. Üzgün bir sesle, “Ben de gerçek Dorian Gray’le kalıyorum,” dedi.
es: El pintor se mordió el labio y, con la taza en la mano, se acercó al cuadro. —Me quedaré con el verdadero Dorian —dijo tristemente.
vi_translation: The painter bit his lip and walked, with a cup in hand, towards the painting. "I will stay with Dorian indeed," he said, sorrowfully.
tr_translation: The painter, biting his lip, went to the painting with a tea glass in his hand. In a sad voice, he said, "I am also staying with the real Dorian Gray."
es_translation: The painter bit his lip and, with the cup in his hand, approached the painting. —I will stay with the real Dorian —he said sadly.

en: “Is it the real Dorian?” cried the original of the portrait, strolling across to him. “Am I really like that?”
vi: “Đó là Dorian thật à?” nguyên mẫu bức chân dung kêu lên, lững thững đi qua chỗ y. “Có phải tôi thật sự giống thế không?”
tr: Portrenin modeli, “Gerçek Dorian Gray bu mu?” diye sorarak ressamın yanına doğru yürüdü. “Ben böyle miyim sahiden?
es: —¿Es ése el verdadero Dorian? —exclamó el original del retrato, acercándose a Hallward—. ¿Soy realmente así?
vi_translation: “Is that really Dorian?” the original of the portrait exclaimed, strolling past him. “Do I really look like that?”
tr_translation: The model for the portrait walked towards the painter, asking, "Is this the real Dorian Gray?" "Is this really how I am?"
es_translation: —Is that the real Dorian? —exclaimed the original of the portrait, approaching Hallward—. Am I really like that?

en: “Yes; you are just like that.”
vi: “Đúng; cậu giống hệt thế.”
tr: “Evet, tıpkı böylesin işte.
es: —Sí; exactamente así.
vi_translation: “Yes; you look exactly like that.”
tr_translation: “Yes, you are just like this.”
es_translation: —Yes; exactly like that.

en: “How wonderful, Basil!”
vi: “Tuyệt quá, Basil!”
tr: “Harika bir şey bu, Basil!
es: —¡Maravilloso, Basil!
vi_translation: "Wonderful, Basil!"
tr_translation: "This is wonderful, Basil!"
es_translation: —Marvelous, Basil!

en: “At least you are like it in appearance. But it will never alter,” sighed Hallward. “That is something.”
vi: “Chí ít thì cậu cũng giống nó bên ngoài. Nhưng nó sẽ chẳng bao giờ thay đổi,” Hallward thở dài. “Thế mới quý.”
tr: Hallward, “Yani görünüş olarak böylesin. Hem de bu resim hiç değişmeyecek,” diye göğüs geçirdi. “Bu da bir şeydir.
es: —Tienes al menos el mismo aspecto. Pero él no cambiará —suspiró Hallward—. Eso es algo.
vi_translation: "At least you resemble it on the outside. But it will never change," Hallward sighed. "That's what makes it precious."
tr_translation: Hallward, "So this is how you look. And this picture will never change," he sighed. "That's something."
es_translation: —You at least look the same. But he won't change —sighed Hallward—. That's something.

en: “What a fuss people make about fidelity!” exclaimed Lord Henry. “Why, even in love it is purely a question for physiology. It has nothing to do with our own will. Young men want to be faithful, and are not; old men want to be faithless, and cannot: that is all one can say.”
vi: “Người ta cứ làm quá lên về lòng trung thành!” “Tại sao nhỉ, ngay cả trong tình yêu thì đó cũng chỉ là vấn đề sinh lý. Nó chẳng liên quan gì đến ý chí chúng ta. Trẻ muốn chung tình mà không được; Già muốn bạc tình mà không thể: ấy là tất cả những gì có thể nói.”
tr: Lord Henry, “İnsanlar sadakat konusunu nasıl da gözlerinde büyütürler!” diye söylendi. “Aşk bile salt fizyolojik bir sorundur. Bizim öz irademizle hiç ilişiği yoktur. Gençler sadık kalmak isterler, kalamazlar; yaşlılar sadakatsizlik etmek isterler, edemezler. Söylenecek söz bundan ibaret.
es: —¡Qué obsesión tienen las personas con la fidelidad! —exclamó lord Henry—. Incluso el amor es simplemente una cuestión de fisiología. No tiene nada que ver con la voluntad. Los jóvenes quieren ser fieles y no lo son; los viejos quieren ser infieles y no pueden: eso es todo lo que cabe decir.
vi_translation: “People make too much of loyalty!” “Why, even in love, it is merely a matter of physiology. It has nothing to do with our will. The young want to be faithful but can't; the old want to be unfaithful but can't: that's all there is to say.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, "How people exaggerate the matter of loyalty!" "Even love is merely a physiological issue. It has nothing to do with our own will. Young people want to be faithful, but they cannot; old people want to be unfaithful, but they cannot. That's all there is to say."
es_translation: —What an obsession people have with fidelity! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. Even love is simply a matter of physiology. It has nothing to do with the will. Young people want to be faithful and are not; old people want to be unfaithful and cannot: that is all there is to say.

en: “Don’t go to the theatre to-night, Dorian,” said Hallward. “Stop and dine with me.”
vi: “Đừng đi xem hát đêm nay, Dorian,” Hallward nói. “Ở lại dùng bữa với tôi.”
tr: “Dorian, bu gece tiyatroya gitme,” dedi Hallward. “Kal da yemeği benimle ye.
es: —No vayas esta noche al teatro, Dorian —dijo Hallward—. Quédate a cenar conmigo.
vi_translation: “Don't go to the theater tonight, Dorian,” Hallward said. “Stay and have dinner with me.”
tr_translation: “Dorian, don't go to the theater tonight,” said Hallward. “Stay and have dinner with me.”
es_translation: —Don't go to the theater tonight, Dorian —said Hallward—. Stay and have dinner with me.

en: “I can’t, Basil.”
vi: “Tôi không thể, Basil.”
tr: “Kalamam, Basil.
es: —No puedo, Basil.
vi_translation: "I can't, Basil."
tr_translation: “My pen, Basil.””
es_translation: —I can't, Basil.

en: “Why?”
vi: “Tại sao?”
tr: “Neden?
es: —¿Por qué no?
vi_translation: "Why?"
tr_translation: “Why?”
es_translation: —Why not?

en: “Because I have promised Lord Henry Wotton to go with him.”
vi: “Vì tôi đã hứa với huân tước Henry Wotton là sẽ đi với anh ấy.”
tr: “Lord Henry Wotton’la gitmeye söz verdim de ondan.
es: —Porque he prometido a lord Henry Wotton ir con él.
vi_translation: “Because I promised Lord Henry Wotton that I would go with him.”
tr_translation: “I promised to go with Lord Henry Wotton, that's why.”
es_translation: —Because I have promised Lord Henry Wotton to go with him.

en: “He won’t like you the better for keeping your promises. He always breaks his own. I beg you not to go.”
vi: “Anh ấy chẳng thích cậu hơn vì cậu giữ lời hứa của mình đâu. Anh ấy luôn thất hứa. Tôi van cậu đừng đi.”
tr: “O seni, sözünde durdun diye daha çok sevecek değildir. Kendisi sözünden her zaman cayar. Yalvarırım sana, gitme.
es: —No mejorará su opinión de ti porque cumplas tus promesas. Él siempre falta a las suyas. Te ruego que no vayas.
vi_translation: "He doesn't like you more because you keep your promises. He always breaks his promises. I beg you not to go."
tr_translation: “She won't love you more just because you kept your word. She always breaks her promises. I beg you, don't go.”
es_translation: —His opinion of you won't improve just because you keep your promises. He always breaks his. I beg you not to go.

en: Dorian Gray laughed and shook his head.
vi: Dorian Gray cười và lắc đầu.
tr: Dorian Gray gülerek başını olmaz anlamında salladı.
es: Dorian Gray rió y negó con la cabeza.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray smiled and shook his head.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head with a laugh, indicating no.
es_translation: Dorian Gray laughed and shook his head.

en: “I entreat you.”
vi: “Tôi năn nỉ cậu.”
tr: “Yürekten yakarıyorum.
es: —Te lo suplico.
vi_translation: “I beg you.”
tr_translation: “I am pleading from the heart.”
es_translation: —I beg you.

en: The lad hesitated, and looked over at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea-table with an amused smile.
vi: Chàng trai lưỡng lự và liếc nhìn huân tước Henry, còn y thì theo dõi họ từ bàn trà với một nụ cười thích thú.
tr: Delikanlı duraksadı; çay masasının başından onları bıyık altından gülümseyerek seyretmekte olan Lord Henry’ye baktı.
es: El muchacho vaciló y miró hacia lord Henry, que los contemplaba desde la mesita del té con una sonrisa divertida.
vi_translation: The young man hesitated and glanced at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea table with a delighted smile.
tr_translation: The young man hesitated; he looked at Lord Henry, who was watching them from the head of the tea table with a sly smile.
es_translation: The boy hesitated and looked towards Lord Henry, who was watching them from the tea table with an amused smile.

en: “I must go, Basil,” he answered.
vi: “Tôi phải đi, Basil,” cậu trả lời.
tr: “Gitmem gerek, Basil.
es: —Tengo que ir, Basil —respondió el joven.
vi_translation: “I have to go, Basil,” he replied.
tr_translation: "I must go, Basil.""
es_translation: —I have to go, Basil —replied the young man.

en: “Very well,” said Hallward, and he went over and laid down his cup on the tray. “It is rather late, and, as you have to dress, you had better lose no time. Good-bye, Harry. Good-bye, Dorian. Come and see me soon. Come to-morrow.”
vi: “Thôi được,” Hallward nói; rồi y lại gần và đặt tách xuống khay. “Đã khá muộn rồi, và vì các anh phải thay đồ, nên tốt nhất là các anh đừng mất thời gian nữa. Tạm biệt, Harry. Tạm biệt, Dorian. Đến gặp tôi sớm nhé. Mai đến đi.”
tr: “Peki, öyleyse,” dedi Hallward. Gitti, elindeki çay fincanını tepsiye bıraktı. “Saat geç oldu; daha kılığınızı değiştireceğinize göre fazla zaman yitirmeseniz iyi olur. Güle güle, Harry. Güle güle, Dorian. Gene beklerim; çok uzatma. Yarın gel.
es: —Muy bien —dijo Hallward; y, alejándose, depositó su taza en la bandeja—. Es bastante tarde y, dado que tienes que vestirte, será mejor que no pierdas más tiempo. Hasta la vista, Harry. Hasta la vista, Dorian. Ven pronto a verme. Mañana.
vi_translation: “Alright,” Hallward said; then he approached and placed the cup on the tray. “It's quite late, and since you have to change clothes, it's best not to waste any more time. Goodbye, Harry. Goodbye, Dorian. Come see me soon. Come tomorrow.”
tr_translation: “Well, then,” said Hallward. He went and placed the teacup on the tray. “It's getting late; since you still have to change your outfit, it would be best not to waste too much time. Goodbye, Harry. Goodbye, Dorian. Do come again; don't take too long. Come tomorrow.”
es_translation: —Very well —said Hallward; and, stepping away, he placed his cup on the tray—. It is quite late and, since you have to get dressed, it would be best if you didn't waste any more time. Goodbye, Harry. Goodbye, Dorian. Come see me soon. Tomorrow.

en: “Certainly.”
vi: “Nhất định rồi.”
tr: “Hay hay.
es: —Desde luego.
vi_translation: "Of course."
tr_translation: “There there.”
es_translation: —Of course.

en: “You won’t forget?”
vi: “Cậu sẽ không quên chứ?”
tr: “Unutmazsın ya?
es: —¿No lo olvidarás?
vi_translation: “You won't forget, right?”
tr_translation: “You won't forget, right?”
es_translation: —Will you not forget it?

en: “No, of course not,” cried Dorian.
vi: “Không, đương nhiên là không,” Dorian kêu lên.
tr: Dorian, “Ne münasebet, elbette unutmam,” diye yanıtladı.
es: —¡No, claro que no! —exclamó Dorian.
vi_translation: “No, of course not,” Dorian exclaimed.
tr_translation: Dorian replied, "What do you mean, of course I won't forget."
es_translation: —No, of course not! —exclaimed Dorian.

en: “And ... Harry!”
vi: “À… Harry!”
tr: “Sen de Harry...
es: —Y..., ¡Harry!
vi_translation: "Ah... Harry!"
tr_translation: "You too, Harry..."
es_translation: —And..., Harry!

en: “Yes, Basil?”
vi: “Ừ, Basil?”
tr: “Efendim, Basil?”
es: —¿Sí, Basil?
vi_translation: "Yes, Basil?"
tr_translation: "Sir, Basil?"
es_translation: —Yes, Basil?

en: “Remember what I asked you, when we were in the garden this morning.”
vi: “Nhớ những gì tôi xin anh, khi ta ở trong vườn sáng nay.”
tr: “Bu sabah bahçede senden dilediğim şeyi unutma.
es: —Recuerda lo que te pedí cuando estábamos esta mañana en el jardín.
vi_translation: "Remember what I asked you, when we were in the garden this morning."
tr_translation: "Don't forget the thing I asked of you in the garden this morning.""
es_translation: —Remember what I asked you when we were in the garden this morning.

en: “I have forgotten it.”
vi: “Tôi đã quên mất rồi.”
tr: “Unuttum gitti.
es: —Lo he olvidado.
vi_translation: “I have already forgotten.”
tr_translation: "I forgot, it's gone.""
es_translation: —I have forgotten it.

en: “I trust you.”
vi: “Tôi tin anh.”
tr: “Sana güveniyorum.
es: —Confío en ti.
vi_translation: "I believe you."
tr_translation: "I trust you."
es_translation: —I trust you.

en: “I wish I could trust myself,” said Lord Henry, laughing. “Come, Mr. Gray, my hansom is outside, and I can drop you at your own place. Good-bye, Basil. It has been a most interesting afternoon.”
vi: “Tôi ước gì tôi có thể tin được chính mình,” huân tước Henry vừa nói vừa cười. “Nào, mít-tơ Gray, cỗ mã xa hai bánh của tôi đang ở ngoài kia, và tôi có thể thả anh xuống chỗ anh. Tạm biệt, Basil. Thật là một buổi chiều cực kỳ thú vị.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Keşke ben de kendi kendime güvenebilseydim!” dedi gülerek. “Yürüyün, mr Gray, arabam dışarıda. Sizi evinize bırakabilirim. Hoşça kal, Basil. Çok ilginç bir öğleden sonra geçirdik, doğrusu.
es: —Quisiera poder confiar yo mismo —dijo lord Henry, riendo—. Vamos, señor Gray, mi coche está ahí fuera, le puedo dejar en su casa. Hasta la vista, Basil. Ha sido una tarde interesantísima.
vi_translation: “I wish I could trust myself,” Lord Henry said with a laugh. “Now, Mr. Gray, my hansom cab is outside, and I can drop you off at your place. Goodbye, Basil. It has been an extremely delightful afternoon.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "I wish I could trust myself!" laughing. "Come on, Mr. Gray, my carriage is outside. I can take you home. Goodbye, Basil. We had a very interesting afternoon, indeed."
es_translation: —I wish I could trust myself —said Lord Henry, laughing—. Come on, Mr. Gray, my carriage is outside, I can take you home. Goodbye, Basil. It has been a very interesting afternoon.

en: As the door closed behind them, the painter flung himself down on a sofa, and a look of pain came into his face.
vi: Khi cửa đóng lại sau lưng họ, họa sỹ buông mình xuống xô-pha và một nét đớn đau hiện lên trên mặt y.
tr: Kapı konuklarının ardından kapandığı zaman ressam kendini bir kanepeye bıraktı, yüzünde acı çeken bir ifade belirdi.
es: Cuando la puerta se cerró tras ellos el pintor se dejó caer en un sofá y apareció en su rostro una expresión de sufrimiento.
vi_translation: When the door closed behind them, the artist sank onto the sofa, and a look of pain appeared on his face.
tr_translation: When the door closed behind the guests, the painter let himself fall onto a couch, a pained expression appearing on his face.
es_translation: When the door closed behind them, the painter let himself fall onto a sofa, and an expression of suffering appeared on his face.

en: CHAPTER III.
vi: Chương 3
tr: Üçüncü bölüm
es: Capítulo 3
vi_translation: Chapter 3
tr_translation: Third chapter
es_translation: Chapter 3

en: At half-past twelve next day Lord Henry Wotton strolled from Curzon Street over to the Albany to call on his uncle, Lord Fermor, a genial if somewhat rough-mannered old bachelor, whom the outside world called selfish because it derived no particular benefit from him, but who was considered generous by Society as he fed the people who amused him. His father had been our ambassador at Madrid when Isabella was young and Prim unthought of, but had retired from the diplomatic service in a capricious moment of annoyance on not being offered the Embassy at Paris, a post to which he considered that he was fully entitled by reason of his birth, his indolence, the good English of his dispatches, and his inordinate passion for pleasure. The son, who had been his father’s secretary, had resigned along with his chief, somewhat foolishly as was thought at the time, and on succeeding some months later to the title, had set himself to the serious study of the great aristocratic art of doing absolutely nothing. He had two large town houses, but preferred to live in chambers as it was less trouble, and took most of his meals at his club. He paid some attention to the management of his collieries in the Midland counties, excusing himself for this taint of industry on the ground that the one advantage of having coal was that it enabled a gentleman to afford the decency of burning wood on his own hearth. In politics he was a Tory, except when the Tories were in office, during which period he roundly abused them for being a pack of Radicals. He was a hero to his valet, who bullied him, and a terror to most of his relations, whom he bullied in turn. Only England could have produced him, and he always said that the country was going to the dogs. His principles were out of date, but there was a good deal to be said for his prejudices.
vi: Lúc mười hai giờ rưỡi trưa hôm sau, huân tước Henry Wotton thủng thẳng đi bộ từ phố Curzon qua Albany để ghé thăm chú mình, huân tước Fermor, một ông già độc thân vui tính mặc dầu cư xử hơi thô, người bị cả thế giới bên ngoài cho là ích kỷ vì chẳng kiếm được món lợi ngoại lệ nào từ ông, nhưng lại là người được giới thượng lưu xem là rất hào phóng do ông nuôi những ai tiêu khiển cho ông. Cha ông từng làm đại sứ của ta ở Madrid khi Isabella còn trẻ, và Prim thì chưa được ai nghĩ tới, nhưng đã thôi làm cho ngành ngoại giao vào một khoảnh khắc thất thường do bực mình với việc không được mời làm đại sứ ở Paris, một chức vụ mà ông xem như là ông hoàn toàn được quyền làm vì dòng dõi ông, vì sự lười nhác của ông, vì thứ tiếng Anh hoàn hảo trong các bản thông điệp của ông, và vì nỗi đam mê khoái lạc vô độ của ông. Cậu con trai, người từng làm thư ký cho cha mình, cũng từ chức cùng sếp, một việc mà lúc ấy ai cũng cho là hơi dại dột, và khi kế vị được tước hiệu sau đó vài tháng, đã ốp mình vào việc nghiên cứu nghiêm túc môn nghệ thuật quý tộc vĩ đại là tuyệt đối chẳng làm gì cả. Ông có hai căn nhà lớn trên phố, nhưng ưa sống trong nhà trọ sẵn đồ cho đàn ông chưa vợ, để đỡ phiền, và ăn chủ yếu ở câu lạc bộ. Ông cũng có để ý ít nhiều đến việc quản lý các mỏ than của mình ở các tỉnh miền trung du, tự bào chữa cho vết nhơ công nghiệp này trên cơ sở rằng một lợi ích của việc có than là nó cho phép một quý ông có đủ khả năng đàng hoàng đốt gỗ trong lò sưởi của mình. Trong chính trị, ông là đảng viên đảng Bảo thủ, trừ lúc đảng Bảo thủ cầm quyền, trong suốt giai đoạn đó, ông thẳng thừng sỉ nhục họ vì việc biến thành bọn Cấp tiến. Ông là một anh hùng với người hầu của mình, kẻ vẫn bắt nạt ông, và là nỗi kinh sợ với phần lớn họ hàng, những kẻ bị ông bắt nạt lần lượt. Chỉ mỗi nước Anh mới có thể sản sinh ra ông, và ông luôn nói rằng cái nước này đang xuống chó. Các nguyên tắc của ông đã lỗi thời, nhưng có rất nhiều điều có thể nói để ủng hộ các định kiến của ông.
tr: Ertesi gün saat yarımda Lord Henry Wotton, Curzon Sokağı’ndan çıktı, amcası Lord Fermor’u ziyaret etmek için Albany Oteli’nin yolunu tuttu. Kimi dobra davranışlarına karşı güler, söyler, dost tutumlu bir ihtiyar olan Lord Fermor’dan belli bir çıkar sağlayamayan dünya onu bencillikle suçlardı. Oysa sosyete onu cömert sayardı, çünkü Lord Fermor kendini eğlendiren kimselerin karnını doyururdu. Babası, Isabella’nın gençliğinde, daha Prim akılda bile yokken, Madrid Büyükelçiliği yapmış, ne var ki Paris Büyükelçisi yapılmayınca tepesi atarak diplomasi mesleğinden ayrılmıştı. Lord Fermor, soyu, haylazlığı, hazırladığı raporları, güzel dili ve aşırı zevk, sefa düşkünlüğü nedeniyle bu görevi tam anlamıyla kendisinin hak ettiğini düşünmüştü. Babasının sekreterliğini yapan oğlu da onunla birlikte istifasını vermişti. Biraz aptallık ettiği düşünülmüştü o sıralar. Birkaç ay sonra babasının unvanı kendine kalan yeni Lord Fermor kendini, aristokrasinin o şahane sanatını, yani tümüyle boş gezme sanatını ciddi olarak incelemeye adamıştı. Kent içinde iki kocaman evi vardı, ama daha az zahmetli olduğu için bir otel dairesinde oturmayı yeğliyor, genellikle yemeklerini de orada yiyordu. Midland dolaylarında sahip olduğu kömür ocaklarının yönetimiyle az buçuk ilgileniyor, bu çabayı göstermekle şanına sürdüğü lekeyi affettirmek için, “Kömürün tek bir yararı var: Kibar tabakaya kendi şöminelerinde odun yakabilme ayrıcalığını sağlıyor!” diyordu. Siyasal açıdan bir Tory idi, Torylerin hükümette olduğu zamanlar dışında. Böyle dönemlerde Lord Fermor onları, “Radikaller sürüsü” olarak tanımlayıp yerin dibine batırırdı. Onu, tepesine binen bir buyurganlıkla yöneten özel uşağının gözünde Lord Fermor bir kahraman, kendisinin buyurganlıkla tepelerine bindiği hısım akrabasının gözündeyse bir zorbaydı. Onu ancak İngiltere yetiştirmiş olabilirdi, o da her zaman ülkenin kötüye gittiğini söyler dururdu. İlkeleri biraz çağını doldurmuş olsa önyargıları için söylenecek laf yoktu doğrusu.
es: A las doce Y media del día siguiente lord Henry Wotton fue paseando desde Curzon Street hasta el Albany para visitar a su tío, lord Fermor, un viejo solterón, cordial pero un tanto brusco, a quien en general se tachaba de egoísta porque el mundo no obtenía de él beneficio alguno, pero al que la buena sociedad consideraba generoso porque daba de comer a la gente que le divertía. Su padre había sido embajador en Madrid cuando Isabel II era joven y nadie había pensado aún en el general Prim, pero abandonó la carrera diplomática caprichosamente por el despecho que sintió al ver que no le ofrecían la embajada de París, puesto al que creía tener pleno derecho en razón de su nacimiento, de su indolencia, del excelente inglés de sus despachos y de su desmesurada pasión por los placeres. El hijo, que había sido secretario de su padre, y que presentó también la dimisión, gesto que por entonces se consideró un tanto descabellado, sucedió a su padre en el título unos meses después, y se consagró a cultivar con seriedad el gran arte aristocrático de no hacer absolutamente nada. Aunque poseía dos grandes casas en Londres, prefería vivir en habitaciones alquiladas, que le causaban menos molestias, y hacía en su club la mayoría de las comidas. Se preocupaba algo de la gestión de sus minas de carbón en las Midlands, y se excusaba de aquel contacto con la industria alegando que poseer minas de carbón otorgaba a un caballero el privilegio de quemar leña en el hogar de su propia chimenea. En política era conservador, excepto cuando los conservadores gobernaban, periodo en el que los insultaba sistemáticamente, acusándolos de ser una pandilla de radicales. Era un héroe para su ayuda de cámara, que lo tiranizaba, y un personaje aterrador para la mayoría de sus parientes, a quienes él, a su vez, tiranizaba. Era una persona que sólo podía haber nacido en Inglaterra, y siempre afirmaba que el país iba a la ruina. Sus principios estaban anticuados, pero se podía decir mucho en favor de sus prejuicios.
vi_translation: At half-past twelve the next day, Lord Henry Wotton leisurely walked from Curzon Street through Albany to visit his uncle, Lord Fermor, a cheerful old bachelor despite his somewhat rude manners. The outside world considered him selfish because they couldn't gain any exceptional benefits from him, but the upper class viewed him as very generous because he supported those who entertained him. His father had been our ambassador in Madrid when Isabella was young, and Prim was not yet thought of, but he had left the diplomatic service in a fit of pique over not being invited to be the ambassador in Paris, a position he believed he was entirely entitled to because of his lineage, his laziness, his perfect English in his dispatches, and his excessive passion for pleasure. The son, who had been his father's secretary, also resigned along with his boss, a move that was considered somewhat foolish at the time, and when he inherited the title a few months later, he devoted himself to the serious study of the great aristocratic art of doing absolutely nothing. He had two large houses in town but preferred to live in a furnished bachelor apartment to avoid inconvenience and mostly dined at his club. He also paid some attention to managing his coal mines in the Midlands, justifying this industrial stain on the grounds that one advantage of having coal was that it allowed a gentleman to afford to burn wood in his fireplace. In politics, he was a Conservative, except when the Conservatives were in power, during which time he openly insulted them for turning into Radicals. He was a hero to his valet, who bullied him, and a terror to most of his relatives, whom he bullied in turn. Only England could have produced him, and he always said that the country was going to the dogs. His principles were outdated, but there was much to be said in favor of his prejudices.
tr_translation: The next day at half-past twelve, Lord Henry Wotton left Curzon Street and headed towards the Albany Hotel to visit his uncle, Lord Fermor. The world, which could not derive any benefit from Lord Fermor, who was a cheerful, talkative, and friendly old man despite some of his blunt behaviors, accused him of selfishness. However, society considered him generous because Lord Fermor would feed those who entertained him. His father had been the Ambassador to Madrid during Isabella's youth, long before Prim was even thought of, but he had quit the diplomatic profession in a fit of anger when he was not made Ambassador to Paris. Lord Fermor believed he fully deserved this position due to his lineage, mischief, the reports he prepared, his eloquence, and his excessive love of pleasure and luxury. His son, who was acting as his secretary, had also submitted his resignation along with him. It was thought that he had been a bit foolish at the time. A few months later, the new Lord Fermor, who inherited his father's title, dedicated himself to seriously studying that magnificent art of aristocracy, namely the art of doing absolutely nothing. He had two huge houses in the city, but preferred to stay in a hotel suite because it was less troublesome, and usually had his meals there as well. He took a slight interest in managing the coal mines he owned around the Midlands, and to excuse the stain on his honor for making this effort, he would say, "There is only one benefit of coal: it provides the upper class with the privilege of burning wood in their own fireplaces!" Politically, he was a Tory, except when the Tories were in power. During such times, Lord Fermor would denounce them as a "pack of Radicals" and condemn them vehemently. In the eyes of his personal valet, who managed him with an overbearing authority, Lord Fermor was a hero, while to his relatives, whom he managed with the same overbearing authority, he was a tyrant. Only England could have produced him, and he was always saying that the country was going to the dogs. His principles might have been somewhat outdated, but there was no denying his prejudices.
es_translation: At half past twelve the next day, Lord Henry Wotton walked from Curzon Street to Albany to visit his uncle, Lord Fermor, an old bachelor, cordial but somewhat brusque, who was generally considered selfish because the world gained no benefit from him, but whom good society deemed generous because he fed people who amused him. His father had been an ambassador in Madrid when Isabel II was young and no one had yet thought of General Prim, but he capriciously abandoned his diplomatic career out of spite when he saw that he was not offered the embassy in Paris, a position he believed he had full right to due to his birth, his indolence, the excellent English of his dispatches, and his excessive passion for pleasures. The son, who had been his father's secretary and who also resigned, a gesture that was considered somewhat reckless at the time, succeeded his father in the title a few months later, and dedicated himself seriously to cultivating the great aristocratic art of doing absolutely nothing. Although he owned two large houses in London, he preferred to live in rented rooms, which caused him fewer inconveniences, and he took most of his meals at his club. He was somewhat concerned with the management of his coal mines in the Midlands, and excused that contact with industry by claiming that owning coal mines granted a gentleman the privilege of burning wood in his own fireplace. In politics, he was a conservative, except when the conservatives were in power, at which time he systematically insulted them, accusing them of being a bunch of radicals. He was a hero to his valet, who tyrannized him, and a terrifying figure to most of his relatives, whom he, in turn, tyrannized. He was a person who could only have been born in England, and he always claimed that the country was going to ruin. His principles were outdated, but much could be said in favor of his prejudices.

en: When Lord Henry entered the room, he found his uncle sitting in a rough shooting-coat, smoking a cheroot and grumbling over The Times. “Well, Harry,” said the old gentleman, “what brings you out so early? I thought you dandies never got up till two, and were not visible till five.”
vi: Khi huân tước Henry vào phòng, y thấy chú mình đang ngồi, mặc cái áo đi săn thô kệch, hút điếu xì gà xén tày hai đầu, và càu nhàu trên tờ The Times, “À, Harry,” ông già nói, “chuyện gì đã đưa cháu ra ngoài sớm vậy? Chú cứ nghĩ bọn công tử bột các cháu chẳng bao giờ dậy trước hai giờ, và không xuất hiện trước năm giờ.”
tr: Lord Henry içeri girdiğinde amcasını sırtında spor bir ceketle yaprak sigarası tüttürerek Times gazetesini okuyup homurdanır durumda buldu. “Vay, Harry,” dedi ihtiyar. “Ne işin var burada böyle erken erken? Ben de, siz sosyete züppeleri saat ikiden önce yataktan kalkmaz, beşten önce göze görünmezsiniz sanırdım.
es: Cuando lord Henry entró en la habitación de su tío lo encontró vestido con una tosca chaqueta de caza, fumando un cigarro habano y refunfuñando mientras leía The Times. —Vaya, Harry —dijo el anciano caballero—, ¿qué te ha hecho salir tan pronto de casa? Creía que los dandis no se levantaban hasta las dos y que no aparecían en público hasta las cinco.
vi_translation: When Lord Henry entered the room, he saw his uncle sitting, wearing a coarse hunting jacket, smoking a cigar cut at both ends, and grumbling over The Times, "Ah, Harry," the old man said, "what brings you out so early? I thought you dandies never got up before two and never appeared before five."
tr_translation: When Lord Henry entered, he found his uncle grumbling while reading the Times newspaper, puffing on a leaf cigar, and wearing a sports jacket. "Well, Harry," said the old man. "What are you doing here so early? I thought you high-society fops wouldn't get out of bed before two and wouldn't show your faces before five."
es_translation: When Lord Henry entered his uncle's room, he found him dressed in a coarse hunting jacket, smoking a Havana cigar, and grumbling while reading The Times. —Well, Harry —said the elderly gentleman—, what has made you leave the house so early? I thought dandies didn't get up until two and didn't appear in public until five.

en: “Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George. I want to get something out of you.”
vi: “Tình cảm gia đình thuần khiết thôi, cháu cam đoan với chú thế, chú George ạ. Cháu muốn nhờ chú việc này.”
tr: “İnanın bana, George Amca, beni buraya getiren salt akraba sevgisidir. Sizden bir şey koparmak istiyorum da!
es: —Puro afecto familiar, tío George, te lo aseguro. Quiero pedirte algo.
vi_translation: “It's just pure family affection, I assure you of that, Uncle George.” “I want to ask you for this favor.”
tr_translation: “Believe me, Uncle George, it is purely familial love that brought me here. I want to get something from you!”
es_translation: —Pure familial affection, Uncle George, I assure you. I want to ask you something.

en: “Money, I suppose,” said Lord Fermor, making a wry face. “Well, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people, nowadays, imagine that money is everything.”
vi: “Tiền hả, chú nghĩ vậy,” huân tước Fermor nói, làm mặt nhăn. “Nào, ngồi xuống và kể hết cho chú nghe về nó. Thanh niên ngày nay cứ tưởng tiền là tất cả.
tr: Lord Fermor, “Para olsa gerek,” diye yüzünü buruşturdu. “Her neyse, otur da anlat bakalım. Zamane gençleri hayatta her şeyin para olduğunu sanıyorlar.
es: —Dinero, imagino —respondió lord Fermor, torciendo el gesto—. Bueno; siéntate y cuéntamelo todo. En estos tiempos que corren los jóvenes se imaginan que el dinero lo es todo.
vi_translation: "Money, you think so," Lord Fermor said, making a face. "Now, sit down and tell me all about it. Young people today think money is everything."
tr_translation: Lord Fermor grimaced, "It must be about money," he said. "Anyway, sit down and tell me about it. Young people these days think that money is everything in life."
es_translation: —Money, I imagine —responded Lord Fermor, twisting his expression—. Well; sit down and tell me everything. These days, young people imagine that money is everything.

en: “Yes,” murmured Lord Henry, settling his button-hole in his coat; “and when they grow older they know it. But I don’t want money. It is only people who pay their bills who want that, Uncle George, and I never pay mine. Credit is the capital of a younger son, and one lives charmingly upon it. Besides, I always deal with Dartmoor’s tradesmen, and consequently they never bother me. What I want is information: not useful information, of course; useless information.”
vi: “Vâng,” huân tước Henry thì thào, chỉnh lại đóa hoa cài trên khuyết áo; “và khi họ già đi thì họ biết đúng là thế thật. Nhưng cháu không cần tiền. Chỉ những ai phải trả hóa đơn mới cần nó, thưa chú George, và cháu chẳng bao giờ phải trả cái của mình. Tín dụng là vốn liếng của con thứ, và hắn sống thoải mái nhờ nó. Vả lại, cháu luôn giao dịch với các thương nhân của Dartmoor, do đó họ chẳng bao giờ làm phiền cháu. Cái cháu muốn là thông tin; không phải thông tin hữu ích, dĩ nhiên; mà thông tin vô ích.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Evet,” diye mırıldandı. “Yaşlandıkları zaman da bunun böyle olduğunu biliyorlar. Ne var ki benim istediğim para değil. Yalnızca borçlarını ödeyen kişiler para ister, sevgili George Amca, oysa ben borçlarımı hiç ödemem. Soyluların küçük oğullarının sermayesi kredidir, bu krediyle de pek hoş yaşanabilir. Hem ben hep Dartmoor esnafıyla iş yaparım, bu yüzden de onlar beni hiç rahatsız etmezler. Yok, benim istediğim bilgi. İşe yarar bilgi değil doğallıkla, işe yaramayacak bilgiler.
es: —Sí —murmuró lord Henry, colocándose mejor la flor que llevaba en el ojal de la chaqueta—; y cuando se hacen viejos no se lo imaginan: lo saben. Pero no quiero dinero. Sólo las personas que pagan sus facturas necesitan dinero, tío George, y yo nunca pago las mías. El crédito es el capital de un segundón, y se vive agradablemente con él. Además, siempre me trato con los proveedores de Dartmoor y, en consecuencia, nunca me molestan. Lo que quiero es información: no información útil, por supuesto; información perfectamente inútil.
vi_translation: “Yes,” Lord Henry whispered, adjusting the flower in his buttonhole; “and when they grow old, they know it is true. But you don't need money. Only those who have bills to pay need it, Uncle George, and I never have to pay mine. Credit is the capital of the second son, and he lives comfortably on it. Besides, I always deal with the merchants of Dartmoor, so they never bother me. What I want is information; not useful information, of course; but useless information.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, "Yes." "They know this to be true even when they grow old. However, what I want is not money. Only those who pay their debts want money, dear Uncle George, whereas I never pay my debts. The capital of the younger sons of nobles is credit, and one can live quite pleasantly with this credit. Besides, I always do business with the Dartmoor tradesmen, so they never bother me. No, what I want is knowledge. Not useful knowledge, of course, but useless knowledge."
es_translation: —Yes —murmured Lord Henry, adjusting the flower in his jacket's buttonhole—; and when they grow old, they don't imagine it: they know it. But I don't want money. Only people who pay their bills need money, Uncle George, and I never pay mine. Credit is the capital of a second son, and one lives pleasantly with it. Besides, I always deal with the suppliers from Dartmoor and, consequently, they never bother me. What I want is information: not useful information, of course; perfectly useless information.

en: “Well, I can tell you anything that is in an English Blue Book, Harry, although those fellows nowadays write a lot of nonsense. When I was in the Diplomatic, things were much better. But I hear they let them in now by examination. What can you expect? Examinations, sir, are pure humbug from beginning to end. If a man is a gentleman, he knows quite enough, and if he is not a gentleman, whatever he knows is bad for him.”
vi: “Ừ, chú có thể kể cho cháu nghe mọi điều có trong cuốn Sách Xanh của Anh, Harry, mặc dù ngày nay các gã ấy viết rất nhiều thứ nhảm nhí. Khi chú còn làm trong ngành ngoại giao, các cái tốt hơn nhiều. Nhưng chú nghe nói bây giờ họ cho chúng vào bằng thi cử. Cháu có thể trông mong gì nữa? Thi cử, thưa cậu, chỉ là trò bịp bợm từ đầu đến cuối. Nếu ai là một quý nhân, anh ta sẽ biết đủ nhiều, còn nếu anh ta không phải một quý nhân, thì tất cả những gì anh ta biết đều hại cho anh ta.”
tr: “Valla, Harry, İngiltere’nin Mavi Kitabı’nda bulunan bilgilerden hangisini istersen sana aktarabilirim. Gerçi günümüzde bunu yazan herifler de sapıttılar ya. Ben diplomatik servisteyken işler daha düzenliydi. Oysa şimdi duyduğuma göre oraya da sınavla adam alıyorlarmış. Sınav denen şey de, mirim, baştan sona martavaldır. İnsan kibar takımından beyefendiyse bildikleri ona yeter de artar bile. Yok, beyefendi değilse, bildiği her şey kendisi için zararlıdır.
es: —Te puedo contar todo lo que contiene cualquier informe oficial, aunque quienes los redactan hoy en día escriben muchas tonterías. Cuando yo estaba en el cuerpo diplomático las cosas iban mucho mejor. Pero, según tengo entendido, ahora les hacen un examen de ingreso. ¿Hay que extrañarse del resultado? Los exámenes, señor mío, son pura mentira de principio a fin. Si una persona es un caballero, sabe más que suficiente, y si no lo es, todo lo que sepa es malo para él.
vi_translation: "Yes, I can tell you everything in the British Blue Book, Harry, although these days they write a lot of nonsense. When I was in the diplomatic service, things were much better. But I hear now they let them in through exams. What else can you expect? Exams, my boy, are just a fraud from start to finish. If a man is a gentleman, he will know enough, and if he is not a gentleman, then all he knows will only harm him."
tr_translation: "Well, Harry, I can relay to you any information you want from the Blue Book of England. Although, nowadays, the guys who write it have gone crazy. When I was in the diplomatic service, things were more orderly. But now, from what I hear, they even hire people there through exams. That thing called an exam, my friend, is nonsense from start to finish. If a person is a gentleman from the polite society, what he knows is more than enough for him. If he's not a gentleman, everything he knows is harmful to him."
es_translation: —I can tell you everything that any official report contains, although those who write them nowadays write a lot of nonsense. When I was in the diplomatic corps, things were much better. But, as I understand it, now they have to take an entrance exam. Should we be surprised at the result? Exams, my dear sir, are pure lies from beginning to end. If a person is a gentleman, he knows more than enough, and if he is not, everything he knows is bad for him.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray does not belong to Blue Books, Uncle George,” said Lord Henry languidly.
vi: “Mít-tơ Dorian Gray không liên quan đến Sách Xanh, thưa chú George,” huân tước Henry nói, uể oải.
tr: Lord Henry o tembel sesiyle, “mr Dorian Gray’in Mavi Kitap’ta yeri yok, George Amca,” dedi.
es: —El señor Dorian Gray no tiene nada que ver con el mundo de los informes oficiales, tío George —dijo lord Henry lánguidamente.
vi_translation: "Mr. Dorian Gray has nothing to do with the Blue Book, Uncle George," Lord Henry said languidly.
tr_translation: Lord Henry said in his lazy voice, "Mr. Dorian Gray has no place in the Blue Book, Uncle George."
es_translation: —Mr. Dorian Gray has nothing to do with the world of official reports, Uncle George —said Lord Henry languidly.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he?” asked Lord Fermor, knitting his bushy white eyebrows.
vi: “Mít-tơ Dorian Gray? Anh ta là ai?” huân tước Fermor hỏi, nhíu cặp mày rậm bạc trắng.
tr: Lord Fermor o çalı gibi beyaz kaşlarını çatarak, “Dorian Gray mi?” diye sordu. “O da kim?
es: —¿El señor Dorian Gray? ¿Quién es? —preguntó lord Fermor, frunciendo el espeso entrecejo cano.
vi_translation: “Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he?” Lord Fermor asked, furrowing his thick white eyebrows.
tr_translation: Lord Fermor furrowed his bushy white eyebrows and asked, "Dorian Gray?" "Who is he?"
es_translation: —Mr. Dorian Gray? Who is he? —asked Lord Fermor, furrowing his thick gray brow.

en: “That is what I have come to learn, Uncle George. Or rather, I know who he is. He is the last Lord Kelso’s grandson. His mother was a Devereux, Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What was she like? Whom did she marry? You have known nearly everybody in your time, so you might have known her. I am very much interested in Mr. Gray at present. I have only just met him.”
vi: “Đó là điều mà cháu đến để được nghe đây, chú George. Hoặc đúng hơn, cháu đã biết cậu ấy là ai. Cậu ấy là cháu trai của huân tước Kelso cuối cùng. Mẹ của cậu ấy là một người nhà Devereux; bà Margaret Devereux. Cháu muốn chú kể cháu nghe về mẹ cậu ấy. Cô ấy như thế nào? Cô ấy cưới ai? Chú biết gần như tất cả mọi người cùng thời, nên chú có thể biết cô ấy. Hiện tại cháu rất quan tâm đến mít-tơ Gray. Cháu vừa mới gặp cậu ấy.
tr: “İşte benim öğrenmeye geldiğim de bu, George Amca. Daha doğrusu, kim olduğunu bilmiyorum. Son Lord Kelso’nun torunu. Annesi Devereuxlerdenmiş, Leydi Margaret Devereux. Bana ondan söz etmenizi istiyorum. Nasıl bir kadındı? Kiminle evlendi? Siz zamanında hemen herkesi tanımışsınız; onu da tanıdınız belki. Şu sırada mr Gray’le yakından ilgileniyorum. Yeni tanıştık daha.
es: —Eso es lo que he venido a averiguar, tío George. Debo decir, más bien, que sé quién es. Es el nieto del último lord Kelso. Su madre era una Devereux, lady Margaret Devereux. Quiero que me hables de su madre. ¿Cómo era? ¿Con quién se casó? Trataste prácticamente a todo el mundo en tu época, de manera que quizá la hayas conocido. En el momento actual me interesa mucho el señor Gray. Acaban de presentármelo.
vi_translation: “That is what I came to hear, Uncle George. Or rather, I already know who he is. He is the grandson of the last Lord Kelso. His mother was a Devereux; Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What was she like? Whom did she marry? You know almost everyone of that time, so you might know her. At present, I am very interested in Mr. Gray. I have just met him.
tr_translation: "That's exactly what I came to learn, Uncle George. Or rather, I don't know who he is. The grandson of the late Lord Kelso. His mother was from the Devereux family, Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about her. What kind of woman was she? Whom did she marry? You've known almost everyone in your time; perhaps you knew her too. I'm currently very interested in Mr. Gray. We just met recently."
es_translation: —That is what I have come to find out, Uncle George. I should rather say, I know who he is. He is the grandson of the last Lord Kelso. His mother was a Devereux, Lady Margaret Devereux. I want you to tell me about his mother. What was she like? Whom did she marry? You practically dealt with everyone in your time, so perhaps you knew her. At the present moment, I am very interested in Mr. Gray. He has just been introduced to me.

en: “Kelso’s grandson!” echoed the old gentleman. “Kelso’s grandson! ... Of course.... I knew his mother intimately. I believe I was at her christening. She was an extraordinarily beautiful girl, Margaret Devereux, and made all the men frantic by running away with a penniless young fellow—a mere nobody, sir, a subaltern in a foot regiment, or something of that kind. Certainly. I remember the whole thing as if it happened yesterday. The poor chap was killed in a duel at Spa a few months after the marriage. There was an ugly story about it. They said Kelso got some rascally adventurer, some Belgian brute, to insult his son-in-law in public—paid him, sir, to do it, paid him—and that the fellow spitted his man as if he had been a pigeon. The thing was hushed up, but, egad, Kelso ate his chop alone at the club for some time afterwards. He brought his daughter back with him, I was told, and she never spoke to him again. Oh, yes; it was a bad business. The girl died, too, died within a year. So she left a son, did she? I had forgotten that. What sort of boy is he? If he is like his mother, he must be a good-looking chap.”
vi: “Cháu trai của Kelso!” ông già lặp lại — “cháu trai của Kelso!… Phải rồi… Chú biết mẹ nó tường tận. Chú tin là chú đã dự lễ rửa tội của cô ta. Cô ta là một phụ nữ tuyệt đẹp, Margaret Devereux; và khiến cho cả lũ đàn ông phát điên lên vì bỏ trốn với một gã thanh niên không xu dính túi; một kẻ chẳng là ai cả, cháu ạ, một sĩ quan cấp úy ở trung đoàn bộ binh, hoặc thứ gì đó đại loại như vậy. Chắc chắn. Chú còn nhớ toàn bộ mọi chuyện như thể nó vừa mới diễn ra hôm qua. Thanh niên tội nghiệp ấy bị giết trong cuộc thách đấu tay đôi ở Spa, vài tháng sau đám cưới. Có một câu chuyện đáng sợ về vụ này. Họ bảo Kelso sai một thằng giang hồ côn đồ nào đó, một thằng cục súc người Bỉ, đến sỉ nhục con rể mình giữa công chúng; trả tiền gã, cháu ạ, để làm việc đó, trả tiền gã; và rằng thằng cha ấy đã xiên nạn nhân của mình như thể anh ta là con bồ câu. Chuyện bị bưng bít, nhưng, ôi giời, Kelso ăn món sườn một mình ở câu lạc bộ suốt một thời gian khá lâu sau đó. Lão đưa con gái về lại với mình, chú nghe kể vậy, và cô ấy không bao giờ nói chuyện lại với lão. Ừ, đúng rồi; đó là một vụ rất tệ. Cô gái cũng chết; chết trong vòng một năm. Vậy là cô ấy có để lại đứa con trai hả? Chú quên mất chuyện ấy. Thằng bé thuộc dạng nào? Nếu nó giống mẹ thì chắc nó phải là một chàng trai rất đẹp.”
tr: İhtiyar Lord, “Kelso’nun torunu!” diye yeğeninin sözlerini tekrarladı. “Kelso’nun torunu!.. Tabii ya... Annesini çok yakından tanırdım. Vaftiz töreninde hazır bulunmuştum, yanılmıyorsam. Olağanüstü güzel bir kızdı, bu Margaret Devereux. Derken beş parasız bir gençle kaçtı, peşinden koşan hayranlarının hepsinin aklını başından aldı. Kaçtığı genç adı anılmaz biriydi, mirim, bir piyade alayında astsubay mı, öyle bir şey. Tabii ya. Daha dünmüş gibi aklımda hepsi. Zavallı çocuk, düğünden birkaç ay sonra Spa’da, bir düelloda öldü. Bununla ilgili çirkin bir de söylenti çıkmıştı. Damadına, ele güne karşı hakarette bulunsun diye Kelso’nun aşağılık bir serseriyle anlaştığını söylüyorlardı. Belçikalı bir hayvanmış herif. Kelso bu herife para vermiş sözümona; resmen para vermiş, Belçikalı da avını keklik avlar gibi vurmuş. Olay örtbas edildi, mirim, ne var ki ondan sonra kulüpte kimse Kelso’ya sokulmaz oldu. Duyduğuma göre kızını da alıp getirmiş ama kız bir daha onunla hiç konuşmamış. Evet, pis işti, doğrusunu istersen. Kız da ölüp gitti, yılına varmadan öldü. Demek geride bir erkek çocuk bırakmış ha? Bak bunu unutmuşum. Neye benziyor çocuk? Anasına benzemişse yakışıklıdır.
es: —¡Nieto de Kelso! —repitió el anciano caballero—. El nieto de Kelso... Claro... Conocí muy bien a su madre. Creo que asistí a su bautizo. Era una joven extraordinariamente hermosa, Margaret Devereux, y volvió loco a todo el mundo escapándose con un joven que no tenía un céntimo, un don nadie, señor mío, un suboficial de infantería o algo por el estilo. Ya lo creo. Lo recuerdo todo como si hubiera sucedido ayer. Al pobre infeliz lo mataron en un duelo en Spa pocos meses después de la boda. Una historia muy fea. Dijeron que Kelso se agenció un aventurero sin escrúpulos, un animal belga, para que insultara en público a su yerno; le pagó, señor mío, para que lo hiciera; le pagó y luego aquel individuo ensartó al suboficial como si fuera un pichón. Echaron tierra sobre el asunto, pero, cielo santo, Kelso comió solo en el club durante cierto tiempo después de aquello. Recogió a su hija, según me contaron, pero la chica nunca volvió a dirigirle la palabra. Sí, sí, un asunto muy feo. Margaret también se murió, en menos de un año. De manera que dejó un hijo, ¿no es eso? Lo había olvidado. ¿Cómo es el chico? Si es como su madre debe de ser bien parecido.
vi_translation: “Kelso's grandson!” the old man repeated — “Kelso's grandson!… That's right… I knew his mother very well. I believe I attended her baptism. She was a beautiful woman, Margaret Devereux; and she drove all the men crazy by eloping with a penniless young man; a nobody, my dear, a lieutenant in the infantry regiment, or something like that. Absolutely. I remember the whole thing as if it happened yesterday. The poor young man was killed in a duel at Spa, a few months after the wedding. There's a dreadful story about it. They say Kelso hired some thug, a brutal Belgian, to insult his son-in-law in public; paid him, my dear, to do it, paid him; and that fellow skewered his victim as if he were a pigeon. The matter was hushed up, but, oh dear, Kelso ate his chops alone at the club for quite a long time afterward. He took his daughter back, I heard, and she never spoke to him again. Yes, indeed; it was a very bad business. The girl died too; died within a year. So she left a son, did she? I had forgotten that. What sort of boy is he? If he takes after his mother, he must be a very handsome young man.”
tr_translation: The old Lord repeated his nephew's words, "Kelso's grandson!" "Kelso's grandson!.. Of course... I knew his mother very well. I was present at her christening, if I'm not mistaken. She was an extraordinarily beautiful girl, this Margaret Devereux. Then she eloped with a penniless young man, driving all her admirers crazy. The young man she eloped with was a nobody, sir, a sergeant in an infantry regiment or something like that. Of course. It's all as clear as if it were yesterday. Poor boy, he died in a duel in Spa a few months after the wedding. There was an ugly rumor about it. They said Kelso had hired a lowlife to insult his son-in-law in public. The guy was a Belgian brute. Apparently, Kelso paid this guy; literally paid him, and the Belgian shot his prey like a sitting duck. The incident was covered up, sir, but after that, no one at the club would go near Kelso. I heard he brought his daughter back, but she never spoke to him again. Yes, it was a dirty business, to be honest. The girl died too, within a year she was dead. So she left behind a son? I had forgotten that. What does the boy look like? If he looks like his mother, he must be handsome.”
es_translation: —Grandson of Kelso! —repeated the elderly gentleman—. The grandson of Kelso... Of course... I knew his mother very well. I believe I attended his christening. She was an extraordinarily beautiful young woman, Margaret Devereux, and she drove everyone mad by running off with a young man who didn't have a penny, a nobody, sir, a non-commissioned infantry officer or something like that. Indeed. I remember it all as if it had happened yesterday. The poor fellow was killed in a duel in Spa a few months after the wedding. A very ugly story. They said Kelso hired an unscrupulous adventurer, a Belgian brute, to publicly insult his son-in-law; he paid him, sir, to do it; he paid him and then that individual skewered the non-commissioned officer like a pigeon. They covered up the matter, but, good heavens, Kelso dined alone at the club for some time after that. He took his daughter in, so I was told, but the girl never spoke to him again. Yes, yes, a very ugly affair. Margaret also died, in less than a year. So she left a son, didn't she? I had forgotten. What is the boy like? If he is like his mother, he must be quite handsome.

en: “He is very good-looking,” assented Lord Henry.
vi: “Cậu ấy rất đẹp,” huân tước Henry tán thành.
tr: Lord Henry, “Çok yakışıklı,” diye amcasını doğruladı.
es: —Es bien parecido —asintió lord Henry.
vi_translation: “He is very beautiful,” Lord Henry agreed.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "Very handsome," he confirmed his uncle.
es_translation: —He is quite handsome —agreed Lord Henry.

en: “I hope he will fall into proper hands,” continued the old man. “He should have a pot of money waiting for him if Kelso did the right thing by him. His mother had money, too. All the Selby property came to her, through her grandfather. Her grandfather hated Kelso, thought him a mean dog. He was, too. Came to Madrid once when I was there. Egad, I was ashamed of him. The Queen used to ask me about the English noble who was always quarrelling with the cabmen about their fares. They made quite a story of it. I didn’t dare show my face at Court for a month. I hope he treated his grandson better than he did the jarvies.”
vi: “Chú mong là nó sẽ rơi vào những bàn tay thích hợp,” ông già tiếp tục. “Lẽ ra nó đã có cả đống tiền chờ sẵn nếu như Kelso làm điều đúng đắn cho nó. Mẹ nó cũng có tiền đấy. Tất cả tài sản nhà Selby chuyển về cô ấy, qua ông của cô ấy. Ông của cô ấy ghét Kelso, nghĩ tay đó là một thằng chó bần tiện. Lão thì cũng vậy thôi. Đến Madrid một lần hồi chú ở đó. Ôi giời, chú phát ngượng với lão. Nữ hoàng hay hỏi chú về một quý tộc Anh thường xuyên cãi nhau với xà ích về tiền cước. Họ dựng cả một câu chuyện về vụ đó. Chú không dám ló mặt ra tại Cung điện suốt một tháng liền. Chú mong là lão đối xử với cháu mình tốt hơn là lão đã từng làm với những người đánh xe thuê.
tr: İhtiyar Lord sözünü sürdürerek, “Umarım doğru dürüst ellere düşer,” dedi. “Kelso, gerekeni yapmışsa çocuğun bir küp paraya konması gerekir. Anası da paralıydı. Selbylerin olanca mülkü kalmıştı dedesinden. Bu dede, Kelso’dan nefret eder, hain hayvan, derdi ona. Sahiden de öyleydi ya. Bir kez Madrid’e gelmişti, ben oradayken. Beni yerin dibine soktuydu. Kraliçe bana, arabacılarla ücret konusunda kavgaya tutuşan İngiliz soylusunu sorardı hep. Arabacılar olayları allayıp pullayıp anlatırlardı. Tam bir ay sarayda yüzümü gösteremedim. Umarım arabacılara yaptığını torununa yapmamıştır.
es: —Espero que caiga en buenas manos —prosiguió el anciano—. Heredará un montón de dinero si Kelso se ha portado bien con él. Su madre también tenía dinero. Le correspondieron todas las propiedades de Selby, a través de su abuelo. Su abuelo odiaba a Kelso, lo consideraba un tacaño de mucho cuidado. Y no se equivocaba. Fue a Madrid en una ocasión cuando yo estaba allí. Cielo santo, logró que me avergonzase de él. La reina me preguntaba quién era el noble inglés que siempre se peleaba con los cocheros por el precio de las carreras. Menuda historia. Pasé un mes sin aparecer por la Corte. Confío en que tratara a su nieto mejor que a los cocheros de alquiler.
vi_translation: “I hope it falls into the right hands,” the old man continued. “It would have had a pile of money waiting if Kelso had done the right thing for it. Its mother also has money. All the Selby family assets were transferred to her, through her grandfather. Her grandfather hated Kelso, thought he was a despicable scoundrel. He was just the same. Came to Madrid once while I was there. Oh my, I was so embarrassed by him. The Queen often asked me about an English nobleman who frequently argued with the coachmen over fares. They made up a whole story about that incident. I didn't dare show my face at the Palace for a whole month. I hope he treats his grandchild better than he treated those hired drivers.”
tr_translation: The old Lord continued, "I hope he falls into the right hands," he said. "If Kelso has done what is necessary, the child should come into a pot of money. His mother was wealthy too. She had inherited all the Selbys' property from her grandfather. This grandfather hated Kelso, called him a treacherous animal. And indeed he was. He had come to Madrid once, while I was there. He had humiliated me. The Queen would always ask me about the English nobleman who got into fights with the coachmen over fares. The coachmen would embellish the stories. I couldn't show my face at the palace for a whole month. I hope he didn't do to his grandson what he did to the coachmen."
es_translation: —I hope it falls into good hands —continued the old man—. He will inherit a lot of money if Kelso has treated him well. His mother also had money. She received all the Selby properties through her grandfather. His grandfather hated Kelso, he considered him a very stingy man. And he was not wrong. He went to Madrid once when I was there. Good heavens, he made me ashamed of him. The queen asked me who the English nobleman was who always argued with the coachmen over the fare. What a story. I spent a month without appearing at the Court. I trust he treated his grandson better than the hired coachmen.

en: “I don’t know,” answered Lord Henry. “I fancy that the boy will be well off. He is not of age yet. He has Selby, I know. He told me so. And ... his mother was very beautiful?”
vi: “Cháu không biết,” huân tước Henry trả lời. “Cháu cho là cậu bé ấy sẽ giàu sụ thôi. Cậu ấy còn chưa đến tuổi. Cậu ấy được hưởng Selby, cháu biết. Cậu ấy bảo cháu vậy. Còn… mẹ cậu ấy rất đẹp phải không?”
tr: “Bilmiyorum,” dedi Lord Henry. “Çocuğun parasız kalacağını sanmıyorum. Daha ergenlik yaşına varmamış. Selby ona bakıyor. Biliyorum, kendisi söyledi bana. Demek... Annesi çok güzeldi ha?
es: —No lo sé —respondió lord Henry—. Imagino que al chico no le faltará de nada. Todavía no es mayor de edad. Sé que Selby es suyo: lo sé porque me lo ha dicho él. Y.., ¿su madre, entonces, era muy hermosa?
vi_translation: “I don't know,” Lord Henry replied. “I suppose that boy will be very rich. He is not of age yet. He will inherit Selby, you know. He told me so. And… his mother is very beautiful, isn't she?”
tr_translation: “I don't know,” said Lord Henry. “I don't think the child will be left without money. He hasn't even reached adolescence yet. Selby is looking after him. I know, he told me himself. So... His mother was very beautiful, huh?”
es_translation: —I don't know —responded Lord Henry—. I imagine the boy will want for nothing. He is still not of age. I know Selby is his: I know because he told me so. And... was his mother very beautiful then?

en: “Margaret Devereux was one of the loveliest creatures I ever saw, Harry. What on earth induced her to behave as she did, I never could understand. She could have married anybody she chose. Carlington was mad after her. She was romantic, though. All the women of that family were. The men were a poor lot, but, egad! the women were wonderful. Carlington went on his knees to her. Told me so himself. She laughed at him, and there wasn’t a girl in London at the time who wasn’t after him. And by the way, Harry, talking about silly marriages, what is this humbug your father tells me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an American? Ain’t English girls good enough for him?”
vi: “Margaret Devereux là một trong những tạo vật đáng yêu nhất mà chú từng nhìn thấy, Harry à. Cái gì trên cõi trần tục này đã xui khiến cô ấy cư xử như cô ấy từng làm, chú không bao giờ có thể hiểu được. Cô ấy có thể cưới bất cứ ai cô ấy chọn. Carlington say mê cô ấy. Cô ấy mơ mộng, thế đấy. Mọi phụ nữ trong họ nhà ấy đều vậy. Đàn ông thì một lũ đáng thương, nhưng, giời ơi! đàn bà thì tuyệt vời. Carlington quỳ gối mà lết đến cô ấy. Tự hắn kể cho chú nghe như vậy. Cô ấy cười hắn, vậy mà không một cô gái nào ở London thời đó lại không theo đuổi hắn. Nhân thể, Harry, đang nói về những cuộc hôn nhân ngớ ngẩn, thế cái chuyện tầm bậy mà bố cháu kể cho chú nghe về việc Dartmoor muốn cưới một người Mỹ là thế nào? Chả nhẽ nào mà gái Anh không đủ tốt cho gã hay sao?”
tr: “Harry, Margaret Devereux ömrümde gördüğüm en güzel yaratıklardan biriydi. Hangi akla uydu da öyle işler karıştırdı, bilemeyeceğim. Kime isterse varabilirdi. Carlington çıldırıyordu onun için. Ama kız romantikti. O ailenin bütün kadınları romantikti. Erkeklerinde iş yoktu ama, kadınları şahaneydi doğrusu! Carlington Margaret’e diz çöküp yalvarmış, kendisi söylediydi bana. Margaret ona gülüp geçmiş, oysa o sıralar Londra’da kaç kız varsa Carlington’un peşindeydi. Ha, aklıma gelmişken, Harry... Uygunsuz evlilikten konuşuyorduk ya... Babandan duyduğuma göre Dartmoor, Amerikalının biriyle evlenmek istiyormuş, nedir bu rezalet? İngiliz kızları nesine yetmiyormuş?
es: —Margaret Devereux era una de las criaturas más encantadoras que he visto nunca, Harry. Qué la impulsó a comportarse como lo hizo es algo que nunca entenderé. Podría haberse casado con quien hubiera querido. Carlington estaba loco por ella. Pero era una romántica. Todas las mujeres de esa familia lo han sido. Los hombres no valían nada, pero, cielo santo, las mujeres eran maravillosas. Carlington se declaró de rodillas. Me lo dijo él mismo. Margaret Devereux se rió de él, y no había por entonces una chica en Londres que no quisiera pescarlo. Y, por cierto, Harry, hablando de matrimonios estúpidos, ¿qué es esa patraña que me cuenta tu padre de que Dartmoor se quiere casar con una americana? ¿Es que las chicas inglesas no son lo bastante buenas para él?
vi_translation: “Margaret Devereux was one of the most delightful creatures I have ever seen, Harry. What on earth could have induced her to behave as she did, I can never understand. She could have married anyone she chose. Carlington was madly in love with her. She was dreamy, that's it. All the women in that family are. The men are a poor lot, but, my God! the women are wonderful. Carlington crawled on his knees to her. He himself told me so. She laughed at him, yet there wasn't a girl in London at that time who wouldn't have pursued him. By the way, Harry, speaking of foolish marriages, what is this nonsense your father told me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an American? Isn't an English girl good enough for him?”
tr_translation: “Harry, Margaret Devereux was one of the most beautiful creatures I have ever seen. What possessed her to get involved in such things, I will never know. She could have married anyone she wanted. Carlington was madly in love with her. But the girl was romantic. All the women in that family were romantic. The men were useless, but the women were truly magnificent! Carlington had knelt down and begged Margaret, he himself told me. Margaret just laughed it off, even though at that time every girl in London was after Carlington. Oh, now that I remember, Harry... We were talking about unsuitable marriages... From what I heard from your father, Dartmoor wants to marry some American, what is this scandal? What’s wrong with English girls?”
es_translation: —Margaret Devereux was one of the most charming creatures I have ever seen, Harry. What drove her to behave as she did is something I will never understand. She could have married anyone she wanted. Carlington was madly in love with her. But she was a romantic. All the women in that family have been. The men were worthless, but, good heavens, the women were wonderful. Carlington proposed on his knees. He told me so himself. Margaret Devereux laughed at him, and there wasn't a girl in London at the time who didn't want to catch him. And, by the way, Harry, speaking of foolish marriages, what is that nonsense your father tells me about Dartmoor wanting to marry an American? Are English girls not good enough for him?

en: “It is rather fashionable to marry Americans just now, Uncle George.”
vi: “Thì lấy Mỹ cũng là chuyện khá hợp mốt bây giờ mà, chú George.”
tr: “George Amcacığım, şu sıralar Amerikalılarla evlenmek biraz moda oldu da.
es: —Ahora está bastante de moda casarse con americanas, tío George.
vi_translation: “Marrying an American is quite fashionable nowadays, Uncle George.”
tr_translation: "Uncle George, marrying Americans has become a bit of a trend these days.""
es_translation: —Now it's quite fashionable to marry American women, Uncle George.

en: “I’ll back English women against the world, Harry,” said Lord Fermor, striking the table with his fist.
vi: “Chú sẽ đặt cược vào phụ nữ Anh trước cả thế giới, Harry,” huân tước Fermor nói, đấm nắm tay lên bàn.
tr: Lord Fermor yumruğunu masaya indirerek, “Harry, bence İngiliz kadınları bir yana, dünya bir yana,” dedi.
es: —Yo apoyo a las mujeres inglesas contra el mundo entero, Harry —dijo lord Fermor, golpeando la mesa con el puño.
vi_translation: “I would bet on English women against the whole world, Harry,” Lord Fermor said, pounding his fist on the table.
tr_translation: Lord Fermor slammed his fist on the table and said, "Harry, I think English women are one thing, and the world is another."
es_translation: —I support English women against the whole world, Harry —said Lord Fermor, hitting the table with his fist.

en: “The betting is on the Americans.”
vi: “Tiền cược đang đổ vào bên phụ nữ Mỹ.”
tr: “Oysa Amerikalılar gözde.
es: —Todo el mundo apuesta por las americanas.
vi_translation: “The bets are pouring in on the American women's side.”
tr_translation: “But Americans are favorites.”
es_translation: —Everyone bets on the Americans.

en: “They don’t last, I am told,” muttered his uncle.
vi: “Họ chẳng bền đâu, chú nghe đồn,” chú y càu nhàu.
tr: “Dayanıksızmışlar, diye duyuyorum.
es: —No duran, según me han dicho —murmuró su tío.
vi_translation: “They won't last, I heard,” he grumbled.
tr_translation: “I hear they are not durable,””
es_translation: —They don't last, so I've been told —murmured his uncle.

en: “A long engagement exhausts them, but they are capital at a steeplechase. They take things flying. I don’t think Dartmoor has a chance.”
vi: “Sự ràng buộc dài lâu làm họ kiệt sức, song họ xuất sắc trong cuộc đua ngựa vượt rào. Họ bay vượt qua chúng. Cháu không nghĩ Dartmoor có cơ hội.”
tr: “Maç uzun sürerse yorulup bitkin düşüyorlar, gelgelelim düz koşuda üstlerine yok. Sanki uçuyorlar! Ben Dartmoor’a hiç şans tanımıyorum.
es: —Las carreras de fondo las agotan, pero son inigualables en las de obstáculos. Lo saltan todo sin pestañear. No creo que Dartmoor tenga la menor posibilidad.
vi_translation: “The long-term binding exhausts them, but they excel in the steeplechase. They soar over the obstacles. I don't think Dartmoor stands a chance.”
tr_translation: "If the match lasts long, they get tired and exhausted, but when it comes to straight running, there's no one better than them. It's as if they're flying! I don't give Dartmoor any chance at all."
es_translation: —Long-distance races wear them out, but they are unmatched in obstacle races. They jump over everything without blinking. I don't think Dartmoor has the slightest chance.

en: “Who are her people?” grumbled the old gentleman. “Has she got any?”
vi: “Ai là người nhà cô ta?” ông già càu nhàu. “Cô ta có ai không?”
tr: İhtiyar Lord homurdanarak, “Ailesi kimlermiş?” diye sordu. “Daha doğrusu, ailesi var mıymış?
es: —¿Quiénes son sus padres? —gruñó el anciano—. ¿Acaso los tiene?
vi_translation: "Who is her family?" the old man grumbled. "Does she have anyone?"
tr_translation: The old Lord grumbled, "Who are his family?" he asked. "Or rather, does he even have a family?"
es_translation: —Who are your parents? —grumbled the old man—. Do you even have any?

en: Lord Henry shook his head. “American girls are as clever at concealing their parents, as English women are at concealing their past,” he said, rising to go.
vi: Huân tước Henry lắc đầu. “Gái Mỹ cũng giỏi trong việc giấu cha mẹ như phụ nữ Anh trong việc giấu quá khứ,” y vừa nói vừa đứng dậy định đi.
tr: Lord Henry başını salladı. “İngiliz kadınları geçmişlerini saklamakta nasıl ustaysalar, Amerikalı kızlar da ana babalarını saklamakta o denli kurnaz oluyorlar,” diyerek gitmek üzere ayağa kalktı.
es: Lord Henry negó con la cabeza. —Las jóvenes americanas son tan inteligentes para esconder a sus padres como las mujeres inglesas para ocultar su pasado —dijo lord Henry, levantándose para marcharse.
vi_translation: Lord Henry shook his head. "American girls are just as good at hiding things from their parents as English women are at hiding their past," he said as he stood up to leave.
tr_translation: Lord Henry nodded his head. “While English women are adept at hiding their pasts, American girls are equally cunning at hiding their parents,” he said, standing up to leave.
es_translation: Lord Henry shook his head. —American young women are as clever at hiding things from their parents as English women are at concealing their past —said Lord Henry, getting up to leave.

en: “They are pork-packers, I suppose?”
vi: “Họ là những người buôn thịt lợn, chú nghĩ vậy đúng không?”
tr: “Domuz mezbahasında falan çalışıyorlar olsa gerek, öyle değil mi?
es: —Serán chacineros, supongo.
vi_translation: “They are pork traders, don't you think so?”
tr_translation: “They must be working at a pig slaughterhouse or something, isn't that right?”
es_translation: —They must be butchers, I suppose.

en: “I hope so, Uncle George, for Dartmoor’s sake. I am told that pork-packing is the most lucrative profession in America, after politics.”
vi: “Cháu hy vọng thế, chú George, vì lợi cho Dartmoor. Cháu nghe đồn rằng buôn thịt lợn là nghề lãi nhất ở Mỹ, chỉ sau chính trị.”
tr: “Umarım öyledir, George Amca, Dartmoor’un hesabına öyle olmasını umarım. Denilene göre Amerika’da politikadan sonra en kârlı meslek domuz mezbahacılığıymış.
es: —Eso espero, tío George, por el bien de Dartmoor. Me dicen que la chacinería es una de las profesiones más lucrativas de los Estados Unidos, después de la política.
vi_translation: “I hope so, Uncle George, for the sake of Dartmoor. I've heard that pork trading is the most profitable business in America, second only to politics.”
tr_translation: "I hope so, Uncle George, for Dartmoor's sake, I hope so." "They say that after politics, the most profitable profession in America is pig slaughtering.""
es_translation: —I hope so, Uncle George, for Dartmoor's sake. They tell me that butchery is one of the most lucrative professions in the United States, after politics.

en: “Is she pretty?”
vi: “Cô ta xinh không?”
tr: “Kız güzel mi bari?
es: —¿Es bonita esa muchacha?
vi_translation: “Is she pretty?”
tr_translation: “Is the girl at least beautiful?”
es_translation: —Is that girl pretty?

en: “She behaves as if she was beautiful. Most American women do. It is the secret of their charm.”
vi: “Cô ta cư xử cứ như mình đẹp lắm vậy. Phần lớn phụ nữ Mỹ làm thế. Đó là bí quyết sự quyến rũ của họ.”
tr: “Güzelmiş gibi havalarda. Amerikan kadınlarının çoğu böyle. Çekiciliklerinin gizi de bu.
es: —Se comporta como si fuese hermosa. La mayoría de las americanas lo hacen. Es el secreto de su encanto.
vi_translation: “She acts as if she is very beautiful. Most American women do that. That is the secret of their charm.”
tr_translation: "As if it's beautiful in the weather. Most American women are like this. The secret of their charm is this."
es_translation: —She behaves as if she were beautiful. Most American women do. It's the secret of their charm.

en: “Why can’t these American women stay in their own country? They are always telling us that it is the paradise for women.”
vi: “Tại sao những phụ nữ Mỹ ấy không thể ở lại nước họ? Họ luôn bảo ta rằng đó là thiên đường cho phụ nữ.”
tr: “Bu Amerikalı kadınlar kendi memleketlerinde otursalar olmuyor mu? Oranın kadınlar için bir cennet olduğunu başımıza kakıp duruyorlar ya.
es: —¿Por qué no se quedan en su país? Siempre nos están diciendo que es el paraíso de las mujeres.
vi_translation: “Why can't those American women stay in their own country? They always tell us that it is a paradise for women.”
tr_translation: “Can't these American women stay in their own country? They keep bragging that it's a paradise for women there.”
es_translation: —Why don't they stay in their country? They are always telling us that it is a paradise for women.

en: “It is. That is the reason why, like Eve, they are so excessively anxious to get out of it,” said Lord Henry. “Good-bye, Uncle George. I shall be late for lunch, if I stop any longer. Thanks for giving me the information I wanted. I always like to know everything about my new friends, and nothing about my old ones.”
vi: “Nó thế thật. Đó là nguyên nhân tại sao mà, như Eve, họ lại quá khao khát thoát khỏi nó đến thế,” huân tước Henry nói. “Tạm biệt, chú George. Cháu sẽ muộn bữa trưa mất, nếu cháu ở lại lâu hơn. Cảm ơn vì đã cho cháu thông tin cháu cần. Cháu luôn muốn biết hết về bạn mới, và hết muốn biết về bạn cũ.”
tr: “Amerika gerçekten de öyle. Amerikalı kadınlar da işte bu yüzden, tıpkı Havva gibi, oradan kaçıp kurtulmak için can atıyorlar ya!” dedi Lord Henry. “Hoşça kalın, George Amca. Biraz daha oyalanırsam yemeğe geç kalacağım. Bana istediğim bilgiyi verdiğiniz için teşekkürler. Yeni edindiğim dostlara ilişkin bilinecek ne varsa bilmek isterim oldum olası, eski dostlarım konusunda hiçbir şey bilmemek...
es: —Lo es. Ésa es la razón de que, como Eva, estén tan excesivamente ansiosas de abandonarlo —dijo lord Henry—. Adiós, tío George. Gracias por darme la información que quería. Me gusta saberlo todo sobre mis nuevos amigos y nada sobre los viejos.
vi_translation: “It is indeed so. That is why, like Eve, they are so eager to escape from it,” said Lord Henry. “Goodbye, Uncle George. I will be late for lunch if I stay any longer. Thank you for giving me the information I needed. I always want to know everything about new friends, and everything about old friends.”
tr_translation: “America is really like that. And that's why American women, just like Eve, are eager to escape from there!” said Lord Henry. “Goodbye, Uncle George. If I linger a bit more, I'll be late for dinner. Thank you for giving me the information I wanted. I've always wanted to know everything about my new friends, but nothing about my old friends...”
es_translation: —It is. That is the reason why, like Eve, they are so excessively anxious to leave it —said Lord Henry—. Goodbye, Uncle George. Thank you for giving me the information I wanted. I like to know everything about my new friends and nothing about the old ones.

en: “Where are you lunching, Harry?”
vi: “Cháu ăn trưa ở đâu vậy, Harry?”
tr: “Yemeği nerede yiyorsun, Harry?
es: —¿Dónde almuerzas hoy, Harry?
vi_translation: "Where did you have lunch, Harry?"
tr_translation: “Where do you eat, Harry?”
es_translation: —Where are you having lunch today, Harry?

en: “At Aunt Agatha’s. I have asked myself and Mr. Gray. He is her latest protégé.”
vi: “Ở chỗ dì Agatha. Cháu xin cho mình và mít- tơ Gray. Cậu ấy là protégé1 mới nhất của dì ấy. 1 Người được bảo trợ.
tr: “Agatha Hala’da. Kendi kendimi davet ettirdim, bir de mr Gray’i. mr Gray, halamın en son protégé’si.
es: —En casa de tía Agatha. He hecho que me invite, junto con el señor Gray, que es su último protégé.
vi_translation: "At Aunt Agatha's place." "I requested for myself and Mr. Gray. He is her latest protégé." 1 Sponsored person.
tr_translation: “Agatha is at my aunt's. I invited myself, and also Mr. Gray. Mr. Gray is my aunt's latest protégé.”
es_translation: —At Aunt Agatha's house. I have arranged for her to invite me, along with Mr. Gray, who is her latest protégé.
