en: “Humph! tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me any more with her charity appeals. I am sick of them. Why, the good woman thinks that I have nothing to do but to write cheques for her silly fads.”
vi: “Hừm! Bảo dì Agatha nhà cháu, Harry, là đừng quấy rầy chú thêm một tí nào nữa với những lời kêu gọi làm từ thiện của bà ấy. Chú phát ốm với chúng. Tại sao mà người đàn bà tốt bụng ấy lại nghĩ là chú không có việc gì khác để làm ngoài viết séc cho những trò ngớ ngẩn nhất thời của bà ấy.”
tr: “Sevsinler! Harry, Agatha Halana söyle, bağış isteğiyle canımı sıkmaktan vazgeçsin. Şurama geldi. Yahu, hatuncağız sanıyor ki onun enayi tutkuları için çek yazmaktan başka hiç işim yok!
es: —¡Umm! Dile a tu tía Agatha, Harry, que no me moleste más con sus empresas caritativas. Estoy harto. Caramba, la buena mujer cree que no tengo nada mejor que hacer que escribir cheques para sus estúpidas ocurrencias.
vi_translation: “Hmph! Tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me any more with her charity appeals. I'm sick of them. Why does that good woman think I have nothing better to do than write checks for her whimsical nonsense.”
tr_translation: “Let them love! Harry, tell Aunt Agatha to stop bothering me with donation requests. I've had it up to here. Good grief, the poor woman thinks I have nothing better to do than write checks for her silly obsessions!”
es_translation: —Hmm! Tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me anymore with her charitable enterprises. I'm fed up. Goodness, the good woman thinks I have nothing better to do than write checks for her stupid whims.

en: “All right, Uncle George, I’ll tell her, but it won’t have any effect. Philanthropic people lose all sense of humanity. It is their distinguishing characteristic.”
vi: “Được rồi, chú George, cháu sẽ bảo dì ấy, nhưng cũng chẳng có tác dụng gì đâu. Những người nhân từ thường đánh mất mọi ý thức nhân tính. Đó là đặc điểm nổi bật của họ.
tr: “Peki, amcacığım, ben söylerim ama hiç etkisi olmayacaktır. Hayır işleriyle uğraşan kişiler tüm insanlıklarını yitiriyorlar. Onları bu özellikleriyle ayırt edebilirsin.
es: —De acuerdo, tío George, se lo diré, pero no tendrá ningún efecto. Las personas filantrópicas pierden toda noción de humanidad. Se las reconoce por eso.
vi_translation: “Alright, Uncle George, I will tell her, but it won't make any difference. Kind-hearted people often lose all sense of humanity. That is their most prominent characteristic.”
tr_translation: “Well, uncle, I will tell them, but it will have no effect. People who are involved in charity work lose all their humanity. You can distinguish them by this characteristic.”
es_translation: —Alright, Uncle George, I'll tell him, but it won't have any effect. Philanthropic people lose all sense of humanity. They are recognized by that.

en: The old gentleman growled approvingly and rang the bell for his servant. Lord Henry passed up the low arcade into Burlington Street and turned his steps in the direction of Berkeley Square.
vi: Ông già lẩm bẩm đồng tình, và rung chuông gọi người hầu. Huân tước Henry đi qua con đường có mái vòm che thấp dẫn ra phố Burlington, rồi quay bước theo hướng quảng trường Berkeley.
tr: İhtiyar Lord beğenisini belirten bir homurtu çıkararak çıngırağı çalıp uşağını çağırdı. Lord Henry alçak kemerin altından geçerek Burlington Sokağı’na çıktı, oradan da adımlarını Berkeley Meydanı’na yöneltti.
es: El anciano caballero gruñó aprobadoramente y llamó para que entrara su criado. Lord Henry atravesó unos soportales de poca altura para llegar a Burlington Street, y dirigió sus pasos en dirección a la plaza de Berkeley.
vi_translation: The old man muttered in agreement and rang the bell to call the servant. Lord Henry walked through the low-arched passage leading to Burlington Street, then turned towards Berkeley Square.
tr_translation: The old Lord let out a grunt of approval and rang the bell to call his servant. Lord Henry passed under the low arch and stepped out onto Burlington Street, from where he directed his steps towards Berkeley Square.
es_translation: The elderly gentleman grunted approvingly and called for his servant to come in. Lord Henry crossed some low arcades to reach Burlington Street, and made his way towards Berkeley Square.

en: So that was the story of Dorian Gray’s parentage. Crudely as it had been told to him, it had yet stirred him by its suggestion of a strange, almost modern romance. A beautiful woman risking everything for a mad passion. A few wild weeks of happiness cut short by a hideous, treacherous crime. Months of voiceless agony, and then a child born in pain. The mother snatched away by death, the boy left to solitude and the tyranny of an old and loveless man. Yes; it was an interesting background. It posed the lad, made him more perfect, as it were. Behind every exquisite thing that existed, there was something tragic. Worlds had to be in travail, that the meanest flower might blow.... And how charming he had been at dinner the night before, as with startled eyes and lips parted in frightened pleasure he had sat opposite to him at the club, the red candleshades staining to a richer rose the wakening wonder of his face. Talking to him was like playing upon an exquisite violin. He answered to every touch and thrill of the bow.... There was something terribly enthralling in the exercise of influence. No other activity was like it. To project one’s soul into some gracious form, and let it tarry there for a moment; to hear one’s own intellectual views echoed back to one with all the added music of passion and youth; to convey one’s temperament into another as though it were a subtle fluid or a strange perfume: there was a real joy in that—perhaps the most satisfying joy left to us in an age so limited and vulgar as our own, an age grossly carnal in its pleasures, and grossly common in its aims.... He was a marvellous type, too, this lad, whom by so curious a chance he had met in Basil’s studio, or could be fashioned into a marvellous type, at any rate. Grace was his, and the white purity of boyhood, and beauty such as old Greek marbles kept for us. There was nothing that one could not do with him. He could be made a Titan or a toy. What a pity it was that such beauty was destined to fade! ... And Basil? From a psychological point of view, how interesting he was! The new manner in art, the fresh mode of looking at life, suggested so strangely by the merely visible presence of one who was unconscious of it all; the silent spirit that dwelt in dim woodland, and walked unseen in open field, suddenly showing herself, Dryadlike and not afraid, because in his soul who sought for her there had been wakened that wonderful vision to which alone are wonderful things revealed; the mere shapes and patterns of things becoming, as it were, refined, and gaining a kind of symbolical value, as though they were themselves patterns of some other and more perfect form whose shadow they made real: how strange it all was! He remembered something like it in history. Was it not Plato, that artist in thought, who had first analyzed it? Was it not Buonarotti who had carved it in the coloured marbles of a sonnet-sequence? But in our own century it was strange.... Yes; he would try to be to Dorian Gray what, without knowing it, the lad was to the painter who had fashioned the wonderful portrait. He would seek to dominate him—had already, indeed, half done so. He would make that wonderful spirit his own. There was something fascinating in this son of love and death.
vi: Vậy đó là câu chuyện về dòng dõi của Dorian Gray. Sống sượng như nó từng được kể cho y nghe, song nó đã khuấy động lòng y bằng sự ám thị về một chuyện tình lãng mạn lạ lùng, gần như hiện đại. Một phụ nữ đẹp đã gánh chịu mọi rủi ro cho niềm đam mê điên dại của mình. Vài tuần hạnh phúc phóng túng bị cắt ngắn bởi một tội ác ghê tởm, xảo trá. Nhiều tháng thống khổ câm lặng, rồi một đứa trẻ sinh ra trong đau đớn. Người mẹ bị cái chết bắt cóc, thằng bé bị bỏ lại trong cảnh cô đơn và sự bạo ngược của một lão già không tim. Vâng; đó là một cái nền thú vị. Nó tôn chàng trai lên, làm cho cậu thành ra hoàn hảo hơn thì phải. Đằng sau mọi thứ tuyệt đẹp từng tồn tại thường phải có gì đó bi thảm. Thế gian phải chịu nỗi đau sinh đẻ, để bông hoa tầm thường nhất cũng có thể hé nở… Và cậu ấy đã quyến rũ làm sao ở bữa ăn đêm trước, lúc mà, với đôi mắt hoảng hốt và đôi môi hé mở trong niềm hân hoan khiếp đảm, cậu ngồi đối diện y trong câu lạc bộ, cái chao đèn đỏ nhuộm màu hồng thẫm hơn lên sự kinh ngạc bừng tỉnh trên mặt cậu. Nói với cậu cũng giống như chơi trên một cây vĩ cầm tinh xảo. Cậu đáp lại mọi đụng chạm và rung động của vĩ kéo… Có gì đó mê hoặc không chịu nổi trong việc gây ảnh hưởng. Không có hoạt động khác nào giống thế. Phóng chiếu tâm hồn mình vào một dáng hình hòa nhã nào đó, rồi để nó nán lại đấy một lát; để nghe quan điểm trí tuệ của chính mình dội ngược lại mình cùng mọi khúc nhạc cộng thêm từ niềm đam mê và tuổi thanh xuân; để truyền khí chất mình qua người khác như thể nó là một chất lưu huyền ảo hoặc nước hoa kỳ lạ; có một niềm vui rất thật trong việc ấy — không chừng là niềm vui vừa ý nhất còn lại với chúng ta trong một thời đại quá hạn chế và thô bỉ như của chúng ta, một thời đại vô cùng trần tục về khoái lạc, vô cùng tầm thường về mục tiêu… Cậu ấy, chàng trai mà do một sự tình cờ lạ lùng nên y đã gặp được trong xưởng vẽ của Basil, cũng là một kiểu mẫu phi thường; hoặc có thể được tạo thành một kiểu mẫu phi thường, dẫu thế nào đi nữa. Sự duyên dáng là của cậu, cả sự thuần khiết trắng trong thời niên thiếu, cả vẻ đẹp như vẻ đẹp mà các bức tượng cẩm thạch Hy Lạp cổ xưa giữ lại cho chúng ta. Chẳng có gì mà người ta không thể làm với cậu. Cậu có thể được chế tác thành một người khổng lồ hoặc một món đồ chơi. Thật đáng tiếc làm sao vì sắc đẹp như vậy lại phải chịu định mệnh tàn phai!... Còn Basil? Theo quan điểm tâm lý học thì anh ta mới thú vị làm sao! Bút pháp nghệ thuật mới mẻ, cách nhìn đời tươi mới, được khơi gợi một cách hết sức kỳ lạ chỉ bởi sự hiện diện hữu hình của một kẻ hoàn toàn không nhận thức được về điều ấy; một linh hồn lặng lẽ vẫn cư ngụ trong vùng rừng lờ mờ tối, vẫn dạo bước vô hình trên cánh đồng lộ thiên, bỗng dưng khoe mình, như nữ thần rừng và không sợ hãi, bởi vì trong tâm hồn anh ta, kẻ vẫn đi tìm nàng nơi đó, đã bừng tỉnh cái sức tưởng tượng phi thường mà trước chỉ riêng mình nó thì những thứ phi thường phải lộ ra; chỉ hình và mẫu của những thứ ấy thôi đã trở nên, có thể nói, tinh túy, và đạt được một loại giá trị có tính biểu tượng, mặc dầu chính chúng là các mẫu của một hình thái nào đó khác biệt và hoàn hảo hơn mà cái bóng của nó đã được chúng biến thành thật: mọi điều này mới kỳ lạ làm sao! Y nhớ lại một điều gì đó giống như thế trong lịch sử. Có phải là Plato, chàng nghệ sỹ tư tưởng ấy, người đầu tiên phân tích nó hay không? Có phải là Buonarotti, người đã chạm nó lên cẩm thạch màu của một chùm thơ xô-nê? Nhưng trong thế kỷ của chúng ta thì nó thật kỳ lạ… Vâng; y sẽ cố gắng để trở thành, với Dorian Gray, một kẻ mà chàng trai ấy, dẫu không hay biết, nhưng đã trở thành với người họa sỹ từng tạo ra bức chân dung kỳ diệu đó. Y sẽ tìm cách chi phối cậu ấy — thật ra thì gần như đã làm vậy được rồi. Y sẽ biến linh hồn phi thường ấy thành của riêng mình. Có gì đó thật quyến rũ trong đứa con trai này của Tình yêu và Cái chết.
tr: Dorian Gray’in ana babasının öyküsü buydu, demek. Kaba çizgilerle anlatılmış olmasına karşın bu öykü garip, çağdaş bir romantizm çağrıştırarak ona heyecan vermişti. Delice bir tutku uğruna her şeyi gözden çıkaran güzel bir kadın. Birkaç hafta süren çılgın bir mutluluğun iğrenç, hain bir cinayetle sona ermesi. Aylar süren dilsiz bir çile, sonra acılar içinde dünyaya gelen bir çocuk. Anneyi ölümün koparıp alması, çocuğun yaşlı, sevgisiz bir ihtiyarın elinde tek başına kalakalması. Evet, ilginç bir ortam. Dorian için bir arka plan oluşturuyor, onu daha bile kusursuz kılıyordu sanki. Var olan her kusursuz şeyin ardında acılar gizliydi. En sıradan çiçeğin açması için dünyanın çile çekmesi gerekiyordu sanki... Çocuk önceki gece kulüpte yedikleri yemekte irkilmiş gözleri, ürkek bir zevkle aralanmış dudaklarıyla Lord Henry’nin karşısına oturmuş, şamdanların kırmızı gölgelikleri, yüzünde yavaş yavaş uyanmakta olan şaşkın bilinci daha derin bir gül rengine boyarken nasıl da tatlıydı. Onunla konuşmak nefis bir kemanı çalmaya benziyordu. Çocuk yayın her dokunuşuna, her çekilişine ses veriyordu... İnsanın etkisini böylesine kullanıp uygulamasında müthiş sarmalayıcı bir yön vardı. Başka hiçbir uğraş boy ölçüşemezdi bununla. Kişinin kendi ruhunu apayrı, güzel bir forma aktarıp bir süre orada tutması, düşüncelerinin yankı bulması, buna gençliğin ve heyecanın müziğinin eklenmesi ve kendi huyunu, tutumunu, kaypak bir sıvı, gizemli bir kokuymuşçasına, başka birine iletmesi. Gerçek bir kıvanç vardı bunda... Belki de bizimki kadar sınırlı ve çiğ bir çağda, zevkleri kabaca şehvetli, amaçları kabaca bayağı olan bir çağda elimize kalan en doyurucu kıvanç... Sonra, tuhaf bir rastlantıyla Basil’in stüdyosunda tanıdığı bu çocuğun harika bir kişiliği de vardı; ya da hiç değilse kişiliği harika bir forma sokulabilirdi. Zariflik ondaydı, delikanlılığın ak duruluğu ve eski Yunan mermerlerinin bizler için saklamış olduğu güzellik. İnsanın bu çocuğa veremeyeceği şekil yoktu. Ondan bir titan da yapılabilirdi, bir oyuncak da. Ama böyle bir güzelliğin solup gitmeye yazgılı olması ne yazıktı... Ya Basil? Ruhbilimsel yönden nasıl da ilginçti! Yeni bir sanat yöntemi, hayata bambaşka bir bakış açısı... Karşısındaki gencin salt gözle görülebilir varlığı ressama bunları çağrıştırmıştı, oysa gencin bunlardan hiç haberi yoktu. Loş korularda yaşayan, tarlaların açıklığında göze gözükmeden dolaşan o sessiz, dişi ruh, apansız kendini gösteriyordu, orman tanrıçaları gibi, korkusuz. Ressamın kendi ruhunda harikulade bir göz açılmıştı ve harikulade şeyler ancak bu göze gözükür. Böylece eşyanın en basit çizgileriyle örnekleri incelip yücelerek simgesel bir değer kazanmıştı, sanki bunlar bambaşka ve daha kusursuz bir formun örnekleriydiler ve bu formun gölgelerini gerçek kılıyorlardı. Ne tuhaftı bütün bunlar! Lord Henry tarihte buna benzer bir şeyler anımsar gibiydi. Platon değil miydi, o düşüncelerin ressamı, bunu ilk irdeleyen? Bunu bir sone’nin renkli mermerlerine ilk oyan Buonarroti olmamış mıydı? Gelgelelim şu bizim çağımızda böyle bir şey irkiltiyordu. Evet, Dorian Gray o harika portreyi çizen ressama, kendi de bilmeden neyi simgelemişse, Lord Henry de Dorian Gray’e onu simgelemeye çalışacaktı. Ona egemen olmaya çalışacaktı, zaten yarı yarıya olmuştu bile, daha şimdiden. O güzelim ruhu kendine mal edecekti. Bu aşk ve ölüm çocuğunda insanı saran bir büyü vardı.
es: Aquélla era, por tanto, la historia familiar de Dorian Gray. Pese a lo esquemático del relato, le había impresionado porque hacía pensar en una historia de amor extraña, casi moderna. Una mujer hermosa que se arriesga a todo por una loca pasión. Unas pocas semanas de felicidad sin límite truncadas por un crimen odioso, por una traición. Meses de silenciosos sufrimientos, y luego un hijo nacido en el dolor. La madre arrebatada por la muerte, el niño abandonado a la soledad y a la tiranía de un anciano sin corazón. Sí; unos antecedentes interesantes, que situaban al muchacho, que le añadían una nueva perfección, por así decirlo. Detrás de todas las cosas exquisitas hay algo trágico. Para que florezca la más humilde de las flores se necesita el esfuerzo de mundos... Y, ¡qué encantador había estado durante la cena la noche anterior, cuando, la sorpresa en los ojos y los labios entreabiertos por el placer y el temor, se había sentado frente a él en el club, las pantallas rojas de las lámparas avivando el rubor despertado en su rostro por el asombro! Hablar con él era como tocar el más delicado de los violines. Dorian respondía a cada toque y vibración del arco... Había algo terriblemente cautivador en influir sobre alguien. No existía otra actividad parecida. Proyectar el alma sobre una forma agradable, detenerse un momento; emitir las propias ideas para que las devuelva un eco, acompañadas por la música de una pasión juvenil; transmitir a otro la propia sensibilidad como si se tratase de un fluido sutil o de un extraño perfume; allí estaba la fuente de una alegría verdadera, tal vez la más satisfactoria que todavía nos permite una época tan mezquina y tan vulgar como la nuestra, una época zafiamente carnal en sus placeres y enormemente vulgar en sus metas... Aquel muchacho a quien por una extraña casualidad había conocido en el estudio de Basil encarnaba además un modelo maravilloso o, al menos, se le podía convertir en un ser maravilloso. Suyo era el encanto, y la pureza inmaculada de la adolescencia, junto a una belleza que sólo los antiguos mármoles griegos conservan para nosotros. No había nada que no se pudiera hacer con él. Se le podía convertir en un titán o en un juguete. ¡Qué lástima que semejante belleza estuviera destinada a marchitarse!... ¡Y Basil? Desde un punto de vista psicológico, ¡qué interesante era! Un nuevo estilo artístico, un modo nuevo de ver la vida, todo ello sugerido de manera tan extraña por la simple presencia de alguien que era todo eso de manera inconsciente; el espíritu silencioso que mora en bosques sombríos y camina sin ser visto por campos abiertos, mostrándose, de repente, como una dríade, y sin temor, porque en el alma que la busca se ha despertado ya esa singular capacidad a la que corresponde la revelación de las cosas maravillosas; las simples formas, los simples contornos de las cosas que se estilizaban, por así decirlo, adquiriendo algo semejante a un valor simbólico, como si fuesen a su vez el esbozo de otra forma más perfecta, a cuya sombra dotaban de realidad: ¡qué extraño era todo! Recordaba algo parecido en la historia del pensamiento. ¿No fue Platón, aquel artista de las ideas, quien lo había analizado por vez primera? ¿No había sido Buonarotti quien lo esculpió en el mármol multicolor de una sucesión de sonetos? Pero en nuestro siglo era extraño... Sí; trataría de ser para Dorian Gray lo que él, sin saberlo, había sido para el autor de aquel retrato maravilloso. Trataría de dominarlo; en realidad ya lo había hecho a medias. Haría suyo aquel espíritu maravilloso. Había algo fascinante en aquel hijo del Amor y de la Muerte.
vi_translation: So that is the story of Dorian Gray's lineage. As blunt as it was told to him, it stirred his heart with the suggestion of a strange, almost modern romance. A beautiful woman had risked everything for her mad passion. A few weeks of wild happiness cut short by a hideous, deceitful crime. Months of silent suffering, then a child born in pain. The mother kidnapped by death, the boy left in loneliness and the cruelty of a heartless old man. Yes; it was an interesting background. It elevated the young man, made him seem more perfect. Behind everything beautiful that has ever existed, there must be something tragic. The world must endure the pain of childbirth, so that even the most ordinary flower can bloom… And how enchanting he was at dinner the night before, when, with frightened eyes and lips parted in dreadful joy, he sat opposite him in the club, the red lampshade casting a deeper crimson on his awakened astonishment. Talking to him was like playing on a finely tuned violin. He responded to every touch and vibration of the bow… There was something irresistibly fascinating about exerting influence. No other activity was quite like it. To project one's soul into a graceful form, and let it linger there for a while; to hear one's own intellectual views echoed back with all the added music of passion and youth; to transmit one's temperament through another as if it were some magical fluid or strange perfume; there was a very real pleasure in it — perhaps the most satisfying pleasure left to us in an age as limited and coarse as ours, an age utterly mundane in its pleasures, utterly mediocre in its aims… He, the young man whom by a strange chance he had met in Basil's studio, was also an extraordinary model; or could be made into an extraordinary model, in any case. Grace was his, along with the pure innocence of youth, and beauty like that which the ancient Greek marble statues have preserved for us. There was nothing that could not be done with him. He could be crafted into a giant or a toy. How tragic it was that such beauty should be destined to fade!... And Basil? How interesting he was from a psychological perspective! A fresh artistic style, a new outlook on life, strangely inspired merely by the visible presence of someone completely unaware of it; a quiet soul still dwelling in the dim forest, still walking invisibly in the open field, suddenly revealing itself, like a fearless forest goddess, because in his soul, the one who sought her there, had awakened the extraordinary imagination that before only it could reveal the extraordinary; the mere form and pattern of those things had, so to speak, become essential, and achieved a kind of symbolic value, even though they were models of a different and more perfect form whose shadow they had made real: how strange all this was! He recalled something similar in history. Was it Plato, that artist of thought, who first analyzed it? Was it Buonarotti, who carved it into the colored marble of a sonnet sequence? But in our century, it was truly strange… Yes; he would try to become, to Dorian Gray, what that young man, unknowingly, had become to the artist who created that marvelous portrait. He would seek to dominate him — in fact, he had almost done so already. He would make that extraordinary soul his own. There was something truly enchanting about this child of Love and Death.
tr_translation: So, this was the story of Dorian Gray's parents. Despite being told in broad strokes, this story had excited him by evoking a strange, contemporary romanticism. A beautiful woman who sacrificed everything for a mad passion. A few weeks of wild happiness ending in a vile, treacherous murder. Months of silent suffering, then a child born in pain. The mother being taken by death, the child left alone in the hands of an old, loveless man. Yes, an interesting background. It formed a backdrop for Dorian, making him seem even more perfect. Behind every perfect thing, there was hidden pain. It was as if the world had to suffer for the most ordinary flower to bloom... The boy had sat across from Lord Henry at the dinner they had at the club the previous night, with startled eyes and lips parted with timid pleasure, as the red shades of the candelabras painted the slowly awakening consciousness on his face a deeper rose color, how sweet he had been. Talking to him was like playing a fine violin. The boy responded to every touch, every pull of the bow... There was something immensely enveloping about wielding one's influence in this way. No other occupation could compare to this. To transfer one's own soul into a separate, beautiful form and hold it there for a while, to have one's thoughts echoed, to add the music of youth and excitement to it, and to transmit one's own temperament and attitude, like a slippery liquid, a mysterious scent, to another. There was a true joy in this...Perhaps in an era as limited and crude as ours, with pleasures roughly sensual and goals roughly vulgar, this was the most fulfilling joy left to us... Then, by a strange coincidence, this boy he had met in Basil's studio had a wonderful personality; or at least his personality could be shaped into a wonderful form. He had elegance, the pure clarity of youth, and the beauty that ancient Greek marbles had preserved for us. There was no shape that could not be given to this boy. He could be made into a titan or a toy. But how sad it was that such beauty was destined to fade away...And Basil? How interesting he was from a psychological standpoint! A new art method, a completely different perspective on life... The mere visible presence of the young man had evoked these in the painter, while the young man was completely unaware of them. That silent, feminine spirit living in dim groves, wandering unseen in the open fields, suddenly revealed itself, fearless, like the forest goddesses. A marvelous eye had opened in the painter's own soul, and marvelous things could only be seen by this eye. Thus, the simplest lines and forms of objects had become refined and exalted, gaining a symbolic value, as if they were examples of a completely different and more perfect form, and these forms made their shadows real. How strange all this was! Lord Henry seemed to recall something similar in history. Was it not Plato, that painter of thoughts, who first examined this? Was it not Buonarroti who first carved this into the colorful marbles of a sonnet? Yet in our current age, such a thing was startling. Yes, just as Dorian Gray had unknowingly symbolized something to the painter who drew that wonderful portrait, Lord Henry would try to make Dorian Gray symbolize it to him. He would try to dominate him, and he was already halfway there, even now. He would claim that beautiful soul for himself. There was an enchanting allure in this child of love and death.
es_translation: That was, therefore, the family history of Dorian Gray. Despite the schematic nature of the story, it had impressed him because it made one think of a strange, almost modern love story. A beautiful woman who risks everything for a mad passion. A few weeks of boundless happiness cut short by a heinous crime, by a betrayal. Months of silent suffering, and then a child born in pain. The mother snatched away by death, the child abandoned to loneliness and the tyranny of a heartless old man. Yes; some interesting antecedents, which placed the boy, which added a new perfection to him, so to speak. Behind all exquisite things, there is something tragic. For the humblest of flowers to bloom, the effort of worlds is needed...And, how charming he had been during dinner the night before, when, with surprise in his eyes and lips parted in pleasure and fear, he had sat across from him at the club, the red screens of the lamps enhancing the blush awakened in his face by astonishment! Talking to him was like playing the most delicate of violins. Dorian responded to every touch and vibration of the bow...There was something terribly captivating about influencing someone. There was no other activity like it. Projecting the soul onto a pleasing form, pausing for a moment; emitting one's own ideas to be echoed back, accompanied by the music of youthful passion; transmitting one's own sensitivity to another as if it were a subtle fluid or a strange perfume; there lay the source of true joy, perhaps the most satisfying that such a mean and vulgar age as ours still allows, an age crudely carnal in its pleasures and enormously vulgar in its goals...That boy whom he had met by a strange chance in Basil's studio also embodied a wonderful model or, at least, could be turned into a wonderful being. His was the charm, and the immaculate purity of adolescence, along with a beauty that only ancient Greek marbles preserve for us. There was nothing that could not be done with him. He could be turned into a titan or a toy. What a pity that such beauty was destined to wither!... And Basil? From a psychological point of view, how interesting he was! A new artistic style, a new way of seeing life, all suggested so strangely by the mere presence of someone who was all that unconsciously; the silent spirit that dwells in shadowy forests and walks unseen through open fields, suddenly revealing itself like a dryad, and without fear, because in the soul that seeks it, that singular capacity has already awakened, to which the revelation of wonderful things corresponds; the simple forms, the simple contours of things that were stylized, so to speak, acquiring something akin to symbolic value, as if they were in turn the sketch of another more perfect form, whose shadow endowed them with reality: how strange it all was! He remembered something similar in the history of thought. Was it not Plato, that artist of ideas, who had analyzed it for the first time? Was it not Buonarotti who sculpted it in the multicolored marble of a succession of sonnets? But in our century it was strange...Yes; he would try to be for Dorian Gray what he, unknowingly, had been for the author of that wonderful portrait. He would try to dominate him; in reality, he had already done so halfway. He would make that wonderful spirit his own. There was something fascinating about that child of Love and Death.

en: Suddenly he stopped and glanced up at the houses. He found that he had passed his aunt’s some distance, and, smiling to himself, turned back. When he entered the somewhat sombre hall, the butler told him that they had gone in to lunch. He gave one of the footmen his hat and stick and passed into the dining-room.
vi: Bỗng dưng y dừng lại và ngó lên các ngôi nhà. Y thấy rằng y đã đi qua nhà dì mình mấy quãng, và, tự cười với mình, quay lại. Lúc y bước vào cái sảnh hơi ảm đạm thì quản gia thưa với y rằng họ đã đi ăn rồi. Y đưa cho một người hầu cầm cái mũ và ba- toong của y, rồi đi vào phòng ăn.
tr: Birden Lord Henry durdu, yandaki evlere baktı. Halasının evini epey geçtiğini görünce kendi kendine gülümseyerek geri döndü. Biraz kasvetli olan hole girdiğinde başuşak ona yemeğin başladığını bildirdi. Lord Henry şapkasıyla bastonunu uşak yamaklarından birine vererek yemek odasına girdi.
es: De repente, lord Henry se detuvo y contempló las casas que lo rodeaban. Se dio cuenta de que había dejado atrás la de su tía y, sonriendo, volvió sobre sus pasos. Cuando entró en el vestíbulo, un tanto sombrío, el mayordomo le hizo saber que los comensales ya se habían sentado a la mesa. Entregó el sombrero y el bastón a uno de los lacayos y pasó al comedor.
vi_translation: Suddenly, he stopped and looked up at the houses. He realized that he had walked past his aunt's house by several blocks, and, smiling to himself, turned back. When he stepped into the somewhat gloomy hall, the butler informed him that they had already gone to eat. He handed his hat and cane to a servant, then went into the dining room.
tr_translation: Suddenly, Lord Henry stopped and looked at the houses beside him. Seeing that he had passed his aunt's house by quite a bit, he turned back with a smile to himself. When he entered the somewhat gloomy hall, the head butler informed him that dinner had started. Lord Henry handed his hat and cane to one of the footmen and entered the dining room.
es_translation: Suddenly, Lord Henry stopped and contemplated the houses that surrounded him. He realized that he had passed his aunt's house and, smiling, retraced his steps. When he entered the somewhat gloomy hall, the butler informed him that the diners had already sat down at the table. He handed his hat and cane to one of the footmen and proceeded to the dining room.

en: “Late as usual, Harry,” cried his aunt, shaking her head at him.
vi: “Lại đến muộn như mọi khi, Harry,” dì y la lên, lắc đầu với y.
tr: Halası ona bakıp başını sallayarak, “Geciktin, Harry!” diye bağırdı. “Her zamanki gibi.
es: —Tarde como de costumbre —exclamó su tía, reprendiéndolo con un movimiento de cabeza.
vi_translation: “Late again as always, Harry,” his aunt yelled, shaking her head at him.
tr_translation: His aunt looked at him, shaking her head, and shouted, "You're late, Harry!" "As always."
es_translation: —Late as usual —exclaimed his aunt, reprimanding him with a shake of her head.

Multiple_ents: ['señor erskine de treadley', 'vandeleu', 'faudel', 'ms vandeleur', 'thomas burdon', 'lady agatha', 'lord henry', 'señora vandeleur', 'duquesa de harley', 'faude', 'the duchess of harley', 'düşes harley', 'sir thomas burdon', 'treadley', 'dorian', 'dorian gray', 'vandeleur', 'lord faudel', 'harley', 'thomas burdo', 'erskine', 'agath', 'leydi agatha']
en: He invented a facile excuse, and having taken the vacant seat next to her, looked round to see who was there. Dorian bowed to him shyly from the end of the table, a flush of pleasure stealing into his cheek. Opposite was the Duchess of Harley, a lady of admirable good-nature and good temper, much liked by every one who knew her, and of those ample architectural proportions that in women who are not duchesses are described by contemporary historians as stoutness. Next to her sat, on her right, Sir Thomas Burdon, a Radical member of Parliament, who followed his leader in public life and in private life followed the best cooks, dining with the Tories and thinking with the Liberals, in accordance with a wise and well-known rule. The post on her left was occupied by Mr. Erskine of Treadley, an old gentleman of considerable charm and culture, who had fallen, however, into bad habits of silence, having, as he explained once to Lady Agatha, said everything that he had to say before he was thirty. His own neighbour was Mrs. Vandeleur, one of his aunt’s oldest friends, a perfect saint amongst women, but so dreadfully dowdy that she reminded one of a badly bound hymn-book. Fortunately for him she had on the other side Lord Faudel, a most intelligent middle-aged mediocrity, as bald as a ministerial statement in the House of Commons, with whom she was conversing in that intensely earnest manner which is the one unpardonable error, as he remarked once himself, that all really good people fall into, and from which none of them ever quite escape.
vi: Y bịa ra một lý do dễ nghe để bào chữa, và ngồi xuống chỗ trống cạnh dì, nhìn quanh xem những ai đang ở đây. Dorian cúi đầu bẽn lẽn chào y từ đầu bàn bên kia, một chút ửng hồng hân hoan lẻn lên má cậu. Đối diện là nữ công tước Harley; một quý bà hiền hậu và tốt tính đáng kính, được lòng mọi người quen, và có những nét cân đối kiến trúc phì nhiêu mà ở các phụ nữ không phải là nữ công tước thì vẫn được miêu tả bởi các sử gia đương thời bằng từ “béo phị”. Ngồi bên cạnh bà, phía tay phải, là ngài Thomas Burdon, một đảng viên đảng Cấp tiến, thành viên Nghị viện, kẻ bám theo lãnh đạo mình trong cuộc sống công khai, còn trong cuộc sống riêng tư thì bám theo các đầu bếp giỏi nhất, ăn với các đảng viên đảng Bảo thủ, nghĩ với các đảng viên đảng Tự do, tuân thủ một quy tắc khôn ngoan và nổi tiếng. Vị trí bên trái bà bị chiếm bởi mít-tơ Erskine xứ Treadley, một quý ông lớn tuổi khá quyến rũ và có văn hóa, một người tuy vậy nhưng bị nhiễm thói quen xấu là im lặng do đã từng, như ông có lần giải thích với bà Agatha, nói hết mọi điều ông cần phải nói trước khi ông ba mươi tuổi. Người bên cạnh ông là phu nhân Vandeleur, một trong số các bạn lâu năm nhất của dì y, một thiên thần hoàn hảo giữa đám đàn bà, nhưng ăn bận tồi tàn khủng khiếp đến nỗi bà nhắc người ta nhớ đến một cuốn sách thánh ca đóng dối. May cho y là ngồi bên phía bên kia bà là huân tước Faudel, một trung niên tầm thường vô cùng thông minh, tóc tai cũng trơ trụi hệt như bài phát biểu của bộ trưởng trong Hạ viện, người mà bà chuyện trò với cái kiểu sốt sắng sôi nổi vẫn là một lỗi không thể dung thứ, như y có lần tự lưu ý chính mình, mà mọi người thật sự tốt bụng đều bị rơi vào và chẳng ai trong số họ từng thoát hẳn ra được khỏi nó.
tr: Lord Henry dilinin ucuna ilk gelen özrü bildirdi, halasının yanında boş duran yere oturarak, sofrada kimler bulunduğunu görmek için çevresine bakındı. Masanın karşı ucunda oturan Dorian, yüzüne sevinçli bir renk yayılarak, utangaç utangaç ona bakıp gülümsedi. Karşıda iyi huyu, iyi yüreği çok beğeni toplayan, bütün tanıdıklarının çok sevdiği Düşes Harley vardı. Günümüzün tarihçileri bu hanımın mimari boyutlara ulaşan yapısına düşes olmayan kadınlarda rastladıkları zaman, “tıknaz” olarak tanımlarlar. Onun sağ yanında Parlamento’nun radikal üyesi Sir Thomas Burdon oturuyordu. Kendisi tüzel yaşantısında önderinin, özel yaşantısında en usta aşçıların izini sürerek, Torylerle birlikte yemek yiyip Liberallerle birlikte düşünerek iyi bilinen, akıllıca bir kurala uyardı... Sağında Treadleyli mr Erskine oturmaktaydı. Hatırı sayılır bir çekiciliğe ve kültüre sahip olan bu yaşlı bay, ne yazık ki suskunluk gibi kötü bir huy edinmişti, çünkü, bir keresinde Leydi Agatha’ya açıkladığı üzere, söyleyecek nesi varsa otuz yaşından önce söyleyip bitirdiği kanısındaydı. Lord Henry’nin yanındaysa halasının en eski dostlarından ms Vandeleur vardı: Melek gibi bir kadın, gelgelelim öylesine rüküş ve kılıksızdı ki insana kötü ciltlenmiş bir dua kitabını anımsatıyordu. Lord Henry’nin şansı varmış ki kadının öbür yanında son derece zeki, orta yaşlı, vasat bir kişi olan Lord Faudel oturmaktaydı. Lord Faudel’in, Avam Kamarası’nda harcanmış bir bakan sözü gibi cascavlak bir kafası vardı. ms Vandeleur da son derece samimi bir dürüstlükle onunla konuşmaktaydı. Lord Henry’nin bir keresinde söylediği gibi, bu samimi dürüstlük, gerçekten iyi olan bütün insanların düştüğü ve hiçbirinin tümüyle kurtulamadığı tek bağışlanmaz hataydı.
es: Lord Henry inventó una excusa banal y, después de acomodarse en el sitio vacío al lado de lady Agatha, miró a su alrededor para ver a los invitados. Dorian Gray le hizo una tímida inclinación de cabeza desde el extremo de la mesa, apareciendo en sus mejillas un rubor de satisfacción. Frente a él tenía a la duquesa de Harley, una dama con un carácter y un valor admirables, muy querida por todos los que la conocían, y con las amplias proporciones arquitectónicas a las que los historiadores contemporáneos, cuando no se trata de duquesas, dan el nombre de corpulencia. A su derecha estaba sentado sir Thomas Burdon, miembro radical del Parlamento, que seguía a su líder en la vida pública y a los mejores cocineros en la privada, cenando con los conservadores y pensando con los liberales, según una regla tan prudente como bien conocida. El asiento a la izquierda de la duquesa estaba ocupado por el señor Erskine de Treadley, anciano caballero de considerable encanto y cultura, que había caído sin embargo en la mala costumbre de guardar silencio, puesto que, como explicó en una ocasión a lady Agatha, todo lo que tenía que decir lo había dicho antes de cumplir los treinta. A la izquierda de lord Henry se sentaba la señora Vandeleur, una de las amigas más antiguas de su tía, santa entre las mujeres, pero tan terriblemente poco atractiva que hacía pensar en un himnario mal encuadernado. Afortunadamente para él, la señora Vandeleur tenía a su otro lado a lord Faudel -una mediocridad muy inteligente, de más de cuarenta años y calva tan rotunda como una declaración ministerial en la Cámara de los Comunes—, con quien conversaba de esa manera tan intensamente seria que es el único error imperdonable, como él mismo había señalado en una ocasión, en el que caen todas las personas realmente buenas y del que ninguna de ellas escapa por completo.
vi_translation: Y came up with a plausible excuse to justify himself, and sat down in the empty seat next to his aunt, looking around to see who was there. Dorian shyly bowed his head in greeting from the other end of the table, a slight flush of joy creeping up his cheeks. Opposite him was the Duchess of Harley; a kind-hearted and good-natured lady, esteemed by all her acquaintances, and possessing a fertile architectural symmetry that in women who are not duchesses is still described by contemporary historians with the word "obese". Sitting next to her, on her right, was Sir Thomas Burdon, a member of the Radical Party, a Member of Parliament, who followed his leader in public life, but in private life followed the best chefs, dined with Conservatives, thought with Liberals, adhering to a wise and famous rule. The position on her left was occupied by Mr. Erskine of Treadley, a rather charming and cultured elderly gentleman, who nevertheless had acquired the bad habit of silence because, as he once explained to Mrs. Agatha, he had said everything he needed to say before he was thirty. Next to him was Lady Vandeleur, one of his aunt's oldest friends, a perfect angel among women, but dressed so terribly that she reminded people of a poorly bound hymn book. Fortunately for him, sitting on the other side of her was Lord Faudel, an extraordinarily intelligent middle-aged man, as bald as a minister's speech in the House of Commons, with whom she conversed in that eager, lively manner that, as he once noted to himself, was an unforgivable fault that all truly kind-hearted people fell into and from which none of them ever fully escaped.
tr_translation: Lord Henry uttered the first excuse that came to his tongue, and, sitting in the empty seat next to his aunt, looked around to see who was present at the table. Dorian, sitting at the far end of the table, looked at him shyly and smiled, a joyful color spreading across his face. Opposite him was Duchess Harley, whose good nature and kind heart were greatly admired, and who was loved by all her acquaintances. Modern historians, when they encounter the architectural proportions of this lady in women who are not duchesses, describe them as "stout." To her right sat Sir Thomas Burdon, a radical member of Parliament. He adhered to a well-known, wise rule by following his leader in public life and the most skilled chefs in private life, dining with the Tories and thinking with the Liberals... On his right sat Mr. Erskine of Treadley. This elderly gentleman, who possessed considerable charm and culture, unfortunately had acquired the bad habit of silence, because, as he once explained to Lady Agatha, he believed he had said everything he had to say before the age of thirty. Next to Lord Henry was Ms. Vandeleur, one of his aunt's oldest friends: An angelic woman, yet so dowdy and shabby that she reminded one of a poorly bound prayer book. Lord Henry was fortunate that on the other side of the woman sat Lord Faudel, an extremely intelligent, middle-aged, and mediocre person. Lord Faudel had a completely bald head, like a wasted ministerial promise in the House of Commons. Ms. Vandeleur was speaking to him with utmost sincere honesty. As Lord Henry once said, this sincere honesty was the only unforgivable mistake that all truly good people fell into and from which none could entirely escape.
es_translation: Lord Henry invented a trivial excuse and, after settling into the empty seat next to Lady Agatha, looked around to see the guests. Dorian Gray gave him a timid nod from the end of the table, a blush of satisfaction appearing on his cheeks. Opposite him was the Duchess of Harley, a lady with admirable character and courage, much loved by all who knew her, and with the ample architectural proportions that contemporary historians, when not referring to duchesses, call corpulence. To his right sat Sir Thomas Burdon, a radical member of Parliament, who followed his leader in public life and the best chefs in private, dining with the conservatives and thinking with the liberals, according to a rule as prudent as it was well-known. The seat to the left of the Duchess was occupied by Mr. Erskine of Treadley, an elderly gentleman of considerable charm and culture, who had nevertheless fallen into the bad habit of keeping silent, since, as he once explained to Lady Agatha, everything he had to say he had said before he turned thirty. To the left of Lord Henry sat Mrs. Vandeleur, one of his aunt's oldest friends, saintly among women, but so terribly unattractive that she made one think of a poorly bound hymnal. Fortunately for him, Mrs. Vandeleur had on her other side Lord Faudel—a very intelligent mediocrity, over forty years old and as bald as a ministerial statement in the House of Commons—with whom she conversed in that intensely serious manner that is the only unforgivable error, as he himself had once pointed out, that all truly good people fall into and from which none of them entirely escape.

en: “We are talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry,” cried the duchess, nodding pleasantly to him across the table. “Do you think he will really marry this fascinating young person?”
vi: “Chúng tôi đang nói về Dartmoor tội nghiệp đấy, huân tước Henry,” nữ công tước kêu lên, gật đầu niềm nở với y qua bàn. “Anh có nghĩ là hắn sẽ thật sự cưới cô gái trẻ quyến rũ này không?”
tr: Düşes masanın öbür yanından ona gülüp başını sallayarak, “Zavallı Dartmoor’u konuşuyorduk, Lord Henry,” dedi. “Dartmoor bu büyüleyici genç kızla gerçekten evlenecek mi dersin?
es: —Estamos hablando del pobre Dartmoor, lord Henry —exclamó la duquesa, haciéndole, desde el otro lado de la mesa, un gesto amistoso con la cabeza—. ¿Cree usted que se casará realmente con esa joven tan fascinante?
vi_translation: “We are talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry,” the duchess exclaimed, nodding warmly at him across the table. “Do you think he will really marry this charming young girl?”
tr_translation: The Duchess, laughing and nodding her head from the other side of the table, said, "We were talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry." "Do you think Dartmoor will really marry this charming young girl?"
es_translation: —We are talking about poor Dartmoor, Lord Henry —exclaimed the duchess, giving him a friendly nod from across the table—. Do you think he will really marry that fascinating young woman?

en: “I believe she has made up her mind to propose to him, Duchess.”
vi: “Tôi tin cô ấy đã quyết định cầu hôn với hắn, thưa nữ công tước.
tr: “Sanırım kız ona evlenme önermeye kararlıymış, düşes.
es: —Creo que la joven está decidida a pedir su mano, duquesa.
vi_translation: “I believe she has decided to propose to him, Your Grace.”
tr_translation: “I think the girl was determined to propose to him, Duchess.”
es_translation: —I believe the young woman is determined to ask for her hand, Duchess.

en: “How dreadful!” exclaimed Lady Agatha. “Really, some one should interfere.”
vi: “Khiếp thật!” Bà Agatha la lên. “Thật sự là ai đó nên can thiệp.
tr: Leydi Agatha, “Ne feci!” diye bağırdı. “Biri çıkıp engellemeli.
es: —¡Qué espanto! —exclamó lady Agatha—. Alguien debería tomar cartas en el asunto.
vi_translation: “How terrifying!” Mrs. Agatha exclaimed. “Someone really should intervene.”
tr_translation: Lady Agatha shouted, "What have I done!" "Someone must stop this."
es_translation: —What a fright! —exclaimed Lady Agatha—. Someone should take action on this matter.

en: “I am told, on excellent authority, that her father keeps an American dry-goods store,” said Sir Thomas Burdon, looking supercilious.
vi: “Tôi nghe nói, theo một nguồn hết sức tin cậy, là cha cô ấy quản lý một tiệm tạp hóa bên Mỹ,” ngài Thomas Burdon nói, trông có vẻ khinh khỉnh.
tr: Sir Thomas Burdon kibirli bir ifadeyle, “Güvenilir bir yerden duyduğuma göre kızın babası Amerika’da manifatura dükkânı işletiyormuş,” diye konuştu.
es: —Me han informado, de muy buena tinta, que su padre tiene un almacén de áridos —dijo sir Thomas Burdon con aire desdeñoso.
vi_translation: "I heard, according to a very reliable source, that her father manages a grocery store in America," said Mr. Thomas Burdon, looking disdainful.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas Burdon said with a haughty expression, "I have heard from a reliable source that the girl's father runs a dry goods store in America."
es_translation: —I have been reliably informed that his father owns a gravel warehouse —said Sir Thomas Burdon disdainfully.

en: “My uncle has already suggested pork-packing, Sir Thomas.”
vi: “Chú tôi đã đưa ra giả thuyết là buôn thịt lợn, thưa ngài Thomas.
tr: Sir Thomas Burdon kibirli bir ifadeyle, “Güvenilir bir yerden duyduğuma göre kızın babası Amerika’da manifatura dükkânı işletiyormuş,” diye konuştu.
es: —Mi tío ha sugerido y a que se trata de chacinería, sir Thomas.
vi_translation: “My uncle hypothesized that it was pork trading, Sir Thomas.”
tr_translation: Sir Thomas Burdon said with a haughty expression, "I have heard from a reliable source that the girl's father runs a dry goods store in America."
es_translation: —My uncle has suggested that it is about charcuterie, Sir Thomas.

en: “Dry-goods! What are American dry-goods?” asked the duchess, raising her large hands in wonder and accentuating the verb.
vi: “Tạp hóa! Tạp hóa Mỹ là gì?” nữ công tước hỏi, giơ hai bàn tay to lớn của mình lên đầy vẻ ngạc nhiên, và nhấn mạnh động từ.
tr: Düşes o iri ellerini şaşkın şaşkın açarak, “Manifatura mı! Amerikan manifaturası nedir ki?” diye sordu.
es: —¡Áridos! ¿Qué mercancías son ésas? —preguntó la duquesa, alzando sus grandes manos en gesto de asombro y acentuando mucho el verbo.
vi_translation: “General store! What is an American general store?” the duchess asked, raising her large hands in surprise, and emphasizing the verb.
tr_translation: The Duchess, opening her large hands in astonishment, "Fabric! What is American fabric?" she asked.
es_translation: —Arid goods! What kind of merchandise is that? —asked the duchess, raising her large hands in a gesture of astonishment and heavily emphasizing the verb.

en: “American novels,” answered Lord Henry, helping himself to some quail.
vi: “Các tiểu thuyết Mỹ,” huân tước Henry trả lời, tự mời mình một chút chim cun cút.
tr: Lord Henry tabağına biraz bıldırcın alarak, “Amerikan romanları,” diye karşılık verdi.
es: —Novelas americanas —respondió lord Henry, mientras se servía una codorniz.
vi_translation: “American novels,” Lord Henry replied, helping himself to a bit of quail.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, taking some quail onto his plate, responded, "American novels."
es_translation: —American novels —replied Lord Henry, while serving himself a quail.

en: The duchess looked puzzled.
vi: Nữ công tước có vẻ bối rối.
tr: Düşes hiçbir şey anlayamamış gibiydi.
es: La duquesa pareció desconcertada.
vi_translation: The duchess seemed confused.
tr_translation: The Duchess seemed to understand nothing.
es_translation: The duchess seemed bewildered.

en: “Don’t mind him, my dear,” whispered Lady Agatha. “He never means anything that he says.”
vi: “Đừng để ý đến nó, bạn ơi,” bà Agatha thì thào. “Nó chẳng bao giờ nghiêm túc với những gì mà nó nói ra.”
tr: Leydi Agatha, “Sen ona bakma, cicim,” diye fısıldadı. “Onun hiçbir sözünü ciddiye almamak gerekir.
es: —No le haga caso, querida —susurró lady Agatha—. Mi sobrino nunca habla en serio.
vi_translation: "Don't pay attention to it, my friend," whispered Mrs. Agatha. "It is never serious about what it says."
tr_translation: Lady Agatha whispered, "Don't pay attention to her, darling." "You shouldn't take any of her words seriously."
es_translation: —Don't pay attention to him, dear —whispered Lady Agatha—. My nephew never speaks seriously.

en: “When America was discovered,” said the Radical member—and he began to give some wearisome facts. Like all people who try to exhaust a subject, he exhausted his listeners. The duchess sighed and exercised her privilege of interruption. “I wish to goodness it never had been discovered at all!” she exclaimed. “Really, our girls have no chance nowadays. It is most unfair.”
vi: “Khi châu Mỹ được khám phá,” thành viên đảng Cấp tiến nói, và ông ta bắt đầu đưa ra vài sự kiện chán ngắt. Như mọi kẻ cứ cố gắng vắt kiệt một chủ đề, ông ta cũng vắt kiệt người nghe mình. Nữ công tước thở dài, và sử dụng đặc quyền ngắt lời của bà. “Tôi chỉ cầu mong sao cho nó chưa bao giờ được khám phá ra luôn!” bà kêu lên. “Thật sự là hiện nay các cô gái của chúng ta không có cơ hội. Thế là quá đỗi bất công.
tr: Radikal Parlamento üyesi, “Amerika keşfedildiği zaman,” diye söze başladı ve sıkıcı birtakım bilgiler sıralamaya girişti. Bir konuyu anlatıp tüketmeye çalışan bütün kişiler gibi sonunda dinleyenlerin sabrını tüketti. Düşes göğüs geçirerek, karşısındakinin sözünü yarıda kesmek ayrılacağını kullandı: “Keşke keşfedilmemiş olsaydı!” diye hafifçe bağırdı. “Tanrı biliyor ya, bizim kızlarımızın hiç şansı kalmadı artık. Büyük haksızlık bu.
es: —Cuando se descubrió América... —intervino el miembro radical de la Cámara de los Comunes, procediendo a enumerar algunos datos aburridísimos. Como todas las personas que tratan de agotar un tema, logró agotar a sus oyentes. La duquesa suspiró e hizo uso de su posición privilegiada para interrumpir. —¡Ojalá nunca la hubieran descubierto! —exclamó—. A decir verdad, nuestras jóvenes no tienen ahora la menor oportunidad. Es una gran injusticia.
vi_translation: “When America was discovered,” the member of the Radical party said, and he began to present some tedious facts. Like anyone who tries to exhaust a topic, he also exhausted his listeners. The Duchess sighed and used her privilege to interrupt. “I only wish it had never been discovered at all!” she exclaimed. “Truly, our girls nowadays have no chance. It is so terribly unfair.”
tr_translation: The Radical Parliament member began his speech with, "When America was discovered," and proceeded to list a series of tedious facts. Like all people who try to exhaust a topic, he eventually exhausted the patience of his listeners. The Duchess sighed and used the interruption to cut off the person in front of her: "I wish it had never been discovered!" she exclaimed softly. "God knows, our daughters have no chance anymore. This is a great injustice."
es_translation: —When America was discovered... —intervened the radical member of the House of Commons, proceeding to enumerate some extremely boring facts. Like all people who try to exhaust a topic, he succeeded in exhausting his listeners. The duchess sighed and used her privileged position to interrupt. —I wish they had never discovered it! —he exclaimed—. To tell the truth, our young women don't have the slightest chance now. It's a great injustice.

en: “Perhaps, after all, America never has been discovered,” said Mr. Erskine; “I myself would say that it had merely been detected.”
vi: “Không chừng rốt cuộc thì châu Mỹ chưa bao giờ được phát hiện ra,” mít-tơ Erskine nói. “Tự tôi vẫn nói là nó chỉ được nhận ra mà thôi.”
tr: mr Erskine, “Belki de Amerika hiç keşfedilmedi aslında,” dedi. “Bana sorarsanız yalnızca ortaya çıkarıldı.
es: —Quizá, después de todo, América nunca haya sido descubierta —dijo el señor Erskine—; yo diría más bien que fue meramente detectada.
vi_translation: “Perhaps in the end, America was never actually discovered,” Mr. Erskine said. “I always say it was merely recognized.”
tr_translation: Mr. Erskine said, "Perhaps America was never actually discovered." "If you ask me, it was only revealed."
es_translation: —Perhaps, after all, America was never truly discovered —said Mr. Erskine—; I would rather say it was merely detected.

en: “Oh! but I have seen specimens of the inhabitants,” answered the duchess vaguely. “I must confess that most of them are extremely pretty. And they dress well, too. They get all their dresses in Paris. I wish I could afford to do the same.”
vi: “Ồ! Nhưng tôi từng thấy vài thể loại dân đó,” nữ công tước trả lời, rất vô tâm. “Tôi phải thú nhận là phần lớn họ cực kỳ dễ thương. Và họ mặc đồ cũng đẹp nữa. Họ mua mọi món quần áo của họ ở Paris. Tôi ước gì mình có đủ khả năng làm thế.”
tr: Düşes, “Ha! Ama ben oranın yerlilerinden örnekler gördüm,” diye konuştu. “Ne yalan söyleyeyim, çoğunluğu iyice alımlı. İyi de giyiniyorlar. Bütün kılıklarını Paris’ ten alıyorlar. Keşke benim durumum buna elverse!
es: —Sí, sí, pero yo he visto especímenes de sus habitantes —respondió vagamente la duquesa—. He de confesar que la mayoría de las mujeres son extraordinariamente bonitas. Y además visten bien. Compran toda la ropa en París. Me gustaría poder permitírmelo.
vi_translation: “Oh! But I have seen a few of those types of people,” the duchess replied, very carelessly. “I must admit that most of them are extremely charming. And they dress well too. They buy all their clothes in Paris. I wish I could afford to do that.”
tr_translation: The Duchess said, "Ha! But I have seen examples of the natives from there." "To be honest, most of them are quite attractive. They also dress well. They get all their outfits from Paris. I wish my situation allowed for that!"
es_translation: —Yes, yes, but I have seen specimens of its inhabitants —the duchess responded vaguely—. I must confess that most of the women are extraordinarily beautiful. And they also dress well. They buy all their clothes in Paris. I would like to be able to afford it.

en: “They say that when good Americans die they go to Paris,” chuckled Sir Thomas, who had a large wardrobe of Humour’s cast-off clothes.
vi: “Họ bảo là khi những người Mỹ tử tế mà chết thì họ đi đến Paris,” ngài Thomas cười khúc khích, ngài có một tủ lớn đựng toàn quần áo vứt đi của sự Hài hước.
tr: Sir Thomas, “Diyorlar ki iyi Amerikalılar ölünce Paris’e giderlermiş,” diye kıs kıs güldü. Kendisinin dolabı Humour’s’un elden düşme giysileriyle doluydu.
es: —Dicen que cuando mueren, los americanos buenos van a París —rió entre dientes sir Thomas, que tenía un gran armario de frases ingeniosas ya desechadas.
vi_translation: “They say that when good Americans die, they go to Paris,” Sir Thomas chuckled, he had a large wardrobe full of discarded Humor.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas chuckled, "They say that good Americans go to Paris when they die." His wardrobe was filled with Humour's second-hand clothes.
es_translation: —They say that when good Americans die, they go to Paris —chuckled Sir Thomas, who had a large wardrobe of discarded witty phrases.

en: “Really! And where do bad Americans go to when they die?” inquired the duchess.
vi: “Thật á! Thế còn những người Mỹ xấu xa thì đi đâu khi họ qua đời?” nữ công tước thắc mắc.
tr: Düşes, “Demeyin!” dedi. “Peki ya kötü Amerikalılar ölünce nereye giderlermiş?
es: —¿De verdad? Y, ¿adónde van los malos? —quiso saber la duquesa.
vi_translation: “Really! So where do bad Americans go when they die?” the duchess inquired.
tr_translation: The Duchess said, "Don't say that!" "Well, where do bad Americans go when they die?"
es_translation: —Really? And, where do the bad ones go? —the duchess wanted to know.

en: “They go to America,” murmured Lord Henry.
vi: “Họ đi Mỹ,” huân tước Henry thì thào.
tr: Lord Henry, “Amerika’ya,” diye mırıldandı.
es: —Van a los Estados Unidos —murmuró lord Henry.
vi_translation: “They go to America,” Lord Henry whispered.
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, "To America."
es_translation: —They are going to the United States —murmured Lord Henry.

en: Sir Thomas frowned. “I am afraid that your nephew is prejudiced against that great country,” he said to Lady Agatha. “I have travelled all over it in cars provided by the directors, who, in such matters, are extremely civil. I assure you that it is an education to visit it.”
vi: Ngài Thomas nhăn mặt. “Tôi sợ là cháu bà có định kiến đối với đất nước vĩ đại ấy,” ông nói với bà Agatha. “Tôi đã đi khắp mọi nơi ở đó, trong các toa xe được lo liệu chu đáo bởi các giám đốc, những người, trong các chuyện như vậy, cực kỳ lễ độ. Tôi cam đoan với bà rằng đi thăm nơi đó là cả một sự giáo dục.”
tr: Sir Thomas yüzünü astı. Leydi Agatha’ya, “Korkarım yeğeninizin bu büyük ülkeye karşı bir önyargısı var,” dedi. “Ben, bu konularda son derece nazik olan yöneticilerin sağladığı arabalarla, karış karış gezdim bu ülkeyi. Emin olun, bu gezi başlı başına bir eğitim sayılır.
es: Sir Thomas frunció el ceño. —Me temo que su sobrino tiene prejuicios contra ese gran país —le dijo a lady Agatha—. He viajado por todo el territorio, en coches suministrados por los directores, que son, en esas cuestiones, extraordinariamente hospitalarios. Le aseguro que es muy instructivo visitarlos Estados Unidos.
vi_translation: Sir Thomas frowned. “I’m afraid your grandson has a prejudice against that great country,” he said to Mrs. Agatha. “I have traveled everywhere there, in carriages meticulously arranged by directors, who, in such matters, are extremely polite. I assure you that visiting that place is an education in itself.”
tr_translation: Sir Thomas frowned. He said to Lady Agatha, "I am afraid your nephew has a prejudice against this great country." "I have traveled every inch of this country with the carriages provided by the administrators, who are extremely kind in these matters. Believe me, this journey in itself is an education.""
es_translation: Sir Thomas frowned. —I am afraid your nephew has prejudices against that great country —he said to Lady Agatha—. I have traveled all over the territory, in cars provided by the directors, who are extraordinarily hospitable in these matters. I assure you it is very instructive to visit the United States.

en: “But must we really see Chicago in order to be educated?” asked Mr. Erskine plaintively. “I don’t feel up to the journey.”
vi: “Nhưng liệu ta có thật sự cần phải trông thấy Chicago để mà được giáo dục?” mít-tơ Erskine hỏi lại, rầu rĩ. “Tôi không thấy đủ sức cho hành trình ấy.”
tr: mr Erskine, “İyi de, eğitilmek için ille Chicago’ya gitmek zorunda mıyız?” diye sızlandı. “Ben böyle bir yolu göze alamıyorum şahsen.
es: —¿De verdad tenemos que ver Chicago para estar bien educados? —preguntó el señor Erskine quejumbrosamente—. No me siento capaz de emprender ese viaje.
vi_translation: “But do we really need to see Chicago to be educated?” Mr. Erskine asked again, gloomily. “I don't feel up to that journey.”
tr_translation: Mr. Erskine complained, "But do we really have to go to Chicago to get an education?" "Personally, I can't take such a risk."
es_translation: —Do we really have to see Chicago to be well-educated? —asked Mr. Erskine querulously—. I don't feel capable of undertaking that trip.

en: Sir Thomas waved his hand. “Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the world on his shelves. We practical men like to see things, not to read about them. The Americans are an extremely interesting people. They are absolutely reasonable. I think that is their distinguishing characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, an absolutely reasonable people. I assure you there is no nonsense about the Americans.”
vi: Ngài Thomas vẫy tay. “Mít-tơ Erskine xứ Treadley có cả thế giới trên giá sách của mình. Những người thực tế như chúng ta thích thấy các thứ chứ không chỉ đọc về chúng. Người Mỹ là một dân tộc cực kỳ thú vị. Họ tuyệt đối lý trí. Tôi nghĩ đó là đặc điểm nổi bật của họ. Vâng, mít-tơ Erskine, một dân tộc tuyệt đối lý trí. Tôi đảm bảo với ông là chẳng có gì vô lý ở người Mỹ cả.”
tr: Sir Thomas elini salladı. “Treadleyli mr Erskine için dünya kitap raflarında saklıdır. Oysa biz pratik kişiler dünyadaki şeyleri okumayı değil, görmeyi severiz. Amerikalılar son derece ilginç bir halk. Tümden akılcı kişiler. Ayırt edici nitelikleri budur bence. Evet, mr Erskine, tümden akılcı, mantıklı bir toplum. Emin olun. Amerikalılarda hiç saçma sapanlık yok.
es: Sir Thomas agitó la mano. —El señor Erskine de Treadley tiene el mundo en las estanterías de su biblioteca. A nosotros, los hombres prácticos, nos gusta ver las cosas, no leer su descripción. Los americanos son un pueblo muy interesante. Y totalmente razonable. Creo que es la característica que los distingue. Sí, señor Erskine, un pueblo totalmente razonable. Le aseguro que los americanos no se andan por las ramas.
vi_translation: Sir Thomas waved his hand. "Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the whole world on his bookshelf. Practical people like us prefer to see things rather than just read about them. Americans are an extremely interesting people. They are absolutely rational. I think that is their most prominent characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, an absolutely rational people. I assure you there is nothing irrational about Americans at all."
tr_translation: Sir Thomas waved his hand. “The world is hidden on the bookshelves for Mr. Erskine with his Treadley. But we practical people prefer to see things in the world rather than read about them. Americans are an extremely interesting people. Completely rational individuals. I think that is their distinguishing characteristic. Yes, Mr. Erskine, a completely rational, logical society. Rest assured. There is nothing nonsensical about Americans.”
es_translation: Sir Thomas waved his hand. —Mr. Erskine of Treadley has the world on the shelves of his library. We, practical men, like to see things, not read their descriptions. Americans are a very interesting people. And totally reasonable. I think that is the characteristic that distinguishes them. Yes, Mr. Erskine, a totally reasonable people. I assure you that Americans do not beat around the bush.

en: “How dreadful!” cried Lord Henry. “I can stand brute force, but brute reason is quite unbearable. There is something unfair about its use. It is hitting below the intellect.”
vi: “Đáng sợ thật!’ huân tước Henry kêu lên. “Tôi có thể chống lại sức mạnh tàn bạo, nhưng lý trí tàn bạo thì đúng là không chịu nổi. Có gì đó gian lận trong việc sử dụng nó. Nó đánh vào dưới trí tuệ.
tr: Lord Henry, “Ne feci!” dedi. “Mutlak güce katlanabilirim ama mutlak mantık hiç çekilmez. Böyle bir şeyin kullanımında bir haksızlık bulurum ben. Kafanın belden aşağısına vurmak sayarım.
es: —¡Terrible! —exclamó lord Henry—. No me gusta la fuerza bruta, pero la razón bruta es totalmente insoportable. No está bien utilizarla. Es como golpear por debajo del intelecto.
vi_translation: “How terrifying!” exclaimed Lord Henry. “I can resist brute force, but brute reason is truly unbearable. There is something deceitful in its use. It strikes below the intellect.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "I didn't do it!" he said. "I can endure absolute power, but absolute logic is unbearable. I find an injustice in the use of such a thing. I consider it a blow below the belt."
es_translation: —Terrible! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. I do not like brute force, but brute reason is absolutely unbearable. It is not right to use it. It is like hitting below the intellect.

en: “I do not understand you,” said Sir Thomas, growing rather red.
vi: “Tôi không hiểu cậu,” ngài Thomas nói, mặt trở nên khá đỏ.
tr: Sir Thomas, yüzü biraz kızararak, “Sizi anlamıyorum,” dedi.
es: —No le entiendo —dijo sir Thomas, enrojeciendo considerablemente.
vi_translation: “I don't understand you,” Mr. Thomas said, his face becoming quite red.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas, with his face slightly reddening, said, "I don't understand you."
es_translation: —I don't understand you —said Sir Thomas, blushing considerably.

en: “I do, Lord Henry,” murmured Mr. Erskine, with a smile.
vi: “Tôi hiểu, huân tước Henry,” mít-tơ Erskine lẩm bẩm, với một nụ cười.
tr: mr Erskine gülümseyerek, “Ben anlıyorum,” diye mırıldandı.
es: —Yo sí, lord Henry —murmuró el señor Erskine con una sonrisa.
vi_translation: “I understand, Lord Henry,” Mr. Erskine muttered, with a smile.
tr_translation: Mr. Erskine murmured with a smile, "I understand."
es_translation: —I do, Lord Henry —murmured Mr. Erskine with a smile.

en: “Paradoxes are all very well in their way....” rejoined the baronet.
vi: “Các nghịch biện đều rất hay theo cách riêng của chúng…” tòng nam tước đáp lại.
tr: Sir Thomas, “Çelişki dediğin sırasında çekilir ama...” diye söze başladı.
es: —Las paradojas están muy bien a su manera... —intervino el baronet.
vi_translation: “Paradoxes are all very interesting in their own way…” the young baron replied.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas began to speak, "A contradiction is endured in its time, but..."
es_translation: —Paradoxes are all well and good in their own way... —interjected the baronet.

en: “Was that a paradox?” asked Mr. Erskine. “I did not think so. Perhaps it was. Well, the way of paradoxes is the way of truth. To test reality we must see it on the tight rope. When the verities become acrobats, we can judge them.”
vi: “Có phải đó là một sự nghịch biện không?” mít-tơ Erskine hỏi. “Tôi không nghĩ vậy đâu. Không chừng nó là thế. Thôi được, con đường nghịch biện là con đường chân lý. Để kiểm tra Thực tại thì chúng ta phải thấy nó trên sợi dây kéo căng. Khi các Chân lý trở thành những người biểu diễn nhào lộn thì ta mới có thể phán xét chúng.”
tr: mr Erskine, “Çelişki miydi bu?” diye sordu. “Bana öyle gelmedi. Ama belki öyleydi. Ne yapalım, gerçeğe giden yol çelişkiden geçer. Gerçeği sınamak istiyorsak ilkin cambazın ipi üstünde görmemiz gerekir. Doğruları ancak cambazlaştıkları zaman ölçüye vurabiliriz.
es: —¿Era eso una paradoja? —preguntó el señor Erskine—. No me lo ha parecido. Quizá lo fuera. Bien, el camino de las paradojas es el camino de la verdad. Para poner a prueba la realidad, hemos de verla en la cuerda floja. Cuando las verdades se hacen acróbatas podemos juzgarlas.
vi_translation: “Is that a paradox?” Mr. Erskine asked. “I don't think so. Maybe it is. Well, the path of paradox is the path of truth. To test Reality, we must see it on a tightrope. When Truths become acrobats, then we can judge them.”
tr_translation: Mr. Erskine asked, "Was this a contradiction?" "It didn't seem so to me. But maybe it was. Well, the path to truth passes through contradiction. If we want to test the truth, we must first see it on the tightrope. We can only measure truths when they become acrobats."
es_translation: —Was that a paradox? —asked Mr. Erskine—. It didn't seem like it to me. Maybe it was. Well, the path of paradoxes is the path of truth. To test reality, we must see it on the tightrope. When truths become acrobats, we can judge them.

en: “Dear me!” said Lady Agatha, “how you men argue! I am sure I never can make out what you are talking about. Oh! Harry, I am quite vexed with you. Why do you try to persuade our nice Mr. Dorian Gray to give up the East End? I assure you he would be quite invaluable. They would love his playing.”
vi: “Trời ơi!” bà Agatha nói, “đàn ông các anh thích cãi lý làm sao! Tôi tin chắc tôi chẳng bao giờ có thể phân biệt được những gì các anh đang nói đến. À! Harry, dì khá là phật ý với cháu. Tại sao cháu lại cố gắng thuyết phục mít-tơ Dorian Gray đẹp trai của chúng ta bỏ East End? Dì cam đoan là cậu ấy sẽ thật sự vô giá. Họ rất thích cậu ấy chơi.”
tr: Leydi Agatha, “Bak hele!” dedi. “Siz erkekler tartışmayı nasıl da seviyorsunuz. Nelerden konuştuğunuzu dünyada anlayamıyorum, inan olsun. Ha, Harry, sana çok kızgınım. Bizim cici mr Dorian Gray’imizi East End’den vazgeçirmeye çalışmanın âlemi ne? Bize son derece yararı dokunacak, inan. Herkes onun piyano çalışına bayılacak.
es: —¡Dios del cielo! —dijo lady Agatha—, ¡cómo discuten ustedes los hombres! Estoy segura de que nunca sabré de qué están hablando. Por cierto, Harry, estoy muy enfadada contigo. ¿Por qué tratas de convencer a nuestro Dorian Gray, una persona tan encantadora, para que renuncie al East End? Te aseguro que sería inapreciable. A nuestros habituales les hubiera encantado oírle tocar.
vi_translation: "Oh my God!" said Mrs. Agatha, "you men love to argue so much! I'm sure I'll never be able to understand what you are talking about. Ah! Harry, I am quite displeased with you. Why are you trying to persuade our handsome Mr. Dorian Gray to leave East End? I assure you he will be truly invaluable. They really enjoy having him play."
tr_translation: Lady Agatha said, "Look here!" "You men just love to argue. I can never understand what you're talking about, honestly. Oh, Harry, I'm very angry with you. What's the point of trying to dissuade our dear Mr. Dorian Gray from going to the East End? It will be extremely beneficial for us, believe me. Everyone will love his piano playing."
es_translation: —Good heavens! —said Lady Agatha—, how you men argue! I'm sure I'll never know what you're talking about. By the way, Harry, I am very angry with you. Why are you trying to convince our Dorian Gray, such a charming person, to give up the East End? I assure you it would be invaluable. Our regulars would have loved to hear him play.

en: “I want him to play to me,” cried Lord Henry, smiling, and he looked down the table and caught a bright answering glance.
vi: “Cháu muốn cậu ấy chơi cho cháu,” huân tước Henry la lên, cười, rồi y nhìn xuống đầu kia bàn và bắt gặp ánh mắt sáng ngời đáp lại.
tr: Lord Henry gülümseyerek, “Onun benim için piyano çalmasını istiyorum,” dedi. Masanın karşı ucuna baktı, kendi gülümsemesini yanıtlayan parıl parıl bir gülümseme yakaladı.
es: —Quiero que toque para mí —exclamó lord Henry sonriendo. Cuando miró hacia el extremo de la mesa captó como respuesta un brillo en la mirada de Dorian.
vi_translation: “I want him to play for me,” Lord Henry exclaimed, laughing, then he looked down to the other end of the table and met a bright, responsive gaze.
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled and said, "I want him to play the piano for me." He looked to the other end of the table and caught a sparkling smile that answered his own.
es_translation: —I want you to play for me —exclaimed Lord Henry, smiling. When he looked towards the end of the table, he caught a gleam in Dorian's eyes as a response.

en: “But they are so unhappy in Whitechapel,” continued Lady Agatha.
vi: “Nhưng họ rất khốn khổ ở Whitechapel,” bà Agatha tiếp tục.
tr: Leydi Agatha, “Ama Whitechapel’dakiler öyle mutsuz ki!” diye konuşmasını sürdürdü.
es: —Pero en Whitechapel la gente es muy desgraciada —protestó lady Agatha.
vi_translation: “But they are very miserable in Whitechapel,” Mrs. Agatha continued.
tr_translation: Lady Agatha continued, "But the ones in Whitechapel are so unhappy!"
es_translation: —But in Whitechapel, people are very unfortunate —protested Lady Agatha.

en: “I can sympathize with everything except suffering,” said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders. “I cannot sympathize with that. It is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid in the modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with the colour, the beauty, the joy of life. The less said about life’s sores, the better.”
vi: “Cháu có thể thông cảm với mọi điều, ngoại trừ sự đau khổ,” huân tước Henry nói, nhún vai. “Cháu không thế thông cảm với điều ấy được. Nó quá xấu xí, quá kinh khủng, quá buồn thảm. Có gì đó hết sức bệnh hoạn trong sự thông cảm tân thời với nỗi đau. Người ta nên thông cảm với sắc màu, vẻ đẹp, niềm vui sống. Càng ít nói về những đớn đau phiền muộn của cuộc đời thì càng tốt.”
tr: Lord Henry omuz silkerek, “Dünyada her şeye karşı anlayışlı davranabilirim, acı çekmek dışında,” dedi. “İşte buna anlayış gösteremem. Gereğinden fazla çirkin, feci, üzücüdür. Çağımızın acıya karşı gösterdiği yakınlıkta son derece hastalıklı bir şeyler var. İnsan yaşamın rengine, güzelliğine, yaşam sevincine yakınlık göstermelidir. Yaşamın cerahatli yaralarından ne kadar konuşmazsak o kadar iyi bence.
es: —Soy capaz de simpatizar con cualquier cosa menos con el sufrimiento —dijo lord Henry, encogiéndose de hombros—. Hasta eso no llego. Es demasiado feo, demasiado horrible, demasiado angustioso. Hay algo terriblemente morboso en la simpatía de nuestra época por el dolor. Debemos interesarnos por los colores, por la belleza, por la alegría de vivir. Cuanto menos se hable de las miserias de la vida, tanto mejor.
vi_translation: “I can sympathize with everything except suffering,” said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders. “I cannot sympathize with that. It is too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid about modern sympathy with pain. One should sympathize with color, beauty, the joy of life. The less said about the sorrows and woes of life, the better.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry shrugged, "I can sympathize with everything in the world except suffering," he said. "That is something I cannot sympathize with. It is excessively ugly, tragic, and distressing. There is something extremely morbid in our age's affinity for pain. One should show affinity for the color, beauty, and joy of life. The less we talk about life's festering wounds, the better, in my opinion."
es_translation: —I can sympathize with anything except suffering —said Lord Henry, shrugging his shoulders—. I can't go that far. It's too ugly, too horrible, too distressing. There is something terribly morbid about our era's sympathy for pain. We should be interested in colors, in beauty, in the joy of living. The less we talk about the miseries of life, the better.

en: “Still, the East End is a very important problem,” remarked Sir Thomas with a grave shake of the head.
vi: “Tuy nhiên, East End là một vấn đề hệ trọng,” ngài Thomas nhận xét, với một cái lắc đầu nghiêm nghị.
tr: Sir Thomas başını ciddilikle sallayarak, “Gene de East End çok önemli bir sorun,” dedi.
es: —De todos modos, el East End es un problema muy importante —señaló sir Thomas, con un grave movimiento de cabeza.
vi_translation: “However, the East End is a serious matter,” Sir Thomas remarked, with a solemn shake of his head.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas shook his head seriously and said, "Nevertheless, the East End is a very important issue."
es_translation: —In any case, the East End is a very important problem —remarked Sir Thomas, with a grave nod of his head.

en: “Quite so,” answered the young lord. “It is the problem of slavery, and we try to solve it by amusing the slaves.”
vi: “Đúng thế,” chàng huân tước trẻ tuổi đáp lại. “Đó là vấn đề nô lệ, và chúng ta cố giải quyết nó bằng cách tiêu khiển cho các nô lệ.”
tr: Genç Lord, “Hem de nasıl!” dedi. “East End bir kölelik sorunudur, biz de bunu köleleri eğlendirerek çözümlemeye kalkışıyoruz.
es: —Muy cierto —respondió el joven lord—. Es el problema de la esclavitud, y tratamos de resolverlo divirtiendo a los esclavos.
vi_translation: “That's right,” the young lord replied. “It's a matter of slavery, and we try to solve it by entertaining the slaves.”
tr_translation: The Young Lord said, "Indeed, very much so!" "East End is a slavery problem, and we are trying to solve it by entertaining the slaves."
es_translation: —Very true —replied the young lord—. It is the problem of slavery, and we try to solve it by entertaining the slaves.

en: The politician looked at him keenly. “What change do you propose, then?” he asked.
vi: Chính trị gia nhìn y sắc lẻm. “Vậy anh đề xuất sự thay đổi nào, hả?” ông hỏi.
tr: Politikacı gözlerini kısarak ona baktı. “Öyleyse siz ne gibi bir değişiklik öneriyorsunuz?” diye sordu.
es: El político le miró con mucho interés. —¿Qué cambio propone usted, en ese caso? —preguntó.
vi_translation: The politician looked at him sharply. "So what changes do you propose, huh?" he asked.
tr_translation: The politician squinted his eyes and looked at him. “So, what kind of change are you proposing?” he asked.
es_translation: The politician looked at him with great interest. —What change do you propose, in that case? —he asked.

en: Lord Henry laughed. “I don’t desire to change anything in England except the weather,” he answered. “I am quite content with philosophic contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt through an over-expenditure of sympathy, I would suggest that we should appeal to science to put us straight. The advantage of the emotions is that they lead us astray, and the advantage of science is that it is not emotional.”
vi: Huân tước Henry cười. “Tôi không mong muốn thay đổi bất cứ thứ gì ở Anh ngoài thời tiết,” y trả lời. “Tôi khá là thỏa mãn với sự suy ngẫm về triết học. Nhưng, do thế kỷ mười chín đã vỡ nợ vì chi tiêu quá tay cho sự thương cảm, thành thử tôi đề nghị là ta nên thỉnh cầu Khoa học đưa ta về chính đạo. Lợi thế của các cảm xúc là ở chỗ chúng dẫn ta đi lạc, còn lợi thế của Khoa học là ở chỗ nó không có cảm xúc.”
tr: Lord Henry güldü. “Ben İngiltere’de havadan başka hiçbir şeyi değiştirmek istemiyorum,” diye karşılık verdi. “Felsefî düşüncelere dalmak bana yetiyor. Şu var ki, on dokuzuncu yüzyıl bizim anlayış ve acımamızı har vurup harman savurmamız yüzünden iflas ettiğine göre benim önerim, bizi düzeltmesi için bilime başvurmamızdır. Duyguların avantajı şudur ki bizi yolumuzdan saptırırlar; bilimin avantajıysa duygusal olmamasındadır.
es: Lord Henry se echó a reír. —No deseo cambiar nada en Inglaterra, a excepción del clima —respondió—. Me basta y me sobra con la contemplación filosófica.
