Pero como el siglo XIX se ha arruinado por un excesivo gasto de simpatía, sugiero que se acuda a la ciencia para solucionarlo. La ventaja de las emociones es que nos llevan por el mal camino, y la ventaja de la ciencia es que excluye la emoción.
vi_translation: Lord Henry laughed. “I do not wish to change anything in England except the weather,” he replied. “I am quite satisfied with philosophical contemplation. But, as the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt from overspending on sympathy, I suggest that we should appeal to Science to bring us back to the right path. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray, while the advantage of Science is that it has no emotions.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed. “There is nothing I want to change in England except the weather,” he replied. “Delving into philosophical thoughts is enough for me. The fact is, since the nineteenth century has gone bankrupt due to our reckless squandering of understanding and compassion, my suggestion is that we turn to science to correct us. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray; the advantage of science is that it is not emotional.”
es_translation: Lord Henry laughed. —I do not wish to change anything in England, except the weather —he replied—. I am more than satisfied with philosophical contemplation. But since the 19th century has been ruined by an excessive expenditure of sympathy, I suggest turning to science to solve it. The advantage of emotions is that they lead us astray, and the advantage of science is that it excludes emotion.

en: “But we have such grave responsibilities,” ventured Mrs. Vandeleur timidly.
vi: “Nhưng ta mang những trách nhiệm hết sức trầm trọng,” bà Vandeleur đánh bạo, bẽn lẽn.
tr: ms Vandeleur çekinerek, “Ama öylesine ağır ve ciddi sorumluluklar taşıyoruz ki!” diye bir görüş ortaya attı.
es: —Pero tenemos gravísimas responsabilidades —aventuró tímidamente la señora Uandeleur.
vi_translation: “But I bear very grave responsibilities,” Mrs. Vandeleur ventured, shyly.
tr_translation: Ms. Vandeleur hesitantly suggested, "But we bear such heavy and serious responsibilities!"
es_translation: —But we have very serious responsibilities —ventured Mrs. Uandeleur timidly.

en: “Terribly grave,” echoed Lady Agatha.
vi: “Trầm trọng khủng khiếp,” bà Agatha lặp lại.
tr: “Son derece ağır ve ciddi,” diye Leydi Agatha onun sözlerini tekrarladı.
es: —Sumamente graves -se hizo eco lady Agatha.
vi_translation: "Terribly serious," Mrs. Agatha repeated.
tr_translation: “Extremely serious and grave,” Lady Agatha repeated his words.
es_translation: —Extremely serious - echoed Lady Agatha.

en: Lord Henry looked over at Mr. Erskine. “Humanity takes itself too seriously. It is the world’s original sin. If the caveman had known how to laugh, history would have been different.”
vi: Huân tước Henry đưa mắt nhìn qua mít-tơ Erskine. “Loài người coi mình quá quan trọng. Đó là nguyên tội của thế giới. Nếu người sống trong hang biết cách cười, Lịch sử chắc đã khác.”
tr: Lord Henry, mr Erskine’den yana baktı. “İnsanoğlu kendini aşırı ciddiye alıyor. Dünyanın işlediği ilk günah budur. Mağara adamı gülmesini bilseydi tarih çok daha başka olurdu.
es: Lord Henry miró con detenimiento al señor Erskine. —La humanidad se toma demasiado en serio. Es el pecado original del mundo. Si los cavernícolas hubieran sabido reír, la historia habría sido distinta.
vi_translation: Lord Henry glanced at Mr. Erskine. "Human beings consider themselves too important. That is the original sin of the world. If the cave dwellers had known how to laugh, history would have been different."
tr_translation: Lord Henry looked towards Mr. Erskine. "Man takes himself too seriously. This is the first sin the world committed. If the caveman knew how to laugh, history would be very different."
es_translation: Lord Henry looked intently at Mr. Erskine. —Humanity takes itself too seriously. It is the original sin of the world. If the cavemen had known how to laugh, history would have been different.

en: “You are really very comforting,” warbled the duchess. “I have always felt rather guilty when I came to see your dear aunt, for I take no interest at all in the East End. For the future I shall be able to look her in the face without a blush.”
vi: “Anh thật sự là rất biết cách an ủi,” nữ công tước thỏ thẻ. “Tôi luôn cảm thấy khá là có lỗi những khi đến gặp dì anh, vì tôi chẳng quan tâm chút nào đến East End. Từ giờ trở đi thì tôi có thể nhìn vào mắt bà ấy mà không đỏ mặt.”
tr: Düşes şakrak bir sesle, “Siz benim içimi rahatlatıyorsunuz,” dedi. “Sevgili halanızı görmeye geldiğimde hep suçluluk duygusuna kapılırım, çünkü East End beni zerrece ilgilendirmiyor. Bundan böyle halanızın yüzüne bakarken utançtan kızarmayacağım artık.
es: —No sabe cuánto me consuela oírle —gorjeó la duquesa—. Siempre me siento muy culpable cuando vengo a ver a su querida tía, porque no me intereso en absoluto por el East End. En el futuro podré mirarla a la cara sin sonrojarme.
vi_translation: “You really know how to comfort someone,” the duchess whispered. “I always feel quite guilty whenever I visit your aunt, because I don't care at all about the East End. From now on, I can look her in the eye without blushing.”
tr_translation: The Duchess said in a cheerful voice, “You put my mind at ease.” “I always feel guilty when I come to see your dear aunt, because the East End doesn't interest me in the slightest. From now on, I won't blush with shame when I look at your aunt's face.”
es_translation: —You don't know how much it comforts me to hear you —chirped the duchess—. I always feel very guilty when I come to see your dear aunt, because I am not at all interested in the East End. In the future, I will be able to look her in the face without blushing.

en: “A blush is very becoming, Duchess,” remarked Lord Henry.
vi: “Đỏ mặt thì cũng rất hợp mà, thưa nữ công tước,” huân tước Henry nhận xét.
tr: Lord Henry, “Kızarmak insana yakışan bir şeydir düşes,” diye fikir yürüttü.
es: —Sonrojarse es muy favorecedor, duquesa —señaló lord Henry.
vi_translation: “Blushing suits you very well too, madam duchess,” Lord Henry remarked.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "Blushing becomes a person, Duchess," he opined.
es_translation: —Blushing is very becoming, Duchess —remarked Lord Henry.

en: “Only when one is young,” she answered. “When an old woman like myself blushes, it is a very bad sign. Ah! Lord Henry, I wish you would tell me how to become young again.”
vi: “Chỉ khi người ta còn trẻ thôi,” bà đáp lại. “Khi một bà già như tôi đỏ mặt lên, đó là một dấu hiệu rất xấu. À, huân tước Henry này, tôi ước gì anh có thể chỉ tôi cách làm sao để trẻ lại.
tr: Düşes, “Ancak gençler için,” dedi. “Benim gibi yaşlı bir kadın kızardı mı kötüye işarettir. Ah, Lord Henry, keşke bana yeni baştan genç olmanın yolunu gösterebilseniz!
es: —Sólo cuando se es joven —respondió ella—. Cuando una anciana como yo se sonroja, es muy mala señal. ¡Ah, me gustaría que me dijera usted cómo volver a ser joven!
vi_translation: “Only when one is still young,” she replied. “When an old lady like me blushes, it is a very bad sign. Ah, Lord Henry, I wish you could show me how to become young again.”
tr_translation: The Duchess said, "But only for the young." "For an old woman like me, blushing is a bad sign. Oh, Lord Henry, I wish you could show me how to be young again!"
es_translation: —Only when one is young —she replied—. When an old woman like me blushes, it's a very bad sign. Ah, I wish you could tell me how to be young again!

en: He thought for a moment. “Can you remember any great error that you committed in your early days, Duchess?” he asked, looking at her across the table.
vi: Y nghĩ một lát. “Bà có thể nhớ được một sai lầm lớn nào đó mà bà từng phạm phải thuở ban đầu không, thưa nữ công tước?” y hỏi, nhìn bà qua bàn.
tr: Lord Henry bir an düşündü. Sonra karşısındaki kadına bakarak, “Eski günlerinizde yaptığınız büyük bir hata anımsayabiliyor musunuz, düşes?” diye sordu.
es: Lord Henry meditó unos instantes. —¿Recuerda usted algún gran error que cometiera en sus primeros tiempos, duquesa? —preguntó mirándola desde el otro lado de la mesa.
vi_translation: He thought for a moment. “Can you remember any major mistake you made in the early days, Duchess?” he asked, looking at her across the table.
tr_translation: Lord Henry thought for a moment. Then, looking at the woman in front of him, he asked, "Can you recall a great mistake you made in your old days, Duchess?"
es_translation: Lord Henry pondered for a moment. —Do you remember any big mistake you made in your early days, Duchess? —he asked, looking at her from the other side of the table.

en: “Then commit them over again,” he said gravely. “To get back one’s youth, one has merely to repeat one’s follies.”
vi: “Vậy thì phạm lại chúng nữa đi,” y nói, nghiêm trang. “Để quay lại tuổi xuân, người ta chỉ cần làm lại những việc điên rồ của mình.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Öyleyse bunları yeniden yapın,” diye ciddilikle yanıtladı. “İnsanın gençliğini yeniden kazanabilmesi için çılgınlıklarını yinelemesi yeterlidir.
es: —Pues vuelva a cometerlos —dijo él con gravedad—. Para recuperar la juventud, basta con repetir las mismas locuras.
vi_translation: "Then commit them again," he said, solemnly. "To return to youth, one only needs to repeat their own follies."
tr_translation: Lord Henry replied seriously, "Then do them again." "To regain one's youth, one only needs to repeat one's follies."
es_translation: —Well, commit them again —he said gravely—. To regain youth, it is enough to repeat the same follies.

en: “A delightful theory!” she exclaimed. “I must put it into practice.”
vi: “Một lý thuyết thú vị!” bà thốt lên. “Tôi phải áp dụng nó vào thực tiễn.
tr: Düşes, “Harika bir kuram,” dedi. “Hemen uygulamalıyım.
es: —¡Deliciosa teoría! —exclamó ella—. He de ponerla en práctica.
vi_translation: “An interesting theory!” she exclaimed. “I must apply it in practice.”
tr_translation: The Duchess said, "A wonderful theory." "I must apply it immediately."
es_translation: —Delicious theory! —she exclaimed—. I must put it into practice.

en: “A dangerous theory!” came from Sir Thomas’s tight lips. Lady Agatha shook her head, but could not help being amused. Mr. Erskine listened.
vi: “Một lý thuyết nguy hiểm!” đến từ đôi môi mím chặt của ngài Thomas. Bà Agatha lắc đầu, nhưng không thể nhịn cười. Mít-tơ Erskine lắng nghe.
tr: Sir Thomas büzülmüş dudaklarıyla, “Tehlikeli bir kuram!” diye konuştu. Leydi Agatha da başını salladı ama keyiflenmekten kendini alamıyordu. mr Erskine kulak kesilmişti.
es: —¡Una teoría peligrosa! —dijo sir Thomas, la boca tensa. Lady Agatha movió desaprobadoramente la cabeza, pero la idea le pareció de todos modos divertida. El señor Erskine escuchaba.
vi_translation: "A dangerous theory!" came from the tightly pressed lips of Mr. Thomas. Mrs. Agatha shook her head but couldn't help laughing. Mr. Erskine listened.
tr_translation: Sir Thomas spoke with pursed lips, "A dangerous theory!" Lady Agatha nodded her head but couldn't help feeling amused. Mr. Erskine was all ears.
es_translation: —A dangerous theory! —said Sir Thomas, his mouth tense. Lady Agatha shook her head disapprovingly, but the idea still seemed amusing to her. Mr. Erskine was listening.

en: “Yes,” he continued, “that is one of the great secrets of life. Nowadays most people die of a sort of creeping common sense, and discover when it is too late that the only things one never regrets are one’s mistakes.”
vi: “Vâng,” y nói tiếp, “đó là một trong những bí mật vĩ đại nhất của cuộc sống. Ngày nay phần lớn mọi người chết vì một loại lương tri rón rén, và phát hiện ra lúc đã quá muộn rằng những thứ duy nhất mà người ta chẳng bao giờ hối tiếc chính là các lỗi lầm của mình.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Evet,” diye ekledi. “Yaşamın büyük gizlerinden biridir bu. Şimdilerde çoğu kimse bir tür ilerlemiş sağduyu yüzünden ölüyor. İş işten geçtikten sonra ayırdına varıyorlar ki insanın pişman olmadığı tek şey hatalarıdır.
es: —Sí —continuó el joven lord—; se trata de uno de los grandes secretos de la vida. En la actualidad la mayoría de la gente muere de una indigestión de sentido común y descubre cuando ya es demasiado tarde que lo único que nunca lamentamos son nuestros errores.
vi_translation: “Yes,” he continued, “that is one of the greatest secrets of life. Nowadays most people die of a creeping common sense, and discover too late that the only things one never regrets are one's mistakes.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry added, "Yes." "It is one of the great mysteries of life. Nowadays, most people die of a sort of creeping common sense. They realize too late that the only things one never regrets are one's mistakes."
es_translation: —Yes —continued the young lord—; it is one of the great secrets of life. Nowadays, most people die of an indigestion of common sense and discover when it is already too late that the only things we never regret are our mistakes.

en: A laugh ran round the table.
vi: Một tràng cười chạy vòng quanh bàn.
tr: Masanın çevresinde bir kahkaha dolaştı.
es: Se oyeron risas en torno a la mesa.
vi_translation: A burst of laughter ran around the table.
tr_translation: Laughter circulated around the table.
es_translation: Laughter was heard around the table.

en: He played with the idea and grew wilful; tossed it into the air and transformed it; let it escape and recaptured it; made it iridescent with fancy and winged it with paradox. The praise of folly, as he went on, soared into a philosophy, and philosophy herself became young, and catching the mad music of pleasure, wearing, one might fancy, her wine-stained robe and wreath of ivy, danced like a Bacchante over the hills of life, and mocked the slow Silenus for being sober. Facts fled before her like frightened forest things. Her white feet trod the huge press at which wise Omar sits, till the seething grape-juice rose round her bare limbs in waves of purple bubbles, or crawled in red foam over the vat’s black, dripping, sloping sides. It was an extraordinary improvisation. He felt that the eyes of Dorian Gray were fixed on him, and the consciousness that amongst his audience there was one whose temperament he wished to fascinate seemed to give his wit keenness and to lend colour to his imagination. He was brilliant, fantastic, irresponsible. He charmed his listeners out of themselves, and they followed his pipe, laughing. Dorian Gray never took his gaze off him, but sat like one under a spell, smiles chasing each other over his lips and wonder growing grave in his darkening eyes.
vi: Y đùa nghịch với ý tưởng ấy, và dần dần trở nên ngoan cố; tung nó lên không khí và biến đổi nó; để mặc nó trốn đi rồi bắt lại; làm cho nó tỏa sáng óng ánh bằng trí tưởng tượng, rồi chắp cánh cho nó bằng nghịch biện. Lời tán dương sự điên rồ, như y đang tiếp tục, bay vút lên tầm cao một triết học, còn chính Triết học thì trở nên trẻ trung, bắt lấy tiếng nhạc cuồng điên của Lạc thú, mặc, ta có thể tưởng tượng, chiếc áo dài lem luốc rượu vang, đội vòng dây thường xuân, nhảy múa như một cô đồng thờ thần rượu trên khắp các ngọn đồi của sự sống, chế giễu lão thần Silenus chậm chạp vì không bị say xỉn. Các sự thật lao vùn vụt trước nàng như lũ thú rừng hoảng sợ. Đôi chân trắng muốt của nàng giẫm đạp cái máy ép khổng lồ mà trên đó Omar thông thái ngồi, cho đến khi nước nho sôi sục dâng lên quanh các chi để trần của nàng trong những sóng bong bóng đỏ tía, hoặc trườn trong bọt đỏ trên khắp các thành dốc, đen, ướt sũng của cái bể. Đó là một khúc ứng khẩu phi thường. Y cảm thấy rằng đôi mắt Dorian Gray dồn hết vào y, và cái ý thức rằng giữa khán thính giả của mình nơi đây đang có một kẻ sở hữu cái khí chất mà y muốn thôi miên, dường như cho trí thông minh của y sự sắc nhọn, và thêm màu cho trí tưởng tượng của y. Y tài hoa, lập dị, tắc trách. Y dụ người nghe ra khỏi chính họ, và họ vừa bám theo tiếng sáo của y vừa cười. Dorian Gray không lúc nào rời mắt khỏi y, nhưng ngồi như một kẻ bị bỏ bùa, những nụ cười đuổi nhau trên môi, và sự kinh ngạc từ từ chuyển thành trang nghiêm trong đôi mắt thẫm dần.
tr: Lord Henry bu fikirle oynadıkça daha da coşuyordu. Fikri havaya atıp değişime uğratıyor, elinden kaçmasına izin vermişken yeniden yakalıyor, fantezilerle süsleyip yanar dönerleştiriyor, üzerine çelişkiden kanatlar takıyordu. Çılgınlığa düzdüğü övgü biraz sonra bir felsefeye dönüştü. Şimdi felsefenin kendisi de gençleşmiş, zevki sefanın çılgın müziğine uymuştu; insana öyle geliyordu ki sırtında şarap lekeli giysisi ve başında taflan tacıy-la, yaşam tepelerinin üstünde bir Bakkhus müridi gibi dans ediyor ve ağırkanlı Silenus’u2 ayık olduğu için alaya alıyordu. Gerçekler onun önü sıra kaçıp gidiyorlardı, ürkek orman hayvanları gibi. Onun o beyaz ayakları bil- ge Omar’ın teknesindeki üzümleri çiğnedikçe köpüklü üzüm suyu mor kabarcıklı dalgalarla çıplak bacaklarının çevresinde yükseliyor, kızıl bir köpük seli olarak teknenin ıslak, eğimli, siyah küpeştesinden taşıyordu. Şaşırtıcı bir doğaçlamaydı bu! Lord Henry, Dorian Gray’in gözlerinin kendi üstüne dikilmiş olduğunu duyumsuyor, dinleyenlerin arasında gözünü kamaştırmak istediği birisinin bulunduğunu bilmek sanki onun mizah duyusunu keskinleştiriyor, hayal gücüne renk katıyordu. Konuşması parlak, inanılmaz, sorumsuzdu. Dinleyenleri büyüleyerek sanki kendilerinden dışarı çekiyor, onlar da güle oynaya onun çaldığı kavalın peşinden gidiyorlardı. Dorian Gray gözlerini ondan hiç ayırmadan büyülenmiş gibi, öylece oturuyordu, dudaklarında gülücükler birbirini kovalıyor ve gitgide kararan gözlerindeki şaşkınlık ve hayranlık derinleşiyordu.
es: Lord Henry jugó con la idea, animándose cada vez más; la lanzó al aire y la transformó; la dejó escapar y volvió a capturarla; la adornó con todos los fuegos de la fantasía y le dio alas con la paradoja. El elogio de la locura, mientras lord Henry proseguía, se elevó hasta las alturas de la filosofía, y la filosofía misma se hizo joven y, contagiada por la música desenfrenada del placer, vestida, cabría imaginar, con su túnica manchada de vino y una guirnalda de hiedra, danzó como una bacante sobre las colinas de la vida y se burló del plácido Sileno por su sobriedad. Los hechos huyeron ante ella como asustados animalitos del bosque. Sus pies alabastrinos pisaron el enorme lagar donde sienta sus reales el sabio Omar, hasta que el zumo rosado de la vid se elevó en torno a sus extremidades desnudas en oleadas de burbujas moradas, o se deslizó en espuma por las negras paredes inclinadas de la cuba. Fue una extraordinaria improvisación. Lord Henry sentía fijos en él los ojos de Dorian Gray, y saber que había entre quienes lo escuchaban alguien a quien deseaba fascinar parecía dar mayor agudeza a su ingenio y prestar colores más vivos a su imaginación. Se mostró brillante, fantástico, irresponsable. Encantó a sus oyentes haciendo que se olvidaran de sí mismos, y que siguieran, riendo, la melodía de su caramillo. Dorian Gray nunca apartó de él los ojos, y permaneció inmóvil como si estuviera encantado, sucediéndose las sonrisas sobre sus labios, mientras el asombro, en el fondo de sus ojos, adoptaba una pensativa gravedad.
vi_translation: He toyed with that idea, and gradually became obstinate; tossing it into the air and transforming it; letting it escape and then catching it again; making it shine brilliantly with imagination, then giving it wings with paradox. The praise of madness, as he continued, soared to the heights of philosophy, while Philosophy itself became youthful, catching the frenzied music of Pleasure, wearing, we might imagine, a wine-stained robe, crowned with ivy, dancing like a Bacchante across the hills of life, mocking the slow old god Silenus for not being drunk. Truths rushed past her like frightened wild animals. Her pure white feet trampled the enormous press on which wise Omar sat, until the fermenting grape juice rose around her bare limbs in waves of purple bubbles, or crawled in red foam over the steep, black, drenched sides of the vat. It was an extraordinary improvisation. He felt that Dorian Gray's eyes were fixed on him, and the awareness that among his audience there was someone possessing the temperament he wished to mesmerize seemed to sharpen his intellect and add color to his imagination. He was talented, eccentric, irresponsible. He lured his listeners out of themselves, and they followed his pipe laughing. Dorian Gray never took his eyes off him, but sat like one enchanted, smiles chasing each other on his lips, and wonder slowly turning to solemnity in his darkening eyes.
tr_translation: Lord Henry became more and more excited as he toyed with this idea. He tossed the idea into the air, transforming it, letting it slip away only to catch it again, adorning it with fantasies and making it iridescent, attaching wings of contradiction to it. The praise he lavished on madness soon turned into a philosophy. Now the philosophy itself had rejuvenated, aligning with the wild music of pleasure and revelry; it seemed as though, dressed in a wine-stained garment and crowned with a laurel wreath, it danced like a Bacchus follower over the hills of life, mocking the slow Silenus for being sober. Truths fled before him, like timid forest animals. As his white feet trampled the grapes in wise Omar’s vat, the frothy grape juice rose around his bare legs in waves of purple bubbles, spilling over the wet, sloping, black edge of the vat as a flood of crimson foam. It was an astonishing improvisation! Lord Henry sensed that Dorian Gray’s eyes were fixed upon him, and knowing that there was someone among the listeners whom he wanted to dazzle seemed to sharpen his sense of humor and add color to his imagination. His speech was brilliant, incredible, and irresponsible. Enchanting his listeners, it was as if he drew them out of themselves, and they followed him merrily to the tune of his pipe. Dorian Gray sat there as if mesmerized, never taking his eyes off him, smiles chasing each other on his lips, and the astonishment and admiration in his increasingly darkening eyes deepening.
es_translation: Lord Henry played with the idea, becoming more and more animated; he tossed it into the air and transformed it; he let it escape and recaptured it; he adorned it with all the fires of fantasy and gave it wings with paradox. The praise of folly, as Lord Henry continued, rose to the heights of philosophy, and philosophy itself became young and, infected by the unrestrained music of pleasure, dressed, one might imagine, in its wine-stained robe and an ivy garland, danced like a bacchante over the hills of life and mocked the placid Silenus for his sobriety. Facts fled before it like frightened little animals of the forest. Its alabaster feet trod the enormous winepress where the wise Omar holds court, until the rosy juice of the vine rose around its bare limbs in waves of purple bubbles, or slid in foam down the black sloping walls of the vat. It was an extraordinary improvisation. Lord Henry felt Dorian Gray's eyes fixed on him, and knowing that among those listening there was someone he wished to fascinate seemed to sharpen his wit and lend brighter colors to his imagination. He was brilliant, fantastic, irresponsible. He enchanted his listeners, making them forget themselves, and follow, laughing, the melody of his pipe. Dorian Gray never took his eyes off him, and remained motionless as if he were enchanted, smiles succeeding one another on his lips, while the astonishment in the depths of his eyes took on a thoughtful gravity.

en: At last, liveried in the costume of the age, reality entered the room in the shape of a servant to tell the duchess that her carriage was waiting. She wrung her hands in mock despair. “How annoying!” she cried. “I must go. I have to call for my husband at the club, to take him to some absurd meeting at Willis’s Rooms, where he is going to be in the chair. If I am late he is sure to be furious, and I couldn’t have a scene in this bonnet. It is far too fragile. A harsh word would ruin it. No, I must go, dear Agatha. Good-bye, Lord Henry, you are quite delightful and dreadfully demoralizing. I am sure I don’t know what to say about your views. You must come and dine with us some night. Tuesday? Are you disengaged Tuesday?”
vi: Cuối cùng, mặc bộ chế phục thời đại, Thực tại bước vào phòng dưới lốt một người hầu để thưa với nữ công tước rằng cỗ xe ngựa của bà đang chờ. Bà vặn vẹo đôi tay giả bộ thất vọng. “Chán thật!” bà kêu lên. “Tôi phải đi. Tôi phải tạt qua gặp chồng ở câu lạc bộ, để đưa ông ấy đến cuộc họp ngớ ngẩn nào đó ở các phòng Willis, nơi ông ấy sẽ chủ trì. Nếu tôi đến trễ, ông ấy chắc chắn sẽ giận điên lên, và tôi không thể cãi nhau trong lúc đội cái mũ bê-rê này. Nó quá là mỏng manh. Một lời nói thô bạo cũng có thể hủy hoại nó. Không, tôi phải đi, Agatha thân mến. Tạm biệt, huân tước Henry, anh đúng là thú vị, và quá chừng đồi bại. Tôi chắc chắn là tôi không biết nói gì về quan điểm anh. Tối nào đó anh phải đến dùng bữa với chúng tôi đi. Thứ Ba nhé? Anh có rảnh vào thứ Ba không?”
tr: En sonunda, çağın üniformasına bürünmüş olarak gerçek, uşak kılığında salona girdi, düşese arabasının beklediğini bildirdi. Düşes yapmacık bir umarsızlıkla ellerini ovuşturarak, “Ne can sıkıcı şey!” diye bağırdı. “Gitmem gerek. Kulüpten kocamı alıp gülünç bir toplantıya götürmek zorundayım, Willis’in evinde. Bizimki toplantının başkanlığını yapacak da. Gecikirsem mutlaka öfkelenir. Ben de başımda bu şapka varken kavgaya gelemem. Çok nazlı bir şapka bu. Sert bir sözle mahvolabilir. Yok, gitmem gerek, canım Agatha. Hoşça kalın, Lord Henry, çok şeker ve moral bozucusunuz. Görüşleriniz konusunda ne diyeceğimi bilemiyorum. Bir akşam bize, akşam yemeğine beklerim. Salı nasıl? Salı akşamına bir sözünüz var mı?
es: Finalmente, cubierta con la librea de la época, la realidad entró en la estancia en forma de lacayo para decir que a la duquesa la esperaba su coche. La noble señora se retorció las manos con fingida desesperación. —¡Qué fastidio! —exclamó—. He de marcharme. Tengo que recoger a mi marido en el club para llevarlo a Willis's Rooms, donde debe presidir no sé qué absurda reunión. Si llego tarde se enfurecerá sin duda, y no puedo exponerme a una escena con este sombrero. Es demasiado frágil. Una palabra dura acabaría con él. No, he de irme, mi querida Agatha. Hasta la vista, lord Henry, es usted absolutamente delicioso y terriblemente desmoralizador. Desde luego, no sabría qué decir sobre sus ideas. Tiene que venir a cenar con nosotros una de estas noches. ¿El martes? ¿Está usted libre el martes?
vi_translation: Finally, wearing the uniform of the era, Reality stepped into the room disguised as a servant to inform the duchess that her carriage was waiting. She twisted her hands, pretending to be disappointed. “How boring!” she exclaimed. “I have to go. I have to drop by to meet my husband at the club to take him to some silly meeting at Willis's rooms, where he will be presiding. If I am late, he will surely be furious, and I can't argue while wearing this beret. It's too delicate. A harsh word could ruin it. No, I must go, dear Agatha. Goodbye, Lord Henry, you are truly amusing, and so very decadent. I certainly don't know what to say about your views. You must come to dine with us some evening. Tuesday? Are you free on Tuesday?”
tr_translation: In the end, reality, dressed in the uniform of the age, entered the room in the guise of a servant and informed the duchess that her carriage was waiting. The duchess, rubbing her hands with feigned helplessness, exclaimed, "How annoying!" "I have to go. I have to pick up my husband from the club and take him to a ridiculous meeting at Willis's house. He is to preside over the meeting. If I'm late, he will surely be angry. And I can't come to a quarrel with this hat on my head. It's a very delicate hat. It could be ruined by a harsh word. No, I must go, dear Agatha. Goodbye, Lord Henry, you are very sweet and demoralizing. I don't know what to say about your views. I invite you to dinner at our place one evening. How about Tuesday? Do you have any plans for Tuesday evening?"
es_translation: Finally, covered in the livery of the time, reality entered the room in the form of a footman to announce that the duchess's carriage was waiting for her. The noble lady wrung her hands in feigned despair. —What a nuisance! —she exclaimed—. I have to leave. I have to pick up my husband at the club to take him to Willis's Rooms, where he has to preside over some absurd meeting. If I arrive late, he will undoubtedly be furious, and I can't risk a scene with this hat. It is too fragile. A harsh word would destroy it. No, I must go, my dear Agatha. Goodbye, Lord Henry, you are absolutely delightful and terribly demoralizing. Of course, I wouldn't know what to say about your ideas. You must come to dinner with us one of these nights. Tuesday? Are you free on Tuesday?

en: “For you I would throw over anybody, Duchess,” said Lord Henry with a bow.
vi: “Vì bà thì tôi có thể bỏ rơi bất cứ ai, thưa nữ công tước,” huân tước Henry nói, với một cái cúi đầu.
tr: Lord Henry eğilerek, “Sizin için bütün sözlerimden cayarım, düşes,” dedi.
es: —Por usted, duquesa, ¿de quién no prescindiría yo? —respondió lord Henry, con una inclinación de cabeza.
vi_translation: "For you, I could abandon anyone, Your Grace," Lord Henry said, with a bow.
tr_translation: Lord Henry leaned in and said, "I would renounce all my words for you, Duchess."
es_translation: —For you, Duchess, whom would I not do without? —replied Lord Henry, with a nod of his head.

en: “Ah! that is very nice, and very wrong of you,” she cried; “so mind you come”; and she swept out of the room, followed by Lady Agatha and the other ladies.
vi: “À! Thế rất dễ thương và cũng rất sai từ phía anh đấy,” bà kêu lên; “vậy anh nhớ đến nhé;” và bà lướt nhanh ra khỏi phòng, theo sau là bà Agatha và các bà khác.
tr: Düşes, “Ah, çok şeker, çok ayıp!” dedi. “Bekliyorum, öyleyse. Böyle diyerek tüm tantanasıyla salondan çıktı. Leydi Agatha ile öbür hanımlar da peşinden gittiler.
es: —¡Ah! ¡Muy amable y muy cruel por su parte! —exclamó la duquesa—; pero no se olvide de venir —y abandonó la habitación seguida por lady Agatha y las otras damas.
vi_translation: "Ah! That is very charming and also very wrong on your part," she exclaimed; "so remember that;" and she quickly glided out of the room, followed by Mrs. Agatha and the other ladies.
tr_translation: The Duchess said, "Oh, very sweet, very shameful!" "I am waiting, then." With that, he left the room with all his fuss. Lady Agatha and the other ladies followed him.
es_translation: —Ah! Very kind and very cruel of you! —exclaimed the Duchess—; but don't forget to come —and she left the room followed by Lady Agatha and the other ladies.

en: When Lord Henry had sat down again, Mr. Erskine moved round, and taking a chair close to him, placed his hand upon his arm.
vi: Khi huân tước Henry lại ngồi xuống, mít-tơ Erskine đi vòng qua, mang một chiếc ghế lại gần y, đặt bàn tay lên cánh tay y.
tr: Lord Henry yerine oturduğunda mr Erskine döndü, ona yakın bir yere oturarak elini onun koluna koydu.
es: Cuando lord Henry se hubo sentado de nuevo, el señor Erskine, dando la vuelta a la mesa, y colocándose a su lado, le puso una mano en el brazo.
vi_translation: When Lord Henry sat down again, Mr. Erskine walked around, brought a chair close to him, and placed his hand on his arm.
tr_translation: When Lord Henry sat down, Mr. Erskine turned, sat close to him, and placed his hand on his arm.
es_translation: When Lord Henry had sat down again, Mr. Erskine, walking around the table, and placing himself beside him, put a hand on his arm.

en: “You talk books away,” he said; “why don’t you write one?”
vi: “Anh nói sách thua xa,” y bảo; “sao anh không viết một cuốn?”
tr: “Sözlerinizle kitapları sönük bırakıyorsunuz,” dedi. “Neden oturup bir kitap yazmıyorsunuz?
es: —Usted habla mucho de libros —dijo—; ¿por qué no escribe uno?
vi_translation: “You say books fall short,” he said; “why don't you write one?”
tr_translation: “You overshadow books with your words,” he said. “Why don't you sit down and write a book?”
es_translation: —You talk a lot about books —he said—; why don't you write one?

en: “I am too fond of reading books to care to write them, Mr. Erskine. I should like to write a novel certainly, a novel that would be as lovely as a Persian carpet and as unreal. But there is no literary public in England for anything except newspapers, primers, and encyclopaedias. Of all people in the world the English have the least sense of the beauty of literature.”
vi: “Tôi quá thích đọc sách để quan tâm đến việc viết chúng, thưa mít-tơ Erskine. Tôi thích viết tiểu thuyết, dĩ nhiên; một tiểu thuyết đáng yêu như tấm thảm Ba Tư, và phi thực như vậy. Nhưng không có văn giới ở Anh cho bất cứ thứ gì ngoại trừ báo, sách vỡ lòng và bách khoa toàn thư. Trong tất cả các dân tộc trên thế giới này thì người Anh có ít khả năng thưởng thức vẻ đẹp văn chương nhất.
tr: “mr Erskine, kitap sevgim öyle büyüktür ki kitap yazmama engeldir. Gerçi bir roman yazmayı çok isterim, bir Acem halısı kadar güzel bir roman, öylesine de asılsız. Gelgelelim İngiltere’de halk gündelik gazetelerle ansiklopedilerden başka kitap okumuyor ki! Dünya halkları arasında edebiyatın güzelliğinden en az anlayan halk İngilizlerdir.
es: —Me gusta demasiado leerlos para molestarme en escribirlos, señor Erskine. Desde luego, me gustaría escribir una novela, una novela que fuese tan encantadora y tan irreal como una alfombra persa. Pero en Inglaterra no hay público más que para periódicos, libros de texto y enciclopedias. No hay en todo el mundo personas con menos sentido de la belleza literaria que los ingleses.
vi_translation: “I am too fond of reading books to care about writing them, Mr. Erskine. I like writing novels, of course; a novel as lovely as a Persian carpet, and just as unreal. But there is no literary market in England for anything except newspapers, primers, and encyclopedias. Of all the peoples in the world, the English have the least ability to appreciate the beauty of literature.”
tr_translation: “Mr. Erskine, my love for books is so great that it prevents me from writing one. Although I would love to write a novel, as beautiful as a Persian carpet, and just as fictitious. However, in England, people read nothing but daily newspapers and encyclopedias! Among the peoples of the world, the English are the ones who understand the beauty of literature the least.”
es_translation: —I like reading them too much to bother writing them, Mr. Erskine. Of course, I would like to write a novel, a novel that would be as charming and unreal as a Persian carpet. But in England, there is an audience only for newspapers, textbooks, and encyclopedias. There are no people in the whole world with less sense of literary beauty than the English.

en: “I fear you are right,” answered Mr. Erskine. “I myself used to have literary ambitions, but I gave them up long ago. And now, my dear young friend, if you will allow me to call you so, may I ask if you really meant all that you said to us at lunch?”
vi: “Tôi sợ là anh đúng,” mít-tơ Erskine trả lời. “Tự tôi từng có khát vọng văn chương, nhưng đã gác chúng lại từ lâu lắm rồi. Và giờ đây, anh bạn trẻ thân mến của tôi, nếu anh sẽ cho phép tôi gọi anh thế, liệu tôi có thể hỏi là anh có thật sự nghiêm túc về tất cả những gì anh vừa nói với chúng tôi vào bữa trưa hay không?”
tr: mr Erskine, “Korkarım haklısınız,” dedi. “Ben de bir zamanlar edebiyatla ilgili emeller beslerdim, ama yıllar önce vazgeçtim. Şimdi de... İzin verirseniz size genç dostum diyeyim... Yemekte söylediklerinizin hepsinde ciddi miydiniz?
es: —Me temo que tiene usted razón —respondió el señor Erskine—. Yo mismo tuve ambiciones literarias, pero las abandoné hace mucho. Y ahora, mi joven y querido amigo, si me permite que le dé ese nombre, ¿le puedo preguntar si mantiene usted todo lo que nos ha dicho durante el almuerzo?
vi_translation: “I'm afraid you are right,” Mr. Erskine replied. “I once had literary aspirations myself, but I set them aside long ago. And now, my dear young friend, if you will allow me to call you that, may I ask if you were truly serious about everything you said to us at lunch?”
tr_translation: Mr. Erskine said, "I'm afraid you're right." "I once had literary ambitions myself, but I gave them up years ago. And now... If you allow me to call you my young friend... Were you serious about everything you said at dinner?"
es_translation: —I am afraid you are right —replied Mr. Erskine—. I myself had literary ambitions, but I abandoned them long ago. And now, my young and dear friend, if you allow me to call you that, may I ask if you stand by everything you told us during lunch?

en: “I quite forget what I said,” smiled Lord Henry. “Was it all very bad?”
vi: “Tôi quên sạch những gì tôi nói rồi,” huân tước Henry cười. “Có phải chúng xấu cả không?”
tr: Lord Henry, “Neler dediğimi unuttum gitti,” diye gülümsedi. “Çok mu kötü şeyler söyledim?
es: —He olvidado por completo lo que he dicho —sonrió lord Henry—. ¿Tan inmoral era?
vi_translation: “I have completely forgotten what I said,” Lord Henry laughed. “Were they all bad?”
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled, "I have completely forgotten what I said." "Did I say very bad things?"
es_translation: —I have completely forgotten what I said —smiled Lord Henry—. Was it so immoral?

en: “Very bad indeed. In fact I consider you extremely dangerous, and if anything happens to our good duchess, we shall all look on you as being primarily responsible. But I should like to talk to you about life. The generation into which I was born was tedious. Some day, when you are tired of London, come down to Treadley and expound to me your philosophy of pleasure over some admirable Burgundy I am fortunate enough to possess.”
vi: “Rất xấu thật. Thực ra tôi coi anh cực kỳ nguy hiểm, và nếu có bất cứ chuyện gì xảy ra với nữ công tước tử tế của chúng tôi thì tất cả chúng tôi sẽ nhìn anh như kẻ chịu trách nhiệm chính. Nhưng tôi muốn đàm đạo với anh về cuộc sống. Thế hệ mà trong đó tôi được sinh ra rất chán. Một hôm nào đó, khi anh đã mệt mỏi với London, hãy xuống Treadley, và giảng giải cho tôi về môn triết học hoan lạc của anh trong khi dùng chút rượu Buốc-gô-nhơ tuyệt hảo mà tôi may mắn được sở hữu.”
tr: “Hem de çok kötü. Doğruyu isterseniz benim gözümde siz çok tehlikeli bir kişisiniz. Değerli düşesimize bir şey olursa hepimiz baş sorumlu olarak sizi göreceğiz. Ama ben sizinle yaşam üstüne konuşmak isterim. Bizim kuşak pek can sıkıcı çıktı. Günlerden bir gün, Londra’dan bıktığınızda Treadley’e buyrun. Şans eseri çok nefis Burgundy şarabım var. Bunu yudumlarken şu ‘keyif felsefeniz’i ayrıntılı olarak açıklarsınız bana.
es: —Sumamente inmoral. De hecho le considero extraordinariamente peligroso, y si algo le sucede a nuestra buena duquesa le tendremos por responsable directo. Pero me gustaría hablar con usted sobre la vida. La generación de la que formo parte es francamente aburrida. Algún día, cuando se canse de Londres, venga a Treadley, expóngame su filosofía del placer mientras degustamos un excelente borgoña que tengo la fortuna de poseer.
vi_translation: “Very bad indeed. In fact, I consider you extremely dangerous, and if anything happens to our kind duchess, we will all look at you as the main person responsible. But I want to discuss life with you. The generation in which I was born is very boring. One day, when you are tired of London, come down to Treadley and explain to me your philosophy of pleasure while enjoying some excellent Burgundy wine that I am fortunate to possess.”
tr_translation: “And very bad indeed. To be honest, in my eyes, you are a very dangerous person. If anything happens to our dear duchess, we will all see you as the main culprit. But I would like to talk to you about life. Our generation turned out to be quite boring. One day, when you get tired of London, come to Treadley. By chance, I have some very exquisite Burgundy wine. While sipping it, you can explain to me in detail this ‘philosophy of pleasure’ of yours.”
es_translation: —Extremely immoral. In fact, I consider him extraordinarily dangerous, and if anything happens to our good duchess, we will hold him directly responsible. But I would like to talk to you about life. The generation I am part of is frankly boring. Someday, when you tire of London, come to Treadley, explain to me your philosophy of pleasure while we enjoy an excellent Burgundy that I am fortunate enough to possess.

en: “I shall be charmed. A visit to Treadley would be a great privilege. It has a perfect host, and a perfect library.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ rất vui sướng. Chuyến thăm thú Treadley hẳn là đặc ân lớn. Nơi có một chủ nhà hoàn hảo, và một thư viện hoàn hảo.”
tr: “Çok sevinirim. Treadley’i gelip görmeyi büyük onur sayarım. Kusursuz bir ev sahibi, kusursuz bir kitaplığı var.
es: —Me encantará. Una visita a Treadley será un gran privilegio. Cuenta con un perfecto anfitrión y una biblioteca igualmente perfecta.
vi_translation: "I will be very delighted." "A visit to Treadley must be a great privilege." "A place with a perfect host, and a perfect library."
tr_translation: "I would be very happy. I would consider it a great honor to come and see Treadley. He is a perfect host, and he has a perfect library."
es_translation: —I will love it. A visit to Treadley will be a great privilege. It boasts a perfect host and an equally perfect library.

en: “You will complete it,” answered the old gentleman with a courteous bow. “And now I must bid good-bye to your excellent aunt. I am due at the Athenaeum. It is the hour when we sleep there.”
vi: “Anh sẽ bổ sung cho nó được trọn vẹn,” ông già trả lời, với cái cúi đầu nhã nhặn. “Và giờ thì tôi phải chào tạm biệt bà dì tuyệt vời của anh. Tôi phải đến câu lạc bộ văn học. Giờ này là lúc chúng tôi ngủ ở đó.”
tr: Yaşlı beyefendi nazik bir eğilişle, “Siz Treadley’i tamamlarsınız,” dedi. “Şimdi artık saygıdeğer halanıza veda etmem gerek. Anthenaeum Kulübü’nde beni bekliyorlar. Orada şimdi bizim uyuduğumuz saattir.
es: —Su presencia le añadirá un nuevo encanto —respondió el anciano caballero, con una cortés inclinación—. Y ahora tengo que despedirme de su excelente tía. Me esperan en el Atheneum. Es la hora en que dormimos allí.
vi_translation: “I will complete it to make it perfect,” the old man replied, with a polite bow. “And now I must say goodbye to your wonderful aunt. I have to go to the literary club. This is the time when we sleep there.”
tr_translation: The elderly gentleman, with a polite bow, said, "You will complete Treadley." "Now I must bid farewell to your esteemed aunt. They are waiting for me at the Athenaeum Club. It is the time we sleep there now."
es_translation: —Your presence will add a new charm —replied the elderly gentleman, with a courteous bow—. And now I must take my leave of your excellent aunt. I am expected at the Atheneum. It is the hour when we sleep there.

en: “All of you, Mr. Erskine?”
vi: “Tất cả các ông hay sao, mít-tơ Erskine?”
tr: “Hepinizin mi, mr Erskine?
es: —¿Todos, señor Erskine?
vi_translation: “All of you, Mr. Erskine?”
tr_translation: “All of you, Mr. Erskine?”
es_translation: —All of them, Mr. Erskine?

en: “Forty of us, in forty arm-chairs. We are practising for an English Academy of Letters.”
vi: “Bốn chục người bọn tôi, trong bốn chục cái ghế bành. Chúng tôi tập luyện để làm một Viện Văn Anh quốc.”
tr: “Kırk koltukta, kırkımız birden. Bir İngiliz edebiyat akademisi kurmaya çalışıyoruz da.
es: —Cuarenta, en cuarenta sillones. Hacemos prácticas para una Academia Inglesa de las Letras.
vi_translation: “Forty of us, in forty armchairs. We are training to establish a British Academy of Literature.”
tr_translation: "Forty of us, all at forty seats. We are trying to establish an English literature academy."
es_translation: —Forty, in forty armchairs. We are doing exercises for an English Academy of Letters.

en: Lord Henry laughed and rose. “I am going to the park,” he cried.
vi: Huân tước Henry cười và đứng dậy. “Tôi đi công viên đây,” y kêu lên.
tr: Lord Henry gülerek ayağa kalktı. “Ben parka gidiyorum,” dedi.
es: Lord Henry rió, poniéndose en pie. —Me voy al parque —exclamó.
vi_translation: Lord Henry laughed and stood up. "I'm going to the park," he exclaimed.
tr_translation: Lord Henry stood up laughing. "I am going to the park," he said.
es_translation: Lord Henry laughed, standing up. —I'm going to the park —he exclaimed.

en: As he was passing out of the door, Dorian Gray touched him on the arm. “Let me come with you,” he murmured.
vi: Lúc y đi qua cửa, Dorian Gray chạm vào cánh tay y. “Cho tôi đi cùng anh,” cậu thì thầm.
tr: Kapıdan çıkarken Dorian Gray onun koluna dokundu. “İzin verin ben de sizinle geleyim,” diye mırıldandı.
es: Al atravesar la puerta, Dorian Gray le tocó en el brazo. —Permítame ir con usted —murmuró.
vi_translation: As he walked past the door, Dorian Gray touched his arm. "Let me go with you," he whispered.
tr_translation: As he was leaving through the door, Dorian Gray touched his arm. "Allow me to come with you," he murmured.
es_translation: As he passed through the door, Dorian Gray touched him on the arm. —Allow me to go with you —he murmured.

en: “But I thought you had promised Basil Hallward to go and see him,” answered Lord Henry.
vi: “Nhưng tôi tưởng cậu đã hứa với Basil Hallward là đến gặp anh ấy,” huân tước Henry trả lời.
tr: Lord Henry, “Ama ben sizin gidip Basil Hallward’ı görmeye söz verdiğinizi sanıyordum,” dedi.
es: —Creía que le había prometido a Basil Hallward que iría usted a verlo —respondió lord Henry.
vi_translation: “But I thought you promised Basil Hallward to go see him,” Lord Henry replied.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "But I thought you promised to go see Basil Hallward," he said.
es_translation: —I thought you had promised Basil Hallward that you would go see him —replied Lord Henry.

en: “I would sooner come with you; yes, I feel I must come with you. Do let me. And you will promise to talk to me all the time? No one talks so wonderfully as you do.”
vi: “Tôi thích đi cùng anh hơn; vâng, tôi thấy tôi phải đi cùng anh. Hãy cho phép tôi. Và anh sẽ hứa là nói chuyện với tôi mọi lúc chứ? Không ai nói hay như anh.”
tr: “Sizinle gelmeyi yeğlerim. Evet, sizinle olmak geliyor içimden. Kuzum, izin verin de geleyim. Hem de hiç durmadan benimle konuşacağınıza söz verin. Hiç kimse sizin kadar harikulade konuşamıyor.
es: —Prefiero ir con usted; sí, siento que debo ir con usted. Permítamelo. Y prometa hablarme todo el tiempo. Nadie lo hace tan bien.
vi_translation: “I prefer to go with you; yes, I feel I must go with you. Please allow me. And will you promise to talk to me all the time? No one speaks as well as you.”
tr_translation: “I would prefer to come with you. Yes, I feel like being with you. My dear, let me come with you. And promise me that you will talk to me without stopping. No one can talk as wonderfully as you.”
es_translation: —I prefer to go with you; yes, I feel that I must go with you. Allow me. And promise to talk to me all the time. Nobody does it as well as you do.

en: “Ah! I have talked quite enough for to-day,” said Lord Henry, smiling. “All I want now is to look at life. You may come and look at it with me, if you care to.”
vi: “À! Tôi đã nói khá đủ cho cả ngày hôm nay rồi,” huân tước Henry vừa nói vừa cười. “Tất cả những gì tôi muốn lúc này là nhìn đời. Cậu có thể đi và nhìn nó cùng tôi, nếu cậu thích.
tr: Lord Henry gülümseyerek, “Yok, bugün konuştuğum yeter de artar bile,” dedi. “Şimdi tek isteğim yaşamı seyretmek. Eğer isterseniz siz de gelip benimle birlikte seyredebilirsiniz. 1. Dönemin toplum rehberi (telefon rehberi gibi) kullanılan genel terim; sokak ağzıdır.
es: —¡Ah! Ya he hablado más que suficiente por hoy —dijo lord Henry, sonriendo—. Todo lo que quiero ahora es mirar la vida. Puede usted venir y mirarla conmigo, si lo tiene a bien.
vi_translation: "Ah! I've said quite enough for today already," Lord Henry said with a laugh. "All I want now is to observe life. You can come and observe it with me, if you like."
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled and said, "No, I've talked enough for today." "Now, my only desire is to watch life. If you want, you can come and watch it with me." 1. The general term used for the period's social guide (like a phone directory) is street slang.
es_translation: —Ah! I have already spoken more than enough for today —said Lord Henry, smiling—. All I want now is to watch life. You can come and watch it with me, if you please.

Multiple_ents: ['clovis eve', 'clodion', 'queen', 'les centnouvelles', 'valoi', 'valoisli margaret', 'dorian gray', 'margarita de valois', 'margaret', 'margaret of valois', 'lord henry', 'henry', 'vương hậu']
en: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray was reclining in a luxurious arm-chair, in the little library of Lord Henry’s house in Mayfair. It was, in its way, a very charming room, with its high panelled wainscoting of olive-stained oak, its cream-coloured frieze and ceiling of raised plasterwork, and its brickdust felt carpet strewn with silk, long-fringed Persian rugs. On a tiny satinwood table stood a statuette by Clodion, and beside it lay a copy of Les Cent Nouvelles, bound for Margaret of Valois by Clovis Eve and powdered with the gilt daisies that Queen had selected for her device. Some large blue china jars and parrot-tulips were ranged on the mantelshelf, and through the small leaded panes of the window streamed the apricot-coloured light of a summer day in London.
vi: Một chiều nọ, sau đó một tháng, Dorian Gray ngồi nghỉ trên cái ghế bành sang trọng, trong thư viện nhỏ ở nhà huân tước Henry tại Mayfair. Đó là một căn phòng rất duyên, theo kiểu riêng, với chân tường lát các pa- nen cao bằng gỗ sồi nhuộm màu ô-liu, các trụ ngạch màu kem và trần đắp vữa nổi, còn tấm nỉ màu bụi- gạch phủ sàn được trải lên bằng những tấm thảm lụa Ba Tư tua dài. Trên cái bàn gỗ sơn tiêu tí hon bày một bức tượng Clodion nhỏ, còn bên cạnh nó đặt một cuốn Les Cent Nouvelles, được Clovis Eve đóng cho Margaret nhà Valois, và được trang trí bằng những cây cúc mạ vàng mà chính Vương Hậu đã chọn cho huy hiệu của mình. Vài bình sứ xanh lam lớn với những bông tu-líp vẹt sắp hàng trên xích- đông trên lò sưởi, và qua những pa-nô bọc chì nhỏ xíu của cửa sổ ùa vào thứ ánh sáng màu mơ chín của một ngày hè London.
tr: Bir ay sonra bir öğleden sonra Dorian Gray, Lord Henry’nin Mayfair’deki evinin küçük kitaplığında, son derece rahat bir koltuğa gömülmüş, oturmaktaydı. Zeytin rengine boyanmış meşe ağacından, kabarık lambrilerle kaplı, krem renkli kartonpiyerleri ve tavan süslemeleri olan, uzun püsküllü ipek Acem seccadeleri serpiştirilmiş kiremit tozu rengindeki halıyla duvardan duvara döşenmiş bu odanın kendine özgü bir sevimliliği vardı. Sarı Hint ağacından ufacık bir sehpa üzerinde Clodion’un yapıtı olan küçük bir heykel, yanında da Les Cent Nouvelles’in (Yeni Yüz Öykü) bir kopyası duruyordu. Bu kitap Valoisli Margaret için Clovis Eve tarafından ciltlenmiş, üstüne Kraliçe’nin kendi seçtiği yaldızlı papatyalar serpiştirilmişti. Şöminenin üstüne mavi porselenden iri vazolara renk renk laleler yerleştirilmişti; pencerenin kurşunla birbirine birleştirilmiş ufak camlarından içeri Londra’da bir yaz gününün kayısı renkli ışığı süzülüyordu.
es: Cierta tarde, un mes después, Dorian Gray estaba recostado en un lujoso sillón, en la pequeña biblioteca de la casa de lord Henry en Mayfair. Se trataba, en su estilo, de una habitación muy agradable, con alto revestimiento de madera de roble color oliva, friso de color crema, techo de escayola y alfombra de fieltro color ladrillo, sobre la que se habían extendido otras alfombras persas de seda, más pequeñas, con largos flecos. En una diminuta mesa de madera de satín había una estatuilla obra de Clodion y, junto a ella, un ejemplar de Les CentNouvelles, encuadernado para Margarita de Valois por Clovis Eve y adornado con las margaritas que la reina había elegido como emblema. Algunos grandes jarrones de porcelana azul con tulipanes de colores abigarrados ocupaban la repisa de la chimenea y, a través de los emplomados rectángulos de cristal de la ventana, se derramaba la luz de color albaricoque de un día de verano en Londres.
vi_translation: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray sat resting on a luxurious armchair in the small library at Lord Henry's house in Mayfair. It was a very charming room, in its own way, with wainscoting of olive-stained oak panels, cream-colored pilasters, and a ceiling adorned with plaster reliefs, while the dusty-brick colored carpet was covered with long-fringed Persian silk rugs. On the tiny lacquered table stood a small Clodion statue, and next to it lay a copy of Les Cent Nouvelles, bound by Clovis Eve for Margaret of Valois, decorated with gilded daisies that the Queen herself had chosen for her emblem. Several large blue porcelain vases with parrot tulips lined the mantelpiece, and through the tiny leaded panes of the window streamed the ripe-apricot light of a London summer day.
tr_translation: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray was sitting, sunk into an extremely comfortable chair, in the small library of Lord Henry's house in Mayfair. This room, paneled with oak painted in olive color, with cream-colored cornices and ceiling decorations, and scattered with long-tasseled silk Persian prayer rugs on a brick-red carpet that covered the floor wall-to-wall, had a unique charm of its own. On a tiny table made of yellow Indian wood stood a small statue by Clodion, and next to it, a copy of Les Cent Nouvelles (The One Hundred New Stories). This book had been bound by Clovis Eve for Margaret of Valois, with gilded daisies chosen by the Queen herself scattered over it. On the mantelpiece, large vases of blue porcelain held tulips of various colors; the apricot-colored light of a summer day in London filtered through the small leaded panes of the window.
es_translation: One afternoon, a month later, Dorian Gray was reclining in a luxurious armchair in the small library of Lord Henry's house in Mayfair. It was, in its style, a very pleasant room, with high olive-colored oak paneling, a cream-colored frieze, a plaster ceiling, and a brick-colored felt carpet, over which smaller silk Persian rugs with long fringes had been spread. On a tiny satinwood table, there was a statuette by Clodion and, next to it, a copy of Les Cent Nouvelles, bound for Marguerite de Valois by Clovis Eve and adorned with the daisies that the queen had chosen as her emblem. Some large blue porcelain vases with multicolored tulips occupied the mantelpiece, and through the leaded glass rectangles of the window, the apricot-colored light of a summer day in London poured in.

en: Lord Henry had not yet come in. He was always late on principle, his principle being that punctuality is the thief of time. So the lad was looking rather sulky, as with listless fingers he turned over the pages of an elaborately illustrated edition of Manon Lescaut that he had found in one of the book-cases. The formal monotonous ticking of the Louis Quatorze clock annoyed him. Once or twice he thought of going away.
vi: Huân tước vẫn chưa về tới. Y luôn trễ hẹn theo nguyên tắc, nguyên tắc của y cho rằng sự đúng giờ là kẻ trộm thời gian. Thành thử chàng trai có vẻ khá sưng sỉa, trong lúc cậu dùng những ngón tay thờ ơ để lật qua các trang của một phiên bản Manon Lescaut được minh họa công phu mà cậu tìm thấy trên một trong các tủ sách. Tiếng tích tắc đều đều chiếu lệ của chiếc đồng hồ thời Louis XIV làm cậu bực bội. Một đôi lần cậu nghĩ đến việc bỏ đi.
tr: Lord Henry daha gelmemişti. Her yere kasıtlı olarak geç kalırdı, çünkü dakik olmayı zaman hırsızlığı saymak onun ilkesiydi. Bu yüzden de Dorian Gray, raflardan birinde bulduğu çok ayrıntılı resimlenmiş bir Manon Lescaut kopyasını isteksiz parmaklarıyla karıştırırken eni konu somurtuyordu. Louis Quatorze saatin o resmi, tekdüze tıkırtısı da sinirini bozuyordu. Bir iki kez, kalkıp gitmeyi bile aklından geçirdi.
es: Lord Henry no había vuelto aún. Siempre se retrasaba por principio, ya que, en su opinión, la puntualidad es el ladrón del tiempo. De manera que el muchacho parecía bastante enfurruñado mientras con una mano distraída pasaba las páginas de una edición de Manon Lescaut, suntuosamente ilustrada, que había encontrado en una de las estanterías. El solemne y monótono tictac del reloj Luis XIV le molestaba. Una o dos veces pensó en marcharse.
vi_translation: The lord has not yet returned. He is always late by principle, his principle being that punctuality is the thief of time. As a result, the young man seemed quite sulky, while he used his indifferent fingers to flip through the pages of an elaborately illustrated edition of Manon Lescaut that he found on one of the bookshelves. The monotonous ticking of the Louis XIV clock annoyed him. A couple of times he thought about leaving.
tr_translation: Lord Henry had not arrived yet. He was deliberately late everywhere, as it was his principle to consider punctuality a theft of time. Therefore, Dorian Gray was sulking quite a bit as he reluctantly flipped through a very intricately illustrated copy of Manon Lescaut he found on one of the shelves. The monotonous ticking of the Louis Quatorze clock was also getting on his nerves. A couple of times, he even considered getting up and leaving.
es_translation: Lord Henry had not returned yet. He was always late on principle, as, in his opinion, punctuality is the thief of time. So the boy seemed quite sulky as he distractedly flipped through the pages of a sumptuously illustrated edition of Manon Lescaut that he had found on one of the shelves. The solemn and monotonous ticking of the Louis XIV clock bothered him. Once or twice he thought about leaving.

en: At last he heard a step outside, and the door opened. “How late you are, Harry!” he murmured.
vi: Cuối cùng cậu nghe thấy tiếng bước chân bên ngoài, và cửa mở. “Sao anh muộn thế, Harry!” cậu lẩm bẩm.
tr: En sonunda dışarıda bir ayak sesi duydu; kapı açıldı. Dorian, “Amma geç kaldın, Harry!” diye söylendi.
es: Finalmente oyó pasos fuera y se abrió la puerta. —¡Qué tarde llegas, Harry! —murmuró.
vi_translation: Finally, he heard footsteps outside, and the door opened. "Why are you so late, Harry!" he muttered.
tr_translation: Finally, he heard footsteps outside; the door opened. Dorian complained, "But you're late, Harry!"
es_translation: Finally, he heard footsteps outside and the door opened. —How late you arrive, Harry! —he murmured.

en: “I am afraid it is not Harry, Mr. Gray,” answered a shrill voice.
vi: “Tôi e là không phải Harry đâu, mít-tơ Gray,” một giọng nói lanh lảnh đáp lại.
tr: “Yazık ki Harry değil, mr Gray,” diye tiz bir ses yanıt verdi.
es: —Me temo que no se trata de Harry, señor Gray —respondió una voz muy aguda.
vi_translation: “I'm afraid it's not Harry, Mr. Gray,” a shrill voice replied.
tr_translation: “Unfortunately, not Harry, Mr. Gray,” replied a shrill voice.
es_translation: —I'm afraid it is not about Harry, Mr. Gray —responded a very sharp voice.

en: He glanced quickly round and rose to his feet. “I beg your pardon. I thought—”
vi: Cậu nhìn nhanh chung quanh, và nhỏm dậy. “Tôi xin lỗi. Tôi cứ tưởng…”
tr: Delikanlı çarçabuk başını çevirerek ayağa kalktı. “Özür dilerim. Ben sizi...
es: Dorian se volvió rápidamente, poniéndose en pie. —Le ruego me disculpe. Creí...
vi_translation: He quickly looked around and sat up. "I'm sorry. I thought..."
tr_translation: The young man quickly turned his head and stood up. “I apologize. I didn't mean to...”
es_translation: Dorian quickly turned, standing up. —I beg your pardon. I thought...

en: “You thought it was my husband. It is only his wife. You must let me introduce myself. I know you quite well by your photographs. I think my husband has got seventeen of them.”
vi: “Anh tưởng là chồng tôi. Mà chỉ là vợ anh ấy. Anh nên để tôi tự giới thiệu mình. Tôi biết anh khá rõ nhờ các bức ảnh của anh. Tôi nghĩ chồng tôi có được mười bảy bức cả thảy.”
tr: “Kocam sandınız. Yalnızca onun karısıyım oysa! Kendimi tanıtmama izin verin. Ben sizi çok iyi tanıyorum, fotoğraflarınızdan. Sanırım kocamda on yedi tane resminiz var.
es: —Creyó usted que era mi marido. Soy sólo su mujer. Permítame que me presente. A usted lo conozco bien por sus fotografías. Me parece que mi marido tiene diecisiete.
vi_translation: “You thought I was my husband. But I am just his wife. You should let me introduce myself. I know you quite well from your photos. I think my husband has seventeen of them in total.”
tr_translation: "You thought I was my husband. But I'm only his wife! Allow me to introduce myself. I know you very well, from your photographs. I believe my husband has seventeen pictures of you."
es_translation: —You thought he was my husband. I am only his wife. Allow me to introduce myself. I know you well from your photographs. I think my husband has seventeen.

en: “Not seventeen, Lady Henry?”
vi: “Không phải mười bảy đâu, cô Henry?”
tr: “On yedi tane olamaz, Leydi Henry!
es: —No, lady Wotton, ¡no diecisiete!
vi_translation: “Isn't it seventeen, Miss Henry?”
tr_translation: “There cannot be seventeen, Lady Henry!”
es_translation: —No, Lady Wotton, not seventeen!

en: “Well, eighteen, then. And I saw you with him the other night at the opera.” She laughed nervously as she spoke, and watched him with her vague forget-me-not eyes. She was a curious woman, whose dresses always looked as if they had been designed in a rage and put on in a tempest. She was usually in love with somebody, and, as her passion was never returned, she had kept all her illusions. She tried to look picturesque, but only succeeded in being untidy. Her name was Victoria, and she had a perfect mania for going to church.
vi: “À, mười tám, thế đấy. Và tôi thấy anh với anh ấy đêm hôm nọ ở nhà hát ô-pê-ra.” Cô cười bồn chồn lúc cô nói, và nhìn cậu bằng đôi mắt lưu ly lơ đãng. Cô là một phụ nữ hiếu kỳ, quần áo cô lúc nào nhìn cũng như thể chúng được thiết kế trong cơn điên và mặc vào trong cơn bão. Cô thường hay phải lòng ai đó, và, do niềm yêu của cô chẳng khi nào đáp trả, nên cô giữ lại hết các ảo tưởng của mình. Cô cố gắng để có vẻ ngoài gây ấn tượng, nhưng chỉ thành công trong việc trở nên lôi thôi lếch thếch. Tên cô là Victoria, và cô nghiện đi nhà thờ đến phát cuồng.
tr: “On sekiz tane, öyleyse. Geçen gece operada onun yanında gördüm sizi.” Kadın konuşurken sinirli sinirli gülüyor, o mine mavisi, bulanık gözleriyle genç adamı süzüyordu. Giysileri her zaman bir öfke krizi sırasında tasarlanıp bir kasırga arasında giyilmiş gibi dururdu. Her zaman birilerine vurgundu ama aşkı hiçbir zaman karşılık görmediği için hayallerini asla yitirmemişti. Değişik ve çarpıcı görünmeye çalışır, yazık ki ancak dağınık görünmeyi başarırdı. Adı Victoria’ydı ve kiliseye gitmek konusunda önlenmez bir tutkusu vardı.
es: —Dieciocho, entonces. Y los vi juntos la otra noche en la ópera —rió con nerviosismo mientras hablaba, contemplándolo con sus ojos azules, un poco vagos, de nomeolvides. Era una mujer curiosa, cuyos vestidos siempre daban la impresión de haber sido diseñados en la cólera y utilizados en la tempestad. De ordinario estaba enamorada de alguien y, como su pasión nunca era correspondida, había conservado todas sus ilusiones. Trataba de conseguir una apariencia pintoresca, pero sólo conseguía dar sensación de desaseo. Se llamaba Victoria y tenía la manía perseverante de ir a la iglesia.
vi_translation: “Ah, eighteen, that's it. And I saw you with him the other night at the opera house.” She laughed nervously as she spoke, and looked at him with absent-minded glassy eyes. She was a curious woman, her clothes always looked as if they were designed in a frenzy and worn in a storm. She often fell in love with someone, and, since her affections were never reciprocated, she retained all her illusions. She tried to appear impressive, but only succeeded in becoming shabby and unkempt. Her name was Victoria, and she was insanely addicted to going to church.
tr_translation: “Eighteen, then.” “I saw you next to him at the opera last night.” The woman laughed nervously as she spoke, scrutinizing the young man with her azure, cloudy eyes. Her clothes always looked as if they had been designed during a fit of rage and worn amidst a whirlwind. She was always infatuated with someone, but since her love was never reciprocated, she never lost her dreams. She tried to appear different and striking, but unfortunately, she only managed to look disheveled. Her name was Victoria, and she had an irrepressible passion for going to church.
es_translation: —Eighteen, then. And I saw them together the other night at the opera —she laughed nervously as she spoke, gazing at him with her blue, somewhat vague, forget-me-not eyes. She was a curious woman, whose dresses always gave the impression of having been designed in anger and worn in a storm. Ordinarily, she was in love with someone, and since her passion was never reciprocated, she had preserved all her illusions. She tried to achieve a picturesque appearance, but only managed to give an impression of untidiness. Her name was Victoria and she had the persistent obsession of going to church.

en: “That was at Lohengrin, Lady Henry, I think?”
vi: “Tôi nghĩ đó là tại vở Lohengrin, phải không cô Henry?”
tr: “Lohengrin’de olsa gerek, değil mi, Leydi Henry?”
es: —Se trataba de Lohengrin, si no recuerdo mal.
vi_translation: “I think it was at the Lohengrin performance, wasn't it, Miss Henry?”
tr_translation: "It must be in Lohengrin, right, Lady Henry?"
es_translation: —It was Lohengrin, if I remember correctly.

en: “Yes; it was at dear Lohengrin. I like Wagner’s music better than anybody’s. It is so loud that one can talk the whole time without other people hearing what one says. That is a great advantage, don’t you think so, Mr. Gray?”
vi: “Đúng; đó là tại Lohengrin thân thương. Tôi thích nhạc Wagner hơn nhạc bất cứ ai. Nó to đến nỗi ta có thể nói chuyện suốt cả buổi mà không người nào khác nghe thấy những gì ta nói. Đó là một lợi thế lớn của nó: anh có nghĩ vậy không, mít-tơ Gray?”
tr: “Evet, canım Lohengrin’de. Wagner’in müziğini hepsinden çok severim ben. Öylesine gürültülü ki insan baştan sona konuşabiliyor, ne dediğini başkaları duymadan. Bu da büyük bir ayrıcalık, öyle değil mi sizce, mr Gray?
es: —Sí, era mi querido Lohengrin. La música de Wagner me gusta más que ninguna otra. Es tan ruidosa que se puede hablar todo el tiempo sin que otras personas oigan lo que se dice. Eso es una gran ventaja, ¿no le parece, señor Gray?
vi_translation: “Yes; it is because of dear Lohengrin. I prefer Wagner's music over anyone else's. It is so loud that we can talk the whole time without anyone else hearing what we say. That is a great advantage of it: don't you think so, Mr. Gray?”
tr_translation: “Yes, dear, at Lohengrin. I love Wagner's music the most. It's so loud that one can talk from start to finish without others hearing what they say. Isn't that a great privilege, don't you think, Mr. Gray?”
es_translation: —Yes, it was my dear Lohengrin. I like Wagner's music more than any other. It is so loud that you can talk all the time without other people hearing what is being said. That is a great advantage, don't you think, Mr. Gray?

en: The same nervous staccato laugh broke from her thin lips, and her fingers began to play with a long tortoise-shell paper-knife.
vi: Cũng một tiếng cười nhát gừng bồn chồn như thế bật ra khỏi đôi môi mỏng của cô, và các ngón tay cô bắt đầu nghịch một con dao rọc giấy dài làm bằng đồi mồi.
tr: İncecik dudaklarından gene o kesik, sinirli kahkaha döküldü, parmakları uzun, üç renkli bir mektup açacağıyla oynamaya başladı.
es: La misma risa, nerviosa y entrecortada, se escapó de los delgados labios, y sus dedos empezaron a jugar con un abrecartas de carey.
vi_translation: The same nervous, abrupt laugh escaped from her thin lips, and her fingers began to play with a long paper knife made of tortoiseshell.
tr_translation: From her thin lips once again spilled that abrupt, nervous laugh, and she began to play with a long, three-colored letter opener.
es_translation: The same laugh, nervous and intermittent, escaped from the thin lips, and their fingers began to play with a tortoiseshell letter opener.

en: Dorian smiled and shook his head: “I am afraid I don’t think so, Lady Henry. I never talk during music—at least, during good music. If one hears bad music, it is one’s duty to drown it in conversation.”
vi: Dorin cười và lắc đầu: “Tôi e là tôi không nghĩ vậy đâu, cô Henry. Tôi chẳng bao giờ nói chuyện lúc nghe nhạc, chí ít là lúc nhạc hay. Nếu ai đó nghe phải nhạc dở thì bổn phận của họ là át nó đi bằng cuộc chuyện trò.”
tr: Dorian gülümseyerek başını sarstı. “Üzgünüm ama ben böyle düşünmüyorum, Leydi Henry. Müzik dinlerken hiç konuşmam ben. Yani iyi müzik dinlerken. Kötü müzik duyduğumuz zaman da konuşarak bastırmak boynumuzun borcudur.
es: Dorian sonrió y negó con la cabeza. —Me temo que no estoy de acuerdo, lady Wotton. Nunca hablo cuando suena la música; al menos, si se trata de buena música. Si la música es mala, es nuestro deber ahogarla con la conversación.
vi_translation: Dorin smiled and shook his head: "I'm afraid I don't think so, Miss Henry." "I never talk while listening to music, at least not when the music is good." "If someone has to listen to bad music, it's their duty to drown it out with conversation."
tr_translation: Dorian shook his head with a smile. “I'm sorry, but I don't think so, Lady Henry. I never talk while listening to music. I mean, while listening to good music. When we hear bad music, it is our duty to drown it out by talking.”
es_translation: Dorian smiled and shook his head. —I'm afraid I don't agree, Lady Wotton. I never speak when music is playing; at least, if it's good music. If the music is bad, it is our duty to drown it out with conversation.

en: “Ah! that is one of Harry’s views, isn’t it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry’s views from his friends. It is the only way I get to know of them. But you must not think I don’t like good music. I adore it, but I am afraid of it. It makes me too romantic. I have simply worshipped pianists—two at a time, sometimes, Harry tells me. I don’t know what it is about them. Perhaps it is that they are foreigners. They all are, ain’t they? Even those that are born in England become foreigners after a time, don’t they? It is so clever of them, and such a compliment to art. Makes it quite cosmopolitan, doesn’t it? You have never been to any of my parties, have you, Mr. Gray? You must come. I can’t afford orchids, but I spare no expense in foreigners. They make one’s rooms look so picturesque. But here is Harry! Harry, I came in to look for you, to ask you something—I forget what it was—and I found Mr. Gray here. We have had such a pleasant chat about music. We have quite the same ideas. No; I think our ideas are quite different. But he has been most pleasant. I am so glad I’ve seen him.”
vi: “À ha! Đó là một trong các quan điểm của Harry, phải không, mít-tơ Gray? Tôi luôn nghe được quan điểm của Harry từ bạn bè anh ấy. Đó là cách duy nhất để tôi quen thuộc với họ. Nhưng anh không nên nghĩ là tôi không thích nhạc hay. Tôi mê nó, nhưng tôi sợ nó. Nó làm tôi quá mơ mộng. Chỉ là tôi rất tôn sùng các nghệ sỹ dương cầm — hai người cùng lúc, đôi khi thế ấy, Harry bảo tôi. Tôi không biết do cái gì ở họ. Không chừng do họ là người ngoại quốc. Họ đều thế cả, phỏng ạ? Thậm chí những ai được sinh ra ở Anh cũng sẽ thành người ngoại quốc sau một thời gian, phải không? Điều đó thật khôn ngoan về phía họ, và thật là một lời ca tụng với nghệ thuật. Biến nó thành ra của toàn thế giới, đúng không? Anh chưa bao giờ đến dự buổi tiệc nào của tôi, phải không, mít-tơ Gray? Anh nên đến. Tôi không đủ khả năng mua phong lan, song tôi không tiếc tiền chi cho người ngoại quốc. Họ làm cho phòng ta nhìn đẹp như tranh. Nhưng Harry đây rồi! — Harry, em đến tìm anh, để hỏi anh đôi điều — em quên là gì rồi — và em thấy mít-tơ Gray ở đây. Bọn em đã tán chuyện rất vui về âm nhạc. Bọn em có những ý tưởng hoàn toàn giống nhau. Không; em nghĩ là ý tưởng bọn em hoàn toàn khác nhau. Nhưng cậu ấy vô cùng dễ chịu. Em vui biết mấy vì em được gặp cậu ấy.”
tr: “Ha, Harry’nin görüşlerinden biri bu, değil mi, mr Gray? Harry’nin görüşlerini hep arkadaşlarından duyarım. Ancak bu yoldan gelir benim kulağıma. Sakın benim iyi müzikten hoşlanmadığımı sanmayın. Bayılırım ama korkarım da. Aşırı bir romantiklik verir bana. Piyanistlere resmen taptığım olmuştur, kimi zaman iki piyaniste birden, Harry’nin dediğine bakılırsa. Piyanistlerde ne var, bilemiyorum. Belki de yabancı oluşları. Hepsi de yabancı oluyorlar, öyle değil mi? İngiltere’de doğmuş olanlar bile bir süre sonra yabancı olup çıkıyorlar, değil mi? Çok becerikli oluyorlar, bu da hep sanatın becerisi. Sanat kozmopolit bir nitelik kazanıyor bu yoldan... mr Gray, hiç benim toplantılarıma gelmediniz değil mi? Gelmelisiniz. Orkide alacak param yok ama salonuma yabancıları toplamaya gelince hiçbir harcamadan kaçmam. Öyle pitoresk bir hava katıyorlar ki salonlara... İşte Harry de geldi!.. Harry, seni arıyordum, bir şey soracaktım ama ne soracağımı unuttum, işte burada da mr Gray’i buldum. Müzik konusunda öyle tatlı çene çaldık ki. Düşüncelerimiz birbirine adeta eş. Yok, düşüncelerimiz iyice zıt gibi geliyor. Ama kendisi çok sevimli. Görüştüğümüze öyle sevindim ki!
es: —¡Ah! Ésa es una de las ideas de Harry, ¿no es así, señor Gray? Siempre oigo las ideas de Harry de labios de sus amigos. Es así como me entero de que existen. Pero no debe usted pensar que no me gusta la buena música. La adoro, pero me da miedo. Me pone demasiado romántica. Sencillamente, venero a los pianistas; dos a la vez, en algunas ocasiones, me dice Harry. No sé qué es lo que tienen. Quizá el ser extranjeros. Todos lo son, ¿no es cierto? Incluso los que han nacido en Inglaterra se convierten en extranjeros con el tiempo, ¿no le parece? ¡Qué habilidad la suya! Y para el arte, ¡qué excelente cumplido! La hace sumamente cosmopolita, ¿verdad? ¿No ha estado usted nunca en alguna de mis fiestas, señor Gray? Tiene que venir. No puedo permitirme orquídeas, pero no reparo en gastos con extranjeros. ¡Hacen que la casa parezca tan pintoresca! ¡Pero aquí está Harry! Harry, vine buscándote para preguntarte algo, no recuerdo qué, y encontré al señor Gray. Hemos tenido una conversación muy agradable sobre música. Tenemos exactamente las mismas ideas. No; creo que nuestras ideas son completamente distintas. Pero ha sido la simpatía personificada. Y me alegro mucho de haberlo conocido.
vi_translation: “Aha! That is one of Harry's views, isn't it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry's views from his friends. That's the only way I am familiar with them. But you shouldn't think that I don't like good music. I love it, but I fear it. It makes me too dreamy. I just adore pianists — two at a time, sometimes, that's what Harry tells me. I don't know what it is about them. Perhaps it's because they are foreigners. They all are, aren't they? Even those born in England become foreigners after a while, don't they? That is very wise of them, and quite a compliment to the art. Making it belong to the whole world, right? You have never attended any of my parties, have you, Mr. Gray? You should come. I can't afford orchids, but I don't mind spending on foreigners. They make the room look as pretty as a picture. But here is Harry! — Harry, I came to find you, to ask you something — I forgot what it was — and I found Mr. Gray here. We have been having a delightful conversation about music. We have exactly the same ideas. No; I think our ideas are completely different. But he is extremely pleasant. I am so glad I met him.”
tr_translation: “Ha, this is one of Harry's views, isn't it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry's views from his friends. They only reach my ears this way. Don't think that I don't like good music. I love it but I also fear it. It gives me an excessive romanticism. There have been times when I literally worshipped pianists, sometimes even two pianists at once, according to Harry. I don't know what it is about pianists. Maybe it's their foreignness. They are all foreigners, aren't they? Even those born in England become foreigners after a while, don't they? They become very skillful, and this is always the skill of art. Art gains a cosmopolitan quality in this way... Mr. Gray, you have never come to my gatherings, have you? You should come. I don't have money to buy orchids, but when it comes to gathering foreigners in my salon, I spare no expense. They add such a picturesque atmosphere to the salons... Here comes Harry!.. Harry, I was looking for you, I wanted to ask you something but I forgot what it was, and here I found Mr. Gray. We had such a sweet chat about music. Our thoughts are almost identical. No, our thoughts seem quite opposite. But he is very charming. I'm so glad we met!”
es_translation: —Ah! That is one of Harry's ideas, isn't it, Mr. Gray? I always hear Harry's ideas from the lips of his friends. That's how I find out they exist. But you mustn't think I don't like good music. I adore it, but it scares me. It makes me too romantic. I simply worship pianists; two at a time, on some occasions, Harry tells me. I don't know what it is about them. Perhaps it's that they are foreigners. They all are, aren't they? Even those born in England become foreigners over time, don't you think? What skill they have! And for art, what an excellent compliment! It makes it extremely cosmopolitan, doesn't it? Have you never been to one of my parties, Mr. Gray? You must come. I can't afford orchids, but I spare no expense with foreigners. They make the house look so picturesque! But here is Harry! Harry, I came looking for you to ask you something, I don't remember what, and I found Mr. Gray. We've had a very pleasant conversation about music. We have exactly the same ideas. No; I think our ideas are completely different. But he has been the epitome of kindness. And I am very glad to have met him.

en: “I am charmed, my love, quite charmed,” said Lord Henry, elevating his dark, crescent-shaped eyebrows and looking at them both with an amused smile. “So sorry I am late, Dorian. I went to look after a piece of old brocade in Wardour Street and had to bargain for hours for it. Nowadays people know the price of everything and the value of nothing.”
vi: “Anh vui sướng lắm, tình yêu của anh, rất vui sướng,” huân tước Henry nói, nhướng cặp mày đen hình lưỡi liềm lên và nhìn cả hai người bọn họ với một nụ cười hân hoan. “Tôi rất xin lỗi vì bị muộn, Dorian. Tôi đi coi một bức gấm thêu kim tuyến cổ trên phố Wardour, và phải mặc cả vài tiếng cho nó. Ngày nay người ta biết giá mọi thứ còn giá trị thì không.”
tr: Lord Henry hilal biçimli koyu kaşlarını kaldırıp ikisini de keyifli bir gülümseyişle süzerek, “Ben de çok sevindim, sevgilim, çok sevindim,” dedi. “Dorian, öyle üzgünüm ki geciktim diye. Wardour Sokağı’na, eski bir brokara bakmaya gittim, saatlerce pazarlık etmek zorunda kaldım. Günümüzde insanlar her şeyin fiyatını biliyorlarsa da hiçbir şeyin değerini bilmiyorlar.
es: —Espléndido, amor mío, espléndido —dijo lord Henry, alzando la doble media luna oscura de las cejas y contemplando a ambos con una sonrisa divertida. —Siento llegar tarde, Dorian. Fui en busca de una pieza de brocado antiguo en Wardour Street, y he tenido que regatear durante horas para conseguirla. En los días que corren la gente sabe el precio de todo y el valor de nada.
vi_translation: “I am very delighted, my love, very delighted,” Lord Henry said, raising his crescent-shaped black eyebrows and looking at both of them with a joyful smile. “I am very sorry for being late, Dorian.
