I went to see an old gold-embroidered tapestry on Wardour Street, and had to bargain for a few hours for it. Nowadays people know the price of everything but the value of nothing.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry raised his crescent-shaped dark eyebrows and, gazing at both with a pleasant smile, said, "I am very glad too, my dear, very glad." "Dorian, I am so sorry for being late. I went to Wardour Street to look at an old brocade and had to bargain for hours. Nowadays people know the price of everything but the value of nothing."
es_translation: —Splendid, my love, splendid —said Lord Henry, raising the dark double crescent of his eyebrows and gazing at both with an amused smile. —I'm sorry for being late, Dorian. I went looking for a piece of antique brocade on Wardour Street, and I had to haggle for hours to get it. These days, people know the price of everything and the value of nothing.

en: “I am afraid I must be going,” exclaimed Lady Henry, breaking an awkward silence with her silly sudden laugh. “I have promised to drive with the duchess. Good-bye, Mr. Gray. Good-bye, Harry. You are dining out, I suppose? So am I. Perhaps I shall see you at Lady Thornbury’s.”
vi: “Em sợ là em phải đi,” cô Henry kêu lên, phá tan sự im lặng khó xử bằng tiếng cười ngờ nghệch bất chợt của mình. “Em đã hứa đi xe với nữ công tước rồi. Tạm biệt, mít-tơ Gray. Tạm biệt, Harry. Em nghĩ là anh sẽ ra ngoài ăn, phải không? Em cũng vậy. Có lẽ em sẽ gặp anh ở chỗ bà Thornbury.”
tr: Leydi Henry gergin bir sessizliği o kesik, anlamsız gülüşüyle bozarak, “Yazık ki benim gitmem gerek!” dedi. “Düşesle araba gezintisi yapmaya söz verdim. Hoşça kalın, mr Gray. Hoşça kal, Harry. Akşam yemeğini dışarıda yiyorsun herhalde, değil mi? Ben de öyle. Belki Leydi Thornburylerde karşılaşırız.
es: —Me temo que he de irme —exclamó lady Wotton, rompiendo un silencio embarazoso con su repentina risa sin sentido—. He prometido salir en coche con la duquesa. Hasta la vista, señor Gray. Hasta luego, Harry. Imagino que cenas fuera. Yo también. Quizá te vea en casa de lady Thornbury.
vi_translation: "I'm afraid I have to go," Miss Henry exclaimed, breaking the awkward silence with her sudden silly laughter. "I promised to ride with the duchess." "Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Goodbye, Harry. I think you're going out to eat, aren't you? So am I." "Maybe I'll see you at Mrs. Thornbury's."
tr_translation: Lady Henry broke the tense silence with her abrupt, meaningless laugh, saying, "It's a pity that I have to go!" "I promised the Duchess to go for a carriage ride. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. Goodbye, Harry. I suppose you are dining out tonight, aren't you? So am I. Perhaps we'll meet at Lady Thornbury's."
es_translation: —I'm afraid I must be going —exclaimed Lady Wotton, breaking an awkward silence with her sudden senseless laughter—. I have promised to go out in the carriage with the Duchess. Goodbye, Mr. Gray. See you later, Harry. I imagine you are dining out. So am I. Perhaps I'll see you at Lady Thornbury's.

en: “I dare say, my dear,” said Lord Henry, shutting the door behind her as, looking like a bird of paradise that had been out all night in the rain, she flitted out of the room, leaving a faint odour of frangipanni. Then he lit a cigarette and flung himself down on the sofa.
vi: “Chắc vậy, em yêu,” huân tước Henry nói, khép cửa lại sau lưng cô, trong lúc, nhìn như con chim thiên đường vừa ở cả đêm ngoài mưa, cô vụt ra khỏi phòng, để lại một mùi hương hoa sứ mơ hồ. Sau đó y châm điếu thuốc và buông mình xuống xô-pha.
tr: Lord Henry, “Olabilir, iki gözüm,” diyerek kapıyı onun ardından kapadı. Kadın, bütün gece yağmurda kalmış bir Zümrüdüanka kuşu görünümüyle ardında hafif bir frangipani kokusu bırakarak odadan dışarı süzülmüştü. Kocası bir sigara yakıp kendini bir kanepeye attı.
es: —Imagino que sí, querida mía -lord Henry cerró la puerta tras ella, cuando, con el aspecto de un ave del paraíso que se hubiera pasado toda la noche bajo la lluvia, salió revoloteando de la habitación, dejando un leve olor a tarta de almendras; luego encendió un cigarrillo y se dejó caer en el sofá.
vi_translation: “Probably, my dear,” Lord Henry said, closing the door behind her, as she, looking like a bird of paradise that had spent the whole night in the rain, darted out of the room, leaving behind a faint scent of frangipani. After that, he lit a cigarette and sank into the sofa.
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "Maybe, my dear," and closed the door behind her. The woman, with the appearance of a Phoenix that had been in the rain all night, glided out of the room, leaving behind a faint scent of frangipani. Her husband lit a cigarette and threw himself onto a couch.
es_translation: —I imagine so, my dear - Lord Henry closed the door behind her, when, looking like a bird of paradise that had spent the whole night in the rain, she fluttered out of the room, leaving a faint scent of almond cake; then he lit a cigarette and sank into the sofa.

en: “Never marry a woman with straw-coloured hair, Dorian,” he said after a few puffs.
vi: “Đừng bao giờ cưới một phụ nữ tóc màu rơm nhé, Dorian,” y nói, sau vài hơi ngắn.
tr: Sigarasından birkaç soluk çektikten sonra, “Dorian, sakın saçları çilek renginde olan bir kadınla evlenme!” dedi.
es: —Nunca te cases con una mujer con el pelo de color pajizo, Dorian —dijo después de lanzar unas cuantas bocanadas de humo.
vi_translation: "Never marry a woman with straw-colored hair, Dorian," he said, after a few short breaths.
tr_translation: After taking a few puffs from his cigarette, he said, "Dorian, never marry a woman with strawberry-colored hair!"
es_translation: —Never marry a woman with straw-colored hair, Dorian —he said after blowing a few puffs of smoke.

en: “Why, Harry?”
vi: “Sao lại thế, Harry?”
tr: “O nedenmiş, Harry?”
es: —¿Por qué, Harry?
vi_translation: "Why is that, Harry?"
tr_translation: “Why is that, Harry?”
es_translation: —Why, Harry?

en: “Because they are so sentimental.”
vi: “Vì họ đa cảm lắm.”
tr: “Çok duygusal oluyorlar da ondan.
es: —Porque son muy sentimentales.
vi_translation: "Because they are very sentimental."
tr_translation: “They become very emotional, that's why.”
es_translation: —Because they are very sentimental.

en: “But I like sentimental people.”
vi: “Nhưng tôi thích những người đa cảm.”
tr: “Ben duygusal insanları severim ama!
es: —Pero a mí me gusta la gente sentimental.
vi_translation: “But I like sentimental people.”
tr_translation: “But I love emotional people!”
es_translation: —But I like sentimental people.

en: “Never marry at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women, because they are curious: both are disappointed.”
vi: “Đừng cưới xin gì cả, Dorian. Đàn ông cưới vì họ mệt mỏi; đàn bà thì vì họ tò mò; cả hai đều thất vọng.
tr: “Hiç evlenme, Dorian. Erkek, yorgun düştüğü için evlenir, kadın merak duyduğu için. İkisi de hayal kırıklığına uğrarlar.
es: —No te cases, Dorian. Los hombres se casan porque están cansados; las mujeres, porque sienten curiosidad: unos y otras acaban decepcionados.
vi_translation: "Don't get married at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women because they are curious; both are disappointed."
tr_translation: “Never marry, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired, women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.”
es_translation: —Don't get married, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired; women, because they are curious: both end up disappointed.

en: “I don’t think I am likely to marry, Harry. I am too much in love. That is one of your aphorisms. I am putting it into practice, as I do everything that you say.”
vi: “Tôi không nghĩ là tôi lại có thể cưới, Henry. Tôi quá nặng lòng yêu. Ấy là một trong các châm ngôn của anh. Tôi đã thực hành nó, như tôi vẫn làm mọi điều mà anh nói.
tr: “Benim evlenme olasılığım yok gibi bir şey, Harry. Evlenmeyecek kertede âşığım çünkü. İşte senin aforizmalarından biri. Senin sözünden hiç çıkmadığım için bunu gerçek yaşantımda uygulamaya koyuyorum.
es: —Creo que no es probable que me case, Harry. Estoy demasiado enamorado. Ése es uno de tus aforismos. Lo estoy poniendo en práctica, y hago todo lo que recomiendas.
vi_translation: "I don't think I could ever get married, Henry. I am too heavily in love. That is one of your maxims. I have practiced it, as I always do with everything you say."
tr_translation: “I have almost no chance of getting married, Harry. Because I am in love to the extent that I won't get married. Here is one of your aphorisms. Since I never go against your words, I am putting this into practice in my real life.”
es_translation: —I don't think it's likely that I'll get married, Harry. I'm too much in love. That's one of your aphorisms. I'm putting it into practice, and I'm doing everything you recommend.

en: “Who are you in love with?” asked Lord Henry after a pause.
vi: “Cậu yêu ai?” huân tước Henry hỏi, sau một lúc im lặng.
tr: Lord Henry bir duralamadan sonra, “Kime âşıksın?” diye sordu.
es: —¿De quién te has enamorado? —preguntó lord Henry, después de una pausa.
vi_translation: "Who do you love?" Lord Henry asked, after a moment of silence.
tr_translation: After a pause, Lord Henry asked, "Who are you in love with?"
es_translation: —Who have you fallen in love with? —asked Lord Henry, after a pause.

en: “With an actress,” said Dorian Gray, blushing.
vi: “Một nữ diễn viên,” Dorian Gray nói, đỏ mặt.
tr: Dorian Gray pespembe kesilerek, “Bir tiyatro oyuncusuna,” diye yanıtladı.
es: —De una actriz —dijo Dorian Gray, ruborizándose.
vi_translation: “An actress,” Dorian Gray said, blushing.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray blushingly replied, "To an actress."
es_translation: —From an actress —said Dorian Gray, blushing.

en: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “That is a rather commonplace début.”
vi: Huân tước Henry nhún vai. “Đó là một début khá tầm thường.
tr: Lord Henry omuz silkti. “Çok beylik bir başlangıç bu.
es: Lord Henry se encogió de hombros. —Es un debut bastante corriente.
vi_translation: Lord Henry shrugged. "That was a rather mediocre début."
tr_translation: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. "This is a very conventional beginning."
es_translation: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. —It's a rather ordinary debut.

en: “You would not say so if you saw her, Harry.”
vi: “Chắc anh sẽ không nói thế nếu anh đã thấy nàng, Harry.”
tr: “Onu görsen böyle demezdin, Harry.
es: —No dirías eso si la vieras, Harry.
vi_translation: "You probably wouldn't say that if you had seen her, Harry."
tr_translation: "If you saw him, you wouldn't say that, Harry.""
es_translation: —You wouldn't say that if you saw her, Harry.

en: “Who is she?”
vi: “Cô ấy là ai?”
tr: “Kim bu kız?”
es: —¿Quién es?
vi_translation: "Who is she?"
tr_translation: "Who is this girl?"
es_translation: —Who is it?

en: “Her name is Sibyl Vane.”
vi: “Tên nàng là Sibyl Vane.”
tr: “Adı Sibyl Vane.
es: —Se llama Sibyl Vane.
vi_translation: "Her name is Sibyl Vane."
tr_translation: “Her name is Sibyl Vane.”
es_translation: —Her name is Sibyl Vane.

en: “Never heard of her.”
vi: “Chưa bao giờ nghe về cô ấy.”
tr: “Hiç duymadım.
es: —Nunca he oído hablar de ella.
vi_translation: “Never heard of her.”
tr_translation: “I have never heard of it.”
es_translation: —I've never heard of her.

en: “No one has. People will some day, however. She is a genius.”
vi: “Chưa ai từng. Nhưng ai cũng sẽ, một ngày nào đó. Nàng là thiên tài.”
tr: “Kimse duymamış. Ama günü gelince herkes duyacak. Kız büyük yetenek.
es: —Nadie ha oído. Pero todo el mundo oirá algún día. Es un genio.
vi_translation: “No one ever has. But everyone will, one day. She is a genius.”
tr_translation: “No one has heard. But when the day comes, everyone will hear. The girl is very talented.”
es_translation: —No one has heard. But everyone will hear someday. He is a genius.

en: “My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. Women represent the triumph of matter over mind, just as men represent the triumph of mind over morals.”
vi: “Cậu bé thân mến của tôi ơi, chẳng có gái nào là thiên tài cả. Gái là giới tính để làm cảnh. Họ chẳng bao giờ có gì để nói, nhưng họ lại nói chuyện rất duyên. Gái đại diện cho chiến thắng của vật chất trước tinh thần, đúng như trai đại diện cho chiến thắng của tinh thần trước luân lý.”
tr: “Sevgili yavrum, hiçbir kadın büyük yetenek olamaz. Kadınlar süs için yaratılmış bir cinstirler. Hiçbir zaman söyleyecek bir şeyleri yoktur, ama pek tatlı söylerler bunu. Kadınlar fiziğin zihin üstündeki yengisini simgelerler, nasıl ki erkekler de zihnin ahlak üstündeki yengisinin simgeleridir.
es: —Mi querido muchacho, ninguna mujer es un genio. Las mujeres son un sexo decorativo. Nunca tienen nada que decir, pero lo dicen encantadoramente. Representan el triunfo de la materia sobre la mente, de la misma manera que los hombres representan el triunfo de la mente sobre la moral.
vi_translation: “My dear boy, there are no girls who are geniuses. Girls are the gender meant for display. They never have anything to say, but they speak very charmingly. Girls represent the triumph of matter over spirit, just as boys represent the triumph of spirit over morality.”
tr_translation: “My dear child, no woman can be a great talent. Women are a gender created for adornment. They never have anything to say, but they say it very sweetly. Women symbolize the triumph of the physical over the mind, just as men symbolize the triumph of the mind over morality.”
es_translation: —My dear boy, no woman is a genius. Women are a decorative sex. They never have anything to say, but they say it charmingly. They represent the triumph of matter over mind, in the same way that men represent the triumph of mind over morals.

en: “Harry, how can you?”
vi: “Harry, sao anh có thể?”
tr: “Harry, nasıl böyle konuşabilirsin?
es: —¿Cómo puedes decir una cosa así, Harry?
vi_translation: "Harry, how could you?"
tr_translation: “Harry, how can you talk like that?”
es_translation: —How can you say such a thing, Harry?

en: “My dear Dorian, it is quite true. I am analysing women at present, so I ought to know. The subject is not so abstruse as I thought it was. I find that, ultimately, there are only two kinds of women, the plain and the coloured. The plain women are very useful. If you want to gain a reputation for respectability, you have merely to take them down to supper. The other women are very charming. They commit one mistake, however. They paint in order to try and look young. Our grandmothers painted in order to try and talk brilliantly. Rouge and esprit used to go together. That is all over now. As long as a woman can look ten years younger than her own daughter, she is perfectly satisfied. As for conversation, there are only five women in London worth talking to, and two of these can’t be admitted into decent society. However, tell me about your genius. How long have you known her?”
vi: “Dorian thân mến của tôi, nó đúng là vậy đấy. Tôi đang phân tích phụ nữ, cho nên tôi phải biết chứ. Đối tượng không đến nỗi quá khó hiểu như tôi tưởng. Tôi phát hiện ra rằng, rốt cuộc thì, chỉ có hai loại phụ nữ, đơn sắc và đa sắc. Phụ nữ đơn sắc rất hữu ích. Nếu anh muốn được cái tiếng đứng đắn thì anh chỉ cần dẫn họ xuống ăn tối. Những phụ nữ loại kia lại rất quyến rũ. Tuy nhiên họ phạm phải một lỗi. Họ trang điểm để cố gắng trông có vẻ trẻ trung. Bà nội chúng ta trang điểm để cố gắng nói chuyện giỏi giang. Phấn sáp và hóm hỉnh từng đi cùng nhau. Giờ thì chuyện ấy qua mất rồi. Chừng nào mà đàn bà còn có thể nhìn trẻ hơn chục tuổi so với con gái mình thì cô ta còn mãn nguyện. Để chuyện trò thì chỉ có năm phụ nữ ở London đáng để nói cùng, mà hai trong số họ không thể được nhận vào giới thượng lưu khuôn phép. Tuy nhiên, hãy kể cho tôi nghe về thiên tài của cậu. Cậu quen cô ấy lâu chưa?”
tr: “Sevgili Dorian, çok doğru da ondan. Şu günlerde hep kadınları incelemekteyim, bu yüzden bilmem gerekir. Konu sandığım kadar bulanık değil. Şimdi görüyorum ki iki tür kadın var, renkli ve renksiz. Renksiz kadınlar çok işe yarıyor. Namuslu, efendi diye adın çıksın istiyorsan onlardan birini yemeğe çıkart, yeter. Öteki kadınlarsa çok çekiciler. Ne var ki bir tek hataları var. Genç görünmek çabasıyla boyanırlar. Ninelerimiz parlak konuşmalar yapabilmek çabasıyla boyanırlardı. Allıkla mizah bir arada yürürdü o sıralar. Ama şimdi o dönem kapandı artık. Bir kadın kendi kızından on yaş küçük gösterebildiği sürece hayatından hoşnuttur. Konuşmaya gelince; Londra’da konuşmaya değer topu topu beş kadın var... ki bunlardan ikisini aile çevresine sokamazsın. Her neyse, sen bana büyük yetenekli kızını anlat. “Of, Harry, fikirlerin dehşet veriyor bana.
es: —Mi querido Dorian, no es más que la verdad. Estoy analizando a las mujeres en el momento actual, de manera que debo saberlo. No es un tema tan abstruso como yo pensaba. Descubro que, en último extremo, sólo hay dos clases de mujeres, las corrientes y las que se pintan. Las primeras son muy útiles. Si quieres conseguir una reputación de persona respetable, basta con invitarlas a cenar. Las otras mujeres son sumamente encantadoras. Pero cometen un error. Se pintan con el fin de parecer jóvenes. Nuestras abuelas se pintaban para tratar de hablar con brillantez. Rouge y esprit solían ir juntos. Ahora eso se ha acabado. Siempre que una mujer pueda parecer diez años más joven que sus hijas, estará perfectamente satisfecha. En cuanto a conversación, sólo hay cinco mujeres en Londres con las que merece la pena hablar, y a dos de ellas no las recibe la buena sociedad. De todos modos, háblame de tu genio. ¿Cuánto hace que la conoces?
vi_translation: “My dear Dorian, it is indeed so. I am analyzing women, so I should know. The subject is not as difficult to understand as I thought. I have discovered that, ultimately, there are only two kinds of women, monochromatic and polychromatic. Monochromatic women are very useful. If you want to appear respectable, you just need to take them out to dinner. The other type of women are very charming. However, they make one mistake. They wear makeup to try to look youthful. Our grandmothers wore makeup to try to speak well. Powder and wit used to go together. Now that is a thing of the past. As long as a woman can look ten years younger than her daughter, she is content. For conversation, there are only five women in London worth talking to, and two of them cannot be admitted into polite society. However, tell me about your genius. Have you known her long?”
tr_translation: “Dear Dorian, it is very true, that's why. These days I am always studying women, so I should know. The subject is not as obscure as I thought. Now I see that there are two types of women, colorful and colorless. Colorless women are very useful. If you want to be known as honorable and decent, just take one of them out to dinner, that's enough. The other women are very attractive. However, they have one single flaw. They paint themselves in an effort to look young. Our grandmothers used to paint themselves in an effort to make bright speeches. Blush and humor went hand in hand in those days. But now that era is over. A woman is happy as long as she can look ten years younger than her own daughter. When it comes to conversation; there are only five women in London worth talking to... and you can't introduce two of them into your family circle. Anyway, tell me about your highly talented girl.” “Oh, Harry, your ideas terrify me.”
es_translation: —My dear Dorian, it is nothing but the truth. I am analyzing women at the moment, so I must know. It is not as abstruse a subject as I thought. I find that, ultimately, there are only two kinds of women, the plain ones and those who paint themselves. The former are very useful. If you want to gain a reputation as a respectable person, just invite them to dinner. The other women are extremely charming. But they make a mistake. They paint themselves to look young. Our grandmothers painted themselves to try to speak brilliantly. Rouge and esprit used to go together. Now that is over. As long as a woman can look ten years younger than her daughters, she will be perfectly satisfied. As for conversation, there are only five women in London worth talking to, and two of them are not received by good society. Anyway, tell me about your genius. How long have you known her?

en: “Ah! Harry, your views terrify me.”
vi: “Ôi! Harry, quan điểm của anh làm tôi kinh sợ.
tr: “Of, Harry, fikirlerin dehşet veriyor bana.
es: —¡Harry, Harry! Tus opiniones me aterran.
vi_translation: “Oh! Harry, your perspective frightens me.”
tr_translation: “Oh, Harry, your ideas terrify me.”
es_translation: —Harry, Harry! Your opinions terrify me.

en: “Never mind that. How long have you known her?”
vi: “Đừng để ý đến nó. Cậu quen cô ấy lâu chưa?”
tr: “Aldırma şimdi. Kaç zamandır tanıyorsun onu?
es: —No te preocupes por eso. ¿Cuánto hace que la conoces?
vi_translation: "Don't pay attention to it." "Have you known her for long?"
tr_translation: "Never mind now. How long have you known him?"
es_translation: —Don't worry about that. How long have you known her?

en: “About three weeks.”
vi: “Độ ba tuần.”
tr: “Üç hafta kadar oluyor.
es: —Unas tres semanas.
vi_translation: "About three weeks."
tr_translation: “It has been about three weeks.”
es_translation: —About three weeks.

en: “And where did you come across her?”
vi: “Và cậu bắt gặp cô ấy ở đâu?”
tr: “Nerede tanıştınız?
es: —Y, ¿cómo te tropezaste con ella?
vi_translation: "And where did you run into her?"
tr_translation: "Where did you meet?"
es_translation: —And, how did you run into her?

en: “I will tell you, Harry, but you mustn’t be unsympathetic about it. After all, it never would have happened if I had not met you. You filled me with a wild desire to know everything about life. For days after I met you, something seemed to throb in my veins. As I lounged in the park, or strolled down Piccadilly, I used to look at every one who passed me and wonder, with a mad curiosity, what sort of lives they led. Some of them fascinated me. Others filled me with terror. There was an exquisite poison in the air. I had a passion for sensations.... Well, one evening about seven o’clock, I determined to go out in search of some adventure. I felt that this grey monstrous London of ours, with its myriads of people, its sordid sinners, and its splendid sins, as you once phrased it, must have something in store for me. I fancied a thousand things. The mere danger gave me a sense of delight. I remembered what you had said to me on that wonderful evening when we first dined together, about the search for beauty being the real secret of life. I don’t know what I expected, but I went out and wandered eastward, soon losing my way in a labyrinth of grimy streets and black grassless squares. About half-past eight I passed by an absurd little theatre, with great flaring gas-jets and gaudy play-bills. A hideous Jew, in the most amazing waistcoat I ever beheld in my life, was standing at the entrance, smoking a vile cigar. He had greasy ringlets, and an enormous diamond blazed in the centre of a soiled shirt. ‘Have a box, my Lord?’ he said, when he saw me, and he took off his hat with an air of gorgeous servility. There was something about him, Harry, that amused me. He was such a monster. You will laugh at me, I know, but I really went in and paid a whole guinea for the stage-box. To the present day I can’t make out why I did so; and yet if I hadn’t—my dear Harry, if I hadn’t—I should have missed the greatest romance of my life. I see you are laughing. It is horrid of you!”
vi: “Tôi sẽ kể cho anh, Harry; nhưng anh không nên ác cảm với chuyện đó. Rốt cuộc thì chuyện đó có lẽ chẳng bao giờ xảy ra nếu tôi không gặp anh. Anh khiến tôi thấy khát khao muốn biết hết mọi thứ về cuộc sống. Suốt nhiều ngày sau khi tôi gặp anh, có gì đó dường như đập rộn ràng trong huyết mạch tôi. Những lúc tôi đi lang thang vô định trong Công viên, hay tản bộ xuống Piccadilly, tôi thường nhìn vào mỗi người đi ngang qua tôi, và tự hỏi, với sự tò mò điên khùng, là họ đang sống kiểu gì. Vài kẻ trong số họ mê hoặc tôi. Những kẻ khác khiến tôi thấy sợ. Có một độc chất tinh tế nào đó trong không khí. Tôi mê các cảm xúc mạnh… Vậy là, một tối nọ, độ bảy giờ, tôi quyết định ra ngoài kiếm tìm cuộc phiêu lưu nào đó. Tôi cảm thấy rằng thành phố London xám xịt, khổng lồ của chúng ta, với ngàn vạn con người, với những tội nhân ti tiện, với những tội lỗi mê hồn của nó, như anh có lần diễn đạt, phải có gì đó dành sẵn cho tôi. Tôi tưởng tượng ra cả ngàn thứ. Chỉ sự hiểm nguy thôi cũng đã cho tôi cảm giác thích thú. Tôi nhớ lại những gì anh đã nói với tôi vào cái buổi chiều kỳ diệu ấy khi chúng ta lần đầu dùng bữa cùng nhau, rằng ‘sự kiếm tìm cái đẹp chính là bí mật thật sự của cuộc sống.’ Tôi không biết mình chờ đợi gì, song tôi ra ngoài và lang thang về phía Đông, sớm lạc đường trong một mê cung phố xá cáu bẩn và các quảng trường đen ngòm không có lấy một cọng cỏ. Độ tám giờ rưỡi, tôi đi ngang qua một nhà hát nhỏ lố bịch, với những chiếc đèn khí đốt vĩ đại sáng rực và các áp phích quảng cáo lòe loẹt. Một lão Do Thái gớm guốc, mặc chiếc gi-lê kinh ngạc nhất tôi từng thấy trong đời, đang đứng ngay lối vào, hút một điếu xì gà mạt hạng. Lão có những món tóc quăn nhờn dầu và một viên kim cương cực to tỏa sáng rực rỡ ở chính giữa chiếc sơ mi lem luốc. “Lấy một lô đi, huân tước ơi?” lão nói, khi thấy tôi, và bỏ mũ xuống với thái độ nô lệ hoa mỹ. Có gì đó ở lão, Harry, khiến tôi thích thú. Lão quả là quái vật. Anh sẽ cười tôi, tôi biết, nhưng tôi thật sự đã vào và trả nguyên một đồng ghi-nê cho lô sát sân khấu. Đến hôm nay tôi vẫn không thể hiểu tại sao tôi làm vậy; tuy nhiên nếu tôi không làm — Harry thân mến của tôi, nếu tôi không làm, chắc tôi đã lỡ mất chuyện tình lãng mạn vĩ đại nhất đời mình. Tôi thấy anh cười. Anh thật quá quắt.
tr: “Anlatacağım, Harry. Yalnız bu konuda olumsuz davranmayacaksın. Zaten seninle tanışmasaydım onunla da asla tanışmayacaktım. Sen bana yaşamakla ilgili her şeyi öğrenmek için çılgın bir istek aşıladın. Seni tanıdıktan sonra günlerce damarlarım yürek gibi attı sanki. Parkta oyalandığım, Piccadilly’den aşağı yürüdüğüm sıralarda yanımdan her geçene bakıyor, acaba ne biçim bir yaşam sürüyor, diye delicesine bir meraka kapılıyordum. Kimi sanki büyülüyordu beni, kimi dehşetle dolduruyordu. Havada nefis bir zehir vardı. Heyecana doyamıyordum... İşte neyse, bir akşam saat yedi sularında sokağa çıkıp serüven aramaya karar verdim. İçimden öyle geliyordu ki Londra, bir gün senin dediğin gibi; iğrenç günahkârları ve şahane günahlarıyla bizim bu gri, canavar Londra’mız, herhalde bana sunacak bir şeyler saklıyordu. Baş başa ilk yemek yediğimiz o harikulade gecede bana söylediklerin aklımdaydı: Hani güzellik peşinde koşmak yaşamın gerçek gizidir, demiştin. Ne umduğumu şimdi bilmiyorum. Sokağa çıktım, doğu yönünde ilerledim. Çok geçmeden birbirine geçmiş pis sokaklar, kararmış, çimensiz alanlar arasında yolumu şaşırdım. Saat sekiz buçuk sularında küçücük, gülünç bir tiyatronun önünden geçtim. Kapısının önünde kocaman alevli gaz meşaleleri, cicili bicili afişler vardı. Ömrümde gördüğüm en şaşırtıcı yeleği giymiş bir Yahudi girişte durmuş, pis bir yaprak sigarası tüttürmekteydi. Bukleli saçları yağlıydı, sırtındaki pis gömleğin önünde de bir elmas ışıldıyordu. Beni görünce, “Bir loca ister misiniz, sayın lordum?” diyerek şahane bir dalkavuklukla şapkasını çıkardı. Harry, bu adamda öyle bir şey vardı ki keyif verdi bana. Öyle biçimsizdi ki! Beni alaya alacaksın, biliyorum, ama tuttum girdim içeri, birinci mevki locaya tam bir gine ödedim. Neden yaptım, bugün bile çıkartamıyorum. Ne var ki girmeseydim... Sevgili Harry, girmeseydim hayatımın en büyük sevda serüvenini kaçırmış olacaktım. İşte, gülüyorsun. Çok kötüsün, Harry!
es: —Te lo voy a contar, Harry; pero tienes que ser comprensivo. Después de todo, no me habría pasado si no te hubiera conocido. Hiciste que sintiera un tremendo deseo de saberlo todo acerca de la vida. Durante varios días, después de conocerte, algo especial me latía en las venas. Mientras estaba en el parque o me paseaba por Picadilly, miraba a todas las personas con las que me cruzaba, preguntándome con tremenda curiosidad cómo era su vida. Algunas personas me fascinaban. Otras me llenaban de horror. Venenos exquisitos flotaban en el aire. Sentía pasión por las sensaciones... Bien, una tarde, hacia las siete, decidí salir en busca de alguna aventura. Sentía que este Londres nuestro, tan gris y tan monstruoso, con sus miríadas de personas, sus sórdidos pecadores y sus espléndidos pecados, tal como tú dijiste una vez, me reservaba algo. Me imaginé mil cosas. La simple sensación de peligro me llenaba de gozo. Recordé lo que me habías dicho en aquella maravillosa velada cuando cenamos juntos por vez primera, sobre el hecho de que la búsqueda de la belleza es el verdadero secreto de la vida. No sé qué esperaba, pero salí a la calle y me dirigí hacia el este, perdiéndome muy pronto en un laberinto de calles mugrientas y plazas oscuras y sin hierba. A eso de las ocho y media pasé por delante de un absurdo teatrillo, con luces brillantes y carteles chillones. En la entrada había un judío horroroso, con el chaleco más exótico que he visto en mi vida y fumando un cigarro apestoso. El cabello le caía en bucles grasientos y en mitad de una sucia camisa resplandecía un enorme diamante. «¿Un palco, milord?», dijo al verme, y se quitó el sombrero con un aire fascinantemente servil. Había algo en él que me divirtió, Harry. ¡Era tan monstruoso! Te vas a reír de mí, lo sé, pero entré y pagué nada menos que una guinea por un palco junto al escenario. Todavía hoy sigo sin saber por qué lo hice; pero si no lo hubiera hecho, mi querido Harry, me hubiera perdido la gran historia de amor de mi vida. Veo que te estás riendo. ¡Qué mal me parece!
vi_translation: “I will tell you, Harry; but you must not be prejudiced against it. After all, it probably would never have happened if I hadn't met you. You made me feel a longing to know everything about life. For many days after I met you, something seemed to be throbbing in my veins. When I wandered aimlessly in the Park, or strolled down Piccadilly, I often looked at each person who passed me by, and wondered, with a mad curiosity, what kind of life they were living. Some of them fascinated me. Others made me feel afraid. There was some subtle poison in the air. I was enamored with strong emotions... So, one evening, around seven o'clock, I decided to go out and seek some adventure. I felt that our gray, gigantic city of London, with its myriad people, with its petty criminals, with its enthralling sins, as you once put it, must have something in store for me. I imagined a thousand things. The mere danger gave me a sense of delight. I remembered what you had said to me on that marvelous afternoon when we first dined together, that ‘the search for beauty is the true secret of life.’ I didn't know what I was waiting for, but I went out and wandered eastward, soon getting lost in a maze of grimy streets and dark squares without a blade of grass. Around half-past eight, I passed a ridiculous little theater, with great blazing gas lamps and gaudy posters. A hideous Jew, wearing the most astonishing waistcoat I had ever seen in my life, was standing at the entrance, smoking a vile cigar. He had greasy ringlets and a huge diamond blazing in the center of his soiled shirt. “Take a box, my lord?” he said, when he saw me, and took off his hat with a florid servility. There was something about him, Harry, that amused me. He was indeed a monster. You will laugh at me, I know, but I actually went in and paid a whole guinea for a box near the stage. To this day I cannot understand why I did it; yet if I hadn't — My dear Harry, if I hadn't, I would have missed the greatest romance of my life. I see you laughing. You are outrageous.
tr_translation: “I will tell you, Harry. Just don't be negative about it. If I hadn't met you, I would never have met him either. You instilled in me a crazy desire to learn everything about living. After meeting you, it felt like my veins were beating like a heart for days. When I lingered in the park, walked down Piccadilly, I looked at everyone passing by, wondering what kind of life they were leading, with a mad curiosity. Some seemed to enchant me, some filled me with horror. There was a delicious poison in the air. I couldn't get enough of the excitement...Anyway, one evening around seven o'clock, I decided to go out and look for an adventure. I felt that London, as you once said; our gray, monstrous London with its disgusting sinners and magnificent sins, surely had something to offer me. I remembered what you told me on that wonderful night when we had our first dinner together: You said that the real secret of life is to pursue beauty. I don't know what I was expecting now. I went out and headed east. Soon I got lost among the intertwined filthy streets and dark, grassless areas. Around half-past eight, I passed in front of a tiny, ridiculous theater. There were huge flaming gas torches and flashy posters at its entrance. A Jew wearing the most astonishing waistcoat I had ever seen was standing at the entrance, puffing on a filthy leaf cigarette. His curly hair was greasy, and a diamond sparkled on the front of his dirty shirt. When he saw me, he took off his hat with magnificent obsequiousness and said, "Would you like a box, my lord?"Harry, there was something about this man that amused me. He was so grotesque! I know you'll mock me, but I went in, paid a full guinea for a first-class box. Why I did it, I still can't figure out today. But if I hadn't gone in...Dear Harry, if I hadn't gone in, I would have missed the greatest love adventure of my life. There, you're laughing. You're so wicked, Harry!”
es_translation: —I'm going to tell you, Harry; but you have to be understanding. After all, it wouldn't have happened if I hadn't met you. You made me feel a tremendous desire to know everything about life. For several days after meeting you, something special was pulsing through my veins. While I was in the park or walking through Piccadilly, I looked at all the people I passed, wondering with tremendous curiosity what their lives were like. Some people fascinated me. Others filled me with horror. Exquisite poisons floated in the air. I felt a passion for sensations... Well, one afternoon, around seven, I decided to go out in search of some adventure. I felt that this London of ours, so gray and so monstrous, with its myriads of people, its sordid sinners and its splendid sins, as you once said, had something in store for me. I imagined a thousand things. The mere sensation of danger filled me with joy. I remembered what you had told me that wonderful evening when we dined together for the first time, about the fact that the pursuit of beauty is the true secret of life. I don't know what I was expecting, but I went out into the street and headed east, soon losing myself in a labyrinth of grimy streets and dark, grassless squares. Around eight-thirty, I passed by a ridiculous little theater, with bright lights and garish posters. At the entrance, there was a horrid Jew, with the most exotic waistcoat I have ever seen in my life, smoking a foul-smelling cigar. His hair fell in greasy curls, and in the middle of a dirty shirt, a huge diamond sparkled. "A box, milord?" he said when he saw me, and he took off his hat with a fascinatingly servile air. There was something about him that amused me, Harry. He was so monstrous! You're going to laugh at me, I know, but I went in and paid no less than a guinea for a box next to the stage. To this day, I still don't know why I did it; but if I hadn't, my dear Harry, I would have missed the great love story of my life. I see you're laughing. How bad that seems to me!

en: “I am not laughing, Dorian; at least I am not laughing at you. But you should not say the greatest romance of your life. You should say the first romance of your life. You will always be loved, and you will always be in love with love. A grande passion is the privilege of people who have nothing to do. That is the one use of the idle classes of a country. Don’t be afraid. There are exquisite things in store for you. This is merely the beginning.”
vi: “Tôi không cười, Dorian; chí ít thì tôi không cười cậu. Nhưng cậu không nên nói chuyện tình lãng mạn vĩ đại nhất đời cậu. Cậu nên nói chuyện tình lãng mạn đầu tiên trong đời cậu. Cậu sẽ luôn được yêu, và cậu sẽ luôn đem lòng yêu người yêu. Một grande passion1 là đặc quyền đặc lợi của những người chẳng có việc gì để làm. Đó là một lợi ích của các giai cấp ăn không ngồi rồi của một quốc gia. 1 Niềm đam mê vĩ đại. Đừng sợ. Có những thứ tuyệt đẹp đã dành sẵn cho cậu. Chuyện này chỉ là khởi đầu.”
tr: “Gülmüyorum, Dorian, yani gülmem sana değil. Yalnız, hayatımın en büyük sevda serüveni dememelisin. Hayatımın ilk sevda serüveni, demelisin. Sen her zaman sevileceksin, her zaman sevdaya sevdalı olarak yaşayacaksın. Grande passion yaşamak, yapacak hiçbir şeyi olmayanların ayrıcalığıdır. Bir ülkede çalışmayıp boş gezen sınıflar bulunmasının yararı budur. Korkma. Nefis şeyler bekliyor seni. Bu daha başlangıcı.
es: —No me río, Dorian; al menos, no me río de ti. Pero no debes decir la gran historia de amor de tu vida. Debes decir la primera. Siempre te querrán, y tú siempre estarás enamorado del amor. Una grande passion es el privilegio de quienes no tienen nada que hacer. Ésa es la única utilidad de las clases ociosas de un país. No tengas miedo. Te están reservadas aventuras exquisitas. Esto no es más que el principio.
vi_translation: “I am not laughing, Dorian; at least I am not laughing at you. But you should not talk about the greatest romantic affair of your life. You should talk about the first romantic affair of your life. You will always be loved, and you will always fall in love with your lover. A grande passion1 is the privilege of those who have nothing to do. It is a benefit of the idle classes of a nation. 1 A great passion. Don't be afraid. There are wonderful things already prepared for you. This is just the beginning."
tr_translation: “I'm not laughing, Dorian, I mean, I'm not laughing at you. It's just that you shouldn't say it's the greatest love adventure of my life. You should say it's the first love adventure of my life. You will always be loved, you will always live as someone in love with love. To experience a grande passion is the privilege of those who have nothing to do. This is the benefit of having idle classes in a country. Don't be afraid. Wonderful things await you. This is just the beginning.”
es_translation: —I'm not laughing, Dorian; at least, I'm not laughing at you. But you shouldn't say it's the great love story of your life. You should say it's the first. They will always love you, and you will always be in love with love. A great passion is the privilege of those who have nothing to do. That is the only utility of the idle classes of a country. Don't be afraid. Exquisite adventures are reserved for you. This is just the beginning.

en: “Do you think my nature so shallow?” cried Dorian Gray angrily.
vi: “Anh có nghĩ là bản chất tôi rất nông cạn không?” Dorian Gray la lên, tức giận.
tr: Dorian Gray kızgınlıkla, “Sen benim yaradılışımı bu kadar sığ mı sanıyorsun?” diye bağırdı.
es: —¿Tan superficial me consideras? —exclamó Dorian Gray, muy dolido.
vi_translation: "Do you think that I am very shallow by nature?" Dorian Gray shouted, angry.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray shouted angrily, "Do you think my nature is that shallow?"
es_translation: —Do you consider me that superficial? —exclaimed Dorian Gray, very hurt.

en: “No; I think your nature so deep.”
vi: “Không; tôi nghĩ bản chất cậu rất sâu kín.
tr: “Yoo, ben senin yaradılışını işte bu kadar derin sanıyorum.
es: —No; te creo muy profundo.
vi_translation: “No; I think your nature is very secretive.”
tr_translation: "Yo, I think your creation is just this profound."
es_translation: —No; I think you're very profound.

en: “How do you mean?”
vi: “Ý anh sao?”
tr: “Nasıl yani?
es: —¿Qué quieres decir?
vi_translation: “What do you mean?”
tr_translation: “What do you mean?”
es_translation: —What do you mean?

en: “My dear boy, the people who love only once in their lives are really the shallow people. What they call their loyalty, and their fidelity, I call either the lethargy of custom or their lack of imagination. Faithfulness is to the emotional life what consistency is to the life of the intellect—simply a confession of failure. Faithfulness! I must analyse it some day. The passion for property is in it. There are many things that we would throw away if we were not afraid that others might pick them up. But I don’t want to interrupt you. Go on with your story.”
vi: “Cậu bé yêu quý của tôi ơi, người chỉ yêu một lần trong đời là người thật sự nông cạn. Cái mà họ gọi là chung thủy, trung thực, thì tôi gọi là trạng thái hôn mê của thói quen hoặc sự thiếu vắng trí tưởng tượng. Lòng chung thủy là cái thứ gì với cuộc sống cảm xúc thì tính kiên định cũng là vậy với cuộc sống trí tuệ thôi — đơn giản là một sự thú nhận thất bại. Chung thủy! Tôi sẽ phải phân tích nó một ngày nào đó. Sự ham muốn tư hữu nằm trong nó. Có nhiều thứ mà ta chắc đã quăng đi nếu ta không sợ là kẻ khác có thể nhặt chúng về. Nhưng tôi không muốn ngắt lời cậu. Tiếp tục câu chuyện của cậu đi.”
tr: “Sevgili yavrum, ömürlerinde tek bir kez sevenlerdir asıl sığ olanlar. Onların vefa, sadakat diye adlandırdıkları şeyi ben, ya alışkanlığın verdiği rahatlığa ya da hayal gücünün yokluğuna bağlarım. Zihinsel yaşam için tutarlılık neyse duygusal yaşam için de vefa odur: basit bir yenilgi itirafı. Vefa! Bunu incelemem gerekiyor günlerden bir gün. Sahiplik tutkusu da giriyor bu işin içine. Başkaları alır diye korkmasak çoktan atacağımız bir sürü şey var. Ama senin öykünü kesmek istemiyorum. Sürdür anlatmanı.
es: —Mi querido muchacho, las personas que sólo aman una vez en la vida son realmente las personas superficiales. A lo que ellos llaman su lealtad, y su fidelidad, yo lo llamo sopor de rutina o falta de imaginación. La fidelidad es a la vida de las emociones lo que la coherencia a la vida del intelecto: simplemente una confesión de fracaso. ¡Fidelidad! Tengo que analizarla algún día. La pasión de la propiedad está en ella. Hay muchas cosas de las que nos desprenderíamos si no tuviéramos miedo de que otros las recogieran. Pero no te quiero interrumpir. Sigue con tu historia.
vi_translation: “My dear boy, the person who loves only once in their life is truly shallow. What they call fidelity and honesty, I call a state of habitual coma or a lack of imagination. Loyalty in the realm of emotions is akin to consistency in the realm of intellect — simply an admission of failure. Loyalty! I will have to analyze it someday. The desire for possession lies within it. There are many things we would surely discard if we were not afraid that others might pick them up. But I don't want to interrupt you. Continue with your story.”
tr_translation: “My dear child, those who love only once in their lives are the truly shallow ones. What they call loyalty and fidelity, I attribute either to the comfort of habit or to the lack of imagination. For emotional life, loyalty is what consistency is for intellectual life: a simple admission of defeat. Loyalty! I need to examine this one day. The passion for possession also plays a part in this. There are many things we would have discarded long ago if we weren't afraid others would take them. But I don't want to interrupt your story. Continue with your narration.”
es_translation: —My dear boy, people who only love once in their lives are really the superficial ones. What they call their loyalty and fidelity, I call it the lethargy of routine or lack of imagination. Fidelity is to the life of emotions what coherence is to the life of the intellect: simply a confession of failure. Fidelity! I have to analyze it someday. The passion for ownership is in it. There are many things we would get rid of if we weren't afraid that others would pick them up. But I don't want to interrupt you. Continue with your story.

en: “Well, I found myself seated in a horrid little private box, with a vulgar drop-scene staring me in the face. I looked out from behind the curtain and surveyed the house. It was a tawdry affair, all Cupids and cornucopias, like a third-rate wedding-cake. The gallery and pit were fairly full, but the two rows of dingy stalls were quite empty, and there was hardly a person in what I suppose they called the dress-circle. Women went about with oranges and ginger-beer, and there was a terrible consumption of nuts going on.”
vi: “Thế rồi tôi thấy mình đang ngồi trong một lô riêng nhỏ dễ sợ, với một tấm màn hạ thô kệch lồ lộ trước mặt tôi. Tôi ngó ra ngoài từ sau rèm và quan sát rạp hát. Nó là một thứ lòe loẹt, toàn những thần ái tình và sừng dê kết hoa quả, như cái bánh cưới hạng ba. Hạng chuồng gà và hạng nhì khá đầy, nhưng hai hàng ghế xỉn màu trước sân khấu thì trống trơn, và hầu như chẳng có ai trong cái mà tôi nghĩ họ gọi là ban-công. Phụ nữ đi quanh với cam và bia gừng, và có một sự tiêu thụ quả hạch nhiều khủng khiếp đang diễn ra.”
tr: “Neyse, kendimi feci bir locacıkta buldum, burnumun dibinde de iyice bayağı bir sahne perdesi. Locanın perdesinin arkasından bakarak salonu gözden geçirdim. Zavallı bir yerdi. Cupidlerle, tuhaf şeylerle süslüydü. Pek dolu sayılmazdı. Ortada dolaşan kadınlar portakal, içecek satıyorlardı, herkes de findık fıstık yiyordu sanki.
es: —Bueno, me encontré sentado en un palquito espantoso, con un telón de lo más vulgar delante de los ojos. Desde mi discreto escondite me dediqué a examinar la sala. Era un lugar perfectamente chabacano, todo él cupidos y cornucopias, como una tarta nupcial de cuarta categoría. El paraíso y la platea estaban bastante llenos, pero las dos primeras filas de descoloridas butacas se hallaban completamente vacías y apenas había nadie en las mejores entradas del anfiteatro. Había mujeres vendiendo naranjas y refrescos y se consumían grandes cantidades de frutos secos.
vi_translation: "Then I found myself sitting in a dreadfully small private box, with a crude curtain hanging blatantly in front of me. I peeked out from behind the curtain and observed the theater. It was a gaudy affair, full of cupids and goat horns adorned with fruits, like a third-rate wedding cake. The gallery and the second tier were quite full, but the two rows of drab seats in front of the stage were completely empty, and there was hardly anyone in what I think they call the balcony. Women were walking around with oranges and ginger beer, and there was an enormous consumption of nuts taking place."
tr_translation: “Anyway, I found myself in a terribly small box, with a very mediocre stage curtain right in front of me. I looked around the hall from behind the curtain of the box. It was a miserable place. It was decorated with Cupids and strange things. It wasn't very full. Women were walking around selling oranges and drinks, and it seemed like everyone was eating nuts.”
es_translation: —Well, I found myself sitting in a dreadful little box, with the most vulgar curtain in front of my eyes. From my discreet hiding place, I set about examining the room. It was a perfectly tacky place, all cupids and cornucopias, like a fourth-rate wedding cake. The gallery and the stalls were quite full, but the first two rows of faded seats were completely empty and there were hardly any people in the best seats of the amphitheater. There were women selling oranges and refreshments, and large quantities of nuts were being consumed.

en: “It must have been just like the palmy days of the British drama.”
vi: “Hẳn là giống hệt như những ngày huy hoàng của Kịch nghệ Anh quốc.”
tr: “İngiliz Tiyatrosu’nun Altın Çağı, desene.
es: —Debía de ser como en los días gloriosos del drama británico.
vi_translation: “Surely it is just like the glorious days of English Theatre.”
tr_translation: “The Golden Age of English Theatre, you say.”
es_translation: —It must have been like in the glorious days of British drama.

en: “Just like, I should fancy, and very depressing. I began to wonder what on earth I should do when I caught sight of the play-bill. What do you think the play was, Harry?”
vi: “Giống hệt, tôi nghĩ vậy, và rất buồn chán. Khi tôi bắt đầu tự hỏi mình nên làm cái quái gì đây, thì tôi chợt thấy tấm áp phích quảng cáo. Anh nghĩ vở kịch tên gì, Harry?”
tr: “Herhalde; insanın içine çöküntü veriyordu. Acaba ne halt etsem diye kara kara düşünüyordum ki gözüm programa ilişti. Oynanan oyun neydi dersin, Harry?
es: —Precisamente, creo yo, y muy deprimente. Empezaba a preguntarme qué demonios estaba haciendo allí, cuando me fijé en el programa. ¿Qué obra crees que representaban, Harry?
vi_translation: “Exactly the same, I think so, and very boring. When I started to wonder what the heck I should do, I suddenly saw the advertisement poster. What do you think the play was called, Harry?”
tr_translation: “Probably; it was giving a sense of collapse inside a person. I was pondering deeply about what to do when my eyes caught the program. Guess what the play was, Harry?”
es_translation: —Precisely, I think, and very depressing. I was beginning to wonder what the hell I was doing there when I noticed the program. What play do you think they were performing, Harry?

en: “I should think ‘The Idiot Boy’, or ‘Dumb but Innocent’. Our fathers used to like that sort of piece, I believe. The longer I live, Dorian, the more keenly I feel that whatever was good enough for our fathers is not good enough for us. In art, as in politics, les grandpères ont toujours tort.”
vi: “Tôi nghĩ là ‘Chú bé Ngốc nghếch, hoặc Ngớ ngẩn nhưng Ngây thơ.’ Cha ông ta thường thích loại tác phẩm này, tôi tin thế. Càng sống lâu, Dorian, thì tôi càng cảm nhận sâu sắc hơn rằng bất cứ cái gì từng đủ hay cho cha ông ta thì đều không đủ hay cho ta. Trong nghệ thuật, cũng như trong chính trị, les grandpères ont toujours tort1." 1 Một chi tiết từ Hamlet.
tr: “Bana kalırsa, gerzek çocuk ya da salak ve masum derim. Babalarımız bu gibi oyunları severlerdi, sanıyorum. Dorian, her yaşadığım gün şunu biraz daha anlıyorum ki babalarımız hiçbir şeyi bizden iyi bilmezlermiş. Siyasette olduğu gibi sanatta da, les grand-peres ont toujours tort. Dedeler hep haksızdır.
es: —Imagino que El joven idiota o Mudo pero inocente. A nuestros padres les gustaba ese tipo de obras, según creo. Cuantos más años tengo, Dorian, más convencido estoy de que lo que era suficientemente bueno para nuestros padres no lo es para nosotros. En arte, como en política, les grand-péres ont toujours tort.
vi_translation: “I think it is ‘The Foolish Boy, or Silly but Innocent.’ Our ancestors often liked this type of work, I believe so. The longer I live, Dorian, the more deeply I feel that whatever was good enough for our ancestors is not good enough for us. In art, as in politics, les grandpères ont toujours tort1." 1 A detail from Hamlet.
tr_translation: “If you ask me, I would say foolish child or silly and innocent. Our fathers used to love such games, I believe. Dorian, with each passing day, I understand a bit more that our fathers didn't know anything better than us. In politics as in art, les grand-peres ont toujours tort. Grandfathers are always wrong.”
es_translation: —I imagine The Young Idiot or Dumb but Innocent. Our parents liked that kind of plays, I believe. The older I get, Dorian, the more convinced I am that what was good enough for our parents is not good enough for us. In art, as in politics, les grand-péres ont toujours tort.

en: “This play was good enough for us, Harry. It was Romeo and Juliet. I must admit that I was rather annoyed at the idea of seeing Shakespeare done in such a wretched hole of a place. Still, I felt interested, in a sort of way. At any rate, I determined to wait for the first act. There was a dreadful orchestra, presided over by a young Hebrew who sat at a cracked piano, that nearly drove me away, but at last the drop-scene was drawn up and the play began. Romeo was a stout elderly gentleman, with corked eyebrows, a husky tragedy voice, and a figure like a beer-barrel. Mercutio was almost as bad. He was played by the low-comedian, who had introduced gags of his own and was on most friendly terms with the pit. They were both as grotesque as the scenery, and that looked as if it had come out of a country-booth. But Juliet! Harry, imagine a girl, hardly seventeen years of age, with a little, flowerlike face, a small Greek head with plaited coils of dark-brown hair, eyes that were violet wells of passion, lips that were like the petals of a rose. She was the loveliest thing I had ever seen in my life. You said to me once that pathos left you unmoved, but that beauty, mere beauty, could fill your eyes with tears. I tell you, Harry, I could hardly see this girl for the mist of tears that came across me. And her voice—I never heard such a voice. It was very low at first, with deep mellow notes that seemed to fall singly upon one’s ear. Then it became a little louder, and sounded like a flute or a distant hautboy. In the garden-scene it had all the tremulous ecstasy that one hears just before dawn when nightingales are singing. There were moments, later on, when it had the wild passion of violins. You know how a voice can stir one. Your voice and the voice of Sibyl Vane are two things that I shall never forget. When I close my eyes, I hear them, and each of them says something different. I don’t know which to follow. Why should I not love her? Harry, I do love her. She is everything to me in life. Night after night I go to see her play. One evening she is Rosalind, and the next evening she is Imogen. I have seen her die in the gloom of an Italian tomb, sucking the poison from her lover’s lips. I have watched her wandering through the forest of Arden, disguised as a pretty boy in hose and doublet and dainty cap. She has been mad, and has come into the presence of a guilty king, and given him rue to wear and bitter herbs to taste of. She has been innocent, and the black hands of jealousy have crushed her reedlike throat. I have seen her in every age and in every costume. Ordinary women never appeal to one’s imagination. They are limited to their century. No glamour ever transfigures them. One knows their minds as easily as one knows their bonnets. One can always find them. There is no mystery in any of them. They ride in the park in the morning and chatter at tea-parties in the afternoon. They have their stereotyped smile and their fashionable manner. They are quite obvious. But an actress! How different an actress is! Harry! why didn’t you tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?”
vi: “Vở kịch này đủ hay cho ta, Harry. Nó là Romeo và Juliet. Tôi phải thú nhận là tôi đã khá khó chịu với cái ý tưởng xem diễn Shakespeare trong cái hốc tồi tàn thảm hại thế này. Tuy nhiên, tôi vẫn thấy thú vị, phần nào. Dẫu sao đi nữa, tôi quyết chờ hồi đầu. Có một ban nhạc chán ngấy, được giữ bè bởi một người Hê-brơ trẻ ngồi bên cây dương cầm vỡ, điều ấy suýt nữa thì đã xua tôi đi, nhưng cuối cùng thì màn được kéo lên, và vở diễn bắt đầu. Romeo là một ông già mập mạp, với cặp lông mày bôi đen bằng than bần, giọng khàn khàn bi kịch, và thân hình như thùng bia. Mercutio cũng tệ gần như thế. Hắn được đóng bởi một diễn viên hài nhảm, tự chêm thêm những lời bỡn cợt của chính mình và có quan hệ hết sức thân thiện với đám khán giả hạng nhì. Cả hai người bọn họ cũng lố bịch chẳng khác gì cảnh phông, còn nó nhìn như thể từng xuất hiện ở một rạp chợ quê. Nhưng Juliet thì! Harry, hãy hình dung một cô gái, tuổi vừa mười bảy, mặt nhỏ tươi như hoa, đầu bé kiểu Hy Lạp, với những cuộn tóc tết nâu sẫm, mắt là giếng tím đam mê, môi tựa cánh hoa hồng. Nàng là tạo vật đáng yêu nhất tôi từng thấy trong đời. Anh có lần bảo tôi rằng sự thống thiết cũng chẳng làm anh mủi lòng, nhưng sắc đẹp ấy, chỉ sắc đẹp ấy thôi, có thể dâng lệ lên đầy mắt anh. Tôi nói anh nghe, Harry, tôi khó khăn lắm mới có thể nhìn thấy cô gái này vì màn lệ ấy giăng ngang qua tôi. Và giọng nàng — tôi chưa bao giờ được nghe một giọng nói như vậy. Thoạt đầu nó rất khẽ khàng, với những nốt ngọt sâu, dường như rót từng cái một vào tai ta. Sau đó nó trở nên hơi to hơn, và vang lên như ống sáo hay cây ô-boa xa xôi. Trong cảnh vườn, nó ngân lên mọi nỗi đê mê rung rinh mà người ta nghe thấy ngay trước bình minh khi họa mi hót. Có những khoảnh khắc, muộn hơn, khi nó mang niềm đam mê phóng túng của vĩ cầm. Anh biết một giọng nói có thể làm xao lòng người thế nào. Giọng anh và giọng Sibyl Vane là hai cái mà tôi sẽ chẳng bao giờ quên nổi. Khi tôi nhắm mắt, tôi nghe thấy chúng, và mỗi cái nói lên điều gì đó khác biệt. Tôi không biết nên theo cái nào. Làm sao tôi không yêu nàng được? Harry, tôi đã yêu nàng. Với tôi, nàng quan trọng nhất trên đời. Đêm lại đêm, tôi đến xem nàng diễn. Đêm này nàng là Rosalind, đêm sau nàng là Imogen. Tôi từng thấy nàng chết trong bóng tối mờ mịt của một hầm mộ Ý, sau khi mút chất độc từ môi người tình của mình. Tôi từng ngắm nàng lang thang qua rừng Arden, cải trang như cậu bé dễ thương đi bít tất dài và mặc áo chẽn, đội mũ lưỡi trai xinh xắn. Nàng đã bị điên, đã đến diện kiến một ông vua tội lỗi, đưa cây hương thảo cho ông ta dùng1, và cỏ đắng cho ông ta nếm. Nàng đã ngây thơ, và bàn tay đen ghen tuông đã xiết lấy cái cổ họng như cây sậy của nàng. Tôi từng thấy nàng ở mọi thời đại và mặc mọi trang phục. Các phụ nữ bình thường chẳng bao giờ lôi cuốn trí tưởng tượng của ta. Họ bị giới hạn trong thế kỷ của mình. Không sức quyến rũ huyền bí nào từng tôn được họ lên. Ta hiểu trí tuệ họ cũng dễ như ta hiểu cái mũ bô-nê của họ. Ta luôn tìm được họ. Chẳng có gì bí ẩn ở bất cứ ai trong số họ. Họ đi ngựa trong công viên vào buổi sáng, nói huyên thiên trong tiệc trà vào buổi chiều. Họ có nụ cười rập khuôn và phong cách sang trọng. Họ vô cùng dễ thấy. Nhưng một nữ diễn viên! Sao mà một nữ diễn viên lại khác biệt đến thế! Harry! Sao anh không bảo tôi rằng tạo vật duy nhất đáng để yêu là một nữ diễn viên?”
tr: “Bu oyun bizim beğenimize de uygundu, Harry. Romeo ile Juliet’ti. İtiraf edeyim ki bu izbe oyukta Shakespeare seyretmek düşüncesi önce sinirimi bozdu. Gene de tuhaf bir ilgi duymuştum. Hiç değilse birinci perdeyi izlemeye kararlıydım. Feci bir orkestra vardı; en başta da çatlak bir piyano çalan genç bir Musevi. Müzik beni neredeyse kaçırtıyordu ama en sonunda sahnenin perdesi açıldı, oyun başladı. Romeo kaşları mantarla boyanmış, trajedilere uygun boğuk sesli, yapısı bira fıçılarına benzeyen tıknaz, yaşlı bir beydi. Mercutio da hemen hemen onun kadar kötü. Bu rolü çok adi bir komik oynuyordu. Araya kendi icadı replikler serpiştirmişti, orkestradakilerle de içli dışlıydı. Aktörlerin ikisi de sahnenin dekoru kadar biçimsizdiler, dekor bir köy panayırından alınmışa benziyordu... Gelgelelim Juliet!.. Harry, bir kız düşün ki on yedisinde var yok, minicik, çiçek gibi bir yüz, eski Yunan resimleri gibi küçük bir baş, halka halka koyu kestane saç örgüleri, gözler sanki mosmor ihtiras kuyuları, gül yaprağı gibi dudaklar. Ömrümde gördüğüm en güzel şeydi bu kız. Bir keresinde sen bana dokunaklı şeylerin seni etkilemediğini söylemiştin, gene de o güzellik, salt o güzellik senin bile gözlerini yaşartabilirdi. İnan bana, Harry, gözüme dolan yaşlar yüzünden kızı doğru dürüst göremez olmuştum. Ya sesi! Ömrümde böyle ses duymamıştım ki ben! İlkin çok yavaş çıkıyordu, insanın kulağına sanki tane tane dökülen, derin, yumuşacık notalar. Sonra biraz daha yükselince bir flüte benzedi ya da uzaktan duyulan bir obua sesine. Bahçe sahnesinde bu ses, şafaktan önce bülbüller ötünce duyulan o titreşimli coşkuyu yansıtıyordu. Sonradan zaman zaman bir kemanın başıboş ihtirasıyla çınladığı oldu. Sesler insanı nasıl etkiler sırasında, bilirsin. Ömrümde unutamayacağım iki şey varsa senin sesinle Sibyl Vane’in sesidir. Gözümü yumunca duyabiliyordum bu sesleri; ikisi de ayrı ayrı şeyler söylüyorlar. Hangisini dinleyeceğimi bilemiyorum. Neden sevmeyecekmişim onu Harry, seviyorum onu. Benim için hayatta her şey o. Her Tanrı’nın gecesi onu seyretmeye, tiyatroya gidiyorum. Bir gece Rosalind oluyor, ertesi gece İmojen. Onun bir İtalyan mezarlığının loşluğunda, âşığının dudağındaki zehri emerek öldüğünü gördüm. Uzun çorap, dizlik pantolon, zarif kep giyip güzel bir delikanlı kılığına girerek Arden Ormanı’nda gezindiğini gördüm. Bir keresinde delirdi, suçlu bir kralın karşısına çıktı, ona tatsın diye acı otlar verdi. Bir keresinde masumdu, gene de kıskançlığın kara elleri onun o kuğu boynunu sıkıp ezdi. Her türlü kılıkta, her çağda gördüm onu. Olağan insanlar hayal gücümüzü etkileyemezler. Çağlarıyla sınırlıdırlar. Onları kalıplarından çekip çıkaracak hiçbir büyü yoktur. Şapkaları gibi kafalarının içini de ezbere biliriz. Kolayca bulabiliriz onları. Hiçbirinde gizem yoktur. Sabahları parkta ata binerler, öğleden sonra çay partilerinde gevezelik ederler. Gülüşleri klişeleşmiş, davranışları modaya uydurulmuştur. Kolayca okunabilirler. Ama bir tiyatro oyuncusu! Tiyatro oyuncusu olan kadın nasıl da bambaşkadır! Harry, sevilmeye değer tek şeyin bir aktris olduğunu neden söylemedin bana?
es: —La obra era suficientemente buena para nosotros, Harry. Se trataba de Romeo y Julieta. He de reconocer que no me hizo mucha gracia la idea de ver representar a Shakespeare en un antro como aquél. Pero sentí interés, de todos modos. Decidí presenciar al menos el primer acto. Había una orquesta detestable, presidida por un hebreo joven sentado ante un piano desafinado que casi me echó del teatro; pero finalmente se alzó el telón y comenzó la obra. Romeo era un caballero corpulento y con muchos años a sus espaldas, cejas pintadas con negro de corcho, ronca voz de tragedia y silueta cíe barril de cerveza. Mercutio era casi igual de siniestro. Lo interpretaba un cómico de la legua que había añadido al texto chistes de su cosecha y mantenía relaciones sumamente amistosas con la platea. Los dos eran tan grotescos como el decorado, que parecía salido de una barraca de feria. Pero, ¡Julieta! Imagínate una muchachita de apenas diecisiete años, con un rostro como de flor, una cabecita griega con cabellos de color castaño oscuro recogidos en trenzas, ojos que eran pozos violeta de pasión, labios como pétalos de rosa. ¡La criatura más encantadora que había visto nunca! Una vez me dijiste que el patetismo no te conmovía en absoluto, pero que la belleza, la simple belleza, podía llenarte los ojos de lágrimas. Te lo aseguro, Harry, apenas veía a esa muchacha porque siempre tenía los ojos nublados por las lágrimas. ¡Y su voz! No he oído nunca una voz semejante. Sólo un hilo al principio, con notas bajas y melodiosas, que parecían caer una a una en el oído. Luego creció en volumen, y sonaba como una flauta o un lejano oboe. En la escena del jardín tuvo todo el júbilo estremecido de los ruiseñores cuando cantan poco antes del amanecer. Hubo momentos, más adelante, en los que alcanzó la desenfrenada pasión de los violines. Sabes perfectamente cuánto puede afectarnos una voz. Tu voz y la de Sibyl Vane son dos cosas que nunca olvidaré. Cuando cierro los ojos las oigo, y cada una dice algo diferente. No sé a cuál seguir. ¿Por qué tendría que no amarla? La quiero, Harry. Para mí lo es todo. Voy a verla actuar día tras día. Una noche es Rosalinda y la siguiente Imogen. La he visto morir en la penumbra de un sepulcro italiano, recogiendo el veneno de labios de su amante. La he contemplado atravesando el bosque de las Ardenas, disfrazada de muchacho, con calzas, jubón y un gorro delicioso. Ha sido la loca que se presenta ante un rey culpable, dándole ruda para llevar y hierbas amargas que gustar. Ha sido inocente, y las negras manos de los celos han aplastado su cuello de junco. La he visto en todas las épocas y con todos los trajes. Las mujeres ordinarias no hacen volar nuestra imaginación. Están ancladas en su siglo. La fascinación nunca las transfigura. Se sabe lo que tienen en la cabeza con la misma facilidad que si se tratara del sombrero. Siempre se las encuentra. No hay misterio en ninguna de ellas. Van a pasear al parque por la mañana y charlan por la tarde en reuniones donde toman el té. Tienen una sonrisa estereotipada y los modales del momento. Son transparentes. ¡Pero una actriz! ¡Qué diferente es una actriz, Harry! ¿Por qué no me dijiste que la única cosa merecedora de amor es una actriz?
vi_translation: “This play is good enough for me, Harry. It is Romeo and Juliet. I must confess that I was quite annoyed with the idea of watching Shakespeare performed in such a shabby, miserable nook. However, I still found it somewhat interesting. Anyway, I decided to wait for the first act. There was a dreadful band, kept in tune by a young Hebrew man sitting by a broken piano, which almost drove me away, but finally the curtain rose, and the play began. Romeo was a fat old man, with eyebrows blackened with burnt cork, a hoarse tragic voice, and a body like a beer barrel. Mercutio was almost as bad. He was played by a low comedian, who inserted his own jokes and had a very friendly relationship with the second-class audience. Both of them were as ridiculous as the scenery, which looked as if it had appeared in a country fair theater. But Juliet! Harry, imagine a girl, just seventeen years old, with a small face as fresh as a flower, a Greek-style head, with dark brown braided hair, eyes like wells of passionate violet, lips like rose petals. She is the most lovely creature I have ever seen in my life. You once told me that pathos does not move you, but that beauty, only beauty, could bring tears to your eyes. I tell you, Harry, I could hardly see this girl because of the veil of tears that came across me. And her voice — I have never heard a voice like that. At first it was very soft, with deep sweet notes, as if each one was being poured into your ear. Then it became a little louder, and sounded like a distant flute or oboe. In the garden scene, it echoed with all the trembling ecstasy one hears just before dawn when the nightingale sings. There were moments, later, when it had the wild passion of a violin. You know how a voice can stir one. Your voice and Sibyl Vane's voice are the two that I will never forget. When I close my eyes, I hear them, and each says something different. I do not know which to follow. How could I not love her? Harry, I have loved her. To me, she is the most important thing in the world. Night after night, I go to see her perform. One night she is Rosalind, the next night she is Imogen. I have seen her die in the dim darkness of an Italian tomb, after sucking the poison from her lover's lips. I have watched her wander through the forest of Arden, disguised as a pretty boy in long hose and doublet, wearing a dainty cap. She has been mad, and has come to a guilty king, giving him rosemary to use, and rue to taste. She has been innocent, and the black hand of jealousy has strangled her reed-like throat. I have seen her in every age and in every costume. Ordinary women never appeal to one's imagination. They are limited to their century. No mystical charm ever elevates them. We understand their minds as easily as we understand their bonnets. We always find them. There is no mystery in any of them. They ride in the park in the morning, chatter at tea-parties in the afternoon. They have stereotyped smiles and fashionable manners. They are quite obvious. But an actress! How different an actress is! Harry! Why did you not tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?”
tr_translation: “This play was also to our liking, Harry. It was Romeo and Juliet. I must admit that the idea of watching Shakespeare in this dingy hole initially irritated me. Still, I felt a strange interest. I was determined to at least watch the first act. There was a terrible orchestra; at the forefront, a young Jew playing a cracked piano. The music almost drove me away, but finally, the curtain on the stage opened, and the play began. Romeo was an old man with eyebrows painted with mushroom, a hoarse voice suitable for tragedies, and a build resembling beer barrels. Mercutio was almost as bad as him. A very vulgar comedian played this role. He had sprinkled his own invented lines and was very chummy with the orchestra members. Both actors were as shapeless as the stage decor, which looked like it was taken from a village fair... But Juliet!.. Harry, imagine a girl who is barely seventeen, tiny, with a face like a flower, a small head like in ancient Greek paintings, dark chestnut ringlets, eyes like deep purple wells of passion, lips like rose petals. She was the most beautiful thing I had ever seen in my life. Once, you told me that touching things didn't affect you, yet that beauty, just that beauty, could even bring tears to your eyes. Believe me, Harry, I could barely see the girl properly because of the tears in my eyes. And her voice! I had never heard such a voice in my life! At first, it came out very slowly, like deep, soft notes dropping one by one into your ear. Then, as it rose a bit more, it resembled a flute or the sound of an oboe heard from afar. In the garden scene, this voice reflected that trembling excitement heard when nightingales sing before dawn. Later, at times, it resonated with the wild passion of a violin. You know how voices can affect a person at times. If there are two things I will never forget in my life, they are your voice and the voice of Sibyl Vane. When I closed my eyes, I could hear these voices; both were saying different things. I don't know which one to listen to. Why shouldn't I love her, Harry? I love her. She is everything to me in life. Every night, I go to the theater to watch her. One night she is Rosalind, the next night Imogen. I saw her die in the dimness of an Italian cemetery, sucking the poison from her lover's lips. I saw her wander in the Forest of Arden, dressed as a beautiful young man in long stockings, knee breeches, and an elegant cap. Once, she went mad, stood before a guilty king, and gave him bitter herbs to taste. Once, she was innocent, yet the black hands of jealousy squeezed and crushed her swan-like neck. I have seen her in every guise, in every era. Ordinary people cannot affect our imagination. They are limited by their times. There is no magic to pull them out of their molds. We know the insides of their heads as well as their hats. We can easily find them. There is no mystery in any of them. They ride horses in the park in the mornings, chatter at tea parties in the afternoons. Their laughter is clichéd, their behavior is tailored to fashion. They are easily readable. But an actress! A woman who is an actress is so different! Harry, why didn't you tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?”
es_translation: —The play was good enough for us, Harry. It was Romeo and Juliet. I must admit that I wasn't too thrilled about the idea of seeing Shakespeare performed in a place like that. But I was interested, nonetheless. I decided to at least watch the first act. There was a dreadful orchestra, led by a young Jew sitting at an out-of-tune piano that almost drove me out of the theater; but finally the curtain rose and the play began. Romeo was a burly gentleman with many years behind him, eyebrows painted with cork black, a hoarse tragic voice, and the silhouette of a beer barrel. Mercutio was almost equally sinister. He was played by a traveling comedian who had added his own jokes to the text and maintained extremely friendly relations with the audience. Both were as grotesque as the set, which looked like it came from a fairground booth. But, Juliet! Imagine a little girl of barely seventeen, with a flower-like face, a Greek-like head with dark brown hair braided, eyes that were violet wells of passion, lips like rose petals. The most enchanting creature I had ever seen! Once you told me that pathos didn't move you at all, but that beauty, simple beauty, could fill your eyes with tears. I assure you, Harry, I could hardly see that girl because my eyes were always clouded with tears. And her voice! I've never heard a voice like it. Just a thread at first, with low, melodious notes that seemed to fall one by one into the ear. Then it grew in volume, and sounded like a flute or a distant oboe. In the garden scene, it had all the trembling joy of nightingales when they sing just before dawn. There were moments later when it reached the unrestrained passion of violins. You know perfectly well how much a voice can affect us. Your voice and Sibyl Vane's are two things I will never forget. When I close my eyes, I hear them, and each says something different. I don't know which to follow. Why shouldn't I love her? I love her, Harry. She means everything to me. I go to see her act day after day. One night she is Rosalind and the next Imogen. I've seen her die in the gloom of an Italian tomb, taking poison from her lover's lips. I've watched her cross the Forest of Arden, disguised as a boy, in breeches, doublet, and a delightful cap. She has been the madwoman who appears before a guilty king, giving him rue to wear and bitter herbs to taste. She has been innocent, and the black hands of jealousy have crushed her reed-like neck. I've seen her in all ages and in all costumes. Ordinary women don't stir our imagination. They are anchored in their century. Fascination never transfigures them. You know what's in their heads as easily as if it were their hat. You always find them. There's no mystery in any of them. They go for walks in the park in the morning and chat in the afternoon at tea parties. They have a stereotyped smile and the manners of the moment. They are transparent. But an actress! How different an actress is, Harry! Why didn't you tell me that the only thing worth loving is an actress?

en: “Because I have loved so many of them, Dorian.”
vi: “Vì tôi đã yêu rất nhiều cô trong số họ rồi, Dorian.”
tr: “Çünkü öyle çok aktris sevdim ki, Dorian!
es: —Porque he querido a demasiadas, Dorian.
vi_translation: “Because I have loved many of them already, Dorian.”
tr_translation: “Because I loved so many actresses, Dorian!”
es_translation: —Because I have loved too many, Dorian.

en: “Oh, yes, horrid people with dyed hair and painted faces.”
vi: “Ồ, vâng, những cô dễ sợ, tóc nhuộm mặt vẽ.”
tr: “Ha, evet, boyalı saçlı, boyalı yüzlü iğrenç kişiler.
es: —Sí, claro; gente horrible con el pelo teñido y el rostro pintado.
vi_translation: “Oh, yes, those scary girls, with dyed hair and painted faces.”
tr_translation: "Ha, yes, disgusting people with dyed hair and painted faces.""
es_translation: —Yes, of course; horrible people with dyed hair and painted faces.

en: “Don’t run down dyed hair and painted faces. There is an extraordinary charm in them, sometimes,” said Lord Henry.
vi: “Đừng chê bai tóc nhuộm mặt vẽ. Có nét duyên lạ ở chúng, đôi khi,” huân tước Henry nói.
tr: “Boyalı saçla boyalı yüzü hor görme,” dedi Lord Henry. “Kimi zaman olağanüstü çekici olabiliyorlar.
es: —No desprecies el pelo teñido y los rostros pintados. En ocasiones tienen un encanto extraordinario —dijo lord Henry.
vi_translation: “Don't criticize dyed hair and painted faces. There is sometimes a strange charm in them,” Lord Henry said.
tr_translation: “Do not scorn painted hair and painted face,” said Lord Henry. “Sometimes they can be extraordinarily attractive.”
es_translation: —Do not disdain dyed hair and painted faces. Sometimes they have an extraordinary charm —said Lord Henry.

en: “I wish now I had not told you about Sibyl Vane.”
vi: “Giờ tôi chỉ ước gì tôi chưa kể cho anh về Sibyl Vane.”
tr: “Keşke Sibyl Vane’i anlatmasaydım sana.
es: —Ahora quisiera no haberte contado nada sobre Sybil Vane.
vi_translation: “Now I just wish I hadn't told you about Sibyl Vane.”
tr_translation: "I wish I hadn't told you about Sibyl Vane."
es_translation: —Now I wish I hadn't told you anything about Sybil Vane.

en: “You could not have helped telling me, Dorian. All through your life you will tell me everything you do.”
vi: “Cậu không thể không kể cho tôi đâu, Dorian. Rồi suốt đời mình, cậu sẽ kể cho tôi mọi chuyện cậu làm.”
tr: “Anlatmamak elinde değil ki, Dorian. Ömür boyu yaptığın her şeyi bana anlatacaksın sen.
es: —No hubieras podido evitarlo, Dorian. A lo largo de tu vida me contarás todo lo que hagas.
vi_translation: "You can't not tell me, Dorian. For the rest of your life, you will tell me everything you do."
tr_translation: “You can't help but tell, Dorian. You will tell me everything you do for the rest of your life.”
es_translation: —You couldn't have avoided it, Dorian. Throughout your life, you will tell me everything you do.

en: “Yes, Harry, I believe that is true. I cannot help telling you things. You have a curious influence over me. If I ever did a crime, I would come and confess it to you. You would understand me.”
vi: “Vâng, Harry, tôi tin là đúng thế. Tôi không thể không kể các cái cho anh. Anh có một ảnh hưởng kỳ lạ lên tôi. Nếu khi nào đó tôi có phạm tội, tôi cũng sẽ đến thú nhận về nó với anh. Anh sẽ hiểu tôi.
tr: “Evet, sanırım öyle olacak, Harry. Her şeyi sana anlatmamak elimde değil. Tuhaf bir etkin var üzerimde. Günün birinde ağır bir suç işlesem bile gelip sana itiraf ederdim. Sen beni anlardın.
es: —Tienes razón, Harry; creo que estás en lo cierto. No puedo dejar de contarte las cosas. Tienes una curiosa influencia sobre mí. Si alguna vez cometiera un delito, vendría a confesártelo. Tú lo entenderías.
vi_translation: “Yes, Harry, I believe that's true. I can't help but tell you everything. You have a strange influence on me. If I ever commit a crime, I would come to confess it to you. You would understand me.”
tr_translation: "Yes, I think it will be so, Harry. I can't help but tell you everything. You have a strange effect on me. Even if I committed a serious crime one day, I would come and confess to you. You would understand me."
es_translation: —You are right, Harry; I think you are correct. I can't help but tell you things. You have a curious influence over me. If I ever committed a crime, I would come to confess it to you. You would understand.

en: “People like you—the wilful sunbeams of life—don’t commit crimes, Dorian. But I am much obliged for the compliment, all the same. And now tell me—reach me the matches, like a good boy—thanks—what are your actual relations with Sibyl Vane?”
vi: “Những người như cậu — các tia nắng bướng bỉnh của đời — sẽ không phạm tội đâu, Dorian. Nhưng tôi vẫn hết sức cảm ơn vì lời khen, dẫu thế nào. Giờ thì hãy kể cho tôi — với giùm tôi mấy que diêm, làm ơn, cảm ơn: — quan hệ trên thực tế của cậu với Sibyl Vane là thế nào?”
tr: “Senin gibi kişiler –yaşamın güneş ışınları– ağır suç işlemezler, Dorian. Gene de iltifatına çok teşekkür ederim. Şimdi de söyle bana... Kibriti uzatır mısın, bir zahmet? Sağ ol... Sibyl Vane’le arandaki ilişkinin adı nedir?
es: —Personas como tú, los caprichosos rayos de sol de la vida, no delinquen. Pero, de todos modos, te quedo muy agradecido por ese cumplido. Y ahora dime..., alcánzame las cerillas, como un buen chico, gracias... ¿Cuáles son tus relaciones actuales con Sybil Vane?
vi_translation: “People like you — the stubborn rays of life — will not commit crimes, Dorian. But I still very much appreciate the compliment, nonetheless. Now tell me — pass me the matches, please, thank you: — what is your actual relationship with Sibyl Vane?”
tr_translation: “People like you – the sunbeams of life – do not commit serious crimes, Dorian. Nevertheless, thank you very much for the compliment. Now tell me... Would you be so kind as to pass the match? Thank you... What is the nature of your relationship with Sibyl Vane?”
