es_translation: —People like you, the whimsical rays of sunshine in life, do not commit crimes. But, anyway, I am very grateful to you for that compliment. And now tell me... hand me the matches, like a good boy, thank you... What are your current relations with Sybil Vane?

en: Dorian Gray leaped to his feet, with flushed cheeks and burning eyes. “Harry! Sibyl Vane is sacred!”
vi: Dorian Gray nhảy lên, má đỏ, mắt rực. “Harry! Sibyl Vane là thiêng liêng!”
tr: Dorian Gray yüzü kızarmış, gözleri ateş püskürerek ayağa fırladı. “Harry! Sibyl Vane kutsaldır!
es: Dorian Gray se puso en pie de un salto, las mejillas encendidas y los ojos echando fuego. —¡Harry! ¡Sybil Vane es sagrada!
vi_translation: Dorian Gray jumped up, his cheeks red, his eyes blazing. "Harry! Sibyl Vane is sacred!"
tr_translation: Dorian Gray blushed, his eyes blazing with anger as he jumped to his feet. "Harry! Sibyl Vane is sacred!"
es_translation: Dorian Gray jumped to his feet, his cheeks flushed and his eyes blazing. —Harry! Sybil Vane is sacred!

en: “It is only the sacred things that are worth touching, Dorian,” said Lord Henry, with a strange touch of pathos in his voice. “But why should you be annoyed? I suppose she will belong to you some day. When one is in love, one always begins by deceiving one’s self, and one always ends by deceiving others. That is what the world calls a romance. You know her, at any rate, I suppose?”
vi: “Chỉ những thứ thiêng liêng mới đáng để đụng vào thôi, Dorian,” huân tước Henry nói, với một chút hứng khởi kỳ lạ trong giọng. “Nhưng tại sao cậu lại phải bực mình? Tôi cho là cô nàng sẽ thuộc về cậu vào một ngày nào đó. Khi ta yêu, ta luôn bắt đầu bằng việc lừa mình, và ta luôn chấm dứt bằng việc lừa người. Đó là cái mà thế gian gọi là sự lãng mạn. Cậu đã quen cô nàng rồi, dẫu sao đi nữa, tôi nghĩ thế đúng không?”
tr: Lord Henry, “Yalnızca kutsal şeylere dokunmaya değer,” dedi. Sesinde tuhaf bir hüzün vardı. “Ne diye kızıyorsun? Herhalde kız bir gün gelip senin olacak. İnsan âşık olduğu zaman hep kendi kendini aldatmakla işe başlar, başkalarını aldatmakla sona erdirir. Dünyamızın romantizm dediği işte budur... Onunla hiç değilse tanıştın sanırım, değil mi?
es: —Sólo las cosas sagradas merecen ser tocadas, Dorian —dijo lord Henry, con una extraña nota de patetismo en la voz—. Pero, ¿por qué tienes que enfadarte? Supongo que será tuya algún día. Cuando se está enamorado, empiezas por engañarte a ti mismo y acabas engañando a los demás. Eso es lo que el mundo llama una historia de amor. Al menos, la conoces personalmente, imagino.
vi_translation: “Only sacred things are worth touching, Dorian,” Lord Henry said, with a strange touch of excitement in his voice. “But why are you upset? I suppose she will belong to you one day. When we love, we always begin by deceiving ourselves, and we always end by deceiving others. That is what the world calls romance. You are already acquainted with her, anyway, I think, aren't you?”
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "Only sacred things are worth touching." There was a strange sadness in his voice. "Why are you angry? Surely the girl will be yours one day. When a person falls in love, they always start by deceiving themselves and end by deceiving others. This is what our world calls romance... I suppose you have at least met her, haven't you?"
es_translation: —Only sacred things deserve to be touched, Dorian —said Lord Henry, with a strange note of pathos in his voice—. But why do you have to get angry? I suppose it will be yours someday. When you are in love, you start by deceiving yourself and end up deceiving others. That is what the world calls a love story. At least, you know her personally, I imagine.

en: “Of course I know her. On the first night I was at the theatre, the horrid old Jew came round to the box after the performance was over and offered to take me behind the scenes and introduce me to her. I was furious with him, and told him that Juliet had been dead for hundreds of years and that her body was lying in a marble tomb in Verona. I think, from his blank look of amazement, that he was under the impression that I had taken too much champagne, or something.”
vi: “Dĩ nhiên tôi đã quen nàng. Vào đêm đầu tiên tôi ở nhà hát, lão Do Thái dễ sợ ấy đã ghé qua lô tôi sau khi buổi diễn kết thúc, và ngỏ ý dẫn tôi vào sau sân khấu và giới thiệu tôi với nàng. Tôi đã giận điên lên với lão, bảo lão rằng Juliet đã chết hàng trăm năm nay rồi, và rằng xác nàng đang nằm trong một hầm mộ cẩm thạch ở Verona. Tôi nghĩ, từ vẻ mặt ngây ra vì sửng sốt của lão, rằng lão có cảm tưởng rằng tôi đã nốc quá nhiều sâm-panh, hoặc chơi thứ gì đó.”
tr: “Tabii tanıştım. Tiyatroya ilk gittiğim gece o yaşlı Yahudi oyunun sonunda locama geldi, beni kulise götürüp onunla tanıştırmayı önerdi. Çok kızdım ona. Juliet öleli yüzlerce yıl oluyor, Verona’da mermer bir lahit içinde yatıyor, dedim. Yüzündeki afallamış bakıştan anladığıma göre herif benim şampanyayı çok kaçırmış olduğumu sandı.
es: —Claro que la conozco. La primera noche que estuve en el teatro, el horrible judío viejo se presentó en el palco después de que terminara la representación y se ofreció a llevarme entre bastidores y presentármela. Consiguió enfurecerme, y le dije que Julieta llevaba muerta cientos de años y que su cuerpo yacía en Verona, en una tumba de mármol. Por la mirada de asombro que me lanzó, creo que tuvo la impresión de que había bebido demasiado champán o algo parecido.
vi_translation: "Of course, I knew her. On the first night I was at the theater, that dreadful old Jew came by my box after the performance ended and offered to take me backstage and introduce me to her. I was furious with him, telling him that Juliet had been dead for hundreds of years, and that her body was lying in a marble tomb in Verona. From the stunned look on his face, I thought he had the impression that I had drunk too much champagne or was on something."
tr_translation: “Of course I did. The first night I went to the theater, that old Jew came to my box at the end of the play and suggested taking me backstage to introduce me to her. I was very angry with him. I said, Juliet has been dead for hundreds of years, lying in a marble tomb in Verona. From the bewildered look on his face, I understood that he thought I had had too much champagne.”
es_translation: —Of course I know her. The first night I was at the theater, the horrible old Jew came to the box after the performance ended and offered to take me backstage and introduce me to her. He managed to infuriate me, and I told him that Juliet had been dead for hundreds of years and that her body lay in Verona, in a marble tomb. From the look of astonishment he gave me, I think he got the impression that I had drunk too much champagne or something like that.

en: “I am not surprised.”
vi: “Tôi không ngạc nhiên.
tr: “Hiç şaşmam.
es: —No me sorprende.
vi_translation: “I am not surprised.”
tr_translation: “I never waver.”
es_translation: —It doesn't surprise me.

en: “Then he asked me if I wrote for any of the newspapers. I told him I never even read them. He seemed terribly disappointed at that, and confided to me that all the dramatic critics were in a conspiracy against him, and that they were every one of them to be bought.”
vi: “Sau đó lão hỏi tôi có phải tôi viết cho tờ báo nào đó không. Tôi bảo lão rằng tôi chưa bao giờ thậm chí là đọc chúng. Lão dường như thất vọng ghê gớm với việc ấy, và tâm sự với tôi rằng mọi nhà phê bình kịch nghệ đang tham gia vào một âm mưu hống lại lão, và rằng họ là cái bọn mà đứa nào cũng bị mua.”
tr: “Sonra bana gazeteci olup olmadığımı sordu. Ben de gazete okumadığımı söyledim. Adam bunu duyunca çok büyük hayal kırıklığına uğradı, besbelli. Bütün tiyatro eleştirmenlerinin ona karşı komplo kurduklarını, hepsinin de hiç ayrımsız satılık olduklarını anlattı bana.
es: —Luego me preguntó si escribía para algún periódico. Le dije que nunca los leía. Pareció terriblemente decepcionado al oírlo, y me confesó que todos los críticos teatrales le eran hostiles y que a todos se los podía comprar.
vi_translation: “Then he asked me if I wrote for any newspaper. I told him that I had never even read them. He seemed terribly disappointed by that, and confided in me that all the theater critics were part of a conspiracy against him, and that they were all bought.”
tr_translation: “Then he asked me if I was a journalist. I told him that I didn't read newspapers. When he heard this, he was very disappointed, obviously. He told me that all theater critics were conspiring against him, and that they were all, without exception, for sale.”
es_translation: —Then he asked me if I wrote for any newspaper. I told him that I never read them. He seemed terribly disappointed to hear that, and he confessed to me that all the theater critics were hostile to him and that they could all be bought.

en: “I should not wonder if he was quite right there. But, on the other hand, judging from their appearance, most of them cannot be at all expensive.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ không lấy làm lạ nếu ông ta hoàn toàn đúng ở điểm này. Nhưng, mặt khác, cứ xét theo tướng mạo họ, chắc là phần lớn trong số họ cũng chẳng đắt mấy đâu.”
tr: “Bu söylediğinde haklıysa hiç şaşmam. Ama öte yandan da, çoğunun kılığına bakarsan, pek de pahalı olmasalar gerekir.
es: —No me extrañaría que tuviera razón en eso. Pero, por otra parte, a juzgar por el aspecto que tiene la mayoría, no deben de ser demasiado caros.
vi_translation: “I wouldn't be surprised if he was completely right on this point. But, on the other hand, judging by their appearance, most of them probably aren't worth much either.”
tr_translation: “If he is right in what he says, I wouldn't be surprised. But on the other hand, if you look at most of their appearances, they shouldn't be very expensive.”
es_translation: —It wouldn't surprise me if you were right about that. But, on the other hand, judging by the way most of them look, they can't be too expensive.

en: “Well, he seemed to think they were beyond his means,” laughed Dorian. “By this time, however, the lights were being put out in the theatre, and I had to go. He wanted me to try some cigars that he strongly recommended. I declined. The next night, of course, I arrived at the place again. When he saw me, he made me a low bow and assured me that I was a munificent patron of art. He was a most offensive brute, though he had an extraordinary passion for Shakespeare. He told me once, with an air of pride, that his five bankruptcies were entirely due to ‘The Bard,’ as he insisted on calling him. He seemed to think it a distinction.”
vi: “Ừ, lão dường như nghĩ họ ngoài khả năng lão,” Dorian cười. “Tuy nhiên đến lúc đó thì đèn đóm bắt đầu tắt trong nhà hát và tôi phải đi. Lão muốn tôi thử vài điếu xì gà mà lão giới thiệu rất hăng. Tôi từ chối. Đêm hôm sau, dĩ nhiên, tôi lại đến nơi đó. Lúc lão thấy tôi, lão cúi rạp xuống chào tôi, và quả quyết với tôi rằng tôi là một người bảo trợ hào phóng của nghệ thuật. Lão là một kẻ cục súc cực tởm, thế nhưng lão lại ấp ủ một niềm đam mê đặc biệt với Shakespeare. Có lần lão bảo tôi, với vẻ tự hào, rằng năm lần vỡ nợ của lão toàn là do ‘Thi Bá’, như lão cứ nhất định gọi ông ta. Lão dường như nghĩ nó là sự trọng vọng.”
tr: Dorian, “Bilmem, o eleştirmenleri kendi kesesine göre fazla pahalı buluyordu sanırım,” diye güldü. “Bu arada tiyatronun lambaları söndürülmeye başlandığından oradan ayrıldım. Yahudi bana yaprak sigarası sunmak istiyor, bu markayı şiddetle tavsiye ediyordu. Almadım. Ama ertesi gece gene oraya döndüm, doğallıkla. Yahudi beni görünce yerlere kadar eğildi, benim cömert bir sanat dostu olduğumu söyledi. Sinir bozucu bir herifti doğrusu, şu var ki Shakespeare’e karşı görülmedik bir tutku besliyordu. Bir keresinde bana beş kez iflas ettiğini, iflaslarının beşinin de Shakespeare yüzünden olduğunu övünerek söyledi. Buna bir ayrıcalık gözüyle bakıyordu sanki.
es: —Bien; pero él parece pensar que están por encima de sus posibilidades —rió Dorian—. Para entonces, sin embargo, ya estaban apagando las luces del teatro y tuve que irme. El judío quiso que probara unos cigarros de los que hizo grandes alabanzas. Pero decliné su ofrecimiento. A la noche siguiente, volví, por supuesto. Al verme, me hizo una profunda reverencia y me aseguró que yo era un munificente protector del arte. Es un ser insufrible, pero Shakespeare le apasiona. Ya me ha dicho, visiblemente orgulloso, que sus cinco bancarrotas se debieron enteramente a «el Bardo», como insiste en llamarlo. Parece considerarlo un timbre de gloria.
vi_translation: “Yes, he seems to think they are beyond his capability,” Dorian laughed. “However, by then the lights in the theater started to go out and I had to leave. He wanted me to try a few cigars that he enthusiastically recommended. I refused. The next night, of course, I went back there. When he saw me, he bowed deeply to greet me, and assured me that I was a generous patron of the arts. He was an extremely repulsive brute, yet he harbored a particular passion for Shakespeare. Once he told me, with a proud look, that his five bankruptcies were all due to the ‘Bard,’ as he insisted on calling him. He seemed to think it was a mark of respect.”
tr_translation: Dorian laughed, "I don't know, I think he found those critics too expensive for his own pocket." "By the way, I left because the theater's lights were starting to be turned off. The Jew wanted to offer me a leaf cigarette, he strongly recommended this brand. I didn't take it. But the next night I returned there, naturally. When the Jew saw me, he bowed down to the ground and said that I was a generous patron of the arts. He was truly an annoying fellow, but he had an unprecedented passion for Shakespeare. Once, he proudly told me that he had gone bankrupt five times, and all five bankruptcies were because of Shakespeare. He seemed to view this as a privilege."
es_translation: —Well; but he seems to think they are beyond his means —laughed Dorian—. By then, however, they were already turning off the theater lights and I had to leave. The Jew wanted me to try some cigars which he praised highly. But I declined his offer. The next night, I returned, of course. Upon seeing me, he made a deep bow and assured me that I was a munificent patron of the arts. He is an insufferable being, but Shakespeare is his passion. He has already told me, visibly proud, that his five bankruptcies were entirely due to "the Bard," as he insists on calling him. He seems to consider it a badge of honor.

en: “It was a distinction, my dear Dorian—a great distinction. Most people become bankrupt through having invested too heavily in the prose of life. To have ruined one’s self over poetry is an honour. But when did you first speak to Miss Sibyl Vane?”
vi: “Đó là một sự trọng vọng, Dorian thân mến của tôi — một sự trọng vọng vĩ đại. Phần lớn mọi người bị vỡ nợ do đầu tư quá đậm vào cuộc sinh tồn. Phá sản vì thơ là một vinh dự. Nhưng khi nào cậu nói chuyện lần đầu với cô Sibyl Vane?”
tr: “Ayrıcalıktır ya, sevgili Dorian, büyük bir ayrıcalık. Çoğu kişiler yaşamın düzyazısına aşırı yatırım yapmak yüzünden iflas ederler. Şiir yüzünden batmak bir onurdur... Ama sen Miss Sibyl Vane’le ne zaman konuştun ilk olarak?
es: —Lo es, mi querido Dorian; un verdadero timbre de gloria. La mayoría de la gente se arruina por invertir demasiado en la prosa de la vida. Arruinarse por la poesía es un honor. ¿Cuándo hablaste por vez primera con la señorita Sybil Vane?
vi_translation: “It is an honor, my dear Dorian — a great honor. Most people go bankrupt from investing too heavily in the struggle for existence. Going bankrupt because of poetry is a distinction. But when did you first speak to Miss Sibyl Vane?”
tr_translation: “It is a privilege, dear Dorian, a great privilege. Most people go bankrupt because they invest too much in the prose of life. To go bankrupt because of poetry is an honor... But when did you first speak to Miss Sibyl Vane?”
es_translation: —It is, my dear Dorian; a true badge of glory. Most people ruin themselves by investing too much in the prose of life. To be ruined by poetry is an honor. When did you first speak with Miss Sybil Vane?

en: “The third night. She had been playing Rosalind. I could not help going round. I had thrown her some flowers, and she had looked at me—at least I fancied that she had. The old Jew was persistent. He seemed determined to take me behind, so I consented. It was curious my not wanting to know her, wasn’t it?”
vi: “Đêm thứ ba. Lúc ấy nàng đang đóng vai Rosalind. Tôi không thể không đi vòng ra sau. Tôi đã tung cho nàng ít hoa, và nàng đã nhìn tôi; chí ít thì tôi đã tưởng tượng là nàng có làm thế. Lão Do Thái rất dai dẳng. Lão dường như kiên quyết bám sau tôi, vậy nên tôi đồng ý. Cái sự không muốn quen nàng của tôi cũng lạ, phải không?”
tr: “Üçüncü gece. O, Rosalind’i oynuyordu. Kulise gitmekten kendimi alamadım. Ona birkaç çiçek atmıştım, o da bana bakmıştı, daha doğrusu bakmış gibi gelmişti bana. İhtiyar Yahudi üsteleyip duruyordu. Beni kulise götürmeyi aklına koymuştu, ben de boyun eğdim. Bu kızla tanışmak istemeyişim tuhaf değil miydi, sence?
es: —La tercera noche. Había interpretado a Rosalinda. Me fue imposible no ir a verla. Le había lanzado unas flores y ella me miró; al menos, imaginé que lo había hecho. El viejo judío insistió. Estaba decidido a llevarme entre bastidores, de manera que acepté. Es curioso que no deseara conocerla, ¿no te parece?
vi_translation: “The third night. At that time she was playing the role of Rosalind. I couldn't help but go around to the back. I threw her some flowers, and she looked at me; at least I imagined she did. The old Jew was very persistent. He seemed determined to follow me, so I agreed. Isn't it strange that I didn't want to get to know her?”
tr_translation: “The third night. She was playing Rosalind. I couldn't stop myself from going backstage. I had thrown her a few flowers, and she had looked at me, or rather, it seemed to me that she had looked. The old Jew kept insisting. He was determined to take me backstage, and I yielded. Wasn't it strange that I didn't want to meet this girl, don't you think?”
es_translation: —The third night. She had played Rosalind. It was impossible for me not to go see her. I had thrown some flowers to her and she looked at me; at least, I imagined she had. The old Jew insisted. He was determined to take me backstage, so I agreed. It's curious that I didn't want to meet her, don't you think?

en: “No; I don’t think so.”
vi: “Không; tôi không nghĩ vậy.”
tr: “Yok, sanmıyorum.
es: —No; no me parece curioso.
vi_translation: "No; I don't think so."
tr_translation: “No, I don't think so.”
es_translation: —No; it doesn't seem curious to me.

en: “My dear Harry, why?”
vi: “Harry thân mến của tôi, tại sao?”
tr: “Sevgili Harry, ama neden?
es: —¿Por qué, mi querido Harry?
vi_translation: “My dear Harry, why?”
tr_translation: “Dear Harry, but why?”
es_translation: —Why, my dear Harry?

en: “I will tell you some other time. Now I want to know about the girl.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ kể cậu nghe lúc khác. Giờ tôi muốn biết về cô gái này.”
tr: “Başka zaman anlatırım. Şimdi bu kız konusunu öğrenmek istiyorum.
es: —Te lo diré en alguna otra ocasión. Ahora quiero saber más sobre esa chica.
vi_translation: “I will tell you another time. Now I want to know about this girl.”
tr_translation: “I'll tell you another time. Now I want to learn about this girl.”
es_translation: —I'll tell you some other time. Now I want to know more about that girl.

en: “Sibyl? Oh, she was so shy and so gentle. There is something of a child about her. Her eyes opened wide in exquisite wonder when I told her what I thought of her performance, and she seemed quite unconscious of her power. I think we were both rather nervous. The old Jew stood grinning at the doorway of the dusty greenroom, making elaborate speeches about us both, while we stood looking at each other like children. He would insist on calling me ‘My Lord,’ so I had to assure Sibyl that I was not anything of the kind. She said quite simply to me, ‘You look more like a prince. I must call you Prince Charming.’”
vi: “Sibyl? Ôi, nàng rất đỗi nhút nhát, rất đỗi dịu dàng. Có gì đó của một đứa trẻ ở nàng. Mắt nàng mở to trong nỗi kinh ngạc tuyệt trần khi tôi kể cho nàng những gì tôi nghĩ về buổi diễn của nàng, và nàng dường như hoàn toàn không ý thức được về tài năng của mình. Tôi nghĩ cả hai chúng tôi khá bồn chồn. Lão Do Thái đứng nhe răng cười nhăn nhở tại ô cửa vào phòng giải lao bụi bặm, đọc những lời trau chuốt về cả hai chúng tôi, trong lúc chúng tôi đứng nhìn nhau như trẻ con. Lão cứ nhất định gọi tôi là “huân tước,” vậy nên tôi phải quả quyết với Sibyl rằng tôi chẳng liên quan đến hạng người này. Nàng nói với tôi rất đơn giản, ‘Anh nhìn giống hoàng tử hơn. Tôi nên gọi anh là Hoàng tử Quyến rũ.’”
tr: “Sibyl mi? Ah, öyle utangaç, öyle yumuşak başlı ki! Çocuksu bir havası var zaten. Oyununu nasıl beğendiğimi söyleyince gözleri nefis bir inanmazlık ve hoşnutlukla iri iri açıldı. Etkisinin gücünden habersiz görünüyordu. İkimiz de az buçuk sıkılganlık çekiyorduk, sanırım. İhtiyar Yahudi o tozlu giyinme odasının kapısında durmuş ağzı kulaklarında, bizim üstümüze tumturaklı laflar ederken biz iki çocuk gibi durmuş birbirimizin yüzüne bakıyorduk. Adam ille de ‘Sayın Lordum’ deyip duruyordu bana. Bu yüzden Sibyl’e, lord falan olmadığımı söylemek zorunda kaldım. O da hiç yapmacıksız bir yalınlıkla, ‘Lorddan çok bir prense benziyorsunuz; size Tatlı Prens demem uygun düşer,’ dedi.
es: —¿Sybil? ¡Tan tímida y tan amable! Hay algo infantil en ella. Abrió mucho los ojos con el más sincero de los asombros cuando le dije lo que pensaba de su interpretación, y pareció no tener conciencia de su talento. Creo que los dos estábamos bastante nerviosos. El judío viejo sonreía desde la puerta del polvoriento camerino, diciendo frases rebuscadas sobre los dos, mientras Sibyl y yo nos mirábamos como niños. El viejo insistía en llamarme «mylord», y tuve que explicar a Sybil que no era nada parecido. Ella me dijo: «Más bien parece usted un príncipe. Le llamaré Príncipe Azul».
vi_translation: “Sibyl? Oh, she is so very shy, so very gentle. There is something of a child in her. Her eyes opened wide in utter amazement when I told her what I thought of her performance, and she seemed completely unaware of her own talent. I think both of us were quite nervous. The old Jew stood grinning at the entrance to the dusty greenroom, uttering polished phrases about both of us, while we stood looking at each other like children. He insisted on calling me 'lord,' so I had to assure Sibyl that I had nothing to do with such people. She told me very simply, 'You look more like a prince. I should call you Prince Charming.'”
tr_translation: “Sibyl, my dear? Ah, she is so shy, so gentle! She already has a childlike air about her. When I told her how much I liked her performance, her eyes opened wide with a delightful disbelief and pleasure. She seemed unaware of the power of her influence. I think we were both feeling a bit awkward. The old Jew stood at the door of that dusty dressing room, grinning from ear to ear, while he showered us with grandiose words, and we stood there like two children, looking at each other. The man kept insisting on calling me ‘My Lord.’ So I had to tell Sibyl that I wasn’t a lord at all. And with a completely unaffected simplicity, she said, ‘You look more like a prince than a lord; it would be fitting to call you Sweet Prince.’”
es_translation: —Sybil? So shy and so kind! There is something childlike about her. She opened her eyes wide with the most sincere astonishment when I told her what I thought of her performance, and she seemed to have no awareness of her talent. I think we were both quite nervous. The old Jew smiled from the door of the dusty dressing room, saying elaborate phrases about the two of us, while Sybil and I looked at each other like children. The old man insisted on calling me "mylord," and I had to explain to Sybil that I was nothing of the sort. She said to me: "You rather look like a prince. I will call you Prince Charming."

en: “Upon my word, Dorian, Miss Sibyl knows how to pay compliments.”
vi: “Xin thề danh dự, Dorian, cô Sibyl rất biết cách khen.
tr: “Vay canına, Dorian, Miss Sibyl iltifat etmesini biliyormuş.
es: —A fe mía, Dorian, la señorita Sybil sabe cómo hacer cumplidos.
vi_translation: “I swear on my honor, Dorian, Miss Sibyl knows how to compliment very well.”
tr_translation: "My goodness, Dorian, Miss Sibyl knows how to compliment.""
es_translation: —By my faith, Dorian, Miss Sybil knows how to give compliments.

en: “You don’t understand her, Harry. She regarded me merely as a person in a play. She knows nothing of life. She lives with her mother, a faded tired woman who played Lady Capulet in a sort of magenta dressing-wrapper on the first night, and looks as if she had seen better days.”
vi: “Anh không hiểu nàng, Harry. Nàng xem tôi chỉ như một nhân vật trong một vở kịch. Nàng không biết gì về cuộc sống. Nàng sống cùng mẹ, một phụ nữ mệt mỏi héo hon, đóng vai bà Capulet bận một loại áo choàng đỏ thẫm trong đêm đầu, và nhìn như thể bà ta từng trải qua những ngày tốt hơn.
tr: “Sen onu anlayamıyorsun, Harry. O beni yalnızca bir oyun kişisi olarak görüyordu. Hayatı hiç tanımıyor ki! Annesiyle birlikte oturuyor. Annesi geçkin, yorgun bir kadıncağız. İlk gittiğim gece sırtında kimonomsu mor bir giysiyle Leydi Capulet’i oynamıştı. Güngörmüş de şimdilerde düşkünleşmişe benziyor.
es: —No la entiendes, Harry. Me veía sólo como un personaje en una obra de teatro. No sabe nada de la vida. Vive con su madre, una mujer apagada y fatigada que, con una túnica más o menos carmesí, interpretó la primera noche a la señora Capuleto; una mujer con aspecto de haber conocido días mejores.
vi_translation: “You don't understand her, Harry. She sees me as just a character in a play. She knows nothing about life. She lives with her mother, a weary and withered woman, who plays Lady Capulet wearing a kind of dark crimson cloak on the first night, and looks as if she has seen better days.”
tr_translation: “You can't understand him, Harry. He only saw me as a character in a play. He doesn't know life at all! He lives with his mother. His mother is an elderly, tired woman. The first night I went, she played Lady Capulet in a kimono-like purple garment. She seems to have been well-off but has now fallen on hard times.”
es_translation: —You don't understand, Harry. She saw me only as a character in a play. She knows nothing about life. She lives with her mother, a worn-out and fatigued woman who, in a more or less crimson robe, played Lady Capulet on the first night; a woman who looks like she has seen better days.

en: “I know that look. It depresses me,” murmured Lord Henry, examining his rings.
vi: “Tôi biết cái vẻ này. Nó khiến tôi nản lòng,” huân tước Henry lẩm bẩm, săm soi những cái nhẫn của mình.
tr: Lord Henry ellerindeki yüzükleri gözden geçirerek, “Bilirim o tipleri, içimi sıkarlar,” diye mırıldandı.
es: —Conozco ese aspecto. Me deprime —murmuró lord Henry, examinando sus sortijas.
vi_translation: "I know this look. It discourages me," Lord Henry muttered, scrutinizing his rings.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, examining the rings on his fingers, murmured, "I know those types, they bore me."
es_translation: —I know that look. It depresses me —murmured Lord Henry, examining his rings.

en: “The Jew wanted to tell me her history, but I said it did not interest me.”
vi: “Lão Do Thái muốn kể cho tôi nghe lai lịch nàng, song tôi bảo tôi chẳng quan tâm.”
tr: “Yahudi bana onun yaşamöyküsünü anlatmak istedi ya, ilgimi çekmiyor, dedim.
es: —El judío me quería contar su historia, pero le dije que no me interesaba.
vi_translation: “The old Jew wanted to tell me her background, but I told him I wasn't interested.”
tr_translation: “The Jew wanted to tell me his life story, but I said, I'm not interested.”
es_translation: —The Jew wanted to tell me his story, but I told him I wasn't interested.

en: “You were quite right. There is always something infinitely mean about other people’s tragedies.”
vi: “Cậu hoàn toàn đúng. Luôn có gì đó vô cùng thảm hại ở các bi kịch của người khác.
tr: “En doğrusunu yapmışsın. Başkalarının trajedilerinde her zaman son derece çirkin, acı bir şey vardır.
es: —Tuviste toda la razón. Siempre hay algo infinitamente mezquino en las tragedias de los demás.
vi_translation: “You are absolutely right. There is always something incredibly pathetic about other people's tragedies.”
tr_translation: “You did the right thing. There is always something extremely ugly and bitter in the tragedies of others.”
es_translation: —You were absolutely right. There is always something infinitely petty in the tragedies of others.

en: “Sibyl is the only thing I care about. What is it to me where she came from? From her little head to her little feet, she is absolutely and entirely divine. Every night of my life I go to see her act, and every night she is more marvellous.”
vi: “Sibyl là điều duy nhất tôi để ý tới. Việc gì đến tôi cái chuyện nàng ở đâu ra? Từ cái đầu bé đến đôi chân nhỏ, nàng tuyệt đối và hoàn toàn thần thánh. Mỗi đêm trong đời, tôi lại đến xem tiết mục của nàng, và mỗi đêm nàng lại diệu kỳ hơn.
tr: “Tek ilgilendiğim şey, Sibyl. Onun soyu sopu falan umurumda değil. O minicik başından minicik ayaklarına kadar tümüyle, tümden şahane bir yaratık. Her Tanrı’nın gecesi onu sahnede seyretmeye gidiyorum, her gece onu daha harika buluyorum.
es: —Sybil es lo único que me interesa. ¿Qué más me da de dónde haya salido? Desde la cabecita a los piececitos es absoluta y enteramente divina. Noche tras noche voy a verla actuar, y cada noche lo hace mejor que la anterior.
vi_translation: “Sibyl is the only thing I care about. What does it matter to me where she comes from? From her small head to her tiny feet, she is absolutely and completely divine. Every night of my life, I go to see her performance, and each night she is more marvelous.”
tr_translation: “The only thing I care about is Sibyl. I don't care about her lineage or background. From her tiny head to her tiny feet, she is entirely, utterly a marvelous creature. Every night of the week, I go to watch her on stage, and every night I find her more wonderful.”
es_translation: —Sybil is the only thing that interests me. What do I care where she came from? From her little head to her tiny feet, she is absolutely and entirely divine. Night after night I go to see her perform, and each night she does better than the last.

en: “That is the reason, I suppose, that you never dine with me now. I thought you must have some curious romance on hand. You have; but it is not quite what I expected.”
vi: “Tôi tin rằng đó là lý do mà dạo này cậu chẳng bao giờ đi ăn tối với tôi. Tôi nghĩ cậu phải có sẵn chuyện tình lãng mạn lạ kỳ nào đó trong tay rồi. Cậu đã có; nhưng nó không đúng là cái tôi mong chờ.”
tr: “Şimdilerde benimle hiç yemeğe çıkmayışının nedeni de bu olsa gerek. Senin ilginç bir gönül serüveni yaşadığını kestiriyordum. Sahiden de öyleymiş ama bu serüven benim tahminimden farklı çıktı.
es: —Imagino que ésa es la razón de que ya nunca cenes conmigo. Pensaba, y estaba en lo cierto, que quizá tuvieras entre manos alguna curiosa historia de amor. Pero no se trata exactamente de lo que yo imaginaba.
vi_translation: “I believe that is the reason why you never go out to dinner with me these days. I think you must have some strange romantic affair on your hands already. You did; but it was not what I expected.”
tr_translation: “I suppose this is why you haven't been going out to eat with me lately. I had a feeling you were having an interesting romantic adventure. Indeed, it turned out to be true, but this adventure was different from what I had imagined.”
es_translation: —I imagine that's the reason you never have dinner with me anymore. I thought, and I was right, that perhaps you had some curious love story on your hands. But it's not exactly what I imagined.

en: “My dear Harry, we either lunch or sup together every day, and I have been to the opera with you several times,” said Dorian, opening his blue eyes in wonder.
vi: “Harry thân mến của tôi, ta vẫn ăn trưa hoặc ăn chiều cùng nhau mỗi ngày, và tôi từng đến nhà hát ô-pê-ra với anh vài lần,” Dorian nói, mở to đôi mắt xanh kinh ngạc.
tr: “Sevgili Harry, hemen her gün ya öğle ya akşam yemeğini birlikte yiyoruz, kaç kez de operaya geldim seninle,” diye Dorian Gray mavi gözlerini şaşkın şaşkın açarak yanıtladı.
es: —Mi querido Harry, tú y yo almorzamos o cenamos juntos todos los días; y he ido varias veces a la ópera contigo —dijo Dorian, abriendo mucho los ojos para manifestar su asombro.
vi_translation: “My dear Harry, we still have lunch or dinner together every day, and I have been to the opera with you a few times,” Dorian said, opening his wide blue eyes in astonishment.
tr_translation: “Dear Harry, we have lunch or dinner together almost every day, and I have come to the opera with you many times,” Dorian Gray replied, opening his blue eyes in astonishment.
es_translation: —My dear Harry, you and I have lunch or dinner together every day; and I have gone to the opera with you several times —said Dorian, opening his eyes wide to show his astonishment.

en: “You always come dreadfully late.”
vi: “Cậu luôn đến trễ phát sợ.”
tr: “Her zaman müthiş geç kalıyorsun.
es: —Siempre llegas terriblemente tarde.
vi_translation: “You always arrive terribly late.”
tr_translation: “You are always terribly late.”
es_translation: —You always arrive terribly late.

en: “Well, I can’t help going to see Sibyl play,” he cried, “even if it is only for a single act. I get hungry for her presence; and when I think of the wonderful soul that is hidden away in that little ivory body, I am filled with awe.”
vi: “Vâng, tôi không thể không đi xem Sibyl diễn,” cậu kêu lên, “thậm chí nếu chỉ là một hồi lẻ. Tôi bị thèm khát vóc dáng nàng; và khi tôi nghĩ về linh hồn diệu kỳ ẩn sâu trong cơ thể ngọc ngà nhỏ nhắn ấy, lòng tôi ngập tràn nỗi sợ.”
tr: Genç adam, “Ne yapayım!” diye bağırdı. “Sibyl’in oyununu görmeye gitmeden edemiyorum, tek bir perde için bile olsa! Onu görebilmek için acıkıyorum sanki. Hele o fildişi bedende gizli olan harikulade ruhu düşündükçe sanki huşu duyuyorum.
es: —No puedo dejar de ver actuar a Sybil —exclamó—, aunque sólo presencie el primer acto. Siento necesidad de su presencia; y cuando pienso en el alma maravillosa escondida en ese cuerpecito de marfil, me lleno de asombro.
vi_translation: “Yes, I cannot help but go see Sibyl perform,” he exclaimed, “even if it is just a single act. I crave her figure; and when I think of the wondrous soul hidden within that petite, exquisite body, my heart is filled with fear.”
tr_translation: The young man shouted, "What should I do!" "I can't help but go to see Sibyl's play, even if it's just for a single act! I feel like I'm starving to see her. Especially when I think about the marvelous soul hidden in that ivory body, I feel a sense of awe."
es_translation: —I can't stop watching Sybil perform —he exclaimed—, even if I only see the first act. I feel the need for her presence; and when I think of the marvelous soul hidden in that little ivory body, I am filled with wonder.

en: “You can dine with me to-night, Dorian, can’t you?”
vi: “Cậu có thể đi ăn với tôi tối nay không, Dorian?”
tr: “Bu gece benimle yemeğe gelirsin artık değil mi, Dorian?
es: —Esta noche cenas conmigo, ¿no es cierto?
vi_translation: "Can you have dinner with me tonight, Dorian?"
tr_translation: “You will come to dinner with me tonight, won't you, Dorian?”
es_translation: —You're having dinner with me tonight, aren't you?

en: He shook his head. “To-night she is Imogen,” he answered, “and to-morrow night she will be Juliet.”
vi: Cậu lắc đầu. “Tối nay nàng là Imogen,” cậu trả lời, “và tối mai nàng sẽ là Juliet.”
tr: “Bu gece benimle yemeğe gelirsin artık değil mi, Dorian? Dorian başını salladı. “Bu gece Sibyl Imogen oluyor,” diye karşılık verdi. “Yarın gece de Juliet.
es: Dorian Gray hizo un gesto negativo con la cabeza. —Hoy hace de Imogen —respondió—, y mañana por la noche será Julieta.
vi_translation: He shook his head. "Tonight she is Imogen," he replied, "and tomorrow night she will be Juliet."
tr_translation: Dorian nodded his head. "Tonight Sibyl is Imogen," he replied. "Tomorrow night she is Juliet."
es_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head. —Today she plays Imogen —he replied—, and tomorrow night she will be Juliet.

en: “When is she Sibyl Vane?”
vi: “Thế khi nào cô ấy là Sibyl Vane?”
tr: “Ya ne zaman Sibyl Vane oluyor?
es: —¿Cuándo es Sybil Vane?
vi_translation: “So when is she Sibyl Vane?”
tr_translation: “When do I become Sibyl Vane?”
es_translation: —When is Sybil Vane?

en: “Never.”
vi: “Chẳng khi nào.”
tr: “Hiçbir zaman.
es: —Nunca.
vi_translation: "Never."
tr_translation: “Never.”
es_translation: —Never.

en: “I congratulate you.”
vi: “Xin chúc mừng cậu.”
tr: “Kutlarım seni.
es: —Te felicito.
vi_translation: "Congratulations to you."
tr_translation: “Congratulations to you.”
es_translation: —I congratulate you.

en: “How horrid you are! She is all the great heroines of the world in one. She is more than an individual. You laugh, but I tell you she has genius. I love her, and I must make her love me. You, who know all the secrets of life, tell me how to charm Sibyl Vane to love me! I want to make Romeo jealous. I want the dead lovers of the world to hear our laughter and grow sad. I want a breath of our passion to stir their dust into consciousness, to wake their ashes into pain. My God, Harry, how I worship her!” He was walking up and down the room as he spoke. Hectic spots of red burned on his cheeks. He was terribly excited.
vi: “Sao anh quá đáng thế! Nàng là tất cả các nữ anh hùng vĩ đại của thế giới hội tụ lại trong một. Nàng nhiều hơn một cá nhân đơn lẻ. Anh cười, nhưng tôi nói cho anh biết: nàng là thiên tài. Tôi yêu nàng, và tôi phải làm cho nàng yêu tôi. Anh, người biết mọi bí mật cuộc sống, hãy chỉ tôi cách mê hoặc Sibyl Vane để nàng yêu tôi! Tôi muốn bắt Romeo phải ghen. Tôi muốn những tình nhân đã khuất của thế giới này phải nghe thấy tiếng cười của chúng tôi và trở nên buồn bã. Tôi muốn một hơi thở đam mê của chúng tôi khuấy tung cát bụi họ vào cõi tỉnh, đánh thức tro tàn họ ở miền đau. Chúa ơi, Harry, sao tôi tôn sùng nàng đến thế!” Cậu bước tới bước lui trong phòng lúc cậu nói. Những đốm ửng đỏ vì sốt thiêu đốt má cậu. Cậu bị kích động khủng khiếp.
tr: “Ne iğrençsin, Harry! Sibyl dünyanın bütün büyük kadın kahramanlarının birleşimidir. Bireyin ötesinde bir şey o. Gülüyorsun ama sana söylüyorum, büyük bir yetenek o. Onu seviyorum, onun da beni sevmesini sağlamalıyım. Sen ki yaşamın tüm gizlerini bilirsin, söyle bana, nasıl bir büyü yapayım da Sibyl Vane beni sevsin? Romeo’ yu kıskandırmak istiyorum. Tarihin ölmüş âşıkları bizim gülüşlerimizi duysunlar da hüzünlensinler istiyorum. Bizim ateşimizden bir soluk onların toprağına can versin, küllerini uyandırıp acı çektirsin istiyorum. Ulu Tanrım, ona nasıl tapıyorum bilsen, Harry! Dorian konuşurken odada volta atıp duruyordu. Yanaklarında humma ateşi gibi kırmızı lekeler yanıyordu. Genç adam aşırı derecede heyecanlıydı.
es: —¡Qué malvado eres! Sybil es todas las grandes heroínas del mundo en una sola. Es más que una sola persona. Te ríes, pero yo te repito que es maravillosa. La quiero, y he de hacer que me quiera. Tú, que conoces todos los secretos de la vida, dime cómo hechizar a Sybil Vane para que me quiera. Deseo dar celos a Romeo. Quiero que todos los amantes muertos oigan nuestras risas y se entristezcan. Quiero que un soplo de nuestra pasión remueva su polvo, despierte sus cenizas y los haga sufrir. ¡Cielos, Harry, cómo la adoro! —iba de un lado a otro de la habitación mientras hablaba. Manchas rojas, como de fiebre, le encendían las mejillas. Estaba terriblemente exaltado.
vi_translation: “Why are you so unreasonable! She is all the great heroines of the world combined into one. She is more than a single individual. You laugh, but I tell you: she is a genius. I love her, and I must make her love me. You, who know all the secrets of life, show me how to enchant Sibyl Vane so that she loves me! I want to make Romeo jealous. I want the past lovers of this world to hear our laughter and become sad. I want a breath of our passion to stir their dust into consciousness, to awaken their ashes in the realm of pain. God, Harry, why do I adore her so!” He paced back and forth in the room as he spoke. Feverish red spots burned on his cheeks. He was terribly agitated.
tr_translation: “How disgusting you are, Harry! Sibyl is the combination of all the great female heroines of the world. She is something beyond the individual. You laugh, but I'm telling you, she is a great talent. I love her, and I must make her love me too. You, who know all the secrets of life, tell me, what spell should I cast to make Sibyl Vane love me? I want to make Romeo jealous. I want the dead lovers of history to hear our laughter and feel sorrow. I want a breath of our fire to give life to their soil, to awaken their ashes and make them suffer. My God, if you only knew how I worship her, Harry!” Dorian was pacing back and forth in the room while talking. Red spots, like the fever of a fever, were burning on his cheeks. The young man was extremely excited.
es_translation: —How wicked you are! Sybil is all the great heroines of the world in one. She is more than a single person. You laugh, but I repeat to you that she is wonderful. I love her, and I must make her love me. You, who know all the secrets of life, tell me how to enchant Sybil Vane so that she loves me. I wish to make Romeo jealous. I want all the dead lovers to hear our laughter and be saddened. I want a breath of our passion to stir their dust, awaken their ashes, and make them suffer. Heavens, Harry, how I adore her! —he was moving from one side of the room to the other as he spoke. Red spots, like fever, burned on his cheeks. He was terribly excited.

en: Lord Henry watched him with a subtle sense of pleasure. How different he was now from the shy frightened boy he had met in Basil Hallward’s studio! His nature had developed like a flower, had borne blossoms of scarlet flame. Out of its secret hiding-place had crept his soul, and desire had come to meet it on the way.
vi: Huân tước Henry quan sát cậu với cảm giác hài lòng ý nhị. Sao mà lúc này cậu khác đến thế với thằng bé bẽn lẽn, khiếp hãi mà y từng gặp ở xưởng vẽ của Basil Hallward! Bản tính cậu đã nảy nở tựa một đóa hoa, đã trổ bông rực đỏ. Hồn cậu đã lẻn ra khỏi nơi ẩu náu bí mật, và Dục đang trên đường đi gặp nó.
tr: Lord Henry onu gizli bir hazla seyretmekteydi. Bu Dorian, Basil Hallward’ın stüdyosunda gördüğü o utangaç, ürkek çocuktan nasıl da bambaşkaydı! Kişiliği bir çiçek gibi gelişmiş, kızıl alev tomurcuklar açmıştı. Ruhu, sığındığı gizli yerden çıkmış, arzu da onu yarı yolda karşılamıştı.
es: Lord Henry sentía un secreto placer contemplándolo. ¡Qué diferente era ya del muchachito tímido y asustado que había conocido en el estudio de Basil Hallward! Había madurado, produciendo flores de fuego escarlata. Desde su secreto escondite, el alma se le había salido al mundo, y el Deseo había acudido a reunirse con ella por el camino.
vi_translation: Lord Henry observed him with a subtle sense of satisfaction. How different he was now from the shy, frightened boy he had once met in Basil Hallward's studio! His nature had blossomed like a flower, had bloomed in vivid red. His soul had slipped out of its secret hiding place, and Desire was on its way to meet it.
tr_translation: Lord Henry was watching him with a secret pleasure. How different this Dorian was from the shy, timid boy he had seen in Basil Hallward's studio! His personality had blossomed like a flower, with crimson flame buds. His soul had emerged from its hidden place, and desire had met it halfway.
es_translation: Lord Henry felt a secret pleasure in watching him. How different he was already from the timid and frightened boy he had met in Basil Hallward's studio! He had matured, producing flowers of scarlet fire. From its secret hiding place, his soul had come out into the world, and Desire had come to meet it along the way.

en: “And what do you propose to do?” said Lord Henry at last.
vi: “Và cậu định làm gì?” huân tước Henry nói, rốt cuộc.
tr: Lord Henry, “Peki, ne yapmayı planlıyorsun?” diye sordu en sonunda.
es: —Y, ¿qué es lo que te propones hacer? —dijo finalmente lord Henry.
vi_translation: “And what do you intend to do?” Lord Henry said, finally.
tr_translation: Lord Henry asked finally, "Well, what do you plan to do?"
es_translation: —And, what do you intend to do? —said Lord Henry finally.

en: “I want you and Basil to come with me some night and see her act. I have not the slightest fear of the result. You are certain to acknowledge her genius. Then we must get her out of the Jew’s hands. She is bound to him for three years—at least for two years and eight months—from the present time. I shall have to pay him something, of course. When all that is settled, I shall take a West End theatre and bring her out properly. She will make the world as mad as she has made me.”
vi: “Tôi muốn anh và Basil đi cùng tôi một đêm nào đó để xem nàng diễn. Tôi không mảy may sợ hãi kết quả. Anh chắc chắn sẽ công nhận thiên tài của nàng. Sau đó ta phải kéo nàng ra khỏi tay lão Do Thái ấy. Nàng bị trói buộc bởi hợp đồng với lão suốt ba năm — ít nhất là suốt hai năm và tám tháng — từ lúc này. Tôi sẽ phải trả gì đó cho lão, dĩ nhiên. Khi mọi chuyện êm xuôi, tôi sẽ thuê nhà hát West End và đưa nàng ra một cách thích đáng. Nàng sẽ làm cả thế giới phát điên như nàng đã làm với tôi.”
tr: “Basil’le bir gece gelin, onun oyununu görün, istiyorum. Zerrece korkum yok bunun sonucundan. Onun üstün yeteneğini kabul edeceksiniz, bu kesin. Sonra onu o Yahudi’nin ellerinden kurtarmalıyım. Üç yıllık kontratla bağlı ona, yani bugünden sonra iki yıl, sekiz ay. Yahudi’ye bir şeyler ödemem gerekecek, doğallıkla. Bunlar yola girdikten sonra West End’de bir tiyatro tutup Sibyl’i şöyle adam gibi tanıtırım. Bütün dünyayı da, tıpkı beni büyülediği gibi büyüleyecektir.
es: —Quiero que Basil y tú vengáis conmigo alguna noche para verla actuar. No tengo el menor temor al resultado. Sin duda, reconoceréis su genio. Luego hemos de arrancarla de las manos de ese viejo judío. Está atada a él por tres años, al menos dos años y ocho meses, desde el momento presente. Tendré que pagarle algo, por supuesto. Cuando todo esté arreglado, la traeré a algún teatro del West End y la presentaré como es debido. Enloquecerá al mundo como me ha enloquecido a mí.
vi_translation: “I want you and Basil to come with me one night to see her perform. I am not in the least bit afraid of the outcome. You will surely acknowledge her talent. After that, we must get her out of that Jew's hands. She is bound by a contract with him for three years — at least for two years and eight months — from now. I will have to pay him something, of course. When everything is settled, I will rent the West End theater and present her properly. She will drive the whole world crazy as she has done to me.”
tr_translation: “Come one night with Basil, see his play, I want you to. I have no fear at all of the outcome. You will acknowledge his superior talent, this is certain. Then I must save him from that Jew’s hands. He is bound to him by a three-year contract, which means two years and eight months from today. I will have to pay the Jew something, naturally. Once these things are settled, I will rent a theater in West End and properly introduce Sibyl. She will enchant the whole world, just as she has enchanted me.”
es_translation: —I want Basil and you to come with me some night to see her perform. I have no fear of the outcome. Without a doubt, you will recognize her genius. Then we must rescue her from the hands of that old Jew. She is bound to him for three years, at least two years and eight months from now. I will have to pay him something, of course. When everything is settled, I will bring her to some theater in the West End and present her as she deserves. She will drive the world mad as she has driven me mad.

en: “That would be impossible, my dear boy.”
vi: “Chuyện ấy bất khả thi mà, cậu bé của tôi?”
tr: “Olacak şey değil bu, yavrucuğum.
es: —¡Eso es imposible, amigo mío!
vi_translation: "That is impossible, my boy?"
tr_translation: “This is unbelievable, my dear.”
es_translation: —That is impossible, my friend!

en: “Yes, she will. She has not merely art, consummate art-instinct, in her, but she has personality also; and you have often told me that it is personalities, not principles, that move the age.”
vi: “Vâng, nàng sẽ làm được. Nàng không chỉ có nghệ thuật, thiên hướng nghệ thuật tuyệt trần, trong mình, mà nàng còn có cá tính nữa; và anh hay bảo tôi rằng chính cá tính chứ không phải nguyên tắc mới là cái chuyển dời thời đại.”
tr: “Evet, büyüleyecek. Sibyl’de olan yalnızca sanat yeteneği, kusursuz bir sanatsal içgüdü değil, kişiliği de var. Sen de bana kaç kez demişsindir, çağı etkileyen ilkeler değil kişilerdir, diye.
es: —Lo hará. No sólo hay en ella arte, arte e instinto consumados; también tiene personalidad; y tú me has dicho a menudo que son las personalidades, no los principios, lo que mueve nuestra época.
vi_translation: "Yes, she will be able to do it. She not only has art, an exquisite artistic inclination within her, but she also has personality; and he often tells me that it is personality, not principles, that moves the ages."
tr_translation: “Yes, she will enchant. What Sibyl has is not only artistic talent, a perfect artistic instinct, but also personality. You have told me many times that it is not principles but personalities that influence the age.”
es_translation: —She will do it. There is not only art in her, consummate art and instinct; she also has personality; and you have often told me that it is personalities, not principles, that move our age.

en: “Well, what night shall we go?”
vi: “Thôi được, vậy đêm nào ta sẽ đi?”
tr: “Peki, hangi gece gidiyoruz?
es: —Bien; ¿qué noche iremos?
vi_translation: “Alright, so which night shall we go?”
tr_translation: “So, which night are we going?”
es_translation: —Alright; which night will we go?

en: “Let me see. To-day is Tuesday. Let us fix to-morrow. She plays Juliet to-morrow.”
vi: “Để tôi xem. Hôm nay là thứ Ba. Ta hãy chốt ngày mai nhé. Mai nàng diễn Juliet.”
tr: “Dur bakayım. Bugün salı. Yarın diyelim. Sibyl yarın Juliet’i oynuyor.
es: —Déjame ver. Hoy es martes. Quedemos para mañana. Mañana interpreta a Julieta.
vi_translation: "Let me see. Today is Tuesday. Let's finalize it for tomorrow. Tomorrow you will play Juliet."
tr_translation: “Wait a minute. Today is Tuesday. Let's say tomorrow. Sibyl is playing Juliet tomorrow.”
es_translation: —Let me see. Today is Tuesday. Let's meet tomorrow. Tomorrow she plays Juliet.

en: “All right. The Bristol at eight o’clock; and I will get Basil.”
vi: “Được rồi. Bristol, lúc tám giờ; và tôi sẽ đưa Basil đến.”
tr: “Peki. Saat sekizde Bristol’de. Ben Basil’i alırım.
es: —De acuerdo. En el Bristol alas ocho; yo llevaré a Basil.
vi_translation: “Alright. Bristol, at eight o'clock; and I will bring Basil along.”
tr_translation: “Okay. At eight o'clock in Bristol. I'll pick up Basil.”
es_translation: —Agreed. At the Bristol at eight; I will bring Basil.

en: “Not eight, Harry, please. Half-past six. We must be there before the curtain rises. You must see her in the first act, where she meets Romeo.”
vi: “Không phải tám giờ, Harry, làm ơn. Sáu rưỡi đi. Ta phải ở đó trước khi rèm lên. Anh phải thấy nàng trong hồi đầu tiên, khi nàng gặp Romeo.”
tr: “Sekiz olmaz, Harry, lütfen, altı buçuk. Perde açılmadan orada olmalıyım. İlk perdede görmelisin onu, Romeo’yla karşılaştığı zaman.
es: —A las ocho no, Harry, te lo ruego. A las seis y media. Hemos de estar allí antes de que se levante el telón. Has de verla en el primer acto, cuando conoce a Romeo.
vi_translation: “Not eight o'clock, Harry, please. Six-thirty. I have to be there before the curtain rises. You have to see her in the first act, when she meets Romeo.”
tr_translation: “Not eight, Harry, please, six-thirty. I must be there before the curtain rises. You have to see her in the first act, when she meets Romeo.”
es_translation: —Not at eight, Harry, I beg you. At six-thirty. We have to be there before the curtain rises. You have to see her in the first act, when she meets Romeo.

en: “Half-past six! What an hour! It will be like having a meat-tea, or reading an English novel. It must be seven. No gentleman dines before seven. Shall you see Basil between this and then? Or shall I write to him?”
vi: “Sáu rưỡi! Giờ gì thế này! Thế thì có khác gì uống trà thịt, hoặc đọc tiểu thuyết Anh. Phải bảy giờ. Không có người tử tế nào ăn tối trước bảy giờ cả. Cậu sẽ gặp Basil giữa giờ này và giờ sau được chứ? Hay tôi sẽ phải viết cho anh ấy?”
tr: “Altı buçuk ha! Ne tuhaf bir saat! Çay yerine et suyu içmek gibi bir şey ya da bir İngiliz romanı okumak. Yedi yapalım şunu. Hiçbir centilmen yediden önce akşam yemeği yemez. Sen bu arada Basil’i görecek misin, yoksa ben bir not yazayım mı?
es: —¡Seis y media! ¡Qué horas! Sería como tomar una merienda-cena o leer una novela inglesa. Tiene que ser a las siete. Ningún caballero cena antes de las siete. ¿He de ver a Basil de aquí a mañana? ¿O bastará con que le escriba?
vi_translation: “Six-thirty! What kind of time is this! It's no different than having meat tea or reading an English novel. It has to be seven o'clock. No decent person has dinner before seven o'clock. Will you meet Basil between this hour and the next? Or should I write to him?”
tr_translation: “Half past six, ha! What a strange hour! It's like drinking broth instead of tea or reading an English novel. Let's make it seven. No gentleman dines before seven. Will you see Basil in the meantime, or should I write a note?”
es_translation: —Six thirty! What a time! It would be like having a tea-dinner or reading an English novel. It has to be at seven. No gentleman dines before seven. Should I see Basil between now and tomorrow? Or will it be enough to write to him?

en: “Dear Basil! I have not laid eyes on him for a week. It is rather horrid of me, as he has sent me my portrait in the most wonderful frame, specially designed by himself, and, though I am a little jealous of the picture for being a whole month younger than I am, I must admit that I delight in it. Perhaps you had better write to him. I don’t want to see him alone. He says things that annoy me. He gives me good advice.”
vi: “Basil thân mến! Tôi không để mắt đến anh ấy cả tuần nay rồi. Cũng hơi quá quắt về phía tôi, vì anh ấy đã gửi cho tôi bức chân dung của tôi trong một cái khung tuyệt đẹp, được thiết kế đặc biệt bởi chính anh ấy, và, mặc dù tôi hơi ghen với bức tranh vì được trẻ hơn tôi cả tháng, tôi vẫn phải thừa nhận là tôi thích thú với nó. Có lẽ anh viết cho anh ấy thì hay hơn. Tôi không muốn gặp anh ấy một mình. Anh ấy sẽ nói những điều khiến tôi bực bội. Anh ấy cứ cho tôi những lời khuyên tốt.”
tr: “Sevgili Basil! Onu görmeyeli bir hafta oluyor. Çok ayıp oldu, çünkü bana portremi yolladı, tasarımını kendi yaptığı harika bir çerçeve içinde. Gerçi benden bir ay daha genç diye kıskanıyorum ama itiraf etmeliyim ki bayılıyorum bu portreye. Belki sen yazsan daha iyi olur. Onunla baş başa kalmak istemiyorum. Hep beni sinirlendirecek şeyler söylüyor: Çok yerinde öğütler veriyor bana.
es: —¡El bueno de Basil! Hace una semana que no le pongo la vista encima. Me da muchísima vergüenza, porque me ha enviado el cuadro con un magnífico marco, especialmente diseñado por él y, aunque estoy un poco celoso del retrato por ser un mes más joven que yo, debo admitir que me maravilla verlo. Quizá sea mejor que le escribas, no quiero estar a solas con él. Dice cosas que me fastidian. Se empeña en darme buenos consejos.
vi_translation: "Dear Basil! I haven't laid eyes on him all week." "It's a bit excessive on my part, as he sent me my portrait in a beautiful frame, specially designed by himself, and, although I'm a bit jealous of the painting for being a whole month younger than me, I must admit I am delighted with it." "Perhaps it's better if you write to him." "I don't want to meet him alone." "He will say things that annoy me." "He keeps giving me good advice."
tr_translation: "Dear Basil! It has been a week since I last saw him. It was very rude of me because he sent me my portrait, in a wonderful frame that he designed himself. Although I am jealous because he is a month younger than me, I must admit that I love this portrait. Maybe it would be better if you wrote. I don't want to be alone with him. He always says things that irritate me: He gives me very appropriate advice."
es_translation: —Good old Basil! I haven't laid eyes on him for a week. I'm very embarrassed because he sent me the painting with a magnificent frame, specially designed by him, and although I'm a bit jealous of the portrait for being a month younger than me, I must admit that it amazes me to see it. Maybe it's better if you write to him, I don't want to be alone with him. He says things that annoy me. He insists on giving me good advice.

en: Lord Henry smiled. “People are very fond of giving away what they need most themselves. It is what I call the depth of generosity.”
vi: Huân tước Henry cười. “Con người rất thích cho đi những gì mà chính họ cần hơn cả. Đó là cái mà tôi gọi là tận cùng rộng lượng.
tr: Lord Henry gülümsedi. “İnsanlar ihtiyaç duydukları şeyleri elden çıkarmaya bayılırlar. Cömertliğin en dibi, diyorum ben buna.
es: Lord Henry sonrió. —A la gente le encanta regalar lo que más necesita. Es lo que yo llamo el insondable abismo de la generosidad.
vi_translation: Lord Henry laughed. "People love to give away what they need most themselves. That is what I call the height of generosity."
tr_translation: Lord Henry smiled. “People love to get rid of the things they need. I call it the height of generosity.”
es_translation: Lord Henry smiled. —People love to give away what they need the most. It is what I call the unfathomable abyss of generosity.

en: “Oh, Basil is the best of fellows, but he seems to me to be just a bit of a Philistine. Since I have known you, Harry, I have discovered that.”
vi: “Ôi, Basil là người bạn tốt nhất, nhưng với tôi thì anh ấy dường như hơi hủ lậu một chút. Từ khi tôi quen anh, Harry, tôi mới phát hiện ra điều đó.”
tr: “Yok, Basil dünya iyisi bir adam, ama az buçuk yontulmamış gibi geliyor bana. Seni tanıdıktan sonra bunun ayırdına vardım, Harry.
es: —No, no; Basil es la mejor de las personas, pero un tanto prosaico. Lo he descubierto a raíz de conocerte, Harry.
vi_translation: “Oh, Basil is the best friend, but to me, he seems a bit old-fashioned. Since I met you, Harry, I have realized that.”
tr_translation: “No, Basil is a really good man, but he seems a bit unrefined to me. After getting to know you, I realized this, Harry.”
es_translation: —No, no; Basil is the best of people, but somewhat prosaic. I discovered this after meeting you, Harry.

en: “Basil, my dear boy, puts everything that is charming in him into his work. The consequence is that he has nothing left for life but his prejudices, his principles, and his common sense. The only artists I have ever known who are personally delightful are bad artists. Good artists exist simply in what they make, and consequently are perfectly uninteresting in what they are. A great poet, a really great poet, is the most unpoetical of all creatures. But inferior poets are absolutely fascinating. The worse their rhymes are, the more picturesque they look. The mere fact of having published a book of second-rate sonnets makes a man quite irresistible. He lives the poetry that he cannot write. The others write the poetry that they dare not realize.”
vi: “Basil, thưa cậu bé thân mến của tôi, đã đưa hết những gì quyến rũ trong anh ấy vào tác phẩm của mình. Hậu quả là anh ấy chẳng còn lại gì để sống ngoài định kiến, nguyên tắc, và trí khôn. Các nghệ sỹ duy nhất mà tôi từng biết, những kẻ hết sức thú vị về mặt cá nhân, là những nghệ sỹ tồi. Nghệ sỹ giỏi sống trọn vẹn trong cái mà họ tạo ra, và vì vậy cho nên họ hoàn toàn không thú vị chút nào trong cái vai đời mà họ phải đóng. Một thi nhân vĩ đại, một thi nhân thật sự vĩ đại, là một kẻ thiếu thi vị nhất trong mọi sinh vật. Nhưng các thi nhân kém cỏi lại tuyệt đối quyến rũ. Thơ họ càng tệ thì trông họ càng xinh. Chỉ mỗi việc xuất bản được một cuốn thơ xô-nê hạng hai cũng đủ biến người ta thành kẻ hấp dẫn đến mức hoàn toàn không thế cưỡng lại được. Y sống cái bài thơ mà y không thể viết nổi. Các thi nhân khác thì viết những bài thơ mà họ không dám hiện thực hóa.”
tr: “Sevgili çocuk, Basil kişiliğindeki tüm sevimli yönleri uğraşına aktarır. Sonuç olarak da yaşamı için kala kala önyargıları, ilkeleri, bir de sağduyusu kalır. Benim tanıdığım sanatçılardan gündelik yaşamda sevimli olanlar yalnızca kötü sanatçılardır. İyi sanatçılar yalnızca ürünlerinde var olurlar, bunun sonucu olarak da kişilikleri silik kalır. Büyük şair, gerçekten büyük olan şair, tüm yaratıkların içinde şiirden en uzak olanıdır. Oysa üçüncü, dördüncü sınıf şairler ilginçtirler. Şiirleri ne kadar kötüyse görünümleri o kadar çarpıcıdır. İkinci sınıf bir sone kitabı yayınlatmış olmak insanı resmen dayanılmaz yapmaya yeter. Bu adam yazamadığı şiiri yaşar. Ötekilerse, yani gerçek şairler hayatta gerçekleştirmeyi göze alamadıklarını şiir olarak yazarlar.
es: —Basil, mi querido muchacho, pone en el trabajo todas sus mejores cualidades. La consecuencia es que para la vida sólo le quedan los prejuicios, los principios y el sentido común. Los únicos artistas encantadores que conozco son malos artistas. Los buenos sólo existen en lo que hacen y, en consecuencia, carecen por completo de interés como personas. Un gran poeta, un poeta verdaderamente grande, es la menos poética de todas las criaturas. Pero los poetas de poca monta son absolutamente fascinantes. Cuanto peores son sus rimas, más pintoresco es su aspecto. El simple hecho de haber publicado un libro de sonetos de segunda categoría hace a un hombre absolutamente irresistible. Vive la poesía que es incapaz de escribir. Los otros escriben la poesía que no se atreven a poner por obra.
vi_translation: “Basil, my dear boy, has put all his charm into his work. As a result, he has nothing left to live on but prejudices, principles, and intellect. The only artists I have ever known who are personally delightful are bad artists. A good artist lives wholly in what he creates, and consequently has no life in anything else. A great poet, a really great poet, is the most unpoetical of all creatures. But inferior poets are absolutely fascinating. The worse their rhymes, the more picturesque they look. The mere fact of having published a second-rate sonnet makes a man quite irresistible. He lives the poetry that he cannot write. The others write the poetry that they dare not realize.”
tr_translation: “Dear child, Basil channels all the charming aspects of his personality into his work. As a result, all that remains for his life are his prejudices, principles, and common sense. Among the artists I know, those who are charming in everyday life are only the bad artists. Good artists exist solely in their works, and as a result, their personalities remain dull. The great poet, the truly great poet, is the one who is the furthest from poetry among all creatures. However, third and fourth-rate poets are interesting. The worse their poetry, the more striking their appearance. Having published a second-rate sonnet book is enough to make a person utterly unbearable. This man lives the poetry he cannot write. The others, the real poets, write as poetry what they dare not achieve in life.”
es_translation: —Basil, my dear boy, puts all his best qualities into his work. The consequence is that for life he is left with only prejudices, principles, and common sense. The only charming artists I know are bad artists. The good ones exist only in what they do and, consequently, are completely uninteresting as people. A great poet, a truly great poet, is the least poetic of all creatures. But the lesser poets are absolutely fascinating. The worse their rhymes, the more picturesque their appearance. The mere fact of having published a second-rate book of sonnets makes a man absolutely irresistible. He lives the poetry he is incapable of writing. The others write the poetry they do not dare to enact.

en: “I wonder is that really so, Harry?” said Dorian Gray, putting some perfume on his handkerchief out of a large, gold-topped bottle that stood on the table. “It must be, if you say it. And now I am off. Imogen is waiting for me. Don’t forget about to-morrow. Good-bye.”
vi: “Tôi tự hỏi điều đó có thật vậy không, Harry?” Dorian Gray nói, tẩm chút nước hoa lên chiếc khăn tay của mình từ một cái chai nắp vàng khá lớn vẫn để trên bàn. “Chắc là thế thôi, nếu anh đã nói thế. Còn bây giờ tôi đi đây. Imogen đang đợi tôi. Đừng quên chuyện ngày mai nhé. Tạm biệt.”
tr: Dorian, “Bilmem ki Harry, böyle mi gerçekten?” diyerek masanın üstündeki altın tıpalı büyük şişeden mendiline biraz koku sürdü. “Öyle olsa gerek, mademki sen öyle diyorsun. Şimdi artık ben gidiyorum. Imogen bekliyor. Yarını unutma, ha! Hoşça kal.
es: —Me pregunto si es realmente así, Harry —dijo Dorian Gray, derramando sobre su pañuelo un poco de perfume de un gran frasco con tapón dorado que estaba sobre la mesa—. Debe de ser, si tú lo dices. Y ahora tengo que marcharme. Imogen me espera. No te olvides de mañana. Hasta la vista.
vi_translation: “I wonder if that is really true, Harry?” Dorian Gray said, dabbing some perfume on his handkerchief from a rather large gold-capped bottle that was still on the table. “It must be, if you say so. Now I must go. Imogen is waiting for me. Don't forget about tomorrow. Goodbye.”
tr_translation: Dorian, "I don't know, Harry, is it really like that?" he said, applying some perfume from the large bottle with the golden stopper onto his handkerchief. "It must be, since you say so. Now I am leaving. Imogen is waiting. Don't forget about tomorrow, okay? Goodbye."
es_translation: —I wonder if it is really so, Harry —said Dorian Gray, pouring a bit of perfume from a large bottle with a golden stopper that was on the table onto his handkerchief—. It must be, if you say so. And now I have to leave. Imogen is waiting for me. Don't forget about tomorrow. See you later.

en: As he left the room, Lord Henry’s heavy eyelids drooped, and he began to think. Certainly few people had ever interested him so much as Dorian Gray, and yet the lad’s mad adoration of some one else caused him not the slightest pang of annoyance or jealousy. He was pleased by it. It made him a more interesting study. He had been always enthralled by the methods of natural science, but the ordinary subject-matter of that science had seemed to him trivial and of no import. And so he had begun by vivisecting himself, as he had ended by vivisecting others. Human life—that appeared to him the one thing worth investigating. Compared to it there was nothing else of any value. It was true that as one watched life in its curious crucible of pain and pleasure, one could not wear over one’s face a mask of glass, nor keep the sulphurous fumes from troubling the brain and making the imagination turbid with monstrous fancies and misshapen dreams. There were poisons so subtle that to know their properties one had to sicken of them. There were maladies so strange that one had to pass through them if one sought to understand their nature. And, yet, what a great reward one received! How wonderful the whole world became to one! To note the curious hard logic of passion, and the emotional coloured life of the intellect—to observe where they met, and where they separated, at what point they were in unison, and at what point they were at discord—there was a delight in that! What matter what the cost was? One could never pay too high a price for any sensation.
vi: Lúc cậu rời phòng, cặp mi mắt nặng trĩu của huân tước Henry rũ xuống, và y bắt đầu nghĩ. Chắc chắn chỉ có vài người từng khiến y quan tâm đến nhiều như Dorian Gray, tuy nhiên sự sùng bái điên dại của chàng trai với ai đó khác cũng chẳng gây ra cho y mảy may dằn vặt ghen tuông hay phiền muộn nào. Y hài lòng với chuyện này. Nó biến cậu thành một đối tượng nghiên cứu thú vị hơn. Y luôn bị mê hoặc bởi các phương pháp của khoa học tự nhiên, nhưng chủ đề thông thường của môn khoa học ấy với y dường như rất tầm phào và không quan trọng. Vậy nên y đã bắt đầu bằng việc mổ sống chính mình, cũng như y đã kết thúc bằng việc mổ sống kẻ khác. Đời người — nó xuất hiện trước y như một thứ đáng để nghiên cứu kỹ lưỡng. So với nó thì chẳng còn thứ gì khác có chút giá trị nào. Đúng là khi ta nhìn đời trong cái lò luyện kỳ lạ toàn những nỗi đau và niềm vui của nó, ta không thể đeo mặt nạ kính để che mặt, cũng không thể giữ cho khói lưu huỳnh không hành hạ não, và khiến cho trí tưởng tượng bị vẩn đục bởi những ảo giác quái dị và những giấc mộng méo mó. Có những độc chất tinh vi đến nỗi để biết được các đặc tính của chúng thì ta phải bị ốm vì chúng. Có những chứng bệnh lạ lùng đến nỗi ta phải trải qua chúng nếu ta tìm cách hiểu bản chất của chúng. Tuy nhiên, ta sẽ được nhận phần thưởng vĩ đại biết bao! Cả thế giới sẽ trở nên tuyệt diệu nhường nào với ta! Để ghi nhớ được lô-gich khắc nghiệt lạ lùng của niềm đam mê, và cuộc đời cảm xúc đa sắc của trí tuệ — để quan sát xem chúng gặp nhau ở đâu, chúng chia tay ở đâu, tại điểm nào chúng hòa hợp, tại điểm nào chúng bất hòa — có một niềm khoái cảm trong việc ấy! Giá cả thế nào thì quan trọng gì? Ta có lẽ chưa từng trả quá cao cho cái giá của bất cứ cảm giác nào.
tr: Dorian dışarı çıkınca Lord Henry ağır gözkapaklarını indirerek düşünmeye başladı. Şurası bir gerçek ki onu Dorian Gray kadar ilgilendiren pek az kişi çıkmıştı. Gene de çocuğun başka birine çılgınca tutulmuş olması genç lorda zerrece kıskançlık ya da can sıkıntısı vermiyordu. Tersine, hoşuna gidiyordu onun. Bu tutku Dorian Gray’i daha ilginç, incelemeye değer kılıyordu. Lord Henry oldum olası doğa bilimlerine karşı derin bir merak beslemiş, gelgelelim bu bilimlerin sıradan konularını önemsiz, enti püften bulmuştu. Böylece o da kendi kendini mikroskop altına koyarak incelemekle işe başlamış, sonunda başkalarını didikleyip inceler olmuştu. İnsan yaşamı: Lord Henry’nin gözünde incelemeye değer olan tek şey buydu. Bu kadar değerli bir şey olamazdı. Gerçi inceleyen kişi yaşamı acılarla sevinçlerin karışımıyla dolu olan deney tüpünün içinde gözlemlerken, yüzüne camdan maske takamıyor, zehirli buharların beyni etkileyerek imgelemin garip fanteziler, şekilsiz hayallerle zonklamasını engelleyemiyordu. Öylesine sinsi zehirler vardı ki, insanın onların niteliklerini ayırt edebilmesi için onlarla zehirlenmesi gerekti. Gene de bu inceleme en sonunda insana nasıl da şahane bir ödül veriyordu! Dünya insanın gözünde nasıl da harikulade olup çıkıyordu! Tutkunun o tuhaf, katı mantığını ve zihnin duygusallıkla renklenen yaşantısını fark etmek, bu ikisinin nerede bir araya geldiklerini, nerede ayrıldıklarını, nerede uzlaşıp nerede çatıştıklarını gözlemlemek... Ne büyük bir kıvanç gizliydi bunda! Pahası kimin umurunda? Hiçbir heyecanın bedeli aşırı yüksek sayılmazdı.
es: Cuando Dorian Gray salió de la habitación, lord Henry cerró los ojos y empezó a pensar. Ciertamente, pocas personas le habían interesado tanto como Dorian Gray, si bien la desmedida adoración del muchacho por otra persona no le producía la menor punzada de fastidio ni de celos. Le agradaba, por el contrario. Lo convertía en un objeto de estudio más interesante. Siempre le habían cautivado los métodos de las ciencias naturales, pero no su materia habitual, que le parecía trivial y sin importancia. De manera que había empezado por hacer vivisección consigo mismo y había terminado haciéndosela a otros. La vida humana era lo único que le parecía digno de investigar. Comparado con eso, no había nada que tuviera el menor valor. Aunque si se contemplaba la vida en su curioso crisol de dolor y placer, no era posible cubrir el propio rostro con una máscara de cristal, ni evitar que los vapores sulfúricos alterasen el cerebro y enturbiaran la imaginación con monstruosas fantasías y sueños deformes. Existían venenos tan sutiles que para conocer sus propiedades había que enfermar con ellos. Y enfermedades tan extrañas que era necesario padecerlas para entender su naturaleza. ¡Qué grande, sin embargo, la recompensa recibida! ¡Qué cosa tan maravillosa llegaba a ser el mundo entero! Percibir la peculiar lógica inflexible de la pasión, y la vida del intelecto emocionalmente coloreada; observar dónde se encontraban y dónde se separaban, en qué punto funcionaban al unísono y en qué punto surgían las discordancias: ¡qué gran placer el así obtenido! ¿Qué importancia tenía el precio? Nunca se pagaba demasiado por las sensaciones.
vi_translation: When he left the room, Lord Henry's heavy eyelids drooped, and he began to think. Surely, only a few people had ever interested him as much as Dorian Gray, yet the young man's mad adoration for someone else did not cause him the slightest pang of jealousy or distress. He was pleased with this. It made him a more interesting subject for study. He had always been fascinated by the methods of natural science, but the usual subjects of that science seemed to him trivial and unimportant. So he had begun with the vivisection of himself, as he had ended with the vivisection of others. Life — it appeared to him as something to be studied minutely. Nothing else seemed to be of any value in comparison. Indeed, when one looks at life in its strange crucible of pain and pleasure, one cannot wear a mask to shield the face, nor keep the fumes of sulfur from tormenting the brain, and clouding the imagination with monstrous fancies and distorted dreams. There are subtle poisons so exquisite that to know their properties one has to fall ill from them. There are strange maladies so bizarre that one has to go through them to understand their nature. Yet, how great the reward will be! How wonderful the world will become to us! To remember the strange, relentless logic of passion, and the multicolored life of the intellect — to observe where they meet, where they part, at what points they harmonize, at what points they are at odds — there is a pleasure in that! What does the cost matter? Perhaps we have never paid too high a price for any sensation.
tr_translation: When Dorian went out, Lord Henry closed his heavy eyelids and began to ponder. The fact was that there were very few people who interested him as much as Dorian Gray did. Yet, the young lord felt not the slightest jealousy or annoyance that the boy was madly infatuated with someone else. On the contrary, he found it pleasing. This passion made Dorian Gray more interesting, more worthy of study. Lord Henry had always harbored a deep curiosity about the natural sciences, though he found their ordinary subjects trivial and insignificant. Thus, he began by examining himself under the microscope, eventually turning to dissect and study others. Human life: this was the only thing worth examining in Lord Henry's eyes. Nothing could be as valuable. Indeed, while the observer watched life in the test tube filled with a mixture of pains and joys, he could not wear a glass mask, nor could he prevent the poisonous vapors from affecting his brain, causing his imagination to throb with strange fantasies and shapeless dreams. There were such insidious poisons that one had to be poisoned by them to discern their qualities. Yet, in the end, how magnificent a reward this examination gave to a person! How marvelous the world became in one's eyes! To notice the strange, rigid logic of passion and the experiences of the mind tinged with sentimentality, to observe where these two converged, where they diverged, where they reconciled, and where they clashed... What a great delight was hidden in this! Who cared about the cost? No excitement's price was too high.
es_translation: When Dorian Gray left the room, Lord Henry closed his eyes and began to think. Certainly, few people had interested him as much as Dorian Gray, although the boy's excessive adoration for another person did not cause him the slightest twinge of annoyance or jealousy. On the contrary, he liked it. It made him a more interesting object of study. He had always been fascinated by the methods of the natural sciences, but not by their usual subject matter, which seemed trivial and unimportant to him. So he had started by performing vivisection on himself and had ended up doing it to others. Human life was the only thing that seemed worthy of investigation to him. Compared to that, nothing else had the slightest value. Although if one contemplated life in its curious crucible of pain and pleasure, it was not possible to cover one's face with a crystal mask, nor to prevent the sulfurous vapors from altering the brain and clouding the imagination with monstrous fantasies and deformed dreams. There were poisons so subtle that to know their properties one had to fall ill with them. And diseases so strange that it was necessary to suffer from them to understand their nature. How great, however, was the reward received! How wonderful the whole world became! To perceive the peculiar inflexible logic of passion, and the life of the intellect emotionally colored; to observe where they met and where they separated, at what point they functioned in unison and at what point discordances arose: what great pleasure was thus obtained! What did the price matter? One never paid too much for sensations.

en: He was conscious—and the thought brought a gleam of pleasure into his brown agate eyes—that it was through certain words of his, musical words said with musical utterance, that Dorian Gray’s soul had turned to this white girl and bowed in worship before her. To a large extent the lad was his own creation. He had made him premature. That was something. Ordinary people waited till life disclosed to them its secrets, but to the few, to the elect, the mysteries of life were revealed before the veil was drawn away. Sometimes this was the effect of art, and chiefly of the art of literature, which dealt immediately with the passions and the intellect. But now and then a complex personality took the place and assumed the office of art, was indeed, in its way, a real work of art, life having its elaborate masterpieces, just as poetry has, or sculpture, or painting.
vi: Y nhận ra — và ý nghĩ ấy đem một tia hoan lạc vào trong đôi mắt nâu mã não của y — rằng nhờ vài lời nào đó của y, những lời du dương được nói với cách phát âm du dương, mà tâm hồn Dorian Gray đã quay qua cô gái trắng muốt này và cúi đầu tôn kính trước cô. Ở một mức độ rất lớn, chàng trai là tạo tác của chính y. Y tạo ra cậu ấy hơi non. Việc ấy cũng có cái đúng. Người thường sẽ chờ cho đến khi cuộc sống để lộ các bí mật ra với họ, nhưng với vài người, với ai được chọn, những sự huyền bí của cuộc sống sẽ lộ ra trước khi tấm mạng che bị gạt đi. Đôi lúc đó là tác động của nghệ thuật, và chủ yếu của nghệ thuật văn chương, thứ vẫn có quan hệ trực tiếp với đam mê và trí tuệ. Nhưng thỉnh thoảng, một cá tính phức tạp giành chỗ và chiếm lấy trụ sở của nghệ thuật; do thật sự, theo cách riêng, vốn là một công việc nghệ thuật chân chính, nên Cuộc sống có những kiệt tác công phu của nó, hệt như thơ, hay điêu khắc, hay hội họa vẫn có.
