tr: Lord Henry şunun bilincindeydi ki –ve bunu bilmek o akik rengindeki gözlerine bir zevk ışıltısı veriyordu– onun söylediği birtakım sözler yüzünden, ezgili bir sesle söylenmiş ezgili sözler yüzünden Dorian Gray’in ruhu bu zambak kıza doğru dönmüş, bu kızın önünde secdeye gelmişti. Çocuk, büyük oranda onun yaratımıydı. Lord Henry erken geliştirmişti onu. Bu da bir şeydi. Olağan insanlar, yaşam onlara gizlerini açsın diye beklerlerdi. Gelgelelim bir avuç seçkin kişiye yaşamın gizleri daha perde açılmadan önce görünürdü. Kimileyin sanatın, özellikle de yazın sanatının etkisiyle olurdu bu; çünkü yazın sanatı tutkularla ve zihinle doğrudan doğruya haşır neşirdir. Kimileyin de karmaşık bir kişilik sanatın yerine geçip, onun görevini üstlenir, kısacası kendince gerçek bir sanat ürünü olup çıkardı. Hayatın da tıpkı şiir gibi, heykel, resim gibi, özene bezene yarattığı başyapıtları vardır.
es: Sabía perfectamente -y la idea produjo un brillo de placer en sus ojos de ágata— que gracias a determinadas palabras suyas, palabras musicales dichas de manera musical, el alma de Dorian Gray se había vuelto hacia aquella blanca jovencita y se había inclinado en adoración ante ella. En gran medida aquel muchacho era una creación suya. Había acelerado su madurez, lo que no carecía de importancia. La gente ordinaria esperaba a que la vida les desvelase sus secretos, pero para unos pocos, para los elegidos, la vida revelaba sus misterios antes de apartar el velo. Esto era a veces consecuencia del arte, y sobre todo del arte de la literatura, que se ocupa de manera inmediata de las pasiones y de la inteligencia. Pero de cuando en cuando una personalidad compleja ocupaba su sitio y asumía las funciones del arte, y era, de hecho, a su manera, una verdadera obra de arte, porque, al igual que la poesía, la escultura o la pintura, la vida cuenta con refinadas obras maestras.
vi_translation: He realized — and the thought brought a gleam of delight into his agate-brown eyes — that thanks to some words of his, melodious words spoken with a melodious accent, Dorian Gray's soul had turned towards this pure white girl and bowed reverently before her. To a very large extent, the young man was his own creation. He had fashioned him a bit prematurely. There was some rightness in that. Ordinary people would wait until life revealed its secrets to them, but for a few, for those chosen, the mysteries of life would unveil themselves before the veil was lifted. Sometimes it is the influence of art, and primarily of literary art, which has a direct connection with passion and intellect. But occasionally, a complex personality takes the place and assumes the role of art; for indeed, in its own way, being a true work of art, Life has its elaborate masterpieces, just as poetry, or sculpture, or painting does.
tr_translation: Lord Henry was aware –and knowing this gave a gleam of pleasure to his agate-colored eyes– that because of some words he had said, words spoken in a melodious voice, Dorian Gray's soul had turned towards this lily-like girl, had bowed before her. The boy was largely his creation. Lord Henry had developed him early. That was something. Ordinary people waited for life to reveal its secrets to them. However, to a handful of select individuals, life's secrets were revealed before the curtain even rose. Sometimes this happened under the influence of art, especially literature; because literature deals directly with passions and the mind. Sometimes a complex personality would take the place of art, assuming its role, in short, becoming a true work of art in its own right. Life, just like poetry, sculpture, and painting, has its meticulously created masterpieces.
es_translation: He knew perfectly well—and the idea produced a gleam of pleasure in his agate eyes—that thanks to certain words of his, musical words spoken in a musical manner, the soul of Dorian Gray had turned towards that white young girl and had bowed in adoration before her. To a great extent, that boy was his creation. He had accelerated his maturity, which was not insignificant. Ordinary people waited for life to unveil its secrets to them, but for a few, for the chosen ones, life revealed its mysteries before lifting the veil. This was sometimes a consequence of art, and especially of the art of literature, which deals immediately with passions and intelligence. But every now and then a complex personality took its place and assumed the functions of art, and was, in fact, in its own way, a true work of art, because, like poetry, sculpture, or painting, life has refined masterpieces.

en: Yes, the lad was premature. He was gathering his harvest while it was yet spring. The pulse and passion of youth were in him, but he was becoming self-conscious. It was delightful to watch him. With his beautiful face, and his beautiful soul, he was a thing to wonder at. It was no matter how it all ended, or was destined to end. He was like one of those gracious figures in a pageant or a play, whose joys seem to be remote from one, but whose sorrows stir one’s sense of beauty, and whose wounds are like red roses.
vi: Vâng, chàng trai hơi non. Y đã thu hoạch vụ chiêm lúc trời hãy còn xuân. Nhịp đập đam mê thanh xuân hãy còn trong cậu, nhưng cậu đã bắt đầu có ý thức về bản thân. Thật thú vị khi quan sát cậu. Với khuôn mặt tuyệt đẹp và tâm hồn tuyệt đẹp, cậu là một tạo vật gây kinh ngạc. Chẳng quan trọng mọi chuyện kết thúc ra sao, hoặc đã phải chịu định mệnh kết thúc thế nào. Cậu giống như một trong những nhân vật từ bi ấy trong một đám rước lộng lẫy hoặc một vở kịch, mà những niềm vui của người dường như rất xa cách ta, song các nỗi buồn của người lại khơi gợi khả năng thưởng thức cái đẹp trong ta, và các vết thương của người hệt như những đóa hoa hồng.
tr: Evet, genç adam zamanından önce gelişmişti. Hasadını baharda kaldırıyordu. Gençliğin yaşam hızı ve ateşiyle doluydu ve kendi varoluşunun bilincine de varmaya başlıyordu. Büyük zevkti onu gözlemlemek. O güzel yüzü, güzel ruhuyla delikanlı inanılması güç bir şeydi, doğrusu. Sonun nasıl geleceğinden, alnına neler yazılmış olduğundan kime ne? Bir sahne oyunundaki, bir karnavaldaki kişileri andırıyordu: Hani sevinçleri bizden uzakmış gibi gelir de, acıları güzellik duyumuzu okşar ve yaraları kırmızı güller gibi kanar.
es: Sí; el adolescente era precoz. Estaba recogiendo la cosecha todavía en primavera. Tenía dentro de sí el latido y la pasión de la juventud, pero empezaba a reflexionar sobre todo ello. Era delicioso contemplarlo. Con su hermoso rostro y su alma igualmente hermosa, era un motivo de asombro. Daba lo mismo cómo terminara todo o cómo estuviese destinado a terminar. Era como una de esas figuras llenas de encanto en una cabalgata o en una obra de teatro, cuyas alegrías nos parecen muy lejanas, pero cuyos pesares despiertan nuestro sentido de la belleza, y cuyas heridas son como rosas rojas.
vi_translation: Yes, the young man is a bit inexperienced. He harvested the winter crop while it was still spring. The pulse of youthful passion still beats within him, but he has begun to develop self-awareness. It is truly interesting to observe him. With a beautiful face and a beautiful soul, he is a creature of wonder. It doesn't matter how things end, or what fate has decreed for the end. He is like one of those compassionate characters in a magnificent procession or a play, whose joys seem very distant from us, yet whose sorrows evoke our capacity to appreciate beauty, and whose wounds are like roses.
tr_translation: Yes, the young man had matured ahead of his time. He was reaping his harvest in the spring. He was filled with the speed and fire of youth and was beginning to become aware of his own existence. It was a great pleasure to observe him. That beautiful face, with his beautiful soul, the young man was truly something unbelievable. Who cares how the end will come, or what is written on his forehead? He resembled characters from a stage play, from a carnival: You know, their joys seem distant from us, their sorrows caress our sense of beauty, and their wounds bleed like red roses.
es_translation: Yes; the teenager was precocious. He was harvesting still in spring. He had within him the heartbeat and passion of youth, but he was beginning to reflect on it all. It was delightful to watch him. With his beautiful face and equally beautiful soul, he was a source of wonder. It didn't matter how it all ended or how it was destined to end. He was like one of those charming figures in a parade or a play, whose joys seem very distant to us, but whose sorrows awaken our sense of beauty, and whose wounds are like red roses.

en: Soul and body, body and soul—how mysterious they were! There was animalism in the soul, and the body had its moments of spirituality. The senses could refine, and the intellect could degrade. Who could say where the fleshly impulse ceased, or the psychical impulse began? How shallow were the arbitrary definitions of ordinary psychologists! And yet how difficult to decide between the claims of the various schools! Was the soul a shadow seated in the house of sin? Or was the body really in the soul, as Giordano Bruno thought? The separation of spirit from matter was a mystery, and the union of spirit with matter was a mystery also.
vi: Tâm hồn và thể xác, thể xác và tâm hồn — sao mà chúng bí ẩn làm vậy! Có thú tính trong tâm hồn, và thể xác có những khoảnh khắc tâm linh của nó. Cảm giác có thể tinh luyện, còn trí tuệ có thể thoái hóa. Ai có thể nói ở đâu thì sự thôi thúc nhục dục dừng lại, hoặc sự thôi thúc tự nhiên bắt đầu? Sao chúng lại nông cạn đến thế, các định nghĩa độc đoán của các nhà tâm lý học tầm thường! Tuy vậy, rất khó để lựa chọn giữa các sự khẳng định của những trường phái khác nhau! Có phải tâm hồn là cái bóng ngồi trong ngôi nhà của tội lỗi? Hay có phải thể xác thực sự ở trong tâm hồn, như Giordano Bruno từng nghĩ? Sự chia cắt tinh thần khỏi vật chất là một điều huyền bí, và sự hợp nhất tinh thần với vật chất cũng là một điều huyền bí như thế.
tr: Ruh ve beden, bedenle ruh: Nasıl da gizemliydiler! Ruh hayvanlaşabiliyor, beden de sırasında ruh kesiliyordu. Duyguların yücelttiğini zihin aşağılayabiliyordu. Tensel itkinin nerede bitip fizik itkinin nerede başladığını kim bilebilirdi? Sıradan ruhbilimcilerin gelişigüzel tanımlamaları nasıl da sığdı! Öte yandan çeşitli ruhbilim okullarının savları arasında seçim yapmak ne kadar zordu! Ruh acaba günah evinin içinde oturan bir gölge miydi? Yoksa beden mi aslında ruhun içindeydi, Giardano Bruno’nun düşündüğü gibi. Ruhun maddeden ayrılması da bir sırdı, tıpkı ruhun maddeyle birleşmesinin bir sır olduğu gibi.
es: Alma y cuerpo, cuerpo y alma, ¡qué misteriosos eran! Había animalismo en el alma, y el cuerpo tenía sus momentos de espiritualidad. Los sentidos podían refinarse y la inteligencia degradarse. ¿Quién podía decir dónde cesaba el impulso carnal o empezaba el psíquico? ¡Qué superficiales eran las arbitrarias definiciones de los psicólogos ordinarios! Y, sin embargo, ¡qué dificil pronunciarse entre las afirmaciones de las distintas escuelas! ¿Era el alma un fantasma que habitaba en la casa del pecado? ¿O el cuerpo se funde realmente con el alma, como pensaba Giordano Bruno? La separación entre espíritu y materia era un misterio, y la unión del espíritu con la materia también lo era.
vi_translation: The soul and the body, the body and the soul — how mysterious they are! There is animal instinct in the soul, and the body has its moments of spirituality. Sensations can be refined, while intellect can degenerate. Who can say where the urge of lust ends, or the natural impulse begins? How shallow are the arbitrary definitions of mediocre psychologists! Yet, it is very difficult to choose between the assertions of different schools of thought! Is the soul the shadow sitting in the house of sin? Or is the body truly within the soul, as Giordano Bruno once thought? The separation of spirit from matter is a mystery, and the union of spirit with matter is just as much a mystery.
tr_translation: Spirit and body, body and spirit: How mysterious they were! The spirit could become animalistic, and the body could at times become spirit. What the emotions exalted, the mind could disdain. Who could know where the physical impulse ended and the bodily impulse began? How shallow were the haphazard definitions of ordinary psychologists! On the other hand, how difficult it was to choose among the claims of various psychological schools! Was the spirit a shadow residing within the house of sin? Or was the body actually within the spirit, as Giardano Bruno thought? The separation of the spirit from matter was a mystery, just as the union of the spirit with matter was a mystery.
es_translation: Soul and body, body and soul, how mysterious they were! There was animalism in the soul, and the body had its moments of spirituality. The senses could be refined and the intelligence degraded. Who could say where the carnal impulse ceased or the psychic one began? How superficial were the arbitrary definitions of ordinary psychologists! And yet, how difficult it was to take a stance between the assertions of the different schools! Was the soul a ghost that inhabited the house of sin? Or did the body truly merge with the soul, as Giordano Bruno thought? The separation between spirit and matter was a mystery, and the union of spirit with matter was also one.

en: He began to wonder whether we could ever make psychology so absolute a science that each little spring of life would be revealed to us. As it was, we always misunderstood ourselves and rarely understood others. Experience was of no ethical value. It was merely the name men gave to their mistakes. Moralists had, as a rule, regarded it as a mode of warning, had claimed for it a certain ethical efficacy in the formation of character, had praised it as something that taught us what to follow and showed us what to avoid. But there was no motive power in experience. It was as little of an active cause as conscience itself. All that it really demonstrated was that our future would be the same as our past, and that the sin we had done once, and with loathing, we would do many times, and with joy.
vi: Y bắt đầu tự hỏi không biết ta có thể biến tâm lý học thành một môn khoa học thuần túy để mỗi vết nứt nhỏ của đời đều bị lộ ra trước ta hay không. Tuy nhiên ta luôn hiểu lầm về mình và hiếm khi hiểu được người khác. Kinh nghiệm không có giá trị luân thường đạo lý nào cả. Nó chỉ là cái tên mà con người gán cho các lỗi lầm của mình. Các nhà đạo đức học, theo lệ thường, xem nó như một phương thức cảnh báo, đã đòi cho nó một hiệu lực luân lý nhất định trong sự hình thành tính cách, đã tán dương nó như thứ gì đó dạy ta biết điều gì nên theo đuổi và cho ta thấy điều gì nên tránh. Nhưng không có động lực nào trong kinh nghiệm. Nó cũng ít mục đích tích cực như chính lương tâm. Mọi điều mà nó thật sự chứng minh được chỉ là tương lai ta cũng chẳng khác gì quá khứ ta, và cái tội lỗi mà ta từng có lần phạm phải, cùng với nỗi kinh tởm, thì ta vẫn sẽ phạm tiếp nhiều lần nữa, mà với niềm vui.
tr: Lord Henry merak etmeye başlamıştı: Acaba psikolojiyi alabildiğine kesin, mutlak bir bilim dalı haline getirerek en küçük yaşam pınarlarının bile göz önüne serilmesini sağlamak elimizde miydi? Şu durumda kendi kendimizi hep yanlış anlıyor, başkalarını da pek seyrek anlayabiliyorduk. Deneyim denen şey etik yönden bir değer taşımıyordu. İnsanların hatalarına verdikleri bir addan ibaretti. Ahlakçılar genel olarak bunu bir tür uyarı saymışlar, kişiliğin gelişmesinde etik bir yararı olduğunu ileri sürmüşler, neyi izleyip neden kaçınacağımıza ilişkin bir işaret diye övünmüşlerdi. Şu var ki deneyimde itici güç yoktu. Oynadığı etkin rol vicdanın rolü kadar önemsizdi. Ortaya koyduğu tek gerçek, geleceğimizin de geçmişimize eş olacağıydı; bundan önce bir kez, tiksinerek işlediğimiz günahı bundan böyle birçok kez işleyecektik, hem de seve seve.
es: Empezó a preguntarse si alguna vez se conseguiría hacer de la psicología una ciencia tan exacta que fuese capaz de revelarnos hasta el último manantial de la vida. Mientras tanto, siempre nos equivocamos sobre nosotros mismos y raras veces entendemos a los demás. La experiencia carece de valor ético. Es sencillamente el nombre que dan los hombres a sus errores. Por regla general los moralistas la consideran una advertencia, reclaman para ella cierta eficacia ética en la formación del carácter, la alaban como algo que nos enseña qué camino hemos de seguir y qué abismos evitar. Pero la experiencia carece de fuerza determinante. Tiene tan poco de causa activa como la misma conciencia. Lo único que realmente demuestra es que nuestro futuro será igual a nuestro pasado, y que el pecado que hemos cometido una vez, y con amargura, lo repetiremos muchas veces, y con alegría.
vi_translation: Y began to wonder if it was possible to turn psychology into a pure science so that every small crack in life would be exposed before us. However, we always misunderstand ourselves and rarely understand others. Experience has no moral value at all. It is merely the name people give to their mistakes. Ethicists, as usual, see it as a warning method, demand a certain moral efficacy in character formation for it, and praise it as something that teaches us what to pursue and shows us what to avoid. But there is no motivation in experience. It has as little positive purpose as conscience itself. All it truly proves is that our future will be no different from our past, and the sin we once committed with disgust, we will continue to commit many times more, but with joy.
tr_translation: Lord Henry had begun to wonder: Was it within our power to turn psychology into an absolutely precise and definitive science, thereby ensuring that even the smallest springs of life were laid bare? In that case, we were always misunderstanding ourselves and rarely understanding others. What was called experience had no ethical value. It was merely a name people gave to their mistakes. Moralists generally considered it a kind of warning, claimed it had an ethical benefit in the development of personality, and boasted that it was a sign of what to follow and what to avoid. However, there was no driving force in experience. The active role it played was as insignificant as the role of conscience. The only truth it revealed was that our future would be equal to our past; we would commit the sin we once committed with disgust many times in the future, and this time with pleasure.
es_translation: He began to wonder if psychology would ever become such an exact science that it could reveal to us the very last spring of life. Meanwhile, we always make mistakes about ourselves and rarely understand others. Experience lacks ethical value. It is simply the name men give to their errors. Generally, moralists consider it a warning, claim for it some ethical efficacy in character formation, and praise it as something that teaches us which path to follow and which abysses to avoid. But experience lacks determining force. It has as little active cause as conscience itself. The only thing it really proves is that our future will be the same as our past, and that the sin we have committed once, and with bitterness, we will repeat many times, and with joy.

en: It was clear to him that the experimental method was the only method by which one could arrive at any scientific analysis of the passions; and certainly Dorian Gray was a subject made to his hand, and seemed to promise rich and fruitful results. His sudden mad love for Sibyl Vane was a psychological phenomenon of no small interest. There was no doubt that curiosity had much to do with it, curiosity and the desire for new experiences, yet it was not a simple, but rather a very complex passion. What there was in it of the purely sensuous instinct of boyhood had been transformed by the workings of the imagination, changed into something that seemed to the lad himself to be remote from sense, and was for that very reason all the more dangerous. It was the passions about whose origin we deceived ourselves that tyrannized most strongly over us. Our weakest motives were those of whose nature we were conscious. It often happened that when we thought we were experimenting on others we were really experimenting on ourselves.
vi: Y thấy rõ rằng phương pháp thực nghiệm là phương pháp duy nhất mà theo nó thì ta có thể đạt tới bất cứ phân tích khoa học nào về niềm đam mê; và chắc chắn Dorian Gray là một đối tượng được tạo vừa tay y, và dường như hứa hẹn những kết quả phong phú và hữu ích. Tình yêu điên cuồng đột ngột của cậu ta với Sybil Vane là một hiện tượng tâm lý không mấy quan trọng. Chắc chắn rằng sự tò mò có liên quan rất nhiều với chuyện đó, sự tò mò và nỗi khát khao những kinh nghiệm mới mẻ; tuy nhiên nó không phải là một niềm đam mê đơn giản mà rất phức tạp thì đúng hơn. Những gì đã có trong nó thực ra là bản năng nhục dục thời niên thiếu bị biến đổi bởi những hoạt động của trí tưởng tượng, chuyển hóa thành cái gì đó mà dường như với chính chàng trai lại tách rất xa khỏi cảm giác, và vì chính lý do đó mà nó lại còn nguy hiểm hơn. Chính những đam mê mà ta vẫn tự lừa mình về nguồn gốc của chúng lại là những thứ hành ta dữ nhất. Các mô-típ yếu nhất của ta là những thứ mà bản chất chúng là cái ta không nhận thức được. Thường thì khi ta tưởng ta đang thử người, thật ra ta lại đang thử mình.
tr: Lord Henry şunu açıkça görüyordu ki insanı tutkuların bilimsel irdelenmesine götürecek tek yol deneysel yöntemdi. Dorian Gray de gerçekten onun için biçilmiş kaftan bir denekti, parlak, verimli sonuçlar vaat ediyordu. Sibyl Vane’e karşı ansızın kapıldığı bu çılgın tutku, ilginçlik yönü hiç de küçümsenmeyecek, olağandışı psikolojik bir olaydı. Bunda merakın büyük rol oynadığı hiç kuşku götürmezdi, merak ve yenilik isteği. Gene de basit bir tutku değildi bu, çok karmaşıktı. Bileşimindeki gençlikten gelen şehvet güdüsü, imgelemin etkisiyle değişime uğramış, çocuğun kendi gözüne mantıktan, sağduyudan uzak görünen, bu yüzden de büsbütün tehlikeli olan bir duyguya dönüşmüştü. Kaynakları konusunda kendi kendimizi aldattığımız tutkulardı üzerimizde en amansız baskıları kuran. En cılız itkilerimiz de niteliğini bildiklerimizdi. Çok zaman başkaları üstünde deneyler yaptığımızı sandığımız sırada, gerçekte kendi üzerimizde deneyler yapıyorduk.
es: Consideraba evidente que el método experimental era el único que le llevaría al análisis científico de las pasiones; Dorian Gray, por su parte, era el sujeto soñado, y parecía prometer abundantes y preciosos resultados. Su repentino e insensato amor por Sybil Vane era un fenómeno psicológico de interés nada desdeñable. Sin duda, la curiosidad tenía mucho que ver con ello; la curiosidad y el deseo de nuevas experiencias; no se trataba, sin embargo, de una pasión simple sino muy complicada. Lo que había en ella de instinto adolescente puramente sensual había sido transformado gracias a la actividad de la imaginación, transformado en algo que al muchacho mismo le parecía alejado de los sentidos y que era, por esa misma razón, mucho más peligroso. Las pasiones sobre cuyo origen uno se engaña son las que más tiranizan. Los motivos que mejor se conocen tienen mucha menos fuerza. Cuántas veces sucedía que, al creer que se experimenta sobre otros, experimentamos en realidad sobre nosotros mismos.
vi_translation: He saw clearly that the experimental method was the only method by which one could achieve any scientific analysis of passion; and certainly, Dorian Gray was a subject perfectly suited for him, and seemed to promise rich and useful results. His sudden mad love for Sybil Vane was a psychological phenomenon of little importance. It was certain that curiosity had a great deal to do with it, curiosity and the desire for new experiences; however, it was not a simple passion but rather a very complex one. What was actually in it was the sensual instinct of youth transformed by the activities of the imagination, turning into something that seemed to the young man himself to be very far removed from sensation, and for that very reason, it was even more dangerous. It is the passions that we deceive ourselves about their origins that torment us the most. Our weakest motives are those whose nature we are unaware of. Often when we think we are testing others, we are actually testing ourselves.
tr_translation: Lord Henry could clearly see that the only way to lead a person to the scientific examination of passions was the experimental method. Dorian Gray was indeed a perfect subject for him, promising bright and fruitful results. This sudden mad passion he had developed for Sibyl Vane was an extraordinary psychological event, not to be underestimated in its peculiarity. There was no doubt that curiosity played a major role in this, curiosity and the desire for novelty. Yet it was not a simple passion; it was very complex. The lustful impulse derived from youth, altered by the influence of imagination, had transformed into a feeling that seemed far from logic and common sense to the boy himself, and thus all the more dangerous. It was the passions about whose origins we deceived ourselves that exerted the most relentless pressures on us. Our weakest impulses were those whose nature we knew. Often, when we thought we were experimenting on others, we were actually experimenting on ourselves.
es_translation: He considered it evident that the experimental method was the only one that would lead him to the scientific analysis of passions; Dorian Gray, for his part, was the ideal subject, and seemed to promise abundant and precious results. His sudden and foolish love for Sybil Vane was a psychological phenomenon of no small interest. Undoubtedly, curiosity had much to do with it; curiosity and the desire for new experiences; it was not, however, a simple passion but a very complicated one. What there was in it of purely sensual adolescent instinct had been transformed thanks to the activity of the imagination, transformed into something that to the boy himself seemed far removed from the senses and which was, for that very reason, much more dangerous. The passions about whose origin one deceives oneself are the ones that most tyrannize. The motives that are best known have much less force. How many times it happened that, believing we are experimenting on others, we are actually experimenting on ourselves.

en: While Lord Henry sat dreaming on these things, a knock came to the door, and his valet entered and reminded him it was time to dress for dinner. He got up and looked out into the street. The sunset had smitten into scarlet gold the upper windows of the houses opposite. The panes glowed like plates of heated metal. The sky above was like a faded rose. He thought of his friend’s young fiery-coloured life and wondered how it was all going to end.
vi: Trong lúc huân tước Henry ngồi mơ màng với những điều này, một cú gõ chạm vào cánh cửa, và người hầu của y bước vào, nhắc y nhớ rằng đã đến giờ thay quần áo để đi ăn tối. Y đứng dậy và nhìn ra phố. Buổi hoàng hôn phả sắc vàng thắm đỏ lên những cửa sổ tầng trên các ngôi nhà đối diện. Các pa-nô rực sáng như những tấm kim loại bị đốt nóng. Bầu trời trên cao như bông hồng héo úa. Y nghĩ về cuộc đời trẻ trung rừng rực màu lửa của bạn mình, và tự hỏi nó sẽ đi hết đến cái kết ra sao.
tr: Lord Henry oturmuş dalgın dalgın bunları düşünürken kapıya vuruldu, özel uşağı içeri girerek, akşam yemeği için giyinme zamanının geldiğini bildirdi. Lord Henry kalktı, pencereden sokağa baktı. Günbatımı karşı sıradaki evlerin üst kat pencerelerini kızıl altına dönüştürmüştü. Camlar kızgın metal levhalar gibi ışıyorlardı. Yukarıda gökyüzü solmuş bir gülü andırıyordu. Lord Henry arkadaşının taze, ateş rengindeki yaşantısını düşündü, bu olup bitenlerin sonunun neye varacağını merak etti.
es: Un golpe en la puerta sacó a lord Henry de aquella larga ensoñación. Su ayuda de cámara le recordó que tenía que vestirse para cenar. Se levantó y miró hacia la calle. El ocaso había deshecho en dorados escarlatas las ventanas altas de las casas de enfrente. Los cristales brillaban como láminas de metal al rojo vivo. Arriba, el cielo era como una rosa marchita. Lord Henry pensó en su amigo, en aquella vida coloreada por todos los fuegos de la juventud, y se preguntó cómo terminaría todo.
vi_translation: While Lord Henry sat dreaming about these things, a knock touched the door, and his servant entered, reminding him that it was time to change clothes for dinner. He stood up and looked out onto the street. The sunset cast a deep golden-red hue on the upper windows of the houses opposite. The panes glowed like sheets of metal heated by fire. The sky above was like a withered rose. He thought about the fiery, youthful life of his friend and wondered how it would all end.
tr_translation: While Lord Henry sat lost in these thoughts, there was a knock at the door, and his personal servant entered to inform him that it was time to dress for dinner. Lord Henry stood up and looked out the window at the street. The sunset had turned the upper floor windows of the houses across the street into crimson gold. The panes glowed like sheets of heated metal. Above, the sky resembled a faded rose. Lord Henry thought of his friend's fresh, fiery life and wondered what the outcome of all this would be.
es_translation: A knock on the door brought Lord Henry out of that long reverie. His valet reminded him that he needed to dress for dinner. He stood up and looked towards the street. The sunset had turned the tall windows of the houses across the street into golden scarlets. The glass panes shone like sheets of red-hot metal. Above, the sky was like a withered rose. Lord Henry thought of his friend, of that life colored by all the fires of youth, and wondered how it would all end.

en: When he arrived home, about half-past twelve o’clock, he saw a telegram lying on the hall table. He opened it and found it was from Dorian Gray. It was to tell him that he was engaged to be married to Sibyl Vane.
vi: Khi y về đến nhà, độ mười hai giờ rưỡi, y thấy một bức điện tín nằm trên chiếc bàn ngoài sảnh. Y mở nó ra, và thấy nó của Dorian Gray. Nó báo cho y biết rằng cậu đã hứa hôn với Sibyl Vane.
tr: Saat yarım sularında evine döndüğü zaman holdeki masanın üstünde bir telgraf buldu. Açtığında Dorian Gray’den geldiğini anladı. Telgraf Dorian Gray’in Sibyl Vane’le evlenmek üzere sözlenmiş olduğunu bildiriyordu.
es: Cuando regresó a su casa, a eso de las doce y media, vio un telegrama sobre la mesa del vestíbulo. Al abrirlo descubrió que era de Dorian Gray. Le anunciaba que se había prometido con la señorita Sibyl Vane.
vi_translation: When he got home, around half past twelve, he found a telegram lying on the table in the hall. He opened it and saw that it was from Dorian Gray. It informed him that he was engaged to Sibyl Vane.
tr_translation: When he returned home around half-past six, he found a telegram on the table in the hall. When he opened it, he realized it was from Dorian Gray. The telegram was informing that Dorian Gray had gotten engaged to marry Sibyl Vane.
es_translation: When he returned home, around half past twelve, he saw a telegram on the vestibule table. Upon opening it, he discovered that it was from Dorian Gray. It announced that he had become engaged to Miss Sibyl Vane.

en: CHAPTER V.
vi: Chương 5
tr: Beşinci bölüm
es: Capítulo 5
vi_translation: Chapter 5
tr_translation: Fifth chapter
es_translation: Chapter 5

en: “Mother, Mother, I am so happy!” whispered the girl, burying her face in the lap of the faded, tired-looking woman who, with back turned to the shrill intrusive light, was sitting in the one arm-chair that their dingy sitting-room contained. “I am so happy!” she repeated, “and you must be happy, too!”
vi: Mẹ ơi, mẹ ơi, con hạnh phúc quá!” cô gái thì thầm, vùi mặt vào lòng người đàn bà có vẻ mệt mỏi, héo hon, lưng quay lại ánh sáng chói gắt xâm nhập, ngồi trên một cái ghế bành mà phòng khách dơ bẩn của họ sẵn có. “Con hạnh phúc quá!” nàng nhắc lại, “và mẹ cũng phải hạnh phúc nhé!”
tr: Kız, “Anne, anneciğim, öyle mutluyum ki!” diye fısıldayarak başını yorgun, geçkin görünümlü kadının kucağına gömdü. Kadın rahatsız edici, çiğ ışığa sırtını dönmüş, o pejmürde odadaki tek koltukta oturmaktaydı. Kız, “Öyle mutluyum ki sen de mutlu olmalısın!” dedi.
es: —Qué feliz soy, madre! —susurró la muchacha, escondiendo el rostro en el regazo de la marchita mujer, de aspecto cansado, que, vuelta de espaldas a la luz demasiado estridente de la ventana, estaba sentada en el único sillón que contenía su sórdida sala de estar—. Soy muy feliz —repitió—, ¡y tú también debes serlo!
vi_translation: "Mom, mom, I'm so happy!" the girl whispered, burying her face into the lap of the tired, withered woman, her back turned to the glaring light that intruded, sitting on an armchair in their filthy living room. "I'm so happy!" she repeated, "and you must be happy too!"
tr_translation: The girl whispered, "Mom, mommy, I am so happy!" as she buried her head in the lap of the tired, elderly-looking woman. The woman, with her back turned to the harsh, glaring light, was sitting in the only chair in that shabby room. The girl said, "I am so happy that you must be happy too!"
es_translation: —How happy I am, mother! —whispered the girl, hiding her face in the lap of the withered woman, who looked tired, and who, with her back turned to the too-bright light from the window, was sitting in the only armchair that her sordid living room contained—. I am very happy —she repeated—, and you must be too!

en: Mrs. Vane winced and put her thin, bismuth-whitened hands on her daughter’s head. “Happy!” she echoed, “I am only happy, Sibyl, when I see you act. You must not think of anything but your acting. Mr. Isaacs has been very good to us, and we owe him money.”
vi: Bà Vane co rúm lại, đặt đôi tay gầy bạc màu bít-mút1 lên đầu con gái mình. “Hạnh phúc!” bà lặp lại, “mẹ chỉ hạnh phúc, Sibyl, khi mẹ thấy con diễn. 1 Bismuth Oxychloride: Một chất được tìm thấy trong tự nhiên, được dùng để trang điểm từ thời xưa. Con không nên nghĩ về bất cứ điều gì ngoài diễn xuất của con. Mít-tơ Isaacs rất tốt với chúng ta, và chúng ta nợ tiền ông ấy.
tr: ms Vane şöyle bir irkilerek o zayıf, bizmuttan3 beyazlanmış ellerini kızının başına koydu. “Mutlu mu dedin, Sibyl! Ben yalnızca seni sahnede gördüğüm zaman mutlu oluyorum. Mesleğinden başka hiçbir şey düşünmemelisin. mr Isaacs bize çok iyilik etti. Ona para borçluyuz.
es: La señora Vane hizo una mueca de dolor y puso las delgadas manos, con la blancura de los afeites, sobre la cabeza de su hija. —¡Feliz! —repitió como un eco—. Sólo soy feliz cuando te veo actuar. Sólo debes pensar en tu carrera. El señor Isaacs ha sido muy bueno con nosotras, y le debemos dinero.
vi_translation: Mrs. Vane shrank back, placing her thin, discolored batiste hands on her daughter's head. “Happiness!” she repeated, “I am only happy, Sibyl, when I see you perform.” 1 Bismuth Oxychloride: A substance found in nature, used for makeup since ancient times. You should not think about anything other than your acting. Mr. Isaacs is very good to us, and we owe him money.”
tr_translation: Ms. Vane shuddered slightly and placed her thin, bismuth-whitened hands on her daughter's head. "Did you say happy, Sibyl! I am only happy when I see you on stage. You should think of nothing but your profession. Mr. Isaacs has done us many favors. We owe him money."
es_translation: Mrs. Vane winced in pain and placed her thin, makeup-whitened hands on her daughter's head. —Happy! —he repeated like an echo—. I am only happy when I see you perform. You should only think about your career. Mr. Isaacs has been very good to us, and we owe him money.

en: The girl looked up and pouted. “Money, Mother?” she cried, “what does money matter? Love is more than money.”
vi: Cô gái ngước mắt lên và bĩu môi. “Tiền, tiền?” nàng kêu lên, “tiền thì quan trọng gì? Tình yêu quan trọng hơn tiền.
tr: Kız başını kaldırıp annesine bakarak dudağını sarkıttı. “Para mı dedin anne?” diye çıkıştı. “Parayı neden önemseyelim? Aşk paradan üstündür.
es: La muchacha alzó la cabeza e hizo un puchero. —¿Dinero, madre? —exclamó—, ¿qué importancia tiene el dinero? El amor es más que el dinero.
vi_translation: The girl looked up and pouted. “Money, money?” she exclaimed, “what's so important about money? Love is more important than money.”
tr_translation: The girl lifted her head and looked at her mother, pouting her lip. "Did you say money, mom?" she retorted. “Why should we care about money? Love is superior to money.”
es_translation: The girl raised her head and pouted. —Money, mother? —he exclaimed—, what importance does money have? Love is more than money.

en: “Mr. Isaacs has advanced us fifty pounds to pay off our debts and to get a proper outfit for James. You must not forget that, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a very large sum. Mr. Isaacs has been most considerate.”
vi: “Mít-tơ Isaacs đã ứng trước cho ta năm chục bảng để trả nợ, và để sắm sửa các trang bị thích hợp cho James. Con không nên quên chuyện ấy, Sibyl. Năm chục bảng là số tiền rất lớn. Mít-tơ Isaacs đã hết sức chu đáo.”
tr: “Borçlarımızı ödeyelim. James’e de doğru dürüst kılık düzebilelim diye mr Isaacs elli sterlin verdi bize. Bunu unutmamalısın, Sibyl. Elli sterlin çok büyük para. mr Isaacs çok iyilik etti bize.
es: —El señor Isaacs nos ha adelantado cincuenta libras para pagar nuestras deudas, y para vestir a James como es debido. No debes olvidarlo, Sibyl. Cincuenta libras es mucho. El señor Isaacs ha tenido muchas consideraciones con nosotras.
vi_translation: "Mr. Isaacs advanced me fifty pounds to pay off debts and to purchase suitable equipment for James. You should not forget that, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a very large sum of money. Mr. Isaacs has been extremely considerate."
tr_translation: “Let's pay our debts. Mr. Isaacs gave us fifty pounds so that we could also properly dress James. You must not forget this, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a lot of money. Mr. Isaacs did us a great favor.”
es_translation: —Mr. Isaacs has advanced us fifty pounds to pay our debts and to dress James properly. You must not forget it, Sibyl. Fifty pounds is a lot. Mr. Isaacs has been very considerate with us.

en: “He is not a gentleman, Mother, and I hate the way he talks to me,” said the girl, rising to her feet and going over to the window.
vi: “Ông ấy không phải là một quý nhân, mẹ ơi, và con ghét cái lối mà ông ấy nói với con,” cô gái nói, đứng nhỏm dậy, lại gần cửa sổ.
tr: “mr Isaacs centilmen değil ki anne,” diyerek kız ayağa kalkıp pencereye yürüdü. “Benimle konuşma tarzından nefret ediyorum.
es: —No es un caballero, madre, y me desagrada mucho la manera que tiene de hablarme —dijo la muchacha, poniéndose en pie y acercándose a la ventana.
vi_translation: “He is not a gentleman, mother, and I hate the way he talks to me,” the girl said, standing up and moving closer to the window.
tr_translation: “Mr. Isaacs is not a gentleman, mother,” said the girl as she stood up and walked to the window. “I hate the way he talks to me.”
es_translation: —He is not a gentleman, mother, and I greatly dislike the way he speaks to me —said the girl, standing up and approaching the window.

en: “I don’t know how we could manage without him,” answered the elder woman querulously.
vi: “Mẹ không biết ta có thể xoay xở ra sao nếu không có ông ấy,” người đàn bà lớn tuổi hơn đáp lại, cáu kỉnh.
tr: Annesi, huysuzlanarak, “Onsuz ne yapardık bilemiyorum,” dedi.
es: —No sé cómo podríamos arreglárnoslas sin él —respondió la mujer de más edad con tono quejumbroso.
vi_translation: “I don't know how I would manage without him,” the older woman replied, irritably.
tr_translation: Her mother, grumbling, said, "I don't know what we would do without him."
es_translation: —I don't know how we could manage without him —replied the older woman in a whining tone.

en: Sibyl Vane tossed her head and laughed. “We don’t want him any more, Mother. Prince Charming rules life for us now.” Then she paused. A rose shook in her blood and shadowed her cheeks. Quick breath parted the petals of her lips. They trembled. Some southern wind of passion swept over her and stirred the dainty folds of her dress. “I love him,” she said simply.
vi: Sibyl Vane hất đầu lên và cười. “Ta không cần ông ấy nữa, mẹ ơi. Hoàng tử Quyến rũ sẽ cai trị cuộc đời cho ta từ bây giờ.” Rồi nàng ngưng lại. Một bông hồng lay động trong máu nàng, phủ bóng lên má nàng. Hơi thở gấp gáp tách rời các cánh hoa môi. Chúng run rẩy. Làn gió Nam nồng nàn nào đó cuốn khắp người nàng, lay động các nếp váy xinh. “Con yêu anh ấy,” nàng nói, giản đơn.
tr: Sibyl başını sarsarak güldü. “Ona ihtiyacımız yok artık, anne. Şimdi başımızda Tatlı Prens var.” Sibyl duraladı. Kanında bir gül savrulmuşçasına yanakları pembeleşti. Soluğunun sıkışmasıyla dudaklarının çiçekleri aralandı, titremeye başladı. Sıcak bir tutku yeli esip elbisesinin ince kıvrımlarına dolaştı. Sibyl, “Onu seviyorum,” dedi yalınlıkla.
es: Sibyl movió la cabeza y se echó a reír. —Ya no nos hace falta, madre. El príncipe azul gobierna ahora nuestras vidas —luego hizo una pausa. Una rosa se agitó en su sangre, encendiéndole las mejillas. La respiración, acelerada, abrió los pétalos de sus labios, que temblaron. Un viento meridional de pasión sopló sobre ella, moviendo los delicados pliegues del vestido—. Le quiero —añadió con sencillez.
vi_translation: Sibyl Vane tossed her head back and laughed. “I don't need him anymore, mother. The Charming Prince will rule my life from now on.” Then she paused. A rose bloomed in her blood, casting a shadow on her cheek. Her breath quickened, parting the petals of her lips. They trembled. A certain passionate Southern wind swept over her, rustling her pretty dress. “I love him,” she said, simply.
tr_translation: Sibyl shook her head and laughed. "We don't need him anymore, mother. Now we have the Sweet Prince with us." Sibyl paused. Her cheeks blushed as if a rose had been tossed in her blood. Her lips parted, trembling, as her breath caught. A warm breeze of passion swirled around the delicate folds of her dress. Sibyl said simply, "I love him."
es_translation: Sibyl moved her head and started to laugh. —We no longer need it, mother. The prince charming now governs our lives —then she paused. A rose stirred in her blood, setting her cheeks ablaze. Her breath, quickened, parted the petals of her lips, which trembled. A southern wind of passion blew over her, moving the delicate folds of her dress—. I love him —she added simply.

en: “Foolish child! foolish child!” was the parrot-phrase flung in answer. The waving of crooked, false-jewelled fingers gave grotesqueness to the words.
vi: “Con bé dại dột! con bé dại dột!” là các lời-vẹt mắng trả. Cái vẫy các ngón tay cong queo, đeo ngọc giả bổ sung sự lố bịch vào lời nói.
tr: Aldığı karşılık, papağan yinelemesini andıran bir, “Aptal çocuk! Aptal çocuk!” ünlemi oldu. Yalancı taşlı yüzükler taşıyan eğri parmakların sallanışı sözcüklere daha bir tuhaflık katıyordu.
es: —¡Estúpida niña!, ¡estúpida niña! —fue la frase cotorril que recibió como respuesta. El movimiento de unos dedos deformados, cubiertos de falsas joyas, dio un carácter grotesco a aquellas palabras.
vi_translation: “The foolish girl! The foolish girl!” were the parroted scolding words. The waving of crooked fingers, adorned with fake jewels, added absurdity to the words.
tr_translation: The response he received was a parrot-like repetition, "Stupid child! Stupid child!" The waving of the crooked fingers adorned with fake gemstone rings added an extra layer of oddity to the words.
es_translation: —Stupid girl! Stupid girl! —was the parrot-like phrase that she received in response. The movement of some deformed fingers, covered in fake jewels, gave a grotesque character to those words.

en: The girl laughed again. The joy of a caged bird was in her voice. Her eyes caught the melody and echoed it in radiance, then closed for a moment, as though to hide their secret. When they opened, the mist of a dream had passed across them.
vi: Cô gái lại cười. Niềm vui chim-lồng ngân lên trong giọng nàng. Đôi mắt nàng bắt được giai điệu, dội lại nó thành ánh hào quang; rồi nhắm vào một lát, như thể để giấu đi bí mật của chúng. Khi chúng mở ra, màn sương mơ màng trôi ngang qua chúng.
tr: Kız gene güldü. Sesinde kafese kapatılmış bir kuşun kıvancı vardı. Gözleri de bu ezgiyi kaparak sanki pırıltı biçiminde yansıttı, sonra da içlerindeki gizi saklamak istercesine bir an yumuldu. Yeniden açıldıkları zaman içlerinden bir hülyanın sisi geçmiş gibiydi.
es: La muchacha volvió a reírse. Su voz reflejaba la alegría de un pájaro enjaulado. Sus ojos retomaron la melodía y le hicieron eco con su brillo: luego se cerraron por un momento, como para ocultar su secreto. Cuando se volvieron a abrir, los velaba la niebla de un sueño.
vi_translation: The girl laughed again. The joy of a caged bird resonated in her voice. Her eyes caught the melody, reflecting it as a radiant glow; then closed for a moment, as if to hide their secret. When they opened, a dreamy mist drifted across them.
tr_translation: The girl laughed again. There was the joy of a bird trapped in a cage in her voice. Her eyes also captured this melody and seemed to reflect it in the form of a sparkle, then closed for a moment as if to hide the secret within them. When they reopened, it was as if a mist of a dream had passed through them.
es_translation: The girl laughed again. Her voice reflected the joy of a caged bird. Her eyes picked up the melody and echoed it with their brightness: then they closed for a moment, as if to hide their secret. When they opened again, they were veiled by the mist of a dream.

en: Thin-lipped wisdom spoke at her from the worn chair, hinted at prudence, quoted from that book of cowardice whose author apes the name of common sense. She did not listen. She was free in her prison of passion. Her prince, Prince Charming, was with her. She had called on memory to remake him. She had sent her soul to search for him, and it had brought him back. His kiss burned again upon her mouth. Her eyelids were warm with his breath.
vi: Sự khôn ngoan môi-mỏng bảo ban nàng từ chiếc ghế sờn, bóng gió thận trọng, trích dẫn từ cuốn sách về sự hèn nhát mà tác giả nó nhại lại cái tên của lẽ thường. Nàng không nghe. Nàng đang tự do trong nhà giam đam mê của mình. Hoàng tử của nàng, Hoàng tử Quyến rũ, đang ở cùng nàng. Nàng đã yêu cầu Trí nhớ tái tạo anh. Nàng đã gửi hồn mình đi tìm anh, và nó đã mang anh về. Nụ hôn anh lại cháy trên miệng nàng. Mi mắt nàng lại ấm hơi thở anh.
tr: Kısık dudaklı akılsa o eprimiş koltuktan sesini yükseltiyor, sakıngan davranmanın gereğine dokunuyor, yazarının “sağduyu” adına öykündüğü ünlü “korkaklık” kitabından alıntılar yapıyordu. Kız onu dinlemiyordu bile. Tutkusunun zindanı içinde özgürdü. Kendi masal şehzadesi, Tatlı Prens şimdi yanı başındaydı. Sibyl, prensini yanı başında canlandırsın diye belleğe başvurmuştu. Bellek de prensi alıp ona getirmişti. Prensin öpüşü genç kızın dudaklarını yakıyordu gene. Soluğu kızın gözkapaklarının üstünde sıcacıktı.
es: La sabiduría de unos labios demasiado finos le habló desde el sillón desgastado, aconsejando prudencia, con citas de ese libro sobre la cobardía cuyo autor se disfraza con el nombre de sentido común. No la escuchó. Era libre en la cárcel de su pasión. Su príncipe, el príncipe azul, estaba con ella. Había llamado a la memoria para reconstruirlo. Envió a su alma a buscarlo, y su alma volvió con él. Su beso le quemaba de nuevo la boca. Su aliento le entibiaba los párpados.
vi_translation: The wisdom of thin-lipped advice spoke to her from the worn chair, cautiously alluding, quoting from a book on cowardice whose author parodied the name of common sense. She did not listen. She was free in the prison of her passion. Her prince, Prince Charming, was with her. She had asked Memory to recreate him. She had sent her soul to find him, and it had brought him back. His kiss burned on her lips once more. Her eyelids were warm with his breath again.
tr_translation: The cautious mind was raising its voice from that worn-out armchair, touching on the necessity of being careful, and quoting from the famous "cowardice" book that its author admired in the name of "common sense." The girl wasn't even listening to it. She was free within the prison of her passion. Her own fairy tale prince, Sweet Prince, was now right beside her. Sibyl had turned to memory so that it could bring her prince to life beside her. And memory had brought the prince to her. The prince's kiss was burning the young girl's lips again. His breath was warm on the girl's eyelids.
es_translation: The wisdom of lips that were too thin spoke to her from the worn-out armchair, advising prudence, with quotes from that book on cowardice whose author disguises himself with the name of common sense. She did not listen. She was free in the prison of her passion. Her prince, the prince charming, was with her. She had called upon memory to reconstruct him. She sent her soul to find him, and her soul returned with him. His kiss burned her mouth again. His breath warmed her eyelids.

en: Then wisdom altered its method and spoke of espial and discovery. This young man might be rich. If so, marriage should be thought of. Against the shell of her ear broke the waves of worldly cunning. The arrows of craft shot by her. She saw the thin lips moving, and smiled.
vi: Sau đó Sự khôn ngoan thay đổi phương pháp và bảo ban về sự theo dõi và sự phát hiện. Chàng thanh niên này chắc là giàu. Nếu vậy, cưới xin là việc nên nghĩ đến. Trên vành tai nàng vỡ tan những làn sóng gian giảo thạo đời. Các mũi tên mánh khóe bắn sượt qua nàng. Nàng nhìn đôi môi mỏng động đậy, và mỉm cười.
tr: Derken akıl, kullandığı yöntemi değiştirdi; “ağız arama” ve “öğrenip anlama”dan söz açtı. Bu genç adam zengin olabilirdi. Eğer öyleyse nikâh düşünülmeliydi. Kızın kulağının sedefi üstüne kurnazlığın dalgaları çarpmaya başladı; yüreğine sinsiliğin okları saplandı. Kız o ince dudakların kıpırdadığını görüyor, gülümsüyordu.
es: La sabiduría cambió entonces de método y habló de espiar y descubrir. Aquel joven podía ser rico. En caso afirmativo, había que pensar en el matrimonio. Contra la concha del oído de Sibyl se estrellaban las olas de la prudencia mundana. Las flechas de la astucia pasaban sin tocarla. Vio que los finos labios se movían, y sonrió.
vi_translation: Then Wisdom changed its method and instructed about tracking and detection. This young man must be wealthy. If so, marriage is something to consider. On the rim of her ear, waves of worldly cunning shattered. Arrows of trickery grazed past her. She watched the thin lips move and smiled.
tr_translation: Then the mind changed its method; it spoke of "probing" and "learning and understanding." This young man could be wealthy. If so, marriage should be considered. Waves of cunning began to crash upon the pearl of the girl's ear; arrows of deceit pierced her heart. The girl saw those thin lips moving and smiled.
es_translation: Wisdom then changed its method and spoke of spying and discovering. That young man could be rich. If so, one had to think about marriage. Against Sibyl's ear, the waves of worldly prudence crashed. The arrows of cunning passed without touching her. She saw the thin lips move, and smiled.

en: Suddenly she felt the need to speak. The wordy silence troubled her. “Mother, Mother,” she cried, “why does he love me so much? I know why I love him. I love him because he is like what love himself should be. But what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. And yet—why, I cannot tell—though I feel so much beneath him, I don’t feel humble. I feel proud, terribly proud. Mother, did you love my father as I love Prince Charming?”
vi: Bỗng nhiên nàng thấy cần nói. Sự im lặng lắm lời làm phiền nàng. “Mẹ, mẹ,” nàng kêu lên, “sao anh ấy lại yêu con nhiều đến thế? Con thì biết tại sao con yêu anh ấy. Con yêu anh ấy vì anh ấy giống như những gì mà chính Tình yêu nên trở thành. Nhưng anh ấy thấy gì ở con nhỉ? Con không xứng với anh ấy. Nhưng mà — vì sao nhỉ, con không thể nói ra — dẫu con thấy kém anh ấy rất nhiều, con vẫn không thấy tự ti. Con thấy tự hào, hết sức tự hào. Mẹ, mẹ có yêu cha con như con yêu Hoàng tử Quyến rũ không?”
tr: Birden, konuşmak ihtiyacı duydu. Bu söz dolu sessizlik onu tedirgin ediyordu. “Anne, anne!” dedi. “Bu çocuk neden bu kadar çok seviyor beni? Ben onu neden sevdiğimi biliyorum. Onu seviyorum, çünkü o aşkın ta kendisinin sanki canlı bir simgesi. Ama o bende ne görüyor? Ona layık değilim ki ben. Gene de... bilmem neden... ondan çok aşağıda olduğumu hissediyorum, ama ezik hissetmiyorum kendimi. Gurur duyuyorum, müthiş gururlanıyorum. Anne, sen de babamı böyle sevmiş miydin, benim Tatlı Prens’i sevdiğim gibi?
es: De repente sintió la necesidad de hablar. El silencio lleno de palabras la desazonaba. —Madre, madre —exclamó—, ¿por qué me quiere tanto? Sé que yo le quiero. Le quiero porque es la imagen de lo que el mismo Amor debe ser. Pero, ¿qué ve él en mí? No soy digna de él. Y sin embargo, aunque me veo tan por debajo de él, no siento humildad: siento orgullo, un orgullo terrible, pero no sé explicar por qué.
vi_translation: Suddenly she felt the need to speak. The loud silence bothered her. “Mother, mother,” she cried out, “why does he love me so much? I know why I love him. I love him because he is like what Love itself should become. But what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. But — why, I cannot say — even though I feel so much inferior to him, I do not feel inferior. I feel proud, extremely proud. Mother, did you love my father as I love Prince Charming?”
tr_translation: Suddenly, he felt the need to speak. This silence full of words was making him uneasy. “Mom, mom!” she said. “Why does this child love me so much? I know why I love him. I love him because he is like a living symbol of love itself. But what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. Still... I don't know why... I feel that I am far below him, but I don't feel crushed. I feel proud, incredibly proud. Mom, did you love my father like this, the way I love my Sweet Prince?”
es_translation: Suddenly, she felt the need to speak. The silence full of words unsettled her. —Mother, mother —she exclaimed—, why do you love me so much? I know that I love you. I love you because you are the image of what Love itself must be. But, what does he see in me? I am not worthy of him. And yet, although I see myself so far below him, I do not feel humility: I feel pride, a terrible pride, but I cannot explain why. Mother, did you love my father as I love the blue prince?

en: The elder woman grew pale beneath the coarse powder that daubed her cheeks, and her dry lips twitched with a spasm of pain. Sybil rushed to her, flung her arms round her neck, and kissed her. “Forgive me, Mother. I know it pains you to talk about our father. But it only pains you because you loved him so much. Don’t look so sad. I am as happy to-day as you were twenty years ago. Ah! let me be happy for ever!”
vi: Người đàn bà lớn tuổi hơn tái mặt đi dưới lớp phấn thô trát má, và đôi môi khô của bà giật giật vì một cơn đau. Sybyl lao đến chỗ bà, quàng tay nàng quanh cổ bà, hôn bà. “Tha lỗi cho con, mẹ nhé. Con biết việc nói về cha làm mẹ đau đớn. Nhưng nó chỉ làm mẹ đau vì mẹ yêu cha quá nhiều. Đừng nhìn buồn thế. Hôm nay con đang hạnh phúc như mẹ từng hạnh phúc hai mươi năm trước. Ôi! Hãy cho con được hạnh phúc mãi mãi
tr: Anne, yanaklarına sıvanmış o kalın pudranın altında sapsarı kesildi, o kuru dudaklarında bir sinir oynadı. Sibyl koşup onu kucaklayarak öptü. “Bağışla beni, anneciğim. Biliyorum, babamdan konuşmak üzüyor seni. Ama böyle üzülüyorsan onu bir zamanlar çok sevdiğin içindir. Bu kadar üzgün durma. Sen yirmi yıl önce nasıl mutlu idiysen ben de bugün öyle mutluyum. Ah, ne olur, ömür boyu mutlu olayım!
es: Madre, ¿querías a mi padre como yo quiero al príncipe azul? —la mujer de más edad palideció bajo los polvos demasiado visibles que le embadurnaban las mejillas, y sus labios secos se estremecieron en un espasmo de dolor. Sibyl corrió hacia ella, se abrazó a su cuello y la besó—. Perdóname, madre. Ya sé que hablar de mi padre te hace sufrir. Pero sufres porque lo querías muchísimo. No te entristezcas. Soy tan feliz hoy como lo eras tú hace veinte años. ¡Ah, déjame que sea feliz para siempre!
vi_translation: The older woman turned pale under the coarse powder on her cheeks, and her dry lips twitched in pain. Sybyl rushed to her, wrapped her arms around her neck, and kissed her. "Forgive me, mother. I know talking about father causes you pain. But it only hurts because you loved him so much. Don't look so sad. Today, I am as happy as you were twenty years ago. Oh! Let me be happy forever!”
tr_translation: Anne turned pale under the thick layer of powder smeared on her cheeks, a nerve twitched on her dry lips. Sibyl ran up to her, hugged her, and kissed her. “Forgive me, my dear mother. I know talking about my father upsets you. But if you are so upset, it is because you once loved him very much. Don't look so sad. Just as you were happy twenty years ago, I am happy today. Oh, please, let me be happy for a lifetime!”
es_translation: —the older woman paled under the too-visible powders that smeared her cheeks, and her dry lips trembled in a spasm of pain. Sibyl ran to her, hugged her neck, and kissed her—. Forgive me, mother. I know that talking about my father makes you suffer. But you suffer because you loved him very much. Do not be sad. I am as happy today as you were twenty years ago. Ah, let me be happy forever!

en: “My child, you are far too young to think of falling in love. Besides, what do you know of this young man? You don’t even know his name. The whole thing is most inconvenient, and really, when James is going away to Australia, and I have so much to think of, I must say that you should have shown more consideration. However, as I said before, if he is rich ...”
vi: “Con ơi, con còn quá trẻ để mà nghĩ đến chuyện đắm đuối vì yêu. Vả lại, con biết gì về chàng thanh niên này? Con thậm chí còn chưa biết tên nó. Toàn bộ chuyện này là hết sức phiền phức, và thực ra, khi James sắp bỏ đi Úc, còn mẹ có quá nhiều thứ phải nghĩ đến, mẹ phải nói là con lẽ ra nên tỏ vẻ biết nghĩ hơn. Tuy vậy, như mẹ nói lúc nãy, giả dụ nó giàu...”
tr: “Yavrucuğum, çok küçüksün sen daha, âşık olmayı düşünecek yaşta değilsin. Hem bu genç hakkında ne biliyorsun ki? Adını bile bilmiyorsun onun. Nereden baksan çok uygunsuz bir durum, çok sırasız. Tam James’in Avustralya’ya gideceği şu sıralarda düşünecek dünya kadar sorunum varken senden biraz daha anlayış beklerdim doğrusu. Her neyse, dediğim gibi, eğer bu çocuk paralıysa...
es: —Hijita mía, eres demasiado joven para pensar en enamorarte. Además, ¿qué sabes de ese joven? Ni siquiera su nombre. Todo esto es muy poco conveniente y, a decir verdad, cuando lames está a punto de irse a Australia y yo tengo tantas preocupaciones, he de decir que podrías haber mostrado un poco más de consideración.
vi_translation: "My child, you are still too young to be thinking about being infatuated with love. Moreover, what do you know about this young man? You don't even know his name yet. This whole thing is extremely troublesome, and actually, with James about to leave for Australia, and me having too many things to think about, I must say that you should have shown more consideration. However, as I said earlier, if he were rich..."
tr_translation: “My dear child, you are still very young, you are not at the age to think about falling in love. Besides, what do you know about this young man? You don't even know his name. From any angle, it’s a very inappropriate situation, very untimely. At a time when I have a world of problems to think about, especially with James going to Australia, I would have expected a bit more understanding from you, honestly. Anyway, as I said, if this boy is wealthy...”
es_translation: —My dear daughter, you are too young to think about falling in love. Besides, what do you know about that young man? You don't even know his name. All of this is very inconvenient and, to be honest, when lames is about to go to Australia and I have so many worries, I must say that you could have shown a bit more consideration. However, as I have said before, in the case that he is rich... —Mother, mother!

en: “Ah! Mother, Mother, let me be happy!”
vi: “Ôi! Mẹ, mẹ ơi, hãy để con được hạnh phúc!”
tr: “Anne, anneciğim, ne olur, izin ver de mutlu olayım!
es: Sin embargo, como ya he dicho antes, en el caso de que sea rico... —¡Madre, madre! ¡Permíteme ser feliz!
vi_translation: "Oh! Mother, mother, please let me be happy!"
tr_translation: “Mom, dear mom, please, let me be happy!”
es_translation: Let me be happy!

en: Mrs. Vane glanced at her, and with one of those false theatrical gestures that so often become a mode of second nature to a stage-player, clasped her in her arms. At this moment, the door opened and a young lad with rough brown hair came into the room. He was thick-set of figure, and his hands and feet were large and somewhat clumsy in movement. He was not so finely bred as his sister. One would hardly have guessed the close relationship that existed between them. Mrs. Vane fixed her eyes on him and intensified her smile. She mentally elevated her son to the dignity of an audience. She felt sure that the tableau was interesting.
vi: Bà Vane liếc nhìn nàng, và, với một trong những điệu bộ sân khấu giả tạo vẫn rất hay trở thành một thứ kiểu cách thuộc về bản chất thứ nhì của các diễn viên kịch nghệ, ôm chặt nàng trong cánh tay. Đúng lúc này, cửa mở, và một chàng trai trẻ với mái tóc nâu bờm xờm bước vào phòng. Cậu có thân hình chắc nịch, tay chân to, và hơi lóng ngóng. Cậu không được nuôi kỹ như chị cậu. Người ta khó mà đoán được mối quan hệ gần gũi tồn tại giữa họ. Bà Vane dồn mắt vào cậu, cười sâu hơn. Bà thầm nâng con trai mình lên tầm khán giả. Bà cảm thấy chắc chắn là hoạt cảnh rất thú vị.
tr: ms Vane kızına baktı, sonra tiyatro oyuncularında ikinci huy olup çıkan o yapay jestlerden biriyle onu kucaklayıp bağrına bastı. Tam bu sırada kapı açıldı ve dağınık, kestane saçlı bir genç erkek odaya girdi. Tıknaz yapılı, elleriyle ayakları iri iri, devinimleri biraz uyumsuzdu. Kız kardeşinin zarafetinden yoksundu. İnsan onların arasındaki yakın kan bağını dünyada kestiremezdi. ms Vane gözlerini ona dikti, dudaklarındaki gülümseme genişledi. Kafasında oğlunu “izleyici” düzeyine yükseltmişti. Oluşturduğu “tablo”nun ilginçliğinden kuşkusu yoktu.
es: La señora Vane se la quedó mirando y, con uno de esos falsos gestos teatrales que con tanta frecuencia se convierten casi en segunda naturaleza para un actor, la estrechó entre sus brazos. En aquel momento se abrió la puerta, y un joven de áspero pelo castaño entró en la habitación. Era más bien corpulento, tenía grandes los pies y las manos y se movía con cierta torpeza. No poseía la delicadeza de su hermana y era difícil adivinar el estrecho parentesco que existía entre los dos. La señora Vane fijó sus ojos en él, y su sonrisa se intensificó. Mentalmente elevaba a su hijo a la categoría de público. Estaba segura de que el tableau era interesante.
vi_translation: Mrs. Vane glanced at her, and, with one of those theatrical, artificial gestures that often become a second nature to actors, hugged her tightly in her arms. At this moment, the door opened, and a young man with shaggy brown hair stepped into the room. He had a sturdy build, large limbs, and was somewhat clumsy. He was not as well-bred as his sister. It was hard to guess the close relationship that existed between them. Mrs. Vane fixed her eyes on him, smiling more deeply. She silently elevated her son to the level of an audience. She felt certain that the scene was very interesting.
tr_translation: Ms. Vane looked at her daughter, then embraced her with one of those artificial gestures that become a second nature to actors and pressed her to her chest. At that very moment, the door opened and a young man with disheveled chestnut hair entered the room. He was stocky, with large hands and feet, and his movements were somewhat awkward. He lacked his sister's grace. One could never guess the close blood relation between them. Ms. Vane fixed her eyes on him, the smile on her lips widened. In her mind, she had elevated her son to the level of an "audience." She had no doubt about the interesting nature of the "scene" she had created.
es_translation: Mrs. Vane stared at her and, with one of those false theatrical gestures that so often become almost second nature to an actor, embraced her. At that moment, the door opened, and a young man with coarse brown hair entered the room. He was rather stout, had large feet and hands, and moved with a certain clumsiness. He did not possess his sister's delicacy, and it was difficult to discern the close kinship between the two. Mrs. Vane fixed her eyes on him, and her smile intensified. Mentally, she elevated her son to the status of an audience. She was sure that the tableau was interesting.

en: “You might keep some of your kisses for me, Sibyl, I think,” said the lad with a good-natured grumble.
vi: “Chị có thể giữ lại vài nụ hôn cho em không, Sybil, em rất mong,” chàng trai nói, với tiếng lầu bầu hiền hậu.
tr: Delikanlı sevecen bir homurtuyla, “Sibyl, öpücüklerinin birazını da bana saklayabilirsin yani,” dedi.
es: —Podrías guardar algunos de tus besos para mí, Sibyl, pienso yo —dijo el muchacho con tono de amable reproche.
vi_translation: "Can you save a few kisses for me, Sybil? I would really appreciate it," the young man said, with a gentle murmur.
tr_translation: The young man said with a tender growl, "Sibyl, you can save some of your kisses for me too."
es_translation: —You could save some of your kisses for me, Sibyl, I think —said the boy in a tone of gentle reproach.

en: “Ah! but you don’t like being kissed, Jim,” she cried. “You are a dreadful old bear.” And she ran across the room and hugged him.
vi: “Ôi! Nhưng em không thích được hôn mà, Jim,” nàng la lên. “Em là con gấu già khó chịu.” Và nàng chạy ngang qua phòng đến ôm chặt cậu.
tr: Sibyl, “Ama sen öpülmekten hoşlanmazsın ki, Jim!” dedi. “Ayıcıklar gibi homurdanmasını bilirsin!” diyerek koşup onu sımsıkı kucakladı.
es: —¡Pero si no te gusta que te besen! —exclamó su hermana—. Siempre has sido un cardo borriquero. Y cruzó corriendo la habitación para abrazarlo.
vi_translation: "Oh! But I don't like being kissed, Jim," she exclaimed. "I am a grumpy old bear." And she ran across the room to hug him tightly.
tr_translation: Sibyl said, "But you don't like to be kissed, Jim!" “You know how to grumble like a bear!” she said, running up to him and hugging him tightly.
es_translation: —But you don't like being kissed! —exclaimed her sister—. You've always been a prickly thistle. And she ran across the room to hug him.

en: James Vane looked into his sister’s face with tenderness. “I want you to come out with me for a walk, Sibyl. I don’t suppose I shall ever see this horrid London again. I am sure I don’t want to.”
vi: James Vane âu yếm nhìn mặt chị mình. “Em muốn chị ra ngoài đi dạo với em, Sibyl. Em không tin là em sẽ còn có lúc thấy thành phố London kinh khủng này nữa. Em chắc chắn là em không muốn thế.”
tr: James Vane kız kardeşinin yüzüne sevgiyle baktı. “Benimle birlikte bir yürüyüşe gelmeni istiyorum, Sibyl. Londra denilen bu feci kenti bir daha göreceğimi sanmıyorum. Görmeyi de istemiyorum.
es: James Vane contempló con ternura el rostro de su hermana. —Ven conmigo a dar un paseo, Sibyl. No creo que vuelva a ver nunca este horrible Londres. Estoy seguro de que no lo echaré de menos.
vi_translation: James Vane lovingly looked at his sister's face. "I want you to go for a walk with me, Sibyl. I don't believe I will ever see this dreadful city of London again. I am certain that I don't want to."
tr_translation: James Vane looked at his sister's face with love. “I want you to come for a walk with me, Sibyl. I don't think I will see this dreadful city called London again. Nor do I want to see it.”
es_translation: James Vane contemplated his sister's face with tenderness. —Come with me for a walk, Sibyl. I don't think I'll ever see this horrible London again. I'm sure I won't miss it.

en: “My son, don’t say such dreadful things,” murmured Mrs. Vane, taking up a tawdry theatrical dress, with a sigh, and beginning to patch it. She felt a little disappointed that he had not joined the group. It would have increased the theatrical picturesqueness of the situation.
vi: “Con trai của mẹ, đừng nói những điều đáng sợ như vậy,” bà Vane lẩm bẩm, nhặt bộ phục trang lòe loẹt lên, với tiếng thở dài, và bắt đầu vá nó. Bà cảm thấy hơi thất vọng vì cậu không nhập nhóm. Việc đó sẽ gia tăng tính sinh động đậm chất sân khấu của tình huống.
tr: ms Vane, “Oğlum benim, böyle şeyler söyleme!” diye mırıldandı. İçini çekerek eski püskü, ucuz bir sahne elbisesini eline alıp yamamaya başladı. Oğlu gelip onlara katılmadı diye biraz hayal kırıklığına uğramıştı. James onlara katılsa daha çarpıcı bir sahne ortaya çıkardı.
es: —No digas esas cosas tan horribles, hijo mío —murmuró la señora Vane, retomando, con un suspiro, una chabacana pieza de vestuario teatral que empezó a remendar. La apenaba un tanto que James no se hubiera incorporado a la compañía, lo que hubiera aumentado el pintoresquismo teatral de la situación.
vi_translation: "My son, don't say such frightening things," Mrs. Vane murmured, picking up the gaudy costume with a sigh, and began to mend it. She felt a bit disappointed that he didn't join the group. That will increase the theatrical vividness of the situation.
tr_translation: Ms. Vane murmured, "My son, don't say such things!" Sighing, she picked up an old, shabby, cheap stage costume and began to mend it. She was a bit disappointed that her son hadn't joined them. Had James joined them, a more striking scene would have emerged.
es_translation: —Don't say such horrible things, my son —murmured Mrs. Vane, resuming, with a sigh, a tawdry piece of theatrical clothing that she began to mend. It saddened her somewhat that James had not joined the company, which would have increased the theatrical picturesque nature of the situation.

en: “Why not, Mother? I mean it.”
vi: “Sao lại không, hả mẹ? Con nói thật mà.”
tr: “Neden söylemeyeyim anne? İçten konuşuyorum.
es: —¿Por qué no, madre? Es lo que siento.
vi_translation: “Why not, mom? I'm telling the truth.”
tr_translation: "Why shouldn't I say it, mom? I'm speaking sincerely."
es_translation: —Why not, mother? It's what I feel.

en: “You pain me, my son. I trust you will return from Australia in a position of affluence. I believe there is no society of any kind in the Colonies—nothing that I would call society—so when you have made your fortune, you must come back and assert yourself in London.”
vi: “Con làm mẹ đau đớn, con trai của mẹ. Mẹ tin con sẽ quay về từ Úc với địa vị giàu sang. Mẹ tin là không có tầng lớp thượng lưu bất cứ dạng nào ở các thuộc địa, không có gì mà mẹ có thể gọi là tầng lớp thượng lưu; vậy nên khi con đã phát đạt rồi thì con phải quay về và khẳng định mình ở London.”
tr: “Beni üzüyorsun, oğlum. Ben senin Avustralya’dan paralı pullu, mevki sahibi bir adam olarak döneceğine inanıyorum. Kolonilerde sosyete diye bir şey olduğuna inanmıyorum, yani benim sosyete diyebileceğim herhangi bir şey. Bu yüzden, orada yükünü tuttuktan sonra buraya dönüp Londra’da kendini göstermek zorundasın.
es: —Me duele que digas eso, hijo mío. No pierdo la esperanza de que regreses de Australia después de hacer fortuna. Creo que la buena sociedad no existe en las colonias; al menos, nada de lo que yo considero buena sociedad; de manera que cuando hayas triunfado deberás volver a Londres y convertirte aquí en una persona conocida.
vi_translation: "You cause me pain, my son. I believe you will return from Australia with a wealthy status. I believe there is no upper class of any kind in the colonies, nothing that I can call the upper class; so when you have succeeded, you must come back and establish yourself in London."
tr_translation: "You are upsetting me, my son. I believe that you will return from Australia as a wealthy and reputable man. I do not believe that there is such a thing as society in the colonies, at least not anything I would call society. Therefore, after you have made your fortune there, you must return here and make your mark in London."
es_translation: —It hurts me that you say that, my son. I haven't lost hope that you will return from Australia after making a fortune. I believe that good society does not exist in the colonies; at least, nothing of what I consider good society; so when you have succeeded, you should return to London and become a well-known person here.

en: “Society!” muttered the lad. “I don’t want to know anything about that. I should like to make some money to take you and Sibyl off the stage. I hate it.”
vi: “Tầng lớp thượng lưu!” chàng trai lẩm bẩm. “Con chẳng muốn biết gì về cái đó. Con chỉ muốn kiếm chút tiền để đưa mẹ và Sibyl ra khỏi sân khấu. Con ghét nó.”
tr: Çocuk, “Sosyete mi!” diye söylendi. “O konuyla hiç ilgilenmek istemiyorum. Benim istediğim biraz para yapıp seninle Sibyl’i sahneden uzaklaştırmak. Nefret ediyorum sahne yaşantısından.
es: —¡Buena sociedad! —murmuró el muchacho—. No me interesa nada la buena sociedad. Me gustaría ganar algún dinero para sacaros a ti y a Sibyl de los escenarios. Aborrezco la vida del teatro.
vi_translation: "The upper class!" the young man muttered. "I don't want to know anything about that. I just want to make some money to get mother and Sibyl off the stage. I hate it."
tr_translation: The child muttered, “High society!” “I don't want to get involved with that at all. What I want is to make some money and take you and Sibyl away from the stage. I hate the stage life.”
es_translation: —Good society! —murmured the boy—. I am not interested in good society at all. I would like to earn some money to get you and Sibyl off the stage. I abhor the life of the theater.

en: “Oh, Jim!” said Sibyl, laughing, “how unkind of you! But are you really going for a walk with me? That will be nice! I was afraid you were going to say good-bye to some of your friends—to Tom Hardy, who gave you that hideous pipe, or Ned Langton, who makes fun of you for smoking it. It is very sweet of you to let me have your last afternoon. Where shall we go? Let us go to the park.”
vi: “Ôi, Jim!” Sibyl vừa cười vừa nói, “Sao em ác thế! Nhưng em thật sự sẽ đi dạo với chị chứ? Hay quá! Chị sợ em đi chào tạm biệt vài người bạn em — chào Tom Hardy, cái cậu đã tặng em cái tẩu gớm guốc này, hay Ned Langton, cái cậu đã đùa cợt em vì hút nó. Em thật dễ thương vì đã cho chị hưởng buổi chiều cuối cùng của em. Mình sẽ đi đâu đây? Mình hãy đi Công viên nhé.”
tr: Sibyl, “Aman Jim, ne kadar acımasızsın!” diye güldü. “Sahi, benimle yürüyüşe çıkmayı mı istiyorsun? Ne güzel. Senin kendi arkadaşlarınla vedalaşacağını sanıyordum ben: Sana o feci pipoyu veren Tom Hardy, bu pipoyu içiyorsun diye seni alaya alan Ned Langton. Son öğleden sonranı bana ayırman çok tatlı. Nereye gideceğiz? Hadi, parka gidelim.
es: —¡Jim! —exclamó Sibyl, riendo—, ¡qué poco amable por tu parte! ¿De verdad quieres dar un paseo conmigo? ¡Eso está bien! Temía que fueses a despedirte de algunos de tus amigos..., de Tom Hardy, que te regaló esa pipa espantosa, o de Ned Langton, que te toma el pelo fumando en ella. Me conmueve que me concedas tu última tarde. ¿Qué hacemos? ¿Vamos al parque?
vi_translation: "Oh, Jim!" Sibyl said with a laugh, "Why are you so mean! But will you really take a walk with me? That's great! I was afraid you were going to say goodbye to some of your friends — say goodbye to Tom Hardy, the guy who gave you that hideous pipe, or Ned Langton, the guy who teased you for smoking it. You are so sweet for letting me enjoy your last afternoon. Where shall we go? Let's go to the Park."
tr_translation: Sibyl laughed, "Aman Jim, how cruel you are!" "Really, do you want to go for a walk with me? How nice. I thought you would be saying goodbye to your own friends: Tom Hardy, who gave you that dreadful pipe, and Ned Langton, who mocks you for smoking it. It's so sweet of you to spend your last afternoon with me. Where shall we go? Let's go to the park."
es_translation: —Jim! —exclaimed Sibyl, laughing—, how unkind of you! Do you really want to take a walk with me? That's good! I was afraid you were going to say goodbye to some of your friends..., to Tom Hardy, who gave you that dreadful pipe, or to Ned Langton, who teases you by smoking it. It touches me that you are giving me your last afternoon. What shall we do? Shall we go to the park?

en: “I am too shabby,” he answered, frowning. “Only swell people go to the park.”
vi: “Em nhếch nhác quá,” cậu trả lời, mặt nhăn nhó. “Chỉ những ai bảnh bao mới đi Công viên thôi.”
tr: Kardeşi kaşlarını çatarak, “Çok kılıksızım,” dedi. “Parka yalnızca sosyetik kişiler gidiyor.
es: —No tengo ropa adecuada —respondió su hermano, frunciendo el ceño—. Al parque sólo va gente elegante.
vi_translation: "You look so messy," he replied, frowning. "Only those who are well-dressed go to the Park."
tr_translation: His brother frowned and said, "I look so shabby." "Only high society people go to the park."
es_translation: —I don't have suitable clothes —replied her brother, frowning—. Only elegant people go to the park.

en: “Nonsense, Jim,” she whispered, stroking the sleeve of his coat.
vi: “Linh tinh quá, Jim,” nàng thì thầm, ve vuốt tay áo cậu.
tr: Sibyl onun paltosunun kolunu okşayarak, “Saçmalıyorsun,” dedi.
es: —Tonterías, Jim —susurró Sibyl, acariciándole la manga de la chaqueta.
vi_translation: "Too much nonsense, Jim," she whispered, stroking his sleeve.
tr_translation: Sibyl, stroking the sleeve of his coat, said, "You're talking nonsense."
es_translation: —Nonsense, Jim —whispered Sibyl, stroking the sleeve of his jacket.

en: He hesitated for a moment. “Very well,” he said at last, “but don’t be too long dressing.” She danced out of the door. One could hear her singing as she ran upstairs. Her little feet pattered overhead.
vi: Cậu lưỡng lự một lúc. “Thôi được,” rốt cuộc cậu nói, “nhưng đừng thay đồ quá lâu đấy.” Nàng nhảy chân sáo ra khỏi cửa. Có thể nghe tiếng nàng hát lúc nàng chạy lên gác. Đôi chân nhỏ của nàng gõ lốp cốp trên đầu.
tr: James bir an duraladı. Sonunda, “Peki,” dedi. “Ama giyinip kuşanacağım diye pek oyalanma. Sibyl dans edercesine odadan çıktı. Üst katta şarkı söylediğini duydular. O küçük ayakları tavanda pıtırdıyordu.
es: James vaciló un momento. —De acuerdo —dijo por fin—, pero no tardes demasiado en vestirte. Sibyl dio unos pasos de baile hasta la puerta. Se la oyó cantar mientras subía corriendo las escaleras y luego el ruido de sus pies en el piso superior.
vi_translation: He hesitated for a moment. "Alright," he finally said, "but don't take too long to change." She skipped out of the door. You could hear her singing as she ran upstairs. Her little feet pitter-pattered overhead.
tr_translation: James paused for a moment. Finally, he said, "Alright." "But don't take too long getting dressed up." Sibyl exited the room as if dancing. They heard her singing upstairs. Her little feet were pattering on the ceiling.
es_translation: James hesitated for a moment. —Alright —he finally said—, but don't take too long to get dressed. Sibyl took a few dance steps to the door. She was heard singing as she ran up the stairs and then the sound of her feet on the upper floor.

en: He walked up and down the room two or three times. Then he turned to the still figure in the chair. “Mother, are my things ready?” he asked.
