Pensamos que somos generosos porque atribuimos a nuestro vecino las virtudes que más pueden beneficiarnos. Alabamos al banquero para que no nos penalice por estar en números rojos y encontramos buenas cualidades en el salteador de caminos con la esperanza de que respete nuestra bolsa. Creo todo lo que he dicho. Desprecio profundamente el optimismo. En cuanto a echar a perder una vida, una vida sólo se echa a perder cuando se detiene su crecimiento. Si quieres estropear una personalidad, basta reformarla. Por lo que hace al matrimonio, por supuesto que sería una estupidez, pero hay otros vínculos, mucho más interesantes, entre hombres y mujeres. Estoy desde luego dispuesto a alentarlos. Tienen el encanto de estar de moda. Pero aquí llega Dorian, que te lo contará todo mejor que yo.
vi_translation: Lord Henry laughed. “The reason why all of us like to think so well of others is because we are all afraid of ourselves. The basis of optimism is sheer terror. We think we are generous because we credit our neighbors with the possession of those virtues that are likely to benefit us. We praise the banker so that we can overdraw our accounts, and find good qualities in the highwayman in the hope that he may spare our pockets. I am quite serious in all that I say. I disapprove of optimism more than anything. As for a spoiled life, no life is spoiled but one whose growth is arrested. If you want to harm nature, you only need to reform it. As for marriage, it is of course ridiculous, but there are other ties far more interesting between men and women. I am all for encouraging them. They have the charm of novelty. But here is Dorian himself. He will tell you more than I can.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed. "We all love to attribute goodness to others because we all fear for our own heads. The basis of optimism is sheer terror. We think ourselves magnanimous because we can see virtues in our neighbors that might benefit us. We praise the banker so we can withdraw more money from our account, and we find good qualities in the highwayman so he won't rob us. I was serious in everything I said. I utterly despise optimism. As for the extinguishing of life; no life is extinguished, as long as its development hasn't been cut short. If you want to ruin a character, just reform it! As for marriage, it's certainly nonsense, but there are other, more interesting bonds between men and women. I will not refrain from encouraging these. They all have the allure of being the latest fashion. But look, here comes Dorian. He will give you more information than I can."
es_translation: Lord Henry burst out laughing. —The reason we like to think well of others is that we are afraid of what might happen to us. The basis of optimism is terror. We think we are generous because we attribute to our neighbor the virtues that can benefit us the most. We praise the banker so that he does not penalize us for being in the red, and we find good qualities in the highwayman in the hope that he will respect our purse. I believe everything I have said. I deeply despise optimism. As for ruining a life, a life is only ruined when its growth is stopped. If you want to spoil a personality, just reform it. As for marriage, of course it would be foolish, but there are other bonds, much more interesting, between men and women. I am certainly willing to encourage them. They have the charm of being fashionable. But here comes Dorian, who will tell you everything better than I can.

en: “My dear Harry, my dear Basil, you must both congratulate me!” said the lad, throwing off his evening cape with its satin-lined wings and shaking each of his friends by the hand in turn. “I have never been so happy. Of course, it is sudden—all really delightful things are. And yet it seems to me to be the one thing I have been looking for all my life.” He was flushed with excitement and pleasure, and looked extraordinarily handsome.
vi: “Harry thân mến của tôi, Basil thân mến của tôi, hai anh nên chúc mừng tôi đi!” chàng trai nói, quăng chiếc áo choàng buổi chiều với đôi cánh lót xa tanh, và bắt tay lần lượt từng bạn. “Tôi chưa bao giờ hạnh phúc như vậy. Đương nhiên là đột ngột; mọi chuyện thật sự thú vị. Tuy vậy tôi thấy nó dường như là điều mà tôi đã tìm kiếm suốt cả cuộc đời mình.” Cậu đỏ mặt lên vì kích động và vui sướng, và nhìn có vẻ đẹp trai lạ thường.
tr: “Sevgili Harry, sevgili Basil, ikiniz de kutlamalısınız beni!” diyen genç adam saten astarlı pelerinini attı ve arkadaşlarının sırayla elini sıktı. “Ömrümde böyle mutlu olmamıştım. Biliyorum, ani oldu. Bütün sevinçli şeyler öyledir, ama gene de bu ömrümce arayıp durduğum şeymiş gibi geliyor bana.” Heyecan ve mutluluktan kızarmış, olağanüstü yakışıklı görünüyordu.
es: —Basil, Harry, ¡los dos tenéis que felicitarme! —dijo el muchacho, desprendiéndose impaciente de la capa con forro de satén y procediendo a estrechar la mano de sus dos amigos—. No he sido nunca tan feliz. Ya sé que es repentino; todo lo realmente delicioso lo es. Y, sin embargo, me parece que no he buscado otra cosa en toda mi vida —tenía la tez encendida a causa de la alegría y la emoción, y parecía singularmente apuesto.
vi_translation: “My dear Harry, my dear Basil, you should congratulate me!” the young man said, tossing aside his afternoon cloak with satin-lined wings, and shaking hands with each friend in turn. “I have never been so happy. Of course, it is sudden; everything is truly exciting. However, I feel it seems like the thing I have been searching for all my life.” He blushed with excitement and joy, and looked extraordinarily handsome.
tr_translation: “Dear Harry, dear Basil, you both must congratulate me!” said the young man, throwing off his satin-lined cloak and shaking his friends' hands one by one. “I have never been this happy in my life. I know, it was sudden. All joyful things are, but still, it feels like this is what I have been searching for all my life.” Flushed with excitement and happiness, he looked extraordinarily handsome.
es_translation: —Basil, Harry, you both have to congratulate me! —said the young man, impatiently shedding the satin-lined cloak and proceeding to shake hands with his two friends—. I've never been so happy. I know it's sudden; everything truly delightful is. And yet, it seems to me that I haven't sought anything else my entire life —his complexion was flushed with joy and emotion, and he looked remarkably handsome.

en: “I hope you will always be very happy, Dorian,” said Hallward, “but I don’t quite forgive you for not having let me know of your engagement. You let Harry know.”
vi: “Tôi mong cậu sẽ luôn luôn hạnh phúc, Dorian,” Hallward nói, “nhưng tôi thật sự không thể tha thứ được cho cậu vì chuyện cậu không cho tôi biết về sự hứa hôn của cậu. Mà cậu lại cho Harry biết.”
tr: Hallward, “Umarım ömür boyu mutlu olursun, Dorian,” dedi. “Gene de nişanını bana bildirmediğin için seni pek bağışlayamıyorum. Harry’ye söylemişsin.
es: —Espero que seas siempre muy feliz, Dorian —dijo Hallward—, pero no te perdono del todo que no me hayas informado de tu compromiso. A Harry sí se lo has dicho.
vi_translation: “I hope you will always be happy, Dorian,” Hallward said, “but I really cannot forgive you for not telling me about your engagement. Yet you told Harry.”
tr_translation: Hallward said, "I hope you will be happy for life, Dorian." "Still, I can't quite forgive you for not informing me of your engagement. You told Harry.""
es_translation: —I hope you are always very happy, Dorian —said Hallward—, but I do not entirely forgive you for not informing me of your engagement. You have told Harry.

en: “And I don’t forgive you for being late for dinner,” broke in Lord Henry, putting his hand on the lad’s shoulder and smiling as he spoke. “Come, let us sit down and try what the new chef here is like, and then you will tell us how it all came about.”
vi: “Và tôi không tha thứ cho cậu vì đến muộn bữa tối,” huân tước Henry ngắt lời, đặt tay lên vai chàng trai, và mỉm cười trong lúc y nói. “Nào, ta hãy ngồi xuống và thử xem đầu bếp mới ở đây thế nào, sau đó cậu sẽ kể cho bọn tôi nghe xem mọi chuyện đã xảy ra thế nào.”
tr: “Ben de seni yemeğe geç kaldığın için bağışlayamıyorum,” diye araya giren Lord Henry elini delikanlının omzuna koydu. Gülümsüyordu. “Buyurun, oturalım da bakalım yeni chef nasılmış görelim. Sen de bize bütün bunların nasıl olup bittiğini anlatırsın.
es: —Y yo no te perdono que llegues tarde a cenar —intervino lord Henry, poniendo una mano en el hombro del muchacho y sonriendo mientras hablaba—. Vamos a sentarnos y a enterarnos de qué tal es el nuevo chef, y luego nos explicarás cómo ha sucedido todo.
vi_translation: “And I do not forgive you for being late for dinner,” Lord Henry interrupted, placing a hand on the young man's shoulder, and smiling as he spoke. “Now, let us sit down and see how the new chef here is, then you will tell us what happened.”
tr_translation: "I can't forgive you for being late to dinner either," said Lord Henry, interrupting and placing his hand on the young man's shoulder. He was smiling. "Come on, let's sit down and see how the new chef is. You can tell us how all this happened."
es_translation: —And I do not forgive you for being late to dinner —interjected Lord Henry, placing a hand on the boy's shoulder and smiling as he spoke—. Let's sit down and find out how the new chef is, and then you can explain to us how everything happened.

en: “There is really not much to tell,” cried Dorian as they took their seats at the small round table. “What happened was simply this. After I left you yesterday evening, Harry, I dressed, had some dinner at that little Italian restaurant in Rupert Street you introduced me to, and went down at eight o’clock to the theatre. Sibyl was playing Rosalind. Of course, the scenery was dreadful and the Orlando absurd. But Sibyl! You should have seen her! When she came on in her boy’s clothes, she was perfectly wonderful. She wore a moss-coloured velvet jerkin with cinnamon sleeves, slim, brown, cross-gartered hose, a dainty little green cap with a hawk’s feather caught in a jewel, and a hooded cloak lined with dull red. She had never seemed to me more exquisite. She had all the delicate grace of that Tanagra figurine that you have in your studio, Basil. Her hair clustered round her face like dark leaves round a pale rose. As for her acting—well, you shall see her to-night. She is simply a born artist. I sat in the dingy box absolutely enthralled. I forgot that I was in London and in the nineteenth century. I was away with my love in a forest that no man had ever seen. After the performance was over, I went behind and spoke to her. As we were sitting together, suddenly there came into her eyes a look that I had never seen there before. My lips moved towards hers. We kissed each other. I can’t describe to you what I felt at that moment. It seemed to me that all my life had been narrowed to one perfect point of rose-coloured joy. She trembled all over and shook like a white narcissus. Then she flung herself on her knees and kissed my hands. I feel that I should not tell you all this, but I can’t help it. Of course, our engagement is a dead secret. She has not even told her own mother. I don’t know what my guardians will say. Lord Radley is sure to be furious. I don’t care. I shall be of age in less than a year, and then I can do what I like. I have been right, Basil, haven’t I, to take my love out of poetry and to find my wife in Shakespeare’s plays? Lips that Shakespeare taught to speak have whispered their secret in my ear. I have had the arms of Rosalind around me, and kissed Juliet on the mouth.”
vi: “Thật ra cũng chẳng có gì nhiều nhặn để kể,” Dorian kêu lên, lúc họ ngồi xuống quanh chiếc bàn tròn nhỏ. “Những gì xảy ra đơn giản là thế này. Sau khi tôi cáo từ anh chiều qua, Harry, tôi thay quần áo, ăn tối qua loa tại cái nhà hàng Ý nhỏ xíu trên phố Rupert mà anh đã giới thiệu cho tôi, và lúc tám giờ thì xuống nhà hát. Sibyl đang đóng vai Rosalind. Dĩ nhiên cảnh phông rất kinh khủng, và Orlando thì ngớ ngẩn. Nhưng Sibyl! Giá như anh thấy nàng! Khi nàng bước ra trong bộ quần áo con trai, nàng cực kỳ hoàn hảo. Nàng mặc áo chẽn nhung màu rêu với tay áo màu vỏ quế, đi bít tất nâu nịt-chéo thon dài, đội mũ lưỡi trai xanh lục nhỏ xinh với cái lông chim ưng đính vào viên đá quý, khoác áo choàng có mũ trùm đầu và lót vải đỏ đục. Dường như tôi chưa bao giờ thấy nàng tuyệt mỹ hơn. Nàng có mọi nét duyên thanh tú của bức tượng Tanagra mà anh để trong xưởng vẽ của anh, Basil. Tóc nàng tụm quanh mặt nàng như những chiếc lá đen quanh đóa hồng phai. Về phần diễn xuất của nàng — ừ, anh sẽ thấy nàng đêm nay. Nàng đơn giản là một nghệ sỹ bẩm sinh. Tôi ngồi trong khoang lô tăm tối và bị mê hoặc tuyệt đối. Tôi quên mình đang ở London và đang ở thế kỷ mười chín. Tôi đã biến đi rất xa với tình yêu của mình đến một khu rừng mà chưa ai từng thấy. Sau khi buổi diễn kết thúc, tôi ra đằng sau sân khấu và nói chuyện với nàng. Lúc chúng tôi ngồi với nhau, bỗng nhiên trong mắt nàng hiện lên một nét nào đấy mà tôi chưa từng thấy ở đó trước đây. Môi tôi nhích về phía môi nàng. Chúng tôi hôn nhau. Tôi không thể miêu tả cho các anh những gì tôi cảm thấy vào khoảnh khắc ấy. Tôi thấy dường như là cả cuộc đời tôi đã bị rút vào một điểm hoàn hảo của một niềm hân hoan hồng hào. Nàng run khắp người, và rung như bông thủy tiên trắng. Rồi nàng tụt xuống và quỳ gối hôn tay tôi. Tôi cảm thấy tôi không nên kể cho các anh nghe mọi chuyện này, nhưng tôi không thể kìm được. Dĩ nhiên, ước hẹn của chúng tôi là bí mật tuyệt đối. Nàng thậm chí chưa kể cho mẹ nàng. Tôi không biết những người giám hộ tôi sẽ nói gì. Huân tước Radley chắc chắn sẽ nổi đóa. Tôi chẳng quan tâm. Tôi sẽ đến tuổi trưởng thành sau chưa đầy một năm nữa, và lúc đó thì tôi có thể làm gì tôi muốn. Tôi đã đúng, Basil, phải không nhỉ, khi dẫn tình yêu của mình ra ngoài thơ, và tìm thấy vợ mình trong kịch Shakespeare? Đôi môi mà Shakespeare dạy nói đã thì thầm bí mật của chúng vào tai tôi. Tôi đã được đôi tay Rosalind ôm quanh mình, và được hôn Juliet lên miệng.”
tr: Küçük, yuvarlak masanın başına geçerlerken Dorian, “Anlatılacak pek bir şey yok,” dedi. “Olup biten şu: Harry, dün akşam senden ayrıldıktan sonra giysilerimi değiştim, Rupert Sokağı’ndaki, hani senin bana öğrettiğin o küçük İtalyan lokantasında yemek yedim, saat sekizde de tiyatroya gittim. Sibyl Rosalind’i oynuyordu. Dekor feciydi, Orlando’yu oynayan da gülünçtü, doğallıkla. Ama Sibyl! Onu görebilseydiniz! Oğlan kılığını giymiş olarak sahneye çıktığında tek kelimeyle harikaydı. Bol, tarçın renkli kolları olan daracık, yosun renkli bir kadife ceketle, uzun, kahverengi çorap giymiş, donuk kırmızı astarlı, kapüşonlu bir pelerine sarınmıştı! Başında da zarif, minicik, yeşil bir şapka vardı. Şapkaya parlak bir taşla bir şahin tüyü tutturulmuştu. Her zamankinden daha zarif, kusursuz gözüktü gözüme. Basil, hani senin stüdyonda o Tanagra heykelciği var ya, işte Sibyl ondaki o ince uyumu yansıtıyordu. Saçları, uçuk renkli bir gülün çevresindeki koyu yapraklar gibi yığılmıştı yüzünün çevresine. Çıkardığı oyuna gelince... İşte, bu gece onu siz de göreceksiniz. Tek kelimeyle doğuştan sanatçı bu kız. O küflü locada otururken tamamen kendimi kaptırmıştım. Londra’da olduğumu, on dokuzuncu yüzyılda yaşadığımı unutmuştum. Sevdiğimle birlikte uzaklarda, kimseciklerin görmemiş olduğu bir ormandaydım. Perde kapanınca arkaya dolanıp onunla konuştum. Yan yana oturduğumuz sırada onun gözlerinde şimdiye değin hiç görmemiş olduğum bir bakış belirdi. Benim dudaklarım da onunkilere doğru uzandı. Birbirimizi öptük. O anda neler hissettiğimi anlatamam size. Sanki tüm yaşantım kusursuz, gül renkli bir sevinç noktasında toplanmıştı. O da tepeden tırnağa titriyor, beyaz bir nergis çiçeği gibi sarsılıyordu. Derken dizüstü çökerek ellerimi öpmeye başladı... Bütün bunları size anlatmamak gerekirmiş gibi geliyor, gene de kendimi tutamıyorum. Nişanımız çok gizli, doğallıkla. O kendi annesine bile söylemedi daha. Vasilerim buna ne diyecekler, bilemiyorum. Lord Radley yüzde yüz küplere binecek. Umurumda değil. Bir yıla varmadan ergenliğe ulaşacağım, o zaman canımın istediğini yapabilirim. Basil, aşkımı şiirde bulup eşimi Shakespeare’in oyunlarından seçmekle doğru bir iş yaptım, değil mi? Konuşmayı Shakespeare’den öğrenen dudaklar gizlerini benim kulağıma fısıldadılar. Rosalind kollarını benim boynuma doladı; ben Juliet’i ağzından öptüm.
es: —En realidad no hay mucho que contar —exclamó Dorian mientras los tres ocupaban sus sitios en torno a la reducida mesa redonda—. Ayer, sencillamente, después de dejarte; Harry, me vestí, cené en el pequeño restaurante italiano de Rupert Street que tú me hiciste conocer, y a las ocho estaba en el teatro. Sibyl interpretaba a Rosalinda. Por supuesto, el decorado era horroroso y el actor que hacía de Orlando absurdo. ¡Sibyl, en cambio! ¡Tendrías que haberla visto! Cuando apareció vestida de muchacho estaba absolutamente maravillosa. Llevaba un jubón de terciopelo color musgo con mangas de color canela, calzas marrones, un precioso sombrerito verde con una pluma de halcón sujeta por una joya, y un gabán con capucha forrado de rojo mate. Nunca me había parecido tan exquisita. Tenía la gracia delicada de esa figurilla de Tanagra que tienes en tu estudio, Basil. Los cabellos rodeándole la cara como hojas oscuras en torno a una pálida rosa. En cuanto a su interpretación..., bueno, vais a verla esta noche. Es, ni más ni menos, una artista nata. Me quedé completamente embobado en mi palco cochambroso. Me olvidé de que estaba en Londres y en el siglo XIX. Me había ido con mi amada a un bosque que nadie había visto nunca. Cuando terminó la representación, pasé entre bastidores y hablé con ella. Mientras estábamos sentados uno al lado del otro, apareció de repente en sus ojos una mirada que yo no había visto nunca. Mis labios se movieron hacia los suyos. Nos besamos. No soy capaz de describiros lo que sentí en aquel momento. Me pareció que la vida entera se concentraba en un punto perfecto de alegría color rosa. Sibyl se puso a temblar de pies a cabeza, estremeciéndose como un narciso blanco. Luego se arrodilló y me besó las manos. Comprendo que no debería contaros todo esto, pero no puedo evitarlo. Por supuesto, nuestro compromiso es un secreto total. Sibyl ni siquiera se lo ha dicho a su madre. No sé lo que dirán mis tutores. Lord Radley montará sin duda en cólera. Me da igual. Seré mayor de edad en menos de un año, y entonces podré hacer lo que quiera. ¿No es cierto que he hecho bien sacando a mi amor de la poesía y encontrando a mi esposa en las obras de Shakespeare? Labios a los que Shakespeare enseñó a hablar han susurrado su secreto en mi oído. Me han rodeado los brazos de Rosalinda y he besado a Julieta en la boca.
vi_translation: “Actually, there isn't much to tell,” Dorian exclaimed, as they sat down around the small round table. “What happened is simply this. After I left you yesterday afternoon, Harry, I changed clothes, had a quick dinner at that tiny Italian restaurant on Rupert Street that you recommended to me, and at eight o'clock I went down to the theater. Sibyl was playing Rosalind. Of course, the scenery was dreadful, and Orlando was absurd. But Sibyl! If only you had seen her! When she came out in her boy's costume, she was absolutely perfect. She wore a moss-green velvet doublet with cinnamon-colored sleeves, long cross-gartered brown stockings, a small green cap with an eagle feather fastened by a jewel, and a cloak with a hood lined with dull red fabric. It seemed I had never seen her more exquisite. She had all the delicate charm of the Tanagra statue you have in your studio, Basil. Her hair clustered around her face like black leaves around a faded rose. As for her acting — well, you will see her tonight. She is simply a born artist. I sat in the darkened box and was absolutely enthralled. I forgot I was in London and in the nineteenth century. I had wandered far away with my love to a forest that no one had ever seen. After the performance ended, I went backstage and talked to her. As we sat together, suddenly there appeared in her eyes a look that I had never seen there before. My lips moved towards hers. We kissed. I cannot describe to you what I felt at that moment. It seemed as if my whole life had been narrowed to a perfect point of rosy joy. She trembled all over, and shook like a white narcissus. Then she sank down and knelt, kissing my hands. I feel I shouldn't be telling you all this, but I can't help it. Of course, our engagement is an absolute secret. She hasn't even told her mother. I don't know what my guardians will say. Lord Radley will certainly be furious. I don't care. I will come of age in less than a year, and then I can do whatever I like. I was right, Basil, wasn't I, to take my love out of poetry, and find my wife in Shakespeare's plays? The lips that Shakespeare taught to speak have whispered their secrets into my ear. I have been embraced by Rosalind's arms, and kissed by Juliet on the mouth.”
tr_translation: As they sat down at the small, round table, Dorian said, "There isn't much to tell." "Here's what happened: Harry, after leaving you last night, I changed my clothes, had dinner at that little Italian restaurant on Rupert Street that you taught me about, and went to the theater at eight o'clock. Sibyl was playing Rosalind. The set was terrible, and the actor playing Orlando was ridiculous, naturally. But Sibyl! If only you could have seen her! When she came on stage dressed as a boy, she was simply marvelous. She wore a tight, moss-colored velvet jacket with loose, cinnamon-colored sleeves, long brown stockings, and a cloak with a dull red lining and a hood! She also had a delicate, tiny green hat on her head. A hawk feather was fastened to the hat with a shiny stone. She looked more elegant and perfect than ever to me. Basil, you know that Tanagra figurine in your studio, well, Sibyl reflected that delicate harmony. Her hair was piled around her face like dark leaves around a pale-colored rose. As for her performance... Well, you'll see her tonight. This girl is a born artist, in a word. While sitting in that musty box, I was completely captivated. I forgot I was in London, living in the nineteenth century. I was in a distant forest, unseen by anyone, with my beloved. When the curtain fell, I went backstage and talked to her. While we were sitting side by side, a look appeared in her eyes that I had never seen before. My lips moved towards hers. We kissed. I can't describe to you what I felt at that moment. It was as if my entire life had culminated in a perfect, rose-colored point of joy. She was trembling from head to toe, shaking like a white narcissus flower. Then she knelt down and began to kiss my hands... It feels as if I shouldn't be telling you all this, yet I can't help myself. Our engagement is very secret, of course. She hasn't even told her own mother yet. I don't know what my guardians will say about this. Lord Radley will be absolutely furious. I don't care. In less than a year, I'll come of age, and then I can do whatever I want. Basil, I did the right thing by finding my love in poetry and choosing my wife from Shakespeare's plays, didn't I? Lips that learned to speak from Shakespeare whispered their secrets into my ear. Rosalind wrapped her arms around my neck; I kissed Juliet on the mouth."
es_translation: —Actually, there isn't much to tell —exclaimed Dorian as the three of them took their seats around the small round table—. Yesterday, simply, after leaving you, Harry, I got dressed, had dinner at the little Italian restaurant on Rupert Street that you introduced me to, and by eight I was at the theater. Sibyl was playing Rosalind. Of course, the set was horrible and the actor playing Orlando was absurd. Sibyl, on the other hand! You should have seen her! When she appeared dressed as a boy, she was absolutely marvelous. She wore a moss-colored velvet doublet with cinnamon-colored sleeves, brown hose, a lovely green hat with a hawk feather held by a jewel, and a hooded cloak lined with matte red. She had never seemed so exquisite to me. She had the delicate grace of that Tanagra figurine you have in your studio, Basil. Her hair framing her face like dark leaves around a pale rose. As for her performance..., well, you're going to see it tonight. She is, no more no less, a born artist. I was completely enthralled in my shabby box. I forgot that I was in London and in the 19th century. I had gone with my beloved to a forest that no one had ever seen. When the performance ended, I went backstage and talked to her. While we were sitting next to each other, a look suddenly appeared in her eyes that I had never seen before. My lips moved towards hers. We kissed. I can't describe to you what I felt at that moment. It seemed to me that my entire life was concentrated in a perfect point of rosy joy. Sibyl began to tremble from head to toe, shivering like a white narcissus. Then she knelt down and kissed my hands. I understand that I shouldn't be telling you all this, but I can't help it. Of course, our engagement is a total secret. Sibyl hasn't even told her mother. I don't know what my guardians will say. Lord Radley will undoubtedly be furious. I don't care. I'll be of age in less than a year, and then I can do whatever I want. Isn't it true that I did well by taking my love out of poetry and finding my wife in Shakespeare's plays? Lips that Shakespeare taught to speak have whispered their secret in my ear. Rosalind's arms have embraced me and I have kissed Juliet on the mouth.

en: “Yes, Dorian, I suppose you were right,” said Hallward slowly.
vi: “Vâng, Dorian, tôi cho là cậu đúng,” Hallward nói, chậm rãi.
tr: Hallward, “Evet, Dorian, doğru yapmışsın, sanırım,” diye yanıtladı ağır ağır.
es: —Sí, Dorian —dijo Hallward, hablando muy despacio—; supongo que has hecho bien.
vi_translation: "Yes, Dorian, I suppose you are right," Hallward said slowly.
tr_translation: Hallward replied slowly, "Yes, Dorian, I think you have done the right thing."
es_translation: —Yes, Dorian —said Hallward, speaking very slowly—; I suppose you have done well.

en: “Have you seen her to-day?” asked Lord Henry.
vi: “Hôm nay cậu có gặp cô ấy không?” huân tước Henry hỏi.
tr: Lord Henry, “Sibyl’i bugün gördün mü?” diye sordu.
es: —¿La has visto hoy? —preguntó lord Henry.
vi_translation: "Did you see her today?" Lord Henry asked.
tr_translation: Lord Henry asked, "Did you see Sibyl today?"
es_translation: —Have you seen her today? —asked Lord Henry.

en: Dorian Gray shook his head. “I left her in the forest of Arden; I shall find her in an orchard in Verona.”
vi: Dorian Gray lắc đầu. “Tôi để nàng lại trong rừng Arden, tôi sẽ tìm thấy nàng trong một vườn cây ăn trái ở Verona.”
tr: Dorian Gray başını salladı. “Onu Aden Ormanı’nda bıraktım, Verona’da bir meyve bahçesinde bulacağım.
es: Dorian Gray negó con la cabeza. —La dejé en el bosque de Arden y hoy la encontraré en un huerto de Verona.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head. "I left her in the forest of Arden, I will find her in an orchard in Verona."
tr_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head. “I left it in the Forest of Aden, I will find it in an orchard in Verona.”
es_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head. —I left her in the Forest of Arden and today I will find her in an orchard in Verona.

en: Lord Henry sipped his champagne in a meditative manner. “At what particular point did you mention the word marriage, Dorian? And what did she say in answer? Perhaps you forgot all about it.”
vi: Huân tước Henry nhắp sâm-panh với vẻ trầm tư. “Thế vào thời điểm cụ thể nào thì cậu nhắc đến từ kết hôn vậy, Dorian? Và cô ấy nói gì để trả lời? Không chừng cậu quên hết rồi.”
tr: Lord Henry şampanyasını düşünceli bir tavırla yudumlayarak, “Dorian, hangi noktada evlilik sözü ettin?” diye sordu. “Onun karşılığı ne oldu? Yoksa unuttun mu bunları?
es: Lord Henry saboreó su champán con aire meditabundo. —¿En qué punto mencionaste la palabra matrimonio, Dorian? ¿Y qué respondió ella? Quizá lo hayas olvidado por completo.
vi_translation: Lord Henry sipped champagne thoughtfully. "So at what specific moment did you mention the word marriage, Dorian? And what did she say in response? Perhaps you've forgotten everything."
tr_translation: Lord Henry, sipping his champagne thoughtfully, asked, "Dorian, at what point did you mention marriage?" "What was her response? Or have you forgotten these things?"
es_translation: Lord Henry savored his champagne with a contemplative air. —At what point did you mention the word marriage, Dorian? And what did she respond? Perhaps you have completely forgotten.

en: “My dear Harry, I did not treat it as a business transaction, and I did not make any formal proposal. I told her that I loved her, and she said she was not worthy to be my wife. Not worthy! Why, the whole world is nothing to me compared with her.”
vi: “Harry thân mến của tôi, tôi không coi nó như một giao dịch thương mại, và tôi không đưa ra bất cứ lời đề nghị chính thức nào cả. Tôi bảo nàng rằng tôi yêu nàng, và nàng nói nàng không xứng đáng làm vợ tôi. Không xứng đáng! Tại sao, với tôi thì cả thế giới này chẳng là gì so với nàng.
tr: “Sevgili Harry, bir iş kontratı gibi ele almadım ben bu konuyu, resmî bir öneride de bulunmadım. Onu sevdiğimi söyledim, o da benim eşim olmaya kendini layık bulmadığını söyledi. Layık değilmiş! Oysa benim gözümde dünya bir yana, o bir yana.
es: —Mi querido Harry, no me comporté como si fuera un trato comercial, y no le hice explícitamente una propuesta de matrimonio. Le dije que la amaba y ella respondió que no era digna de ser mi esposa. ¡Que no era digna! ¡Cuando el mundo entero no es nada para mí comparado con ella!
vi_translation: “My dear Harry, I do not consider it as a commercial transaction, and I am not making any formal offer at all. I told her that I love her, and she said she is not worthy to be my wife. Not worthy! Why, to me, the whole world is nothing compared to her.”
tr_translation: “Dear Harry, I didn't approach this matter like a job contract, nor did I make a formal proposal. I said that I loved her, and she said that she didn't consider herself worthy of being my wife. Not worthy! But in my eyes, the world on one side, and her on the other.”
es_translation: —My dear Harry, I did not behave as if it were a business deal, and I did not explicitly make a marriage proposal. I told her that I loved her and she responded that she was not worthy to be my wife. That she was not worthy! When the entire world is nothing to me compared to her!

en: “Women are wonderfully practical,” murmured Lord Henry, “much more practical than we are. In situations of that kind we often forget to say anything about marriage, and they always remind us.”
vi: “Phụ nữ cực kỳ thực dụng,” huân tước Henry lẩm bẩm — "thực dụng hơn nhiều so với chúng ta. Trong những tình huống kiểu đó, ta thường quên nói bất cứ điều gì về hôn nhân, và họ luôn nhắc nhở ta.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Kadınlar olağanüstü pratiktirler,” diye mırıldandı. “Bizden çok daha pratik. Bu gibi durumlarda bizler evlilikten söz açmayı çok zaman unuturuz da onlar hep aklımıza getirirler.
es: —Las mujeres son maravillosamente prácticas —murmuró lord Henry—; mucho más prácticas que nosotros. En situaciones como ésa, olvidamos con frecuencia mencionar la palabra matrimonio, pero ellas nos lo recuerdan siempre.
vi_translation: “Women are extremely practical,” Lord Henry muttered — "much more practical than we are. In those kinds of situations, we often forget to say anything about marriage, and they always remind us.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, "Women are extraordinarily practical." "Much more practical than we are. In situations like this, we often forget to bring up marriage, but they always remind us."
es_translation: —Women are wonderfully practical —murmured Lord Henry—; much more practical than we are. In situations like that, we often forget to mention the word marriage, but they always remind us.

en: Hallward laid his hand upon his arm. “Don’t, Harry. You have annoyed Dorian. He is not like other men. He would never bring misery upon any one. His nature is too fine for that.”
vi: Hallward để bàn tay mình lên cánh tay y. “Đừng, Harry. Anh đã làm Dorian khó chịu rồi đó. Cậu ấy không giống những người đàn ông khác. Cậu ấy sẽ chẳng bao giờ mang khổ đau đến cho bất cứ ai. Bản chất cậu ấy quá cao thượng với việc ấy.”
tr: Hallward elini onun koluna koydu. “Yapma, Harry. Dorian’ı kızdırdın. Dorian başka erkeklere benzemez. Kimseye bile bile acı çektirmez. Ruhu böyle şeyler yapmayacak kadar soyludur.
es: Hallward le puso una mano en el brazo. —No, Harry. Has disgustado a Dorian, que no es como otros hombres. Dorian nunca haría desgraciada a otra persona. Tiene demasiada delicadeza para una cosa así.
vi_translation: Hallward put his hand on his arm. "Don't, Harry. You have already upset Dorian. He is not like other men. He will never bring sorrow to anyone. His nature is too noble for that."
tr_translation: Hallward put his hand on his arm. "Don't do it, Harry." "You have upset Dorian." "Dorian is not like other men." "He would never intentionally cause anyone pain." "His soul is too noble for such things.""
es_translation: Hallward put a hand on his arm. —No, Harry. You have upset Dorian, who is not like other men. Dorian would never make another person unhappy. He is too delicate for such a thing.

en: Lord Henry looked across the table. “Dorian is never annoyed with me,” he answered. “I asked the question for the best reason possible, for the only reason, indeed, that excuses one for asking any question—simple curiosity. I have a theory that it is always the women who propose to us, and not we who propose to the women. Except, of course, in middle-class life. But then the middle classes are not modern.”
vi: Huân tước Henry nhìn ngang qua bàn. “Dorian chẳng bao giờ khó chịu với tôi,” y trả lời. “Tôi đưa ra câu hỏi ấy vì lý do tốt nhất có thể, vì lý do duy nhất mà, quả thực, miễn thứ được cho người ta vì đã đưa ra bất cứ câu hỏi nào — sự tò mò hồn nhiên. Tôi có một lý thuyết rằng luôn luôn là phụ nữ cầu hôn ta, chứ không phải ta cầu hôn phụ nữ. Ngoại trừ, dĩ nhiên, ở cuộc sống của giai cấp tiểu tư sản. Nhưng hiện nay thì giai cấp tiểu tư sản đã tụt hậu với thời đại.”
tr: Lord Henry masanın karşı tarafına bakarak, “Dorian bana asla kızmaz,” diye yanıtladı. “O soruyu dünyanın en yerinde nedeniyle sordum; daha doğrusu herhangi bir soru sormanın tek nedeni, yani basit bir merak. Ben bir kuram üretmişimdir: Erkekler kadınlara evlenme teklif etmez. Evlilik teklifi her zaman kadından gelir. Orta sınıf yaşantısı bunun dışında kalır, doğallıkla. Ama orta sınıflar çağdaş değildir ki zaten.
es: Lord Henry miró por encima de la mesa. —Dorian no está nunca disgustado conmigo —respondió—. He hecho la pregunta por la mejor de las razones, por la única razón, a decir verdad, que disculpa de hacer cualquier pregunta: la simple curiosidad. Mantengo la teoría de que son siempre las mujeres quienes nos proponen el matrimonio y no nosotros a ellas. Excepto, por supuesto, las personas de la clase media. Pero lo cierto es que las clases medias no son modernas.
vi_translation: Lord Henry looked across the table. “Dorian is never annoyed with me,” he replied. “I asked that question for the best possible reason, the only reason that, indeed, excuses one for asking any question at all — sheer curiosity. I have a theory that it is always women who propose to us, and not we who propose to women. Except, of course, in the lives of the lower middle class. But nowadays the lower middle class is behind the times.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, looking across the table, replied, "Dorian never gets angry with me." "I asked that question for the most valid reason in the world; or rather, the only reason to ask any question, which is simple curiosity. I have a theory: Men do not propose to women. The marriage proposal always comes from the woman. The middle-class life is an exception to this, naturally. But the middle classes are not contemporary anyway."
es_translation: Lord Henry looked over the table. —Dorian is never upset with me —he replied—. I asked the question for the best of reasons, for the only reason, in truth, that justifies asking any question: simple curiosity. I maintain the theory that it is always women who propose marriage to us and not we to them. Except, of course, for people of the middle class. But the truth is that the middle classes are not modern.

en: Dorian Gray laughed, and tossed his head. “You are quite incorrigible, Harry; but I don’t mind. It is impossible to be angry with you. When you see Sibyl Vane, you will feel that the man who could wrong her would be a beast, a beast without a heart. I cannot understand how any one can wish to shame the thing he loves. I love Sibyl Vane. I want to place her on a pedestal of gold and to see the world worship the woman who is mine. What is marriage? An irrevocable vow. You mock at it for that. Ah! don’t mock. It is an irrevocable vow that I want to take. Her trust makes me faithful, her belief makes me good. When I am with her, I regret all that you have taught me. I become different from what you have known me to be. I am changed, and the mere touch of Sibyl Vane’s hand makes me forget you and all your wrong, fascinating, poisonous, delightful theories.”
vi: Dorian Gray cười và hất đầu. “Anh đúng là bất trị, Harry; nhưng tôi chẳng để ý đâu. Không thể nào giận anh được. Khi anh gặp Sibyl thì anh sẽ cảm thấy rằng kẻ nào có thể hại nàng ắt phải là một con thú, một con thú không tim. Tôi không thể hiểu vì sao mà ai đó có thể lại muốn làm nhục người họ yêu. Tôi yêu Sibyl Vane. Tôi muốn đặt nàng lên bệ vàng, và nhìn thế giới tôn sùng cô gái thuộc về tôi. Hôn nhân là gì? Một lời nguyện thề không thể hủy bỏ. Anh nhạo báng nó vì thế chứ gì. Ôi! đừng nhạo báng. Đó là một lời nguyện thề không thể hủy bỏ mà tôi muốn gánh vác. Kỳ vọng của nàng khiến tôi chung tình, lòng tin của nàng khiến tôi tử tế. Khi tôi bên nàng, tôi hối tiếc mọi điều mà anh đã dạy tôi. Tôi trở nên khác biệt với người mà anh biết tôi đã từng là. Tôi đã thay đổi, và chỉ cần chạm nhẹ vào tay Sibyl Vane thôi cũng đủ khiến tôi quên anh và mọi lý thuyết sai trái, mê hoặc, độc hại, thú vị của anh.”
tr: Dorian Gray gülerek başını arkaya attı. “Sen hiç yola gelmeyeceksin, Harry, ama umurumda değil. Sana kızmanın yolu yok. Sibyl Vane’i görünce anlayacaksın, ona kötülük eden kimse canavar demektir, kalpsiz bir canavar. İnsan sevdiği şeyi nasıl olur da utanç verici duruma düşürür, anlayamıyorum. Sibyl Vane’i seviyorum ben. Onu altın bir tahtın üstüne çıkartmak, bütün dünyanın sevdiğim kadına tapındığını görmek istiyorum. Evlilik nedir? Geri alınamayan bir yemin. Bu yüzden alaya alıyorsun evliliği. Kuzum, alay etme. Bu geri alınmaz andı içmek istiyorum ben. Sibyl’in bana güvenmesi bana sadakat aşılıyor, inancı beni iyi bir insan yapıyor. Onun yanındayken senin öğrettiklerini öğrendiğim için yeriniyorum. Senin tanıdığından daha başka bir kişi oluyorum. Değişiyorum. Sibyl Vane’in elinin bir tek dokunuşu bana senin o yanlış, büyüleyici, zehirli, keyifli kuramlarının hepsini unutturuyor.
es: Dorian Gray se echó a reír y movió la cabeza. —Eres completamente incorregible, Harry; pero no me importa. Es imposible enfadarse contigo. Cuando veas a Sibyl Vane comprenderás que el hombre que la tratara mal sería un desalmado, un ser sin corazón. No entiendo que nadie quiera avergonzar al ser que ama. Y yo amo a Sibyl Vane. Quiero colocarla sobre un pedestal de oro, y ver cómo el mundo venera a la mujer que es mía. ¿Qué es el matrimonio? Una promesa irrevocable. Por eso te burlas de él. ¡No lo hagas! Es una promesa irrevocable la que yo quiero hacer. La confianza de Sibyl me hace fiel, su fe me hace bueno. Cuando estoy con ella, reniego de todo lo que me has enseñado. Me convierto en alguien diferente del que has conocido. He cambiado y el simple hecho de tocar la mano de Sibyl Vane hace que te olvide y que olvide tus falsas teorías, tan fascinantes, tan emponzoñadas, tan deliciosas.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray smiled and tossed his head. “You are incorrigible, Harry; but I don't mind. It is impossible to be angry with you. When you meet Sibyl, you will feel that anyone who could harm her must be a beast, a heartless beast. I cannot understand why anyone would want to disgrace the person they love. I love Sibyl Vane. I want to place her on a golden pedestal and watch the world worship the girl who belongs to me. What is marriage? An irrevocable vow. You mock it for that reason, don't you? Oh! don't mock it. It is an irrevocable vow that I want to bear. Her expectations make me faithful, her trust makes me kind. When I am with her, I regret everything you have taught me. I become different from the person you knew I used to be. I have changed, and just a touch of Sibyl Vane's hand is enough to make me forget you and all your wrong, fascinating, poisonous, delightful theories.”
tr_translation: Dorian Gray threw his head back laughing. “You will never come around, Harry, but I don't care. There is no way to be angry with you. When you see Sibyl Vane, you will understand, anyone who harms her is a monster, a heartless monster. I can't understand how someone can disgrace what they love. I love Sibyl Vane. I want to raise her on a golden throne, to see the whole world worship the woman I love. What is marriage? An irrevocable vow. That is why you mock marriage. My dear, don't mock it. I want to take this irrevocable vow. Sibyl's trust in me instills loyalty in me, her faith makes me a good person. When I am with her, I regret learning what you taught me. I become a different person than the one you know. I am changing. A single touch of Sibyl Vane's hand makes me forget all your wrong, enchanting, poisonous, delightful theories.”
es_translation: Dorian Gray laughed and shook his head. —You are completely incorrigible, Harry; but I don't mind. It is impossible to be angry with you. When you see Sibyl Vane, you will understand that the man who treated her badly would be a heartless, soulless being. I don't understand how anyone could want to shame the one they love. And I love Sibyl Vane. I want to place her on a golden pedestal and see the world revere the woman who is mine. What is marriage? An irrevocable promise. That is why you mock it. Don't do it! It is an irrevocable promise that I want to make. Sibyl's trust makes me faithful, her faith makes me good. When I am with her, I renounce everything you have taught me. I become someone different from the one you have known. I have changed, and the mere act of touching Sibyl Vane's hand makes me forget you and forget your false theories, so fascinating, so poisoned, so delightful.

en: “And those are ...?” asked Lord Henry, helping himself to some salad.
vi: “Và đó là…?” huân tước Henry hỏi, tự phục vụ mình một ít xa-lát.
tr: Lord Henry tabağına biraz salata alarak, “Peki, neymiş bu kuramlar?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Mis teorías...? —preguntó lord Henry, sirviéndose un poco de ensalada.
vi_translation: "And that is...?" Lord Henry asked, serving himself some salad.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, taking some salad onto his plate, asked, "Well, what are these theories?"
es_translation: —My theories...? —asked Lord Henry, serving himself some salad.

en: “Oh, your theories about life, your theories about love, your theories about pleasure. All your theories, in fact, Harry.”
vi: “Ôi, các lý thuyết của anh về cuộc sống, các lý thuyết của anh về tình yêu, các lý thuyết của anh về khoái lạc. Thực ra là mọi lý thuyết của anh, Harry.”
tr: “Oo, işte senin hayat konusundaki, aşk konusundaki, keyif konusundaki kuramların. Kısacası, senin bütün kuramların, Harry.
es: —Tus teorías sobre la vida, tus teorías sobre el amor, tus teorías sobre el placer. Todas tus teorías, de hecho.
vi_translation: “Oh, your theories about life, your theories about love, your theories about pleasure. In fact, all your theories, Harry.”
tr_translation: "Oh, here are your theories about life, about love, about pleasure. In short, all your theories, Harry."
es_translation: —Your theories about life, your theories about love, your theories about pleasure. All your theories, in fact.

en: “Pleasure is the only thing worth having a theory about,” he answered in his slow melodious voice. “But I am afraid I cannot claim my theory as my own. It belongs to Nature, not to me. Pleasure is Nature’s test, her sign of approval. When we are happy, we are always good, but when we are good, we are not always happy.”
vi: “Khoái lạc là thứ duy nhất xứng đáng có một lý thuyết về nó,” y trả lời, bằng giọng nói chậm rãi, du dương của mình. “Nhưng tôi e rằng tôi không thể nhận xằng lý thuyết của tôi là của chính tôi. Nó thuộc về Tự nhiên, không thuộc về tôi. Khoái lạc là phép thử của Tự nhiên, dấu hiệu chấp thuận của bà ấy. Khi ta hạnh phúc thì ta luôn tử tế, nhưng khi ta tử tế thì không phải lúc nào ta cũng hạnh phúc.”
tr: Lord Henry o acelesiz, ezgili sesiyle, “Üzerinde kuram geliştirmeye değer tek şey keyiftir,” dedi. “Ne var ki bu konudaki kuramım benim kendimindir, diye iddia edemem. Doğanındır o, benim değil. Keyif, Doğa’nın sınavı, onay imgesidir. Mutlu olduğumuz zamanlarda hep iyi bir insan oluruz da iyi insan olduğumuz zamanlarda ille de mutlu olmayabiliriz.
es: —El placer es la única cosa sobre la que merece la pena elaborar una teoría —respondió lord Henry separando bien las palabras con su voz melodiosa—. Pero mucho me temo que no me puedo atribuir esa teoría como propia. No me pertenece a mí, pertenece a la Naturaleza. El placer es la prueba de fuego de la Naturaleza. Cuando somos felices siempre somos buenos, pero cuando somos buenos no siempre somos felices.
vi_translation: “Pleasure is the only thing worth having a theory about,” he replied, in his slow, melodious voice. “But I am afraid I cannot claim my theory as my own. It belongs to Nature, not to me. Pleasure is Nature's test, her sign of approval. When we are happy, we are always good, but when we are good, we are not always happy.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, with his languid, melodious voice, said, "The only thing worth developing a theory about is pleasure." "However, I cannot claim that this theory is my own. It belongs to Nature, not to me. Pleasure is Nature's test, its approval symbol. When we are happy, we are always good people, but when we are good people, we may not necessarily be happy."
es_translation: —Pleasure is the only thing worth having a theory about —replied Lord Henry, carefully enunciating each word with his melodious voice—. But I am very much afraid that I cannot claim that theory as my own. It does not belong to me; it belongs to Nature. Pleasure is Nature's touchstone. When we are happy, we are always good, but when we are good, we are not always happy.

en: “Ah! but what do you mean by good?” cried Basil Hallward.
vi: “Ôi! Nhưng ý anh muốn nói gì đối với sự tử tế?” Basil Hallward kêu lên.
tr: Basil Hallward, “Güzel ama iyi insandan kastın nedir?” diye sordu.
es: —Sí, pero, ¿qué quieres decir con bueno? —exclamó Basil Hallward.
vi_translation: “Oh! But what do you mean by kindness?” Basil Hallward exclaimed.
tr_translation: Basil Hallward asked, "What do you mean by a beautiful but good person?"
es_translation: —Yes, but what do you mean by good? —exclaimed Basil Hallward.

en: “Yes,” echoed Dorian, leaning back in his chair and looking at Lord Henry over the heavy clusters of purple-lipped irises that stood in the centre of the table, “what do you mean by good, Harry?”
vi: “Vâng,” Dorian lặp lại, ngả lưng lên ghế, và nhìn huân tước Henry bên trên những bó hoa diên vĩ môi-tía nặng trĩu để giữa bàn, “ý anh muốn nói gì đối với sự tử tế, Harry?”
tr: Dorian da, “Evet,” diye onu onayladı. Arkasına yaslandı, masanın ortasında duran mor dudaklı susam çiçeklerinin üzerinden Lord Henry’ye baktı. “İyi insan tanımıyla neyi kastediyorsun, Harry?
es: —Sí —asintió Dorian, recostándose en el asiento, y mirando a lord Henry sobre el tupido ramo de iris morados que ocupaba el centro de la mesa—, ¿qué quieres decir con bueno?
vi_translation: “Yes,” Dorian repeated, leaning back in his chair, and looking at Lord Henry over the heavy bunches of purple-lipped irises placed in the middle of the table, “what do you mean by kindness, Harry?”
tr_translation: Dorian said, "Yes," approving him. He leaned back and looked at Lord Henry over the purple-lipped sesame flowers in the middle of the table. "What do you mean by the definition of a good person, Harry?"
es_translation: —Yes —Dorian agreed, leaning back in his seat and looking at Lord Henry over the thick bouquet of purple irises that occupied the center of the table—, what do you mean by good?

en: “To be good is to be in harmony with one’s self,” he replied, touching the thin stem of his glass with his pale, fine-pointed fingers. “Discord is to be forced to be in harmony with others. One’s own life—that is the important thing. As for the lives of one’s neighbours, if one wishes to be a prig or a Puritan, one can flaunt one’s moral views about them, but they are not one’s concern. Besides, individualism has really the higher aim. Modern morality consists in accepting the standard of one’s age. I consider that for any man of culture to accept the standard of his age is a form of the grossest immorality.”
vi: “Sống tử tế nghĩa là sống hòa hợp với chính mình,” y đáp lại, chạm vào cái chân cốc mảnh mai bằng những ngón tay nhợt nhạt, nhọn xinh. “Bất đồng là bị buộc phải sống hòa hợp với người khác. Cuộc đời chính ta — đó là điều quan trọng. Còn về đời những người quanh ta, nếu ta muốn thành một kẻ khinh khỉnh hoặc khắt khe, thì ta có thể khoe khoang các quan điểm đạo đức của ta về họ, nhưng họ không phải mối quan tâm của ta. Ngoài ra, Chủ nghĩa cá nhân thật sự có mục đích cao hơn. Đức hạnh thời hiện đại cốt ở việc chấp nhận chuẩn mực thời đại của ta. Tôi cho là với bất cứ người có văn hóa nào thì việc chấp nhận chuẩn mực thời đại của anh ta chính là một hình thức phi luân vô đạo trắng trợn nhất.”
tr: Lord Henry kadehinin incecik sapına o solgun, sivri uçlu parmaklarıyla dokunarak, “İyi insan olmak demek insanın kendi kendisiyle uyum içinde olması demektir,” dedi. “Uyumsuzluk da insanın başkalarıyla uyum içinde olmaya zorlanması demektir. Kişinin kendi yaşamı: Önemli olan budur. Komşularımızın yaşamlarına gelince; insan tutucu ya da püriten olmak isterse bunlara ilişkin ahlaksal görüşlerini ilan edebilir, ama aslında bunlar bizi hiç ilgilendirmez. Zaten bireyselliğin güttüğü amaç daha yücedir. Çağdaş ahlak çağın ölçüsünü benimsemekten ibarettir. Bence herhangi bir kültürlü kişinin yaşadığı çağın ölçüsünü benimsemesi en kabasından bir ahlaksızlıktır.
es: —Ser bueno es estar en armonía con uno mismo —replicó lord Henry, tocando el delicado pie de la copa con dedos muy blancos y finos—. Hay disonancia cuando uno se ve forzado a estar en armonía con otros. La propia vida..., eso es lo importante. En cuanto a la vida de nuestros vecinos, si uno quiere ser un hipócrita o un puritano, podemos hacer alarde de nuestras ideas sobre moral, pero en realidad esas personas no son asunto nuestro. Por otra parte, las metas del individualismo son las más elevadas. La moralidad moderna consiste en aceptar las normas de la propia época. Pero yo considero que, para un hombre culto, aceptar las normas de su época es la peor inmoralidad.
vi_translation: “Living kindly means living in harmony with oneself,” he replied, touching the slender stem of the glass with his pale, delicate fingers. “Disagreement means being forced to live in harmony with others. One's own life — that is what matters. As for the lives of those around us, if we wish to become disdainful or strict, we can flaunt our moral views about them, but they are not our concern. Moreover, true Individualism has a higher purpose. Modern virtue lies in accepting the standards of our time. I believe that for any cultured person, accepting the standards of his time is the most blatant form of immorality.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, touching the thin stem of his glass with those pale, pointed fingers, said, "To be a good person means to be in harmony with oneself." "Disharmony is being forced to be in harmony with others. One's own life: That is what matters. As for the lives of our neighbors; if one wants to be conservative or puritanical, they can proclaim their moral views about them, but in reality, they do not concern us at all. Moreover, the aim pursued by individuality is higher. Contemporary morality is merely adopting the standards of the age. In my opinion, for any cultured person to adopt the standards of their age is the grossest form of immorality."
es_translation: —To be good is to be in harmony with oneself —replied Lord Henry, touching the delicate foot of the glass with very white and fine fingers—. There is dissonance when one is forced to be in harmony with others. One's own life... that is what is important. As for the lives of our neighbors, if one wants to be a hypocrite or a puritan, we can flaunt our ideas about morality, but in reality, those people are not our concern. On the other hand, the goals of individualism are the highest. Modern morality consists in accepting the norms of one's own era. But I consider that, for a cultured man, accepting the norms of his era is the worst immorality.

en: “But, surely, if one lives merely for one’s self, Harry, one pays a terrible price for doing so?” suggested the painter.
vi: “Nhưng chắc chắn là nếu ta sống chỉ vì mình, Harry, ta sẽ phải trả một cái giá khủng khiếp cho việc đó chứ?” họa sỹ gợi ý
tr: Ressam, “Ama Harry, insan salt kendisi için yaşarsa karşılığında mutlaka müthiş bir bedel ödemez mi?” diye görüşünü belirtti.
es: —Pero, por supuesto, si uno vive tan sólo para uno mismo, ha de pagar un precio terrible por hacerlo, ¿no es cierto, Harry? —preguntó el pintor.
vi_translation: "But surely if we live only for ourselves, Harry, we will have to pay a terrible price for it, won't we?" the artist suggested.
tr_translation: The painter said, "But Harry, if a person lives solely for themselves, don't they inevitably pay a tremendous price in return?"
es_translation: —But, of course, if one lives only for oneself, one must pay a terrible price for it, isn't that right, Harry? —asked the painter.

en: “Yes, we are overcharged for everything nowadays. I should fancy that the real tragedy of the poor is that they can afford nothing but self-denial. Beautiful sins, like beautiful things, are the privilege of the rich.”
vi: “Vâng, ta phải trả cái giá quá đắt cho mọi thứ thời nay. Tôi cho rằng bi kịch thực sự của người nghèo là họ không thể đủ khả năng để làm bất cứ cái gì ngoài sự hy sinh. Các tội lỗi đẹp đẽ, cũng như các thứ đẹp đẽ, là đặc quyền đặc lợi của người giàu.”
tr: “Evet, bugünlerde her şeyimizi aşırı pahalıya satın alıyorum. Bana kalırsa yoksulların gerçek trajedisi şu ki keseleri ancak karınlarını doyurmaya yetiyor. Güzel günahlar da, güzel nesneler gibi, zenginlerin harcıdır.
es: —Sí, en los tiempos que corren se nos cobra excesivamente por todo. Tengo la impresión de que la verdadera tragedia de los pobres es que no pueden permitirse nada excepto renunciar a sí mismos. Los pecados hermosos, como los objetos hermosos, son el privilegio de los ricos.
vi_translation: “Yes, we have to pay too high a price for everything these days. I think the real tragedy of the poor is that they cannot afford to do anything except sacrifice. Beautiful sins, like beautiful things, are the privilege of the rich.”
tr_translation: “Yes, these days I buy everything at an extremely high price. In my opinion, the real tragedy of the poor is that their purses are only enough to fill their stomachs. Beautiful sins, like beautiful objects, are the domain of the rich.”
es_translation: —Yes, in these times we are excessively charged for everything. I have the impression that the true tragedy of the poor is that they cannot afford anything except to give up on themselves. Beautiful sins, like beautiful objects, are the privilege of the rich.

en: “One has to pay in other ways but money.”
vi: “Ta phải trả bằng những cách khác ngoài tiền.
tr: “İnsan bu bedeli paradan başka şeylerle de ödemek zorunda kalıyor.
es: —Hay que pagar de otras maneras además de con dinero.
vi_translation: “I have to pay in ways other than money.”
tr_translation: “A person has to pay this price with things other than money as well.”
es_translation: —One must pay in ways other than with money.

en: “What sort of ways, Basil?”
vi: “Cái loại cách nào thế, Basil?”
tr: “Örneğin nasıl şeyler, Basil?
es: —¿De qué maneras, Basil?
vi_translation: “What kind of method is that, Basil?”
tr_translation: “For example, what kind of things, Basil?”
es_translation: —In what ways, Basil?

en: “Oh! I should fancy in remorse, in suffering, in ... well, in the consciousness of degradation.”
vi: “Ôi! Tôi cho là bằng sự ăn năn, bằng sự đau khổ, bằng… ừ, bằng ý thức về sự tha hóa.
tr: “Örneğin nasıl şeyler, Basil? “Ne bileyim ben, pişmanlık, vicdan azabı, sonra... Aşağılanmanın bilinci.
es: —Imagino que con remordimientos, sufriendo..., bueno, dándose cuenta de la degradación.
vi_translation: "Oh! I believe that through repentance, through suffering, through... yes, through the awareness of degradation.""
tr_translation: “For example, what kind of things, Basil?” “How should I know, regret, remorse, then... The consciousness of humiliation.”
es_translation: —I imagine with remorse, suffering..., well, realizing the degradation.

en: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. “My dear fellow, mediæval art is charming, but mediæval emotions are out of date. One can use them in fiction, of course. But then the only things that one can use in fiction are the things that one has ceased to use in fact. Believe me, no civilized man ever regrets a pleasure, and no uncivilized man ever knows what a pleasure is.”
vi: Huân tước Henry nhún vai. “Bạn ơi, nghệ thuật trung cổ đẹp thật đấy, nhưng những cảm xúc trung cổ thì lỗi thời rồi. Người ta có thể dùng chúng trong tiểu thuyết, dĩ nhiên. Nhưng mặt khác thì những thứ duy nhất mà người ta có thể dùng trong tiểu thuyết là những thứ mà người ta đã thôi dùng trên thực tế. Tin tôi đi, không có người văn minh nào từng hối tiếc một khoái lạc, và chẳng có kẻ thiếu văn minh nào từng biết khoái lạc là gì.”
tr: Lord Henry omuzlarını silkti. “İki gözüm, Ortaçağ sanatı pek hoştur, gelgelelim Ortaçağ duygularının modası çoktan geçti. Romanlarda kullanabiliriz bu duyguları. Ama zaten romanlarda kullandığımız şeyler gerçek yaşamda kullanmadığımız şeyler değil midir? İnan bana, hiçbir uygar kişi sürdüğü keyiften ötürü pişmanlık çekmez, hiçbir ilkel kişi de keyfin ne olduğunu bilmez.
es: Lord Henry se encogió de hombros. —Amigo mío, el arte medieval es encantador, pero las emociones medievales están anticuadas. Se las puede utilizar en las novelas, por supuesto. Pero las cosas que se pueden utilizar en la narrativa son las que han dejado de usarse en la vida real. Créeme, ningún hombre civilizado se arrepiente nunca de un placer, y los no civilizados nunca llegan a saber qué es un placer.
vi_translation: Lord Henry shrugged. “My friend, medieval art is truly beautiful, but medieval emotions are outdated. One can use them in novels, of course. But on the other hand, the only things one can use in novels are those that people have stopped using in reality. Believe me, no civilized person has ever regretted a pleasure, and no uncivilized person has ever known what pleasure is.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. "My dear, Medieval art is quite charming, however, the fashion of Medieval sentiments is long gone. We can use these sentiments in novels. But aren't the things we use in novels precisely the things we don't use in real life? Believe me, no civilized person regrets the pleasure they have enjoyed, and no primitive person knows what pleasure is."
es_translation: Lord Henry shrugged his shoulders. —My friend, medieval art is charming, but medieval emotions are outdated. They can be used in novels, of course. But the things that can be used in narrative are those that have ceased to be used in real life. Believe me, no civilized man ever regrets a pleasure, and the uncivilized never come to know what a pleasure is.

en: “I know what pleasure is,” cried Dorian Gray. “It is to adore some one.”
vi: “Tôi biết khoái lạc là gì,” Dorian Gray la lên. “Đó là tôn thờ ai đó.”
tr: Dorian, “Keyfin ne olduğunu ben biliyorum!” diye atıldı... “Birine tapınmak.
es: —Yo sé lo que es el placer —exclamó Dorian Gray—. Adorar a alguien.
vi_translation: “I know what pleasure is,” Dorian Gray exclaimed. “It is to adore someone.”
tr_translation: Dorian exclaimed, "I know what pleasure is!" "Worshiping someone."
es_translation: —I know what pleasure is —exclaimed Dorian Gray—. To adore someone.

en: “That is certainly better than being adored,” he answered, toying with some fruits. “Being adored is a nuisance. Women treat us just as humanity treats its gods. They worship us, and are always bothering us to do something for them.”
vi: “Điều ấy hẳn là tốt hơn bị tôn thờ,” y trả lời, nghịch với ít trái cây. “Bị tôn thờ là một sự phiền toái kinh khủng. Đàn bà đối xử với ta hệt như loài người đối xử với các vị thần của nó. Họ thờ ta, và luôn phiền ta làm gì đó cho họ.”
tr: Lord Henry meyveleri evirip çevirerek, “Evet, bu tapılmaktan yeğdir,” diye yanıtladı. “Tapılmak can sıkıntısıdır. İnsanoğlu tanrılarına nasıl davranırsa kadınlar da bize öyle davranırlar. Tapınırlar bize, ille onlar için bir şeyler yapalım diye dürtükleyip dururlar.
es: —Sin duda eso es mejor que ser adorado —respondió lord Henry, jugueteando con una fruta—. Ser adorado es muy molesto. Las mujeres nos tratan como la humanidad trata a sus dioses. Nos rinden culto y están siempre molestándonos para que hagamos algo por ellas.
vi_translation: “That is certainly better than being worshipped,” he replied, playing with some fruit. “Being worshipped is a terrible nuisance. Women treat me just like humans treat their gods. They worship me, and always bother me to do something for them.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, turning the fruits over, replied, "Yes, it is better than being worshipped." "Being worshipped is tedious. As mankind treats their gods, so do women treat us. They worship us, constantly prodding us to do something for them."
es_translation: —Undoubtedly that is better than being adored —replied Lord Henry, playing with a fruit—. Being adored is very annoying. Women treat us like humanity treats its gods. They worship us and are always bothering us to do something for them.

en: “I should have said that whatever they ask for they had first given to us,” murmured the lad gravely. “They create love in our natures. They have a right to demand it back.”
vi: “Tôi phải nói là bất cứ thứ gì họ xin ta thì họ đều đã cho ta trước,” chàng trai lẩm bẩm, trang trọng. “Họ tạo ra Tình yêu trong bản tính ta. Họ có quyền đòi nó lại.”
tr: Dorian ciddi bir ifadeyle, “Bana sorarsan onların bizden istedikleri şey, ne olursa olsun, başlangıçta bize vermiş oldukları şeylerdir,” diye yanıtladı. “Onlar bizim benliğimizde sevgi yaratıyorlar. Bunu bizden istemeye hakları var.
es: —Yo diría que cualquier cosa que piden nos la han dado antes —murmuró el muchacho con mucha seriedad—. Crean el amor en nuestra alma. Tienen derecho a pedir correspondencia.
vi_translation: “I must say that whatever they ask of us, they have already given us first,” the young man murmured solemnly. “They created Love within our nature. They have the right to demand it back.”
tr_translation: Dorian replied with a serious expression, "If you ask me, whatever it is they want from us, it's the things they initially gave us." "They create love within our being. They have the right to ask this from us."
es_translation: —I would say that anything they ask for has been given to us before —murmured the young man very seriously—. They create love in our soul. They have the right to ask for reciprocation.

en: “That is quite true, Dorian,” cried Hallward.
vi: “Điều đó hoàn toàn đúng, Dorian,” Hallward kêu lên.
tr: Hallward, “Çok doğru söyledin, Dorian,” dedi.
es: —Eso es completamente cierto —exclamó Hallward.
vi_translation: "That is absolutely true, Dorian," Hallward exclaimed.
tr_translation: Hallward said, "You spoke very correctly, Dorian."
es_translation: —That is completely true —exclaimed Hallward.

en: “Nothing is ever quite true,” said Lord Henry.
vi: “Chẳng có điều gì từng hoàn toàn đúng cả,” huân tước Henry nói.
tr: Lord Henry, “Hiçbir şey tam anlamıyla doğru değildir,” diye fikir yürüttü.
es: —Nada es completamente cierto —dijo lord Henry.
vi_translation: “Nothing has ever been completely right,” Lord Henry said.
tr_translation: Lord Henry speculated, "Nothing is completely true."
es_translation: —Nothing is completely certain —said Lord Henry.

en: “This is,” interrupted Dorian. “You must admit, Harry, that women give to men the very gold of their lives.”
vi: “Điều này đấy,” Dorian ngắt lời. “Anh phải thừa nhận, Harry, là đàn bà cho đàn ông chính cái ngàn vàng của đời họ.”
tr: Dorian, “Bu doğrudur ama,” diye onun sözünü kısa kesti. “Bunu kabul etmelisin, Harry. Kadınlar erkeklere hayatlarının altın cevherini çıkartıp verirler.
es: —Esto sí —le interrumpió Dorian—. Has de admitir, Harry, que las mujeres entregan a los hombres el oro mismo de sus vidas.
vi_translation: "This is it," Dorian interrupted. "You must admit, Harry, that women give men the very gold of their lives."
tr_translation: Dorian, "This is true, but," he cut him short. "You must accept this, Harry. Women give men the golden ore of their lives."
es_translation: —This is true —Dorian interrupted him—. You have to admit, Harry, that women give men the very gold of their lives.

en: “Possibly,” he sighed, “but they invariably want it back in such very small change. That is the worry. Women, as some witty Frenchman once put it, inspire us with the desire to do masterpieces and always prevent us from carrying them out.”
vi: “Cũng có thể,” y thở dài, “nhưng họ lúc nào cũng muốn nó quay lại từng trinh. Đó chính là điều đáng lo. Đàn bà, như người Pháp dí dỏm nào đó có lần nói, truyền cho ta nỗi khát khao tạo ra các kiệt tác, và luôn ngăn ta thực hiện chúng.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Olabilir,” diye içini çekti. “Ne var ki mutlaka kırk para olarak geri isterler. Sıkıntı burada. Esprili bir Fransız’ın dediği gibi, kadınlar bizde başyapıtlar yaratma isteği uyandırırlar, sonra da her keresinde buna engel olurlar.
es: —Es posible -suspiró el otro—,pero inevitablemente lo reclaman en calderilla. Ése es el problema. Las mujeres, como dijo en cierta ocasión un francés con mucho ingenio, despiertan en nosotros el deseo de producir obras maestras, pero luego nos impiden siempre llevarlas a cabo.
vi_translation: “It’s possible,” he sighed, “but they always want it to return to its original state.” “That is the worrying thing.” “Women, as some witty Frenchman once said, inspire in us the desire to create masterpieces, and always prevent us from achieving them.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry sighed, "Maybe." "However, they always want it back as forty pence. That's the problem. As a witty Frenchman once said, women inspire us to create masterpieces, only to prevent us from doing so every time."
es_translation: —It's possible -sighed the other—, but inevitably they demand it in small change. That is the problem. Women, as a very witty Frenchman once said, awaken in us the desire to produce masterpieces, but then they always prevent us from carrying them out.

en: “Harry, you are dreadful! I don’t know why I like you so much.”
vi: “Harry, anh thật đáng sợ! Tôi không hiểu tại sao mà tôi lại thích anh nhiều thế được.
tr: “Harry, çok kötüsün! Seni neden bu kadar çok seviyorum, bilmem.
es: —¡Eres horrible, Harry! No sé por qué te tengo tanto afecto.
vi_translation: “Harry, you are really scary! I don't understand why I like you so much.”
tr_translation: "Harry, you are so bad!" "I don't know why I love you so much."
es_translation: —You're horrible, Harry! I don't know why I have so much affection for you.

en: “You will always like me, Dorian,” he replied. “Will you have some coffee, you fellows? Waiter, bring coffee, and fine-champagne, and some cigarettes. No, don’t mind the cigarettes—I have some. Basil, I can’t allow you to smoke cigars. You must have a cigarette. A cigarette is the perfect type of a perfect pleasure. It is exquisite, and it leaves one unsatisfied. What more can one want? Yes, Dorian, you will always be fond of me. I represent to you all the sins you have never had the courage to commit.”
vi: “Cậu sẽ luôn thích tôi, Dorian,” y đáp lại. “Ta dùng chút cà phê chứ, các bạn? — Anh bồi, mang cà phê, cô nhắc fine-champagne, và vài điếu thuốc ra nhé. Không: thôi đừng thuốc lá; tôi còn một ít. Basil, tôi không thể để cậu hút xì gà. Cậu phải hút một điếu thuốc lá. Một điếu thuốc là một kiểu mẫu hoàn hảo của một khoái lạc hoàn hảo. Nó rất tuyệt, và nó để mặc ta không thỏa mãn. Ta còn muốn gì hơn? Vâng, Dorian, cậu sẽ luôn yêu mến tôi. Với cậu, tôi đại diện cho mọi tội lỗi mà cậu chưa bao giờ đủ can đảm để phạm phải.”
tr: “Sen beni ömür boyu seveceksin, Dorian... Beyler, kahve alır mısınız?.. Garson, kahve getir, en iyisinden şampanya, bir kutu da sigara. Yok, sigara istemez; bende var. Basil, puro tüttürmene izin veremem, sigara al şuradan. Sigara kusursuz keyfin kusursuz bir örneğidir. Nefistir ve bitince insanı doyumsuz bırakır. Hayatta başka ne istenir? Evet, Dorian, her zaman seveceksin beni. Çünkü ben senin işlemeyi göze alamadığın tüm günahları simgeliyorum.
es: —Me lo tendrás siempre —replicó lord Henry—. ¿Tomaréis café? Camarero, traiga café, fine champagne y cigarrillos. No, olvídese de los cigarrillos; tengo algunos yo. Basil, no te permito que fumes puros. Enciende un cigarrillo. El cigarrillo es el perfecto ejemplo de placer perfecto. Es exquisito y deja insatisfecho. ¿Qué más se puede pedir? Sí, Dorian, siempre me tendrás afecto. Represento para ti todos los pecados que nunca has tenido el valor de cometer.
vi_translation: “You will always like me, Dorian,” he replied. “Shall we have some coffee, friends? — Waiter, bring coffee, fine-champagne, and a few cigarettes. No: never mind the cigarettes; I still have some. Basil, I can't let you smoke cigars. You must smoke a cigarette. A cigarette is the perfect example of a perfect pleasure. It is exquisite, and it leaves one unsatisfied. What more could one want? Yes, Dorian, you will always be fond of me. To you, I represent all the sins you have never had the courage to commit.”
tr_translation: “You will love me for a lifetime, Dorian... Gentlemen, would you like some coffee?.. Waiter, bring coffee, the best champagne, and a box of cigarettes. No, he doesn't want cigarettes; I have some. Basil, I can't allow you to smoke a cigar, take a cigarette from there. A cigarette is a perfect example of perfect pleasure. It is insatiable and leaves one unsatisfied when it ends. What else is desired in life? Yes, Dorian, you will always love me. Because I symbolize all the sins you dare not commit.”
es_translation: —You will always have me —replied Lord Henry—. Will you have coffee? Waiter, bring coffee, fine champagne, and cigarettes. No, forget the cigarettes; I have some myself. Basil, I do not permit you to smoke cigars. Light a cigarette. The cigarette is the perfect example of perfect pleasure. It is exquisite and leaves one unsatisfied. What more could one ask for? Yes, Dorian, you will always have affection for me. I represent to you all the sins you have never had the courage to commit.

en: “What nonsense you talk, Harry!” cried the lad, taking a light from a fire-breathing silver dragon that the waiter had placed on the table. “Let us go down to the theatre. When Sibyl comes on the stage you will have a new ideal of life. She will represent something to you that you have never known.”
vi: “Anh nói linh tinh gì thế, Harry!” chàng trai la lên, châm thuốc từ con rồng bạc phun lửa mà anh bồi đặt trên bàn. “Ta hãy đi xuống nhà hát nào. Khi Sybil lên sân khấu, anh sẽ có một lý tưởng mới về cuộc sống. Với anh, nàng sẽ đại diện cho điều gì đó mà anh chưa bao giờ biết đến.”
tr: Delikanlı, “Amma saçmalıyorsun, Harry!” diyerek garsonun masaya bırakmış olduğu alev soluyan gümüş ejderhanın içinden bir kibrit aldı. “Hadi tiyatroya gidelim. Sibyl sahneye çıktığı zaman sen hayatta yeni bir ideal kazanmış olacaksın. O senin gözünde, şimdiye değin hiç bilmediğin bir şey simgeleyecek.
es: —¡Qué cosas tan absurdas dices! —exclamó el muchacho, utilizando el encendedor de plata con forma de dragón que el camarero había dejado sobre la mesa. —Vámonos al teatro. Cuando Sibyl salga a escena, encontrarás un nuevo ideal de vida. Significará para ti algo que nunca has conocido.
vi_translation: “What nonsense are you talking about, Harry!” the young man shouted, lighting a cigarette from the silver dragon that his servant had placed on the table. “Let's go down to the theater. When Sybil takes the stage, you will have a new ideal about life. To you, she will represent something that you have never known before.”
tr_translation: The young man said, "You're talking nonsense, Harry!" and took a match from the silver dragon that the waiter had left on the table, which was breathing fire. "Let's go to the theater. When Sibyl takes the stage, you will have gained a new ideal in life. In your eyes, she will symbolize something you have never known before."
es_translation: —What absurd things you say! —exclaimed the boy, using the silver dragon-shaped lighter that the waiter had left on the table. —Let's go to the theater. When Sibyl comes on stage, you will find a new ideal of life. It will mean something to you that you have never known before.

en: “I have known everything,” said Lord Henry, with a tired look in his eyes, “but I am always ready for a new emotion. I am afraid, however, that, for me at any rate, there is no such thing. Still, your wonderful girl may thrill me. I love acting. It is so much more real than life. Let us go. Dorian, you will come with me. I am so sorry, Basil, but there is only room for two in the brougham. You must follow us in a hansom.”
vi: “Tôi đã biết mọi thứ rồi,” huân tước Henry nói, với vẻ mệt mỏi trong mắt, “nhưng tôi luôn sẵn sàng chờ một cảm xúc mới. Tuy vậy, tôi vẫn sợ là, với tôi, dẫu gì, cũng chẳng có thứ như vậy. Thế nhưng, biết đâu cô gái kỳ diệu của cậu có thể làm tôi rung động. Tôi yêu diễn xuất. Nó thực hơn nhiều so với cuộc sống. Ta đi nào. Dorian, cậu sẽ đi cùng tôi. Tôi rất xin lỗi, Basil, chỉ có một buồng đôi trên cỗ xe độc mã ấy. Anh phải chạy theo chúng tôi trên cỗ xe hai bánh vậy.”
tr: Lord Henry gözlerinde yorgun bir bakışla, “Her şeyi tattım ben,” dedi. “Gene de yeni duygulara her zaman açığım. Ama korkarım ki hiç değilse benim için böyle bir şey olamaz. Her neyse, senin bu harika kız, bir de bakarsın mest etmiş beni. Tiyatro oyunculuğuna bayılırım. Gerçek yaşamdan çok daha sahicidir. Hadi, gidelim. Dorian, sen benimle geliyorsun. Basil, çok üzgünüm, arabam iki kişilik. Sen başka bir arabayla arkadan geleceksin artık.
es: —Lo he conocido todo —dijo lord Henry, en sus ojos una expresión de cansancio—, pero siempre estoy dispuesto a experimentar una nueva emoción. Mucho me temo, sin embargo, que, al menos para mí, eso es algo que no existe. De todos modos, quizá tu maravillosa chica me subyugue. Me encanta el teatro. Es mucho más real que la vida. Vamos, Dorian. Tú vendrás conmigo. Lo siento, Basil, pero sólo hay sitio para dos en la berlina. Tendrás que seguirnos en un coche de punto.
vi_translation: "I already know everything," Lord Henry said, with a weary look in his eyes, "but I am always ready to wait for a new emotion. However, I still fear that, for me, there is no such thing. But who knows, your wonderful girl might be able to move me. I love acting. It is much more real than life. Let's go. Dorian, you will come with me. I am very sorry, Basil, there is only one double seat on that hansom cab. You will have to follow us in the two-wheeled carriage."
tr_translation: Lord Henry, with a tired look in his eyes, said, "I have tasted everything." "Yet, I am always open to new emotions. But I fear that such a thing cannot happen, at least for me. Anyway, your wonderful girl might just enchant me. I adore theater acting. It is much more real than real life. Come on, let's go. Dorian, you are coming with me. Basil, I am very sorry, my car is a two-seater. You will have to follow in another car.
es_translation: —I have known everything —said Lord Henry, with an expression of weariness in his eyes—, but I am always willing to experience a new emotion. I greatly fear, however, that, at least for me, that is something that does not exist. Anyway, perhaps your wonderful girl will captivate me. I love the theater. It is much more real than life. Come on, Dorian. You will come with me. I'm sorry, Basil, but there is only room for two in the carriage. You will have to follow us in a cab.

en: They got up and put on their coats, sipping their coffee standing. The painter was silent and preoccupied. There was a gloom over him. He could not bear this marriage, and yet it seemed to him to be better than many other things that might have happened. After a few minutes, they all passed downstairs. He drove off by himself, as had been arranged, and watched the flashing lights of the little brougham in front of him. A strange sense of loss came over him. He felt that Dorian Gray would never again be to him all that he had been in the past. Life had come between them.... His eyes darkened, and the crowded flaring streets became blurred to his eyes. When the cab drew up at the theatre, it seemed to him that he had grown years older.
vi: Họ đứng dậy và mặc áo khoác vào, đứng uống từng hớp cà phê. Họa sỹ im lặng và lơ đãng. Một nỗi sầu ngự trị y. Y không thể chịu được cuộc hôn nhân này, song y thấy nó dường như lại tốt đẹp hơn nhiều chuyện khác, những chuyện rất có thể xảy ra. Sau vài phút, cả bọn họ đi xuống dưới nhà. Y tự đi, như đã được sắp xếp, và ngắm những ánh đèn nhấp nhánh của cỗ xe độc mã nhỏ trước mặt y. Một cảm giác mất mát khang khác choán lấy y. Y cảm thấy rằng Dorian Gray sẽ chẳng bao giờ lại còn trọn vẹn với y những gì mà cậu ấy đã từng là trong dĩ vãng. Đời đã xen vào giữa họ… Mắt y tối sầm, và những con phố đông đúc, rực sáng bỗng nhòa đi trong mắt y. Khi cỗ mã xa đỗ lại trước nhà hát, y thấy dường như y đã già đi nhiều tuổi.
tr: Ayağa kalktılar, bir yandan kahvelerini yudumlarken paltolarını giydiler. Ressam kendi düşüncelerine dalmış, sessizdi. Üstüne bir keyifsizlik çökmüştü. Bu evliliğin düşüncesine dayanamıyor, gene de bunun, akla gelen birçok olasılıktan daha iyi olduğunu düşünüyordu. Birkaç dakika sonra aşağı indiler. Ressam, kararlaştırılmış olduğu gibi, tek başına bir arabaya bindi ve önü sıra giden küçük arabanın ışıltılı lambalarına gözünü dikti. İçini tuhaf bir kaybetme duygusu bürüdü. Dorian Gray’le aralarındaki eski yakınlığı bir daha asla bulamayacağını sezinliyordu. Aralarına hayat girmişti... Gözleri karardı, o kalabalık, ışıklı yollar gözlerinin önünden yitti. Araba tiyatronun önünde durduğu zaman Basil Hallward kendini yıllarca yaşlanmış gibi hissediyordu.
es: Se levantaron para ponerse los abrigos, tomándose el café de pie. El pintor, preocupado, había enmudecido. Le había invadido la melancolía. Le desagradaba mucho aquel matrimonio, aunque en realidad le parecía mejor que otras muchas cosas que podrían haber sucedido. Muy poco después salían a la calle.
