Anh dạy em thực tại thật ra là gì. Đêm nay, lần đầu trong đời mình, em nhìn thấu sự rỗng tuếch, sự giả vờ, sự ngờ nghệch của cái hoạt cảnh phô trương vô nghĩa mà em luôn diễn trong ấy. Đêm nay, lần đầu, em ngộ ra rằng Romeo là ghê tởm, già nua, tô vẽ, rằng ánh trăng trong vườn là giả, rằng cảnh phông là tầm thường, rằng những lời em phải nói là hão huyền, không phải là lời em, không phải là những gì em muốn nói. Anh đã mang lại cho em điều gì đó cao cả hơn, điều gì đó mà mọi nghệ thuật chỉ là một sự phản chiếu của nó. Anh đã làm cho em hiểu tình yêu thực ra là gì. Tình yêu của em! Tình yêu của em! Hoàng tử Quyến rũ! Hoàng tử cuộc đời! Em phát ốm với những cái bóng. Với em, anh hơn mọi nghệ thuật trên đời từ trước đến giờ. Em phải làm gì với những con rối trong vở kịch? Khi em đến nhà hát đêm nay, em không thể hiểu cớ làm sao mà mọi thứ lại bỏ em mà đi. Em tưởng rằng em sẽ diễn hay tuyệt vời. Em phát hiện ra rằng em không thể làm gì cả. Đột nhiên lòng em chợt nhận ra mọi điều này có nghĩa là gì. Nhận thức ấy thật tuyệt vời với em. Em nghe họ huýt sáo, và em cười. Họ có thể biết gì về một tình yêu như của chúng mình? Hãy đưa em đi, Dorian — đưa em đi với anh, đến nơi nào chỉ có chúng mình mà thôi. Em ghét sân khấu. Em có thể mô phỏng một niềm đam mê mà em không cảm thấy, nhưng em không thể mô phỏng một thứ đã thiêu đốt em như lửa. Ôi, Dorian, Dorian, bây giờ anh đã hiểu thế nghĩa là gì chưa? Thậm chí nếu em có thể làm thế chăng nữa thì em vẫn thấy việc diễn cảnh yêu đương sẽ là một sự xúc phạm. Anh đã làm cho em hiểu ra điều ấy.”
tr: “Dorian, Dorian!” diye hafifçe bağırdı. “Seni tanımazdan önce hayatımdaki tek gerçek sahnedeki oyunumdu. Yalnızca sahnedeyken yaşıyordum. Oyunların hepsi gerçekti benim gözümde. Bir gece Rosalind oluyordum, öbür gece Portia. Beatrice’in sevinci benim sevincim, Cordelia’nın üzüntüleri benim üzüntümdü. Her şeye inanıyordum. Benim yanım sıra, sahneye çıkan o kaba saba insanlar Tanrı gibi görünüyordu gözüme. Boyalı dekorlar dünyamdı. Gölgelerden başka bir şey bilmiyor, gölgeleri sahici sanıyordum. Sonra sen geldin, benim güzel sevgilim... Ruhumu zindanından kurtardın sen. Asıl gerçeği öğrettin bana. Ömür boyu rol almış olduğum bu boş gösterinin kofluğunu, yapmacıklığını, aptallığını bu gece, ilk kez gördüm. Bu gece, ilk olarak Romeo’nun iğrenç, yaşlı, boyalı olduğunu, meyve bahçesine vuran ay ışığının sahici olmadığını gördüm: Söylemek zorunda olduğum sözler asılsızdı, benim sözlerim, benim söylemek istediklerim değildi. Bunu gördüm bu gece. Sen bana daha yüce bir şey vermiştin, öyle bir şey ki, tüm sanat onun bir izdüşümünden ibarettir. Sen bana aşkın gerçekte ne olduğunu öğretmiştin, sevgilim, sevgilim benim! Tatlı Prens! Yaşam Prensi! Gölgelerden bıktım ben artık. Sen sanatın tümünden önemlisin benim için, sonsuza dek. Bir sahne oyunundaki kuklalarla ne işim var benim? Bu gece sahneye çıktığımda eski coşkunun nasıl olup da yittiğine ilkin akıl erdiremedim. Harikulade olacağımı sanmıştım. Baktım, hiçbir şey yapamıyorum. Derken birden, her şeyi anladım. Ve bunu bilmek içimi zevkle ürpertti. Onların yuhalarını duydum, gülümsedim. Ne anlarlardı onlar bizimki gibi bir aşktan? Al beni götür, Dorian! Al beni, baş başa kalabileceğimiz bir yere götür. Tiksiniyorum sahneden. Hiç bilmediğim bir tutkunun taklidini yapabilirim belki, ama beni ateş gibi kavuran bir tutkunun taklidini yapamam. Dorian, Dorian, şimdi kavrıyorsun değil mi, her şeyin önemini? Sahnede âşık rolüne çıkmak, becerebilsem bile küfür gibi bir şey olur benim için. Bunu bana sen gösterdin.
es: —Dorian, Dorian —exclamó—, antes de conocerte, actuar era la única realidad de mi vida. Sólo vivía para el teatro. Creía que todo lo que pasaba en el teatro era verdad. Era Rosalinda una noche y Porcia otra. La alegría de Beatriz era mi alegría, e igualmente mías las penas de Cordelia. Lo creía todo. La gente vulgar que trabajaba conmigo me parecía tocada de divinidad. Los decorados eran mi mundo. Sólo sabía de sombras, pero me parecían reales. Luego llegaste tú, ¡mi maravilloso amor!, y sacaste a mi alma de su prisión. Me enseñaste qué es la realidad. Esta noche, por primera vez en mi vida, he visto el vacío, la impostura, la estupidez del espectáculo sin sentido en el que participaba. Hoy, por vez primera, me he dado cuenta de que Romeo era horroroso, viejo, y de que iba maquillado; que la luna sobre el huerto era mentira, que los decorados eran vulgares y que las palabras que decía eran irreales, que no eran mías, no eran lo que yo quería decir. Tú me has traído algo más elevado, algo de lo que todo el arte no es más que un reflejo. Me has hecho entender lo que es de verdad el amor. ¡Amor mío! ¡Mi príncipe azul! ¡Príncipe de mi vida! Me he cansado de las sombras. Eres para mí más de lo que pueda ser nunca el arte. ¿Qué tengo yo que ver con las marionetas de una obra? Cuando he salido a escena esta noche, no entendía cómo era posible que me hubiera quedado sin nada. Pensaba hacer una interpretación maravillosa y de pronto he descubierto que era incapaz de actuar. De repente he comprendido lo que significa amarte. Saberlo me ha hecho feliz. He sonreído al oír protestar a los espectadores. ¿Qué saben ellos de un amor como el nuestro? Llévame lejos, Dorian; llévame contigo a donde podamos estar completamente solos. Aborrezco el teatro. Sé imitar una pasión que no siento, pero no la que arde dentro de mí como un fuego. Dorian, Dorian, ¿no entiendes lo que significa? Incluso aunque pudiera hacerlo, sería para mí una profanación representar que estoy enamorada. Tú me has hecho verlo.
vi_translation: “Dorian, Dorian,” she cried, “before I knew you, acting was a reality of my life. Only in the theater did I truly live. I thought it was all true. I was Rosalind one night, Portia another. Beatrice's joy was my joy, Cordelia's sorrow belonged to me as well. I believed it all. It seemed to me that the mortals who acted with me were like gods. The painted scenery was my world. I knew nothing but shadows, and I thought they were real. You came — oh, my exquisite love! — and you freed my soul from its prison. You taught me what reality truly is. Tonight, for the first time in my life, I saw through the emptiness, the pretense, the foolishness of the meaningless spectacle in which I had always acted. Tonight, for the first time, I realized that Romeo is disgusting, old, painted, that the moonlight in the garden is fake, that the scenery is trivial, that the words I had to say were hollow, not my own, not what I wanted to say. You have brought me something greater, something that all art is merely a reflection of. You have made me understand what love truly is. My love! My love! Prince Charming! Prince of life! I am sick of shadows. To me, you are above all the art in the world that has ever existed. What should I do with the puppets in the play? When I went to the theater tonight, I couldn't understand why everything left me. I thought I would perform wonderfully. I found that I couldn't do anything at all. Suddenly my heart realized what all this meant. That realization was wonderful to me. I heard them whistle, and I laughed. What could they know about a love like ours? Take me away, Dorian — take me away with you, to a place where it's just the two of us. I hate the stage. I can mimic a passion that I do not feel, but I cannot mimic something that has burned me like fire. Oh, Dorian, Dorian, do you understand now what it means? Even if I could, I would still find acting out love scenes an insult. You have made me realize that.
tr_translation: “Dorian, Dorian!” she cried softly. “Before I knew you, the only reality in my life was my play on the stage. I only lived when I was on stage. All the plays were real in my eyes. One night I was Rosalind, the next night Portia. Beatrice’s joy was my joy, Cordelia’s sorrows were my sorrows. I believed in everything. Alongside me, those rough people who appeared on stage seemed like gods to me. The painted sets were my world. I knew nothing but shadows, and I thought shadows were real. Then you came, my beautiful lover... You freed my soul from its prison. You taught me the true reality. Tonight, for the first time, I saw the hollowness, the artificiality, the stupidity of this empty show I had been acting in all my life. Tonight, I saw for the first time that Romeo was hideous, old, painted, and that the moonlight hitting the orchard was not real: The words I had to say were false, they were not my words, not what I wanted to say. I saw this tonight. You had given me something higher, something that all art is but a reflection of. You taught me what love really is, my lover, my lover! Sweet Prince! Prince of Life! I am tired of shadows now. You are more important to me than all art, forever. What do I have to do with puppets in a play? When I went on stage tonight, at first I couldn’t understand how the old enthusiasm had vanished. I thought I would be marvelous. I saw that I could do nothing. Then suddenly, I understood everything. And knowing this thrilled me with joy. I heard their boos, I smiled. What did they know of a love like ours? Take me away, Dorian! Take me to a place where we can be alone. I am disgusted with the stage. I might be able to mimic a passion I have never known, but I cannot mimic a passion that burns me like fire. Dorian, Dorian, now you understand, don’t you, the importance of everything? To play the role of a lover on stage would be like blasphemy for me, even if I could do it. You showed me this.”
es_translation: "Dorian, Dorian," she exclaimed, "before I met you, acting was the only reality of my life. I lived only for the theater. I believed that everything that happened in the theater was true. I was Rosalind one night and Portia another. Beatrice's joy was my joy, and Cordelia's sorrows were equally mine. I believed it all. The common people who worked with me seemed touched by divinity. The sets were my world. I only knew shadows, but they seemed real to me. Then you came, my wonderful love, and freed my soul from its prison. You taught me what reality is. Tonight, for the first time in my life, I saw the emptiness, the imposture, the stupidity of the meaningless spectacle in which I participated. Today, for the first time, I realized that Romeo was horrible, old, and made-up; that the moon over the orchard was a lie, that the sets were vulgar and that the words I spoke were unreal, that they were not mine, not what I wanted to say. You have brought me something higher, something of which all art is but a reflection. You have made me understand what love truly is. My love! My prince charming! Prince of my life! I am tired of shadows. You are more to me than art could ever be. What do I have to do with the puppets of a play? When I went on stage tonight, I couldn't understand how I had been left with nothing. I thought I would give a wonderful performance and suddenly I found I was incapable of acting. Suddenly I understood what it means to love you. Knowing it made me happy. I smiled when I heard the audience protest. What do they know of a love like ours? Take me away, Dorian; take me with you to where we can be completely alone. I abhor the theater. I know how to imitate a passion I do not feel, but not the one that burns within me like a fire. Dorian, Dorian, don't you understand what it means? Even if I could do it, it would be a desecration for me to pretend to be in love. You have made me see it.

en: He flung himself down on the sofa and turned away his face. “You have killed my love,” he muttered.
vi: Cậu buông mình xuống xô-pha và quay mặt đi. “Em đã giết tình tôi,” cậu thì thầm.
tr: Genç adam kendini kanepeye bırakarak başını öte yana çevirdi. “Aşkımı öldürdün,” diye söylendi.
es: Dorian se dejó caer en el sofá y evitó mirarla. —Has matado mi amor —murmuró.
vi_translation: He let himself fall onto the sofa and turned away. "You have killed my love," he whispered.
tr_translation: The young man threw himself onto the couch and turned his head to the other side. "You killed my love," he muttered.
es_translation: Dorian let himself fall onto the sofa and avoided looking at her. —You have killed my love —she murmured.

en: She looked at him in wonder and laughed. He made no answer. She came across to him, and with her little fingers stroked his hair. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. He drew them away, and a shudder ran through him.
vi: Nàng ngạc nhiên nhìn cậu, bật cười. Cậu không đáp lại. Nàng đến gần cậu, vuốt ve tóc cậu bằng những ngón tay nhỏ của mình. Nàng quỳ xuống và áp tay hai bàn tay cậu lên môi. Cậu giật chúng ra, một cơn rùng mình chạy xuyên qua cậu.
tr: Kız ona anlamamış gibi bakarak güldü. Dorian karşılık vermedi. Kız geldi, o minik elleriyle onun saçlarını okşadı. Diz çöktü, onun ellerini dudaklarına bastırdı. Dorian ellerini çekti, bedeninde bir ürperti dolaştı.
es: Sibyl lo miró asombrada y se echó a reír. El muchacho no respondió. Ella se acercó, y con una mano le acarició el pelo. A continuación se arrodilló y se apoderó de sus manos, besándoselas. Dorian las retiró, estremecido por un escalofrío.
vi_translation: She looked at him in surprise and laughed. He did not respond. She approached him, gently stroking his hair with her small fingers. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. He pulled them away, a shiver running through him.
tr_translation: The girl laughed, looking at him as if she didn't understand. Dorian did not respond. The girl came over and stroked his hair with her tiny hands. She knelt down and pressed his hands to her lips. Dorian pulled his hands away, a shiver ran through his body.
es_translation: Sibyl looked at him astonished and burst out laughing. The boy did not respond. She approached, and with one hand caressed his hair. Then she knelt down and took his hands, kissing them. Dorian withdrew them, shivering from a chill.

en: Then he leaped up and went to the door. “Yes,” he cried, “you have killed my love. You used to stir my imagination. Now you don’t even stir my curiosity. You simply produce no effect. I loved you because you were marvellous, because you had genius and intellect, because you realized the dreams of great poets and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown it all away. You are shallow and stupid. My God! how mad I was to love you! What a fool I have been! You are nothing to me now. I will never see you again. I will never think of you. I will never mention your name. You don’t know what you were to me, once. Why, once ... Oh, I can’t bear to think of it! I wish I had never laid eyes upon you! You have spoiled the romance of my life. How little you can know of love, if you say it mars your art! Without your art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, magnificent. The world would have worshipped you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.”
vi: Sau đó cậu đứng phắt dậy, đi ra cửa. “Đúng,” cậu kêu lên, “em đã giết chết tình tôi. Em từng khơi gợi trí tưởng tượng của tôi. Bây giờ thậm chí em còn không khơi gợi nổi sự tò mò của tôi. Em đơn giản là không gây được chút ấn tượng nào. Tôi yêu em vì em tuyệt diệu, vì em có thiên tài và trí tuệ, vì em hiện thực hóa được các giấc mộng của những thi nhân vĩ đại và đem được hình hài với chất liệu đến cho những chiếc bóng của nghệ thuật. Em đã vứt bỏ hết rồi. Em rỗng tuếch và đần độn. Chúa ơi! Tôi đã yêu em rồ dại biết bao! Tôi đã khờ dại thế nào! Giờ đây em chẳng còn là gì với tôi nữa. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ gặp lại em. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ nghĩ đến em. Tôi sẽ không bao giờ nhắc đến tên em. Em không biết em từng là thế nào với tôi, trước kia. Sao mà, trước kia… Ôi, tôi không thể chịu được khi nghĩ lại! Tôi ước gì tôi chưa từng để mắt đến em! Em phá hỏng những mơ mộng đời tôi. Sao mà em lại có thể hiểu ít về ái tình như vậy, nếu em nói nó làm hỏng nghệ thuật của em! Không có nghệ thuật thì em chẳng là gì cả. Lẽ ra tôi sẽ làm cho em trở nên nổi tiếng, huy hoàng, lộng lẫy. Lẽ ra thế giới sẽ tôn thờ em, và lẽ ra em sẽ mang tên tôi. Bây giờ em là cái gì? Một cô đào hạng ba với gương mặt xinh xắn.”
tr: Sonra yerinden fırlayarak kapıya yürüdü. “Evet,” diye bağırdı. “Aşkımı öldürdün sen benim. Eskiden hayal gücümü beslerdin. Şimdi merakımı bile uyandıramıyorsun. Zerrece etkilemiyorsun beni. Ben seni sevdimse şahane olduğun için sevdim; üstün yeteneğin, zihinsel gücün vardı, büyük şairlerin hayallerini gerçekleştiriyor, sanatın gölgesine biçim veriyor, somutluk katıyordun. Bunların hepsini fırlatıp attın. Sığ ve aptalsın. Ulu Tanrım! Ne delilikmiş seni sevmek! Ne kadar aptalmışım! Gözümde hiçsin artık. Bir daha asla görmeyeceğim seni, asla düşünmeyeceğim. Adını asla ağzıma almayacağım. Eskiden benim gözümde neydin, bilmiyorsun. Bir de ben... Of, düşünmeye bile dayanamıyorum! Keşke seni hiç görmemiş olsaydım! Hayatımın büyük aşkını mahvettin. Aşkın senin sanatını bozuyor madem, sen aşkı hiç tanımıyorsun demektir! Sanatın olmayınca sen bir hiçsin. Ben seni ünlü, parlak, şahane biri yapacaktım. Dünya senin önünde diz çökecekti, sen de benim adımı taşıyacaktın. Şimdi nesin ki? Güzel yüzlü, üçüncü sınıf bir aktris.
es: Luego se puso en pie de un salto, dirigiéndose hacia la puerta. —Sí —exclamó—; has matado mi amor. Eras un estímulo para mi imaginación. Ahora ni siquiera despiertas mi curiosidad. No tienes ningún efecto sobre mí. Te amaba porque eras maravillosa, porque tenías genio e inteligencia, porque hacías reales los sueños de los grandes poetas y dabas forma y contenido a las sombras del arte. Has tirado todo eso por la ventana. Eres superficial y estúpida. ¡Cielo santo! ¡Qué loco estaba al quererte! ¡Qué imbécil he sido! Ya no significas nada para mí. Nunca volveré a verte. Nunca pensaré en ti. Nunca mencionaré tu nombre. No te das cuenta de lo que representabas para mí. Pensarlo me resulta intolerable. ¡Quisiera no haberte visto nunca! Has destruido la poesía de mi vida. ¡Qué poco sabes del amor si dices que ahoga el arte! Sin el arte no eres nada. Yo te hubiera hecho famosa, espléndida, deslumbrante. El mundo te hubiera adorado, y habrías llevado mi nombre. Pero, ahora, ¿qué eres? Una actriz de tercera categoría con una cara bonita.
vi_translation: Then he stood up abruptly and walked to the door. “Yes,” he cried out, “you have killed my love. You once stirred my imagination. Now you don't even arouse my curiosity. You simply don't make any impression at all. I loved you because you were marvelous, because you had genius and intellect, because you realized the dreams of great poets and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown it all away. You are empty and dull. God! How madly I loved you! How foolish I was! Now you are nothing to me. I will never see you again. I will never think of you again. I will never mention your name again. You don't know what you were to me, before. How, before... Oh, I can't bear to think about it! I wish I had never laid eyes on you! You have ruined the dreams of my life. How can you understand so little about love, if you say it ruins your art! Without art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, magnificent. The world would have worshipped you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.”
tr_translation: Then, she sprang up and walked to the door. “Yes,” she shouted. “You killed my love. You used to nourish my imagination. Now you can't even arouse my curiosity. You don't affect me in the slightest. If I loved you, it was because you were magnificent; you had superior talent, mental strength, you realized the dreams of great poets, gave shape to the shadow of art, and added concreteness. You threw all of that away. You are shallow and stupid. My God! What madness it was to love you! How foolish I was! Now you are nothing in my eyes. I will never see you again, never think of you. I will never utter your name. You don't know what you used to be in my eyes. And I... Oh, I can't even bear to think about it! I wish I had never seen you! You ruined the great love of my life. If love ruins your art, it means you don't know love at all! Without your art, you are nothing. I was going to make you famous, brilliant, magnificent. The world would have knelt before you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A beautiful-faced, third-rate actress.”
es_translation: Then he jumped to his feet, heading towards the door. —Yes —he exclaimed—; you have killed my love. You were a stimulus for my imagination. Now you don't even awaken my curiosity. You have no effect on me. I loved you because you were wonderful, because you had genius and intelligence, because you made the dreams of great poets real and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown all that out the window. You are superficial and stupid. Good heavens! How crazy I was to love you! What a fool I have been! You no longer mean anything to me. I will never see you again. I will never think of you. I will never mention your name. You don't realize what you represented to me. Thinking about it is intolerable to me. I wish I had never seen you! You have destroyed the poetry of my life. How little you know about love if you say it stifles art! Without art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, dazzling. The world would have adored you, and you would have carried my name. But now, what are you? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.

en: The girl grew white, and trembled. She clenched her hands together, and her voice seemed to catch in her throat. “You are not serious, Dorian?” she murmured. “You are acting.”
vi: Cô gái trắng bợt đi và run lẩy bẩy. Nàng đan hai bàn tay chặt vào nhau, và giọng nàng dường như mắc nghẹn trong cổ họng. “Anh không nghiêm túc đấy chứ, Dorian?” nàng thì thầm. “Anh đang diễn.”
tr: Kız bembeyaz kesilmiş, titriyordu. Ellerini birbirine kilitledi, boğazında düğümlenen bir sesle, “Ciddi değilsin, değil mi, Dorian?” diye mırıldandı. “Rol yapıyorsun.
es: Sibyl palideció y empezó a temblar. Juntó las manos, apretándolas mucho, y dijo, con una voz que se le perdía en la garganta: —No hablas en serio, ¿verdad, Dorian? —murmuró—. Estás actuando.
vi_translation: The girl turned pale and trembled. She clasped her hands tightly together, and her voice seemed to catch in her throat. “You can't be serious, Dorian?” she whispered. “You are acting.”
tr_translation: The girl turned completely pale and was trembling. She clasped her hands together and murmured with a voice caught in her throat, "You're not serious, are you, Dorian?" "You're acting."
es_translation: Sibyl turned pale and began to tremble. She clasped her hands tightly and said, in a voice that was almost lost in her throat: —You can't be serious, Dorian? —he murmured—. You're acting.

en: “Acting! I leave that to you. You do it so well,” he answered bitterly.
vi: “Diễn! Tôi nhường việc đó lại cho em. Em làm tốt vậy mà,” cậu trả lời cay đắng.
tr: Delikanlı acı bir sesle, “Rol yapmak mı? Onu sana bırakıyorum ben,” diye karşılık verdi. “Öyle iyi beceriyorsun ki!
es: —¿Actuando? Eso lo dejo para ti, que lo haces tan bien —respondió él con amargura.
vi_translation: "Act! I'll leave that job to you. You do it so well," he replied bitterly.
tr_translation: The young man replied in a bitter voice, "Acting? I'll leave that to you," he responded. "You do it so well!"
es_translation: —Acting? I'll leave that to you, since you do it so well —he responded bitterly.

en: She rose from her knees and, with a piteous expression of pain in her face, came across the room to him. She put her hand upon his arm and looked into his eyes. He thrust her back. “Don’t touch me!” he cried.
vi: Nàng nhỏm dậy, và, với vẻ đau đớn đáng thương trên mặt, đi ngang phòng đến chỗ cậu. Nàng đặt bàn tay mình lên cánh tay cậu, nhìn vào mắt cậu. Cậu đẩy nàng lùi lại. “Đừng đụng vào tôi!” cậu hét lên.
tr: Sibyl diz çöktüğü yerden doğruldu; yüzünde acı çektiğini gösteren bir ifade vardı. Elini onun eline koyarak gözlerinin içine baktı. Dorian onu itti. “Dokunma bana!” diye bağırdı.
es: Alzándose de donde se había arrodillado y, con una penosa expresión de dolor en el rostro, la muchacha cruzó la habitación para acercarse a él. Le puso la mano en el brazo, mirándole a los ojos. Dorian la apartó con violencia. —¡No me toques! -gritó.
vi_translation: She sat up, and, with a look of pitiable pain on her face, walked across the room to him. She placed her hand on his arm, looking into his eyes. He pushed her back. “Don't touch me!” he shouted.
tr_translation: Sibyl rose from where she had knelt; there was an expression on her face that showed she was in pain. She placed her hand on his and looked into his eyes. Dorian pushed him. “Don't touch me!” he shouted.
es_translation: Rising from where she had knelt and, with a painful expression of sorrow on her face, the girl crossed the room to approach him. She placed her hand on his arm, looking into his eyes. Dorian pushed her away violently. —Don't touch me! -he shouted.

en: A low moan broke from her, and she flung herself at his feet and lay there like a trampled flower. “Dorian, Dorian, don’t leave me!” she whispered. “I am so sorry I didn’t act well. I was thinking of you all the time. But I will try—indeed, I will try. It came so suddenly across me, my love for you. I think I should never have known it if you had not kissed me—if we had not kissed each other. Kiss me again, my love. Don’t go away from me. I couldn’t bear it. Oh! don’t go away from me. My brother ... No; never mind. He didn’t mean it. He was in jest.... But you, oh! can’t you forgive me for to-night? I will work so hard and try to improve. Don’t be cruel to me, because I love you better than anything in the world. After all, it is only once that I have not pleased you. But you are quite right, Dorian. I should have shown myself more of an artist. It was foolish of me, and yet I couldn’t help it. Oh, don’t leave me, don’t leave me.” A fit of passionate sobbing choked her. She crouched on the floor like a wounded thing, and Dorian Gray, with his beautiful eyes, looked down at her, and his chiselled lips curled in exquisite disdain. There is always something ridiculous about the emotions of people whom one has ceased to love. Sibyl Vane seemed to him to be absurdly melodramatic. Her tears and sobs annoyed him.
vi: Một tiếng rên khẽ vỡ ra từ nàng, và nàng nhào xuống chân cậu, nằm đó như một đóa hoa bị giẫm nát. “Dorian, Dorian, đừng bỏ em!” nàng thì thào. “Em rất lấy làm tiếc vì em đã diễn không tốt. Em nghĩ đến anh mọi lúc. Nhưng em sẽ cố — thật mà, em sẽ cố. Nó đến với em mới bất ngờ làm sao, tình yêu em dành cho anh. Em nghĩ em sẽ không bao giờ biết đến nó nếu anh đã không hôn em — nếu chúng mình không hôn nhau. Hôn em nữa đi, tình yêu của em. Đừng xa em. Em không chịu nổi đâu. Ôi! Đừng xa em. Em trai em… Không; đừng bận tâm. Nó không có ý gì đâu. Nó nói đùa thôi… Nhưng anh, ôi! Anh không thể tha thứ cho em vì chuyện đêm nay được sao? Em sẽ làm hết sức, và cố gắng tiến bộ. Đừng tàn nhẫn với em vì em yêu anh hơn mọi thứ trên đời. Rốt cuộc thì mới có một lần này là em không làm vui lòng anh. Nhưng anh hoàn toàn đúng, Dorian. Lẽ ra em không nên thể hiện mình hơn một diễn viên. Đó là sự ngu ngốc của em; tuy nhiên em đã không đừng được. Ôi, đừng bỏ em, đừng bỏ em.” Một cơn thổn thức thiết tha bóp nghẹt nàng. Nàng cúi mình trên sàn như con thú bị thương, còn Dorian Gray, với đôi mắt đẹp, nhìn xuống nàng, và đôi môi chạm trổ của cậu uốn cong trong sự khinh bỉ cao độ. Luôn có gì đó lố bịch ở các cảm xúc của những kẻ mà ta đã hết yêu. Cậu thấy Sibyl Vane dường như lâm ly một cách vô lý. Những giọt nước mắt và tiếng thổn thức của nàng làm cậu khó chịu.
tr: Dudaklarından hafif bir inilti kopan genç kız kendini Dorian’ın ayakları dibine attı, örselenmiş bir çiçek gibi orada yattı, kaldı. “Dorian, terk etme beni, Dorian!” diye fısıldadı. “Öyle pişmanım ki iyi bir oyun çıkarmadığım için. Hep seni düşünüyordum. Ama gayret edeceğim, inan bana, gayret edeceğim. Öyle gafil avladı ki beni, sana duyduğum aşk. Sen beni öpmeseydin, öpüşmeseydik, sanırım aşkı hiç tanımayacaktım. Gene öp beni, sevgilim. Beni bırakıp gitme, dayanamam. Ne olur, bırakma beni. Erkek kardeşim... Yok, aldırma. Ciddi değildi, numara yapıyordu. Ama sen, ah, bu gecelik bağışlayamaz mısın beni? Öyle çok çalışacağım ki rollerime, daha iyi olmaya çabalayacağım. Ne olur, zalim davranma bana, çünkü seni dünyada her şeyden çok seviyorum. Ne de olsa topu topu bir kerecik hayal kırıklığına uğrattım seni. Gene de çok haklısın, Dorian. Sanatımı dışa vurmalıydım. Budalalık ettim ama elimde değildi. Ne olur, bırakma beni, bırakıp gitme beni.” Kız soluğu hıçkırıklarla tıkanarak, yaralı bir hayvan gibi yerde büzülmüştü. Dorian o güzel gözleriyle ona yukarıdan bakıyordu, o kalemle çizilmişi andıran dudakları zarif bir küçümsemeyle bükülüydü. Artık sevmediğimiz kişilerin duygularında her zaman bize gülünç gelen bir şey vardır. Dorian da şimdi Sibyl’in davranışında gülünesi bir melodram buluyor, gözyaşlarıyla hıçkırıklarına sinirleniyordu.
es: A Sibyl se le escapó un gemido apenas audible mientras se arrojaba a sus pies, quedándose allí como una flor pisoteada. —¡No me dejes, Dorian! —susurró—. Siento no haber interpretado bien mi papel. Pensaba en ti todo el tiempo. Pero lo intentaré, claro que lo intentaré. Se me presentó tan de repente..., mi amor por ti. Creo que nunca lo habría sabido si no me hubieras besado, si no nos hubiéramos besado. Bésame otra vez, amor mío. No te alejes de mí. No lo soportaría. No me dejes. Mi hermano... No; es igual. No sabía lo que decía. Era una broma... Pero tú, ¿no me puedes perdonar lo que ha pasado esta noche? Trabajaré muchísimo y me esforzaré por mejorar. No seas cruel conmigo, porque te amo más que a nada en el mundo. Después de todo, sólo he dejado de complacerte en una ocasión. Pero tienes toda la razón, Dorian, tendría que haber demostrado que soy una artista. Qué cosa tan absurda; aunque, en realidad, no he podido evitarlo. No me dejes, por favor —un ataque de apasionados sollozos la atenazó. Se encogió en el suelo como una criatura herida, y los labios bellamente dibujados de Dorian Gray, mirándola desde lo alto, se curvaron en un gesto de consumado desdén. Las emociones de las personas que se ha dejado de amar siempre tienen algo de ridículo. Sibyl Vane le resultaba absurdamente melodramática. Sus lágrimas y sus sollozos le importunaban.
vi_translation: A faint moan escaped from her, and she fell at his feet, lying there like a trampled flower. “Dorian, Dorian, don't leave me!” she whispered. “I am so sorry that I did not perform well. I think of you all the time. But I will try — really, I will try. How suddenly it came to me, the love I have for you. I think I would never have known it if you had not kissed me — if we had not kissed each other. Kiss me again, my love. Don't leave me. I can't bear it. Oh! Don't leave me. My brother… No; don't worry. It means nothing. He was just joking… But you, oh! Can't you forgive me for tonight? I will do my best, and try to improve. Don't be cruel to me because I love you more than anything in the world. After all, it is only this one time that I have not pleased you. But you are entirely right, Dorian. I should not have shown myself more than an actress. That was my foolishness; yet I could not help it. Oh, don't leave me, don't leave me.” An earnest sob choked her. She bent over the floor like a wounded animal, while Dorian Gray, with his beautiful eyes, looked down at her, and his chiselled lips curled in extreme disdain. There is always something ridiculous about the emotions of those whom one has ceased to love. He found Sibyl Vane to be absurdly melodramatic. Her tears and sobs irritated him.
tr_translation: The young girl, from whose lips a faint moan escaped, threw herself at Dorian's feet and lay there like a bruised flower. “Dorian, don't leave me, Dorian!” she whispered. “I am so sorry for not giving a good performance. I was always thinking of you. But I will try, believe me, I will try. The love I feel for you caught me so off guard. If you hadn't kissed me, if we hadn't kissed, I think I would never have known love. Kiss me again, my love. Don't leave me, I can't bear it. Please, don't leave me. My brother... No, never mind. He wasn't serious, he was pretending. But you, oh, can't you forgive me just for tonight? I will work so hard on my roles, I will strive to be better. Please, don't be cruel to me, because I love you more than anything in the world. After all, I only disappointed you once. Still, you are very right, Dorian. I should have expressed my art. I acted foolishly but I couldn't help it. Please, don't leave me, don't leave me.” The girl, her breath choked with sobs, curled up on the ground like a wounded animal. Dorian was looking down at her with those beautiful eyes, his lips, which resembled something drawn with a pen, curved in an elegant disdain. There is always something that seems ridiculous to us in the emotions of people we no longer love. Dorian now found something laughably melodramatic in Sibyl's behavior, and he was irritated by her tears and sobs.
es_translation: A barely audible moan escaped from the Sibyl as she threw herself at his feet, remaining there like a trampled flower. —Don't leave me, Dorian! —she whispered—. I'm sorry I didn't perform my role well. I was thinking of you the whole time. But I will try, of course I will try. It came to me so suddenly..., my love for you. I think I would never have known if you hadn't kissed me, if we hadn't kissed. Kiss me again, my love. Don't walk away from me. I couldn't bear it. Don't leave me. My brother... No; it doesn't matter. He didn't know what he was saying. It was a joke... But you, can't you forgive me for what happened tonight? I will work very hard and strive to improve. Don't be cruel to me, because I love you more than anything in the world. After all, I have only failed to please you once. But you are absolutely right, Dorian, I should have shown that I am an artist. What an absurd thing; although, in reality, I couldn't help it. Don't leave me, please —a fit of passionate sobs seized her. She curled up on the floor like a wounded creature, and the beautifully shaped lips of Dorian Gray, looking down at her, curved in a gesture of consummate disdain. The emotions of people one has ceased to love always have something ridiculous about them. Sibyl Vane seemed absurdly melodramatic to him. Her tears and sobs annoyed him.

en: “I am going,” he said at last in his calm clear voice. “I don’t wish to be unkind, but I can’t see you again. You have disappointed me.”
vi: “Tôi đi đây,” cuối cùng cậu nói, bằng cái giọng điềm tĩnh, trong trẻo của mình. “Tôi không muốn thành ra độc ác, nhưng tôi không thể gặp lại em. Em đã làm tôi chán.
tr: Sonunda, “Ben gidiyorum,” dedi, serinkanlı, duru bir sesle. “Kırıcı olmak istemiyorum, ama seni bir daha göremem. Beni hayal kırıklığına uğrattın.
es: —Me voy —dijo por fin, con voz clara y tranquila—. No quiero parecer descortés, pero me será imposible volver a verte. Me has decepcionado.
vi_translation: “I'm leaving,” he finally said, in his calm, clear voice. “I don't want to become cruel, but I can't see you again. You have made me bored.”
tr_translation: Finally, "I'm leaving," he said in a calm, clear voice. "I don't want to be hurtful, but I can't see you again. You have disappointed me."
es_translation: —I'm leaving —he finally said, with a clear and calm voice—. I don't want to seem rude, but it will be impossible for me to see you again. You have disappointed me.

en: She wept silently, and made no answer, but crept nearer. Her little hands stretched blindly out, and appeared to be seeking for him. He turned on his heel and left the room. In a few moments he was out of the theatre.
vi: Nàng khóc lặng lẽ, không đáp lại, nhưng bò đến gần hơn. Đôi tay nhỏ của nàng duỗi ra mò mẫm, hình như để tìm cậu. Cậu quay gót, rời khỏi phòng. Sau vài phút, cậu đã ra khỏi nhà hát.
tr: Kız sessiz sessiz ağlıyordu. Karşılık vermedi ama usulca ona yaklaştı. O minik ellerini açmış, onu arıyordu sanki. Dorian topuğu üzerinde dönerek dışarı çıktı. Birkaç dakika sonra tiyatrodan ayrılmıştı bile.
es: Sibyl lloraba en silencio, pero no respondió; tan sólo se arrastró, para acercarse más a Dorian. Extendió las manos ciegamente, dando la impresión de buscarlo. El muchacho se dio la vuelta y salió de la habitación. Unos instantes después había abandonado el teatro.
vi_translation: She cried silently, not responding, but crawled closer. Her small hands reached out, seemingly to find him. He turned on his heel and left the room. After a few minutes, he was out of the theater.
tr_translation: The girl was crying silently. She didn't respond but approached him quietly. She had opened her tiny hands, as if she was searching for him. Dorian turned on his heel and walked out. A few minutes later, he had already left the theater.
es_translation: Sibyl wept in silence, but did not respond; she only crawled to get closer to Dorian. She extended her hands blindly, giving the impression of searching for him. The boy turned around and left the room. A few moments later, he had left the theater.

en: Where he went to he hardly knew. He remembered wandering through dimly lit streets, past gaunt, black-shadowed archways and evil-looking houses. Women with hoarse voices and harsh laughter had called after him. Drunkards had reeled by, cursing and chattering to themselves like monstrous apes. He had seen grotesque children huddled upon door-steps, and heard shrieks and oaths from gloomy courts.
vi: Cậu hầu như không biết mình đi đâu. Cậu nhớ là đã lang thang qua những con phố sáng lờ mờ, qua các cổng vòm hoang vắng phủ bóng đen và những ngôi nhà trông rất độc ác. Những người đàn bà giọng khàn đặc và cười chói tai gọi với theo cậu. Những kẻ say loạng choạng đi qua, chửi thề và tự huyên thuyên với chính mình như những con khỉ khổng lồ. Cậu thấy những đứa trẻ kỳ cục túm tụm vào với nhau trên các ngưỡng cửa, và nghe những tiếng la hét nguyền rủa từ những sân nhà u ám.
tr: Nereye gittiğinin pek ayırdında değildi. Sonradan, loş sokaklardan, çıplak kemerlerin kara gölgelerinden, uğursuz görünümlü evlerin önünden geçtiğini anımsayacaktı. Boğuk sesli, haşin gülüşlü kadınlar arkasından seslenmişlerdi. Kendi kendilerine dev maymunlar gibi söylenip söverek sarhoşlar devrilip geçmişti yanından. Kapı önlerine sinmiş acayip çocuklar görmüş, kasvetli avlulardan yükselen haykırışlar, sövgüler duymuştu.
es: Apenas supo dónde iba. Más tarde recordó haber vagado por calles mal iluminadas, de haber atravesado lúgubres pasadizos, poblados de sombras negras y casas inquietantes. Mujeres de voces roncas y risas ásperas lo habían llamado. Borrachos de paso inseguro habían pasado a su lado entre maldiciones, charloteando consigo mismos como monstruosos antropoides. Había visto niños grotescos apiñados en umbrales y oído chillidos y juramentos que salían de patios melancólicos.
vi_translation: You hardly knew where you were going. You remembered wandering through dimly lit streets, past deserted archways shrouded in darkness, and houses that looked very sinister. Women with hoarse voices and shrill laughter called out to you. Drunken men staggered by, cursing and muttering to themselves like giant monkeys. You saw strange children huddled together on doorsteps, and heard shouts and curses from gloomy courtyards.
tr_translation: He was not quite aware of where he was going. Later, he would remember passing through dim streets, the dark shadows of bare arches, and in front of ominous-looking houses. Women with hoarse voices and harsh laughter had called out after him. Drunkards, muttering and cursing to themselves like giant monkeys, had stumbled past him. He had seen strange children crouched in doorways, and heard cries and curses rising from gloomy courtyards.
es_translation: He barely knew where he was going. Later, he remembered wandering through poorly lit streets, having crossed gloomy passages populated with black shadows and unsettling houses. Women with hoarse voices and harsh laughs had called out to him. Drunkards with unsteady steps had passed by him, cursing, chattering to themselves like monstrous anthropoids. He had seen grotesque children huddled in doorways and heard screams and curses coming from melancholy courtyards.

en: As the dawn was just breaking, he found himself close to Covent Garden. The darkness lifted, and, flushed with faint fires, the sky hollowed itself into a perfect pearl. Huge carts filled with nodding lilies rumbled slowly down the polished empty street. The air was heavy with the perfume of the flowers, and their beauty seemed to bring him an anodyne for his pain. He followed into the market and watched the men unloading their waggons. A white-smocked carter offered him some cherries. He thanked him, wondered why he refused to accept any money for them, and began to eat them listlessly. They had been plucked at midnight, and the coldness of the moon had entered into them. A long line of boys carrying crates of striped tulips, and of yellow and red roses, defiled in front of him, threading their way through the huge, jade-green piles of vegetables. Under the portico, with its grey, sun-bleached pillars, loitered a troop of draggled bareheaded girls, waiting for the auction to be over. Others crowded round the swinging doors of the coffee-house in the piazza. The heavy cart-horses slipped and stamped upon the rough stones, shaking their bells and trappings. Some of the drivers were lying asleep on a pile of sacks. Iris-necked and pink-footed, the pigeons ran about picking up seeds.
vi: Khi bình mình vừa ló rạng, cậu thấy mình ngay gần Covent Garden. Bóng tối đã tan, và, ửng hồng vì lửa nhạt, bầu trời tự lõm vào thành một viên trân châu hoàn mỹ. Những cỗ xe ngựa khổng lồ chất đầy hoa loa kèn gà gật đang lọc xọc chạy từ từ xuống phố vắng bóng loáng. Không khí ngào ngạt hương hoa, và vẻ đẹp của chúng dường như đem đến cho cậu một liều thuốc làm dịu nỗi đau. Cậu theo vào chợ, quan sát người ta dỡ xe. Một người xà ích mặc áo khoác trắng mời cậu ít trái anh đào. Cậu cảm ơn y, tự hỏi tại sao y lại từ chối nhận dù chỉ một xu cho chúng, và bắt đầu thờ ơ ăn chúng. Chúng được hái lúc nửa đêm, và hơi trăng lạnh giá đã thấm vào chúng. Một dãy dài các bé trai vác những thùng uất kim hương vằn vện và hoa hồng vàng với đỏ, đi thành hàng dọc trước mặt cậu, lách lối xuyên qua các đống rau khổng lồ màu ngọc lục bảo. Dưới cái cổng xây, có các cột trụ bị nắng tẩy xám, lảng vảng một lũ con gái đầu trần lấm lem vì lê đất, chờ phiên đấu giá qua. Các đám đông khác vây quanh các cánh cửa quay của tiệm cà phê ở hiên. Những con ngựa thồ nặng nề vừa trượt và giậm chân trên đá gồ ghề, vừa rung nhạc và yên cương. Vài người đánh xe nằm ngủ trên đống bao tải. Cổ cầu vồng, chân hồng, lũ bồ câu chạy loanh quanh mổ hạt.
tr: Tan ağardığı sırada kendini Covent Garden yakınlarında buldu. Karanlık kalkmış ve uçuk yalazlarla aydınlanan gök kusursuz bir inci gibi toparlanmıştı. Parlak taşlı, boş sokak boyunca zambak yüklü kocaman arabalar ağır ağır tangırdayarak ilerliyorlardı. Hava zambak kokusuyla baygınlaşmıştı sanki. Çiçeklerin güzelliği genç çocuğun çektiği acıya merhem gibi geldi. Dorian arabaların peşi sıra pazaryerine yürüdü, adamların yük boşaltmasını seyretti. Büzgülü, beyaz mintanlı bir arabacı bir avuç kiraz sundu ona. Dorian teşekkür etti, adamın neden para almadığını anlamayarak isteksizce kirazları yemeye başladı. Kirazlar geceleyin toplanmışlardı, ay ışığının ayazı içlerine işlemişti. Omuzlarında kasalar dolusu çizgili lale, kırmızılı sarılı güller taşıyan uzun bir çocuk sırası, sebzelerin yüksek, zümrüt yeşili yığınlarının arasından kendilerine yol açarak Dorian’ın önünden geçit töreni yaptılar. Güneşten ağarmış gri direkli kemerin altında, salkım saçak giyimli, açık başlı bir sürü kız açık artırmanın bitmesini bekliyorlardı. Kimileri Piazza’daki kafenin sallangaçlı kapısının önüne yığılmışlardı. Çuval yığınlarının üstünde uyuyakalmış arabacılar vardı. Cüsseli araba beygirleri arnavutkaldırımının üstünde ayaklarını sürçerek sendeledikçe, üzerlerindeki eyerler sarsılıyor, çıngıraklar çıngırdıyordu. Mor boyunlu, pembe ayaklı güvercinler ortalıkta koşuşarak, yerdeki tohumları gagalıyorlardı.
es: Al rayar el alba se encontró cerca de Covent Garden. Al alzarse el velo de la oscuridad, el cielo, enrojecido por débiles resplandores, se vació hasta convertirse en una perla perfecta. Grandes carros, llenos de lirios balanceantes, recorrían lentamente la calle resplandeciente y vacía. El aire se llenó con el perfume de las flores, y su belleza pareció proporcionarle un analgésico para su dolor. Siguió caminando hasta el mercado, y contempló cómo descargaban los vehículos. Un carrero de blusa blanca le ofreció unas cerezas. Dorian le dio las gracias y, preguntándose por qué el otro se había negado a aceptar dinero a cambio, empezó a comérselas distraídamente. Las habían recogido a media noche, y tenían la frialdad de la luna. Una larga hilera de muchachos que transportaban cajones de tulipanes y de rosas amarillas y rojas desfilaron ante él, abriéndose camino entre enormes montones, verde jade, de hortalizas. Bajo el gran pórtico, de columnas grises desteñidas por el sol, una bandada de chicas desarrapadas, con la cabeza descubierta, esperaban, ociosas, a que terminara la subasta. Otras se amontonaban alrededor de las puertas batientes del café de la Piazza. Los pesados percherones se resbalaban y golpeaban con fuerza los ásperos adoquines, agitando sus arneses con campanillas. Algunos de los cocheros dormían sobre montones de sacos. Con sus cuellos metálicos y sus patas rosadas, las palomas corrían de acá para allá picoteando semillas.
vi_translation: When dawn just broke, he found himself near Covent Garden. The darkness had dissipated, and, tinged pink by the pale fire, the sky curved into a perfect pearl. Huge horse-drawn carriages loaded with nodding lilies were clattering slowly down the shiny empty street. The air was fragrant with flowers, and their beauty seemed to bring him a soothing balm for his pain. He followed into the market, watching people unload the carriages. A coachman in a white coat offered him some cherries. He thanked him, wondering why he refused to accept even a penny for them, and began to eat them indifferently. They had been picked at midnight, and the cold moonlight had seeped into them. A long line of boys carrying crates of striped tulips and yellow with red roses marched in front of him, weaving their way through the massive emerald-green heaps of vegetables. Under the archway, with columns bleached gray by the sun, a group of girls with dirt-smeared bare heads were lingering, waiting for the auction to end. Other crowds gathered around the revolving doors of the coffee shop on the terrace. Heavy pack horses were both slipping and stamping on the rough stones, jingling their harnesses and saddles. Some coachmen were sleeping on piles of sacks. With rainbow necks and pink feet, the pigeons were scurrying around pecking at seeds.
tr_translation: At dawn, he found himself near Covent Garden. The darkness had lifted, and the sky, illuminated by pale glimmers, had gathered into a perfect pearl. Along the bright-stoned, empty street, large carts loaded with lilies were slowly clattering forward. The air seemed to be drowsy with the scent of lilies. The beauty of the flowers felt like a balm to the young boy's suffering. Dorian walked to the marketplace following the carts, watching the men unload their cargo. A carter in a white, ruffled shirt offered him a handful of cherries. Dorian thanked him, reluctantly starting to eat the cherries, not understanding why the man didn't take any money. The cherries had been picked at night, with the frost of the moonlight seeping into them. A line of tall boys carrying crates full of striped tulips and red and yellow roses on their shoulders paraded in front of Dorian, making their way through the high, emerald green heaps of vegetables. Under the archway with sun-bleached gray pillars, a crowd of girls, dressed in ragged clothes and bareheaded, were waiting for the auction to end. Some had piled up in front of the swinging door of the café in the Piazza. There were carters who had fallen asleep on top of the piles of sacks. The hefty cart horses stumbled on the cobblestones, their saddles shaking and bells jingling as they staggered. Pigeons with purple necks and pink feet were running around, pecking at the seeds on the ground.
es_translation: At the break of dawn, he found himself near Covent Garden. As the veil of darkness lifted, the sky, reddened by faint glows, emptied itself to become a perfect pearl. Large carts, filled with swaying lilies, slowly traveled down the gleaming and empty street. The air filled with the fragrance of flowers, and their beauty seemed to provide him with an analgesic for his pain. He continued walking to the market and watched as the vehicles were unloaded. A carter in a white blouse offered him some cherries. Dorian thanked him and, wondering why the other had refused to accept money in return, began to eat them absentmindedly. They had been picked at midnight and had the coolness of the moon. A long line of boys carrying crates of tulips and yellow and red roses paraded before him, making their way through enormous jade-green heaps of vegetables. Under the grand portico, with its sun-faded gray columns, a flock of ragged girls, bareheaded, waited idly for the auction to end. Others crowded around the swinging doors of the Piazza café. The heavy draft horses slipped and struck the rough cobblestones hard, shaking their harnesses with bells. Some of the drivers slept on piles of sacks. With their metallic necks and pinkish legs, the pigeons ran back and forth pecking at seeds.

en: After a little while, he hailed a hansom and drove home. For a few moments he loitered upon the doorstep, looking round at the silent square, with its blank, close-shuttered windows and its staring blinds. The sky was pure opal now, and the roofs of the houses glistened like silver against it. From some chimney opposite a thin wreath of smoke was rising. It curled, a violet riband, through the nacre-coloured air.
vi: Một lát sau, cậu gọi một cỗ xe ngựa hai bánh, và chạy về nhà. Suốt vài phút, cậu tha thẩn trên ngưỡng cửa, nhìn quanh cái quảng trường yên ắng với những ô cửa sổ trơ trụi, cánh chớp đóng chặt, và các tấm rèm lồ lộ. Bầu trời giờ đây như viên ngọc mắt mèo thuần khiết, các mái nhà lấp lánh như bạc trên nền trời. Từ ống khói nào đó đối diện, một làn khói mảnh bốc lên. Nó cuộn lại, một dải tím, xuyên qua không khí màu xà cừ.
tr: Bir süre sonra Dorian bir araba çevirip evine gitti. Eşikte birkaç dakika oyalanarak sessiz meydanın panjurları kapalı, boş bakışlı pencerelerini süzdü. Gökyüzü katıksız bir opaldi şimdi, evlerin damları da gümüş gibi ışıldıyordu. Karşıki bir bacadan ince bir duman şeridi yükselmekteydi. Duman, eflatun bir kurdele gibi sedef renkli havanın içinde kıvrılıyordu.
es: Después de algún tiempo, Dorian Gray paró un coche de punto que lo llevó a su casa. Una vez allí, se detuvo unos instantes en el umbral, recorriendo con la mirada la plaza silenciosa, con sus ventanas vacías, sus contraventanas, y los estores de mirada fija. El cielo se había convertido en un puro ópalo, y los tejados de las casas brillaban como plata bajo él. De alguna chimenea al otro lado de la plaza empezaba a alzarse una delgada columna de humo que pronto curvó en el aire nacarado sus volutas moradas.
vi_translation: A moment later, he called for a two-wheeled carriage and hurried home. For several minutes, he lingered on the doorstep, looking around the quiet square with its bare windows, tightly shut shutters, and exposed curtains. The sky now resembled a pure cat's eye gem, and the rooftops glittered like silver against the sky. From a chimney opposite, a thin wisp of smoke rose. It curled, a purple ribbon, through the pearlescent air.
tr_translation: After a while, Dorian hailed a carriage and went home. He lingered on the threshold for a few minutes, gazing at the closed shutters and vacant-looking windows of the silent square. The sky was now a pure opal, and the rooftops of the houses gleamed like silver. A thin plume of smoke was rising from a chimney across the way. The smoke curled through the pearly air like a lilac ribbon.
es_translation: After some time, Dorian Gray hailed a cab that took him to his house. Once there, he paused for a moment on the threshold, surveying the silent square with its empty windows, shutters, and fixed-gaze blinds. The sky had turned into a pure opal, and the rooftops of the houses shone like silver beneath it. From some chimney on the other side of the square, a thin column of smoke began to rise, soon curling its purple spirals in the pearly air.

en: In the huge gilt Venetian lantern, spoil of some Doge’s barge, that hung from the ceiling of the great, oak-panelled hall of entrance, lights were still burning from three flickering jets: thin blue petals of flame they seemed, rimmed with white fire. He turned them out and, having thrown his hat and cape on the table, passed through the library towards the door of his bedroom, a large octagonal chamber on the ground floor that, in his new-born feeling for luxury, he had just had decorated for himself and hung with some curious Renaissance tapestries that had been discovered stored in a disused attic at Selby Royal. As he was turning the handle of the door, his eye fell upon the portrait Basil Hallward had painted of him. He started back as if in surprise. Then he went on into his own room, looking somewhat puzzled. After he had taken the button-hole out of his coat, he seemed to hesitate. Finally, he came back, went over to the picture, and examined it. In the dim arrested light that struggled through the cream-coloured silk blinds, the face appeared to him to be a little changed. The expression looked different. One would have said that there was a touch of cruelty in the mouth. It was certainly strange.
vi: Trong cây đèn lồng Venice mạ vàng đồ sộ, từng cướp được từ soái hạm của viên Tổng trấn nào đó, lúc này đang treo trên trần của cái sảnh rộng lớn lát pa-nô gỗ sồi, những ngọn đèn vẫn cháy từ ba vòi phun bập bùng: trông chúng như những cánh hoa lửa xanh mỏng, viền lửa trắng. Cậu tắt chúng, và, sau khi quăng mũ và áo choàng lên bàn, đi xuyên qua thư viện về phía cửa phòng ngủ của mình, một gian bát giác rộng mênh mông ở tầng trệt mà, theo cảm nhận mới phát sinh của mình về sự xa hoa, cậu vừa tự trang hoàng lại, treo vài tấm thảm lạ thời kỳ Phục hưng đã bị phát hiện ra là cất trong một gác mái bỏ đi tại Selby Royal. Trong lúc cậu xoay tay nắm cửa, mắt cậu để ý đến bức chân dung Basil Hallward vẽ cậu. Cậu giật mình lùi lại như thể bị bất ngờ. Sau đó cậu bước vào trong phòng mình, trông hơi bối rối. Sau khi đã cởi nút áo khoác, cậu dường như lưỡng lự. Cuối cùng cậu quay lại, đến gần bức tranh, xem kỹ nó. Trong ánh sáng lờ mờ bị chặn bớt lại khi len qua những tấm rèm lụa màu kem, khuôn mặt hiện ra trước cậu đã thay đổi một chút. Vẻ mặt trông đã khác. Chắc người ta sẽ bảo rằng có nét gì đó tàn nhẫn trên miệng. Chuyện này thật kỳ lạ.
tr: Evin meşe kaplamalı, geniş giriş holünde asılı kocaman, yaldızlı Venedik avizesinin –bir Doj gemisinden alınma bir ganimet– üç lambası hâlâ titrek yalazlarla yanmaktaydı: Çevrelerine beyaz ateş germiş alevden üç ince yaprağa benziyorlardı. Dorian paltosuyla şapkasını masanın üstüne atarak lambaları söndürdü, kitaplıktan geçerek yatak odasına yöneldi. Giriş katında sekiz köşeli, geniş bir bölme olan bu odayı Dorian, içinde yeni uyanan gösteriş merakıyla, kendi beğenisine göre dekore etmişti. Duvarlara Selby Sokağı’ndaki kullanılmayan bir tavan arasında bulunmuş olan, Rönesans işi, değişik duvar halıları asmıştı. Tam kapının tokmağını çevirirken gözü Basil Hallward’ın çizmiş olduğu portresine ilişti. Delikanlı şaşalamış gibi irkilerek geriledi. Sonra kaşları hafifçe çatılmış olarak yatak odasına girdi. Yakasını çıkardıktan sonra bir an duraksadı sanki. Sonunda gene döndü geldi, yaklaştı, portreyi inceledi. Krem renkli ipek güneşliklerden zar zor sızan loş ışıkta portrenin yüzü biraz değişmiş gibi geldi ona. İfade başka görünüyordu. Ağzın duruşunda hafif bir zalimlik olduğu söylenebilirdi. Tuhaf şeydi doğrusu.
es: En la enorme linterna veneciana —botín dorado de alguna góndola ducal— que colgaba del techo del gran vestíbulo revestido de madera de roble, aún ardían las luces de tres mecheros, semejantes a delgados pétalos azules con un borde de fuego blanco. Los apagó y, después de arrojar capa y sombrero sobre la mesa, cruzó la biblioteca en dirección a la puerta de su dormitorio, una amplia habitación octogonal en el piso bajo que, dada su reciente pasión por el lujo, acababa de hacer decorar a su gusto, colgando de las paredes curiosas tapicerías renacentistas que habían aparecido almacenadas en un ático olvidado de Selby Royal. Mientras giraba la manecilla de la puerta, su mirada se posó sobre el retrato pintado por Basil Hallward. La sorpresa le obligó a detenerse. Luego entró en su cuarto sin perder la expresión de perplejidad. Después de quitarse la flor que llevaba en el ojal de la chaqueta, pareció vacilar. Finalmente regresó a la biblioteca, se acercó al cuadro y lo examinó con detenimiento. Iluminado por la escasa luz que empezaba a atravesar los estores de seda de color crema, le pareció que el rostro había cambiado ligeramente. La expresión parecía distinta. Se diría que había aparecido un toque de crueldad en la boca. Era, sin duda, algo bien extraño.
vi_translation: In the massive gold-plated Venetian lantern, once seized from the flagship of some governor, now hanging from the ceiling of the large oak-paneled hall, the lights still burned from three flickering nozzles: they looked like thin blue petals of fire, edged with white flames. He extinguished them, and, after tossing his hat and cloak onto the table, walked through the library towards the door of his bedroom, a vast octagonal room on the ground floor that, in accordance with his newly developed sense of luxury, he had just redecorated, hanging a few rare Renaissance tapestries that had been discovered stored in an abandoned attic at Selby Royal. As he turned the doorknob, his eyes caught sight of the portrait Basil Hallward had painted of him. He recoiled in surprise. Then he stepped into his room, looking somewhat bewildered. After unbuttoning his coat, he seemed to hesitate. Finally, he turned back, approached the painting, and examined it closely. In the dim light filtered through the cream-colored silk curtains, the face before him had changed a little. The expression looked different. One might say there was something cruel about the mouth. This was very strange.
tr_translation: The house's oak-paneled, spacious entrance hall had a large, gilded Venetian chandelier –a spoil taken from a Doge's ship– whose three lamps were still flickering with trembling flames: They resembled three thin leaves of fire surrounded by white heat. Dorian threw his coat and hat onto the table, extinguished the lamps, and headed to the bedroom through the library. This room on the ground floor, an octagonal, spacious section, was decorated by Dorian according to his own taste, with a newly awakened penchant for ostentation. He had hung Renaissance-style, varied tapestries on the walls, which had been found in an unused attic on Selby Street. Just as he was turning the door handle, his eyes fell on the portrait painted by Basil Hallward. The young man recoiled as if startled. Then, with his eyebrows slightly furrowed, he entered the bedroom. After removing his collar, he seemed to hesitate for a moment. Finally, he turned back again, approached, and examined the portrait. In the dim light barely seeping through the cream-colored silk curtains, the face in the portrait seemed to have changed a bit. The expression looked different. There was a slight cruelty in the set of the mouth. It was truly a strange thing.
es_translation: In the enormous Venetian lantern —a golden booty from some ducal gondola— that hung from the ceiling of the great oak-paneled hall, the lights of three burners still burned, resembling slender blue petals with a white fire edge. He extinguished them and, after throwing his cloak and hat onto the table, crossed the library towards the door of his bedroom, a spacious octagonal room on the ground floor that, given his recent passion for luxury, he had just had decorated to his taste, hanging curious Renaissance tapestries on the walls that had been found stored in a forgotten attic at Selby Royal. As he turned the door handle, his gaze fell upon the portrait painted by Basil Hallward. The surprise made him stop. Then he entered his room without losing the expression of perplexity. After removing the flower he wore in the buttonhole of his jacket, he seemed to hesitate. Finally, he returned to the library, approached the painting, and examined it closely. Illuminated by the scant light beginning to filter through the cream-colored silk blinds, it seemed to him that the face had changed slightly. The expression seemed different. It appeared that a touch of cruelty had emerged in the mouth. It was, without a doubt, something very strange.

en: He turned round and, walking to the window, drew up the blind. The bright dawn flooded the room and swept the fantastic shadows into dusky corners, where they lay shuddering. But the strange expression that he had noticed in the face of the portrait seemed to linger there, to be more intensified even. The quivering ardent sunlight showed him the lines of cruelty round the mouth as clearly as if he had been looking into a mirror after he had done some dreadful thing.
vi: Cậu quay lại, và, bước đến cửa sổ, kéo rèm lên. Bình minh rực rỡ ùa vào phòng, quét các bóng đen quái dị vào những góc tối, nơi chúng nằm run rẩy. Nhưng nét lạ mà cậu để ý thấy trên gương mặt của bức chân dung dường như vẫn lần lữa ở đó, thậm chí có vẻ đậm hơn. Ánh nắng rung rinh, nóng rực cho cậu thấy các vết nhăn tàn nhẫn quanh miệng một cách rõ nét như thể cậu nhìn vào gương sau khi cậu làm một chuyện gì đó rất tồi tệ.
tr: Dorian dönüp pencereye gitti, güneşliği kaldırdı. Parlak tan ışığı, odayı sel gibi basarak heyula gölgeleri köşelere itti, gölgeler oralarda ürperip büzüşerek kalakaldılar. Ne var ki Dorian’ın portrenin yüzünde görür gibi olduğu o garip ifade yerli yerinde duruyordu, hatta belirginleşmişti bile denebilir. Titreşimli, coşkulu güneş ışığı Dorian’a ağzın uçlarındaki acımasız çizgileri gösteriyordu, korkunç bir iş yaptıktan sonra aynaya bakarmışçasına açık seçik.
es: Dándose la vuelta, se dirigió hacia la ventana y alzó el estor. El resplandor del alba inundó la habitación y barrió hacia los rincones oscuros las sombras fantásticas, que se inmovilizaron, temblorosas. Pero la extraña expresión que Dorian Gray había advertido en el rostro del retrato siguió presente, más intensa si cabe. La temblorosa y ardiente luz del sol le mostró los pliegues crueles en torno a la boca con la misma claridad que si se hubiera mirado en un espejo después de cometer alguna acción abominable.
vi_translation: He turned around, and, walking to the window, pulled up the curtain. The radiant dawn flooded into the room, sweeping the grotesque shadows into the dark corners where they lay trembling. But the strange feature he noticed on the face of the portrait seemed to linger there, even appearing more pronounced. The shimmering, scorching sunlight revealed the merciless wrinkles around the mouth as clearly as if he were looking into a mirror after doing something very bad.
tr_translation: Dorian turned and went to the window, lifting the blind. The bright dawn light flooded the room, pushing the ghostly shadows into the corners, where they shivered and shrank, remaining there. However, the strange expression that Dorian thought he saw on the portrait's face remained, and it could even be said that it had become more pronounced. The trembling, exuberant sunlight showed Dorian the merciless lines at the corners of the mouth, as clear as if he were looking into a mirror after committing a terrible deed.
es_translation: Turning around, he walked towards the window and lifted the blind. The glow of dawn flooded the room and swept the fantastic shadows into the dark corners, where they froze, trembling. But the strange expression that Dorian Gray had noticed on the face of the portrait remained, more intense if possible. The trembling and burning sunlight revealed the cruel folds around the mouth with the same clarity as if he had looked in a mirror after committing some abominable act.

en: He winced and, taking up from the table an oval glass framed in ivory Cupids, one of Lord Henry’s many presents to him, glanced hurriedly into its polished depths. No line like that warped his red lips. What did it mean?
vi: Cậu rụt lại, và, nhặt lên khỏi bàn một chiếc gương hình ô-van được đóng khung bằng các thần Cupid ngà voi, một trong nhiều món quà mà huân tước Henry tặng cậu, vội vã nhìn vào đáy sâu bóng loáng của nó. Không vết nhăn nào như cái đã làm méo mó đôi môi đỏ của cậu. Vậy nghĩa là sao?
tr: Delikanlı irkilerek gözlerini kırpıştırdı. Masanın üzerinden, Lord Henry’nin sayısız armağanlarından biri olan, fildişi Cupidlerle çevrelenmiş oval bir ayna alarak, sırlı derinliklerine telaşla göz attı. Kırmızı dudaklarını çirkinleştiren öyle bir çizgi yoktu ki! Ne demek oluyordu bu?
es: Estremecido, tomó de la mesa un espejo oval, encuadrado por cupidos de marfil, uno de los muchos regalos que lord Henry le había hecho, y lanzó una mirada rápida a sus brillantes profundidades. Ninguna arruga parecida había deformado sus labios rojos. ¿Qué significaba aquello?
vi_translation: He drew back, and, picking up from the table an oval mirror framed with ivory Cupids, one of the many gifts Lord Henry had given him, hurriedly looked into its glossy depths. There was no wrinkle such as the one that had distorted his red lips. What did it mean?
tr_translation: The young man flinched and blinked his eyes. He took an oval mirror surrounded by ivory Cupids, one of Lord Henry's numerous gifts, from the table and anxiously looked into its reflective depths. There was no such line that disfigured his red lips! What did this mean?
es_translation: Trembling, he took from the table an oval mirror, framed by ivory cupids, one of the many gifts Lord Henry had given him, and cast a quick glance at its bright depths. No similar wrinkle had deformed his red lips. What did it mean?

en: He rubbed his eyes, and came close to the picture, and examined it again. There were no signs of any change when he looked into the actual painting, and yet there was no doubt that the whole expression had altered. It was not a mere fancy of his own. The thing was horribly apparent.
vi: Cậu dụi mắt, đến gần bức tranh, xem kỹ lại nó. Không có các dấu hiệu về bất cứ sự sửa chữa nào khi cậu nhìn vào lớp sơn thực tế, tuy nhiên chắc chắn rằng toàn bộ vẻ mặt đã thay đổi. Đó không chỉ là sự tưởng tượng của chính cậu. Điều ấy dễ thấy một cách khủng khiếp.
tr: Dorian gözlerini ovuşturarak iyice yanaşıp portreyi yeniden gözden geçirdi. Resmin kendisine bakınca herhangi bir değişiklik belirtisi seçilmiyordu, gene de yüzün bütün ifadesinin başkalaşmış olduğu kuşku kaldırmazdı. Ona öyle gelmiş değildi. Ürkütücü değişim gözle görülebiliyordu.
es: Después de frotarse los ojos, se acercó al cuadro y lo examinó de nuevo. No había ninguna señal de cambio cuando miraba el lienzo y, sin embargo, no cabía la menor duda de que la expresión del retrato era distinta. No se lo había inventado. Se trataba de una realidad atrozmente visible.
vi_translation: He rubbed his eyes, approached the painting, and examined it closely. There were no signs of any repairs when he looked at the actual paint layer, yet it was certain that the entire expression had changed. It was not just his own imagination. That was terribly obvious.
tr_translation: Dorian rubbed his eyes, moved closer, and examined the portrait again. There was no sign of any change when he looked at the picture, yet the entire expression of the face had unmistakably altered. It had not seemed so to him. The frightening change was visibly apparent.
es_translation: After rubbing his eyes, he approached the painting and examined it again. There was no sign of change when he looked at the canvas, and yet, there was no doubt that the expression in the portrait was different. He had not imagined it. It was a horribly visible reality.

en: He threw himself into a chair and began to think. Suddenly there flashed across his mind what he had said in Basil Hallward’s studio the day the picture had been finished. Yes, he remembered it perfectly. He had uttered a mad wish that he himself might remain young, and the portrait grow old; that his own beauty might be untarnished, and the face on the canvas bear the burden of his passions and his sins; that the painted image might be seared with the lines of suffering and thought, and that he might keep all the delicate bloom and loveliness of his then just conscious boyhood. Surely his wish had not been fulfilled? Such things were impossible. It seemed monstrous even to think of them. And, yet, there was the picture before him, with the touch of cruelty in the mouth.
vi: Cậu buông mình xuống ghế và bắt đầu nghĩ. Đột nhiên trong óc cậu lóe lên những lời cậu nói ở xưởng vẽ của Basil Hallward vào cái hôm bức tranh được hoàn thành. Đúng, cậu nhớ chúng rõ mồn một. Cậu đã thốt lên một mong ước điên cuồng là chính cậu vẫn trẻ, còn bức chân dung già đi; mong vẻ đẹp của cậu không bị phai mờ, còn gương mặt trên tấm toan thì mang gánh nặng đam mê và tội lỗi của cậu; mong hình ảnh được họa lại bị khô héo đi với những nếp nhăn đau khổ nghĩ suy, còn cậu vẫn giữ lại được mọi vẻ tươi nhuận thanh tú và sự đáng yêu của cái tuổi niên thiếu mà hồi ấy vừa mới ý thức được. Có chắc là mong ước của cậu không được thỏa mãn hay không? Những chuyện kiểu này không thể xảy ra. Thậm chí chỉ cần nghĩ về chúng dường như đã quái dị. Tuy nhiên, bức tranh đang trước mặt cậu, với nét tàn nhẫn trên miệng.
tr: Dorian kendini bir koltuğa bırakarak düşünmeye başladı. Birden aklından, portrenin bittiği gün Basil Hallward’ın stüdyosunda söylediği sözler geçti. Evet, açıkça anımsıyordu. Kendisi genç kalsa da portre yaşlansa diye çılgın bir dilekte bulunmuştu; kendi güzelliği hiç pas tutmasa, tutkularıyla günahlarının yükünü tuval üstündeki bu yüz taşısa diye; düşünce ve acı belirten çizgiler bu boyalı yüze kazılsa da kendisi yeni algıladığı şu delikanlılığın nazlı tazeliğini olduğu gibi saklayabilse diye. Ama bu dileği gerçekleşmiş olamazdı, değil mi? Böyle şeyler olanaksızdı. Düşünmesi bile usdışı. Gelgelelim işte resim de gözlerinin önündeydi, dudaklarındaki zalim ifadeyle.
es: Dejándose caer sobre una silla empezó a pensar. De repente, como en un relámpago, se acordó de lo que dijera en el estudio de Basil Hallward el día en que el pintor concluyó el retrato. Sí; lo recordaba perfectamente. Había expresado un deseo insensato: que el retrato envejeciera y que él se conservara joven; que la perfección de sus rasgos permaneciera intacta, y que el rostro del lienzo cargara con el peso de sus pasiones y de sus pecados; que en la imagen pintada aparecieran las arrugas del sufrimiento y de la meditación, pero que él conservara todo el brillo delicado y el atractivo de una adolescencia que acababa de tomar conciencia de sí misma. No era posible que su deseo hubiera sido escuchado. Cosas así no sucedían, eran imposibles. Parecía monstruoso incluso pensar en ello. Y, sin embargo, allí estaba el retrato, con un toque de crueldad en la boca.
vi_translation: He dropped himself into the chair and began to think. Suddenly, the words he had spoken in Basil Hallward's studio on the day the painting was completed flashed through his mind. Yes, he remembered them vividly. He had uttered a wild wish that he himself would remain young while the portrait aged; that his beauty would not fade, while the face on the canvas bore the burden of his passions and sins; that the painted image would wither with the lines of suffering and thought, while he retained all the freshness and charm of youth that he had just become conscious of at that time. Was it certain that his wish had not been fulfilled? Such things could not happen. Even thinking about them seemed bizarre. Yet, the painting was before him, with a cruel expression on its mouth.
tr_translation: Dorian dropped himself into a chair and began to think. Suddenly, the words he had spoken in Basil Hallward's studio on the day the portrait was finished came to his mind. Yes, he remembered them clearly. He had made a wild wish that he might stay young while the portrait grew old; that his own beauty might never fade, and that the burden of his passions and sins might be borne by the face on the canvas; that the lines of thought and suffering might be etched onto that painted face while he kept the delicate freshness of his newly perceived youth. But that wish couldn't have come true, could it? Such things were impossible. Even thinking about it was irrational. Yet there was the picture before his eyes, with that cruel expression on its lips.
es_translation: Letting himself fall onto a chair, he began to think. Suddenly, like a flash of lightning, he remembered what he had said in Basil Hallward's studio the day the painter finished the portrait. Yes; he remembered it perfectly. He had expressed a foolish wish: that the portrait would age and that he would remain young; that the perfection of his features would stay intact, and that the face on the canvas would bear the weight of his passions and his sins; that the painted image would show the wrinkles of suffering and contemplation, but that he would retain all the delicate brilliance and allure of an adolescence that had just become self-aware. It was not possible that his wish had been granted. Things like that didn't happen, they were impossible. It seemed monstrous even to think of it. And yet, there was the portrait, with a touch of cruelty in the mouth.

en: Cruelty! Had he been cruel? It was the girl’s fault, not his. He had dreamed of her as a great artist, had given his love to her because he had thought her great. Then she had disappointed him. She had been shallow and unworthy. And, yet, a feeling of infinite regret came over him, as he thought of her lying at his feet sobbing like a little child. He remembered with what callousness he had watched her. Why had he been made like that? Why had such a soul been given to him? But he had suffered also. During the three terrible hours that the play had lasted, he had lived centuries of pain, aeon upon aeon of torture. His life was well worth hers. She had marred him for a moment, if he had wounded her for an age. Besides, women were better suited to bear sorrow than men. They lived on their emotions. They only thought of their emotions. When they took lovers, it was merely to have some one with whom they could have scenes. Lord Henry had told him that, and Lord Henry knew what women were. Why should he trouble about Sibyl Vane? She was nothing to him now.
vi: Tàn nhẫn! Cậu có tàn nhẫn không nhỉ? Đó là lỗi của cô gái, không phải của cậu. Cậu đã mơ về nàng như một nghệ sỹ vĩ đại, đã dâng hiến tình yêu của cậu cho nàng vì cậu nghĩ nàng vĩ đại. Vậy mà nàng đã làm cậu chán. Nàng nông cạn và không xứng đáng. Tuy nhiên, một cảm giác hối hận khôn cùng chiếm lấy cậu, lúc cậu nghĩ về việc nàng nằm dưới chân cậu khóc thổn thức như đứa bé. Cậu nhớ cậu đã quan sát nàng với sự nhẫn tâm đến thế nào. Sao cậu lại được tạo ra như thế? Sao một tâm hồn như vậy lại được đem cho cậu? Nhưng cậu cũng đau khổ mà. Suốt ba giờ khủng khiếp mà vở kịch kéo dài, cậu đã sống hàng thế kỷ đớn đau, tỷ tỷ năm thống khổ. Đời cậu cũng đáng giá như đời nàng. Nàng cũng đã làm hỏng cậu một lát, nếu cậu có làm tổn thương nàng cả thế kỷ. Ngoài ra, phụ nữ quen chịu đau hơn đàn ông. Họ sống bằng cảm xúc. Họ chỉ nghĩ về cảm xúc của họ. Khi họ chọn tình nhân thì chỉ là để có ai đấy mà họ có thể cãi nhau. Huân tước Henry đã bảo cậu thế, và huân tước Henry biết phụ nữ là thế nào. Sao cậu lại phải bận lòng vì Sibyl Vane? Giờ đây nàng chẳng là gì với cậu.
tr: Zalim ha? Zalimlik mi etmişti o? Suç kızdaydı, onda değil. O Sibyl’i büyük bir sanatçı olarak düşlemiş, büyük gördüğü için ona aşkını vermişti. Sonra da kız onu hayal kırıklığına uğratmıştı. Onun aşkına layık olmayan sığ bir davranışta bulunmuştu. Gene de, kızın yerde, onun ayakları dibinde çocuklar gibi hıçkırdığını düşününce Dorian’ın içinde sonsuz bir pişmanlık duygusu uyandı. Onu nasıl taşyüreklilikle seyrettiğini anımsıyordu da! Neden böyle yaratılmıştı acaba? Neden böyle bir ruh verilmişti ona? Ama o da acı çekmişti. Oyunun sürdüğü üç korkunç saat boyunca kimbilir kaç yüzyıllık ıstırap, sonsuzluklar dolusu işkence yaşamıştı. Kendi hayatı onunkine bedeldi. Kendisi Sibyl’i bir süreliğine yaraladıysa, Sibyl de onun yaşantısına bir an için gölge düşürmüştü ya. Hem zaten kadınlar çile çekmeye erkeklerden daha yatkındılar. Duygularıyla beslenirdi onlar. Salt duygularını düşünürlerdi. El altında biri olsun, karşılıklı bir şeyler yaşayabilsinler diye sevgili edinirlerdi. Bunu ona Lord Henry söylemişti, Lord Henry de kadınların ne olduğunu bilirdi. Dorian tatlı canını ne diye üzecekti Sibyl Vane için? Kız artık onun gözünde bir hiçti.
es: ¡Crueldad! ¿Había sido cruel? Sibyl era la culpable y no él. La había soñado gran artista, y por creerla grande le había entregado su amor. Pero Sibyl le había decepcionado, demostrando ser superficial e indigna. Y, sin embargo, un sentimiento de infinito pesar se apoderó de él, al recordarla acurrucada a sus pies y sollozando como una niñita. Rememoró con cuánta indiferencia la había contemplado. ¿Por qué la naturaleza le había hecho así? ¿Por qué se le había dado un alma como aquélla? Pero también él había sufrido. Durante las tres terribles horas de la representación había vivido siglos de dolor, eternidades de tortura. Su vida bien valía la de Sibyl. Ella lo había maltratado, aunque Dorian le hubiera infligido una herida duradera. Las mujeres, además, estaban mejor preparadas para el dolor. Vivían de sus emociones. Sólo pensaban en sus emociones. Cuando tomaban un amante, no tenían otro objetivo que disponer de alguien a quien hacer escenas. Lord Henry se lo había explicado, y lord Henry sabía cómo eran las mujeres. ¿Qué razón había para preocuparse por Sibyl Vane? Ya no significaba nada para él.
vi_translation: Ruthless! Are you ruthless? It was the girl's fault, not yours. You dreamed of her as a great artist, offered your love to her because you thought she was great. Yet she bored you. She was shallow and unworthy. However, an immense sense of regret took over you when you thought of her lying at your feet, sobbing like a child. You remember how ruthlessly you observed her. Why were you made this way? Why was such a soul given to you? But you also suffered. Throughout the three terrible hours that the play lasted, you lived through centuries of pain, countless years of agony. Your life was as valuable as hers. She also ruined you for a moment, if you hurt her for a century. Besides, women are more accustomed to pain than men. They live by their emotions. They only think about their emotions. When they choose a lover, it's just to have someone to quarrel with. Lord Henry told you so, and Lord Henry knows what women are like. Why should you care about Sibyl Vane? She is nothing to you now.
