tr_translation: Is he cruel? Had he acted cruelly? The fault was with the girl, not him. He had imagined Sibyl as a great artist, and because he saw her as great, he had given her his love. Then the girl had disappointed him. She had behaved in a shallow manner unworthy of his love. Still, when he thought of the girl sobbing at his feet like a child, an endless feeling of regret arose within Dorian. He remembered how heartlessly he had watched her! Why was he created this way? Why was such a soul given to him? But he had suffered too. During those three terrible hours of the play, who knows how many centuries of agony, how many eternities of torment he had lived through. His own life was worth as much as hers. If he had wounded Sibyl for a while, Sibyl had also cast a shadow over his life for a moment. Besides, women were more prone to suffering than men. They thrived on their emotions. They only thought about their feelings. They took lovers just to have someone at hand, to share mutual experiences. Lord Henry had told him this, and Lord Henry knew what women were like. Why should Dorian trouble his sweet self over Sibyl Vane? The girl was now nothing in his eyes.
es_translation: Cruelty! Had he been cruel? Sibyl was the one to blame, not him. He had dreamed of her as a great artist, and believing her to be great, he had given her his love. But Sibyl had disappointed him, proving to be superficial and unworthy. And yet, a feeling of infinite sorrow took hold of him, as he remembered her curled up at his feet, sobbing like a little girl. He recalled how indifferently he had watched her. Why had nature made him like this? Why had he been given a soul like that? But he had also suffered. During the three terrible hours of the performance, he had lived through centuries of pain, eternities of torture. His life was worth as much as Sibyl's. She had mistreated him, although Dorian had inflicted a lasting wound on her. Women, moreover, were better prepared for pain. They lived off their emotions. They only thought about their emotions. When they took a lover, they had no other goal than to have someone to make scenes with. Lord Henry had explained it to him, and Lord Henry knew how women were. What reason was there to worry about Sibyl Vane? She no longer meant anything to him.

en: But the picture? What was he to say of that? It held the secret of his life, and told his story. It had taught him to love his own beauty. Would it teach him to loathe his own soul? Would he ever look at it again?
vi: Nhưng còn bức tranh? Cậu đã nói gì về chuyện ấy? Nó nắm giữ bí mật đời cậu, kể lại chuyện của cậu. Nó dạy cậu yêu vẻ đẹp của mình. Nó có dạy cậu ghét tâm hồn mình không? Liệu cậu có bao giờ nhìn lại nó không?
tr: Peki, ya resim? Resme ne demeliydi peki? Bu portre, onun hayatının sırrını gizliyor, onun öyküsünü anlatıyordu. Ona kendi güzelliğini sevmesini öğretmişti. Şimdi de kendi ruhundan tiksinmesini mi öğretecekti? Dorian bir daha bakabilecek miydi bu resme?
es: Pero, ¿y el retrato? ¿Qué iba a decir del retrato? El lienzo de Basil Hallward contenía el secreto de su vida, narraba su historia. Le había enseñado a amar su propia belleza. ¿Le enseñaría también a aborrecer su propia alma? ¿Volvería alguna vez a mirarlo?
vi_translation: But what about the painting? What did you say about it? It holds the secret of your life, recounts your story. It taught you to love your own beauty. Did it teach you to hate your soul? Do you ever look at it again?
tr_translation: Well, what about the painting? What should be said about the painting then? This portrait was hiding the secret of his life, telling his story. It had taught him to love his own beauty. Was it now going to teach him to loathe his own soul? Would Dorian be able to look at this painting again?
es_translation: But, what about the portrait? What was he going to say about the portrait? Basil Hallward's canvas contained the secret of his life, it narrated his story. It had taught him to love his own beauty. Would it also teach him to loathe his own soul? Would he ever look at it again?

en: No; it was merely an illusion wrought on the troubled senses. The horrible night that he had passed had left phantoms behind it. Suddenly there had fallen upon his brain that tiny scarlet speck that makes men mad. The picture had not changed. It was folly to think so.
vi: Không; nó chỉ là một ảo ảnh được chế tác nhờ vào những cảm giác hỗn loạn. Cái đêm khủng khiếp mà cậu đã trải qua vẫn còn để lại những bóng ma sau nó. Đột nhiên trong não cậu rớt xuống cái đốm đỏ tươi nhỏ xíu vẫn khiến con người điên loạn. Bức tranh không thay đổi. Nghĩ vậy thật nực cười.
tr: Yok, yok; mesele onun gergin sinirlerinin yarattığı bir yanılsamadan ibaretti. Geçirdiği feci gece geride hortlaklar bırakmıştı. Beynine birdenbire insanları zıvanadan çıkartan o minicik kızıl ben düşmüştü. Yoksa portre değişmiş değildi. Böyle düşünmek çılgınlıktı.
es: No; se trataba simplemente de una ilusión que se aprovechaba de sus sentidos desorientados. La horrible noche pasada había engendrado fantasmas. De repente, esa minúscula mancha escarlata que vuelve locos a los hombres se había desplomado sobre su cerebro. El cuadro no había cambiado. Era locura pensarlo.
vi_translation: No; it is merely an illusion crafted by chaotic sensations. The terrible night you experienced still leaves behind its ghosts. Suddenly, a tiny bright red spot dropped in your brain, still capable of driving a person mad. The painting remains unchanged. Thinking that is truly ridiculous.
tr_translation: No, no; the issue was merely an illusion created by his tense nerves. The dreadful night he had experienced had left behind phantoms. Suddenly, that tiny red mole that drives people crazy had fallen into his mind. Otherwise, the portrait had not changed. Thinking this way was madness.
es_translation: No; it was simply an illusion that took advantage of his disoriented senses. The horrible night past had spawned ghosts. Suddenly, that tiny scarlet spot that drives men mad had collapsed upon his brain. The scene had not changed. It was madness to think so.

en: Yet it was watching him, with its beautiful marred face and its cruel smile. Its bright hair gleamed in the early sunlight. Its blue eyes met his own. A sense of infinite pity, not for himself, but for the painted image of himself, came over him. It had altered already, and would alter more. Its gold would wither into grey. Its red and white roses would die. For every sin that he committed, a stain would fleck and wreck its fairness. But he would not sin. The picture, changed or unchanged, would be to him the visible emblem of conscience. He would resist temptation. He would not see Lord Henry any more—would not, at any rate, listen to those subtle poisonous theories that in Basil Hallward’s garden had first stirred within him the passion for impossible things. He would go back to Sibyl Vane, make her amends, marry her, try to love her again. Yes, it was his duty to do so. She must have suffered more than he had. Poor child! He had been selfish and cruel to her. The fascination that she had exercised over him would return. They would be happy together. His life with her would be beautiful and pure.
vi: Tuy nhiên nó vẫn quan sát cậu, với khuôn mặt tuyệt đẹp đã bị làm hỏng và nụ cười tàn nhẫn. Mái tóc rực rỡ của nó phát sáng trong nắng sớm. Đôi mắt xanh lam của nó gặp mắt cậu. Một cảm giác thương xót vô biên, không phải cho cậu, mà cho hình vẽ về chính cậu, choán lấy cậu. Nó đã biến đổi rồi, và sẽ còn biến đổi nữa. Màu vàng óng của nó sẽ khô héo thành màu xám. Những bông hồng đỏ và trắng sẽ chết. Vì mỗi tội lỗi mà cậu phạm phải, một vết nhơ sẽ làm lốm đốm và hư hỏng vẻ đẹp của nó. Nhưng cậu sẽ không phạm tội. Bức tranh, thay đổi hay không thay đổi, với cậu vẫn sẽ là một biểu tượng hữu hình về lương tâm. Cậu sẽ cưỡng lại sự cám dỗ. Cậu sẽ không gặp huân tước Henry nữa — sẽ không, dẫu thế nào đi nữa, nghe các lý thuyết độc hại quỷ quyệt mà trong vườn của Basil Hallward đã lần đầu khơi lên trong cậu niềm đam mê với những thứ không thể. Cậu sẽ quay lại với Sibyl Vane, sẽ đền bù cho nàng, cưới nàng, cố yêu nàng lại. Vâng, đó là trách nhiệm cậu phải làm. Nàng chắc hẳn đã chịu đựng nhiều đau khổ hơn cậu. Cô bé đáng thương! Cậu đã ích kỷ và tàn nhẫn với nàng. Sự quyến rũ mà nàng từng làm khổ cậu sẽ quay lại. Họ sẽ hạnh phúc bên nhau. Đời cậu bên nàng sẽ đẹp và thanh khiết.
tr: Gel gör ki portre onu gözetlemekteydi, o güzel, kusurlu yüzü, o zalim ağzıyla. Saçları sabahın erken ışığında parlıyor, mavi gözleri onun gözlerine değiyordu. Dorian’ın içini sonsuz bir acıma bürüdü; kendisi için değil de şu boyalı imgesi için. İmge daha şimdiden değişime uğramıştı, daha da uğrayacaktı. Saçlarının altın rengi sönüp kırçıla dönüşecekti. Kırmızı beyaz gülleri solacaktı. Kendi işlediği her günaha karşılık bir leke portrenin güzelliğini bozacak, mahvedecekti. Ama hayır, Dorian günah işlemeyecekti. Resim, değişse de değişmese de, onun vicdanının gözle görülür simgesi olacaktı. Dorian şeytana uymayacaktı. Lord Henry’yle görüşmeyecekti bundan böyle. Basil Hallward’ın bahçesinde ilk dinlediği zaman içinde olmayacak şeylere karşı tutkular uyandıran o sinsi, zehirli fikirlerine kulağını tıkayacaktı hiç değilse. Sibyl Vane’e geri dönecek, gönlünü alacak, onunla evlenecek, onu yeniden sevmeye çalışacaktı. Evet, onun göreviydi bunları yapmak. Sibyl ondan daha çok acı çekmiş olsa gerekti. Zavallı yavrucak! Dorian bencillik etmiş, ona karşı taşyürekli davranmıştı. Onda bulduğu büyü geri gelirdi elbet. Birlikte mutlu olurlardı. Dorian onunla birlikte güzel, saf bir yaşam sürerdi.
es: Sin embargo, el retrato seguía contemplándolo, con el hermoso rostro deformado por una cruel sonrisa. Sus cabellos resplandecían, brillantes, bajo el sol matinal. Los ojos azules del lienzo se clavaban en los suyos. Un indecible sentimiento de compasión le invadió, pero no por él, sino por aquella imagen pintada. Ya había cambiado y aún cambiaría más. El oro se marchitaría en gris. Las rosas, rojas y blancas, morirían. Por cada pecado que cometiera, una mancha vendría a ensuciar y a destruir su belleza. Pero no volvería a pecar. El cuadro, igual o distinto, sería el emblema visible de su conciencia. Resistiría a la tentación. Nunca volvería a ver a lord Henry: no volvería a escuchar, al menos, aquellas teorías sutilmente ponzoñosas que, en el jardín de Basil Hallward, habían despertado en él por vez primera el deseo de cosas imposibles. Volvería junto a Sibyl Vane, le pediría perdón, se casaría con ella, se esforzaría por amarla de nuevo. Sí; era su deber hacerlo. Sin duda había sufrido más que él. ¡Pobre chiquilla! ¡Qué cruel y egoísta había sido! La fascinación que provocara en él renacería. Serían felices juntos. Su vida con ella sería hermosa y pura.
vi_translation: However, it still observed him, with a beautiful face that had been marred and a cruel smile. Its radiant hair glowed in the early sunlight. Its blue eyes met his. An overwhelming sense of pity, not for him, but for the drawing of himself, consumed him. It had already transformed, and would continue to transform. Its golden hue would wither into gray. The red and white roses would die. For every sin he committed, a blemish would mar and spoil its beauty. But he would not sin. The painting, whether changed or unchanged, would still be a tangible symbol of his conscience. He would resist temptation. He would not see Lord Henry again — would not, in any case, listen to the insidious, poisonous theories that had first stirred in him a passion for the impossible in Basil Hallward's garden. He would return to Sibyl Vane, make amends to her, marry her, and try to love her again. Yes, that was his duty. She must have endured more suffering than he had. Poor girl! He had been selfish and cruel to her. The charm that she had once tormented him with would return. They would be happy together. His life with her would be beautiful and pure.
tr_translation: But see, the portrait was watching him, with its beautiful, flawed face, with its cruel mouth. Its hair was shining in the early light of the morning, and its blue eyes were touching his. Dorian was filled with an infinite pity; not for himself, but for that painted image. The image had already undergone a change, and it would undergo more. Its golden hair would fade and turn gray. The red and white roses would wither. Every sin he committed would mar and ruin the beauty of the portrait with a stain. But no, Dorian would not sin. Whether the picture changed or not, it would be the visible symbol of his conscience. Dorian would not succumb to the devil. He would not meet with Lord Henry anymore. At least, he would close his ears to those insidious, poisonous ideas that had awakened passions for impossible things when he first heard them in Basil Hallward's garden. He would return to Sibyl Vane, make amends, marry her, and try to love her again. Yes, it was his duty to do these things. Sibyl must have suffered more than he had. Poor little child! Dorian had been selfish and had acted heartlessly towards her. The magic he found in her would surely return. They would be happy together. Dorian would lead a beautiful, pure life with her.
es_translation: However, the portrait continued to gaze at him, with the beautiful face distorted by a cruel smile. Its hair shone, bright, under the morning sun. The blue eyes of the canvas were fixed on his own. An indescribable feeling of compassion overwhelmed him, but not for himself, rather for that painted image. It had already changed and would change even more. The gold would wither into gray. The roses, red and white, would die. For every sin he committed, a stain would come to soil and destroy its beauty. But he would not sin again. The painting, whether the same or different, would be the visible emblem of his conscience. He would resist temptation. He would never see Lord Henry again: at least, he would not listen to those subtly poisonous theories that, in Basil Hallward's garden, had first awakened in him the desire for impossible things. He would return to Sibyl Vane, ask her for forgiveness, marry her, and strive to love her again. Yes; it was his duty to do so. Surely she had suffered more than he had. Poor girl! How cruel and selfish he had been! The fascination she had once caused in him would be reborn. They would be happy together. His life with her would be beautiful and pure.

en: He got up from his chair and drew a large screen right in front of the portrait, shuddering as he glanced at it. “How horrible!” he murmured to himself, and he walked across to the window and opened it. When he stepped out on to the grass, he drew a deep breath. The fresh morning air seemed to drive away all his sombre passions. He thought only of Sibyl. A faint echo of his love came back to him. He repeated her name over and over again. The birds that were singing in the dew-drenched garden seemed to be telling the flowers about her.
vi: Cậu đứng dậy khỏi ghế, kéo tấm chắn lớn ngay trước bức chân dung, rùng mình lúc nhìn nó. “Kinh thật!” cậu lẩm bẩm với mình và bước lại gần cửa sổ rồi mở nó ra. Khi cậu bước ra ngoài, trên cỏ, cậu hít một hơi thở sâu. Không khí ban mai tươi mát dường như xua đi mọi niềm đam mê ảm đạm của cậu. Cậu chỉ nghĩ về Sibyl. Một tiếng dội yếu ớt của tình yêu đã quay lại với cậu. Cậu nhắc đi nhắc lại tên nàng. Lũ chim hót trong khu vườn đẫm sương dường như đang kể cho các bông hoa nghe về nàng.
tr: Ayağa kalktı, portrenin tam önüne büyük bir paravan çekti. Gözü resme değince ürperdi. “Ne feci!” diye mırıldanarak yürüdü, camlı kapıyı açtı. Çimenlere basınca derin derin soludu. Taze sabah havası içindeki bütün karanlık duyguları kovmuştu sanki. Şimdi yalnızca Sibyl’i düşünüyordu. Eski aşkının titrek bir yankısını duyar gibi oldu. Sibyl’in adını yinelemeye başladı. Çiy ıslaklığındaki bahçede şakıyan kuşlar, çiçeklere Sibyl’in şarkısını söylemekteydiler.
es: Se levantó de la silla y colocó un biombo de grandes dimensiones delante del retrato, estremeciéndose mientras lo contemplaba. «¡Qué horror!», murmuró, y, acercándose a la puerta que daba al jardín, la abrió. Al pisar la hierba, respiró hondo. El frescor del aire matutino pareció ahuyentar todas sus sombrías pasiones. Pensaba sólo en Sibyl. Un débil eco del antiguo amor reapareció en su pecho. Repitió muchas veces su nombre. Los pájaros que cantaban en el jardín empapado de rocío parecían hablar de ella a las flores.
vi_translation: He stood up from the chair, pulled the large curtain right in front of the portrait, shuddering as he looked at it. “Horrifying!” he muttered to himself and walked over to the window, then opened it. When he stepped outside, onto the grass, he took a deep breath. The fresh morning air seemed to dispel all his gloomy passions. He thought only of Sibyl. A faint echo of love had returned to him. He repeated her name over and over. The birds singing in the dew-laden garden seemed to be telling the flowers about her.
tr_translation: He stood up and drew a large screen right in front of the portrait. He shuddered when his eyes fell upon the painting. “How dreadful!” he murmured as he walked and opened the glass door. He took a deep breath as he stepped onto the grass. It was as if the fresh morning air had driven away all his dark feelings. Now he was thinking only of Sibyl. He felt as if he could hear a faint echo of his old love. He began to repeat Sibyl’s name. The birds singing in the dew-damp garden were singing Sibyl’s song to the flowers.
es_translation: He got up from the chair and placed a large screen in front of the portrait, shuddering as he gazed at it. “What a horror!” he murmured, and, approaching the door that led to the garden, he opened it. As he stepped on the grass, he took a deep breath. The freshness of the morning air seemed to drive away all his dark passions. He thought only of Sibyl. A faint echo of the old love reappeared in his chest. He repeated her name many times. The birds singing in the dew-soaked garden seemed to speak of her to the flowers.

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: Chương 8
tr: Sekizinci bölüm
es: Capítulo 8
vi_translation: Chapter 8
tr_translation: Eighth chapter
es_translation: Chapter 8

en: It was long past noon when he awoke. His valet had crept several times on tiptoe into the room to see if he was stirring, and had wondered what made his young master sleep so late. Finally his bell sounded, and Victor came in softly with a cup of tea, and a pile of letters, on a small tray of old Sevres china, and drew back the olive-satin curtains, with their shimmering blue lining, that hung in front of the three tall windows.
vi: Trưa qua đã lâu lúc cậu tỉnh giấc. Người hầu đã vài lần nhón chân rón rén vào phòng để xem cậu dậy chưa, và tự hỏi chuyện gì khiến cho cậu chủ của hắn ngủ muộn như vậy. Cuối cùng, cái chuông kêu vang, Victor nhẹ nhàng bước vào với ly trà, chồng thư, trên cái khay nhỏ bằng sứ Sèvres cổ, và kéo lùi các tấm rèm xa- tanh màu ô liu, với lớp lót xanh lam lung linh, treo trước ba ô cửa sổ cao.
tr: Dorian uyandığı zaman saat öğleyi çoktan geçmişti. Uşağı birçok kez onun uyanıp uyanmadığını görmek için ayağının ucuna basarak odaya girmiş, genç efendinin böyle geç saatlere kadar uyumasının nedenini merak etmişti. Sonunda çıngırak çaldı. Victor yumuşak adımlarla içeri girdi. Elindeki antika Sevr porseleninden tepsinin üzerinde bir fincan çayla bir deste mektup vardı. Odanın üç yüksek penceresini örten pırıltılı mavi astarlı, zeytin renkli perdeleri açtı.
es: Era más de mediodía cuando se despertó. Su ayuda de cámara había entrado varias veces de puntillas en la habitación, preguntándose qué hacía dormir hasta tan tarde a su amo. Dorian tocó finalmente la campanilla, y Víctor apareció sin hacer ruido con una taza de té y un montón de cartas en una bandejita de porcelana de Sévres. Luego descorrió las cortinas de satén color oliva, con forro azul irisado, que cubrían las tres altas ventanas de la alcoba.
vi_translation: It was long past noon when he woke up. The servant had tiptoed into the room several times to see if he was awake yet, wondering what had caused his master to sleep so late. Finally, the bell rang, and Victor gently entered with a cup of tea, a stack of letters, on a small antique Sèvres porcelain tray, and drew back the olive satin curtains, lined with shimmering blue, hanging in front of the three tall windows.
tr_translation: When Dorian woke up, it was already well past noon. His servant had tiptoed into the room several times to see if he had woken up, wondering why the young master was sleeping so late. Finally, the bell rang. Victor entered softly. On the antique Sèvres porcelain tray in his hand were a cup of tea and a stack of letters. He opened the olive-colored curtains lined with shimmering blue that covered the room's three tall windows.
es_translation: It was past noon when he woke up. His valet had tiptoed into the room several times, wondering what could make his master sleep so late. Dorian finally rang the bell, and Victor appeared silently with a cup of tea and a pile of letters on a Sévres porcelain tray. Then he drew back the olive satin curtains, lined with iridescent blue, that covered the three tall windows of the alcove.

en: “Monsieur has well slept this morning,” he said, smiling.
vi: “Sáng nay mông-xừ ngủ ngon quá,” hắn nói, mỉm cười.
tr: “Mösyö uyudular iyi bu sabah,” dedi gülümseyerek.
es: —El señor ha dormido muy bien esta noche —dijo, sonriendo.
vi_translation: “You slept well this morning, sir,” he said, smiling.
tr_translation: “Monsieur slept well this morning,” he said with a smile.
es_translation: "The gentleman slept very well last night," he said, smiling.

en: “What o’clock is it, Victor?” asked Dorian Gray drowsily.
vi: “Mấy giờ rồi, Victor?” Dorian Gray hỏi, thẫn thờ.
tr: Dorian uykulu uykulu, “Saat kaç, Victor?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Qué hora es, Víctor? —preguntó Dorian, todavía medio despierto.
vi_translation: "What time is it, Victor?" Dorian Gray asked, absent-mindedly.
tr_translation: Dorian asked sleepily, "What time is it, Victor?"
es_translation: —What time is it, Victor? —asked Dorian, still half asleep.

en: “One hour and a quarter, Monsieur.”
vi: “Một giờ mười lăm rồi, thưa mông-xừ.”
tr: “Bir saatle bir çeyrek, mösyö.
es: —La una y cuarto, señor.
vi_translation: “It’s one fifteen already, sir.”
tr_translation: “An hour and a quarter, monsieur.”
es_translation: —One fifteen, sir.

en: How late it was! He sat up, and having sipped some tea, turned over his letters. One of them was from Lord Henry, and had been brought by hand that morning. He hesitated for a moment, and then put it aside. The others he opened listlessly. They contained the usual collection of cards, invitations to dinner, tickets for private views, programmes of charity concerts, and the like that are showered on fashionable young men every morning during the season. There was a rather heavy bill for a chased silver Louis-Quinze toilet-set that he had not yet had the courage to send on to his guardians, who were extremely old-fashioned people and did not realize that we live in an age when unnecessary things are our only necessities; and there were several very courteously worded communications from Jermyn Street money-lenders offering to advance any sum of money at a moment’s notice and at the most reasonable rates of interest.
vi: Muộn thật rồi! Cậu ngồi dậy, và, sau khi nhắp chút trà, quay qua các lá thư. Một trong số chúng là của huân tước Henry, được đưa tay sáng nay. Cậu lưỡng lự một lát, rồi đặt nó qua bên. Các lá thư khác thì cậu mở thờ ơ. Chúng bao gồm bộ sưu tập thường lệ về danh thiếp, giấy mời ăn tối, vé xem triển lãm riêng, chương trình hòa nhạc từ thiện, và tương tự, những thứ vẫn được gửi tới tấp đến cho các thanh niên sang trọng vào mỗi buổi sáng trong mùa. Có một hóa đơn khá nặng, cho một bộ trang điểm chạm bạc theo phong cách thời Louis XV, mà cậu vẫn chưa đủ can đảm gửi cho các người giám hộ mình, những kẻ quá đỗi cổ hủ và không nhận thức được rằng chúng ta đang sống trong một thời đại mà những thứ không cần thiết lại là những thứ duy nhất cần thiết của chúng ta; ở đó còn có vài thông báo được trình bày rất nhã nhặn từ những kẻ cho vay tiền trên phố Jermyn để chào mời cho mượn bất cứ số tiền nào ngay lập tức và với mức lãi suất phải chăng nhất.
tr: Amma da geç olmuştu ha! Dorian doğrulup oturdu, birkaç yudum çay içtikten sonra mektuplarını ele aldı. Bunlardan biri Lord Henry’dendi; o sabah elden gönderilmişti. Delikanlı bir an duraksadı, sonra mektubu bir yana koydu. Ötekileri isteksizce açtı. Gene her zamanki gibi mevsim boyunca, sosyete gençlerinin başına yağmur gibi yağan kartvizitlerden, yemek çağrılarından, özel gösterim biletlerinden, yardımlaşma konserlerinin programlarından oluşma bir yığın. Bir de kabartma kakmalı gümüş Louis Quinze tuvalet takımı için oldukça yüklü bir fatura vardı ki, bunu daha vasilerine iletmeyi göze alamamıştı. Vasileri son derece darkafalı olduklarından şu yaşadığımız çağda kişilerin ancak gereksiz şeylere ihtiyaç duyduklarını anlayamıyorlardı! Jermyn Sokağı’ndaki faizci ve tefecilerden de büyük saygıyla yazılmış birçok mektup vardı. Bunlar Dorian’a her istediği anda, en uygun faiz koşullarıyla istediği kadar borç para vermeyi öneriyorlardı.
es: ¡Qué tarde ya! Se sentó en la cama y, después de tomar unos sorbos de té, se ocupó del correo. Una de las cartas era de lord Henry, y la habían traído a mano por la mañana. Dorian vaciló un momento y luego terminó por apartarla. Las demás las abrió distraídamente. Contenían la usual colección de tarjetas, invitaciones para cenar, entradas para exposiciones privadas, programas de conciertos con fines benéficos y otras cosas parecidas que llueven todas las mañanas sobre los jóvenes de la buena sociedad durante la temporada. Había también una factura considerable por un juego de utensilios de aseo Luis XV de plata repujada, factura que Dorian no se había atrevido aún a reexpedir a sus tutores, personas extraordinariamente chapadas a la antigua, incapaces de comprender que vivimos en una época en la que ciertas cosas innecesarias son nuestras únicas necesidades; también encontró varias comunicaciones, redactadas en términos muy corteses, de los prestamistas de Jermyn Street, ofreciéndose a adelantarle cualquier cantidad de dinero sin molestas esperas y a unas tasas de interés sumamente razonables.
vi_translation: It was really late! He sat up, and, after sipping some tea, turned to the letters. One of them was from Lord Henry, delivered by hand this morning. He hesitated for a moment, then set it aside. The other letters he opened indifferently. They included the usual collection of calling cards, dinner invitations, private exhibition tickets, charity concert programs, and the like, the things that are incessantly sent to fashionable young men every morning during the season. There was a rather hefty bill for a silver-gilt dressing set in the style of Louis XV, which he had not yet had the courage to send to his guardians, who were exceedingly old-fashioned and unaware that we live in an age where the unnecessary are our only necessities; there were also a few very politely presented notices from moneylenders on Jermyn Street offering to lend any amount of money immediately and at the most reasonable rates of interest.
tr_translation: But it was already late, huh! Dorian sat up, took a few sips of tea, and then picked up his letters. One of them was from Lord Henry; it had been delivered by hand that morning. The young man hesitated for a moment, then put the letter aside. He opened the others reluctantly. As usual during the season, it was a pile consisting of calling cards, dinner invitations, private show tickets, and charity concert programs that rained down on the heads of young socialites. There was also a rather hefty bill for a silver Louis Quinze dressing set with embossed inlays, which he had not yet dared to forward to his guardians. His guardians were so narrow-minded that they couldn't understand that in this day and age, people only needed unnecessary things! There were also many letters written with great respect from pawnbrokers and moneylenders on Jermyn Street. They were offering Dorian as much money as he wanted, at the most favorable interest rates, whenever he desired.
es_translation: How late it is already! He sat on the bed and, after taking a few sips of tea, attended to the mail. One of the letters was from Lord Henry, and it had been delivered by hand in the morning. Dorian hesitated for a moment and then ended up setting it aside. He opened the others absentmindedly. They contained the usual collection of cards, dinner invitations, tickets for private exhibitions, concert programs for charitable purposes, and other similar things that rain down every morning on young people of good society during the season. There was also a considerable bill for a set of Louis XV silver embossed grooming utensils, a bill that Dorian had not yet dared to forward to his guardians, extraordinarily old-fashioned people, incapable of understanding that we live in an age where certain unnecessary things are our only necessities; he also found several communications, written in very polite terms, from the moneylenders on Jermyn Street, offering to advance him any amount of money without bothersome delays and at very reasonable interest rates.

en: After about ten minutes he got up, and throwing on an elaborate dressing-gown of silk-embroidered cashmere wool, passed into the onyx-paved bathroom. The cool water refreshed him after his long sleep. He seemed to have forgotten all that he had gone through. A dim sense of having taken part in some strange tragedy came to him once or twice, but there was the unreality of a dream about it.
vi: Độ chục phút sau, cậu đứng dậy, khoác vội chiếc áo choàng may tỉ mỉ bằng len ca-sơ-mia thêu lụa, đi vào buồng tắm lát đá mã não. Nước lạnh làm cậu tươi tỉnh lại sau giấc ngủ dài. Cậu dường như đã quên mọi chuyện cậu vừa trải qua. Một cảm giác mơ hồ về việc từng tham gia vào bi kịch lạ lùng nào đó có đến với cậu một đôi lần, nhưng có gì đó phi thực trong giấc mộng về nó.
tr: On dakika kadar sonra Dorian yataktan kalktı, sırtına ipek işlemeli yün kaşmirden gösterişli bir kimono alarak damarlı siyah akik kaplı banyoya geçti. Uyuduğu uzun uykudan sonra serin su tazelik verdi ona. Çektiği sıkıntıların hepsini unutmuş gibiydi. Birkaç kez içine tuhaf bir trajedide rol almış gibi hayal meyal bir duygu düştüyse de bunda bir düşün asılsızlığı vardı.
es: Al cabo de unos diez minutos Dorian se levantó y, echándose por los hombros una lujosa bata de lana de Cachemira con bordados en seda, entró en el cuarto de baño con suelo de ónice. El agua fresca lo despejó después de las muchas horas de sueño. Parecía haber olvidado lo sucedido el día anterior. Una vaga sensación de haber participado en alguna extraña tragedia se le pasó por la cabeza una o dos veces, pero con la irrealidad de un sueño.
vi_translation: About ten minutes later, he stood up, hastily put on a meticulously tailored cashmere coat embroidered with silk, and went into the agate-tiled bathroom. The cold water refreshed him after the long sleep. He seemed to have forgotten everything he had just gone through. A vague feeling of having participated in some strange tragedy came to him a few times, but there was something unreal about the dream of it.
tr_translation: About ten minutes later, Dorian got out of bed, put on a luxurious kimono made of wool cashmere embroidered with silk, and went to the bathroom covered in veined black onyx. After the long sleep he had, the cool water refreshed him. It was as if he had forgotten all the troubles he had endured. Although a vague feeling of having played a role in a strange tragedy crossed his mind a few times, it had the baselessness of a dream.
es_translation: After about ten minutes, Dorian got up and, throwing a luxurious Cashmere wool robe with silk embroidery over his shoulders, entered the bathroom with an onyx floor. The fresh water cleared him after many hours of sleep. He seemed to have forgotten what had happened the day before. A vague sensation of having participated in some strange tragedy crossed his mind once or twice, but with the unreality of a dream.

en: As soon as he was dressed, he went into the library and sat down to a light French breakfast that had been laid out for him on a small round table close to the open window. It was an exquisite day. The warm air seemed laden with spices. A bee flew in and buzzed round the blue-dragon bowl that, filled with sulphur-yellow roses, stood before him. He felt perfectly happy.
vi: Ngay sau khi mặc xong quần áo, cậu đi vào thư viện và ngồi xuống dùng bữa sáng nhẹ kiểu Pháp đã được bày ra cho cậu trên một chiếc bàn tròn nhỏ gần ô cửa sổ mở toang. Đó là một ngày tuyệt đẹp. Không khí ấm áp dường như đậm đà hương vị. Một con ong bay vào, vo ve quanh cái bát sứ in hình rồng xanh lam, chứa đầy hoa hồng vàng lưu huỳnh, để trước mặt cậu. Cậu cảm thấy vô cùng hạnh phúc.
tr: Dorian giyinir giyinmez kitaplığa gitti, açık camlı kapının önüne kurulmuş olan küçük, yuvarlak bir masada Fransız usulü hafif bir kahvaltı yaptı. Nefis bir gündü. Ilık hava baharat yüklüydü sanki. Bir arı içeri girdi, Dorian’ın önünde duran, kükürt sarısı güllerle dolu, mavi ejderhalı vazonun çevresini vızıldayarak döndü. Dorian’ın içinde katıksız bir mutluluk vardı.
es: En cuanto se hubo vestido, entró en la biblioteca y se sentó a tomar un ligero desayuno francés, servido sobre una mesita redonda, próxima a la ventana abierta. Hacía un día maravilloso. El aire tibio parecía cargado de especias. Una abeja entró por la ventana y zumbó alrededor del cuenco color azul con motivos de dragones que, lleno de rosas amarillas, tenía delante. Dorian se sintió perfectamente feliz.
vi_translation: Right after putting on his clothes, he went into the library and sat down to a light French breakfast that had been laid out for him on a small round table near the wide-open window. It was a beautiful day. The warm air seemed to be rich with flavor. A bee flew in, buzzing around the porcelain bowl decorated with blue dragons, filled with sulfur-yellow roses, placed in front of him. He felt extremely happy.
tr_translation: As soon as Dorian dressed, he went to the library and had a light French-style breakfast at the small, round table set in front of the open glass door. It was a splendid day. The warm air seemed to be laden with spices. A bee flew in and buzzed around the vase with blue dragons, filled with sulfur-yellow roses, that stood in front of Dorian. Dorian felt pure happiness within him.
es_translation: As soon as he had dressed, he entered the library and sat down to have a light French breakfast, served on a round table next to the open window. It was a wonderful day. The warm air seemed laden with spices. A bee flew in through the window and buzzed around the blue bowl with dragon motifs, filled with yellow roses, that he had in front of him. Dorian felt perfectly happy.

en: Suddenly his eye fell on the screen that he had placed in front of the portrait, and he started.
vi: Bỗng nhiên mắt cậu để ý thấy tấm chắn mà cậu đã đặt trước bức chân dung, và cậu giật mình.
tr: Birden gözleri portrenin önüne çekmiş olduğu paravana takılınca genç adam irkildi.
es: De repente, su mirada se posó sobre el biombo situado delante del retrato y se estremeció.
vi_translation: Suddenly, his eyes noticed the shield he had placed in front of the portrait, and he was startled.
tr_translation: When his eyes suddenly caught the screen placed in front of the portrait, the young man was startled.
es_translation: Suddenly, his gaze fell upon the screen placed in front of the portrait, and he shuddered.

en: “Too cold for Monsieur?” asked his valet, putting an omelette on the table. “I shut the window?”
vi: “Mông-xừ có bị lạnh quá không?” người hầu hỏi, đặt món trứng ốp-lết lên bàn. “Tôi đóng cửa sổ lại nhé?”
tr: Uşağı sofraya bir omlet bırakırken, “Mösyöye serin mi geldi hava?” diye sordu. “Pencereyi kapıyorum.
es: —¿El señor tiene frío? —preguntó el ayuda de cámara, colocando una tortilla sobre la mesita—. ¿Cierro la ventana?
vi_translation: "Are you too cold, sir?" the servant asked, placing the omelette on the table. "Shall I close the window?"
tr_translation: As the boy placed an omelet on the table, he asked, "Did the weather feel chilly to Monsieur?" "I'm closing the window."
es_translation: —Is the gentleman cold? —asked the valet, placing an omelet on the small table—. Shall I close the window?

en: Dorian shook his head. “I am not cold,” he murmured.
vi: Dorian lắc đầu. “Tôi không lạnh,” cậu lẩm bẩm.
tr: Dorian başını sarsarak, “Üşümüyorum,” diye mırıldandı.
es: Dorian negó con un movimiento de cabeza. —No tengo frío —murmuró.
vi_translation: Dorian shook his head. "I'm not cold," he muttered.
tr_translation: Shaking his head, Dorian murmured, "I'm not cold."
es_translation: Dorian shook his head. —I'm not cold —he murmured.

en: Was it all true? Had the portrait really changed? Or had it been simply his own imagination that had made him see a look of evil where there had been a look of joy? Surely a painted canvas could not alter? The thing was absurd. It would serve as a tale to tell Basil some day. It would make him smile.
vi: Mọi chuyện ấy có thật sao? Bức chân dung có biến đổi thật không? Hay chỉ là trí tưởng tượng của chính cậu đã khiến cho cậu thấy nét xấu xa ở nơi từng có nét vui mừng? Chắc chắn là một tấm toan sơn màu thì không thể thay đổi được chứ nhỉ? Vụ này thật ngớ ngẩn. Nó có thể dùng như một câu chuyện để kể cho Basil nghe một ngày nào đó. Nó sẽ khiến anh ấy cười.
tr: Gerçek miydi anımsadıkları? Portre sahiden değişime uğramış mıydı? Yoksa salt kendi imgelemi miydi, eskiden bir kıvanç ifadesinin olduğu yerde bir hainlik ifadesi görmesine yol açan? Boyalı bir tuval elbette ki değişemezdi, öyle değil mi? Gülünçtü bu. Günün birinde Basil’e anlatabileceği bir öykü çıkmıştı işte. Basil bunu dinleyince gülümseyecekti.
es: ¿Era cierto todo lo que recordaba? ¿Había cambiado de verdad el retrato? ¿O le había hecho ver su imaginación una expresión malvada donde sólo había un gesto alegre? Era imposible que un lienzo cambiara. Absurdo. Sería una excelente historia que contarle a Basil algún día. Le haría sonreír.
vi_translation: Is all of this really true? Did the portrait really change? Or was it just your own imagination that made you see the evil where there once was joy? Surely a painted canvas cannot change, right? This is really absurd. It could be used as a story to tell Basil someday. It would make him laugh.
tr_translation: Were the memories real? Had the portrait truly undergone a change? Or was it merely his own imagination that led him to see an expression of treachery where once there had been an expression of pride? A painted canvas certainly couldn't change, could it? This was ridiculous. He now had a story he could tell Basil one day. Basil would smile when he heard it.
es_translation: Was everything he remembered true? Had the portrait really changed? Or had his imagination made him see an evil expression where there was only a joyful gesture? It was impossible for a canvas to change. Absurd. It would be an excellent story to tell Basil someday. It would make him smile.

en: And, yet, how vivid was his recollection of the whole thing! First in the dim twilight, and then in the bright dawn, he had seen the touch of cruelty round the warped lips. He almost dreaded his valet leaving the room. He knew that when he was alone he would have to examine the portrait. He was afraid of certainty. When the coffee and cigarettes had been brought and the man turned to go, he felt a wild desire to tell him to remain. As the door was closing behind him, he called him back. The man stood waiting for his orders. Dorian looked at him for a moment. “I am not at home to any one, Victor,” he said with a sigh. The man bowed and retired.
vi: Tuy nhiên, sao mà ký ức của cậu về toàn bộ vụ này lại sinh động đến thế! Thoạt đầu là trong lờ mờ tối, sau đó là trong buổi bình minh chói ngời, cậu đã nhìn thấy nét tàn nhẫn quanh đôi môi biến dạng. Cậu gần như sợ người hầu ra khỏi phòng. Cậu biết rằng lúc ấy cậu sẽ một mình và có lẽ cậu sẽ kiểm tra bức chân dung. Cậu lo sợ sự chắc chắn. Khi cà phê và thuốc lá đã được mang vào và người hầu quay đi, cậu cảm thấy một ước muốn rồ dại là bảo hắn ở lại. Lúc cửa đang khép vào sau lưng hắn thì cậu gọi hắn lại. Người hầu đứng chờ lệnh cậu. Dorian nhìn hắn một lát. “Tôi không ở nhà nhé, Victor, ai cũng kệ,” cậu nói, với một tiếng thở dài. Người hầu cúi đầu và lui ra.
tr: Öte yandan, bu olayın anısı nasıl da canlıydı! İlkin alacakaranlığın loşluğunda, sonra da parlak tan ışığında Dorian o gergin dudaklardaki taşyürekli ifadeyi görmüştü. Şimdi genç adam uşağının dışarı çıkmasından adeta ürküyordu. Yalnız kaldığında portreyi gözden geçirmekten kendini alamayacağını biliyordu çünkü. Kesin bilgi edinmekten korkuyordu. Uşak kahveyle sigaraları getirip de gitmeye davranınca Dorian onu alıkoymak için çılgın bir isteğe kapıldı. Tam kapı kapanırken adamı geri çağırdı. Uşak durmuş buyruk bekliyordu. Dorian bir ona baktı. Sonra içini çekerek, “Kim ararsa arasın, evde yokum, Victor,” dedi. Adam eğildi, çekildi.
es: Sin embargo, ¡qué preciso era el recuerdo! Primero en la confusa penumbra y luego en el luminoso amanecer, había visto el toque de crueldad en los labios contraídos. Casi temió que llegara el momento en que el criado abandonase la biblioteca. Sabía que cuando se quedara solo tendría que examinar el retrato. Le daba miedo enfrentarse con la certeza. Cuando, después de traer el café y los cigarrillos, Víctor se volvió para marcharse, Dorian sintió un absurdo deseo de decirle que se quedara. Mientras la puerta se cerraba tras él, lo llamó. Víctor se detuvo, esperando instrucciones. Dorian se lo quedó mirando unos instantes. —No estoy para nadie —dijo, acompañando las palabras con un suspiro. Víctor hizo una inclinación de cabeza y desapareció.
vi_translation: However, how vivid his memory of the whole incident was! At first, it was in the dim darkness, then in the bright dawn, he saw the cruel expression around the distorted lips. He was almost afraid of the servant leaving the room. He knew that at that moment he would be alone and perhaps he would check the portrait. He feared certainty. When the coffee and cigarettes had been brought in and the servant turned away, he felt a mad desire to tell him to stay. As the door was closing behind him, he called him back. The servant stood waiting for his orders. Dorian looked at him for a moment. “I am not at home, Victor, to anyone,” he said, with a sigh. The servant bowed and withdrew.
tr_translation: On the other hand, how vivid was the memory of this event! First in the dimness of twilight, then in the bright dawn light, Dorian had seen the stone-hearted expression on those tense lips. Now the young man was almost terrified of his servant going outside. Because he knew that when he was alone, he wouldn't be able to resist examining the portrait. He was afraid of gaining definite knowledge. When the servant brought the coffee and cigarettes and was about to leave, Dorian was seized by a frantic desire to keep him. Just as the door was closing, he called the man back. The servant stopped, waiting for orders. Dorian looked at her. Then, sighing, he said, "Whoever calls, I'm not home, Victor." The man bent down, then withdrew.
es_translation: However, how precise the memory was! First in the confusing twilight and then in the luminous dawn, he had seen the touch of cruelty in the contracted lips. He almost feared the moment when the servant would leave the library. He knew that when he was alone he would have to examine the portrait. He was afraid to face the certainty. When, after bringing the coffee and cigarettes, Victor turned to leave, Dorian felt an absurd desire to tell him to stay. As the door closed behind him, he called out to him. Victor stopped, waiting for instructions. Dorian stared at him for a few moments. —I'm not available for anyone —he said, accompanying the words with a sigh. Victor nodded and disappeared.

en: Then he rose from the table, lit a cigarette, and flung himself down on a luxuriously cushioned couch that stood facing the screen. The screen was an old one, of gilt Spanish leather, stamped and wrought with a rather florid Louis-Quatorze pattern. He scanned it curiously, wondering if ever before it had concealed the secret of a man’s life.
vi: Sau đó cậu đứng dậy khỏi bàn, châm thuốc, buông mình xuống chiếc đi-văng lót đệm xa hoa kê đối diện tấm chắn. Tấm chắn là một cổ vật, bằng da Tây Ban Nha mạ vàng, được dập nổi và chế tác với một họa tiết khá cầu kỳ theo phong cách thời Vua Louis XV. Cậu tò mò xem kỹ nó, tự hỏi không biết có khi nào trước đây nó đã từng che đậy bí mật đời ai không.
tr: O zaman Dorian masa başından kalktı, bir sigara yaktı ve kendini paravanın karşısındaki bol yastıklı bir kanepeye bıraktı. Paravan çok eskiydi, yaldızlı İspanyol meşininden yapılmış, biraz gösterişli bir Louis Quatorze baskısıyla süslenmişti. Dorian paravanı merakla süzerek, acaba bundan önce bir insan yaşamının gizine hiç siper oldu mu, diye düşündü.
es: Dorian se alzó entonces de la mesa, encendió un cigarrillo y se dejó caer sobre un diván extraordinariamente cómodo, situado delante del biombo. El biombo era antiguo, de cuero español dorado, estampado con un dibujo Luis XIV demasiado florido. Dorian lo examinó con curiosidad, preguntándose si habría ocultado ya alguna vez el secreto de una vida.
vi_translation: Then he got up from the table, lit a cigarette, and let himself down onto the luxurious cushioned divan opposite the screen. The screen was an antique, made of gold-plated Spanish leather, embossed and crafted with a rather intricate design in the style of King Louis XV. He examined it curiously, wondering if it had ever concealed anyone's secrets before.
tr_translation: Then Dorian got up from the table, lit a cigarette, and threw himself onto a sofa with plenty of cushions opposite the screen. The screen was very old, made of gilded Spanish leather, and adorned with a somewhat ostentatious Louis Quatorze pattern. As Dorian gazed at the screen curiously, he wondered if it had ever shielded the secret of a human life before.
es_translation: Dorian then rose from the table, lit a cigarette, and let himself fall onto an extraordinarily comfortable divan situated in front of the screen. The screen was old, made of gilded Spanish leather, stamped with an overly florid Louis XIV design. Dorian examined it with curiosity, wondering if it had ever hidden the secret of a life.

en: Should he move it aside, after all? Why not let it stay there? What was the use of knowing? If the thing was true, it was terrible. If it was not true, why trouble about it? But what if, by some fate or deadlier chance, eyes other than his spied behind and saw the horrible change? What should he do if Basil Hallward came and asked to look at his own picture? Basil would be sure to do that. No; the thing had to be examined, and at once. Anything would be better than this dreadful state of doubt.
vi: Rốt cuộc thì cậu có nên dịch nó qua bên không? Sao không để mặc nó ở đó? Biết thì có ích lợi gì? Nếu chuyện là thật thì nó quá khủng khiếp. Nếu không phải là thật thì sao lại phải bận tâm với nó? Nhưng sẽ thế nào nếu như, do định mệnh hoặc sự tình cờ chí tử nào đó, những con mắt khác với mắt cậu lại dò xét đằng sau và thấy sự thay đổi kinh khủng ấy? Cậu sẽ phải làm gì nếu Basil Hallward ghé qua và đòi xem bức tranh của anh ấy? Basil chắc chắn sẽ làm vậy. Không; vật này phải được kiểm tra lại, ngay lập tức. Dẫu có bất cứ chuyện gì thì cũng tốt hơn là tình trạng ngờ vực khủng khiếp này.
tr: Paravanı bir yana çekse miydi her şeye karşın? Ama neden olduğu yerde bırakmasın? Bilmenin ne yararı vardı ki? Anımsadığı şey doğruysa ürkütücü bir şeydi. Doğru değilse canını üzmek niye? Öte yandan, ya korkunç bir rastlantıyla kendisininkinden başka gözler paravanın ardına bakar da o feci değişimi görürse? Basil Hallward gelip de kendi resmine bakmayı dilerse Dorian ne yapabilirdi? Basil elbet bir gün yapacaktı bunu. Yok yok, resmin hemen incelenmesi gerekti, hem de hemen şimdi. Kuşkunun neden olduğu bu korkunç gerilime yeğdir.
es: ¿Debía realmente apartarlo, después de todo? ¿Por qué no dejarlo donde estaba? ¿De qué servía conocer la verdad? Si resultaba cierto, era terrible. Si no, ¿por qué preocuparse? Pero, ¿y si, por alguna fatalidad o una casualidad aún más terrible, otros ojos hubieran mirado detrás del biombo, comprobando el horrible cambio? ¿Qué haría si se presentara Basil Hallward y pidiese contemplar el cuadro? Era seguro que Basil acabaría por hacer una cosa así. No; tenía que examinar el retrato, y hacerlo de inmediato. Cualquier cosa mejor que aquella espantosa duda.
vi_translation: In the end, should you move it over there? Why not just leave it there? What good is knowing? If it's true, then it's too terrible. If it isn't real, then why bother with it? But what if, due to fate or some fatal coincidence, eyes other than yours scrutinize it and see that terrible change? What would you do if Basil Hallward dropped by and demanded to see his painting? Basil would certainly do that. No; this thing must be checked again, immediately. Whatever happens, it would be better than this terrible state of suspicion.
tr_translation: Should he pull the screen aside despite everything? But why not leave it where it is? What good would it do to know? If what he remembered was true, it was something terrifying. If it wasn't true, why upset himself? On the other hand, what if by some horrible coincidence, other eyes besides his own looked behind the screen and saw that dreadful change? What could Dorian do if Basil Hallward came and wanted to look at his own painting? Basil would certainly do this one day. No, no, the painting needed to be examined immediately, right now. It was preferable to this terrible tension caused by doubt.
es_translation: Did he really have to put it away, after all? Why not leave it where it was? What was the use of knowing the truth? If it turned out to be true, it was terrible. If not, why worry? But, what if, by some fatality or an even more terrible chance, other eyes had looked behind the screen, witnessing the horrible change? What would he do if Basil Hallward showed up and asked to see the painting? It was certain that Basil would eventually do something like that. No; he had to examine the portrait, and do it immediately. Anything was better than that dreadful doubt.

en: He got up and locked both doors. At least he would be alone when he looked upon the mask of his shame. Then he drew the screen aside and saw himself face to face. It was perfectly true. The portrait had altered.
vi: Cậu đứng dậy và khóa cả hai cửa lại. Chí ít thì cậu cũng sẽ ở một mình khi nhìn vào cái mặt nạ nhục nhã của cậu. Sau đó cậu kéo tấm màn chắn qua bên, và thấy chính mình, mặt đối mặt. Đúng thật rồi: bức tranh đã thay đổi.
tr: Dorian kalktı, kapıların ikisini de kilitledi. Utancının maskesine bakarken yalnız olmalıydı hiç değilse. Dorian paravanı çekti, kendisiyle yüz yüze geldi. Her şey tam anlamıyla gerçekti: Portre değişmişti.
es: Se levantó y cerró las dos puertas con llave. Al menos estaría solo mientras contemplaba la máscara de su vergüenza. Luego apartó el biombo y se vio cara a cara. Era totalmente cierto. El retrato había cambiado.
vi_translation: He stood up and locked both doors. At least he would be alone when he looked at his shameful mask. Then he pulled the curtain aside and saw himself, face to face. It was true: the picture had changed.
tr_translation: Dorian stood up and locked both doors. He had to be alone at least while looking at the mask of his shame. Dorian drew the screen and came face to face with himself. Everything was completely real: The portrait had changed.
es_translation: He got up and locked the two doors. At least he would be alone while he contemplated the mask of his shame. Then he moved the screen and saw himself face to face. It was completely true. The portrait had changed.

en: As he often remembered afterwards, and always with no small wonder, he found himself at first gazing at the portrait with a feeling of almost scientific interest. That such a change should have taken place was incredible to him. And yet it was a fact. Was there some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms that shaped themselves into form and colour on the canvas and the soul that was within him? Could it be that what that soul thought, they realized?—that what it dreamed, they made true? Or was there some other, more terrible reason? He shuddered, and felt afraid, and, going back to the couch, lay there, gazing at the picture in sickened horror.
vi: Như cậu hay nhớ lại sau này, và luôn với chút ngạc nhiên, cậu thấy mình thoạt đầu đã ngắm nhìn bức chân dung với một cảm giác thích thú gần như có tính khoa học. Một sự thay đổi như vậy lại xảy ra được là việc không thể tin nổi với cậu. Tuy nhiên đó là sự thật. Lẽ nào lại có một ái lực tinh vi nào đó giữa các nguyên tử hóa học, những thứ đã tự sắp thành hình và màu trên tấm toan, với linh hồn trong cậu? Liệu có thể nào mà những gì cái linh hồn ấy nghĩ đến thì chúng sẽ hiện thực hóa được? — và những gì nó mơ đến thì chúng sẽ biến thành sự thật? Hoặc còn nguyên nhân nào đó khác, khủng khiếp hơn? Cậu rùng mình, cảm thấy sợ hãi, và, quay lại đi-văng, nằm đó, ngắm bức tranh với nỗi khiếp sợ phát ốm.
tr: Portreyi neredeyse bilimsel bir ilgiyle süzdü. Bu hareketini sonraları şaşırarak anımsayacaktı. Böyle bir değişimin gerçekleşmiş olması usuna sığmıyordu. Gel gör ki değişim gerçekti, vardı, oradaydı. Tuval üzerinde bir araya gelerek rengi ve formu oluşturan kimyasal atomlarla Dorian’ın içindeki ruh arasında gizli bir bağıntı mı vardı yoksa? Bu ruhun düşündüklerini o atomların kavrayabilmesi olası mıydı? Yoksa daha başka, daha müthiş bir neden mi vardı? Genç adam ürperdi, korktu, gene kanepeye gidip uzanarak içini çürüten bir dehşetle gözlerini resme dikti.
es: Como después recordaría con frecuencia, y siempre con notable asombro, se encontró mirando al retrato con un sentimiento que era casi de curiosidad científica. Que aquel cambio hubiera podido producirse le resultaba increíble. Y, sin embargo, era un hecho. ¿Existía alguna sutil afinidad entre los átomos químicos, que se convertían en forma y color sobre el lienzo, y el alma que habitaba en el interior de su cuerpo? ¿Podría ser que lo que el alma pensaba, lo hicieran realidad? ¿Que dieran consistencia a lo que él soñaba? ¿O había alguna otra razón, más terrible? Se estremeció, sintió miedo y, volviendo al diván, se tumbó en él, contemplando el retrato sobrecogido de horror.
vi_translation: As he often recalled later, and always with some surprise, he found himself initially gazing at the portrait with a sense of almost scientific fascination. Such a change occurring was something he found incredible. Yet it was the truth. Could there be some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms, which had arranged themselves into shape and color on the canvas, and his soul? Could it be that what his soul thought of would materialize? — and what it dreamed of would become reality? Or was there some other cause, more terrifying? He shuddered, feeling frightened, and, turning back to the couch, lay there, staring at the painting with a sickening dread.
tr_translation: He scrutinized the portrait with an almost scientific interest. He would later recall this action with surprise. It was beyond his comprehension that such a transformation had taken place. Yet, the transformation was real, it existed, it was there. Was there a hidden connection between the chemical atoms that came together on the canvas to form color and shape and the soul within Dorian? Was it possible for those atoms to grasp the thoughts of this soul? Or was there another, more terrifying reason? The young man shuddered, frightened, and went back to the couch, lying down and fixing his eyes on the painting with a consuming horror.
es_translation: As he would frequently recall later, and always with notable astonishment, he found himself looking at the portrait with a feeling that was almost of scientific curiosity. That such a change could have occurred seemed incredible to him. And yet, it was a fact. Was there some subtle affinity between the chemical atoms, which turned into form and color on the canvas, and the soul that inhabited the interior of his body? Could it be that what the soul thought, they made real? That they gave substance to what he dreamed? Or was there some other, more terrible reason? He shuddered, felt fear, and, returning to the divan, lay down on it, contemplating the portrait overwhelmed with horror.

en: Three o’clock struck, and four, and the half-hour rang its double chime, but Dorian Gray did not stir. He was trying to gather up the scarlet threads of life and to weave them into a pattern; to find his way through the sanguine labyrinth of passion through which he was wandering. He did not know what to do, or what to think. Finally, he went over to the table and wrote a passionate letter to the girl he had loved, imploring her forgiveness and accusing himself of madness. He covered page after page with wild words of sorrow and wilder words of pain. There is a luxury in self-reproach. When we blame ourselves, we feel that no one else has a right to blame us. It is the confession, not the priest, that gives us absolution. When Dorian had finished the letter, he felt that he had been forgiven.
vi: Ba giờ điểm chuông, rồi bốn, rồi nửa giờ rung tiếng chuông đôi của nó, nhưng Dorian Gray vẫn không nhúc nhích. Cậu đang cố gắng thu thập các sợi chỉ đỏ tươi của đời, để dệt chúng thành một hoa văn; để lần đường qua cái mê cung đam mê đỏ máu mà cậu đang lang thang qua. Cậu không biết phải làm gì, hay nghĩ gì. Rốt cuộc, cậu lại gần bàn, viết một lá thư say đắm cho cô gái cậu yêu, cầu xin sự tha thứ của cô, và buộc cho mình cái tội điên. Cậu trải ra hết trang này đến trang khác những lời rồ dại về nỗi buồn, và những lời rồ dại hơn về niềm đau. Có một lạc thú xa xỉ trong việc tự trách mình. Khi ta tự trách mình thì ta cảm thấy rằng không ai khác có quyền trách ta. Chính sự thú tội, chứ không phải vị linh mục, mới mang lại cho ta sự miễn xá. Khi Dorian viết xong thư, cậu cảm thấy là cậu đã được tha thứ.
tr: Saat üçü vurdu, sonra dördü, yarım saatlerin çifte vuruşu duyuldu, ama Dorian Gray yerinden kıpırdamıyordu. Hayatın kızıl ipliklerini bir araya getirip örerek bir örnek çıkarmaya, içinde dolaştığı şu kan renkli tutku labirentinde çıkar bir yol bulmaya çabalıyordu. Ne yapacağını, ne düşüneceğini bildiği yoktu. En sonunda masa başına geçti, sevdiği kıza, af dileyen, kendi kendini zırdelilikle suçlayan ateşli bir mektup yazdı. Birbiri ardına birçok sayfaları üzüntüsünü dile getiren çılgın ve acısını dile getiren daha da çılgın sözcüklerle doldurdu. Kişinin kendi kendini suçlaması doyum verici bir lükstür. Kendimizi suçladığımız zaman başka hiç kimsenin bizi suçlamaya hakkı yokmuş gibi gelir. Kişiyi günahtan arındıran itirafın kendisidir, yoksa günah çıkartan papaz değil. Dorian mektubu bitirdiği zaman bağışlanmış olduğunu duyumsuyordu.
es: Sonaron las tres de la tarde, las cuatro, y la media hora dejó oír su doble carillón, pero Dorian Gray no se movió. Trataba de reunir los hilos escarlata de la vida y de tejerlos siguiendo un modelo; encontrar un camino, perdido como estaba en un laberinto de pasiones desatadas. No sabía qué hacer, ni qué pensar. Finalmente, volvió a la mesa y escribió una carta ardiente a la muchacha a la que había amado, implorando su perdón y acusándose de demencia. Llenó cuartilla tras cuartilla con atormentadas palabras de pesar y otras aún más patéticas de dolor. Existe la voluptuosidad del autorreproche. Cuando nos culpamos sentimos que nadie más tiene derecho a hacerlo. Es la confesión, no el sacerdote, lo que nos da la absolución. Cuando Dorian terminó la carta sintió que había sido perdonado.
vi_translation: The clock struck three, then four, then its half-hour double chime rang, but Dorian Gray still did not move. He was trying to gather the bright red threads of life, to weave them into a pattern; to find his way through the blood-red labyrinth of passion that he was wandering through. He did not know what to do, or what to think. Eventually, he approached the table, wrote a passionate letter to the girl he loved, begging for her forgiveness, and accusing himself of madness. He poured out page after page of wild words about sorrow, and even wilder words about pain. There was a luxurious pleasure in self-reproach. When we blame ourselves, we feel that no one else has the right to blame us. It is the confession, not the priest, that gives us absolution. When Dorian finished the letter, he felt that he had been forgiven.
tr_translation: The clock struck three, then four, the double chimes of the half-hours were heard, but Dorian Gray did not move. He was trying to weave the crimson threads of life together to create a pattern, to find a way out of this blood-colored labyrinth of passion in which he wandered. He had no idea what to do or what to think. Finally, he sat down at the table and wrote a passionate letter to the girl he loved, asking for forgiveness and accusing himself of madness. He filled many pages one after another with words of sorrow and even more frenzied words expressing his pain. Self-reproach is a satisfying luxury. When we blame ourselves, it feels as if no one else has the right to blame us. It is the confession itself that purifies a person from sin, not the confessor priest. When Dorian finished the letter, he felt he had been forgiven.
es_translation: The clock struck three in the afternoon, then four, and the half-hour chimed its double carillon, but Dorian Gray did not move. He tried to gather the scarlet threads of life and weave them following a pattern; to find a path, lost as he was in a labyrinth of unbridled passions. He did not know what to do, nor what to think. Finally, he returned to the table and wrote a fervent letter to the girl he had loved, imploring her forgiveness and accusing himself of madness. He filled sheet after sheet with tormented words of regret and even more pathetic ones of pain. There is a voluptuousness in self-reproach. When we blame ourselves, we feel that no one else has the right to do so. It is the confession, not the priest, that gives us absolution. When Dorian finished the letter, he felt that he had been forgiven.

en: Suddenly there came a knock to the door, and he heard Lord Henry’s voice outside. “My dear boy, I must see you. Let me in at once. I can’t bear your shutting yourself up like this.”
vi: Đột nhiên có tiếng gõ cửa, và cậu nghe giọng huân tước Henry bên ngoài. “Cậu bé thân mến của tôi, tôi phải gặp cậu. Cho tôi vào ngay nào. Tôi không thể chịu được việc cậu tự giam mình lại như thế này.”
tr: Birden kapı vuruldu, Dorian, dışardan Lord Henry’ nin sesini duydu: “Yavrucuğum, seni görmem gerek. Hemen aç şu kapıyı. Senin böyle kapanıp kalmana dayanamıyorum.
es: De repente, llamaron a la puerta, y oyó la voz de lord Henry en el exterior. —Dorian, amigo mío. He de verte. Déjame entrar ahora mismo. Es inaceptable que te encierres de esta manera.
vi_translation: Suddenly, there was a knock on the door, and he heard Lord Henry's voice outside. “My dear boy, I must see you. Let me in at once. I can't bear you shutting yourself up like this.”
tr_translation: Suddenly, there was a knock on the door, Dorian heard Lord Henry's voice from outside: "My dear, I need to see you. Open this door at once. I can't stand you shutting yourself in like this."
es_translation: Suddenly, there was a knock at the door, and he heard Lord Henry's voice outside. —Dorian, my friend. I must see you. Let me in right now. It is unacceptable for you to lock yourself up like this.

en: He made no answer at first, but remained quite still. The knocking still continued and grew louder. Yes, it was better to let Lord Henry in, and to explain to him the new life he was going to lead, to quarrel with him if it became necessary to quarrel, to part if parting was inevitable. He jumped up, drew the screen hastily across the picture, and unlocked the door.
vi: Thoạt đầu cậu không trả lời, nhưng vẫn bất động. Tiếng gõ cửa vẫn tiếp tục, và to dần lên. Phải, tốt hơn là cứ cho huân tước Henry vào, để giải thích cho anh ấy về cuộc đời mới mà cậu sắp sống, để cãi nhau với anh ấy nếu thành ra cần cãi nhau, để chia tay nếu việc chia tay là không thể tránh được. Cậu đứng phắt dậy, kéo vội tấm chắn ngang qua bức tranh, và mở khóa cửa.
tr: Dorian ilkin hiçbir karşılık vermeyerek kıpırdamadan durdu. Vuruşlar durmuyor, daha da şiddetleniyordu. Evet, Lord Henry’yi içeri almak daha iyiydi, süreceği yepyeni yaşantıyı anlatmak, kavga etmek gereği doğarsa kavga etmek, ayrılık kaçınılmaz olup çıkarsa ayrılmak. Dorian yerinden fırlayarak paravanı telaşla resmin önüne çekti, sonra kapının kilidini açtı.
es: Al principio no contestó, inmovilizado por completo. Pero los golpes en la puerta continuaron, haciéndose más insistentes. Sí, era mejor dejar entrar a lord Henry y explicarle la nueva vida que había decidido llevar, reñir con él si era necesario hacerlo, alejarse de él si la separación era inevitable. Poniéndose en pie de un salto, se apresuró a correr el biombo para que ocultara el cuadro, y luego procedió a abrir la puerta.
vi_translation: At first, he did not answer, but remained motionless. The knocking on the door continued, growing louder. Yes, it was better to let Lord Henry in, to explain to him about the new life he was about to live, to argue with him if an argument became necessary, to part ways if parting ways was unavoidable. He stood up abruptly, quickly drew the curtain across the painting, and unlocked the door.
tr_translation: Dorian stood motionless, giving no response. The blows did not stop; they grew even more intense. Yes, it was better to let Lord Henry in, to tell him about the brand new life he was going to lead, to argue if necessary, and to part ways if separation became inevitable. Dorian jumped up and hurriedly pulled the screen in front of the painting, then unlocked the door.
es_translation: At first, he did not respond, completely immobilized. But the knocks on the door continued, becoming more insistent. Yes, it was better to let Lord Henry in and explain the new life he had decided to lead, argue with him if necessary, distance himself from him if separation was inevitable. Jumping to his feet, he hurried to move the screen to hide the painting, and then proceeded to open the door.

en: “I am so sorry for it all, Dorian,” said Lord Henry as he entered. “But you must not think too much about it.”
vi: “Tôi rất lấy làm tiếc vì tất cả chuyện này,” huân tước Henry nói, lúc y bước vào. “Nhưng cậu không nên nghĩ ngợi quá nhiều về nó.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Çok üzgünüm bu olanlara, Dorian,” diyerek içeri girdi. “Ama çok takma kafana.
es: —Siento mucho todo lo que ha pasado, Dorian —dijo lord Henry al entrar—. Pero no debes pensar demasiado en ello.
vi_translation: "I am very sorry about all of this," Lord Henry said, as he walked in. "But you shouldn't think too much about it."
tr_translation: Lord Henry entered, saying, "I am very sorry about what happened, Dorian." "But don't worry too much about it."
es_translation: —I am very sorry for everything that has happened, Dorian —said Lord Henry as he entered—. But you must not think too much about it.

en: “Do you mean about Sibyl Vane?” asked the lad.
vi: “Anh định nói đến Sibyl Vane?” chàng trai hỏi.
tr: Çocuk, “Sibyl Vane konusunu mu demek istiyorsun?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Te refieres a Sibyl Vane? —preguntó el joven.
vi_translation: “Are you referring to Sibyl Vane?” the young man asked.
tr_translation: The child asked, "Do you mean the matter of Sibyl Vane?"
es_translation: —Are you referring to Sibyl Vane? —asked the young man.

en: “Yes, of course,” answered Lord Henry, sinking into a chair and slowly pulling off his yellow gloves. “It is dreadful, from one point of view, but it was not your fault. Tell me, did you go behind and see her, after the play was over?”
vi: “Vâng, dĩ nhiên,” huân tước Henry trả lời, hạ mình xuống ghế, chầm chậm tháo đôi găng tay vàng ra. “Thật kinh khủng, dưới quan điểm nào đó, nhưng đấy không phải lỗi của cậu. Hãy kể cho tôi, cậu có đi ra sau và gặp cô ấy không, sau khi vở kịch kết thúc ấy?” “Có.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Evet, elbette,” diyerek bir koltuğa çöktü, sarı eldivenlerini ağır ağır çıkarmaya girişti. “Feci bir şey bir bakıma ama suç sende değildi. Söyle bana, oyun bittikten sonra kulise gidip gördün mü onu? “Evet.
es: —Sí, por supuesto —respondió lord Henry, dejándose caer en una silla y quitándose lentamente los guantes amarillos—. Es horrible, desde cierto punto de vista, pero tú no tienes la culpa. Dime, ¿fuiste a verla después de que terminara la obra? —Sí.
vi_translation: “Yes, of course,” Lord Henry replied, lowering himself into a chair and slowly removing his yellow gloves. “It's terrible, in a way, but it's not your fault. Tell me, did you go backstage and see her after the play ended?”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "Yes, of course," he said, sinking into a chair and slowly starting to remove his yellow gloves. "It's a terrible thing in a way, but it wasn't your fault. Tell me, did you go backstage and see her after the play was over?"
es_translation: —Yes, of course —replied Lord Henry, dropping into a chair and slowly removing his yellow gloves—. It is horrible, from a certain point of view, but it is not your fault. Tell me, did you go to see her after the play was over?

en: “Yes.”
vi: “Có.”
tr: “Evet.
es: —Sí.
vi_translation: “Yes.”
tr_translation: “Yes.”
es_translation: —Yes.

en: “I felt sure you had. Did you make a scene with her?”
vi: “Tôi chắc rằng cậu có đi. Thế cậu có gây sự với cô ấy không?”
tr: “Böyle olduğunu tahmin etmiştim ben de. Kavga ettin mi onunla?
es: —Estaba convencido de que había sido así. ¿Le hiciste una escena?
vi_translation: “I'm sure you went. Did you have a quarrel with her?”
tr_translation: “I had guessed it would be like this too. Did you fight with him?”
es_translation: —I was convinced that it had been that way. Did you make a scene?

en: “I was brutal, Harry—perfectly brutal. But it is all right now. I am not sorry for anything that has happened. It has taught me to know myself better.”
vi: “Tôi cục súc thật, Harry — cực kỳ cục súc. Nhưng giờ thì ổn cả rồi. Tôi không hối tiếc với bất cứ chuyện gì đã xảy ra. Nó dạy cho tôi hiểu mình hơn.”
tr: “Hayvancasına, Harry, resmen hayvancasına. Ama her şey yoluna girdi artık. Olup bitenlerden ötürü çok pişmanım. Bana kendi kendimi çok daha iyi tanımasını öğretti.
es: —Fui brutal, Harry, terriblemente brutal. Pero ahora todo está resuelto. No siento lo que ha sucedido. Me ha enseñado a conocerme mejor.
vi_translation: "I was really rough, Harry — extremely rough. But now everything is fine. I don't regret anything that happened. It taught me to understand myself better."
tr_translation: “Like an animal, Harry, literally like an animal. But everything is fine now. I'm very sorry for what happened. It taught me to know myself much better.”
es_translation: —I was brutal, Harry, terribly brutal. But now everything is resolved. I don't regret what happened. It has taught me to know myself better.

en: “Ah, Dorian, I am so glad you take it in that way! I was afraid I would find you plunged in remorse and tearing that nice curly hair of yours.”
vi: “Ồ, Dorian, tôi rất vui vì cậu tiếp nhận chuyện này theo cách ấy! Tôi đã sợ là tôi sẽ thấy cậu chìm trong hối hận và bứt mái tóc quăn đẹp đẽ ấy của cậu.”
tr: “Dorian, işi bu yönden ele aldığına çok sevindim! Seni vicdan azabına gömülmüş, o canım kıvırcık saçlarını yolar bulacağımı sanmıştım.
es: —¡Ah, Dorian, cómo me alegro que te lo tomes de esa manera! Temía encontrarte hundido en el remordimiento y mesándote esos cabellos tuyos tan agradables.
vi_translation: "Oh, Dorian, I am so glad you are taking this in such a way! I was afraid I would see you drowning in regret and tearing out that beautiful curly hair of yours."
tr_translation: "Dorian, I'm so glad you're approaching the matter this way! I thought I would find you buried in guilt, tearing out those lovely curly locks of yours."
es_translation: —Ah, Dorian, how glad I am that you are taking it this way! I feared finding you sunk in remorse and tearing at that lovely hair of yours.

en: “I have got through all that,” said Dorian, shaking his head and smiling. “I am perfectly happy now. I know what conscience is, to begin with. It is not what you told me it was. It is the divinest thing in us. Don’t sneer at it, Harry, any more—at least not before me. I want to be good. I can’t bear the idea of my soul being hideous.”
vi: “Tôi đã vượt qua mọi chuyện ấy rồi,” Dorian nói, lắc đầu và cười. “Lúc này tôi vô cùng hạnh phúc. Trước hết, tôi đã biết lương tâm là gì. Nó không phải là cái anh đã kể cho tôi. Nó là thứ thiêng liêng nhất trong ta. Đừng chế nhạo nó, Harry, thêm nữa — chí ít là đừng có trước mặt tôi. Tôi muốn thành người tốt. Tôi không thể chịu được cái ý nghĩ là linh hồn tôi sẽ trở nên tởm lợm.”
tr: Dorian başını sarsarak, “Onların hepsini atlattım,” diye gülümsedi. “Şimdi tam anlamıyla mutluyum. İlk söz olarak şunu söyleyim ki vicdanın ne olduğunu biliyorum artık. Senin söylediğin şey değil. Benliğimizin en Tanrısal yanı. Dudak bükme artık Harry; benim yanımda yapma hiç değilse. Ben iyi bir insan olmak istiyorum. Ruhumun çirkinleşip korkunçlaşmasına dayanamam.
es: —He superado todo eso —dijo Dorian, moviendo la cabeza y sonriendo—. Ahora soy totalmente feliz. Sé lo que es la conciencia, para empezar. No es lo que me dijiste que era. Es lo más divino que hay en nosotros. No te burles, Harry, no vuelvas a hacerlo..., al menos, delante de mí. Quiero ser bueno. No soporto la idea de la fealdad de mi alma.
vi_translation: "I have overcome all that," Dorian said, shaking his head and smiling. "At this moment, I am extremely happy. First of all, I have learned what a conscience is. It is not what you told me it was. It is the most sacred thing within us. Do not mock it, Harry, any further — at least not in front of me. I want to be a good person. I cannot bear the thought that my soul will become loathsome."
tr_translation: Dorian shook his head, smiling, "I have overcome all of them." "Now I am truly happy. Let me say first that I now know what conscience is. It is not what you said. It is the most divine part of our being. Don't sneer, Harry; at least not in my presence. I want to be a good person. I cannot bear my soul becoming ugly and horrible."
es_translation: —I have overcome all that —said Dorian, shaking his head and smiling—. Now I am completely happy. I know what conscience is, to begin with. It is not what you told me it was. It is the most divine thing within us. Do not mock, Harry, do not do it again..., at least, not in front of me. I want to be good. I cannot bear the idea of the ugliness of my soul.

en: “A very charming artistic basis for ethics, Dorian! I congratulate you on it. But how are you going to begin?”
vi: “Một nền tảng nghệ thuật rất duyên dáng cho đạo đức, Dorian! Tôi chúc mừng cậu vì điều đó. Nhưng cậu sắp bắt đầu thế nào?”
tr: “Dorian, etik için ne hoş, ne sanatsal bir temel bu böyle! Kutlarım, bunu düşündüğün için. Peki, nasıl başlayacaksın buna?
es: —¡Una encantadora base artística para la ética, Dorian! Te felicito por ello. Pero, ¿cómo te propones empezar?
vi_translation: "A very graceful foundation of art for ethics, Dorian! I congratulate you on that." "But how are you going to start?"
tr_translation: “Dorian, what a delightful and artistic basis for ethics this is! Congratulations for thinking of it. So, how will you start this?”
es_translation: —A charming artistic basis for ethics, Dorian! I congratulate you on that. But how do you propose to start?

en: “By marrying Sibyl Vane.”
vi: “Bằng việc cưới Sibyl Vane.”
tr: “Sibyl Vane’le evlenerek.
es: —Casándome con Sibyl Vane.
vi_translation: “By marrying Sibyl Vane.” "Marry Sibyl Vane!"
tr_translation: “By marrying Sibyl Vane.”
es_translation: —Marrying Sibyl Vane. —Marrying Sibyl Vane!

en: “Marrying Sibyl Vane!” cried Lord Henry, standing up and looking at him in perplexed amazement. “But, my dear Dorian—”
vi: “Cưới Sibyl Vane!” huân tước Henry kêu lên, đứng dậy, nhìn cậu sửng sốt và bối rối. “Nhưng, Dorian thân mến của tôi…”
tr: “Sibyl Vane’le evlenmek mi?” diyerek Lord Henry yerinden fırladı ve duyduklarını anlamamış gibi hayretle çocuğa bakakaldı. “Evet, Harry, biliyorum senin ne diyeceğini.
es: —¡Casándote con Sibyl Vane! —exclamó lord Henry, poniéndose en pie y contemplándolo con infinito asombro—. Pero, mi querido Dorian...
vi_translation: Lord Henry exclaimed, standing up, looking at him in astonishment and confusion. "But, my dear Dorian..."
tr_translation: “Marrying Sibyl Vane?” said Lord Henry, jumping up from his seat and staring at the boy in astonishment as if he hadn't understood what he had just heard. “Yes, Harry, I know what you're going to say.
es_translation: —exclaimed Lord Henry, standing up and looking at him with infinite astonishment—. But, my dear Dorian...

en: “Yes, Harry, I know what you are going to say. Something dreadful about marriage. Don’t say it. Don’t ever say things of that kind to me again. Two days ago I asked Sibyl to marry me. I am not going to break my word to her. She is to be my wife.”
vi: “Vâng, Harry, tôi biết anh sắp nói gì. Một điều gì đó khủng khiếp về hôn nhân. Đừng nói. Đừng bao giờ nói những thứ kiểu đó với tôi nữa. Hai hôm trước tôi đã cầu hôn Sibyl. Tôi sẽ không bội ước với nàng. Nàng sẽ là vợ tôi!”
tr: “Evet, Harry, biliyorum senin ne diyeceğini. Evliliği yerin dibine batıran bir şey! Sakın söyleme. Bir daha sakın bu gibi şeyler söyleme bana. İki gün önce Sibyl Vane’ den benimle evlenmesini istemiştim. Sözümden dönmeyeceğim. O benim eşim olacak.
es: —Sí, Harry, sé lo que me vas a decir. Algo terrible sobre el matrimonio. No lo digas. No me vuelvas a decir cosas como ésas. Hace dos días le pedí a Sibyl que se casara conmigo. No voy a faltar a mi palabra. ¡Será mi esposa!
vi_translation: “Yes, Harry, I know what you're about to say. Something terrible about marriage. Don't say it. Never say things like that to me again. Two days ago I proposed to Sibyl. I will not break my promise to her. She will be my wife!”
tr_translation: “Yes, Harry, I know what you're going to say. Marriage is something that ruins everything! Don't say it. Never say such things to me again. Two days ago, I asked Sibyl Vane to marry me. I will not go back on my word. She will be my wife.”
es_translation: —Yes, Harry, I know what you're going to tell me. Something terrible about marriage. Don't say it. Don't tell me things like that again. Two days ago I asked Sibyl to marry me. I'm not going to break my word. She will be my wife!

en: “Your wife! Dorian! ... Didn’t you get my letter? I wrote to you this morning, and sent the note down by my own man.”
vi: “Vợ cậu! Dorian!... Cậu có nhận được thư tôi không? Tôi biên cho cậu sáng nay, và gửi giấy xuống, qua người của tôi.”
tr: “Eşin mi! Dorian!.. Mektubumu almadın mı? Bu sabah yazdım, hem de kendi adamımla yolladım.
es: —¿Tu esposa...? ¿No has recibido mi carta? Te he escrito esta mañana, y te envié la nota con mi criado.
vi_translation: "Your wife! Dorian!..." "Did you receive my letter?" "I wrote to you this morning and sent it down with my man."
tr_translation: “Is it you! Dorian!.. Didn't you get my letter? I wrote it this morning and sent it with my own man.”
