es_translation: —Your wife...? Haven't you received my letter? I wrote to you this morning, and I sent the note with my servant.

en: “Your letter? Oh, yes, I remember. I have not read it yet, Harry. I was afraid there might be something in it that I wouldn’t like. You cut life to pieces with your epigrams.”
vi: “Thư của anh? À, vâng, tôi nhớ rồi. Tôi còn chưa đọc nó, Harry. Tôi sợ là có thể có gì đó trong ấy mà tôi không thích. Anh cắt đời vụn ra bằng các châm ngôn trào phúng của anh.”
tr: “Mektubun mu? Ha evet! Daha okumamıştım Harry. Hoşuma gitmeyecek bir şey yazmışsındır, diye korktum. Sen şu özdeyişlerinle hayatı lokma lokma doğruyorsun da.
es: —¿Tu carta? Ah, sí, ya recuerdo. No la he leído aún, Harry. Temía que hubiera en ella algo que me disgustara. Cortas la vida en pedazos con tus epigramas.
vi_translation: “Your letter? Ah, yes, I remember now. I haven't read it yet, Harry. I'm afraid there might be something in it that I don't like. You dissect life with your satirical maxims.”
tr_translation: “Your letter? Oh yes! I hadn't read it yet, Harry. I was afraid you might have written something I wouldn't like. You always dissect life bit by bit with your aphorisms.”
es_translation: —Your letter? Ah, yes, now I remember. I haven't read it yet, Harry. I was afraid there might be something in it that would upset me. You cut life into pieces with your epigrams.

en: “You know nothing then?”
vi: “Vậy là cậu chưa biết gì hết?”
tr: “Hiçbir şey bilmiyor musun yani?
es: —Entonces, ¿no sabes nada?
vi_translation: "So you don't know anything yet?"
tr_translation: “So, you don't know anything at all?”
es_translation: —So, you don't know anything?

en: “What do you mean?”
vi: “Anh có ý gì?”
tr: “Ne demek istiyorsun?
es: —¿Qué quieres decir?
vi_translation: “What do you mean?”
tr_translation: "What do you mean?"
es_translation: —What do you mean?

en: Lord Henry walked across the room, and sitting down by Dorian Gray, took both his hands in his own and held them tightly. “Dorian,” he said, “my letter—don’t be frightened—was to tell you that Sibyl Vane is dead.”
vi: Huân tước Henry đi ngang phòng, và, ngồi xuống bên Dorian Gray, nắm hai bàn tay cậu trong bàn tay mình, giữ chặt chúng. “Dorian,” y nói, “lá thư của tôi — đừng hoảng sợ nhé — là để kể cho cậu rằng Sibyl Vane đã chết.”
tr: Lord Henry geldi, Dorian’ın yanı başına oturarak iki elini birden kendi elleri arasına aldı, sımsıkı tuttu. “Dorian,” dedi. “Mektubumda... sakın korkma... sana Sibyl Vane’in ölümünü bildirmiştim.
es: Lord Henry cruzó la habitación y, sentándose junto a Dorian Gray, le tomó las dos manos, apretándoselas mucho. —Dorian... —dijo—, mi carta..., no te asustes..., era para decirte que Sibyl Vane ha muerto.
vi_translation: Lord Henry walked across the room, and, sitting down beside Dorian Gray, took both of his hands in his own, holding them tightly. “Dorian,” he said, “my letter — don't be alarmed — is to tell you that Sibyl Vane is dead.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry came, sat down beside Dorian, and took both of his hands in his own, holding them tightly. “Dorian,” he said. “In my letter... don't be afraid... I informed you of Sibyl Vane’s death.”
es_translation: Lord Henry crossed the room and, sitting down next to Dorian Gray, took both his hands, squeezing them tightly. —Dorian... —he said—, my letter..., don't be frightened..., it was to tell you that Sibyl Vane has died.

en: A cry of pain broke from the lad’s lips, and he leaped to his feet, tearing his hands away from Lord Henry’s grasp. “Dead! Sibyl dead! It is not true! It is a horrible lie! How dare you say it?”
vi: Một tiếng kêu đau đớn vỡ ra trên môi chàng trai, cậu đứng phắt dậy, giật tay mình khỏi nắm tay của huân tước Henry. “Chết! Sibyl chết! Không đúng! Đó là một sự dối trá khủng khiếp! Sao anh dám nói thế?”
tr: Dorian, dudaklarından acı bir çığlık koparak ayağa fırladı, ellerini Lord Henry’nin avucundan çekip aldı. “Ölüm ha! Sibyl mi öldü? Doğru değil işte! Pis bir yalan bu! Ne yüzle söylüyorsun böyle bir şeyi?
es: Un grito de dolor escapó de los labios del muchacho, que se puso en pie bruscamente, liberando sus manos de la presión de lord Henry. —¡Muerta! ¡Sibyl muerta! ¡No es verdad! ¡Es una mentira espantosa! ¿Cómo te atreves a decir una cosa así?
vi_translation: A cry of pain broke from the young man's lips, he stood up abruptly, pulling his hand away from Lord Henry's grasp. “Dead! Sibyl dead! No, that's a terrible lie! How dare you say that?”
tr_translation: Dorian leapt to his feet with a bitter cry escaping his lips, pulling his hands away from Lord Henry's grasp. “Death! Sibyl is dead? That can't be true! It's a filthy lie! How dare you say such a thing?”
es_translation: A cry of pain escaped from the boy's lips, who stood up abruptly, freeing his hands from Lord Henry's grip. —Dead! Sibyl dead! It’s not true! It’s a dreadful lie! How dare you say such a thing?

en: “It is quite true, Dorian,” said Lord Henry, gravely. “It is in all the morning papers. I wrote down to you to ask you not to see any one till I came. There will have to be an inquest, of course, and you must not be mixed up in it. Things like that make a man fashionable in Paris. But in London people are so prejudiced. Here, one should never make one’s début with a scandal. One should reserve that to give an interest to one’s old age. I suppose they don’t know your name at the theatre? If they don’t, it is all right. Did any one see you going round to her room? That is an important point.”
vi: “Thật đấy, Dorian,” huân tước Henry nói, nghiêm trang. “Tin đăng trong mọi báo sáng. Tôi viết cho cậu để xin cậu đừng gặp bất cứ ai trước khi tôi đến. Sẽ phải có một cuộc điều tra, đương nhiên, và cậu không nên bị dính líu đến nó. Những chuyện thế này làm cho người ta trở nên sang trọng ở Paris. Nhưng ở London thì mọi người quá định kiến. Ở đây, ta không nên bước vào đời bằng một vụ bê bối. Ta nên để dành nó lại mà gây chú ý đến tuổi già của ta. Tôi cho là ở nhà hát họ không biết tên cậu? Nếu họ không biết thì không sao cả. Có ai đó thấy cậu đi vòng ra phòng cô ấy không? Đó là điểm hệ trọng.”
tr: Lord Henry ciddi bir tavırla, “Doğru, Dorian,” dedi “Sabah gazetelerinin hepsi yazıyor. Ben gelinceye kadar kimseyle görüşmeyesin diye yazdım sana. Bir soruşturma olacak tabii, ister istemez, ama sen bulaşmamalısın. Böyle şeyler Paris’te bir insanı aranılır kılar. Gelgelelim Londra ahalisi öyle darkafalıdır ki! Burada sosyeteye ilk adımını bir skandalla atmaya hiç gelmez. Skandalları saklayıp yaşlılığında ilgi çekici olmak için kullanacaksın. Tiyatrodakiler senin adını bilmiyorlar sanırım, değil mi? Bilmiyorlarsa sorun yok. Onun odasına gittiğini gören oldu mu? Bu nokta çok önemli.
es: —Es completamente cierto, Dorian —dijo lord Henry, con gran seriedad—. Lo encontrarás en todos los periódicos de la mañana. Te he escrito para pedirte que no recibieras a nadie hasta que yo llegara. Habrá una investigación, por supuesto, pero no debes verte mezclado en ella. En París, cosas como ésa ponen de moda a un hombre. Pero en Londres la gente tiene muchos prejuicios. Aquí es impensable debutar con un escándalo. Eso hay que reservarlo para dar interés a la vejez. Imagino que en el teatro no saben cómo te llamas. Si es así no hay ningún problema. ¿Te vio alguien dirigirte hacia su camerino? Eso es importante.
vi_translation: "Really, Dorian," Lord Henry said, solemnly. "The news is in every morning paper. I wrote to you to ask you not to meet anyone before I arrive. There will have to be an investigation, of course, and you shouldn't be involved in it. Such matters make one fashionable in Paris. But in London, people are too prejudiced. Here, one shouldn't enter life with a scandal. We should save it to draw attention to our old age. I suppose they don't know your name at the theater? If they don't, then it's all right. Did anyone see you going around to her room? That is the crucial point."
tr_translation: Lord Henry said with a serious tone, "That's right, Dorian," he said. "All the morning newspapers are writing about it. I wrote to you so that you wouldn't see anyone until I arrived. There will inevitably be an investigation, but you must not get involved. Such things make a person sought after in Paris. However, the people of London are so narrow-minded! It's not good to take your first step into society here with a scandal. You should save the scandals and use them to be interesting in your old age. I suppose the people at the theater don't know your name, do they? If they don't, there's no problem. Did anyone see you go to his room? This point is very important."
es_translation: —It is completely true, Dorian —said Lord Henry, with great seriousness—. You will find it in all the morning newspapers. I wrote to you to ask you not to receive anyone until I arrived. There will be an investigation, of course, but you must not get involved in it. In Paris, things like that make a man fashionable. But in London, people have many prejudices. Here it is unthinkable to debut with a scandal. That must be reserved to add interest to old age. I imagine that in the theater they don't know your name. If that is the case, there is no problem. Did anyone see you heading towards her dressing room? That is important.

en: Dorian did not answer for a few moments. He was dazed with horror. Finally he stammered, in a stifled voice, “Harry, did you say an inquest? What did you mean by that? Did Sibyl—? Oh, Harry, I can’t bear it! But be quick. Tell me everything at once.”
vi: Dorian không đáp lại mất một lúc. Cậu bàng hoàng vì khiếp sợ. Cuối cùng cậu lắp bắp bằng một giọng nói nghẹn ngào, “Harry, có phải anh nói một cuộc điều tra không? Anh có ý gì vậy? Có phải Sibyl…? Ôi, Harry, tôi không thể chịu đựng được! Nhưng nhanh lên. Kể hết cho tôi luôn đi.”
tr: Dorian bir süre karşılık vermedi. Dehşetten serseme dönmüştü. Sonunda boğuk sesle, “Harry,” diye kekeledi. “Soruşturma mı dedin? Ne demek istedin yani? Yoksa Sibyl?.. Of, Harry, dayanamam! Çabuk olsana. Her şeyi anlat bana, hemen.
es: Dorian tardó unos instantes en contestar. Estaba aturdido por el horror. —¿Has hablado de una investigación? —tartamudeó finalmente con voz ahogada—. ¿Qué quieres decir con eso? ¿Acaso Sibyl...? ¡Es superior a mis fuerzas, Harry! Pero habla pronto. Cuéntamelo todo inmediatamente.
vi_translation: Dorian did not respond for a moment. He was stunned with fear. Finally, he stammered in a choked voice, "Harry, did you say an investigation? What do you mean by that? Is it Sibyl...? Oh, Harry, I can't bear it! But hurry up. Tell me everything at once."
tr_translation: Dorian did not respond for a while. He was stunned with horror. Finally, in a hoarse voice, he stammered, “Harry,” “Did you say an inquiry? What do you mean by that? Or is it Sibyl?.. Oh, Harry, I can't stand it! Hurry up. Tell me everything, right now.”
es_translation: Dorian took a few moments to answer. He was stunned by the horror. —Have you spoken about an investigation? —he finally stammered with a choked voice—. What do you mean by that? Has Sibyl...? It's more than I can bear, Harry! But speak quickly. Tell me everything immediately.

en: “I have no doubt it was not an accident, Dorian, though it must be put in that way to the public. It seems that as she was leaving the theatre with her mother, about half-past twelve or so, she said she had forgotten something upstairs. They waited some time for her, but she did not come down again. They ultimately found her lying dead on the floor of her dressing-room. She had swallowed something by mistake, some dreadful thing they use at theatres. I don’t know what it was, but it had either prussic acid or white lead in it. I should fancy it was prussic acid, as she seems to have died instantaneously.”
vi: “Tôi chắc chắn nó không phải là tai nạn, Dorian, mặc dù nó phải được đưa ra công chúng theo cách ấy. Dường như lúc cô ấy đang rời khỏi nhà hát với mẹ, độ mười hai rưỡi, thì cô ấy nói cô ấy quên gì đó trên gác. Họ đợi cô ấy một lúc, nhưng cô ấy không xuống lại. Cuối cùng họ tìm thấy cô ấy nằm chết trên sàn phòng thay đồ của mình. Cô ấy đã nuốt nhầm phải thứ gì đó, một thứ khủng khiếp nào đó mà họ sử dụng ở các nhà hát. Tôi không biết nó là gì, nhưng nó có a-xít xyan-hy-đric hoặc chì trắng ở trong. Tôi cho rằng nó là a-xít xyan-hy-đric, vì cô ấy dường như chết ngay lập tức.”
tr: “Ölümün kaza olmadığından kuşkum yok, Dorian; ne var ki herkese tiyatrodan ayrılırken, yukarıda bir şey unuttuğunu söylemiş. Bir süre beklemişlerse de aşağı inmemiş. Neden sonra soyunma odasında, yerde bulmuşlar, cansız yatıyormuş. Yanlışlıkla bir şey yutmuş, tiyatroda kullanılan feci bir şey. Neymiş bilmiyorum ya, içinde ya asit prusik ya da üstübeç varmış ki kızcağız hemencecik ölmüş.
es: —Estoy convencido de que no ha sido un accidente, aunque hay que conseguir qué la opinión pública lo vea de esa manera. Parece que cuando salía del teatro con su madre, alrededor de las doce y media más o menos, dijo que había olvidado algo en el piso de arriba. Esperaron algún tiempo por ella, pero no regresó. Finalmente la encontraron muerta, tumbada en el suelo de su camerino. Había tragado algo por equivocación, alguna cosa terrible que usan en los teatros. No sé qué era, pero tenía ácido prúsico o carbonato de plomo. Imagino que era ácido prúsico, porque parece haber muerto instantáneamente.
vi_translation: “I am certain it was not an accident, Dorian, although it had to be presented to the public that way. It seems that while she was leaving the theater with her mother, around half past twelve, she said she had forgotten something upstairs. They waited for her for a while, but she did not come back down. Eventually, they found her lying dead on the floor of her dressing room. She had accidentally ingested something, some terrible substance that they use in theaters. I don't know what it was, but it had either hydrocyanic acid or white lead in it. I assume it was hydrocyanic acid, because she seemed to have died instantly.”
tr_translation: "I have no doubt that the death was not an accident, Dorian; however, she told everyone while leaving the theater that she had forgotten something upstairs. They waited for a while, but she didn't come down. Then they found her in the dressing room, lying on the floor, lifeless. She accidentally swallowed something, something terrible used in the theater. I don't know what it was, but it contained either prussic acid or white lead, which caused the poor girl to die immediately."
es_translation: —I am convinced that it was not an accident, although we need to make the public opinion see it that way. It seems that when she was leaving the theater with her mother, around half past twelve or so, she said she had forgotten something upstairs. They waited for her for some time, but she did not return. Finally, they found her dead, lying on the floor of her dressing room. She had swallowed something by mistake, some terrible thing they use in theaters. I don't know what it was, but it had prussic acid or lead carbonate. I imagine it was prussic acid, because she seems to have died instantly.

en: “Harry, Harry, it is terrible!” cried the lad.
vi: “Harry, Harry, thật kinh khủng!” chàng trai kêu lên.
tr: Delikanlı, “Harry, Harry, korkunç bu!” diye bağırdı.
es: —¡Qué cosa tan atroz, Harry! —exclamó el muchacho.
vi_translation: “Harry, Harry, it's terrible!” the young man exclaimed.
tr_translation: The young man shouted, "Harry, Harry, this is horrible!"
es_translation: —What an atrocious thing, Harry! —exclaimed the young man.

en: “Yes; it is very tragic, of course, but you must not get yourself mixed up in it. I see by The Standard that she was seventeen. I should have thought she was almost younger than that. She looked such a child, and seemed to know so little about acting. Dorian, you mustn’t let this thing get on your nerves. You must come and dine with me, and afterwards we will look in at the opera. It is a Patti night, and everybody will be there. You can come to my sister’s box. She has got some smart women with her.”
vi: “Đúng; chuyện này rất bi thảm, đương nhiên, nhưng cậu không được để mình bị dính líu đến nó. Tôi thấy trên tờ The Standard là cô ấy mười bảy tuổi. Tôi cứ tưởng cô ấy còn trẻ hơn thế. Cô ấy trông như đứa bé, và dường như biết rất ít về diễn xuất. Dorian, cậu không được để chuyện này vào đầu. Cậu phải đi ăn tối với tôi, sau đó ta sẽ ghé qua nhà hát ô-pê-ra. Đêm nay là của Patti, và mọi người sẽ ở đó. Cậu có thể đến lô của em gái tôi. Nó đi cùng vài cô ăn diện.”
tr: “Evet, evet, çok acıklı bir şey ya, sen bu işe bulaşmamalısın. Standart’ta okuduğuma göre yaşı on yediymiş. Bana sorsan daha bile küçük derdim. Öyle çocuksu duruyor, oyunculuk konusunda öylesine bilgisiz duruyordu ki! Dorian, sakın bu iş sinirlerini bozmasın senin. Gel, yemeği benimle ye, sonra da operaya bir bakarız. Patti’nin gecesi bu gece, herkes orada olacak demektir. Ablamın locasına gelebilirsin. Yanında çok modern hanımlar olacak.
es: —Sí, verdaderamente trágica, desde luego, pero tú no debes verte mezclado en ello. He visto en el Standard que tenía diecisiete años. Yo la hubiera creído aún más joven. ¡Tenía tal aspecto de niña y parecía una actriz con tan poca experiencia! Dorian, no debes permitir que este asunto te altere los nervios. Cenarás conmigo y luego nos pasaremos por la ópera. Esta noche canta la Patti y estará allí todo el mundo. Puedes venir al palco de mi hermana. Irá con unas amigas muy elegantes.
vi_translation: "Yes; this matter is very tragic, of course, but you must not let yourself get involved in it. I saw in The Standard that she was seventeen years old. I thought she was younger than that. She looked like a child, and seemed to know very little about acting. Dorian, you must not let this get into your head. You must have dinner with me, and then we will drop by the opera house. Tonight is Patti's night, and everyone will be there. You can come to my sister's box. She is going with a few well-dressed ladies."
tr_translation: "Yes, yes, it's a very tragic thing, you shouldn't get involved in this. According to what I read in the Standard, he was seventeen years old. If you asked me, I would have said he was even younger. He looked so childish, so ignorant about acting! Dorian, don't let this upset your nerves. Come, have dinner with me, and then we can check out the opera. It's Patti's night tonight, which means everyone will be there. You can come to my sister's box. There will be very modern ladies with you."
es_translation: —Yes, truly tragic, of course, but you must not get involved in it. I saw in the Standard that she was seventeen years old. I would have thought her even younger. She had such a childlike appearance and seemed like such an inexperienced actress! Dorian, you must not let this matter upset your nerves. You will dine with me and then we will go to the opera. Patti is singing tonight and everyone will be there. You can come to my sister's box. She will be there with some very elegant friends.

en: “So I have murdered Sibyl Vane,” said Dorian Gray, half to himself, “murdered her as surely as if I had cut her little throat with a knife. Yet the roses are not less lovely for all that. The birds sing just as happily in my garden. And to-night I am to dine with you, and then go on to the opera, and sup somewhere, I suppose, afterwards. How extraordinarily dramatic life is! If I had read all this in a book, Harry, I think I would have wept over it. Somehow, now that it has happened actually, and to me, it seems far too wonderful for tears. Here is the first passionate love-letter I have ever written in my life. Strange, that my first passionate love-letter should have been addressed to a dead girl. Can they feel, I wonder, those white silent people we call the dead? Sibyl! Can she feel, or know, or listen? Oh, Harry, how I loved her once! It seems years ago to me now. She was everything to me. Then came that dreadful night—was it really only last night?—when she played so badly, and my heart almost broke. She explained it all to me. It was terribly pathetic. But I was not moved a bit. I thought her shallow. Suddenly something happened that made me afraid. I can’t tell you what it was, but it was terrible. I said I would go back to her. I felt I had done wrong. And now she is dead. My God! My God! Harry, what shall I do? You don’t know the danger I am in, and there is nothing to keep me straight. She would have done that for me. She had no right to kill herself. It was selfish of her.”
vi: “Vậy là tôi đã sát hại Sibyl Vane,” Dorian Gray nói, phần nào với chính mình — “sát hại nàng một cách hiển nhiên như thể tôi đã cắt cái cổ họng nhỏ của nàng bằng dao. Tuy nhiên các đóa hồng không kém xinh vì mọi chuyện này. Lũ chim vẫn hót vui như thế trong vườn nhà tôi. Và đêm nay tôi đi ăn với anh, rồi vào nhà hát ô-pê-ra, và đi ăn đêm đâu đó, tôi nghĩ, sau đấy. Sao mà cuộc đời này lại kịch tính và phi thường đến thế! Nếu tôi đọc mọi chuyện này trong sách, Harry, tôi nghĩ tôi sẽ khóc vì nó. Chẳng biết tại sao mà bây giờ thì chuyện đó đã thật sự xảy ra, và với tôi, nó dường như quá đỗi kỳ lạ để mà rơi nước mắt. Đây là bức thư tình say đắm đầu tiên tôi từng viết trong đời mình. Cũng lạ là bức thư tình say đắm đầu tiên của tôi lại được gửi đến một cô gái đã chết. Họ có thể cảm nhận không nhỉ, tôi tự hỏi, những kẻ trắng bệch lặng yên mà ta gọi là người chết? Sibyl! Nàng có thể cảm nhận, hoặc hiểu, hoặc nghe? Ôi, Harry, sao mà tôi lại yêu nàng làm vậy, trước đây! Lúc này tôi thấy như đã lâu năm lắm rồi. Nàng từng là tất cả với tôi. Rồi đến cái đêm khủng khiếp đó — có phải nó thực ra chỉ mới là đêm qua? — khi nàng diễn quá tệ, và tim tôi gần như tan vỡ. Nàng đã giải thích hết với tôi. Thực sự thống thiết. Nhưng tôi chẳng mảy may động lòng. Tôi nghĩ nàng rỗng tuếch. Đột nhiên có gì đó xảy ra khiến tôi sợ. Tôi không thể kể cho anh nghe nó là gì, nhưng nó thật khủng khiếp. Tôi đã nói tôi sẽ quay lại với nàng. Tôi thấy tôi đã làm sai. Và giờ thì nàng đã chết. Chúa ơi! Chúa ơi! Harry, tôi sẽ phải làm gì? Anh không hiểu về cảnh nguy hiểm mà tôi đang lâm vào, và không có gì giữ được tôi ngay ngắn nữa. Nàng lẽ ra đã làm được điều ấy cho tôi. Nàng không có quyền tự sát. Đó là sự ích kỷ của nàng.”
tr: Dorian, biraz da kendi kendine, “Demek Sibyl Vane’i öldürdüm,” dedi. “O minicik boynunu bıçakla kesmişçesine öldürdüm onu. Oysa ben onu öldürdüm diye güllerin güzelliği azalmış değil. Kuşlar aynı mutlulukla bahçemde şakıyorlar. Ben de bu gece seninle yemek yiyip operaya gideceğim, sonra da bir yerlerde supé yeriz, herhalde. Şu yaşam denen şey nasıl da dramatik! Harry, bütün bunları bir kitapta okumuş olsaydım hiç kuşkusuz ağlardım. Oysa şimdi sahiden oldu ya, her şey öyle olağanüstü geliyor ki gözyaşlarım akamıyor. İşte bak, ömrümde ilk yazdığım ateşli aşk mektubu. İlk ateşli aşk mektubumun ölmüş bir kıza yazılmış olması ne tuhaf! Onların da hisleri var mıdır ki, ölü dediğimiz o sessiz, beyaz kişilerin? Ah, Sibyl! Hissedebilir mi, bilebilir mi, dinleyebilir mi? Ah, Harry, nasıl da sevmiştim onu bir zamanlar! Yıllar öncesindeymiş gibi geliyor şimdi. Her şeyimdi o benim. Derken o korkunç gece oldu... Dün gece miydi gerçekten... Sibyl çok kötü oynadı, benim de yüreğim neredeyse paramparça oldu. Sibyl her şeyi anlattı bana. Son derece dokunaklıydı ama benim yüreğimi kıpırdatmadı bile. Onu sığ buluyordum. Sonra birden beni ürküten bir şey oldu. Bunun ne olduğunu sana söyleyemem ama korkunçtu. Sibyl’e dönmeye karar verdim. Ona haksızlık ettiğimi düşünüyordum. Şimdi de o öldü. Ah, Tanrım, ulu Tanrım! Harry, ne yapacağım ben şimdi? Nasıl tehlikede olduğumu sen bilmiyorsun; doğru yoldan sapmamı önleyecek kimse de yok. O olsa yapardı bunu benim için. Kendini öldürmeye hiç hakkı yoktu. Çok bencillik etti doğrusu.
es: —De manera que he asesinado a Sibyl Vane —dijo Dorian Gray, hablando a medias consigo mismo—; como si le hubiera cortado el cuello con un cuchillo. Pero no por ello las rosas son menos hermosas. Ni los pájaros cantan con menos alegría en mi jardín. Y esta noche cenaré contigo, y luego iremos a la ópera y supongo que acabaremos la velada en algún otro sitio. ¡Qué extraordinariamente dramática es la vida! Si todo esto lo hubiera leído en un libro, Harry, creo que me habría hecho llorar. Sin embargo, ahora que ha sucedido de verdad, y que me ha sucedido a mí, parece demasiado prodigioso para derramar lágrimas. Aquí está la primera carta de amor apasionada que he escrito en mi vida. Es bien extraño que mi primera carta de amor esté dirigida a una muchacha muerta. ¿Tienen sentimientos, me pregunto, esos blancos seres silenciosos a los que llamamos los muertos? ¿Puede Sibyl sentir, entender o escuchar? ¡Ah, Harry, cómo la amaba hace muy poco! Pero ahora me parece que han pasado años. Lo era todo para mí. Luego llegó aquella noche horrible, ¿ayer?, en la que actuó tan espantosamente mal y en la que casi se me rompió el corazón. Me lo explicó todo. Era terriblemente patético. Pero no me conmovió en lo más mínimo. Me pareció una persona superficial. Aunque luego ha sucedido algo que me ha dado miedo. No puedo decirte qué, pero ha sido terrible. Y decidí volver con Sibyl. Comprendí que me había portado mal con ella. Y ahora está muerta. ¡Dios del cielo, Harry! ¿Qué voy a hacer? No sabes en qué peligro me encuentro, y no hay nada que pueda mantenerme en el camino recto. Sibyl lo hubiera conseguido. No tenía derecho a quitarse la vida. Se ha portado de una manera muy egoísta.
vi_translation: “So I have murdered Sibyl Vane,” Dorian Gray said, somewhat to himself — “murdered her as surely as if I had cut her little throat with a knife. Yet the roses are not less lovely for all that. The birds sing just as happily in my garden. And tonight I am dining with you, then going to the opera, and I suppose, afterwards, we will go somewhere for supper. How extraordinarily dramatic life is! If I had read all this in a book, Harry, I think I would have wept over it. Somehow, now that it has actually happened, and to me, it seems too strange for tears. This is the first passionate love letter I have ever written in my life. Strangely enough, my first passionate love letter was addressed to a dead girl. Can they feel, I wonder, those silent, white people we call the dead? Sibyl! Can she feel, or understand, or listen? Oh, Harry, how I loved her once! It seems years ago now. She was everything to me. Then came that dreadful night — was it really only last night? — when she played so badly, and my heart almost broke. She explained it all to me. It was really pathetic. But I was not moved a bit. I thought her shallow. Suddenly something happened that made me afraid. I cannot tell you what it was, but it was terrible. I said I would go back to her. I felt I had done wrong. And now she is dead. God! God! Harry, what am I to do? You don’t know the danger I am in, and there is nothing to keep me straight. She would have done that for me. She had no right to kill herself. It was selfish of her.”
tr_translation: Dorian, somewhat to himself, said, "So I killed Sibyl Vane.""I killed her as surely as if I had cut her little throat with a knife.""Yet the beauty of the roses has not lessened because I killed her.""The birds are singing in my garden just as happily.""And tonight, I will dine with you and go to the opera, and then we will probably have supper somewhere. ""How dramatic life is!""Harry, if I had read all this in a book, I would undoubtedly have cried."" But now that it has actually happened, everything seems so extraordinary that I cannot shed a tear." "Look, here is the first passionate love letter I have ever written. " "How strange that my first passionate love letter is written to a dead girl!""Do they have feelings, those silent, white beings we call the dead?""Oh, Sibyl! Can she feel, can she know, can she listen?""Oh, Harry, how I loved her once!" "It feels like it was years ago now.""She was everything to me.""Then that terrible night happened...""Was it really last night...""Sibyl acted very badly, and my heart was almost shattered. ""Sibyl told me everything." "It was extremely touching, but it did not move my heart at all.""I found her shallow.""Then suddenly something happened that frightened me.""I cannot tell you what it was, but it was terrible.""I decided to go back to Sibyl.""I thought I had wronged her.""And now she is dead.""Oh, God, great God! Harry, what am I going to do now?""You don't know how much danger I am in; there is no one to keep me on the right path.""She would have done that for me.""She had no right to kill herself.""She was very selfish indeed.""
es_translation: —So I have murdered Sibyl Vane —said Dorian Gray, speaking half to himself—; as if I had cut her throat with a knife. But the roses are no less beautiful for it. Nor do the birds sing with less joy in my garden. And tonight I will dine with you, and then we will go to the opera and I suppose we will end the evening somewhere else. How extraordinarily dramatic life is! If I had read all this in a book, Harry, I think it would have made me cry. However, now that it has really happened, and that it has happened to me, it seems too marvelous to shed tears over. Here is the first passionate love letter I have ever written in my life. It is very strange that my first love letter is addressed to a dead girl. Do those white silent beings we call the dead have feelings, I wonder? Can Sibyl feel, understand, or hear? Ah, Harry, how I loved her just a short while ago! But now it seems like years have passed. She was everything to me. Then came that horrible night, was it yesterday?, when she acted so dreadfully bad and my heart almost broke. She explained everything to me. It was terribly pathetic. But it did not move me in the least. She seemed a superficial person to me. Although something has happened since that has frightened me. I can't tell you what, but it has been terrible. And I decided to go back to Sibyl. I realized that I had treated her badly. And now she is dead. Good heavens, Harry! What am I going to do? You don't know what danger I am in, and there is nothing that can keep me on the right path. Sibyl would have managed it. She had no right to take her own life. She has behaved in a very selfish manner.

en: “My dear Dorian,” answered Lord Henry, taking a cigarette from his case and producing a gold-latten matchbox, “the only way a woman can ever reform a man is by boring him so completely that he loses all possible interest in life. If you had married this girl, you would have been wretched. Of course, you would have treated her kindly. One can always be kind to people about whom one cares nothing. But she would have soon found out that you were absolutely indifferent to her. And when a woman finds that out about her husband, she either becomes dreadfully dowdy, or wears very smart bonnets that some other woman’s husband has to pay for. I say nothing about the social mistake, which would have been abject—which, of course, I would not have allowed—but I assure you that in any case the whole thing would have been an absolute failure.”
vi: “Dorian thân mến của tôi,” huân tước Henry trả lời, lấy một điếu thuốc khỏi hộp, và giơ ra một hộp diêm vàng lá, “cách duy nhất mà đàn bà từng cải tạo được đàn ông là làm gã chán ngấy đến nỗi mất hết mọi sự quan tâm có thể có với cuộc sống. Nếu cậu lấy cô gái này thì cậu sẽ khổ. Dĩ nhiên cậu sẽ đối xử tử tế với cô ấy. Ta luôn tử tế với những người mà ta chẳng hề để ý đến. Nhưng cô ấy sẽ sớm phát hiện ra là cậu tuyệt đối dửng dưng với cô ấy. Và khi phụ nữ phát hiện ra điều đó ở chồng, cô ta sẽ trở nên vô cùng nhếch nhác, hoặc đội những cái mũ rất sang mà chồng cô khác phải trả. Tôi chưa nói đến cái sai lầm về mặt xã hội, mà có lẽ là nhục nhã, và, dĩ nhiên, tôi sẽ không để xảy ra, nhưng tôi đảm bảo với cậu rằng trong bất cứ trường hợp nào chăng nữa thì toàn bộ vụ này vẫn sẽ là một thất bại tuyệt đối.”
tr: Lord Henry tablasından bir sigara alıp, altın kaplama bir kibrit kutusu çıkartarak, “Sevgili Dorian,” dedi. “Bir kadının bir erkeği yola getirmesinin tek bir yolu vardır: Öyle canını sıkar ki, onu yaşamından tümüyle bezdirir. Bu kızla evlenseydin feci mutsuz olacaktın. Ona iyi bakacaktın, doğallıkla. Gene de o senin kendisine tümden ilgisiz olduğunu kısa zamanda algılayacaktı. Kadınlar da kocasının ilgisizliğini öğrenince ya iyice bakımsız, kılıksız olur çıkarlar ya da başka bir kadının kocasına aldırttığı pek şık şapkalarla dolaşmaya başlarlar. Bu evliliğin toplumsal yanlışına değinmiyorum. Böyle bir şeye ben izin vermezdim elbet, gene de, inan bana, bu iş hiçbir yönden yürümezdi.
es: —Mi querido Dorian —respondió lord Henry, sacando un cigarrillo de la pitillera y luego un estuche para cerillas con baño de oro—, la única manera de que una mujer reforme a un hombre es aburriéndolo tan completamente que pierda todo interés por la vida. Si te hubieras casado con esa chica, habrías sido muy desgraciado. Por supuesto la hubieras tratado amablemente. Siempre se puede ser amable con las personas que no nos importan nada. Pero habría descubierto enseguida que sólo sentías indiferencia por ella. Y cuando una mujer descubre eso de su marido, o empieza a vestirse muy mal o lleva sombreros muy elegantes que tiene que pagar el marido de otra mujer. Y no hablo del faux pas social, que habría sido lamentable, y que, por supuesto, yo no hubiera permitido, pero te aseguro que, de todos modos, el asunto habría sido un fracaso de principio a fin.
vi_translation: “My dear Dorian,” Lord Henry replied, taking a cigarette from the box and holding out a gold-leaf matchbox, “the only way women have ever reformed men is by boring them so completely that they lose all possible interest in life. If you marry this girl, you will be miserable. Of course, you will treat her kindly. We are always kind to those we care nothing about. But she will soon discover that you are absolutely indifferent to her. And when a woman finds that out about her husband, she either becomes terribly dowdy, or wears very chic hats that another woman's husband has to pay for. I am not even speaking of the social mistake, which would probably be disgraceful, and, of course, I would not allow it to happen, but I assure you that in any case, the whole affair will be an absolute failure.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry took a cigarette from the table, pulled out a gold-plated matchbox, and said, "My dear Dorian." "There is only one way for a woman to reform a man: She bores him so much that he becomes utterly disenchanted with life. If you had married this girl, you would have been terribly unhappy. You would have taken good care of her, naturally. Yet she would soon realize that you were completely indifferent to her. When women learn of their husband's indifference, they either become utterly neglected and unkempt or start parading around in very chic hats that another woman has made her husband notice. I'm not even mentioning the social mistake of such a marriage. I would never have allowed such a thing, of course, but believe me, this would not have worked out in any way."
es_translation: —My dear Dorian —replied Lord Henry, taking a cigarette from his cigarette case and then a gold-plated matchbox—, the only way for a woman to reform a man is by boring him so completely that he loses all interest in life. If you had married that girl, you would have been very unhappy. Of course, you would have treated her kindly. One can always be kind to people one doesn't care about at all. But she would have soon discovered that you only felt indifference towards her. And when a woman discovers that about her husband, she either starts dressing very poorly or wears very elegant hats that another woman's husband has to pay for. And I'm not talking about the social faux pas, which would have been regrettable, and which, of course, I would not have allowed, but I assure you that, in any case, the matter would have been a failure from start to finish.

en: “I suppose it would,” muttered the lad, walking up and down the room and looking horribly pale. “But I thought it was my duty. It is not my fault that this terrible tragedy has prevented my doing what was right. I remember your saying once that there is a fatality about good resolutions—that they are always made too late. Mine certainly were.”
vi: “Tôi cho là nó sẽ thế thật,” chàng trai lẩm bẩm, bước tới bước lui trong phòng, và có vẻ xanh xao kinh khủng. “Nhưng tôi nghĩ đó là bổn phận của tôi. Chẳng phải lỗi của tôi nếu bi kịch khủng khiếp này ngăn cản tôi làm những gì đúng đắn. Tôi nhớ anh đã từng nói rằng luôn có một định mệnh tồi tệ với những quyết định tử tế — rằng chúng luôn được đưa ra quá muộn. Của tôi chắc cũng vậy.”
tr: Çocuk, “Yürümezdi herhalde,” dedi. Odanın içinde bir aşağı bir yukarı dolaşıp duruyordu; benzi korkunç derecede soluktu. “Ama ben bunu görev sayıyordum. Bu feci trajedi benim doğru bulduğum şeyi yapmamı engellediyse suç bende değil. Hatırlıyorum da, bir gün sen, iyi niyetlerde bir uğursuzluk vardır, her zaman çok geç kalırlar, demiştin. Benim iyi niyetim sahiden de çok geç kaldı.
es: —Imagino que sí —murmuró el muchacho, paseando por la habitación, horriblemente pálido—. Pero pensaba que era mi deber. No es culpa mía que esta espantosa tragedia me impida actuar correctamente. Recuerdo que en una ocasión dijiste que existe una fatalidad ligada a las buenas resoluciones, y es que siempre se hacen demasiado tarde. Las mías desde luego.
vi_translation: “I suppose it really will be like that,” the young man muttered, pacing back and forth in the room, and looking terribly pale. “But I think it is my duty. It's not my fault if this terrible tragedy prevents me from doing what is right. I remember you once said that there is always a bad fate with kind decisions — that they are always made too late. Mine must be the same.”
tr_translation: The child said, "It probably wouldn't have worked." He was pacing up and down the room; his face was terribly pale. "But I considered this my duty. If this terrible tragedy prevented me from doing what I believed was right, it's not my fault. I remember you once said that there is a curse in good intentions, they always come too late. My good intention indeed came too late."
es_translation: —I suppose so —murmured the boy, pacing around the room, horribly pale—. But I thought it was my duty. It is not my fault that this dreadful tragedy prevents me from acting correctly. I remember you once said that there is a fatality tied to good resolutions, and that is they always come too late. Mine certainly do.

en: “Good resolutions are useless attempts to interfere with scientific laws. Their origin is pure vanity. Their result is absolutely nil. They give us, now and then, some of those luxurious sterile emotions that have a certain charm for the weak. That is all that can be said for them. They are simply cheques that men draw on a bank where they have no account.”
vi: “Các quyết định tử tế là những cố gắng vô ích nhằm cản trở các định luật khoa học. Căn nguyên của chúng là sự kiêu căng thuần túy. Kết quả của chúng là số không tuyệt đối. Chúng cho ta, lúc này lúc khác, vài thứ cảm xúc cằn cỗi xa xỉ vẫn có sức hấp dẫn nhất định với những kẻ yếu đuối. Đó là tất cả những gì có thể nói về chúng. Chúng chỉ là những tấm séc mà người ta rút ở một ngân hàng nơi họ không có tài khoản.
tr: “İyi niyetler bilimsel kuralların işine karışmak için yapılan boşuna girişimlerdir. Çıkış noktaları da katıksız kibirdir, sonuçları kocaman bir sıfır. Zaman zaman bize kısır gene de zevkli birtakım duyguların lüksünü yaşatırlar ki zayıf kişilere bu epey çekici gelir. İyi niyet konusunda söylenebilecek tek olumlu şey budur. İnsanların para yatırmadıkları bir bankanın hesabına yazdıkları bir çekten başka bir şey değildir, iyi niyet.
es: —Las buenas resoluciones son intentos inútiles de modificar leyes científicas. No tienen otro origen que la vanidad. Y el resultado es absolutamente nulo. De cuando en cuando nos proporcionan algunas de esas suntuosas emociones estériles que tienen cierto encanto para los débiles. Eso es lo mejor que se puede decir de ellas. Son cheques que hay que cobrar en una cuenta sin fondos.
vi_translation: “Kind decisions are futile attempts to obstruct the laws of science. Their root cause is pure arrogance. Their result is absolute zero. They give us, from time to time, a few barren luxurious emotions that still hold a certain appeal to the weak. That is all that can be said about them. They are merely checks drawn on a bank where one has no account.”
tr_translation: “Good intentions are futile attempts to interfere with scientific rules. Their starting point is pure arrogance, and their results amount to a big zero. From time to time, they allow us to experience the luxury of some barren yet pleasurable emotions, which can be quite appealing to weak individuals. This is the only positive thing that can be said about good intentions. Good intentions are nothing more than a check written on an account at a bank where people have not deposited any money.”
es_translation: —Good resolutions are futile attempts to modify scientific laws. They have no other origin than vanity. And the result is absolutely null. From time to time they provide us with some of those sumptuous sterile emotions that have a certain charm for the weak. That is the best that can be said of them. They are checks that must be cashed from an account with no funds.

en: “Harry,” cried Dorian Gray, coming over and sitting down beside him, “why is it that I cannot feel this tragedy as much as I want to? I don’t think I am heartless. Do you?”
vi: “Harry,” Dorian Gray la lên, lại gần và ngồi xuống bên y, “sao tôi lại không thể cảm nhận bi kịch này nhiều như tôi muốn? Tôi không nghĩ mình vô tâm. Anh thấy sao?”
tr: Dorian Gray, “Harry,” diyerek geldi, arkadaşının yanına oturdu. “Neden bu trajediyi istediğim oranda derinden hissedemiyorum ben? Oysa taşyürekli olduğumu da sanmıyorum. Öyle miyim sence?
es: —Harry —exclamó Dorian Gray, acercándose y sentándose a su lado—, ¿por qué no siento esta tragedia con la intensidad que quisiera? No creo que me falte corazón. ¿Qué opinas tú?
vi_translation: "Harry," Dorian Gray exclaimed, approaching and sitting down beside him, "why can't I feel this tragedy as much as I want to? I don't think I'm heartless. What do you think?"
tr_translation: Dorian Gray said, "Harry," as he sat down next to his friend. "Why can't I feel this tragedy as deeply as I want? Yet, I don't think I am stone-hearted. Do you think I am?"
es_translation: —Harry —exclaimed Dorian Gray, approaching and sitting next to him—, why don't I feel this tragedy with the intensity I would like? I don't think I lack heart. What do you think?

en: “You have done too many foolish things during the last fortnight to be entitled to give yourself that name, Dorian,” answered Lord Henry with his sweet melancholy smile.
vi: “Cậu đã làm quá nhiều chuyện ngu ngốc suốt hai tuần qua để được quyền cho mình cái tên ấy, Dorian,” huân tước Henry trả lời, với nụ cười ngọt ngào, sầu não của y.
tr: Lord Henry, “Şu son on on beş gündür öylesine budalaca işler yaptın ki kendine bu sıfatı yakıştırmaya hakkın olduğunu sanmıyorum, Dorian,” diye o tatlı, hüzünlü gülümseyişiyle yanıtladı.
es: —Has hecho demasiadas tonterías durante los últimos quince días para que se te pueda acusar de eso, Dorian —respondió lord Henry, con su dulce sonrisa melancólica.
vi_translation: "You have done too many foolish things over the past two weeks to have the right to call yourself that, Dorian," Lord Henry replied, with his sweet, melancholic smile.
tr_translation: Lord Henry replied with that sweet, melancholy smile, "Dorian, you have done such foolish things in the last ten or fifteen days that I don't think you have the right to attribute this title to yourself."
es_translation: —You have done too many foolish things over the last fortnight to be accused of that, Dorian —replied Lord Henry, with his sweet, melancholic smile.

en: The lad frowned. “I don’t like that explanation, Harry,” he rejoined, “but I am glad you don’t think I am heartless. I am nothing of the kind. I know I am not. And yet I must admit that this thing that has happened does not affect me as it should. It seems to me to be simply like a wonderful ending to a wonderful play. It has all the terrible beauty of a Greek tragedy, a tragedy in which I took a great part, but by which I have not been wounded.”
vi: Chàng trai cau mày. “Tôi không thích lời giải thích ấy, Harry,” cậu đáp lại, “nhưng tôi vui vì anh không nghĩ tôi vô tâm. Tôi không thuộc dạng này. Tôi biết mình không thế. Tuy nhiên tôi phải thừa nhận rằng cái chuyện đã xảy ra này chẳng tác động đến tôi như nó lẽ ra phải tác động. Tôi thấy nó dường như chỉ giống với một cái kết tuyệt vời cho một vở kịch tuyệt vời. Nó có mọi vẻ đẹp khủng khiếp của một bi kịch Hy Lạp, một bi kịch mà tôi đảm nhận một vai vĩ đại trong nó, song tôi lại không bị tổn thương vì nó.”
tr: Dorian yüzünü astı. “Bu açıklama hoşuma gitmedi, Harry. Gene de beni kalpsiz bulmadığına sevindim. Hiç de kalpsiz değilim ki ben. Biliyorum bunu. Gene de itiraf etmeliyim ki bu olay etkilemesi gerektiği gibi etkilemiyor beni. Kısaca, harika bir sahne, oyunun harika bitişi gibi geliyor. Bir antik Yunan trajedisinin ürkütücü güzelliğine sahip. Bu trajedide büyük bir rol oynamışım ben sanki, ne var ki yara almamışım.
es: El muchacho frunció el ceño. —No me gusta esa explicación, Harry —replicó—, pero me alegra que no me juzgues sin corazón. No es verdad. Sé que lo tengo. Y sin embargo he de reconocer que lo que ha sucedido no me afecta como debiera. Me parece sencillamente un final estupendo para una obra maravillosa. Tiene la belleza terrible de una tragedia griega, una tragedia en la que he tenido un papel muy destacado, pero que no me ha dejado heridas.
vi_translation: The young man frowned. “I don't like that explanation, Harry,” he replied, “but I'm glad you don't think I'm heartless. I'm not that kind of person. I know I'm not. However, I must admit that what happened didn't affect me as it should have. It seemed to me like just a wonderful ending to a wonderful play. It had all the terrible beauty of a Greek tragedy, a tragedy in which I played a great role, yet I wasn't hurt by it.”
tr_translation: Dorian frowned. “I don't like this explanation, Harry. Still, I'm glad you don't find me heartless. I'm not heartless at all. I know that. Yet I must admit that this event doesn't affect me as it should. In short, it feels like a wonderful scene, like the perfect ending of a play. It has the eerie beauty of an ancient Greek tragedy. It's as if I played a major role in this tragedy, but came out unscathed.”
es_translation: The boy frowned. —I don't like that explanation, Harry —he replied—, but I'm glad you don't judge me as heartless. It's not true. I know I have one. And yet I must admit that what has happened does not affect me as it should. It simply seems to me a wonderful ending to a marvelous play. It has the terrible beauty of a Greek tragedy, a tragedy in which I played a very prominent role, but which has left me unscathed.

en: “It is an interesting question,” said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the lad’s unconscious egotism, “an extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves, and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.”
vi: “Đó là một câu hỏi thú vị,” huân tước Henry nói, y thấy một niềm vui tao nhã trong việc chơi đùa với tính vị kỷ vô thức của chàng trai — “một câu hỏi cực kỳ thú vị. Tôi nghĩ rằng lời giải thích chính xác là thế này. Một điều thường xảy ra là các bi kịch thật sự trong đời lại xuất hiện theo một lối phản nghệ thuật đến nỗi chúng làm tổn thương ta bằng sự hung hãn thô bạo, sự rời rạc tuyệt đối, sự vô nghĩa phi lý, sự thiếu vắng phong cách. Chúng ảnh hưởng đến ta hệt như sự thô tục ảnh hưởng đến ta. Chúng cho ta một ấn tượng về sức mạnh hung ác tuyệt đối, và ta cưỡng lại chúng. Tuy nhiên, đôi lúc, một bi kịch có các yếu tố nghệ thuật đẹp đẽ cắt ngang đời ta. Nếu những yếu tố đẹp đẽ này là thật, thì toàn bộ sự việc rất dễ hấp dẫn khả năng cảm nhận của ta về hiệu ứng kịch. Đột nhiên ta thấy rằng ta không còn là diễn viên nữa, mà là các khán giả của vở kịch. Hoặc đúng hơn thì ta là cả hai. Ta xem chính mình, và chính nỗi ngạc nhiên với sự trình diễn này đã mê hoặc ta. Trong cảnh ngộ hiện thời, chuyện gì đã thực sự xảy ra? Có người tự sát vì yêu cậu. Ước gì tôi có lúc được hưởng một trải nghiệm như vậy. Nó sẽ khiến tôi đem lòng yêu tình yêu suốt quãng đời còn lại của mình. Những người từng mê tôi — không nhiều lắm, nhưng cũng có một số — luôn nhất định sống tiếp, rất lâu sau khi tôi đã thôi quan tâm đến họ, hoặc họ quan tâm đến tôi. Họ đẫy ra, nhạt đi, và khi tôi gặp lại họ thì họ lập tức trôi vào kỷ niệm. Cái ký ức kinh dị ấy về đàn bà! Nó là một thứ đáng sợ biết bao! Và nó để lộ ra một tình trạng mụ mẫm trí tuệ triệt để làm sao! Ta nên hấp thu sắc màu cuộc sống, nhưng đừng bao giờ nhớ các chi tiết của nó. Các chi tiết luôn thô tục.”
tr: Delikanlının bilinçsiz bencilliğini kışkırtmaktan büyük ve gizli bir tat alan Lord Henry, “İlginç bir sorun bu, son derece ilginç,” dedi. “Bana öyle geliyor ki gerçek açıklaması şöyle: Çoğu zaman hayatın gerçek trajedileri sanat ölçülerinden öyle uzaktırlar ki içerdikleri kaba şiddetle, tutarsızlıklarıyla, anlamdan yoksun oluşlarının gülünçlüğüyle, zariflikten, kıvraklıktan yoksun oluşlarıyla bizi incitirler. Tıpkı kalabalığın etkisi gibidir üzerimizdeki etkileri. Katıksız bir kaba kuvvet izlenimi bırakırlar üzerimizde, biz de buna başkaldırırız. Öte yandan, arada bir, sanatsal güzellik öğeleri taşıyan bir trajedi hayatımıza girer. Bu güzellik öğeleri sahiciyse olay bizi doğrudan, dramatik yapısı yönünden etkiler. Birden bakarız ki artık oyuncu olmaktan çıkmış, oyunun seyircisi olmuşuz. Daha doğrusu hem oyuncuyuzdur hem seyirci. Kendi kendimizi seyrederiz de gösterideki olağanüstülüğe kapılır gideriz. Bu olayda olan da nedir gerçekte? Bir kız senin aşkın uğruna kendini öldürmüş. Keşke ben de yaşamış olsaydım böyle bir şeyi. Ömür boyu aşka âşık ederdi beni. Bana tapan kişiler... sayıları pek çok olmasa da... benim onlara ya da onların bana... duyduğumuz ilgi söndükten çok sonralara kadar hayatta kalmakta direttiler hep. Şişmanlayıp bezdirici kişiler oldular. Karşılaştığımız zaman da hemen eski anıları canlandırmaya girişiyorlar. Ah, kadının o müthiş belleği! Ne korkunç şeydir o! Nasıl katıksız bir zihin yosunlaşmasını ortaya vurur! İnsan yaşamın rengini emmeli de ayrıntılarını asla hatırlamamalı. Ayrıntılar her zaman avam işidir.
es: —Es un caso interesante —dijo lord Henry, que encontraba un placer sutil enjugar con el egoísmo inconsciente de su joven amigo—; un caso sumamente interesante. Creo que la verdadera explicación es ésta: sucede con frecuencia que las tragedias reales de la vida ocurren de una manera tan poco artística que nos hieren por lo crudo de su violencia, por su absoluta incoherencia, su absurda ausencia de significado, su completa falta de estilo. Nos afectan como lo hace la vulgaridad. Sólo nos producen una impresión de fuerza bruta, y nos rebelamos contra eso. A veces, sin embargo, cruza nuestras vidas una tragedia que posee elementos de belleza artística. Si esos elementos de belleza son reales, todo el conjunto apela a nuestro sentido del efecto dramático. De repente descubrimos que ya no somos los actores, sino los espectadores de la obra. O que somos más bien las dos cosas. Nos observamos, y el mero asombro del espectáculo nos seduce. En el caso presente, ¿qué es lo que ha sucedido en realidad? Alguien se ha matado por amor tuyo. Me gustaría haber tenido alguna vez una experiencia semejante. Me hubiera hecho enamorarme del amor para el resto de mi vida. Las personas que me han adorado (no han sido muchas, pero sí algunas), siempre han insistido en seguir viviendo después de que yo dejase de quererlas y ellas dejaran de quererme a mí. Se han vuelto corpulentas y tediosas, y cuando me encuentro con ellas se lanzan inmediatamente a los recuerdos. ¡Ah, esa terrible memoria de las mujeres! ¡Qué cosa más espantosa! ¡Y qué total estancamiento intelectual revela! Se deben absorberlos colores de la vida, pero nunca recordar los detalles. Los detalles siempre son vulgares.
vi_translation: “That is an interesting question,” Lord Henry said, finding a refined pleasure in playing with the unconscious selfishness of the young man — “a very interesting question. I think the correct explanation is this. It often happens that the real tragedies in life occur in such an anti-artistic manner that they hurt us with their brutal aggression, absolute disjointedness, absurd senselessness, and lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of absolute malicious power, and we resist them. However, sometimes, a tragedy with beautiful artistic elements intersects our lives. If these beautiful elements are real, then the whole affair easily captivates our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer actors, but the audience of the play. Or rather, we are both. We watch ourselves, and it is the very surprise of this performance that fascinates us. In the current situation, what has actually happened? Someone has committed suicide because they loved you. I wish I could have such an experience sometime. It would make me love love for the rest of my life. The people who have been infatuated with me — not many, but there have been some — always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they for me. They fade away, become dull, and when I meet them again, they immediately drift into memory. That dreadful memory of women! How terrifying it is! And how it reveals a state of complete intellectual dullness! We should absorb the colors of life, but never remember its details. The details are always vulgar.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, who took great and secret pleasure in provoking the young man's unconscious selfishness, said, "This is an interesting problem, extremely interesting." " It seems to me that the real explanation is this: Often, the real tragedies of life are so far removed from the standards of art that they hurt us with their crude violence, their inconsistencies, the absurdity of their lack of meaning, their lack of elegance and grace. They affect us much like a crowd does. They leave us with an impression of pure brute force, and we rebel against it. On the other hand, occasionally, a tragedy with elements of artistic beauty enters our lives. If these elements of beauty are genuine, the event affects us directly, in terms of its dramatic structure. Suddenly, we find that we are no longer actors, but spectators of the play. Or rather, we are both actors and spectators. We watch ourselves and get carried away by the extraordinariness of the spectacle. So what has really happened in this event? A girl has killed herself for your love. I wish I had experienced something like that. It would have made me fall in love with love for a lifetime. The people who adored me...though they were not many in number...always insisted on surviving long after the interest I had in them or they had in me had faded. They became fat and tiresome people. Whenever we met, they immediately started to revive old memories. Ah, the terrible memory of a woman! What a dreadful thing it is! How it reveals the pure mossiness of the mind! One should absorb the color of life but never remember its details. Details are always the business of the vulgar."
es_translation: —It is an interesting case —said Lord Henry, who found a subtle pleasure in playing with the unconscious selfishness of his young friend—; a most interesting case. I believe the true explanation is this: it often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an unartistic manner that they wound us by the rawness of their violence, by their absolute incoherence, their absurd lack of meaning, their complete lack of style. They affect us as vulgarity does. They only leave us with an impression of brute force, and we rebel against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy crosses our lives that possesses elements of artistic beauty. If those elements of beauty are real, the entire ensemble appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we discover that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather that we are both things. We observe ourselves, and the mere wonder of the spectacle seduces us. In the present case, what has really happened? Someone has killed themselves for love of you. I would have liked to have had such an experience once. It would have made me fall in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me (there have not been many, but a few), have always insisted on continuing to live after I stopped loving them and they stopped loving me. They have become corpulent and tedious, and when I meet them, they immediately dive into memories. Ah, that terrible memory of women! What a dreadful thing! And what total intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colors of life, but never remember the details. The details are always vulgar.

en: “I must sow poppies in my garden,” sighed Dorian.
vi: “Tôi phải gieo thuốc phiện trong vườn nhà mình,” Dorian thở dài.
tr: Dorian, “Bahçeme haşhaş ekmeliyim,” diyerek içini çekti.
es: —He de sembrar amapolas en el jardín —suspiró Dorian.
vi_translation: “I have to plant opium in my own garden,” Dorian sighed.
tr_translation: Dorian sighed, "I should plant poppies in my garden."
es_translation: —I must plant poppies in the garden —sighed Dorian.

en: “There is no necessity,” rejoined his companion. “Life has always poppies in her hands. Of course, now and then things linger. I once wore nothing but violets all through one season, as a form of artistic mourning for a romance that would not die. Ultimately, however, it did die. I forget what killed it. I think it was her proposing to sacrifice the whole world for me. That is always a dreadful moment. It fills one with the terror of eternity. Well—would you believe it?—a week ago, at Lady Hampshire’s, I found myself seated at dinner next the lady in question, and she insisted on going over the whole thing again, and digging up the past, and raking up the future. I had buried my romance in a bed of asphodel. She dragged it out again and assured me that I had spoiled her life. I am bound to state that she ate an enormous dinner, so I did not feel any anxiety. But what a lack of taste she showed! The one charm of the past is that it is the past. But women never know when the curtain has fallen. They always want a sixth act, and as soon as the interest of the play is entirely over, they propose to continue it. If they were allowed their own way, every comedy would have a tragic ending, and every tragedy would culminate in a farce. They are charmingly artificial, but they have no sense of art. You are more fortunate than I am. I assure you, Dorian, that not one of the women I have known would have done for me what Sibyl Vane did for you. Ordinary women always console themselves. Some of them do it by going in for sentimental colours. Never trust a woman who wears mauve, whatever her age may be, or a woman over thirty-five who is fond of pink ribbons. It always means that they have a history. Others find a great consolation in suddenly discovering the good qualities of their husbands. They flaunt their conjugal felicity in one’s face, as if it were the most fascinating of sins. Religion consoles some. Its mysteries have all the charm of a flirtation, a woman once told me, and I can quite understand it. Besides, nothing makes one so vain as being told that one is a sinner. Conscience makes egotists of us all. Yes; there is really no end to the consolations that women find in modern life. Indeed, I have not mentioned the most important one.”
vi: “Không cần đâu,” bạn cậu đáp lại. “Cuộc sống luôn có thuốc phiện trong tay. Dĩ nhiên, thỉnh thoảng nhiều cái cũng kéo dài. Tôi có hồi không mặc gì ngoài màu tím suốt một mùa, như một hình thức để tang có tính chất nghệ thuật cho một chuyện tình không muốn chết. Tuy vậy, cuối cùng, nó vẫn chết. Tôi quên mất cái gì đã giết nó. Tôi nghĩ là lời đề nghị của cô ta về việc hy sinh cả thế giới cho tôi. Đó luôn là khoảnh khắc kinh khủng. Nó khiến ta sợ chết khiếp trước sự vĩnh viễn. À đấy — cậu tin không? — tuần trước, ở chỗ bà Hampshire, tôi thấy mình ngồi ăn tối cạnh quý cô đang được nói đến, và cô ta khăng khăng đòi quay lại từ đầu, đào bới dĩ vãng, vun đắp tương lai. Tôi đã chôn tình mình dưới luống lan nhật quang. Cô ta lôi nó lên lại, và quả quyết với tôi là tôi đã làm hỏng đời cô ta. Tôi buộc phải nói rõ là cô ta đã ăn một bữa quá khủng, vậy nên tôi không thấy lo lắng gì. Nhưng cô ta đã thể hiện một sự thiếu tế nhị làm sao. Một nét duyên của dĩ vãng là ở chỗ nó là dĩ vãng. Nhưng đàn bà chẳng bao giờ nhận ra màn hạ lúc nào. Họ luôn muốn hồi sáu, và ngay khi sự quan tâm đến vở kịch đã hết hẳn thì họ lại đề nghị tiếp tục nó. Nếu họ được cho phép làm theo kiểu của họ, mỗi hài kịch chắc sẽ có một cái kết bi thảm, còn mỗi bi kịch chắc sẽ lên đỉnh bằng một trò hề. Họ giả tạo một cách duyên dáng, nhưng họ không có khả năng thưởng thức nghệ thuật. Cậu tốt số hơn tôi nhiều. Tôi cam đoan với cậu, Dorian, là không một cô nào tôi từng biết lại có thể làm cho tôi cái việc mà Sibyl Vane đã làm cho cậu. Các cô gái bình thường luôn tự an ủi mình. Vài người trong số họ làm thế bằng cách chuộng các sắc màu đa cảm. Đừng bao giờ tin cô nào mặc màu tím hoa cà, dù tuổi cô ta có là bao nhiêu, hoặc cô nào ngoài ba lăm mà vẫn thích ruy-băng hồng. Nó luôn có nghĩa là họ đang có chuyện. Những cô khác thì tìm thấy sự an ủi vĩ đại trong việc bỗng dưng phát hiện ra các phẩm chất tốt đẹp ở chồng mình. Họ khoe khoang hạnh phúc vợ chồng vào mặt ta, như thể nó là tội lỗi quyến rũ nhất. Tôn giáo cũng an ủi được vài cô. Sự thần bí của nó có mọi nét quyến rũ của một cuộc tình lăng nhăng, một cô nọ có lần bảo tôi thế; và tôi có thể hiểu rõ điều ấy. Ngoài ra, chẳng có gì khiến ta tự đắc như được bảo rằng ta là một kẻ tội đồ. Lương tâm biến tất cả chúng ta thành bọn vị kỷ. Vâng; thực ra có vô cùng nhiều sự an ủi mà đàn bà đã tìm ra trong cuộc sống hiện đại. Quả thực là tôi còn chưa nhắc đến cái quan trọng nhất.”
tr: Arkadaşı, “Gereği yok,” diye karşılık verdi. “Hayatın elinde her zaman haşhaş demetleri vardır. Arada bir kimi şeyler uzayıp gitmez değil. Bir keresinde bir mevsim boyunca yakamda hep menekşe taşımıştım: bir türlü ölemeyen bir aşk için bir tür sanatsal yas tutma yöntemi olarak. Ne var ki sonunda aşk öldü. Ne yüzünden öldüğünü hatırlamıyorum. Kızın, bütün dünyayı benim yüzümden feda etmeyi önermesi yüzündendi, yanılmıyorsam. Bu, her zaman korkunç bir dakikadır. İnsanın yüreğine ebediyet korkusu salar. Neyse... İnanır mısın... Bir hafta önce, Leydi Hampshirelardaki yemekte kendimi sözü geçen hanımın yanında buldum... Ve hanım her şeyi yeniden yaşamakta, geçmişi eşeleyip geleceği konuşmakta diretti. Ben yaşadığım aşkı bir çiçek yatağına gömmüştüm. Kadın bunu çekti çıkardı, onun hayatını mahvettiğime yeminler etti. Şunu söylemek zorundayım ki sofrada tıka basa yemek yediği için bu konuda kaygıya kapılmadım. Gelgelelim öylesine çiğlikti ki bu yaptığı! Geçmişin tek çekiciliği geçmiş olmasındadır. Oysa kadınlar perdenin ne zaman kapandığını asla bilemezler. İlle de bir altıncı perde isterler; oyunun hiçbir ilginçliği kalmadığı anda onlar sürdürmeyi önerirler. Onlara uysam her komedi trajik bir sona bağlanır, her trajediyse farsa dönüşürdü. Kadınların çok cana yakın bir yapaylıkları vardır ya, hiç sanat kavramları yoktur. Sen benden daha şanslısın. Seni temin ederim, Dorian, Sibyl Vane’in senin için yaptığını, tanıdığım kadınlardan hiçbiri benim için yapmazdı. Sıradan kadınlar her zaman avunmayı bilirler. Kimisi, romantik renklere bürünerek yapar bunu. Yaşı ne olursa olsun, eflatun giyen hiçbir kadına güvenme... Ne de otuz beşini aşmış, pembe kurdele düşkünü kadınlara. Mutlaka arkalarında bir tarihçe var, demektir. Kimi kadınlar da durduk yerde kocalarının iyi yönlerini keşfetmekten büyük avuntu duyarlar. Mutlu evliliklerini insanın yüzüne çarparlar, en çekicisinden bir günahmış gibi. Kimini de din avutur. Dinin gizemlerinde cilveleşmenin tadı saklıdır, diye bir kadın söylemişti bana, bir seferinde. Bunu pek güzel anlıyorum. Hem zaten dünyada insanın kibrini en okşayan şey, sen günahkârsın, denmesidir. Vicdan hepimizi bencil yapıp çıkar. Evet, kadınların çağdaş yaşamda buldukları avuntuların sonu gelmiyor. Aslında bunların en önemlisine daha değinmedim.
es: —No hace falta —replicó su amigo—. La vida siempre distribuye amapolas a manos llenas. Por supuesto, de cuando en cuando las cosas se alargan. En una ocasión no llevé más que violetas durante toda una temporada, a manera de luto artístico por una historia de amor que no acababa de morir. A la larga, terminó por hacerlo. No recuerdo ya qué fue lo que la mató. Probablemente, su propuesta de sacrificar por mí el mundo entero. Ése es siempre un momento terrible. Le llena a uno con el terror de la eternidad. Pues bien, ¿querrás creerlo?, la semana pasada, en casa de lady Hampshire, me encontré cenando junto a la dama de quien te hablo, e insistió en revisar toda la historia, en desenterrar el pasado y en remover el futuro. Yo había sepultado mi amor bajo un lecho de asfódelos. Ella lo sacó de nuevo a la luz, asegurándome que había destrozado su vida. Me veo obligado a señalar que procedió a devorar una cena copiosísima, de manera que no sentí la menor ansiedad. Pero, ¡qué falta de buen gusto la suya! El único encanto del pasado es que es el pasado. Pero las mujeres nunca se enteran de que ha caído el telón. Siempre quieren un sexto acto, y tan pronto como la obra pierde interés, sugieren continuarla. Si se las dejara salirse con la suya, todas las comedias tendrían un final trágico, y todas las tragedias culminarían en farsa. Son encantadoramente artificiales, pero carecen de sentido artístico. Tú has tenido más suerte que yo. Te aseguro que ninguna de las mujeres que he conocido hubiera hecho por mí lo que Sibyl Vane ha hecho por ti. Las mujeres ordinarias se consuelan siempre. Algunas se lanzan a los colores sentimentales. Nunca te fíes de una mujer que se viste de malva, cualquiera que sea su edad, o de una mujer de más de treinta y cinco aficionada a las cintas de color rosa. Eso siempre quiere decir que tienen un pasado. Otras se consuelan descubriendo de repente las excelentes cualidades de sus maridos. Hacen ostentación en tus narices de su felicidad conyugal, como si fuera el más fascinante de los pecados. Algunas se consuelan con la religión, cuyos misterios tienen todo el encanto de un coqueteo, según me dijo una mujer en cierta ocasión; y lo comprendo perfectamente. Además, nada le hace a uno tan vanidoso como que lo acusen de pecador. La conciencia nos vuelve egoístas a todos. Sí; son innumerables los consuelos que las mujeres encuentran en la vida moderna. Y, de hecho, no he mencionado aún el más importante.
vi_translation: “No need,” your friend replied. “Life always has opium in hand. Of course, sometimes many things also drag on. There was a time I wore nothing but purple for an entire season, as a form of artistic mourning for a love that didn’t want to die. However, in the end, it still died. I forgot what killed it. I think it was her proposal to sacrifice the whole world for me. That is always a terrible moment. It makes one terrified of permanence. Oh, by the way — can you believe it? — last week, at Mrs. Hampshire’s place, I found myself sitting next to the lady in question at dinner, and she insisted on starting over, digging up the past, nurturing the future. I had buried my love under a bed of heliotrope. She dug it up again and assured me that I had ruined her life. I had to make it clear that she had eaten a dreadful meal, so I wasn’t worried. But how she displayed such a lack of tact. One charm of the past is that it is the past. But women never realize when the curtain has fallen. They always want a sixth act, and just when interest in the play has completely faded, they propose to continue it. If they were allowed to have their way, every comedy would end in a tragedy, and every tragedy would climax with a farce. They are charmingly artificial, but they lack the capacity to appreciate art. You are much luckier than I am. I assure you, Dorian, that no woman I have ever known could do for me what Sibyl Vane has done for you. Ordinary girls always console themselves. Some of them do so by favoring sentimental colors. Never trust a woman who wears mauve, no matter her age, or one over thirty-five who is fond of pink ribbons. It always means they are in trouble. Others find great comfort in suddenly discovering the good qualities of their husbands. They flaunt their marital happiness in our faces as if it were the most seductive sin. Religion also comforts some women. Its mysticism has all the allure of an illicit affair, one woman once told me; and I can quite understand that. Besides, nothing makes one so vain as being told that one is a sinner. Conscience makes us all self-centered. Yes; indeed, there are countless comforts that women have found in modern life. In fact, I haven’t even mentioned the most important one.”
tr_translation: His friend replied, "There's no need." "Life always has bunches of poppies in its hand. Sometimes certain things don't just drag on. Once, for an entire season, I wore a violet on my lapel: as a kind of artistic mourning for a love that simply couldn't die. However, in the end, the love died. I don't remember why it died. It was because the girl proposed sacrificing the whole world for my sake, if I'm not mistaken. That is always a dreadful moment. It instills a fear of eternity in one's heart. Anyway... Would you believe... A week ago, at a dinner at Lady Hampshire's, I found myself next to the mentioned lady... And the lady insisted on reliving everything, digging up the past and talking about the future. I had buried the love I experienced in a flower bed. The woman dug it up, swore that I had ruined her life. I must say, I wasn't worried about it because she was eating heartily at the table. However, what she did was so crude! The only charm of the past is that it is the past. Yet women never know when the curtain has fallen. They always want a sixth act; they propose to continue when the play has lost all its interest. If I followed them, every comedy would end in a tragic note, and every tragedy would turn into a farce. Women have a very endearing artificiality, but no sense of art. You are luckier than I am. I assure you, Dorian, none of the women I know would do for me what Sibyl Vane did for you. Ordinary women always know how to console themselves. Some do it by cloaking themselves in romantic colors. Never trust a woman who wears purple, no matter her age... Nor a woman over thirty-five who is fond of pink ribbons. It means they definitely have a history behind them. Some women find great solace in suddenly discovering the good qualities of their husbands. They flaunt their happy marriages in one's face, like the most attractive sin. Some are consoled by religion. A woman once told me that the pleasure of flirting lies in the mysteries of religion. I understand this very well. Besides, the thing that flatters one's pride the most in the world is being told, you are a sinner. Conscience makes us all selfish. Yes, the consolations women find in contemporary life are endless. In fact, I haven't even touched on the most important one."
es_translation: —No need —replied his friend—. Life always distributes poppies by the handful. Of course, from time to time things get prolonged. On one occasion, I wore nothing but violets for an entire season, as an artistic mourning for a love story that refused to die. In the end, it finally did. I no longer remember what killed it. Probably, her proposal to sacrifice the entire world for me. That is always a terrible moment. It fills one with the terror of eternity. Well, would you believe it? Last week, at Lady Hampshire's house, I found myself dining next to the lady I am telling you about, and she insisted on revisiting the entire story, unearthing the past and stirring up the future. I had buried my love under a bed of asphodels. She brought it back to light, assuring me that I had ruined her life. I must point out that she proceeded to devour a very copious dinner, so I felt no anxiety whatsoever. But, what a lack of good taste on her part! The only charm of the past is that it is the past. But women never realize that the curtain has fallen. They always want a sixth act, and as soon as the play loses interest, they suggest continuing it. If they were allowed to have their way, all comedies would end in tragedy, and all tragedies would culminate in farce. They are charmingly artificial, but they lack artistic sense. You have been luckier than I. I assure you that none of the women I have known would have done for me what Sibyl Vane has done for you. Ordinary women always console themselves. Some turn to sentimental colors. Never trust a woman who dresses in mauve, whatever her age, or a woman over thirty-five who is fond of pink ribbons. That always means they have a past. Others console themselves by suddenly discovering the excellent qualities of their husbands. They flaunt their marital happiness in your face, as if it were the most fascinating of sins. Some console themselves with religion, whose mysteries have all the charm of a flirtation, as a woman once told me; and I understand it perfectly. Besides, nothing makes one as vain as being accused of being a sinner. Conscience makes us all selfish. Yes; the consolations that women find in modern life are innumerable. And, in fact, I have not yet mentioned the most important one.

en: “What is that, Harry?” said the lad listlessly.
vi: “Đó là cái gì vậy, Harry?” chàng trai nói, thờ ơ.
tr: Delikanlı, “O nedir, Harry?” diye durgun bir sesle sordu.
es: —¿Cuál es, Harry? —preguntó el muchacho distraídamente.
vi_translation: "What is that, Harry?" the boy said, indifferently.
tr_translation: The young man asked in a subdued voice, "What is that, Harry?"
es_translation: —Which one is it, Harry? —asked the boy absentmindedly.

en: “Oh, the obvious consolation. Taking some one else’s admirer when one loses one’s own. In good society that always whitewashes a woman. But really, Dorian, how different Sibyl Vane must have been from all the women one meets! There is something to me quite beautiful about her death. I am glad I am living in a century when such wonders happen. They make one believe in the reality of the things we all play with, such as romance, passion, and love.”
vi: “À, sự an ủi hiển nhiên. Giật lấy một kẻ si mê của cô khác khi mất gã của mình. Trong tầng lớp thượng lưu thì việc ấy luôn minh oan cho phụ nữ. Nhưng thực ra, Dorian, Sibyl Vane chắc chắn là khác biệt biết bao so với mọi phụ nữ ta gặp! Tôi thấy có gì đó tuyệt đẹp ở cái chết của cô ấy. Tôi vui vì được sống trong một thế kỷ mà những điều kỳ diệu như vậy xảy ra. Chúng khiến ta tin vào sự có thực của những thứ mà chúng ta ai ai cũng đùa giỡn, như sự lãng mạn, niềm đam mê, và tình yêu.”
tr: “Canım, en beylik avuntu. İnsanın kendi sevgilisini yitirince başkasınınkini kapması. Kibar sosyetede bu, bir kadını her zaman temize çıkartır. Ama gerçekten, Dorian şu Sibyl Vane tanıdığımız bütün öteki kadınlardan nasıl da bambaşkaymış meğer! Ölümünde çok güzel bir şey var bence. Böyle harika şeylerin olabildiği bir yüzyılda yaşadığım için çok mutluyum. Romantizm gibi, tutku gibi, aşk gibi, hepimizin elinde oyuncak olan şeylerin doğruluğuna inandırıyor bu olaylar insanı.
es: —Oh, el consuelo más evidente. El que consiste en apoderarse del admirador de otra cuando se pierde al propio. En la buena sociedad eso siempre rehabilita a una mujer. Pero, realmente, Dorian, ¡qué diferente debía de ser Sibyl Vane de las mujeres que conocemos de ordinario! Hay algo que me parece muy hermoso acerca de su muerte. Me alegro de vivir en un siglo en el que ocurren tales maravillas. Le hacen creer a uno en la realidad de cosas con las que todos jugamos, como romanticismo, pasión y amor.
vi_translation: “Ah, the obvious consolation. Snatching away another woman's admirer when she loses her own. In the upper class, this always vindicates women. But in reality, Dorian, how different Sibyl Vane surely is from every woman we meet! I find something truly beautiful in her death. I am glad to live in a century where such wonders occur. They make us believe in the reality of things that we all jest about, like romance, passion, and love.”
tr_translation: “Dear, the most clichéd consolation. When a person loses their own lover, they snatch someone else's. In polite society, this always exonerates a woman. But truly, Dorian, how different this Sibyl Vane was from all the other women we know! There is something very beautiful in her death, I think. I am so happy to live in a century where such wonderful things can happen. These events make one believe in the truth of things like romance, passion, love, which are toys in all our hands.”
es_translation: —Oh, the most obvious consolation. The one that consists in seizing another's admirer when one loses their own. In good society, that always rehabilitates a woman. But, really, Dorian, how different Sibyl Vane must have been from the women we usually know! There is something that seems very beautiful to me about her death. I am glad to live in a century where such wonders occur. They make one believe in the reality of things we all play with, like romance, passion, and love.

en: “I was terribly cruel to her. You forget that.”
vi: “Tôi quá tàn nhẫn với nàng. Anh quên chuyện ấy sao.”
tr: “Çok gaddar davrandım ona. Bunu unutuyorsun.
es: —Yo he sido horriblemente cruel con ella. Lo estás olvidando.
vi_translation: “I was too cruel to her. Did you forget about that?”
tr_translation: “I treated him very cruelly. You forget this.”
es_translation: —I have been horribly cruel to her. You are forgetting it.

en: “I am afraid that women appreciate cruelty, downright cruelty, more than anything else. They have wonderfully primitive instincts. We have emancipated them, but they remain slaves looking for their masters, all the same. They love being dominated. I am sure you were splendid.
