I have never seen you really and absolutely angry, but I can fancy how delightful you looked. And, after all, you said something to me the day before yesterday that seemed to me at the time to be merely fanciful, but that I see now was absolutely true, and it holds the key to everything.”
vi: “Tôi sợ là phụ nữ lại đánh giá cao sự tàn nhẫn, sự tàn nhẫn thẳng thừng, hơn bất cứ thứ gì khác. Họ có những bản năng nguyên thủy kỳ diệu. Ta đã giải phóng họ, nhưng họ vẫn còn là những nô lệ đi tìm chủ nhân của mình, vẫn vậy thôi. Họ thích được thống trị. Tôi chắc chắn là cậu tuyệt vời. Tôi chưa từng thấy cậu thật sự và hoàn toàn tức giận, nhưng tôi có thể hình dung là trông cậu sẽ thú vị thế nào. Và, rốt cuộc thì, hôm kia cậu đã nói với tôi một điều mà lúc ấy với tôi dường như chỉ là tưởng tượng, song bây giờ thì tôi thấy tuyệt đối chính xác, và nó giữ lời giải cho mọi vấn đề.”
tr: “Korkarım ki kadınlar gaddarlığın, hem de katıksız gaddarlığın değerini her şeyden çok bilirler. İçgüdüleri olağanüstü ilkeldir onların. Biz onlara özgürlüklerini verdik, ama onlar gene de efendilerini arayan birer köle olmayı sürdürüyorlar. Hükmedilmeye bayılırlar. Senin şahane davrandığından ben eminim. Seni hiçbir zaman şöyle yüzde yüz öfkeli görmedim, gene de nasıl güzelleştiğini gözümde canlandırabiliyorum. Hem zaten dün değil önceki gün sen bana bir şey söylemiştin. O zaman bana hayal ürünü bir şey gibi gelmişti ama yüzde yüz doğruymuş meğer; şimdi görüyorum. Her şeyin anahtarı da bunda.
es: —Mucho me temo que las mujeres aprecian la crueldad, la crueldad pura y simple, más que ninguna otra cosa. Tienen instintos maravillosamente primitivos. Las hemos emancipado, pero siguen siendo esclavas en busca de dueño. Les encanta que las dominen. Estoy seguro de que estuviste espléndido. No te he visto nunca enfadado de verdad, aunque me imagino el aspecto tan delicioso que tenías. Y, después de todo, anteayer me dijiste algo que me pareció entonces puramente caprichoso, pero que ahora considero absolutamente cierto y que encierra la clave de todo lo sucedido.
vi_translation: “I am afraid that women tend to value cruelty, blatant cruelty, more than anything else. They have marvelous primal instincts. We have liberated them, but they are still slaves searching for their masters, just the same. They like to be dominated. I am sure you are wonderful. I have never seen you truly and completely angry, but I can imagine how interesting you would look. And, after all, the other day you told me something that at the time seemed like mere imagination to me, but now I see it as absolutely accurate, and it holds the solution to all problems.”
tr_translation: “I'm afraid that women know the value of cruelty, pure cruelty, more than anything else. Their instincts are extraordinarily primitive. We gave them their freedom, but they still continue to be slaves searching for their masters. They love to be ruled. I'm sure you behaved wonderfully. I've never seen you truly angry, but I can imagine how beautiful you would look. Besides, it wasn't yesterday but the day before that you told me something. At the time, it seemed like a figment of imagination to me, but it turns out it was completely true; now I see. The key to everything lies in this.”
es_translation: —I very much fear that women appreciate cruelty, pure and simple cruelty, more than anything else. They have wonderfully primitive instincts. We have emancipated them, but they remain slaves in search of a master. They love to be dominated. I am sure you were splendid. I have never seen you truly angry, although I can imagine how delightful you must have looked. And, after all, the day before yesterday you told me something that seemed purely whimsical at the time, but now I consider absolutely true and that holds the key to everything that happened.

en: “What was that, Harry?”
vi: “Là gì vậy, Harry?”
tr: “Neymiş o, Harry?
es: —¿Qué fue eso, Harry?
vi_translation: “What is it, Harry?”
tr_translation: "What is it, Harry?""
es_translation: —What was that, Harry?

en: “You said to me that Sibyl Vane represented to you all the heroines of romance—that she was Desdemona one night, and Ophelia the other; that if she died as Juliet, she came to life as Imogen.”
vi: “Cậu bảo tôi rằng cậu thấy Sibyl Vane đại diện cho tất cả các nữ anh hùng lãng mạn — rằng cô ấy là Desdemona đêm này, là Ophelia đêm khác; rằng nếu cô ấy chết trong vai Juliet, cô ấy sẽ sống lại trong vai Imogen.”
tr: “Sibyl Vane’in senin gözünde romantik edebiyatın bütün kahramanlarını simgelediğini söylemiştin. Bir gece Desdemona, öbür gece Ophelia oluyor, Juliet kimliğinde ölse bile Imogen olarak yeniden hayata doğuyor, demiştin.
es: —Me dijiste que para ti Sibyl Vane representaba a todas las heroínas novelescas; que una noche era Desdémona y otra Julieta; que si moría como Julieta, volvía a la vida como Imogen.
vi_translation: "You told me that you saw Sibyl Vane as representing all the romantic heroines — that she was Desdemona one night, Ophelia another; that if she died as Juliet, she would come back to life as Imogen."
tr_translation: "You had said that Sibyl Vane symbolized all the heroes of romantic literature in your eyes. One night she becomes Desdemona, the next night Ophelia, and even if she dies as Juliet, she is reborn as Imogen, you had said."
es_translation: —You told me that for you Sibyl Vane represented all the heroines of novels; that one night she was Desdemona and another Juliet; that if she died as Juliet, she came back to life as Imogen.

en: “She will never come to life again now,” muttered the lad, burying his face in his hands.
vi: “Nàng sẽ chẳng bao giờ sống lại nữa,” chàng trai lẩm bẩm, vùi mặt vào tay.
tr: Delikanlı yüzünü ellerine gömerek, “Şimdi artık bir daha asla yeniden doğmayacak,” diye söylendi.
es: —Nunca resucitará ya —murmuró el muchacho, escondiendo la cara entre las manos.
vi_translation: “She will never come back to life again,” the young man muttered, burying his face in his hands.
tr_translation: The young man buried his face in his hands and muttered, "Now it will never be reborn again."
es_translation: —He will never come back to life —murmured the boy, hiding his face in his hands.

en: “No, she will never come to life. She has played her last part. But you must think of that lonely death in the tawdry dressing-room simply as a strange lurid fragment from some Jacobean tragedy, as a wonderful scene from Webster, or Ford, or Cyril Tourneur. The girl never really lived, and so she has never really died. To you at least she was always a dream, a phantom that flitted through Shakespeare’s plays and left them lovelier for its presence, a reed through which Shakespeare’s music sounded richer and more full of joy. The moment she touched actual life, she marred it, and it marred her, and so she passed away. Mourn for Ophelia, if you like. Put ashes on your head because Cordelia was strangled. Cry out against Heaven because the daughter of Brabantio died. But don’t waste your tears over Sibyl Vane. She was less real than they are.”
vi: “Không, cô ấy sẽ chẳng bao giờ sống lại. Cô ấy đã diễn vai cuối cùng của mình. Nhưng cậu phải nghĩ về cái chết cô đơn ấy trong căn phòng thay đồ lòe loẹt rẻ tiền ấy chỉ như một trích đoạn ghê rợn kỳ dị từ bi kịch nào đó thời Vua James I, như một cảnh tuyệt vời của Webster, hoặc Ford, hoặc Cyril Tourneur. Cô gái ấy chưa bao giờ thật sự sống, và vì vậy cô ấy chưa bao giờ thật sự chết. Với cậu thì ít nhất cô ấy luôn là một giấc mơ, một bóng ma vụt qua các vở kịch của Shakespeare và làm cho chúng đẹp hơn nhờ sự hiện diện của nó, một ống sậy mà qua nó thì âm nhạc Shakespeare vang lên phong phú hơn và chan chứa niềm vui hơn. Khoảnh khắc mà cô ấy chạm vào đời thực, cô ấy đã làm hỏng nó, và nó đã làm hỏng cô ấy, vậy nên cô ấy ra đi. Hãy khóc than Ophelia, nếu cậu thích. Hãy bỏ tro cốt vào đầu cậu vì Cordelia bị bóp cổ. Hãy gào thấu trời xanh vì con gái của Brabantio bị chết. Nhưng đừng lãng phí nước mắt cho Sibyl Vane. Cô ấy còn ít thật hơn họ.”
tr: “Hayır, asla hayata doğmayacak bir daha. Son rolünü oynadı. Şu var ki sen o bayağı giyinme odasındaki zavallı ölümü bir on yedinci yüzyıl trajedisinin garip, çarpıcı bir sahnesi olarak düşünmelisin: Webster’den, Ford’dan ya da Cyril Tourneur’den alınma olağandışı bir sahne. Kızcağız gerçekte hiçbir zaman yaşamamıştı, demek ki gerçekte ölmedi. Hiç değilse senin gözünde her zaman bir düştü o, Shakespeare oyunlarının içinden uçup geçen, varlığıyla onlara daha bir güzellik katan bir hayal, Shakespeare’in müziğine daha zengin, daha kıvanç dolu bir seda veren bir saz. Ama bu kız gerçek hayata elini sürdüğü anda leke bırakıyordu; hayat da onu zedeliyordu, o da bu yüzden göçüp gitti işte. Ophelia için yas tut, dilersen. Cordelia’yı boğdular diye karalar bağla. Brabantio’nun kızı öldü diye Tanrı’ya isyan et. Ama gözyaşlarını Sibyl Vane için harcama. Bütün bu kadınlardan çok daha asılsızdı o.
es: —No, nunca más. Ha interpretado su último papel. Pero debes pensar en esa muerte solitaria en un camerino de oropel como un extraño pasaje espeluznante de una tragedia jacobea, como una maravillosa escena de Webster, de Ford, o de Cyril Tourneur. Esa muchacha nunca ha vivido realmente, de manera que tampoco ha muerto de verdad. Para ti, al menos, siempre ha sido un sueño, un fantasma que revoloteaba por las obras de Shakespeare y las hacía más encantadoras con su presencia, un caramillo con el que la música de Shakespeare sonaba mejor y más alegre. En el momento en que tocó la vida real, desapareció el encanto, la vida la echó a perder, y Sibyl murió. Lleva duelo por Ofelia, si quieres. Cúbrete la cabeza con cenizas porque Cordelia ha sido estrangulada. Clama contra el cielo porque ha muerto la hija de Brabantio. Pero no malgastes tus lágrimas por Sibyl Vane. Era menos real que todas ellas.
vi_translation: “No, she will never come back to life. She has played her final role. But you must think of that lonely death in that gaudy, cheap dressing room as just a bizarre, gruesome excerpt from some tragedy of the time of King James I, like a splendid scene of Webster, or Ford, or Cyril Tourneur. That girl never truly lived, and therefore she never truly died. To you, at least, she was always a dream, a phantom flitting through Shakespeare's plays and making them more beautiful by her presence, a reed through which Shakespeare's music sounded richer and more filled with joy. The moment she touched real life, she spoiled it, and it spoiled her, so she went away. Weep for Ophelia, if you like. Put ashes on your head for Cordelia being strangled. Cry to the heavens for Brabantio's daughter dying. But do not waste your tears for Sibyl Vane. She was less real than they are.”
tr_translation: “No, she will never be born into life again. She played her last role. The thing is, you should think of that poor death in the vulgar dressing room as a strange, striking scene from a seventeenth-century tragedy: an extraordinary scene taken from Webster, Ford, or Cyril Tourneur. The poor girl never really lived, so she never really died. At least in your eyes, she was always a dream, a vision that flew through Shakespeare's plays, adding more beauty to them with her presence, a reed that gave a richer, more jubilant tone to Shakespeare's music. But the moment this girl touched real life, she left a stain; life also damaged her, and that's why she passed away. Mourn for Ophelia, if you wish. Wear black because Cordelia was strangled. Rebel against God because Brabantio's daughter died. But do not waste your tears on Sibyl Vane. She was much more unreal than all these women.”
es_translation: —No, never again. She has played her last role. But you must think of that lonely death in a tinsel dressing room as a strange, eerie passage from a Jacobean tragedy, like a wonderful scene by Webster, Ford, or Cyril Tourneur. That girl never really lived, so she never truly died either. To you, at least, she was always a dream, a ghost flitting through Shakespeare's plays and making them more charming with her presence, a pipe with which Shakespeare's music sounded better and more joyful. The moment she touched real life, the charm vanished, life spoiled her, and Sibyl died. Mourn for Ophelia, if you wish. Cover your head with ashes because Cordelia has been strangled. Cry out against the heavens because Brabantio's daughter has died. But do not waste your tears for Sibyl Vane. She was less real than all of them.

en: There was a silence. The evening darkened in the room. Noiselessly, and with silver feet, the shadows crept in from the garden. The colours faded wearily out of things.
vi: Lặng đi. Buổi chiều sẫm lại trong phòng. Yên ắng, với những cái chân bạc, các bóng đen bò vào từ khu vườn. Sắc màu lử lả phai dần khỏi vạn vật.
tr: Bir sessizlik oldu. Odanın içi akşamla karardı. Gümüş ayaklı sessiz gölgeler bahçeden içeri süzüldüler sanki. Renkler yorulmuşçasına solup silindi.
es: Hubo un momento de silencio. La tarde se oscurecía en la biblioteca. Mudas, y con pies de plata, las sombras del jardín entraron en la casa. Los colores desaparecieron cansadamente de los objetos.
vi_translation: Be still. The afternoon darkened in the room. In the silence, with silver legs, shadows crept in from the garden. The fading colors gradually disappeared from everything.
tr_translation: There was a silence. The room darkened with the evening. It was as if silent shadows with silver feet glided in from the garden. Colors faded and vanished as if exhausted.
es_translation: There was a moment of silence. The afternoon was darkening in the library. Mute, and with silver feet, the shadows from the garden entered the house. The colors wearily disappeared from the objects.

en: After some time Dorian Gray looked up. “You have explained me to myself, Harry,” he murmured with something of a sigh of relief. “I felt all that you have said, but somehow I was afraid of it, and I could not express it to myself. How well you know me! But we will not talk again of what has happened. It has been a marvellous experience. That is all. I wonder if life has still in store for me anything as marvellous.”
vi: Một lúc sau, Dorian Gray nhìn lên. “Anh đã giảng về tôi cho chính tôi, Harry,” cậu lẩm bẩm, với chút thở dài nhẹ nhõm. “Tôi cảm thấy mọi điều anh nói, nhưng không hiểu sao tôi lại sợ, và tôi không thể nào diễn đạt cho mình. Sao mà anh hiểu tôi rõ như vậy! Nhưng ta sẽ không nói lại về những gì đã xảy ra. Đó là một kỷ niệm kỳ diệu. Chỉ vậy thôi. Tôi tự hỏi không biết cuộc sống có còn dành lại cho tôi thứ gì đó kỳ diệu như vậy không.”
tr: Bir süre sonra Dorian Gray başını kaldırdı. “Beni bana açıkladın, Harry,” diye mırıldandı, rahat bir soluk alırcasına. “Senin söylediğin şeylerin hepsini hissediyordum, ama korkuyordum, sonra ifade de edemiyordum. Sen beni nasıl da yakından tanıyorsun! Neyse, bu olaydan söz etmeyeceğiz artık. Harika bir deneyim oldu benim için. Hepsi bu. Acaba yaşam benim için böylesine harika başka şeyler de saklıyor mu?
es: Después de algún tiempo Dorian Gray alzó los ojos. —Me has explicado a mí mismo, Harry —murmuró, con algo parecido a un suspiro de alivio—. Aunque sentía lo que has dicho, me daba miedo, y no era capaz de decírmelo. ¡Qué bien me conoces! Pero no vamos a hablar más de lo sucedido. Ha sido una experiencia maravillosa. Eso es todo. Me pregunto si la vida aún me reserva alguna otra cosa tan extraordinaria.
vi_translation: A moment later, Dorian Gray looked up. "You have explained me to myself, Harry," he murmured, with a slight sigh of relief. "I feel everything you say, but somehow I am afraid, and I cannot express it to myself. How do you understand me so well! But we shall not speak again of what has happened. It is a wonderful memory. That's all. I wonder if life has anything as wonderful left for me."
tr_translation: After a while, Dorian Gray lifted his head. “You have explained me to myself, Harry,” he murmured, with a sigh of relief. “I was feeling everything you said, but I was afraid, and then I couldn't express it. How well you know me! Anyway, we won't talk about this event anymore. It was a wonderful experience for me. That's all. I wonder if life has other such wonderful things in store for me?”
es_translation: After some time, Dorian Gray raised his eyes. —You have explained myself to me, Harry —he murmured, with something like a sigh of relief—. Although I felt what you said, I was scared, and I was not able to tell it to myself. How well you know me! But let's not talk anymore about what happened. It has been a wonderful experience. That is all. I wonder if life still has something else as extraordinary in store for me.

en: “Life has everything in store for you, Dorian. There is nothing that you, with your extraordinary good looks, will not be able to do.”
vi: “Cuộc sống còn dành sẵn mọi thứ cho cậu, Dorian. Chẳng có gì mà cậu, với vẻ đẹp đặc biệt của mình, lại không thể làm.
tr: “Hayat senin için her şeyi hazırlıyor, Dorian. Bu olağanüstü güzelliğinle senin yapamayacağın şey yok.
es: —La vida te lo reserva todo, Dorian. No hay nada que no seas capaz de hacer, con tu maravillosa belleza.
vi_translation: "Life still has everything ready for you, Dorian. There is nothing that you, with your exceptional beauty, cannot do."
tr_translation: “Life is preparing everything for you, Dorian. With this extraordinary beauty of yours, there is nothing you cannot do.”
es_translation: —Life has everything in store for you, Dorian. There is nothing you are not capable of doing, with your marvelous beauty.

en: “But suppose, Harry, I became haggard, and old, and wrinkled? What then?”
vi: “Nhưng giả như, Harry, tôi trở nên phờ phạc, già cả, nhăn nheo? Thì sao?”
tr: “Ama Harry, tut ki çöktüm, ihtiyarladım, bumburuşuk oldum. Ya o zaman?
es: —Pero supongamos, Harry, que me volviera ojeroso y viejo y me llenara de arrugas. ¿Qué sucedería entonces?
vi_translation: “But suppose, Harry, I become haggard, old, wrinkled? Then what?”
tr_translation: “But Harry, suppose I collapse, grow old, and become all wrinkled. What about then?”
es_translation: —But suppose, Harry, that I became haggard and old and filled with wrinkles. What would happen then?

en: “Ah, then,” said Lord Henry, rising to go, “then, my dear Dorian, you would have to fight for your victories. As it is, they are brought to you. No, you must keep your good looks. We live in an age that reads too much to be wise, and that thinks too much to be beautiful. We cannot spare you. And now you had better dress and drive down to the club. We are rather late, as it is.”
vi: “À, lúc ấy,” huân tước Henry nói, nhỏm dậy định đi — “lúc ấy, Dorian thân mến của tôi, chắc cậu sẽ phải chiến đấu để giành thắng lợi. Như bây giờ thì chúng đang được mang đến cho cậu. Không, cậu phải giữ sắc đẹp. Chúng ta sống trong cái thời đại đọc quá nhiều để khôn, và nghĩ quá nhiều để đẹp. Chúng tôi rất cần cậu. Và giờ đây cậu nên thay quần áo thì hơn, rồi chạy xuống câu lạc bộ. Chúng ta vậy là đã khá muộn rồi.”
tr: Lord Henry gitmek için ayağa kalkarak, “O zaman mı?” dedi. “O zaman, sevgili Dorian zafer kazanmak istiyorsan savaşmak zorunda kalırsın. Şu durumda zaferler sana hazır sunuluyor. Yok yok, güzelliğini korumalısın. Öyle bir çağda yaşıyoruz ki herkes bilgeliğe ulaşamayacak oranda çok okuyor, güzel olamayacak oranda çok düşünüyor. Sensiz olamayız. Hadi, şimdi artık giyinsen de kulübün yolunu tutsak iyi olur. Geç bile kaldık.
es: —Ah —dijo lord Henry, poniéndose en pie para marcharse—, en ese caso, mi querido Dorian, tendrías que luchar por tus victorias. De momento, se te arrojan a los pies. No; tienes que seguir siendo como eres. Vivimos en una época que lee demasiado para ser sabia y que piensa demasiado para ser hermosa. No podemos pasarnos sin ti. Y ahora más vale que te vistas y vayamos en coche al club. Ya nos hemos retrasado bastante.
vi_translation: “Ah, at that time,” Lord Henry said, getting up as if to leave — “at that time, my dear Dorian, you will have to fight to win. As it is now, they are being brought to you. No, you must keep your beauty. We live in an age that reads too much to be wise, and thinks too much to be beautiful. We need you very much. And now you should change your clothes, then run down to the club. We are quite late already.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry stood up to leave and said, "Then what?" "Then, dear Dorian, if you want to achieve victory, you will have to fight. In this situation, victories are being handed to you. No, no, you must preserve your beauty. We live in an age where everyone reads too much to be wise and thinks too much to be beautiful. We cannot do without you. Come on, it would be best if you got dressed now so we can head to the club. We are already late."
es_translation: —Ah —said Lord Henry, standing up to leave—, in that case, my dear Dorian, you would have to fight for your victories. For now, they are thrown at your feet. No; you have to remain as you are. We live in an age that reads too much to be wise and thinks too much to be beautiful. We cannot do without you. And now you'd better get dressed and let's take the carriage to the club. We have already delayed enough.

en: “I think I shall join you at the opera, Harry. I feel too tired to eat anything. What is the number of your sister’s box?”
vi: “Tôi nghĩ tôi sẽ gặp anh tại nhà hát ô-pê-ra, Harry. Tôi thấy mệt quá, không ăn gì được. Số lô của em gái anh là gì?”
tr: “Ben gelip seni operada bulayım, Harry. Çok yorgunum, hiçbir şey yiyecek halim yok. Ablanın locasının numarası kaç?
es: —Creo que me reuniré contigo en la ópera. Estoy demasiado cansado para comer nada. ¿Cuál es el número del palco de tu hermana?
vi_translation: “I think I will meet you at the opera house, Harry. I feel so tired, I can't eat anything. What is your sister's box number?”
tr_translation: “Let me come and find you at the opera, Harry. I am very tired, I don't have the energy to eat anything. What is the number of your sister's box?”
es_translation: —I think I will meet you at the opera. I am too tired to eat anything. What is your sister's box number?

en: “Twenty-seven, I believe. It is on the grand tier. You will see her name on the door. But I am sorry you won’t come and dine.”
vi: “Hai mươi bảy, tôi cho là thế. Nó ở tầng gác. Cậu sẽ thấy tên em tôi trên cửa. Nhưng tôi rất lấy làm tiếc vì cậu không đến ăn tối.”
tr: “Yirmi yedi, sanıyorum. İlk katta. Kapıda adını görürsün. Keşke benimle yemeğe gelebilseydin.
es: —Veintisiete, me parece. Está en el primer piso. Encontrarás su nombre en la puerta. Pero lamento que no cenes conmigo.
vi_translation: “Twenty-seven, I suppose. It's on the upper floor. You will see my brother's name on the door. But I am very sorry that you didn't come for dinner.”
tr_translation: “Twenty-seven, I think. On the first floor. You will see the name on the door. I wish you could have come to dinner with me.”
es_translation: —Twenty-seven, I think. It's on the first floor. You will find his name on the door. But I regret that you won't dine with me.

en: “I don’t feel up to it,” said Dorian listlessly. “But I am awfully obliged to you for all that you have said to me. You are certainly my best friend. No one has ever understood me as you have.”
vi: “Tôi thấy không đủ sức,” Dorian nói, thờ ơ. “Nhưng tôi rất cảm ơn anh vì mọi điều mà anh đã nói với tôi. Anh chắc chắn là bạn tốt nhất của tôi. Chưa ai từng hiểu tôi như anh.”
tr: Dorian isteksizce, “İçimden gelmiyor,” dedi. “Ama bütün bu söylediklerin için sana minnettarım. Sen gerçekten de en iyi dostumsun benim. Dünyada hiç kimse beni senin anladığın gibi anlayamadı.
es: —No me siento capaz —dijo Dorian distraídamente—, aunque te estoy terriblemente agradecido por todo lo que me has dicho. Eres sin duda mi mejor amigo. Nadie me ha entendido nunca como tú.
vi_translation: "I don't feel up to it," Dorian said, indifferently. "But I am very grateful to you for everything you have said to me. You are certainly my best friend. No one has ever understood me like you do."
tr_translation: Dorian reluctantly said, "I don't feel like it." "But I am grateful to you for all that you have said. You really are my best friend. No one in the world has understood me the way you do."
es_translation: —I don't feel capable —said Dorian distractedly—, although I am terribly grateful to you for everything you have said. You are without a doubt my best friend. No one has ever understood me like you do.

en: “We are only at the beginning of our friendship, Dorian,” answered Lord Henry, shaking him by the hand. “Good-bye. I shall see you before nine-thirty, I hope. Remember, Patti is singing.”
vi: “Ta mới chỉ ở giai đoạn đầu của tình bạn thôi, Dorian,” huân tước Henry trả lời, bắt tay cậu. “Tạm biệt. Tôi sẽ gặp cậu trước chín rưỡi, hy vọng thế. Nhớ đấy, Patti sẽ hát.”
tr: Lord Henry onun elini sıkarak, “Dostluğumuzun daha başlangıcındayız, Dorian,” diye karşılık verdi. “Hoşça kal. Saat dokuz buçuktan önce gelirsin, unutma. Unutma, Patti söylüyor bu gece.
es: —Sólo estamos al comienzo de nuestra amistad —respondió lord Henry, estrechándole la mano—. Hasta luego. Te veré antes de las nueve y media, espero. No te olvides de que canta la Patti.
vi_translation: “We are only at the beginning of our friendship, Dorian,” Lord Henry replied, shaking his hand. “Goodbye. I will see you before half-past nine, I hope. Remember, Patti will sing.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, shaking his hand, replied, "We are just at the beginning of our friendship, Dorian." "Goodbye. Remember to come before half-past nine. Don't forget, Patti is singing tonight."
es_translation: —We are only at the beginning of our friendship —replied Lord Henry, shaking his hand—. See you later. I hope to see you before half-past nine. Don't forget that Patti is singing.

en: As he closed the door behind him, Dorian Gray touched the bell, and in a few minutes Victor appeared with the lamps and drew the blinds down. He waited impatiently for him to go. The man seemed to take an interminable time over everything.
vi: Lúc y đóng cửa lại sau lưng mình, Dorian Gray nhấn chuông, và vài phút sau Victor xuất hiện với các cây đèn và kéo rèm xuống. Cậu nôn nóng chờ hắn đi. Người hầu này dường như làm gì cũng lâu vô tận.
tr: O kapıyı arkasından çekip giderken Dorian çıngırağı çaldı; birkaç dakika sonra da Victor elinde lambalarla geldi, perdeleri indirdi. Dorian onun gitmesini sabırsızlıkla bekledi. Adam her yaptığı işi uzattıkça uzatıyordu sanki.
es: Cuando se cerró la puerta de la biblioteca, Dorian Gray tocó la campanilla y pocos minutos después apareció Víctor con las lámparas y bajó los estores. Dorian esperó con impaciencia a que se fuera. Tuvo la impresión de que tardaba un tiempo infinito en cada gesto.
vi_translation: When he closed the door behind him, Dorian Gray rang the bell, and a few minutes later Victor appeared with the lamps and drew the curtains. He anxiously waited for him to leave. This servant seemed to take an eternity to do anything.
tr_translation: As he pulled the door behind him and left, Dorian rang the bell; a few minutes later, Victor came with the lamps and drew the curtains. Dorian waited impatiently for him to leave. The man seemed to prolong every task he did.
es_translation: When the library door closed, Dorian Gray rang the bell and a few minutes later Victor appeared with the lamps and lowered the blinds. Dorian waited impatiently for him to leave. He had the impression that each gesture took an infinite amount of time.

en: As soon as he had left, he rushed to the screen and drew it back. No; there was no further change in the picture. It had received the news of Sibyl Vane’s death before he had known of it himself. It was conscious of the events of life as they occurred. The vicious cruelty that marred the fine lines of the mouth had, no doubt, appeared at the very moment that the girl had drunk the poison, whatever it was. Or was it indifferent to results? Did it merely take cognizance of what passed within the soul? He wondered, and hoped that some day he would see the change taking place before his very eyes, shuddering as he hoped it.
vi: Ngay sau khi hắn đã ra khỏi, cậu lao về phía tấm chắn, kéo nó lại. Không; trên tranh không có sự thay đổi nào thêm nữa. Nó nhận được tin về cái chết của Sibyl Vane trước khi chính cậu biết về chuyện đó. Nó biết về các sự kiện trong đời ngay lúc chúng xảy ra. Sự tàn nhẫn độc ác làm hỏng các nét đẹp trên miệng đã, chắc chắn, xuất hiện vào ngay khoảnh khắc mà cô gái uống thuốc độc, dẫu có thế nào. Hoặc nó dửng dưng với kết quả? Có khi nào mà nó chỉ nhận thức được những gì diễn ra trong linh hồn hay không? Cậu tự hỏi, và vừa hy vọng rằng ngày nào đó cậu sẽ thấy sự thay đổi diễn ra trước chính mắt cậu, vừa rùng mình khi hy vọng điều đó.
tr: O gider gitmez Dorian koştu, paravanı çekti. Yok, resimde başkaca değişim olmamıştı. Demek Sibyl Vane’ in ölüm haberini resim ondan önce almıştı. Dorian’ın hayatındaki olayları oldukları sırada öğreniyordu. Ağzın o güzel çizgisini çirkinleştiren gaddarlık, hiç kuşku yok, kızcağızın zehri içtiği anda belirmişti. Yoksa portre sonuçlara karşı kayıtsız mıydı? Ruhun içinde olup bitenleri mi kavrıyordu yalnızca? Dorian merak içindeydi. Günün birinde değişimin kendi gözleri önünde meydana gelmesini umuyor, umarken de ürpermekten kendini alamıyordu.
es: Tan pronto como se hubo marchado, corrió hacia el biombo, retirándolo. No; no se había producido ningún nuevo cambio. El retrato había recibido antes que él la noticia de la muerte de Sibyl. Era consciente de los sucesos de la vida a medida que se producían. La disoluta crueldad que desfiguraba las delicadas líneas de la boca había aparecido, sin duda, en el momento mismo en que la muchacha bebió el veneno, fuera el que fuese. ¿O era indiferente a los resultados? ¿Simplemente se enteraba de lo que sucedía en el interior del alma? No sabría decirlo, pero no perdía la esperanza de que algún día pudiera ver cómo el cambio tenía lugar delante de sus ojos, estremeciéndose al tiempo que lo deseaba.
vi_translation: As soon as he was out, he rushed to the shield and pulled it back. No; there was no further change in the painting. It received the news of Sibyl Vane's death before he himself knew about it. It knew about the events in life the moment they happened. The cruel wickedness that marred the beauty of the mouth must have appeared at the very moment the girl drank the poison, no matter what. Or was it indifferent to the outcome? Could it only perceive what happened in the soul? He wondered, and both hoped that someday he would see the change happen before his very eyes, and shuddered at the thought.
tr_translation: As soon as he left, Dorian ran and pulled the screen. No, there was no other change in the picture. So, the painting had received the news of Sibyl Vane's death before he did. It was learning about the events in Dorian's life as they happened. The cruelty that marred the beautiful line of the mouth had undoubtedly appeared the moment the poor girl drank the poison. Or was the portrait indifferent to the consequences? Was it only perceiving what was happening within the soul? Dorian was curious. He hoped that one day the change would occur before his very eyes, and while hoping, he couldn't help but shudder.
es_translation: As soon as he had left, he ran towards the screen, removing it. No; no new change had occurred. The portrait had received the news of Sibyl's death before he did. It was aware of the events of life as they happened. The dissolute cruelty that disfigured the delicate lines of the mouth had undoubtedly appeared at the very moment the girl drank the poison, whatever it was. Or was it indifferent to the results? Did it simply become aware of what was happening inside the soul? He couldn't say, but he did not lose hope that one day he might see the change take place before his eyes, shuddering as he desired it.

en: Poor Sibyl! What a romance it had all been! She had often mimicked death on the stage. Then Death himself had touched her and taken her with him. How had she played that dreadful last scene? Had she cursed him, as she died? No; she had died for love of him, and love would always be a sacrament to him now. She had atoned for everything by the sacrifice she had made of her life. He would not think any more of what she had made him go through, on that horrible night at the theatre. When he thought of her, it would be as a wonderful tragic figure sent on to the world’s stage to show the supreme reality of love. A wonderful tragic figure? Tears came to his eyes as he remembered her childlike look, and winsome fanciful ways, and shy tremulous grace. He brushed them away hastily and looked again at the picture.
vi: Sibyl đáng thương! Mọi chuyện đã lãng mạn làm sao! Nàng hay bắt chước cái chết trên sân khấu. Sau đó chính Cái chết đã đụng đến nàng, và đưa nàng đi với nó. Nàng đã đóng cái cảnh kinh khủng cuối cùng ấy thế nào nhỉ? Nàng có nguyền rủa cậu không, khi nàng chết? Không; nàng đã chết vì yêu cậu, và tình yêu sẽ luôn là một lời nguyền với cậu lúc này. Nàng đã chuộc mọi lỗi, bằng sự hy sinh nàng thực hiện cho đời mình. Cậu sẽ không nghĩ thêm nữa về những gì nàng đã bắt cậu trải qua, về cái đêm khủng khiếp ấy ở nhà hát. Khi cậu nghĩ về nàng, thì như thể có một hình ảnh bi thảm kỳ diệu được gửi đến sân khấu của thế giới này để cho thấy sự thật tối thượng về Tình yêu. Một hình ảnh bi thảm kỳ diệu? Lệ dâng lên mắt cậu lúc cậu nhớ lại vẻ mặt như trẻ con của nàng, và cá tính quyến rũ kỳ lạ, và thái độ ngập ngừng e thẹn. Cậu vội gạt chúng đi, và nhìn lại bức tranh.
tr: Zavallı Sibyl! Nasıl da bir aşk yaşamışlardı ya! Kızcağız sahnede kaç kez ölüm taklidi yapmıştı. Derken ölümün kendisi onu mimlemiş, alıp götürmüştü. O en son ürkünç sahneyi Sibyl nasıl oynamıştı acaba? Can çekişirken lanetlemiş miydi Dorian’ı? Ama yok, Dorian’ın aşkı uğruna ölmüştü o. Bundan böyle aşk Dorian’ın gözünde hep kutsal bir anlam taşıyacaktı. Sibyl hayatını feda ederek tüm günahların bedelini ödemişti. Onun tiyatrodaki o korkunç gecede kendine çektirdiklerini Dorian artık hiç düşünmeyecekti. Sibyl’i yeryüzüne aşkın en yüce gerçeğini göstersin diye gönderilmiş, benzersiz, trajik bir simge olarak düşünecekti. Benzersiz, trajik bir simge ha? Onun o çocuksu görünümünü, cana yakın, düş dolu hallerini, o utangaç ceylan zarifliğini anımsayınca Dorian’ın gözleri yaşla doldu. Delikanlı çabucak zihnini boşaltarak, yeniden resme baktı.
es: ¡Pobre Sibyl! ¡Qué romántico había sido todo! ¡Cuántas veces había fingido en el escenario la muerte que había terminado por tocarla, llevándosela consigo! ¿Cómo habría interpretado aquella última y terrible escena? ¿Lo habría maldecido mientras moría? No; había muerto de amor por él, y el amor sería su sacramento a partir de entonces. Sibyl lo había expiado todo con el sacrificio de su vida. No pensaría más en lo que le había hecho sufrir, en aquella horrible noche en el teatro. Cuando pensara en ella, la vería como una maravillosa figura trágica enviada al escenario del mundo para mostrar la suprema realidad del amor. ¿Una maravillosa figura trágica? Los ojos se le llenaron de lágrimas al recordar su aspecto infantil, su atractiva y fantasiosa manera de ser y su tímida gracia palpitante. Apartó apresuradamente aquellos recuerdos y volvió a mirar el cuadro.
vi_translation: Poor Sibyl! How romantic everything had been! She used to mimic death on stage. Then Death itself touched her, and took her away with it. How did she perform that final dreadful scene? Did she curse you when she died? No; she died because she loved you, and love will always be a curse for you now. She atoned for everything, with the sacrifice she made of her life. You will no longer think about what she made you go through, about that terrible night at the theater. When you think of her, it will be as if a tragic and wonderful image has been sent to the stage of this world to show the ultimate truth about Love. A tragic and wonderful image? Tears welled up in your eyes as you remembered her childlike face, her strange enchanting personality, and her hesitant shyness. You quickly brushed them away, and looked back at the painting.
tr_translation: Poor Sibyl! What a love they had lived! How many times had the girl pretended to die on stage. Then death itself had marked her and taken her away. How had Sibyl played that final dreadful scene? Had she cursed Dorian while she was dying? But no, she had died for Dorian's love. From now on, love would always carry a sacred meaning in Dorian's eyes. Sibyl had sacrificed her life to pay for all sins. Dorian would no longer think about the torment she had endured on that terrible night in the theater. He would think of her as a unique, tragic symbol sent to earth to show the highest truth of love. A unique, tragic symbol, huh? When Dorian remembered her childlike appearance, her charming, dreamy manners, that shy deer-like grace, his eyes filled with tears. The young man quickly cleared his mind and looked at the picture again.
es_translation: Poor Sibyl! How romantic it had all been! How many times had she pretended on stage the death that had finally touched her, taking her away! How would she have performed that last and terrible scene? Would she have cursed him while she died? No; she had died of love for him, and love would be his sacrament from then on. Sibyl had atoned for everything with the sacrifice of her life. He would no longer think of what he had made her suffer, on that horrible night at the theater. When he thought of her, he would see her as a wonderful tragic figure sent to the world's stage to show the supreme reality of love. A wonderful tragic figure? His eyes filled with tears as he remembered her childlike appearance, her attractive and fanciful manner, and her timid, throbbing grace. He hastily pushed those memories aside and looked back at the painting.

en: He felt that the time had really come for making his choice. Or had his choice already been made? Yes, life had decided that for him—life, and his own infinite curiosity about life. Eternal youth, infinite passion, pleasures subtle and secret, wild joys and wilder sins—he was to have all these things. The portrait was to bear the burden of his shame: that was all.
vi: Cậu cảm thấy là đã thật sự đến lúc phải lựa chọn. Hay đã chọn lựa rồi? Vâng, cuộc sống đã quyết định việc ấy cho cậu — cuộc sống, và sự tò mò bất tận của chính cậu về cuộc sống. Tuổi xuân bất diệt, đam mê bất tận, các khoái lạc tinh tế và bí mật, những niềm vui cuồng dại và các tội lỗi còn cuồng dại hơn — cậu sẽ có mọi thứ này. Bức chân dung sẽ phải mang gánh nặng hổ thẹn của cậu: chỉ vậy thôi.
tr: Seçimini yapmak zamanının gelmiş olduğunu hissediyordu. Yoksa zaten yapılmış mıydı seçimi? Evet, yaşam vermişti bu kararı onun adına, yaşam ve onun yaşamı konusundaki sınırsız merakı. Ölümsüz gençlik, sınırsız ihtiras, gizli, gizemli, ince zevkler, çılgın kıvançlar, daha bile çılgın günahlar: Bütün bunlar Dorian’ın olacaktı. Ayıbının yükünüyse portre taşıyacaktı, hepsi bu.
es: Comprendió que había llegado de verdad el momento de elegir. ¿O acaso la elección ya estaba hecha? Sí; la vida había decidido por él; la vida y su infinita curiosidad personal sobre la vida. Eterna juventud, pasión infinita, sutiles y secretos placeres, violentas alegrías y pecados aún más violentos; no quería prescindir de nada. El retrato cargaría con el peso de la vergüenza; eso era todo.
vi_translation: You feel that it is truly time to make a choice. Or have you already chosen? Yes, life has decided that for you — life, and your own endless curiosity about it. Eternal youth, endless passion, refined and secret pleasures, wild joys and even wilder sins — you will have all these. The portrait will bear the burden of your shame: that is all.
tr_translation: He felt that the time had come to make his choice. Or had it already been made? Yes, life had made this decision on his behalf, life and his boundless curiosity about it. Immortal youth, boundless passion, secret, mysterious, subtle pleasures, wild joys, even wilder sins: All these would be Dorian's. As for the burden of his shame, the portrait would bear it, that was all.
es_translation: He understood that the moment to choose had truly arrived. Or had the choice already been made? Yes; life had decided for him; life and his infinite personal curiosity about life. Eternal youth, infinite passion, subtle and secret pleasures, violent joys, and even more violent sins; he did not want to forgo anything. The portrait would bear the weight of the shame; that was all.

en: A feeling of pain crept over him as he thought of the desecration that was in store for the fair face on the canvas. Once, in boyish mockery of Narcissus, he had kissed, or feigned to kiss, those painted lips that now smiled so cruelly at him. Morning after morning he had sat before the portrait wondering at its beauty, almost enamoured of it, as it seemed to him at times. Was it to alter now with every mood to which he yielded? Was it to become a monstrous and loathsome thing, to be hidden away in a locked room, to be shut out from the sunlight that had so often touched to brighter gold the waving wonder of its hair? The pity of it! the pity of it!
vi: Một cảm giác đau đớn râm ran khắp người cậu khi cậu nghĩ về sự mạo phạm đã dành sẵn cho gương mặt đẹp trên tấm toan. Có lần, để nhại lại Narcissus một cách trẻ con, cậu đã hôn, hoặc giả bộ hôn, đôi môi sơn lúc này đang cười thật tàn nhẫn với cậu. Hết sáng này đến sáng khác, cậu đã ngồi trước bức chân dung, kinh ngạc với vẻ đẹp của nó, gần như say mê nó, đôi lúc cậu thấy có vẻ như vậy. Liệu bây giờ nó có thay đổi theo mỗi tâm trạng mà cậu chịu đựng. Liệu nó có thành một thứ gớm guốc ghê tởm, bị giấu đi trong một căn phòng khóa kín, bị che khỏi những tia nắng vẫn thường hay tô sắc vàng óng ả lên mái tóc lượn sóng diệu kỳ của nó. Thương nó quá! Thương nó quá!
tr: Tuvalin üstündeki bu güzelim yüzü bekleyen iğrençlikleri düşündükçe içini acı bürüdü. Şimdi kendisine böylesine zalimce gülümseyen bu boyalı dudakları bir gün çocuksu bir Narsist öykünmesiyle öpmüş, daha doğrusu öper gibi yapmıştı. Kim bilir kaç sabah resmin karşısına geçerek güzelliğini hayran bir inanmazlıkla seyretmişti. Zaman zaman bu resme adeta tutkunmuş gibi gelmişti ona. Şimdi bu resim onun kendini kaptırdığı her ruh haline göre değişime mi uğrayacaktı? İğrenç, dehşet verici bir şey mi olup çıkacaktı, kilitli bir odada gizlenmesi gereken, o nefis, kıvırcık saçların altınını daha da parlatan güneşten saklanması zorunlu olan. Ne yazık! Ne yazık!
es: Un sentimiento de dolor le invadió al pensar en la profanación que aguardaba al hermoso rostro del retrato. En una ocasión, en adolescente burla de Narciso, había besado, o fingido besar, aquellos labios pintados que ahora le sonreían tan cruelmente. Día tras día había permanecido delante del retrato, maravillándose de su belleza, casi —le parecía a veces— enamorado de él. ¿Cambiaría ahora cada vez que cediera a algún capricho? ¿Iba a convertirse en un objeto monstruoso y repugnante, que habría de esconderse en una habitación cerrada con llave, lejos de la luz del sol que con tanta frecuencia había convertido en oro deslumbrante la ondulada maravilla de sus cabellos? ¡Qué perspectiva tan terrible!
vi_translation: A tingling pain spread throughout his body as he thought about the desecration that awaited the beautiful face on the canvas. Once, to childishly mimic Narcissus, he had kissed, or pretended to kiss, the painted lips that were now smiling so cruelly at him. Morning after morning, he had sat before the portrait, marveling at its beauty, almost infatuated with it, sometimes it seemed to him. Would it now change with every mood he endured? Would it become something hideous and disgusting, hidden away in a locked room, shielded from the sunlight that used to cast a golden hue on its wondrous wavy hair? Poor thing! Poor thing!
tr_translation: As he thought of the horrors awaiting that beautiful face on the canvas, his heart filled with pain. He had once kissed, or rather pretended to kiss, those painted lips that now smiled at him so cruelly, in a childish Narcissistic imitation. Who knows how many mornings he had stood before the painting, gazing at its beauty with admiring disbelief. At times, it had seemed to him as if he were almost infatuated with this painting. Would this painting now change according to every mood he succumbed to? Would it become something disgusting, horrifying, something that needed to be hidden in a locked room, away from the sun that made the gold of those exquisite, curly locks shine even brighter? What a pity! What a pity!
es_translation: A feeling of pain overcame him at the thought of the desecration that awaited the beautiful face in the portrait. On one occasion, in an adolescent mockery of Narcissus, he had kissed, or pretended to kiss, those painted lips that now smiled at him so cruelly. Day after day he had stood before the portrait, marveling at its beauty, almost —it sometimes seemed to him— in love with it. Would it now change every time he yielded to some whim? Was it going to become a monstrous and repugnant object, which would have to be hidden in a locked room, away from the sunlight that so often had turned the wavy marvel of his hair into dazzling gold? What a terrible prospect!

en: For a moment, he thought of praying that the horrible sympathy that existed between him and the picture might cease. It had changed in answer to a prayer; perhaps in answer to a prayer it might remain unchanged. And yet, who, that knew anything about life, would surrender the chance of remaining always young, however fantastic that chance might be, or with what fateful consequences it might be fraught? Besides, was it really under his control? Had it indeed been prayer that had produced the substitution? Might there not be some curious scientific reason for it all? If thought could exercise its influence upon a living organism, might not thought exercise an influence upon dead and inorganic things? Nay, without thought or conscious desire, might not things external to ourselves vibrate in unison with our moods and passions, atom calling to atom in secret love or strange affinity? But the reason was of no importance. He would never again tempt by a prayer any terrible power. If the picture was to alter, it was to alter. That was all. Why inquire too closely into it?
vi: Cậu nghĩ một lúc về việc cầu xin để sự đồng cảm khủng khiếp đang tồn tại giữa cậu và bức tranh có thể chấm dứt. Nó đã thay đổi để đáp lại một lời cầu xin; không chừng để đáp lại một lời cầu xin khác thì nó có thể giữ nguyên không thay đổi. Tuy nhiên, người đã biết gì đó về Cuộc sống, liệu có từ bỏ cơ hội còn trẻ mãi, dẫu cái cơ hội ấy có thể kỳ quái thế nào, hoặc nó có thể đầy hậu quả tiền định? Ngoài ra, liệu việc ấy có thực sự dưới tầm kiểm soát của cậu không? Lẽ nào lời cầu xin ấy quả thực đã đem đến sự hoán đổi? Có thể có lý lẽ khoa học kỳ lạ nào đó cho mọi chuyện này không? Nếu sự suy nghĩ có thể gây ảnh hưởng lên cơ thể sống, thì sự suy nghĩ có thể gây ảnh hưởng lên những thứ chết chóc vô cơ không? Vả lại, không có sự suy nghĩ hoặc nỗi khát khao hữu thức, thì những thứ ở ngoài ta có thể rung động được đồng điệu với tâm trạng và đam mê của ta không, nguyên tử có thể gọi được nguyên tử bằng tình yêu bí mật của ái lực kỳ lạ không? Nhưng lý lẽ cũng không còn quan trọng nữa. Cậu sẽ không bao giờ lại xúi giục bất cứ thế lực khủng khiếp nào bằng một lời cầu xin nữa. Nếu bức tranh thay đổi thì kệ cho nó thay đổi. Chỉ vậy thôi. Sao lại phải điều tra quá kỹ về nó?
tr: Genç adam, bir an, kendisiyle resim arasındaki bu tiksindirici, korkunç bağlantı kopsun diye yakarmayı düşündü. Resim bir yakarıya karşılık olarak değişmişti; belki gene bir yakarıya karşılık olarak olduğu gibi kalabilirdi. Öte yandan hayat konusunda herhangi bir bilgisi olan kim çıkar da sonsuza dek genç kalma fırsatını kaçırırdı, bu fırsat ne denli usa sığmaz olursa olsun, içinde ne denli bilinmez sonuçlar taşırsa taşısın? Hem zaten bu gerçekten onun elinde olan bir şey miydi bakalım? Bu rol değişimini gerçekleştiren onun yakarışı mı olmuştu gerçekten? Bütün bu olup bitenlerin garip bir bilimsel açıklaması olamaz mıydı? Düşünce, yaşayan organizmalar üzerinde etki bırakabiliyordu madem, cansız, inorganik şeyler üzerinde de etki bırakıyor olamaz mıydı? Dahası... Bilinçli istek ve düşünce bile olmaksızın, bizim dışımızda bir şeyler, ruhsal durumlarımız ve şiddetli duygularımızla uyum halinde titreşimler yaratamaz mıydı: garip bir yakınlığın gizli aşkıyla atomun atoma seslenişi? Zaten nedenin hiç önemi yoktu. Dorian bundan sonra herhangi bir dilek ve yakarışla herhangi bir müthiş gücü kışkırtmaya asla kalkışmayacaktı. Resmin değişime uğrayacağı varsa, değişime uğrayacaktı. İşte bu kadar. Fazla kurcalamaya ne gerek vardı?
es: Por un momento pensó en rezar para que cesara la espantosa comunión que existía entre el cuadro y él. El cambio se había producido en respuesta a una plegaria; quizás en respuesta a otra volviese a quedar inalterable. Y, sin embargo, ¿quién, que supiera algo sobre la Vida, renunciaría al privilegio de permanecer siempre joven, por fantástica que esa posibilidad pudiera ser o por fatídicas que resultaran las consecuencias? Además, ¿estaba realmente en su mano controlarlo? ¿Había sido una oración la causa del cambio? ¿Podía existir quizá alguna razón científica? Si el pensamiento influía sobre un organismo vivo, ¿no cabía también que ejerciera esa influencia sobre cosas muertas e inorgánicas? Más aún, ¿no era posible que, sin pensamientos ni deseos conscientes, cosas externas a nosotros vibraran en unión con nuestros estados de ánimo y pasiones, átomo llamando a átomo en un secreto amor de extraña afinidad? Pero poco importaba la razón. Nunca volvería a tentar con una plegaria a ningún terrible poder. Si el retrato tenía que cambiar, cambiaría. Eso era todo. ¿Qué necesidad había de profundizar más?
vi_translation: He thought for a moment about pleading for the terrible empathy existing between him and the painting to end. It had changed in response to one plea; perhaps in response to another plea, it could remain unchanged. However, would someone who knew something about Life give up the chance to stay young forever, no matter how strange that chance might be, or how full of predetermined consequences it might be? Besides, was it really within his control? Could it be that the plea had indeed brought about the transformation? Could there be some strange scientific rationale for all of this? If thought could influence a living body, could thought also influence inanimate, lifeless things? Moreover, without conscious thought or desire, could things outside of us resonate in harmony with our moods and passions, could atoms call to atoms with the secret love of strange affinities? But reasoning no longer mattered. He would never again incite any terrible force with a plea. If the painting changed, then let it change. That was all. Why investigate it too closely?
tr_translation: The young man thought for a moment about praying for this disgusting, terrifying connection between himself and the painting to be severed. The painting had changed in response to a prayer; perhaps it could remain as it was in response to another prayer. On the other hand, who with any knowledge of life would pass up the opportunity to stay young forever, no matter how irrational it might be, no matter what unknown consequences it might carry? Besides, was this really something that was within his control? Had his prayer truly been what caused this role reversal? Couldn't there be a strange scientific explanation for all these events? If thought could have an effect on living organisms, couldn't it also have an effect on inanimate, inorganic things? Moreover... Even without conscious desire and thought, couldn't something outside of us create vibrations in harmony with our mental states and intense emotions: the secret love of a strange affinity, the call of atom to atom? In any case, the reason didn't matter at all. From now on, Dorian would never attempt to provoke any terrible power with any wish or prayer. If the painting was going to change, it would change. That was all. What was the point of overthinking it?
es_translation: For a moment he thought of praying for the dreadful communion that existed between the painting and himself to cease. The change had occurred in response to a prayer; perhaps in response to another, it would become unaltered again. And yet, who, knowing something about Life, would renounce the privilege of remaining forever young, no matter how fantastic that possibility might be or how fatal the consequences? Besides, was it really within his power to control it? Had a prayer been the cause of the change? Could there perhaps be some scientific reason? If thought influenced a living organism, could it not also exert that influence on dead and inorganic things? Moreover, was it not possible that, without conscious thoughts or desires, external things to us vibrated in union with our moods and passions, atom calling to atom in a secret love of strange affinity? But the reason mattered little. He would never again tempt any terrible power with a prayer. If the portrait had to change, it would change. That was all. What need was there to delve deeper?

en: For there would be a real pleasure in watching it. He would be able to follow his mind into its secret places. This portrait would be to him the most magical of mirrors. As it had revealed to him his own body, so it would reveal to him his own soul. And when winter came upon it, he would still be standing where spring trembles on the verge of summer. When the blood crept from its face, and left behind a pallid mask of chalk with leaden eyes, he would keep the glamour of boyhood. Not one blossom of his loveliness would ever fade. Not one pulse of his life would ever weaken. Like the gods of the Greeks, he would be strong, and fleet, and joyous. What did it matter what happened to the coloured image on the canvas? He would be safe. That was everything.
vi: Dẫu gì cũng có một khoái lạc thực sự trong việc theo dõi nó. Cậu sẽ có thể bám theo tâm trí mình vào những nơi bí mật của nó. Bức chân dung này sẽ trở thành tấm gương thần diệu nhất với cậu. Do nó đã để lộ cho cậu thấy cơ thể cậu, nên nó sẽ để lộ cho cậu thấy tâm hồn cậu. Và khi mùa đông buông lên nó, cậu vẫn sẽ còn đứng nơi mùa xuân run rẩy trên bờ vực mùa hè. Khi máu lẻn đi khỏi mặt nó, và để lại đằng sau một cái mặt nạ vàng vọt bằng phấn với đôi mắt chì, cậu sẽ còn giữ được vẻ đẹp quyến rũ thời niên thiếu. Không một bông hoa nào trong vẻ đẹp của cậu sẽ có lúc phải héo tàn. Không một nhịp đập nào của đời cậu sẽ có lúc bị yếu đi. Như các vị thần Hy Lạp, cậu sẽ mạnh mẽ, nhanh nhẹn, vui sướng. Quan trọng gì những việc xảy ra với hình ảnh nhiều màu trên tấm toan? Cậu sẽ được an toàn. Đó là điều quan trọng nhất.
tr: Aslında bu değişimi gözlemlemek gerçekten zevkli olacaktı. Dorian kendi zihninin en gizli köşelerine işleyebilecekti böylece. Bu portre onun için aynaların en sihirlisi olacaktı. Nasıl ilkin bedenini gözlerinin önüne sermişse şimdi de ruhunu gözlerinin önüne serecekti. Ve portreye kış gelince, o hâlâ yazın eşiğinde duralayan bir bahar mevsimini yaşıyor olacaktı. Portrenin yüzünden kan çekilip geride tebeşirle çizilmiş kurşun gözlü, solgun bir maske bıraktığında o hâlâ delikanlılığın çekiciliğini ve büyüsünü koruyacaktı. Onun güzelliğinin tek bir çiçeği bile solmayacaktı. Canlılığının tek bir nabız vuruşu zayıflamayacaktı. Antik Yunanlıların tanrıları gibi gürbüz, kıvrak ve kıvançlı kalacaktı o! Tuval üstündeki renkli görüntünün başına gelenlerin ne önemi vardı? Dorian güvenlikte olacaktı ya. Bu, her şey demekti.
es: Porque sería un verdadero placer examinar el retrato. Podría así penetrar hasta en los repliegues más secretos de su alma. El retrato se convertiría en el más mágico de los espejos. De la misma manera que le había descubierto su cuerpo, también le revelaría el alma. Y cuando a ese alma le llegara el invierno, él permanecería aún en donde la primavera tiembla, a punto de convertirse en verano. Cuando la sangre desapareciera de su rostro, para dejar una pálida máscara de yeso con ojos de plomo, él conservaría el atractivo de la adolescencia. Ni un átomo de su belleza se marchitaría nunca. Jamás se debilitaría el ritmo de su vida. Como los dioses de los griegos, sería siempre fuerte, veloz y alegre. ¿Qué importaba lo que le sucediera a la imagen coloreada del lienzo? Él estaría a salvo. Eso era lo único que importaba.
vi_translation: There is indeed a certain pleasure in watching it. You will be able to follow your mind into its secret places. This portrait will become the most magical mirror for you. As it has revealed your body to you, it will reveal your soul to you. And when winter descends upon it, you will still stand in the trembling spring on the verge of summer. When the blood slips away from its face, leaving behind a pale mask with leaden eyes, you will still retain the enchanting beauty of youth. Not a single flower in your beauty will ever wither. Not a single heartbeat of your life will ever weaken. Like the Greek gods, you will be strong, agile, and joyful. What does it matter what happens to the many-colored image on the canvas? You will be safe. That is the most important thing.
tr_translation: Actually, observing this change would have been really enjoyable. Thus, Dorian would be able to delve into the most secret corners of his own mind. This portrait would be the most magical of mirrors for him. Just as it had initially laid bare his body before his eyes, now it would lay bare his soul. And when winter came to the portrait, he would still be living in a spring season lingering on the threshold of summer. When the blood drained from the portrait's face, leaving behind a pale mask with leaden eyes drawn in chalk, he would still retain the allure and charm of youth. Not a single flower of his beauty would wither. Not a single pulse of his vitality would weaken. He would remain robust, agile, and joyous like the gods of ancient Greece! What did it matter what happened to the colorful image on the canvas? Dorian would be safe. This meant everything.
es_translation: Because it would be a true pleasure to examine the portrait. In this way, I could penetrate even the most secret folds of his soul. The portrait would become the most magical of mirrors. Just as it had revealed his body, it would also reveal his soul. And when winter came to that soul, he would still remain where spring trembles, about to turn into summer. When the blood disappeared from his face, leaving a pale plaster mask with leaden eyes, he would retain the allure of adolescence. Not an atom of his beauty would ever wither. The rhythm of his life would never weaken. Like the gods of the Greeks, he would always be strong, swift, and joyful. What did it matter what happened to the colored image on the canvas? He would be safe. That was the only thing that mattered.

en: He drew the screen back into its former place in front of the picture, smiling as he did so, and passed into his bedroom, where his valet was already waiting for him. An hour later he was at the opera, and Lord Henry was leaning over his chair.
vi: Cậu kéo tấm chắn vào lại chỗ cũ trước bức tranh, mỉm cười lúc làm thế, và đi vào phòng ngủ, nơi người hầu đã chờ cậu. Một giờ sau, cậu đã ở nhà hát ô-pê-ra, còn huân tước Henry thì cúi xuống ghế cậu.
tr: Dorian, gülümseyerek, paravanı gene portrenin önüne çekti ve yatak odasına girdi. Burada özel uşağı onu beklemekteydi. Bir saat sonra Dorian Gray operaya varıp oturmuş ve Lord Henry onun sandalyesine yaslanıp ona doğru eğilmişti bile.
es: Volvió a colocar el biombo en su posición anterior, delante del retrato, sonriendo al hacerlo, y entró en el dormitorio, donde ya le esperaba su ayuda de cámara. Una hora después se encontraba en la ópera, y lord Henry se inclinaba sobre su silla.
vi_translation: He pulled the cover back over the painting, smiling as he did so, and went into the bedroom, where the servant was waiting for him. An hour later, he was at the opera house, and Lord Henry was leaning over his seat.
tr_translation: Dorian, smiling, pulled the screen back in front of the portrait and entered the bedroom. His personal valet was waiting for him there. An hour later, Dorian Gray had arrived at the opera and taken his seat, and Lord Henry was already leaning against his chair, bending towards him.
es_translation: He put the screen back in its previous position, in front of the portrait, smiling as he did so, and entered the bedroom, where his valet was already waiting for him. An hour later he was at the opera, and Lord Henry was leaning over his chair.

en: CHAPTER IX.
vi: Chương 9
tr: Dokuzuncu bölüm
es: Capítulo 9
vi_translation: Chapter 9
tr_translation: Ninth chapter
es_translation: Chapter 9

en: As he was sitting at breakfast next morning, Basil Hallward was shown into the room.
vi: Sáng hôm sau, lúc cậu đang ngồi dùng bữa điểm tâm, Basil Hallward xuất hiện trong phòng.
tr: Ertesi sabah Dorian kahvaltı başında otururken, uşak Basil Hallward’ı içeri aldı.
es: Cuando estaba desayunando a la mañana siguiente, el criado hizo entrar a Basil Hallward.
vi_translation: The next morning, while he was having breakfast, Basil Hallward appeared in the room.
tr_translation: The next morning, while Dorian was sitting at breakfast, the servant brought in Basil Hallward.
es_translation: When I was having breakfast the next morning, the servant showed Basil Hallward in.

en: “I am so glad I have found you, Dorian,” he said gravely. “I called last night, and they told me you were at the opera. Of course, I knew that was impossible. But I wish you had left word where you had really gone to. I passed a dreadful evening, half afraid that one tragedy might be followed by another. I think you might have telegraphed for me when you heard of it first. I read of it quite by chance in a late edition of The Globe that I picked up at the club. I came here at once and was miserable at not finding you. I can’t tell you how heart-broken I am about the whole thing. I know what you must suffer. But where were you? Did you go down and see the girl’s mother? For a moment I thought of following you there. They gave the address in the paper. Somewhere in the Euston Road, isn’t it? But I was afraid of intruding upon a sorrow that I could not lighten. Poor woman! What a state she must be in! And her only child, too! What did she say about it all?”
vi: “Tôi rất vui vì tìm được cậu, Dorian,” y nói, trang nghiêm. “Tôi gọi đêm qua, và họ bảo tôi là cậu ở nhà hát ô-pê-ra. Dĩ nhiên tôi biết không thể có chuyện ấy. Nhưng tôi ước gì cậu đã để lại lời nhắn về nơi cậu thực sự đến. Tôi đã trải qua một tối khủng khiếp, phần nào lo sợ là bi kịch này có thể lại theo sau bi kịch kia. Tôi nghĩ lẽ ra cậu có thể đánh điện cho tôi ngay khi cậu vừa nghe tin. Tôi đọc được nó hoàn toàn tình cờ trong số báo The Globe cuối ngày, mà tôi nhặt được ở câu lạc bộ. Tôi đến đây ngay lập tức, và đã khổ sở vì không tìm thấy cậu. Tôi không thể kể cho cậu biết tôi đã đau lòng làm sao với toàn bộ vụ này. Tôi hiểu những gì cậu phải chịu đựng. Nhưng cậu đã ở đâu? Cậu có xuống gặp mẹ cô gái ấy không? Trong giây lát, tôi nghĩ về việc đi theo cậu đến đó. Họ cho địa chỉ trên báo. Đâu đó ở đường Euston, phải không? Nhưng tôi lo sợ về việc xâm phạm vào một nỗi buồn đau mà tôi không thể xoa dịu. Tội nghiệp bà ấy! Hẳn là bà ấy phải trong tình trạng tệ thế nào! Lại còn là con một của bà ấy nữa! Bà ấy nói gì về mọi chuyện này?”
tr: Ressam ciddi bir ifadeyle, “Seni evde bulduğuma sevindim, Dorian,” dedi. “Dün akşam da geldim, operada olduğunu söylediler. Ben bunun doğru olmayacağını biliyordum, doğallıkla. Keşke nereye gittiğini evdekilere söylemiş olsaydın. Feci bir gece geçirdim: Bir trajediyi başka bir trajedi izleyecek diye korkuyordum adeta. Haberi ilk aldığında bana telgraf çekebilirdin değil mi? Bir rastlantıyla gözüme ilişti, kulüpte bulduğum Globe’un akşam baskısında. Derhal buraya koştum, seni bulamayınca çok üzüldüm. Bu olay beni nasıl sarstı, anlatamam. Kim bilir sen nasıl perişansın. Peki ama, neredeydin sen? Kızın annesini mi görmeye gittin? Senin peşin sıra oraya gitmek de bir an aklımdan geçmedi değil. Adresleri gazetede vardı. Euston Sokağı’nda bir yer, değil mi? Ama hafifletemeyeceğim bir acıya saygısızlık etmekten çekindim. Zavallı kadıncağız! Kim bilir nasıl bitiktir! Hem de tek evladı! Neler diyordu, zavallıcık?
es: —Me alegro de haberte encontrado, Dorian —dijo el pintor con entonación solemne—. Vine a verte anoche, y me dijeron que estabas en la ópera. Comprendí que no era posible. Pero siento que no dijeras adónde ibas en realidad. Pasé una velada horrible, temiendo a medias que a una primera tragedia pudiera seguirle otra. Creo que deberías haberme telegrafiado cuando te enteraste de lo sucedido. Lo leí casi por casualidad en la última edición del Globe, que encontré en el club. Vine aquí de inmediato, y sentí mucho no verte. No sé cómo explicarte cuánto lamento lo sucedido. Me hago cargo de lo mucho que sufres. Pero, ¿dónde estabas? ¿Fuiste a ver a la madre de esa muchacha? Por un momento pensé en seguirte hasta allí. Daban la dirección en el periódico. Un lugar en Euston Road, ¿no es eso? Pero tuve miedo de avivar un dolor que no me era posible aliviar. ¡Pobre mujer! ¡En qué estado debe encontrarse! ¡Y su única hija! ¿Qué ha dicho sobre lo sucedido?
vi_translation: “I am very glad to have found you, Dorian,” he said, solemnly. “I called last night, and they told me you were at the opera house. Of course, I knew that couldn't be true. But I wish you had left a message about where you actually went. I had a terrible evening, somewhat fearing that this tragedy might follow another tragedy. I think you could have telegraphed me as soon as you heard the news. I read it entirely by chance in the late edition of The Globe, which I picked up at the club. I came here immediately and was distressed not to find you. I can't tell you how heartbroken I was over the whole affair. I understand what you must be going through. But where were you? Did you go down to see the girl's mother? For a moment, I thought about following you there. They gave the address in the paper. Somewhere on Euston Road, right? But I was afraid of intruding on a grief that I could not alleviate. Poor woman! She must be in such a terrible state! And her only child too! What did she say about all this?”
tr_translation: The painter said with a serious expression, "I'm glad I found you at home, Dorian." "I came yesterday evening as well, they told me you were at the opera. I knew that wouldn't be true, naturally. I wish you had told the household where you were going. I had a terrible night: I was almost afraid that one tragedy would follow another. You could have sent me a telegram when you first got the news, couldn't you? By chance, I saw it in the evening edition of the Globe I found at the club. I ran here immediately, I was very upset when I couldn't find you. I can't tell you how shaken I was by this event. Who knows how devastated you must be. But where were you? Did you go to see the girl's mother? For a moment, I even thought of following you there. The addresses were in the newspaper. A place on Euston Street, right? But I was afraid of being disrespectful to a grief I couldn't alleviate. Poor woman! Who knows how devastated she must be! And her only child! What was she saying, poor thing?"
es_translation: —I'm glad to have found you, Dorian —said the painter with a solemn tone—. I came to see you last night, and they told me you were at the opera. I understood that it wasn't possible. But I regret that you didn't say where you were really going. I had a horrible evening, half fearing that one tragedy might be followed by another. I think you should have telegraphed me when you found out what happened. I read it almost by chance in the last edition of the Globe, which I found at the club. I came here immediately, and I was very sorry not to see you. I don't know how to explain to you how much I regret what happened. I understand how much you are suffering. But, where were you? Did you go to see that girl's mother? For a moment I thought about following you there. They gave the address in the newspaper. A place on Euston Road, isn't that right? But I was afraid of stirring up a pain that I couldn't alleviate. Poor woman! In what state she must be! And her only daughter! What has she said about what happened?

en: “My dear Basil, how do I know?” murmured Dorian Gray, sipping some pale-yellow wine from a delicate, gold-beaded bubble of Venetian glass and looking dreadfully bored. “I was at the opera. You should have come on there. I met Lady Gwendolen, Harry’s sister, for the first time. We were in her box. She is perfectly charming; and Patti sang divinely. Don’t talk about horrid subjects. If one doesn’t talk about a thing, it has never happened. It is simply expression, as Harry says, that gives reality to things. I may mention that she was not the woman’s only child. There is a son, a charming fellow, I believe. But he is not on the stage. He is a sailor, or something. And now, tell me about yourself and what you are painting.”
vi: “Basil thân mến của tôi ơi, sao mà tôi biết được?” Dorian Gray lẩm bẩm, nhấp chút rượu vàng nhạt từ một chiếc ly Venice mỏng manh sủi tăm vàng óng, và nhìn rất buồn. “Tôi đã ở nhà hát ô-pê- ra. Anh lẽ ra nên đến đó. Tôi được gặp cô Gwendolen, em gái Harry, lần đầu. Chúng tôi ở lô của cô ấy. Cô ấy cực kỳ duyên dáng; và Patti hát hay tuyệt trần. Đừng nói về các chủ đề kinh sợ nữa. Nếu ta không nói về một điều nào đó thì nó sẽ chẳng bao giờ xảy ra. Chỉ từ ngữ, như Harry bảo, là đem thực tại đến cho sự vật. Tôi có thể kể là nàng không phải con một của người đàn bà ấy. Còn một cậu con trai, một anh chàng quyến rũ, tôi cho là thế. Nhưng cậu ta không làm diễn viên. Cậu ta là thủy thủ thì phải. Và bây giờ hãy kể tôi nghe về anh và những gì anh đang vẽ.”
tr: Dorian, “Sevgili Basil, ben nereden bileyim?” diye söylendi. Venedik camından yapılma, altın bir özü andıran ince bir kadehten solgun sarı bir şarap içmekteydi ve son derece sıkkın duruyordu. “Ben operadaydım. Oraya gelmeliydin. Harry’nin ablasıyla tanıştım, Leydi Gwendolen. Onun locasındaydık. Şeker gibi bir hanım. Patti de şahane söyledi. Kuzum, acı konulardan konuşma. Bir olayı konuşmazsan olmamış demektir. Harry’nin dediği gibi, olaylara, durumlara gerçeklik kazandıran şey onların dile getirilmesidir, doğrudan doğruya. Şunu da belirteyim ki kız o kadının tek evladı değildi. Bir de oğlu var, çok hoş bir gençmiş, duyduğuma göre. Ama o tiyatrocu değil. Denizci mi ne, öyle bir şey. Neyse, şimdi sen bana kendini anlat, neler çiziyorsun?
es: —Mi querido Basil, ¿cómo quieres que lo sepa? —murmuró Dorian Gray, bebiendo un sorbo de pálido vino blanco de una delicada copa de cristal veneciano, adornada con perlas de oro, con aire de aburrirse muchísimo—. Estaba en la ópera. Deberías haber ido allí. Conocí a lady Gwendolen, la hermana de Harry. Estuvimos en su palco. Es absolutamente encantadora; y la Patti cantó divinamente. No hables de cosas horribles. Basta con no hablar de algo para que no haya sucedido nunca. Como dice Harry, el hecho de expresarlas es lo que da realidad a las cosas. Aunque quizá deba mencionar que no era hija única. Existe un varón, un muchacho excelente, según creo. Pero no se dedica al teatro. Es marinero o algo parecido. Y ahora háblame de ti y de lo que estás pintando.
vi_translation: “My dear Basil, how would I know?” Dorian Gray muttered, sipping some pale gold wine from a delicate Venetian glass with golden bubbles, and looking very sad. “I was at the opera house. You should have been there. I met Harry's sister, Gwendolen, for the first time. We were in her box. She is extremely charming; and Patti sang wonderfully. Don't talk about dreadful subjects anymore. If we don't talk about something, it will never happen. Only words, as Harry says, bring reality to things. I can tell you that she is not the only child of that woman. There is a son, a charming fellow, I suppose. But he is not an actor. He is a sailor, I believe. And now tell me about yourself and what you are painting.”
tr_translation: Dorian grumbled, "Dear Basil, how should I know?" He was drinking a pale yellow wine from a thin glass made of Venetian glass, resembling golden essence, and he looked extremely bored. "I was at the opera. You should have come there. I met Harry's sister, Lady Gwendolen. We were in her box. A lady as sweet as sugar. Patti sang wonderfully. My dear, don't talk about painful subjects. If you don't talk about an event, it means it didn't happen. As Harry says, what gives events and situations reality is their being spoken about, directly. Let me also point out that the girl was not that woman's only child. She also has a son, a very charming young man, from what I've heard. But he is not an actor. He's a sailor or something, something like that. Anyway, now tell me about yourself, what are you drawing?"
es_translation: —My dear Basil, how do you expect me to know? —murmured Dorian Gray, taking a sip of pale white wine from a delicate Venetian crystal glass adorned with gold pearls, with an air of extreme boredom—. I was at the opera. You should have gone there. I met Lady Gwendolen, Harry's sister. We were in her box. She is absolutely charming; and Patti sang divinely. Don't talk about horrible things. It's enough not to talk about something for it to have never happened. As Harry says, the act of expressing things is what gives them reality. Though I might mention that she was not an only child. There is a male, an excellent boy, I believe. But he is not involved in the theater. He is a sailor or something like that. And now tell me about yourself and what you are painting.

en: “You went to the opera?” said Hallward, speaking very slowly and with a strained touch of pain in his voice. “You went to the opera while Sibyl Vane was lying dead in some sordid lodging? You can talk to me of other women being charming, and of Patti singing divinely, before the girl you loved has even the quiet of a grave to sleep in? Why, man, there are horrors in store for that little white body of hers!”
vi: “Cậu đến nhà hát ô-pê-ra?” Hallward nói, phát âm rất chậm, với chút đau đớn căng thẳng trong giọng. “Cậu đến nhà hát ô-pê-ra lúc Sibyl Vane đang nằm chết ở một nhà trọ bẩn thỉu nào đó? Cậu có thể nói với tôi về chuyện những cô gái khác khoe duyên, về việc Patti hát hay tuyệt trần, thậm chí trước khi cô gái cậu yêu có được sự tĩnh lặng của một nấm mồ để ngủ yên? Sao vậy, bạn ơi, có những sự ghê rợn chờ sẵn cái xác nhỏ trắng bợt ấy của cô ta!”
tr: “Operaya mı gittin?” diyen Basil Hallward’ın sesinde üzüntüden kaynaklanan bir gerginlik vardı. Tane tane konuşarak sordu: “Sibyl Vane pis bir pansiyon odasında ölü yatarken sen operaya gittin ha? Sevdiğin kız daha mezarın huzuruna bile kavuşmamışken sen bana başka kadınların şekerliğinden, Patti’nin şahane sesinden söz edebiliyorsun ha? Yahu, kızcağızın o minik beyaz gövdesini ne korkunç şeyler bekliyor, bilmiyor musun?
es: —Fuiste a la ópera —exclamó Hallward, hablando muy despacio, la voz estremecida por el dolor—. ¿Fuiste a la ópera mientras el cadáver de Sibyl Vane yacía en algún sórdido lugar? ¿Eres capaz de hablarme de lo encantadoras que son otras mujeres y de la maravillosa voz de la Patti, antes de que la muchacha a la que amabas disponga siquiera de la paz de un sepulcro donde descansar? ¿Acaso no sabes los horrores que aguardan a ese cuerpo suyo todavía tan blanco?
vi_translation: “You went to the opera house?” Hallward said, pronouncing very slowly, with a bit of painful tension in his voice. “You went to the opera house while Sibyl Vane was lying dead in some filthy lodging? You can talk to me about other girls flaunting their charms, about Patti singing wonderfully, even before the girl you loved had the peace of a grave to sleep in? Why, my friend, there are horrors awaiting that small, pale corpse of hers!”
tr_translation: “Did you go to the opera?” There was a tension in Basil Hallward's voice stemming from sadness. He asked, enunciating each word: “While Sibyl Vane lay dead in a filthy boarding house room, you went to the opera? While the girl you loved hasn't even found peace in her grave, you can talk to me about the sweetness of other women, about Patti’s magnificent voice? Man, don't you know what terrible things await that poor girl's tiny white body?”
es_translation: —You went to the opera —exclaimed Hallward, speaking very slowly, his voice trembling with pain—. Did you go to the opera while Sibyl Vane's corpse lay in some sordid place? Are you capable of talking to me about how charming other women are and the wonderful voice of Patti, before the girl you loved even has the peace of a grave to rest in? Do you not know the horrors that await her body, still so white?

en: “Stop, Basil! I won’t hear it!” cried Dorian, leaping to his feet. “You must not tell me about things. What is done is done. What is past is past.”
vi: “Thôi, Basil! Tôi sẽ không chịu1 được!” Dorian la lớn, đứng phắt dậy. “Anh không nên nói với tôi về các chuyện ấy nữa. Cái gì xong là xong. Cái gì đã qua là quá khứ.” 1 Một điểm tranh cãi ở bản thảo viết tay rất khó đọc của tác giả, nhiều bản in tiếng Anh cho rằng từ này là “hear/nghe.” Tuy nhiên, người dịch chọn phương án dịch theo “bear/chịu.”
tr: “Sus, Basil! Dinlemeyeceğim!” diye bağıran Dorian yerinden fırladı. “Anlatmayacaksın bana böyle şeyler. Olan olmuş. Geçmiş geçmiştir.
es: —¡Basta! ¡No estoy dispuesto a escucharlo! —exclamó Dorian, poniéndose en pie con brusquedad—. No me hables de esas cosas. Lo que está hecho, está hecho. Lo pasado, pasado está.
vi_translation: "Enough, Basil! I can't bear it any longer!" Dorian shouted, standing up abruptly. "You shouldn't talk to me about these things anymore. What's done is done. What's past is past." 1 One point of contention in the author's very hard-to-read handwritten manuscript is that many English prints suggest this word is “hear.” However, the translator chose the translation as “bear.”
tr_translation: “Stop, Basil! I won't listen!” shouted Dorian as he jumped up. “You won't tell me such things. What's done is done. The past is the past.”
es_translation: —Enough! I am not willing to listen to it! —exclaimed Dorian, standing up abruptly—. Do not talk to me about those things. What is done, is done. The past is the past.

en: “You call yesterday the past?”
vi: “Cậu gọi hôm qua là quá khứ?”
tr: “Sen düne geçmiş mi diyorsun?
es: —¿Al día de ayer le llamas el pasado?
vi_translation: “You call yesterday the past?”
tr_translation: “Are you saying that yesterday is in the past?”
es_translation: —Do you call yesterday the past?

en: “What has the actual lapse of time got to do with it? It is only shallow people who require years to get rid of an emotion. A man who is master of himself can end a sorrow as easily as he can invent a pleasure. I don’t want to be at the mercy of my emotions. I want to use them, to enjoy them, and to dominate them.”
vi: “Khoảng thời gian thực tế thì liên quan gì? Chỉ những kẻ nông cạn mới cần hàng năm để thoát khỏi một cảm xúc. Người nào là chủ nhân chính mình thì sẽ có thể chấm dứt nỗi đau một cách dễ dàng như y có thể sáng tạo ra một khoái lạc. Tôi không muốn phó mặc cho cảm xúc định đoạt. Tôi muốn sử dụng chúng, muốn tận hưởng chúng, muốn chi phối chúng.”
tr: “Aradan ne kadar zaman geçmiş olmasının ne önemi var? Ancak sığ kişiler bir duygudan kurtulabilmek için yıllarca beklerler.
