Kendi kendine söz geçirebilen bir kişi nasıl kolayca bir zevk icat edebilirse acısını da aynı kolaylıkla dindirebilir. Kendi duygularımın elinde oyuncak olmak istemiyorum ben. Duygularımı ben kullanmak istiyorum, onların tadını çıkarmak, onlara hükmetmek...
es: —¿Qué tiene que ver el lapso de tiempo transcurrido? Sólo las personas superficiales necesitan años para desechar una emoción. Un hombre que es dueño de sí mismo pone fin a un pesar tan fácilmente como inventa un placer. No quiero estar a merced de mis emociones. Quiero usarlas, disfrutarlas, dominarlas.
vi_translation: “What does actual time have to do with it? Only shallow people need years to get over an emotion. Someone who is the master of themselves can end their pain as easily as they can create a pleasure. I do not want to let emotions decide my fate. I want to use them, to enjoy them, to control them.”
tr_translation: “What does it matter how much time has passed? Only shallow people wait for years to get over a feeling. A person who can control themselves can soothe their pain just as easily as they can invent a pleasure. I don't want to be a toy in the hands of my own emotions. I want to use my emotions, enjoy them, dominate them...”
es_translation: —What does the elapsed time have to do with it? Only superficial people need years to discard an emotion. A man who is master of himself ends a sorrow as easily as he invents a pleasure. I do not want to be at the mercy of my emotions. I want to use them, enjoy them, dominate them.

en: “Dorian, this is horrible! Something has changed you completely. You look exactly the same wonderful boy who, day after day, used to come down to my studio to sit for his picture. But you were simple, natural, and affectionate then. You were the most unspoiled creature in the whole world. Now, I don’t know what has come over you. You talk as if you had no heart, no pity in you. It is all Harry’s influence. I see that.”
vi: “Dorian, điều này thật kinh khủng! Có gì đó đã thay đổi cậu hoàn toàn. Trông cậu vẫn đúng là cậu trai ấy, một cậu trai tuyệt vời, ngày lại ngày, vẫn xuống xưởng vẽ của tôi để ngồi làm mẫu cho bức tranh về mình. Nhưng hồi ấy cậu giản dị, tự nhiên, tình cảm. Cậu từng là tạo vật trinh bạch nhất trên cả cõi đời này. Bây giờ tôi không biết cái gì đã tác động lên cậu. Cậu nói như thể cậu không có tim, không có lòng trắc ẩn trong mình. Tất cả do ảnh hưởng của Harry. Tôi thấy thế.”
tr: “Dorian, çok korkunç bu! Bir şey seni temelden değiştirmiş. Görünüm olarak gene her gün stüdyoma gelip portresi için poz veren o harika çocuksun. Ama o zaman karmaşasız, doğal, sevgi doluydun. Dünyanın en bozulmamış yaratığıydın. Oysa şimdi sana ne olmuş, bilemiyorum. Kalpsiz, acımasızmışsın gibi konuşuyorsun. Hep Harry’nin etkisi bunlar. Bu kadarını görebiliyorum.
es: —¡Eso que dices es horrible, Dorian! Algo te ha cambiado completamente. Sigues teniendo el mismo aspecto que el maravilloso muchacho que, día tras día, venía a mi estudio para posar. Pero entonces eras una persona sencilla, espontánea y afectuosa. Eras la criatura más íntegra de la tierra. Ahora, no sé qué es lo que te ha sucedido. Hablas como si no tuvieras corazón, como si fueras incapaz de compadecerte. Es la influencia de Harry. Lo veo con toda claridad.
vi_translation: “Dorian, this is terrible! Something has completely changed you. You still look like that same boy, a wonderful boy, who day after day, came down to my studio to sit as a model for the painting of yourself. But back then you were simple, natural, affectionate. You used to be the purest creature in the whole world. Now I don't know what has influenced you. You speak as if you have no heart, no compassion within you. It's all due to Harry's influence. That's what I think.”
tr_translation: “Dorian, this is so terrible! Something has fundamentally changed you. In appearance, you are still that wonderful boy who comes to my studio every day to pose for his portrait. But back then, you were uncomplicated, natural, and full of love. You were the most unspoiled creature in the world. But now, I don't know what has happened to you. You speak as if you are heartless and cruel. It's all Harry's influence. That's all I can see.”
es_translation: —What you say is horrible, Dorian! Something has completely changed you. You still look like the wonderful young man who, day after day, came to my studio to pose. But then you were a simple, spontaneous, and affectionate person. You were the most honest creature on earth. Now, I don't know what has happened to you. You speak as if you have no heart, as if you are incapable of compassion. It's Harry's influence. I see it all too clearly.

en: The lad flushed up and, going to the window, looked out for a few moments on the green, flickering, sun-lashed garden. “I owe a great deal to Harry, Basil,” he said at last, “more than I owe to you. You only taught me to be vain.”
vi: Chàng trai đỏ mặt lên, và, lại gần cửa sổ, nhìn ra ngoài vài phút vào thảm cỏ xanh và khu vườn lung linh nắng tạt. “Tôi nợ Harry nhiều lắm, Basil,” cuối cùng cậu nói, — “nhiều hơn tôi nợ anh. Anh chỉ dạy tôi thành kiêu ngạo.”
tr: Çocuk kıpkırmızı kesildi, camlı kapıya yürüyerek bir an dışarıdaki güneş ışınlarının kamçıladığı, yanıp dönen yeşil bahçeye baktı. Sonunda, “Ben Harry’ye çok şey borçluyum, Basil,” dedi. “Sana borçlu olduğumdan daha çok. Sen bana yalnızca kibirli olmayı öğrettin.
es: El muchacho enrojeció y, llegándose hasta la ventana, contempló durante unos instantes el verdor fulgurante del jardín, bañado de sol. —Es mucho lo que le debo a Harry—dijo por fin—; más de lo que te debo a ti. Tú sólo me enseñaste a ser vanidoso.
vi_translation: The young man blushed, and, approaching the window, looked outside for a few minutes at the green lawn and the garden shimmering in the sunlight. “I owe Harry a lot, Basil,” he finally said, — “more than I owe you. You only taught me to be arrogant.”
tr_translation: The child turned bright red, walked to the glass door, and for a moment looked at the green garden outside, which was whipped by the sun's rays, burning and swirling. Finally, he said, "I owe Harry a lot, Basil." "More than I owe you. You only taught me to be arrogant."
es_translation: The boy blushed and, approaching the window, gazed for a few moments at the brilliant green of the garden, bathed in sunlight. —I owe a lot to Harry—he finally said—; more than I owe to you. You only taught me to be vain.

en: “Well, I am punished for that, Dorian—or shall be some day.”
vi: “Thế đấy, tôi đã bị trừng phạt vì việc ấy, Dorian — hoặc ngày nào đó sẽ bị.”
tr: “Evet, bu yüzden de cezalandırıldım Dorian ya da günün birinde cezalandırılacağım.
es: —Sin duda estoy siendo castigado por ello; o lo seré algún día.
vi_translation: "That's it, I have been punished for that, Dorian — or someday will be."
tr_translation: “Yes, that's why I was punished, Dorian, or one day I will be punished.”
es_translation: —No doubt I am being punished for it; or I will be someday.

en: “I don’t know what you mean, Basil,” he exclaimed, turning round. “I don’t know what you want. What do you want?”
vi: “Tôi không hiểu anh muốn nói gì, Basil,” cậu kêu lên, quay lại. “Tôi không hiểu anh muốn gì. Anh muốn gì?”
tr: Dorian, “Anlamıyorum, ne demek istiyorsun, Basil?” diye çekinerek döndü. “Ne istediğini de bilmiyorum. Ne istiyorsun?
es: —No entiendo lo que dices, Basil —exclamó Dorian Gray, volviéndose—. Tampoco sé lo que quieres. ¿Qué es lo que quieres?
vi_translation: "I don't understand what you mean, Basil," he exclaimed, turning around. "I don't understand what you want. What do you want?"
tr_translation: Dorian turned hesitantly, "I don't understand, what do you mean, Basil?" "I don't know what you want either. What do you want?"
es_translation: —I don't understand what you're saying, Basil —exclaimed Dorian Gray, turning around—. I also don't know what you want. What is it that you want?

en: “I want the Dorian Gray I used to paint,” said the artist sadly.
vi: “Tôi muốn Dorian Gray mà tôi từng vẽ,” nghệ sỹ nói, buồn bã.
tr: Ressam, “Resmini çizdiğim o Dorian Gray’i istiyorum,” diye üzüntüyle yanıtladı.
es: —Quiero al Dorian Gray cuyo retrato pinté en otro tiempo —dijo el artista con tristeza.
vi_translation: "I want the Dorian Gray that I once painted," the artist said sadly.
tr_translation: The painter replied sorrowfully, "I want the Dorian Gray I painted in that picture."
es_translation: "I want the Dorian Gray whose portrait I painted long ago," said the artist sadly.

en: “Basil,” said the lad, going over to him and putting his hand on his shoulder, “you have come too late. Yesterday, when I heard that Sibyl Vane had killed herself—”
vi: “Basil,” chàng trai nói, lại gần y, đặt tay mình lên vai y. “Anh đã đến quá muộn. Hôm qua, khi tôi được nghe là Sibyl Vane đã tự sát…”
tr: Delikanlı gidip elini onun omzuna koyarak, “Basil, çok geç kaldın,” dedi. “Dün Sibyl Vane’in kendini öldürdüğünü duyduğum zaman...
es: —Basil —dijo el muchacho, acercándose a él, y poniéndole la mano en el hombro—, has llegado demasiado tarde. Ayer, cuando oí que Sibyl Vane se había quitado la vida...
vi_translation: "Basil," the young man said, approaching him, placing his hand on his shoulder. "You have come too late. Yesterday, when I heard that Sibyl Vane had committed suicide..."
tr_translation: The young man went and put his hand on his shoulder, saying, "Basil, you are very late," he said. "When I heard yesterday that Sibyl Vane had killed herself..."
es_translation: —Basil —said the boy, approaching him and placing his hand on his shoulder—, you have arrived too late. Yesterday, when I heard that Sibyl Vane had taken her own life...

en: “Killed herself! Good heavens! is there no doubt about that?” cried Hallward, looking up at him with an expression of horror.
vi: “Tự sát! Trời ơi! Có chắc chắn về việc ấy không?” Hallward kêu lên, ngước nhìn cậu với vẻ sợ hãi.
tr: Basil Hallward, “Kendini mi öldürmüş? Aman Tanrım! Kesin mi bu?” diye hafifçe bağırarak, dehşet dolu bir yüzle gence baktı.
es: —¡Quitado la vida! ¡Cielo santo! ¿Se sabe a ciencia cierta? —exclamó Hallward, mirando horrorizado a su amigo.
vi_translation: “Suicide! Oh my God! Are you sure about that?” Hallward cried out, looking up at him with a fearful expression.
tr_translation: Basil Hallward, "Did he kill himself? Oh my God! Is it certain?" he exclaimed softly, looking at the young man with a face full of horror.
es_translation: —Taken his life! Good heavens! Is it known for certain? —exclaimed Hallward, looking horrified at his friend.

en: “My dear Basil! Surely you don’t think it was a vulgar accident? Of course she killed herself.”
vi: “Basil thân mến của tôi! Chắc anh không nghĩ đó là một vụ tai nạn tầm thường chứ? Dĩ nhiên cô ấy tự sát.
tr: “Azizim Basil! Bunu adi bir kaza sanmıyorsun ya, herhalde? Elbet kendini öldürdü.
es: —¡Mi querido Basil! ¿No pensarás que ha sido un vulgar accidente? Por supuesto que se ha suicidado.
vi_translation: “My dear Basil! Surely you don't think it was a mere accident? Of course, she committed suicide.”
tr_translation: "My dear Basil! Surely you don't think this was just an ordinary accident, do you? Of course, he killed himself."
es_translation: —My dear Basil! You don't think it was a mere accident, do you? Of course he committed suicide.

en: The elder man buried his face in his hands. “How fearful,” he muttered, and a shudder ran through him.
vi: Người lớn hơn vùi mặt vào bàn tay. “Thật đáng sợ,” y lẩm bẩm, và một cơn rùng mình chạy suốt người y.
tr: Ressam yüzünü ellerine gömerek, “Ne korkunç!” diye söylendi; bütün bedeninde bir ürperti dolaştı.
es: El hombre de más edad se cubrió la cara con las manos. —Qué cosa tan terrible —murmuró, el cuerpo entero sacudido por un estremecimiento.
vi_translation: The older person buried their face in their hands. "It's really scary," they muttered, and a shiver ran through their body.
tr_translation: Burying his face in his hands, the painter muttered, "How terrible!"; a shiver ran through his entire body.
es_translation: The oldest man covered his face with his hands. —What a terrible thing —he murmured, his whole body shaken by a tremor.

en: “No,” said Dorian Gray, “there is nothing fearful about it. It is one of the great romantic tragedies of the age. As a rule, people who act lead the most commonplace lives. They are good husbands, or faithful wives, or something tedious. You know what I mean—middle-class virtue and all that kind of thing. How different Sibyl was! She lived her finest tragedy. She was always a heroine. The last night she played—the night you saw her—she acted badly because she had known the reality of love. When she knew its unreality, she died, as Juliet might have died. She passed again into the sphere of art. There is something of the martyr about her. Her death has all the pathetic uselessness of martyrdom, all its wasted beauty. But, as I was saying, you must not think I have not suffered. If you had come in yesterday at a particular moment—about half-past five, perhaps, or a quarter to six—you would have found me in tears. Even Harry, who was here, who brought me the news, in fact, had no idea what I was going through. I suffered immensely. Then it passed away. I cannot repeat an emotion. No one can, except sentimentalists. And you are awfully unjust, Basil. You come down here to console me. That is charming of you. You find me consoled, and you are furious. How like a sympathetic person! You remind me of a story Harry told me about a certain philanthropist who spent twenty years of his life in trying to get some grievance redressed, or some unjust law altered—I forget exactly what it was. Finally he succeeded, and nothing could exceed his disappointment. He had absolutely nothing to do, almost died of ennui, and became a confirmed misanthrope. And besides, my dear old Basil, if you really want to console me, teach me rather to forget what has happened, or to see it from a proper artistic point of view. Was it not Gautier who used to write about la consolation des arts? I remember picking up a little vellum-covered book in your studio one day and chancing on that delightful phrase. Well, I am not like that young man you told me of when we were down at Marlow together, the young man who used to say that yellow satin could console one for all the miseries of life. I love beautiful things that one can touch and handle. Old brocades, green bronzes, lacquer-work, carved ivories, exquisite surroundings, luxury, pomp—there is much to be got from all these. But the artistic temperament that they create, or at any rate reveal, is still more to me. To become the spectator of one’s own life, as Harry says, is to escape the suffering of life. I know you are surprised at my talking to you like this. You have not realized how I have developed. I was a schoolboy when you knew me. I am a man now. I have new passions, new thoughts, new ideas. I am different, but you must not like me less. I am changed, but you must always be my friend. Of course, I am very fond of Harry. But I know that you are better than he is. You are not stronger—you are too much afraid of life—but you are better. And how happy we used to be together! Don’t leave me, Basil, and don’t quarrel with me. I am what I am. There is nothing more to be said.”
vi: “Không,” Dorian Gray nói, “Chẳng có gì đáng sợ ở đây. Nó là một trong những bi kịch lãng mạn lớn nhất thời đại. Như một quy luật, những người diễn kịch phải sống những cuộc đời tầm thường nhất. Họ là chồng tốt, vợ ngoan, hoặc thứ gì đó nhạt nhẽo. Anh hiểu điều tôi muốn nói chứ — đức hạnh của tầng lớp trung lưu, và mọi thứ kiểu ấy. Sibyl đã khác biệt làm sao! Nàng sống bi kịch đẹp nhất của mình. Nàng luôn là nhân vật nữ chính. Đêm cuối nàng đóng — cái đêm anh xem nàng — nàng diễn tệ vì nàng đã biết đến ái tình thực sự. Khi nàng hiểu ra sự phi thực của nó, nàng chết, như Juliet có lẽ đã chết. Nàng lại chuyển sang một thiên cầu nghệ thuật. Ở nàng có gì đó thuộc về kẻ tử vì đạo. Cái chết của nàng có mọi tính vô ích đáng thương của sự tử vì đạo, mọi vẻ đẹp vô giá trị của nó. Nhưng, như tôi đã nói, anh không nên nghĩ tôi không đau khổ. Nếu anh có đến đây hôm qua vào đúng một thời điểm đặc biệt — độ năm rưỡi, có lẽ, hoặc sáu giờ kém mười lăm — chắc anh sẽ thấy tôi đang khóc. Thậm chí Harry, người lúc ấy ở đây, người đã đưa tin cho tôi, trên thực tế cũng không hình dung được những gì tôi phải trải qua. Tôi đau khổ vô cùng. Rồi nó cũng qua đi. Tôi không thể lặp lại một cảm xúc. Không ai có thể, ngoài những kẻ đa cảm. Và anh rất không công bằng, Basil. Anh xuống đây để an ủi tôi. Đó là nét duyên của anh. Anh thấy tôi đã được an ủi, và anh tức giận. Sao mà lại giống một người đồng cảm đến thế! Anh làm tôi nhớ lại câu chuyện mà Harry kể cho tôi nghe về một kẻ nhân đức nào đó đã bỏ hai mươi năm đời mình ra để cố gắng nhận được một ít đền bù khiếu nại, hoặc để luật lệ bất công nào đó được sửa đổi — tôi quên mất đích xác nó là gì rồi. Rốt cuộc y cũng thành công, và không có gì có thể vượt qua được sự thất vọng của y. Y hoàn toàn chẳng còn việc gì để làm, gần như chết vì chán nản, và trở thành một kẻ yếm thế kinh niên. Ngoài ra, bạn già Basil thân mến của tôi, nếu anh thật sự muốn an ủi tôi, thì thà là hãy dạy tôi quên những gì đã xảy ra, hoặc thấy chúng trên quan điểm nghệ thuật đích thực còn hơn. Có phải Gautier là người từng viết về la consolation des arts1 không nhỉ? Tôi nhớ là đã vớ được một cuốn sách nhỏ bìa giấy da bê trong xưởng vẽ của anh hôm nọ và tình cờ thấy cụm từ thú vị ấy. Quả thật, tôi không còn giống chàng thanh niên mà anh kể cho tôi khi ta xuống Marlow cùng nhau, chàng thành niên hay nói rằng xa-tanh vàng có thể an ủi ta trước mọi khổ đau của cuộc đời. Tôi yêu những thứ xinh xinh mà ta có thể sờ và cầm. Gấm thêu cổ, đồ đồng xanh, tác phẩm sơn mài, chế phẩm chạm ngà voi, những vật dụng tuyệt đẹp chung quanh, sự xa xỉ, sự phù hoa, rất lắm thứ có thể kiếm được từ tất cả các món này. Nhưng tính nghệ sỹ mà chúng tạo được, hoặc để lộ ra, dẫu ở mức độ nào, còn đáng giá hơn với tôi. Trở thành khán giả của đời mình, như Harry nói, là thoát khỏi khổ đau của cuộc đời. Tôi biết anh ngạc nhiên trước việc tôi nói với anh như thế này. Anh không phát hiện ra là tôi đã phát triển thế nào. Tôi từng là một nam sinh khi anh biết tôi. Giờ đây tôi đã là một người đàn ông. Tôi có những niềm đam mê mới, những tư tưởng mới, những ý niệm mới. Tôi đã khác, nhưng anh không được yêu tôi ít đi. Tôi đã thay đổi, nhưng anh phải luôn là bạn tôi. Dĩ nhiên tôi rất mến Harry. Nhưng tôi biết là anh tốt hơn anh ấy. Anh không mạnh mẽ — anh quá sợ đời — nhưng anh tốt hơn. Và ta đã từng hạnh phúc biết bao bên nhau! Đừng bỏ tôi, Basil, và đừng cãi tôi. Tôi là thế nào thì vẫn thế. Chẳng còn gì nữa để nói.”
tr: “Hayır,” dedi Dorian Gray. “Hiçbir korkunçluk yok bunda. Çağın en büyük romantik trajedilerinden biri bu. Genelde tiyatro oyuncuları son derece beylik bir yaşam sürerler. İyi koca, sadık eş ya da buna benzer iç sıkıcı bir şeyler olurlar işte. Anlıyorsun ne demek istediğimi, orta sınıf ahlakı, falan filan. Oysa Sibyl nasıl da bambaşkaydı! En güzel trajedisini oynamadı, yaşadı. Hep bir romantizm kahramanı oldu o. Sahneye çıktığı o son gecede... Senin onu gördüğün gece... Kötü oynadı çünkü aşkın gerçeğini öğrenmiş bulunuyordu. Bu gerçeğin gerçek olmadığını öğrenince de öldü: Tıpkı Juliet’in ölmüş olabileceği gibi. Gene sanat ortamına döndü. Bir ermiş yönü de var Sibyl’in. Ölümünde ermiş ölümlerinin olanca iç burkan boşunalığı var, boşa gitmiş güzelliği. Ama dediğim gibi, acı çekmedim sanma. Dün bir saatte buraya gelmiş olsaydın... Saat beş buçuk, altıya çeyrek kala gibi... Beni gözyaşlarına boğulmuş bulacaktın. Buraya gelen, daha doğrusu bana haberi getiren Harry bile sezemedi benim neler hissettiğimi. Müthiş acı çektim. Sonra geçti. Bir duyguyu yineleyemem ya. Kimse yapamaz bunu, duygusallar dışında. Hem sen bana çok haksızlık ediyorsun, Basil. Beni avutmak için geldin buraya. Çok tatlısın. Ama bakıyorsun ki ben avunmuşum bile. Küplere biniyorsun. Tipik ‘anlayışlı insan’ işte! Harry’nin anlattığı bir öyküyü getiriyorsun aklıma. Hayır işlerine kendini adamış bir adam ömrünün yirmi yılında bir haksızlığı gidermek için uğraşmış ya da eşitsiz bir yasayı düzeltmek mi yoksa, unutmuşum. Her neyse, sonunda başarmış ama bundan daha büyük bir hayal kırıklığına uğrayamazmış. Çünkü yapacak zırnık işi kalmamış, can sıkıntısından öleyazmış ve yeminli bir halk düşmanı olup çıkmış. Hem zaten, azizim Basil, beni gerçekten avutmak istiyorsan, olup bitenleri bana unutturmaya çalışsana ya da olayı sanatsal yönden doğru olarak göstermeye! La consolation des arts üstüne yazılar yazan Gautier değil miydi? Hatırlıyorum da günün birinde senin stüdyonda küçük bir parşömen kaplı kitap elime geçmişti, sayfaları karıştırırken bu nefis tümce çarpmıştı gözüme. Her neyse, hani birlikte Marlow’a gittiğimizde bana bir gençten söz etmiştin: Sarı saten hayatın bütün mutsuzluklarını avutur, dermiş ya, ben onun gibi değilim. Elle dokunulacak, tutulacak, güzel şeyleri seviyorum. Antika brokarlar, yeşil bronzlar, lake işleri, fildişi oymalar, güzel yerler, lüks, debdebe... Bunların insana verebileceği çok şey var. Ama bunların yarattığı, hiç değilse ortaya çıkardığı sanatçı ruh, benim için hepsinden önemli. Harry’nin dediği gibi, kendi yaşantımızın seyircisi durumuna gelirsek hayatın sıkıntılarından kurtulmuş oluruz. Biliyorum, benim böyle konuşmam şaşırttı seni. Ne denli gelişmiş olduğumun ayırdında değildin ki! Sen beni tanıdığında ben bir liseli çocuktum. Şimdi erkek oldum. Yeni duygularım, yeni düşüncelerim, yeni görüşlerim var. Eskisinden başkayım ama sen beni sakın daha az sevme. Değiştim ama sen benim her zaman dostum olmalısın. Harry’yi çok seviyorum, tabii. Gene de senin ondan daha iyi bir insan olduğunu bilmiyor değilim. Daha güçlü olduğunu söyleyemem... Hayattan aşırı korkuyorsun... Gene de daha iyi bir insansın. Birlikte ne mutlu günler geçirirdik! Beni bırakma, Basil, ama beni kınamanı da istemiyorum. Neysem oyum ben. Başkaca diyecek bir şey yok.
es: —No —dijo Dorian Gray—; no tiene nada de terrible. Es una de las grandes tragedias románticas de nuestra época. Por regla general, los actores llevan una vida bien corriente. Son buenos maridos, o esposas fieles, o algo igualmente tedioso. Ya sabes a qué me refiero, virtudes de la clase media y todas esas cosas. ¡Qué diferente era Sibyl, que ha vivido su mejor tragedia! Fue siempre una heroína. La última noche que actuó, la noche en que tú la viste, su interpretación fue mala porque había conocido la realidad del amor. Cuando conoció su irrealidad, murió, como podría haber muerto Julieta. Volvió de nuevo a la esfera del arte. Había algo de mártir en ella. Su muerte tiene toda la patética inutilidad del martirio, toda su belleza desperdiciada. Pero, como iba diciendo, no debes pensar que no he sufrido. Si hubieras venido ayer en cierto momento, hacia las cinco y media, quizá, o las seis menos cuarto, me habrías encontrado llorando. Incluso Harry, que estaba aquí y fue quien me trajo la noticia, no se dio cuenta de lo que me sucedía. Sufrí inmensamente. Luego el sufrimiento acabó. No puedo repetir una emoción. Nadie puede, excepto las personas sentimentales. Y tú eres terriblemente injusto, Basil. Vienes aquí a consolarme. Es muy de agradecer. Me encuentras consolado y te enfureces. ¡Bien por las personas compasivas! Me haces pensar en una historia que me contó Harry acerca de cierto filántropo que se pasó veinte años tratando de rectificar un agravio o de cambiar una ley injusta, no recuerdo exactamente de qué se trataba. Finalmente lo consiguió, y su decepción fue inmensa. Como no tenía absolutamente nada que hacer, casi se murió de ennui, convirtiéndose en un perfecto misántropo. Y además, mi querido Basil, si realmente quieres consolarme, enséñame más bien a olvidar lo que ha sucedido o a verlo desde el ángulo artístico más conveniente. ¿No era Gautier quien hablaba sobre la consolafon des arts? Recuerdo haber encontrado un día en tu estudio un librito con tapas de vitela en el que descubrí por casualidad esa frase deliciosa. Bien, no soy como el joven de quien me hablaste cuando estuvimos juntos en Marlow, el joven para quien el satén amarillo podía consolar a cualquiera de todas las tristezas de la vida. Me gustan las cosas hermosas que se pueden tocar y utilizar. Brocados antiguos, bronces con cardenillo, objetos lacados, marfiles tallados, ambientes exquisitos, lujo, pompa: es mucho lo que se puede disfrutar con todas esas cosas. Pero el temperamento artístico que crean, o que al menos revelan, tiene todavía más importancia para mí. Convertirse en el espectador de la propia vida, como dice Harry, es escapar a sus sufrimientos. Ya sé que te sorprende que te hable de esta manera. No te has dado cuenta de cómo he madurado. No era más que un colegial cuando me conociste. Soy un hombre ya. Tengo nuevas pasiones, nuevos pensamientos, nuevas ideas. Soy diferente, pero no debes tenerme menos afecto. He cambiado, pero tú serás siempre mi amigo. Es cierto que a Harry le tengo mucho cariño. Pero sé que tú eres mejor. Menos fuerte, porque le tienes demasiado miedo a la vida, pero mejor. Y, ¡qué felices éramos cuando estábamos juntos! No me dejes, Basil, ni te pelees conmigo. Soy lo que soy. No hay nada más que decir.
vi_translation: “No,” Dorian Gray said, “There is nothing to be afraid of here. It is one of the greatest romantic tragedies of the age. As a rule, actors live the most mundane lives. They are good husbands, dutiful wives, or something equally dull. You understand what I mean — the virtues of the middle class, and all that sort of thing. How different Sibyl was! She lived her finest tragedy. She was always the heroine. The last night she acted — the night you saw her — she performed poorly because she had known real love. When she realized the unreality of it, she died, as Juliet might have died. She passed into the sphere of art once more. There was something of the martyr about her. Her death had all the pathetic uselessness of martyrdom, all its wasted beauty. But, as I said, you must not think I am heartless. If you had come here yesterday at a particular moment — around half-past five, perhaps, or a quarter to six — you would have found me weeping. Even Harry, who was here at the time, who brought me the news, could not really understand what I went through. I suffered immensely. Then it passed away. I cannot repeat an emotion. No one can, except sentimentalists. And you are very unfair, Basil. You come down here to console me. That is your charm. You find me consoled, and you are furious. How like a sympathetic person! You remind me of a story Harry told me about a charitable man who spent twenty years of his life trying to get some grievance redressed, or some unjust law altered — I forget exactly what it was. In the end, he succeeded, and nothing could exceed his disappointment. He had absolutely nothing to do, almost died of ennui, and became a confirmed misanthrope. Besides, my dear old Basil, if you really want to console me, teach me to forget what has happened, or to see it from the proper artistic point of view. Was it not Gautier who used to write about la consolation des arts? I remember picking up a little vellum-covered book in your studio the other day and chancing upon that delightful phrase. Indeed, I am not the same person who told you that satin could console one for all the miseries of life when we were down at Marlow together. I love beautiful things that one can touch and handle. Old brocades, green bronzes, lacquer-work, carved ivories, exquisite surroundings, luxury, pomp — there is much to be got from all these. But the artistic temperament they create, or at any rate reveal, is more to me than all these. To become the spectator of one's own life, as Harry says, is to escape the suffering of life. I know you are surprised at my talking to you like this. You have not realized how I have developed. I was a schoolboy when you knew me. Now I am a man. I have new passions, new thoughts, new ideas. I am different, but you must not love me less. I have changed, but you must always be my friend. Of course I am very fond of Harry. But I know you are better than he is. You are not strong — you are too afraid of life — but you are better. And how happy we used to be together! Don't leave me, Basil, and don't quarrel with me. I am what I am. There is nothing more to be said.”
tr_translation: “No,” said Dorian Gray. “There is nothing terrible in this. It is one of the greatest romantic tragedies of the age. Generally, theater actors lead extremely stereotypical lives. They become good husbands, faithful wives, or something similarly tedious. You understand what I mean, middle-class morality, and all that. But how different Sibyl was! She didn’t just act out her greatest tragedy, she lived it. She was always a romantic hero. On that last night she went on stage...The night you saw her...She acted poorly because she had learned the reality of love. And when she learned that this reality wasn’t real, she died: Just as Juliet might have died. She returned to the realm of art. Sibyl has a saintly aspect too. In her death, there is all the heartbreaking futility of saintly deaths, the wasted beauty. But as I said, don’t think I didn’t suffer. If you had come here an hour earlier yesterday...Around half-past five, a quarter to six...You would have found me drowned in tears. Even Harry, who came here, or rather brought me the news, couldn’t perceive what I was feeling. I suffered immensely. Then it passed. I can’t repeat an emotion. Nobody can do that, except the sentimental. And you are being very unfair to me, Basil. You came here to console me. You are very sweet. But you see that I am already consoled. You are furious. Typical ‘understanding person’! You remind me of a story Harry told. A man who dedicated himself to charity spent twenty years trying to right a wrong or correct an unjust law, I forget which. Anyway, he finally succeeded but couldn’t have been more disappointed. Because he had nothing left to do, he nearly died of boredom and became a sworn enemy of the people. And besides, dear Basil, if you really want to console me, try to make me forget what happened or show the event to me from an artistic perspective! Wasn’t it Gautier who wrote about the consolation of the arts? I remember one day in your studio, a small parchment-covered book fell into my hands, and as I flipped through the pages, this exquisite sentence caught my eye. Anyway, when we went to Marlow together, you told me about a young man: Yellow satin soothes all the sorrows of life, he said, but I am not like him. I love tangible, touchable, beautiful things. Antique brocades, green bronzes, lacquer works, ivory carvings, beautiful places, luxury, splendor...These things have much to offer a person. But the artistic spirit they create, or at least bring out, is the most important to me. As Harry says, if we become spectators of our own lives, we will be freed from life’s troubles. I know, my talking like this surprises you. You weren’t aware of how much I had developed! When you met me, I was a schoolboy. Now I am a man. I have new feelings, new thoughts, new perspectives. I am different from before, but don’t love me any less. I have changed, but you must always be my friend. I love Harry very much, of course. But I am not unaware that you are a better person than he is. I can’t say you are stronger...You are excessively afraid of life...But you are still a better person. We would have such happy days together! Don’t leave me, Basil, but I don’t want you to judge me either. I am what I am. There is nothing more to say.”
es_translation: —No —said Dorian Gray—; there is nothing terrible about it. It is one of the great romantic tragedies of our time. Generally, actors lead quite ordinary lives. They are good husbands, or faithful wives, or something equally tedious. You know what I mean, middle-class virtues and all that sort of thing. How different was Sibyl, who lived her greatest tragedy! She was always a heroine. The last night she acted, the night you saw her, her performance was bad because she had discovered the reality of love. When she realized its unreality, she died, as Juliet might have died. She returned once more to the sphere of art. There was something of the martyr about her. Her death has all the pathetic uselessness of martyrdom, all its wasted beauty. But, as I was saying, you must not think that I have not suffered. If you had come yesterday at a certain moment, around half-past five, perhaps, or a quarter to six, you would have found me weeping. Even Harry, who was here and brought me the news, did not realize what was happening to me. I suffered immensely. Then the suffering ended. I cannot repeat an emotion. No one can, except sentimental people. And you are terribly unjust, Basil. You come here to console me. It is very much appreciated. You find me consoled and you get furious. Bravo for compassionate people! You make me think of a story Harry told me about a certain philanthropist who spent twenty years trying to rectify a grievance or change an unjust law, I don't remember exactly what it was about. He finally succeeded, and his disappointment was immense. Having absolutely nothing to do, he almost died of ennui, becoming a perfect misanthrope. And besides, my dear Basil, if you really want to console me, teach me rather to forget what has happened or to see it from the most convenient artistic angle. Wasn't it Gautier who spoke about the consolation of the arts? I remember finding a little vellum-bound book in your studio one day where I discovered that delightful phrase by chance. Well, I am not like the young man you told me about when we were together in Marlow, the young man for whom yellow satin could console anyone for all the sorrows of life. I like beautiful things that can be touched and used. Old brocades, bronzes with patina, lacquered objects, carved ivories, exquisite surroundings, luxury, pomp: there is much to enjoy in all these things. But the artistic temperament they create, or at least reveal, is even more important to me. To become the spectator of one's own life, as Harry says, is to escape its sufferings. I know it surprises you that I speak to you this way. You have not realized how I have matured. I was only a schoolboy when you met me. I am a man now. I have new passions, new thoughts, new ideas. I am different, but you must not love me less. I have changed, but you will always be my friend. It is true that I am very fond of Harry. But I know you are better. Less strong, because you are too afraid of life, but better. And how happy we were when we were together! Don't leave me, Basil, nor quarrel with me. I am what I am. There is nothing more to say.

en: The painter felt strangely moved. The lad was infinitely dear to him, and his personality had been the great turning point in his art. He could not bear the idea of reproaching him any more. After all, his indifference was probably merely a mood that would pass away. There was so much in him that was good, so much in him that was noble.
vi: 1 Niềm an ủi trong nghệ thuật. Họa sỹ thấy cảm động kỳ lạ. Chàng trai đã vô cùng chân tình với y, và cá tính cậu đã là bước ngoặt vĩ đại trong nghệ thuật của y. Y không thể ôm ý định quở trách cậu thêm nữa. Rốt cuộc thì sự dửng dưng của cậu chắc có lẽ chỉ là một tâm trạng mà rồi sẽ mất đi. Ở cậu có quá nhiều thứ tốt đẹp, quá nhiều thứ cao quý.
tr: Ressamın içi bir tuhaf burkulmuştu. Bu çocuğu çok, pek çok seviyordu, onun kişiliği kendi sanatında önemli bir dönüm noktası olmuştu. Onu daha fazla azarlamak düşüncesine dayanamazdı. Dorian’ın benliğinde iyi olan, asil olan öyle çok şey vardı ki!
es: El pintor se sintió extrañamente emocionado. Apreciaba infinitamente a Dorian, y gracias a su personalidad su arte había dado un paso decisivo. No cabía seguir pensando en hacerle reproches. Tal vez su indiferencia fuese un estado de ánimo pasajero. ¡Había tanta bondad en él, tanta nobleza!
vi_translation: 1 A source of comfort in art. The artist felt strangely moved. The young man had been incredibly sincere with him, and his personality had been a great turning point in his art. He could no longer harbor the intention to scold him. After all, the young man's indifference was probably just a mood that would eventually pass. There were too many good things, too many noble qualities in him.
tr_translation: The painter's heart was strangely wrenched. He loved this child very, very much; his personality had been an important turning point in his own art. He could not bear the thought of scolding him any further. There were so many good, noble things in Dorian's being!
es_translation: The painter felt strangely moved. He infinitely appreciated Dorian, and thanks to his personality, his art had taken a decisive step forward. There was no point in thinking about reproaching him anymore. Perhaps his indifference was a passing mood. There was so much goodness in him, so much nobility!

en: “Well, Dorian,” he said at length, with a sad smile, “I won’t speak to you again about this horrible thing, after to-day. I only trust your name won’t be mentioned in connection with it. The inquest is to take place this afternoon. Have they summoned you?”
vi: “Thôi được, Dorian,” y nói, sau hết, với một nụ cười buồn, “tôi sẽ không nói với cậu lần nữa về sự việc kinh khủng này, sau hôm nay. Tôi chỉ mong là tên cậu sẽ không bị nhắc đến trong mối liên hệ với nó. Cuộc điều tra sẽ diễn ra chiều nay. Họ có triệu tập cậu chưa?”
tr: Sonunda Hallward buruk bir gülüşle, “Peki, Dorian,” dedi. “Bugünden sonra seninle bu acı konuyu hiç konuşmayacağım. Umarım olaya senin adın karışmaz. Sorgulama bugün öğleden sonra yapılacak. Seni çağırdılar mı?
es: —Bien, Dorian —dijo, finalmente, con una triste sonrisa—; a partir de hoy no volveré a hablarte de ese suceso tan terrible. Sólo deseo que tu nombre no se vea mezclado en un escándalo. La investigación judicial se celebra esta tarde. ¿Te han convocado?
vi_translation: “Alright, Dorian,” he said at last, with a sad smile, “I will not speak to you again about this dreadful matter after today. I just hope that your name will not be mentioned in connection with it. The investigation will take place this afternoon. Have they summoned you yet?”
tr_translation: Finally, with a bitter smile, Hallward said, "Alright, Dorian." "After today, I will never speak to you about this painful matter again. I hope your name does not get involved in the incident. The inquiry will be held this afternoon. Have they summoned you?"
es_translation: —Well, Dorian —he said, finally, with a sad smile—; from today onwards, I will not speak to you again about that terrible event. I only wish that your name is not involved in a scandal. The judicial investigation is being held this afternoon. Have you been summoned?

en: Dorian shook his head, and a look of annoyance passed over his face at the mention of the word “inquest.” There was something so crude and vulgar about everything of the kind. “They don’t know my name,” he answered.
vi: Dorian lắc đầu và một vẻ khó chịu lướt ngang mặt cậu khi nghe nhắc đến từ “cuộc điều tra.” Có gì đó thô bạo và tầm thường ở mọi thứ đại loại như vậy. “Họ không biết tên tôi,” cậu trả lời.
tr: Dorian başını salladı. Sorgulama lafını duyunca yüzünden bir hoşnutsuzluk gelip geçmişti. Bu gibi şeylerde öyle kaba, öyle bayağı bir yön vardı ki! “Adımı bilmiyorlar.
es: Dorian negó con la cabeza; y una expresión de fastidio pasó por su rostro al oír mencionar la palabra «investigación». Todo aquel asunto tenía algo de vulgar y de tosco. —No saben cómo me llamo —respondió.
vi_translation: Dorian shook his head, and a look of discomfort crossed his face at the mention of the word "investigation." There was something crude and vulgar about everything of that sort. "They don't know my name," he replied.
tr_translation: Dorian nodded. When he heard the word "interrogation," a look of displeasure crossed his face. There was something so crude, so vulgar about such matters! “They don't know my name.”
es_translation: Dorian shook his head; and an expression of annoyance crossed his face upon hearing the word "investigation" mentioned. The whole affair had something vulgar and coarse about it. —They don't know my name —he replied.

en: “But surely she did?”
vi: “Nhưng chắc cô ấy biết chứ?”
tr: “Ama Sibyl biliyordu herhalde, değil mi?
es: —¿Tampoco ella?
vi_translation: “But surely she knows, right?”
tr_translation: “But Sibyl knew, didn't she?”
es_translation: —Not her either?

en: “Only my Christian name, and that I am quite sure she never mentioned to any one. She told me once that they were all rather curious to learn who I was, and that she invariably told them my name was Prince Charming. It was pretty of her. You must do me a drawing of Sibyl, Basil. I should like to have something more of her than the memory of a few kisses and some broken pathetic words.”
vi: “Chỉ tên thánh của tôi thôi, và cái ấy thì tôi chắc chắn là nàng chẳng bao giờ nhắc đến với bất cứ ai. Nàng có lần bảo tôi rằng tất cả bọn họ khá tò mò muốn biết tôi là ai, và rằng nàng lúc nào cũng bảo họ rằng tên tôi là Hoàng tử Quyến rũ. Đó là sự dễ thương của nàng. Anh phải vẽ cho tôi một bức về Sibyl, Basil nhé. Tôi muốn có gì đó về nàng nhiều hơn ký ức về mấy nụ hôn và vài lời thống thiết đứt quãng.”
tr: “Yalnızca ilk adımı biliyordu, bunu da kimseye söylemediğinden eminim. Bir keresinde anlatmıştı: Herkes benim kim olduğumu merak ediyormuş, o da her seferinde adımın Tatlı Prens olduğunu söylüyormuş. Ne şeker değil mi? Bana Sibyl’in bir resmini çiz, Basil. Elimde ondan bir şey kalsın istiyorum, birkaç öpücüğün, kırık dökük birkaç sözün anısından öte.
es: —Sólo mi nombre de pila, y estoy seguro de que nunca se lo dijo a nadie. En una ocasión me contó que todos tenían una gran curiosidad por saber quién era yo, pero siempre les decía que era el Príncipe Azul. Una delicadeza por su parte. Has de hacerme un dibujo de Sibyl, Basil. Me gustaría tener algo más que el recuerdo de algunos besos y unas palabras entrecortadas llenas de patetismo.
vi_translation: “Only my Christian name, and that I am sure she never mentioned to anyone. She once told me that they were all quite curious to know who I was, and that she always told them my name was Prince Charming. That was her sweetness. You must paint me a picture of Sibyl, Basil. I want something of her more than the memory of a few kisses and some broken, pathetic words.”
tr_translation: “He only knew the first step, and I'm sure he didn't tell anyone about it. He mentioned once: Everyone was curious about who I was, and he always said my name was Sweet Prince. Isn't that sweet? Draw me a picture of Sibyl, Basil. I want to have something of her, more than just the memory of a few kisses and some broken words.”
es_translation: —Only my first name, and I'm sure she never told anyone. Once she told me that everyone was very curious to know who I was, but she always said I was Prince Charming. A kindness on her part. You must draw a picture of Sibyl for me, Basil. I would like to have more than just the memory of a few kisses and some broken words full of pathos.

en: “I will try and do something, Dorian, if it would please you. But you must come and sit to me yourself again. I can’t get on without you.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ cố thử làm gì đó, Dorian, nếu nó làm cậu vui. Nhưng chính cậu phải đến ngồi làm mẫu lại cho tôi. Tôi không thể làm tiếp nếu thiếu cậu.”
tr: “Bir şeyler yapmaya çalışırım, Dorian, mademki seni sevindirecek. Ama sen de gelip bana yeniden poz vereceksin. Sensiz çalışamıyorum.
es: —Trataré de hacer algo, Dorian, si eso te agrada. Pero tienes que venir y posar para mí de nuevo. Sin ti no hago nada que merezca la pena.
vi_translation: "I will try to do something, Dorian, if it makes you happy. But you must come and sit for me again. I can't continue without you."
tr_translation: “I will try to do something, Dorian, if it will make you happy. But you must come and pose for me again. I can't work without you.”
es_translation: —I will try to do something, Dorian, if that pleases you. But you have to come and pose for me again. Without you, I do nothing worthwhile.

en: “I can never sit to you again, Basil. It is impossible!” he exclaimed, starting back.
vi: “Tôi không bao giờ ngồi làm mẫu cho anh được nữa, Basil. Chuyện ấy không thể được!” cậu la lên, giật lùi lại.
tr: Delikanlı irkilerek, “Ben sana artık asla poz veremem, Basil!” dedi.
es: —Nunca volveré a posar para ti. ¡Es imposible! —exclamó Dorian, retrocediendo.
vi_translation: "I can never sit for you again, Basil. It's impossible!" he cried, drawing back.
tr_translation: The young man shuddered and said, "I can never pose for you again, Basil!"
es_translation: —I will never pose for you again. It's impossible! —exclaimed Dorian, stepping back.

en: The painter stared at him. “My dear boy, what nonsense!” he cried. “Do you mean to say you don’t like what I did of you? Where is it? Why have you pulled the screen in front of it? Let me look at it. It is the best thing I have ever done. Do take the screen away, Dorian. It is simply disgraceful of your servant hiding my work like that. I felt the room looked different as I came in.”
vi: Họa sỹ nhìn cậu chằm chằm. “Cậu bé thân yêu của tôi, vô lý thật!” y kêu lên. “Cậu định nói là cậu không thích cái mà tôi đã làm cho cậu? Nó đâu rồi? Sao cậu lại kéo tấm chắn ra trước nó? Hãy để tôi ngắm nó. Nó là cái đẹp nhất tôi từng làm được. Cất tấm chắn đi, Dorian. Gia nhân của cậu thật đáng xấu hổ khi che đậy tác phẩm của tôi như vậy. Tôi đã cảm thấy căn phòng này có vẻ khang khác từ lúc tôi vào.”
tr: Ressam ona bakakalmıştı. “Sevgili yavrum, saçmalama!” dedi. “Yani yaptığım portreni beğenmediğini mi söylemek istiyorsun? Nerede o? Neden paravan çektin önüne? İzin ver de bakayım. En güzel eserim bu. Kuzum, çek şu paravanı, Dorian. Uşağın benim eserimi böyle gözden gizliyorsa rezalet doğrusu. Tevekkeli değil oda gözüme bir başka göründü içeri girerken.
es: El pintor lo miró fijamente. —¡Mi querido Dorian, eso es una tontería! —exclamó—. ¿Quieres decir que no te gusta el retrato tuyo que pinté? ¿Dónde está? ¿Por qué has colocado ese biombo delante? Déjamelo ver. Es lo mejor que he hecho. Haz el favor de retirar el biombo, Dorian. Me parece vergonzoso que tu criado esconda mi retrato de esa manera. Ahora comprendo por qué la habitación me ha parecido distinta al entrar.
vi_translation: The artist stared at him intently. “My dear boy, how absurd!” he exclaimed. “Are you saying you don't like what I have done for you? Where is it? Why did you pull the screen in front of it? Let me see it. It is the best thing I have ever done. Take the screen away, Dorian. Your servant is shameful for covering my work like that. I felt that this room seemed different from the moment I entered.”
tr_translation: The painter stared at her. "My dear child, don't be ridiculous!" he said. "Are you saying that you don't like the portrait I made of you? Where is it? Why did you put a screen in front of it? Let me see it. This is my best work. My dear, move that screen, Dorian. It's a disgrace if the servant is hiding my work like this. No wonder the room looked different to me when I entered."
es_translation: The painter stared at him intently. —My dear Dorian, that's nonsense! —he exclaimed—. Do you mean to say you don't like the portrait I painted of you? Where is it? Why have you placed that screen in front of it? Let me see it. It's the best thing I've done. Please remove the screen, Dorian. I find it shameful that your servant hides my portrait in that manner. Now I understand why the room seemed different when I entered.

en: “My servant has nothing to do with it, Basil. You don’t imagine I let him arrange my room for me? He settles my flowers for me sometimes—that is all. No; I did it myself. The light was too strong on the portrait.”
vi: “Người hầu của tôi không làm gì với nó cả, Basil. Anh không nghĩ là tôi cho hắn sắp xếp lại phòng tôi cho tôi đấy chứ? Hắn thỉnh thoảng để hoa cho tôi — chỉ vậy thôi. Không; tôi tự làm đấy. Ánh sáng quá mạnh với bức chân dung.
tr: “Uşağımın ilişkisi yok bununla, Basil. Odamı onun düzenlemesine izin verdiğimi mi sanıyorsun! Arada çiçekleri yerleştirir, hepsi bu. Yok, ben yaptım bunu. Portrenin üstüne çok fazla ışık vuruyordu da.
es: —Mi criado no tiene nada que ver con eso. ¿No imaginarás que le dejo arreglar la biblioteca por mí? A veces coloca las flores..., eso es todo. No; soy yo quien lo ha hecho. La luz era demasiado fuerte para el retrato.
vi_translation: “My servant has nothing to do with it, Basil. You don't think I let him arrange my room for me, do you? He occasionally leaves flowers for me — that's all. No; I did it myself. The light is too strong for the portrait.”
tr_translation: “My child has no connection with this, Basil. Do you think I allowed him to arrange my room! He just places the flowers occasionally, that's all. No, I did this. There was too much light falling on the portrait.”
es_translation: —My servant has nothing to do with that. You wouldn't imagine that I let him arrange the library for me, would you? Sometimes he places the flowers... that's all. No; it was I who did it. The light was too strong for the portrait.

en: “Too strong! Surely not, my dear fellow? It is an admirable place for it. Let me see it.” And Hallward walked towards the corner of the room.
vi: “Quá mạnh? Chắc chắn là không, bạn ơi! Đây là một nơi tuyệt diệu cho nó. Hãy để tôi xem nó.” Và Hallward bước về phía góc phòng.
tr: “Çok fazla mı? Yanılıyorsun, dostum. Burası portre için uygun bir yer. Dur, bakayım,” diyerek Hallward resmin durduğu köşeye doğru ilerledi.
es: —¡Demasiado fuerte! No puede ser. Es un sitio admirable para ese cuadro. Déjamelo ver. Un grito de terror escapó de la boca de Dorian Gray, que corrió a situarse entre el pintor y el biombo.
vi_translation: “Too strong? Definitely not, my friend! This is a wonderful place for it. Let me see it.” And Hallward walked towards the corner of the room.
tr_translation: “Is it too much? You are mistaken, my friend. This is a suitable place for the portrait. Wait, let me see,” said Hallward as he moved towards the corner where the painting stood.
es_translation: —Too strong! It can't be. It's an admirable spot for that painting. Let me see it. A scream of terror escaped from the mouth of Dorian Gray, who ran to position himself between the painter and the screen.

en: A cry of terror broke from Dorian Gray’s lips, and he rushed between the painter and the screen. “Basil,” he said, looking very pale, “you must not look at it. I don’t wish you to.”
vi: Một tiếng hét kinh hãi bật ra khỏi môi Dorian Gray, và cậu lao vào giữa họa sỹ với tấm chắn. “Basil,” cậu nói, nhìn tái nhợt, “anh không nên nhìn nó. Tôi không muốn anh làm vậy.”
tr: Dorian Gray, dudaklarından dehşet dolu bir ünlem koparak atıldı, ressamla resmin arasına girdi. Sapsarı kesilmişti. “Basil, bakmamalısın, istemiyorum bakmanı,” dedi.
es: Un grito de terror escapó de la boca de Dorian Gray, que corrió a situarse entre el pintor y el biombo. —Basil —dijo, sumamente pálido—, no debes verlo. No quiero que lo veas.
vi_translation: A terrified scream escaped from Dorian Gray's lips, and he rushed between the painter and the shield. “Basil,” he said, looking pale, “you shouldn't have looked at it. I didn't want you to do that.”
tr_translation: Dorian Gray, with an exclamation of horror escaping from his lips, rushed forward and stood between the painter and the portrait. He had turned deathly pale. “Basil, you must not look at it. I don't want you to,” he said.
es_translation: A scream of terror escaped from the mouth of Dorian Gray, who ran to position himself between the painter and the screen. —Basil —he said, extremely pale—, you must not see it. I don't want you to see it.

en: “Not look at my own work! You are not serious. Why shouldn’t I look at it?” exclaimed Hallward, laughing.
vi: “Không nhìn tác phẩm của tôi! Cậu không nghiêm túc. Sao tôi lại không được nhìn nó?” Hallward la lên, bật cười.
tr: Hallward gülerek, “Kendi yaptığım resme bakmayacak mıyım yani? Ciddi olamazsın!” dedi. “Neden bakmayacakmışım?
es: —¡Que no vea mi propia obra! No hablas en serio. ¿Por qué tendría que no verlo? —preguntó Hallward, riendo.
vi_translation: "Don't look at my work! You're not serious. Why can't I look at it?" Hallward exclaimed, laughing.
tr_translation: Hallward laughed, "Am I not going to look at the painting I made myself? You can't be serious!" he said. "Why wouldn't I look at it?"
es_translation: —I must not see my own work! You're not serious. Why shouldn't I see it? —asked Hallward, laughing.

en: “If you try to look at it, Basil, on my word of honour I will never speak to you again as long as I live. I am quite serious. I don’t offer any explanation, and you are not to ask for any. But, remember, if you touch this screen, everything is over between us.”
vi: “Nếu anh cố nhìn nó, Basil, xin thề danh dự là tôi sẽ không bao giờ nói chuyện lại với anh chừng nào tôi còn sống. Tôi hoàn toàn nghiêm túc. Tôi không đưa ra bất cứ lời thanh minh nào, và anh đừng yêu cầu bất cứ lời nào. Nhưng, hãy nhớ, nếu anh đụng vào tấm chắn này, mọi chuyện chấm dứt giữa chúng ta.”
tr: “Basil, bakmaya kalkışırsan, şerefim üstüne yemin ederim ki seninle bir daha ömür boyu konuşmam. Çok ciddiyim. Hiçbir neden göstermiyorum, sen de sormayacaksın. Ama unutma, bu paravana elini sürersen aramızda her şey bitmiş demektir.
es: —Si tratas de verlo, te juro por mi honor que nunca volveré a dirigirte la palabra mientras viva. Hablo completamente en serio. No te doy ninguna explicación, ni te permito que me la pidas. Pero, recuérdalo, si tocas ese biombo, nuestra amistad se habrá terminado para siempre.
vi_translation: "If you try to look at it, Basil, I swear on my honor that I will never speak to you again as long as I live. I am completely serious. I offer no excuses, and don't ask for any. But remember, if you touch this shield, everything between us is over."
tr_translation: "Basil, if you try to look, I swear on my honor that I will never speak to you again for the rest of my life. I am very serious. I am not giving any reason, and you will not ask. But remember, if you touch this screen, everything between us is over."
es_translation: —If you try to look at it, I swear on my honor that I will never speak to you again as long as I live. I am completely serious. I am not giving you any explanation, nor do I allow you to ask for one. But remember, if you touch that screen, our friendship will be over forever.

en: Hallward was thunderstruck. He looked at Dorian Gray in absolute amazement. He had never seen him like this before. The lad was actually pallid with rage. His hands were clenched, and the pupils of his eyes were like disks of blue fire. He was trembling all over.
vi: Hallward như bị sét đánh. Y nhìn Dorian Gray, sửng sốt hoàn toàn. Y chưa từng thấy cậu như thế này. Chàng trai thật sự tái đi vì tức giận. Bàn tay cậu nắm chặt, và đồng tử mắt như đĩa lửa xanh. Cậu run cả người. “Dorian!”
tr: Hallward yıldırım çarpmışa dönmüştü. Dorian’a hayretler içinde bakıyordu. Onu şimdiye değin hiç böyle görmemişti. Çocuk öfkeden bembeyaz kesilmişti. Yumrukları sıkılı, gözbebekleri mavi ateşten birer çember gibiydi. Tepeden tırnağa titriyordu. “Dorian!
es: Hallward quedó anonadado. Miró a Dorian Gray con infinito asombro. Nunca lo había visto así. El muchacho estaba lívido de rabia. Apretaba los puños y sus pupilas eran como discos de fuego azul. Temblaba de pies a cabeza. —¡Dorian!
vi_translation: Hallward was struck as if by lightning. He looked at Dorian Gray, completely astonished. He had never seen him like this. The young man was truly pale with anger. His hands were clenched, and his pupils were like discs of blue fire. He was trembling all over.
tr_translation: Hallward looked like he had been struck by lightning. He was staring at Dorian in astonishment. He had never seen him like this before. The boy had turned deathly pale with anger. His fists were clenched, and his pupils were like rings of blue fire. He was trembling from head to toe.
es_translation: Hallward was stunned. He looked at Dorian Gray with infinite astonishment. He had never seen him like this. The boy was livid with rage. He clenched his fists, and his pupils were like discs of blue fire. He was trembling from head to toe.

en: “Dorian!”
vi: “Dorian!”
tr: “Dorian!
es: —¡Dorian!
vi_translation: "Dorian!"
tr_translation: “Dorian!”
es_translation: —Dorian!

en: “Don’t speak!”
vi: “Đừng nói!”
tr: “Konuşma!
es: —¡No digas nada!
vi_translation: "Don't speak!"
tr_translation: “Don't speak!”
es_translation: —Don't say anything!

en: “But what is the matter? Of course I won’t look at it if you don’t want me to,” he said, rather coldly, turning on his heel and going over towards the window. “But, really, it seems rather absurd that I shouldn’t see my own work, especially as I am going to exhibit it in Paris in the autumn. I shall probably have to give it another coat of varnish before that, so I must see it some day, and why not to-day?”
vi: “Nhưng vấn đề là gì vậy? Dĩ nhiên tôi sẽ không nhìn nó nếu cậu không muốn tôi làm thế,” y nói, khá lạnh nhạt, quay gót, đi về phía cửa sổ. “Nhưng, thật sự, có vẻ khá vô lý là tôi không thể xem tác phẩm của mình, nhất là khi tôi sắp triển lãm nó ở Paris vào mùa thu. Tôi chắc chắn sẽ phải cho nó một lớp véc-ni khác trước lúc ấy, vậy nên tôi phải xem nó một hôm nào đó, và sao lại không phải hôm nay?”
tr: “Peki, ama neyin var senin?” Ressam biraz soğuk bir ifadeyle, “İstemiyorsan elbette bakmam,” diyerek döndü, bahçe kapısına yürüdü. “Ama kendi eserimi görememem gülünç doğrusu. Hele sonbaharda Paris’te sergileyeceğime göre! Bundan önce üzerinden bir kat cila geçmem gerekecek, herhalde. Yani günün birinde görmem zorunlu olduğuna göre bugün görsem ne çıkar?
es: —Pero, ¿qué es lo que te pasa? Por supuesto que no voy a mirarlo si tú no quieres —dijo, con bastante frialdad, girando sobre los talones y acercándose a la ventana—. Pero me parece bastante absurdo que no pueda ver mi propia obra, sobre todo cuando me dispongo a exponerla en París en otoño. Probablemente tendré que darle otra mano de barniz antes, de manera que tendré que verlo algún día, y ¿por qué no hoy?
vi_translation: “But what is the problem?” “Of course I won't look at it if you don't want me to,” he said, quite coldly, turning on his heel and walking towards the window. “But, really, it seems quite unreasonable that I can't see my own work, especially when I'm about to exhibit it in Paris this fall. I'm certainly going to have to give it another coat of varnish before then, so I have to see it one day, and why not today?”
tr_translation: “Well, but what's wrong with you?” The painter turned with a somewhat cold expression, saying, “If you don't want me to, of course, I won't look,” and walked towards the garden gate. “But it's truly ridiculous that I can't see my own work. Especially since I will exhibit it in Paris in the fall! Before that, I will probably need to apply a coat of varnish. So, given that I will inevitably have to see it someday, what difference does it make if I see it today?”
es_translation: —But, what is wrong with you? Of course I'm not going to look at it if you don't want me to —he said, quite coldly, turning on his heels and approaching the window—. But it seems quite absurd to me that I can't see my own work, especially when I'm about to exhibit it in Paris in the fall. I'll probably have to give it another coat of varnish beforehand, so I'll have to see it someday, and why not today? —Expose it?

en: “To exhibit it! You want to exhibit it?” exclaimed Dorian Gray, a strange sense of terror creeping over him. Was the world going to be shown his secret? Were people to gape at the mystery of his life? That was impossible. Something—he did not know what—had to be done at once.
vi: “Triển lãm nó? Anh muốn triển lãm nó?” Dorian Gray la lên, một cảm giác khiếp sợ kỳ lạ râm ran khắp người cậu. Có phải cả thế giới sắp được cho xem bí mật của cậu? Có phải tất cả mọi người sắp há miệng nhìn điều bí ẩn của đời cậu? Không thể nào. Một việc gì đó — cậu không biết là gì — phải được làm ngay lập tức.
tr: Dorian, “Sergilemek mi? Sergiye mi sokmak istiyorsun?” diye hafifçe bağırarak sordu. İçini tuhaf bir ürkü bürümüştü. Yani onun gizi tüm dünyaya gösterilecek miydi? Herkes onun yaşamının esrarını mı seyredecekti aval aval? Olamazdı bu. Hemencecik bir şeyler... ne olduğunu bilemiyordu ya... yapmak gerekti.
es: —¿Exponerlo? ¿Quieres exponerlo? —exclamó Dorian Gray, sintiendo que le invadía un extraño terror. ¿Iba a ser el mundo testigo de su secreto? ¿Se quedaría la gente con la boca abierta ante el misterio de su vida? Imposible. Había que hacer algo, no sabía aún qué, y hacerlo de inmediato.
vi_translation: “Exhibit it? You want to exhibit it?” Dorian Gray exclaimed, a strange feeling of dread tingling throughout his body. Is the whole world about to see his secret? Is everyone about to gape at the mystery of his life? Impossible. Something — he didn't know what — had to be done immediately.
tr_translation: Dorian, "Exhibit it? Do you want to put it in an exhibition?" he asked, shouting slightly. A strange chill enveloped him. So, would his secret be shown to the whole world? Would everyone gawk at the mystery of his life? This couldn't be. Something had to be done immediately... though he didn't know what it was...
es_translation: Do you want to expose it? —exclaimed Dorian Gray, feeling a strange terror engulf him. Was the world going to witness his secret? Would people be left gaping at the mystery of his life? Impossible. Something had to be done, he didn't know what yet, and it had to be done immediately.

en: “Yes; I don’t suppose you will object to that. Georges Petit is going to collect all my best pictures for a special exhibition in the Rue de Sèze, which will open the first week in October. The portrait will only be away a month. I should think you could easily spare it for that time. In fact, you are sure to be out of town. And if you keep it always behind a screen, you can’t care much about it.”
vi: “Vâng; tôi không nghĩ là anh sẽ phản đối việc ấy. George Petit sắp thu thập mọi bức tranh đẹp nhất của tôi cho một triển lãm đặc biệt ở Rue de Sèze, sẽ khai mạc vào tuần đầu tháng Mười. Bức chân dung sẽ chỉ phải đi xa một tháng. Tôi cho là cậu có thể dễ dàng nhường nó lại trong thời gian ấy. Trên thực tế, cậu chắc chắn sẽ ra ngoài thành phố. Và nếu cậu luôn giữ nó sau một tấm chắn thì cậu cũng không thể quan tâm lắm đến nó.”
tr: “Evet. Buna karşı çıkacağını sanmıyorum. George Petit4 en iyi resimlerimi toparlayıp Sèze Sokağı’nda özel bir sergi açacak, ekimin ilk haftasında. Portreden topu topu bir ay uzak kalacaksın. Sanırım buna kolaylıkla katlanabilirsin. Hatta Londra’dan uzakta bile olabilirsin o sırada. Zaten hep paravan ardında tutuyorsan pek beğenmiyorsun demektir.
es: —Sí; espero que no te opongas. George Petit va a reunir mis mejores obras para una exposición personal en la rue de Séze que se inaugurará la primera semana de octubre. El retrato sólo estará fuera un mes. Creo que podrás pasarte sin él ese tiempo. De hecho es seguro que no estarás en Londres. Y si lo tienes detrás de un biombo, quiere decir que no te importa demasiado.
vi_translation: "Yes; I don't think you will object to that." "George Petit is about to gather all my finest paintings for a special exhibition at Rue de Sèze, which will open in the first week of October. The portrait will only have to be away for a month." "I suppose you can easily part with it during that time." "In fact, you will certainly be out of town." "And if you always keep it behind a screen, you can't be too concerned about it."
tr_translation: “Yes. I don't think you'll object to this. George Petit4 will gather my best paintings and open a private exhibition on Sèze Street, in the first week of October. You will be away from the portrait for only a month. I think you can easily endure this. In fact, you might even be away from London at that time. If you always keep it behind a screen, it means you don't like it very much anyway.”
es_translation: —Yes; I hope you don't mind. George Petit is going to gather my best works for a personal exhibition on rue de Séze that will open the first week of October. The portrait will only be away for a month. I think you can do without it for that time. In fact, it's certain that you won't be in London. And if you have it behind a screen, it means you don't care too much about it.

en: Dorian Gray passed his hand over his forehead. There were beads of perspiration there. He felt that he was on the brink of a horrible danger. “You told me a month ago that you would never exhibit it,” he cried. “Why have you changed your mind? You people who go in for being consistent have just as many moods as others have. The only difference is that your moods are rather meaningless. You can’t have forgotten that you assured me most solemnly that nothing in the world would induce you to send it to any exhibition. You told Harry exactly the same thing.” He stopped suddenly, and a gleam of light came into his eyes. He remembered that Lord Henry had said to him once, half seriously and half in jest, “If you want to have a strange quarter of an hour, get Basil to tell you why he won’t exhibit your picture. He told me why he wouldn’t, and it was a revelation to me.” Yes, perhaps Basil, too, had his secret. He would ask him and try.
vi: Dorian Gray lướt tay qua trán. Có những giọt mồ hôi ở đó. Cậu cảm thấy rằng cậu đang trên bờ vực của một sự hiểm nguy khủng khiếp. “Anh bảo tôi một tháng trước là anh sẽ không bao giờ triển lãm nó,” cậu la lên. “Sao anh lại thay đổi ý định? Anh là một trong những kẻ thường cố gắng nhất quán mà lại có lắm tâm trạng y như những người khác. Sự khác biệt duy nhất là ở chỗ các tâm trạng của anh khá vô nghĩa. Anh không thể quên là anh đã cam đoan với tôi một cách hết sức long trọng rằng không có gì trên đời này có thể xui khiến anh gửi nó đến bất cứ triển lãm nào. Anh cũng bảo Harry đúng như vậy.” Cậu dừng lại đột ngột và một tia sáng hiện lên trong mắt cậu. Cậu nhớ rằng huân tước Henry từng có lần bảo cậu, nửa thật nửa đùa, “nếu cậu muốn có mười lăm phút kỳ lạ, hãy bắt Basil kể cho cậu tại sao anh ta lại không triển lãm bức tranh của cậu. Anh ta đã kể với tôi tại sao anh ta lại không làm, và điều ấy là một sự phát giác với tôi.” Vâng, không chừng Basil cũng có bí mật của mình. Cậu sẽ hỏi anh ấy và thử xem sao.
tr: Dorian elini alnından geçirdi. Teninde terler boncuklanmıştı. Müthiş bir tehlikenin eşiğinde olduğunu duyumsuyordu. “Bir ay önce portreyi asla sergilemeyeceğim, diyordun,” diye çıkıştı. “Neden değiştirdin fikrini? Sizin gibi tutarlı geçinen kişiler de başkaları kadar değişken oluyorsunuz, doğrusu. Şu farkla ki sizdeki değişimler hayli anlamsız kaçıyor. Unutmuş olamazsın, resmimi hiçbir nedenle sergilemeyeceğine yürekten söz vermiştin bana. Harry’ye de aynı şeyi söylemiştin.” Dorian birden durdu, gözlerinde bir ışıltı yandı. Lord Henry’nin bir gün yarı şaka yarı ciddi söylemiş olduğu bir şey aklına gelmişti: “Anlaşılmaz bir yarım saat geçirmek istiyorsan Basil’e sor, portreni niçin sergilemeyeceğini anlatsın sana. Bana anlattı da, gözlerim dört açıldı. Evet, belki Basil’in de bir gizi vardı. Bir sorup kurcalamalıydı.
es: Dorian Gray se pasó la mano por la frente, donde habían aparecido gotitas de sudor. Se sentía al borde de un espantoso abismo. —Hace un mes me dijiste que no lo expondrías nunca —exclamó—. ¿Por qué has cambiado de idea? Las personas que presumís de coherentes sois tan caprichosas como todo el mundo. La única diferencia es que vuestros caprichos carecen de sentido. No es posible que lo hayas olvidado: me aseguraste con toda la solemnidad del mundo que nada te impulsaría a mandarlo a ninguna exposición. Y a Harry le dijiste exactamente lo mismo. Se detuvo de repente y apareció en sus ojos un brillo especial. Recordó que lord Henry le había dicho en una ocasión, medio en serio medio en broma: «Si quieres pasar un cuarto de hora insólito, haz que Basil te cuente por qué no quiere exponer tu retrato. A mí me lo contó, y fue toda una revelación». Sí; quizá también Basil tuviera su secreto. ¿Y si tratara de interrogarlo?
vi_translation: Dorian Gray ran his hand across his forehead. There were beads of sweat there. He felt that he was on the brink of some terrible danger. “You told me a month ago that you would never exhibit it,” he cried out. “Why have you changed your mind? You are one of those people who try to be consistent but have as many moods as others. The only difference is that your moods are quite meaningless. You cannot forget that you solemnly assured me that nothing in the world would induce you to send it to any exhibition. You also told Harry the same thing.” He stopped abruptly and a flash of light appeared in his eyes. He remembered that Lord Henry had once told him, half in earnest, half in jest, “if you want to have fifteen strange minutes, ask Basil to tell you why he won’t exhibit your picture. He told me why he wouldn’t, and it was a revelation to me.” Well, perhaps Basil had his own secret. He would ask him and see what happened.
tr_translation: Dorian passed his hand over his forehead. Sweat had beaded on his skin. He felt he was on the brink of a terrible danger. “A month ago you were saying you would never exhibit the portrait,” he retorted. “Why did you change your mind? People like you, who pride themselves on consistency, are just as fickle as others, to be honest. The difference is that your changes seem quite meaningless. You can't have forgotten, you had solemnly promised me that you would never exhibit my painting for any reason. You had told Harry the same thing.” Dorian suddenly stopped, a sparkle lit up in his eyes. Something Lord Henry had once said half-jokingly, half-seriously came to his mind: “If you want to spend a baffling half hour, ask Basil to explain why he won't exhibit your portrait. He explained it to me, and my eyes were wide open.” Yes, maybe Basil had a secret too. He should ask and probe.
es_translation: Dorian Gray ran his hand across his forehead, where droplets of sweat had appeared. He felt on the edge of a dreadful abyss. —A month ago you told me you would never exhibit it —he exclaimed—. Why have you changed your mind? You people who boast about being consistent are as capricious as everyone else. The only difference is that your whims make no sense. It is not possible that you have forgotten: you assured me with all the solemnity in the world that nothing would compel you to send it to any exhibition. And you told Harry exactly the same thing. He stopped suddenly, and a special gleam appeared in his eyes. He remembered that Lord Henry had once told him, half-seriously and half-jokingly: "If you want to spend an unusual quarter of an hour, have Basil tell you why he doesn't want to exhibit your portrait. He told me, and it was quite a revelation." Yes; perhaps Basil also had his secret. What if he tried to question him?

en: “Basil,” he said, coming over quite close and looking him straight in the face, “we have each of us a secret. Let me know yours, and I shall tell you mine. What was your reason for refusing to exhibit my picture?”
vi: “Basil,” cậu nói, tiến lại rất gần và nhìn thẳng vào mặt y, “mỗi chúng ta đều có một bí mật. Hãy cho tôi biết cái của anh và tôi sẽ kể cho anh nghe cái của tôi. Lý do anh từ chối triển lãm tranh của tôi là gì?”
tr: Dorian ressamın yanı başına gidip doğrudan yüzüne bakarak, “Basil,” dedi. “İkimizin de kendimizce bir gizimiz var. Bana kendi gizini açıkla, ben de sana benimkini söyleyeyim. Portremi sergilemeye karşı çıkmandaki neden neydi?
es: —Basil —le dijo, acercándose mucho y mirándolo fijamente a los ojos—, los dos tenemos un secreto. Hazme saber el tuyo y yo te contaré el mío. ¿Qué razón tenías para negarte a exponer el retrato?
vi_translation: "Basil," he said, coming very close and looking straight into his face, "each of us has a secret. Tell me yours and I will tell you mine. What is the reason you refuse to exhibit my painting?"
tr_translation: Going right up to the painter and looking directly into his face, Dorian said, “Basil.” “We both have our own secrets. Tell me yours, and I’ll tell you mine. What was the reason you opposed exhibiting my portrait?”
es_translation: —Basil —he said, coming very close and looking him straight in the eyes—, we both have a secret. Tell me yours and I will tell you mine. What reason did you have for refusing to exhibit the portrait?

en: The painter shuddered in spite of himself. “Dorian, if I told you, you might like me less than you do, and you would certainly laugh at me. I could not bear your doing either of those two things. If you wish me never to look at your picture again, I am content. I have always you to look at. If you wish the best work I have ever done to be hidden from the world, I am satisfied. Your friendship is dearer to me than any fame or reputation.”
vi: Họa sỹ run bắn lên, không kiềm được mình. “Dorian, nếu tôi kể cho cậu, cậu có thể bớt thích tôi hơn bây giờ, và chắc chắn cậu sẽ cười tôi. Tôi không chịu được việc cậu làm một trong hai điều này. Nếu cậu muốn tôi không bao giờ nhìn bức tranh của cậu nữa, tôi sẵn lòng. Tôi luôn có cậu để nhìn rồi. Nếu cậu muốn tác phẩm đẹp nhất tôi từng làm được lại phải bị che giấu khỏi thế giới, tôi bằng lòng. Tình bạn của cậu đáng quý với tôi hơn mọi tiếng tăm hoặc thanh danh.”
tr: Ressam ürpermekten kendini alamadı. “Dorian, açıklamada bulunursam beni eskisi gibi sevmeyebilirsin; benimle alay edeceğin kesin. Bunların ikisine de dayanamam. Madem portrene bir daha bakmamı istemiyorsun, bu bana yeter. Ben de sana bakarım. Madem ömrümde yaptığım resimlerin en iyisinin gözlerden gizlenmesini istiyorsun, bir diyeceğim yok. Senin dostluğun benim için ünden de şandan da değerlidir.
es: El pintor se estremeció a su pesar. —Si te lo dijera, quizá disminuyera el aprecio que me tienes, y sin duda alguna te reirías de mí. Me resulta insoportable que suceda cualquiera de esas dos cosas. Si no quieres que vuelva a ver el cuadro, lo acepto. Siempre puedo mirarte a ti. Si quieres que mi mejor obra permanezca oculta para el mundo, me doy por satisfecho. Tu amistad es más importante para mí que la fama o la reputación.
vi_translation: The artist trembled, unable to control himself. "Dorian, if I tell you, you might like me less than you do now, and surely you will laugh at me. I cannot bear you doing either of these things. If you want me to never look at your painting again, I am willing. I always have you to look at. If you want the most beautiful work I have ever done to be hidden from the world, I am willing. Your friendship is more precious to me than any fame or reputation."
tr_translation: The painter couldn't help but shudder. “Dorian, if I explain, you might not love me as you used to; you will definitely mock me. I can't endure either of those. If you don't want me to look at your portrait again, that's enough for me. I'll look at you instead. If you want the best painting I've ever done in my life to be hidden from eyes, I have nothing to say. Your friendship is more valuable to me than fame or glory.”
es_translation: The painter shuddered despite himself. —If I told you, it might diminish the appreciation you have for me, and without a doubt, you would laugh at me. It is unbearable for me that either of those two things happen. If you don't want me to see the painting again, I accept it. I can always look at you. If you want my best work to remain hidden from the world, I am satisfied. Your friendship is more important to me than fame or reputation.

en: “No, Basil, you must tell me,” insisted Dorian Gray. “I think I have a right to know.” His feeling of terror had passed away, and curiosity had taken its place. He was determined to find out Basil Hallward’s mystery.
vi: “Không, Basil, anh phải kể cho tôi,” Dorian Gray cố nài. “Tôi nghĩ tôi có quyền được biết.” Cảm giác khiếp sợ của cậu đã mất đi, và sự tò mò lấy lại chỗ của nó. Cậu quyết tâm tìm ra điều bí ẩn của Basil Hallward.
tr: “Yok, Basil, anlat bana,” diye Dorian üsteledi. “Bilmek hakkımdır sanıyorum.” Deminki korku duygusu silinmiş, yerini meraka bırakmıştı. Basil Hallward’ın gizemini öğrenmeye kararlıydı.
es: —No, Basil; me lo tienes que contar —insistió Dorian Gray—. Creo que tengo derecho a saberlo -el sentimiento de terror había desaparecido, sustituido por la curiosidad. Estaba decidido a descubrir el misterio de Basil Hafward.
vi_translation: "No, Basil, you must tell me," Dorian Gray insisted. "I think I have the right to know." His sense of dread had vanished, and curiosity took its place. He was determined to uncover Basil Hallward's secret.
tr_translation: “No, Basil, tell me,” insisted Dorian. “I believe it is my right to know.” The earlier feeling of fear had vanished, replaced by curiosity. He was determined to uncover Basil Hallward’s secret.
es_translation: —No, Basil; you have to tell me —insisted Dorian Gray—. I think I have the right to know it —the feeling of terror had disappeared, replaced by curiosity. He was determined to uncover the mystery of Basil Hallward.

en: “Let us sit down, Dorian,” said the painter, looking troubled. “Let us sit down. And just answer me one question. Have you noticed in the picture something curious?—something that probably at first did not strike you, but that revealed itself to you suddenly?”
vi: “Ta hãy ngồi xuống, Dorian,” họa sỹ nói, trông có vẻ lo lắng. “Ta hãy ngồi xuống. Và chỉ cần trả lời tôi một câu hỏi thôi. Cậu có nhận ra trên bức tranh có gì đó lạ lùng không? — cái gì đó mà chắc có lẽ thoạt đầu không gây ấn tượng với cậu, nhưng lại tự bộc lộ với cậu một cách đột ngột?”
tr: Ressam tedirgin bir ifadeyle, “Dorian, oturalım,” dedi. “Oturalım. Tek bir sorumu yanıtla. Resimde bir gariplik mi ilişti gözüne? Belki ilkin dikkatini çekmeyip de sonradan ansızın gözüne çarpan bir şey?
es: —Vamos a sentarnos, Dorian —dijo el pintor con gesto preocupado—. Siéntate y respóndeme a una sola pregunta. ¿Has notado algo peculiar en el cuadro? ¿Algo que probablemente no advertiste en un primer momento, pero que se te ha revelado de repente?
vi_translation: “Let's sit down, Dorian,” the artist said, looking worried. “Let's sit down. And just answer me one question. Do you notice anything strange about the painting? — something that perhaps didn't strike you at first, but suddenly revealed itself to you?”
tr_translation: The painter said with a nervous expression, "Dorian, let's sit down." "Let's sit down. Answer me one question. Did you notice anything strange in the painting? Perhaps something that didn't catch your eye at first but suddenly struck you later?"
es_translation: "Let's sit down, Dorian," said the painter with a worried expression. “Sit down and answer me just one question. Have you noticed anything peculiar in the painting? Something that you probably didn't notice at first, but that has suddenly revealed itself to you?”

en: “Basil!” cried the lad, clutching the arms of his chair with trembling hands and gazing at him with wild startled eyes.
vi: “Basil!” chàng trai kêu lên, chộp lấy tay ghế bằng bàn tay run rẩy, và chằm chằm nhìn y với đôi mắt hoang dại, thảng thốt.
tr: Dorian titreyen elleriyle koltuğunun kenarlarına yapışıp karşısındaki adama irkilmiş, çılgın gözlerle bakarak, “Basil!” diye inlercesine konuştu.
es: —¡Basil! —exclamó el muchacho, agarrándose a los brazos del sillón con manos temblorosas, y mirándolo con ojos más llenos de miedo que de sorpresa.
