vi_translation: "Basil!" the young man cried out, clutching the arm of the chair with a trembling hand, and staring at him with wild, startled eyes.
tr_translation: With trembling hands, Dorian clung to the edges of his chair and looked at the man in front of him with startled, wild eyes, speaking in a groan, "Basil!"
es_translation: —Basil! —exclaimed the boy, gripping the arms of the chair with trembling hands, and looking at him with eyes more filled with fear than with surprise.

en: “I see you did. Don’t speak. Wait till you hear what I have to say. Dorian, from the moment I met you, your personality had the most extraordinary influence over me. I was dominated, soul, brain, and power, by you. You became to me the visible incarnation of that unseen ideal whose memory haunts us artists like an exquisite dream. I worshipped you. I grew jealous of every one to whom you spoke. I wanted to have you all to myself. I was only happy when I was with you. When you were away from me, you were still present in my art.... Of course, I never let you know anything about this. It would have been impossible. You would not have understood it. I hardly understood it myself. I only knew that I had seen perfection face to face, and that the world had become wonderful to my eyes—too wonderful, perhaps, for in such mad worships there is peril, the peril of losing them, no less than the peril of keeping them.... Weeks and weeks went on, and I grew more and more absorbed in you. Then came a new development. I had drawn you as Paris in dainty armour, and as Adonis with huntsman’s cloak and polished boar-spear. Crowned with heavy lotus-blossoms you had sat on the prow of Adrian’s barge, gazing across the green turbid Nile. You had leaned over the still pool of some Greek woodland and seen in the water’s silent silver the marvel of your own face. And it had all been what art should be—unconscious, ideal, and remote. One day, a fatal day I sometimes think, I determined to paint a wonderful portrait of you as you actually are, not in the costume of dead ages, but in your own dress and in your own time. Whether it was the realism of the method, or the mere wonder of your own personality, thus directly presented to me without mist or veil, I cannot tell. But I know that as I worked at it, every flake and film of colour seemed to me to reveal my secret. I grew afraid that others would know of my idolatry. I felt, Dorian, that I had told too much, that I had put too much of myself into it. Then it was that I resolved never to allow the picture to be exhibited. You were a little annoyed; but then you did not realize all that it meant to me. Harry, to whom I talked about it, laughed at me. But I did not mind that. When the picture was finished, and I sat alone with it, I felt that I was right.... Well, after a few days the thing left my studio, and as soon as I had got rid of the intolerable fascination of its presence, it seemed to me that I had been foolish in imagining that I had seen anything in it, more than that you were extremely good-looking and that I could paint. Even now I cannot help feeling that it is a mistake to think that the passion one feels in creation is ever really shown in the work one creates. Art is always more abstract than we fancy. Form and colour tell us of form and colour—that is all. It often seems to me that art conceals the artist far more completely than it ever reveals him. And so when I got this offer from Paris, I determined to make your portrait the principal thing in my exhibition. It never occurred to me that you would refuse. I see now that you were right. The picture cannot be shown. You must not be angry with me, Dorian, for what I have told you. As I said to Harry, once, you are made to be worshipped.”
vi: “Tôi nhận ra là cậu đã thấy rồi. Đừng nói. Hãy chờ đến lúc cậu nghe xong những gì tôi phải nói. Dorian, từ khoảnh khắc tôi gặp cậu, cá tính cậu đã có ảnh hưởng cực kỳ đặc biệt lên tôi. Tôi bị cậu thống trị, cả tâm hồn, trí tuệ, năng lực. Với tôi, cậu đã trở thành hiện thân hữu hình của mẫu người lý tưởng vô hình mà ký ức về họ vẫn ám ảnh các nghệ sỹ chúng tôi như một giấc mộng tuyệt vời. Tôi tôn thờ cậu. Tôi dần dần trở nên ghen tị với bất cứ ai mà cậu chuyện trò cùng. Tôi muốn có cậu trọn vẹn cho mình tôi. Tôi chỉ hạnh phúc khi tôi bên cậu. Nhưng khi cậu xa tôi, cậu vẫn hiện diện trong nghệ thuật của tôi… Dĩ nhiên tôi chẳng bao giờ để cậu biết gì về việc này. Có lẽ là không thể. Có lẽ cậu sẽ không hiểu. Chính tôi cũng hầu như không hiểu. Tôi chỉ biết rằng tôi đã được gặp mặt đối mặt với sự tuyệt mỹ, và rằng thế giới trở nên diệu kỳ trước mắt tôi — quá đỗi diệu kỳ, có lẽ, vì trong các sự tôn thờ điên cuồng này có mối hiểm nguy, hiểm nguy đánh mất chúng, không kém gì hiểm nguy giữ được chúng… Hết tuần này đến tuần khác trôi qua, tôi càng ngày càng bị hút vào cậu nhiều hơn. Rồi đến một sự phát triển mới. Tôi đã vẽ cậu giống như Paris trong bộ áo giáp xinh đẹp, giống như Adonis với chiếc áo choàng thợ săn và cây giáo săn lợn bóng loáng. Đội vương miện hoa sen trĩu nặng, cậu ngồi trên mũi soái hạm của Adrian, nhìn ngang qua sông Nile xanh đục. Cậu cúi mình trên ao nước tĩnh lặng trong khu rừng Hy Lạp nào đó, và thấy trong sắc bạc lặng lẽ của nước gương mặt kỳ diệu của chính cậu. Và nó là tất cả những gì mà nghệ thuật nên trở thành, vô thức, lý tưởng, xa cách. Một ngày nọ, một ngày mà đôi lúc tôi nghĩ là tai hại, tôi quyết định vẽ một bức chân dung tuyệt vời về cậu như cậu trên thực tế, không phải trong bộ trang phục của các thời đại đã chết, mà trong bộ quần áo của chính cậu và trong thời của chính cậu. Hoặc đó là Chủ nghĩa hiện thực trong cách vẽ, hoặc chỉ là sự ngạc nhiên vì cá tính của cậu đã xuất hiện trực tiếp trước tôi như vậy, không qua màn sương hay tấm mạng nào, tôi không thể kể. Nhưng tôi biết là trong lúc tôi làm việc với nó, tôi thấy dường như mọi vảy và mảng màu đều để lộ bí mật của tôi. Tôi dần dần thấy sợ rằng người khác có thể biết về sự sùng bái thần tượng của tôi. Tôi cảm thấy, Dorian, rằng tôi đã kể quá nhiều, rằng tôi đã đưa quá nhiều mình vào nó. Ấy là lúc tôi quyết định không bao giờ cho phép bức tranh được triển lãm. Cậu đã hơi khó chịu; nhưng lúc đó cậu không nhận ra mọi điều ấy có nghĩa thế nào với tôi. Harry, người mà tôi thảo luận về điều đó, đã cười tôi. Nhưng tôi không để tâm. Khi bức tranh đã xong, và tôi ngồi một mình với nó, tôi cảm thấy là tôi đúng… Thế rồi, vài ngày sau khi nó rời xưởng vẽ của tôi, và ngay sau khi tôi thoát khỏi sự mê hoặc không sao chịu nổi ở sự hiện diện của nó thì tôi thấy dường như tôi đã ngu dại khi hình dung rằng tôi từng thấy gì đó trong nó nhiều hơn cái điều là cậu cực kỳ đẹp trai, và tôi có thể vẽ ra cái đó. Thậm chí bây giờ tôi cũng không thể không cảm thấy thật là một sai lầm khi nghĩ rằng sự đam mê mà ta cảm nhận được trong sáng tác lại thật sự có lúc hiện lên trong tác phẩm ta tạo ra. Nghệ thuật luôn trừu tượng hơn ta tưởng. Hình và màu nói cho ta về hình và màu — chỉ vậy thôi. Tôi thường nghĩ là dường như nghệ thuật giấu được nghệ sỹ một cách trọn vẹn hơn nhiều so với nó có lúc để lộ họ. Và vậy nên khi tôi nhận được lời mời này từ Paris, tôi quyết định biến bức chân dung cậu thành tác phẩm chính trong triển lãm của tôi. Chưa bao giờ tôi nảy ra ý nghĩ là cậu sẽ từ chối. Giờ thì tôi đã thấy rằng cậu đúng. Bức tranh không nên đem ra trưng bày. Cậu không nên giận tôi, Dorian, vì những gì tôi kể cho cậu. Như trước kia tôi từng nói với Harry, cậu được tạo ra để tôn thờ.”
tr: “Görüyorum ki öyle olmuş. Bir şey söyleme. Bekle de benim söyleyeceklerimi dinle. Dorian, seninle tanıştığım dakikadan başlayarak kişiliğin benim üzerimde son derece olağanüstü bir etki bıraktı. Ruhum, beynim, sanat gücüm senin egemenliğinin altına girdi. Gözle görülmeyen bir ideal vardır ki bunun anısı, benzersiz bir düş gibi, biz sanatçıların içinden hiç çıkmaz. İşte sen benim için bu idealin gözle görülür, canlı bir simgesi oldun. Tapıyordum sana. Konuştuğun herkesi kıskanır olmuştum Seni tümden kendime saklamak istiyordum. Ancak seninle birlikteyken mutluydum. Benden uzağa gittiğin zaman da varlığını sanatımda buluyordum... Bunların hiçbirini sana sezdirmedim, doğallıkla. Olacak şey değildi. Anlayamazdın. Kendim bile doğru dürüst anlayamıyordum. Kusursuzluğu yüz yüze görmüş olduğumu, dünyanın harikulade bir görünüme büründüğünü biliyordum yalnızca. Belki de fazla harikulade olmuştu, çünkü böylesi çılgın bir tapınma tehlikelere gebedir: Tapınılan şeyi yitirme tehlikesi kadar elde tutabilmek de tehlikelidir... Haftalara haftalar ekleniyor, ben sana gitgide daha çok kendimi veriyordum. Derken yeni bir gelişme oldu. Seni zarif zırhlar içinde Paris olarak çizmiştim; avcı pelerinli, eli parlak mızraklı Adonis olarak. Başın ağır su nilüferleriyle taçlanmış olarak Hadrianus’un teknesinin burnunda oturmuş, Nil’in o bulanık yeşil sularını seyretmiştin. Bir Yunan korusundaki durgun gölcüğün üzerine eğilerek suyun sessiz gümüşünde kendi yüzünü görmüştün. Bütün bunlar sanata tümüyle uygun şekilde oldu bitti: ideal, uzak, bilinçdışı... Derken günün birinde, kimileyin, uğursuz bir günde, diyeceğim geliyor, senin gerçek halinle bir portreni çizmeye karar verdim. Geçmiş çağların kılıklarıyla değil de senin kendi zamanına ait, kendi giysilerinle çizecektim seni. Beni böyle, peçelerden, sislerden uzak, seni doğrudan ele almaya iten şey yöntemdeki gerçekçilik miydi, bilemiyorum. Bildiğim şu ki bu portre üzerinde çalışırken beliren her boya zerresi, her renk tonu benim gizimi ortaya serer gibiydi. Benim bu puta tapan yönümü başkaları da anlayacak diye korkar oldum. Dorian, bu portreyle çok fazla şey söylediğimi, bu portreye kendimden çok fazla şey kattığımı seziyordum. İşte o zaman resmin sergilenmesine asla izin vermeme kararı aldım. Sen buna sinirlendin biraz; resminin benim gözümde nasıl bir anlam taşıdığını bilemezdin ki. Bunu Harry ile konuştum, o bana güldü ama ben aldırış etmedim. Bitirdikten sonra resmin karşısında otururken kararımın doğru olduğunu hissettim... Neyse, birkaç gün sonra portre stüdyomdan çıktı. Varlığının o dayanılmaz büyüsü üstümden kalkınca bu resimde özel bir şey gördüğümü sanmanın delilik olduğunu düşünmeye başladım. Olup olacağı, sen olağanüstü yakışıklıydın, ben de iyi bir ressamdım, işte. İnsanın yaratırken duyduğu tutku yaratılan ürüne her seferinde, olduğu gibi yansır, diye düşünmek yanlıştır. Şimdi bile bu fikirdeyim. Sanat her zaman bizim sanımızdan daha soyuttur. Biçim renk bize biçim ve rengi anlatır, hepsi bu. Çok zaman bana öyle gelir ki sanat sanatçıyı gözler önüne sereceği yerde büsbütün gözden gizler. İşte böyle. Paris’ ten bu öneriyi aldığım zaman senin portreni sergimin başyapıtı yapmaya karar verdim. Senin buna karşı çıkacağın hiç aklıma gelmedi. Ama şimdi görüyorum ki haklısın. Bu resim sergilenemez. Dorian, bu anlattıklarımdan ötürü kızma bana. Bir keresinde Harry’ye de söylediğim gibi, sen tapılmak için yaratılmışsın.
es: —Ya veo que sí. No digas nada. Espera a escuchar lo que tengo que decir. Desde el momento en que te conocí, tu personalidad ha tenido sobre mí la más extraordinaria de las influencias. Has dominado mi alma, mi cerebro, mis energías. Te convertiste en la encarnación tangible de ese ideal nunca visto cuyo recuerdo obsesiona a los artistas como un sueño inefable. Te idolatraba. Sentía celos de todas las personas con las que hablabas. Te quería para mí solo. Sólo era feliz cuando estaba contigo. Y cuando te alejabas de mí seguías presente en mi arte... Por supuesto nunca te hice saber nada de todo eso. Hubiera sido imposible. No lo habrías entendido. Apenas lo entendía yo. Sólo sabía que había visto la perfección cara a cara, y que, ante mis ojos, el mundo se había convertido en algo maravilloso; demasiado maravilloso, quizá, porque en una adoración tan desmesurada existe un peligro, el peligro de perderla, no menos grave que el de conservarla... Pasaron semanas y semanas, y yo estaba cada día más absorto en ti. Luego sucedió algo nuevo. Te había dibujado como Paris con una primorosa armadura, y como Adonis con capa de cazador y lanza bruñida. Coronado con flores de loto en la proa de la falúa de Adriano, mirando hacia la otra orilla sobre las verdes aguas turbias del Nilo. Inclinado sobre un estanque inmóvil en algún bosque griego, habías visto en la plata silenciosa del agua la maravilla de tu propio rostro. Y todo había sido, como conviene al arte, inconsciente, ideal y remoto. Un día, un día fatídico, pienso a veces, decidí pintar un maravilloso retrato tuyo tal como eres, no con vestiduras de edades muertas, sino con tu ropa y en tu época. No sé si fue el realismo del método o la maravilla misma de tu personalidad, que se me presentó entonces sin intermediarios, sin niebla ni velo. Pero sé que mientras trabajaba en él, con cada pincelada, con cada toque de color me parecía estar revelando mi secreto. Sentí miedo de que otros advirtieran mi idolatría. Comprendí que había dicho demasiado, que había puesto demasiado de mí en aquel cuadro. Decidí entonces no permitir que el retrato se expusiera nunca en público. Tú te molestaste un poco; pero no te diste cuenta de todo lo que significaba para mí. Harry, a quien le hablé de ello, se rió de mí. Pero no me importó. Cuando el cuadro estuvo terminado, y me quedé a solas con él, sentí que yo tenía razón... Luego, a los pocos días, el lienzo abandonó mi estudio, y tan pronto como me libré de la intolerable fascinación de su presencia, me pareció absurdo imaginar que hubiera algo especial en él, aparte del hecho de que tú eras muy bien parecido y de que yo era capaz de pintar. Incluso ahora no puedo por menos de pensar que es un error creer que la pasión que se siente durante la creación aparece de verdad en la obra creada. El arte es siempre más abstracto de lo que imaginamos. La forma y el color sólo nos hablan de sí mismos..., eso es todo. Con frecuencia me parece que el arte esconde al artista mucho más de lo que lo revela. De manera que cuando recibí la invitación de París decidí hacer de tu retrato la pieza principal de mi exposición. Nunca se me ocurrió que te negaras. Ahora comprendo que tenías razón. El retrato no se puede mostrar. No te enfades conmigo por lo que te he contado, Dorian. Como le dije a Harry en una ocasión, estás hecho para ser adorado.
vi_translation: "I realize that you have already seen it. Don't speak. Wait until you have heard what I have to say. Dorian, from the moment I met you, your personality has had an extraordinarily special influence on me. I was dominated by you, soul, intellect, and power. To me, you became the tangible embodiment of the ideal type that the memory of them still haunts us artists like a wonderful dream. I worship you. I gradually became jealous of anyone you talked to. I wanted to have you entirely for myself. I was only happy when I was with you. But when you were away from me, you were still present in my art... Of course, I never let you know about this. Perhaps it was impossible. Perhaps you would not understand. I myself hardly understood. I only knew that I had come face to face with absolute beauty, and that the world became wondrous before my eyes — too wondrous, perhaps, for in these mad adorations there is danger, the danger of losing them, no less than the danger of keeping them... Week after week went by, and I was drawn more and more to you. Then came a new development. I painted you as Paris in beautiful armor, as Adonis with a hunter's cloak and a gleaming boar spear. Wearing a heavy lotus crown, you sat on the prow of Adrian's flagship, gazing across the muddy blue Nile. You bent over a still pond in some Greek forest, and saw in the quiet silver of the water your own wondrous face. And it was everything that art should become, unconscious, ideal, distant. One day, a day that I sometimes think was disastrous, I decided to paint a magnificent portrait of you as you actually are, not in the costume of dead ages, but in your own clothes and in your own time. Whether it was Realism in the painting style, or just the surprise of your personality appearing so directly before me, without any mist or veil, I cannot tell. But I knew that as I worked on it, it seemed as if every stroke and patch of color revealed my secret. I gradually became afraid that others might know about my idol worship. I felt, Dorian, that I had told too much, that I had put too much of myself into it. That was when I decided never to allow the painting to be exhibited. You were slightly annoyed; but at that time you did not realize what all this meant to me. Harry, with whom I discussed it, laughed at me. But I did not mind. When the painting was finished, and I sat alone with it, I felt that I was right... Then, a few days after it left my studio, and just after I escaped the unbearable enchantment of its presence, it seemed to me that I had been foolish to imagine that I had ever seen anything in it more than the fact that you are extraordinarily handsome, and I could paint that. Even now I cannot help feeling that it was a mistake to think that the passion we feel in creation ever really shows itself in the work we create. Art is always more abstract than we imagine. Form and color tell us about form and color — that is all. I often think that art conceals the artist far more completely than it ever reveals them. And so when I received this invitation from Paris, I decided to make your portrait the principal work in my exhibition. Never did it occur to me that you would refuse. Now I see that you were right. The painting should not be displayed. You should not be angry with me, Dorian, for what I have told you. As I once told Harry, you were made to be worshipped."
tr_translation: “I see that it has been so. Do not say anything. Wait and listen to what I have to say. Dorian, from the moment I met you, your personality had an extraordinarily profound effect on me. My soul, my mind, my artistic power came under your dominion. There is an invisible ideal, the memory of which, like a unique dream, never leaves us artists. And you became the visible, living symbol of this ideal for me. I worshipped you. I became jealous of everyone you spoke to. I wanted to keep you entirely to myself. I was only happy when I was with you. When you were away from me, I found your presence in my art...Of course, I did not let you sense any of this. It was impossible. You could not have understood. I myself could not fully understand. I only knew that I had seen perfection face to face, and the world had taken on a marvelous appearance. Perhaps it had become too marvelous, because such a mad worship is fraught with dangers: the danger of losing what is worshipped as much as the danger of being able to keep it...Weeks added to weeks, and I gave myself more and more to you. Then a new development occurred. I had drawn you as Paris in elegant armor; as Adonis with a hunter's cloak and a shining spear in hand. You had sat crowned with heavy water lilies at the bow of Hadrian's boat, watching the murky green waters of the Nile. You had bent over a still pool in a Greek grove and seen your face in the silent silver of the water. All of this happened in a manner entirely suitable to art: ideal, distant, unconscious... Then one day, on what I might call an ominous day, I decided to draw your portrait as you truly are. I would draw you not in the costumes of past ages but in your own time, in your own clothes. I do not know if it was the realism in the method that pushed me to take you directly, away from veils and mists. What I do know is that every speck of paint, every shade of color that appeared while working on this portrait seemed to reveal my secret. I began to fear that others would understand this idolatrous side of me. Dorian, I sensed that I had said too much with this portrait, that I had put too much of myself into it. That is when I decided never to allow the painting to be exhibited. You were a bit upset by this; you could not know what the painting meant to me. I talked about it with Harry, he laughed at me, but I did not care. As I sat in front of the painting after finishing it, I felt that my decision was right...Anyway, a few days later, the portrait left my studio. When the unbearable enchantment of your presence lifted from me, I began to think that it was madness to believe I saw something special in this painting. All it was, was that you were extraordinarily handsome, and I was a good painter, that's all. It is wrong to think that the passion one feels while creating always reflects in the created work as it is. I still hold this view. Art is always more abstract than we think. Form and color tell us about form and color, that's all. Often it seems to me that instead of revealing the artist, art completely hides him from view. That's how it is. When I received this proposal from Paris, I decided to make your portrait the masterpiece of my exhibition. It never occurred to me that you would oppose it. But now I see that you are right. This painting cannot be exhibited. Dorian, do not be angry with me for what I have told you. As I once told Harry, you were created to be worshipped.”
es_translation: —I see that you do. Don't say anything. Wait to hear what I have to say. From the moment I met you, your personality has had the most extraordinary influence on me. You have dominated my soul, my brain, my energies. You became the tangible embodiment of that unseen ideal whose memory haunts artists like an ineffable dream. I idolized you. I felt jealous of everyone you spoke to. I wanted you for myself alone. I was only happy when I was with you. And when you were away from me, you were still present in my art... Of course, I never let you know any of this. It would have been impossible. You wouldn't have understood it. I barely understood it myself. I only knew that I had seen perfection face to face, and that, before my eyes, the world had become something wonderful; too wonderful, perhaps, because in such excessive adoration there is a danger, the danger of losing it, no less serious than that of keeping it... Weeks and weeks passed, and I was more and more absorbed in you every day. Then something new happened. I had drawn you as Paris in a delicate armor, and as Adonis with a hunter's cloak and a polished spear. Crowned with lotus flowers at the prow of Hadrian's barge, looking towards the other shore over the green murky waters of the Nile. Bent over a still pond in some Greek forest, you had seen in the silent silver of the water the wonder of your own face. And everything had been, as befits art, unconscious, ideal, and remote. One day, a fateful day, I sometimes think, I decided to paint a wonderful portrait of you as you are, not in the garments of dead ages, but in your clothes and in your time. I don't know if it was the realism of the method or the very wonder of your personality, which presented itself to me then without intermediaries, without fog or veil. But I know that while I was working on it, with each brushstroke, with each touch of color, it seemed to me that I was revealing my secret. I was afraid that others would notice my idolatry. I realized that I had said too much, that I had put too much of myself into that painting. I then decided not to allow the portrait to ever be exhibited in public. You were a little upset; but you didn't realize all that it meant to me. Harry, to whom I spoke about it, laughed at me. But I didn't care. When the painting was finished, and I was alone with it, I felt that I was right... Then, a few days later, the canvas left my studio, and as soon as I was freed from the intolerable fascination of its presence, it seemed absurd to imagine that there was anything special about it, apart from the fact that you were very handsome and that I was capable of painting. Even now I can't help but think that it is a mistake to believe that the passion felt during creation truly appears in the created work. Art is always more abstract than we imagine. Form and color only speak of themselves..., that's all. It often seems to me that art hides the artist much more than it reveals him. So when I received the invitation from Paris, I decided to make your portrait the main piece of my exhibition. It never occurred to me that you would refuse. Now I understand that you were right. The portrait cannot be shown. Don't be angry with me for what I've told you, Dorian. As I once told Harry, you are made to be adored.

en: Dorian Gray drew a long breath. The colour came back to his cheeks, and a smile played about his lips. The peril was over. He was safe for the time. Yet he could not help feeling infinite pity for the painter who had just made this strange confession to him, and wondered if he himself would ever be so dominated by the personality of a friend. Lord Henry had the charm of being very dangerous. But that was all. He was too clever and too cynical to be really fond of. Would there ever be some one who would fill him with a strange idolatry? Was that one of the things that life had in store?
vi: Dorian Gray hít một hơi dài. Sắc màu quay lại má cậu, và một nụ cười đùa giỡn trên môi cậu. Hiểm nguy đã qua đi. Cậu được an toàn lúc này. Tuy nhiên cậu không thể không cảm thấy nỗi xót thương vô hạn cho người họa sỹ vừa mới bày tỏ lời thú nhận lạ lùng này với cậu, và tự hỏi không biết chính cậu có khi nào sẽ bị thống trị như vậy bởi cá tính của một người bạn nào đó không. Huân tước Henry có sức quyến rũ ở chỗ cực kỳ nguy hiểm. Nhưng chỉ vậy thôi. Anh ấy quá khôn ngoan và quá hay nhạo báng để yêu thương thật lòng. Liệu có khi nào có ai đó làm cậu thấy chứa chan một sự sùng bái thần tượng kỳ lạ không? Liệu đời có dành sẵn cho cậu một người như vậy không?
tr: Dorian Gray derin bir nefes aldı. Yüzünün rengi geri geldi, dudaklarında bir gülüş kıpırdadı. Tehlike atlatılmıştı. Şimdilik güvenlikteydi. Gene de kendisine bu tuhaf itirafı yapan ressama karşı sonsuz bir acıma duymaktan kendini alamıyor, “Acaba ben de günün birinde bir dostun kişiliğinin böylesine egemenliği altına girer miyim?” diye düşünüyordu. Lord Henry çok tehlikeli olmanın çekiciliğine sahipti. Ama hepsi bu. Öylesine aşırı zeki, aşırı alaycıydı ki insan onu sahiden sevemiyordu. Kendi içinde de böyle puta taparcasına tuhaf bir bağlılık uyandırabilecek birileri karşısına çıkacak mıydı acaba? Hayatın ona hazırladığı şeylerden biri de bu muydu?
es: Dorian Gray respiró hondo. Sus mejillas recobraron el color y sus labios juguetearon con una sonrisa. Había pasado el peligro. De momento estaba a salvo. Pero no podía dejar de sentir una piedad infinita por el pintor que acababa de hacerle aquella extraña confesión, al tiempo que se preguntaba si alguna vez llegaría a sentirse tan dominado por la personalidad de un amigo. Lord Henry tenía el encanto de ser muy peligroso. Pero nada más. Era demasiado inteligente y demasiado cínico para que nadie sintiera por él un afecto apasionado. ¿Habría alguna vez alguien que suscitara en él, en Dorian Gray, tan extraña idolatría? ¿Era ésa una de las cosas que le reservaba la vida?
vi_translation: Dorian Gray took a deep breath. Color returned to his cheeks, and a playful smile appeared on his lips. The danger had passed. He was safe now. However, he couldn't help but feel an infinite pity for the artist who had just made this strange confession to him, and wondered if he himself would ever be dominated by the personality of a friend like that. Lord Henry had a charm that was extremely dangerous. But that was all. He was too wise and too mocking to love sincerely. Would there ever be someone who made him feel a strange idol worship? Was life destined to give him such a person?
tr_translation: Dorian Gray took a deep breath. The color returned to his face, a smile flickered on his lips. The danger had passed. For now, he was safe. Nevertheless, he couldn't help but feel an infinite pity for the painter who made this strange confession to him, and he wondered, "Will I ever fall under the dominance of a friend's personality like this?" Lord Henry had the allure of being very dangerous. But that was all. He was so excessively intelligent, so excessively cynical that one couldn't truly love him. Would anyone ever come into his life who could evoke such an idolatrously strange attachment within him? Was this one of the things life had prepared for him?
es_translation: Dorian Gray took a deep breath. His cheeks regained their color and his lips played with a smile. The danger had passed. For the moment, he was safe. But he couldn't help feeling an infinite pity for the painter who had just made that strange confession to him, while wondering if he would ever feel so dominated by the personality of a friend. Lord Henry had the charm of being very dangerous. But nothing more. He was too intelligent and too cynical for anyone to feel a passionate affection for him. Would there ever be someone who would inspire in him, in Dorian Gray, such strange idolatry? Was that one of the things life had in store for him?

en: “It is extraordinary to me, Dorian,” said Hallward, “that you should have seen this in the portrait. Did you really see it?”
vi: “Tôi thấy thật phi thường,” Hallward nói, “là cậu có thể thấy điều này trên bức chân dung. Cậu có thật sự thấy nó không?”
tr: Hallward, “Senin bunları portrede görmüş olman şaşılası bir şey bence,” diye ekledi. “Sahiden gördün mü?
es: —Me parece extraordinario, Dorian —prosiguió Hallward—, que hayas descubierto mi secreto en el retrato. ¿Lo has visto de verdad?
vi_translation: “I find it extraordinary,” Hallward said, “that you can see this in the portrait. Do you really see it?”
tr_translation: Hallward added, "I think it's surprising that you saw these things in the portrait." "Did you really see them?"
es_translation: —It seems extraordinary to me, Dorian —continued Hallward—, that you have discovered my secret in the portrait. Have you really seen it?

en: “I saw something in it,” he answered, “something that seemed to me very curious.”
vi: “Tôi thấy gì đó trên nó,” cậu trả lời, “gì đó dường như rất lạ với tôi.”
tr: Dorian, “Bir şey gördüm,” diye yanıtladı. “Çok tuhafıma giden bir şey gördüm.
es: —Vi algo en él —respondió el joven—; algo que me pareció sumamente curioso.
vi_translation: “I see something on it,” he replied, “something that seems very strange to me.”
tr_translation: Dorian replied, "I saw something." "I saw something that struck me as very strange."
es_translation: —I saw something in him —replied the young man—; something that seemed extremely curious to me.

en: “Well, you don’t mind my looking at the thing now?”
vi: “Vậy à, cậu có thấy phiền không nếu tôi xem nó bây giờ?”
tr: “Şimdi bakmamda bir sakınca yok ya sence?
es: —Bien; ahora ya no te importará que lo vea, ¿no es cierto?
vi_translation: “Really? Do you mind if I watch it now?”
tr_translation: “Do you think there's any harm in me looking now?”
es_translation: —Well; now you won't mind if I see it, right?

en: Dorian shook his head. “You must not ask me that, Basil. I could not possibly let you stand in front of that picture.”
vi: Dorian lắc đầu. “Anh không nên hỏi tôi thế, Basil. Tôi không thể để anh đứng trước bức tranh ấy được.”
tr: Dorian başını salladı. “Bunu benden isteme, Basil. O resmin karşısına geçmene dünyada izin veremem.
es: Dorian negó con un movimiento de cabeza. —No me pidas eso, Basil. No puedo permitir que veas ese cuadro cara a cara.
vi_translation: Dorian shook his head. "You shouldn't ask me that, Basil. I can't let you stand in front of that painting."
tr_translation: Dorian shook his head. "Don't ask this of me, Basil. I can't let you stand in front of that picture, not in this world."
es_translation: Dorian shook his head. —Don't ask me that, Basil. I can't allow you to see that painting face to face.

en: “You will some day, surely?”
vi: “Cậu sẽ cho, một ngày nào đó, phải không?”
tr: “Ama bir gün izin vereceksin herhalde, değil mi?
es: —Pero llegará algún día en que sí.
vi_translation: “You will give it, someday, won't you?”
tr_translation: “But one day you'll allow it, right?”
es_translation: —But a day will come when it will.

en: “Never.”
vi: “Không bao giờ.”
tr: “Hiçbir zaman.
es: —Nunca.
vi_translation: "Never."
tr_translation: “Never.”
es_translation: —Never.

en: “Well, perhaps you are right. And now good-bye, Dorian. You have been the one person in my life who has really influenced my art. Whatever I have done that is good, I owe to you. Ah! you don’t know what it cost me to tell you all that I have told you.”
vi: “Thôi cũng được, không chừng cậu đúng. Giờ thì tạm biệt, Dorian. Cậu là người duy nhất trong đời đã tạo được ảnh hưởng thực sự lên nghệ thuật của tôi. Dẫu tôi có làm cái gì thì nó cũng tốt, tôi nợ cậu. À! Cậu không biết cái giá tôi phải trả để nói được với cậu mọi điều tôi vừa nói với cậu đâu.”
tr: “Ne bileyim, belki de haklısın. Şimdi artık hoşça kal, Dorian. Sen benim hayatımda sanatımı gerçekten etkilemiş olan tek kişisin. İyi sayılabilecek ne ürün çıkarmışsam sana borçluyum. Ah, Dorian, bütün bu söylediklerimi sana söylemek bana nelere mal oldu, bilemezsin.
es: —Bien; quizás estés en lo cierto. Me despido de ti. Has sido la única persona que de verdad ha influido en mi arte. Si he hecho algo que merezca la pena, te lo debo a ti. ¡Ah! No sabes lo que me ha costado decirte todo lo que te he dicho.
vi_translation: “Well, that's fine, maybe you are right. Now, goodbye, Dorian. You are the only person in my life who has truly influenced my art. Whatever I do that is good, I owe it to you. Ah! You have no idea the price I had to pay to be able to tell you everything I just told you.”
tr_translation: “I don't know, maybe you're right. Now, goodbye, Dorian. You are the only person who has truly influenced my art in my life. Whatever good work I have produced, I owe it to you. Ah, Dorian, you can't imagine what it cost me to say all these things to you.”
es_translation: —Well; perhaps you are right. I bid you farewell. You have been the only person who has truly influenced my art. If I have done anything worthwhile, I owe it to you. Ah! You don't know how much it has cost me to tell you everything I have told you.

en: “My dear Basil,” said Dorian, “what have you told me? Simply that you felt that you admired me too much. That is not even a compliment.”
vi: “Basil thân mến của tôi,” Dorian nói, “anh đã nói gì với tôi nhỉ? Chỉ là anh cảm thấy là anh ngưỡng mộ tôi nhiều lắm. Đó thậm chí chưa phải là một lời khen.”
tr: Dorian, “Sevgili Basil, sen bana ne söyledin ki?” dedi. “Beni aşırı beğendiğini söyledin yalnızca. İltifat bile değil bu.
es: —Mi querido Basil —respondió Dorian—, ¿qué es lo que me has contado? Simplemente, que te parecía que me admirabas demasiado. Eso ni siquiera llega a ser un cumplido.
vi_translation: “My dear Basil,” Dorian said, “what did you say to me? You just feel that you admire me a lot. That is not even a compliment.”
tr_translation: Dorian said, "Dear Basil, what did you tell me?" "You only said that you admired me excessively. That's not even a compliment."
es_translation: —My dear Basil —replied Dorian—, what is it that you have told me? Simply, that it seemed to you that you admired me too much. That doesn't even amount to a compliment.

en: “It was not intended as a compliment. It was a confession. Now that I have made it, something seems to have gone out of me. Perhaps one should never put one’s worship into words.”
vi: “Nó không có ý khen. Nó là một sự thú nhận. Bây giờ, vì tôi đã bày tỏ được rồi, có gì đó dường như đã ra khỏi tôi. Có lẽ ta chẳng bao giờ nên diễn tả sự tôn thờ của ta thành lời.
tr: “İltifat olsun diye söylenmedi ki zaten. Bir itiraftı. Bu itirafı yaptım ya, içimde bir şeyler söndü sanki. Belki de insan tapınma duygusunu asla sözlere dökmemeli.
es: —No era mi intención hacerte un cumplido. Ha sido una confesión. Ahora que ya la he hecho, tengo la impresión de haber perdido algo de mí mismo. Quizá nunca se deba traducir en palabras un sentimiento de adoración.
vi_translation: “It was not meant as a compliment. It was a confession. Now, because I have expressed it, something seems to have left me. Perhaps one should never put their adoration into words.”
tr_translation: “It wasn't said as a compliment anyway. It was a confession. Now that I've made this confession, it feels like something inside me has extinguished. Maybe one should never put the feeling of reverence into words.”
es_translation: —It was not my intention to compliment you. It was a confession. Now that I have made it, I feel like I have lost something of myself. Perhaps one should never translate a feeling of adoration into words.

en: “It was a very disappointing confession.”
vi: “Đó là một lời thú nhận rất thất vọng.
tr: “Hayal kırıcı bir itiraf oldu benim için.
es: —Ha sido una confesión muy decepcionante.
vi_translation: “That is a very disappointing confession.”
tr_translation: “It was a disappointing confession for me.”
es_translation: —It has been a very disappointing confession.

en: “Why, what did you expect, Dorian? You didn’t see anything else in the picture, did you? There was nothing else to see?”
vi: “Là sao, cậu mong đợi gì, Dorian? Cậu không thấy gì khác trên bức tranh, phải không? Không có gì khác để thấy sao?”
tr: “Nasıl? Sen ne bekliyordun ki Dorian? Portrede daha başka bir şeyler mi gördün yoksa? Ama görülecek başka bir şey yoktu ki. Öyle değil mi?
es: —¿Qué esperabas, Dorian? No has visto ninguna otra cosa en el cuadro, ¿no es cierto? ¿Había algo más que ver?
vi_translation: “What do you mean, what are you expecting, Dorian? You don't see anything different in the painting, do you? Is there nothing else to see?”
tr_translation: "How? What were you expecting, Dorian? Did you see something else in the portrait? But there was nothing else to see. Isn't that right?"
es_translation: —What did you expect, Dorian? You haven't seen anything else in the picture, have you? Was there anything else to see?

en: “No; there was nothing else to see. Why do you ask? But you mustn’t talk about worship. It is foolish. You and I are friends, Basil, and we must always remain so.”
vi: “Không; chẳng có gì khác để thấy. Sao anh hỏi vậy? Nhưng anh đừng nói về sự tôn thờ. Nó thật ngớ ngẩn. Anh và tôi là bạn, Basil, và ta nên giữ thế mãi.
tr: “Hayır, başka hiçbir şey yoktu. Neden sordun? Hem öyle tapınmaktan fazla konuşma, Basil. Budalaca laflar bunlar. Senle ben dostuz, her zaman da dost kalmalıyız.
es: —No, no había nada más. ¿Por qué lo preguntas? Pero no debes hablar de adoración. No tiene sentido. Tú y yo somos amigos, y hemos de seguir siéndolo siempre.
vi_translation: “No; there is nothing else to see. Why do you ask that? But don't talk about worship. It is really silly. You and I are friends, Basil, and we should remain so forever.”
tr_translation: “No, there was nothing else. Why did you ask? And don't talk so much about worshipping, Basil. These are foolish words. You and I are friends, and we should always remain friends.”
es_translation: —No, there was nothing else. Why do you ask? But you must not speak of worship. It makes no sense. You and I are friends, and we must always remain so.

en: “You have got Harry,” said the painter sadly.
vi: “Anh đã có Harry,” họa sỹ nói, buồn bã.
tr: Ressam üzgün bir sesle, “Harry senin dostun,” dedi.
es: —Tienes a Harry—dijo el pintor con tristeza.
vi_translation: "You have Harry," the artist said, sadly.
tr_translation: The painter said in a sad voice, "Harry is your friend."
es_translation: "You have Harry," said the painter sadly.

en: “Oh, Harry!” cried the lad, with a ripple of laughter. “Harry spends his days in saying what is incredible and his evenings in doing what is improbable. Just the sort of life I would like to lead. But still I don’t think I would go to Harry if I were in trouble. I would sooner go to you, Basil.”
vi: “Ôi, Harry!” chàng trai kêu lên, với tiếng cười rì rầm. “Harry bỏ ra nhiều ngày để nói những chuyện không đâu, và nhiều đêm để làm những việc đâu đâu. Đúng là một kiểu sống mà tôi những muốn trải qua. Nhưng tôi vẫn không nghĩ là tôi có thể đến với Harry nếu tôi gặp rắc rối. Thà tôi đến với anh, Basil.”
tr: Delikanlı, “Ha, Harry!” diye için için güldü. “Harry günlerini inanılmayacak şeyler söylemekle, gecelerini de akla gelmeyecek şeyler yapmakla geçiriyor. Tam benim sürmek istediğim türden bir yaşantı. Gene de bir derdim olduğunda Harry’ye gideceğimi sanmıyorum. Sana gelmeyi yeğlerim, Basil.
es: —¡Ah, Harry! —exclamó el muchacho con una carcajada—. Harry se pasa los días diciendo cosas increíbles y las veladas haciendo cosas improbables. Exactamente la clase de vida que me gustaría llevar. Pero de todos modos no creo que fuese en busca de Harry cuando tuviera problemas. Creo que iría antes a verte a ti.
vi_translation: "Oh, Harry!" the young man exclaimed, with a murmuring laugh. "Harry spends many days talking about trivial matters, and many nights doing pointless things. It's truly a way of life that I would like to experience. But I still don't think I could turn to Harry if I were in trouble. I'd rather turn to you, Basil."
tr_translation: The young man chuckled to himself, "Ah, Harry!" "Harry spends his days saying unbelievable things, and his nights doing unimaginable things. Exactly the kind of life I want to lead. Still, I don't think I would go to Harry if I had a problem. I would prefer to come to you, Basil."
es_translation: —Ah, Harry! —exclaimed the boy with a laugh—. Harry spends his days saying incredible things and his evenings doing improbable things. Exactly the kind of life I would like to lead. But anyway, I don't think I would go looking for Harry when I had problems. I think I would go to see you first.

en: “You will sit to me again?”
vi: “Cậu sẽ ngồi làm mẫu lại cho tôi chứ?”
tr: “Gene poz verecek misin bana?
es: —¿Volverás a posar para mí?
vi_translation: "Will you sit and model for me again?"
tr_translation: “Will you give me a gene?”
es_translation: —Will you pose for me again?

en: “Impossible!”
vi: “Không thể nào!”
tr: “İmkânı yok.
es: —¡Imposible!
vi_translation: "Impossible!"
tr_translation: “It's impossible.”
es_translation: —Impossible!

en: “You spoil my life as an artist by refusing, Dorian. No man comes across two ideal things. Few come across one.”
vi: “Cậu đã làm hỏng đời tôi trên tư cách một nghệ sỹ bằng việc từ chối, Dorian. Không ai tình cờ gặp được hai người lý tưởng của mình. Chỉ vài kẻ tình cờ gặp được một người mà thôi.”
tr: “Bunu geri çevirmekle benim sanat hayatımı baltalıyorsun, Dorian. Hiç kimsenin karşısına ideal olan iki şey çıkmaz. Bir tanesinin çıktığı bile az görülmüştür.
es: —Destrozas mi vida de artista negándote. Nadie se tropieza dos veces con el ideal. Y son muy pocos los que lo encuentran siquiera una.
vi_translation: "You have spoiled my life as an artist by refusing, Dorian. No one ever meets two ideal people. Only a few ever meet one."
tr_translation: "By rejecting this, you are sabotaging my artistic life, Dorian. No one is ever faced with two ideal things. It is rare enough for even one to appear."
es_translation: —You destroy my life as an artist by refusing. No one stumbles upon the ideal twice. And very few even find it once.

en: “I can’t explain it to you, Basil, but I must never sit to you again. There is something fatal about a portrait. It has a life of its own. I will come and have tea with you. That will be just as pleasant.”
vi: “Tôi không thể giải thích cho anh, Basil, nhưng tôi không bao giờ ngồi làm mẫu lại cho anh được nữa. Có gì đó tai hại ở một bức chân dung. Nó có cuộc đời riêng. Tôi sẽ đến uống trà với anh. Thế sẽ vừa đủ vui.”
tr: “Anlatamam, Basil, ne var ki sana bundan böyle asla poz vermemem gerekiyor. Portre denen şeyde uğursuzluk mu oluyor ne! Portrenin kendince bir hayatı oluyor sanki. Ben gelir seninle çay içerim. Bu da aynı derecede zevkli olur.
es: —No te lo puedo explicar, pero no puedo volver a posar para ti. Hay algo fatal en un retrato. Tiene vida propia. Iré a tomar el té contigo. Será igual de placentero.
vi_translation: “I can't explain it to you, Basil, but I can never sit for you again. There is something fatal about a portrait. It has its own life. I will come and have tea with you. That will be enough fun.”
tr_translation: “I can't explain, Basil, but I must never pose for you again. Is there some kind of curse in portraits or what! It's as if the portrait has a life of its own. I'll come and have tea with you. That would be just as enjoyable.”
es_translation: —I can't explain it to you, but I can't pose for you again. There is something fatal in a portrait. It has a life of its own. I'll go have tea with you. It will be just as pleasant.

en: “Pleasanter for you, I am afraid,” murmured Hallward regretfully. “And now good-bye. I am sorry you won’t let me look at the picture once again. But that can’t be helped. I quite understand what you feel about it.”
vi: “Vui hơn với cậu, tôi e là vậy,” Hallward lẩm bẩm, tiếc nuối. “Giờ thì tạm biệt. Tôi rất lấy làm tiếc là cậu không cho tôi nhìn bức tranh một lần nữa. Nhưng biết làm sao. Tôi thấu hiểu những gì cậu cảm thấy ở nó.”
tr: Hallward üzgün üzgün, “Korkarım yalnızca senin için öyle olur,” diye mırıldandı. “Şimdi artık, hoşça kal. Şu resme bir kerecik daha bakmama izin vermediğin için üzgünüm, ama elden ne gelir? Senin bu konudaki duygularını çok iyi anlıyorum.
es: —Placentero para ti, mucho me temo —murmuró Hallward, pesaroso—. Y ahora, adiós. Siento que no me dejes ver el cuadro una vez más. Pero qué se le va a hacer. Entiendo perfectamente tus sentimientos.
vi_translation: “Happier for you, I fear so,” Hallward muttered, regretfully. “Now, goodbye. I am very sorry that you won't let me see the painting one more time. But what can be done. I understand how you feel about it.”
tr_translation: Hallward said sadly, "I'm afraid it would only be that way for you," he murmured. "Now, goodbye. I'm sorry you didn't let me look at the painting one more time, but what can be done? I understand your feelings on this matter very well."
es_translation: —Pleasant for you, I very much fear —murmured Hallward, sorrowful—. And now, goodbye. I regret that you won't let me see the painting once more. But what can be done. I completely understand your feelings.

en: As he left the room, Dorian Gray smiled to himself. Poor Basil! How little he knew of the true reason! And how strange it was that, instead of having been forced to reveal his own secret, he had succeeded, almost by chance, in wresting a secret from his friend! How much that strange confession explained to him! The painter’s absurd fits of jealousy, his wild devotion, his extravagant panegyrics, his curious reticences—he understood them all now, and he felt sorry. There seemed to him to be something tragic in a friendship so coloured by romance.
vi: Lúc y ra khỏi phòng, Dorian Gray cười với mình. Tội nghiệp Basil! Y biết mới ít làm sao về lý do thật! Và rất lạ là, thay vì bị buộc phải để lộ bí mật của mình, cậu lại thành công, gần như tình cờ, trong việc moi được một bí mật của bạn cậu! Lời thú nhận kỳ lạ ấy đã giải thích được biết bao điều cho cậu! Những cơn ghen tuông vô lý của họa sỹ, sự tận tâm cuồng nhiệt của anh ấy, những lời tán tụng quá mức của anh ấy, tính trầm lặng lạ lùng của anh ấy — giờ đây cậu đã hiểu hết chúng, và cậu thấy thương thương. Cậu thấy dường như có gì đó bi kịch ở một tình bạn được tô màu bằng sự lãng mạn như vậy.
tr: O dışarı çıkarken Dorian bıyık altından gülümsedi. Zavallı Basil! Gerçek nedeni hiç bilmiyordu! Sonra, Dorian’ın kendi gizini ele vermek zorunda kalacağı yerde, neredeyse bir rastlantıyla arkadaşının ağzından giz koparmayı başarması da ne tuhaftı! O garip itiraf Dorian’a öyle çok şey açıklıyordu ki! Ressamın gülünç kıskançlık krizleri, delice bağlılığı, aşırıya kaçan övgüleri, anlaşılmaz çekingenlikleri... Dorian şimdi bunların hepsini anlıyor, içini bir acıma bürüyordu. İçine böylesine aşk renginin karışmış olduğu bir dostlukta trajik bir yön yok muydu?
es: Mientras lo veía salir de la habitación, Dorian Gray no pudo evitar una sonrisa. ¡Pobre Basil! ¡Qué lejos estaba de saber la verdadera razón! ¡Y qué extraño era que, en lugar de verse forzado a revelar su propio secreto, hubiera logrado, casi por casualidad, arrancar a su amigo el suyo! ¡Cuántas cosas le había explicado aquella extraña confesión! Los absurdos ataques de celos del pintor, su desmedida devoción, sus extravagantes alabanzas, sus curiosas reticencias..., ahora lo entendía todo, y sintió pena. Le pareció que había algo trágico en una amistad tan cercana al amor.
vi_translation: When he left the room, Dorian Gray smiled to himself. Poor Basil! How little he knew about the real reason! And it was very strange that, instead of being forced to reveal his own secret, he had succeeded, almost by chance, in extracting a secret from his friend! That strange confession had explained so many things to him! The painter's irrational jealousies, his fervent devotion, his excessive praises, his strange silence — now he understood them all, and he felt a bit of pity. It seemed to him that there was something tragic about a friendship colored by such romance.
tr_translation: As he went outside, Dorian smiled to himself. Poor Basil! He never knew the real reason! Then, how strange it was that, almost by chance, he managed to extract the secret from his friend's mouth, where Dorian would have had to reveal his own secret! That strange confession explained so much to Dorian! The painter's ridiculous fits of jealousy, his mad devotion, his excessive praises, his inexplicable shyness... Dorian now understood all of this, and a feeling of pity enveloped him. Wasn't there a tragic aspect to a friendship in which such a color of love was mixed?
es_translation: As he watched him leave the room, Dorian Gray couldn't help but smile. Poor Basil! How far he was from knowing the real reason! And how strange it was that, instead of being forced to reveal his own secret, he had managed, almost by chance, to extract his friend's! How many things that strange confession had explained to him! The painter's absurd fits of jealousy, his excessive devotion, his extravagant praises, his curious reticences... now he understood everything, and he felt pity. It seemed to him that there was something tragic in a friendship so close to love.

en: He sighed and touched the bell. The portrait must be hidden away at all costs. He could not run such a risk of discovery again. It had been mad of him to have allowed the thing to remain, even for an hour, in a room to which any of his friends had access.
vi: Cậu thở dài, và đánh chuông. Bức chân dung phải được giấu đi bằng mọi giá. Cậu không thể mạo hiểm với việc bị khám phá ra lần nữa. Cậu hẳn là phải bị mất trí thì mới cho phép vật này còn được ở lại, thậm chí một giờ thôi, trong căn phòng mà bất cứ người bạn nào của cậu cũng có thể vào.
tr: Genç adam bir göğüs geçirerek çıngırağı çaldı. Ne pahasına olursa olsun portre gizlenmeliydi. Bugünkü gibi bir tehlikeyi bir daha göze alamazdı. Bu resmi arkadaşlarının girip çıktığı bir odada bir saat bile tutmakla delilik etmişti. 4. XIX. yüzyılın son yıllarında en gözde resim galerisi George Petit’inkidir. 1882 yılında kurulmuştur. Pek çok farklı akıma kapılarını açmış, ilk başarılı oldukları dönemde Empresyonistleri sergilemiştir.
es: Suspiró y tocó la campanilla. Tenía que ocultar el retrato a toda costa. No podía correr de nuevo el riesgo de verse descubierto. Había sido una locura permitir que continuara, ni siquiera por una hora, en una habitación donde entraban sus amigos.
vi_translation: He sighed and rang the bell. The portrait had to be hidden at all costs. He couldn't risk being discovered again. He must have been out of his mind to allow this thing to remain, even for an hour, in a room where any of his friends could enter.
tr_translation: The young man sighed deeply and rang the bell. The portrait had to be hidden at all costs. He could not risk such danger again as he did today. It had been madness to keep the painting in a room where his friends came and went, even for an hour. 4. At the end of the 19th century, the most popular art gallery was George Petit's. It was founded in 1882. It opened its doors to many different movements and exhibited the Impressionists during their initial successful period.
es_translation: He sighed and rang the bell. He had to hide the portrait at all costs. He couldn't risk being discovered again. It had been madness to allow it to remain, even for an hour, in a room where his friends entered.

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: Chương 10
tr: (Ç. N. Onuncu bölüm
es: Capítulo 10
vi_translation: Chapter 10
tr_translation: (Ç. N.) Tenth chapter
es_translation: Chapter 10

en: When his servant entered, he looked at him steadfastly and wondered if he had thought of peering behind the screen. The man was quite impassive and waited for his orders. Dorian lit a cigarette and walked over to the glass and glanced into it. He could see the reflection of Victor’s face perfectly. It was like a placid mask of servility. There was nothing to be afraid of, there. Yet he thought it best to be on his guard.
vi: Khi người hầu của cậu vào, cậu nhìn hắn không rời, và tự hỏi không biết hắn có nghĩ đến việc nhòm ra sau tấm chắn không. Người hầu khá điềm tĩnh, chờ lệnh cậu. Dorian châm một điếu thuốc, bước lại gần gương và liếc vào nó. Cậu có thể thấy rõ bóng mặt Victor. Nó như cái mặt nạ bình thản biết thân biết phận nô lệ. Không có gì phải sợ ở đây. Tuy nhiên cậu nghĩ cảnh giác vẫn hơn.
tr: Uşak içeri girince Dorian ona dikkatle baktı. Adamın aklından paravanın ardına bakmayı geçirip geçirmediğini düşündü. Adam serinkanlılıkla duruyor ve efendisinin buyruğunu bekliyordu. Dorian bir sigara yakarak gitti, aynaya bir göz attı. Victor’un yüzünün ayna içindeki yansımasını açıkça görebiliyordu. Bu yüz donuk bir “emir kulu” maskesi gibiydi. Bu yönden korkulacak bir şey yoktu. Gene de Dorian en doğrusunun tetikte bulunmak olduğunu, kafasından geçirdi.
es: Cuando entró el criado, lo miró fijamente, preguntándose si se le habría ocurrido curiosear detrás del biombo. Absolutamente impasible, Víctor esperaba sus órdenes. Dorian encendió un cigarrillo y se acercó al espejo. En él vio reflejado con toda claridad el rostro del ayuda de cámara, máscara perfecta de servilismo. No había nada que temer por aquel lado. Pero enseguida pensó que más le valía estar en guardia.
vi_translation: When his servant came in, he looked at him intently, wondering if he had thought about peeking behind the screen. The servant was quite calm, waiting for his orders. Dorian lit a cigarette, walked over to the mirror, and glanced into it. He could clearly see Victor's reflection. It was like the calm mask of a knowing slave. There was nothing to fear here. However, he thought it was better to remain cautious.
tr_translation: When the servant entered, Dorian looked at him carefully. He wondered if the man had thought about looking behind the screen. The man stood calmly, waiting for his master's command. Dorian lit a cigarette, walked over, and glanced at the mirror. He could clearly see Victor's face reflected in the mirror. This face was like the mask of a "submissive servant." There was nothing to fear from this angle. Still, Dorian thought it best to remain vigilant.
es_translation: When the servant entered, he looked at him intently, wondering if it had occurred to him to snoop behind the screen. Absolutely impassive, Victor awaited his orders. Dorian lit a cigarette and approached the mirror. In it, he saw the face of the valet reflected clearly, a perfect mask of servility. There was nothing to fear from that side. But he immediately thought it was better to stay on guard.

en: Speaking very slowly, he told him to tell the house-keeper that he wanted to see her, and then to go to the frame-maker and ask him to send two of his men round at once. It seemed to him that as the man left the room his eyes wandered in the direction of the screen. Or was that merely his own fancy?
vi: Phát âm rất chậm, cậu bảo hắn nói lại với quản gia là cậu muốn gặp bà ấy, sau đó đến chỗ người làm khung và nhờ ông ta cho hai người thợ của mình đến ngay. Cậu thấy dường như lúc người hầu ra khỏi phòng thì mắt hắn có đảo về phía tấm chắn. Hay đó chỉ là tưởng tượng của cậu?
tr: Tane tane konuşarak adama, kâhya kadını odaya çağırmasını, sonra da çerçeveciye gidip eve iki adam yollamasını tembihlemesini söyledi. Adam odadan çıkarken gözleri paravandan yana kaymış gibi geldi. Yoksa Dorian kuruntuya mı kapılıyordu?
es: Con voz reposada, le encargó decirle al ama de llaves que quería verla, y que después fuese a la tienda del marquista y le pidiese que enviara a dos de sus hombres al instante. Le pareció que mientras salía de la habitación, la mirada de Víctor se desviaba hacia el biombo. ¿O era imaginación suya?
vi_translation: Speaking very slowly, he told him to inform the housekeeper that he wanted to meet her, then go to the frame maker and ask him to send two of his workers immediately. It seemed to him that when the servant left the room, his eyes glanced towards the screen. Or was that just his imagination?
tr_translation: Speaking slowly, he told the man to summon the housekeeper to the room and then to go to the framer and send two men to the house. As the man was leaving the room, it seemed his eyes had glanced towards the screen. Or was Dorian becoming paranoid?
es_translation: In a calm voice, he asked her to tell the housekeeper that he wanted to see her, and then to go to the marquis's shop and ask him to send two of his men immediately. It seemed to her that as she left the room, Victor's gaze shifted towards the screen. Or was it her imagination?

en: After a few moments, in her black silk dress, with old-fashioned thread mittens on her wrinkled hands, Mrs. Leaf bustled into the library. He asked her for the key of the schoolroom.
vi: Một lát sau, mặc váy lụa đen, đeo cặp găng sợi hở ngón lỗi mốt trên đôi tay nhăn nheo, Bà Leaf hối hả vào thư viện. Cậu hỏi bà cái chìa khóa phòng học.
tr: Birkaç dakika sonra, sırtında siyah ipek elbisesiyle, buruşuk ellerinde eski moda, parmaksız ibrişim eldiveniyle ms Leaf içeriye girdi. Dorian ondan okul odasının anahtarını istedi.
es: Al cabo de un momento, con su vestido negro de seda, y mitones de hilo a la vieja usanza cubriéndole las manos, la señora Leaf entró, apresurada, en la biblioteca. Dorian le pidió la llave del aula.
vi_translation: A moment later, wearing a black silk dress and a pair of outdated fingerless gloves on her wrinkled hands, Mrs. Leaf hurried into the library. You asked her for the classroom key.
tr_translation: A few minutes later, Ms. Leaf entered, wearing a black silk dress on her back, and with old-fashioned, fingerless silk gloves on her wrinkled hands. Dorian asked her for the key to the schoolroom.
es_translation: After a moment, with her black silk dress and old-fashioned thread mittens covering her hands, Mrs. Leaf hurriedly entered the library. Dorian asked her for the key to the schoolroom.

en: “The old schoolroom, Mr. Dorian?” she exclaimed. “Why, it is full of dust. I must get it arranged and put straight before you go into it. It is not fit for you to see, sir. It is not, indeed.”
vi: “Phòng học cũ ạ, thưa mít-tơ Dorian?” bà kêu lên. “Tại sao, nó đầy bụi. Tôi phải sửa soạn lại nó, và dọn ngăn nắp trước khi cậu vào. Nó không tiện cho cậu xem đâu. Quả thật là không.”
tr: Kadın, “Eski okul odası mı, mr Dorian?” diye bağırdı. “Ama, toz içinde orası. Sizin girebilmeniz için önce şöyle bir derleyip toplamam, çekidüzen vermem gerek. Bu durumda görülecek gibi değil, valla, inanın görülecek gibi değil.
es: —¿La antigua aula, señor Dorian? —exclamó el ama de llaves—. ¡Pero si está llena de polvo! Tengo que limpiar y poner orden antes de dejarle entrar. No se la puede ver tal como está, no señor.
vi_translation: “The old schoolroom, Mr. Dorian?” she exclaimed. “Why, it's full of dust. I must tidy it up and arrange it neatly before you go in. It's not suitable for you to see it now. Really, it isn't.”
tr_translation: The woman shouted, "The old school room, Mr. Dorian?" "But it's covered in dust. I need to tidy it up a bit and put it in order before you can enter. It's not in a state to be seen, really, believe me, it's not in a state to be seen."
es_translation: —The old classroom, Mr. Dorian? —exclaimed the housekeeper—. But it's full of dust! I have to clean and tidy up before letting you in. You can't see it as it is, no sir.

en: “I don’t want it put straight, Leaf. I only want the key.”
vi: “Tôi không cần nó được dọn ngăn nắp, Leaf. Tôi chỉ cần chìa khóa.
tr: “Düzeltilmesini istemiyorum, ms Leaf. Yalnızca anahtarını istiyorum.
es: —No quiero que ponga usted orden, Leaf. Sólo quiero la llave.
vi_translation: “I don't need it to be tidied up, Leaf. I just need the key.”
tr_translation: “I don't want it fixed, Ms. Leaf. I just want its key.”
es_translation: —I don't want you to put things in order, Leaf. I just want the key.

en: “Well, sir, you’ll be covered with cobwebs if you go into it. Why, it hasn’t been opened for nearly five years—not since his lordship died.”
vi: “Vâng, thưa cậu, mà cậu sẽ bị phủ đầy mạng nhện nếu cậu đi vào trong đó. Tại sao thế ạ, nó đã không được mở ra gần năm năm nay rồi, từ hồi tôn ông qua đời.
tr: “Ama efendim, oraya girerseniz üstünüz başınız örümcek ağı içinde kalır. O oda açılmayalı beş yıl oluyor, neredeyse; Lord Hazretleri’nin ölümünden bu yana açılmadı.
es: —Lo que usted diga, señor, pero se llenará de telarañas. Hace casi cinco años que no se abre, desde que murió su señoría.
vi_translation: “Yes, sir, but you will be covered in cobwebs if you go in there. Why is that? It hasn't been opened for nearly five years, since the old man passed away.”
tr_translation: “But sir, if you go in there, you'll get covered in cobwebs. That room hasn't been opened in almost five years; it hasn't been opened since the Lord's death.”
es_translation: —Whatever you say, sir, but it will be filled with cobwebs. It has been almost five years since it was last opened, since his lordship passed away.

en: He winced at the mention of his grandfather. He had hateful memories of him. “That does not matter,” he answered. “I simply want to see the place—that is all. Give me the key.”
vi: Cậu co rúm lại khi nghe nhắc đến ông ngoại. Cậu có những ký ức căm hờn về ông. “Chẳng sao cả,” cậu trả lời. “Tôi chỉ muốn nhìn chỗ đó — chỉ thế thôi. Đưa tôi chìa khóa.
tr: Dedesinin sözü geçince Dorian irkildi. Dedesine ilişkin çok kötü anıları vardı. “Zararı yok,” dedi. “Ben şöyle bir bakmak istiyorum oraya, başkaca bir şey değil. Siz anahtarı verin bana.
es: Dorian puso mala cara al oír hablar de su abuelo. Tenía muy malos recuerdos suyos. —No importa —dijo—. Sólo quiero verla, eso es todo. Déme la llave.
vi_translation: He recoiled at the mention of his grandfather. He had bitter memories of him. "It's okay," he replied. "I just want to see that place — that's all. Give me the key."
tr_translation: Dorian flinched when his grandfather was mentioned. He had very bad memories related to his grandfather. “No harm,” he said. “I just want to take a look there, nothing else. Give me the key.”
es_translation: Dorian made a grimace upon hearing about his grandfather. He had very bad memories of him. —It doesn't matter —he said—. I just want to see her, that's all. Give me the key.

en: “And here is the key, sir,” said the old lady, going over the contents of her bunch with tremulously uncertain hands. “Here is the key. I’ll have it off the bunch in a moment. But you don’t think of living up there, sir, and you so comfortable here?”
vi: “Chìa khóa đây, thưa cậu,” bà già nói, lục các thứ trong chùm chìa khóa bằng hai bàn tay run run ngờ vực. “Chìa đây. Tôi sẽ gỡ nó ra khỏi chùm ngay đây. Nhưng cậu không nghĩ về việc sẽ sống trên đó chứ, thưa cậu, và cậu ở đây rất thoải mái mà?”
tr: Yaşlı kadın anahtar destesini titrek elleriyle yoklayarak, “Buyurun, efendim, işte anahtar,” dedi. “Şimdi çıkartırım. Sakın odanızı oraya taşımak falan istemiyorsunuz değil mi, efendim? Burada rahatınız öyle yerinde ki.
es: —Y aquí la tiene —dijo la anciana, repasando el contenido de su manojo de llaves con manos trémulamente inseguras—. Ésta es. La sacaré enseguida. ¿No pensará usted vivir allí, tan cómodo como está aquí?
vi_translation: "Here is the key, sir," the old woman said, rummaging through the bunch of keys with her two trembling, doubtful hands. "Here is the key. I will take it off the bunch right away. But you are not thinking of living up there, are you, sir, when you are so comfortable here?"
tr_translation: The old woman, fumbling with the bunch of keys with her trembling hands, said, "Here you go, sir, here is the key." "I will take it out now. You don't want to move your room there or anything, do you, sir? You are so comfortable here.""
es_translation: —And here it is —said the old woman, going through the contents of her bunch of keys with tremblingly uncertain hands—. This is it. I'll take it out right away. You don't think you'll live there as comfortably as you are here, do you?

en: “No, no,” he cried petulantly. “Thank you, Leaf. That will do.”
vi: “Không, không,” cậu la lên, nóng nảy. “Cảm ơn, Leaf. Đủ rồi.”
tr: Dorian, “Yok canım, yok,” diye huysuzlandı. “Teşekkür ederim, Leaf. Şimdilik hepsi bu.
es: —No, no —exclamó Dorian, algo irritado—. Muchas gracias, Leaf. Eso es todo.
vi_translation: “No, no,” he shouted, impatiently. “Thank you, Leaf. That's enough.”
tr_translation: Dorian grumbled, "No way, no." "Thank you, Leaf. That's all for now."
es_translation: —No, no —exclaimed Dorian, somewhat irritated—. Thank you very much, Leaf. That is all.

en: She lingered for a few moments, and was garrulous over some detail of the household. He sighed and told her to manage things as she thought best. She left the room, wreathed in smiles.
vi: Bà nấn ná một lát, và ba hoa về tiểu tiết nào đó trong nhà. Cậu thở dài, bảo bà cứ lo liệu mọi chuyện theo như bà nghĩ là tốt nhất. Bà rời phòng, mặt tươi cười.
tr: Kâhya kadın birkaç dakika daha oyalanarak ev işlerinin bir ayrıntısını konu edip çene çaldı. Genç adam içini çekerek, işleri nasıl biliyorsa öyle idare etmesini söyledi. ms Leaf gülücükler içinde dışarı çıktı.
es: El ama de llaves tardó aún unos momentos en retirarse, extendiéndose sobre algún detalle del gobierno de la casa. Dorian suspiró, y le dijo que lo administrara todo como mejor le pareciera. Finalmente se marchó, deshaciéndose en sonrisas.
vi_translation: She lingered for a moment, rambling about some minor details in the house. He sighed, telling her to handle everything as she thought was best. She left the room, smiling brightly.
tr_translation: The housekeeper woman lingered for a few more minutes, chatting about a detail of the housework. The young man sighed and told her to manage things as she knew best. Ms. Leaf went outside with smiles.
es_translation: The housekeeper took a few more moments to leave, elaborating on some detail of the household management. Dorian sighed and told her to manage everything as she saw fit. Finally, she left, beaming with smiles.

en: As the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked round the room. His eye fell on a large, purple satin coverlet heavily embroidered with gold, a splendid piece of late seventeenth-century Venetian work that his grandfather had found in a convent near Bologna. Yes, that would serve to wrap the dreadful thing in. It had perhaps served often as a pall for the dead. Now it was to hide something that had a corruption of its own, worse than the corruption of death itself—something that would breed horrors and yet would never die. What the worm was to the corpse, his sins would be to the painted image on the canvas. They would mar its beauty and eat away its grace. They would defile it and make it shameful. And yet the thing would still live on. It would be always alive.
vi: Lúc cửa đóng, Dorian nhét chìa khóa vào túi, nhìn quanh phòng. Mắt cậu để ý thấy một cái khăn phủ giường lớn bằng xa-tanh tía, thêu đặc vàng, một tác phẩm lộng lẫy của Venice thời cuối thế kỷ mười bảy mà ông ngoại cậu đã tìm thấy trong một nữ tu viện gần Bologna. Đúng, nó sẽ được dùng để bọc cái thứ khủng khiếp ấy lại. Nó không chừng từng được dùng thường xuyên như một tấm vải phủ áo quan cho người chết. Giờ thì nó che giấu một thứ gì đó có sự mục nát riêng, còn tệ hơn cả sự mục nát của bản thân cái chết — một thứ gì đó sẽ sản sinh ra các nỗi sợ song lại không bao giờ chết. Những gì mà sâu bọ làm với xác chết, cũng là những cái mà các tội lỗi của cậu sẽ làm với hình ảnh được vẽ trên tấm toan. Chúng sẽ phá vẻ đẹp của nó, ăn mất nét duyên của nó. Chúng sẽ làm ô uế nó, khiến nó xấu hổ. Tuy nhiên thứ ấy sẽ vẫn sống tiếp. Nó sẽ sống mãi.
tr: Kapı kapanınca Dorian anahtarı cebine atarak dört bir yanına bakındı. Ağır sırma işlemeli, geniş, mor satenden bir örtü gözüne ilişti. On yedinci yüzyılın sonlarından kalma şahane bir Venedik işlemesi olan bu örtüyü dedesi Bologna dolaylarındaki bir manastırda bulmuştu. Evet, o ürkünç şeyin üstüne örtmeye uygundu. Belki de genellikle cenaze üstüne örtülmek için kullanılmıştı. Şimdi de içinde kendince bir çürümeyi taşıyan bir şeyi gizlemeye yarayacaktı; ölüm çürümesinden daha beter bir çürümeyi taşıyan, durmadan ürküler doğurduğu halde bir türlü ölmeyen bir şey. Solucan ve kurtlar yerdeki ölü için neyse, Dorian’ın günahları da tuval üstündeki boyalı imge için aynı şey olacaktı. Günahlar bu imgenin güzelliğini bozacak, inceliğini kemirecekti. Kirleteceklerdi bu imgeyi, edepsiz bir şeye dönüştüreceklerdi. Ama portre hâlâ yaşamını sürdürecekti. Her zaman canlı kalacaktı.
es: Al cerrarse la puerta, Dorian se guardó la llave en el bolsillo y recorrió la biblioteca con la mirada. Sus ojos se detuvieron en un amplio cubrecama de satén morado con bordados en oro que su abuelo había encontrado en un convento próximo a Bolonia. Sí; serviría para envolver el horrible lienzo. Quizás se había utilizado más de una vez como mortaja. Ahora tendría que ocultar algo con una corrupción peculiar, peor que la de los muertos: algo que engendraría horrores sin por ello morir nunca. Lo que los gusanos eran para el cadáver, serían sus pecados para la imagen pintada en el lienzo, destruyendo su apostura y devorando su gracia. Lo mancharían, convirtiéndolo en algo vergonzoso. Y sin embargo aquella cosa seguiría viva, viviría siempre.
vi_translation: When the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked around the room. His eyes noticed a large satin bedspread, richly embroidered in gold, a splendid work from late seventeenth-century Venice that his grandfather had found in a nunnery near Bologna. Yes, it would be used to wrap that horrible thing. It might have once been frequently used as a shroud for the dead. Now it concealed something with its own decay, worse than the decay of death itself — something that would produce fears but never die. What worms do to a corpse, so would his sins do to the image painted on the canvas. They would mar its beauty, consume its grace. They would defile it, make it shameful. Yet it would continue to live. It would live on forever.
tr_translation: When the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and looked around. A heavy, gold-embroidered, wide, purple satin cover caught his eye. This cover, a magnificent Venetian embroidery from the late seventeenth century, had been found by his grandfather in a monastery near Bologna. Yes, it was suitable to cover that dreadful thing. Perhaps it had generally been used to cover a corpse. Now it would serve to hide something that carried its own kind of decay; something that carried a decay worse than death's decay, something that continually spawned horrors yet never died. What worms and maggots are to a corpse in the ground, Dorian's sins would be to the painted image on the canvas. Sins would mar this image's beauty, gnaw at its delicacy. They would defile this image, turn it into something obscene. But the portrait would still continue to live. It would always remain alive.
es_translation: As the door closed, Dorian put the key in his pocket and scanned the library with his eyes. His eyes stopped on a large purple satin bedspread with gold embroidery that his grandfather had found in a convent near Bologna. Yes; it would serve to wrap the horrible canvas. Perhaps it had been used more than once as a shroud. Now it would have to hide something with a peculiar corruption, worse than that of the dead: something that would spawn horrors without ever dying. What worms were to the corpse, his sins would be to the image painted on the canvas, destroying its comeliness and devouring its grace. They would stain it, turning it into something shameful. And yet that thing would remain alive, it would live forever.

en: He shuddered, and for a moment he regretted that he had not told Basil the true reason why he had wished to hide the picture away. Basil would have helped him to resist Lord Henry’s influence, and the still more poisonous influences that came from his own temperament. The love that he bore him—for it was really love—had nothing in it that was not noble and intellectual. It was not that mere physical admiration of beauty that is born of the senses and that dies when the senses tire. It was such love as Michelangelo had known, and Montaigne, and Winckelmann, and Shakespeare himself. Yes, Basil could have saved him. But it was too late now. The past could always be annihilated. Regret, denial, or forgetfulness could do that. But the future was inevitable. There were passions in him that would find their terrible outlet, dreams that would make the shadow of their evil real.
vi: Cậu rùng mình và, trong chốc lát, cậu ân hận là đã không kể cho Basil nghe lý do thực sự tại sao cậu muốn giấu bức tranh đi. Basil sẽ giúp cậu chống lại ảnh hưởng của huân tước Henry, và những ảnh hưởng còn độc hại hơn có nguồn gốc từ khí chất của chính cậu. Tình yêu mà anh ấy ôm ấp với cậu — vì nó là tình yêu thực sự — không có gì trong nó là không cao quý và trí tuệ. Nó không phải chỉ là sự ngưỡng mộ tự nhiên với sắc đẹp, một sự ngưỡng mộ vẫn được sinh ra từ các giác quan và cũng chết đi khi các giác quan mệt mỏi. Nó là thứ tình yêu như loại mà Michael Angelo, Montaigne, Winckelmann, và chính Shakespeare từng biết đến. Vâng, Basil có thể cứu được cậu. Nhưng giờ đã quá muộn. Dĩ vãng luôn có thể bị hủy diệt. Nỗi ân hận, sự phủ nhận, hoặc tính mau quên có thể làm điều ấy. Nhưng tương lai thì không thể tránh được. Những đam mê trong cậu sẽ tìm được chỗ thoát khủng khiếp của chúng, những giấc mộng sẽ biến cái bóng tội lỗi của chúng thành hiện thực.
tr: Genç adam tepeden tırnağa ürperdi, resmi gizli tutmak isteyişinin gerçek nedenini Basil’e söylemediğine bir an pişman oldu. Lord Henry’nin etkisinde kalmasına ya da kendi zevk düşkünlüğünün tutsağı olmasına karşı koymakta Basil ona yardımcı olurdu. Basil’in ona beslediği aşkta –çünkü gerçekten aşktı bu– asil ve ruhsal olmayan hiçbir şey yoktu. Güzelliğe karşı duyulan salt fiziksel hayranlık değildi bu. Böyle bir hayranlık duyulardan doğar ve duyular yorulduğu zaman da ölür. Yok, bu Michelangelo’nun tatmış olduğu türden bir aşktı, Montaigne’in, Winckelmann’ın, bizzat Shakespeare’in tatmış olduğu türden. Evet, evet, söylemiş olsaydı Basil onu kurtarabilirdi. Ama artık iş işten geçmişti. Geçmiş her zaman ortadan silinebilirdi. Pişmanlık, unutkanlık, yadsımayla başarılabilirdi bu. Gel gör ki gelecek, kaçınılmazdı. Dorian’ın içinde, ihtiyaçları olan müthiş çıkış yollarını er geç bulacak olan tutkular, kötülüklerinin gölgesini gerçeğe dönüştürecek olan düşler yatıyordu.
es: Dorian se estremeció y durante unos instantes lamentó no haberle contado a Basil la verdadera razón para esconder el retrato. El pintor le hubiera ayudado a resistir la influencia de lord Henry, y otra, todavía más venenosa, que procedía de su propio temperamento. En el amor que Basil le profesaba -porque se trataba de verdadero amor— no había nada que no fuera noble e intelectual. No era la simple admiración de la belleza que nace de los sentidos y que muere cuando los sentidos se cansan. Era un amor como el que habían conocido Miguel Ángel, y Montaigne, y Winckelmann, y el mismo Shakespeare. Sí, Basil podría haberlo salvado. Pero ya era demasiado tarde. El pasado siempre se podía aniquilar. Arrepentimiento, rechazo u olvido podían hacerlo. Pero el futuro era inevitable. Había en él pasiones que encontrarían su terrible encarnación, sueños que harían real la sombra de su perversidad.
vi_translation: He shuddered and, for a moment, regretted not telling Basil the real reason why he wanted to hide the painting. Basil would help him resist the influence of Lord Henry, and the even more harmful influences stemming from his own temperament. The love that he cherished for him — because it was true love — had nothing in it that was not noble and intellectual. It was not merely the natural admiration for beauty, an admiration that is born from the senses and also dies when the senses grow weary. It was the kind of love that Michael Angelo, Montaigne, Winckelmann, and even Shakespeare had known. Yes, Basil could have saved him. But now it was too late. The past can always be destroyed. Regret, denial, or forgetfulness can do that. But the future is inevitable. The passions within him would find their terrible outlet, the dreams would turn their shadow of guilt into reality.
tr_translation: The young man shivered from head to toe, regretting for a moment that he hadn't told Basil the real reason for wanting to keep the portrait a secret. Basil would have helped him resist falling under Lord Henry's influence or becoming a prisoner of his own hedonism. In Basil's love for him – for it truly was love – there was nothing base or unspiritual. It was not a mere physical admiration for beauty. Such admiration is born of the senses and dies when the senses grow weary. No, this was the kind of love that Michelangelo had experienced, the kind that Montaigne, Winckelmann, and even Shakespeare had known. Yes, yes, if he had told him, Basil could have saved him. But now it was too late. The past could always be erased. This could be achieved through remorse, forgetfulness, and denial. But the future was inevitable. Within Dorian lay passions that would eventually find their dreadful outlets, dreams that would turn the shadows of his vices into reality.
es_translation: Dorian shuddered and for a few moments regretted not having told Basil the real reason for hiding the portrait. The painter would have helped him resist the influence of Lord Henry, and another, even more poisonous one, that came from his own temperament. In the love that Basil professed for him—because it was true love—there was nothing that was not noble and intellectual. It was not the simple admiration of beauty that arises from the senses and dies when the senses grow tired. It was a love like that known by Michelangelo, and Montaigne, and Winckelmann, and Shakespeare himself. Yes, Basil could have saved him. But it was already too late. The past could always be annihilated. Repentance, rejection, or forgetfulness could do it. But the future was inevitable. There were passions in him that would find their terrible incarnation, dreams that would make real the shadow of his perversity.

en: He took up from the couch the great purple-and-gold texture that covered it, and, holding it in his hands, passed behind the screen. Was the face on the canvas viler than before? It seemed to him that it was unchanged, and yet his loathing of it was intensified. Gold hair, blue eyes, and rose-red lips—they all were there. It was simply the expression that had altered.
