That was horrible in its cruelty. Compared to what he saw in it of censure or rebuke, how shallow Basil’s reproaches about Sibyl Vane had been!—how shallow, and of what little account! His own soul was looking out at him from the canvas and calling him to judgement. A look of pain came across him, and he flung the rich pall over the picture. As he did so, a knock came to the door. He passed out as his servant entered.
vi: Cậu nhặt lên khỏi đi-văng tấm vải lớn màu tía- và-vàng đang che phủ nó, và, giữ tấm vải ấy trong hai tay, đi ra sau tấm chắn. Có phải khuôn mặt trên toan đã đê tiện hơn trước? Cậu thấy dường như nó không thay đổi; tuy nhiên sự căm ghét của cậu với nó đã tăng lên. Tóc vàng, mắt xanh, môi đỏ hồng — chúng còn cả đây. Chỉ vẻ mặt là thay đổi. Có gì đó khủng khiếp trong sự tàn ác của nó. So sánh với những gì cậu thấy trong nó về sự chỉ trích hoặc khiển trách, thì những lời mắng mỏ của Basil về Sibyl Vane mới hời hợt làm sao! — hời hợt làm sao và vớ vẩn biết bao! Linh hồn cậu đang nhìn vào cậu từ tấm toan và đòi cậu ra xét xử. Một vẻ đau đớn xuất hiện trên mặt cậu, và cậu quăng tấm vải phủ quan tài lộng lẫy ấy lên bức tranh. Lúc cậu làm vậy, một tiếng gõ cửa vang lên. Cậu đi ra lúc người hầu bước vào.
tr: Divanın üzerindeki büyük, sırmalı, mor yaygıyı aldı; elinde yaygı, paravanın arkasına geçti. Tuvalin üzerindeki çehre eskisinden daha alçak bir ifade mi taşıyordu acaba? Resim değişmemiş gibi göründü gözüne, gene de bu nesneye karşı duyduğu tiksinti yoğunlaşmıştı. Sırma saç, mavi göz, gül kırmızısı dudaklar... Hepsi yerli yerindeydi. Değişime uğrayan yalnızca ifadeydi. Bu ifade şimdi öyle gaddardı ki tüyler ürpertiyordu. Bu ifadede bulduğu eleştiri ve kınama yanında Basil’in Sibyl Vane konusundaki sitemleri nasıl cılız kalıyordu, nasıl da cılız ve entipüften! Tuvalden ona bakan, yargılayan kendi ruhuydu. Dorian yüzünü acıyla buruşturarak elindeki şahane örtüyü resmin üzerine astı. Tam o sırada kapıya vuruldu. Uşak içeri girdiği sırada Dorian paravanın arkasından çıktı.
es: Dorian retiró del sofá la gran tela morada y oro que lo cubría y, con ella en las manos, pasó detrás del biombo. ¿Se había degradado aún más el rostro del lienzo? Le pareció que no había cambiado; la repugnancia que le inspiraba, sin embargo, iba en aumento. Cabellos de oro, ojos azules, labios encendidos: todo estaba allí. Tan sólo la expresión era distinta. Le asustó su crueldad. Comparado con lo que él descubría allí de censura y de condena, ¡cuán superficiales los reproches de Basil acerca de Sibyl Vane! Superficiales y anodinos. Su alma misma lo miraba desde el lienzo llamándolo a juicio. Dolorosamente afectado, Dorian arrojó la lujosa mortaja sobre el cuadro. Mientras lo hacía, llamaron a la puerta. Salió de detrás del biombo cuando entraba el criado.
vi_translation: He picked up the large purple-and-gold cloth from the divan that was covering it, and, holding the cloth in both hands, walked behind the screen. Had the face on the canvas become more vile than before? It seemed to him that it had not changed; however, his hatred for it had increased. Blonde hair, blue eyes, rosy-red lips — they were all still there. Only the expression had changed. There was something terrible in its cruelty. Compared to what he saw in it of criticism or reproach, how superficial — how shallow and absurd — Basil's rebukes about Sibyl Vane seemed! His soul was looking at him from the canvas and demanding that he be judged. A look of pain appeared on his face, and he flung the magnificent funeral cloth over the painting. As he did so, a knock sounded at the door. He stepped out as the servant entered.
tr_translation: He took the large, embroidered, purple cover from the divan; with the cover in his hand, he went behind the screen. Did the face on the canvas bear a lower expression than before? The painting seemed unchanged to his eye, yet his disgust towards this object had intensified. Golden hair, blue eyes, rose-red lips... Everything was in its place. The only thing that had changed was the expression. This expression was now so cruel that it sent shivers down his spine. Compared to the criticism and condemnation he found in this expression, Basil's reproaches about Sibyl Vane seemed so weak, so feeble and insignificant! It was his own soul looking at him, judging him from the canvas. Dorian, grimacing in pain, hung the magnificent cover over the painting. Just then, there was a knock at the door. As the servant entered, Dorian emerged from behind the screen.
es_translation: Dorian removed the large purple and gold cloth that covered the sofa and, with it in his hands, went behind the screen. Had the face on the canvas degraded even more? It seemed to him that it had not changed; however, the repulsion it inspired in him was increasing. Golden hair, blue eyes, burning lips: everything was there. Only the expression was different. Its cruelty frightened him. Compared to what he discovered there of censure and condemnation, how superficial Basil's reproaches about Sibyl Vane were! Superficial and trivial. His very soul looked at him from the canvas, calling him to judgment. Painfully affected, Dorian threw the luxurious shroud over the painting. As he did so, there was a knock at the door. He came out from behind the screen as the servant entered.

en: “The persons are here, Monsieur.”
vi: “Họ đến đây rồi, thưa mông-xừ.
tr: “Adamlar geldiler, mösyö.
es: —Señor, han llegado esas personas.
vi_translation: “They have arrived, sir.”
tr_translation: "The men have arrived, monsieur."
es_translation: —Sir, those people have arrived.

en: He felt that the man must be got rid of at once. He must not be allowed to know where the picture was being taken to. There was something sly about him, and he had thoughtful, treacherous eyes. Sitting down at the writing-table he scribbled a note to Lord Henry, asking him to send him round something to read and reminding him that they were to meet at eight-fifteen that evening.
vi: Cậu cảm thấy là người hầu này phải bị tống khứ ngay lập tức. Cậu phải không cho hắn biết nơi bức tranh sắp được mang đến. Có gì đó ranh mãnh ở hắn, và hắn có đôi mắt thâm trầm, xảo trá. Ngồi xuống bàn viết, cậu biên vội một lá thư ngắn cho huân tước Henry, xin anh ấy gửi qua cho cậu cái gì đó để đọc, và nhắc anh ấy nhớ là họ sẽ gặp nhau lúc tám giờ mười lăm phút tối nay.
tr: Dorian bu adamı hemencecik başından savması gerektiğini düşündü. Adamda bir sinsilik vardı; gözleri içten pazarlıklı, hilebaz bakıyordu. Dorian yazı masasının başına oturarak Lord Henry’ye bir not karaladı, ondan kendisine okuyacak bir şey yollamasını rica etti, sonra o akşam saat sekizi çeyrek geçe buluşacaklarını anımsattı.
es: Dorian sintió que tenía que deshacerse de Víctor lo antes posible. No debía saber adónde se llevaba el cuadro. Había algo malicioso en él, y en sus ojos brillaba el cálculo y la traición. Sentándose en el escritorio, redactó velozmente una nota para lord Henry, pidiéndole que le mandara alguna lectura y recordándole que habían quedado en verse a las ocho y cuarto.
vi_translation: You felt that this servant had to be dismissed immediately. You must not let him know where the painting is about to be taken. There was something cunning about him, and he had deep, deceitful eyes. Sitting down at the writing desk, you hastily wrote a short letter to Lord Henry, asking him to send you something to read, and reminding him that they would meet at eight fifteen tonight.
tr_translation: Dorian thought that he should get rid of this man immediately. There was a slyness in the man; his eyes looked deceitful and cunning. Dorian sat at his writing desk and scribbled a note to Lord Henry, asking him to send something to read, then reminded him that they would meet at a quarter past eight that evening.
es_translation: Dorian felt that he had to get rid of Victor as soon as possible. He must not know where the painting was being taken. There was something malicious about him, and in his eyes shone calculation and betrayal. Sitting at the desk, he quickly drafted a note to Lord Henry, asking him to send some reading material and reminding him that they had agreed to meet at a quarter past eight.

en: “Wait for an answer,” he said, handing it to him, “and show the men in here.”
vi: “Chờ trả lời,” cậu nói, đưa nó cho hắn, “và dẫn họ vào đây.”
tr: Pusulayı uşağına vererek, “Yanıtını bekle,” dedi. “Adamları da buraya al.
es: —Espere la respuesta —le dijo al ayuda de cámara al tenderle la misiva—, y haga pasar aquí a esos hombres.
vi_translation: “Wait for a response,” he said, handing it to him, “and bring them in here.”
tr_translation: Handing the note to his servant, he said, "Wait for the reply." "Also, bring the men here."
es_translation: —Wait for the response —he said to the valet as he handed him the letter—, and let those men in here.

en: In two or three minutes there was another knock, and Mr. Hubbard himself, the celebrated frame-maker of South Audley Street, came in with a somewhat rough-looking young assistant. Mr. Hubbard was a florid, red-whiskered little man, whose admiration for art was considerably tempered by the inveterate impecuniosity of most of the artists who dealt with him. As a rule, he never left his shop. He waited for people to come to him. But he always made an exception in favour of Dorian Gray. There was something about Dorian that charmed everybody. It was a pleasure even to see him.
vi: Sau hai hay ba phút, lại có tiếng gõ khác, và chính mít-tơ Hubbard, người làm khung lừng danh trên phố South Audley, bước vào cùng một phụ tá trẻ nhìn hơi cục mịch. Mít-tơ Hubbard là một người đàn ông nhỏ con hồng hào, tóc mai dài đỏ, mà sự ngưỡng mộ của y với nghệ thuật đã bị kiềm chế đáng kể bởi cảnh túng thiếu mãn tính của phần lớn nghệ sỹ có quan hệ với y. Theo lệ thường, y chẳng bao giờ rời tiệm. Y chờ mọi người đến với y. Nhưng y luôn đối xử như một trường hợp đặc biệt để tỏ lòng quý mến với Dorian Gray. Có cái gì đó ở Dorian quyến rũ được tất cả mọi người. Thậm chí chỉ nhìn thấy cậu thôi là họ cũng đã vui.
tr: İki üç dakika sonra kapı gene tıkladı ve Güney Audley Sokağı’nın ünlü çerçevecisi mr Hubbard içeri girdi. Yanında da kaba saba görünümlü, genç bir yardımcı vardı. mr Hubbard kırmızı yüzlü, kırmızı sakallı bir adamdı. Müşterisi olan sanatçıların değişmez yoksulluğu onun sanata duyduğu hayranlığı ılımlandırmaya yarardı. Genelde dükkânından hiç ayrılmaz, başkaları onun ayağına gelsin diye beklerdi. Ama Dorian Gray’i her zaman bu kuralın dışında tutardı. Dorian’da herkesin gönlünü çelen şeytan tüyü vardı. Salt onu görmek bile başlı başına zevkti.
es: Dos o tres minutos después se oyó de nuevo llamar a la puerta, y el señor Hubbard en persona, el famoso marquista de South Audley Street, entró con un joven ayudante de aspecto más bien tosco. El señor Hubbard era un hombrecillo de tez colorada y patillas rojas, cuyo entusiasmo por el arte quedaba atemperado por la persistente falta de recursos de la mayoría de los artistas que con él se relacionaban. En principio nunca abandonaba su tienda. Esperaba a que los clientes fuesen a verlo. Pero siempre hacía una excepción en favor del señor Gray. Había algo en Dorian que seducía a todo el mundo. Verlo ya era un placer.
vi_translation: After two or three minutes, there was another knock, and it was Mr. Hubbard, the renowned frame-maker from South Audley Street, who entered with a slightly clumsy young assistant. Mr. Hubbard was a small, rosy man with long red sideburns, whose admiration for art had been significantly restrained by the chronic poverty of most of the artists he dealt with. As a rule, he never left his shop. He waited for people to come to him. But he always made an exception to show his affection for Dorian Gray. There was something about Dorian that charmed everyone. Even just seeing him made them happy.
tr_translation: A few minutes later, the door knocked again and Mr. Hubbard, the famous framer from South Audley Street, entered. He was accompanied by a rough-looking young assistant. Mr. Hubbard was a man with a red face and red beard. The unchanging poverty of the artists who were his clients served to temper his admiration for art. He generally never left his shop, waiting for others to come to him. But he always made an exception for Dorian Gray. Dorian had a charm that captivated everyone. Just seeing him was a pleasure in itself.
es_translation: Two or three minutes later, there was another knock at the door, and Mr. Hubbard himself, the famous framer from South Audley Street, entered with a rather coarse-looking young assistant. Mr. Hubbard was a little man with a ruddy complexion and red sideburns, whose enthusiasm for art was tempered by the persistent lack of resources of most of the artists he dealt with. He never left his shop in principle. He waited for customers to come to see him. But he always made an exception for Mr. Gray. There was something about Dorian that charmed everyone. Just seeing him was a pleasure.

en: “What can I do for you, Mr. Gray?” he said, rubbing his fat freckled hands. “I thought I would do myself the honour of coming round in person. I have just got a beauty of a frame, sir. Picked it up at a sale. Old Florentine. Came from Fonthill, I believe. Admirably suited for a religious subject, Mr. Gray.”
vi: “Tôi có thể làm gì cho cậu đây, mít-tơ Gray?” y nói, xoa xoa hai bàn tay béo lấm chấm tàn nhang. “Tôi nghĩ là tôi sẽ tự cho mình vinh hạnh được đích thân đến đây ngay. Tôi vừa mới lấy được một cái khung rất đẹp, thưa cậu. Tôi vớ được nó ở một cuộc bán đấu giá. Hàng Florence cổ. Xuất xứ Fonthill, tôi tin là vậy. Thích hợp một cách đáng ngưỡng mộ với chủ đề tôn giáo, thưa mít-tơ Gray.”
tr: mr Hubbard o tombul, çilli ellerini ovuşturarak, “Sizin için ne yapabilirim, mr Gray?” diye sordu. “Size bizzat gelmek onurundan yoksun kalmak istemedim. Elimde kız gibi bir çerçeve var, beyefendiciğim. Bir açık artırmada el koydum. Eski Floransa işi. Fronthill’den gelme yanılmıyorsam. Dinsel bir tablo için biçilmiş kaftan, Sayın mr Gray.
es: —¿Qué puedo hacer por usted, señor Gray? —dijo, frotándose las manos, rollizas y pecosas—. He pensado que sería para mí un honor venir en persona. Acabo de adquirir un marco que es una joya. En una subasta. Florentino antiguo. Creo que viene de Fonthill. Maravillosamente adecuado para un tema religioso, señor Gray.
vi_translation: “What can I do for you, Mr. Gray?” he said, rubbing his freckled, chubby hands together. “I thought I would give myself the honor of coming here in person. I have just acquired a very beautiful frame, sir. I picked it up at an auction. Antique Florence. From Fonthill, I believe. Admirably suitable for a religious subject, Mr. Gray.”
tr_translation: Mr. Hubbard, rubbing his plump, freckled hands together, asked, "What can I do for you, Mr. Gray?" "I did not want to miss the honor of coming to you personally. I have a frame as delicate as a girl, sir. I acquired it at an auction. Old Florentine work. If I am not mistaken, it came from Fronthill. Perfect for a religious painting, Mr. Gray."
es_translation: —What can I do for you, Mr. Gray? —he said, rubbing his plump and freckled hands—. I thought it would be an honor for me to come in person. I have just acquired a frame that is a gem. At an auction. Ancient Florentine. I believe it comes from Fonthill. Wonderfully suitable for a religious subject, Mr. Gray.

en: “I am so sorry you have given yourself the trouble of coming round, Mr. Hubbard. I shall certainly drop in and look at the frame—though I don’t go in much at present for religious art—but to-day I only want a picture carried to the top of the house for me. It is rather heavy, so I thought I would ask you to lend me a couple of your men.”
vi: “Tôi rất lấy làm tiếc là ông đã phải mất công đích thân đến đây, mít-tơ Hubbard. Tôi nhất định sẽ tạt qua xem cái khung — mặc dù hiện tại thì tôi không ưa chuộng nghệ thuật tôn giáo cho lắm — nhưng hôm nay tôi chỉ cần đưa giúp tôi một bức tranh lên tầng thượng ngôi nhà. Nó khá nặng, nên tôi nghĩ tôi phải phiền ông cho mượn vài người thợ của ông.”
tr: “Sizi buraya gelmek zahmetine soktuğum için üzgünüm, mr Hubbard. Gerçi dinsel resimlere pek merakım yoktur, ama mutlaka gelip çerçevenize bakarım. Bugün istediğimse, evin üst katına bir resim taşıtmaktan ibaret. Oldukça ağır bir şey; bu yüzden sizden iki yardımcı istemeyi düşündüm.
es: —Siento mucho que se haya tomado tantas molestias, señor Hubbard. Iré desde luego a su establecimiento para ver el marco, aunque últimamente no me interesa demasiado la pintura religiosa, pero en el día de hoy sólo se trata de subir un cuadro a lo más alto de la casa. Pesa bastante, y por eso he pensado en pedirle que me prestara a un par de hombres.
vi_translation: “I am very sorry that you had to come here in person, Mr. Hubbard. I will definitely drop by to see the frame — although currently, I am not very fond of religious art — but today I just need you to help me bring a painting up to the rooftop of the house. It is quite heavy, so I think I will need to borrow a few of your workers.”
tr_translation: “I am sorry for putting you through the trouble of coming here, Mr. Hubbard. Although I am not very interested in religious paintings, I will definitely come and look at your frame. What I want today is simply to have a painting carried to the upper floor of the house. It is quite a heavy thing; that's why I thought of asking you for two helpers.”
es_translation: —I'm very sorry that you went to so much trouble, Mr. Hubbard. I will certainly go to your establishment to see the frame, although lately, religious painting doesn't interest me much, but today it's just about getting a painting to the top of the house. It's quite heavy, and that's why I thought of asking you to lend me a couple of men.

en: “No trouble at all, Mr. Gray. I am delighted to be of any service to you. Which is the work of art, sir?”
vi: “Không có gì phiền hà cả, mít-tơ Gray. Tôi rất vui được phục vụ cậu bất cứ việc gì. Tác phẩm nghệ thuật nào vậy, thưa cậu?”
tr: “Hiç zahmet değil, mr Gray. Size hizmette bulunmak mutluluktur benim için. Söz konusu tablo nerede, beyefendiciğim?
es: —No es ninguna molestia, señor Gray. Es una alegría para mí serle de utilidad. ¿Cuál es la obra de arte?
vi_translation: "It's no trouble at all, Mr. Gray. I'm very happy to serve you in any way. Which artwork is it, sir?"
tr_translation: “It's no trouble at all, Mr. Gray. It is a pleasure to serve you. Where is the painting in question, sir?”
es_translation: —It is no trouble at all, Mr. Gray. It is a joy for me to be of service to you. What is the work of art?

en: “This,” replied Dorian, moving the screen back. “Can you move it, covering and all, just as it is? I don’t want it to get scratched going upstairs.”
vi: “Cái này,” Dorian trả lời, dịch tấm chắn lại. “Ông có thể chuyển nó mà vẫn phủ nguyên mọi cái như thế không? Tôi không muốn nó bị xước khi lên gác.”
tr: Dorian, “Bu,” diyerek paravanayı çekti. “Böyle örtüsüyle falan taşıyabilecek misiniz bunu? Yukarı çıkarken çizilmesini istemiyorum da.
es: —Ésta —replicó Dorian Gray, apartando el biombo—. ¿Podrá usted moverlo, con la tela que lo cubre, tal como está? No quiero que se roce por las escaleras.
vi_translation: “This one,” Dorian replied, shifting the shield. “Can you move it while still covering everything like this? I don't want it to get scratched when we take it upstairs.”
tr_translation: Dorian said, "Here," and pulled the screen. "Will you be able to carry this with its cover and all? I don't want it to get scratched while going upstairs."
es_translation: —This one —replied Dorian Gray, moving the screen aside—. Can you move it, with the cloth covering it, just as it is? I don't want it to get scratched on the stairs.

en: “There will be no difficulty, sir,” said the genial frame-maker, beginning, with the aid of his assistant, to unhook the picture from the long brass chains by which it was suspended. “And, now, where shall we carry it to, Mr. Gray?”
vi: “Sẽ không có gì khó cả, thưa cậu,” người làm khung vui tính ấy nói và bắt đầu, với sự trợ giúp của phụ tá, tháo bức tranh khỏi những sợi xích đồng thau dài thượt treo nó. “Và, giờ thì, chúng tôi sẽ phải khênh nó đi đâu, thưa mít-tơ Gray?”
tr: Güler yüzlü çerçeveci, “Kolay, efendim,” diyerek yanındaki yardımcısıyla birlikte portreyi tutan uzun, pirinç zincirlerin kancasını sökmeye girişti. “Şimdi... Nereye götürelim, mr Gray?
es: —No hay ninguna dificultad —dijo el afable marquista, empezando, con la ayuda de su subordinado, a descolgar el cuadro de las largas cadenas de bronce de las que estaba suspendido—. Y ahora, señor Gray, ¿dónde tenemos que llevarlo?
vi_translation: "There will be nothing difficult at all, sir," the cheerful framer said and began, with the help of his assistant, to remove the painting from the long brass chains that hung it. "And now, where will we have to carry it, Mr. Gray?"
tr_translation: The cheerful framer said, "Easy, sir," and began to remove the hooks of the long brass chains holding the portrait with his assistant. "Now... Where shall we take it, Mr. Gray?"
es_translation: —There is no difficulty at all —said the affable framer, beginning, with the help of his subordinate, to unhook the painting from the long bronze chains from which it was suspended—. And now, Mr. Gray, where do we need to take it?

en: “I will show you the way, Mr. Hubbard, if you will kindly follow me. Or perhaps you had better go in front. I am afraid it is right at the top of the house. We will go up by the front staircase, as it is wider.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ chỉ lối cho ông, mít-tơ Hubbard, nếu ông vui lòng theo tôi. Hoặc có lẽ tốt hơn là ông đi trước đi. Tôi sợ là nó ở ngay tầng cao nhất của ngôi nhà. Chúng ta sẽ đi lên bằng cầu thang phía trước, vì nó rộng hơn.”
tr: “Ben önünüze düşeyim, mr Hubbard; bir zahmet beni izleyin. Ya da siz önden gidin, daha iyi. Korkarım en üst kata tırmanacağız. Ön merdivenden çıkalım, daha geniştir.
es: —Le mostraré el camino, señor Hubbard, si es tan amable de seguirme. O quizá sea mejor que vaya usted delante. Mucho me temo que la habitación está en lo más alto de la casa. Iremos por la escalera principal, que es más ancha.
vi_translation: “I will show you the way, Mr. Hubbard, if you would kindly follow me. Or perhaps it would be better if you went ahead. I am afraid it is right at the top of the house. We will go up by the front stairs, as they are wider.”
tr_translation: “Let me lead the way, Mr. Hubbard; please follow me. Or you go ahead, that's better. I'm afraid we will have to climb to the top floor. Let's take the front stairs, they are wider.”
es_translation: —I will show you the way, Mr. Hubbard, if you would be so kind as to follow me. Or perhaps it would be better if you went ahead. I am very much afraid that the room is at the very top of the house. We will take the main staircase, which is wider.

en: He held the door open for them, and they passed out into the hall and began the ascent. The elaborate character of the frame had made the picture extremely bulky, and now and then, in spite of the obsequious protests of Mr. Hubbard, who had the true tradesman’s spirited dislike of seeing a gentleman doing anything useful, Dorian put his hand to it so as to help them.
vi: Cậu giữ cửa mở cho họ, và họ đi qua để vào sảnh rồi bắt đầu leo lên. Đặc tính công phu của cái khung làm cho bức tranh cực kỳ kềnh càng, và thỉnh thoảng, bất chấp sự phản đối khúm núm của mít-tơ Hubbard, một người có cái tính của mọi thương nhân đích thực là không thích thấy một quý nhân làm bất cứ việc gì hữu ích, Dorian lại đặt tay lên nó như thể để giúp họ.
tr: Dorian onlara kapıyı tuttu, adamlar hole geçip merdiveni tırmanmaya başladılar. Çerçevenin süslü oluşu yüzünden resim son derece cüsseliydi. Bütün gerçek zanaatçılar gibi, kibar bayların yararlı bir iş yaptığını görmekten zerrece hoşlanmayan mr Hubbard’ın aşırı saygılı itirazlarına karşın Dorian arada onlara yardım etmek için elini uzatmak zorunda kalıyordu.
es: Mantuvo la puerta abierta para dejarlos pasar, salieron al vestíbulo e iniciaron la ascensión por la escalera. La barroca ornamentación del marco había hecho que el retrato resultase muy voluminoso y, de cuando en cuando, pese a las obsequiosas protestas del señor Hubbard, a quien horrorizaba, como les sucede a todos los verdaderos comerciantes, la idea de que un caballero haga algo útil, Dorian intentaba echarles una mano.
vi_translation: You held the door open for them, and they went through to the hall and then began to climb up. The elaborate nature of the frame made the painting extremely cumbersome, and occasionally, despite the humble protests of Mr. Hubbard, a man with the characteristic trait of all true merchants of disliking to see a nobleman do anything useful, Dorian would place his hand on it as if to help them.
tr_translation: Dorian held the door for them, the men passed into the hall and began to climb the stairs. Due to the ornate frame, the painting was extremely bulky. Like all true craftsmen, Mr. Hubbard, who did not enjoy seeing polite gentlemen doing useful work in the slightest, had to extend his hand occasionally to help them despite his overly respectful objections.
es_translation: He kept the door open to let them pass, they went out into the lobby and began the ascent up the stairs. The baroque ornamentation of the frame had made the portrait very bulky and, from time to time, despite the obsequious protests of Mr. Hubbard, who was horrified, as all true merchants are, by the idea of a gentleman doing something useful, Dorian tried to lend them a hand.

en: “Something of a load to carry, sir,” gasped the little man when they reached the top landing. And he wiped his shiny forehead.
vi: “Khênh cũng tương đối nặng đấy, thưa cậu,” người đàn ông nhỏ bé ấy thở hổn hển, khi họ đến đầu cầu thang trên cùng. Và y lau cái trán bóng loáng.
tr: En üst sahanlığa ulaştıklarında mr Hubbard, soluk soluğa, “Bayağı da ağırmış ha!” diye mırıldandı. Sonra terden parlayan alnını sildi.
es: —No se puede decir que sea demasiado ligero —dijo el marquista con voz entrecortada cuando llegaron al último descansillo, procediendo a secarse la frente.
vi_translation: "It's relatively heavy to carry, sir," the small man panted as they reached the top of the stairs. And he wiped his shiny forehead.
tr_translation: When they reached the top landing, Mr. Hubbard, out of breath, muttered, "It was quite heavy, huh!" Then he wiped his sweat-shining forehead.
es_translation: —You can't say it's too light —said the sign maker with a breathless voice when they reached the last landing, proceeding to wipe his forehead.

en: “I am afraid it is rather heavy,” murmured Dorian as he unlocked the door that opened into the room that was to keep for him the curious secret of his life and hide his soul from the eyes of men.
vi: “Tôi sợ là nó khá nặng,” Dorian lẩm bẩm, lúc cậu vặn khóa cái cửa mở vào căn phòng sẽ giữ cho cậu sự bí mật lạ kỳ về cuộc đời cậu và che giấu tâm hồn cậu khỏi mắt người đời.
tr: Dorian, “Evet, üzgünüm, gerçekten epey ağır,” diye mırıldanarak bundan böyle yaşamının o tuhaf gizini barındırarak ruhunu yabancı gözlerden saklayacak olan odanın kapısını açtı.
es: —Me temo que pesa bastante —murmuró Dorian, mientras, con la llave que le había entregado la señora Leaf, abría la puerta de la estancia que iba a guardar el extraño secreto de su vida y a ocultar su alma a los ojos de los hombres.
vi_translation: “I’m afraid it’s quite heavy,” Dorian muttered, as he turned the key to the door that would keep the strange secret of his life and hide his soul from the eyes of the world.
tr_translation: Dorian, "Yes, I'm sorry, it is really quite heavy," he murmured as he opened the door to the room that would henceforth harbor the strange secret of his life, shielding his soul from foreign eyes.
es_translation: —I'm afraid it weighs quite a bit —murmured Dorian, while, with the key that Mrs. Leaf had given him, he opened the door to the room that was going to guard the strange secret of his life and hide his soul from the eyes of men.

en: He had not entered the place for more than four years—not, indeed, since he had used it first as a play-room when he was a child, and then as a study when he grew somewhat older. It was a large, well-proportioned room, which had been specially built by the last Lord Kelso for the use of the little grandson whom, for his strange likeness to his mother, and also for other reasons, he had always hated and desired to keep at a distance. It appeared to Dorian to have but little changed. There was the huge Italian cassone, with its fantastically painted panels and its tarnished gilt mouldings, in which he had so often hidden himself as a boy. There the satinwood book-case filled with his dog-eared schoolbooks. On the wall behind it was hanging the same ragged Flemish tapestry where a faded king and queen were playing chess in a garden, while a company of hawkers rode by, carrying hooded birds on their gauntleted wrists. How well he remembered it all! Every moment of his lonely childhood came back to him as he looked round. He recalled the stainless purity of his boyish life, and it seemed horrible to him that it was here the fatal portrait was to be hidden away. How little he had thought, in those dead days, of all that was in store for him!
vi: Cậu không vào nơi này đã hơn bốn năm — quả thực là không, từ khi cậu từng dùng nó lúc đầu như một phòng chơi khi cậu còn là một đứa trẻ, và sau đấy như một phòng học khi cậu lớn hơn đôi chút. Nó là một căn phòng rộng, cân đối, được huân tước Kelso cuối cùng xây dựng đặc biệt để sử dụng cho đứa cháu nhỏ, một thằng bé mà do cái sự giống mẹ đến kỳ lạ, và do cả những lý do khác nữa, nên ông luôn căm ghét và muốn giữ khoảng cách. Nó hiện ra trước mắt Dorian mà chẳng có chút thay đổi nào. Đây, cái cassone1 Ý khổng lồ ấy, với các vách sơn tuyệt đẹp và các đường chỉ thiếp vàng xỉn màu, mà cậu từng rất hay giấu mình trong nó khi còn bé. Đây, cái tủ sách gỗ sơn tiêu chất đầy những cuốn sách giáo khoa quăn góc của cậu. Trên tường sau nó cũng vẫn treo cái tấm thảm Flanders tả tơi ấy, nơi một ông vua và hoàng hậu bạc thếch đương chơi cờ trong vườn, trong khi một đoàn người đi săn bằng chim ưng phi ngựa qua, đem theo lũ chim đội mũ trùm đầu trên nắm tay đeo găng dài. Sao mà cậu lại nhớ được hết mọi thứ rõ đến thế! Mỗi khoảnh khắc trong tuổi thơ bơ vơ của cậu lại quay về với cậu lúc cậu đưa mắt nhìn quanh. Cậu nhớ lại sự trong trắng không vết nhơ của tuổi thơ, và cậu thấy dường như thật khủng khiếp vì đây là nơi mà bức chân dung tai hại này sẽ bị giấu đi. Cậu chẳng nghĩ mấy, vào những ngày đã mất ấy, về mọi chuyện đã được dành sẵn cho cậu! 1 Rương.
tr: Çocukken oyun odası, biraz büyüdüğü zaman da çalışma odası olarak kullandığı bu odaya, dört yılı aşkın bir süredir ayak basmamıştı. Bu geniş, ferah odayı ölen Lord Kelso küçük torunu için özel olarak yaptırtmıştı. Kızına olan şaşılası benzerliğinden ve daha başka nedenlerden ötürü Lord Kelso bu çocuktan her zaman nefret etmiş, onu kendinden uzak tutmak istemişti. Dorian odayı hemen hiç değişmemiş buldu. İşte, küçüklüğünde kaç kez içine girip saklandığı, kanatları düşsel resimlerle süslü, kabartmalarının yaldızı kararmış İtalyan işi cassone. İşte, içinde sayfalarının köşeleri kıvrılmış okul kitaplarının durduğu sarı Hint ağacından yapılma kitap dolabı. Bunun ardındaki duvarda gene o eski püskü Felemenk işi duvar halısı asılı duruyordu: Üzerindeki bahçede rengi solmuş bir kralla kraliçe satranç oynayadursunlar, biraz ötelerinden, zırhlı kol bileklerindeki şahinleriyle ava çıkmış bir avcı kafilesi geçmekteydi. Dorian öyle iyi anımsıyordu ki bunların hepsini! Çevresine bakınırken, yapayalnız geçmiş çocukluğunun her dakikasını yeniden yaşar gibiydi. Çocukluk yaşantısının lekesiz saflığı aklına geldikçe şu uğursuz portrenin bu odaya saklanacağını düşünmek tüylerini ürpertiyordu. O geçmişte kalmış günlerde, hayatın kendisine kim bilir neler neler hazırladığını aklından bile geçirmemişti!
es: Hacía más de cuatro años que no entraba allí, aunque en otro tiempo la hubiera utilizado como cuarto de juegos primero y más adelante como sala de estudio. Habitación amplia y bien proporcionada, el difunto lord Kelso la había construido especialmente para el nieto al que siempre había detestado por el notable parecido con su madre —y también por otras razones—, y al que quería mantener lo más lejos posible. A Dorian le pareció que había cambiado muy poco. Allí estaba el enorme cassone italiano, con sus paneles cubiertos de fantásticas pinturas y sus deslustradas molduras doradas, en cuyo interior se había escondido de pequeño con tanta frecuencia. Allí estaba la librería de madera de satín, llena de sus libros escolares, con signos evidentes de haber sido muy usados. De la pared de detrás aún colgaba el mismo tapiz flamenco muy gastado, donde unos descoloridos rey y reina jugaban al ajedrez en un jardín, mientras un grupo de cetreros pasaba a caballo, con aves encapuchadas en las muñecas enguantadas. ¡Qué bien se acordaba de todo! Los recuerdos de su solitaria infancia se le agolparon en la memoria mientras miraba a su alrededor. Recordó la pureza inmaculada de su vida adolescente, y le pareció horrible que fuese allí donde tuviera que esconder el fatídico retrato. ¡Qué poco había imaginado, en aquellos días muertos para siempre, lo que el destino le reservaba!
vi_translation: You hadn't entered this place for more than four years — indeed, not since you first used it as a playroom when you were a child, and later as a study room when you were a bit older. It was a spacious, well-proportioned room, specially built by the last Lord Kelso for his little grandson, a boy whom he always hated and wanted to keep at a distance due to his uncanny resemblance to his mother and for other reasons as well. It appeared before Dorian's eyes without any change. Here was that enormous Italian cassone, with its beautifully painted panels and tarnished gilt moldings, in which you used to hide so often as a child. Here was the lacquered bookcase filled with your dog-eared textbooks. On the wall behind it still hung that tattered Flanders tapestry, where a faded king and queen were playing chess in a garden, while a group of falconers rode by, carrying their hooded birds on long-gloved hands. How clearly you remembered everything! Every moment of your lonely childhood came back to you as you looked around. You recalled the unstained purity of your childhood, and it seemed so terrible that this was the place where the cursed portrait would be hidden. You hadn't thought much, in those lost days, about all that had been destined for you! 1 Chest.
tr_translation: He had not set foot in this room, which he used as a playroom when he was a child and later as a study room when he grew older, for over four years. This spacious, airy room was specially made by the late Lord Kelso for his young grandson. Due to his astonishing resemblance to his daughter and other reasons, Lord Kelso had always hated this child and wanted to keep him away from himself. Dorian found the room almost unchanged. There was the Italian cassone with its wings adorned with fanciful pictures and its gilded reliefs tarnished, where he had hidden so many times as a child. There was the yellow Indian wood bookcase, holding his school books with their dog-eared pages. On the wall behind it still hung that old, shabby Flemish tapestry: In the garden depicted on it, a faded king and queen played chess, while a little further away, a hunting party with falcons on their armored wrists passed by. Dorian remembered all of these so well! As he looked around, it was as if he was reliving every moment of his lonely childhood. The thought of hiding that cursed portrait in this room made his skin crawl, as he recalled the unblemished purity of his childhood experiences. In those bygone days, he had never even imagined what life had in store for him!
es_translation: It had been more than four years since he last entered there, although at one time he had used it first as a playroom and later as a study room. A spacious and well-proportioned room, the late Lord Kelso had built it especially for the grandson he had always detested for his remarkable resemblance to his mother —and also for other reasons—, and whom he wanted to keep as far away as possible. To Dorian, it seemed that it had changed very little. There was the enormous Italian cassone, with its panels covered in fantastic paintings and its tarnished golden moldings, inside which he had often hidden as a child. There was the satinwood bookcase, full of his schoolbooks, showing evident signs of heavy use. From the wall behind still hung the same very worn Flemish tapestry, where a faded king and queen played chess in a garden, while a group of falconers rode by on horseback, with hooded birds on their gloved wrists. How well he remembered everything! The memories of his solitary childhood crowded into his mind as he looked around. He recalled the immaculate purity of his adolescent life, and it seemed horrible to him that it was there where he had to hide the fateful portrait. How little he had imagined, in those days dead forever, what fate had in store for him!

en: But there was no other place in the house so secure from prying eyes as this. He had the key, and no one else could enter it. Beneath its purple pall, the face painted on the canvas could grow bestial, sodden, and unclean. What did it matter? No one could see it. He himself would not see it. Why should he watch the hideous corruption of his soul? He kept his youth—that was enough. And, besides, might not his nature grow finer, after all? There was no reason that the future should be so full of shame. Some love might come across his life, and purify him, and shield him from those sins that seemed to be already stirring in spirit and in flesh—those curious unpictured sins whose very mystery lent them their subtlety and their charm. Perhaps, some day, the cruel look would have passed away from the scarlet sensitive mouth, and he might show to the world Basil Hallward’s masterpiece.
vi: Nhưng không có chỗ nào khác trong nhà mà lại bảo đảm tránh được các con mắt tò mò như chỗ này. Cậu có chìa khóa, và không ai khác có thể vào. Ở dưới tấm vải tía phủ quan tài, bộ mặt được vẽ trên toan có thể sẽ dần dần trở nên dã man, đần độn ô trọc. Thì đã sao? Không ai có thể thấy nó. Chính cậu cũng sẽ không thấy nó. Tại sao cậu lại phải quan sát sự mục nát gớm guốc của tâm hồn mình? Cậu giữ được tuổi xuân — thế là đủ. Vả lại, xét cho cùng thì chẳng lẽ bản chất cậu lại không thể tốt dần lên? Chẳng có lý do nào mà tương lai chỉ toàn những hổ thẹn. Biết đâu sẽ có một tình yêu nào đó tình cờ đến với đời cậu, tẩy uế cậu, che chở cậu khỏi những tội lỗi dường như đã cựa quậy trong tâm hồn và xác thịt cậu rồi — những tội lỗi kỳ lạ không thể hình dung mà chính sự thần bí của chúng đã thêm cho cậu sự huyền ảo và quyến rũ vốn thuộc về chúng. Không chừng, ngày nào đó, vẻ độc ác sẽ biến mất khỏi đôi môi đỏ nhạy cảm ấy, và cậu có thể cho thế giới xem kiệt tác của Basil Hallward.
tr: Gelgelelim evde, meraklı gözlerden böylesine uzak başka hiçbir köşe yoktu ki. Anahtar onun elindeydi; buraya ondan başka kimse giremezdi. O mor cenaze örtüsünün altındaki boyalı yüz isterse hayvanlaşabilir, hantallaşıp murdarlaşabilirdi. Kime ne? Hiç kimse göremeyecekti ya! Dorian’ın kendisi de görmeyecekti. Ruhunun iğrenç çürüyüşünü ne diye seyretsin? Gençliğini koruyacaktı ya, bu ona yeterdi. Hem zaten ruhu neden zamanla yücelip soylulaşmasın? Geleceğinin o kadar da yüz kızartıcı olması için hiçbir neden yoktu ki ortada. Belki günün birinde hayatına giren bir aşk onu arındırarak günahlardan esirgerdi, neden olmasın? (Ah, çekiciliklerini, büyülerini bizzat gizemlerinden alan, daha şimdiden onun ruhunda, teninde kıpırdayan şu günahlar!) Belki günün birinde o kırmızı, hassas ağzın zalim ifadesi silinip giderdi de Dorian, Basil Hallward’ın başyapıtını bütün dünyaya gösterebilirdi.
es: Pero no había en toda la casa un lugar donde fuese a estar mejor protegido contra miradas inquisitivas. Con la llave en su poder, nadie más podría entrar allí. Bajo su mortaja morada, el rostro pintado en el lienzo podía hacerse bestial, deforme, inmundo. ¿Qué más daba? Nadie lo vería. Ni siquiera él. ¿Por qué tendría que contemplar la odiosa corrupción de su alma? Conservaría la juventud: eso bastaba. Y, además, ¿no cabía la posibilidad de que algún día nacieran en él sentimientos más nobles? No había razón para pensar en un futuro vergonzoso. Quizá el amor pudiera cruzarse en su vida, purificándolo y protegiéndolo de aquellos pecados que ya parecían agitársele en la carne y el espíritu: aquellos curiosos pecados todavía informes cuya indeterminación misma les prestaba sutileza y atractivo. Tal vez, algún día, el rictus de crueldad habría desaparecido de la delicada boca y él estaría en condiciones de mostrar al mundo la obra maestra de Basil Hallward.
vi_translation: But there was no other place in the house that could ensure avoiding prying eyes like this one. You have the key, and no one else can enter. Under the purple cloth covering the coffin, the face painted on the canvas might gradually become savage, dull, and filthy. So what? No one can see it. Even you will not see it. Why should you observe the ghastly decay of your soul? You retain your youth — that is enough. Besides, after all, can't your nature improve? There is no reason why the future should be filled only with shame. Perhaps some love might come into your life by chance, purify you, protect you from the sins that seem to have stirred within your soul and flesh — strange sins that cannot be imagined, whose very mystery has added to you the enchantment and allure that belong to them. Perhaps, one day, the cruelty will disappear from those sensitive red lips, and you can show the world Basil Hallward's masterpiece.
tr_translation: However, there was no other corner in the house so far from curious eyes. The key was in his hand; no one else could enter here. If it wanted, the painted face under that purple funeral cloth could become animalistic, sluggish, and filthy. Who cares? No one would see it anyway! Dorian himself wouldn't see it either. Why should he watch the disgusting decay of his soul? He would preserve his youth, and that would be enough for him. Besides, why shouldn't his soul elevate and ennoble over time? There was no reason for his future to be so disgraceful. Perhaps one day, a love that entered his life would purify him and protect him from sins, why not? (Ah, those sins that derive their allure and charm from their very mystery, already stirring in his soul and body!) Perhaps one day the cruel expression of that red, delicate mouth would fade away, and Dorian could show Basil Hallward's masterpiece to the whole world.
es_translation: But there was no place in the entire house where he would be better protected from inquisitive eyes. With the key in his possession, no one else could enter there. Under its purple shroud, the face painted on the canvas could become bestial, deformed, filthy. What did it matter? No one would see it. Not even him. Why should he have to contemplate the hateful corruption of his soul? He would retain his youth: that was enough. And besides, wasn't there a possibility that one day more noble feelings might be born in him? There was no reason to think of a shameful future. Perhaps love could cross his life, purifying and protecting him from those sins that already seemed to stir in his flesh and spirit: those curious, still formless sins whose very indeterminacy lent them subtlety and allure. Maybe, one day, the rictus of cruelty would have disappeared from his delicate mouth and he would be in a position to show the world Basil Hallward's masterpiece.

en: No; that was impossible. Hour by hour, and week by week, the thing upon the canvas was growing old. It might escape the hideousness of sin, but the hideousness of age was in store for it. The cheeks would become hollow or flaccid. Yellow crow’s feet would creep round the fading eyes and make them horrible. The hair would lose its brightness, the mouth would gape or droop, would be foolish or gross, as the mouths of old men are. There would be the wrinkled throat, the cold, blue-veined hands, the twisted body, that he remembered in the grandfather who had been so stern to him in his boyhood. The picture had to be concealed. There was no help for it.
vi: Không; chuyện ấy là không thể. Hết giờ này đến giờ khác, hết tuần này đến tuần khác, thứ trên toan sẽ già đi. Nó có thể trốn được sự gớm guốc của tội lỗi, nhưng sự gớm guốc của tuổi tác thì đã dành sẵn cho nó. Đôi má sẽ hõm vào hoặc nhão đi. Những vết chân chim vàng vọt sẽ bò quanh đôi mắt bạc màu và làm chúng trở nên khủng khiếp. Tóc sẽ mất sự óng ả, miệng sẽ há ra hoặc trễ xuống, sẽ ngu ngốc hoặc thô tục như miệng người già. Cuống họng nhăn nheo, bàn tay lạnh nổi gân xanh, thân hình vặn vẹo, như cậu nhớ ở ông ngoại, người từng rất nghiêm khắc với cậu trong thời thơ ấu. Bức tranh phải bị giấu đi. Chuyện này thật vô phương cứu chữa.
tr: Ama yok, olacak şey değildi bu. Tuval üstündeki o şey saatten saate, haftadan haftaya yaşlanıyordu. Günahın çirkinliğinden kurtulabilse de ihtiyarlığın çirkinliği onu beklemekteydi. Avurtlar çökecek, pörsüyecekti. Sönükleşen gözler, uçlarını saran çizgilerle çirkinleşecekti. Saç parlaklığını yitirecek, ağız sarkacak ya da çökecek, bütün ihtiyarların ağızları gibi salak ya da tiksinti verici bir görünümü olacaktı. Çocukluğunda ona öylesi sert davranmış olan dedesinden anımsadığı o buruşuk boyun, yamulmuş beden, o mavi damarlı, buz gibi eller... Resim gizli tutulmalıydı. Başka çıkar yol yoktu.
es: No; eso era imposible. Hora a hora, semana a semana, la criatura del lienzo envejecería. Quizá evitara la fealdad del pecado, pero no la de la edad. Las mejillas se descarnarían y se harían fláccidas. Amarillas patas de gallo aparecerían en torno a ojos apagados. El cabello perdería su brillo, la boca se abriría o se le caerían las comisuras, dando al rostro una expresión estúpida o grosera, como sucede con las bocas de los ancianos. Y la garganta se le llenaría de arrugas, las manos de venas azuladas, el cuerpo se le torcería, como sucediera con el de su abuelo, tan severo con él en su adolescencia. Había que esconder el cuadro. No cabía otra solución.
vi_translation: No; that is impossible. Hour after hour, week after week, the thing on the canvas will grow old. It may escape the loathsomeness of sin, but the loathsomeness of age is in store for it. The cheeks will become sunken or flabby. Sallow crow's feet will creep around the faded eyes and make them horrible. The hair will lose its luster, the mouth will gape or sag, becoming foolish or gross like that of an old person. The throat will be wrinkled, the hands cold and veined, the body twisted, like you remember in your grandfather, who was very strict with you in your childhood. The picture must be hidden away. This is truly beyond remedy.
tr_translation: No way, this was impossible. That thing on the canvas was aging hour by hour, week by week. Even if he could escape the ugliness of sin, the ugliness of old age was waiting for him. His cheeks would sink and sag. His eyes would dull and become ugly with lines surrounding their edges. His hair would lose its shine, his mouth would droop or collapse, and like the mouths of all old people, it would have a foolish or disgusting appearance. That wrinkled neck, crooked body, those blue-veined, ice-cold hands he remembered from his grandfather who had treated him so harshly in his childhood... The painting had to be kept secret. There was no other way.
es_translation: No; that was impossible. Hour by hour, week by week, the creature on the canvas would age. It might avoid the ugliness of sin, but not that of age. The cheeks would become gaunt and saggy. Yellow crow's feet would appear around dull eyes. The hair would lose its shine, the mouth would open or the corners would droop, giving the face a stupid or coarse expression, as happens with the mouths of the elderly. And the throat would fill with wrinkles, the hands with bluish veins, the body would become twisted, as had happened with his grandfather, who had been so strict with him in his youth. The painting had to be hidden. There was no other solution.

en: “Bring it in, Mr. Hubbard, please,” he said, wearily, turning round. “I am sorry I kept you so long. I was thinking of something else.”
vi: “Mang nó vào đi, mít-tơ Hubbard, làm ơn,” cậu nói, mệt mỏi, quay người lại. “Tôi lấy làm tiếc là đã giữ ông lại lâu thế. Tôi đang nghĩ về chuyện khác.
tr: Genç adam arkasına dönerek yorgun bir sesle, “İçeri getirin lütfen, mr Hubbard,” dedi. “Kusura bakmayın, beklettim. Aklım başka bir şeye gitti de.
es: —Haga el favor de traerlo aquí, señor Hubbard —dijo con voz cansada, volviéndose—. Siento haberle hecho esperar tanto. Estaba pensando en otra cosa.
vi_translation: "Bring it in, Mr. Hubbard, please," he said, tiredly, turning around. "I'm sorry for keeping you so long. I was thinking about something else."
tr_translation: The young man turned around and said in a tired voice, "Bring it inside, please, Mr. Hubbard." "Sorry for keeping you waiting. My mind wandered to something else."
es_translation: —Please bring it here, Mr. Hubbard —he said in a tired voice, turning around—. I'm sorry to have kept you waiting so long. I was thinking about something else.

en: “Always glad to have a rest, Mr. Gray,” answered the frame-maker, who was still gasping for breath. “Where shall we put it, sir?”
vi: “Được nghỉ lúc nào cũng vui, thưa mít-tơ Gray,” người làm khung trả lời, y vẫn đang há mồm thở. “Chúng tôi sẽ để nó ở đâu được, thưa cậu?”
tr: Hâlâ soluk soluğa olan mr Hubbard, “Ben fırsat buldukça dinlenmeyi severim, mr Gray,” dedi. “Nereye koyuyoruz, beyefendiciğim?
es: —Siempre es bueno descansar un poco, señor Gray —respondió el marquista, que aún respiraba con cierta agitación—. ¿Dónde tenemos que ponerlo?
vi_translation: “It's always nice to have a break, Mr. Gray,” the frame maker replied, still panting. “Where should we put it, sir?”
tr_translation: Still out of breath, Mr. Hubbard said, "I like to rest whenever I get the chance, Mr. Gray." "Where should we put it, sir?""
es_translation: —It's always good to rest a bit, Mr. Gray —replied the tattoo artist, who was still breathing somewhat heavily—. Where do we need to put it?

en: “Oh, anywhere. Here: this will do. I don’t want to have it hung up. Just lean it against the wall. Thanks.”
vi: “Ôi, đâu cũng được. Đây được rồi. Tôi không muốn treo nó lên. Chỉ cần dựa vào tường. Cảm ơn.”
tr: “Neresi olursa. İşte şurası. Asılmasını istemiyorum. Şöyle duvara dayayıverin. Çok teşekkürler.
es: —Oh, en cualquier sitio. Aquí mismo; aquí estará bien. No lo quiero colgar. Apóyelo contra la pared. Gracias.
vi_translation: “Oh, anywhere is fine. This is fine. I don't want to hang it up. Just lean it against the wall. Thank you.”
tr_translation: "Anywhere will do. Just over there. I don't want it hung up. Just lean it against the wall. Thank you very much."
es_translation: —Oh, anywhere. Right here; here will be fine. I don't want to hang it. Lean it against the wall. Thank you.

en: “Might one look at the work of art, sir?”
vi: “Có được nhìn tác phẩm nghệ thuật này không, thưa cậu?”
tr: “Bu sanat yapıtına bakabilir miyiz, efendim?
es: —¿Se puede contemplar la obra de arte, señor Gray?
vi_translation: "May I look at this artwork, sir?"
tr_translation: “Can we look at this artwork, sir?”
es_translation: —Can the artwork be contemplated, Mr. Gray?

en: Dorian started. “It would not interest you, Mr. Hubbard,” he said, keeping his eye on the man. He felt ready to leap upon him and fling him to the ground if he dared to lift the gorgeous hanging that concealed the secret of his life. “I shan’t trouble you any more now. I am much obliged for your kindness in coming round.”
vi: Dorian giật mình. “Nó sẽ không làm ông thích được đâu, mít-tơ Hubbard,” cậu nói, dán mắt vào y. Cậu cảm thấy sẵn sàng nhảy lên y và hất y ngã xuống sàn nếu y dám nhấc tấm rèm lộng lẫy đang che đậy bí mật đời cậu. “Giờ thì tôi sẽ không làm phiền ông thêm nữa. Tôi rất biết ơn vì ông đã tận tình đến giúp.
tr: Dorian irkildi. Gözlerini adamdan ayırmadan, “İlginizi çekmez ki, mr Hubbard,” dedi. Adam onun yaşamının gizini örten o şahane ipeği kaldırmaya cüret edecek olursa, Dorian üstüne atılıp onu yere yıkmaya hazırdı. “Sizi daha fazla tutmayayım artık,” diye ekledi. “Gelmekle gösterdiğiniz nezakete çok teşekkürler.
es: Dorian se sobresaltó. —No le interesaría, señor Hubbard —dijo, mirándolo fijamente. Se sentía dispuesto a abalanzarse sobre él y arrojarlo al suelo si se atrevía a alzar la lujosa tela que ocultaba el secreto de su vida—. No deseo molestarle más. Le estoy muy agradecido por su amabilidad al venir en persona.
vi_translation: Dorian was startled. "You won't like it, Mr. Hubbard," he said, keeping his eyes fixed on him. He felt ready to jump on him and knock him to the floor if he dared to lift the splendid curtain that concealed the secret of his life. "Now I won't trouble you any longer. I am very grateful that you have kindly come to help."
tr_translation: Dorian shuddered. Without taking his eyes off the man, he said, "It wouldn't interest you, Mr. Hubbard." If the man dared to lift that magnificent silk that covered the secret of his life, Dorian was ready to pounce on him and knock him to the ground. "I won't keep you any longer," he added. "Thank you very much for your courtesy in coming."
es_translation: Dorian was startled. —You wouldn't be interested, Mr. Hubbard —he said, staring at him intently. He felt ready to pounce on him and throw him to the ground if he dared to lift the luxurious fabric that hid the secret of his life—. I do not wish to trouble you any further. I am very grateful for your kindness in coming in person.

en: “Not at all, not at all, Mr. Gray. Ever ready to do anything for you, sir.” And Mr. Hubbard tramped downstairs, followed by the assistant, who glanced back at Dorian with a look of shy wonder in his rough uncomely face. He had never seen any one so marvellous.
vi: “Không có gì, không có gì, mít-tơ Gray. Lúc nào cũng sẵn sàng làm bất cứ việc gì cho cậu, thưa cậu.” Và mít-tơ Hubbard bước thình thịch xuống gác, theo sau là người phụ tá, tay này cứ ngoái nhìn Dorian với vẻ ngạc nhiên bẽn lẽn trên bộ mặt cục mịch vô duyên của mình. Y chưa từng thấy ai tuyệt diệu thế.
tr: “Hiçbir şey değil, mr Gray, hiçbir şey değil. Size hizmete her zaman hazırız, efendim. Sonra mr Hubbard gürültülü adımlarla merdivenden aşağı inmeye başladı, yardımcısı da peşinden. Bu genç, bir an başını çevirip o kaba çizgili, alımsız yüzünde bir inanmazlıkla Dorian’a baktı. Ömründe böylesine harikulade birini görmemişti.
es: —Nada de eso, en absoluto, señor Gray. Siempre estaré encantado de hacer cualquier cosa por usted —y el señor Hubbard bajó ruidosamente las escaleras seguido por su ayudante, que se volvió a mirar a Dorian con una expresión de tímido asombro en sus toscas facciones. Nunca había visto a nadie tan maravilloso.
vi_translation: "Nothing, nothing, Mr. Gray. Always ready to do anything for you, sir." And Mr. Hubbard thumped down the stairs, followed by his assistant, who kept glancing back at Dorian with a shy astonishment on his coarse, awkward face. He had never seen anyone so wonderful.
tr_translation: "It's nothing, Mr. Gray, nothing at all. We are always at your service, sir." Then Mr. Hubbard began to descend the stairs with noisy steps, his assistant following behind. This young man turned his head for a moment and looked at Dorian with disbelief on his coarse-featured, unremarkable face. He had never seen anyone so extraordinary in his life.
es_translation: —Nothing of the sort, not at all, Mr. Gray. I will always be delighted to do anything for you —and Mr. Hubbard noisily descended the stairs followed by his assistant, who turned to look at Dorian with an expression of timid astonishment on his coarse features. He had never seen anyone so wonderful.

en: When the sound of their footsteps had died away, Dorian locked the door and put the key in his pocket. He felt safe now. No one would ever look upon the horrible thing. No eye but his would ever see his shame.
vi: Khi tiếng chân họ đã tắt, Dorian khóa cửa lại, nhét chìa vào túi. Giờ đây cậu đã thấy an toàn. Không một ai còn có lúc trông thấy thứ kinh khủng ấy nữa. Không con mắt nào ngoài mắt cậu còn có lúc được nhìn nỗi hổ thẹn của cậu nữa.
tr: Adamların ayak sesleri duyulmaz olunca Dorian kapıyı kilitleyerek anahtarı cebine koydu. Güvenlikteydi artık. O korkunç şeye bir daha hiç kimse asla bakmayacaktı. Dorian’ın utancını kendi gözlerinden başka göz asla görmeyecekti.
es: Cuando se perdió el ruido de sus pisadas, Dorian cerró la puerta y se guardó la llave en el bolsillo. Ahora se sentía seguro. Nadie volvería a contemplar a aquella horrible criatura. Ninguna mirada que no fuera la suya vería su vergüenza.
vi_translation: When their footsteps had faded, Dorian locked the door and put the key in his pocket. Now he felt safe. No one would ever see that horrible thing again. No eyes but his own would ever behold his shame again.
tr_translation: When the men's footsteps could no longer be heard, Dorian locked the door and put the key in his pocket. He was safe now. No one would ever look at that horrible thing again. No eyes other than his own would ever see Dorian's shame.
es_translation: When the sound of his footsteps faded, Dorian closed the door and put the key in his pocket. Now he felt safe. No one would ever look upon that horrible creature again. No eyes but his own would see his shame.

en: On reaching the library, he found that it was just after five o’clock and that the tea had been already brought up. On a little table of dark perfumed wood thickly incrusted with nacre, a present from Lady Radley, his guardian’s wife, a pretty professional invalid who had spent the preceding winter in Cairo, was lying a note from Lord Henry, and beside it was a book bound in yellow paper, the cover slightly torn and the edges soiled. A copy of the third edition of The St. James’s Gazette had been placed on the tea-tray. It was evident that Victor had returned. He wondered if he had met the men in the hall as they were leaving the house and had wormed out of them what they had been doing. He would be sure to miss the picture—had no doubt missed it already, while he had been laying the tea-things. The screen had not been set back, and a blank space was visible on the wall. Perhaps some night he might find him creeping upstairs and trying to force the door of the room. It was a horrible thing to have a spy in one’s house. He had heard of rich men who had been blackmailed all their lives by some servant who had read a letter, or overheard a conversation, or picked up a card with an address, or found beneath a pillow a withered flower or a shred of crumpled lace.
vi: Về đến thư viện, cậu thấy vừa mới hơn năm giờ, và bữa trà đã được bưng lên. Trên cái bàn nhỏ bằng gỗ thơm thẫm màu khảm dày xà cừ, — một món quà của bà Radley, vợ của người giám hộ cậu, một người bệnh chuyên nghiệp dễ thương, từng sống qua mùa đông trước ở Cairo, — có để một lá thư ngắn từ huân tước Henry, và bên cạnh nó là một cuốn sách đóng giấy vàng, bìa hơi rách và lề vấy bẩn. Một bản in lần ba của The St. James's Gazette được đặt trên khay trà. Hiển nhiên là Victor đã về. Cậu tự hỏi không biết hắn có gặp mấy người kia ở sảnh lúc họ đang ra khỏi nhà không, và có moi được từ họ những gì họ đã làm không. Hẳn là hắn đã thấy thiếu bức tranh — chắc chắn đã thấy thiếu nó rồi, khi hắn bày bộ đồ trà. Tấm chắn chưa được đặt lại, và một khoảng trống thấy rõ trên tường. Không chừng một đêm nào đó cậu có thể phát hiện ra hắn đang lẻn lên gác và cố phá cửa căn phòng ấy. Thật khủng khiếp khi có gián điệp trong nhà. Cậu từng nghe về những người giàu bị tống tiền cả đời bởi một gia nhân nào đó đã đọc được một lá thư, hoặc nghe trộm được một cuộc nói chuyện, hoặc vớ được một danh thiếp có một địa chỉ nào đó, hoặc tìm thấy dưới gối một bông hoa héo hay một mảnh đăng ten nhàu.
tr: Dorian kitaplığa varınca saatin beşi geçtiğini, çay tepsisinin getirilmiş olduğunu gördü. Vasisinin eşi Leydi Radley’in armağanı olan (Leydi Radley hastalığı kendine meslek edinmiş, cici bir hanımdı ve geçen kışı Kahire’de geçirmişti) hoş kokulu, koygun ağaçtan yapılma, üstü ağır sedef kakmalı küçük bir masanın üzerinde Lord Henry’den bir pusula duruyordu. Yanında da sarı kâğıt kaplanmış, kapağı biraz yırtık, sayfa uçları kirlice bir kitap vardı. St. James Gazette’nin üçüncü baskısından bir nüsha çay tepsisinin kenarına konmuştu. Victor’ un dönmüş olduğu anlaşılıyordu. Dorian onun holde çerçevecilere rastlayıp da ne iş yaptıklarını ağızlarından almış olup olamayacağını merak etti. Victor portrenin yokluğunu fark edecekti, bu kesin, belki de daha şimdiden, çay tepsisini yerleştirirken fark etmişti bile. Paravan eski yerine çekilmediğinden duvardaki boş yer göz önündeydi. Belki de gecenin birinde Dorian, Victor’u gizlice üst kata çıkıp yukarıdaki odanın kapısını kurcalarken yakalayacaktı. İnsanın kendi evinde casus barındırması feci bir şeydi. Hizmetçilerden biri bir mektup okudu, bir konuşmaya kulak misafiri oldu, üstünde adres yazılı bir kart ele geçirdi ya da yastığın altında solmuş bir çiçek, buruşmuş bir parça dantel buldu diye ömür boyu şantaja kurban olan zengin kişilerden konuşulduğunu Dorian duymuştu.
es: Al entrar en la biblioteca se dio cuenta de que acababan de dar las cinco y de que ya le habían traído el té. Sobre una mesita de oscura madera fragante con abundantes incrustaciones de nácar, regalo de lady Radley, la esposa de su tutor, una enferma profesional de gustos delicados, que había pasado en El Cairo el invierno anterior, se hallaba una nota de lord Henry y, a su lado, un libro de cubierta amarilla, ligeramente rasgada y con los bordes estropeados. En la bandeja del té descansaba también un ejemplar de la tercera edición de The St James's Gazette. Era evidente que Víctor había regresado. Se preguntó si se habría cruzado en el vestíbulo con el señor Hubbard cuando se marchaba, interrogándolo discretamente para saber qué habían hecho él y su ayudante. Sin duda echaría de menos el cuadro; lo habría echado ya de menos mientras colocaba el servicio del té. El biombo no había vuelto a ocupar su sitio y el hueco en la pared resultaba perfectamente visible. Quizás alguna noche encontrara a su criado subiendo sigilosamente las escaleras e intentando forzar la puerta de la antigua sala de estudio. Era horrible tener a un espía en la propia casa. Había oído historias sobre personas con mucho dinero, chantajeadas toda su vida por un criado que había leído una carta, u oído casualmente una conversación, o que se había guardado una tarjeta con una dirección, o que había encontrado bajo una almohada una flor marchita o un arrugado jirón de encaje.
vi_translation: Upon arriving at the library, he saw that it was just past five o'clock, and tea had already been served. On the small table made of dark fragrant wood inlaid with thick mother-of-pearl — a gift from Mrs. Radley, the wife of his guardian, a charming professional invalid who had spent the previous winter in Cairo — there was a short letter from Lord Henry, and next to it was a book bound in yellow paper, with a slightly torn cover and stained margins. A third edition of The St. James's Gazette was placed on the tea tray. It was evident that Victor had returned. He wondered if Victor had met those people in the hall as they were leaving the house, and if he had managed to extract from them what they had been doing. Surely he must have noticed the missing painting — he must have certainly noticed it when he set up the tea service. The screen had not been put back, and a clear gap was visible on the wall. Perhaps one night he might catch Victor sneaking upstairs and trying to break into that room. It was terrifying to have a spy in the house. He had heard of wealthy people being blackmailed for life by a servant who had read a letter, or eavesdropped on a conversation, or picked up a business card with an address, or found a wilted flower or a crumpled lace under a pillow.
tr_translation: When Dorian reached the library, he saw that it was past five o'clock and the tea tray had been brought in. On a small table made of fragrant, dark wood with heavy mother-of-pearl inlay, a gift from his guardian's wife Lady Radley (a sweet lady who had made a profession of her illness and had spent the last winter in Cairo), there was a note from Lord Henry. Next to it was a book with a yellow paper cover, slightly torn at the edges, and somewhat dirty page edges. St. A copy of the third edition of the James Gazette had been placed on the edge of the tea tray. It was apparent that Victor had returned. Dorian wondered if he had run into him in the hall and managed to find out what the framers were doing. Victor would certainly notice the absence of the portrait, perhaps he had already noticed it while arranging the tea tray. Since the screen had not been moved back to its original place, the empty spot on the wall was visible. Perhaps one night, Dorian would catch Victor sneaking upstairs and tampering with the door of the room above. It was a terrible thing to have a spy in one's own house. Dorian had heard of wealthy people who had been blackmailed for life because a servant read a letter, overheard a conversation, found a card with an address on it, or discovered a faded flower or a crumpled piece of lace under a pillow.
es_translation: Upon entering the library, he realized that it had just struck five and that his tea had already been brought. On a small table of dark fragrant wood with abundant mother-of-pearl inlays, a gift from Lady Radley, the wife of his tutor, a professional invalid with delicate tastes who had spent the previous winter in Cairo, there was a note from Lord Henry and, beside it, a book with a yellow cover, slightly torn and with frayed edges. On the tea tray, there was also a copy of the third edition of The St James's Gazette. It was evident that Victor had returned. He wondered if he had crossed paths with Mr. Hubbard in the hallway as he was leaving, discreetly questioning him to find out what he and his assistant had done. Undoubtedly, he would miss the painting; he would have already missed it while setting up the tea service. The screen had not been put back in its place, and the gap on the wall was perfectly visible. Perhaps one night he would find his servant stealthily climbing the stairs and trying to force the door of the old study room. It was horrible to have a spy in one's own house. He had heard stories about wealthy people, blackmailed all their lives by a servant who had read a letter, or overheard a conversation, or kept a card with an address, or found a withered flower under a pillow or a crumpled piece of lace.

en: He sighed, and having poured himself out some tea, opened Lord Henry’s note. It was simply to say that he sent him round the evening paper, and a book that might interest him, and that he would be at the club at eight-fifteen. He opened The St. James’s languidly, and looked through it. A red pencil-mark on the fifth page caught his eye. It drew attention to the following paragraph:
vi: Cậu thở dài, và, sau khi rót cho mình chút trà, mở thư huân tước Henry ra. Thư chỉ nói rằng anh ấy gửi đến cho cậu tờ báo chiều và một cuốn sách mà cậu có lẽ sẽ thích, và rằng anh ấy sẽ ở câu lạc bộ lúc tám giờ mười lăm. Cậu uể oải mở tờ The St. James's, xem lướt qua nó. Một dấu chì đỏ trên trang năm lọt vào mắt cậu. Nó kéo sự chú ý đến mẩu tin tiếp theo sau:
tr: Göğüs geçirerek bardağına çay koydu, sonra Lord Henry’nin mektubunu açtı. Lord Henry, ona akşam gazetesiyle belki ilgisini çekebilecek bir kitap yolladığını, saat sekiz on beşte de kulübünde olacağını bildiriyordu. Dorian gazeteyi tembel tembel açıp gözden geçirdi. Beşinci sayfadaki kırmızı işaret dikkatini çekti. İşaretlenen başlık şuydu:
es: Suspiró y, después de servirse una taza de té, leyó la nota de lord Henry. Sólo le decía que le enviaba el periódico de la tarde y un libro que quizá le interesase; y que estaría en el club a las ocho y cuarto. Dorian abrió lánguidamente The Gazette para echarle una ojeada. En la página cinco, un párrafo marcado con lápiz rojo atrajo su atención:
vi_translation: He sighed, and, after pouring himself some tea, opened Lord Henry's letter. The letter only said that he was sending him the evening newspaper and a book that he might like, and that he would be at the club at a quarter past eight. He lazily opened The St. James's, skimming through it. A red pencil mark on page five caught his eye. It drew attention to the following news item:
tr_translation: Sighing, he poured tea into his cup, then opened Lord Henry's letter. Lord Henry informed him that he had sent him the evening newspaper along with a book that might interest him, and that he would be at his club at eight fifteen. Dorian lazily opened the newspaper and skimmed through it. The red mark on the fifth page caught his attention. The marked headline was:
es_translation: He sighed and, after serving himself a cup of tea, read Lord Henry's note. It only said that he was sending him the evening newspaper and a book that might interest him; and that he would be at the club at a quarter past eight. Dorian languidly opened The Gazette to take a look at it. On page five, a paragraph marked with a red pencil caught his attention:

en: INQUEST ON AN ACTRESS.—An inquest was held this morning at the Bell Tavern, Hoxton Road, by Mr. Danby, the District Coroner, on the body of Sibyl Vane, a young actress recently engaged at the Royal Theatre, Holborn. A verdict of death by misadventure was returned. Considerable sympathy was expressed for the mother of the deceased, who was greatly affected during the giving of her own evidence, and that of Dr. Birrell, who had made the post-mortem examination of the deceased.
vi: “Cuộc điều tra về một nữ diễn viên. Một cuộc điều tra đã được tiến hành sáng nay tại Bell Tavern, Hoxton Road, bởi mít-tơ Danby, nhân viên điều tra các vụ tử vong bất thường của quận, với xác Sibyl Vane, một nữ diễn viên trẻ mới được tuyển dụng tại nhà hát Royal, Holborn. Cuộc điều tra đã đưa ra phán quyết rằng nguyên nhân cái chết là do tai nạn bất ngờ. Sự thương cảm to lớn đã được bày tỏ với mẹ nạn nhân, người bị xúc động mạnh trong lúc làm chứng cùng bác sỹ Birrell, người đã thực hiện cuộc khám nghiệm tử thi nạn nhân.”
tr: BİR TİYATRO OYUNCUSUYLA İLGİLİ SORUŞTURMA. Bu sabah Hoxton Yolu, Bell Tavern adresinde, bölge soruşturması: mr Danby tarafından, Hollborn’daki Royal Tiyatrosu’nun genç oyuncularından Sibyl Vane’in ölümüyle ilgili soruşturmanın duruşması yapıldı. Ölümün kaza sonucu olduğu hükme bağlandı. Ölen kızın annesinin acısı hazır bulunanların gözlerini yaşarttı. ms Vane hem kendisi ifade verirken hem de Sibyl Vane’in otopsisini gerçekleştiren dr Birrell’in ifadesi sırasında sık sık fenalık geçirdi.
es: «INVESTIGACIÓN JUDICIAL SOBRE UNA ACTRIZ. Esta mañana, en Bell Tavern, Hoxton Road, el señor Danby, coroner del distrito, ha llevado a cabo una investigación acerca de la muerte de Sibyl Vane, joven actriz recientemente contratada por el Royal Theatre de Holberon. El veredicto ha sido de muerte accidental. Son muchas las muestras de condolencia que ha recibido la madre de la desaparecida, que se ha mostrado muy afectada por los hechos durante su testimonio personal, al que ha seguido el del doctor Birrell, autor del examen post-mortem de la fallecida».
vi_translation: “The investigation into an actress. — An investigation was conducted this morning at Bell Tavern, Hoxton Road, by Mr. Danby, the coroner for the district, regarding the body of Sibyl Vane, a young actress recently employed at the Royal Theatre, Holborn. The investigation concluded that the cause of death was accidental. Great sympathy was expressed for the victim's mother, who was deeply affected while testifying alongside Dr. Birrell, who performed the post-mortem examination on the victim.”
tr_translation: INVESTIGATION ABOUT A THEATER ACTRESS. This morning, at the address Bell Tavern, Hoxton Road, a district inquiry was held by Mr. Danby regarding the investigation into the death of Sibyl Vane, one of the young actresses of the Royal Theatre in Holborn. The death was ruled as accidental. The grief of the deceased girl's mother brought tears to the eyes of those present. Ms. Vane frequently fainted both while giving her own testimony and during the testimony of Dr. Birrell, who conducted the autopsy of Sibyl Vane.
es_translation: «JUDICIAL INQUIRY INTO AN ACTRESS. This morning, at Bell Tavern, Hoxton Road, Mr. Danby, the district coroner, conducted an inquiry into the death of Sibyl Vane, a young actress recently contracted by the Royal Theatre of Holberon. The verdict was accidental death. Many expressions of condolence have been received by the deceased's mother, who was very affected by the events during her personal testimony, which was followed by that of Dr. Birrell, who conducted the post-mortem examination of the deceased.»

en: He frowned, and tearing the paper in two, went across the room and flung the pieces away. How ugly it all was! And how horribly real ugliness made things! He felt a little annoyed with Lord Henry for having sent him the report. And it was certainly stupid of him to have marked it with red pencil. Victor might have read it. The man knew more than enough English for that.
vi: Cậu cau mày, và, xé tờ báo làm đôi, đi ngang phòng và ném các mảnh đi. Mọi chuyện mới đáng sợ làm sao! Và sự đáng sợ thực tế đã làm mọi thứ thành ra khủng khiếp biết bao! Cậu thấy hơi khó chịu với huân tước Henry vì đã gửi cho cậu cái bản tường thuật ấy. Và chắc chắn là anh ấy rất ngớ ngẩn thì mới đánh dấu nó bằng chì đỏ. Victor có thể đã đọc nó. Hắn biết thừa đủ tiếng Anh để làm vậy.
tr: Dorian yüzünü buruşturarak gazeteyi ortasından yırttı, bahçeye attı. Nasıl da çirkindi bu olay! Gerçek çirkinlik de her şeyin öylesine tadını kaçırıyordu ki! Dorian haberi kendisine ilettiği için Lord Henry’ye biraz sinirlenmişti. Hele kırmızı kalemle işaretlemesi sahiden aptallıktı. Victor okuyabilirdi bunu. Herifin buna yetecek de artacak kadar İngilizcesi vardı.
es: Dorian frunció el entrecejo y, rasgando el periódico en dos, cruzó la habitación y se deshizo de los trozos. ¡Qué desagradable era todo ello! ¡Y cómo la fealdad contribuía a hacer más reales las cosas! Se sintió un tanto molesto con lord Henry por haberle enviado aquella noticia. Y desde luego era un estupidez que la hubiera señalado con lápiz rojo. Víctor podía haberla leído. Sabía inglés más que suficiente para hacerlo.
vi_translation: He frowned, and, tearing the newspaper in half, walked across the room and threw the pieces away. How frightening everything was! And the actual frightfulness made everything so terrible! He felt a bit annoyed with Lord Henry for sending him that report. And surely he was very foolish to mark it with red pencil. Victor could have read it. He knew enough English to do so.
tr_translation: Dorian frowned and tore the newspaper in half, throwing it into the garden. How ugly this incident was! Real ugliness spoiled everything so much! Dorian was a bit annoyed with Lord Henry for bringing the news to him. Especially marking it with a red pencil was truly foolish. Victor could read it. The fellow's English was more than sufficient for that.
es_translation: Dorian frowned and, tearing the newspaper in two, crossed the room and disposed of the pieces. How unpleasant it all was! And how ugliness contributed to making things more real! He felt somewhat annoyed with Lord Henry for having sent him that news. And it was certainly foolish of him to have marked it with a red pencil. Victor could have read it. He knew more than enough English to do so.

en: Perhaps he had read it and had begun to suspect something. And, yet, what did it matter? What had Dorian Gray to do with Sibyl Vane’s death? There was nothing to fear. Dorian Gray had not killed her.
vi: Không chừng hắn đã đọc nó rồi, và đã bắt đầu nghi ngờ gì đó. Tuy nhiên, thế thì sao nào? Dorian Gray có làm gì với cái chết của Sibyl Vane đâu nào? Chẳng có gì phải sợ. Dorian Gray không giết cô ta.
tr: Belki okumuştu da bir şeylerden kuşkulanmaya başlamıştı bile. Öte yandan da, ne çıkardı bundan? Dorian Gray’in Sibyl Vane’in ölümüyle ne ilişiği vardı? Korkacak bir şey yoktu ki ortada. Sibyl’i o öldürmemişti ya!
es: Quizá lo había hecho, y empezaba a sospechar algo. ¿Qué más daba, de todos modos? ¿Qué tenía que ver Dorian Gray con la muerte de Sibyl Vane? No había nada que temer. Él no la había matado.
vi_translation: Maybe he has already read it, and has started to suspect something. However, so what? What does Dorian Gray have to do with Sibyl Vane's death? There is nothing to fear. Dorian Gray did not kill her.
tr_translation: Maybe he had read it and had already started to suspect something. On the other hand, what would come of it? What did Dorian Gray have to do with Sibyl Vane's death? There was nothing to be afraid of. He hadn't killed Sibyl!
es_translation: Maybe he had done it, and he was beginning to suspect something. What did it matter, anyway? What did Dorian Gray have to do with Sibyl Vane's death? There was nothing to fear. He hadn't killed her.

en: His eye fell on the yellow book that Lord Henry had sent him. What was it, he wondered. He went towards the little, pearl-coloured octagonal stand that had always looked to him like the work of some strange Egyptian bees that wrought in silver, and taking up the volume, flung himself into an arm-chair and began to turn over the leaves. After a few minutes he became absorbed. It was the strangest book that he had ever read. It seemed to him that in exquisite raiment, and to the delicate sound of flutes, the sins of the world were passing in dumb show before him. Things that he had dimly dreamed of were suddenly made real to him. Things of which he had never dreamed were gradually revealed.
vi: Mắt cậu để ý thấy cuốn sách vàng mà huân tước Henry đã gửi cho cậu. Nó là cái gì đây, cậu tự hỏi. Cậu đi về phía cái kệ bát giác nhỏ màu ngọc trai mà cậu luôn thấy giống như một công trình mà những con ong Ai Cập lạ kỳ nào đó đã đắp bằng bạc, và nhặt cuốn sách lên, buông mình xuống ghế bành, bắt đầu lật qua các trang giấy. Sau vài phút, cậu bị hút vào. Nó là cuốn sách lạ nhất mà cậu từng đọc. Cậu thấy dường như là trong trang phục tuyệt đẹp, và theo tiếng sáo tinh tế, các tội lỗi của thế giới này đang giễu qua trước cậu trong một màn trình diễn câm lặng. Những thứ cậu đã lờ mờ mơ đến đột nhiên thành hiện thực trước cậu. Những thứ mà cậu chưa từng mơ về chúng thì từ từ lộ ra.
tr: Gözleri Lord Henry’nin yollamış olduğu sarı kitaba takıldı. Neydi bu acaba? Dorian küçük, sedef renkli, sekiz köşeli sehpaya yürüdü –bu sehpa ona hep, gümüş işleyen gizemli Mısır arılarının ürünüymüş gibi gelirdi– ve kitabı eline alarak bir koltuğa gömülüp sayfaları karıştırmaya başladı. Birkaç dakika içinde kendini kaptırdı. Bu, şimdiye değin okuduğu en garip kitaptı. Sanki tüm dünya günahları, nefis giysilere bürünmüş, flütlerin tatlı ezgisine ayak uydurarak gözlerinin önünde dilsiz bir geçit töreni yapıyorlardı. Onun hayal meyal düşlediği şeyler ansızın gerçeklik kazanıyordu. Düşlerinde bile görmemiş olduğu şeyler adım adım gözlerinin önüne seriliyordu.
es: Contempló el libro que lord Henry le enviaba. Se preguntó qué sería.
