Pietro Barbi, the Venetian, known by the name of Paul II[10], who, in his vanity, wanted to claim the title of Fermosus, and whose y tiara, valued at two hundred thousand florins, was bought at the price of an abominable sin; Gian Maria Visconti, who used bloodhounds to hunt men, and whose body, when murdered, was covered with roses by a courtesan who had loved him; the Borgia on his white steed, and the Fratricide riding beside him, with the cloak stained by Perotto's blood; Pietro Riario, the young cardinal archbishop of Florence, son and favorite of Sixtus IV, whose beauty was only matched by his debauchery, who received Eleanor of Aragon in a pavilion of white and crimson silk, filled with nymphs and centaurs, and who covered a young boy with gold leaf to play the role, for the occasion, of Ganymede or Hylas; Ezzelino, whose melancholy was only cured by the spectacle of death and who had a passion for blood, as other men have for red wine; son of the Evil One, it was said, who had cheated his infernal father when gambling his soul with dice; Giambattista Cibo, who, mockingly, took the name of Innocent, and into whose lethargic veins a Jewish doctor injected the blood of three youths; Sigismondo Malatesta, the lover of Isotta and lord of Rimini, whose effigy was burned in Rome as an enemy of God and men, who strangled Polyssena with a napkin, gave Ginevra poison in an emerald cup, and, wishing to honor a shameful passion, built a pagan church for Christian worship; Charles VI, so terribly in love with his brother's wife that a leper warned him of the madness that was approaching and who, when his brain became ill and he began to rave, could only be calmed with Saracen cards, illustrated with images of Love, Death, and Madness; and, with his elegant doublet, jeweled cap, and curls like acanthus leaves, Grifonetto Baglioni, who killed Astorre along with his betrothed, and Simonetto with his page, whose charm was such that, while he lay dying in the yellow square of Perugia, those who had hated him were moved to tears, and whom Atalanta, who had cursed him, blessed.

en: There was a horrible fascination in them all. He saw them at night, and they troubled his imagination in the day. The Renaissance knew of strange manners of poisoning—poisoning by a helmet and a lighted torch, by an embroidered glove and a jewelled fan, by a gilded pomander and by an amber chain. Dorian Gray had been poisoned by a book. There were moments when he looked on evil simply as a mode through which he could realize his conception of the beautiful.
vi: Có một sự mê hoặc khủng khiếp trong tất cả bọn họ. Cậu nhìn thấy họ ban đêm, và họ hành hạ trí tưởng tượng của cậu ban ngày. Thời Phục hưng biết về những cách đầu độc kỳ lạ — đầu độc bằng mũ giáp và đuốc sáng, bằng găng thêu và quạt nạm ngọc, bằng quả thơm mạ vàng và bằng dây chuyền hổ phách. Dorian Gray bị đầu độc bằng một cuốn sách. Có những lúc mà cậu nhìn cái xấu chỉ như một phương pháp mà nhờ nó cậu có thể hiện thực hóa được ý niệm của cậu về cái đẹp.
tr: Bütün bunlarda tüyler ürpertici bir çekicilik vardı. Dorian onları geceleyin görüyor, gündüzleri bu imgelerle zihni tedirgin oluyordu. Rönesans çağı değişik, tuhaf zehirleme yöntemlerine tanık olmuştu: Zehirlemede miğferler, yanan bir meşale, işlemeli eldivenler, taşlı yelpazeler, yaldızlı koku şişeleri, kehribar gerdanlıklar kullanılmıştı. Dorian Gray’i ise bir kitap zehirlemişti. Dorian’ ın kötülüğü yalnızca, kafasındaki güzellik kavramını gerçekleştirmede kullanılacak bir yol olarak gördüğü zamanlar oluyordu. 5. Petronius: “Modanın öncüsü”, Neron’un yakın dostu; sarayda düzenlenen eğlencelerin mimarı. (Ç. N. 6. Ahlakî yasaların reddi. (Ç. N.
es: Todos despertaban en Dorian una horrible fascinación. Los veía de noche y le perturbaban durante el día. El Renacimiento conoció extrañas maneras de envenenar: por medio de un casco y una antorcha encendida; de un guante bordado y un abanico enjoyado; de una almohadilla perfumada y un collar de ámbar. A Dorian Gray lo había envenenado un libro. En determinados momentos veía el mal únicamente como un medio que le permitía poner por obra su concepción de lo bello.
vi_translation: There is a terrible fascination in all of them. You see them at night, and they torment your imagination by day. The Renaissance knew of strange ways of poisoning — poisoning by helmet and bright torch, by embroidered glove and jeweled fan, by gilded pineapple and by amber necklace. Dorian Gray was poisoned by a book. There are times when you see evil merely as a means by which you can realize your conception of beauty.
tr_translation: There was a spine-chilling allure in all of this. Dorian saw them at night, and during the day his mind was disturbed by these images. The Renaissance era had witnessed various, strange methods of poisoning: Helmets, a burning torch, embroidered gloves, jeweled fans, gilded perfume bottles, and amber necklaces were used in poisoning. But Dorian Gray was poisoned by a book. Dorian only saw evil as a means to realize the concept of beauty in his mind. 5. Petronius: "The pioneer of fashion," a close friend of Nero; the architect of the entertainments held at the palace. (Ç. N.) 6. Rejection of moral laws.
es_translation: Everyone awakened in Dorian a horrible fascination. He saw them at night and they disturbed him during the day. The Renaissance knew strange ways of poisoning: by means of a helmet and a lit torch; a embroidered glove and a jeweled fan; a perfumed cushion and an amber necklace. Dorian Gray had been poisoned by a book. At certain moments he saw evil only as a means that allowed him to put into practice his conception of beauty.

en: It was on the ninth of November, the eve of his own thirty-eighth birthday, as he often remembered afterwards.
vi: Đó là vào ngày chín tháng Mười một, đêm trước sinh nhật thứ ba mươi tám của cậu, như cậu hay nhớ lại sau này.
tr: Olayın dokuz kasımda, otuz sekizinci yaş gününün arifesinde geçtiğini Dorian sonradan sık sık anımsayacaktı.
es: Fue el nueve de noviembre, la víspera de su trigésimo octavo cumpleaños, como Dorian recordaría después con frecuencia.
vi_translation: It was on the ninth of November, the night before your thirty-eighth birthday, as you often recall later.
tr_translation: Dorian would often recall later that the event took place on November ninth, on the eve of his thirty-eighth birthday.
es_translation: It was the ninth of November, the eve of his thirty-eighth birthday, as Dorian would often remember later.

en: He was walking home about eleven o’clock from Lord Henry’s, where he had been dining, and was wrapped in heavy furs, as the night was cold and foggy. At the corner of Grosvenor Square and South Audley Street, a man passed him in the mist, walking very fast and with the collar of his grey ulster turned up. He had a bag in his hand. Dorian recognized him. It was Basil Hallward. A strange sense of fear, for which he could not account, came over him. He made no sign of recognition and went on quickly in the direction of his own house.
vi: Cậu đang đi bộ về nhà lúc độ mười một giờ từ nhà huân tước Henry, nơi cậu ăn tối, và quấn người trong áo lông dày, vì đêm lạnh mù sương. Tại góc Grosvenor Square và phố South Audley, một người đàn ông đi ngang qua cậu trong sương mù, bước rất nhanh, với cổ áo un-xtơ xám lật đứng. Y cầm một cái túi trong tay. Dorian nhận ra y. Đó là Basil Hallward. Một nỗi sợ kỳ lạ, mà cậu không thể giải thích, ập đến với cậu. Cậu không tỏ vẻ nhận ra, và tiếp tục rảo bước về phía nhà mình.
tr: Lord Henry’nin evinde yediği akşam yemeğinin dönüşünde, saat on bir sularında evine yürüyordu. Kürküne bürünmüştü, çünkü soğuk, sisli bir geceydi. Grosvenor Meydanı’yla Güney Audley Sokağı’nın yanından, sisin içinde hızlı hızlı yürüyerek bir adam geçti. Sırtındaki uzun ve gri, bol paltonun yakasını kaldırmıştı, elinde bir çanta taşıyordu. Dorian onu tanımıştı. Bu, Basil Hallward’dı. Dorian’ın içini, nedenini bilemediği tuhaf bir korku bürüdü. Herhangi bir tanışlık belirtisi göstermeden kendi evinin yönünde adımlarını sıklaştırdı.
es: Regresaba de casa de lord Henry, donde había cenado, a eso de las once, bien envuelto en un abrigo de piel, porque la noche era fría y neblinosa. En la esquina de Grosvenor Square y South Audley Street, un individuo que caminaba muy deprisa, alzado el cuello del abrigo, se cruzó con él entre la niebla. En la mano llevaba un maletín. Dorian lo reconoció. Era Basil Hallward. Una extraña sensación de miedo, inexplicable, lo dominó. No hizo gesto alguno de reconocimiento y siguió caminando a buen paso en dirección a su casa.
vi_translation: You were walking home at around eleven o'clock from Lord Henry's house, where you had dinner, wrapped in a thick fur coat because the night was cold and foggy. At the corner of Grosvenor Square and South Audley Street, a man passed by you in the fog, walking very quickly, with the collar of his gray ulster coat turned up. He was carrying a bag in his hand. Dorian recognized him. It was Basil Hallward. A strange fear, which he could not explain, came over him. He did not show any sign of recognition and continued to walk briskly towards his home.
tr_translation: On his way back from the dinner he had at Lord Henry's house, he was walking home around eleven o'clock. He was wrapped in his fur coat, because it was a cold, foggy night. A man passed by quickly through the fog, near Grosvenor Square and South Audley Street. He had the collar of his long, gray, loose coat turned up and was carrying a bag in his hand. Dorian recognized him. It was Basil Hallward. A strange fear, the cause of which he could not understand, seized Dorian. Without showing any sign of recognition, he quickened his steps in the direction of his own house.
es_translation: He was returning from Lord Henry's house, where he had dined, around eleven, well wrapped in a fur coat, because the night was cold and foggy. At the corner of Grosvenor Square and South Audley Street, an individual walking very quickly, with the collar of his coat raised, crossed paths with him in the fog. In his hand, he was carrying a briefcase. Dorian recognized him. It was Basil Hallward. A strange, inexplicable sensation of fear dominated him. He made no gesture of recognition and continued walking briskly towards his house.

en: But Hallward had seen him. Dorian heard him first stopping on the pavement and then hurrying after him. In a few moments, his hand was on his arm.
vi: Nhưng Hallward đã thấy cậu. Dorian nghe thấy y thoạt đầu dừng lại trên vỉa hè, rồi hối hả theo cậu. Lát sau, bàn tay y đã ở trên cánh tay cậu.
tr: Gelgelelim Hallward onu görmüştü. Dorian onun ilkin durduğunu, sonra da kendi peşinden seğirttiğini duydu. Birkaç dakika sonra ressam, Dorian’ın kolunu tutmuştu.
es: Pero Hallward lo había visto. Dorian le oyó primero detenerse y luego apresurar el paso tras él. Al cabo de unos instantes sintió su mano en el brazo.
vi_translation: But Hallward had seen him. Dorian heard him first stop on the sidewalk, then hurriedly follow him. A moment later, his hand was on his arm.
tr_translation: However, Hallward had seen him. Dorian heard him first stop, then follow after him. A few minutes later, the painter had grabbed Dorian's arm.
es_translation: But Hallward had seen him. Dorian heard him first stop and then quicken his pace behind him. After a few moments, he felt his hand on his arm.

en: “Dorian! What an extraordinary piece of luck! I have been waiting for you in your library ever since nine o’clock. Finally I took pity on your tired servant and told him to go to bed, as he let me out. I am off to Paris by the midnight train, and I particularly wanted to see you before I left. I thought it was you, or rather your fur coat, as you passed me. But I wasn’t quite sure. Didn’t you recognize me?”
vi: “Dorian! May thật là may! Tôi đã đợi cậu trong thư viện của cậu suốt từ lúc chín giờ. Cuối cùng tôi thấy thương người hầu mỏi mệt của cậu, và bảo hắn đi ngủ, lúc hắn để tôi về. Tôi sẽ đi Paris bằng chuyến tàu nửa đêm, và tôi đặc biệt muốn gặp cậu trước khi tôi lên đường. Tôi nghĩ đó là cậu, hoặc đúng hơn là áo khoác lông của cậu, lúc cậu đi qua tôi. Nhưng tôi không chắc lắm. Cậu có nhận ra tôi không?”
tr: “Dorian! Ne inanılmaz bir şans! Saat dokuzdan bu yana senin kitaplığında yolunu gözledim. Sonunda zavallı yorgun uşağına acıdım da ben gideyim sen de yat, dedim. Gece yarısı treniyle Paris’e yolcuyum da gitmeden önce seninle görüşmeyi özellikle istiyordum. Demin yanımdan geçeni sana benzettim, daha doğrusu senin kürk paltona. Gene de emin değildim. Sen beni tanımadın mı?
es: —¡Dorian! ¡Qué suerte la mía! Llevo desde las nueve esperándote en la biblioteca de tu casa. Finalmente me he compadecido de tu criado, que parecía muy cansado, y, mientras me acompañaba hasta la puerta, le he dicho que se fuera a la cama. Salgo para París en el tren de medianoche, y tenía mucho interés en verte antes. Me ha parecido que eras tú o, más bien, tu abrigo de pieles, cuando te has cruzado conmigo. Pero no estaba seguro. ¿No me has reconocido?
vi_translation: “Dorian! How fortunate! I have been waiting for you in your library since nine o'clock. Finally, I felt sorry for your tired servant and told him to go to bed when he let me out. I will be going to Paris on the midnight train, and I especially wanted to see you before I leave. I thought it was you, or rather your fur coat, when you passed by me. But I wasn't quite sure. Did you recognize me?”
tr_translation: “Dorian! What an incredible chance! I have been waiting for you in your library since nine o'clock. Finally, I took pity on your poor tired servant and told him to go, and you to sleep. I am leaving for Paris on the midnight train and I especially wanted to see you before I go. I thought the person who just passed by looked like you, or rather like your fur coat. Still, I wasn't sure. Didn't you recognize me?”
es_translation: —Dorian! How lucky I am! I've been waiting for you in your library since nine o'clock. Finally, I took pity on your servant, who seemed very tired, and as he accompanied me to the door, I told him to go to bed. I'm leaving for Paris on the midnight train, and I was very interested in seeing you before then. I thought it was you or, rather, your fur coat, when you passed by me. But I wasn't sure. Didn't you recognize me?

en: “In this fog, my dear Basil? Why, I can’t even recognize Grosvenor Square. I believe my house is somewhere about here, but I don’t feel at all certain about it. I am sorry you are going away, as I have not seen you for ages. But I suppose you will be back soon?”
vi: “Trong màn sương này ư, Basil thân mến của tôi? Sao mà được, tôi thậm chí không thể nhận ra Grosvenor Square ấy chứ. Tôi tin là nhà mình đâu đó quanh đây, nhưng tôi cũng không chắc lắm vào chuyện ấy. Tôi lấy làm tiếc là anh sắp đi xa, vì tôi sẽ không được gặp anh rất lâu. Nhưng tôi cho là anh sẽ sớm quay về chứ?”
tr: “Azizim Basil, bu siste ha? Grosvenor Meydanı’nı bile tanıyamıyorum ben. Yanılmıyorsam evim buralarda bir yerde olacak ya bundan pek emin değilim. Yolcu olduğuna üzüldüm doğrusu, çünkü görüşmeyeli yıllar oluyor. Ama yakında dönersin sanırım, değil mi?
es: —¿Con esta niebla, mi querido Basil? ¡Soy incapaz de reconocer Grosvenor Square! Creo que mi casa está por aquí cerca, pero tampoco estoy demasiado seguro. Siento que te vayas, porque llevo siglos sin verte. Pero supongo que volverás pronto.
vi_translation: “In this fog, my dear Basil? How could I, I can't even recognize Grosvenor Square. I believe my house is somewhere around here, but I'm not very sure about that. I'm sorry that you're going away, because I won't see you for a long time. But I suppose you'll be back soon, won't you?”
tr_translation: “My dear Basil, in this fog? I can't even recognize Grosvenor Square. If I'm not mistaken, my house should be somewhere around here, but I'm not very sure about that. I'm truly sorry that you're a traveler, because it's been years since we last met. But I suppose you'll be back soon, won't you?”
es_translation: —With this fog, my dear Basil? I am unable to recognize Grosvenor Square! I think my house is nearby, but I am not too sure either. I'm sorry you're leaving, because I haven't seen you in ages. But I suppose you'll be back soon.

en: “No: I am going to be out of England for six months. I intend to take a studio in Paris and shut myself up till I have finished a great picture I have in my head. However, it wasn’t about myself I wanted to talk. Here we are at your door. Let me come in for a moment. I have something to say to you.”
vi: “Không: tôi sẽ xa nước Anh độ sáu tháng. Tôi định thuê một xưởng vẽ ở Paris, và giam mình lại đến khi tôi làm xong được bức tranh vĩ đại mà tôi đã có trong đầu. Tuy vậy, cái tôi muốn nói không phải là về mình. Đây, ta đang ở cửa nhà cậu rồi. Hãy cho tôi vào một lát. Tôi có đôi điều muốn nói với cậu.”
tr: “Yok, altı ay yurtdışında kalacağım. Niyetim Paris’te stüdyo tutup kafamda tasarladığım resmi bitirinceye dek kapanmak. Ama benim istediğim kendimi konuşmak değil. Senin kapına geldik. İzin ver, beş dakikalığına gireyim. Sana bir diyeceğim var.
es: —No; voy a estar ausente seis meses. Me propongo alquilar un estudio en París, y encerrarme hasta que acabe un cuadro muy importante que tengo en la cabeza. Pero no quiero hablarte de mí. Ya estamos delante de tu casa. Permíteme entrar un momento. Tengo algo que decirte.
vi_translation: “No: I will be away from England for about six months. I plan to rent a studio in Paris and lock myself in until I finish the great painting that I have in mind. However, what I want to talk about is not myself. Here, we are at your door already. Let me in for a moment. I have something to tell you.”
tr_translation: “No, I will stay abroad for six months. My intention is to rent a studio in Paris and lock myself in until I finish the painting I have designed in my mind. But what I want is not to talk about myself. We came to your door. Let me in for five minutes. I have something to tell you.”
es_translation: —No; I will be away for six months. I plan to rent a studio in Paris and lock myself in until I finish a very important painting that I have in mind. But I don't want to talk about myself. We are already in front of your house. Allow me to come in for a moment. I have something to tell you.

en: “I shall be charmed. But won’t you miss your train?” said Dorian Gray languidly as he passed up the steps and opened the door with his latch-key.
vi: “Tôi rất vui. Nhưng liệu rồi anh có bị lỡ tàu không?” Dorian Gray nói, uể oải, lúc cậu bước lên các bậc thềm và mở cửa bằng cái chìa khóa rập ngoài của mình.
tr: “Çok sevinirim ama trenini kaçırmaz mısın?” diye soran Dorian tembel tembel basamakları çıktı, anahtarıyla kapıyı açtı.
es: —Encantado. Pero, ¿no perderás el tren? —preguntó Dorian Gray lánguidamente, mientras subía los escalones de la entrada y abría la puerta con su llave.
vi_translation: "I am very happy." "But will you miss the train?" Dorian Gray said languidly, as he stepped up the stairs and opened the door with his latchkey.
tr_translation: “I would be very happy, but won't you miss your train?” asked Dorian as he lazily climbed the steps and opened the door with his key.
es_translation: —Delighted. But, won't you miss the train? —asked Dorian Gray languidly, as he climbed the entrance steps and opened the door with his key.

en: The lamplight struggled out through the fog, and Hallward looked at his watch. “I have heaps of time,” he answered. “The train doesn’t go till twelve-fifteen, and it is only just eleven. In fact, I was on my way to the club to look for you, when I met you. You see, I shan’t have any delay about luggage, as I have sent on my heavy things. All I have with me is in this bag, and I can easily get to Victoria in twenty minutes.”
vi: Ánh đèn len qua màn sương, và Hallward nhìn đồng hồ. “Tôi còn chán vạn thời gian,” y trả lời. “Tàu không chạy cho đến tận mười hai giờ mười lăm, mà bây giờ chỉ mới mười một giờ. Trên thực tế, lúc gặp cậu là tôi đang trên đường đến câu lạc bộ để tìm cậu. Cậu thấy đấy, tôi sẽ không bị trễ giờ vì hành lý đâu, vì tôi đã gửi những thứ nặng rồi. Mọi thứ tôi mang theo mình đều ở trong cái túi này, và tôi có thể dễ dàng đến ga Victoria trong hai chục phút.
tr: Fenerin ışığı sisi delip geçmeye yelteniyordu. Ressam saatine bakarak, “Daha zamanım var,” dedi. “Tren on iki on beşte kalkıyor, daha on bir. Demin karşılaştığımızda seni bulmaya, kulübüne gidiyordum. Bagaj sorunum falan da yok, çünkü ağır şeyleri önceden yolladım. Yanıma tek şu çantayı aldım. Victoria İstasyonu’na yirmi dakikada bol bol yetişirim.
es: La luz del farol más cercano se esforzaba por atravesar la niebla, y Hallward consultó su reloj. —Tengo tiempo de sobra —respondió—. El tren no sale hasta las doce y cuarto y sólo son las once. De hecho me dirigía al club, para ver si te encontraba allí, cuando nos hemos cruzado. No tendré que esperar por el equipaje, porque ya he facturado los baúles. Todo lo que llevo conmigo es este maletín, y no tardaré más de veinte minutos en llegar a Victoria.
vi_translation: The light pierced through the fog, and Hallward looked at his watch. “I have plenty of time,” he replied. “The train doesn't leave until twelve fifteen, and it's only eleven o'clock now. In fact, when I met you, I was on my way to the club to find you. You see, I won't be late because of the luggage, as I've already sent the heavy stuff ahead. Everything I'm carrying is in this bag, and I can easily get to Victoria Station in twenty minutes.”
tr_translation: The light of the lantern was trying to pierce through the fog. Looking at his watch, the painter said, "I still have time." "The train leaves at twelve fifteen, it's only eleven now. When we met earlier, I was on my way to your club to find you. I don't have any luggage issues either, because I sent the heavy things ahead. I only took this bag with me. I'll easily make it to Victoria Station in twenty minutes."
es_translation: The light from the nearest streetlamp struggled to pierce through the fog, and Hallward checked his watch. —I have plenty of time —he replied—. The train doesn't leave until a quarter past twelve and it's only eleven. In fact, I was heading to the club to see if I could find you there when we crossed paths. I won't have to wait for the luggage because I've already checked the trunks. All I have with me is this briefcase, and it won't take me more than twenty minutes to get to Victoria.

en: Dorian looked at him and smiled. “What a way for a fashionable painter to travel! A Gladstone bag and an ulster! Come in, or the fog will get into the house. And mind you don’t talk about anything serious. Nothing is serious nowadays. At least nothing should be.”
vi: Dorian nhìn anh ta và cười. “Một họa sỹ lịch sự mà du hành kiểu này sao! Một túi glát-xtôn, một áo un-xtơ! Vào đi, không thì sương mù sẽ vào nhà mất. Và lưu ý anh là đừng nói về bất cứ chuyện gì nghiêm túc. Thời buổi này chẳng có gì là nghiêm túc cả. Chí ít thì cũng chẳng có gì phải thế.”
tr: Dorian ona bakarak gülümsedi. “Tam da ünlü bir ressama yaraşır bir yolculuk yöntemi! Bir yol çantasıyla bir kumaş palto! Hadi, içeri gel, yoksa sis eve dolacak. Sakın ciddi konulardan konuşmak yok ha! Şimdilerde hiçbir şey ciddiye alınmıyor. Daha doğrusu, alınmamalı.
es: Dorian sonrió, mirándolo. —¡Qué manera de viajar para un pintor célebre! ¡Un maletín y un abrigo cualquiera! Entra, o la niebla se nos meterá en casa. Y hazme el favor de no hablar sobre nada serio. Nada es serio en los tiempos que corren. Por lo menos, no debería serlo.
vi_translation: Dorian looked at him and laughed. "A polite artist traveling like this! A Gladstone bag, an ulster coat! Come in, or the fog will get into the house. And mind you, don't talk about anything serious. Nothing is serious these days. At least, nothing should be."
tr_translation: Dorian smiled at him. "Just the kind of journey fit for a famous painter! A travel bag and a cloth coat! Come on in, or the fog will fill the house. Don't talk about serious matters! Nothing is taken seriously these days. Or rather, nothing should be."
es_translation: Dorian smiled, looking at him. —What a way to travel for a famous painter! A briefcase and any old coat! Come in, or the fog will get into the house. And do me a favor, don't talk about anything serious. Nothing is serious in these times. At least, it shouldn't be.

en: Hallward shook his head, as he entered, and followed Dorian into the library. There was a bright wood fire blazing in the large open hearth. The lamps were lit, and an open Dutch silver spirit-case stood, with some siphons of soda-water and large cut-glass tumblers, on a little marqueterie table.
vi: Hallward lắc đầu lúc y vào nhà, rồi theo Dorian vào trong thư viện. Ánh lửa gỗ rực rỡ đang cháy dữ dội trong lòng cái lò sưởi mở lớn. Đèn đã được thắp, một hộp-rượu bạc mở toang của Hà Lan đang đứng, cùng vài xi-phông nước sô-đa và những cái cốc lớn bằng thủy tinh chạm khắc, trên cái bàn nhỏ dát hoa văn.
tr: Hallward başını sallayarak içeri girdi, Dorian’ın peşi sıra kitaplığa yürüdü. Buradaki büyük, açık ocakta gürül gürül bir odun ateşi yanmaktaydı. Lambalar yakılmış, küçük bir kakmalı masanın üzerine Felemenk gümüşünden bir içki kutusu konmuştu. İçinde sifonlu soda şişeleriyle büyük boy kristal bardaklar duruyordu.
es: Hallward movió la cabeza mientras entraba, y siguió a Dorian hasta la biblioteca. En la gran chimenea ardía un alegre fuego de leña. Las lámparas estaban encendidas y, encima de una mesita de marquetería, descansaba, abierto, un armarito holandés de plata para licores, con algunos sifones y altos vasos de cristal tallado.
vi_translation: Hallward shook his head as he entered the house, then followed Dorian into the library. A brilliant wood fire was blazing fiercely in the large open fireplace. The lamps were lit, a silver Dutch liquor box stood open, along with some soda water siphons and large engraved glass cups, on the small inlaid table.
tr_translation: Hallward shook his head as he entered and followed Dorian to the library. In the large open fireplace here, a wood fire was crackling loudly. Lamps were lit, and a Flemish silver drink box was placed on a small inlaid table. Inside were large crystal glasses with soda bottles with siphons.
es_translation: Hallward shook his head as he entered and followed Dorian into the library. In the large fireplace, a cheerful wood fire was burning. The lamps were lit, and on top of a marquetry table rested an open Dutch silver liquor cabinet, with some siphons and tall cut-glass glasses.

en: “You see your servant made me quite at home, Dorian. He gave me everything I wanted, including your best gold-tipped cigarettes. He is a most hospitable creature. I like him much better than the Frenchman you used to have. What has become of the Frenchman, by the bye?”
vi: “Cậu thấy đấy, gia nhân cậu làm tôi thấy hệt như ở nhà, Dorian. Hắn đem cho tôi mọi cái tôi cần, kể cả những điếu thuốc lá đầu vàng ngon nhất của cậu. Hắn là một tạo vật rất mến khách. Tôi thích hắn hơn nhiều so với người Pháp mà cậu từng có. À này, có chuyện gì xảy ra với người Pháp đó vậy?”
tr: “Görüyorsun ya, Dorian, hizmetçi pek güzel ağırladı beni. Ne istedimse verdi, senin şu en pahalı, yaldız uçlu sigaralarından bile sundu. Pek konuksever bir tip. O eski Fransız uşağından kat kat daha çok sevdim bunu. Sahi, o Fransız’a ne oldu?
es: —Como ves, tu criado no ha podido tratarme mejor. Me ha dado todo lo que quería, incluidos tus mejores cigarrillos de boquilla dorada. Es una persona muy hospitalaria. Me gusta mucho más que aquel francés que tenías antes. Por cierto, ¿qué se ha hecho de él?
vi_translation: “You see, your servant makes me feel just like at home, Dorian. He gives me everything I need, including your finest gold-tipped cigarettes. He is a very hospitable creature. I like him much more than the Frenchman you used to have. By the way, what happened to that Frenchman?”
tr_translation: "You see, Dorian, the servant treated me very well. She gave me whatever I wanted, even offered me those expensive, gold-tipped cigarettes of yours. Quite a hospitable type. I liked her much more than that old French valet. By the way, what happened to that Frenchman?"
es_translation: —As you can see, your servant couldn't have treated me better. He gave me everything I wanted, including your best cigarettes with the golden filter. He is a very hospitable person. I like him much more than that Frenchman you had before. By the way, what happened to him?

en: Dorian shrugged his shoulders. “I believe he married Lady Radley’s maid, and has established her in Paris as an English dressmaker. Anglomanie is very fashionable over there now, I hear. It seems silly of the French, doesn’t it? But—do you know?—he was not at all a bad servant. I never liked him, but I had nothing to complain about. One often imagines things that are quite absurd. He was really very devoted to me and seemed quite sorry when he went away. Have another brandy-and-soda? Or would you like hock-and-seltzer? I always take hock-and-seltzer myself. There is sure to be some in the next room.”
vi: Dorian nhún vai. “Tôi cho là hắn đã cưới cô hầu của bà Radley, và đã ổn định cuộc sống cho cô ta ở Paris như một thợ may người Anh. Sự sùng Anh đang rất mốt bên đó bây giờ, tôi nghe nói thế. Người Pháp có vẻ ngờ nghệch nhỉ? Nhưng — anh biết không? — hắn hoàn toàn không phải là gia nhân tồi. Tôi chưa hề thích hắn, nhưng tôi cũng chẳng có gì phải phàn nàn về hắn. Người ta hay tưởng tượng ra những thứ khá vô lý. Hắn thật sự rất tận tâm với tôi, và dường như khá buồn khi hắn phải rời đi. Dùng thêm bran-đi với sô-đa nữa chứ? Hay anh thích vang trắng Rai-nơ và nước khoáng xen-xe? Tự tôi luôn uống vang trắng Rai-nơ và nước khoáng xen- xe. Chắc là có một ít ở phòng bên.
tr: Dorian omuz silkti. “Sanırım Leydi Radley’in özel hizmetçisiyle evlendi. Ona Paris’te ‘İngiliz Terzisi’ diye bir de dükkân açmış, galiba. Duyduğuma göre orada şimdilerde Anglomanie pek yaygınmış. Fransız saçmalığı bence, öyle değil mi? Gene de... Biliyor musun?.. Hiç de kötü bir uşak değildi aslında. Onu hiç sevmezdim ama, yakınmam için de hiçbir neden olmazdı ortada. İnsan çok zaman gülünç kuruntulara kapılıyor. Aslında adamcağız çok bağlıydı bana, yol verdiğimde çok üzüldü, sanırım. Bir brendiyle soda daha alır mısın? Yoksa beyaz şarapla maden sodası mı istersin? Ben beyaz şarapla maden sodası içerim hep. Öbür odada mutlaka vardır.
es: Dorian se encogió de hombros. —Creo que se casó con la doncella de lady Radley, y la ha instalado en París como modista inglesa. La anglomanie está ahora muy de moda allí, según me dicen. Parece un poco tonto por parte de los franceses, ¿no crees? En realidad no era en absoluto un mal criado. Nunca me gustó, pero no tengo motivos de queja. A veces uno se imagina cosas muy absurdas. Me tenía cariño y, según tengo entendido, sintió mucho marcharse. ¿Quieres otro coñac? ¿O prefieres vino del Rin con agua de Seltz? Eso es lo que yo tomo siempre. Seguramente habrá una botella en la habitación de al lado.
vi_translation: Dorian shrugged. “I suppose he married Mrs. Radley's maid and settled her in Paris as an English dressmaker. English fashion is very trendy over there now, I hear. The French seem rather silly, don't they? But — you know what? — he wasn't a bad servant at all. I never liked him, but I had no complaints about him either. People often imagine quite absurd things. He was really very devoted to me, and seemed quite sad when he had to leave. Would you like some more brandy and soda? Or do you prefer Rhine white wine and seltzer? I always drink Rhine white wine and seltzer myself. There should be some in the next room.”
tr_translation: Dorian shrugged his shoulders. "I think he married Lady Radley's personal maid. He even opened a shop for her in Paris called 'The English Tailor,' I believe. From what I hear, Anglomania is quite popular there nowadays. French nonsense, in my opinion, don't you think? Still... You know?.. He wasn't actually a bad servant. I never liked him, but there was never any reason for me to complain. People often get caught up in ridiculous notions. In fact, the poor man was very devoted to me; he was very upset when I let him go, I think. Would you like another brandy and soda? Or would you prefer white wine with soda water? I always drink white wine with soda water. There must be some in the other room."
es_translation: Dorian shrugged his shoulders. —I believe he married Lady Radley's maid, and has set her up in Paris as an English dressmaker. Anglomania is very fashionable there now, so they tell me. It seems a bit silly on the part of the French, don't you think? He wasn't really a bad servant at all. I never liked him, but I have no complaints. Sometimes one imagines very absurd things. He was fond of me and, as I understand it, he was very sorry to leave. Would you like another cognac? Or would you prefer Rhine wine with Seltzer water? That's what I always have. There is surely a bottle in the room next door.

en: “Thanks, I won’t have anything more,” said the painter, taking his cap and coat off and throwing them on the bag that he had placed in the corner. “And now, my dear fellow, I want to speak to you seriously. Don’t frown like that. You make it so much more difficult for me.”
vi: “Cảm ơn, tôi không uống gì thêm nữa đâu,” họa sỹ nói, bỏ mũ và cởi áo khoác, quăng chúng lên cái túi mà y đặt trong góc. “Và giờ thì, bạn quý ơi, tôi muốn nói chuyện nghiêm túc với cậu. Đừng nhăn thế. Cậu làm tôi khó xử hơn nhiều rồi.”
tr: Ressam kasketiyle paltosunu çıkarıp bir köşeye bıraktığı çantasının üstüne atarak, “Teşekkürler, başka bir şey almayayım artık,” diye yanıtladı. “Bana bak, dostum, seninle ciddi konuşmak istiyordum. Suratını asmasana öyle. İşimi büsbütün güçleştiriyorsun.
es: —Gracias, no quiero nada más —dijo el pintor, quitándose la gorra y el abrigo, y arrojándolos sobre el maletín que había dejado en un rincón—. Y ahora, mi querido Dorian, tenemos que hablar seriamente. No frunzas el ceño. Me lo pones mucho más difícil.
vi_translation: "Thank you, I won't drink anything more," the artist said, taking off his hat and coat, and throwing them onto the bag he had placed in the corner. "And now, dear friend, I want to have a serious talk with you. Don't frown like that. You've already made things much more difficult for me."
tr_translation: The painter took off his cap and coat, throwing them on top of the bag he had left in a corner, and replied, "Thank you, I won't have anything else." "Look here, my friend, I wanted to have a serious talk with you. Don't make such a face. You're making my job completely difficult."
es_translation: —Thank you, I don't want anything else —said the painter, taking off his cap and coat, and throwing them over the briefcase he had left in a corner—. And now, my dear Dorian, we have to talk seriously. Don't frown. You make it much more difficult for me.

en: “What is it all about?” cried Dorian in his petulant way, flinging himself down on the sofa. “I hope it is not about myself. I am tired of myself to-night. I should like to be somebody else.”
vi: “Thế nó liên quan đến chuyện gì?” Dorian la lên, theo cái lối nóng nảy của mình, và buông mình xuống xô-pha. “Tôi mong nó không liên quan đến tôi. Tôi mệt với chính tôi đêm nay. Tôi những muốn biến thành ai đó khác.
tr: Dorian huysuzlanarak, “Neymiş konuşacağın?” diye sordu. “Benimle ilgili değildir, umarım. Bu gece kendi kendimden bıkmış durumdayım. Bir başkası olmak istiyorum.
es: —¿De qué se trata? —exclamó Dorian, sin esconder su irritación, dejándose caer en el sofá—. Espero que no tenga nada que ver conmigo. Esta noche estoy cansado de mí mismo. Me gustaría ser otra persona.
vi_translation: “So what does it have to do with?” Dorian exclaimed, in his usual impatient manner, and threw himself onto the sofa. “I hope it has nothing to do with me. I am tired of myself tonight. I wish I could become someone else.”
tr_translation: Dorian asked sulkily, "What is it that you want to talk about?" "I hope it is not about me. I am tired of myself tonight. I want to be someone else."
es_translation: —What is it about? —exclaimed Dorian, not hiding his irritation, as he let himself fall onto the sofa—. I hope it has nothing to do with me. Tonight I am tired of myself. I would like to be someone else.

en: “It is about yourself,” answered Hallward in his grave deep voice, “and I must say it to you. I shall only keep you half an hour.”
vi: “Nó liên quan đến cậu,” Hallward trả lời, bằng cái giọng trầm ấm từ tốn của anh, “và tôi phải nói nó với cậu. Tôi sẽ chỉ giữ cậu lại độ nửa giờ.”
tr: “Seninle ilgili.” Hallward o kalın, ciddi sesiyle karşılık verdi. “Mutlaka söylemem gerekiyor. Yalnızca yarım saatini alacağım.
es: —Se trata de ti —respondió Hallward con voz seria y resonante—, y no tengo más remedio que decírtelo. Sólo necesito media hora.
vi_translation: "It concerns you," Hallward replied, in his warm, deliberate voice, "and I must tell you about it." "I will only keep you for about half an hour."
tr_translation: "It's about you." Hallward replied in that thick, serious voice. "I absolutely must tell you. It will only take half an hour of your time."
es_translation: —It is about you —replied Hallward with a serious and resonant voice—, and I have no choice but to tell you. I only need half an hour.

en: Dorian sighed and lit a cigarette. “Half an hour!” he murmured.
vi: Dorian thở dài, châm một điếu thuốc lá. “Nửa giờ!” cậu lẩm bẩm.
tr: Dorian içini çekerek bir sigara yaktı. “Yarım saatmiş!” diye mırıldandı.
es: Dorian suspiró y encendió un cigarrillo. -¡Media hora! —murmuró.
vi_translation: Dorian sighed, lighting a cigarette. "Half an hour!" he muttered.
tr_translation: Dorian sighed and lit a cigarette. “Half an hour!” he muttered.
es_translation: Dorian sighed and lit a cigarette. "Half an hour!" he murmured.

en: “It is not much to ask of you, Dorian, and it is entirely for your own sake that I am speaking. I think it right that you should know that the most dreadful things are being said against you in London.”
vi: “Xin cậu thế thì cũng không nhiều nhặn gì đâu, Dorian, và tôi nói cũng hoàn toàn là vì cậu thôi. Tôi nghĩ đúng là cậu nên biết rằng có những chuyện hết sức đáng sợ về cậu đang bị xì xào ở Luân đôn.
tr: “Senden bu istediğim çok bir şey sayılmaz, Dorian. Zaten tamamen senin iyiliğin için konuşuyorum. Londra’da senin arkandan son derece kötü şeylerin söylendiğini bilmen çok doğru olur bence.
es: —No es demasiado lo que te pido, y hablo únicamente en interés tuyo. Creo que es justo que sepas que en Londres se dicen de ti las cosas más espantosas.
vi_translation: "Asking you for this isn't much at all, Dorian, and I'm saying it entirely for your sake. I think you should know that there are some very frightening things being whispered about you in London."
tr_translation: “What I am asking from you is not much, Dorian. I am speaking entirely for your own good. I think it is very important for you to know that extremely bad things are being said about you in London.”
es_translation: —It is not too much that I ask of you, and I speak solely in your interest. I think it is fair for you to know that in London the most dreadful things are being said about you.

en: “I don’t wish to know anything about them. I love scandals about other people, but scandals about myself don’t interest me. They have not got the charm of novelty.”
vi: “Tôi không muốn biết gì về chúng. Tôi thích những vụ tai tiếng liên quan đến người khác, nhưng những vụ tai tiếng liên quan đến tôi thì tôi lại chẳng quan tâm. Chúng không có sức hấp dẫn của tính mới lạ.”
tr: “Hiçbirini bilmek istemiyorum. Başkaları için yapılan dedikodulara bayılırım da benim için yapılan dedikodularla hiç ilgilenmem. Yeni ve değişik olma çekiciliğinden yoksundur çünkü bunlar.
es: —No quiero saber nada de eso. Me encantan los escándalos acerca de otras personas, pero las habladurías que me conciernen no me interesan. Carecen del encanto de la novedad.
vi_translation: “I don't want to know anything about them. I like scandals involving others, but I don't care about scandals involving me. They don't have the allure of novelty.”
tr_translation: “I don't want to know any of it. I love gossip about others, but I have no interest in gossip about myself. It lacks the allure of being new and different.”
es_translation: —I don't want to know anything about that. I love scandals about other people, but gossip that concerns me doesn't interest me. They lack the charm of novelty.

Multiple_ents: ['eras', 'lord staveley', 'lord kent', 'erais', 'duque de berwick', 'james', 'adrian singleton', 'y', 'dorian', 'berwick', 'doria', 'the duke of berwick', 'henry ashton', 'staveley', 'kent', 'ngài henry ashton', 'duke of perth']
en: “They must interest you, Dorian. Every gentleman is interested in his good name. You don’t want people to talk of you as something vile and degraded. Of course, you have your position, and your wealth, and all that kind of thing. But position and wealth are not everything. Mind you, I don’t believe these rumours at all. At least, I can’t believe them when I see you. Sin is a thing that writes itself across a man’s face. It cannot be concealed. People talk sometimes of secret vices. There are no such things. If a wretched man has a vice, it shows itself in the lines of his mouth, the droop of his eyelids, the moulding of his hands even. Somebody—I won’t mention his name, but you know him—came to me last year to have his portrait done. I had never seen him before, and had never heard anything about him at the time, though I have heard a good deal since. He offered an extravagant price. I refused him. There was something in the shape of his fingers that I hated. I know now that I was quite right in what I fancied about him. His life is dreadful. But you, Dorian, with your pure, bright, innocent face, and your marvellous untroubled youth—I can’t believe anything against you. And yet I see you very seldom, and you never come down to the studio now, and when I am away from you, and I hear all these hideous things that people are whispering about you, I don’t know what to say. Why is it, Dorian, that a man like the Duke of Berwick leaves the room of a club when you enter it? Why is it that so many gentlemen in London will neither go to your house or invite you to theirs? You used to be a friend of Lord Staveley. I met him at dinner last week. Your name happened to come up in conversation, in connection with the miniatures you have lent to the exhibition at the Dudley. Staveley curled his lip and said that you might have the most artistic tastes, but that you were a man whom no pure-minded girl should be allowed to know, and whom no chaste woman should sit in the same room with. I reminded him that I was a friend of yours, and asked him what he meant. He told me. He told me right out before everybody. It was horrible! Why is your friendship so fatal to young men? There was that wretched boy in the Guards who committed suicide. You were his great friend. There was Sir Henry Ashton, who had to leave England with a tarnished name. You and he were inseparable. What about Adrian Singleton and his dreadful end? What about Lord Kent’s only son and his career? I met his father yesterday in St. James’s Street. He seemed broken with shame and sorrow. What about the young Duke of Perth? What sort of life has he got now? What gentleman would associate with him?”
vi: “Chúng phải được cậu quan tâm, Dorian. Mọi quý ông đều quan tâm đến thanh danh của mình. Cậu không muốn mọi người nói chuyện về cậu như về kẻ nào đó hèn hạ và tha hóa. Dĩ nhiên cậu có địa vị, của cải, và mọi thứ đại loại thế. Nhưng địa vị và của cải không phải là tất cả. Lưu ý cậu là tôi không tin những tin đồn ấy tí nào. Chí ít thì tôi cũng không thể tin chúng khi tôi gặp cậu. Tội lỗi là thứ biết tự viết về mình lên ngang mặt người. Nó không thể bị giấu đi. Mọi người thỉnh thoảng lại nói về những tật xấu bí mật. Không có những thứ như vậy đâu. Nếu một kẻ bất hạnh có tật xấu nào đó thì nó sẽ tự phơi bày trên những nếp nhăn ở miệng, sự cụp xuống của mi mắt, thậm chí khuôn bàn tay. Có một người — tôi sẽ không nói tên y, nhưng cậu biết y — năm ngoái đến chỗ tôi để nhờ vẽ chân dung cho y. Tôi chưa hề gặp y trước đây, và chưa hề nghe bất cứ điều gì về y vào thời điểm ấy, mặc dù sau đó thì tôi được nghe rất nhiều. Y đưa ra một cái giá cực kỳ cao. Tôi từ chối y. Có gì đó trong hình thù các ngón tay y làm tôi ghét. Giờ thì tôi đã biết là mình hoàn toàn đúng với những điều mà tôi hình dung về y. Đời y thật đáng sợ. Nhưng cậu, Dorian, với khuôn mặt trong sáng, rạng rỡ, ngây thơ và tuổi thanh xuân tuyệt diệu không chút ưu phiền — tôi không tin vào bất cứ điều gì chống lại cậu. Tuy nhiên tôi rất ít khi gặp cậu, mà lâu nay cậu cũng chẳng hề xuống xưởng vẽ, thành thử khi tôi xa cậu, và tôi được nghe mọi chuyện ghê tởm mà mọi người xì xào về cậu, tôi không biết phải nói sao. Tại sao mà, Dorian, một người như công tước Berwick lại bỏ ra khỏi phòng của một câu lạc bộ khi cậu vào đó? Tại sao mà rất nhiều quý ông ở London không đến nhà cậu mà cũng không mời cậu đến nhà họ? Cậu từng là bạn huân tước Staveley. Tôi gặp ông ta tuần trước tại một bữa tối. Tên cậu tình cờ được nêu lên trong cuộc chuyện trò, do liên quan tới các bức tiểu họa mà cậu cho cuộc triển lãm ở Dudley mượn. Staveley bĩu môi, và bảo rằng cậu có thể có thị hiếu nghệ thuật tuyệt vời, nhưng cậu là kẻ mà không cô gái có tâm hồn trong trắng nào nên được phép quen, và là kẻ mà không phụ nữ tiết hạnh nào nên ngồi cùng phòng. Tôi nhắc ông ta rằng tôi là bạn cậu, và hỏi ông ta có ý gì. Ông ta kể cho tôi. Ông ta kể cho tôi ngay trước mặt mọi người. Thật kinh khủng! Vì sao mà tình bạn của cậu lại tai hại làm vậy với những người trẻ tuổi? Một chàng trai khốn khổ ở đội Cận vệ đã tự tử. Cậu là bạn thân của anh ta. Ngài Henry Ashton phải rời khỏi nước Anh với một cái tên nhơ nhuốc. Cậu và ông ta từng không rời nhau nửa bước. Còn về Adrian Singleton và cái kết thúc rùng rợn của anh ta thì sao? Còn về đứa con trai duy nhất của huân tước Kent và sự nghiệp của nó thì sao? Tôi gặp cha nó hôm qua trên phố St. James. Ông ấy dường như suy sụp vì nhục nhã và buồn bã. Còn về cậu công tước trẻ xứ Perth thì sao? Bây giờ cậu ta sống cái kiểu gì vậy? Người tử tế nào còn muốn giao thiệp với cậu ấy nữa?”
tr: “İlgilenmek zorundasın, Dorian. Centilmen olan herkes kendi saygınlığına değer verir. Herkesin senden alçak, aşağılık, iğrenç biri diye söz etmesi hoşuna gidemez. Elbette mevkiin, servetin falan var ama mevkiiyle servet her şey değildir. Şunu söyleyeyim, ben bu dedikodulara zerrece inanmıyorum. Daha doğrusu seni gördüğüm zaman inanmazlığa kapılıyorum. Günah kişinin yüzüne yazılan bir şeydir. Gizli tutulamaz. Kimi zaman insanların perde arkasındaki kötü alışkanlıklarından söz ederler. Yok böyle bir şey! Adamcağızın kötü bir alışkanlığı varsa hemen dışarı vurur: ağzının çizgilerinde, gözkapaklarının yuvarlağında, hatta ellerinin biçiminde. Geçen yıl birisi... adını vermeyeceğim, sen kendisini tanıyorsun... portresini yaptırmak için bana geldi. Onu daha önce görmemiştim; hakkında da şimdi çok şey öğrendim, ama o zaman hiçbir şey bilmiyordum. Bana fahiş bir para önerdi. Önerisini geri çevirdim. Parmaklarının biçimindeki bir şeyden nefret etmiştim. Ona ilişkin sezgilerimin çok yerinde olduğunu şimdi biliyorum. İğrenç bir hayat sürüyor... Ama sen, Dorian, şu duru, masum, nur yüzünle, şu harikulade, pürüzsüz gençliğinle... Senin aleyhinde söylenen hiçbir şeye inanamam ben. Ne var ki çok seyrek görüyorum seni, artık stüdyoma da gelmez oldun. Senden uzakta olduğum zamanlarda, herkesin senin arkandan fısıldadığı o berbat şeyleri duydukça ne diyeceğimi bilemiyorum. Dorian, Berwick Dükü gibi adam, sen içeri girdiğin zaman ne diye kulüpteki odadan çıkıp gider? Londralı pek çok saygın beyefendi neden seni ziyarete gelmez ya da davet etmez? Eskiden Lord Staveley’in dostuydun. Geçen hafta yemekte birlikteydik. Laf arasında senin adın geçti, şu Dudley Galerisi’ndeki sergiye ödünç verdiğin minyatürler bahanesiyle. Staveley şöyle bir dudak bükerek dedi ki, senin sanat konusundaki beğenilerin çok ince olabilirmiş, ama kendin öyle bir adammışsın ki hiçbir temiz genç kızın seni tanımasına izin verilmemeliymiş, hiçbir namuslu kadın da seninle aynı odada bile oturmamalıymış. Senin arkadaşın olduğumu ona anımsattım; ne demek istediğini sordum. O da bana anlattı. Herkesin önünde, adlı adınca anlattı. Korkunçtu. Senin dostluğun gençlere neden felaket getiriyor, Dorian? Muhafız alayından Henry Ashton, adına kara çalındığı için İngiltere’den ayrılmak zorunda kaldı. İçtiğiniz su ayrı gitmezdi. Ya Adrian Singleton’a ne demeli, başına gelen korkunç akıbete? Ya Lord Kent’in tek oğlunun meslek yaşamı? Dün St. James Sokağı’nda babasına rastladım. Adamcağız utancından, derdinden çökmüş gibiydi. Ya genç Perth Dükü? Sürdüğü hayat neye benziyor şimdi? Hangi saygın kişi onunla dostluk eder?
es: —Deben interesarte, Dorian. Todo caballero está interesado en su buen nombre. No puedes querer que la gente hable de ti como de alguien vil y depravado. Disfrutas, por supuesto, de tu posición, y de tu fortuna, y todo lo que llevan consigo. Pero posición y fortuna no lo son todo. Yo no doy ningún crédito a esos rumores. Al menos, no los creo cuando te veo. El pecado es algo que los hombres llevan escrito en la cara. No se puede ocultar. La gente habla a veces de vicios secretos. No existe tal cosa. Si un pobre desgraciado tiene un vicio, lo denuncian las arrugas de la boca, la caída de los párpados, incluso la forma de las manos. Alguien, no voy a decir su nombre, pero a quien tú conoces, vino a mí el año pasado para que pintara su retrato. Nunca lo había visto antes, ni tampoco había oído nada acerca de él por aquel entonces, aunque después sí he sabido muchas cosas. Me ofreció una cantidad exorbitante. Me negué a retratarlo. Había algo en la forma de sus dedos que me pareció detestable. Ahora sé que la impresión que me produjo no era equivocada. Su vida es un horror. Pero tú, Dorian, con ese rostro tuyo, inocente, luminoso, con esa maravillosa juventud tuya que permanece siempre igual, ¿cómo voy a creer nada malo de ti? Y sin embargo te veo muy pocas veces, nunca vienes al estudio, y cuando estoy lejos de ti y oigo todas esas cosas odiosas que la gente susurra, no sé qué decir. ¿Por qué, Dorian, una persona como el duque de Berwick abandona el salón de un club cuando tú entras en él? ¿Por qué hay en Londres tantos caballeros que no van a tu casa ni te invitan a la suya? Eras muy amigo de lord Staveley. Coincidí con él en una cena la semana pasada. Tu nombre salió en la conversación, con motivo de las miniaturas que has prestado para la exposición en la galería Dudley. Staveley hizo un gesto de desagrado, y dijo que quizá tuvieras unos gustos muy artísticos, pero que no debía permitirse que conocieras a ninguna joven pura; y que ninguna mujer casta debía sentarse contigo en la misma habitación. Le recordé que yo era amigo tuyo y le pedí que explicara lo que quería decir. Lo hizo. Lo hizo delante de todo el mundo. ¡Fue horrible! ¿Por qué tu amistad es tan desastrosa para los jóvenes? Está el caso de ese desgraciado muchacho de la Guardia que se suicidó. Eras su amigo íntimo. Pienso en sir Henry Ashton, que tuvo que abandonar Inglaterra, su reputación manchada para siempre. Erais inseparables. ¿Y qué decir de Adrian Singleton, que terminó de una manera tan terrible? ¿Y el hijo único de lord Kent y su carrera? Ayer me tropecé con su padre en St. James Street. Parecía deshecho por la vergüenza y la pena. ¿Y el joven duque de Perth? ¿Qué vida lleva en la actualidad? ¿Qué caballero querrá que se le vea con él?
vi_translation: “You must care about them, Dorian. Every gentleman cares about his reputation. You don't want people talking about you as if you were some vile and corrupt creature. Of course, you have position, wealth, and all that sort of thing. But position and wealth are not everything. Mind you, I don't believe these rumors at all. At least, I can't believe them when I see you. Sin writes itself across a man's face. It cannot be concealed. People sometimes talk about secret vices. There are no such things. If a wretched man has a vice, it shows itself in the lines of his mouth, the droop of his eyelids, even the shape of his hands. There was a man — I won't mention his name, but you know him — who came to me last year to have his portrait painted. I had never seen him before, and had not heard anything about him at the time, though I have heard a great deal since. He offered an exorbitant price. I refused him. There was something in the shape of his fingers that I hated. Now I know that I was quite right in what I fancied about him. His life is dreadful. But you, Dorian, with your pure, bright, innocent face, and your marvelous untroubled youth — I can't believe anything against you. And yet I seldom see you, and you never come down to the studio anymore, and when I am away from you, and I hear all these hideous things that people whisper about you, I don't know what to say. Why is it, Dorian, that a man like the Duke of Berwick leaves the room when you enter it? Why is it that so many gentlemen in London will neither go to your house nor invite you to theirs? You were a friend of Lord Staveley. I met him at dinner last week. Your name happened to come up in conversation, in connection with the miniatures you have lent to the exhibition at Dudley. Staveley curled his lip, and said that you might have the most artistic taste, but that you were a man whom no pure-minded girl should be allowed to know, and whom no chaste woman should sit in the same room with. I reminded him that I was a friend of yours, and asked him what he meant. He told me. He told me right before everybody. It was horrible! Why is your friendship so fatal to young men? There was that wretched boy in the Guards who committed suicide. You were his great friend. Sir Henry Ashton had to leave England, with a tarnished name. You and he were inseparable. What about Adrian Singleton and his dreadful end? What about Lord Kent's only son and his career? I met his father yesterday in St. James's Street. He seemed broken with shame and sorrow. What about the young Duke of Perth? What sort of life is he leading now? Who is it that wants to associate with him anymore?”
tr_translation: “You have to care, Dorian. Every gentleman values his own dignity. You can't enjoy everyone talking about you as a vile, despicable, disgusting person. Of course, you have your position, wealth, and so on, but position and wealth aren't everything. Let me tell you, I don't believe these rumors in the slightest. Or rather, when I see you, I find it hard to believe. Sin is something written on a person's face. It can't be hidden. Sometimes people talk about others' bad habits behind the scenes. There's no such thing! If a man has a bad habit, it immediately shows: in the lines of his mouth, the roundness of his eyelids, even the shape of his hands. Last year, someone... I won't name him, you know him... came to me to have his portrait done. I hadn't seen him before; I've learned a lot about him since, but at the time I knew nothing. He offered me an exorbitant amount of money. I refused his offer. There was something about the shape of his fingers that I hated. I now know that my intuitions about him were very accurate. He leads a disgusting life... But you, Dorian, with your clear, innocent, radiant face, with your marvelous, smooth youth... I can't believe anything said against you. However, I see you very rarely, you don't come to my studio anymore. When I'm away from you, hearing those terrible things everyone whispers behind your back, I don't know what to think. Dorian, why does a man like the Duke of Berwick leave the room at the club when you enter? Why do many respectable gentlemen in London neither visit you nor invite you? You used to be friends with Lord Staveley. We had dinner together last week. In passing, your name came up, under the pretext of the miniatures you lent to the exhibition at the Dudley Gallery. Staveley curled his lip and said that while your tastes in art might be very refined, you were the kind of man no decent young girl should be allowed to know, and no respectable woman should even sit in the same room with. I reminded him that I was your friend; I asked what he meant. He told me. He told me in front of everyone, by name. It was terrible. Why does your friendship bring ruin to young men, Dorian? Henry Ashton from the Guards had to leave England because of the slander against him. You were inseparable. And what about Adrian Singleton, the terrible fate that befell him? And the career of Lord Kent's only son? Yesterday, on St. James Street, I ran into his father. The poor man seemed crushed by shame and sorrow. And the young Duke of Perth? What kind of life is he leading now? What respectable person would befriend him?”
es_translation: —They must interest you, Dorian. Every gentleman is interested in his good name. You cannot want people to speak of you as someone vile and depraved. You enjoy, of course, your position, and your fortune, and everything that comes with them. But position and fortune are not everything. I do not give any credit to those rumors. At least, I do not believe them when I see you. Sin is something that men wear on their faces. It cannot be hidden. People sometimes talk about secret vices. There is no such thing. If a poor wretch has a vice, it is revealed by the wrinkles around his mouth, the droop of his eyelids, even the shape of his hands. Someone, I will not say his name, but whom you know, came to me last year to have his portrait painted. I had never seen him before, nor had I heard anything about him at that time, although I have since learned many things. He offered me an exorbitant amount. I refused to paint him. There was something about the shape of his fingers that I found detestable. Now I know that the impression he gave me was not wrong. His life is a horror. But you, Dorian, with that innocent, luminous face of yours, with that wonderful youth of yours that remains ever the same, how can I believe anything bad about you? And yet I see you very rarely, you never come to the studio, and when I am away from you and hear all those hateful things that people whisper, I do not know what to say. Why, Dorian, does someone like the Duke of Berwick leave a club room when you enter it? Why are there so many gentlemen in London who neither go to your house nor invite you to theirs? You were very close friends with Lord Staveley. I met him at a dinner last week. Your name came up in conversation, regarding the miniatures you have lent for the exhibition at the Dudley Gallery. Staveley made a gesture of displeasure and said that you might have very artistic tastes, but that you should not be allowed to meet any pure young woman; and that no chaste woman should sit in the same room with you. I reminded him that I was your friend and asked him to explain what he meant. He did. He did it in front of everyone. It was horrible! Why is your friendship so disastrous for young men? There is the case of that unfortunate young man from the Guards who committed suicide. You were his close friend. I think of Sir Henry Ashton, who had to leave England, his reputation forever stained. You were inseparable. And what about Adrian Singleton, who ended in such a terrible way? And the only son of Lord Kent and his career? Yesterday I ran into his father in St. James Street. He seemed shattered by shame and sorrow. And the young Duke of Perth? What kind of life does he lead now? What gentleman would want to be seen with him?

en: “Stop, Basil. You are talking about things of which you know nothing,” said Dorian Gray, biting his lip, and with a note of infinite contempt in his voice. “You ask me why Berwick leaves a room when I enter it. It is because I know everything about his life, not because he knows anything about mine. With such blood as he has in his veins, how could his record be clean? You ask me about Henry Ashton and young Perth. Did I teach the one his vices, and the other his debauchery? If Kent’s silly son takes his wife from the streets, what is that to me? If Adrian Singleton writes his friend’s name across a bill, am I his keeper? I know how people chatter in England. The middle classes air their moral prejudices over their gross dinner-tables, and whisper about what they call the profligacies of their betters in order to try and pretend that they are in smart society and on intimate terms with the people they slander. In this country, it is enough for a man to have distinction and brains for every common tongue to wag against him. And what sort of lives do these people, who pose as being moral, lead themselves? My dear fellow, you forget that we are in the native land of the hypocrite.”
vi: “Thôi đi, Basil. Anh đang nói về những việc mà anh chẳng biết gì,” Dorian Gray nói, cắn môi, với một nốt khinh miệt vô biên trong giọng. “Anh hỏi tôi tại sao Berwick rời phòng khi tôi vào. Đó là vì tôi biết mọi điều về đời hắn, chứ không phải vì hắn biết điều gì về đời tôi. Với dòng máu mà hắn có trong huyết quản như vậy, làm sao mà lý lịch của hắn có thể sạch sẽ được? Anh hỏi tôi về Henry Ashton và Perth trẻ. Tôi có dạy người này các thói hư tật xấu, còn người kia thì sự trụy lạc không? Nếu thằng con ngờ nghệch của Kent có nhặt vợ nó về từ trên phố thì việc ấy cũng liên quan gì đến tôi? Nếu Adrian Singleton viết tên bạn nó trên ngân phiếu, tôi cũng có phải là người trông nom nó đâu? Tôi thừa biết mọi người huyên thiên ra sao ở Anh. Giai cấp trung lưu thổ lộ các định kiến đạo đức của họ trên những bàn ăn béo ngậy, và xì xào về cái mà họ gọi là sự trác táng của những người trên họ để cố làm ra vẻ là họ ở tầng lớp tao nhã, và có quan hệ thân tình với những người mà họ nói xấu. Ở cái đất nước này thì người ta chỉ cần có sự khác biệt và bộ não là đã đủ để mọi cái lưỡi tầm thường múa lên chửi họ. Và cái kiểu đời nào mà chính những kẻ ấy, những kẻ tự cho mình là có đạo đức ấy, đang sống thế nhỉ? Bạn tôi ơi, anh quên mất là ta đang ở vùng đất quê hương của bọn đạo đức giả rồi.”
tr: Dorian dudağını dişleyerek, “Yeter, Basil,” dedi. “Hiç bilmediğin şeyler hakkında konuşuyorsun.” Sesinde sonsuz bir küçümseme vardı. “Ben girdiğimde Berwick’in neden odadan çıktığını soruyorsun. Ben onun yaşamıyla ilgili her şeyi biliyorum da ondan; yoksa o benim yaşantımla ilgili her şeyi bildiği için değil. Damarlarında öyle bir kan aktığına göre sicili nasıl temiz olabilir? Henry Ashton’la genç Perth’i sordun bana. Birine o kötü tutkuları, öbürüne o ahlak düşkünlüğünü ben mi öğrettim yani? Kent’in o salak oğlu sokaktan kadın aldıysa bana ne? Adrian Singleton bir senedin altına arkadaşının imzasını atarken ben yanı başındaydım da onu yola getirmekle mi yükümlüydüm? İngiltere’de hiç kimsenin dilinde kemik yok; biliyorum. Orta sınıflar ahlak konularındaki önyargılarını o görgüsüz sofralarının başında açıklarlar. Üst tabakaların sözüm ona ahlaksızlıkları konusunda fısıldaşarak kendileri de sosyetedenmiş gibi görünmeye çalışırlar; kara çaldıkları kişileri yakından tanıyormuş numarası yaparlar. Bu ülkede insan biraz seçkin, biraz kafalı olmaya görsün, hemen avam tabakasının diline düşer... Peki, ya kendilerini ahlak simgesi olarak gösteren bu kişilerin sürdüğü yaşantı nasıldır? Aziz dostum, unutma ki bizler ikiyüzlülüğün anavatanı olan bir ülkede yaşıyoruz.
es: —Ya basta, Basil. Estás hablando de cosas de las que nada sabes —dijo Dorian Gray mordiéndose los labios y con un tono de infinito desprecio en la voz—. Me preguntas porqué Berwick se marcha de una habitación cuando yo entro. Se debe a todo lo que yo sé acerca de su vida, no a lo que él sabe acerca de la mía. Con la sangre que lleva en las venas, ¿cómo podría ser una persona sin mancha? Me preguntas por Henry Ashton y el joven Perth. ¿Acaso soy yo quien les ha enseñado sus vicios a uno y al otro su libertinaje? Si el tonto del hijo de Kent va a buscar a su mujer en el arroyo, ¿qué tiene eso que ver conmigo? Si Adrian Singleton reconoce una deuda firmando el pagaré con el nombre de uno de sus amigos, ¿acaso soy yo su guardián? Sé muy bien hasta qué punto les gusta hablar a los ingleses. Las clases medias airean sus prejuicios morales en sus vulgares comedores, y murmuran sobre lo que ellos llaman la depravación de las clases superiores con el objeto de hacer creer que pertenecen a la buena sociedad y son íntimos de las personas a las que calumnian. En este país basta que un hombre sea distinguido e inteligente para que todas las lenguas vulgares se desaten contra él. Dime tú, ¿qué vida llevan todas esas personas que presumen de ser los guardianes de la moralidad? Mi querido amigo, olvidas que vivimos en el país de la hipocresía.
vi_translation: "Stop it, Basil. You are talking about things you know nothing about," Dorian Gray said, biting his lip, with an infinite note of contempt in his voice. "You ask me why Berwick left the room when I entered. It is because I know everything about his life, not because he knows anything about mine. With the blood he has in his veins, how could his background be clean? You ask me about Henry Ashton and young Perth. Did I teach one his vices and the other his depravity? If Kent's foolish son picked up his wife from the street, what does that have to do with me? If Adrian Singleton wrote his friend's name on a check, am I his guardian? I am well aware of how everyone gossips in England. The middle class expresses their moral prejudices over their greasy dinner tables, and gossip about what they call the debauchery of those above them to try to appear as if they belong to the upper class and have intimate relations with those they slander. In this country, all one needs is to be different and have a brain for every common tongue to lash out at them. And what kind of lives do those very people, who consider themselves moral, lead? My friend, you forget that we are in the homeland of hypocrisy."
tr_translation: Dorian bit his lip and said, "Enough, Basil."" You are talking about things you know nothing about. "There was an infinite contempt in his voice. " You are asking why Berwick left the room when I entered. It is because I know everything about his life; not because he knows everything about mine. How can his record be clean with that kind of blood running through his veins? You asked me about Henry Ashton and young Perth. Did I teach one those vile passions and the other that moral depravity? If Kent's foolish son picked up a woman from the street, what is it to me? Was I supposed to set Adrian Singleton on the right path when he forged his friend's signature on a note while I was beside him? I know that in England, no one has a bone in their tongue. The middle classes express their moral prejudices at their uncouth tables. The upper classes whisper about supposed immoralities to appear as if they are part of society; they pretend to know closely the people they slander. In this country, as soon as someone is a bit distinguished, a bit intellectual, they immediately become the subject of the common people's gossip...Well, what about the lives of those who present themselves as symbols of morality? My dear friend, do not forget that we live in a country that is the homeland of hypocrisy."
es_translation: —That's enough, Basil. You are talking about things you know nothing about —said Dorian Gray, biting his lips and with a tone of infinite contempt in his voice—. You ask me why Berwick leaves a room when I enter. It is due to everything I know about his life, not what he knows about mine. With the blood he has in his veins, how could he be a person without blemish? You ask me about Henry Ashton and young Perth. Am I the one who taught them their vices and the other his debauchery? If the fool son of Kent goes to look for his wife in the gutter, what does that have to do with me? If Adrian Singleton acknowledges a debt by signing the promissory note with the name of one of his friends, am I his guardian? I know very well to what extent the English like to talk. The middle classes air their moral prejudices in their vulgar dining rooms, and murmur about what they call the depravity of the upper classes in order to make believe they belong to good society and are intimate with the people they slander. In this country, it is enough for a man to be distinguished and intelligent for all vulgar tongues to be unleashed against him. Tell me, what kind of life do all those people who claim to be the guardians of morality lead? My dear friend, you forget that we live in the country of hypocrisy.

en: “Dorian,” cried Hallward, “that is not the question. England is bad enough I know, and English society is all wrong. That is the reason why I want you to be fine. You have not been fine. One has a right to judge of a man by the effect he has over his friends. Yours seem to lose all sense of honour, of goodness, of purity. You have filled them with a madness for pleasure. They have gone down into the depths. You led them there. Yes: you led them there, and yet you can smile, as you are smiling now. And there is worse behind. I know you and Harry are inseparable. Surely for that reason, if for none other, you should not have made his sister’s name a by-word.”
vi: “Dorian,” Hallward la lên, “đó không phải là vấn đề. Anh quốc đúng là khá tệ, tôi biết, và xã hội Anh thì lầm lạc cả rồi. Đó là lý do tại sao tôi muốn cậu thành người cao quý. Cậu không phải người cao quý. Người ta có quyền phán xét một người theo ảnh hưởng mà y tác động lên bạn bè. Bạn bè cậu dường như đã mất hết mọi ý thức về danh dự, về lòng tốt, về sự thanh khiết. Cậu đã truyền cho họ sự thèm khát khoái lạc đến rồ dại. Họ đã rơi xuống đáy. Cậu đã dẫn họ xuống đó. Đúng: cậu đã dẫn họ xuống đó, và cậu còn có thể cười, như cậu đang cười lúc này. Và còn có chuyện quá quắt hơn nữa đằng sau. Tôi biết cậu và Harry không rời nhau nửa bước. Rõ ràng là vì lý do ấy, nếu như không vì lý do nào khác, lẽ ra cậu không nên làm cho cái tên của em gái anh ta thành trò cười.”
tr: Hallward, “Dorian, sorun bu değil,” diye çıkıştı. “İngiltere’nin kötü yönleri olduğunu bilmez değilim. İngiliz toplum yapısı da temelden bozuk. İşte bunun için senin temiz, üstün olmanı istiyorum. Şimdiye dek olamadın. Kişiyi arkadaşlarının üzerindeki etkisiyle ölçmeye hakkımız vardır. Senin arkadaşların tüm onur kavramlarını, iyilik, temizlik kaygılarını yitiriyorlar sanki. Onlara zevk ve sefa çılgınlığı aşılıyorsun. Hepsi de birer uçurumun dibine düşüp kalmışlar. Sen sürükledin onları oraya. Evet, sen sürükledin, gene de gülümseyip geçebiliyorsun, işte şu anda yaptığın gibi. Hem bundan daha kötüsü de var. Senin Harry ile arandan su sızmadığını biliyorum. Başka neden olmasa da sırf bu nedenle, onun kız kardeşinin adını dillere düşürmekten kaçınmalıydın.
es: —Dorian —exclamó Hallward—, no es ése el problema. Inglaterra no está libre de pecado, lo sé, y la sociedad inglesa tiene mucho de qué arrepentirse. Ésa es precisamente la razón de que a ti te quiera yo intachable. Pero no lo has sido. Se puede juzgar a una persona por el efecto que tiene sobre sus amigos. Los tuyos parecen perder por completo el sentimiento del honor, de la bondad, de la pureza. Lo único que les transmites es una sed desenfrenada de placer, y no, se detienen hasta llegar al fondo del abismo. Pero eres tú quien los ha llevado hasta allí. Sí, has sido tú, y sin embargo aún eres capaz de sonreír, como lo estás haciendo ahora. Pero todavía hay más. Sé que Harry y tú sois inseparables. Por esa misma razón, si no por otra, no deberías haber permitido que su hermana se convirtiera en la comidilla de toda la ciudad.
vi_translation: “Dorian,” Hallward shouted, “that is not the issue. England is indeed quite bad, I know, and English society is all wrong. That is why I want you to be a noble person. You are not a noble person. One has the right to judge a person by the influence they exert on their friends. Your friends seem to have lost all sense of honor, of kindness, of purity. You have instilled in them a mad craving for pleasure. They have hit rock bottom. You have led them there. Yes: you have led them there, and you can still laugh, as you are laughing now. And there is something even more outrageous behind it. I know you and Harry are inseparable. Clearly for that reason, if for no other, you should not have made his sister's name a laughingstock.”
tr_translation: Hallward scolded, "Dorian, that's not the issue." "I'm not unaware that England has its bad sides. The structure of English society is fundamentally flawed. That's why I want you to be pure and superior. You haven't been able to be so until now. We have the right to judge a person by the influence they have on their friends. It's as if your friends are losing all sense of honor, goodness, and cleanliness. You instill in them a frenzy of pleasure and indulgence. They've all fallen into the depths of an abyss. You dragged them there. Yes, you dragged them, yet you can still smile and brush it off, just like you're doing right now. And there's something even worse than that. I know that you and Harry are inseparable. If for no other reason, you should have avoided bringing disgrace to his sister's name just because of that."
es_translation: —Dorian —exclaimed Hallward—, that is not the issue. England is not free from sin, I know, and English society has much to repent for. That is precisely the reason why I want you to be blameless. But you have not been. One can judge a person by the effect they have on their friends. Yours seem to completely lose their sense of honor, kindness, and purity. The only thing you transmit to them is an unbridled thirst for pleasure, and they do not stop until they reach the bottom of the abyss. But it is you who has led them there. Yes, it has been you, and yet you are still capable of smiling, as you are doing now. But there is still more. I know that Harry and you are inseparable. For that very reason, if for no other, you should not have allowed his sister to become the talk of the town.

en: “Take care, Basil. You go too far.”
vi: “Coi chừng, Basil. Anh đi quá xa rồi đấy.”
tr: “Yavaş ol Basil. Çok ileri gidiyorsun.
es: —Cuidado, Basil. Estás yendo demasiado lejos.
vi_translation: "Be careful, Basil." "You are going too far."
tr_translation: "Take it easy, Basil. You are going too far."
es_translation: —Careful, Basil. You are going too far.

en: “I must speak, and you must listen. You shall listen. When you met Lady Gwendolen, not a breath of scandal had ever touched her. Is there a single decent woman in London now who would drive with her in the park? Why, even her children are not allowed to live with her. Then there are other stories—stories that you have been seen creeping at dawn out of dreadful houses and slinking in disguise into the foulest dens in London. Are they true? Can they be true? When I first heard them, I laughed. I hear them now, and they make me shudder. What about your country-house and the life that is led there? Dorian, you don’t know what is said about you. I won’t tell you that I don’t want to preach to you. I remember Harry saying once that every man who turned himself into an amateur curate for the moment always began by saying that, and then proceeded to break his word. I do want to preach to you. I want you to lead such a life as will make the world respect you. I want you to have a clean name and a fair record. I want you to get rid of the dreadful people you associate with. Don’t shrug your shoulders like that. Don’t be so indifferent. You have a wonderful influence. Let it be for good, not for evil. They say that you corrupt every one with whom you become intimate, and that it is quite sufficient for you to enter a house for shame of some kind to follow after. I don’t know whether it is so or not. How should I know? But it is said of you. I am told things that it seems impossible to doubt. Lord Gloucester was one of my greatest friends at Oxford. He showed me a letter that his wife had written to him when she was dying alone in her villa at Mentone. Your name was implicated in the most terrible confession I ever read. I told him that it was absurd—that I knew you thoroughly and that you were incapable of anything of the kind. Know you? I wonder do I know you? Before I could answer that, I should have to see your soul.”
vi: “Tôi phải nói, và cậu phải nghe. Cậu sẽ phải nghe. Khi tôi gặp cô Gwendolen, chưa một hơi thở tai tiếng nào từng chạm đến cô ấy. Vậy mà bây giờ liệu có dù chỉ một phụ nữ đoan trang nào ở London còn chịu đi xe cùng cô ấy trong Công viên nữa không? Tại sao, thậm chí con cái cô ấy còn không được cho phép sống với cô ấy. Rồi là các câu chuyện khác — những câu chuyện là cậu từng bị nhìn thấy đang lẻn ra lúc bình minh khỏi các căn nhà kinh sợ và mặc quần áo cải trang để lén vào các khu nhà ổ chuột bẩn thỉu nhất ở London. Chúng có đúng không? Chúng có thể đúng được không? Khi tôi nghe chúng lần đầu, tôi đã bật cười. Giờ đây tôi nghe chúng, và chúng khiến tôi rùng mình. Còn về căn nhà thôn dã của cậu thì sao, và cuộc sống diễn ra ở đó thì thế nào? Dorian, cậu không biết người ta đồn gì về cậu đâu. Tôi sẽ không bảo cậu là tôi không muốn khuyên răn cậu. Tôi nhớ Harry có lần nói rằng mỗi người biến mình thành ra một cha phó nghiệp dư trong chốc lát thì luôn bắt đầu bằng việc nói thế, rồi quay ra thất hứa. Tôi rất muốn khuyên răn cậu. Tôi muốn cậu sống một cuộc đời thế nào mà khiến cho thế gian phải tôn trọng cậu. Tôi muốn cậu có một cái tên sạch và một lý lịch đẹp. Tôi muốn cậu tống cổ những kẻ đáng sợ mà cậu đang giao du. Đừng nhún vai như thế. Đừng tỏ vẻ dửng dưng như vậy. Cậu có một ảnh hưởng tuyệt vời. Hãy để nó phục vụ cái tốt, đừng phục vụ cái xấu. Họ nói là cậu làm hỏng tất cả những ai mà cậu trở nên thân thiết, và rằng chỉ cần cậu vào một ngôi nhà là cũng đủ để nỗi nhục nhã nào đó theo sau. Tôi không biết có đúng vậy hay không. Làm sao mà tôi biết được? Nhưng đấy là người ta đồn về cậu. Tôi được kể những điều mà dường như không thể nghi ngờ. Huân tước Gloucester là một trong những người bạn thân nhất của tôi ở Oxford. Ông ấy cho tôi xem lá thư mà vợ ông ấy viết cho ông ấy khi bà ấy hấp hối trong cảnh đơn côi ở biệt thự của mình tại Mentone. Tên cậu bị ám chỉ đến trong lời thú tội khủng khiếp nhất tôi từng đọc. Tôi bảo ông ấy rằng chuyện đó vô lý — là tôi hiểu rõ cậu, và rằng cậu không thể làm được bất cứ chuyện gì kiểu đó. Hiểu cậu? Tôi tự hỏi tôi có hiểu cậu thật không? Trước khi tôi có thể trả lời điều ấy, có lẽ tôi phải thấy linh hồn cậu.”
tr: “Konuşmak zorundayım, sen de ister istemez dinleyeceksin. Sen Leydi Gwendolen’le tanıştığın sırada onun adına zerrece leke düşmemişti. Oysa şimdi Londra’da, onunla parkta gezintiye çıkacak tek bir aile kadını var mıdır? Sen ne diyorsun, çocuklarının bile onunla bir arada oturmasına izin verilmiyor. Sonra başka söylentiler de var: Senin gizlice kötü şöhretli evlerden çıktığını görenler varmış; kılık değiştirerek Londra’nın en adi, en pis sefahat yuvalarına gittiğin gözleniyormuş. Doğru mu bunlar? Doğru olabilir mi? İlk duyduğumda gülüp geçtim. Şimdi duydukça tüylerim diken diken oluyor. Ya taşradaki evin, orada olup bitenler? Dorian, arkandan neler söylendiğini bilmiyorsun sen! Sana akıl vermek istemediğimi ileri sürecek değilim. Hiç unutmam, Harry, bir keresinde, akıl hocalığı yapmaya soyunan herkesin söze bunu demekle başladığını, sonra da bunu yalanladığını söylemişti. Ben sana akıl öğretmeye niyetliyim. Senin saygın bir ünün, temiz bir sicilin olsun istiyorum. Haşır neşir olduğun o berbat kişileri başından savmanı istiyorum. Omuz silkme öyle. Bu kadar boş verme. Olağanüstü etkileyicisin.
