Bu etkini kötülüğe değil iyiliğe kullan. Senin yakınlık kurduğun herkesin ahlakını bozduğunu söylüyorlar. Sen bir evin eşiğinden içeri adımını attın mı ardından mutlaka bir rezillik, utanç gelirmiş, öyle diyorlar. Böyle mi, değil mi, bilmiyorum. Ben nereden bileyim? Ama senin için işte böyle diyorlar. Öyle şeyler söylüyorlar ki, doğrulukları kuşku kaldırmıyor, Lord Glouchester Oxford’dayken en yakın arkadaşlarımdandı. Karısı Mentone’daki villasında tek başına, ölüm döşeğindeyken ona bir mektup yazmış; bana gösterdi. Okuduğum en korkunç itiraftı bu; senin ismine dokundurmada bulunuyordu. Ben bunun gülünç bir şey olduğunu, seni çok iyi tanıdığımı, senin böyle bir şeyi dünyada yapamayacağını söyledim dostuma. Seni tanımak ha? Seni sahiden tanıyor muyum acaba? Bunun yanıtını verebilmem için ruhunu görmem gerek.
es: —He de hablar y tú tienes que escucharme. Cuando conociste a lady Gwendolen no la había rozado aún ni la más leve sombra de escándalo. ¿Pero hay una sola mujer decente en Londres que esté ahora dispuesta a pasear en coche con ella por el parque? ¡Ni siquiera a sus hijos se les permite vivir con ella! Y luego hay otros rumores..., rumores según los cuales se te ha visto salir sigilosamente al amanecer de casas espantosas e introducirte disfrazado en las madrigueras más infames de Londres. ¿Son ciertos esos rumores? ¿Pueden ser verdad? Cuando los oí por vez primera me eché a reír. Ahora, cuando los oigo, hacen que me estremezca. ¿Qué decir de tu casa en el campo y de la vida que allí se hace? No sabes lo que se cuenta de ti, Dorian. No te voy a decir que no quiero sermonearte. Recuerdo cómo Harry afirmó en una ocasión que todo hombre que, en un momento determinado, decide desempeñar el papel de sacerdote, empieza diciendo eso, y acto seguido procede a faltar a su palabra. Quiero sermonearte. Deseo que tu vida haga que el mundo te respete. Que tengas un nombre sin tacha y una reputación por encima de toda sospecha. Que te libres de esas terribles personas con las que te tratas. No te encojas de hombros una vez más. No te muestres tan indiferente. Es mucha la influencia que tienes. Que sea para el bien, no para el mal. Dicen que corrompes a todas las personas con las que intimas, y que cuando entras en una casa, llega, pisándote los talones, la vergüenza de una u otra especie. No sé si es cierto o no. ¿Cómo podría saberlo? Pero eso es lo que dicen de ti. Me han contado cosas que parece imposible poner en duda. Lord Gloucester era uno de mis mejores amigos en Oxford. Me mostró una carta que le escribió su esposa cuando moría, sola, en su villa de Mentone. Tu nombre aparecía en ella, mezclado con la más terrible confesión que he leído nunca. A él le dije que era absurdo; que te conocía perfectamente, y que eras incapaz de nada parecido. ¿Te conozco? Me pregunto si es verdad que te conozco. Antes de contestar tendría que ver tu alma.
vi_translation: “I must speak, and you must listen. You will have to listen. When I met Miss Gwendolen, not a single breath of scandal had ever touched her. But now is there even one respectable woman in London who would still ride with her in the Park? Why, even her own children are not allowed to live with her. Then there are other stories — stories that you were seen sneaking out at dawn from dreadful houses and disguising yourself to slip into the filthiest slums in London. Are they true? Can they be true? When I first heard them, I laughed. Now I hear them, and they make me shudder. And what about your country house, and the life that is lived there? Dorian, you don’t know what people say about you. I won’t tell you that I don’t want to lecture you. I remember Harry once said that everyone who turns themselves into an amateur priest for a moment always begins by saying that, and then breaks their promise. I do want to lecture you. I want you to live a life that makes the world respect you. I want you to have a clean name and a fair record. I want you to get rid of those dreadful people you are associating with. Don’t shrug like that. Don’t be so indifferent. You have a wonderful influence. Let it be for good, not for evil. They say you corrupt everyone you become intimate with, and that just your entering a house is enough to bring some shame in your wake. I don’t know if it’s true or not. How could I know? But that is what is said about you. I have been told things that seem impossible to doubt. Lord Gloucester was one of my closest friends at Oxford. He showed me the letter his wife wrote to him when she was dying alone at their villa in Mentone. Your name was mentioned in the most terrible confession I have ever read. I told him it was absurd — that I knew you well, and that you couldn’t have done anything of that kind. Know you? I wonder if I really know you? Before I can answer that, perhaps I need to see your soul.”
tr_translation: “I have to speak, and you will have to listen whether you want to or not. When you met Lady Gwendolen, her name was spotless. But now, is there a single family woman in London who would take a walk with her in the park? What are you saying, even her children are not allowed to sit with her. Then there are other rumors: people have seen you secretly leaving notorious houses; it is observed that you go to the most vile, dirtiest dens of debauchery in London in disguise. Are these true? Could they be true? When I first heard, I laughed it off. Now, as I hear more, my hair stands on end. And your house in the countryside, what goes on there? Dorian, you don’t know what people are saying behind your back! I am not going to claim that I don’t want to give you advice. I will never forget, Harry once said that everyone who sets out to mentor starts by saying this and then contradicts it. I intend to teach you wisdom. I want you to have a respectable reputation, a clean record. I want you to get rid of those horrible people you are involved with. Don’t shrug your shoulders like that. Don’t be so indifferent. You are extraordinarily influential. Use this influence for good, not evil. They say that everyone you associate with has their morals corrupted. They say that once you step over the threshold of a house, disgrace and shame inevitably follow. Is it true or not, I don’t know. How should I know? But this is what they say about you. They say things that leave no room for doubt, Lord Glouchester was one of my closest friends when he was at Oxford. His wife wrote him a letter while she was alone on her deathbed at their villa in Mentone; he showed it to me. It was the most horrifying confession I have ever read; it implicated your name. I told my friend that it was ridiculous, that I knew you very well, that you could never do such a thing in the world. Know you? Do I really know you? To answer that, I would need to see your soul.”
es_translation: —I must speak, and you have to listen to me. When you met Lady Gwendolen, not even the slightest shadow of scandal had touched her yet. But is there a single decent woman in London now willing to ride with her in the park? Not even her children are allowed to live with her! And then there are other rumors... rumors that say you have been seen sneaking out at dawn from dreadful houses and entering the most infamous dens in London in disguise. Are those rumors true? Can they be true? When I first heard them, I laughed. Now, when I hear them, they make me shudder. What about your house in the country and the life that is led there? You don't know what is said about you, Dorian. I'm not going to tell you that I don't want to lecture you. I remember how Harry once said that every man who, at a certain moment, decides to play the role of a priest, starts by saying that, and then proceeds to break his word. I want to lecture you. I want your life to make the world respect you. To have a spotless name and a reputation above all suspicion. To rid yourself of those terrible people you associate with. Don't shrug your shoulders once more. Don't show such indifference. You have a lot of influence. Let it be for good, not for evil. They say you corrupt everyone you become intimate with, and that when you enter a house, shame of one kind or another follows closely behind you. I don't know if it's true or not. How could I know? But that is what they say about you. I've been told things that seem impossible to doubt. Lord Gloucester was one of my best friends at Oxford. He showed me a letter his wife wrote to him when she was dying, alone, in her villa in Mentone. Your name appeared in it, mixed with the most terrible confession I have ever read. I told him it was absurd; that I knew you perfectly, and that you were incapable of anything like that. Do I know you? I wonder if it's true that I know you. Before answering, I would have to see your soul. —See my soul!

en: “To see my soul!” muttered Dorian Gray, starting up from the sofa and turning almost white from fear.
vi: “Thấy linh hồn tôi!” Dorian Gray lẩm bẩm, đứng phắt dậy khỏi xô-pha và gần như trắng bệch đi vì sợ.
tr: Dorian Gray, “Ruhumu görmek ha!” diye söylenerek yerinden fırladı. Korkudan benzi solmuştu.
es: —¡Ver mi alma! —murmuró Dorian Gray, alzándose del sofá y palideciendo de miedo.
vi_translation: "See my soul!" Dorian Gray muttered, standing up abruptly from the sofa and almost turning pale with fear.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray, "See my soul, huh!" he muttered, jumping up from his seat. His face had turned pale with fear.
es_translation: —murmured Dorian Gray, rising from the sofa and paling with fear.

en: “Yes,” answered Hallward gravely, and with deep-toned sorrow in his voice, “to see your soul. But only God can do that.”
vi: “Đúng,” Hallward trả lời, trang nghiêm, và với sự buồn bã tông-trầm trong giọng — “thấy linh hồn cậu. Nhưng chỉ có Chúa mới có thể làm thế.”
tr: Hallward sesinde derin bir üzüntü tınısıyla, “Evet,” diye ciddiyetle karşılık verdi. “Senin ruhunu görmek. Ama bunu ancak Tanrı yapabilir.
es: —Sí —respondió Hallward con mucha seriedad y un tono profundamente pesaroso—; ver tu alma. Pero eso sólo lo puede hacer Dios.
vi_translation: “Yes,” Hallward replied, solemnly, and with a deep sadness in his tone — “to see your soul. But only God can do that.”
tr_translation: Hallward replied seriously, with a deep tone of sadness in his voice, "Yes." "To see your soul. But only God can do that."
es_translation: —Yes —replied Hallward with great seriousness and a deeply sorrowful tone—; to see your soul. But only God can do that.

en: A bitter laugh of mockery broke from the lips of the younger man. “You shall see it yourself, to-night!” he cried, seizing a lamp from the table. “Come: it is your own handiwork. Why shouldn’t you look at it? You can tell the world all about it afterwards, if you choose. Nobody would believe you. If they did believe you, they would like me all the better for it. I know the age better than you do, though you will prate about it so tediously. Come, I tell you. You have chattered enough about corruption. Now you shall look on it face to face.”
vi: Một tiếng cười cay đắng giễu cợt bật ra khỏi môi người trẻ hơn. “Anh sẽ tận mắt thấy nó, đêm nay!” cậu la lên, nắm lấy một cây đèn trên bàn. “Đi: nó là vật do chính tay anh tạo ra. Sao anh lại không nên ngắm nó? Sau đó anh có thể kể cho thế gian nghe tất cả về nó, nếu anh quyết định thế. Chẳng ai tin anh đâu. Nếu họ tin anh, họ còn thích tôi hơn vì điều ấy. Tôi hiểu về thời đại này hơn anh hiểu, mặc dù anh sẽ ba hoa về nó một cách hết sức nhạt nhẽo. Đi, tôi bảo anh. Anh đã huyên thiên đủ nhiều về sự mục nát rồi. Giờ thì anh sẽ thấy nó mặt đối mặt.”
tr: Dorian, acı, alaylı bir gülüşle, masanın üstünden bir lamba kaptığı gibi, “Kendi gözlerinle göreceksin, bu gece!” diye bağırdı. “Yürü! Senin elinin ürünü nasılsa. Neden görmeyesin? Sonradan istersen âleme bildirebilirsin. Kimse inanmayacaktır, nasılsa. İnansalar da bu yüzden beni daha bile beğeneceklerdir. Sen oturup iç sıkıcı söylevler çeksen bile ben çağımızı senden daha iyi tanıyorum. Yürü, dedim sana. Ahlak düşkünlüğü konusunda çaldığın çeneler yetti. Şimdi onu yüz yüze göreceksin!
es: Una amarga risotada de burla salió de los labios de su interlocutor. —¡Vas a tener ocasión de verla esta misma noche! —exclamó, tomando una lámpara de la mesa—. Ven: es obra tuya. ¿Por qué tendría que ocultártela? Después se lo podrás contar al mundo, si así lo decides. Nadie te creerá. Si de verdad te creyeran, aún me tendrían en mayor aprecio. Conozco la época en que vivimos mejor que tú, aunque perores sobre ella tan tediosamente como lo haces. Ven, te digo. Ya has hablado bastante de corrupción. Ahora vas a tener ocasión de verla cara a cara.
vi_translation: A bitter, mocking laugh escaped from the younger person's lips. "You will see it with your own eyes, tonight!" he shouted, grabbing a lamp on the table. "Go: it is something made by your own hands. Why shouldn't you look at it? Then you can tell the world all about it, if you decide to. Nobody will believe you. If they do believe you, they will like me more because of it. I understand this era better than you do, even though you will boast about it in the most boring way. Go, I tell you. You have prattled enough about decay already. Now you will see it face to face."
tr_translation: Dorian, with a pained, mocking laugh, grabbed a lamp from the table and shouted, "You will see with your own eyes, tonight!" "Walk! It is your handiwork anyway. Why shouldn't you see it? Later, if you wish, you can tell the whole world. No one will believe you, anyway. Even if they do, they will like me even more because of it. Even if you sit and give dreary speeches, I know our age better than you do. Walk, I told you. Enough of your prattling about moral decay. Now you will see it face to face!"
es_translation: A bitter mocking laugh escaped from the lips of his interlocutor. —You will have the chance to see it tonight! —he exclaimed, taking a lamp from the table—. Come: it is your work. Why should I hide it from you? Later you can tell the world, if you decide to do so. Nobody will believe you. If they truly believed you, they would hold me in even higher regard. I know the times we live in better than you, even though you drone on about them as tediously as you do. Come, I tell you. You have talked enough about corruption. Now you will have the chance to see it face to face.

en: There was the madness of pride in every word he uttered. He stamped his foot upon the ground in his boyish insolent manner. He felt a terrible joy at the thought that some one else was to share his secret, and that the man who had painted the portrait that was the origin of all his shame was to be burdened for the rest of his life with the hideous memory of what he had done.
vi: Có sự rồ dại kiêu hãnh trong mỗi lời cậu thốt ra. Cậu giậm chân trên sàn với thái độ xấc láo trẻ con. Cậu cảm thấy một niềm vui khủng khiếp với suy nghĩ rằng có ai đó khác để sẻ chia bí mật của cậu, và rằng cái người đã vẽ bức chân dung vốn là căn nguyên mọi nỗi ô nhục của cậu sẽ phải gánh chịu suốt quãng đời còn lại cái ký ức ghê gớm về việc y từng làm.
tr: Dudaklarından dökülen her sözcükte kendini beğenmişliğin çılgınlığı vardı. Ayağını çocuksu bir küstahlıkla yere vurdu. Gizini bir başkasıyla paylaşacağını düşünmek, tüm ayıbının başlangıcı olan portreyi yapan adamın da, yaptığı işin korkunç anısını ömür boyu bir yük gibi omzunda taşıyacağını bilmek, ona ürpertici bir kıvanç veriyordu.
es: La locura del orgullo estaba presente en cada palabra. Dorian Gray golpeó el suelo con el pie con insolencia de niño. La idea de que alguien compartiera su secreto le producía una espantosa alegría, y más aún que el hombre que había pintado el retrato que era el origen de toda su vergüenza cargara para el resto de su vida con el horrible recuerdo de lo que había hecho.
vi_translation: There is a mad pride in every word you utter. You stomp your foot on the floor with a childish insolence. You feel a terrible joy at the thought that there is someone else to share your secret, and that the person who painted the portrait, which is the source of all your shame, will have to bear the dreadful memory of what he has done for the rest of his life.
tr_translation: In every word that fell from her lips, there was the madness of arrogance. She stomped her foot on the ground with a childish insolence. The thought of sharing her secret with someone else, knowing that the man who painted the portrait, which was the beginning of all her shame, would carry the terrible memory of his work as a burden on his shoulders for life, gave her a chilling delight.
es_translation: The madness of pride was present in every word. Dorian Gray struck the ground with the insolence of a child. The idea that someone might share his secret filled him with a dreadful joy, especially that the man who had painted the portrait, which was the source of all his shame, would carry for the rest of his life the horrible memory of what he had done.

en: “Yes,” he continued, coming closer to him and looking steadfastly into his stern eyes, “I shall show you my soul. You shall see the thing that you fancy only God can see.”
vi: “Vâng,” cậu tiếp tục, lại gần y, nhìn không rời vào đôi mắt nghiêm khắc của y, “tôi sẽ cho anh thấy linh hồn tôi. Anh sẽ thấy thứ mà anh tưởng là chỉ có Chúa có thể thấy.”
tr: Ressama iyice sokuldu, gözlerini onun sert bakan gözlerinin ta içine dikerek, “Evet,” diye ekledi. “Ruhumu göstereceğim sana. Yalnızca Tanrı’nın görebileceğini sandığın şeyi sen de göreceksin.
es: —Sí —continuó, acercándosele más, y mirando sin pestañear los ojos severos de su amigo—. Voy a mostrarte mi alma. Voy a mostrarte esa cosa que, según imaginas, sólo Dios puede ver.
vi_translation: "Yes," he continued, approaching him, not taking his eyes off his stern gaze, "I will show you my soul." "You will see what you thought only God could see."
tr_translation: The painter leaned in closer, fixing his gaze deep into his stern eyes, and added, "Yes." "I will show you my soul. You will see what you thought only God could see."
es_translation: —Yes —he continued, getting closer to him, and staring unblinkingly into his friend's stern eyes—. I'm going to show you my soul. I'm going to show you that thing which, according to you, only God can see.

en: Hallward started back. “This is blasphemy, Dorian!” he cried. “You must not say things like that. They are horrible, and they don’t mean anything.”
vi: Hallward giật mình lùi lại. “Báng bổ, Dorian!” y kêu lên. “Cậu không nên nói những điều như thế. Chúng thật khủng khiếp, và chúng chẳng có ý nghĩa gì cả.
tr: Hallward bir adım gerileyerek, “Günaha giriyorsun, Dorian!” diye bağırdı. “Konuşma böyle. Korkunç şeyler bu söylediklerin, hem de zırva.
es: Hallward retrocedió instintivamente. —¡Eso es una blasfemia, Dorian! —exclamó—. No debes decir esas cosas. Son horribles, y no significan nada.
vi_translation: Hallward started back with a look of horror. "Blasphemy, Dorian!" he cried. "You must not say such things. They are horrible, and they mean nothing at all."
tr_translation: Hallward took a step back, shouting, "You are sinning, Dorian!" "Don't talk like that. What you are saying is terrible, and nonsense."
es_translation: Hallward instinctively stepped back. —That is blasphemy, Dorian! —he exclaimed—. You must not say such things. They are horrible, and they mean nothing.

en: “You think so?” He laughed again.
vi: “Anh nghĩ vậy sao?” Cậu lại cười.
tr: “Öyle mi sanıyorsun?” Dorian gene güldü.
es: —¿Es eso lo que crees? —le replicó Dorian Gray, riendo de nuevo.
vi_translation: "Do you think so?" He smiled again.
tr_translation: "Is that what you think?" Dorian laughed again.
es_translation: —Is that what you think? —replied Dorian Gray, laughing again.

en: “I know so. As for what I said to you to-night, I said it for your good. You know I have been always a stanch friend to you.”
vi: “Tôi biết vậy. Về phần những gì tôi nói với cậu đêm nay, tôi nói vì muốn tốt cho cậu. Cậu biết tôi luôn là người bạn trung thành với cậu.”
tr: “Öyle olduğunu biliyorum. Benim sana bu gece dediklerime gelince; senin iyiliğin için söyledim. Eskiden beri senin en güvenilir dostun olmuşumdur, biliyorsun bunu.
es: —Lo sé. En cuanto a lo que te he dicho esta noche, lo he hecho por tu bien. Sabes que he sido siempre un amigo fiel.
vi_translation: “I know that. As for what I told you tonight, I said it because I want the best for you. You know I have always been a loyal friend to you.”
tr_translation: “I know it is so. As for what I told you tonight; I said it for your own good. I have always been your most reliable friend, you know this.”
es_translation: —I know. As for what I told you tonight, I did it for your own good. You know that I have always been a loyal friend.

en: “Don’t touch me. Finish what you have to say.”
vi: “Đừng đụng vào tôi. Nói nốt những gì anh phải nói đi.”
tr: “El sürme bana. Sözünü bitir.
es: —No me toques. Termina lo que tengas que decir.
vi_translation: "Don't touch me. Say whatever you have to say."
tr_translation: “Don't push me. Finish what you were saying.”
es_translation: —Don't touch me. Finish what you have to say.

en: A twisted flash of pain shot across the painter’s face. He paused for a moment, and a wild feeling of pity came over him. After all, what right had he to pry into the life of Dorian Gray? If he had done a tithe of what was rumoured about him, how much he must have suffered! Then he straightened himself up, and walked over to the fire-place, and stood there, looking at the burning logs with their frostlike ashes and their throbbing cores of flame.
vi: Một thoáng nhăn nhó đau đớn vụt qua mặt họa sỹ. Y dừng lại một lát, và một cảm xúc thương xót dữ dội đến với y. Rốt cuộc, y có quyền gì để mà xoi mói vào đời Dorian Gray? Giả dụ cậu ta có làm một phần rất nhỏ những gì thiên hạ đã đồn đại, thì cậu ta cũng đã phải chịu biết bao đau khổ! Sao đó y thẳng người lên, bước lại gần lò sưởi, đứng đó, nhìn những khúc gỗ cháy với tro tàn như sương giá và những cái lõi lửa nhoi nhói.
tr: Acılı bir ifade ressamın yüzünü yalayıp geçti. Hallward bir an duraladı, sonra içini derin bir acıma duygusu bürüdü. Öyle ya, Dorian Gray’in hayatına burnunu sokmaya onun ne hakkı vardı? Dorian, hakkında söylenenlerin binde birini bile yapmışsa eğer, kimbilir neler çekmişti! Hallward doğrularak şömineye doğru yürüdü, orada durup yanan kütüklerin kırağıya benzer küllerine, yürek gibi atan ateşten özlerine baktı.
es: El dolor crispó por un instante las facciones del pintor. Quedó mudo, invadido por un sentimiento de compasión infinita. Después de todo, ¿qué derecho tenía él a inmiscuirse en la vida de Dorian? Aunque no hubiera hecho más que una décima parte de lo que de él se contaba, ¡cuánto tenía que haber sufrido! Pero enseguida se irguió, dirigiéndose hacia la chimenea, y allí se quedó, contemplando los leños, que ardían con cenizas semejantes a la escarcha y corazones palpitantes hechos de llamas.
vi_translation: A fleeting grimace of pain flashed across the artist's face. He paused for a moment, and a fierce feeling of pity came over him. After all, what right did he have to pry into Dorian Gray's life? Even if the young man had done a fraction of what people gossiped about, he must have suffered immensely! Then he straightened up, walked over to the fireplace, stood there, watching the burning logs with frost-like ashes and the glowing embers.
tr_translation: A painful expression briefly crossed the painter's face. Hallward paused for a moment, then was overwhelmed by a deep sense of pity. After all, what right did he have to interfere in Dorian Gray's life? If Dorian had done even a fraction of what was said about him, who knows what he had endured! Hallward straightened up and walked towards the fireplace, where he stood and looked at the frost-like ashes of the burning logs, and the heart-like core of the fire.
es_translation: The pain contorted the painter's features for an instant. He remained silent, overwhelmed by a feeling of infinite compassion. After all, what right did he have to interfere in Dorian's life? Even if he had done only a tenth of what was said about him, how much he must have suffered! But he immediately straightened up, heading towards the fireplace, and there he stayed, gazing at the logs, which burned with ashes resembling frost and throbbing hearts made of flames.

en: “I am waiting, Basil,” said the young man in a hard clear voice.
vi: “Tôi đang đợi đây, Basil,” người trẻ nói, bằng giọng rõ ràng, cứng rắn.
tr: Dorian katı, duru bir sesle, “Bekliyorum, Basil,” dedi.
es: —Estoy esperando, Basil —dijo el joven, con voz clara y dura.
vi_translation: “I am waiting here, Basil,” the young man said, in a clear, firm voice.
tr_translation: Dorian said in a firm, clear voice, "I am waiting, Basil."
es_translation: —I am waiting, Basil —said the young man, with a clear and hard voice.

en: He turned round. “What I have to say is this,” he cried. “You must give me some answer to these horrible charges that are made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely untrue from beginning to end, I shall believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them! Can’t you see what I am going through? My God! don’t tell me that you are bad, and corrupt, and shameful.”
vi: Y quay lại. “Điều tôi phải nói là thế này,” y la lên. “Cậu phải cho tôi câu trả lời nào đó về những lời buộc tội khủng khiếp bị đưa ra để chống lại cậu. Nếu cậu bảo tôi rằng chúng sai tuyệt đối từ đầu đến cuối, tôi sẽ tin cậu. Phủ nhận chúng đi, Dorian, phủ nhận chúng đi! Chẳng lẽ cậu không thế thấy những gì tôi phải trải qua? Chúa ơi! Đừng bảo tôi là cậu xấu xa, đồi bại, nhục nhã.”
tr: Ressam ona doğru döndü. “Söyleyeceğim şu: Sana yöneltilen bu iğrenç suçlamalar konusunda bana bir açıklamada bulunmalısın. Hepsinin baştan sona uydurma olduğunu söylersen inanacağım. Yalanla bunları, Dorian, hepsini yalanla! Neler çektiğimi gözün görmüyor mu? Ulu Tanrım, kötü yürekli, ahlaksız, rezil biri olduğunu söyleme bana!
es: El pintor se volvió. —Lo que tengo que decir es esto —exclamó—. Has de darme alguna respuesta a las terribles acusaciones que se hacen contra ti. Si me dices que son absolutamente falsas de principio a fin, te creeré. ¡Niégalas, Dorian, hazme el favor de negarlas! ¿No ves lo mucho que estoy sufriendo? ¡Dios del cielo! No me digas que eres un malvado, un corrupto, un infame.
vi_translation: He turned back. "What I have to say is this," he shouted. "You must give me some answer to these terrible accusations that have been made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely false from beginning to end, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them! Can't you see what I have to go through? Good God! Don't tell me that you are wicked, depraved, and dishonorable."
tr_translation: The painter turned towards him. “What I have to say is this: You must give me an explanation regarding these disgusting accusations directed at you. If you tell me they are completely fabricated, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, deny them all! Can't you see what I've been through? Good God, don't tell me you are a wicked, immoral, disgraceful person!”
es_translation: The painter turned around. —What I have to say is this —he exclaimed—. You must give me some answer to the terrible accusations made against you. If you tell me that they are absolutely false from beginning to end, I will believe you. Deny them, Dorian, do me the favor of denying them! Don't you see how much I am suffering? Good heavens! Don't tell me that you are a wicked, corrupt, infamous person.

en: Dorian Gray smiled. There was a curl of contempt in his lips. “Come upstairs, Basil,” he said quietly. “I keep a diary of my life from day to day, and it never leaves the room in which it is written. I shall show it to you if you come with me.”
vi: Dorian Gray cười. Có một cái bĩu khinh miệt trên môi cậu. “Đi lên gác nào, Basil,” cậu nói, bình thản. “Tôi giữ một cuốn nhật ký đời tôi từ ngày này qua ngày khác, và nó chẳng bao giờ rời căn phòng mà trong đó nó được viết. Tôi sẽ cho anh xem nó nếu anh đi cùng tôi.”
tr: Dorian Gray gülümsedi. Dudakları küçümseyen bir gülüşle bükülmüştü. Genç adam serinkanlılıkla, “Yukarı gel, Basil,” dedi. “Yaşantımı günü gününe not ettiğim bir güncem var, ama yazdığım odadan dışarı hiç çıkarmıyorum. Gelirsen sana da gösteririm.
es: Dorian Gray sonrió. Un gesto de desprecio le curvó los labios. —Sube conmigo, Basil —dijo con calma—. Llevo un diario de mi vida que no sale nunca de la habitación donde se escribe. Te lo enseñaré si me acompañas.
vi_translation: Dorian Gray laughed. There was a contemptuous curl on his lips. "Come upstairs, Basil," he said calmly. "I keep a diary of my life from day to day, and it never leaves the room in which it is written. I will show it to you if you come with me."
tr_translation: Dorian Gray smiled. His lips curled in a contemptuous smile. The young man, with composure, “Come upstairs, Basil,” he said. “I have a diary where I note down my daily life, but I never take it out of the room where I write it. If you come, I'll show it to you too.”
es_translation: Dorian Gray smiled. A gesture of disdain curved his lips. —Come upstairs with me, Basil —he said calmly—. I keep a diary of my life that never leaves the room where it is written. I will show it to you if you accompany me.

en: “I shall come with you, Dorian, if you wish it. I see I have missed my train. That makes no matter. I can go to-morrow. But don’t ask me to read anything to-night. All I want is a plain answer to my question.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ đi cùng cậu, Dorian, nếu cậu muốn thế. Tôi thấy tôi đã lỡ tàu. Thế cũng chẳng sao. Mai tôi có thể đi. Nhưng đừng yêu cầu tôi đọc bất cứ thứ gì đêm nay. Tất cả những gì tôi muốn chỉ là một câu trả lời thẳng thắn cho câu hỏi của tôi.”
tr: “Gelirim, Dorian, madem istiyorsun. Zaten trenim de kaçmış bu arada. Önemli değil. Yarın giderim. Yalnız bu gece hiçbir şey okutma bana. Tek istediğim soruma açık bir yanıt.
es: —Subiré contigo, Dorian, si así lo deseas. Veo que ya he perdido el tren. Da lo mismo. Saldré mañana. Pero no me pidas que lea nada esta noche. Todo lo que quiero es una respuesta directa a mi pregunta.
vi_translation: “I will go with you, Dorian, if you want that. I see that I have missed the train. That’s alright. I can go tomorrow. But don’t ask me to read anything tonight. All I want is a straightforward answer to my question.”
tr_translation: "I'll come, Dorian, since you want me to. Anyway, I've missed my train as well. It's not important. I'll go tomorrow. Just don't make me read anything tonight. All I want is a clear answer to my question."
es_translation: —I will go up with you, Dorian, if you wish. I see that I have already missed the train. It doesn't matter. I will leave tomorrow. But don't ask me to read anything tonight. All I want is a direct answer to my question.

en: “That shall be given to you upstairs. I could not give it here. You will not have to read long.”
vi: “Nó sẽ được đưa cho anh ở trên gác. Tôi không thể đưa nó ra ở đây. Anh sẽ không phải đọc lâu đâu.”
tr: “Bu yanıt sana yukarıda verilecek. Burada söyleyemem. Uzun boylu okumana da gerek kalmayacak.
es: —Te será dada en el último piso. No te la puedo dar aquí. No será necesario que leas mucho rato.
vi_translation: “It will be given to you upstairs. I can't bring it out here. You won't have to read for long.”
tr_translation: "This answer will be given to you above. I can't say it here. You won't need to read for long either."
es_translation: —It will be given to you on the top floor. I can't give it to you here. It won't be necessary for you to read for long.

en: CHAPTER XIII.
vi: Chương 13
tr: On üçüncü bölüm
es: Capítulo 13
vi_translation: Chapter 13
tr_translation: Chapter Thirteen
es_translation: Chapter 13

en: He passed out of the room and began the ascent, Basil Hallward following close behind. They walked softly, as men do instinctively at night. The lamp cast fantastic shadows on the wall and staircase. A rising wind made some of the windows rattle.
vi: Cậu ra khỏi phòng, và bắt đầu đi lên, Basil Hallward theo sát đằng sau. Họ bước êm, như mọi người vẫn làm theo bản năng trong đêm. Đèn hắt những cái bóng quái dị lên tường và cầu thang. Một làn gió nổi lên gây ra vài tiếng cửa sổ lạch cạch.
tr: Dorian Gray dışarı çıkarak merdiveni tırmanmaya başladı; Basil Hallward onun peşinden gidiyordu. İnsanların geceleri içgüdüsel olarak yaptıkları gibi, usul usul yürüyorlardı. Lamba merdivenin duvarlarına olmayacak gölgeler düşürüyor, dışarıda hızlanan rüzgâr kimi pencereleri tangırdatıyordu.
es: Dorian salió de la habitación y empezó a subir, seguido muy de cerca por Basil Hallward. Caminaban sin hacer ruido, como se hace instintivamente de noche. La lámpara arrojaba sombras fantásticas sobre la pared y la escalera. El viento, que empezaba a levantarse, hacía tabletear algunas ventanas.
vi_translation: He left the room and began to go upstairs, with Basil Hallward following closely behind. They walked quietly, as people instinctively do at night. The lights cast strange shadows on the walls and stairs. A gust of wind arose, causing a few windows to rattle.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray stepped outside and began to climb the stairs; Basil Hallward was following him. As people instinctively do at night, they were walking quietly. The lamp cast improbable shadows on the walls of the staircase, and the wind picking up outside rattled some of the windows.
es_translation: Dorian left the room and began to ascend, closely followed by Basil Hallward. They walked without making noise, as one instinctively does at night. The lamp cast fantastic shadows on the wall and the staircase. The wind, which was beginning to rise, made some windows rattle.

en: When they reached the top landing, Dorian set the lamp down on the floor, and taking out the key, turned it in the lock. “You insist on knowing, Basil?” he asked in a low voice.
vi: Khi họ lên đến đầu cầu thang cao nhất. Dorian để đèn xuống sàn, lấy chìa ra, vặn nó trong ổ khóa. “Anh nhất định đòi biết, đúng không Basil?” cậu hỏi, bằng giọng nói nhỏ nhẹ.
tr: En üst sahanlıkta Dorian lambayı yere bıraktı, anahtarı çıkarıp kilitte döndürdü. Yavaş sesle, “Öğrenmekte direniyor musun, Basil?” diye sordu.
es: Cuando alcanzaron el descansillo del ático, Dorian dejó la lámpara en el suelo y, sacando la llave, la introdujo en la cerradura. —¿De verdad quieres saberlo, Basil? —le preguntó en voz baja.
vi_translation: When they reached the top of the highest staircase. Dorian put the lamp down on the floor, took out a key, and turned it in the lock. “You really insist on knowing, don't you Basil?” he asked, in a gentle voice.
tr_translation: At the top landing, Dorian placed the lamp on the ground, took out the key, and turned it in the lock. In a low voice, "Are you resisting learning, Basil?" he asked.
es_translation: When they reached the attic landing, Dorian placed the lamp on the floor and, taking out the key, inserted it into the lock. —Do you really want to know, Basil? —he asked in a low voice.

en: “Yes.”
vi: “Đúng.”
tr: “Evet.
es: —Sí.
vi_translation: “Correct.”
tr_translation: “Yes.”
es_translation: —Yes.

en: “I am delighted,” he answered, smiling. Then he added, somewhat harshly, “You are the one man in the world who is entitled to know everything about me. You have had more to do with my life than you think”; and, taking up the lamp, he opened the door and went in. A cold current of air passed them, and the light shot up for a moment in a flame of murky orange. He shuddered. “Shut the door behind you,” he whispered, as he placed the lamp on the table.
vi: “Tôi rất hân hạnh,” cậu trả lời, mỉm cười. Sau đó cậu nói thêm, có phần cay nghiệt, “anh là người duy nhất trên thế gian được quyền biết hết về tôi. Anh đã liên quan với đời tôi nhiều hơn là anh tưởng,” và, cầm đèn lên, cậu mở cửa rồi đi vào. Một luồng khí lạnh luồn qua họ, ánh sáng bùng lên một lát trong ngọn lửa da cam u ám. Cậu rùng mình. “Khép cái cửa sau anh lại đi,” cậu thì thào, và đặt cây đèn lên bàn.
tr: Dorian, “Çok sevindim,” diye gülümsedi. Sonra biraz haşin bir sesle ekledi: “Dünyada benimle ilgili her şeyi bilmeye hakkı olan bir kişi varsa o da sensin. Benim hayatımda oynadığın rol sandığından daha büyüktür.” Sonra lambayı yerden alıp kapıyı açarak içeri girdi. Soğuk bir hava esintisi onları sıyırıp geçti, lambanın ışığı bir an için isli turuncu bir yalazla yukarı doğru fışkırdı. Dorian ürperdi. “Kapıyı kapat,” diye fısıldayarak lambayı masanın üzerine bıraktı.
es: —No te imaginas cuánto me alegro —respondió, sonriendo. Luego añadió, con cierta violencia—: eres la única persona en el mundo que tiene derecho a saberlo todo de mí. Estás más estrechamente ligado a mi vida de lo que crees —luego, recogiendo la lámpara, abrió la puerta y entró en la antigua sala de juegos. Una corriente de aire frío los asaltó, y la lámpara emitió por unos instantes una llama de turbio color naranja. Dorian Gray se estremeció—. Cierra la puerta -le susurró a Basil, mientras colocaba la lámpara sobre la mesa.
vi_translation: “I am very honored,” he replied, smiling. Then he added, somewhat bitterly, “you are the only person in the world who has the right to know everything about me. You have been more involved in my life than you think,” and, picking up the lamp, he opened the door and went in. A cold draft passed through them, the light flared for a moment in the dim orange flame. He shivered. “Close the door behind you,” he whispered, and placed the lamp on the table.
tr_translation: Dorian smiled, "I am very glad," he said. Then, in a slightly harsh voice, he added, "If there is one person in the world who has the right to know everything about me, it is you. The role you play in my life is greater than you think." Then he picked up the lamp from the floor, opened the door, and went inside. A cold draft brushed past them, and the light of the lamp flared up for a moment with a sooty orange flame. Dorian shivered. "Close the door," he whispered, placing the lamp on the table.
es_translation: —You can't imagine how glad I am —he replied, smiling. Then he added, with a certain violence—: you are the only person in the world who has the right to know everything about me. You are more closely tied to my life than you think —then, picking up the lamp, he opened the door and entered the old playroom. A cold draft assaulted them, and the lamp emitted for a few moments a flame of murky orange color. Dorian Gray shivered—. Close the door —he whispered to Basil, while placing the lamp on the table.

en: Hallward glanced round him with a puzzled expression. The room looked as if it had not been lived in for years. A faded Flemish tapestry, a curtained picture, an old Italian cassone, and an almost empty book-case—that was all that it seemed to contain, besides a chair and a table. As Dorian Gray was lighting a half-burned candle that was standing on the mantelshelf, he saw that the whole place was covered with dust and that the carpet was in holes. A mouse ran scuffling behind the wainscoting. There was a damp odour of mildew.
vi: Hallward đưa mắt nhìn quanh mình, với vẻ bối rối. Căn phòng trông như thể không được ở đã nhiều năm. Một tấm thảm Flander phai màu, một bức tranh bị che màn, một cassone cổ của Ý, và một tủ sách gần như trống rỗng — đó là tất cả những gì mà dường như nó có chứa, ngoài một cái ghế và một cái bàn. Lúc Dorian Gray thắp lại một cây nến cháy dở ở cái giá trên lò sưởi, cậu thấy là toàn bộ nơi này đã bị phủ bụi, và thảm thủng lỗ chỗ. Một con chuột chạy lục sục sau ván ốp chân tường. Mùi nấm mốc ẩm thấp đâu đây.
tr: Hallward yüzünde şaşırmış bir ifadeyle çevresine bakındı. Oda yıllardır kullanılmamışa benziyordu. Rengi atmış, Felemenk işi bir duvar halısı, önü perdeli bir resim, eski bir İtalyan sandığı, hemen hemen boş duran bir kitap dolabı... Odada yalnızca bunlar var gibiydi; bir de masayla sandalye. Dorian Gray şöminenin üstündeki yarım mumu yakarken Hallward her yerin toz içinde, halının delik deşik olduğunu gördü. Duvar kaplamasının ardında bir fare tıkırdıyordu. Havada nemli bir küf kokusu vardı.
es: Hallward miró a su alrededor, desconcertado. Se diría que aquella habitación llevaba años sin usarse. Un descolorido tapiz flamenco, un cuadro detrás de una cortina, un antiguo cassone italiano, y una librería casi vacía era todo lo que parecía encerrar, además de una silla y una mesa. Mientras Dorian Gray encendía una vela medio consumida que descansaba sobre la repisa de la chimenea, Basil advirtió que todo estaba cubierto de polvo y que la alfombra tenía muchos agujeros. Un ratón corrió a esconderse tras el revestimiento de madera. La habitación entera olía a moho y a humedad.
vi_translation: Hallward looked around him, with a bewildered expression. The room looked as if it hadn't been inhabited for many years. A faded Flanders carpet, a veiled painting, an old Italian cassone, and an almost empty bookshelf — that seemed to be all it contained, apart from a chair and a table. When Dorian Gray relit a half-burned candle on the mantelpiece, he saw that the entire place was covered in dust, and the carpet was riddled with holes. A rat scurried behind the wainscoting. The smell of damp mold lingered in the air.
tr_translation: Hallward looked around with a surprised expression on his face. The room seemed to have been unused for years. A faded Flemish tapestry, a picture with a curtain in front of it, an old Italian chest, an almost empty bookcase... These seemed to be the only things in the room; and a table and a chair. While Dorian Gray lit the half-burnt candle on the mantelpiece, Hallward saw that everything was covered in dust and the carpet was full of holes. A rat was scurrying behind the wall paneling. There was a damp, musty smell in the air.
es_translation: Hallward looked around, bewildered. It seemed as if that room had not been used for years. A faded Flemish tapestry, a painting behind a curtain, an old Italian cassone, and an almost empty bookshelf were all it seemed to contain, besides a chair and a table. While Dorian Gray lit a half-burned candle that rested on the mantelpiece, Basil noticed that everything was covered in dust and that the carpet had many holes. A mouse ran to hide behind the wooden paneling. The entire room smelled of mold and dampness.

en: “So you think that it is only God who sees the soul, Basil? Draw that curtain back, and you will see mine.”
vi: “Vậy là anh nghĩ rằng chỉ có Chúa mới thấy được linh hồn, đúng không Basil? Kéo tấm màn này ra, anh sẽ thấy linh hồn tôi.”
tr: “Demek sen insanın ruhunu ancak Tanrı görebilir sanıyorsun, öyle mi Basil? Şu perdeyi çek, benim ruhumu göreceksin.
es: —De manera que, según tú, sólo Dios ve el alma, ¿no es eso? Descorre la cortina y verás la mía.
vi_translation: “So you think that only God can see the soul, right Basil? Pull this curtain aside, and you will see my soul.”
tr_translation: "So you think only God can see a person's soul, do you Basil? Draw that curtain, and you will see my soul."
es_translation: —So, according to you, only God sees the soul, isn't that right? Draw back the curtain and you will see mine.

en: The voice that spoke was cold and cruel. “You are mad, Dorian, or playing a part,” muttered Hallward, frowning.
vi: Giọng nói ấy lạnh lùng và độc ác. “Cậu điên rồi, Dorian, hoặc đang đóng một vai kịch,” Hallward thì thầm, nhăn mặt.
tr: Konuşan ses soğuk ve zalimdi. Hallward kaşlarını çatarak, “Dorian, sen delisin ya da rol yapıyorsun,” dedi.
es: La voz que hablaba era fría y cruel. —Estás loco, Dorian, o representas un papel —murmuró Hallward, frunciendo el ceño.
vi_translation: That voice was cold and cruel. "You're mad, Dorian, or you're playing a part," Hallward whispered, grimacing.
tr_translation: The voice that spoke was cold and cruel. Frowning, Hallward said, "Dorian, you are either mad or pretending,"
es_translation: The voice that spoke was cold and cruel. —You are crazy, Dorian, or you are playing a role —murmured Hallward, frowning.

en: “You won’t? Then I must do it myself,” said the young man, and he tore the curtain from its rod and flung it on the ground.
vi: “Anh sẽ không làm à? Vậy thì tôi phải tự làm thôi,” người trẻ nói; giật phăng tấm màn khỏi song, quăng nó lên sàn.
tr: “Açmıyor musun? Bana düşüyor öyleyse,” diyen genç adam perdeyi çubuğundan çekip kopartarak yere attı.
es: —¿No te atreves? En ese caso lo haré yo —dijo el joven, arrancando la cortina de la barra que la sostenía y arrojándola al suelo.
vi_translation: “You won't do it? Then I'll have to do it myself,” the young person said, yanking the curtain off the bar and throwing it onto the floor.
tr_translation: "Aren't you opening it? Then it's up to me," said the young man, pulling the curtain from its rod and throwing it to the ground.
es_translation: —Don't you dare? In that case, I'll do it —said the young man, tearing the curtain from the bar that held it and throwing it to the ground.

en: An exclamation of horror broke from the painter’s lips as he saw in the dim light the hideous face on the canvas grinning at him. There was something in its expression that filled him with disgust and loathing. Good heavens! it was Dorian Gray’s own face that he was looking at! The horror, whatever it was, had not yet entirely spoiled that marvellous beauty. There was still some gold in the thinning hair and some scarlet on the sensual mouth. The sodden eyes had kept something of the loveliness of their blue, the noble curves had not yet completely passed away from chiselled nostrils and from plastic throat. Yes, it was Dorian himself. But who had done it? He seemed to recognize his own brushwork, and the frame was his own design. The idea was monstrous, yet he felt afraid. He seized the lighted candle, and held it to the picture. In the left-hand corner was his own name, traced in long letters of bright vermilion.
vi: Một tiếng thét ghê rợn bật ra khỏi môi họa sỹ khi y thấy bộ mặt gớm guốc trên tấm toan đang nhe răng cười với y trong ánh sáng lờ mờ. Có gì đó ở vẻ mặt nó làm y thấy đầy kinh tởm và căm ghét. Trời ơi! Đó là bộ mặt của chính Dorian Gray, y đang nhìn vào bộ mặt của chính Dorian Gray! Sự ghê rợn dù gì cũng vẫn còn chưa phá hỏng được hết vẻ đẹp diệu kỳ ấy. Vẫn còn ánh vàng nào đó trên mái tóc thưa và sắc hồng nào đó trên đôi môi gợi tình. Đôi mắt u mê còn giữ được chút gì đó đáng yêu trong màu lam của chúng, những đường cong quý phái vẫn còn chưa mất hẳn khỏi cặp lỗ mũi chạm trổ và cái cổ họng điêu khắc. Đúng, đó chính là Dorian. Nhưng ai đã làm ra nó? Y dường như nhận ra bút pháp của mình, và cái khung là thiết kế của chính y. Ý nghĩ ấy thật kỳ dị, tuy nhiên y thấy sợ. Y nắm lấy cây nến đã thắp, cầm nó đến bức tranh. Trên góc tay trái có tên y, được phác ra bằng các chữ cái dài màu son tươi.
tr: O loş ışıkta tuvalden kendisine sırıtan iğrenç yüzü görünce ressamın dudaklarından bir dehşet ünlemi koptu. Bu yüzün ifadesinde içini tiksinti ve ürpermeyle dolduran bir şey vardı. Aman Tanrım! Karşısındaki şey Dorian Gray’in yüzüydü. Portreye dadanan ürkünç etki –ne olabilirdi bu?– o şahane güzelliği henüz tümüyle bozamamıştı. Seyrelmiş saçlarında hâlâ biraz altın pırıltısı, o şehvetli ağızda hâlâ biraz kırmızılık vardı. Sulu ayyaş gözlerde eski güzel maviliklerinden bir şeyler kalmış, o kalemle çizilmişe benzeyen burunla biçimli boynun soylu yuvarlağı henüz tümden silinmemişti. Evet, Dorian’ın kendisiydi bu. Peki ama, çizen kimdi? Hallward kendi fırça vuruşlarını tanır gibi oldu; çerçevenin tasarımı da onundu. Olmayacak şeydi bu, gene de ressam bir korkuya kapılarak mumu aldı, resme doğru kaldırdı. Sol köşede, uzun, parlak kırmızı renklerle yazılmış kendi adı duruyordu.
es: De los labios del pintor escapó una exclamación de horror al ver, en la penumbra, el espantoso rostro que le sonreía desde el lienzo. Había algo en su expresión que le produjo de inmediato repugnancia y aborrecimiento. ¡Dios del cielo! ¡Era el rostro de Dorian Gray lo que estaba viendo! La misteriosa abominación aún no había destruido por completo su extraordinaria belleza. Quedaban restos de oro en los cabellos que clareaban y una sombra de color en la boca sensual. Los ojos hinchados conservaban algo de la pureza de su azul, las nobles curvas no habían desaparecido por completo de la cincelada nariz ni del cuello bien modelado. Sí, se trataba de Dorian. Pero, ¿quién lo había hecho? Le pareció reconocer sus propias pinceladas y, en cuanto al marco, también el diseño era suyo. La idea era monstruosa, pero, de todos modos, sintió miedo. Apoderándose de la vela encendida, se acercó al cuadro. Abajo, a la izquierda, halló su nombre, trazado con largas letras de brillante bermellón.
vi_translation: A horrifying scream burst from the artist's lips when he saw the grotesque face on the canvas grinning at him in the dim light. There was something about its expression that made him feel utterly disgusted and hateful. My God! It was the face of Dorian Gray himself, he was looking at the face of Dorian Gray himself! The horror had not yet completely ruined that extraordinary beauty. There was still some golden hue in the thinning hair and some pink on the sensual lips. The dull eyes still retained some charm in their blue, the noble curves had not entirely vanished from the sculpted nostrils and the chiseled throat. Yes, it was Dorian. But who had created it? He seemed to recognize his own brushwork, and the frame was his own design. The thought was bizarre, yet it frightened him. He grabbed the lit candle and brought it closer to the painting. In the lower left corner was his name, sketched in long, fresh red letters.
tr_translation: When the painter saw the hideous face grinning at him from the canvas in that dim light, a cry of horror escaped his lips. There was something in the expression of that face that filled him with disgust and dread. Good God! The thing in front of him was the face of Dorian Gray. The dreadful influence that had settled on the portrait –what could it be?– had not yet completely ruined that exquisite beauty. There was still a bit of golden shimmer in the thinning hair, and a bit of redness in that sensual mouth. Something of the old beautiful blue remained in the watery, drunken eyes, and the noble curve of the pencil-drawn nose and shapely neck had not yet entirely vanished. Yes, it was Dorian himself. But who had painted it? Hallward seemed to recognize his own brush strokes; the design of the frame was also his. It was impossible, yet the painter, seized by fear, took the candle and raised it towards the painting. In the bottom left corner, his own name was written in long, bright red letters.
es_translation: A cry of horror escaped the painter's lips upon seeing, in the dim light, the ghastly face that smiled at him from the canvas. There was something in its expression that immediately filled him with disgust and loathing. Good heavens! It was the face of Dorian Gray that he was seeing! The mysterious abomination had not yet completely destroyed its extraordinary beauty. There were still traces of gold in the lightening hair and a hint of color in the sensual mouth. The swollen eyes retained some of the purity of their blue, the noble curves had not entirely vanished from the chiseled nose nor from the well-shaped neck. Yes, it was Dorian. But who had done it? He seemed to recognize his own brushstrokes, and as for the frame, the design was also his. The idea was monstrous, but nonetheless, he felt afraid. Seizing the lit candle, he approached the painting. Below, on the left, he found his name, inscribed in long letters of bright vermilion.

en: It was some foul parody, some infamous ignoble satire. He had never done that. Still, it was his own picture. He knew it, and he felt as if his blood had changed in a moment from fire to sluggish ice. His own picture! What did it mean? Why had it altered? He turned and looked at Dorian Gray with the eyes of a sick man. His mouth twitched, and his parched tongue seemed unable to articulate. He passed his hand across his forehead. It was dank with clammy sweat.
vi: Nó là một bản nhái tồi tệ nào đó, một sự châm biếm bỉ ổi, ti tiện nào đó. Y chưa bao giờ làm ra cái thứ ấy. Mặc dù vậy, nó vẫn là tranh của y. Y biết nó, và y cảm thấy như thể máu y đã thay đổi trong một khoảnh khắc từ lửa thành nước đá lờ đờ. Tranh của chính y! Thế nghĩa là sao? Sao nó lại biến đổi? Y quay lại, nhìn Dorian Gray bằng cặp mắt người ốm. Miệng y giật giật, cái lưỡi khô rang dường như không thể phát âm rõ ràng. Y đưa tay qua ngang trán. Nó nhớp nháp mồ hôi ẩm lạnh.
tr: İğrenç bir taklit olsa gerekti bu, alçak, hain bir alay. Bu resmi yapan asla o değildi. Gene de resim onun yaptığı resimdi. Hallward onu tanımış ve sanki damarlarındaki kan bir anda ateş olmaktan çıkıp buza dönmüştü. Kendi resmi ha! Ne anlama geliyordu bu? Neden böyle değişime uğramıştı bu resim! Hallward döndü, ateşli bir hastanın gözleriyle Dorian’a baktı. Ağzı seğiriyor, kurumuş dili sanki dönüp konuşmayı beceremiyordu. Elini alnından geçirdi. Cildi terden ıslanmış, yapış yapış olmuştu.
es: Se trataba de una parodia repugnante, de una infame e innoble caricatura. Aquel lienzo no era obra suya. Y, sin embargo, era su retrato. No cabía la menor duda, y sintió como si, en un momento, la sangre que le corría por las venas hubiera pasado del fuego al hielo inerte. ¡Su cuadro! ¿Qué significaba aquello? ¿Por qué había cambiado? Volviéndose, miró a Dorian Gray con ojos de enfermo. La boca se le contrajo y la lengua, completamente seca, fue incapaz de articular el menor sonido. Se pasó la mano por la frente, recogiendo un sudor pegajoso.
vi_translation: It was some terrible imitation, a vile, despicable parody. He had never created such a thing. Yet, it was still his painting. He knew it, and he felt as if his blood had changed in an instant from fire to sluggish ice water. His very own painting! What did that mean? How had it transformed? He turned back, looking at Dorian Gray with the eyes of a sick man. His mouth twitched, his parched tongue seemed unable to articulate clearly. He passed his hand across his forehead. It was clammy with cold sweat.
tr_translation: This must have been a disgusting imitation, a vile, treacherous mockery. The person who made this painting was never him. Yet the painting was the one he had made. Hallward had recognized it, and it was as if the blood in his veins had suddenly turned from fire to ice. His own painting, huh! What did this mean? Why had this painting undergone such a transformation! Hallward turned and looked at Dorian with the eyes of a feverish patient. His mouth was twitching, his dry tongue seemed incapable of turning to speak. He ran his hand across his forehead. His skin was wet with sweat, sticky.
es_translation: It was a repugnant parody, an infamous and ignoble caricature. That canvas was not his work. And yet, it was his portrait. There was no doubt about it, and he felt as if, in a moment, the blood running through his veins had gone from fire to inert ice. His painting! What did it mean? Why had it changed? Turning around, he looked at Dorian Gray with sick eyes. His mouth contracted and his tongue, completely dry, was unable to articulate the slightest sound. He wiped his forehead with his hand, collecting a sticky sweat.

en: The young man was leaning against the mantelshelf, watching him with that strange expression that one sees on the faces of those who are absorbed in a play when some great artist is acting. There was neither real sorrow in it nor real joy. There was simply the passion of the spectator, with perhaps a flicker of triumph in his eyes. He had taken the flower out of his coat, and was smelling it, or pretending to do so.
vi: Người trẻ dựa vào cái giá trên lò sưởi, quan sát y với cái vẻ lạ lùng mà người ta vẫn thấy trên mặt những ai bị hút vào một vở kịch khi nghệ sỹ vĩ đại nào đó diễn. Không có nỗi buồn thật sự nào và cũng chẳng có niềm vui thật sự nào trên nó. Chỉ có sự say mê của một khán giả, với có lẽ là một tia sáng lung linh chiến thắng trong mắt. Cậu đã lấy bông hoa ra khỏi áo khoác của mình, và đang ngửi nó, hoặc giả bộ làm thế.
tr: Dorian Gray şöminenin çerçevesine dayanmış onu seyretmekteydi; yüzünde, büyük bir sanatçının sahnede çıkardığı oyunu seyredenlerin yüzünde görülen o tuhaf ifade vardı. Ne gerçek bir üzüntüydü bu ne de gerçek bir kıvanç. Yalnızca seyretmenin tutkusu, bir de belki gözlerinde bir zafer kıvılcımı. Dorian palto yakasındaki çiçeği çıkarmış kokluyor ya da koklar gibi yapıyordu.
es: Su joven amigo, apoyado contra la repisa de la chimenea, lo contemplaba con la extraña expresión que se descubre en quienes contemplan absortos una representación teatral cuando actúa algún gran intérprete. No era ni de verdadero dolor ni de verdadera alegría. Se trataba simplemente de la pasión del espectador, quizá con un pasajero resplandor de triunfo en los ojos. Dorian Gray se había quitado la flor que llevaba en el ojal, y la estaba oliendo o fingía olerla.
vi_translation: The young man leaned against the mantelpiece, observing him with the strange expression one often sees on the faces of those who are captivated by a play when some great artist performs. There was no real sorrow and no real joy on it. Only the fascination of a spectator, with perhaps a shimmering glint of triumph in his eyes. He had taken the flower out of his coat, and was smelling it, or pretending to do so.
tr_translation: Dorian Gray was leaning against the frame of the fireplace, watching him; on his face was that strange expression seen on the faces of those watching a great artist perform on stage. It was neither genuine sorrow nor genuine joy. Only the passion of watching, and perhaps a spark of triumph in his eyes. Dorian had removed the flower from his coat collar and was either smelling it or pretending to do so.
es_translation: His young friend, leaning against the mantelpiece, watched him with the strange expression one sees on those who are absorbed in a theatrical performance when a great actor is performing. It was neither of true sorrow nor of true joy. It was simply the passion of the spectator, perhaps with a fleeting glimmer of triumph in his eyes. Dorian Gray had removed the flower he wore in his buttonhole and was smelling it or pretending to smell it.

en: “What does this mean?” cried Hallward, at last. His own voice sounded shrill and curious in his ears.
vi: “Thế này nghĩa là sao?” rốt cuộc Hallward kêu to. Giọng y vang lên lanh lảnh lạ lùng trong tai y.
tr: En sonunda Hallward, “Ne demek oluyor bu?” diye hafifçe bağırdı. Kendi sesi kendi kulağına tiz, tuhaf geldi.
es: —¿Qué significa esto? —exclamó Hallward, finalmente. Su propia voz le resultó discordante y extraña.
vi_translation: “What does this mean?” Hallward finally exclaimed. His voice sounded strangely shrill in his own ears.
tr_translation: Finally, Hallward shouted softly, "What does this mean?" His own voice sounded shrill and strange to his ears.
es_translation: —What does this mean? —exclaimed Hallward, finally. His own voice sounded discordant and strange to him.

en: “Years ago, when I was a boy,” said Dorian Gray, crushing the flower in his hand, “you met me, flattered me, and taught me to be vain of my good looks. One day you introduced me to a friend of yours, who explained to me the wonder of youth, and you finished a portrait of me that revealed to me the wonder of beauty. In a mad moment that, even now, I don’t know whether I regret or not, I made a wish, perhaps you would call it a prayer....”
vi: “Nhiều năm về trước, khi tôi còn là một cậu bé,” Dorian Gray nói, vò nát bông hoa trong tay, “anh gặp tôi, tâng bốc tôi, dạy tôi tự đắc với sắc đẹp của mình. Một ngày nọ, anh giới thiệu tôi với một người bạn của anh, và anh ấy đã giảng giải cho tôi về sự kỳ diệu của tuổi xuân, còn anh đã hoàn thành bức chân dung về tôi, một bức tranh để lộ cho tôi thấy sự diệu kỳ của sắc đẹp. Trong một khoảnh khắc điên rồ, mà, thậm chí lúc này, tôi cũng không biết mình có ân hận hay không, tôi đã thốt lên một ước ao, có lẽ anh sẽ gọi nó là một lời cầu xin…”
tr: Dorian Gray çiçeği avucunda ezerek, “Yıllar önce, ben genç bir çocukken tanıştık,” dedi. “Sen beni pohpohladın, güzelliğimle gurur duymayı öğrettin bana. Günün birinde bir dostunla tanıştırdın; o bana gençliğin mucizesini açıkladı, senin yapıp bitirdiğin portre de güzelliğin mucizesini serdi gözlerimin önüne. Bir çılgınlık dakikasında... Gerçi şimdi bile buna pişman olup olmadığımı bilemiyorum ya... Bir dilekte bulundum, belki bir yakarı da diyebilirsin buna...
es: —Hace años, cuando no era más que un adolescente —dijo Dorian Gray, aplastando la flor con la mano—, me conociste, me halagaste la vanidad y me enseñaste a sentirme orgulloso de mi belleza. Un día me presentaste a uno de tus amigos, que me explicó la maravilla de la juventud, mientras tú terminabas el retrato que me reveló el milagro de la belleza. En un momento de locura del que, incluso ahora, ignoro aún si lamento o no, formulé un deseo, aunque quizá tú lo llamaras una plegaria...
vi_translation: “Many years ago, when I was just a boy,” Dorian Gray said, crushing the flower in his hand, “you met me, flattered me, taught me to be proud of my beauty. One day, you introduced me to a friend of yours, and he explained to me the wonders of youth, while you completed the portrait of me, a painting that revealed to me the marvel of beauty. In a moment of madness, which, even now, I do not know if I regret, I uttered a wish, perhaps you would call it a prayer…”
tr_translation: Dorian Gray, crushing the flower in his hand, said, "Years ago, when I was a young boy, we met." "You flattered me, taught me to take pride in my beauty. One day, you introduced me to a friend; he explained the miracle of youth to me, and the portrait you had completed revealed the miracle of beauty before my eyes. In a moment of madness... Though even now, I don't know if I regret it... I made a wish, or perhaps you could call it a plea..."
es_translation: —Years ago, when I was nothing more than a teenager —said Dorian Gray, crushing the flower with his hand—, you met me, flattered my vanity, and taught me to take pride in my beauty. One day you introduced me to one of your friends, who explained the wonder of youth to me, while you finished the portrait that revealed to me the miracle of beauty. In a moment of madness, of which even now I still do not know if I regret or not, I made a wish, although perhaps you would call it a prayer...

en: “I remember it! Oh, how well I remember it! No! the thing is impossible. The room is damp. Mildew has got into the canvas. The paints I used had some wretched mineral poison in them. I tell you the thing is impossible.”
vi: “Tôi nhớ ra nó rồi! Ôi, tôi nhớ nó mới rõ làm sao! Không! Việc này không thể xảy ra. Căn phòng ẩm thấp. Nấm mốc lan tràn trên toan. Những thứ sơn tôi dùng có khoáng chất độc hại nào đó trong chúng. Tôi khẳng định với cậu rằng chuyện này là không thể xảy ra.”
tr: “Anımsıyorum! Hem de öylesine açık seçik anımsıyorum ki! Ama yok, olacak şey değil bu. Oda rutubetli, tuvali mantar bürümüş olmalı. Kullandığım boyalarda lanet olası bir mineral zehri mi vardı yoksa! Olmayacak şey, diyorum sana.
es: —¡Lo recuerdo! ¡Sí, lo recuerdo perfectamente! ¡No! Eso es imposible. Esta habitación está llena de humedad. El moho ha atacado el lienzo. Los colores que utilicé contenían algún desafortunado veneno mineral. Te aseguro que es imposible.
vi_translation: "I remember it now!" "Oh, I remember it so clearly! No! This cannot happen." "The room is damp." "Mold is spreading on the canvas." "The paints I used had some harmful minerals in them." "I assure you that this cannot happen."
tr_translation: “I remember! I remember so clearly! But no, this can't be happening. The room must be damp, the canvas covered in mold. Was there some damn mineral poison in the paints I used! It's impossible, I'm telling you.”
es_translation: —I remember! Yes, I remember it perfectly! No! That is impossible. This room is full of humidity. The mold has attacked the canvas. The colors I used contained some unfortunate mineral poison. I assure you it is impossible. —What is impossible?

en: “Ah, what is impossible?” murmured the young man, going over to the window and leaning his forehead against the cold, mist-stained glass.
vi: “Chà, cái gì không thể xảy ra?” người trẻ lẩm bẩm, lại gần cửa sổ, tựa trán lên kính lạnh nhuộm sương.
tr: Dorian, “Olmayacak şey var mı?” diye mırıldanarak pencereye yürüdü, alnını sisten puslanmış cama yasladı.
es: —¿Qué es imposible? —murmuró Dorian, acercándose al balcón y apoyando la frente contra el frío cristal empañado por la niebla.
vi_translation: “Well, what can't happen?” the young person muttered, approaching the window and resting their forehead on the cold, mist-covered glass.
tr_translation: Dorian murmured, "Is there anything that won't happen?" as he walked to the window and pressed his forehead against the fogged-up glass.
es_translation: —murmured Dorian, approaching the balcony and resting his forehead against the cold glass fogged by the mist.

en: “You told me you had destroyed it.”
vi: “Cậu bảo tôi là cậu đã phá hủy nó.
tr: “Hani resmi ortadan kaldırdığını söylemiştin.
es: —Me dijiste que lo habías destruido.
vi_translation: “You told me that you had destroyed it.”
tr_translation: “You said you had removed the picture.”
es_translation: —You told me that you had destroyed it.

en: “I was wrong. It has destroyed me.”
vi: “Tôi đã sai. Nó phá hủy tôi.”
tr: “Yalan söylemişim. O beni mahvetti.
es: —Estaba equivocado. El retrato me ha destruido a mí.
vi_translation: “I was wrong. It destroyed me.”
tr_translation: “I lied. It destroyed me.”
es_translation: —I was wrong. The portrait has destroyed me.

en: “I don’t believe it is my picture.”
vi: “Tôi không tin nó là tranh của tôi.”
tr: “Bu benim yaptığım resim ha... İnanmıyorum.
es: —No creo que sea mi cuadro.
vi_translation: “I don't believe it is my painting.”
tr_translation: “This is the painting I made, huh... I can't believe it.”
es_translation: —I don't think it's my painting.

en: “Can’t you see your ideal in it?” said Dorian bitterly.
vi: “Anh không thấy lý tưởng của anh trong nó à?” Dorian nói, cay đắng.
tr: “İdealini göremiyor musun resimde?” Dorian acı acı sordu.
es: —¿No descubres en él a tu ideal? —preguntó Dorian con amargura.
vi_translation: “Don’t you see your ideal in it?” Dorian said, bitterly.
tr_translation: "Can't you see your ideal in the painting?" Dorian asked bitterly.
es_translation: —Don't you see your ideal in him? —asked Dorian bitterly.

en: “My ideal, as you call it...”
vi: “Lý tưởng của tôi, như anh gọi nó…”
tr: “İdealim, dediğin gibi...
es: —Mi ideal, como tú lo llamas...
vi_translation: “My ideal, as you call it…”
tr_translation: “My ideal, as you said...”
es_translation: —My ideal, as you call it...

en: “As you called it.”
vi: “Như anh gọi nó chứ.”
tr: “Benim değil, senin dediğin gibi.
es: —Como tú lo llamaste.
vi_translation: “As you call it.”
tr_translation: “Not as I say, but as you say.”
es_translation: —As you called it.

en: “There was nothing evil in it, nothing shameful. You were to me such an ideal as I shall never meet again. This is the face of a satyr.”
vi: “Chẳng có gì xấu xa trong nó cả, chẳng có gì nhục nhã. Với tôi, cậu cũng như một lý tưởng mà tôi sẽ chẳng bao giờ còn gặp lại được nữa. Còn cái này là bộ mặt của thần dâm.”
tr: “Hiçbir kötülük, hiçbir günah karışmamıştı ona, utanılacak hiçbir yönü yoktu. Sen benim gözümde öylesine bir idealdin ki bir daha asla bulamayacağım. Oysa bu bir iblisin yüzü.
es: —No había maldad en él, no tenía nada de qué avergonzarse. Fuiste para mí el ideal que nunca volveré a encontrar. Y ése es el rostro de un sátiro.
vi_translation: “There is nothing evil in it, nothing shameful. To me, you are like an ideal that I will never encounter again. And this is the face of the god of lust.”
tr_translation: “No evil, no sin had touched her, there was nothing to be ashamed of. You were such an ideal in my eyes that I will never find again. Yet this is the face of a demon.”
es_translation: —There was no malice in him, he had nothing to be ashamed of. You were for me the ideal that I will never find again. And that is the face of a satyr.

en: “It is the face of my soul.”
vi: “Đó là bộ mặt của linh hồn tôi.”
tr: “Benim ruhumun yüzü bu.
es: —Es el rostro de mi alma.
vi_translation: “That is the face of my soul.”
tr_translation: “This is the face of my soul.”
es_translation: —It is the face of my soul.

en: “Christ! what a thing I must have worshipped! It has the eyes of a devil.”
vi: “Lạy Chúa! Thế mà tôi cứ tôn sùng một thứ thế này sao! Nó có cặp mắt của một con quỷ.”
tr: “Ulu Tanrım! Ben böyle bir şeye tapınmışım ha! Bunun gözleri şeytan gözü.
es: —¡Cielo santo! ¡Qué criatura elegí para adorar! Tiene los ojos de un demonio.
vi_translation: "Oh God! And to think I have been venerating something like this!" "It has the eyes of a demon."
tr_translation: "Oh Great God! Have I worshipped something like this! Its eyes are the eyes of the devil."
es_translation: —Heavens above! What a creature I chose to adore! It has the eyes of a demon.

en: “Each of us has heaven and hell in him, Basil,” cried Dorian with a wild gesture of despair.
vi: “Mỗi chúng ta đều có Thiên đường và Địa ngục trong mình, Basil,” Dorian kêu lên, với một cử chỉ thất vọng rồ dại.
tr: Dorian ellerini çılgın bir umarsızlıkla açarak, “Her birimiz Cennet’i de Cehennem’i de içimizde taşıyoruz, Basil,” dedi.
es: —Todos llevamos dentro el cielo y el infierno, Basil —exclamó Dorian con un desmedido gesto de desesperación.
vi_translation: "Each of us has Heaven and Hell within us, Basil," Dorian exclaimed, with a gesture of wild despair.
tr_translation: Opening his arms with wild abandon, Dorian said, "Each of us carries both Heaven and Hell within us, Basil."
es_translation: —We all carry heaven and hell within us, Basil —exclaimed Dorian with an excessive gesture of despair.

en: Hallward turned again to the portrait and gazed at it. “My God! If it is true,” he exclaimed, “and this is what you have done with your life, why, you must be worse even than those who talk against you fancy you to be!” He held the light up again to the canvas and examined it. The surface seemed to be quite undisturbed and as he had left it. It was from within, apparently, that the foulness and horror had come. Through some strange quickening of inner life the leprosies of sin were slowly eating the thing away. The rotting of a corpse in a watery grave was not so fearful.
vi: Hallward lại quay về phía bức chân dung, và nhìn chằm chằm vào nó. “Chúa ơi! Nếu nó là thật,” y la lên, “và đây là thứ cậu đã làm với đời mình, tại sao, thì cậu chắc hẳn là còn tệ hơn cả những gì mà bọn người xì xào về cậu vẫn nghĩ là cậu đã trở thành!” Y lại cầm nến đến gần tấm toan và xem xét nó. Mặt ngoài dường như hoàn toàn không bị suy suyển, giống hệt như y đã để lại. Hình như tình trạng kinh tởm ghê rợn ấy đến từ bên trong. Qua sự thúc đẩy lạ lùng nào đó của cuộc sống bên trong mà bệnh hủi tội lỗi đã ăn dần thứ này. Sự thối rữa của xác chết trong nấm mộ ngập nước cũng không đáng sợ như vậy.
tr: Hallward gene portreye doğru dönerek gözlerini dikip baktı. “Ulu Tanrım, eğer dediklerin doğruysa, sen hayatını bu biçimde yaşamışsan... Seni kötüleyenlerin sandığından da betersin demektir!” Işığı gene kaldırarak portreyi inceledi. Tuvalin yüzeyi kendi bıraktığı gibi duruyordu, ellenmemişti. İğrençlik, korkunçluk, içten dışa vurmuştu sanki. İçten içe depreşen bir tuhaf yaşamla günahın cüzam yaraları, resimdeki yüzü yavaş yavaş kemirmekteydi. Bir cesedin rutubetli bir mezar çukurunda çürüyüp gitmesi bile böylesine tüyler ürpertici olamazdı.
es: Hallward se volvió de nuevo hacia el retrato y lo contempló fijamente. —¡Dios mío! Si es cierto —exclamó—, y esto es lo que has hecho con tu vida, ¡eres todavía peor de lo que imaginan quienes te atacan! —acercó de nuevo la vela al lienzo para examinarlo. La superficie parecía seguir exactamente como él la dejara. La corrupción y el horror surgían, al parecer, de las entrañas del cuadro. La vida interior del retratado se manifestaba misteriosamente, y la lepra del pecado devoraba lentamente el cuadro. La descomposición de un cadáver en un sepulcro lleno de humedades no sería un espectáculo tan espantoso.
vi_translation: Hallward turned back to the portrait and stared at it. "Good God! If it is true," he cried, "and this is what you have done with your life, why, then you must be worse than what people whisper about you!" He took the candle closer to the canvas and examined it. The surface seemed completely unchanged, exactly as he had left it. It seemed that the hideous horror came from within. Through some strange inner life force, the leprosy of sin had slowly eaten away at this thing. The decay of a corpse in a watery grave was not as dreadful as this.
tr_translation: Hallward turned towards the portrait and stared at it. "Good God, if what you say is true, if you have lived your life in this way... You are worse than what your detractors think!" He raised the light again and examined the portrait. The surface of the canvas was as he had left it, untouched. It was as if the hideousness, the horror, had been revealed from within. With a strange life festering from within, the leprous sores of sin were slowly gnawing at the face in the picture. Even the decay of a corpse in a damp grave could not be so horrifying.
es_translation: Hallward turned again towards the portrait and stared at it intently. —My God! If it's true —he exclaimed—, and this is what you've done with your life, you are even worse than those who attack you imagine! —he brought the candle closer to the canvas again to examine it. The surface seemed to remain exactly as he had left it. The corruption and horror appeared to emerge from the depths of the painting. The inner life of the portrayed person manifested mysteriously, and the leprosy of sin slowly devoured the painting. The decomposition of a corpse in a damp grave would not be such a dreadful sight.

en: His hand shook, and the candle fell from its socket on the floor and lay there sputtering. He placed his foot on it and put it out. Then he flung himself into the rickety chair that was standing by the table and buried his face in his hands.
vi: Tay y run, cây nến rơi từ đế xuống sàn, nằm đó kêu xèo xèo. Y đặt chân lên nó và dập tắt nó. Sau đó y buông mình xuống cái ghế lung lay để bên bàn và vùi mặt vào tay.
tr: Hallward’ın elleri titremeye başlamıştı; şamdandaki mum yere düştü ve orada cızırdamaya başladı. Ressam ayağıyla basıp mumu söndürdü. Sonra masa başında duran dingildeyen sandalyeye kendini bırakarak yüzünü ellerine gömdü.
es: Le tembló la mano; la vela cayó de la palmatoria al suelo y empezó a chisporrotear. Hallward la apagó con el pie. Luego se dejó caer en la desvencijada silla cercana a la mesa y escondió el rostro entre las manos.
vi_translation: With a swift motion, the candle fell from its holder to the floor, lying there with a sizzle. He stepped on it and extinguished it. Then he let himself fall into the wobbly chair next to the table and buried his face in his hands.
tr_translation: Hallward's hands began to tremble; the candle on the candelabrum fell to the ground and started to sizzle there. The painter stepped on the candle with his foot and extinguished it. Then, dropping himself into the wobbling chair by the table, he buried his face in his hands.
es_translation: His hand trembled; the candle fell from the candlestick to the floor and began to sputter. Hallward extinguished it with his foot. Then he let himself fall into the rickety chair near the table and hid his face in his hands.

en: “Good God, Dorian, what a lesson! What an awful lesson!” There was no answer, but he could hear the young man sobbing at the window. “Pray, Dorian, pray,” he murmured. “What is it that one was taught to say in one’s boyhood? ‘Lead us not into temptation. Forgive us our sins. Wash away our iniquities.’ Let us say that together. The prayer of your pride has been answered. The prayer of your repentance will be answered also. I worshipped you too much. I am punished for it. You worshipped yourself too much. We are both punished.”
vi: “Chúa lòng lành, Dorian, một bài học ghê thật! một bài học khủng khiếp!” Không có tiếng trả lời, nhưng y có thể nghe thấy người trẻ đang thổn thức bên cửa sổ. “Cầu nguyện đi, Dorian, cầu nguyện đi,” y lẩm bẩm. “Câu gì mà ta được dạy nói hồi còn bé ấy nhỉ ‘Xin đừng dẫn chúng con đến sự cám dỗ. Xin tha thứ cho tội lỗi của chúng con. Xin gột rửa các thói tật của chúng con.’ Ta hãy nói thế cùng nhau. Lời nguyện cầu tự trọng của cậu sẽ được đáp lại. Lời nguyện cầu ăn năn của cậu cũng sẽ được đáp lại. Tôi tôn thờ cậu quá nhiều. Tôi bị trừng phạt vì điều ấy. Cậu cũng tôn thờ chính mình quá nhiều. Cả hai ta đều bị trừng phạt.”
tr: “Aman Tanrım, Dorian, nasıl bir ders bu! Ne müthiş bir ders! Yanıt çıkmadı ama ressam Dorian’ın pencere başında hıçkırdığını duyabiliyordu. “Dua et, Dorian, dua et,” diye mırıldandı. “Hani çocukluğumuzda öğrettikleri bir dua vardı; nasıldı o? Bizi yanlış yollara saptırma. Günahlarımızı bağışla. Kötülüklerimizin kirini yuğ, temizle. Gel, birlikte okuyalım şunu. Kibrinin yakarışı karşılığını bulmuş. Pişmanlığının yakarışı da karşılık görecektir. Seni fazla göklere çıkartmıştım ben. Şimdi bunun cezasını görüyorum. Sen de kendini fazla göklere çıkardın. İkimiz de cezalandırılıyoruz.
es: —¡Cielo santo, Dorian, qué lección! ¡Qué terrible lección! —no recibió respuesta, pero oía sollozara su amigo junto a la ventana—. Reza, Dorian, reza —murmuró—. ¿Qué era lo que nos enseñaban a decir cuando éramos niños? «No nos dejes caer en la tentación. Perdona nuestros pecados. Borra nuestras iniquidades.» Vamos a repetirlo juntos. La plegaria de tu orgullo encontró respuesta. La plegaria de tu arrepentimiento también será escuchada. Te admiré en exceso. Ambos hemos sido castigados.
vi_translation: "Good Lord, Dorian, what a dreadful lesson! What a terrible lesson!" There was no answer, but he could hear the young man sobbing by the window. "Pray, Dorian, pray," he murmured. "What was that phrase we were taught to say as children? 'Lead us not into temptation. Forgive us our sins. Cleanse us of our vices.' Let us say it together. Your prayer of self-respect will be answered. Your prayer of repentance will also be answered. I worshipped you too much. I am punished for that. You also worshipped yourself too much. We are both punished."
tr_translation: “My God, Dorian, what a lesson this is! What a tremendous lesson!” There was no response, but the painter could hear Dorian sobbing by the window. “Pray, Dorian, pray,” he murmured. “There was a prayer they taught us in our childhood; how did it go? Lead us not into temptation. Forgive us our sins. Wash away the stain of our wickedness. Come, let’s recite it together. Your plea of pride has been answered. Your plea of remorse will also be answered. I had exalted you too much. Now I am seeing the punishment for it. You also exalted yourself too much. We are both being punished.”
es_translation: —Good heavens, Dorian, what a lesson! What a terrible lesson! —he received no response, but he heard his friend sobbing by the window—. Pray, Dorian, pray —he murmured—. What was it that they taught us to say when we were children? “Lead us not into temptation. Forgive us our sins. Blot out our iniquities.” Let's repeat it together. Your prayer of pride was answered. Your prayer of repentance will also be heard. I admired you too much. We have both been punished.

en: Dorian Gray turned slowly around and looked at him with tear-dimmed eyes. “It is too late, Basil,” he faltered.
vi: Dorian Gray chầm chậm quay lại, nhìn y với đôi mắt nhòa lệ. “Quá muộn rồi, Basil,” cậu ấp úng.
