Dorian looked at his own long-fingered, snow-white hands and involuntarily shuddered slightly as he turned the page. A little later, he found those beautiful quatrains written about Venice:
es_translation: After lying down on the sofa, he looked at the title of the book. It was Émaux et Camées[14], the Charpentier edition on Japan paper, with an engraving by Jacquemart[15]. The binding was of lime green leather, with a gold lattice, sprinkled with pomegranates. It had been given to him by Adrian Singleton. As he turned the pages, his eyes stopped at a poem about Lacenaire's[16] hand, the icy yellowish hand «du supplice encore mal lavée», with its red hair and its «doigts de faune». Dorian Gray looked at his own fingers, white as wax, shuddered involuntarily, and moved on until he reached the splendid stanzas dedicated to Venice:

en: Sort de l’eau son corps rose et blanc.
vi: Sort de l'eau son corps rose et blanc.
tr: Pembe beyaz bedeniyle çıkar sulardan.
es: Sort de feau son corps rose et blanc.
vi_translation: Her pink and white body emerges from the water.
tr_translation: She emerges from the waters with her pink and white body.
es_translation: Emerges from the water, her body pink and white.

en: Les dômes, sur l’azur des ondes
vi: "Les dômes, sur l'azur des ondes
tr: Kubbeler suların mavisinde yansır,
es: Les dómes, sur I'azur des ondes
vi_translation: "The domes, on the azure of the waves
tr_translation: The domes reflect in the blue of the waters,
es_translation: The domes, on the azure of the waves

en: L’esquif aborde et me dépose,
vi: "L'esquif aborde et me dépose,
tr: Sahile bıraktı beni kayık,
es: L'esquif aborde et me dépose
vi_translation: "The skiff lands and drops me off,
tr_translation: The boat left me on the shore,
es_translation: The skiff approaches and drops me off

en: How exquisite they were! As one read them, one seemed to be floating down the green water-ways of the pink and pearl city, seated in a black gondola with silver prow and trailing curtains. The mere lines looked to him like those straight lines of turquoise-blue that follow one as one pushes out to the Lido. The sudden flashes of colour reminded him of the gleam of the opal-and-iris-throated birds that flutter round the tall honeycombed Campanile, or stalk, with such stately grace, through the dim, dust-stained arcades. Leaning back with half-closed eyes, he kept saying over and over to himself:
vi: Sao mà chúng tuyệt vời làm vậy! Lúc ta đọc chúng, ta dường như trôi theo các con kênh xanh lục của một thành phố hồng trân châu, ngồi trong chiếc xuồng đen với mũi bạc và mành quét lê. Chỉ các dòng thơ thôi mà với cậu trông đã giống như những vạch thẳng ngọc lam bám theo ta khi ta phóng về Lido. Các chớp màu bất chợt thì nhắc cậu nhớ về ánh lập lòe của những con chim cổ-họng- ngọc-mắt-mèo-và-ngũ-sắc vẫy cánh quanh cái Tháp chuông cao vút lủng lỗ như tổ ong, hoặc chao lượn, với vẻ duyên dáng cực kỳ oai nghiêm, qua các vòm cuốn tối mò, lầm bụi. Ngả ra sau, nhắm hờ đôi mắt, cậu cứ nói mãi nói mãi với mình:
tr: Nasıl da nefisti bu dizeler! İnsan bu satırları okurken o pembeli sedefli kentin yeşil sudan yollarında, perdeleri uçuşmuş, burnu gümüşten bir siyah gondol içinde kayıp geçer gibi oluyordu. Salt bu satırların biçimi bile Dorian’a, Lido’ya giderken izlenen o firuze mavisi, düz çizgileri çağrıştırıyordu. Birden çakan renkler ona yüksek, petekli Campanile çevresinde kanat çırpan, tozlu loş kemerlerin altında ağırbaşlı bir uyumla yürüyen o yanardöner mor boyunlu kuşları anımsatıyordu. Dorian gözlerini yarı yumup arkasına yaslanarak kendi kendine, Mermer basamaklarında
es: ¡Qué versos exquisitos! Al leerlos se tenía la impresión de estar flotando por los verdes canales de la ciudad de color rosa y gris perla, sentado en una góndola negra con la proa de plata y unos cendales arrastrados por la brisa. Los versos mismos le parecían las rectas estelas azul turquesa que siguen al visitante cuando navega hacia el Lido. Los repentinos estallidos de color le recordaban los destellos de las palomas —la garganta de color ópalo e iris— que revolotean en torno al esbelto campanile acolmenado, o que pasean, con tranquila elegancia, entre los polvorientos arcos en penumbra. Recostándose, con los ojos semicerrados, Dorian repitió una y otra vez los versos:
vi_translation: How wonderful they are! When I read them, I seem to drift along the green canals of a pink pearl city, sitting in a black boat with a silver prow and a trailing canopy. Just the lines of poetry alone, to you, seem like turquoise streaks following me as I speed towards Lido. The sudden flashes of color remind you of the flickering light of the cat-eyed, emerald-throated, and multi-colored birds fluttering around the towering, honeycomb-like Bell Tower, or gracefully soaring, with an air of majestic elegance, through the dark, dusty arches. Leaning back, eyes half-closed, you keep talking to yourself endlessly:
tr_translation: How exquisite were these verses! While reading these lines, one felt as if they were gliding through the green water roads of that pink and pearly city in a black gondola with silver prow and fluttering curtains. The mere form of these lines evoked for Dorian the turquoise blue, straight lines followed when going to Lido. The sudden flashes of color reminded him of those iridescent purple-necked birds flapping around the high, honeycombed Campanile and walking with dignified harmony under the dusty, dim arches. Dorian half-closed his eyes and leaned back, saying to himself, On the marble steps
es_translation: What exquisite verses! Reading them gave the impression of floating through the green canals of the city of pink and pearl gray, sitting in a black gondola with a silver prow and some veils dragged by the breeze. The verses themselves seemed like the straight turquoise blue wakes that follow the visitor when sailing towards the Lido. The sudden bursts of color reminded him of the flashes of the pigeons —the opal and iris-colored throats— that flutter around the slender beehive-shaped campanile, or that stroll, with quiet elegance, among the dusty arches in the shadows. Leaning back, with his eyes half-closed, Dorian repeated the verses over and over again:

en: Sur le marbre d’un escalier.”
vi: Sur le marbre d'un escalier."
tr: dizelerini yineleyip durmaya başladı.
es: Sur le marbre d'un escalier».
vi_translation: On the marble of a staircase."
tr_translation: He started repeating the lines over and over again.
es_translation: On the marble of a staircase.

en: The whole of Venice was in those two lines. He remembered the autumn that he had passed there, and a wonderful love that had stirred him to mad delightful follies. There was romance in every place. But Venice, like Oxford, had kept the background for romance, and, to the true romantic, background was everything, or almost everything. Basil had been with him part of the time, and had gone wild over Tintoret. Poor Basil! What a horrible way for a man to die!
vi: Toàn bộ Venice trong hai dòng thơ này. Cậu nhớ mùa thu mà cậu đã qua ở đây, và một mối tình kỳ diệu đã kích động cậu làm những việc điên rồ, thú vị. Chất lãng mạn có ở mọi nơi. Song Venice, cũng như Oxford, giữ được hậu cảnh cho sự lãng mạn, và, với sự lãng mạn đích thực, hậu cảnh là tất cả, hoặc gần như là tất cả. Basil đã ở bên cậu một phần thời gian ấy, đã rất phấn khích với Tintoret. Tội nghiệp Basil! chết mới thảm làm sao!
tr: Venedik’in tümü bu iki satırdaydı. Dorian orada geçirdiği güz mevsimini, onu şahane çılgınlıklara kışkırtan o harikulade aşkı anımsadı. Her yer romantizm doluydu. Venedik, tıpkı Oxford gibi, romantizme uygun dekorunu saklayabilmişti ki gerçek romantikler için de dekor her şey demekti ya da hemen her şey. Basil de bir süre onunla kalmış, Tintoretto için deli divane olmuştu. Zavallı Basil! Ne feci bir ölüme kurban gitmişti.
es: Toda Venecia estaba contenida allí. Recordó el otoño que había pasado en la ciudad, y el maravilloso amor que le empujó a desenfrenadas y deliciosas locuras. Había poesía por doquier. Porque Venecia, como Oxford, conservaba el adecuado ambiente poético y, para el verdadero romántico, el ambiente lo era todo, o casi todo. Basil pasó con él algún tiempo durante aquella estancia, y se había entusiasmado con Tintoreto. ¡Pobre Basil! ¡Qué muerte tan horrible la suya!
vi_translation: All of Venice in these two lines of poetry. You remember the autumn you spent here, and a wonderful romance that inspired you to do crazy, delightful things. Romance is everywhere. But Venice, like Oxford, provides the backdrop for romance, and with true romance, the backdrop is everything, or nearly everything. Basil was with you for part of that time, very excited about Tintoret. Poor Basil! What a tragic death!
tr_translation: All of Venice was in these two lines. Dorian remembered the autumn season he spent there, that marvelous love that incited him to magnificent follies. Everywhere was filled with romance. Venice, like Oxford, had managed to preserve its romantic decor, which meant everything, or almost everything, to true romantics. Basil had also stayed with him for a while, becoming madly infatuated with Tintoretto. Poor Basil! What a terrible death he had met.
es_translation: All of Venice was contained there. He remembered the autumn he had spent in the city, and the wonderful love that drove him to wild and delightful madness. There was poetry everywhere. Because Venice, like Oxford, preserved the proper poetic atmosphere and, for the true romantic, the atmosphere was everything, or almost everything. Basil spent some time with him during that stay, and he had become enthusiastic about Tintoretto. Poor Basil! What a horrible death he had!

en: He sighed, and took up the volume again, and tried to forget. He read of the swallows that fly in and out of the little café at Smyrna where the Hadjis sit counting their amber beads and the turbaned merchants smoke their long tasselled pipes and talk gravely to each other; he read of the Obelisk in the Place de la Concorde that weeps tears of granite in its lonely sunless exile and longs to be back by the hot, lotus-covered Nile, where there are Sphinxes, and rose-red ibises, and white vultures with gilded claws, and crocodiles with small beryl eyes that crawl over the green steaming mud; he began to brood over those verses which, drawing music from kiss-stained marble, tell of that curious statue that Gautier compares to a contralto voice, the “monstre charmant” that couches in the porphyry-room of the Louvre. But after a time the book fell from his hand. He grew nervous, and a horrible fit of terror came over him. What if Alan Campbell should be out of England? Days would elapse before he could come back. Perhaps he might refuse to come. What could he do then? Every moment was of vital importance.
vi: Cậu thở dài, lại cầm sách lên, và cố quên. Cậu đọc về những con én bay vào bay ra tiệm cà phê nhỏ ở Smyrna nơi các Ha-gi1 ngồi đếm tràng hạt hổ phách còn các lái buôn vấn khăn hút những cái tẩu dài có núm tua và trang nghiêm trò chuyện cùng nhau; cậu đọc về cây cột Obelisk ở quảng trường Concorde, rỉ những giọt lệ hoa cương trong cảnh tha hương cô độc âm u, ước ao được về lại chốn xưa theo dòng sông Nile nóng nực phủ kín hoa sen, nơi có các tượng Sphinx, có lũ cò quăm đỏ hồng, có bọn kền kền trắng với vuốt mạ vàng, và những con cá sấu, với những con mắt be-rin nhỏ tí, bò qua bùn xanh lục bốc hơi; cậu bắt đầu nghiền ngẫm các câu thơ mà, kéo nhạc ra khỏi cẩm thạch in dấu nụ hôn, kể về bức tượng kỳ lạ đã được Gautier so sánh với một giọng nữ trầm, “monstre charmant” vẫn nằm trong phòng póc-fia ở Louvre. Nhưng một lúc sau, cuốn sách rơi khỏi tay cậu. Cậu trở nên bồn chồn, một cơn sợ hãi khủng khiếp ập đến với cậu. Sẽ ra sao nếu Alan Campbell đã rời khỏi Anh? Nhiều ngày sẽ trôi qua cho đến khi y có thể quay trở về. Không chừng y có thể từ chối đến. Thế thì cậu biết làm gì? Mỗi khoảnh khắc đều quan trọng sống còn.
tr: Dorian göğüs geçirerek kitabı gene eline aldı, her şeyi unutmaya çalıştı. İzmir’deki küçük kahveyi anlatan satırları okudu: pencerelerden girip çıkan kırlangıçları, oturmuş kehribar tespihlerini çeken hacıları, o uzun, püsküllü çubuklarını tüttürerek birbirleriyle ağırbaşlı konuşmalar yürüten sarıklı tüccarları. Paris’teki Place de la Concord’un dikilitaşını anlatan şiiri okudu: O güneşsiz sürgününde yapayalnız, granitten gözyaşları döken ve su nilüferleriyle kaplı sıcak Nil kıyılarında, sfenkslerin, gül kırmızısı ibislerin, yaldız pençeli beyaz atmacaların arasında, ufak yeşim gözlü timsahların dumanı tüten çamurlar arasında süründükleri yerlerde olmaya can atan dikilitaş... Gautier’nin davudi bir sese benzettiği o tuhaf yontuyu, Louvre’un porfir odasında çömelmiş pusuda bekleyen monstre charmant’ı anlatan ve dudak izleriyle kaplı mermerden şiir damıtan dizeler Dorian’ın zihnini sarmıştı. Ne var ki bir süre sonra kitap elinden düştü. İçi ürküntüyle doldu, sonra müthiş bir korkuya kapıldı. Ya Alan Campbell ülke dışındaysa? O dönünceye kadar aradan günler geçerdi. Belki de Dorian’a gelmeyi reddederdi. O zaman Dorian ne yapardı? Her geçen dakika yaşamsal bir önem taşıyordu.
es: Dorian Gray suspiró, abrió de nuevo el libro de Gautier, y se esforzó por olvidar. Leyó los versos dedicados al pequeño café de Esmirna donde los hayis pasan sus cuentas de ámbar, y los mercaderes enturbantados fuman sus largas pipas adornadas con borlas, al tiempo que conversan sobre temas profundos mientras las golondrinas entran y salen haciendo rápidos quiebros; leyó sobre el obelisco de la Place de la Concorde que llora lágrimas de granito en su solitario exilio sin sol y anhela volver al ardiente Nilo cubierto de flores de loto, donde hay esfinges e ibis rosados y buitres blancos de garras doradas y cocodrilos con ojillos de berilo que se arrastran por el humeante cieno verde; y empezó a soñar con las estrofas que, extrayendo música del mármol manchado de besos, hablan de la curiosa estatua que Gautier compara con una voz de contralto, el «monstre charmant» tumbado en el Louvre en la sala de los pórfidos. Pero al cabo de algún tiempo el libro se le cayó de las manos. Le fue dominando el nerviosismo, que culminó con un tremendo ataque de terror. ¿Qué sucedería si Alan Campbell no estaba en Inglaterra? Tendrían que pasar días y días antes de que regresara. Quizás se negara a volver. ¿Qué hacer entonces? Cada minuto contaba; era de importancia vital.
vi_translation: He sighed, picked up the book again, and tried to forget. He read about the swallows flying in and out of a small café in Smyrna where the Hadjis sat counting amber beads while the turbaned merchants smoked long tasseled pipes and solemnly conversed with each other; he read about the Obelisk in the Place de la Concorde, weeping granite tears in its gloomy, lonely exile, longing to return to the hot Nile covered with lotus flowers, where there were Sphinx statues, red-pink ibises, white vultures with gilded claws, and crocodiles, with tiny berin eyes, crawling through the green steaming mud; he began to ponder the verses that, drawing music from the marble kissed by a kiss, spoke of the strange statue that Gautier had compared to a contralto voice, “monstre charmant” still lying in the porphyry room at the Louvre. But after a while, the book fell from his hands. He became restless, a terrible fear overwhelmed him. What if Alan Campbell had left England? Many days would pass before he could return. He might even refuse to come. Then what would he do? Every moment was of critical importance.
tr_translation: Dorian sighed deeply and picked up the book again, trying to forget everything. He read the lines describing the small café in Izmir: the swallows flitting in and out of the windows, the pilgrims sitting and pulling their amber rosaries, the turbaned merchants having solemn conversations while puffing on their long, tasseled pipes. He read the poem describing the obelisk at Place de la Concorde in Paris: In its sunless exile, utterly alone, shedding granite tears and longing to be on the warm banks of the Nile covered with water lilies, among the sphinxes, rose-red ibises, white hawks with gilded talons, and the small jade-eyed crocodiles crawling through the steaming mud. The verses describing that strange sculpture, which Gautier likened to a deep, resonant voice, the monstre charmant crouching in ambush in the porphyry room of the Louvre, and distilling poetry from marble covered in lip marks, enveloped Dorian's mind. But after a while, the book fell from his hand. He was filled with dread, then he was seized by a terrible fear. What if Alan Campbell was out of the country? Days would pass until he returned. Perhaps he would refuse to come to Dorian. What would Dorian do then? Every passing minute carried vital importance.
es_translation: Dorian Gray sighed, opened Gautier's book again, and tried to forget. He read the verses dedicated to the little café in Smyrna where the hajis pass their amber beads, and the turbaned merchants smoke their long pipes adorned with tassels, while they converse about profound topics as the swallows dart in and out making quick turns; he read about the obelisk in the Place de la Concorde that sheds granite tears in its lonely sunless exile and longs to return to the burning Nile covered with lotus flowers, where there are sphinxes and pink ibises and white vultures with golden claws and crocodiles with beryl eyes that crawl through the steaming green mud; and he began to dream with the stanzas that, drawing music from the marble stained with kisses, speak of the curious statue that Gautier compares to a contralto voice, the "monstre charmant" lying in the Louvre in the hall of porphyries. But after some time the book fell from his hands. Nervousness began to dominate him, culminating in a tremendous attack of terror. What would happen if Alan Campbell was not in England? Days and days would have to pass before he returned. Perhaps he would refuse to come back. What to do then? Every minute counted; it was of vital importance.

en: They had been great friends once, five years before—almost inseparable, indeed. Then the intimacy had come suddenly to an end. When they met in society now, it was only Dorian Gray who smiled: Alan Campbell never did.
vi: Họ từng là bạn thân, năm năm trước — gần như không rời nhau nửa bước, thật sự. Sau đó sự gần gũi đột nhiên đi đến một kết thúc. Giờ thì những khi họ gặp nhau trong xã hội thượng lưu, chỉ có Dorian Gray cười; Alan Campbell chẳng bao giờ làm thế.
tr: Bir zamanlar, bundan beş yıl önce çok yakın arkadaştılar. Alan Campbell’le, içtikleri su ayrı gitmezdi. Derken bu yakınlık birden sona erivermişti. Şimdi insan içinde karşılaştıkları zaman yalnızca Dorian Gray gülümseyerek selam veriyordu. Alan Campbell hiç karşılık vermiyordu bu selamlara.
es: Habían sido grandes amigos en otro tiempo, cinco años atrás; casi inseparables, a decir verdad. Luego su intimidad terminó bruscamente. Cuando se encontraban en público, era Dorian Gray quien sonreía, nunca Alan Campbell.
vi_translation: They had been close friends, five years ago — almost inseparable, really. Then the closeness had suddenly come to an end. Now when they met in high society, only Dorian Gray smiled; Alan Campbell never did.
tr_translation: Once, five years ago, they were very close friends. Alan Campbell and he were inseparable. Then, this closeness suddenly came to an end. Now, when they met in public, only Dorian Gray would smile and greet him. Alan Campbell never responded to these greetings.
es_translation: They had been great friends once, five years ago; almost inseparable, to tell the truth. Then their intimacy ended abruptly. When they met in public, it was Dorian Gray who smiled, never Alan Campbell.

en: He was an extremely clever young man, though he had no real appreciation of the visible arts, and whatever little sense of the beauty of poetry he possessed he had gained entirely from Dorian. His dominant intellectual passion was for science. At Cambridge he had spent a great deal of his time working in the laboratory, and had taken a good class in the Natural Science Tripos of his year. Indeed, he was still devoted to the study of chemistry, and had a laboratory of his own in which he used to shut himself up all day long, greatly to the annoyance of his mother, who had set her heart on his standing for Parliament and had a vague idea that a chemist was a person who made up prescriptions. He was an excellent musician, however, as well, and played both the violin and the piano better than most amateurs. In fact, it was music that had first brought him and Dorian Gray together—music and that indefinable attraction that Dorian seemed to be able to exercise whenever he wished—and, indeed, exercised often without being conscious of it. They had met at Lady Berkshire’s the night that Rubinstein played there, and after that used to be always seen together at the opera and wherever good music was going on. For eighteen months their intimacy lasted. Campbell was always either at Selby Royal or in Grosvenor Square. To him, as to many others, Dorian Gray was the type of everything that is wonderful and fascinating in life. Whether or not a quarrel had taken place between them no one ever knew. But suddenly people remarked that they scarcely spoke when they met and that Campbell seemed always to go away early from any party at which Dorian Gray was present. He had changed, too—was strangely melancholy at times, appeared almost to dislike hearing music, and would never himself play, giving as his excuse, when he was called upon, that he was so absorbed in science that he had no time left in which to practise. And this was certainly true. Every day he seemed to become more interested in biology, and his name appeared once or twice in some of the scientific reviews in connection with certain curious experiments.
vi: 1 Tín đồ Hồi giáo từng hành hương về thánh địa Mecca Y là một người đàn ông trẻ cực kỳ thông minh, mặc dù y không thật sự biết thưởng thức các nghệ thuật hữu hình, và bất cứ khả năng cảm nhận vẻ đẹp thi ca nào mà y có được thì cũng là do y tiếp thu trọn vẹn từ Dorian. Niềm đam mê trí tuệ trội hơn cả của y là về khoa học. Ở Cambridge, y dùng rất nhiều thời gian để làm việc trong phòng thí nghiệm, giành được hạng cao trong kỳ thi sinh viên khoa học tự nhiên giỏi của năm. Quả thực, y vẫn tận tụy nghiên cứu hóa học, và có một phòng thí nghiệm riêng, mà trong đó y thường giam mình lại suốt cả ngày dài, rất làm phiền lòng mẹ y, một người thiết tha mong muốn y có chỗ đứng trong Nghị viện, và có một ý niệm mơ hồ rằng hóa học gia là kẻ cho đơn thuốc. Tuy nhiên, y cũng là một nhạc công xuất sắc và chơi cả vỹ cầm với dương cầm đều hay hơn đa số những người không chuyên. Trên thực tế, chính âm nhạc đã là cái đầu tiên đưa y và Dorian Gray lại với nhau — âm nhạc và sức hút không thể định nghĩa được mà Dorian dường như có thể sử dụng đến bất cứ lúc nào cậu muốn, và quả thật là đã sử dụng thường xuyên và vô thức. Họ đã làm quen ở chỗ bà Berkshire vào cái đêm mà Rubinstein diễn ở đó, sau đấy thường xuyên gặp nhau tại nhà hát ô-pê-ra, và bất cứ nơi nào có nhạc hay. Sự gần gũi của họ kéo dài mười tám tháng. Campbell luôn ở Selby Royal hoặc Grosvenor Square. Với y, cũng như với nhiều người khác, Dorian Gray là đại diện điển hình cho tất cả những gì diệu kỳ và quyến rũ trên đời. Có cuộc cãi cọ nào đã xảy ra giữa họ hay không thì không ai từng hay biết. Nhưng đột nhiên mọi người để ý thấy là họ hầu như không nói chuyện với nhau khi gặp gỡ, và rằng Campbell dường như luôn về sớm khỏi mọi buổi tiệc mà Dorian Gray có mặt. Y cũng thay đổi, — thỉnh thoảng lại u uất lạ lùng, có vẻ gần như là ghét nghe nhạc, chẳng bao giờ tự chơi, và tỏ ý xin lỗi, khi y được mời lên, rằng y say mê khoa học đến mức chẳng còn thời gian để mà tập. Và điều này chắc là đúng. Mỗi ngày qua đi, y dường như lại quan tâm nhiều hơn đến sinh vật học, và tên y xuất hiện một đôi lần trong vài tạp chí khoa học, có liên quan đến vài thí nghiệm kỳ lạ.
tr: Gerçi görsel sanatlardan aslında anlamazdı, şiirin güzelliğini bir nebze duyumsamayı da zar zor Dorian’ dan öğrenmişti, ama son derece kafalı bir genç adamdı. Başlıca zihinsel tutkusu fen bilimleriydi. Cambridge’ deyken zamanının büyük bölümünü laboratuvarda çalışarak geçirirdi. Son sınıfta da doğal bilimler onur sınavlarında iyi bir derece kazanmıştı. Hâlâ kimya çalışmalarına meraklıydı aslında, özel bir laboratuvarı da vardı. Sabahtan akşama kadar buraya kapanarak, kimyacıların reçete dolduran kişiler olduğunu sanan, onun Parlamento’ya girmesini kafasına takmış olan annesinin sinirlerini oynatırdı. Bir yandan da mükemmel bir müzisyendi; hem kemanı hem de piyanoyu çoğu amatörlerden çok daha iyi çalardı. Zaten onu Dorian Gray’le bir araya getiren şey de müzik olmuştu; müzik, bir de Dorian’ın canı istediğinde (çok zaman da ayırdında olmadan) uyandırdığı o anlatılmaz çekim gücü. Leydi Berkshirelarda tanışmışlardı, Rubinstein’ın orada piyano çaldığı gece. Sonraları operada, kaliteli müzik çalınan her yerde birlikte görülür oldular. Bu yakınlık on sekiz ay sürdü. Campbell Selby Royal’den, Grosvenor Meydanı’ndaki evden çıkmaz olmuştu. Birçokları gibi onun gözünde de Dorian Gray dünyadaki şahane ve büyüleyici olan her şeyin simgesiydi. Aralarında bir kavga geçip geçmediği hiçbir zaman öğrenilemedi. Ne var ki karşılaştıkları zaman hemen hiç konuşmadıkları birden dikkati çekmeye başladı. Dorian Gray’in de hazır bulunduğu toplantılardan Campbell erkenden ayrılır olmuştu. Campbell çok değişmişti, tuhaf bir durgunluğa kapılıyordu sanki, müzik dinlemekten hoşlanmıyor gibiydi; artık hiç piyano çalmıyor, çalması istendiğinde de, özür olarak, bilimsel uğraşlara aşırı daldığı için müzik çalışmaya vakti kalmadığını ileri sürüyordu, bu gerçekten de doğruydu. Genç adamın biyolojiye olan ilgisi sanki her geçen gün artıyordu. Kimi bilim dergilerinde tuhaf deneylerle ilgili olarak birkaç kez adı geçmişti.
es: Se trataba de un joven extraordinariamente inteligente, aunque sin verdadero aprecio por las artes plásticas y que, si en algo había llegado a captar la belleza de la poesía, se lo debía por completo a Dorian. Su pasión intelectual dominante era la ciencia. En Cambridge pasaba gran parte del tiempo trabajando en el laboratorio, y había obtenido una buena calificación en el examen final de ciencias naturales. De hecho, aún seguía dedicado al estudio de la química, y tenía laboratorio propio, donde solía encerrarse el día entero, lo que irritaba mucho a su madre, que tendía a confundir a los químicos con los boticarios, y a quien ilusionaba sobre todo que consiguiese un escaño en el Parlamento. Campbell era, por otra parte, un músico excelente, y tocaba el violín y el piano mejor que la mayoría de los aficionados. La música había sido, de hecho, el lazo de unión entre Dorian Gray y él: la música y la indefinible capacidad de atracción que Dorian podía utilizar a voluntad y que de hecho utilizaba con frecuencia sin. ser consciente de ello. Se habían conocido en casa de lady Berkshire la noche en que tocó allí Rubinstein[17] , y después se los veía con frecuencia juntos en la ópera y dondequiera que se interpretara buena música. Su intimidad había durado dieciocho meses. Campbell estaba siempre en Selby Royal o en Grosvenor Square. Para él, como para muchos otros, Dorian Gray representaba el modelo de todo lo que la vida tiene de maravilloso y fascinante. Nadie sabía si habían llegado a pelearse. Pero, de repente, otras personas se dieron cuenta de que apenas hablaban cuando se veían, y de que Campbell se marchaba pronto de las fiestas a las que asistía Dorian Gray. Había cambiado, por otra parte: se mostraba extrañamente melancólico a veces, casi parecía que la música le desagradase, y no tocaba nunca, dando como excusa, cuando se le pedía que interpretase algo, estar tan absorto en la ciencia que le faltaba tiempo para practicar. Y era sin duda cierto. Cada día que pasaba daba la impresión de estar más interesado por la biología, y su nombre había aparecido una o dos veces en algunas dulas revistas científicas, en relación con ciertos curiosos experimentos.
vi_translation: A Muslim pilgrim once journeyed to the holy city of Mecca He was an extremely intelligent young man, although he did not truly appreciate the tangible arts, and any ability to perceive the beauty of poetry that he possessed was entirely absorbed from Dorian. His predominant intellectual passion was for science. At Cambridge, he spent a lot of time working in the laboratory, achieving high marks in the annual examination for outstanding natural science students. Indeed, he remained devoted to the study of chemistry, and had a private laboratory where he often secluded himself all day long, much to the distress of his mother, who earnestly wished for him to have a position in Parliament, and had a vague notion that a chemist was someone who wrote prescriptions. However, he was also an excellent musician and played both the violin and the piano better than most amateurs. In fact, it was music that first brought him and Dorian Gray together — music and the indefinable charm that Dorian seemed able to wield whenever he wished, and indeed did so frequently and unconsciously. They met at Mrs. Berkshire's on the night Rubinstein performed there, and subsequently often encountered each other at the opera house, and anywhere there was good music. Their closeness lasted eighteen months. Campbell was always at Selby Royal or Grosvenor Square. To him, as to many others, Dorian Gray was the epitome of all that was wonderful and enchanting in life. Whether any quarrel had occurred between them, no one ever knew. But suddenly people noticed that they hardly spoke to each other when they met, and that Campbell seemed always to leave early from any party where Dorian Gray was present. He also changed — sometimes becoming strangely melancholic, appearing almost to hate music, never playing himself, and apologizing when invited to do so, saying that he was so engrossed in science that he had no time to practice. And this was probably true. With each passing day, he seemed to become more interested in biology, and his name appeared a few times in various scientific journals, related to some peculiar experiments.
tr_translation: Although he didn't really understand visual arts, he had barely learned to appreciate the beauty of poetry from Dorian, but he was an extremely intelligent young man. His main intellectual passion was the natural sciences. While at Cambridge, he spent most of his time working in the laboratory. In his final year, he had also achieved a good grade in the honors exams for natural sciences. He was still interested in chemistry studies, and he even had a private laboratory. By shutting himself in there from morning till night, he would get on the nerves of his mother, who thought chemists were just people who filled prescriptions and was fixated on him entering Parliament. On the other hand, he was an excellent musician; he played both the violin and the piano much better than most amateurs. In fact, it was music that brought him together with Dorian Gray; music, and that indescribable attraction Dorian often (unconsciously) evoked whenever he wished. They had met at Lady Berkshire's, on the night Rubinstein played the piano there. Later, they were often seen together at the opera, and everywhere quality music was played. This closeness lasted for eighteen months. Campbell had practically moved into the house on Grosvenor Square from Selby Royal. Like many others, to him, Dorian Gray was the symbol of everything magnificent and enchanting in the world. It was never known whether they had a quarrel. However, it soon became noticeable that they hardly spoke when they met. Campbell began to leave gatherings where Dorian Gray was present, early. Campbell had changed a lot; he seemed to fall into a strange lethargy, as if he no longer enjoyed listening to music; he no longer played the piano, and when asked to play, he would excuse himself by saying that he was too engrossed in his scientific pursuits to have time for music practice, which was indeed true. The young man's interest in biology seemed to grow with each passing day. His name had appeared several times in some scientific journals in connection with strange experiments.
es_translation: He was an extraordinarily intelligent young man, although without a true appreciation for the visual arts, and if he had come to grasp the beauty of poetry at all, he owed it entirely to Dorian. His dominant intellectual passion was science. At Cambridge, he spent a large part of his time working in the laboratory, and he had obtained a good grade in the final natural sciences exam. In fact, he was still dedicated to the study of chemistry, and he had his own laboratory, where he would often lock himself up all day, much to the irritation of his mother, who tended to confuse chemists with apothecaries, and who was especially hopeful that he would secure a seat in Parliament. Campbell was, on the other hand, an excellent musician, and he played the violin and the piano better than most amateurs. Music had, in fact, been the bond between Dorian Gray and him: music and the indefinable charm that Dorian could use at will and often did use without being aware of it. They had met at Lady Berkshire's house the night Rubinstein played there, and afterward, they were frequently seen together at the opera and wherever good music was performed. Their intimacy had lasted eighteen months. Campbell was always at Selby Royal or in Grosvenor Square. For him, as for many others, Dorian Gray represented the model of everything wonderful and fascinating in life. Nobody knew if they had ended up fighting. But, suddenly, other people noticed that they barely spoke when they saw each other, and that Campbell would soon leave the parties that Dorian Gray attended. He had changed, moreover: he sometimes appeared strangely melancholic, almost as if music displeased him, and he never played, giving as an excuse, when asked to perform something, that he was so absorbed in science that he lacked time to practice. And it was undoubtedly true. With each passing day, he seemed more interested in biology, and his name had appeared once or twice in some scientific journals, in relation to certain curious experiments.

en: This was the man Dorian Gray was waiting for. Every second he kept glancing at the clock. As the minutes went by he became horribly agitated. At last he got up and began to pace up and down the room, looking like a beautiful caged thing. He took long stealthy strides. His hands were curiously cold.
vi: Đó là người mà Dorian Gray đang chờ. Cậu cứ nhìn đồng hồ từng giây. Các phút qua đi, cậu trở nên bối rối khủng khiếp. Cuối cùng cậu đứng dậy, bắt đầu bước tới bước lui trong phòng, trông như một con thú đẹp bị nhốt vào cũi. Cậu sải những bước dài vụng trộm. Tay cậu lạnh một cách kỳ lạ.
tr: İşte Dorian Gray’in beklemekte olduğu adam buydu. Dorian her an duvardaki saate bakıp duruyor, dakikalar geçtikçe içindeki çirkin, kaygılı heyecan artıyordu. En sonunda kalktı, odanın içini arşınlamaya başladı: Kafese kapatılmış güzel bir yaratık gibiydi. Uzun, sinsi adımlarla yürüyordu. Elleri buz kesmişti, nedense.
es: Tal era el hombre que Dorian Gray esperaba. Su mirada se volvía hacia el reloj a cada momento. A medida que pasaban los minutos aumentaba su agitación. Finalmente se levantó y empezó a pasear por la estancia, con el aspecto de un bello animal enjaulado. Caminaba a grandes zancadas que tenían algo de furtivo. Y las manos se le habían quedado extrañamente frías.
vi_translation: That is the person whom Dorian Gray is waiting for. He keeps looking at the clock every second. As the minutes pass, he becomes terribly anxious. Finally, he stands up and begins to pace back and forth in the room, looking like a beautiful beast trapped in a cage. He takes long, stealthy strides. His hands are strangely cold.
tr_translation: This was the man Dorian Gray had been waiting for. Dorian kept looking at the clock on the wall every moment, and as the minutes passed, the ugly, anxious excitement inside him grew. Finally, he got up and began pacing the room: He was like a beautiful creature trapped in a cage. He walked with long, stealthy steps. His hands were ice-cold, for some reason.
es_translation: Such was the man that Dorian Gray was waiting for. His gaze turned towards the clock every moment. As the minutes passed, his agitation increased. Finally, he got up and began to pace around the room, with the appearance of a beautiful caged animal. He walked with long strides that had something furtive about them. And his hands had become strangely cold.

en: The suspense became unbearable. Time seemed to him to be crawling with feet of lead, while he by monstrous winds was being swept towards the jagged edge of some black cleft of precipice. He knew what was waiting for him there; saw it, indeed, and, shuddering, crushed with dank hands his burning lids as though he would have robbed the very brain of sight and driven the eyeballs back into their cave. It was useless. The brain had its own food on which it battened, and the imagination, made grotesque by terror, twisted and distorted as a living thing by pain, danced like some foul puppet on a stand and grinned through moving masks. Then, suddenly, time stopped for him. Yes: that blind, slow-breathing thing crawled no more, and horrible thoughts, time being dead, raced nimbly on in front, and dragged a hideous future from its grave, and showed it to him. He stared at it. Its very horror made him stone.
vi: Tình trạng chờ đợi trở nên không thể chịu nổi. Cậu thấy thời gian dường như lê các bước chân chì, trong khi cậu bị quét bởi những trận gió quái về phía cái cạnh lởm chởm của khe nứt đen nào đó trên vách đứng. Cậu biết cái gì đang chờ cậu ở đó; thấy nó thực sự, và, rùng mình, ép đôi tay ẩm lên hai mi mắt cháy bỏng như thể cậu có thể lấy trộm thị lực, đẩy nhãn cầu vào lại trong hang. Vô ích. Não có thứ dưỡng chất riêng mà nó vẫn ăn bám, còn trí tưởng tượng, bị nỗi sợ biến thành kỳ quái, thì quằn quại và vặn vẹo như một sinh vật bị đau, nhảy múa như con rối xấu xí nào đó trên bệ, nhe răng nhăn nhở qua cái mặt nạ động đậy. Sau đó, đột nhiên, Thời gian dừng lại vì cậu. Vâng: cái thứ mù lòa, thở chậm ấy không bò nữa, và các ý nghĩ khủng khiếp, do Thời gian bị tê liệt, nên đua nhanh lên trước, lôi một tương lai gớm guốc ra khỏi mộ phần, cho cậu xem nó. Cậu nhìn chòng chọc vào nó. Chính sự ghê rợn của nó khiến cậu hóa đá.
tr: Bekleyişinin gerilimi dayanılmaz kertelerdeydi. Dorian’a öyle geliyordu ki kendisi müthiş rüzgârlarla, kapkara bir uçurum ağzındaki yalçın kayalara doğru sürüklenirken, zaman kurşundan ayaklarla emeklemekteydi. O uçurumda kendisini neyin beklediğini Dorian biliyordu; bilmiyor, görüyordu ve tepeden tırnağa ürperiyor, yanan gözkapaklarını nemli elleriyle bastırıyordu, beyninin görme gücünü ezmek, gözlerini yuvalarının içine sokmak istiyordu. Ama işe yaramıyordu bu. Beyin semirmek için kendiliğinden besin buluyordu. Dehşetin çığırdan çıkardığı imgelem de can acısıyla çırpınıp kıvranan bir canlı varlıkmışçasına, ip ucundaki iğrenç bir kukla gibi oynayıp duruyor, değişken maskelerin altından sırıtıyordu. Derken, ansızın, Dorian Gray için zaman durdu. Evet, o ağır soluyan, kör gözlü şey yürümüyordu. Şimdi zaman ölmüştü ya, kanını dondurucu düşünceler seyirtip öne geçmiş, çirkin, ürpertici bir geleceği mezarından çıkarmış, Dorian’a gösteriyorlardı. Dorian bakakalmıştı buna. Gördüğü şeyin dehşetiyle taş kesilmişti.
es: La incertidumbre se hizo insoportable. Tuvo la impresión de que el tiempo se arrastraba con pies de plomo, mientras él, empujado por monstruosos huracanes, avanzaba hacia el borde dentado de un negro precipicio. Dorian sabía lo que le esperaba allí abajo; lo veía, incluso, y, estremecido, se aplastó con manos húmedas los párpados ardientes como si quisiera robarle la vista al cerebro mismo, empujando los globos de los ojos hasta el fondo de las órbitas. Pero era inútil. El cerebro disponía de su propio alimento, en el que se cebaba, y la imaginación, lanzada a grotescos excesos por el terror, se retorcía y deformaba como un ser vivo a causa del dolor, bailaba como una horrible marioneta sobre un escenario, y hacía muecas detrás de máscaras animadas. Luego, de repente, el Tiempo se detuvo para él. Sí; aquella dimensión ciega, de lentísima respiración, dejó de arrastrarse, y horribles pensamientos, puesto que el Tiempo había muerto, emprendieron una veloz carrera y desenterraron el espantoso futuro de su tumba para mostrárselo. Dorian lo contempló fijamente. Y el horror que sintió lo dejó petrificado.
vi_translation: The state of waiting became unbearable. He felt time dragging its leaden feet, while he was swept by monstrous gusts towards the jagged edge of some black fissure on the cliff face. He knew what was waiting for him there; saw it truly, and, shuddering, pressed his damp hands to his burning eyelids as if he could steal his vision, pushing his eyeballs back into their sockets. In vain. The brain has its own nutrients that it still feeds on, and the imagination, twisted by fear, writhed and contorted like a pained creature, dancing like some ugly puppet on a stage, grinning through its twitching mask. Then, suddenly, Time stopped for him. Yes: that blind, slow-breathing thing no longer crawled, and the terrible thoughts, with Time paralyzed, raced ahead, dragging a ghastly future out of its grave, showing it to him. He stared at it. Its very horror turned him to stone.
tr_translation: The tension of his waiting was at unbearable levels. It seemed to Dorian that while he was being swept towards jagged rocks at the mouth of a pitch-black abyss by tremendous winds, time was crawling with leaden feet. Dorian knew what awaited him in that abyss; he didn't just know, he saw it, and he shuddered from head to toe, pressing his burning eyelids with his damp hands, wanting to crush the vision in his brain, to push his eyes back into their sockets. But it wasn't working. The brain was finding nourishment on its own to feed itself. Imagination, driven mad by horror, was writhing and struggling like a living creature in pain, playing like a disgusting puppet on a string, grinning from beneath shifting masks. Then, suddenly, time stopped for Dorian Gray. Yes, that heavy-breathing, blind-eyed thing was no longer moving. Now that time had died, chilling thoughts raced ahead, unearthing a hideous, horrifying future and showing it to Dorian. Dorian stood transfixed by it. He was petrified by the horror of what he saw.
es_translation: The uncertainty became unbearable. He had the impression that time was dragging its feet, while he, pushed by monstrous hurricanes, advanced towards the jagged edge of a black precipice. Dorian knew what awaited him down there; he even saw it, and, trembling, he pressed his burning eyelids with damp hands as if he wanted to steal the sight from his very brain, pushing his eyeballs deep into their sockets. But it was useless. The brain had its own sustenance, on which it fed, and the imagination, driven to grotesque excesses by terror, writhed and deformed like a living being in pain, danced like a horrible puppet on a stage, and grimaced behind animated masks. Then, suddenly, Time stopped for him. Yes; that blind dimension, with its slow breathing, ceased to drag on, and horrible thoughts, since Time had died, began a rapid race and unearthed the dreadful future from its grave to show it to him. Dorian stared at it fixedly. And the horror he felt left him petrified.

en: At last the door opened and his servant entered. He turned glazed eyes upon him.
vi: Rốt cuộc cửa mở, và gia nhân của cậu bước vào. Cậu đảo mắt đờ đẫn nhìn hắn.
tr: En sonunda kapı açıldı, uşağı içeri girdi. Dorian camlaşmış gözlerini ona çevirdi.
es: Finalmente la puerta se abrió, dando paso al ayuda de cámara. Dorian Gray lo miró con ojos vidriosos.
vi_translation: Finally, the door opened, and his servant stepped in. He looked at him with glazed eyes.
tr_translation: Finally, the door opened, and the servant entered. Dorian turned his glazed eyes to him.
es_translation: Finally, the door opened, giving way to the valet. Dorian Gray looked at him with glassy eyes.

en: “Mr. Campbell, sir,” said the man.
vi: “Mít-tơ Campbell đến, thưa ngài,” người ấy nói.
tr: “mr Campbell, efendim,” dedi adam.
es: —El señor Campbell —anunció.
vi_translation: “Mr. Campbell has arrived, sir,” the person said.
tr_translation: "Mr. Campbell, sir," said the man.
es_translation: —Mr. Campbell —he announced.

en: A sigh of relief broke from his parched lips, and the colour came back to his cheeks.
vi: Một tiếng thở nhẹ nhõm bật ra khỏi đôi môi khô rang của cậu, và sắc màu trở lại má cậu.
tr: Dorian’ın kavrulmuş dudaklarından rahat bir soluk kurtuldu, yüzünün rengi geri geldi.
es: Un suspiro de alivio escapó entonces de los labios resecos de Dorian Gray el color regresó a sus mejillas.
vi_translation: A sigh of relief escaped from his parched lips, and color returned to his cheeks.
tr_translation: A relieved breath escaped from Dorian's parched lips, and the color returned to his face.
es_translation: A sigh of relief then escaped from the parched lips of Dorian Gray, and color returned to his cheeks.

en: “Ask him to come in at once, Francis.” He felt that he was himself again. His mood of cowardice had passed away.
vi: “Mời ông ấy vào ngay đi, Francis.” Cậu thấy mình lại là mình. Tâm trạng hèn nhát của cậu đã biến mất.
tr: “Hemen içeri buyur et, Francis.” Dorian kendine gelmişti artık. Deminki ödlekliği geçip gitmişti.
es: —Hágalo pasar ahora mismo, Francis —sintió que volvía a ser el de siempre. Había superado el momento de cobardía.
vi_translation: "Please let him in immediately, Francis." He felt like himself again. His cowardly mood had vanished.
tr_translation: "Please come in, Francis." Dorian had composed himself by now. The earlier cowardice had passed.
es_translation: —Have him come in right now, Francis —he felt like his old self again. He had overcome the moment of cowardice.

en: The man bowed and retired. In a few moments, Alan Campbell walked in, looking very stern and rather pale, his pallor being intensified by his coal-black hair and dark eyebrows.
vi: Người hầu cúi đầu và lui ra. Một lát sau, Alan Campbell bước vào, trông rất nghiêm nghị và khá nhợt nhạt, vẻ xanh xao của y còn bị làm nổi bật thêm bởi mái tóc đen như than với đôi lông mày sẫm màu.
tr: Uşak eğildi, çekildi. Birkaç dakika sonra da Campbell içeri girdi. Yüzü çok sert, biraz da solgundu, saçlarıyla kaşlarının o kömür karası da benzinin solgunluğunu vurgular gibiydi.
es: El criado hizo una inclinación de cabeza y se retiró. Instantes después entró Alan Campbell, con aspecto severo y bastante pálido, la palidez intensificada por los cabellos y las cejas de color negro azabache.
vi_translation: The servant bowed his head and withdrew. A moment later, Alan Campbell walked in, looking very stern and quite pale, his pallor further accentuated by his coal-black hair and dark eyebrows.
tr_translation: The servant bowed and withdrew. A few minutes later, Campbell entered. His face was very stern, a bit pale, and the coal-black of his hair and eyebrows seemed to accentuate the pallor of his complexion.
es_translation: The servant bowed his head and withdrew. Moments later, Alan Campbell entered, looking severe and quite pale, the pallor intensified by his jet-black hair and eyebrows.

en: “Alan! This is kind of you. I thank you for coming.”
vi: “Alan! Anh tử tế quá. Tôi cảm ơn anh vì đã đến.
tr: “Alan! Çok iyisin. Geldiğin için sağ ol, var ol.
es: —¡Atan! ¡Cuánta amabilidad por tu parte! Te agradezco mucho que hayas venido.
vi_translation: “Alan! You are so kind. Thank you for coming.”
tr_translation: “Alan! You are very good. Thank you for coming, much appreciated.”
es_translation: —Atan! How kind of you! Thank you so much for coming.

en: “I had intended never to enter your house again, Gray. But you said it was a matter of life and death.” His voice was hard and cold. He spoke with slow deliberation. There was a look of contempt in the steady searching gaze that he turned on Dorian. He kept his hands in the pockets of his Astrakhan coat, and seemed not to have noticed the gesture with which he had been greeted.
vi: “Tôi đã định không bao giờ bước vào nhà anh lần nữa, Gray. Nhưng anh bảo đây là vấn đề sống còn.” Giọng y gắt và lạnh. Y nói thong thả. Một vẻ khinh miệt trong cái ánh mắt dò xét điềm tĩnh mà y đảo qua Dorian. Y thủ tay trong túi áo lông cừu ca- ra-cun, và dường như không để ý đến cử chỉ mà y được chào đón.
tr: “Evinize bir daha ayak basmamaya niyetliydim, Gray. Ama bunun bir ölüm kalım meselesi olduğunu yazmışsınız.” Genç adamın sesi katı, soğuk çıkmıştı. Ağır, tane tane konuşuyordu. Dorian’a diktiği keskin bakışta bir küçümseyiş vardı. Ellerini astragan paltosunun ceplerinden çıkarmamış, Dorian’ın selam jestini görmezlikten gelmişti.
es: —Me había propuesto no volver a pisar tu casa, Gray. Pero se me ha dicho que era una cuestión de vida o muerte —su voz era dura y fría y hablaba con estudiada lentitud. Había una expresión de desprecio en la mirada insistente con que procedió a estudiar el rostro de Dorian. Mantenía las manos en los bolsillos de su abrigo de astracán y dio la impresión de no haberse percatado del gesto con el que había sido recibido.
vi_translation: “I had decided never to step into your house again, Gray. But you said this was a matter of life and death.” His voice was harsh and cold. He spoke slowly. A look of contempt in the calm scrutinizing gaze he cast at Dorian. He kept his hands in the pockets of his karakul wool coat, and seemed indifferent to the gesture with which he was greeted.
tr_translation: “I was determined never to set foot in your house again, Gray. But you wrote that this is a matter of life and death.” The young man's voice was firm and cold. He spoke slowly and deliberately. There was a hint of disdain in the sharp look he directed at Dorian. He hadn't taken his hands out of the pockets of his astrakhan coat and had ignored Dorian's gesture of greeting.
es_translation: —I had resolved not to set foot in your house again, Gray. But I was told it was a matter of life and death —his voice was hard and cold, and he spoke with studied slowness. There was an expression of contempt in the insistent gaze with which he proceeded to study Dorian's face. He kept his hands in the pockets of his astrakhan coat and gave the impression of not having noticed the gesture with which he had been received.

en: “Yes: it is a matter of life and death, Alan, and to more than one person. Sit down.”
vi: “Đúng: đây là vấn đề sống còn, Alan, và với nhiều hơn một cá nhân. Mời anh ngồi.”
tr: “Evet, ölüm kalım meselesi, Alan, hem de yalnızca bir tek kişi için değil. Otur, kuzum.
es: —Sí; se trata de una cuestión de vida o muerte, Alan, y para más de una persona. Haz el favor de sentarte.
vi_translation: “Correct: this is a matter of life and death, Alan, and for more than one individual. Please have a seat.”
tr_translation: “Yes, it's a matter of life and death, Alan, and not just for one single person. Have a seat, dear.”
es_translation: —Yes; it is a matter of life and death, Alan, and for more than one person. Please sit down.

en: Campbell took a chair by the table, and Dorian sat opposite to him. The two men’s eyes met. In Dorian’s there was infinite pity. He knew that what he was going to do was dreadful.
vi: Campbell chiếm cái ghế cạnh bàn, còn Dorian ngồi đối diện y. Mắt hai người gặp nhau. Trong mắt Dorian có tình thương vô bờ. Cậu biết rằng điều cậu sắp làm là rất đáng sợ.
tr: Campbell masa başındaki bir sandalyeye oturdu. Dorian’ın onun karşısına geçti. Bakışları birleşti. Dorian’ ın bakışlarında sonsuz bir acıma vardı. Yapacağı işin korkunç olduğunu biliyordu.
es: Campbell ocupó una silla junto a la mesa, y Dorian se sentó frente a él. Los dos hombres se miraron a los ojos. En los de Dorian había una infinita compasión. Sabía que lo que se disponía a hacer era espantoso.
vi_translation: Campbell took the seat next to the table, while Dorian sat opposite him. Their eyes met. There was boundless affection in Dorian's eyes. He knew that what he was about to do was very frightening.
tr_translation: Campbell sat down on a chair at the desk. Dorian stood across from him. Their gazes met. There was infinite pity in Dorian's eyes. He knew the task he was about to do was dreadful.
es_translation: Campbell occupied a chair next to the table, and Dorian sat across from him. The two men looked into each other's eyes. In Dorian's eyes, there was infinite compassion. He knew that what he was about to do was dreadful.

en: After a strained moment of silence, he leaned across and said, very quietly, but watching the effect of each word upon the face of him he had sent for, “Alan, in a locked room at the top of this house, a room to which nobody but myself has access, a dead man is seated at a table. He has been dead ten hours now. Don’t stir, and don’t look at me like that. Who the man is, why he died, how he died, are matters that do not concern you. What you have to do is this—”
vi: Sau một lúc im lặng căng thẳng, cậu nghiêng qua và nói, rất bình thản, nhưng quan sát kỹ tác động của từng lời cậu nhắn gửi trên mặt y, “Alan, trong một căn phòng khóa kín trên tầng thượng tòa nhà này, một căn phòng mà chẳng ai ngoài tôi được quyền vào, có một người chết đang ngồi bên bàn. Hắn đã chết độ mười giờ. Đừng cựa, và đừng nhìn tôi như thế. Người đó là ai, vì sao hắn chết, hắn chết thế nào, là các vấn đề không liên quan đến anh. Việc anh phải làm là thế này…”
tr: Kısa, gergin bir sessizlikten sonra konuğuna doğru eğildi, serinkanlılıkla, gene de her sözünün karşısındaki yüzde uyandırdığı etkiyi gözleyerek, “Alan,” dedi. “Bu evin en üst katındaki kilitli bir odada, bir masa başında oturmuş ölü bir adam var. Odaya benden başka kimse girip çıkamaz. Adam öleli de on saat oluyor. Kıpırdanma, bana da öyle bakma. Bu adam kimdir, nasıl ölmüştür, neden ölmüştür... Bunlar seni ilgilendirmeyen konular. Şimdi senin yapman gereken şey yalnızca...
es: Después de un tenso momento de silencio, se inclinó hacia adelante y dijo, con mucha calma, pero atento al efecto de cada palabra sobre el rostro de su visitante: —Alan, en una habitación cerrada con llave en el ático de esta casa, en una habitación a la que nadie, excepto yo mismo, tiene acceso, hay un muerto sentado ante una mesa. Hace ya diez horas que falleció. No te muevas, ni me mires de esa manera. Quién es esa persona, por qué ha muerto, cómo ha muerto, son cuestiones que no te conciernen. Lo que tienes que hacer es esto...
vi_translation: After a moment of tense silence, he leaned over and said, very calmly, but carefully observing the impact of each word he conveyed on his face, "Alan, in a locked room on the top floor of this building, a room that no one but me has the right to enter, there is a dead man sitting at the table. He has been dead for about ten hours. Don't move, and don't look at me like that. Who that person is, why he died, how he died, are matters that do not concern you. What you need to do is this…”
tr_translation: After a short, tense silence, he leaned towards his guest, calmly, yet observing the effect of each of his words on the face opposite him, and said, "Alan." "In a locked room on the top floor of this house, there is a dead man sitting at a desk. No one but me can enter or leave the room. The man has been dead for ten hours. Don't fidget, and don't look at me like that. Who this man is, how he died, why he died... These are matters that do not concern you. Now, the only thing you need to do is..."
es_translation: After a tense moment of silence, he leaned forward and said, very calmly, but attentive to the effect of each word on the face of his visitor: —Alan, in a locked room in the attic of this house, in a room that no one, except myself, has access to, there is a dead man sitting at a table. He has been dead for ten hours now. Do not move, nor look at me that way. Who that person is, why he died, how he died, are matters that do not concern you. What you have to do is this...

en: “Stop, Gray. I don’t want to know anything further. Whether what you have told me is true or not true doesn’t concern me. I entirely decline to be mixed up in your life. Keep your horrible secrets to yourself. They don’t interest me any more.”
vi: “Dừng lại, Gray. Tôi không muốn biết gì thêm nữa. Dù những gì anh nói với tôi là thật hay không thật thì cũng chẳng liên quan đến tôi. Tôi hoàn toàn từ chối việc bị dính dáng đến đời anh. Hãy giữ các bí mật khủng khiếp của anh lại cho chính mình. Tôi không quan tâm đến chúng nữa.”
tr: “Yeter, Gray. Başka bir şey bilmek istemiyorum. Bana söylediklerinizin doğru olup olmaması da beni ilgilendirmez. Hayatınıza karışmayı reddediyorum. Pis sırlarınızı kendinize saklayın. Bunlar beni zerrece ilgilendirmiyor artık.
es: —Basta, Gray. No quiero saber nada más. Ignoro si lo que me acabas de contar es mentira o verdad. No me importa. Me niego por completo a verme mezclado en tu vida. Guarda para ti solo tus horribles secretos. Han dejado de interesarme.
vi_translation: “Stop, Gray. I don't want to know anything more. Whether what you tell me is true or not, it doesn't concern me. I completely refuse to be involved in your life. Keep your terrible secrets to yourself. I don't care about them anymore.”
tr_translation: “Enough, Gray. I don't want to know anything else. I don't care whether what you told me is true or not. I refuse to interfere in your life. Keep your dirty secrets to yourself. These things don't concern me in the slightest anymore.”
es_translation: —Enough, Gray. I don't want to know anything more. I don't know if what you just told me is a lie or the truth. I don't care. I completely refuse to get involved in your life. Keep your horrible secrets to yourself. They no longer interest me.

en: “Alan, they will have to interest you. This one will have to interest you. I am awfully sorry for you, Alan. But I can’t help myself. You are the one man who is able to save me. I am forced to bring you into the matter. I have no option. Alan, you are scientific. You know about chemistry and things of that kind. You have made experiments. What you have got to do is to destroy the thing that is upstairs—to destroy it so that not a vestige of it will be left. Nobody saw this person come into the house. Indeed, at the present moment he is supposed to be in Paris. He will not be missed for months. When he is missed, there must be no trace of him found here. You, Alan, you must change him, and everything that belongs to him, into a handful of ashes that I may scatter in the air.”
vi: “Alan, anh sẽ phải quan tâm đến chúng. Anh sẽ phải quan tâm đến một điều này. Tôi rất lấy làm tiếc cho anh, Alan. Nhưng tôi không thể tự giúp mình. Anh là người duy nhất có thể cứu tôi. Tôi buộc phải lôi anh vào chuyện này. Tôi không có lựa chọn. Alan, anh là nhà khoa học. Anh biết về hóa học, và những thứ loại ấy. Anh làm các thí nghiệm. Những gì anh phải làm là hủy cái thứ trên gác — hủy nó sao cho không một dấu vết nào của nó còn sót lại. Không ai thấy người này vào nhà. Quả thật, ai cũng cho là lúc này hắn đang ở Paris. Hắn sẽ không được ai nhớ ra trong nhiều tháng. Phải làm sao để khi người ta nhớ ra hắn thì không thể tìm được chút gì của hắn ở đây. Anh, Alan, anh phải biến hắn, và mọi thứ thuộc về hắn, thành một nắm tro mà tôi có thể tung vào không khí.”
tr: “İster istemez ilgilendirecek, Alan. Bu sır, çaresiz, ilgilendirecek seni. Sana çok, pek çok acıyorum, dostum, ne var ki başka çıkar yolum yok. Beni kurtarabilecek tek kişi sensin. Seni bu işe karıştırmak zorundayım. Başka seçenek yok elimde. Sen bilim adamısın, Alan. Kimyadan falan anlıyorsun. Deneyler yapmışlığın var. Şimdi yapman gereken de yukarıdaki o şeyi ortadan kaldırman, geriye hiçbir iz kalmamacasına. Bu kimsenin bu eve girdiğini kimse görmedi. Aylarca yokluğunun farkına varılmayacak. Farkına varılınca da bu evde onun hiçbir izine rastlanmamalı. Sen, Alan, evet, sen adamı ve ona ait ne varsa hepsini şöyle havaya savurabileceğim bir avuç küle çevirmelisin.
es: —Tienen que interesarte, Alan. Éste, en concreto, va a tener que interesarte. Lo siento muchísimo por ti, pero no puedo evitarlo. Eres la única persona que me puede salvar. Estoy obligado a forzar tu intervención. No tengo alternativa. Eres un hombre de ciencia, Alan. Sabes química y otras cosas relacionadas con ella. Has hecho experimentos. Se trata de que destruyas el cuerpo sin vida que está ahí arriba; de destruirlo de manera que no quede el menor rastro. Nadie vio entrar a esa persona en esta casa. Se piensa, de hecho, que se encuentra actualmente en París. Pasarán meses antes de que se le eche de menos. Cuando eso suceda, es preciso que no quede aquí traza alguna suya. Tú, Alan, debes encargarte de convertirlos, a él y a todas sus pertenencias, en un puñado de cenizas que puedan esparcirse al viento.
vi_translation: “Alan, you will have to take care of them. You will have to take care of this one thing. I am very sorry for you, Alan. But I cannot help myself. You are the only one who can save me. I am forced to drag you into this. I have no choice. Alan, you are a scientist. You know about chemistry, and things of that sort. You conduct experiments. What you have to do is destroy the thing in the attic — destroy it so that not a trace of it remains. No one saw this person enter the house. Indeed, everyone thinks he is currently in Paris. He will not be remembered for many months. We must make sure that when people do remember him, they cannot find anything of him here. You, Alan, you must turn him, and everything of his, into a handful of ashes that I can scatter into the air.”
tr_translation: “It will inevitably concern you, Alan. This secret, helplessly, will concern you. I pity you a lot, very much, my friend, but I have no other way out. You are the only person who can save me. I have to involve you in this matter. I have no other option. You are a scientist, Alan. You understand chemistry and such. You have conducted experiments. Now, what you need to do is to get rid of that thing upstairs, leaving no trace behind. No one saw anyone enter this house. It will be months before anyone notices its absence. When they do notice, there should be no trace of it in this house. You, Alan, yes, you must turn the man and everything belonging to him into a handful of ashes that I can scatter into the air.”
es_translation: —They have to interest you, Alan. This one, in particular, is going to have to interest you. I'm very sorry for you, but I can't help it. You are the only person who can save me. I am forced to compel your intervention. I have no alternative. You are a man of science, Alan. You know chemistry and other related things. You have conducted experiments. The matter at hand is for you to destroy the lifeless body that is up there; to destroy it in such a way that not the slightest trace remains. No one saw that person enter this house. It is believed, in fact, that they are currently in Paris. Months will pass before they are missed. When that happens, it is essential that no trace of them remains here. You, Alan, must take charge of turning them, and all their belongings, into a handful of ashes that can be scattered to the wind.

en: “You are mad, Dorian.”
vi: “Anh điên rồi, Dorian.”
tr: “Sen delirmişsin, Dorian.
es: —Estás loco, Dorian.
vi_translation: “You are crazy, Dorian.”
tr_translation: “You have gone mad, Dorian.”
es_translation: —You are crazy, Dorian.

en: “Ah! I was waiting for you to call me Dorian.”
vi: “Chà! Tôi đang chờ anh gọi tôi là Dorian.
tr: “Ah! Bana, Dorian demeni bekliyordum.
es: —¡Ah! Esperaba anhelante a que me llamaras Dorian.
vi_translation: "Wow! I was waiting for you to call me Dorian."
tr_translation: “Ah! I was expecting you to call me, Dorian.”
es_translation: —Ah! I was eagerly waiting for you to call me, Dorian.

en: “You are mad, I tell you—mad to imagine that I would raise a finger to help you, mad to make this monstrous confession. I will have nothing to do with this matter, whatever it is. Do you think I am going to peril my reputation for you? What is it to me what devil’s work you are up to?”
vi: “Anh điên rồi, tôi nói anh nghe — điên vì nghĩ là tôi sẽ nhấc dù chỉ một ngón tay lên để giúp anh, điên vì nói ra lời thú tội ghê gớm này. Tôi sẽ chẳng liên quan đến việc này, dẫu nó có là gì chăng nữa. Anh tưởng tôi sẽ liều thanh danh của tôi cho anh sao? Anh có đang làm cái việc quỷ quái gì thì cũng can hệ gì đến tôi?”
tr: “Delirmişsin, diyorum sana. Benim sana yardım için parmağımı bile oynatacağımı sanman... Bana bu korkunç itirafta bulunman, hepsi delilik. Bu iş ne olursa olsun, ben karışmıyorum. Adıma senin uğruna leke sürdürtmek tehlikesini göze alır mıyım sanıyorsun? Gene nasıl iblisçe bir iş karıştırdığından bana ne?
es: —Estás loco, te lo repito... Loco por imaginar que vaya a alzar un dedo por ayudarte, loco por hacer esa confesión monstruosa. No quiero tener nada que ver con ese asunto, se trate de lo que se trate. ¿Me crees dispuesto a poner en peligro mi reputación por ti? ¿Qué me importa en qué tarea diabólica te hayas metido?
vi_translation: “You’re crazy, I’m telling you — crazy for thinking I would lift even a finger to help you, crazy for uttering this horrendous confession. I will have nothing to do with this, whatever it is. Do you think I would risk my reputation for you? Whatever devilish thing you’re doing, what does it have to do with me?”
tr_translation: “You are insane, I'm telling you. You think I would even lift a finger to help you... Confessing this horrible thing to me, it's all madness. No matter what this is about, I'm not getting involved. Do you think I would risk tarnishing my name for your sake? Why should I care about whatever devilish scheme you've gotten yourself into this time?”
es_translation: —You are crazy, I repeat... Crazy to imagine that I would lift a finger to help you, crazy to make that monstrous confession. I don't want to have anything to do with that matter, whatever it is. Do you think I'm willing to put my reputation at risk for you? What do I care about what diabolical task you've gotten yourself into?

en: “It was suicide, Alan.”
vi: “Đó là vụ tự tử, Alan.”
tr: “İntihardı, Alan.
es: —Se trata de un suicidio, Alan.
vi_translation: “It was a suicide, Alan.”
tr_translation: “It was suicide, Alan.”
es_translation: —This is a suicide, Alan.

en: “I am glad of that. But who drove him to it? You, I should fancy.”
vi: “Tôi rất mừng với điều đó. Nhưng ai dồn hắn đến việc đó? Anh hả, tôi cho là thế.”
tr: “İşte buna sevindim. Ama adamı intihara iten etken neydi? Muhtemelen senin yüzündendir.
es: —Me alegro de saberlo. Pero, ¿quién lo ha empujado al suicidio? Estoy seguro de que has sido tú.
vi_translation: “I am very happy with that. But who pushed him to do that? You, I suppose.”
tr_translation: “Well, I'm glad about that. But what was the factor that drove the man to suicide? It was probably because of you.”
es_translation: —I'm glad to hear that. But, who pushed him to suicide? I'm sure it was you.

en: “Do you still refuse to do this for me?”
vi: “Anh vẫn từ chối làm việc này cho tôi sao?”
tr: “Benim için bu işi yapmayı hâlâ reddediyorsun ha?
es: —¿Sigues negándote a hacer lo que te pido?
vi_translation: “Are you still refusing to do this for me?”
tr_translation: “You still refuse to do this job for me, huh?”
es_translation: —Are you still refusing to do what I ask?

en: “Of course I refuse. I will have absolutely nothing to do with it. I don’t care what shame comes on you. You deserve it all. I should not be sorry to see you disgraced, publicly disgraced. How dare you ask me, of all men in the world, to mix myself up in this horror? I should have thought you knew more about people’s characters. Your friend Lord Henry Wotton can’t have taught you much about psychology, whatever else he has taught you. Nothing will induce me to stir a step to help you. You have come to the wrong man. Go to some of your friends. Don’t come to me.”
vi: “Dĩ nhiên tôi từ chối. Tôi sẽ tuyệt đối không liên quan gì với nó. Tôi chẳng quan tâm nỗi nhục nào sẽ đến với anh. Anh hoàn toàn xứng đáng với nó. Tôi sẽ không lấy làm buồn khi được thấy anh bị ruồng bỏ, bị ruồng bỏ công khai. Sao anh dám yêu cầu tôi, giữa bao nhiêu người trên đời, dính líu vào vụ ghê rợn này? Tôi cứ tưởng anh hiểu biết nhiều hơn về tính cách con người. Huân tước Henry Wotton, bạn anh, không thể dạy anh nhiều về tâm lý học, dù ông ấy đã dạy anh nhiều điều khác. Chẳng có gì xui khiến được tôi nhích một bước để giúp anh. Anh đã đến nhầm người. Hãy đến ai đó khác trong số các bạn anh. Đừng đến gặp tôi.”
tr: “Tabii ki reddediyorum. Hiçbir şekilde karışmayacağım bu olaya. Bu yüzden rezil olsan da vız gelir. Her türlü rezilliği hak ettin sen. Senin, hem de elâlem içinde beş paralık olduğunu görsem de üzülmem. Dünyada başka adam kalmamış gibi bir de benden, böyle feci bir işe bulaşmamı hangi yüzle isteyebiliyorsun? İnsan karakterini daha iyi anladığını sanırdım. Dostun Lord Henry Wotton sana başka neler öğretti bilemem ya, ruhbilim dalında pek bir şey öğretmemiş olsa gerek. Dünyada hiçbir baskı benim sana yardım etmemi sağlayamaz. Yanlış adam seçtin. Dostlarından birine git. Bana gelme.
es: —Claro que me niego. No quiero tener nada que ver con ello. No me importa lo que te acarree. Mereces todo lo que te suceda. No me entristecerá verte deshonrado, públicamente deshonrado. ¿Cómo te atreves a pedirme, a mí especialmente, que tome parte en ese horror? Hubiera creído que entendías mejor la manera de ser de las personas. Quizá tu amigo lord Henry Wotton no te ha enseñado tanto sobre psicología, aunque te haya enseñado mucho sobre otras cosas. Nada me llevará a dar un paso por ayudarte. Te has equivocado de persona. Acude a alguno de tus amigos. No a mí.
vi_translation: “Of course I refuse. I will absolutely have nothing to do with it. I don't care what disgrace will come to you. You completely deserve it. I will not be saddened to see you being abandoned, being publicly abandoned. How dare you ask me, among so many people in the world, to get involved in this horrendous affair? I thought you understood more about human nature. Lord Henry Wotton, your friend, cannot teach you much about psychology, even though he has taught you many other things. Nothing could compel me to take a step to help you. You have come to the wrong person. Go to someone else among your friends. Do not come to see me.
tr_translation: “Of course I refuse. I will not get involved in this matter in any way. So, even if you become disgraced, it doesn't matter to me. You deserve every kind of disgrace. Even if I see you being humiliated in front of everyone, I wouldn't feel sorry. As if there were no other men left in the world, how can you ask me to get involved in such a terrible thing with what face? I thought you understood human character better. I don't know what else your friend Lord Henry Wotton has taught you, but he must not have taught you much in the field of psychology. No pressure in the world can make me help you. You chose the wrong man. Go to one of your friends. Don't come to me.”
es_translation: —Of course, I refuse. I don't want to have anything to do with it. I don't care what it brings you. You deserve everything that happens to you. It won't sadden me to see you dishonored, publicly dishonored. How dare you ask me, especially me, to take part in that horror? I would have thought you understood people's nature better. Maybe your friend Lord Henry Wotton hasn't taught you much about psychology, even though he has taught you a lot about other things. Nothing will make me take a step to help you. You have chosen the wrong person. Go to one of your friends. Not to me.

en: “Alan, it was murder. I killed him. You don’t know what he had made me suffer. Whatever my life is, he had more to do with the making or the marring of it than poor Harry has had. He may not have intended it, the result was the same.”
vi: “Alan, đó là tội sát nhân. Tôi đã giết hắn. Anh không biết hắn đã bắt tôi phải chịu những gì. Dẫu đời tôi có thế nào, hắn cũng đã liên quan đến việc tạo ra hoặc làm hỏng nó nhiều hơn là Harry đáng thương từng làm. Hắn có thể không chủ định, nhưng kết quả thì giống nhau.”
tr: “Alan, cinayetti bu. Onu ben öldürdüm. Bana neler çektirdi, bilemezsin ki! Yaşadığım hayat ne olursa olsun, bunu yapıp yıkmakta bu adamın etkisi zavallı Harry’ ninkinden kat kat fazlaydı. Belki bilerek isteyerek yapmadı, ama sonuç değişmez ki!
es: —Ha sido un asesinato, Alan. Lo he matado. No sabes lo que me ha hecho sufrir. Se piense lo que se quiera de mi vida, él ha contribuido más a destrozarla que el pobre Harry. Quizá no fuera su intención, pero el resultado ha sido el mismo.
vi_translation: “Alan, that's murder. I killed him. You don't know what he made me endure. No matter how my life turned out, he was more involved in creating or ruining it than poor Harry ever was. He may not have intended it, but the result is the same.”
tr_translation: “Alan, this is murder. I killed him. You have no idea what he put me through! No matter what kind of life I lived, this man's influence in causing destruction was far greater than poor Harry's. Maybe he didn't do it intentionally, but the result doesn't change!”
es_translation: —It has been a murder, Alan. I have killed him. You don't know how much he made me suffer. Think what you will of my life, he has contributed more to ruining it than poor Harry. Perhaps it wasn't his intention, but the result has been the same.

en: “Murder! Good God, Dorian, is that what you have come to? I shall not inform upon you. It is not my business. Besides, without my stirring in the matter, you are certain to be arrested. Nobody ever commits a crime without doing something stupid. But I will have nothing to do with it.”
vi: “Tội sát nhân! Chúa lòng lành, Dorian, anh đã đến mức này sao? Tôi sẽ không khai ra anh. Đó không phải việc của tôi. Vả lại, dẫu tôi có không nhúc nhích gì trong vụ này, anh chắc chắn vẫn sẽ bị bắt. Chưa ai từng phạm tội mà rồi lại không làm gì đó ngu ngốc. Nhưng tôi sẽ không dính vào nó.”
tr: “Cinayet mi, aman Tanrım! Sonunda işi buna mı vardırdın, Dorian? Seni ele verecek değilim. Beni ilgilendirmez. Zaten ben işi kurcalamasam da sen er geç ele geçersin. Suç işleyenler mutlaka bir aptallık yaparlar. Ama bu işe ben bulaşmayacağım.
es: —¡Asesinato! ¡Cielo santo, Dorian! ¿A eso has llegado finalmente? No te denunciaré. No es asunto mío. Además, sin necesidad de que yo mueva un dedo acabarán por detenerte. Nadie comete nunca un delito sin hacer algo estúpido. Pero me niego a intervenir.
vi_translation: “Murder! Good Lord, Dorian, have you gone this far? I will not turn you in. That is not my business. Besides, even if I do nothing in this matter, you will surely be caught. No one has ever committed a crime without doing something foolish afterward. But I will not get involved in it.”
tr_translation: “Murder, oh my God! Did you finally come to this, Dorian? I won't turn you in. It doesn't concern me. Even if I don't investigate, you'll get caught sooner or later. Criminals always make a mistake. But I won't get involved in this.”
es_translation: —Murder! Good heavens, Dorian! Is that what you've come to at last? I won't turn you in. It's none of my business. Besides, without me lifting a finger, they'll end up catching you. No one ever commits a crime without doing something stupid. But I refuse to get involved.

en: “You must have something to do with it. Wait, wait a moment; listen to me. Only listen, Alan. All I ask of you is to perform a certain scientific experiment. You go to hospitals and dead-houses, and the horrors that you do there don’t affect you. If in some hideous dissecting-room or fetid laboratory you found this man lying on a leaden table with red gutters scooped out in it for the blood to flow through, you would simply look upon him as an admirable subject. You would not turn a hair. You would not believe that you were doing anything wrong. On the contrary, you would probably feel that you were benefiting the human race, or increasing the sum of knowledge in the world, or gratifying intellectual curiosity, or something of that kind. What I want you to do is merely what you have often done before. Indeed, to destroy a body must be far less horrible than what you are accustomed to work at. And, remember, it is the only piece of evidence against me. If it is discovered, I am lost; and it is sure to be discovered unless you help me.”
vi: “Anh phải dính líu ít nhiều vào nó thôi. Chờ, chờ một chút; hãy nghe tôi. Chỉ cần nghe thôi, Alan. Tất cả những gì tôi xin anh chỉ là thực hiện một thí nghiệm khoa học nào đó. Anh đến bệnh viện và nhà xác, và những việc ghê rợn mà anh làm ở đấy không tác động được đến anh. Nếu trong phòng mổ gớm guốc nào đó hoặc phòng thí nghiệm hôi hám nào đó, anh thấy người này nằm trên một cái bàn bằng chì với các máng đỏ múc vào nó để máu chảy qua, anh sẽ chỉ nhìn hắn như một đối tượng đáng ngưỡng mộ. Anh sẽ không buồn máy mắt. Anh sẽ không nghĩ là anh làm gì đó sai. Trái lại, chắc anh sẽ cảm thấy rằng anh đang giúp ích cho nhân loại, hoặc làm gia tăng tổng vốn kiến thức thế gian, hoặc thỏa sự tò mò trí tuệ, hoặc thứ gì đó đại loại thế. Những gì mà tôi cần anh làm cũng chỉ là những gì anh thường xuyên làm trước đây. Thật ra thì tiêu hủy một cái xác chắc hẳn là việc ít khủng khiếp hơn nhiều so với những gì anh đã quen làm. Và, hãy nhớ, đó là bằng chứng duy nhất chống lại tôi. Nếu nó bị phát hiện ra, tôi thua; và chắc chắn nó sẽ bị phát hiện ra trừ phi anh giúp tôi.”
tr: “İstemesen de bulaşacaksın, Alan. Dur, bekle bir dakika, dinle beni. Yalnızca dinle, Alan. Benim senden istediğim bilimsel bir deney yapmandan ibaret. Hastanelere, morglara falan gidiyorsun, oralarda yaptığın iğrenç işler seni sarsmıyor. Eğer ürkünç bir otopsi odasında, kokudan geçilmeyen bir laboratuvarda görsen bu adamı... Kan aksın diye olukları olan kurşun bir masa üstünde bulsan, güzel bir inceleme konusu olarak görürdün. Kılın bile kıpırdamazdı. Yaptığının kötü bir iş olduğunu düşünmezdin. Tersine, insanlığın yararına çalıştığını düşünürdün, yeryüzündeki bilgi dağarcığına katkıda bulunduğun, entelektüel bir merakı giderdiğin falan gibi şeyler. Benim senden istediğim şey, senin şimdiye kadar kaç kez yapmış olduğun bir şey. Hatta bir cesedi ortadan kaldırmak senin genelde yaptığın işlerden çok daha az korkunç olsa gerek! Sonra unutma ki bu ceset bana karşı kullanılabilecek tek kanıt. Bulunursa benim mahvolduğum gündür. Ki sen bana yardım etmezsen bulunacağı da kesin.
es: —Tendrás que hacerlo. Espera, espera un momento; escúchame. Sólo tienes que oírme. Todo lo que te pido es que lleves a cabo un determinado experimento científico. Vas a los hospitales y a los depósitos de cadáveres y los horrores que ves allí no te afectan. Si en una espantosa sala de disección o en un laboratorio maloliente encontraras a un ser humano sobre una mesa de plomo al que se han hecho unas incisiones rojas para permitir que salga la sangre, lo mirarías como una cosa admirable. No te inmutarías. No pensarías que estabas haciendo nada reprobable. Considerarías, por el contrario, que trabajabas en beneficio de la raza humana, o que aumentabas su caudal de conocimientos, o satisfacías su curiosidad intelectual, o algo por el estilo. Lo que quiero que hagas es, sencillamente, algo que ya has hecho muchas veces. A decir verdad, destruir un cadáver debe de ser mucho menos horrible que lo que estás acostumbrado a hacer.
