es: Dorian era uno de sus invitados preferidos, y siempre le decía que se alegraba muchísimo de no haberlo conocido de joven. «Sé, querido mío, que me hubiera enamorado perdidamente de usted», solía decir, «y que me habría liado la manta a la cabeza por su causa. Es una suerte que nadie hubiera pensado en usted por entonces. Cabe, de todos modos, que la idea de la manta no me atrajera demasiado, porque nunca llegué a coquetear con nadie. Aunque creo que la culpa fue más bien de Narborough. Era terriblemente miope, y se obtiene muy poco placer engañando a un marido que no ve absolutamente nada».
vi_translation: Dorian was one of the people she was particularly fond of, and she always told him that she was extremely happy not to have known him when she was young. “I know, dear, that I might have gone madly in love with you,” she often said, “and thrown my cap over the windmill for you. Luckily, you weren't even thought of back then. Besides, our clothes were too ugly, and the windmill too calm, so I never even had a single flirtation with anyone. However, that was entirely Narborough's fault. He was terribly nearsighted, and there was no fun in deceiving a husband who never saw anything.”
tr_translation: Dorian was one of her favorites. Lady Narborough always used to tell the young man that she was grateful she hadn't met him in her youth. “I know, my dear, I would have fallen madly in love with you,” she would say. “I would have sacrificed everything for you. Fortunately, you weren't even a thought in your parents' minds back then. Actually, I never even tried to flirt with anyone. But that was Narborough's fault. He was so nearsighted! What's the fun in cheating on a husband who can't even see the tip of his own nose?”
es_translation: Dorian was one of her favorite guests, and she always told him that she was very glad not to have known him when she was young. “I know, my dear, that I would have fallen madly in love with you,” she used to say, “and that I would have thrown caution to the wind for your sake. It's a good thing no one thought of you back then. However, it may be that the idea of throwing caution to the wind didn't appeal to me much, because I never ended up flirting with anyone. Although I think the blame was more Narborough's. He was terribly nearsighted, and there's very little pleasure in deceiving a husband who can't see a thing.”

en: Her guests this evening were rather tedious. The fact was, as she explained to Dorian, behind a very shabby fan, one of her married daughters had come up quite suddenly to stay with her, and, to make matters worse, had actually brought her husband with her. “I think it is most unkind of her, my dear,” she whispered. “Of course I go and stay with them every summer after I come from Homburg, but then an old woman like me must have fresh air sometimes, and besides, I really wake them up. You don’t know what an existence they lead down there. It is pure unadulterated country life. They get up early, because they have so much to do, and go to bed early, because they have so little to think about. There has not been a scandal in the neighbourhood since the time of Queen Elizabeth, and consequently they all fall asleep after dinner. You shan’t sit next either of them. You shall sit by me and amuse me.”
vi: Khách khứa chiều ấy khá chán. Chuyện là, như bà giải thích cho Dorian đằng sau một cái quạt rất sờn, một trong các cô con gái đã kết hôn của bà đột ngột chuyển đến ở với bà, và, để làm cho mọi việc tệ hơn, còn đem cả chồng theo. “Tôi nghĩ con bé quá xấu tính, cậu ơi,” bà thì thào. “Dĩ nhiên tôi đến ở với chúng nó mọi mùa hè sau khi tôi về từ Homburg, nhưng dù gì thì một bà già như tôi đôi lúc cũng phải có không khí trong lành, và ngoài ra, tôi thật sự khuấy động chúng. Cậu không biết chúng trải qua một cuộc sống thế nào dưới đó đâu. Một cách sinh hoạt thôn quê mộc mạc thuần phác. Chúng dậy sớm vì có rất nhiều việc phải làm, và ngủ sớm vì có rất ít việc phải nghĩ. Chẳng có vụ bê bối nào trong xóm từ thời Nữ hoàng Elizabeth, do đó mà chúng nó đứa nào cũng ngủ thiếp đi sau bữa tối. Cậu sẽ không phải ngồi cạnh cả hai đứa chúng nó. Cậu sẽ ngồi cạnh tôi, và làm tôi vui.”
tr: O geceki çağrılılar bir hayli can sıkıcıydı. Leydi hazretleri elindeki iyice eski yelpazeyi yüzüne siper ederek Dorian’a anlattı: Evli kızlarından biri durup dururken ona gece yatısına gelmiş ve bu yetmezmiş gibi kocasını da birlikte getirmiş. Leydi Narborough, “Kızım çok ayıp etti doğrusu, hayatım,” diye fısıldadı. “Gerçi ben her yaz Hamburg dönüşü gidip onlarda kalıyorum, benim gibi ihtiyar bir kadının arada bir temiz hava alması gerekir. Hem zaten, inan, sayemde biraz canlanıyorlar. O yerde nasıl bir yaşam sürdüklerini bilsen aklın durur. Saf, köy yaşantısı. Sabahleyin erkenden kalkıyorlar, çünkü yapacak pek çok işleri var; akşamleyin de erkenden yatıyorlar, çünkü düşünecek hiçbir şeyleri yok. O yörede Kraliçe Elizabeth’in çağından bu yana hiç skandal olmamış, bu yüzden akşam yemeğinden sonra oturdukları yerde uyuyakalıyorlar. Seni onların yanına oturtmayacağım. Sen benim yanıma oturup beni eğlendireceksin.
es: Sus invitados de aquella noche eran personas más bien aburridas. La verdad, le explicó la anfitriona a Dorian Gray desde detrás de un abanico bastante venido a menos, era que una de sus hijas casadas se había presentado de repente para pasar una temporada con ella y, para empeorar las cosas, lo había hecho acompañada por su marido. —Creo que ha sido una crueldad por su parte, querido mío —le susurró—. Es cierto que yo los visito todos los veranos al regresar de Homburg, pero una anciana como yo necesita aire fresco a veces y, además, consigo despertarlos. No se puede imaginar la existencia que llevan. Vida rural en estado puro. Se levantan pronto porque tienen mucho que hacer, y también se acuestan pronto porque apenas tienen nada en qué pensar. No ha habido un escándalo por los alrededores desde los tiempos de la reina Isabel, y en consecuencia todos se quedan dormidos después de cenar. Haga el favor de no sentarse junto a ninguno de los dos. Siéntese a mi lado.
vi_translation: The guests that afternoon were quite boring. The thing is, as she explained to Dorian behind a very worn fan, one of her married daughters had suddenly moved in with her, and, to make matters worse, had brought her husband along. "I think she's very mean, dear," she whispered. "Of course, I stay with them every summer after I return from Homburg, but after all, an old lady like me sometimes needs fresh air, and besides, I really stir them up. You have no idea what kind of life they lead down there. A simple, rustic country life. They wake up early because there's so much to do, and go to bed early because there's so little to think about. There hasn't been a scandal in the village since the time of Queen Elizabeth, so they all fall asleep after dinner. You won't have to sit next to both of them. You will sit next to me and make me happy."
tr_translation: The guests that night were quite annoying. Lady Narborough shielded her face with an old fan and told Dorian: One of her married daughters had suddenly come to stay the night, and as if that wasn't enough, she had brought her husband along. Lady Narborough whispered, “My daughter was very rude, my dear.” “Although I go and stay with them every summer on my way back from Hamburg, an old woman like me needs to get some fresh air from time to time. And besides, believe me, I bring a bit of life to them. If you knew what kind of life they lead there, you'd be astonished. Simple, village life. They wake up early in the morning because they have a lot to do; they go to bed early in the evening because they have nothing to think about. There hasn't been a scandal in that area since the time of Queen Elizabeth, so they fall asleep where they sit after dinner. I won't sit you next to them. You will sit next to me and entertain me.”
es_translation: His guests that night were rather boring people. The truth, the hostess explained to Dorian Gray from behind a rather shabby fan, was that one of her married daughters had suddenly shown up to spend some time with her and, to make matters worse, she had done so accompanied by her husband. —I believe it was cruel of you, my dear —she whispered—. It is true that I visit them every summer upon returning from Homburg, but an old woman like me needs fresh air sometimes and, besides, I manage to wake them up. You cannot imagine the existence they lead. Pure rural life. They get up early because they have a lot to do, and they also go to bed early because they have hardly anything to think about. There hasn't been a scandal around here since the days of Queen Elizabeth, and consequently, everyone falls asleep after dinner. Please do not sit next to either of them. Sit next to me.

Multiple_ents: ['lady alice chapman', 'lady ruxton', 'ernest harrowde', 'dorian', 'ruxto', 'erlynne', 'erlynn', 'ruxton', 'alice chapma', 'ernest harrowden', 'alice chapman', 'ms erlynne']
en: Dorian murmured a graceful compliment and looked round the room. Yes: it was certainly a tedious party. Two of the people he had never seen before, and the others consisted of Ernest Harrowden, one of those middle-aged mediocrities so common in London clubs who have no enemies, but are thoroughly disliked by their friends; Lady Ruxton, an overdressed woman of forty-seven, with a hooked nose, who was always trying to get herself compromised, but was so peculiarly plain that to her great disappointment no one would ever believe anything against her; Mrs. Erlynne, a pushing nobody, with a delightful lisp and Venetian-red hair; Lady Alice Chapman, his hostess’s daughter, a dowdy dull girl, with one of those characteristic British faces that, once seen, are never remembered; and her husband, a red-cheeked, white-whiskered creature who, like so many of his class, was under the impression that inordinate joviality can atone for an entire lack of ideas.
vi: Dorian khẽ nói một lời ngợi khen duyên dáng, và nhìn quanh phòng. Đúng: quả là một buổi tiệc nhạt nhẽo. Trong số họ có hai người mà cậu chưa từng thấy trước đây, còn những người khác gồm có Ernest Harrowden, một trong số các thường dân trung niên rất phổ biến ở các câu lạc bộ London, một người không có kẻ thù, nhưng bị bạn bè ghét cay ghét đắng; bà Ruxton, một phụ nữ ăn diện quá mức, bốn mươi bảy tuổi, mũi quặp, luôn cố tình để mình bị làm hại, nhưng chất phác một cách đặc biệt đến nỗi chưa từng có ai chịu tin vào bất cứ chuyện gì chống lại bà mới chán; bà Erlynne, một kẻ vô danh dám nghĩ dám làm, với giọng nói ngọng thú vị và mái tóc đỏ Venice; cô Alice Chapman, con gái bà chủ tiệc, một cô gái đần độn ăn bận lạc mốt, có một trong các bộ mặt đặc Anh mà ai thấy một lần là chẳng bao giờ nhớ được; và chồng cô ấy, một tạo vật má đỏ, tóc mai trắng, kẻ mà, giống như nhiều người cùng giai cấp, cứ ngỡ rằng thái độ vui vẻ quá mức có thể bù đắp được sự thiếu vắng hoàn toàn về tư tưởng.
tr: Dorian ağzında kibar bir iltifat geveleyerek çevresine bakındı. Evet, gerçekten de can sıkıcı bir toplantıydı. Oradakilerden ikisini Dorian hiç görmemişti. Öbürleri de şunlardı: Ernest Harrowden, Londra kulüplerinde çok sık rastlanan, hiç düşmanı olmamakla birlikte dostlarının nefretini kazanan orta yaşlı, beylik tiplerden biri. Leydi Ruxton, durmadan kendi adını kötüye çıkarmaya çalışan ama son derece anlamsız olduğu için kimseyi böyle bir şeye inandıramayan ve buna pek üzülen kırk yedi yaşında, gaga burunlu, aşırı giyimli bir hanım. ms Erlynne, Venedik kırmızısı saçları, dilinin tatlı peltekliğiyle gözü yüksekte, girgin bir hiç. Leydi Alice Chapman, ev sahibinin kızı. Bir görenin bir daha asla anımsayamadığı tipik İngiliz yüzüyle rüküş, donuk bir kız. Ve kocası, sınıfından olan birçok kişi gibi, akıl fukaralığının açığını aşırı neşeyle kapayabileceğini sanan kırmızı yanaklı, beyaz sakallı bir yaratık.
es: Dorian murmuró el adecuado cumplido y recorrió el salón con la vista. Sí; no era mucho lo que cabía esperar de aquellos comensales. A dos de los invitados no los había visto nunca, y los restantes eran: Ernest Harrowden, una de las mediocridades de mediana edad que tanto abundan en los clubs londinenses y que carecen de enemigos pero a quienes sus amigos aborrecen cordialmente; lady Ruxton, una mujer de cuarenta y siete años y de nariz ganchuda, que se vestía con exageración y trataba siempre de colocarse en situaciones comprometidas, si bien, para gran desencanto suyo, nadie estaba nunca dispuesto a creer nada en contra suya, dada su extrema fealdad; la señora Erlynne, una arrivista que no era nadie, con un ceceo delicioso y cabellos de color rojo veneciano; lady Alice Chapman, la hija de la anfitriona, una aburrida joven sin la menor elegancia, con uno de esos característicos rostros británicos que, una vez vistos, jamás se recuerdan; y su marido, criatura de mejillas rubicundas y patillas canas que, como tantos de su clase, vivía convencido de que una desmedida jovialidad es disculpa suficiente para la absoluta falta de ideas.
vi_translation: Dorian softly uttered a graceful compliment and looked around the room. Indeed: it was a dull party. Among them were two people he had never seen before, and the others included Ernest Harrowden, one of those very common middle-aged civilians at London clubs, a man with no enemies but deeply hated by his friends; Mrs. Ruxton, an overly dressed woman of forty-seven, with a hooked nose, always deliberately putting herself in harm's way, but so particularly naive that no one ever believed anything against her to the point of frustration; Mrs. Erlynne, an audacious nobody with an interesting lisp and Venetian red hair; Miss Alice Chapman, the hostess's daughter, a dull-witted girl dressed out of fashion, with one of those distinctly English faces that once seen is never remembered; and her husband, a rosy-cheeked, white-whiskered creature who, like many of his class, believed that excessive cheerfulness could make up for the complete absence of thought.
tr_translation: Dorian mumbled a polite compliment as he looked around. Yes, it was indeed a boring gathering. Dorian had never seen two of the people there. The others were: Ernest Harrowden, one of those middle-aged, stereotypical types often seen in London clubs, who, despite having no enemies, managed to earn the hatred of his friends. Lady Ruxton, a forty-seven-year-old, hook-nosed, overdressed woman who constantly tried to ruin her own reputation but was so utterly meaningless that she couldn't convince anyone of it, and was quite upset about that. Ms. Erlynne, with her Venetian red hair and sweet lisp, an ambitious, intrusive nobody. Lady Alice Chapman, the host's daughter. A drab, dowdy girl with a typical English face that one could never remember after seeing it once. And her husband, a red-cheeked, white-bearded creature who, like many of his class, believed he could compensate for his lack of intelligence with excessive cheerfulness.
es_translation: Dorian murmured the appropriate compliment and scanned the room with his eyes. Yes; there wasn't much to be expected from those guests. Two of the guests he had never seen before, and the rest were: Ernest Harrowden, one of those middle-aged mediocrities that are so abundant in London clubs and who have no enemies but are cordially despised by their friends; Lady Ruxton, a forty-seven-year-old woman with a hooked nose, who dressed extravagantly and always tried to place herself in compromising situations, although, much to her disappointment, no one was ever willing to believe anything against her, given her extreme ugliness; Mrs. Erlynne, a social climber who was a nobody, with a delightful lisp and Venetian red hair; Lady Alice Chapman, the hostess's daughter, a boring young woman without the slightest elegance, with one of those characteristic British faces that, once seen, are never remembered; and her husband, a creature with ruddy cheeks and gray sideburns who, like so many of his kind, lived convinced that excessive joviality was sufficient excuse for the absolute lack of ideas.

en: He was rather sorry he had come, till Lady Narborough, looking at the great ormolu gilt clock that sprawled in gaudy curves on the mauve-draped mantelshelf, exclaimed: “How horrid of Henry Wotton to be so late! I sent round to him this morning on chance and he promised faithfully not to disappoint me.”
vi: Dorian thấy khá hối hận vì đã đến đây, cho đến khi bà Narborough, nhìn vào cái đồng hồ lớn bằng đồng mạ vàng đang nằm ưỡn ẹo các đường cong hoa mỹ ở cái giá treo màn tím nhạt bên trên lò sưởi, la lớn: “Sao mà Henry Wotton đến muộn khiếp vậy! Sáng nay tôi có nhắn hú họa đến tận nhà anh ấy, và anh ấy hứa chắc chắn là sẽ không làm tôi thất vọng.”
tr: Dorian buraya geldiği için pişman olmaya başlamıştı ki ev sahibesi şömine rafının leylak rengi örtüsü üstünde gösterişli kıvrımlarla duran büyük, yaldızlı pirinç saate bakarak, “Henry Wotton’un bu kadar geç kalması da hınzırlık ama!” dedi. “Bu sabah haber yolladım, beni kırmayacağına söz verdi.
es: Estaba ya bastante arrepentido de haber aceptado la invitación cuando lady Narborough, mirando al gran reloj dorado que dilataba sus llamativas curvas sobre la repisa de la chimenea, cubierta de tela malva, exclamó —¡Qué mal me parece que Henry Wottom llegue tan tarde! Esta mañana, al azar, he mandado a un propio a su casa, y ha prometido con gran seriedad no defraudarme.
vi_translation: Dorian felt quite regretful for having come here, until Mrs. Narborough, looking at the large gilded bronze clock that was languidly curving its ornate lines on the pale purple curtain holder above the fireplace, exclaimed loudly: "Why is Henry Wotton so terribly late! This morning I sent a message to his house on a whim, and he promised me he would definitely not disappoint me."
tr_translation: Dorian had just begun to regret coming here when the hostess, looking at the large, gilded brass clock with its ostentatious curves on the lilac-colored cloth of the mantelpiece, said, "It's quite naughty of Henry Wotton to be this late!" "I sent word this morning, and he promised he wouldn't disappoint me."
es_translation: He was already quite regretful for having accepted the invitation when Lady Narborough, looking at the large golden clock that spread its striking curves over the mantelpiece, covered with mauve cloth, exclaimed —How bad it seems to me that Henry Wottom is arriving so late! This morning, on a whim, I sent a messenger to his house, and he promised with great seriousness not to disappoint me.

en: It was some consolation that Harry was to be there, and when the door opened and he heard his slow musical voice lending charm to some insincere apology, he ceased to feel bored.
vi: Harry mà ở đây thì cũng an ủi được phần nào, rồi khi cửa mở và cậu nghe cái giọng nói du dương từ tốn của y nêm thêm chút duyên dáng cho lời tạ lỗi thiếu chân tình nào đó, cậu không thấy buồn nữa.
tr: Neyse, Henry’nin geleceğini bilmek bir avuntuydu, hiç değilse. Biraz sonra kapı açılıp da onun yapmacık bir özre tatlılık katan o aheste, ezgili sesini duyunca Dorian Gray’in bütün sıkıntısı dağıldı.
es: Era un consuelo contar con la compañía de Harry, y cuando se abrió la puerta y Dorian oyó su voz, lenta y melodiosa, que prestaba encanto a una disculpa poco sincera por su retraso, le abandonó el aburrimiento.
vi_translation: If Harry were here, it would be somewhat comforting, and when the door opened and he heard the melodious, deliberate voice adding a touch of charm to some insincere apology, he no longer felt sad.
tr_translation: Anyway, knowing that Henry would come was a consolation, at least. When the door opened a little later and he heard that slow, melodious voice of his that added sweetness to a feigned apology, all of Dorian Gray's anxiety vanished.
es_translation: It was a comfort to have Harry's company, and when the door opened and Dorian heard his slow and melodious voice, which lent charm to an insincere apology for his tardiness, his boredom left him.

en: But at dinner he could not eat anything. Plate after plate went away untasted. Lady Narborough kept scolding him for what she called “an insult to poor Adolphe, who invented the menu specially for you,” and now and then Lord Henry looked across at him, wondering at his silence and abstracted manner. From time to time the butler filled his glass with champagne. He drank eagerly, and his thirst seemed to increase.
vi: Nhưng cậu không thể ăn gì trong bữa tối. Hết đĩa này đến đĩa khác rời đi mà chưa hề được nếm. Bà Narborough cứ trách cậu vì cái mà bà gọi là “sự xúc phạm đến Adolphe tội nghiệp, người đã sáng chế ra cái thực đơn này để dành riêng cho cậu,” và thỉnh thoảng huân tước Henry lại nhìn qua cậu, ngạc nhiên trước sự im lặng và thái độ lơ đãng của cậu. Đôi lúc, quản gia lại rót đầy sâm-panh vào ly của cậu. Cậu hăm hở uống, và cơn khát của cậu dường như cứ cồn cào hơn lên.
tr: Gelgelelim yemekte hiçbir şey yiyemedi. Önüne konan tabaklar el sürülmeden kaldırılıyordu. Leydi Narborough, “Bu mönüyü senin için özel hazırlayan zavallı Adolphe’u küçük düşürüyorsun,” diyerek onu paylayıp duruyor, Lord Henry de arada bir karşıdan bakarak ondaki bu sessizlikle dalgınlığı anlamaya çalışıyordu. Arada uşak kadehine şampanya doldurdukça Dorian susamış gibi içiyor, içtikçe de sanki susuzluğu artıyordu.
es: Durante la cena, sin embargo, fue incapaz de comer. Los criados le fueron retirando plato tras plato sin que probase nada. Lady Narborough no cesó de reprenderlo por lo que ella calificaba de «insulto al pobre Adolphe, que ha inventado el menú especialmente para usted», y alguna vez lord Henry lo miró desde el otro lado de la mesa, sorprendido de su silencio y su aire distante. De cuando en cuando el mayordomo le llenaba la copa de champán. Dorian Gray bebía con avidez, pero su sed iba en aumento.
vi_translation: But he couldn't eat anything at dinner. Dish after dish was taken away untouched. Mrs. Narborough kept scolding him for what she called “an affront to poor Adolphe, who had devised the menu especially for him,” and occasionally Lord Henry glanced at him, surprised by his silence and distracted demeanor. From time to time, the butler refilled his glass with champagne. He drank eagerly, and his thirst seemed to grow more intense.
tr_translation: However, he couldn't eat anything at the meal. The plates placed in front of him were taken away untouched. Lady Narborough kept scolding him, saying, "You're humiliating poor Adolphe, who prepared this menu especially for you," while Lord Henry occasionally looked across, trying to understand his silence and distraction. Whenever the servant filled his glass with champagne, Dorian drank as if he were thirsty, and the more he drank, the thirstier he seemed to become.
es_translation: During dinner, however, he was unable to eat. The servants kept removing one dish after another without him tasting anything. Lady Narborough did not stop scolding him for what she called "an insult to poor Adolphe, who has invented the menu especially for you," and occasionally Lord Henry looked at him from the other side of the table, surprised by his silence and distant demeanor. From time to time the butler would fill his glass with champagne. Dorian Gray drank eagerly, but his thirst kept increasing.

en: “Dorian,” said Lord Henry at last, as the chaud-froid was being handed round, “what is the matter with you to-night? You are quite out of sorts.”
vi: “Dorian,” rốt cuộc huân tước Henry nói, khi món chaud-froid1 được chuyền quanh, “tối nay cậu có chuyện gì thế? Cậu có vẻ rất khó chịu. 1 Thịt đông.
tr: En sonunda, chaud-froid9 dağıtıldığı sırada Lord Henry, “Dorian,” dedi. “Neyin var senin bu gece? Pek keyifsizsin.
es: —Dorian —dijo finalmente lord Henry, mientras se servía el chaud froíd—, ¿qué te pasa esta noche? Pareces abatido.
vi_translation: “Dorian,” Lord Henry finally said, as the chaud-froid was being passed around, “what's the matter with you tonight? You seem very upset.” 1 Frozen meat.
tr_translation: In the end, as the chaud-froid9 was being served, Lord Henry said, "Dorian." "What's wrong with you tonight? You seem quite out of sorts."
es_translation: —Dorian —said Lord Henry finally, while serving himself the chaud froid—, what is wrong with you tonight? You seem downcast.

en: “I believe he is in love,” cried Lady Narborough, “and that he is afraid to tell me for fear I should be jealous. He is quite right. I certainly should.”
vi: “Tôi tin là cậu ấy đang yêu,” bà Narborough kêu lên, “và cậu ấy sợ kể cho tôi nghe vì lo là tôi sẽ ghen. Cậu ấy hoàn toàn đúng đấy. Tôi chắc chắn sẽ ghen.
tr: Leydi Narborough, “Bence Dorian âşık!” diye araya girdi. “Ama kıskanırım diye korkusundan bana söylemeyi göze alamıyor. Çok da doğru düşünüyor. Gerçekten kıskanırım.
es: —Creo que está enamorado —exclamó lady Narborough—, y no se atreve a decírmelo por temor a que sienta celos. Y tiene toda la razón, porque los sentiría.
vi_translation: "I believe he is in love," exclaimed Mrs. Narborough, "and he is afraid to tell me because he worries that I will be jealous. He is absolutely right. I would certainly be jealous."
tr_translation: Lady Narborough interrupted, "But Dorian is in love!" "However, he doesn't dare tell me for fear that I might be jealous. He's quite right to think so. I really would be jealous."
es_translation: —I believe he is in love —exclaimed Lady Narborough—, and he doesn't dare to tell me for fear that I might feel jealous. And he is absolutely right, because I would feel jealous.

Multiple_ents: ['ferroll', 'dorian', 'dorian gray', 'leydi narborough', 'ferrol', 'narborough', 'lady narborough', 'madam ferrol', 'madame de ferrol']
en: “Dear Lady Narborough,” murmured Dorian, smiling, “I have not been in love for a whole week—not, in fact, since Madame de Ferrol left town.”
vi: “Thưa bà Narborough,” Dorian lẩm bẩm, mỉm cười, “tôi không được yêu cả tuần nay rồi — thật sự là không được yêu từ khi ma-đam de Ferrol rời thành phố.”
tr: Dorian gülümseyerek, “Sevgili Leydi Narborough,” diye mırıldandı. “Bir hafta var ki kimseye gönül vermedim. Yani madam Ferrol’un Londra’dan ayrılışından beri.
es: —Mi querida lady Narborough —murmuró Dorian Gray sonriendo—. Llevo sin enamorarme toda una semana; exactamente desde que madame de Ferroll abandonó Londres.
vi_translation: "Dear Mrs. Narborough," Dorian murmured, smiling, "I haven't been in love for a whole week — truly not since Madame de Ferrol left town."
tr_translation: Dorian smiled and murmured, "Dear Lady Narborough," "It has been a week since I have given my heart to anyone. That is, since Madam Ferrol left London."
es_translation: —My dear Lady Narborough —murmured Dorian Gray, smiling—. I haven't fallen in love for a whole week; precisely since Madame de Ferroll left London.

en: “How you men can fall in love with that woman!” exclaimed the old lady. “I really cannot understand it.”
vi: “Sao mà đàn ông các cậu lại có thể yêu được người đàn bà ấy!” bà già la lên. “Tôi thật sự không thể hiểu nổi.”
tr: Yaşlı hanım, “Siz erkekler de!” diye bağırdı. “O kadına nasıl âşık olabiliyorsunuz! Hiç anlayamıyorum.
es: —¡Cómo es posible que los hombres se enamoren de esa mujer! —exclamó la anciana señora—. Es algo que no consigo entender.
vi_translation: “How can you men love that woman!” the old lady shouted. “I really can't understand.”
tr_translation: The old lady shouted, "You men!" "How can you fall in love with that woman! I just don't understand."
es_translation: —How is it possible that men fall in love with that woman! —exclaimed the elderly lady—. It is something I cannot understand.

en: “It is simply because she remembers you when you were a little girl, Lady Narborough,” said Lord Henry. “She is the one link between us and your short frocks.”
vi: “Đơn giản là vì cô ấy nhớ về bà khi bà còn là một thiếu nữ nhỏ nhắn, thưa bà Narborough,” huân tước Henry nói. “Cô ấy là mắt xích duy nhất giữa chúng tôi và những chiếc váy ngắn của bà.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Kendisi sizin çocukluğunuzu anımsatıyor da ondan, Leydi Narborough,” dedi. “Sizin kısa elbiselerinizle bizler arasındaki tek halka o.
es: —Se debe sencillamente a que madame de Ferroll se acuerda de la época en que usted no era más que una niña, lady Narborough —dijo lord Henry—. Es el único eslabón entre nosotros y los trajes cortos de usted.
vi_translation: “Simply because she remembers you as a petite young girl, Mrs. Narborough,” Lord Henry said. “She is the only link between us and your short dresses.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "He reminds you of your childhood, Lady Narborough," he said. "He is the only link between your short dresses and us."
es_translation: —It is simply because Madame de Ferroll remembers the time when you were just a child, Lady Narborough —said Lord Henry—. She is the only link between us and your short dresses.

en: “She does not remember my short frocks at all, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well at Vienna thirty years ago, and how décolletée she was then.”
vi: “Cô ấy không nhớ được tí nào về những chiếc váy ngắn của tôi đâu, huân tước Henry. Nhưng tôi nhớ cô ấy rất rõ ở Vienna ba mươi năm trước, và hồi ấy cô ấy décolletée1 thế nào.” 1 Mặc áo hở vai.
tr: “O benim kısa elbiselerimi hiç de anımsatmıyor, Lord Henry. Ama ben onu otuz yıl öncesinin Viyana’sından pek iyi anımsıyorum: O zaman nasıl décolletée gezdiğini falan.
es: —No se acuerda en absoluto de mis trajes cortos, lord Henry. Pero yo la recuerdo perfectamente en Viena hace treinta años, así como los escotes que llevaba por entonces.
vi_translation: “She doesn't remember anything about my short dresses, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well in Vienna thirty years ago, and how décolletée1 she was back then.” 1 Wear an off-shoulder top.
tr_translation: “It doesn't remind me of my short dresses at all, Lord Henry. But I remember her very well from Vienna thirty years ago: how she used to walk around décolletée and all.”
es_translation: —You don't remember my short dresses at all, Lord Henry. But I remember you perfectly in Vienna thirty years ago, as well as the necklines you wore back then.

en: “She is still décolletée,” he answered, taking an olive in his long fingers; “and when she is in a very smart gown she looks like an édition de luxe of a bad French novel. She is really wonderful, and full of surprises. Her capacity for family affection is extraordinary. When her third husband died, her hair turned quite gold from grief.”
vi: “Cô ấy vẫn còn décolletée,” y trả lời, nhặt một trái ô-liu bằng các ngón tay dài của mình; “và khi cô ấy mặc một chiếc áo dài rất sang thì trông cô ấy như một édition de luxe2 của một tiểu thuyết Pháp dở tệ. Cô ấy thật sự tuyệt vời, và đầy bất ngờ. “Khả năng yêu thương gia đình của cô ấy rất phi thường. Khi chồng thứ ba của cô ấy chết, tóc cô ấy đổi màu vàng óng vì thương tiếc. 2 Bản in cao cấp.
tr: Lord Henry o uzun parmaklarıyla bir zeytin alarak, “Kendisi şimdi de décolletée geziyor,” diye yanıtladı. “Çok şık giyindiği zamanlarda da kötü bir Fransız romanının de luxe basımını andırıyor. Gerçekten harika bir kadın, şaşırtmacalarla dolu. Hele aile sevgisi görülmedik bir şey. Üçüncü kocası öldüğünde zavallının saçları kederden sapsarı kesilmişti.
es: —Sigue siendo partidaria de los escotes —respondió lord Henry, cogiendo una aceituna con los dedos—, y cuando lleva un vestido muy elegante parece una édítion de luxe de una mala novela francesa. Es realmente maravillosa y siempre depara sorpresas. Su capacidad para el afecto familiar es extraordinaria. Al morir su tercer esposo, el cabello se le puso completamente dorado de la pena.
vi_translation: “She is still décolletée,” he replied, picking up an olive with his long fingers; “and when she wears a very elegant dress, she looks like a deluxe edition of a terribly bad French novel. She is truly wonderful, and full of surprises. “Her ability to love her family is extraordinary. When her third husband died, her hair turned golden from grief.” 2 Premium prints.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, taking an olive with his long fingers, replied, "She is now going around décolletée." "Even when she dresses very stylishly, she resembles a de luxe edition of a bad French novel. She is truly a marvelous woman, full of surprises. Especially her family affection is something unseen. When her third husband died, the poor woman's hair turned completely yellow from grief."
es_translation: —She still favors low necklines —replied Lord Henry, picking up an olive with his fingers—, and when she wears a very elegant dress, she looks like a deluxe edition of a bad French novel. She is truly wonderful and always full of surprises. Her capacity for family affection is extraordinary. When her third husband died, her hair turned completely golden from grief.

en: “How can you, Harry!” cried Dorian.
vi: “Sao anh có thể, Harry!” Dorian la lên.
tr: Dorian, “Harry, ayıp sana!” dedi.
es: —¡Harry, cómo te atreves! —protestó Dorian.
vi_translation: “How could you, Harry!” Dorian exclaimed.
tr_translation: Dorian said, "Harry, shame on you!"
es_translation: —Harry, how dare you! —protested Dorian.

en: “It is a most romantic explanation,” laughed the hostess. “But her third husband, Lord Henry! You don’t mean to say Ferrol is the fourth?”
vi: “Một lời giải thích vô cùng lãng mạn,” bà chủ tiệc bật cười. “Nhưng chồng thứ ba của cô ta cơ à, huân tước Henry! Anh không có ý nói Ferrol là thứ tư chứ.”
tr: Ev sahibesi, “Çok romantik bir yakıştırma,” diye güldü. “Ama siz, üçüncü kocası mı dediniz Lord Henry? Yani Ferrol dördüncü koca mı demek istiyorsunuz?
es: —Es una explicación sumamente romántica —rió la anfitriona—. Pero, ¡su tercer marido, lord Henry! ¿No querrá usted decir que Ferroll es el cuarto?
vi_translation: “A very romantic explanation,” the hostess laughed. “But her third husband, Lord Henry! You don't mean to say Ferrol is the fourth, do you?”
tr_translation: The hostess laughed, "A very romantic comparison." "But did you say her third husband, Lord Henry? Do you mean to say Ferrol is her fourth husband?"
es_translation: —It is an extremely romantic explanation —laughed the hostess—. But, her third husband, Lord Henry! Are you not suggesting that Ferroll is the fourth?

en: “Certainly, Lady Narborough.”
vi: “Đúng thế đấy, thưa bà Narborough.”
tr: “Elbette, hanımefendi.
es: —Efectivamente, lady Narborough.
vi_translation: “That's right, Mrs. Narborough.”
tr_translation: “Of course, madam.”
es_translation: —Indeed, Lady Narborough.

en: “I don’t believe a word of it.”
vi: “Tôi không tin tí nào.”
tr: “Tek kelimesine bile inanmıyorum.
es: —No creo una sola palabra.
vi_translation: "I don't believe it at all."
tr_translation: “I don't believe a single word.”
es_translation: —I don't believe a single word.

en: “Well, ask Mr. Gray. He is one of her most intimate friends.”
vi: “Vậy thì hãy hỏi mít-tơ Gray. Cậu ấy là một trong những người bạn gần gũi nhất của cô ta.”
tr: “Öyleyse mr Gray’e sorun. Kendisi o hanımın en yakın dostlarından biridir.
es: —Bien, pregunte al señor Gray. Es uno de sus amigos más íntimos.
vi_translation: “Then ask Mr. Gray. He is one of her closest friends.”
tr_translation: "Then ask Mr. Gray. He is one of that lady's closest friends."
es_translation: —Well, ask Mr. Gray. He is one of his closest friends.

en: “Is it true, Mr. Gray?”
vi: “Chuyện đó đúng không, mít-tơ Gray?”
tr: “Doğru mu bunlar, mr Gray?
es: —¿Es cierto, señor Gray?
vi_translation: “Is that true, Mr. Gray?”
tr_translation: “Are these true, Mr. Gray?”
es_translation: —Is it true, Mr. Gray?

en: “She assures me so, Lady Narborough,” said Dorian. “I asked her whether, like Marguerite de Navarre, she had their hearts embalmed and hung at her girdle. She told me she didn’t, because none of them had had any hearts at all.”
vi: “Cô ấy quả quyết như vậy, thưa bà Narborough,” Dorian nói. “Tôi hỏi cô ấy là có phải cô ấy, giống như Marguerite de Navarre, đã ướp tim họ và treo ở thắt lưng không. Cô ấy bảo tôi là cô ấy không làm thế, vì chẳng ai trong số họ có trái tim nào cả.”
tr: Dorian, “Kendisi yeminle öyle olduğunu söylüyor, efendim,” dedi. “Ben kendisine sordum: Hani Marguerite de Navarre gibi, kocalarının kalplerini mumyalayıp kemerine astı mı, diye. Bunu yapmadığını söyledi, çünkü hepsi de kalpsizmiş.
es: —Eso es lo que ella me ha asegurado, lady Narborough —respondió Dorian—. Le pregunté si, al igual que Margarita de Navarra, había embalsamado los corazones de los difuntos para colgárselos de la cintura. Me dijo que no, porque ninguno de ellos tenía corazón.
vi_translation: “She is so determined, Mrs. Narborough,” said Dorian. “I asked her if, like Marguerite de Navarre, she preserved their hearts and hung them at her waist. She told me she didn't, because none of them had any hearts at all.”
tr_translation: Dorian said, "He swears that it is so, sir." "I asked him: Did she, like Marguerite de Navarre, mummify their hearts and hang them on her belt? He said she did not, because they were all heartless."
es_translation: —That is what she assured me, Lady Narborough —replied Dorian—. I asked her if, like Margaret of Navarre, she had embalmed the hearts of the deceased to hang them from her waist. She told me no, because none of them had a heart.

en: “Four husbands! Upon my word that is trop de zêle.”
vi: “Bốn chồng! Thề danh dự, thế là trop de zèle1.”
tr: “Dört koca ha! Vay canına, tam trop de zèle –işgüzarlık– bu!
es: —¡Cuatro maridos! A fe mía que eso es trop de zéle.
vi_translation: "Four husbands! I swear on my honor, that's too much zeal."
tr_translation: “Four big ha! Wow, that's exactly trop de zèle –overzealousness– this is!”
es_translation: —Four husbands! By my faith, that is trop de zéle.

en: “Trop d’audace, I tell her,” said Dorian.
vi: “Trop d'audace2, tôi bảo cô ấy thế,” Dorian nói.
tr: Dorian, “Trop d’audace –gözükaralık– derim ben kendisine,” dedi.
es: -Trop d'audace, le dije yo —comentó Dorian Gray.
vi_translation: “Too much audacity2, I told her that,” Dorian said.
tr_translation: Dorian said, "Too much audacity –recklessness– I would say to him."
es_translation: —Trop d'audace, I told him —commented Dorian Gray.

en: “Oh! she is audacious enough for anything, my dear. And what is Ferrol like? I don’t know him.”
vi: 1 Quá sung. 2 Quá gan. “Ôi! Cô ấy đủ gan làm mọi thứ, bạn ơi. Còn Ferrol thì như thế nào? Tôi không biết y.”
tr: “Oo, cüret yönünden onun maşallahı vardır, hayatım. Şu Ferrol neye benziyor, peki? Hiç tanımıyorum.
es: —No es audacia lo que le falta, querido mío. Y, ¿cómo es Ferroll? No lo conozco.
vi_translation: Too excited. Too daring. “Oh! She has the guts to do anything, my friend. And what about Ferrol? I don't know him.”
tr_translation: “Oh, he is certainly daring, my dear. What does this Ferrol look like, then? I don't know him at all.”
es_translation: —It's not audacity that he lacks, my dear. And, what is Ferroll like? I don't know him.

en: “The husbands of very beautiful women belong to the criminal classes,” said Lord Henry, sipping his wine.
vi: “Mấy thằng chồng của gái đẹp toàn là bọn trộm cắp,” huân tước Henry vừa nói vừa nhắp rượu.
tr: Lord Henry, “Çok güzel kadınların kocaları ağır suç işleyenlerin sınıfından sayılır,” diyerek şarabından bir yudum aldı.
es: —Los maridos de mujeres muy hermosas pertenecen a la clase delictiva —dijo lord Henry, saboreando el vino.
vi_translation: "The husbands of beautiful women are all thieves," said Lord Henry as he sipped his drink.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "Husbands of very beautiful women are considered to be in the class of heavy criminals," he said, taking a sip of his wine.
es_translation: —Husbands of very beautiful women belong to the criminal class —said Lord Henry, savoring the wine.

en: Lady Narborough hit him with her fan. “Lord Henry, I am not at all surprised that the world says that you are extremely wicked.”
vi: Bà Narborough đập quạt vào y. “Huân tước Henry, tôi không ngạc nhiên tí nào với việc người đời bảo là anh cực kỳ đồi bại.”
tr: Leydi Narborough ona yelpazesiyle vurdu. “Lord Henry, dünya âlemin sizin için son derece kötü, hınzır bir adam demesine hiç şaşmıyorum.
es: Lady Narborough le golpeó con su abanico. —Lord Henry, no me sorprende en absoluto que el mundo diga de usted que es extraordinariamente malvado.
vi_translation: Mrs. Narborough tapped him with her fan. "Lord Henry, I am not at all surprised that people say you are extremely wicked."
tr_translation: Lady Narborough struck him with her fan. "Lord Henry, I am not at all surprised that the whole world says you are an extremely bad, mischievous man."
es_translation: Lady Narborough struck him with her fan. —Lord Henry, I am not at all surprised that the world says you are extraordinarily wicked.

en: “But what world says that?” asked Lord Henry, elevating his eyebrows. “It can only be the next world. This world and I are on excellent terms.”
vi: “Nhưng người nào nói vậy?” huân tước Henry nói, nhướng mày. “Chỉ có thể là người đời sau. Người đời này thì tôi có quan hệ rất tốt.”
tr: Lord Henry, “İyi ama hangi dünyaymış o?” diye kaşlarını kaldırdı. “Olsa olsa öteki dünyadır. Çünkü bu dünyayla benim aramdan su sızmıyor.
es: —Pero, ¿qué mundo dice eso? —preguntó lord Henry, alzando las cejas—. Sólo puede ser el mundo venidero. Este mundo y yo mantenemos excelentes relaciones.
vi_translation: “But who said that?” Lord Henry said, raising an eyebrow. “It could only be someone from the future. I have a very good relationship with people of this time.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry raised his eyebrows, "Well, which world is that?" "It must be the other world. Because there is no gap between this world and me."
es_translation: —But, which world says that? —asked Lord Henry, raising his eyebrows—. It can only be the world to come. This world and I maintain excellent relations.

en: “Everybody I know says you are very wicked,” cried the old lady, shaking her head.
vi: “Tất cả những ai tôi quen đều bảo anh rất đồi bại,” bà già kêu lên, lắc đầu.
tr: Yaşlı hanım başını sallayarak, “Tanıdığım herkes sizin çok hınzır olduğunuzu söylüyor,” dedi.
es: —Todas las personas que conozco dicen que es usted de lo más perverso —exclamó la anciana señora, moviendo la cabeza.
vi_translation: “Everyone I know says you are very depraved,” the old woman exclaimed, shaking her head.
tr_translation: The elderly lady nodded her head and said, "Everyone I know says that you are very mischievous."
es_translation: —All the people I know say that you are the most wicked —exclaimed the elderly lady, shaking her head.

en: Lord Henry looked serious for some moments. “It is perfectly monstrous,” he said, at last, “the way people go about nowadays saying things against one behind one’s back that are absolutely and entirely true.”
vi: Huân tước Henry trông có vẻ rất nghiêm túc được một lúc. “Gớm guốc thay,” rốt cuộc y nói, “cái cách mọi người ngày nay cứ xì xào đồn đại sau lưng ta những chuyện hoàn toàn tuyệt đối chính xác.”
tr: Lord Henry bir süre ciddi durdu. Sonunda, “Düpedüz rezalet yani!” dedi. “Bugünlerde herkes kişinin ardından öyle laflar çıkartıyor ki hepsi de kesinlikle, yüzde yüz doğru.
es: Lord Henry adoptó por unos instantes un aire serio. —Es perfectamente intolerable —dijo, finalmente— la manera en que la gente va por ahí diciendo, a espaldas de uno, cosas que son absoluta y completamente ciertas.
vi_translation: Lord Henry looked very serious for a moment. “How dreadful,” he finally said, “the way people nowadays gossip behind one's back about things that are absolutely and entirely true.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry stood serious for a while. Finally, he said, "It's an outright scandal!" "These days, everyone spreads such rumors about a person that they are absolutely, one hundred percent true."
es_translation: Lord Henry adopted a serious air for a moment. "It is perfectly intolerable," he said finally, "the way people go around saying, behind one's back, things that are absolutely and completely true."

en: “Isn’t he incorrigible?” cried Dorian, leaning forward in his chair.
vi: “Anh ta có phải là kẻ bất trị không?” Dorian kêu lên, nghiêng người trên ghế về phía trước.
tr: Dorian öne doğru eğilerek, “Bu adam yola gelmez, öyle değil mi?” dedi.
es: —¿Verdad que es incorregible? —exclamó Dorian, inclinándose hacia adelante en el asiento.
vi_translation: “Is he incorrigible?” Dorian exclaimed, leaning forward in his chair.
tr_translation: Dorian leaned forward and said, "This man won't come around, will he?"
es_translation: "Isn't he incorrigible?" exclaimed Dorian, leaning forward in his seat.

en: “I hope so,” said his hostess, laughing. “But really, if you all worship Madame de Ferrol in this ridiculous way, I shall have to marry again so as to be in the fashion.”
vi: “Tôi hy vọng thế,” bà chủ tiệc vừa cười vừa nói. “Nhưng thực sự là nếu tất cả các anh tôn sùng ma-đam de Ferrol theo cái kiểu lố bịch này thì tôi sẽ phải tái hôn để theo được mốt.”
tr: Ev sahibesi, “Öyledir umarım,” diye güldü. “Ama sahi söylüyorum, eğer hepiniz Madam Ferrol’a böyle ayılıp bayılıyorsanız benim de moda olabilmek için yeniden evlenmem gerekecek, demektir.
es: —Eso espero —dijo, riendo, la anfitriona—. Pero si todos ustedes adoran a madame de Ferroll de esa manera tan ridícula, tendré que volver a casarme para estar a la moda.
vi_translation: "I hope so," the hostess said with a smile. "But really, if all of you worship Madame de Ferrol in this ridiculous manner, I will have to remarry to keep up with the trend."
tr_translation: The hostess laughed, "I hope so." "But I'm serious, if you all are so enamored with Madam Ferrol, it means I'll have to get married again to be in fashion.""
es_translation: —I hope so —said the hostess, laughing—. But if all of you adore Madame de Ferroll in such a ridiculous manner, I will have to remarry to stay in fashion.

en: “You will never marry again, Lady Narborough,” broke in Lord Henry. “You were far too happy. When a woman marries again, it is because she detested her first husband. When a man marries again, it is because he adored his first wife. Women try their luck; men risk theirs.”
vi: “Bà sẽ chẳng bao giờ tái hôn đâu, bà Narborough,” huân tước Henry ngắt lời. “Bà quá hạnh phúc. Gái tái hôn vì ghét chồng đầu. Trai tái hôn vì mê vợ đầu. Gái thử thời vận; trai liều rủi may.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Siz bir daha asla evlenmeyeceksiniz, sayın Leydi,” dedi. “Bunu düşünmeyecek kadar mutlusunuz. Kadınların yeniden evlenmeleri ilk kocalarından nefret ettikleri içindir. Erkeklerin yeniden evlenmeleriyse ilk karılarına tapındıkları içindir. Kadınlar şanslarını denemek uğruna yaparlar bunu, erkeklerse şanslarını yitirmek pahasına.
es: —Nunca volverá usted a casarse, lady Narborough —intervino lord Henry—. Era usted demasiado feliz. Cuando una mujer vuelve a casarse es porque detestaba a su primer marido. Cuando un hombre vuelve a casarse es porque adoraba a su primera mujer. Las mujeres prueban suerte. Los hombres arriesgan la suya.
vi_translation: "You will never remarry, Mrs. Narborough," Lord Henry interrupted. "You are too happy. Women remarry because they hate their first husband. Men remarry because they are enamored with their first wife. Women take a chance; men take a risk."
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "You will never marry again, my lady," he said. "You are too happy to think about it. Women remarry because they hate their first husbands. Men remarry because they adore their first wives. Women do it to try their luck, men do it at the risk of losing theirs."
es_translation: —You will never remarry, Lady Narborough —interjected Lord Henry—. You were too happy. When a woman remarries, it is because she detested her first husband. When a man remarries, it is because he adored his first wife. Women try their luck. Men risk theirs.

en: “Narborough wasn’t perfect,” cried the old lady.
vi: “Narborough cũng không hoàn hảo đâu,” bà già kêu lên.
tr: Yaşlı hanım, “Kocam Narborough kusursuz değildi ki!” dedi.
es: —Narborough no era perfecto —exclamó la anciana señora.
vi_translation: “Narborough is not perfect either,” the old lady exclaimed.
tr_translation: The elderly lady said, "My husband Narborough was not perfect!"
es_translation: —Narborough was not perfect —exclaimed the elderly lady.

en: “If he had been, you would not have loved him, my dear lady,” was the rejoinder. “Women love us for our defects. If we have enough of them, they will forgive us everything, even our intellects. You will never ask me to dinner again after saying this, I am afraid, Lady Narborough, but it is quite true.”
vi: “Nếu ông ấy mà thế, chắc bà đã chẳng yêu ông ấy đâu, thưa bà,” là lời đối đáp. “Đàn bà yêu chúng tôi vì các nhược điểm của chúng tôi. Nếu chúng tôi có đủ nhiều cái đó thì họ sẽ tha thứ cho chúng tôi mọi thứ, thậm chí cả trí thông minh. Bà sẽ không bao giờ mời tôi đến ăn tối nữa, sau câu nói này, tôi e là vậy, phải không bà Narborough; nhưng nó hoàn toàn chính xác.”
tr: “Kusursuz olsaydı onu sevmezdiniz zaten, sayın hanımefendi! Kadınlar kusurlarımızdan ötürü severler bizi. Yeterince kusurumuz varsa her türlü aksaklığımızı bağışlarlar, zekâmızı bile. Bunu söyledim ya, biliyorum, beni bir daha hiç yemeğe çağırmayacaksınız, sayın leydi, ama ne yapayım, gerçek bu.
es: —Si lo hubiera sido, no lo hubiera usted amado, mi querida señora —fue la respuesta de lord Henry—. Las mujeres nos aman por nuestros defectos. Si tenemos los suficientes nos lo perdonan todo, incluida la inteligencia. Mucho me temo que después de esto nunca volverá usted a invitarme a cenar, lady Narborough, pero es completamente cierto.
vi_translation: “If he were like that, you probably wouldn't have loved him, madam,” was the reply. “Women love us for our weaknesses. If we have enough of those, they will forgive us for everything, even intelligence. You will never invite me to dinner again after this remark, I fear, will you, Mrs. Narborough; but it is entirely accurate.”
tr_translation: “If he were perfect, you wouldn't love him anyway, madam! Women love us for our flaws. If we have enough flaws, they forgive all our shortcomings, even our intelligence. Now that I've said this, I know you will never invite me to dinner again, my lady, but what can I do, this is the truth.”
es_translation: —If he had been, you would not have loved him, my dear lady —was Lord Henry's response—. Women love us for our defects. If we have enough of them, they forgive us everything, including intelligence. I very much fear that after this you will never invite me to dinner again, Lady Narborough, but it is completely true.

en: “Of course it is true, Lord Henry. If we women did not love you for your defects, where would you all be? Not one of you would ever be married. You would be a set of unfortunate bachelors. Not, however, that that would alter you much. Nowadays all the married men live like bachelors, and all the bachelors like married men.”
vi: “Dĩ nhiên là chính xác rồi, huân tước Henry. Nếu đàn bà chúng tôi không yêu các anh vì nhược điểm của các anh, thì tất cả các anh rồi sẽ ra làm sao? Không một ai trong số các anh sẽ có lúc lấy vợ. Các anh sẽ là một lũ độc thân bất hạnh. Không, dẫu sao thì điều ấy cũng chẳng thay đổi được các anh là mấy. Ngày nay ông nào có vợ cũng sống như người độc thân, còn ông nào độc thân thì cũng cứ như người có vợ.”
tr: “Elbette öyle, Lord Henry. Biz kadınlar sizleri kusurlarınızdan ötürü sevmeseydik haliniz nice olurdu? Bir tekiniz bile evlenemezdiniz. Bir bahtsız bekârlar sürüsü! Öte yandan bekâr kalmak da sizleri pek öyle değiştirmezdi ya! Günümüzde bütün evli erkekler bekâr hayatı sürüyor, bütün bekârlar da evliymiş gibi yaşıyor.
es: —Claro que es cierto, lord Henry. Si las mujeres no amaran a los hombres por sus defectos, ¿dónde estarían todos ustedes? Ninguno se habría casado. Serían una colección de solteros infelices. Aunque tampoco eso los habría cambiado mucho. En los días que corren todos los hombres casados viven como solteros, y todos los solteros como casados.
vi_translation: "Of course it's accurate, Lord Henry. If we women didn't love you for your weaknesses, what would become of all of you? None of you would ever get married. You would all be an unhappy bunch of bachelors. No, after all, that wouldn't change you much. Nowadays, a married man lives like a bachelor, and a bachelor lives like a married man."
tr_translation: “Of course, Lord Henry. If we women didn't love you for your flaws, what would become of you? Not a single one of you would be able to marry. A hapless herd of bachelors! On the other hand, remaining single wouldn't change you much either! Nowadays, all married men live like bachelors, and all bachelors live as if they were married.”
es_translation: —Of course it's true, Lord Henry. If women didn't love men for their flaws, where would all of you be? None would have gotten married. You would be a collection of unhappy bachelors. Although that wouldn't have changed you much either. Nowadays, all married men live like bachelors, and all bachelors like married men.

en: “Fin de siêcle,” murmured Lord Henry.
vi: "Fin de siècle1," huân tước Henry lẩm bẩm.
tr: Lord Henry, “Fin de siécle, yüzyılın sonu,” diye mırıldandı.
es: —Fin de siécle —murmuró lord Henry.
vi_translation: "End of the century," Lord Henry muttered.
tr_translation: Lord Henry murmured, "Fin de siècle, the end of the century."
es_translation: —End of the century —murmured Lord Henry.

en: “Fin du globe,” answered his hostess.
vi: "Fin du globe2," bà chủ tiệc đáp lại. 1 Hết thế kỷ. 2 Tận thế.
tr: Ev sahibesi, “Fin du globe, dünyanın sonu,” diye karşılık verdi.
es: —Fin de globe —respondió su anfitriona.
vi_translation: "End of the world2," the hostess replied. 1 End of the century. 2 Apocalypse.
tr_translation: The landlady replied, "Fin du globe, the end of the world."
es_translation: —End of the world —replied his hostess.

en: “I wish it were fin du globe,” said Dorian with a sigh. “Life is a great disappointment.”
vi: "Tôi mong nó là fin du globe," Dorian thở dài, nói. “Đời là cả một sự thất vọng vĩ đại.
tr: Dorian, “Keşke fin du globe olsaydı!” diye göğüs geçirdi. “Yaşamak öyle büyük bir hayal kırıklığı ki!
es: —Sí que me gustaría que fuese fin de globe —dijo Dorian con un suspiro—. La vida es una gran desilusión.
vi_translation: "I hope it is the end of the world," Dorian sighed, saying. "Life is one great disappointment."
tr_translation: Dorian sighed, "I wish it were the end of the world!" "Living is such a great disappointment!"
es_translation: —Yes, I would like it to be the end of the world —said Dorian with a sigh—. Life is a great disappointment.

en: “Ah, my dear,” cried Lady Narborough, putting on her gloves, “don’t tell me that you have exhausted life. When a man says that one knows that life has exhausted him. Lord Henry is very wicked, and I sometimes wish that I had been; but you are made to be good—you look so good. I must find you a nice wife. Lord Henry, don’t you think that Mr. Gray should get married?”
vi: “Ôi, cậu ơi,” bà Narborough la lên, xỏ găng vào, “đừng bảo tôi là cậu đã vắt kiệt Đời rồi. Khi ai đó nói thế thì người ta biết ngay là Đời đã vắt kiệt hắn. Huân tước Henry rất đồi bại, và đôi lúc tôi mong là tôi cũng thế; nhưng cậu được tạo ra để thành người tử tế — trông cậu thật là tử tế. Tôi phải kiếm cho cậu một cô vợ đẹp. Huân tước Henry, anh có nghĩ là mít-tơ Gray đây nên lấy vợ không?”
tr: Ev sahibesi eldivenlerini takarak, “Ah, güzelim, hayatı şimdiden tüketmişsin gibi konuşma öyle! Birisi böyle konuştuğu zaman, hayat onu tüketmiş demektir. Bak, Lord Henry çok kötü adam, çok hınzır. Arada ben de özenirim buna. Oysa sen iyilik için yaratılmışsın. Öyle melek gibi bir görünümün var ki içimden sana şöyle güzel bir eş bulmak geliyor. Lord Henry, sizce de mr Gray’in artık evlenmesi gerekmez mi?
es: —Ah, querido mío —exclamó lady Narborough calzándose los guantes—, no me diga que ya ha agotado la vida. Cuando un hombre dice eso, ya se sabe que es la vida la que lo ha agotado a él. Lord Henry es muy perverso, y a mí a veces me gustaría haberlo sido; pero usted está hecho para ser bueno: parece tan bueno que he de encontrarle una esposa encantadora. ¿No le parece, lord Henry, que el señor Gray debería casarse?
vi_translation: "Oh, dear," Mrs. Narborough exclaimed, putting on her gloves, "don't tell me that you have exhausted Life already. When someone says that, it is immediately clear that Life has exhausted them. Lord Henry is very corrupt, and sometimes I wish I were too; but you were made to be a good person — you look so decent. I must find you a beautiful wife. Lord Henry, do you think Mr. Gray here should get married?”
tr_translation: Putting on her gloves, the hostess said, "Ah, my dear, don't talk as if you've already exhausted life! When someone talks like that, it means life has exhausted them. Look, Lord Henry is a very bad man, very mischievous. Sometimes I envy him for that. But you were created for goodness. You have such an angelic appearance that I feel like finding you a nice spouse. Lord Henry, don't you think Mr. Gray should get married by now?"
es_translation: —Ah, my dear —exclaimed Lady Narborough while putting on her gloves—, don't tell me that you have already exhausted life. When a man says that, it is known that it is life that has exhausted him. Lord Henry is very wicked, and sometimes I wish I had been; but you are made to be good: you seem so good that I must find you a charming wife. Don't you think, Lord Henry, that Mr. Gray should get married?

en: “I am always telling him so, Lady Narborough,” said Lord Henry with a bow.
vi: “Tôi luôn bảo cậu ấy vậy đấy, thưa bà Narborough,” huân tước Henry nói, với một cái cúi đầu.
tr: Lord Henry hafifçe eğilerek, “Ben kendisine hep bunu söyleyip duruyorum, Leydi Narborough,” dedi.
es: —Es lo que yo le digo siempre, lady Narborough —respondió lord Henry con una inclinación de cabeza.
vi_translation: "I always tell him that, Mrs. Narborough," Lord Henry said, with a bow.
tr_translation: Lord Henry, bowing slightly, said, "I always keep telling him that, Lady Narborough."
es_translation: —It is what I always tell you, Lady Narborough —replied Lord Henry with a nod of his head.

en: “Well, we must look out for a suitable match for him. I shall go through Debrett carefully to-night and draw out a list of all the eligible young ladies.”
vi: “Được rồi, chúng tôi phải tìm một đám phù hợp với cậu. Đêm nay tôi sẽ xem kỹ hết Debrett, và thảo ra một danh sách mọi thiếu nữ thích hợp.”
tr: “İyi öyleyse, ona şöyle uygun bir eş arayalım artık. Ben bu akşam Debrett’i iyicene tarayayım da evlenmeye uygun genç kızların listelerini çıkarayım.
es: —De acuerdo; en ese caso debemos buscarle un buen partido. Esta noche examinaré cuidadosamente el Debrett y prepararé una lista con las jóvenes más adecuadas.
vi_translation: "Alright, we have to find a suitable match for you. Tonight, I will thoroughly review Debrett and draft a list of all the eligible young ladies."
tr_translation: "Alright then, let's find a suitable match for him now. I'll thoroughly go through Debrett's this evening and make a list of eligible young ladies for marriage."
es_translation: —Agreed; in that case, we must find him a good match. Tonight, I will carefully examine the Debrett and prepare a list of the most suitable young ladies.

en: “With their ages, Lady Narborough?” asked Dorian.
vi: “Với tuổi của họ nữa chứ, phải không bà Narborough?” Dorian hỏi.
tr: Dorian, “Yaşlarını da belirterek,” dedi.
es: —¿Sin olvidar la edad de las candidatas, lady Narborough? —preguntó Dorian.
vi_translation: “With their age too, right Mrs. Narborough?” Dorian asked.
tr_translation: Dorian said, "By stating their ages as well."
es_translation: —Without forgetting the age of the candidates, Lady Narborough? —asked Dorian.

en: “Of course, with their ages, slightly edited. But nothing must be done in a hurry. I want it to be what The Morning Post calls a suitable alliance, and I want you both to be happy.”
vi: “Dĩ nhiên, với tuổi của họ, có sửa sơ sơ. Nhưng chẳng việc gì phải vội. Tôi muốn nó như là cái mà báo The Morning Post vẫn gọi là môn đăng hộ đối, và tôi muốn vợ chồng cậu được hạnh phúc.
tr: “Elbet yaşları da belirtilecek, ufak tefek rötuşlarla. Yalnız bu iş aceleye gelmemeli. Bunun, The Morning Post gazetesinde dedikleri gibi, uygun bir bileşim olmasını istiyorum, ikinizin de çok mutlu olmanızı istiyorum.
es: —Sin olvidar la edad, por supuesto, aunque ligeramente revisada. Pero no debe hacerse nada con prisas. Quiero que sea lo que The Morning Post llama un enlace conveniente, y que los dos sean felices.
vi_translation: “Of course, at their age, there are some minor adjustments. But there's no need to rush. I want it to be what The Morning Post calls a well-matched marriage, and I want you two to be happy.”
tr_translation: “Of course, their ages will also be mentioned, with minor retouches. But this job should not be rushed. I want this to be, as they say in The Morning Post newspaper, an appropriate composition, I want both of you to be very happy.”
es_translation: —Without forgetting the age, of course, although slightly revised. But nothing should be done in a hurry. I want it to be what The Morning Post calls a convenient match, and for both to be happy.

en: “What nonsense people talk about happy marriages!” exclaimed Lord Henry. “A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her.”
vi: “Mọi người đã nói biết bao nhiêu thứ nhảm nhí về các cuộc hôn nhân hạnh phúc!” huân tước Henry kêu lên. “Đàn ông có thể hạnh phúc với bất cứ cô nào, miễn đừng yêu cô ấy.”
tr: Lord Henry, “İnsanlar mutlu evlilik konusunda nasıl da saçmalarlar!” dedi. “Bir erkek herhangi bir kadınla mutlu olabilir, yeter ki onu sevmesin.
es: —¡Qué cosas tan absurdas dice la gente sobre los matrimonios felices! —exclamó lord Henry—. Un hombre puede ser feliz con una mujer siempre que no la quiera.
vi_translation: “People have said so many nonsensical things about happy marriages!” Lord Henry exclaimed. “A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry said, "How people do talk nonsense about happy marriages!" "A man can be happy with any woman, as long as he does not love her."
es_translation: —What absurd things people say about happy marriages! —exclaimed Lord Henry—. A man can be happy with a woman as long as he does not love her.

en: “Ah! what a cynic you are!” cried the old lady, pushing back her chair and nodding to Lady Ruxton. “You must come and dine with me soon again. You are really an admirable tonic, much better than what Sir Andrew prescribes for me. You must tell me what people you would like to meet, though. I want it to be a delightful gathering.”
vi: “Ôi! Anh đúng là kẻ hay nhạo báng!” bà già la lên, đẩy ghế ra sau, gật đầu với bà Ruxton. “Anh phải sớm đến ăn tối với tôi lần nữa nhé. Anh thật sự là một liều thuốc bổ tuyệt diệu, tốt hơn nhiều so với thứ mà ngài Andrew kê cho tôi. Tuy nhiên anh phải kể tôi nghe xem anh thích gặp người thế nào. Tôi muốn nó là một cuộc hội họp thú vị.”
tr: Ev sahibesi, “Ah, siz, siniklerin başısınız!” diyerek sandalyesini arkaya itti, Leydi Ruxton’a bir baş işareti yaptı. “Yakında gene yemeğe gelin, olur mu? Pek etkin bir kuvvet şurubusunuz, Sir Andrew’nun reçetesinden çok daha etkilisiniz. Yalnız, kimlerle bir arada bulunmak istediğinizi söyleyin bana. Eğlenceli bir toplantı olsun isterim.
es: —¡Ah! ¡Qué cinismo el suyo! —dijo la anciana señora, empujando la silla hacia atrás y haciendo un gesto con la cabeza a lady Ruxton—. Tiene que volver muy pronto a cenar conmigo. Es usted realmente un tónico admirable, mucho mejor que lo que sir Andrew me receta. Ha de decirme con qué personas le gustaría encontrarse. Deseo que sea una velada absolutamente deliciosa.
vi_translation: "Oh! You really are a mocker!" the old lady exclaimed, pushing her chair back and nodding at Mrs. Ruxton. "You must come to dinner with me again soon. You truly are a wonderful tonic, much better than what Sir Andrew prescribed for me. However, you must tell me what kind of people you like to meet. I want it to be an interesting gathering."
tr_translation: The hostess, "Ah, you, the chief of cynics!" she said, pushing her chair back and nodding to Lady Ruxton. "Come again for dinner soon, will you? You are quite an effective tonic, much more effective than Sir Andrew's prescription. Just tell me who you would like to be with. I want it to be a fun gathering."
es_translation: —Ah! What cynicism on your part! —said the elderly lady, pushing the chair back and nodding to Lady Ruxton—. You must come back very soon to have dinner with me. You are truly an admirable tonic, much better than what Sir Andrew prescribes for me. You must tell me which people you would like to meet. I want it to be an absolutely delightful evening.

en: “I like men who have a future and women who have a past,” he answered. “Or do you think that would make it a petticoat party?”
vi: “Tôi thích đàn ông có tương lai, và đàn bà có quá khứ,” y trả lời. “Hay bà nghĩ là thế sẽ làm cho nó thành một buổi tiệc quá gái không?”
tr: Lord Henry, “Geleceği olan erkeklerle geçmişi olan kadınlardan hoşlanırım ben,” diye karşılık verdi. “Yoksa böyle bir toplantıya gelecek erkek bulunmaz mı?
es: —Me gustan los hombres con futuro y las mujeres con pasado —respondió lord Henry—. ¿O cree que sería demasiado grande el desequilibrio?
vi_translation: “I like men with a future, and women with a past,” he replied. “Or do you think that will make it too much of a ladies' party?”
tr_translation: Lord Henry replied, "I like men with a future and women with a past." "Or is it impossible to find men who would come to such a gathering?"
es_translation: —I like men with a future and women with a past —replied Lord Henry—. Or do you think the imbalance would be too great?

en: “I fear so,” she said, laughing, as she stood up. “A thousand pardons, my dear Lady Ruxton,” she added, “I didn’t see you hadn’t finished your cigarette.”
vi: “Tôi e là vậy,” bà vừa nói vừa cười, lúc bà đứng dậy. “Ngàn lần xin lỗi, bà Ruxton yêu quý của tôi,” bà nói thêm. “Tôi không thấy bà chưa hút xong thuốc.
tr: Ev sahibesi, “Korkarım öyle olur,” diye gülerek ayağa kalktı. Sonra, “Bin kez özür dilerim, azizim Leydi Ruxton,” diye ekledi. “Sigaranızı bitirmediğinizi görmemiştim.
es: —Mucho me temo —dijo ella riendo, mientras se ponía en pie—. Mil perdones, mi querida lady Ruxton -añadió al instante—. Veo que no ha terminado usted su cigarrillo.
vi_translation: “I'm afraid so,” she said with a smile, as she stood up. “A thousand apologies, my dear Mrs. Ruxton,” she added. “I didn't realize you hadn't finished your cigarette.”
tr_translation: The hostess stood up laughing, "I'm afraid it will be so," she said. Then she added, "A thousand apologies, my dear Lady Ruxton." "I hadn't noticed you hadn't finished your cigarette."
es_translation: —I greatly fear —she said laughing, as she stood up—. A thousand pardons, my dear Lady Ruxton —she added instantly—. I see that you have not finished your cigarette.

en: “Never mind, Lady Narborough. I smoke a great deal too much. I am going to limit myself, for the future.”
vi: “Đừng bận tâm, thưa bà Narborough. Tôi hút quá nhiều. Tôi sắp bớt lại, vì tương lai.
tr: “Zararı yok, Leydi Narborough, zaten çok fazla içiyorum. Bundan böyle azaltacağım.
es: —No se preocupe, lady Narborough. Fumo demasiado. Tengo intención de hacerlo menos en el futuro.
vi_translation: "Don't worry, Mrs. Narborough. I smoke too much." "I am about to cut down, for the future.""
tr_translation: "No harm, Lady Narborough, I already drink too much. From now on, I will reduce it."
es_translation: —Don't worry, Lady Narborough. I smoke too much. I intend to do it less in the future.

en: “Pray don’t, Lady Ruxton,” said Lord Henry. “Moderation is a fatal thing. Enough is as bad as a meal. More than enough is as good as a feast.”
vi: “Xin đừng, thưa bà Ruxton,” huân tước Henry nói. “Kiêng khem là một việc rất tai hại. Điều độ thì như bữa ăn thường. Vô độ thì như bữa tiệc sang.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Kuzum yapmayın, Leydi Ruxton!” diye araya girdi. “Ilımlılık felakettir. Yeter kavramı yayan bir yemek, fazla kavramıysa nefis bir şölendir.
es: —No lo haga, se lo ruego, lady Ruxton —intervino lord Henry—. La moderación es una virtud muy perniciosa. Bastante es tan malo como una comida. Demasiado, tan bueno como un festín.
vi_translation: “Please don't, Mrs. Ruxton,” said Lord Henry. “Abstinence is a very harmful thing. Moderation is like a regular meal. Excess is like a lavish banquet.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry intervened, "My dear, don't do that, Lady Ruxton!" "Moderation is a disaster. A meal that spreads the concept of enough is a feast that spreads the concept of excess."
es_translation: —Don't do it, I beg you, Lady Ruxton —intervened Lord Henry—. Moderation is a very pernicious virtue. Enough is as bad as a meal. Too much, as good as a feast.

en: Lady Ruxton glanced at him curiously. “You must come and explain that to me some afternoon, Lord Henry. It sounds a fascinating theory,” she murmured, as she swept out of the room.
vi: Bà Ruxton tò mò nhìn y. “Anh phải đến giải thích điều ấy cho tôi vào một chiều nào đó, huân tước Henry nhé. Nó nghe như một lý thuyết quyến rũ,” bà khẽ nói lúc đường bệ đi ra khỏi phòng.
tr: Leydi Ruxton ona merakla baktı. “Bir gün gelip bunu açıklayın bana, Lord Henry. İlginç bir kurama benziyor,” diye mırıldanıp eteklerini dalgalandırarak odadan çıktı.
es: Lady Ruxton lo miró con curiosidad. —Tendrá usted que venir y explicármelo alguna tarde, lord Henry. Parece una teoría fascinante —murmuró mientras abandonaba la habitación.
vi_translation: Mrs. Ruxton looked at him curiously. "You must come and explain that to me one afternoon, Lord Henry." "It sounds like a fascinating theory," she said softly as she grandly exited the room.
tr_translation: Lady Ruxton looked at him with curiosity. “One day, come and explain this to me, Lord Henry. It sounds like an interesting theory,” she murmured, fluttering her skirts as she left the room.
es_translation: Lady Ruxton looked at him with curiosity. —You will have to come and explain it to me some afternoon, Lord Henry. It seems like a fascinating theory —he murmured as he left the room.

en: “Now, mind you don’t stay too long over your politics and scandal,” cried Lady Narborough from the door. “If you do, we are sure to squabble upstairs.”
vi: “Giờ thì hãy lưu ý là anh đừng nấn ná quá lâu với các quan điểm chính trị và những vụ tai tiếng nhé,” bà Narborough la lên từ cửa. “Nếu anh làm thế, chúng tôi chắc chắn sẽ cãi nhau trên gác.”
tr: Leydi Narborough eşikte dönerek, “Sakın politika konularınızla dedikodularınızı fazla uzatmayın,” diye seslendi. “Yoksa bizler yukarıda hırlaşmaya başlarız.
es: —Por favor, caballeros, no se queden ustedes demasiado tiempo hablando de política y de escándalos —exclamó lady Narborough desde la puerta—. Si lo hacen, acabaremos peleándonos en el piso de arriba.
vi_translation: "Now, be sure not to linger too long on politics and scandals," Mrs. Narborough called out from the door. "If you do, we are sure to argue upstairs."
tr_translation: Lady Narborough turned at the threshold and called out, "Don't drag out your politics and gossip too much." "Otherwise, we will start bickering upstairs."
es_translation: —Please, gentlemen, do not spend too much time talking about politics and scandals —exclaimed Lady Narborough from the door—. If you do, we will end up fighting upstairs.

en: The men laughed, and Mr. Chapman got up solemnly from the foot of the table and came up to the top. Dorian Gray changed his seat and went and sat by Lord Henry. Mr. Chapman began to talk in a loud voice about the situation in the House of Commons. He guffawed at his adversaries. The word doctrinaire—word full of terror to the British mind—reappeared from time to time between his explosions. An alliterative prefix served as an ornament of oratory. He hoisted the Union Jack on the pinnacles of thought. The inherited stupidity of the race—sound English common sense he jovially termed it—was shown to be the proper bulwark for society.
vi: Mọi người bật cười, mít-tơ Chapman khoan thai đứng dậy từ cuối bàn và đi lên đầu. Dorian Gray đổi chỗ ngồi, lại ngồi cạnh huân tước Henry. Mít-tơ Chapman bắt đầu nói lớn tiếng về tình hình trong Hạ nghị viện. Ông ta cười ha hả vào các đối thủ. Từ nhà khống luận — một từ đầy kinh hãi với tâm trí người Anh — xuất hiện đi xuất hiện lại giữa những tiếng cười như phá. Một tiền tố lặp âm đầu được dùng như đồ trang hoàng cho tài hùng biện. Ông ta kéo quốc kỳ Anh lên đỉnh Tư duy. Sự đần độn được thừa hưởng từ nòi giống — cái lương tri lành mạnh của người Anh theo như ông ta vui vẻ gọi nó — tỏ ra là một bức tường thành thích hợp cho Xã hội.
tr: Erkekler gülüştüler. mr Chapman büyük bir ağırbaşlılıkla masanın alt başındaki yerinden kalkarak üst başına geçti. Dorian Gray de yerini değiştirerek gitti, Lord Henry’nin yanına oturdu. mr Chapman yüksek sesle, Avam Kamarası’ndaki durumu konuşmaya başladı. Hasımlarını andıkça yüksek sesle gülüyordu. Bu patlamaların arasında zaman zaman doktriner sözcüğü geçiyordu. İngiliz kafasına dehşet salan o sözcük. mr Chapman kelime başlarına aynı sesi yineleyen ekler getirmekle konuşmasını süslediğini sanıyordu. İngiliz bayrağını düşüncenin burcuna getirip dikti. Irkının soydan geçme budalalığının –o buna sağlam İngiliz sağduyusu diyordu- toplum için en iyi siper olduğunu kanıtlamaya çalıştı.
es: Los varones rieron, y el señor Chapman se levantó solemnemente del fondo de la mesa y pasó a ocupar la cabecera. Dorian Gray también cambió de sitio y fue a colocarse junto a lord Henry. El señor Chapman empezó a hablar, alzando mucho la voz, sobre la situación en la Cámara de los Comunes, riéndose de sus adversarios. La palabra doctrinaire (un vocablo que inspira terror a las mentes británicas) reaparecía de cuando en cuando entre sus explosiones de carcajadas. Un prefijo aliterativo servía como ornamento a su elocuencia, mientras alzaba la bandera del Imperio sobre los pináculos del Pensamiento. La estupidez innata de la raza (él lo llamaba jovialmente el buen sentido común inglés) se ofreció a los presentes como el baluarte que la Sociedad necesitaba.
vi_translation: Everyone burst into laughter, Mr. Chapman leisurely stood up from the end of the table and walked to the head. Dorian Gray changed his seat, sitting next to Lord Henry again. Mr. Chapman began to speak loudly about the situation in the House of Commons. He laughed heartily at his opponents. The term demagogue — a word that horrifies the English mind — appeared repeatedly amidst the uproarious laughter. An alliterative prefix was used as an ornament for his rhetoric. He hoisted the British flag to the pinnacle of Thought. The inherited dullness of the race — the sound common sense of the English as he cheerfully called it — proved to be a suitable bulwark for Society.
tr_translation: The men laughed. Mr. Chapman, with great solemnity, rose from his place at the lower end of the table and moved to the upper end. Dorian Gray also changed his seat and went to sit next to Lord Henry. Mr. Chapman began to speak loudly about the situation in the House of Commons. He laughed loudly whenever he mentioned his opponents. Among these outbursts, the word "doctrinaire" was occasionally heard. The word that instilled terror in the English mind. Mr. Chapman thought he was embellishing his speech by adding prefixes that repeated the same sound at the beginning of words. He hoisted the English flag to the pinnacle of thought. He tried to prove that the hereditary foolishness of his race – which he called solid English common sense – was the best defense for society.
es_translation: The men laughed, and Mr. Chapman solemnly rose from the end of the table and moved to occupy the head. Dorian Gray also changed his seat and went to place himself next to Lord Henry. Mr. Chapman began to speak, raising his voice significantly, about the situation in the House of Commons, mocking his adversaries. The word doctrinaire (a term that inspires terror in British minds) reappeared from time to time amidst his bursts of laughter. An alliterative prefix served as an ornament to his eloquence, while he raised the flag of the Empire over the pinnacles of Thought. The innate stupidity of the race (he jovially called it good English common sense) was offered to those present as the bulwark that Society needed.

en: A smile curved Lord Henry’s lips, and he turned round and looked at Dorian.
vi: Một nụ cười uốn cong môi huân tước Henry, và y quay qua nhìn Dorian.
tr: Lord Henry, dudakları bir gülümseyişle bükülerek döndü, Dorian’a baktı.
es: Una sonrisa curvó los labios de lord Henry, quien, volviéndose, miró a Dorian.
vi_translation: A smile curved Lord Henry's lips, and he turned to look at Dorian.
tr_translation: Lord Henry turned with a smile curling on his lips and looked at Dorian.
es_translation: A smile curved Lord Henry's lips, who, turning, looked at Dorian.

en: “Are you better, my dear fellow?” he asked. “You seemed rather out of sorts at dinner.”
vi: “Cậu đỡ chưa, bạn tôi ơi?” y hỏi. “Cậu dường như khá khó chịu trong bữa tối.”
tr: “Daha iyisin ya, sevgili dostum?” diye sordu. “Yemekte pek keyifsizdin de.
es: —¿Te encuentras mejor? —preguntó—. Parecías un poco perdido durante la cena.
vi_translation: "Are you feeling better, my friend?" he asked. "You seemed quite uncomfortable during dinner."
tr_translation: “Are you feeling better, my dear friend?” he asked. “You seemed quite unhappy at dinner.”
es_translation: —Are you feeling better? —he asked—. You seemed a bit lost during dinner.

en: “I am quite well, Harry. I am tired. That is all.”
vi: “Tôi ổn mà, Harry. Tôi hơi mệt. Chỉ vậy thôi.”
tr: “İyiyim, Harry. Biraz yorgunum, o kadar.
es: —Estoy perfectamente, Harry. Un poco cansado. Eso es todo.
vi_translation: “I'm fine, Harry. I'm just a bit tired. That's all.”
tr_translation: “I'm fine, Harry. Just a bit tired, that's all.”
es_translation: —I'm perfectly fine, Harry. A little tired. That's all.

en: “You were charming last night. The little duchess is quite devoted to you. She tells me she is going down to Selby.”
vi: “Cậu rất quyến rũ đêm qua. Nữ công tước nhỏ ấy rất hết lòng với cậu. Cô ấy bảo tôi là cô ấy sẽ xuống Selby.”
tr: “Dün gece çok şirindin. Küçük düşesimiz sana hayran. Selby’ye gideceğini söyledi bana.
es: —Anoche te superaste a ti mismo. La duquesita sólo ve por tus ojos. Me ha dicho que irá a Selby.
vi_translation: "You were very charming last night. The little duchess was very devoted to you. She told me that she would go down to Selby."
tr_translation: "You were very charming last night. Our little duchess is fond of you. She told me you are going to Selby."
es_translation: —Last night you outdid yourself. The little duchess only sees through your eyes. She told me she will go to Selby.

en: “She has promised to come on the twentieth.”
vi: “Cô ấy hứa đến vào ngày hai mươi.”
tr: “Yirmisinde gelirim, diye söz verdi.
es: —Ha prometido estar allí para el día veinte.
vi_translation: “She promised to come on the twentieth.”
tr_translation: “I will come when I am twenty, he promised.”
es_translation: —He has promised to be there by the twentieth.

en: “Is Monmouth to be there, too?”
vi: “Monmouth cũng đến đó chứ?”
tr: “Monmouth da geliyor mu?
es: —¿También irá Monmouth?
vi_translation: "Is Monmouth going there too?"
tr_translation: “Is Monmouth coming too?”
es_translation: —Will Monmouth go as well?

en: “Oh, yes, Harry.”
vi: “À, vâng, Harry.”
tr: “Elbette, Harry.
es: —Sí, Harry.
vi_translation: “Ah, yes, Harry.”
tr_translation: "Of course, Harry.""
es_translation: —Yes, Harry.

en: “He bores me dreadfully, almost as much as he bores her. She is very clever, too clever for a woman. She lacks the indefinable charm of weakness.
