es_translation: —How unpleasant you are, Harry! You shouldn't say such dreadful things. Hetty's heart hasn't been broken. She cried, of course, and all that. But she hasn't lost her honor. She can live, like Perdita[18], in her garden of mint and marigolds.

en: “And weep over a faithless Florizel,” said Lord Henry, laughing, as he leaned back in his chair. “My dear Dorian, you have the most curiously boyish moods. Do you think this girl will ever be really content now with any one of her own rank? I suppose she will be married some day to a rough carter or a grinning ploughman. Well, the fact of having met you, and loved you, will teach her to despise her husband, and she will be wretched. From a moral point of view, I cannot say that I think much of your great renunciation. Even as a beginning, it is poor. Besides, how do you know that Hetty isn’t floating at the present moment in some starlit mill-pond, with lovely water-lilies round her, like Ophelia?”
vi: “Và khóc than chàng Florizel2 lật lọng,” huân tước Henry vừa cười vừa nói, lúc y ngả lưng lên ghế. “Dorian thân mến của tôi, cậu có cái tính trẻ con hết sức kỳ lạ. Cậu nghĩ là bây giờ cô gái này sẽ còn có lúc thật sự vừa lòng được với bất cứ ai cùng tầng lớp mình nữa sao? Tôi cho là cô ta sẽ kết hôn vào một ngày nào đó với một gã đánh xe cộc cằn hoặc một tay thợ cày nhăn nhở. Đấy, cái việc đã gặp cậu, đã yêu cậu, sẽ dạy cô ấy xem thường chồng mình, và cô ấy sẽ khổ. Trên quan điểm đạo đức, tôi không thể nói là tôi nghĩ nhiều đến sự hy sinh vĩ đại của cậu. Thậm chí để bắt đầu thì nó cũng kém. Ngoài ra, làm sao mà cậu biết được là lúc này Hetty không trôi nổi trong một hồ chứa nước sáng-sao nào đó, với những bông hoa súng đáng yêu quanh mình, như Ophelia?” 2 Người tình của nàng Perdita.
tr: Lord Henry, “Vefasız Florizel için gözyaşları dökerek,” diye güldü, sırtına yaslandı. “Azizim Dorian, öyle tuhaf çocukluklar yapıyorsun ki arada! Bu kız şimdi artık, kendi sınıfından birisiyle mutlu olabilir mi sanıyorsun? Günün birinde yontulmamış bir arabacıyla evlenecektir, herhalde ya da sırıtkan bir ırgatla. İşte o zaman seni tanımış ve sevmiş olması ona, kocasını hor görmeyi öğretecektir. Ve kızcağız mutsuz olacaktır. Ahlak yönünden senin bu fedakârlığına fazla değer verdiğimi söyleyemem. Başlangıç olarak bile cılız kaçıyor. Hem zaten, nereden biliyorsun, belki Hetty şu anda yıldızlı bir değirmen göletinde yatıyordur, tıpkı Ophelia gibi, güzelim nilüferlerin arasında?
es: —Y llorar por la infidelidad de Florisel —dijo lord Henry, riendo, mientras se inclinaba hacia atrás en la silla—. Mi querido Dorian, tienes curiosas ideas de adolescente. ¿De verdad crees que esa muchacha se contentará ahora con alguien de su posición? Imagino que algún día la casarán con un carretero mal hablado o con un labrador chistoso. Y el hecho de haberte conocido, y de haberte amado, le permitirá despreciar a su marido, lo que la hará perfectamente desgraciada. Desde el punto de vista de la moral, no puedo decir que tu gran renuncia me impresione demasiado. Incluso como modesto principio es muy poquita cosa. Además, ¿quién te dice que en este momento Hetty no flota en algún estanque iluminado por las estrellas y rodeada de lirios, como Ofelia?
vi_translation: "And lamenting the fickle Florizel," Lord Henry said with a laugh, as he leaned back in his chair. "My dear Dorian, you have the most peculiar childish nature. Do you think that now this girl will ever truly be satisfied with anyone of her own class again? I suppose she will marry one day a rough coachman or a grinning plowman. See, having met you, having loved you, will teach her to scorn her husband, and she will suffer. From a moral standpoint, I can't say I think much of your great sacrifice. Even to begin with, it was poor. Besides, how do you know that Hetty is not at this moment floating in some starlit pond, with lovely water lilies around her, like Ophelia?" 2 Lovers of Perdita.
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed, "Shedding tears for the unfaithful Florizel," and leaned back. "My dear Dorian, you do such strange childish things sometimes! Do you think this girl can now be happy with someone from her own class? One day she will probably marry an unrefined coachman or a grinning laborer. And then, having known and loved you will teach her to despise her husband. And the poor girl will be unhappy. I can't say I place much moral value on this sacrifice of yours. It falls short even as a start. Besides, how do you know, maybe Hetty is lying in a starry mill pond right now, just like Ophelia, among the beautiful water lilies?"
es_translation: —And cry over the infidelity of Florisel —said Lord Henry, laughing, as he leaned back in his chair—. My dear Dorian, you have curious adolescent ideas. Do you really think that girl will now be content with someone of her own station? I imagine that someday she will be married off to a foul-mouthed carter or a humorous farmer. And the fact that she has known you, and loved you, will allow her to despise her husband, which will make her perfectly miserable. From a moral standpoint, I can't say that your great renunciation impresses me much. Even as a modest beginning, it is very little. Besides, who is to say that at this moment Hetty is not floating in some star-lit pond surrounded by lilies, like Ophelia?

en: “I can’t bear this, Harry! You mock at everything, and then suggest the most serious tragedies. I am sorry I told you now. I don’t care what you say to me. I know I was right in acting as I did. Poor Hetty! As I rode past the farm this morning, I saw her white face at the window, like a spray of jasmine. Don’t let us talk about it any more, and don’t try to persuade me that the first good action I have done for years, the first little bit of self-sacrifice I have ever known, is really a sort of sin. I want to be better. I am going to be better. Tell me something about yourself. What is going on in town? I have not been to the club for days.”
vi: “Tôi không chịu được chuyện này đâu, Harry! Anh chế nhạo mọi thứ, sau đó gợi ra những bi kịch nghiêm trọng nhất. Lúc này tôi lấy làm tiếc là đã kể cho anh nghe. Tôi chẳng quan tâm đến những gì anh nói với tôi. Tôi biết tôi đúng khi làm cái việc tôi đã làm. Tội nghiệp Hetty! Lúc tôi cưỡi ngựa qua trang trại sáng nay, tôi thấy gương mặt trắng muốt của nàng trong cửa sổ, như cành hoa nhài. Ta đừng nói về nó thêm nữa, và đừng cố thuyết phục tôi rằng việc tốt đầu tiên tôi làm sau nhiều năm, sự hy sinh nhỏ nhoi đầu tiên mà tôi từng biết đến, lại thật sự là một thứ tội lỗi. Tôi muốn sống tử tế hơn. Tôi sắp sống tử tế hơn. Hãy kể tôi nghe đôi điều về anh đi. Có gì đang diễn ra trong thành phố? Tôi không đến câu lạc bộ đã nhiều ngày rồi.”
tr: “Dayanamıyorum, Harry! Her şeyi alaya alıyorsun, sonra da en acı trajedileri dokunduruyorsun. Sana anlattığıma bin pişmanım şimdi. Sen ne desen de vız gelir. Böyle davranmakla doğru iş yaptığımı biliyorum. Zavallı Hetty! Bu sabah atımla çiftliğin önünden geçerken onun o beyaz yüzünü pencerede gördüm; bir demet yasemindi sanki. Artık konuşmayalım bundan. Şunca yıldır yaptığım ilk iyi iş bu, ömrümün ilk fedakârlığı! Bunun bir tür günah olduğuna inandırayım deme beni. Daha iyi bir insan olmak istiyorum. Daha iyi bir insan olacağım. Sen, biraz kendinden söz et bana. Kentte neler olup bitiyor? Günlerdir kulübe uğramadım.
es: —¡Eres insoportable, Harry! Te burlas de todo y acto seguido imaginas las tragedias más espantosas. Siento habértelo contado. Me tiene sin cuidado lo que digas. Sé que he actuado bien. ¡Pobre Hetty! Cuando pasé a caballo esta mañana por delante de su granja, vi su rostro en la ventana, como un ramillete de jazmines. Vamos a no hablar más de ello, y no trates de convencerme de que mi primera buena acción en muchos años, el primer intento de autosacrificio de toda mi vida es en realidad otro pecado más. Quiero ser mejor. Voy a ser mejor. Cuéntame algo sobre ti. ¿Qué está pasando en Londres? Hace días que no voy por el club.
vi_translation: “I can't stand this, Harry! You mock everything, then bring up the most serious tragedies. At this moment, I regret telling you. I don't care about what you say to me. I know I was right in doing what I did. Poor Hetty! When I rode past the farm this morning, I saw her pale face in the window, like a jasmine flower. Let's not talk about it anymore, and don't try to convince me that the first good thing I've done in years, the first small sacrifice I've ever known, is actually a sin. I want to live more kindly. I'm about to live more kindly. Tell me something about yourself. What's happening in the city? I haven't been to the club for many days."
tr_translation: “I can't stand it, Harry! You make fun of everything, and then you touch upon the most bitter tragedies. I'm now a thousand times sorry that I told you. No matter what you say, it doesn't matter to me. I know I'm doing the right thing by acting this way. Poor Hetty! This morning, as I passed by the farm on my horse, I saw her pale face at the window; it was like a bunch of jasmine. Let's not talk about this anymore. This is the first good thing I've done in all these years, the first sacrifice of my life! Don't try to convince me that this is some kind of sin. I want to be a better person. I will be a better person. Tell me a bit about yourself. What's happening in the city? I haven't visited the cabin for days.”
es_translation: —You are unbearable, Harry! You mock everything and then imagine the most dreadful tragedies. I'm sorry I told you about it. I don't care what you say. I know I have acted rightly. Poor Hetty! When I rode past her farm this morning, I saw her face at the window, like a bouquet of jasmine. Let's not talk about it anymore, and don't try to convince me that my first good deed in many years, my first attempt at self-sacrifice in my entire life, is actually just another sin. I want to be better. I'm going to be better. Tell me something about yourself. What's happening in London? It's been days since I went to the club.

en: “The people are still discussing poor Basil’s disappearance.”
vi: “Mọi người vẫn còn bàn tán về sự biến mất của Basil tội nghiệp.
tr: “Herkes hâlâ zavallı Basil’in ortadan yitişini konuşuyor.
es: —La gente sigue hablando de la desaparición del pobre Basil.
vi_translation: “Everyone is still talking about poor Basil's disappearance.”
tr_translation: “Everyone is still talking about poor Basil's disappearance.”
es_translation: —People are still talking about the disappearance of poor Basil.

en: “I should have thought they had got tired of that by this time,” said Dorian, pouring himself out some wine and frowning slightly.
vi: “Tôi cứ tưởng là đến lúc này thì họ đã chán chuyện ấy rồi,” Dorian nói, rót cho mình ít rượu, và hơi nhăn mặt.
tr: Dorian hafifçe yüzünü buruşturup bardağına biraz şarap alarak, “Şimdiye kadar bu konudan usanacaklarını sanmıştım,” dedi.
es: —Yo pensaba que ya se habrían cansado después de tanto tiempo —exclamó Dorian, sirviéndose un poco más de vino y frunciendo ligeramente el ceño.
vi_translation: "I thought they would be tired of that by now," Dorian said, pouring himself some wine, and slightly grimacing.
tr_translation: Dorian slightly grimaced and, pouring himself some wine, said, "I thought they would have been tired of this topic by now."
es_translation: —I thought they would have gotten tired after so much time —exclaimed Dorian, pouring himself a bit more wine and slightly furrowing his brow.

en: “My dear boy, they have only been talking about it for six weeks, and the British public are really not equal to the mental strain of having more than one topic every three months. They have been very fortunate lately, however. They have had my own divorce-case and Alan Campbell’s suicide. Now they have got the mysterious disappearance of an artist. Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the grey ulster who left for Paris by the midnight train on the ninth of November was poor Basil, and the French police declare that Basil never arrived in Paris at all. I suppose in about a fortnight we shall be told that he has been seen in San Francisco. It is an odd thing, but every one who disappears is said to be seen at San Francisco. It must be a delightful city, and possess all the attractions of the next world.”
vi: “Chàng trai yêu quý của tôi, họ mới chỉ nói về nó được sáu tuần, và công chúng Anh quốc thật sự không đủ sức chịu đựng sự căng thẳng tinh thần của việc có hơn một đề tài cho mỗi ba tháng. Tuy nhiên, gần đây họ rất may. Họ đã có vụ ly hôn của tôi và vụ tự tử của Alan Campbell. Giờ thì họ có thêm vụ mất tích bí ẩn của một nghệ sỹ. Scotland Yard vẫn khăng khăng rằng cái người mặc áo un-xtơ xám đi Paris trên chuyến tàu nửa đêm vào ngày mùng chín tháng Mười một ấy chính là Basil tội nghiệp, còn cảnh sát Pháp thì tuyên bố là Basil chưa hề đến Paris nói chung. Tôi cho là sau độ hai tuần nữa thì họ sẽ bảo ta là y bị bắt gặp ở San Francisco. Thật kỳ lạ, nhưng ai biến mất cũng bị đồn là bị bắt gặp ở San Francisco. Nó hẳn là một thành phố vui vẻ, và sở hữu mọi sức hút của cõi sau.”
tr: “Cancağızım, topu topu altı haftadır konuşuyorlar. İngiliz toplumu konuştuğu konuyu üç aydan önce değiştirirse ya da buna ek, fazlalık bir konuyu ele alırsa, bunun zihinsel stresine dayanamaz! Gene de son zamanlarda şansları açıldı. Benim boşanma davamı konuştular, sonra Alan Campbell’in intiharını. Şimdi de bir ressamın ortadan yitişindeki esrar. Dokuz kasımda gece yarısı treniyle Londra’dan ayrılan gri paltolu adamın zavallı Basil olduğunda Scotland Yard hâlâ direniyor. Fransız polisiyse Basil’in Paris’e kesinlikle ayak basmadığını ileri sürüyor. On-on beş gün sonra onun San Francisco’da görülmüş olduğunu duyarız, herhalde. Tuhaf şey, kim ortadan kaybolsa San Francisco’da görüldüğü söyleniyor. Harika bir kent olsa gerek; öbür dünyanın tüm ilginçlikleri orada galiba.
es: —Mi querido muchacho, sólo llevan seis semanas hablando de ello, y el público británico necesita tres meses para soportar la tensión mental que requiere un cambio de tema. De todos modos, ha tenido bastante suerte en estos últimos tiempos. Primero fue el caso de mi divorcio y el suicidio de Alan Campbell. Ahora se les ofrece la misteriosa desaparición de un artista. Scotland Yard sigue insistiendo en que la persona con un abrigo gris que el nueve de noviembre tomó el tren de medianoche camino de Francia era el pobre Basil, y la policía gala afirma que Hallward nunca llegó a París. Supongo que dentro de un par de semanas se nos dirá que lo han visto en San Francisco. Es una cosa extraña, pero de todas las personas que desaparecen acaba diciéndose que las han visto en San Francisco. Debe de ser una ciudad encantadora, y posee todos los atractivos del mundo venidero.
vi_translation: “My dear boy, they have only been talking about it for six weeks, and the British public really cannot endure the mental strain of having more than one topic every three months. However, they have been very fortunate lately. They had my divorce and Alan Campbell's suicide. Now they have the mysterious disappearance of an artist. Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the gray ulster who left for Paris on the midnight train on November ninth was poor Basil, while the French police declare that Basil never arrived in Paris at all. I suppose in about a fortnight they will tell us that he has been seen in San Francisco. It is odd, but everyone who disappears is said to be seen in San Francisco. It must be a delightful city, and possess all the attractions of the next world.”
tr_translation: “My dear, they've only been talking for six weeks. If the English society changes the topic it talks about before three months or adds an extra topic, it cannot withstand the mental stress! Still, they've had some luck recently. They talked about my divorce case, then Alan Campbell’s suicide. And now, the mystery of a painter's disappearance. Scotland Yard still insists that the man in the gray coat who left London on the midnight train on November 9th was not poor Basil. The French police, however, claim that Basil definitely did not set foot in Paris. In ten to fifteen days, we'll probably hear that he was seen in San Francisco. It's strange, whenever someone disappears, it's said they were seen in San Francisco. It must be a wonderful city; it seems all the curiosities of the other world are there.”
es_translation: —My dear boy, they've only been talking about it for six weeks, and the British public needs three months to endure the mental strain that a change of topic requires. Anyway, he has been quite lucky in recent times. First, there was my divorce case and Alan Campbell's suicide. Now they are offered the mysterious disappearance of an artist. Scotland Yard continues to insist that the person in a gray coat who took the midnight train to France on November ninth was poor Basil, and the French police claim that Hallward never arrived in Paris. I suppose that in a couple of weeks we will be told that he has been seen in San Francisco. It's a strange thing, but of all the people who disappear, it always ends up being said that they have been seen in San Francisco. It must be a charming city, and it possesses all the attractions of the world to come.

en: “What do you think has happened to Basil?” asked Dorian, holding up his Burgundy against the light and wondering how it was that he could discuss the matter so calmly.
vi: “Anh nghĩ là chuyện gì đã xảy ra với Basil?” Dorian hỏi, cầm ly Buốc-gô-nhơ ngược sáng, và lấy làm lạ là làm sao mà cậu lại có thể bàn về chuyện này một cách bình tĩnh như vậy.
tr: Dorian, “Basil’in başına ne geldi, dersin?” diye sorarak bardağındaki siyah şarabı ışığa tuttu. Meseleyi böylesi serinkanlılıkla konuşabildiğine kendi de şaşıyordu.
es: —¿Qué crees tú que le ha sucedido a Basil? —preguntó Dorian, colocando la copa de borgoña a contraluz, y preguntándose cómo era posible que hablara de aquel asunto con tanta calma.
vi_translation: “What do you think happened to Basil?” Dorian asked, holding the Burgundy wine glass against the light, and marveling at how he could discuss this matter so calmly.
tr_translation: Dorian asked, "What do you think happened to Basil?" while holding his glass of black wine up to the light. He was surprised at his own ability to discuss the matter so calmly.
es_translation: —What do you think has happened to Basil? —asked Dorian, holding the glass of burgundy up to the light, and wondering how it was possible for him to speak about the matter so calmly.

en: “I have not the slightest idea. If Basil chooses to hide himself, it is no business of mine. If he is dead, I don’t want to think about him. Death is the only thing that ever terrifies me. I hate it.”
vi: “Tôi không có một tí ý tưởng nào cả. Nếu Basil chọn cách giấu mình thì đó chẳng phải việc của tôi. Nếu anh ta chết, tôi không muốn nghĩ về anh ta nữa. Cái chết là thứ duy nhất từng làm tôi sợ. Tôi ghét nó.”
tr: “Zerrece fikrim yok. Basil gizlenmeyi seçmişse beni ilgilendirmez. Ölmüşse, onu düşünmek istemem. İçime dehşet salan tek şey ölümdür. Nefret ediyorum ölümden.
es: —No tengo ni la más remota idea. Si Basil decide esconderse no es asunto mío. Si ha muerto, no quiero pensar en él. La muerte es la única cosa que de verdad me aterra. La aborrezco.
vi_translation: “I have no idea at all. If Basil chooses to hide himself, it’s none of my business. If he is dead, I don't want to think about him anymore. Death is the only thing that has ever scared me. I hate it.”
tr_translation: “I have absolutely no idea. If Basil has chosen to hide, it doesn't concern me. If he's dead, I don't want to think about him. The only thing that fills me with terror is death. I hate death.”
es_translation: —I don't have the slightest idea. If Basil decides to hide, it's none of my business. If he is dead, I don't want to think about him. Death is the only thing that truly terrifies me. I abhor it.

en: “Why?” said the younger man wearily.
vi: “Tại sao?” người trẻ hơn nói, mệt mỏi.
tr: Dorian bezgin bir sesle, “Neden?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Por qué? —preguntó el más joven con tono cansado.
vi_translation: “Why?” the younger person said, tiredly.
tr_translation: Dorian asked in a listless voice, "Why?"
es_translation: —Why? —asked the youngest one in a tired tone.

en: “Because,” said Lord Henry, passing beneath his nostrils the gilt trellis of an open vinaigrette box, “one can survive everything nowadays except that. Death and vulgarity are the only two facts in the nineteenth century that one cannot explain away. Let us have our coffee in the music-room, Dorian. You must play Chopin to me. The man with whom my wife ran away played Chopin exquisitely. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house is rather lonely without her. Of course, married life is merely a habit, a bad habit. But then one regrets the loss even of one’s worst habits. Perhaps one regrets them the most. They are such an essential part of one’s personality.”
vi: “Bởi vì,” huân tước Henry nói, đưa qua dưới lỗ mũi mình các lưới mắt cáo mạ vàng của một hộp giấm thơm mở nắp, “người ta có thể sống qua được mọi thứ thời nay ngoại trừ cái đó. Cái chết và thói thô tục là hai sự việc duy nhất trong thế kỷ mười chín mà người ta không thể giải thích. Thôi ta hãy đi uống cà phê trong phòng nhạc, Dorian. Cậu phải chơi Chopin cho tôi nghe. Cái người đàn ông mà vợ tôi bỏ nhà đi theo ấy là một kẻ chơi Chopin hay tuyệt. Tội nghiệp Victoria! Tôi rất quyến luyến cô ấy. Nhà cửa vắng cô ấy khá là quạnh hiu. Dĩ nhiên cuộc sống hôn nhân chỉ là một thói quen, một thói quen xấu. Nhưng rồi ta vẫn nuối tiếc với sự mất mát ngay cả những thói quen tệ hại nhất của mình. Không chừng ta còn tiếc nuối chúng nhất. Chúng là một phần thiết yếu của tính cách ta.”
tr: Lord Henry açık duran bir amonyak şişesinin yaldız kafesini burun deliklerinin önünden geçirerek, “Çünkü günümüzde kişi ölüm dışında her felaketi atlatabilir de ondan,” dedi. “On dokuzuncu yüzyılda bir punduna getirip ortadan kaldıramadığımız iki olgu varsa bunlar ölümle bayağılıktır. Dorian, kahvemizi müzik odasında içelim. Bana Chopin çal. Karımın kaçtığı adam çok nefis Chopin çalardı. Zavallı Victoria! Pek severdim kendisini. Onsuz ev biraz boş geliyor. Gerçi evlilik hayatı bir alışkanlıktan başka bir şey değildir, kötü bir alışkanlık, gene de insan en kötü alışkanlıklarını bile arıyor. Kötü olanları en çok arıyor, belki de. İnsanın kişiliğinin öyle vazgeçilmez birer parçası ki bunlar.
es: —Porque —respondió lord Henry, llevándose a la nariz una vinagrera dorada y aspirando el olor— en la actualidad se puede sobrevivir a todo, pero no a eso. La muerte y la vulgaridad son los dos hechos del siglo XIX que carecen de explicación. El café lo tomaremos en la sala de música, Dorian. Has de tocar a Chopin en mi honor. El individuo con quien se escapó mi mujer tocaba Chopin de manera verdaderamente exquisita. ¡Pobre Victoria! Le tenía mucho cariño. La casa se ha quedado muy sola sin ella. Por supuesto la vida matrimonial no es más que una costumbre, una mala costumbre. Pero la verdad es que lamentamos la pérdida incluso de nuestras peores costumbres. Quizá sean las que más lamentamos. Son una parte demasiado esencial de nuestra personalidad.
vi_translation: “Because,” Lord Henry said, passing under his nose the gold-plated latticework of an open vinaigrette, “one can survive everything nowadays except that. Death and vulgarity are the only two things in the nineteenth century that one cannot explain. Let's go have coffee in the music room, Dorian. You must play Chopin for me. The man my wife ran away with was an excellent Chopin player. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house is quite lonely without her. Of course, married life is just a habit, a bad habit. But we still regret the loss of even our worst habits. Perhaps we regret them the most. They are an essential part of our character.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry passed the gilded cage of an open ammonia bottle under his nostrils and said, "Because nowadays one can survive any disaster except death." "If there are two phenomena that we haven't managed to eliminate in the nineteenth century, they are death and vulgarity. Dorian, let's have our coffee in the music room. Play me some Chopin. The man my wife ran away with played Chopin beautifully. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house feels a bit empty without her. Although married life is nothing but a habit, a bad habit, still one misses even the worst habits. Perhaps one misses the bad ones the most. They are such an indispensable part of one's personality."
es_translation: —Because —responded Lord Henry, bringing a golden vinaigrette to his nose and inhaling the scent— nowadays one can survive everything, except that. Death and vulgarity are the two facts of the 19th century that lack explanation. We will have coffee in the music room, Dorian. You must play Chopin in my honor. The man with whom my wife ran away played Chopin in a truly exquisite manner. Poor Victoria! I was very fond of her. The house has become very lonely without her. Of course, married life is nothing but a habit, a bad habit. But the truth is that we regret the loss even of our worst habits. Perhaps they are the ones we regret the most. They are too essential a part of our personality.

en: Dorian said nothing, but rose from the table, and passing into the next room, sat down to the piano and let his fingers stray across the white and black ivory of the keys. After the coffee had been brought in, he stopped, and looking over at Lord Henry, said, “Harry, did it ever occur to you that Basil was murdered?”
vi: Dorian không nói gì, nhưng đứng lên khỏi bàn rồi đi qua phòng bên, ngồi xuống bên dương cầm và để mặc cho các ngón tay mình phiêu lãng ngang qua các phím ngà đen trắng. Sau khi cà phê được bưng vào, cậu dừng lại, và, nhìn qua huân tước Henry, nói, “Harry, anh có bao giờ nảy ra ý nghĩ là Basil đã bị giết không?”
tr: Dorian hiçbir şey söylemeyerek masadan kalktı, öbür odaya geçerek piyano başına oturdu, parmaklarını tuşların siyahlı beyazlı fildişi yüzeyinde dolaştırdı. Kahve getirildiği zaman piyano çalmayı bıraktı, Lord Henry’den yana bakarak, “Harry, Basil’in öldürülmüş olabileceği hiç aklından geçti mi?” diye sordu.
es: Dorian no dijo nada, pero se levantó de la mesa y, pasando a la habitación vecina, se sentó ante el piano y dejó que sus dedos se perdieran sobre el marfil blanco y negro de las teclas. Cuando trajeron el café dejó de tocar y, volviéndose hacia lord Henry, dijo: —Harry, ¿se te ha ocurrido pensar alguna vez que quizá Basil Hallward haya muerto asesinado?
vi_translation: Dorian said nothing, but rose from the table and walked to the next room, sitting down at the piano and letting his fingers wander across the black and white ivory keys. After the coffee was brought in, he stopped, and, looking at Lord Henry, said, "Harry, have you ever thought that Basil might have been murdered?"
tr_translation: Dorian stood up from the table without saying anything, went to the other room, and sat at the piano, letting his fingers roam over the black and white ivory keys. When the coffee was brought, he stopped playing the piano and looked towards Lord Henry, "Harry, did it ever occur to you that Basil might have been murdered?" he asked.
es_translation: Dorian said nothing, but he got up from the table and, moving to the adjacent room, sat at the piano and let his fingers wander over the black and white ivory of the keys. When they brought the coffee, he stopped playing and, turning to Lord Henry, said: —Harry, has it ever occurred to you that perhaps Basil Hallward was murdered?

en: Lord Henry yawned. “Basil was very popular, and always wore a Waterbury watch. Why should he have been murdered? He was not clever enough to have enemies. Of course, he had a wonderful genius for painting. But a man can paint like Velasquez and yet be as dull as possible. Basil was really rather dull. He only interested me once, and that was when he told me, years ago, that he had a wild adoration for you and that you were the dominant motive of his art.”
vi: Huân tước Henry ngáp dài. “Basil rất bình dân, và luôn đeo đồng hồ Waterbury1. Sao anh ta lại có thể bị giết được? Anh ta cũng không đủ khôn ngoan để có kẻ thù. Dĩ nhiên anh ta có thiên tài phi thường về hội họa. Nhưng một người có thể vẽ như Velasquez mà vẫn đần độn được chứ. Basil thật sự là khá đần. Anh ta chỉ làm tôi chú ý đến một lần, đó là khi anh ta bảo tôi, nhiều năm trước, là anh ta mê cậu điên cuồng, và cậu là mô-típ chủ đạo trong nghệ thuật của anh ta.” 1 Một loại đồng hồ rẻ tiền thời đó.
tr: Lord Henry esnedi. “Basil çok sevilen bir kişiydi, her zaman da Waterbury marka bir saat taşırdı. Neden öldürülsün? Düşman edinecek kadar zeki değildi. Ressam olarak bir dâhiydi, tabii. Gelgelelim insan Velasquez gibi resim yaptığı halde alabildiğine donuk, can sıkıcı olabilir. Basil de gerçekten biraz donuktu. Yalnızca bir kez ilgimi çekti. O da yıllar önce, sana deli gibi tapındığını söylediği zaman. Sanatına yön veren egemen gücün sen olduğunu söylemişti.
es: Lord Henry bostezó. —Basil era muy popular, y siempre llevaba un reloj Waterbury[19] . ¿Por qué tendrían que haberlo asesinado? No era lo bastante inteligente como para hacerse enemigos. Es cierto que poseía un gran talento para la pintura. Pero una persona puede pintar como Velázquez y ser perfectamente aburrido. Basil lo era. Sólo me interesó una vez, y fue cuando me dijo, hace años, que te adoraba locamente, y que eras el motivo dominante de su arte.
vi_translation: Lord Henry yawned. "Basil is very down-to-earth, and always wears a Waterbury watch. How could he possibly have been killed?" He wasn't even clever enough to have enemies. Of course, he had an extraordinary genius for painting. But a person can paint like Velasquez and still be stupid. Basil was really quite dull. He only caught my attention once, and that was when he told me, many years ago, that he was madly in love with you, and you were the central motif in his art." 1 A cheap type of watch at that time.
tr_translation: Lord Henry yawned. “Basil was a much-loved person, and he always carried a Waterbury brand watch. Why would he be killed? He wasn't smart enough to make enemies. As a painter, he was a genius, of course. However, a person can paint like Velasquez and still be extremely dull and boring. Basil was indeed a bit dull. He only caught my interest once. That was years ago when he told you he adored you madly. He had said that you were the dominant force guiding his art.”
es_translation: Lord Henry yawned. —Basil was very popular, and he always wore a Waterbury watch[19]. Why would anyone have wanted to murder him? He wasn't smart enough to make enemies. It's true that he had great talent for painting. But a person can paint like Velázquez and still be perfectly boring. Basil was. He only interested me once, and that was when he told me, years ago, that he adored you madly, and that you were the dominant motive of his art.

en: “I was very fond of Basil,” said Dorian with a note of sadness in his voice. “But don’t people say that he was murdered?”
vi: “Tôi rất thương Basil,” Dorian nói, với nốt buồn trong giọng. “Nhưng mọi người không nói là anh ta bị giết à
tr: Dorian sesinde bir hüzün titreşimiyle, “Ben Basil’i çok severdim,” dedi. “Ama onun cinayete kurban gitmiş olduğunu söyleyen yok mu?
es: —Yo le tenía mucho cariño —dijo Dorian con una nota de tristeza en la voz—. Pero, ¿no dice la gente que lo han asesinado?
vi_translation: “I care about Basil a lot,” Dorian said, with a note of sadness in his voice. “But didn't people say he was murdered?”
tr_translation: Dorian said with a tremor of sadness in his voice, "I loved Basil very much." "But isn't there anyone saying that he was murdered?"
es_translation: —I was very fond of him —said Dorian with a note of sadness in his voice—. But, don't people say that he was murdered?

en: “Oh, some of the papers do. It does not seem to me to be at all probable. I know there are dreadful places in Paris, but Basil was not the sort of man to have gone to them. He had no curiosity. It was his chief defect.”
vi: “Ôi, vài tờ báo có nói. Tôi thấy dường như chuyện ấy hoàn toàn không thể xảy ra. Tôi biết có những nơi khủng khiếp ở Paris, nhưng Basil không phải loại người đến đấy. Anh ta không tò mò. Đó là nhược điểm chính của anh ta.”
tr: “Kimi gazeteler öyle yazıyor, ama bana hiç de olacak şeymiş gibi gelmiyor. Biliyorum, Paris’te feci yerler var, ama Basil buralara gidecek tipten adam değil ki. Hiç meraklı değildi. Onun başlıca kusuruydu bu.
es: —Lo dicen algunos periódicos, pero a mí no me parece nada probable. Sé que hay lugares terribles en París, pero Basil no era el tipo de persona que va a esos sitios. No tenía curiosidad. Era su principal defecto.
vi_translation: “Oh, some newspapers mentioned it. I find it seems completely impossible. I know there are terrible places in Paris, but Basil is not the kind of person who would go there. He is not curious. That is his main weakness.”
tr_translation: “Some newspapers write that way, but it doesn't seem like something that would happen to me. I know there are terrible places in Paris, but Basil is not the type of man to go to such places. He was never curious. That was his main flaw.”
es_translation: —Some newspapers say so, but it doesn't seem likely to me at all. I know there are terrible places in Paris, but Basil wasn't the type of person who goes to those places. He wasn't curious. That was his main flaw.

en: “What would you say, Harry, if I told you that I had murdered Basil?” said the younger man. He watched him intently after he had spoken.
vi: “Anh sẽ nói gì, Harry, nếu tôi bảo anh là tôi đã giết Basil?” người trẻ hơn nói. Cậu nhìn y chăm chú sau khi cậu đã nói xong.
tr: Dorian, “Harry, Basil’i ben öldürdüm, desem ne dersin?” diye sordu. Konuşurken gözlerini arkadaşının yüzünden ayırmamıştı.
es: —¿Qué dirías, Harry, si te confesara que había asesinado a Basil? —dijo el más joven. Luego se lo quedó mirando fijamente.
vi_translation: “What would you say, Harry, if I told you that I had killed Basil?” the younger man said. He looked at him intently after he had finished speaking.
tr_translation: Dorian asked, "Harry, what would you say if I told you I killed Basil?" As he spoke, he did not take his eyes off his friend's face.
es_translation: —What would you say, Harry, if I confessed that I had murdered Basil? —said the younger man. Then he stared at him intently.

en: “I would say, my dear fellow, that you were posing for a character that doesn’t suit you. All crime is vulgar, just as all vulgarity is crime. It is not in you, Dorian, to commit a murder. I am sorry if I hurt your vanity by saying so, but I assure you it is true. Crime belongs exclusively to the lower orders. I don’t blame them in the smallest degree. I should fancy that crime was to them what art is to us, simply a method of procuring extraordinary sensations.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ nói, bạn yêu quý ơi, là cậu đang diễn một nhân vật không hợp với mình. Mọi tội ác đều thô tục, hệt như mọi sự thô tục đều là tội lỗi. Cậu không có khả năng, Dorian, phạm tội giết người. Tôi xin lỗi nếu tôi làm tổn thương niềm kiêu hãnh của cậu vì nói vậy, nhưng tôi cam đoan với cậu là đó là sự thật. Tội ác thuộc riêng về tầng lớp dưới. Tôi không đổ lỗi cho họ chút nào. Tôi có thể hình dung là tội ác với họ cũng như nghệ thuật với chúng ta, chỉ là một phương pháp tìm cảm giác lạ.”
tr: “Sana yakışmayan bir rol oynuyorsun, derim, dostum. Bütün ağır suçlar bayağıdır, aynı zamanda bütün bayağılıklar da ağır bir suçtur. Cinayet işlemek sana göre değil, Dorian. Böyle demekle gururunu incitiyorsam üzgünüm, ama inan bana, doğruyu söylüyorum. Ağır suçlar tümüyle aşağı sınıflara özgüdür. Onları zerrece kınamıyorum. Bana öyle geliyor ki bizim için sanat neyse onlar için de suç işlemek o: yani olağandışı heyecanlar yaratmanın bir yöntemi.
es: —Diría, mi querido amigo, que tratas de representar un papel que no te va en absoluto. Todo delito es vulgar, de la misma manera que todo lo vulgar es delito. No está en tu naturaleza, Dorian, cometer un asesinato. Siento herir tu vanidad diciéndolo, pero te aseguro que es verdad. El crimen pertenece en exclusiva a las clases bajas. No se lo censuro ni por lo más remoto. Imagino que para ellos es como el arte para nosotros, una manera de procurarse sensaciones extraordinarias.
vi_translation: “I would say, my dear friend, that you are playing a character that does not suit you. All crime is vulgar, just as all vulgarity is a crime. You do not have the capacity, Dorian, to commit murder. I apologize if I hurt your pride by saying so, but I assure you that it is the truth. Crime belongs exclusively to the lower classes. I do not blame them at all. I can imagine that crime to them is like art to us, merely a method of seeking new sensations.”
tr_translation: “You are playing a role that doesn't suit you, my friend, I would say. All serious crimes are vulgar, and at the same time, all vulgarities are serious crimes. Committing murder is not for you, Dorian. If saying this hurts your pride, I am sorry, but believe me, I am telling the truth. Serious crimes are entirely characteristic of the lower classes. I do not condemn them in the slightest. It seems to me that committing crimes for them is what art is for us: a method of creating extraordinary excitements.”
es_translation: —I would say, my dear friend, that you are trying to play a role that does not suit you at all. Every crime is vulgar, just as everything vulgar is a crime. It is not in your nature, Dorian, to commit a murder. I regret hurting your vanity by saying this, but I assure you it is true. Crime belongs exclusively to the lower classes. I do not blame them in the slightest. I imagine that for them it is like art is for us, a way to procure extraordinary sensations.

en: “A method of procuring sensations? Do you think, then, that a man who has once committed a murder could possibly do the same crime again? Don’t tell me that.”
vi: “Một phương pháp tìm cảm giác lạ? Vậy anh nghĩ là một người từng phạm tội giết người sẽ có thể phạm lại cùng một tội như vậy lần nữa? Đừng bảo tôi thế.”
tr: “Olağandışı heyecanlar yaratmanın bir yöntemi ha? Yani sana göre, bir kez cinayet işlemiş olan biri bu suçu bir daha işleyebilir, öyle mi? Laf değil bu.
es: —¿Una manera de procurarse sensaciones? ¿Crees, entonces, que una persona que una vez ha cometido un asesinato podría reincidir en el mismo delito? No me digas que eso es cierto.
vi_translation: “A method to find a strange sensation? So you think that a person who has committed murder once will be able to commit the same crime again? Don't tell me that.”
tr_translation: “A method to create extraordinary excitement, huh? So, according to you, someone who has committed murder once can commit this crime again, right? This is no joke.”
es_translation: —A way to procure sensations? Do you think, then, that a person who has once committed a murder could relapse into the same crime? Don't tell me that's true.

en: “Oh! anything becomes a pleasure if one does it too often,” cried Lord Henry, laughing. “That is one of the most important secrets of life. I should fancy, however, that murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that one cannot talk about after dinner. But let us pass from poor Basil. I wish I could believe that he had come to such a really romantic end as you suggest, but I can’t. I dare say he fell into the Seine off an omnibus and that the conductor hushed up the scandal. Yes: I should fancy that was his end. I see him lying now on his back under those dull-green waters, with the heavy barges floating over him and long weeds catching in his hair. Do you know, I don’t think he would have done much more good work. During the last ten years his painting had gone off very much.”
vi: “Ôi! Bất cứ cái gì cũng có thể trở thành niềm vui nếu người ta làm nó quá thường xuyên,” huân tước kêu lên, cười to. “Đó là một trong những bí mật quan trọng nhất của đời. Tuy vậy tôi có thể hình dung rằng tội giết người luôn là một sai lầm. Ta không bao giờ nên làm gì mà ta lại không thể kể lại sau bữa tối. Nhưng thôi ta bỏ qua Basil đáng thương đi. Tôi ước gì tôi có thể tin là anh ta đã đến được một cái kết thúc thật sự lãng mạn như cậu gợi ý; nhưng tôi không thể. Tôi dám chắc là anh ta đã rớt xuống sông Seine từ một chiếc xe buýt, và rằng người bán vé đã ỉm vụ tai tiếng ấy đi. Vâng: tôi cho rằng đó là cái kết của anh ta. Tôi thấy anh ta lúc này đang nằm ngửa dưới mặt nước xanh đục ấy với những chiếc sà lan nặng trĩu trôi bên trên anh ta, và cỏ dại dài thượt mắc vào tóc anh ta. Cậu biết không, tôi không nghĩ là anh ta lại làm được tác phẩm nào tốt hơn nhiều nữa. Trong thời gian mười năm gần đây, tranh của anh ta chán đi rất nhiều.”
tr: Lord Henry, “Oo, aşırıya kaçtığın zaman her şey zevk olup çıkar,” diye güldü. “Yaşamın en önemli gizlerinden biridir bu. Zaten bana sorarsan cinayet işlemek her zaman hatadır. İnsan, yemek sonrası söyleşilerinde konuşamayacağı hiçbir şey yapmamalıdır. Ama zavallı Basil’i geçelim. Senin aklına gelen öyle romantik bir son, keşke onun başına gelmiş olsa. Ama sanmıyorum. Bence arabadan Seine Irmağı’na düşmüştür, arabanın sürücüsü de olayı örtbas etmiştir. Evet, evet, onun sonu böyle olmuştur bence. Şu anda görür gibiyim: O donuk yeşil suların altında, sırtüstü uzanıyor, o ağır mavnalar onun tepesinden gelip geçiyor, uzun su sazları saçlarına dolanıyor. Biliyor musun, Basil’in bundan sonra pek iyi ürünler verebileceğini sanmıyorum. Şu son on yılda çalışmalarının niteliği iyice düşmüştü.
es: No me digas que eso es cierto. —Cualquier cosa se convierte en placer si se hace con suficiente frecuencia —exclamó lord Henry, riendo—. Ése es uno de los secretos más importantes de la vida. Pero me parece, de todos modos, que el asesinato es siempre una equivocación. Nunca se debe hacer nada de lo que no se pueda hablar después de cenar. Pero vamos a olvidarnos del pobre Basil. Me gustaría poder creer que ha terminado de una manera tan romántica como tú sugieres, pero no puedo. Mi opinión, más bien, es que se cayó en el Sena desde la victoria de un autobús, y que el conductor echó tierra sobre el asunto para evitar el escándalo. Sí; imagino que fue así como acabó. Lo veo tumbado de espaldas bajo esas aguas de color verde mate con las pesadas barcazas pasándole por encima y con las algas enganchadas en el pelo. ¿Sabes? No creo que hubiera hecho en el futuro nada que mereciera la pena. Durante los últimos diez años su pintura había caído mucho.
vi_translation: “Oh! Anything can become a joy if one does it too often,” the lord exclaimed, laughing loudly. “That is one of the most important secrets of life. However, I can imagine that murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that one cannot recount after dinner. But let's leave poor Basil aside. I wish I could believe that he met a truly romantic end as you suggested; but I cannot. I am sure he fell into the Seine from a bus, and that the conductor covered up the scandal. Yes: I suppose that was his end. I see him now lying on his back under that murky water with heavy barges floating above him, and long weeds tangled in his hair. You know, I don't think he would have produced much better work anymore. In the last ten years, his paintings have become very dull.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed, "Oh, when you go to extremes, everything becomes a pleasure." "This is one of the most important secrets of life. In my opinion, committing murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that cannot be talked about after dinner. But let's move on from poor Basil. I wish the romantic end you thought of had happened to him. But I don't think so. I think he fell from the carriage into the Seine River, and the driver covered it up. Yes, yes, I believe that was his end. I can almost see it now: lying on his back under those dull green waters, with heavy barges passing over him, long water reeds tangled in his hair. You know, I don't think Basil could have produced much good work after this. The quality of his work had significantly declined in the last ten years."
es_translation: Don't tell me that's true. —Anything becomes a pleasure if done often enough —exclaimed Lord Henry, laughing—. That is one of the most important secrets of life. But it seems to me, anyway, that murder is always a mistake. One should never do anything that cannot be talked about after dinner. But let's forget about poor Basil. I would like to believe that he ended in as romantic a way as you suggest, but I can't. My opinion, rather, is that he fell into the Seine from the top of a bus, and the driver covered it up to avoid scandal. Yes; I imagine that's how it ended. I see him lying on his back under those matte green waters with heavy barges passing over him and seaweed tangled in his hair. You know? I don't think he would have done anything worthwhile in the future. For the last ten years, his painting had declined a lot.

en: Dorian heaved a sigh, and Lord Henry strolled across the room and began to stroke the head of a curious Java parrot, a large, grey-plumaged bird with pink crest and tail, that was balancing itself upon a bamboo perch. As his pointed fingers touched it, it dropped the white scurf of crinkled lids over black, glasslike eyes and began to sway backwards and forwards.
vi: Dorian thốt ra một tiếng thở dài, còn huân tước Henry lững thững đi ngang phòng và bắt đầu vuốt ve đầu một con vẹt Java kỳ lạ, một con chim lớn lông xám, với đuôi và mào hồng, đang tự giữ thăng bằng trên một cành tre. Lúc những ngón tay nhọn của y chạm vào nó, nó buông cái màng vẩy trắng của các mí mắt nhăn nheo xuống qua đôi mắt đen như kính, và bắt đầu lắc tới lắc lui.
tr: Dorian içini çekti, Lord Henry karşı köşeye yürüdü, bambu bir tüneğin üzerinde dengelenen ilginç bir Java papağanının başını okşamaya başladı. İbiğiyle kuyruğu pembe, tüyleri kurşuni, iri bir kuştu bu. Lord Henry’nin sivri uçlu parmakları dokununca, o kırışık gözkapaklarının beyaz kabuğunu cam gibi kara gözlerinin üstüne indirdi ve öne arkaya sallanmaya başladı.
es: Dorian dejó escapar un suspiro, y lord Henry cruzó la habitación y empezó a acariciar la cabeza de un curioso loro de Java, un ave de gran tamaño y plumaje gris, cresta y cola rojas, que se mantenía en equilibrio sobre una percha de bambú. Al tocarle aquellos dedos afilados, dejó caer la blanca espuma de sus párpados arrugados sobre ojos semejantes a cristales negros, y empezó a mecerse.
vi_translation: Dorian let out a sigh, while Lord Henry strolled leisurely across the room and began to stroke the head of a strange Java parrot, a large gray-feathered bird with a pink tail and crest, balancing itself on a bamboo branch. As his sharp fingers touched it, it lowered the white membrane of its wrinkled eyelids over its glassy black eyes and began to sway back and forth.
tr_translation: Dorian sighed, Lord Henry walked to the opposite corner and began to stroke the head of an interesting Java parrot balanced on a bamboo perch. It was a large bird with a pink crest and tail, and gray feathers. When Lord Henry's pointed fingers touched it, it lowered the white shell of its wrinkled eyelids over its glassy black eyes and began to sway back and forth.
es_translation: Dorian let out a sigh, and Lord Henry crossed the room and began to stroke the head of a curious Java parrot, a large bird with gray plumage, red crest and tail, which balanced itself on a bamboo perch. When touched by those sharp fingers, it let the white foam of its wrinkled eyelids fall over eyes resembling black crystals, and began to sway.

en: “Yes,” he continued, turning round and taking his handkerchief out of his pocket; “his painting had quite gone off. It seemed to me to have lost something. It had lost an ideal. When you and he ceased to be great friends, he ceased to be a great artist. What was it separated you? I suppose he bored you. If so, he never forgave you. It’s a habit bores have. By the way, what has become of that wonderful portrait he did of you? I don’t think I have ever seen it since he finished it. Oh! I remember your telling me years ago that you had sent it down to Selby, and that it had got mislaid or stolen on the way. You never got it back? What a pity! it was really a masterpiece. I remember I wanted to buy it. I wish I had now. It belonged to Basil’s best period. Since then, his work was that curious mixture of bad painting and good intentions that always entitles a man to be called a representative British artist. Did you advertise for it? You should.”
vi: “Vâng,” y nói tiếp, quay lại, lấy khăn tay ra khỏi túi; “tranh của anh ta đúng là chán đi. Tôi thấy dường như nó đã đánh mất gì đó. Nó mất một lý tưởng. Khi cậu và anh ta không còn là bạn bè thân thiết nữa, anh ta dường như cũng không còn là một nghệ sỹ lớn. Cái gì đã chia tách các cậu? Tôi cho là anh ta đã làm cậu chán. Nếu vậy thì anh ta sẽ không bao giờ tha thứ cho cậu. Đó là một thói quen mà những kẻ chán ngắt hay có. À này, chuyện gì đã xảy ra với bức tranh tuyệt diệu mà anh ta làm cho cậu? Tôi không nghĩ là tôi từng có lúc thấy nó từ lúc anh ta hoàn thành nó. Ôi! Tôi nhớ cậu có kể có tôi nghe nhiều năm trước rằng cậu đã gửi nó xuống Selby, và rằng nó bị thất lạc hoặc bị ăn trộm trên đường. Cậu không bao giờ lấy lại được nó sao? Tiếc thật! Nó thật sự là một kiệt tác. Tôi nhớ là tôi muốn mua nó. Tôi ước gì giờ này tôi có nó. Nó thuộc về thời kỳ tốt nhất của Basil. Từ dạo ấy, tác phẩm của anh ta là sự pha trộn lạ lùng giữa hội họa tồi tệ và những mục đích tốt đẹp, một thứ vẫn luôn cho người ta cái quyền được gọi là một nghệ sỹ Anh tiêu biểu. Cậu có đăng báo tìm nó không? Cậu nên làm.”
tr: Lord Henry geri dönerek, “Evet,” diye sözünü sürdürdü. “Resimlerinin kalitesi düşmüştü. Bir şeyler eksilmişti bence. Bir ideal yitmişti. Seninle olan bütün dostluğu sona erince onun resminin büyüklüğü de sona erdi. Sahi, neden uzaklaştınız birbirinizden? Basil senin canını sıkmıştır sanırım. Öyleyse seni hiç bağışlamamıştır. Sıkıcı kişilerin huyudur bu. Lafı açılmışken, senin harika bir portreni çizmişti, ne oldu o? Bittikten sonra hiç görmedim, sanıyorum. Ha, anımsadım; yıllar önce Selby’ye yollamıştın da yolda kaybolmuştu ya da çalınmıştı. Hiç bulamadın ha? Ne yazık! Gerçek bir başyapıttı. Anımsıyorum, satın almak istemiştim. Keşke almış olsaydım! Basil’in resminin en iyi dönemiydi. O zamandan bu yana çalışmaları bir iyi niyetle kötü resim karışımı olup çıktı ki bu tuhaf bileşimi çizen adam nedense örnek İngiliz sanatçısı adına layık görülür. İlan filan verdin mi portre için? Vermelisin.
es: —Sí —continuó lord Henry, volviéndose y sacando un pañuelo del bolsillo—, pintaba cada vez peor. Era como si hubiera perdido algo. Probablemente un ideal. Cuando dejasteis de ser grandes amigos, Basil dejó de ser un gran artista. ¿Qué fue lo que os separó? Imagino que te aburría soberanamente. Si es así, nunca te lo perdonó. Es una costumbre que tienen las personas aburridas. Por cierto, ¿qué ha sido de aquel maravilloso retrato que te hizo? No creo haber vuelto a verlo desde que lo terminó. ¡Sí, claro! Hace años me dijiste, ahora lo recuerdo, que lo habías enviado a Selby y que se perdió o lo robaron por el camino. ¿Nunca lo recuperaste? ¡Qué lástima! Era realmente una obra maestra. Recuerdo que quise comprarlo. Ojalá lo hubiera hecho. Pertenecía al mejor periodo de Basil. Desde entonces, su obra ha tenido esa mezcla curiosa de mala pintura y buenas intenciones que siempre da derecho a decir de alguien que es un artista británico representativo. ¿No publicaste anuncios para intentar recuperarlo? Deberías haberlo hecho.
vi_translation: “Yes,” he continued, turning around, taking a handkerchief out of his pocket; “his paintings are indeed boring. It seems to me that they have lost something. They have lost an ideal. When you and he were no longer close friends, he also seemed to no longer be a great artist. What separated you two? I suppose he bored you. If so, he will never forgive you. That is a habit that boring people tend to have. By the way, what happened to the wonderful painting he made for you? I don't think I've ever seen it since he finished it. Oh! I remember you told me many years ago that you sent it down to Selby, and that it got lost or stolen on the way. Did you never get it back? What a pity! It was truly a masterpiece. I remember I wanted to buy it. I wish I had it now. It belonged to Basil's best period. Since then, his work has been a strange mix of bad painting and good intentions, something that always gives one the right to call him a typical English artist. Did you advertise for it? You should.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry, turning back, continued, "Yes," he said. "The quality of his paintings had declined. Something was missing, in my opinion. An ideal had been lost. When his friendship with you ended, so did the greatness of his painting. By the way, why did you two drift apart? I suppose Basil must have bored you. In that case, he never forgave you. It's the nature of boring people. Speaking of which, he had painted a wonderful portrait of you, what happened to it? I don't think I ever saw it after it was finished. Oh, I remember; you sent it to Selby years ago and it got lost or stolen on the way. You never found it, did you? What a pity! It was a true masterpiece. I remember, I wanted to buy it. I wish I had! It was the best period of Basil's painting. Since then, his works have become a mix of good intentions and bad paintings, and for some reason, the man who draws this strange combination is deemed worthy of the title of exemplary English artist. Did you ever put out an ad for the portrait? You should."
es_translation: —Yes —continued Lord Henry, turning around and taking a handkerchief out of his pocket—, he was painting worse and worse. It was as if he had lost something. Probably an ideal. When you stopped being great friends, Basil stopped being a great artist. What was it that separated you? I imagine he bored you immensely. If so, he never forgave you for it. It's a habit that boring people have. By the way, what happened to that wonderful portrait he made of you? I don't think I've seen it again since he finished it. Oh, yes! Years ago you told me, now I remember, that you had sent it to Selby and that it was lost or stolen along the way. Did you never recover it? What a pity! It was truly a masterpiece. I remember I wanted to buy it. I wish I had done so. It belonged to Basil's best period. Since then, his work has had that curious mix of bad painting and good intentions that always gives one the right to say someone is a representative British artist. Didn't you publish ads to try to recover it? You should have done so.

en: “I forget,” said Dorian. “I suppose I did. But I never really liked it. I am sorry I sat for it. The memory of the thing is hateful to me. Why do you talk of it? It used to remind me of those curious lines in some play—Hamlet, I think—how do they run?—
vi: “Tôi quên,” Dorian nói. “Tôi nghĩ mình đã làm. Nhưng tôi chưa bao giờ thật sự thích nó. Tôi lấy làm tiếc là đã ngồi làm mẫu cho nó. Ký ức về thứ ấy thật đáng ghét với tôi. Sao anh lại nói về nó? Nó hay nhắc tôi nhớ về những dòng thơ lạ kỳ ấy trong một vở kịch nào đó — Hamlet, tôi nghĩ là vậy — nó được viết sao nhỉ?...
tr: Dorian, “Anımsamıyorum,” dedi. “Verdim, herhalde. Zaten ben o portreyi gerçekte hiç sevmemiştim. Anısından bile nefret ediyorum. Nereden lafını açtın? O portre bana bir oyunda duyduğum tuhaf dizeleri anımsatırdı. Hamlet’teydi sanırım. Dur bakayım, nasıldı?
es: —No lo recuerdo —dijo Dorian—. Supongo que lo hice. Pero lo cierto es que nunca me gustó de verdad. Siento haber posado para él. Su recuerdo me resulta odioso. ¿Por qué hablas de aquel retrato? Siempre me recordaba esos curiosos versos de alguna obra, creo que Hamlet... ¿cómo son, exactamente?
vi_translation: “I forgot,” Dorian said. “I think I did. But I never really liked it. I regret having sat for it. The memory of it is really unpleasant to me. Why do you talk about it? It often reminds me of those strange lines in some play — Hamlet, I think — how does it go?...
tr_translation: Dorian said, "I don't remember." "I probably gave it away. Anyway, I never really liked that portrait. I even hate its memory. Why did you bring it up? That portrait reminded me of some strange lines I heard in a play. I think it was in Hamlet. Let me see, how did it go?
es_translation: —I don't remember —said Dorian—. I suppose I did. But the truth is that I never really liked it. I'm sorry I posed for him. His memory is odious to me. Why do you talk about that portrait? It always reminded me of those curious verses from some play, I think Hamlet... how do they go, exactly?

en: “Like the painting of a sorrow,
vi: Như bức tranh đau buồn,
tr: Bir hüznün resmi gibi,
es: ¿O eres como imagen de dolor,
vi_translation: Like a sorrowful painting,
tr_translation: Like a picture of sorrow,
es_translation: Or are you like an image of sorrow,

en: A face without a heart.”
vi: Một bộ mặt không tim.
tr: Kalbi olmayan bir yüz.
es: como un rostro sin alma?
vi_translation: A heartless face.
tr_translation: A face without a heart.
es_translation: like a face without a soul?

en: Yes: that is what it was like.”
vi: Vâng: nó giống như vậy.”
tr: Evet, portre tıpkı böyleydi işte.
es: Sí: eso es lo que era.
vi_translation: Yes: it is like that."
tr_translation: Yes, the portrait was just like that."
es_translation: Yes: that is what it was.

en: Lord Henry laughed. “If a man treats life artistically, his brain is his heart,” he answered, sinking into an arm-chair.
vi: Huân tước Henry bật cười. “Nếu ai nhìn đời như nghệ sỹ, não hắn là tim hắn,” y trả lời, hạ mình xuống ghế bành.
tr: Lord Henry güldü. “İnsan hayatı da sanat yerine koyarsa, kalbi beynidir,” diyerek bir koltuğa gömüldü.
es: Lord Henry se echó a reír. —Si una persona trata la vida artísticamente, su cerebro es su alma —respondió, hundiéndose en un sillón.
vi_translation: Lord Henry laughed. "If one looks at life as an artist, his brain is his heart," he replied, lowering himself into an armchair.
tr_translation: Lord Henry laughed. "If one treats life as a work of art, the heart is the brain," he said, sinking into an armchair.
es_translation: Lord Henry burst out laughing. —If a person treats life artistically, their brain is their soul —he replied, sinking into an armchair.

en: Dorian Gray shook his head and struck some soft chords on the piano. “‘Like the painting of a sorrow,’” he repeated, “‘a face without a heart.’”
vi: Dorian Gray lắc đầu, gõ vài hợp âm dịu dàng lên dương cầm. “Như bức tranh đau buồn,” cậu nhắc lại, “một bộ mặt không tim.”
tr: Dorian Gray başını salladı, sonra piyanoda birkaç yumuşak nota çaldı. “Bir hüznün resmi gibi,” diye yineledi. “Kalbi olmayan bir yüz.
es: Dorian Gray movió la cabeza y extrajo del piano algunos acordes melancólicos. —«Imagen de dolor» —repitió—, «rostro sin alma».
vi_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head, gently striking a few chords on the piano. "Like the sorrowful painting," he repeated, "a heartless face."
tr_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head, then played a few soft notes on the piano. "Like a picture of sadness," he repeated. "A face without a heart."
es_translation: Dorian Gray shook his head and drew some melancholy chords from the piano. —"Image of pain" —he repeated—, "soulless face."

en: The elder man lay back and looked at him with half-closed eyes. “By the way, Dorian,” he said after a pause, “‘what does it profit a man if he gain the whole world and lose—how does the quotation run?—his own soul’?”
vi: Người già hơn nằm ngửa nhìn cậu với đôi mắt nhắm hờ. “À này, Dorian,” y nói, sau một lúc ngập ngừng, “một người có lợi gì nếu hắn giành được cả thế gian để rồi đánh mất’ — câu trích dẫn ấy được viết sao nhỉ? — ‘linh hồn chính hắn’?”
tr: Arkadaşı arkasına yaslanmış, yarı kapalı gözlerle onu süzüyordu. Biraz sonra, “Ha, Dorian,” dedi. “Hani bir söz vardır: Bir insan ki ruhunu yitirmiştir, tüm dünya onun olsa bile... Nasıldı bundan sonrası?.. Kaç para eder... miydi?
es: Su amigo de más edad se recostó en el sillón y lo contempló con los ojos medio cerrados. —Por cierto, Dorian —dijo, después de una pausa—, «¿y qué aprovecha al hombre»..., ¿cómo acaba exactamente la cita?, «ganar todo el mundo y perder su alma[20] ?»
vi_translation: The older man lay on his back, looking at him with half-closed eyes. "Ah, Dorian," he said, after a moment of hesitation, "what does it profit a man if he gains the whole world but loses' — how is that quote written again? — 'his own soul'?"
tr_translation: His friend leaned back, eyeing him with half-closed eyes. A little later, he said, "Ah, Dorian." "There is a saying: A man who has lost his soul, even if he owns the whole world... How did it go after that?.. How much would it be worth... was it?"
es_translation: His older friend reclined in the armchair and gazed at him with half-closed eyes. —By the way, Dorian —he said, after a pause—, "What does it profit a man"..., how exactly does the quote end?, "to gain the whole world and lose his own soul[20]?"

en: The music jarred, and Dorian Gray started and stared at his friend. “Why do you ask me that, Harry?”
vi: Nhạc kêu chói tai và Dorian Gray giật mình, chằm chằm nhìn bạn. “Sao anh hỏi tôi thế, Harry?”
tr: Notalar birbirine karıştı; Dorian Gray irkilerek arkadaşının yüzüne bakakaldı. “Bunu bana niçin soruyorsun, Harry?”
es: El piano dejó escapar una nota desafinada y Dorian Gray, sobresaltado, se volvió a mirar a lord Henry. —¿Por qué me preguntas eso, Harry?
vi_translation: The music screeched and Dorian Gray started, staring intently at his friend. “Why do you ask me that, Harry?”
tr_translation: The notes got mixed up; Dorian Gray started and stared at his friend's face. "Why are you asking me this, Harry?"
es_translation: The piano let out a discordant note and Dorian Gray, startled, turned to look at Lord Henry. —Why do you ask me that, Harry?

en: “My dear fellow,” said Lord Henry, elevating his eyebrows in surprise, “I asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer. That is all. I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. London is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips—it was really very good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he would not have understood me.”
vi: “Bạn yêu ơi,” huân tước Henry nói, nhướng mày lên ngạc nhiên, “tôi hỏi cậu vì tôi tưởng cậu có thể cho tôi câu trả lời. Chỉ vậy thôi. Chủ Nhật vừa rồi, tôi đi qua Công viên, và gần Cổng vòm Cẩm thạch có một đám ít người nhìn tiều tụy đang nghe một gã thuyết pháp đường phố tầm thường nào đó. Lúc đi ngang qua, tôi nghe gã đó hét to câu hỏi ấy cho khán giả của mình. Nó khiến tôi chú ý đến do khá là kịch tính. London rất giàu các ấn tượng kỳ lạ kiểu này. Một Chủ Nhật ướt át, một tín đồ Cơ đốc giáo thô lỗ mặc áo mưa, một vòng mặt người trắng xanh ốm yếu dưới mái vòm nhấp nhô từ những chiếc ô đẫm nước, và một lời chấn động tâm can bị ném vào không khí bởi đôi môi cuồng loạn, the thé — nó thật sự là rất tuyệt theo cách riêng, đúng là một sự ám thị. Tôi nghĩ về việc nói với nhà tiên tri ấy rằng Nghệ thuật có linh hồn, nhưng người thì không. Tôi e là, tuy vậy, có lẽ hắn cũng không hiểu tôi.”
tr: Lord Henry kaşlarını şaşkın şaşkın kaldırarak, “İki gözüm, belki bana bilgi verebilirsin diye düşündüğüm için sordum,” diye yanıtladı. “Hepsi bu. Geçen pazar parktan geçiyordum; Mermer Kemer’in orada bir küme partal giyimli adam durmuş, kılıksız bir sokak vaizini dinlemekteydiler. Geçtiğim sırada herifin bağırarak dinleyenlere bu soruyu sorduğunu duydum. Bir hayli dramatik geldi bana. Londra’mız buna benzer garip sahneler yönünden çok zengin doğrusu. Yağmurlu bir pazar günü, sırtı yağmurluklu, hırt bir Hıristiyan, suları akan şemsiyelerin oluşturduğu delik deşik bir çatı, altında halka olmuş soluk beyaz yüzler... Sonra tiz, isterik bir sesle havaya fırlatılan nefis bir tümce... Gerçekten fevkaladeydi kendi çapında, eni konu etkiliyordu insanı. O peygamber geçinen vaize söylemek geldi içimden: Sanatın ruhu var ama insanın ruhu yoktur, diye. Ama benim ne demek istediğimi anlamayacaktı, nasılsa.
es: —Mi querido amigo —dijo lord Henry, alzando las cejas en un gesto de sorpresa—, te lo preguntaba porque te creía capaz de darme una respuesta. Eso es todo. Cuando iba por el Parque este último domingo, me encontré, cerca de Marble Arch, un grupito de gente mal vestida escuchando a un vulgar predicador callejero. Cuando pasaba por delante, oí cómo aquel hombre le gritaba esa pregunta a su público. Todo ello me pareció bastante dramático. En Londres abundan los efectos curiosos como ése. Un domingo lluvioso, un vulgar cristiano con un impermeable, un círculo de blancos rostros enfermizos bajo un techo desigual de paraguas goteantes, y una frase maravillosa lanzada al aire por unos labios histéricos y una voz chillona..., estuvo bastante bien, a su manera: toda una sugerencia. Se me ocurrió decirle al profeta que el Arte sí tiene un alma, pero no el ser humano. Mucho me temo, de todos modos, que no me hubiera entendido.
vi_translation: “My dear friend,” Lord Henry said, raising an eyebrow in surprise, “I asked you because I thought you might be able to give me an answer. That's all. Last Sunday, I was passing through the Park, and near the Marble Arch, there was a small group of haggard-looking people listening to some mediocre street preacher. As I walked by, I heard him shout that question to his audience. It caught my attention because it was quite dramatic. London is very rich in such strange impressions. A rainy Sunday, a coarse Christian zealot in a raincoat, a circle of pale, sickly faces under the arch bobbing from waterlogged umbrellas, and a soul-stirring proclamation thrown into the air by frenzied, shrill lips — it was truly quite wonderful in its own way, a real suggestion. I thought about telling that prophet that Art has a soul, but man does not. I fear, however, that he might not have understood me.”
tr_translation: Lord Henry raised his eyebrows in surprise and replied, "My dear, I asked because I thought you might be able to inform me." "That's all. Last Sunday, I was passing through the park; near the Marble Arch, a group of shabbily dressed men had stopped and were listening to a scruffy street preacher. As I passed by, I heard the fellow shouting this question to his listeners. It struck me as quite dramatic. Our London is indeed very rich in such strange scenes. A rainy Sunday, a scruffy Christian in a raincoat, a tattered roof formed by dripping umbrellas, and pale white faces gathered underneath... Then a splendid sentence thrown into the air in a shrill, hysterical voice... It was truly extraordinary in its own way, quite affecting. I felt like telling that so-called prophet: Art has a soul, but man does not. But he wouldn't have understood what I meant, anyway."
es_translation: —My dear friend —said Lord Henry, raising his eyebrows in a gesture of surprise—, I asked you because I thought you capable of giving me an answer. That's all. When I was walking through the Park this past Sunday, I came across, near Marble Arch, a small group of poorly dressed people listening to a vulgar street preacher. As I was passing by, I heard that man shouting that question to his audience. It all seemed quite dramatic to me. London abounds with curious effects like that. A rainy Sunday, a vulgar Christian in a raincoat, a circle of pale sickly faces under an uneven roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase thrown into the air by hysterical lips and a shrill voice... it was quite good, in its own way: quite suggestive. It occurred to me to tell the prophet that Art does have a soul, but not the human being. I'm very much afraid, however, that he wouldn't have understood me.

en: “Don’t, Harry. The soul is a terrible reality. It can be bought, and sold, and bartered away. It can be poisoned, or made perfect. There is a soul in each one of us. I know it.”
vi: “Đừng, Harry. Linh hồn là một thứ khủng khiếp có thật. Nó có thể bị mua bán và đổi chác. Nó có thể bị đầu độc, hoặc được làm cho hoàn hảo. Có linh hồn trong mỗi chúng ta. Tôi biết.”
tr: “Sus, Harry. Ruh müthiş bir gerçek. Alınıyor, satılıyor, takas edilebiliyor. Ruhu zehirlemek de, yüceleştirmek de olası. Hepimizin içinde bir ruh var. Ben biliyorum bunu.
es: —No digas eso, Harry. El alma es una terrible realidad. Se puede comprar y vender, y hasta hacer trueques con ella. Se la puede envenenar o alcanzar la perfección. Todos y cada uno de nosotros tenemos un alma. Lo sé muy bien.
vi_translation: “Don't, Harry. The soul is a terrible thing that truly exists. It can be bought and sold. It can be poisoned, or made perfect. There is a soul in each of us. I know.”
tr_translation: “You know, Harry. The soul is an amazing reality. It can be bought, sold, and traded. It is possible to poison the soul or to elevate it. We all have a soul within us. I know this.”
es_translation: —Don't say that, Harry. The soul is a terrible reality. It can be bought and sold, and even traded. It can be poisoned or perfected. Each and every one of us has a soul. I know it very well.

en: “Do you feel quite sure of that, Dorian?”
vi: “Cậu có cảm thấy chắc chắn về điều ấy không, Dorian?”
tr: “Bundan iyice emin misin, Dorian?
es: —¿Estás seguro, Dorian?
vi_translation: "Do you feel certain about that, Dorian?"
tr_translation: “Are you absolutely sure about this, Dorian?”
es_translation: —Are you sure, Dorian?

en: “Quite sure.”
vi: “Chắc chắn.
tr: “Kesinlikle.
es: —Completamente seguro.
vi_translation: “Sure.”
tr_translation: “Absolutely.”
es_translation: —Completely sure.

en: “Ah! then it must be an illusion. The things one feels absolutely certain about are never true. That is the fatality of faith, and the lesson of romance. How grave you are! Don’t be so serious. What have you or I to do with the superstitions of our age? No: we have given up our belief in the soul. Play me something. Play me a nocturne, Dorian, and, as you play, tell me, in a low voice, how you have kept your youth. You must have some secret. I am only ten years older than you are, and I am wrinkled, and worn, and yellow. You are really wonderful, Dorian. You have never looked more charming than you do to-night. You remind me of the day I saw you first. You were rather cheeky, very shy, and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but not in appearance. I wish you would tell me your secret. To get back my youth I would do anything in the world, except take exercise, get up early, or be respectable. Youth! There is nothing like it. It’s absurd to talk of the ignorance of youth. The only people to whose opinions I listen now with any respect are people much younger than myself. They seem in front of me. Life has revealed to them her latest wonder. As for the aged, I always contradict the aged. I do it on principle. If you ask them their opinion on something that happened yesterday, they solemnly give you the opinions current in 1820, when people wore high stocks, believed in everything, and knew absolutely nothing. How lovely that thing you are playing is! I wonder, did Chopin write it at Majorca, with the sea weeping round the villa and the salt spray dashing against the panes? It is marvellously romantic. What a blessing it is that there is one art left to us that is not imitative! Don’t stop. I want music to-night. It seems to me that you are the young Apollo and that I am Marsyas listening to you. I have sorrows, Dorian, of my own, that even you know nothing of. The tragedy of old age is not that one is old, but that one is young. I am amazed sometimes at my own sincerity. Ah, Dorian, how happy you are! What an exquisite life you have had! You have drunk deeply of everything. You have crushed the grapes against your palate. Nothing has been hidden from you. And it has all been to you no more than the sound of music. It has not marred you. You are still the same.”
vi: “Chắc chắn. “À! Vậy thì nó phải là một ảo ảnh. Những thứ mà ta thấy hoàn toàn chắc về chúng thì lại chẳng bao giờ có thật. Đó là sự rủi ro của Niềm tin, là bài học của Ái tình. Sao mà cậu lại nghiêm trang đến thế! Đừng nghiêm túc như vậy. Cậu hoặc tôi thì có liên quan gì với sự mê tín của thời đại chúng ta? Không: ta đã từ bỏ lòng tin của ta vào linh hồn. Chơi gì đó cho tôi nghe đi. Chơi cho tôi nghe một dạ khúc đi, Dorian, và, lúc cậu chơi, hãy nói cho tôi hay, bằng một giọng nói khẽ khàng, rằng cậu đã giữ tuổi xuân của mình như thế nào. Chắc chắn cậu phải có bí quyết nào đó. Tôi chỉ lớn hơn cậu có mười tuổi, vậy mà tôi đã nhăn nheo, mệt mỏi, vàng vọt. Cậu thật kỳ diệu, Dorian. Cậu chưa hề có vẻ quyến rũ hơn cậu đêm nay. Cậu nhắc tôi nhớ về cái ngày tôi thấy cậu lần đầu. Cậu khá hỗn, rất nhát, và tuyệt đối phi thường. Cậu đã thay đổi, dĩ nhiên rồi, nhưng không ở vẻ ngoài. Tôi mong cậu kể tôi nghe về bí quyết của cậu. Để trẻ lại, tôi sẽ làm bất cứ việc gì trên đời, ngoại trừ tập luyện, dậy sớm, hoặc sống lành mạnh. Tuổi trẻ! Chẳng có gì giống nó. Thật ngớ ngẩn khi nói về sự dốt nát của tuổi trẻ. Những người duy nhất mà bây giờ tôi còn nghe ý kiến của họ với một chút tôn trọng là những người trẻ hơn tôi nhiều. Họ dường như ở phía trước tôi. Cuộc đời để lộ cho họ thấy những sự diệu kỳ mới nhất của nó. Còn về người già, tôi luôn mâu thuẫn với người già. Tôi làm việc ấy theo nguyên tắc. Nếu cậu hỏi quan điểm họ về điều gì đó xảy ra hôm qua, họ sẽ long trọng cho cậu biết những quan điểm thịnh hành năm 1820, khi con người còn đi tất cao, tin mọi cái và không biết cái gì cả. Sao mà cái thứ cậu đang chơi lại đáng yêu làm vậy! Tôi tự hỏi có phải Chopin viết nó ở Majorca, với biển khóc quanh nhà, và muối bắn tung lên các ô cửa kính? Nó lãng mạn phi thường. May mắn làm sao khi còn một nghệ thuật không thể bắt chước được để lại cho ta! Đừng dừng lại. Đêm nay tôi cần nhạc. Tôi thấy dường như cậu là Apollo trẻ, và tôi là Marsyas đang lắng nghe cậu. Tôi có những nỗi buồn, Dorian, của riêng tôi, mà ngay cả cậu cũng tuyệt nhiên không biết. Bi kịch tuổi già không phải là người ta đã già, mà là người ta còn trẻ. Tôi đôi khi ngạc nhiên với sự thành thật của chính mình. Ôi, Dorian, sao mà cậu hạnh phúc vậy! Cậu đã có một cuộc đời tuyệt vời làm sao! Cậu đã uống cạn mọi thứ. Cậu đã nghiền nho trên vòm miệng mình. Chẳng có gì giấu được khỏi cậu. Và nó với cậu hoàn toàn không hơn gì tiếng nhạc. Nó không làm hỏng cậu. Cậu vẫn vậy.”
tr: “Hmm. Bir yanılsama olsa gerek. İnsanın yüzde yüz emin olduğu şeyler hiçbir zaman doğru değildir. İmanın felaketi ve de romantizmin öğrettiği ders budur işte. Nasıl da ciddisin! Kuzum, böylesine ciddi olmasana. Çağımızın kör inanlarıyla senin benim ne ilişkimiz var? Yok, yok, biz ruhun varlığına olan inancımızdan vazgeçmiş kişileriz. Bir şeyler çal bana. Bir noktürn çal bana, Dorian. Çalarken de, bir yandan, alçak sesle bana gençliğini nasıl koruduğunu anlat. Bir giz biliyor olmalısın. Ben senden topu topu on yaş büyüğüm, oysa buruştum, yıprandım, rengim uçtu. Sen sahiden olağanüstü bir şeysin sanki. Seni ilk gördüğüm günü getiriyorsun aklıma. Az buçuk küstah, pek utangaç, görülmedik bir şeydin. Değiştin, doğallıkla, ama görünüş yönünden değil. Gizini keşke bana da söylesen. Gençliğimi geri getirebilmek uğruna her şeyi yaparım: Jimnastik yapmak, erken kalkmak, bir de namuslu bir vatandaş olmak dışında, her şeyi. Ah gençlik! Gençlik gibisi var mı? Gençliğin cahilliğinden dem vurmak ne gülünçlük! Şimdilerde görüşlerini saygıyla dinlediğim insanlar yalnızca benden eni konu genç olanlardır. Benim önüme geçmişler gibi geliyor. Yaşam en son harikasını onlara açıklamış. Yaşlılara gelince; ben yaşlıların her düşüncesine karşı çıkıyorum. İlke olarak yapıyorum bunu. Onlara dün olmuş bir şeyle ilgili görüşlerini sor: Sana 1820’lerde geçerli olan görüşleri aktarırlar, hani herkesin uzun çorap giydiği, her şeye inandığı ve de zırnık bir şey bilmediği günler. O çaldığın şey ne kadar güzel! Chopin bunu Mayorka’da mı yazmış acaba? Deniz, villasının eteklerinde ağlar, tuzlu köpükler pencere camlarına vururken? Harika romantik. Elimizde öykünmeci olmayan hiç değilse bir sanat dalının kalmış olması ne büyük nimet! Sakın durma. Bu gece müzik istiyorum. Sanki sen Apollon’muşsun, ben de sana kulak veren Marsyas’mışım gibi geliyor. Ah, Dorian, benim de kendime göre öyle hicranlarım var ki sen bile bilmiyorsun. Yaşlılığın trajedisi insanın ihtiyarlaması değil de genç kalmasıdır. Kimi zaman kendi içtenliğime şaşıyorum. Ah, Dorian, ne mutlu sana! Nasıl da nefis bir yaşam sürdün! Her şeyi dolu dolu yaşadın. Dünya nimetlerini tattın. Hayatın gizlisi saklısı kalmadı senin için. Gene de sen bunların hepsini müzik dinlercesine geçiştirdin. Kötü iz kalmadı üzerinde. Neydiysen gene osun.
es: —¡Ah! entonces tiene que ser una ilusión. Las cosas de las que uno está completamente seguro nunca son verdad. Ésa es la fatalidad de la fe y la lección del romanticismo. ¡Qué aire más solemne! No te pongas tan serio. ¿Qué tenemos tú y yo que ver con las supersticiones de nuestra época? No; nosotros hemos renunciado a creer en el alma. Toca un nocturno para mí, Dorian, y, mientras tocas, dime, en voz baja, cómo has hecho para conservar la juventud. Has de tener algún secreto. Sólo te llevo diez años, pero tengo arrugas y estoy gastado y amarillo. Tú eres realmente admirable, Dorian. Nunca me has parecido tan encantador como esta noche. Haces que recuerde el día en que te conocí. Eras bastante impertinente, muy tímido y absolutamente extraordinario. Has cambiado, por supuesto, pero tu aspecto no. Me gustaría que me dijeras tu secreto. Haría cualquier cosa para recuperar la juventud, excepto ejercicio, levantarme pronto o ser respetable... ¡Juventud! No hay nada como la juventud. Es absurdo hablar de la ignorancia de la juventud. Las únicas personas cuyas opiniones escucho con respeto son las de personas mucho más jóvenes que yo. Parecen ir por delante de mí. La vida les ha revelado sus maravillas más recientes. En cuanto a las personas de edad, siempre les llevo la contraria. Lo hago por principio. Si les pides su opinión sobre algo que sucedió ayer, te dan con toda solemnidad las opiniones que corrían en 1820, cuando la gente llevaba medias altas, creía en todo y no sabían absolutamente nada. ¡Qué hermoso es eso que estás tocando! Me pregunto si Chopin lo escribió en Mallorca, con el mar llorando alrededor de la villa donde vivía, y con gotas de agua salada golpeando los cristales. ¡Maravillosamente romántico! ¡Es una bendición que todavía nos quede un arte no imitativo! No te detengas. Esta noche necesito música. Me pareces el joven Apolo, y yo soy Marsias, escuchándote. Tengo mis propios sufrimientos, Dorian, de los que ni siquiera tú estás enterado. La tragedia de la ancianidad no es ser viejo, sino joven. A veces me sorprende mi propia sinceridad. ¡Ah, Dorian, qué feliz eres! ¡Qué vida tan exquisita la tuya! Has bebido hasta saciarte de todos los placeres. Has saboreado las uvas más maduras. Nada se te ha ocultado. Y todo ello no ha sido para ti más que unos compases musicales. Nada te ha echado a perder. Sigues siendo el mismo.
