vi_translation: "Ah! Then it must be an illusion. The things we are completely certain about never actually exist. That is the risk of Faith, the lesson of Love. Why are you so serious! Don't be so serious. What do you or I have to do with the superstitions of our age? No: I have abandoned my belief in the soul. Play something for me. Play a nocturne for me, Dorian, and, as you play, tell me softly how you have kept your youth. Surely you must have some secret. I am only ten years older than you, yet I am wrinkled, tired, and sallow. You are marvelous, Dorian. You have never looked more charming than you do tonight. You remind me of the day I first saw you. You were quite insolent, very shy, and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but not in appearance. I wish you would tell me your secret. To be young again, I would do anything in the world, except take exercise, get up early, or be respectable. Youth! Nothing is like it. It's really foolish to talk about the ignorance of youth. The only people whose opinions I still listen to with a bit of respect now are those much younger than me. They seem to be ahead of me. Life reveals to them its latest wonders. As for the old, I always have conflicts with the old. I do it on principle. If you ask their opinion on something that happened yesterday, they will solemnly tell you the prevailing opinions of 1820, when people still wore high socks, believed everything, and knew nothing. How lovely the thing you are playing is! I wonder if Chopin wrote it in Majorca, with the sea crying around the house, and salt spraying up on the window panes? It's extraordinarily romantic. How fortunate that there is still an art left to us that cannot be imitated! Don't stop. I need music tonight. I feel as if you are young Apollo, and I am Marsyas listening to you. I have my own sorrows, Dorian, that even you absolutely do not know. The tragedy of old age is not that one is old, but that one is young. I sometimes marvel at my own honesty. Oh, Dorian, how happy you are! What a wonderful life you have had! You have drained everything. You have crushed grapes on your palate. Nothing is hidden from you. And it is to you nothing more than music. It hasn't spoiled you. You are still the same.”
tr_translation: “Hmm. It must be an illusion. The things one is a hundred percent sure of are never true. This is the disaster of faith and the lesson taught by romanticism. How serious you are! My dear, don't be so serious. What do you and I have to do with the blind beliefs of our age? No, no, we are people who have given up our belief in the existence of the soul. Play me something. Play me a nocturne, Dorian. And while playing, tell me in a low voice how you have kept your youth. You must know a secret. I am only ten years older than you, yet I am wrinkled, worn out, and faded. You truly seem to be something extraordinary. You remind me of the day I first saw you. Somewhat arrogant, very shy, you were something unseen. You have changed, naturally, but not in appearance. I wish you would tell me your secret. I would do anything to get my youth back: anything except exercise, getting up early, and being a respectable citizen. Oh youth! Is there anything like youth? How ridiculous it is to talk about the ignorance of youth! Nowadays, the only people whose opinions I listen to with respect are those who are considerably younger than me. They seem to have surpassed me. Life has revealed its latest marvel to them. As for the old; I oppose every thought of the old. I do this as a principle. Ask them their opinion about something that happened yesterday: They will tell you the views that were valid in the 1820s, the days when everyone wore long socks, believed in everything, and knew nothing. What you are playing is so beautiful! Did Chopin write this in Majorca? While the sea wept at the foot of his villa, and the salty foam hit the window panes? Wonderful romantic. What a great blessing it is that we still have at least one art form that is not imitative! Don't stop. I want music tonight. It feels as if you are Apollo, and I am Marsyas listening to you. Oh, Dorian, I have such sorrows of my own that even you do not know. The tragedy of old age is not that one is old, but that one is young. Sometimes I am amazed at my own sincerity. Oh, Dorian, how lucky you are! What a wonderful life you have led! You have lived everything to the fullest. You have tasted the pleasures of the world. There is no secret left in life for you. Yet you have passed through all of this as if listening to music. No bad trace remains on you. You are still what you were.”
es_translation: —Ah! then it must be an illusion. The things one is completely sure of are never true. That is the fatality of faith and the lesson of romanticism. What a solemn air! Don't get so serious. What do you and I have to do with the superstitions of our time? No; we have renounced believing in the soul. Play a nocturne for me, Dorian, and while you play, tell me, in a low voice, how you have managed to keep your youth. You must have some secret. I'm only ten years older than you, but I have wrinkles and I'm worn and yellow. You are truly admirable, Dorian. You have never seemed so charming to me as tonight. You make me remember the day I met you. You were quite impertinent, very shy, and absolutely extraordinary. You have changed, of course, but your appearance has not. I would like you to tell me your secret. I would do anything to regain youth, except exercise, get up early, or be respectable... Youth! There is nothing like youth. It is absurd to talk about the ignorance of youth. The only people whose opinions I listen to with respect are those much younger than me. They seem to be ahead of me. Life has revealed its latest wonders to them. As for older people, I always contradict them. I do it on principle. If you ask their opinion about something that happened yesterday, they solemnly give you the opinions that were current in 1820, when people wore high stockings, believed in everything, and knew absolutely nothing. How beautiful is that which you are playing! I wonder if Chopin wrote it in Mallorca, with the sea crying around the villa where he lived, and with drops of salt water hitting the windows. Wonderfully romantic! It is a blessing that we still have a non-imitative art! Don't stop. Tonight I need music. You seem to me like young Apollo, and I am Marsyas, listening to you. I have my own sufferings, Dorian, of which even you are unaware. The tragedy of old age is not being old, but young. Sometimes my own sincerity surprises me. Ah, Dorian, how happy you are! What an exquisite life you have! You have drunk your fill of all pleasures. You have tasted the ripest grapes. Nothing has been hidden from you. And all of it has been nothing more to you than a few musical bars. Nothing has spoiled you. You remain the same.

en: “I am not the same, Harry.”
vi: “Tôi không còn như thế nữa đâu, Harry.”
tr: “Değilim Harry.
es: —No soy el mismo, Harry.
vi_translation: “I'm not like that anymore, Harry.”
tr_translation: “I'm not, Harry.”
es_translation: —I'm not the same, Harry.

en: “Yes, you are the same. I wonder what the rest of your life will be. Don’t spoil it by renunciations. At present you are a perfect type. Don’t make yourself incomplete. You are quite flawless now. You need not shake your head: you know you are. Besides, Dorian, don’t deceive yourself. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a question of nerves, and fibres, and slowly built-up cells in which thought hides itself and passion has its dreams. You may fancy yourself safe and think yourself strong. But a chance tone of colour in a room or a morning sky, a particular perfume that you had once loved and that brings subtle memories with it, a line from a forgotten poem that you had come across again, a cadence from a piece of music that you had ceased to play—I tell you, Dorian, that it is on things like these that our lives depend. Browning writes about that somewhere; but our own senses will imagine them for us. There are moments when the odour of lilas blanc passes suddenly across me, and I have to live the strangest month of my life over again. I wish I could change places with you, Dorian. The world has cried out against us both, but it has always worshipped you. It always will worship you. You are the type of what the age is searching for, and what it is afraid it has found. I am so glad that you have never done anything, never carved a statue, or painted a picture, or produced anything outside of yourself! Life has been your art. You have set yourself to music. Your days are your sonnets.”
vi: “Phải: cậu vẫn như thế. Tôi tự hỏi quãng đời còn lại của cậu sẽ thế nào. Đừng làm hỏng nó bằng những sự từ bỏ. Lúc này cậu đang là một hình mẫu hoàn hảo. Đừng tự biến mình thành kẻ không toàn diện. Cậu bây giờ hoàn toàn không tì vết. Cậu không cần lắc đầu: cậu biết cậu thế mà. Vả lại, Dorian, đừng lừa mình. Đời không bị chi phối bởi ý chí hay mục đích. Đời là vấn đề của hệ thần kinh, các thớ thịt, và những tế bào chầm chậm lớn lên, nơi tư tưởng giấu mình và đam mê có những giấc mơ riêng. Cậu có thể cho là mình an toàn, và nghĩ mình mạnh mẽ. Nhưng một tông màu tình cờ trong một căn phòng hoặc trên bầu trời ban mai, một mùi hương đặc biệt mà cậu từng có lần yêu và mang những ký ức huyền ảo theo nó, một dòng từ bài thơ nào đó đã quên mà cậu lại tình cờ bắt gặp, một giai điệu từ một nhạc phẩm mà cậu đã thôi chơi — tôi cho cậu biết, Dorian, rằng cuộc sống chúng ta dựa vào chính những thứ như thế. Browning đã viết về chúng ở đâu đó; nhưng cảm xúc của chính ta sẽ tưởng tượng ra chúng cho ta. Có những khoảnh khắc mà mùi thơm của lilas blanc1 đột nhiên bay ngang qua tôi, và tôi phải sống lại tuần trăng kỳ lạ nhất đời mình lần nữa. Tôi ước gì tôi có thể đổi chỗ với cậu, Dorian. Thiên hạ kêu ca cả hai ta, nhưng nó luôn tôn thờ cậu. Nó sẽ luôn tôn thờ cậu. Cậu là hình mẫu tiêu biểu của cái mà thời đại này vẫn tìm kiếm, và của cái mà e là nó đã tìm ra. Tôi rất vui vì cậu chưa hề làm bất cứ thứ gì, chưa từng tạc tượng, vẽ tranh, hoặc tạo ra bất cứ thứ gì ở ngoài cậu! Đời là nghệ thuật của cậu. Cậu đã phổ nhạc cho mình. Ngày tháng của cậu là bản xô-nê của cậu.” 1 Tử đinh hương trắng.
tr: “Yok, yok, hep aynısın. Yaşamın bundan sonra nasıl geçecek, çok merak ediyorum. Fedakârlıklarla berbat etme bunu. Şu halinle mükemmelsin, tamsın. Eksilme. Hiç kusursuzsun şimdi. Başını sallamanın gereği yok: Kusursuz olduğunu sen de biliyorsun. Hem zaten, kendi kendini de aldatma, Dorian. Hayat irade ya da niyetle yönetilmiyor. Hayat bir sinir ve lif sorunudur, hücre sorunu. Düşüncelerimiz bu ağır oluşan hücrelere girip gizlenir, tutkularımız buralarda barınıp düşler kurar. Sen kendini güvenlikte sanırsın belki, güçlü olduğuna inanırsın. Gel gör ki bir odada ya da sabahleyin gökyüzünde gözüne rastgele çarpan bir renk tonu bir zamanlar sevdiğin bir kokunun beraberinde getirdiği gizli anılar, çoktan çalmadığın bir müzikten bir ezgi, unutulmuş bir şiirin yeniden karşına çıkan bir satırı... İnan bana, Dorian, hayatımız böyle şeylere bağlıdır. Browning bu konuyu yazmış bir şiirinde. Sonra bizim kendi duyularımız da bu şeyleri kimi zaman bizim adımıza anımsar, düşler. Öyle anlar olur ki burnuma birden beyaz leylak kokusu gelir, hayatımın en tuhaf ayını yeni baştan yaşamak zorunda kalırım. Ah, Dorian, keşke seninle yer değiştirebilsem! Çevremiz ikimizi de çoğu kez kınadı, ama sana her zaman taptı. Her zaman da tapacak. Sen çağımızın hem aradığı hem de bulmaktan korktuğu imgesin. Ömründe tek bir şey üretmediğine öyle seviniyorum ki! Ne bir heykel yonttun ne bir resim çizdin ne de herhangi bir şey ortaya çıkardın, kendin dışında! Yaşam, senin sanatın oldu. Sen kendi kendini besteledin. Yaşadığın günlerdir senin şiirlerin.
es: —Sí que lo eres. Me pregunto cómo será el resto de tu vida. No la estropees con renunciaciones. En el momento presente eres la perfección misma. No te hagas voluntariamente incompleto. No te falta nada. No muevas la cabeza: sabes que es así. Además, Dorian, no te engañes. La vida no se gobierna ni con la voluntad ni con la intención. La vida es una cuestión de nervios, de fibras, y de células lentamente elaboradas en las que el pensamiento se esconde y la pasión tiene sus sueños. Quizá te imaginas que estás a salvo y crees que eres fuerte. Pero un cambio casual de color en una habitación o en el color del cielo matutino, un determinado perfume que te gustó en una ocasión y que te trae recuerdos sutiles, un verso de un poema olvidado con el que te tropiezas de nuevo, una cadencia de una composición musical que has dejado de tocar... Te aseguro, Dorian, que la vida depende de cosas como ésas. Browning escribe acerca de ello en algún sitio, pero nuestros propios sentidos lo inventan para nosotros. Hay momentos en los que el olor a lilas blancas me domina de repente, y tengo que vivir de nuevo el mes más extraño de mi vida. Bien quisiera cambiarme contigo, Dorian. El mundo no se cansa de denunciarnos a los dos, pero a ti siempre te ha rendido culto. Y siempre lo hará. Eres el prototipo de lo que busca esta época nuestra y tiene miedo de haber encontrado. ¡Me alegro muchísimo de que nunca hayas hecho nada, de que nunca hayas tallado una estatua, ni pintado un cuadro, ni producido nada distinto de tu persona! La vida ha sido tu arte. Has hecho música de ti mismo. Tus días son tus sonetos.
vi_translation: “Right: you are still the same. I wonder what the rest of your life will be like. Don't ruin it with abandonments. Right now you are a perfect model. Don't turn yourself into an incomplete person. You are now completely flawless. You don't need to shake your head: you know you are. Moreover, Dorian, don't deceive yourself. Life is not governed by will or purpose. Life is a matter of nerves, fibers, and slowly growing cells, where thought hides and passion has its own dreams. You may think you are safe, and believe you are strong. But a chance tone in a room or on the morning sky, a particular scent you once loved and that carries with it magical memories, a line from some forgotten poem that you happen to come across, a melody from a piece of music that you have stopped playing — I tell you, Dorian, that our lives depend on such things. Browning wrote about them somewhere; but our own emotions will imagine them for us. There are moments when the scent of lilas blanc1 suddenly passes by me, and I have to relive the strangest honeymoon of my life once again. I wish I could trade places with you, Dorian. People complain about both of us, but they always worship you. They will always worship you. You are the quintessential model of what this age seeks, and what I fear it has found. I am very glad that you have never done anything, never sculpted a statue, painted a picture, or created anything outside of yourself! Life is your art. You have set your own music. Your days are your sonnet.” 1 White lilac.
tr_translation: “No, no, you are always the same. I am very curious about how your life will go on from now. Don't ruin it with sacrifices. You are perfect as you are, complete. Don't diminish. You are flawless now. There's no need to shake your head: you know you are flawless. And besides, don't deceive yourself, Dorian. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a matter of nerves and fibers, a matter of cells. Our thoughts enter and hide in these slowly forming cells, our passions dwell and dream there. You may think you are safe, you may believe you are strong. But then a shade of color that randomly catches your eye in a room or in the morning sky, the hidden memories brought by a scent you once loved, a melody from music you haven't heard in a long time, a line from a forgotten poem that reappears... Believe me, Dorian, our lives depend on such things. Browning wrote a poem on this subject. Then our own senses sometimes remember and dream of these things on our behalf. There are moments when the scent of white lilac suddenly comes to my nose, and I am forced to relive the strangest month of my life. Oh, Dorian, I wish I could trade places with you! Our surroundings often condemned both of us, but they always adored you. And they always will. You are the image that our age both seeks and fears to find. I am so glad you have never produced a single thing in your life! You have neither sculpted a statue nor painted a picture nor created anything, except yourself! Life became your art. You composed yourself. The days you lived are your poems.”
es_translation: —Yes, you are. I wonder what the rest of your life will be like. Don't ruin it with renunciations. At the present moment, you are perfection itself. Don't make yourself voluntarily incomplete. You lack nothing. Don't shake your head: you know it's true. Moreover, Dorian, don't deceive yourself. Life is not governed by will or intention. Life is a matter of nerves, of fibers, and of slowly elaborated cells in which thought hides and passion has its dreams. You might imagine that you are safe and believe that you are strong. But a casual change of color in a room or in the morning sky, a certain perfume that you liked once and that brings back subtle memories, a verse from a forgotten poem that you stumble upon again, a cadence from a musical composition that you have stopped playing... I assure you, Dorian, that life depends on things like those. Browning writes about it somewhere, but our own senses invent it for us. There are moments when the smell of white lilacs suddenly overpowers me, and I have to relive the strangest month of my life. I would gladly change places with you, Dorian. The world never tires of denouncing us both, but it has always worshipped you. And it always will. You are the prototype of what this era of ours seeks and fears it has found. I am so glad that you have never done anything, never carved a statue, nor painted a picture, nor produced anything other than yourself! Life has been your art. You have made music of yourself. Your days are your sonnets.

en: Dorian rose up from the piano and passed his hand through his hair. “Yes, life has been exquisite,” he murmured, “but I am not going to have the same life, Harry. And you must not say these extravagant things to me. You don’t know everything about me. I think that if you did, even you would turn from me. You laugh. Don’t laugh.”
vi: Dorian đứng dậy khỏi dương cầm và vuốt tay qua tóc. “Vâng, đời thật tuyệt,” cậu thì thầm, “nhưng tôi sẽ không sống cuộc đời như thế nữa, Harry. Và anh không nên nói quá lời về tôi. Anh không biết hết về tôi đâu. Tôi nghĩ là nếu anh mà biết thì thậm chí anh sẽ quay lưng với tôi. Anh cười ư. Đừng cười.”
tr: Dorian piyano başından kalkarak elini saçlarının arasından geçirdi. “Evet, nefis bir yaşam sürdüm,” diye mırıldandı. “Gelgelelim aynı yaşamı sürdürecek değilim, Harry. Sen de böyle ölçüsüz şeyler söyleme bana. Beni hiç tanımıyorsun. Tanısan sanırım benden yüz çevirirdin. Gülüyorsun. Gülme.
es: Dorian se levantó del piano y se pasó la mano por el cabello. —Sí; la vida me ha dado placeres exquisitos —murmuró—, pero voy a cambiar, Harry. Y no debes hacerme esos elogios tan excesivos. No lo sabes todo. Creo que si lo supieras, también tú te alejarías de mí. Ríes. No debieras hacerlo.
vi_translation: Dorian stood up from the piano and ran his hand through his hair. “Yes, life is wonderful,” he whispered, “but I will not live that kind of life anymore, Harry. And you shouldn't speak too highly of me. You don't know everything about me. I think that if you knew, you might even turn your back on me. You laugh? Don't laugh.”
tr_translation: Dorian got up from the piano and ran his hand through his hair. “Yes, I have led a delightful life,” he murmured. “However, I am not going to lead the same life, Harry. Don't say such extravagant things to me. You don't know me at all. If you did, I think you would turn away from me. You are laughing. Don't laugh.”
es_translation: Dorian got up from the piano and ran his hand through his hair. —Yes; life has given me exquisite pleasures —he murmured—, but I am going to change, Harry. And you must not give me such excessive praise. You don't know everything. I think that if you knew, you too would distance yourself from me. You laugh. You shouldn't do that.

en: “Why have you stopped playing, Dorian? Go back and give me the nocturne over again. Look at that great, honey-coloured moon that hangs in the dusky air. She is waiting for you to charm her, and if you play she will come closer to the earth. You won’t? Let us go to the club, then. It has been a charming evening, and we must end it charmingly. There is some one at White’s who wants immensely to know you—young Lord Poole, Bournemouth’s eldest son. He has already copied your neckties, and has begged me to introduce him to you. He is quite delightful and rather reminds me of you.”
vi: “Sau cậu lại ngừng chơi, Dorian? Quay lại và cho tôi nghe dạ khúc ấy lần nữa đi. Hãy nhìn mặt trăng vĩ đại màu mật ong đang treo trên không trung mờ tối kia. Nàng đang chờ cậu quyến rũ nàng, và nếu cậu chơi thì nàng sẽ lại gần trái đất hơn. Cậu thôi à? Vậy thì ta hãy đi đến câu lạc bộ. Chiều nay thật đẹp, và ta phải kết thúc nó một cách đẹp đẽ. Có ai đó ở chỗ White rất muốn quen cậu — huân tước trẻ Poole, con cả của Bournemouth. Anh ta đã bắt chước cà-vạt của cậu, và cứ xin tôi giới thiệu cậu với anh ta. Anh ta rất thú vị, và phần nào nhắc tôi nhớ về cậu.”
tr: “Çalmaktan niye vazgeçtin, Dorian? Git de o noktürnü yeni baştan çal bana. Şu gölgeli gökte asılı duran kocaman bal renkli aya baksana. Senin müziğinin büyüsünü bekliyor. Sen piyano çalarsan daha yakına gelecekmiş. Çalmıyorsun ha? Kulübe gidelim öyleyse. Çok güzel bir akşam yaşadık, sonunu da güzel bitirelim. White’ın orada biri var, seninle tanışmaya can atıyor: Genç Lord Poole. Bournemouth’un büyük oğlu. Daha şimdiden, seninkiler gibi boyun bağları kullanıyor, seni tanıştırayım diye de yalvarıp duruyor. Çok sevimli, çekici bir genç, biraz da seni anımsatıyor bana.
es: —¿Por qué has dejado de tocar, Dorian? Vuelve al piano y obséquiame otra vez con ese nocturno. Contempla la enorme luna color de miel que cuelga en la oscuridad. Está esperando a que la encandiles, y si tocas se acercará más a la tierra. ¿No quieres? Vayámonos entonces al club. Ha sido una velada deliciosa y debemos acabarla de la misma manera. Hay alguien en el White que tiene un deseo inmenso de conocerte: se trata del joven lord Poole, el hijo mayor de Bournemouth. Ya te ha copiado las corbatas, y ahora me suplica que te lo presente. Es un muchacho encantador y me recuerda mucho a ti.
vi_translation: “Why did you stop playing, Dorian? Turn back and play that nocturne for me again. Look at the great honey-colored moon hanging in the dim sky. She is waiting for you to charm her, and if you play, she will come closer to the earth. Are you stopping? Then let's go to the club. This evening is so beautiful, and we must end it beautifully. Someone at White's is very eager to meet you — young Lord Poole, the eldest son of Bournemouth. He has been imitating your tie and keeps asking me to introduce you to him. He is quite interesting, and somewhat reminds me of you.”
tr_translation: “Why did you stop playing, Dorian? Go and play that nocturne for me again. Look at the huge amber-colored moon hanging in the shadowy sky. It is waiting for the magic of your music. If you play the piano, it will come closer. You're not playing, huh? Let's go to the club then. We had a very beautiful evening, let's end it nicely. There's someone at White's who is dying to meet you: Young Lord Poole. The eldest son of Bournemouth. He already wears ties like yours and keeps begging me to introduce you. A very charming, attractive young man, he reminds me a bit of you.”
es_translation: —Why did you stop playing, Dorian? Go back to the piano and delight me again with that nocturne. Look at the enormous honey-colored moon hanging in the darkness. It is waiting for you to enchant it, and if you play, it will come closer to the earth. Don't you want to? Then let's go to the club. It has been a delightful evening and we should end it in the same manner. There is someone at the White who has an immense desire to meet you: it's young Lord Poole, the eldest son of Bournemouth. He has already copied your ties, and now he begs me to introduce you to him. He is a charming boy and reminds me a lot of you.

en: “I hope not,” said Dorian with a sad look in his eyes. “But I am tired to-night, Harry. I shan’t go to the club. It is nearly eleven, and I want to go to bed early.”
vi: “Tôi hy vọng là không,” Dorian nói, với nét buồn trong mắt. “Nhưng đêm nay tôi hơi mệt, Harry. Tôi không thể đến câu lạc bộ. Gần mười một giờ rồi, và tôi muốn lên giường sớm.”
tr: Dorian gözlerini hüzünlü bir bakışla yere çevirip, “Umarım bana benzemiyordur,” dedi. “Bu gece yorgunum, Harry. Kulübe gitmeyeceğim. Saat on bire geliyor. Erken yatmak istiyorum.
es: —Espero que no —dijo Dorian, con una expresión triste en los ojos—. Lo cierto es que esta noche estoy cansado, Harry. No voy a ir al club. Son casi las once y quiero acostarme pronto.
vi_translation: “I hope not,” Dorian said, with a sad look in his eyes. “But tonight I'm a bit tired, Harry. I can't go to the club. It's almost eleven o'clock, and I want to go to bed early.”
tr_translation: Dorian turned his eyes to the ground with a sad look and said, "I hope he doesn't resemble me." "I'm tired tonight, Harry. I'm not going to the club. It's almost eleven o'clock. I want to go to bed early."
es_translation: —I hope not —said Dorian, with a sad expression in his eyes—. The truth is that tonight I'm tired, Harry. I'm not going to the club. It's almost eleven and I want to go to bed early.

en: “Do stay. You have never played so well as to-night. There was something in your touch that was wonderful. It had more expression than I had ever heard from it before.”
vi: “Thế ở lại đi. Cậu chưa bao giờ chơi hay như đêm nay. Có gì đó tuyệt vời trong ngón đàn của cậu. Nó biểu cảm hơn nhiều so với những gì tôi từng nghe được từ nó trước đây.”
tr: “Kuzum gitme. Hiç bu geceki kadar güzel piyano çalmamıştın. Bu geceki yorumun bir harikaydı. Bu derece anlamlı çaldığını şimdiye kadar hiç duymamıştım.
es: —Quédate, por favor. Nunca habías tocado tan bien como esta noche. Había algo maravilloso en tu estilo. Resultaba más expresivo que nunca.
vi_translation: "Then stay. You have never played as well as you did tonight. There is something wonderful in your playing. It is much more expressive than anything I have ever heard from it before."
tr_translation: "Please don't go. You have never played the piano as beautifully as you did tonight. Your performance tonight was marvelous. I have never heard you play with such meaning before."
es_translation: —Stay, please. You have never played as well as you did tonight. There was something wonderful about your style. It was more expressive than ever.

en: “It is because I am going to be good,” he answered, smiling. “I am a little changed already.”
vi: “Đó là vì tôi sắp sống tử tế,” cậu đáp lại, mỉm cười, “tôi đã thay đổi một chút.
tr: Dorian gülümseyerek, “İyi bir insan olmaya kararlıyım da ondan,” diye yanıtladı. “Daha şimdiden az buçuk değiştim sanki.
es: —Eso se debe a que voy a ser bueno —respondió él, sonriendo—. Ya he cambiado un poco.
vi_translation: “That is because I am about to live kindly,” he replied, smiling, “I have changed a bit.”
tr_translation: Dorian replied with a smile, "Because I am determined to be a good person." "I feel like I've already changed a little bit."
es_translation: —That is because I am going to be good —he replied, smiling—. I have already changed a bit.

en: “You cannot change to me, Dorian,” said Lord Henry. “You and I will always be friends.”
vi: “Cậu không thể thay đổi với tôi được, Dorian,” huân tước Henry nói. “Cậu và tôi sẽ luôn là bạn.
tr: Lord Henry, “Benim gözümde sen değişemezsin, Dorian,” dedi. “Seninle ömür boyu dost kalacağız.
es: —Para mí no puedes cambiar —dijo lord Henry—. Tú y yo siempre seremos amigos.
vi_translation: "You cannot change with me, Dorian," Lord Henry said. "You and I will always be friends."
tr_translation: Lord Henry, "In my eyes, you can never change, Dorian," he said. "We will remain friends for life."
es_translation: —You cannot change for me —said Lord Henry—. You and I will always be friends.

en: “Yet you poisoned me with a book once. I should not forgive that. Harry, promise me that you will never lend that book to any one. It does harm.”
vi: “Tuy nhiên anh đã đầu độc tôi bằng một cuốn sách, trước kia. Tôi không thể tha thứ cho việc ấy. Harry, hãy hứa với tôi là anh sẽ không bao giờ cho bất cứ ai mượn cuốn sách ấy nữa. Nó gây hại.”
tr: “Oysa bir zamanlar sen beni bir kitapla zehirledin. Bu yüzden seni hiç bağışlamamam gerekir. Harry, bu kitabı kimseye vermeyeceğine yemin et. Çok zarar veriyor.
es: —En una ocasión, sin embargo, me envenenaste con un libro. Eso no lo olvidaré. Harry, prométeme que nunca le prestarás ese libro a nadie. Hace daño.
vi_translation: “However, you poisoned me with a book, before. I cannot forgive that. Harry, promise me that you will never lend that book to anyone else again. It is harmful.”
tr_translation: "Yet once upon a time, you poisoned me with a book. For this reason, I should never forgive you. Harry, swear that you will not give this book to anyone. It causes a lot of harm."
es_translation: —On one occasion, however, you poisoned me with a book. I will not forget that. Harry, promise me that you will never lend that book to anyone. It causes harm.

en: “My dear boy, you are really beginning to moralize. You will soon be going about like the converted, and the revivalist, warning people against all the sins of which you have grown tired. You are much too delightful to do that. Besides, it is no use. You and I are what we are, and will be what we will be. As for being poisoned by a book, there is no such thing as that. Art has no influence upon action. It annihilates the desire to act. It is superbly sterile. The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame. That is all. But we won’t discuss literature. Come round to-morrow. I am going to ride at eleven. We might go together, and I will take you to lunch afterwards with Lady Branksome. She is a charming woman, and wants to consult you about some tapestries she is thinking of buying. Mind you come. Or shall we lunch with our little duchess? She says she never sees you now. Perhaps you are tired of Gladys? I thought you would be. Her clever tongue gets on one’s nerves. Well, in any case, be here at eleven.”
vi: “Chàng trai yêu quý của tôi, cậu thật sự bắt đầu lên mặt dạy đời rồi. Cậu sẽ sớm đi đây đi đó như người cải đạo, và nhà truyền giáo, cảnh báo mọi người đề phòng mọi tội lỗi mà cậu đã chán dần. Cậu quá đỗi thú vị để làm cái việc ấy. Vả lại, nó cũng vô ích. Cậu và tôi thế nào thì thế, ra sao thì ra. Còn với việc bị đầu độc bởi một cuốn sách, không có chuyện như vậy. Nghệ thuật không có ảnh hưởng lên hành động. Nó tiêu diệt ham muốn hành động. Nó cực kỳ vô hậu. Các cuốn sách mà thế gian gọi là đồi bại là những cuốn sách cho thế gian thấy sự xấu hổ của chính nó. Chỉ vậy thôi. Nhưng ta không bàn về văn chương. Mai hãy lại đây. Tôi sẽ đi cưỡi ngựa lúc mười một giờ. Ta có thể đi cùng nhau, và sau đó tôi sẽ đưa cậu đến ăn trưa với bà Branksome. Bà ấy là một phụ nữ hấp dẫn, và muốn hỏi ý cậu về vài tấm thảm mà bà ấy đang nghĩ xem có nên mua không. Cậu nhớ đến nhé. Hoặc ta sẽ ăn trưa với nữ công tước nhỏ của ta? Cô ấy nói là dạo này cô ấy chẳng hề thấy cậu. Không chừng cậu đã chán Gladys? Tôi nghĩ cậu sẽ vậy thôi. Miệng lưỡi sắc sảo của cô ấy chọc tức người ta. Thôi được, dẫu thế nào thì cũng cứ đến đây lúc mười một giờ nhé.”
tr: “Aman oğlum, daha şimdiden ahlak dersi vermeye başladın. Bu gidişle çok geçmeden, dine sonradan dönen yobazlar gibi ortalıkta dolaşıp kendin usanç getirdiğin günahlara karşı âlemi uyarmaya falan başlayacaksın. Oysa sen öyle şirinsin ki bunu yapmak sana hiç yaraşmaz. Zaten işe de yaramaz ki! Seninle ben neysek oyuz, her zaman da öyle kalacağız. Kitapla zehirlenmeye gelince; olmaz öyle şey. Sanatın eylem üzerinde etkisi yoktur. Sanat eyleme geçmek isteğini yok eder. Şahane bir kısırlığı vardır. Toplumun ahlaka aykırı saydığı kitaplar topluma kendi ayıbını gösteren kitaplardır. O kadar. Ama edebiyat tartışması yapacak değiliz. Yarın gene gel. Saat on birde atla çıkıyorum. Belki birlikte gideriz. Sonra da seni Leydi Branksomelar’a, öğle yemeğine götürürüm. Çok hoş bir kadın. Birkaç duvar halısı alacakmış da, sana danışmak istiyordu. Mutlaka gel, ha. Yoksa öğle yemeğini küçük düşesimizle mi yiyelim? Dediğine göre hiç görüşmüyormuşsunuz artık. Yoksa Gladys’ten bıktın mı? Tahmin etmiştim. Hazırcevaplığı insanın sinirine dokunuyor. İşte, her neyse, sen saat on birde burada ol.
es: —Mi querido muchacho, es cierto que estás empezando a moralizar. Muy pronto saldrás por ahí como los conversos y los evangelistas, poniendo a la gente en guardia contra todos los pecados de los que ya te has cansado. Eres demasiado encantador para hacer una cosa así. Además, no sirve de nada. Tú y yo somos lo que somos, y seremos lo que seremos. En cuanto a ser envenenado por un libro, no existe semejante cosa. El arte no tiene influencia sobre la acción. Aniquila el deseo de actuar. Es magníficamente estéril. Los libros que el mundo llama inmorales son libros que muestran al mundo su propia vergüenza. Eso es todo. Pero no vamos a discutir sobre literatura. Ven a verme mañana. Iré a montar a caballo a las once. Podemos hacerlo juntos y luego te llevaré a almorzar con lady Branksome. Es una mujer encantadora, y quiere hacerte una consulta sobre ciertos tapices que piensa comprar. No te olvides de venir. ¿O te parece mejor que almorcemos con nuestra duquesita? Dice que ahora no te ve nunca. ¿Acaso te has cansado de Gladys? Ya pensaba yo que terminaría por sucederte. Esa lengua suya tan inteligente acaba por exasperar a cualquiera. De todos modos, no dejes de estar aquí a las once.
vi_translation: “My dear boy, you really are beginning to moralize. You will soon be going about like a converted person, and a missionary, warning everyone against all the sins you have grown tired of. You are far too delightful to do that. Besides, it is quite useless. Whatever we are, we are. As for being poisoned by a book, there is no such thing. Art has no influence upon action. It annihilates the desire to act. It is superbly sterile. The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame. That is all. But we are not discussing literature. Come round tomorrow. I am going to ride at eleven. We might ride together, and then I will take you to lunch with Mrs. Branksome. She is a charming woman, and wants to consult you about some tapestries she is thinking of buying. Remember to come. Or shall we lunch with my little duchess? She says she never sees you now. Perhaps you are tired of Gladys? I think you are sure to be. Her clever tongue gets on one’s nerves. Well, anyhow, be here at eleven.”
tr_translation: "My dear boy, you've already started giving moral lessons. At this rate, soon you'll be wandering around like those zealots who convert to religion later in life, warning everyone about the sins that once bored you. But you're so charming that it wouldn't suit you at all to do that. Besides, it wouldn't work anyway! You and I are who we are, and we'll always stay that way. As for being poisoned by books; that's impossible. Art has no effect on action. Art destroys the desire to act. It has a magnificent sterility. The books that society considers immoral are the ones that show society its own shame. That's all. But we're not going to have a literary debate. Come again tomorrow. I'm going out on horseback at eleven. Maybe we can go together. Then I'll take you to Lady Branksome for lunch. She's a very charming woman. She wanted to consult you about buying a few tapestries. Make sure you come, okay? Or should we have lunch with our little duchess instead? Apparently, you two aren't seeing each other anymore. Or have you grown tired of Gladys? I suspected as much. Her quick wit can get on one's nerves. Anyway, be here at eleven."
es_translation: —My dear boy, it is true that you are beginning to moralize. Very soon you will go around like converts and evangelists, warning people against all the sins you have grown tired of. You are too charming to do such a thing. Besides, it is useless. You and I are what we are, and we will be what we will be. As for being poisoned by a book, no such thing exists. Art has no influence over action. It annihilates the desire to act. It is magnificently sterile. The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame. That is all. But let's not argue about literature. Come see me tomorrow. I will go horseback riding at eleven. We can do it together and then I'll take you to lunch with Lady Branksome. She is a charming woman, and she wants to consult you about certain tapestries she is thinking of buying. Don't forget to come. Or do you think it's better if we have lunch with our little duchess? She says she never sees you anymore. Have you grown tired of Gladys? I thought it would eventually happen to you. That clever tongue of hers ends up exasperating anyone. Anyway, make sure to be here at eleven.

en: “Must I really come, Harry?”
vi: “Tôi phải đến thật à, Harry?”
tr: “Gelmesem olmaz mı, Harry?
es: —¿Es necesario que venga, Harry?
vi_translation: "Do I really have to go, Harry?"
tr_translation: "Do I have to come, Harry?"
es_translation: —Is it necessary for me to come, Harry?

en: “Certainly. The park is quite lovely now. I don’t think there have been such lilacs since the year I met you.”
vi: “Hẳn rồi. Bây giờ Công viên rất đẹp. Tôi không nghĩ là ở đó từng có những bông tử đinh hương như vậy từ cái năm tôi gặp cậu.”
tr: “Olmaz ya. Park pek güzel şu mevsimde. Seninle tanıştığımız yıldan bu yana leylaklar hiç böyle açmadı sanırım.
es: —Por supuesto. Ahora el Parque está maravilloso. Creo que no ha habido nunca unas lilas tan hermosas desde el año en que te conocí.
vi_translation: “Of course. The park is very beautiful now. I don't think there were ever lilacs like that there since the year I met you.”
tr_translation: "It can't be." "The park is very beautiful this season." "I don't think the lilacs have ever bloomed like this since the year we met.""
es_translation: —Of course. Now the Park is wonderful. I don't think there have ever been such beautiful lilacs since the year I met you.

en: “Very well. I shall be here at eleven,” said Dorian. “Good night, Harry.” As he reached the door, he hesitated for a moment, as if he had something more to say. Then he sighed and went out.
vi: “Được rồi. Tôi sẽ ở đây lúc mười một giờ,” Dorian nói. “Đêm an lành nhé, Harry.” Lúc cậu đi đến cửa, cậu lưỡng lự một lát, như thể cậu có điều gì muốn nói thêm. Rồi cậu thở dài và đi ra ngoài.
tr: “Peki öyleyse,” dedi Dorian. “On birde gelirim. İyi geceler, Harry. Kapıya varınca, bir söyleyeceği daha varmış gibi bir an duraksadı. Sonra içini çekerek dışarı çıktı.
es: —Muy bien. Estaré aquí a las once —dijo Dorian—. Buenas noches, Harry. Al llegar a la puerta, vaciló un momento, como si tuviera algo más que decir. Luego dejó escapar un suspiro y abandonó la habitación.
vi_translation: “Alright. I will be here at eleven o'clock,” Dorian said. “Good night, Harry.” As he walked to the door, he hesitated for a moment, as if he had something more to say. Then he sighed and went out.
tr_translation: "Well then," said Dorian. "I'll come at eleven. Good night, Harry." When he reached the door, he hesitated for a moment as if he had something more to say. Then he sighed and went outside.
es_translation: —Very well. I will be here at eleven —said Dorian—. Good night, Harry. Upon reaching the door, he hesitated for a moment, as if he had something more to say. Then he let out a sigh and left the room.

en: CHAPTER XX.
vi: Chương 20
tr: Yirminci bölüm
es: Capítulo 20
vi_translation: Chapter 20
tr_translation: Twentieth chapter
es_translation: Chapter 20

en: It was a lovely night, so warm that he threw his coat over his arm and did not even put his silk scarf round his throat. As he strolled home, smoking his cigarette, two young men in evening dress passed him. He heard one of them whisper to the other, “That is Dorian Gray.” He remembered how pleased he used to be when he was pointed out, or stared at, or talked about. He was tired of hearing his own name now. Half the charm of the little village where he had been so often lately was that no one knew who he was. He had often told the girl whom he had lured to love him that he was poor, and she had believed him. He had told her once that he was wicked, and she had laughed at him and answered that wicked people were always very old and very ugly. What a laugh she had!—just like a thrush singing. And how pretty she had been in her cotton dresses and her large hats! She knew nothing, but she had everything that he had lost.
vi: Đó là một đêm tuyệt đẹp, ấm đến nỗi cậu vắt áo khoác lên cánh tay, và thậm chí không quàng khăn lụa quanh họng. Lúc cậu vừa lững thững về nhà, vừa hút thuốc, hai thanh niên bận dạ phục đi ngang qua cậu. Cậu nghe thấy một trong hai người thì thào với người còn lại, “Dorian Gray đấy.” Cậu nhớ mình thường hài lòng thế nào những khi được chỉ ra, hoặc nhìn theo, hoặc nói đến. Bây giờ cậu không thiết nghe tên mình nữa. Phân nửa sức hấp dẫn của cái làng nhỏ nơi mà dạo gần đây cậu rất hay đến là ở chỗ chẳng ai biết cậu là ai. Cậu hay bảo cô gái mà cậu đã dụ được tình là cậu nghèo, và nàng tin cậu. Có lần cậu còn bảo nàng là cậu rất ác, và nàng cười cậu, đáp lại rằng kẻ ác luôn rất già và rất xấu. Nàng có tiếng cười lạ làm sao! — hệt như con chim hoét cất tiếng hót. Và nàng xinh đẹp làm sao khi mặc đồ vải bông và đội những chiếc mũ rộng vành! Nàng chẳng biết gì hết, nhưng nàng có hết những gì cậu đã đánh mất.
tr: Nefis bir geceydi. Hava öyle sıcaktı ki Dorian ceketini koluna astı, ipek atkısını boynuna dolamadı bile. Gezine gezine evine dönerken, yanından smokin giymiş iki genç adam geçti. Birinin öbürüne, “İşte Dorian Gray!” diye fısıldadığını Dorian duydu. Parmakla gösterilmekten, bakılmaktan, konuşulmaktan bir zamanlar nasıl hoşlandığını anımsadı. Şimdi kendi adını duymaktan gına gelmişti. Son zamanlarda gediklisi olduğu o küçük köyün şirinliğinin yararı orada kimsenin onu tanımamasıydı. Başını döndürüp gönlünü çaldığı kıza yoksul bir genç olduğunu söylemiş, kız da ona inanmıştı. Bir gün de Dorian ona çok kötü bir insan olduğunu söyleyince kız ona gülmüş, kötü yürekli kişilerin hep çok yaşlı, çok da çirkin olduğunu ileri sürmüştü. Ne de güzel bir gülüşü vardı! Kuş şakıması gibi. O basma entarileri, kocaman şapkalarıyla nasıl güzeldi! Hiçbir şey bilmiyordu, ama Dorian’ın yitirmiş olduğu her şeye sahipti.
es: El aire de la noche era una delicia, tan tibio que Dorian Gray se colocó el abrigo sobre el brazo y ni siquiera se anudó en torno a la garganta la bufanda de seda. Mientras se dirigía hacia su casa, fumando un cigarrillo, dos jóvenes vestidos de etiqueta se cruzaron con él, y oyó cómo uno le susurraba al otro: «Ése es Dorian Gray». Recordó cuánto solía agradarle que alguien lo señalara con el dedo o se le quedara mirando y hablara de él. Ahora le cansaba oír su nombre. Buena parte del encanto del pueblecito adonde había ido con tanta frecuencia últimamente era que nadie lo conocía. A la muchacha a la que cortejó hasta enamorarla le había dicho que era pobre, y Hetty le había creído. En otra ocasión le dijo que era una persona malvada, y ella se echó a reír, respondiéndole que los malvados eran siempre muy viejos y muy feos. ¡Ah, su manera de reírse! Era como el canto de la alondra. Y ¡qué bonita estaba con sus vestidos de algodón y sus sombreros de ala ancha! Hetty no sabía nada de nada, pero poseía todo lo que él había perdido.
vi_translation: It was a beautiful night, so warm that he draped his coat over his arm and didn't even wrap his silk scarf around his neck. As he was leisurely walking home, smoking a cigarette, two young men in evening dress passed by him. He heard one of them whisper to the other, "That's Dorian Gray." He remembered how he used to feel pleased whenever he was pointed out, looked at, or talked about. Now he no longer cared to hear his own name. Half the charm of the small village he had been frequenting lately was that no one knew who he was. He often told the girl he had seduced that he was poor, and she believed him. Once he even told her that he was very wicked, and she laughed at him, replying that wicked people were always very old and very ugly. What a strange laugh she had! — just like a thrush singing. And how beautiful she looked in her cotton dresses and wide-brimmed hats! She knew nothing at all, but she had everything he had lost.
tr_translation: It was a splendid night. The weather was so warm that Dorian slung his jacket over his arm and didn't even wrap his silk scarf around his neck. As he wandered back home, two young men in tuxedos passed by him. Dorian heard one of them whisper to the other, "That's Dorian Gray!" He remembered how he once enjoyed being pointed at, looked at, and talked about. Now he was sick of hearing his own name. The charm of that small village he had recently frequented was that no one there knew him. He had told the girl who had turned his head and stolen his heart that he was a poor young man, and she had believed him. One day, when Dorian told her that he was a very bad person, she laughed at him, claiming that truly bad-hearted people were always very old and very ugly. What a beautiful laugh she had! Like the chirping of birds. How beautiful she was in those calico dresses and big hats! She knew nothing, but she possessed everything that Dorian had lost.
es_translation: The night air was a delight, so warm that Dorian Gray draped his coat over his arm and didn't even tie the silk scarf around his neck. As he headed home, smoking a cigarette, two young men in formal attire crossed paths with him, and he heard one whisper to the other, "That's Dorian Gray. "He remembered how much he used to enjoy being pointed at or stared at and talked about. Now he was tired of hearing his name. A large part of the charm of the little village he had been visiting so frequently lately was that no one knew him. To the girl he courted until she fell in love with him, he had said he was poor, and Hetty had believed him. On another occasion, he told her he was a wicked person, and she laughed, replying that the wicked were always very old and very ugly. Ah, her way of laughing! It was like the song of the lark. And how pretty she looked in her cotton dresses and wide-brimmed hats! Hetty knew nothing at all, but she possessed everything he had lost.

en: When he reached home, he found his servant waiting up for him. He sent him to bed, and threw himself down on the sofa in the library, and began to think over some of the things that Lord Henry had said to him.
vi: Khi cậu về đến nhà, cậu thấy người hầu đang thức chờ cậu. Cậu cho hắn đi ngủ, quăng mình xuống xô-pha trong thư viện, và bắt đầu ngẫm nghĩ vài điều mà huân tước Henry đã nói với cậu.
tr: Dorian evine varınca uşağının yatmamış, kendisini beklemekte olduğunu gördü. Onu yatmaya yollayınca kitaplıktaki kanepeye kendini bıraktı, Lord Henry’nin söylediği kimi şeyleri düşünmeye başladı.
es: Al llegar a su casa, encontró al ayuda de cámara esperándolo. Le dijo que se acostara, se dejó caer en un sofá de la biblioteca y empezó a pensar en las cosas que lord Henry le había dicho.
vi_translation: When he got home, he found the servant awake and waiting for him. He sent him to bed, threw himself onto the sofa in the library, and began to ponder some things that Lord Henry had said to him.
tr_translation: When Dorian arrived home, he saw that his servant had not gone to bed and was waiting for him. After sending him to bed, he threw himself onto the sofa in the library and began to think about some of the things Lord Henry had said.
es_translation: Upon arriving at his house, he found the valet waiting for him. He told him to go to bed, dropped onto a sofa in the library, and began to think about the things Lord Henry had told him.

en: Was it really true that one could never change? He felt a wild longing for the unstained purity of his boyhood—his rose-white boyhood, as Lord Henry had once called it. He knew that he had tarnished himself, filled his mind with corruption and given horror to his fancy; that he had been an evil influence to others, and had experienced a terrible joy in being so; and that of the lives that had crossed his own, it had been the fairest and the most full of promise that he had brought to shame. But was it all irretrievable? Was there no hope for him?
vi: Có đúng thật là người ta không thể thay đổi không? Cậu cảm thấy thèm khát phát điên sự thuần khiết không vương chút bụi trần của thời niên thiếu — thời niên thiếu trắng-hồng của cậu, như huân tước Henry có lần gọi nó. Cậu biết rằng cậu đã tự làm mình ô uế, đã làm tâm hồn mình ngập trong sự đồi trụy và đem những cảnh khủng khiếp vào sự tưởng tượng của mình; rằng cậu đã là kẻ gây ảnh hưởng tai hại đến người khác, đã nếm trải niềm vui dễ sợ khi sống như vậy; và rằng, trong những cuộc đời từng gặp phải đời cậu, thì chính nó lại từng là cái trong sạch nhất, đầy hứa hẹn nhất mà cậu đã làm cho ô nhục. Nhưng liệu nó có thể được phục hồi lại hết không? Có hy vọng nào cho cậu không?
tr: İnsanın asla değişemeyeceği doğru muydu acaba? Dorian’ın içi delikanlılığının o lekelenmemiş saflığına karşı –Lord Henry, gül beyazı, diye tanımlamıştı bunu bir keresinde– çılgın bir özlemle dolup taşıyordu. Kendi benliğini karartmış, zihnine kötülükler doldurmuş, hayal gücünü ürkülerle beslemişti; başkalarını şeytansı etkilemiş ve bundan korkunç bir haz duymuştu; yoluna çıkan ruhların en temizlerini, en umutla dolu olanlarını seçip utanca sürüklemişti. Dorian bunları biliyordu. Gene de... Bütün bunların onarılması mümkün değil miydi acaba? Dorian için hiç umut kalmamış mıydı?
es: ¿Era realmente cierto que no se cambia? Sentía un deseo loco de recobrar la pureza sin mancha de su adolescencia; su adolescencia rosa y blanca, como lord Henry la había llamado en una ocasión. Sabía que estaba manchado, que había llenado su espíritu de corrupción y alimentado de horrores su imaginación; que había ejercido una influencia nefasta sobre otros, y que había experimentado, al hacerlo, un júbilo incalificable; y que, de todas las vidas que se habían cruzado con la suya, había hundido en el deshonor precisamente las más bellas, las más prometedoras. Pero, ¿era todo ello irremediable? ¿No le quedaba ninguna esperanza?
vi_translation: Is it really true that people cannot change? Do you feel a maddening craving for the purity untouched by the dust of the world from your youth — your rosy-white youth, as Lord Henry once called it. You know that you have defiled yourself, have filled your soul with depravity and brought terrible visions into your imagination; that you have been a harmful influence on others, have tasted the dreadful pleasure of living like that; and that, in the lives that have encountered yours, it was the purest, most promising one that you have tainted. But can it all be restored? Is there any hope for you?
tr_translation: Was it really true that a person could never change? Dorian's heart was overflowing with a wild longing for the unblemished purity of his youth – Lord Henry had once described it as rose-white. He had darkened his own self, filled his mind with evils, and fed his imagination with terrors; he had exerted a diabolical influence on others and derived a terrible pleasure from it; he had chosen the purest, most hopeful souls that crossed his path and driven them to shame. Dorian knew these things. And yet... Was it not possible to repair all this? Was there no hope left for Dorian?
es_translation: Was it really true that one does not change? He felt a mad desire to regain the spotless purity of his adolescence; his pink and white adolescence, as Lord Henry had once called it. He knew that he was stained, that he had filled his spirit with corruption and fed his imagination with horrors; that he had exerted a harmful influence on others, and that he had experienced, in doing so, an indescribable joy; and that, of all the lives that had crossed paths with his, he had plunged precisely the most beautiful, the most promising ones into dishonor. But, was all that irremediable? Did he have no hope left?

en: Ah! in what a monstrous moment of pride and passion he had prayed that the portrait should bear the burden of his days, and he keep the unsullied splendour of eternal youth! All his failure had been due to that. Better for him that each sin of his life had brought its sure swift penalty along with it. There was purification in punishment. Not “Forgive us our sins” but “Smite us for our iniquities” should be the prayer of man to a most just God.
vi: Ôi! Trong một khoảnh khắc kỳ quái làm sao của lòng kiêu hãnh và niềm đam mê, cậu đã cầu xin rằng bức chân dung ấy sẽ mang gánh nặng tháng ngày của cậu, còn cậu giữ lại được vẻ đẹp rực rỡ không một vết nhơ của tuổi xuân bất diệt! Mọi thất bại của cậu là do đó mà ra. Chắc sẽ tốt hơn cho cậu nếu mỗi tội lỗi đời cậu đều đem một hình phạt chắc chắn, mau lẹ theo cùng. Trong trừng phạt có thanh tẩy. Không phải “Xin tha tội cho chúng con,” mà “Hãy trừng trị chúng con vì các lỗi lầm” mới nên là lời cầu nguyện của con người với Thiên Chúa rất mực công bằng.
tr: Ah! Nasıl korkunç bir kibir ve tutku dakikasında yakarmıştı, geçen günlerin yükünü portresi taşısın da kendisi sonsuz gençliğin lekesiz görkemini koruyabilsin diye! Bütün hüsranların başlangıcı bu olmuştu. Keşke işlediği her günah kesin, gecikmesiz cezasını da beraber getirseydi, böylesi çok daha iyi olurdu. Ceza görmekte kişiyi arındıran bir şey vardı. İnsanın adil bir tanrıya yönelttiği dua, “Günahlarımızı bağışla,” değil de, “Hatalarımız için bize ceza yolla,” olmalıydı.
es: Pero, ¿era todo ello irremediable? ¿No le quedaba ninguna esperanza? ¡Ah, en qué monstruoso momento de orgullo y de ceguera había rezado para que el retrato cargara con la pesadumbre de sus días y él conservara el esplendor, eternamente intacto, de la juventud! Su fracaso procedía de ahí. Hubiera sido mucho mejor para él que a cada pecado cometido le hubiera acompañado su inevitable e inmediato castigo. En lugar de «perdónanos nuestros pecados», la plegaria de los hombres a un Dios de justicia debería ser «castíganos por nuestras iniquidades».
vi_translation: Oh! In a strange moment of pride and passion, he had prayed that the portrait would bear the burden of his days, while he would retain the radiant, unblemished beauty of eternal youth! All his failures stemmed from that. It would have been better for him if every sin in his life had brought with it a sure and swift punishment. There is purification in punishment. Not "Forgive us our sins," but "Punish us for our wrongdoings" should be the prayer of man to the all-just God.
tr_translation: Ah! How he had prayed in a moment of terrible pride and passion that his portrait might bear the burden of his days, and he himself might keep the untarnished glory of eternal youth! This had been the beginning of all his misfortunes. If only every sin he committed brought its sure, swift penalty with it, it would have been much better. There was something purifying in seeing punishment. The prayer that a man should address to a just god was not, “Forgive us our sins,” but, “Send us punishment for our mistakes.”
es_translation: Did he have no hope left? Oh, in what monstrous moment of pride and blindness had he prayed for the portrait to bear the burden of his days and for him to retain the eternally intact splendor of youth! His failure stemmed from there. It would have been much better for him if each sin committed had been accompanied by its inevitable and immediate punishment. Instead of "forgive us our sins," the prayer of men to a God of justice should be "punish us for our iniquities."

en: The curiously carved mirror that Lord Henry had given to him, so many years ago now, was standing on the table, and the white-limbed Cupids laughed round it as of old. He took it up, as he had done on that night of horror when he had first noted the change in the fatal picture, and with wild, tear-dimmed eyes looked into its polished shield. Once, some one who had terribly loved him had written to him a mad letter, ending with these idolatrous words: “The world is changed because you are made of ivory and gold. The curves of your lips rewrite history.” The phrases came back to his memory, and he repeated them over and over to himself. Then he loathed his own beauty, and flinging the mirror on the floor, crushed it into silver splinters beneath his heel. It was his beauty that had ruined him, his beauty and the youth that he had prayed for. But for those two things, his life might have been free from stain. His beauty had been to him but a mask, his youth but a mockery. What was youth at best? A green, an unripe time, a time of shallow moods, and sickly thoughts. Why had he worn its livery? Youth had spoiled him.
vi: Chiếc gương chạm trổ tỉ mỉ mà huân tước Henry tặng cậu, rất nhiều năm trước đây, đang đứng trên bàn, và các thần Cupid chân tay trắng ngà vẫn cười quanh nó như xưa. Cậu cầm nó lên, như cậu từng làm trong cái đêm kinh khủng ấy, khi cậu lần đầu nhận thấy sự thay đổi trong bức tranh tai hại ấy, và với đôi mắt điên dại, mờ lệ, soi vào tấm chắn bóng láng của nó. Có lần, ai đó từng rất yêu cậu đã viết cho cậu một lá thư điên cuồng, kết bằng những lời sùng bái này: “Thế gian thay đổi vì anh được làm từ ngà voi và vàng mười. Đường cong môi anh viết lại lịch sử.” Những câu này quay lại trí nhớ cậu, và cậu nhắc đi nhắc lại chúng với mình. Sau đó cậu thấy căm ghét sắc đẹp của mình, và, quăng gương xuống sàn, nghiền nát nó thành những mảnh bạc dưới gót chân. Chính sắc đẹp của cậu đã tàn phá cậu, sắc đẹp của cậu và tuổi xuân mà cậu đã cầu xin. Nếu không vì hai thứ này thì đời cậu có thể không bị nhơ nhuốc. Với cậu thì vẻ đẹp chỉ là mặt nạ, tuổi xuân chỉ là trò hề. Tuổi xuân là gì trong trường hợp tốt nhất? Một thời gian xanh non, một thời gian của các tâm trạng hời hợt và các suy nghĩ bệnh hoạn. Sao cậu lại mặc chế phục của nó làm gì? Tuổi xuân đã làm hư cậu.
tr: Lord Henry’nin, yıllar önce vermiş olduğu o değişik oymalı ayna masanın üstünde duruyor, çevresindeki beyaz bedenli Cupidler gene eskisi gibi gülüyorlardı. Dorian uğursuz resimdeki değişimi ilk fark ettiği o korkunç gece yaptığı gibi, aynayı eline aldı, gözyaşlarının bulanıklaştırdığı çılgın gözlerle sırlı camın cilalı kalkanına baktı. Bir zamanlar, ona müthiş tutkun olan birisi çılgın bir mektup yazmış, mektubu şu sözlerle bitirmişti: “Sen fildişiyle altından yapıldığın için dünya değişti. Dudaklarının kıvrımları tarihi yeni baştan yazıyor.” Dorian bu tümceleri anımsadı, mırıldanarak yinelemeye girişti. Sonra kendi güzelliğinden tiksindi, aynayı yere çarparak topuklarının altında ezip gümüş kıymıklara ayırdı. Güzelliği mahvetmişti onu; güzelliği, bir de Tanrı’dan dilediği gençlik. Bu iki şey olmasa hayatına leke düşmeyecekti. Oysa güzelliği salt bir maske olmuştu onun için, gençliği bir hokkabazlık. Zaten en iyi anlamıyla bile, gençlik neydi. Yeşil, ham bir çağ, sığ duygularla, hastalıklı düşüncelerle dolu bir dönem. Neden gençliğin üniformasını taşımıştı sanki? Gençlik onun felaketi olmuştu.
es: El curioso espejo tallado que lord Henry le regalara hacía ya tantos años se hallaba sobre la mesa, y los cupidos de marfileñas extremidades seguían, como antaño, rodeándolo con sus risas. Lo cogió, como había hecho en aquella noche de horror, cuando por primera vez advirtiera un cambio en el retrato fatal, y con ojos desencajados, enturbiados por las lágrimas, contempló su superficie pulimentada. En una ocasión, alguien que le había amado apasionadamente le escribió una carta que concluía con esta manifestación de idolatría: «El mundo ha cambiado porque tú estás hecho de marfil y oro. La curva de tus labios vuelve a escribir la historia». Aquellas frases le volvieron a la memoria, y las repitió una y otra vez. Luego su belleza le inspiró una infinita repugnancia y, arrojando el espejo al suelo, lo aplastó con el talón hasta reducirlo a astillas de plata. Su belleza le había perdido, su belleza y la juventud por la que había rezado. Sin la una y sin la otra, quizá su vida hubiera quedado libre de mancha. La belleza sólo había sido una máscara, y su juventud, una burla. ¿Qué era la juventud en el mejor de los casos? Una época de inexperiencia, de inmadurez, un tiempo de estados de ánimo pasajeros y de pensamientos morbosos. ¿Por qué se había empeñado en vestir su uniforme? La juventud lo había echado a perder.
vi_translation: The intricately carved mirror that Lord Henry had given him, many years ago, stood on the table, and the ivory-limbed Cupids still laughed around it as before. He picked it up, as he had done on that dreadful night, when he first noticed the change in that disastrous picture, and with wild, tear-dimmed eyes, gazed into its polished shield. Once, someone who had loved him very much had written him a mad letter, ending with these adoring words: “The world changes because you are made of ivory and gold. The curves of your lips rewrite history.” These sentences came back to his memory, and he repeated them to himself. Then he grew to hate his own beauty, and, flinging the mirror to the floor, crushed it into silver splinters beneath his heel. It was his beauty that had ruined him, his beauty and the youth he had prayed for. Without these two things, his life might not have been soiled. To him, beauty was only a mask, youth was only a mockery. What was youth at its best? A green, unripe time, a time of shallow moods and sickly thoughts. Why had he worn its livery? Youth had spoiled him.
tr_translation: Lord Henry's intricately carved mirror, given to him years ago, stood on the table, with the white-bodied Cupids around it still laughing as before. Just as he had done on that dreadful night when he first noticed the change in the ominous portrait, Dorian picked up the mirror and looked into its polished shield with eyes blurred by tears of madness. Once, someone who was passionately in love with him had written a frenzied letter, ending it with these words: "The world changed because you were made of ivory and gold. The curves of your lips rewrite history." Dorian remembered these sentences and began to murmur them. Then he became disgusted with his own beauty, smashing the mirror to the ground and shattering it into silver fragments under his heels. It was his beauty that had ruined him; his beauty, and the youth he had prayed to God for. If it weren't for these two things, his life would have remained unblemished. Yet his beauty had become merely a mask for him, and his youth a deception. What was youth, even in its best sense? A green, unripe age, a period filled with shallow emotions and morbid thoughts. Why had he borne the uniform of youth? Youth had been his downfall.
es_translation: The curious carved mirror that Lord Henry had given him so many years ago was on the table, and the ivory-limbed cupids were still, as before, surrounding it with their laughter. He picked it up, as he had done on that night of horror, when he first noticed a change in the fatal portrait, and with eyes wide open, clouded by tears, he gazed at its polished surface. On one occasion, someone who had loved him passionately wrote him a letter that concluded with this declaration of idolatry: "The world has changed because you are made of ivory and gold. The curve of your lips rewrites history." Those phrases came back to his memory, and he repeated them over and over again. Then his beauty inspired in him an infinite disgust, and, throwing the mirror to the ground, he crushed it with his heel until it was reduced to silver splinters. His beauty had ruined him, his beauty and the youth for which he had prayed. Without either, perhaps his life would have remained unstained. Beauty had only been a mask, and his youth, a mockery. What was youth at best? A time of inexperience, of immaturity, a time of fleeting moods and morbid thoughts. Why had he insisted on wearing its uniform? Youth had ruined him.

en: It was better not to think of the past. Nothing could alter that. It was of himself, and of his own future, that he had to think. James Vane was hidden in a nameless grave in Selby churchyard. Alan Campbell had shot himself one night in his laboratory, but had not revealed the secret that he had been forced to know. The excitement, such as it was, over Basil Hallward’s disappearance would soon pass away. It was already waning. He was perfectly safe there. Nor, indeed, was it the death of Basil Hallward that weighed most upon his mind. It was the living death of his own soul that troubled him. Basil had painted the portrait that had marred his life. He could not forgive him that. It was the portrait that had done everything. Basil had said things to him that were unbearable, and that he had yet borne with patience. The murder had been simply the madness of a moment. As for Alan Campbell, his suicide had been his own act. He had chosen to do it. It was nothing to him.
vi: Không nghĩ về dĩ vãng thì hơn. Chẳng có gì thay đổi được nó. Chính mình, chính tương lai mình, mới là những cái cậu phải nghĩ đến. James Vane đã được giấu vào một ngôi mộ vô danh ở nghĩa địa Selby. Alan Campbell đã tự bắn mình một đêm nọ ở phòng thí nghiệm của y, nhưng không để lộ cái bí mật mà y bị ép phải biết. Sự náo động chẳng đâu vào đâu quanh vụ biến mất của Basil Hallward sẽ sớm qua đi. Nó cũng đang tàn dần. Cậu tuyệt đối an toàn. Mà thực ra thì cũng không phải cái chết của Basil Hallward đã đè nặng hơn cả lên tâm trí cậu. Chính tình trạng sống dở chết dở của linh hồn cậu mới làm khổ cậu. Basil đã vẽ ra bức chân dung làm hại đời cậu. Cậu không thể tha thứ cho y về việc ấy. Chính bức chân dung ấy đã làm tất. Basil từng nói với cậu những điều không thể chịu đựng được, và cậu vẫn còn phải kiên nhẫn chịu đựng. Vụ giết người ấy chỉ đơn giản là do cơn điên giận trong một khoảnh khắc. Còn về phần Alan Campbell, vụ tự tử của y là hành động của chính y. Y đã quyết định làm việc ấy. Nó không dính dáng gì đến cậu.
tr: Geçmişi düşünmemek daha iyiydi. Geçmişi hiçbir şey değiştiremezdi ki! Onun şimdi, kendini, kendi geleceğini düşünmesi gerekiyordu. James Vane, Selby Kilisesi’nin bahçesindeki adsız bir mezarda gömülüydü. Alan Campbell bir gece laboratuvarında kendini vurmuş, gene de öğrenmek zorunda kaldığı gizi açıklamamıştı. Basil Hallward’ın ortadan yitmesinin uyandırdığı, pek de aşırı olmayan heyecan yakında yatışırdı. Yatışmaya başlamıştı bile. Bu yönden, Dorian’ın korkacağı hiçbir şey yoktu. Doğruyu söylemek gerekirse onu en çok tasalandıran konu Basil Hallward’ın ölümü değildi. Kendi ruhunun yaşarken ölmüş olmasıydı onu asıl tedirgin eden. Basil onun hayatına gölge düşüren portreyi çizmişti. Dorian bunu bağışlayamazdı. Her şey o portre yüzünden olmuştu. Basil ona öyle şeyler söylemişti ki yenilip yutulmazdı, gene de Dorian sabır gösterip bunları yutmuştu. Cinayet bir anlık bir cinnetten ibaretti. Alan Campbell’e gelince; onun intiharı da kendi işiydi. Alan bu eylemi kendisi seçmişti. Dorian’la hiçbir ilişkisi yoktu bunun.
es: Era mejor no pensar en el pasado. Nada podía cambiarlo. Tenía que pensar en sí mismo, en su futuro. A James Vane lo habían enterrado en una tumba anónima en el cementerio de Selby. Alan Campbell se había suicidado una noche en su laboratorio, pero sin revelar el secreto que le había sido impuesto. La emoción, o la curiosidad, suscitada por la desaparición de Basil Hallward pronto se desvanecería. Ya empezaba a pasar. Por ese lado no tenía nada que temer. Y, de hecho, no era la muerte de Basil Hallward lo que más le abrumaba. Le obsesionaba la muerte en vida de su propia alma. Basil había pintado el retrato que echó a perder su vida. Eso no se lo podía perdonar. El retrato tenía la culpa de todo. Basil le dijo cosas intolerables que él, sin embargo, soportó con paciencia. El asesinato fue obra, sencillamente, de una locura momentánea. En cuanto a Alan Campbell, el suicidio había sido su decisión personal. Había elegido actuar así. Nada tenía que ver con él.
vi_translation: It's better not to think about the past. Nothing can change it. Yourself, your future, are what you should think about. James Vane was buried in an unmarked grave in Selby cemetery. Alan Campbell shot himself one night in his laboratory, but he did not reveal the secret he was forced to know. The pointless commotion around Basil Hallward's disappearance will soon pass. It is also fading away. You are absolutely safe. In fact, it wasn't really Basil Hallward's death that weighed most heavily on your mind. It was the half-dead state of your soul that tormented you. Basil had painted the portrait that ruined your life. You could not forgive him for that. It was that portrait that did everything. Basil had said things to you that were unbearable, and you still had to patiently endure them. The murder was simply the result of a momentary fit of rage. As for Alan Campbell, his suicide was his own act. He decided to do it. It had nothing to do with you.
tr_translation: It was better not to think about the past. Nothing could change the past anyway! Now, he needed to think about himself, his own future. James Vane was buried in an unmarked grave in the garden of Selby Church. Alan Campbell had shot himself one night in his laboratory, yet he had not revealed the secret he had to learn. The not-so-excessive excitement caused by Basil Hallward's disappearance would soon subside. It had already begun to subside. In this regard, Dorian had nothing to fear. To tell the truth, the thing that worried him the most was not Basil Hallward's death. What truly disturbed him was that his own soul had died while he was still alive. Basil had painted the portrait that cast a shadow over his life. Dorian could not forgive this. Everything had happened because of that portrait. Basil had said things to him that were intolerable, yet Dorian had shown patience and tolerated them. The murder was nothing but a moment of madness. As for Alan Campbell; his suicide was his own doing. Alan had chosen this action himself. It had nothing to do with Dorian.
es_translation: It was better not to think about the past. Nothing could change it. He had to think about himself, about his future. James Vane had been buried in an anonymous grave in the Selby cemetery. Alan Campbell had committed suicide one night in his laboratory, but without revealing the secret that had been imposed on him. The emotion, or curiosity, aroused by the disappearance of Basil Hallward would soon fade away. It was already starting to happen. In that regard, he had nothing to fear. And, in fact, it was not Basil Hallward's death that overwhelmed him the most. He was obsessed with the living death of his own soul. Basil had painted the portrait that ruined his life. He could not forgive him for that. The portrait was to blame for everything. Basil had said intolerable things to him, which he, however, endured with patience. The murder was simply the work of a momentary madness. As for Alan Campbell, the suicide had been his personal decision. He had chosen to act that way. It had nothing to do with him.

en: A new life! That was what he wanted. That was what he was waiting for. Surely he had begun it already. He had spared one innocent thing, at any rate. He would never again tempt innocence. He would be good.
vi: Một cuộc đời mới! Đó là cái mà cậu cần. Đó là cái mà cậu chờ đợi. Chắc chắn là cậu đã bắt đầu nó rồi. Dẫu gì thì cậu cũng đã tha cho một sinh vật ngây thơ. Cậu sẽ không bao giờ cám dỗ người ngây thơ nữa. Cậu sẽ tử tế.
tr: Yeni bir yaşam! Dorian’ın istediği buydu. Beklediği de buydu. Hatta bu yeni yaşama daha şimdiden başlamış sayılırdı. Hiç değilse bir masum varlığı esirgemişti ya! Bir daha masumları baştan çıkarmaya asla kalkışmayacaktı. İyi insan olacaktı.
es: ¡Una vida nueva! Eso era lo que necesitaba. Eso era lo que estaba esperando. Sin duda la había empezado ya. Había evitado, al menos, la perdición de una criatura inocente. Nunca volvería a poner la tentación en el camino de la inocencia. Sería bueno.
vi_translation: A new life! That's what you need. That's what you have been waiting for. Surely, you have already started it. After all, you have spared an innocent creature. You will never tempt the innocent again. You will be kind.
tr_translation: A new life! This is what Dorian wanted. This is what he had been waiting for. In fact, he could already be considered to have started this new life. At least he had spared an innocent being! He would never again attempt to corrupt the innocent. He would be a good person.
es_translation: A new life! That was what I needed. That was what I was waiting for. Without a doubt, I had already started it. I had avoided, at least, the ruin of an innocent creature. I would never again place temptation in the path of innocence. I would be good.

en: As he thought of Hetty Merton, he began to wonder if the portrait in the locked room had changed. Surely it was not still so horrible as it had been? Perhaps if his life became pure, he would be able to expel every sign of evil passion from the face. Perhaps the signs of evil had already gone away. He would go and look.
vi: Lúc cậu nghĩ về Hetty Merton, cậu bắt đầu tự hỏi không biết bức chân dung trong căn phòng khóa kín ấy có thay đổi không. Chắc nó không còn kinh như nó đã từng chứ nhỉ? Không chừng nếu như đời cậu bắt đầu sạch hơn thì cậu có thể tống khứ mọi dấu vết đam mê tội lỗi khỏi bộ mặt ấy. Không chừng các dấu vết tội lỗi đã biến mất rồi. Cậu sẽ đi xem.
tr: Hetty Merton’u düşünürken, kilitli odadaki portrenin değişip değişmediğini merak etmeye başladı. Portre hâlâ eskisi kadar iğrenç ve korkunç olamazdı herhalde, öyle değil mi? Belki yaşantısı temizlenirse portrenin yüzünden de bütün o günah ve ihtiras izlerini silebilirdi. Bu kötülük izleri daha şimdiden silinmişti belki de. Dorian gidip bakacaktı.
es: Al pensar en Hetty Merton, empezó a preguntarse si el retrato habría cambiado. Sin duda no sería ya tan horrible como antes. Quizá, si su vida recobraba la pureza, expulsaría de su rostro hasta el último resto de las malas pasiones. Quizás, incluso, habían desaparecido ya. Iría a verlo.
vi_translation: When he thought about Hetty Merton, he began to wonder whether the portrait in the locked room had changed. Surely it couldn't be as horrifying as it once was? Perhaps if his life became purer, he could rid that face of all traces of sinful passion. Maybe the traces of sin had already disappeared. He would go and see.
tr_translation: As he thought about Hetty Merton, he began to wonder if the portrait in the locked room had changed. The portrait couldn't still be as disgusting and horrible as before, could it? Perhaps if he cleansed his life, he could erase all those traces of sin and passion from the face in the portrait as well. Maybe those marks of evil had already been erased. Dorian would go and see.
es_translation: When thinking about Hetty Merton, he began to wonder if the portrait had changed. Surely it would no longer be as horrible as before. Perhaps, if his life regained its purity, it would expel from his face every last trace of evil passions. Perhaps, even, they had already disappeared. He would go see it.

en: He took the lamp from the table and crept upstairs. As he unbarred the door, a smile of joy flitted across his strangely young-looking face and lingered for a moment about his lips. Yes, he would be good, and the hideous thing that he had hidden away would no longer be a terror to him. He felt as if the load had been lifted from him already.
vi: Cậu cầm đèn khỏi bàn và rón rén lên gác. Lúc cậu mở then cửa, một nụ cười hân hoan vụt qua bộ mặt nhìn trẻ lạ lùng của cậu và lần lữa một lát quanh môi cậu. Vâng, cậu sẽ sống tử tế, cái thứ gớm guốc mà cậu đã giấu đi sẽ không còn là nỗi khiếp sợ với cậu lâu hơn nữa. Cậu cảm thấy như thể gánh nặng đã được nhấc khỏi mình.
tr: Lambayı masanın üstünden alarak usulca üst kata çıktı. Kapının sürmesini çekerken şaşılacak kadar genç görünümlü olan yüzünden sevinçli bir gülümseyiş uçup geçti ve bir an dudaklarında oyalandı. Evet, iyi insan olacaktı ve gizli tuttuğu o iğrenç şey artık onu ürkütmeyecekti. Omzundaki yük daha şimdiden kalkmış gibi geliyordu.
es: Tomó la lámpara y subió sigilosamente las escaleras. Al descorrer el cerrojo, una sonrisa de alegría iluminó por un instante el rostro extrañamente joven y se prolongó unos momentos más en torno a los labios. Sí, practicaría el bien, y aquel retrato espantoso que llevaba tanto tiempo escondido dejaría de aterrorizarlo. Sintió que ya se le había quitado un peso de encima.
vi_translation: He took the lamp off the table and crept upstairs. As he unlatched the door, a joyful smile flashed across his strangely youthful face and lingered for a moment around his lips. Yes, he would live decently, the hideous thing he had hidden away would no longer be a terror to him. He felt as if a burden had been lifted from him.
tr_translation: Taking the lamp from the table, he quietly went upstairs. As he pulled the door latch, a joyful smile flitted across his surprisingly youthful face and lingered on his lips for a moment. Yes, he would be a good person, and that disgusting thing he kept hidden would no longer frighten him. It already felt as if the burden on his shoulders had been lifted.
es_translation: He took the lamp and stealthily went up the stairs. As he drew back the bolt, a smile of joy illuminated his strangely young face for an instant and lingered a few moments more around his lips. Yes, he would do good, and that dreadful portrait that had been hidden for so long would cease to terrify him. He felt as if a weight had already been lifted from his shoulders.

en: He went in quietly, locking the door behind him, as was his custom, and dragged the purple hanging from the portrait. A cry of pain and indignation broke from him. He could see no change, save that in the eyes there was a look of cunning and in the mouth the curved wrinkle of the hypocrite. The thing was still loathsome—more loathsome, if possible, than before—and the scarlet dew that spotted the hand seemed brighter, and more like blood newly spilled. Then he trembled. Had it been merely vanity that had made him do his one good deed? Or the desire for a new sensation, as Lord Henry had hinted, with his mocking laugh? Or that passion to act a part that sometimes makes us do things finer than we are ourselves? Or, perhaps, all these? And why was the red stain larger than it had been? It seemed to have crept like a horrible disease over the wrinkled fingers. There was blood on the painted feet, as though the thing had dripped—blood even on the hand that had not held the knife. Confess? Did it mean that he was to confess? To give himself up and be put to death? He laughed. He felt that the idea was monstrous. Besides, even if he did confess, who would believe him? There was no trace of the murdered man anywhere. Everything belonging to him had been destroyed. He himself had burned what had been below-stairs. The world would simply say that he was mad. They would shut him up if he persisted in his story.... Yet it was his duty to confess, to suffer public shame, and to make public atonement.
