There was a God who called upon men to tell their sins to earth as well as to heaven. Nothing that he could do would cleanse him till he had told his own sin. His sin? He shrugged his shoulders. The death of Basil Hallward seemed very little to him. He was thinking of Hetty Merton. For it was an unjust mirror, this mirror of his soul that he was looking at. Vanity? Curiosity? Hypocrisy? Had there been nothing more in his renunciation than that? There had been something more. At least he thought so. But who could tell? ... No. There had been nothing more. Through vanity he had spared her. In hypocrisy he had worn the mask of goodness. For curiosity’s sake he had tried the denial of self. He recognized that now.
vi: Cậu lặng lẽ bước vào, khóa cửa lại sau lưng mình, theo như thói quen, và kéo tấm màn tía khỏi bức chân dung. Một tiếng kêu đau đớn và phẫn nộ buột ra khỏi môi cậu. Cậu không thể thấy sự thay đổi nào, ngoài cái việc là trong đôi mắt ấy có vẻ xảo trá, và trên cái miệng ấy có nếp cong giả nhân giả nghĩa. Thứ ấy vẫn kinh tởm — kinh tởm hơn, nếu có thể, so với trước kia — và giọt sương đỏ vấy bẩn bàn tay thì dường như tươi hơn, giống máu mới đổ hơn. Lúc ấy, cậu run lên. Có phải chỉ sự kiêu hãnh đã khiến cậu làm việc thiện duy nhất của mình? Hay là sự thèm muốn cảm giác mới, như huân tước Henry đã nói bóng gió, với nụ cười chế giễu? Hoặc niềm đam mê diễn vai mà đôi lúc vẫn khiến ta làm những việc tốt đẹp hơn chính ta? Hoặc, không chừng, tất cả những điều này? Và tại sao mà vết đỏ ấy lại lớn hơn trước? Nó dường như đã bò như một căn bệnh khủng khiếp qua các ngón tay nhăn nheo. Có máu trên các bàn chân vẽ màu, như thể thứ ấy đã nhỏ giọt xuống — máu thậm chí có trên cả bàn tay không cầm dao. Thú tội? Có phải điều ấy nghĩa là cậu nên thú tội? Nộp mình, và bị đem giết? Cậu cười. Cậu cảm thấy là ý nghĩ ấy thật kỳ quái. Vả lại, thậm chí nếu cậu thú tội chăng nữa thì ai sẽ tin cậu? Không còn dấu vết nào của kẻ bị giết ở bất cứ đâu. Mọi thứ thuộc về y đã bị tiêu hủy. Chính cậu đã đốt những thứ từng ở tầng dưới. Thiên hạ sẽ chỉ nói là cậu bị mất trí. Họ sẽ nhốt cậu lại nếu cậu khăng khăng giữ câu chuyện của mình… Tuy nhiên, bổn phận của cậu là thú tội, để chịu đựng nỗi nhục công khai, để công khai chuộc lỗi. Có Chúa, và ngài yêu cầu con người phải thú tội trước trần gian cũng như trước thiên đàng. Cậu chẳng thể nào làm gì để thanh tẩy mình cho đến khi cậu kể lại tội lỗi của mình. Tội lỗi của cậu? Cậu nhún vai. Cái chết của Basil Hallward dường như chẳng mấy quan trọng với cậu. Cậu đang nghĩ về Hetty Merton. Vì cái gương linh hồn cậu mà cậu đang nhìn vào này, là một cái gương không trung thực. Kiêu căng? Hiếu kỳ? Đạo đức giả? Chẳng lẽ không còn gì ngoài chúng ở sự từ bỏ của cậu? Còn gì đó nữa chứ. Ít nhất thì cậu cũng tưởng vậy. Nhưng ai có thể cả quyết?... Không. Chẳng còn gì thêm nữa. Do kiêu căng mà cậu tha cho nàng. Vì đạo đức giả mà cậu đeo cái mặt nạ tử tế. Vì hiếu kỳ mà cậu cố phủ nhận bản thân. Giờ đây cậu đã nhận ra điều ấy.
tr: Sessizce odaya girdi. Âdeti olduğu üzere kapıyı ardından kilitledi, sonra portrenin mor örtüsünü çekti. Dudaklarından bir öfke ve acı çığlığı koptu. Hiçbir değişim göremiyordu. Yalnızca gözlerde bir kurnazlık ifadesi ve ağızda ikiyüzlülüğün çizgisi vardı. Portre hâlâ iğrençti –hatta eskisinden daha bile iğrenç–, eli lekeleyen o kızıl çiy taneleri de eskisinden daha canlı duruyor, yeni akmış kana eskisinden daha çok benziyordu. Dorian titremeye başladı. Ömrünün tek iyi işini ona kibri mi yaptırtmıştı acaba? Belki Lord Henry’nin o alaycı kahkahasıyla dokundurduğu gibi, yeni bir heyecan arayışı. Belki arada bir bize olduğumuzdan daha soylu işler yaptırtan o rol yapmak isteği. Belki de bunların hepsi. Olabilir miydi? Ya kırmızı leke. Neden genişlemişti? O buruşuk parmaklara iğrenç bir hastalık gibi yayılmıştı sanki. Resimdeki ayakların üzerinde de kan vardı, parmakların arasından sızıp damlamış sanırdınız; bıçağı tutmamış olan el bile kanlıydı. İtiraf mı yoksa? Onun her şeyi itiraf etmesi gerektiğini mi belirtiyordu bu? Teslim olmak, idam sehpasına gitmek? Dorian güldü. Olmayacak şeydi bu. Hem zaten o itirafta bulunsa bile sözlerine kim inanırdı? Öldürülen adamın hiçbir izi kalmamıştı ortalıkta. Her şeyi ortadan kaldırılmıştı. Alt kattakileri Dorian kendisi yakmıştı. Herkes ona deli gözüyle bakardı. Söylediklerinde direnirse onu tımarhaneye kapatırlardı... Gene de suçunu itiraf etmek, ele güne karşı mahcup olmak, cezasını çekmek de boynunun borcuydu. İnsanların günahlarının hesabını yalnızca öbür dünyada değil, bu dünyada da vermesini isteyen bir tanrı vardı. Günahını açığa vurmadıkça ne yaparsa yapsın, hiçbir şey onu arındıramazdı. Günahı mı? Dorian omuz silkti. Basil Hallward’ın ölümü pek umurunda değildi aslında. O Hetty Merton’u düşünüyordu, çünkü şu karşısındaki ayna, ruhunun aynası, ona haksızlık etmiyor muydu? Kibir ha? Merak? İkiyüzlülük? Bunlardan öte bir şey yok muydu, Hetty’den vazgeçmesinde? Olmaz olur muydu? Vardı; en azından o olduğunu sanıyordu. Ama kim bilebilirdi?.. Hayır. Başkaca hiçbir şey yoktu! Dorian kibri yüzünden kızı esirgemişti. İkiyüzlü olduğu için iyilik maskesi takmıştı. Merak uğruna fedakârlığı denemişti. Bunları şimdi kabul ediyordu. Gelgelelim şu cinayet...
es: Entró sin hacer el menor ruido, volviendo a cerrar la puerta con llave, como tenía por costumbre, y retiró la tela morada que cubría el cuadro. Un grito de dolor e indignación se le escapó de los labios. No se notaba cambio alguno, con la excepción de un brillo de astucia en la mirada y en la boca las arrugas sinuosas de la hipocresía. El lienzo seguía siendo tan odioso como siempre, más, si es que eso era posible; y el rocío escarlata que le manchaba la mano parecía más brillante, con más aspecto de sangre recién derramada. Dorian Gray empezó entonces a temblar. ¿Le había empujado únicamente la vanidad a llevar a cabo su única obra buena? ¿O había sido el deseo de una nueva sensación, como apuntara lord Henry, con su risa burlona? ¿O tal vez el deseo apasionado de representar un papel que nos empuja a hacer cosas mejores de lo que nos corresponde por naturaleza? ¿O, quizá, todo aquello al mismo tiempo? Pero, ¿por qué era más grande la mancha roja? Parecía haberse extendido como una horrible enfermedad sobre los dedos cubiertos de arrugas. Había sangre en los pies pintados, como si aquella cosa hubiera goteado..., sangre incluso en la mano que no había empuñado el cuchillo. ¿Una confesión? ¿Quería aquello decir que iba a confesar su crimen? ¿Que iba a entregarse para que lo ejecutaran? Se echó a reír. La idea le pareció monstruosa. Además, aunque confesara, ¿quién iba a creerlo? No había en ninguna parte resto alguno del pintor asesinado. Todas sus pertenencias habían sido destruidas. Él mismo había quemado maletín y abrigo. El mundo diría simplemente que estaba loco. Lo encerrarían en un manicomio si se empeñaba en repetir la misma historia... Sin embargo, era obligación suya confesar, soportar públicamente la vergüenza y expiar la culpa de manera igualmente pública. Había un Dios que exigía a los seres humanos confesar sus pecados en la tierra así como en el cielo. Nada de lo que hiciera le purificaría si no confesaba su pecado. ¿Su pecado? Se encogió de hombros. La muerte de Basil Hallward le parecía muy poca cosa. Pensaba en Hetty Merton. Porque aquel espejo de su alma que estaba contemplando era un espejo injusto. ¿Vanidad? ¿Curiosidad? ¿Hipocresía? ¿No había habido más que eso en su renuncia? Había habido algo más. Al menos así lo creía él. Pero, ¿cómo saberlo...? No. No hubo nada más. Sólo renunció a la muchacha por vanidad. La hipocresía le había llevado a colocarse la máscara de la bondad. Había ensayado la abnegación por curiosidad. Ahora lo reconocía.
vi_translation: He quietly stepped in, locked the door behind him, as was his habit, and pulled the purple curtain away from the portrait. A cry of pain and anger escaped his lips. He could not see any change, except that in those eyes there was a cunning look, and on that mouth there was a hypocritical curve. It was still disgusting—more disgusting, if possible, than before—and the red dew staining the hand seemed fresher, more like newly shed blood. At that moment, he shivered. Was it only pride that had made him do his one good deed? Or was it the desire for a new sensation, as Lord Henry had hinted, with a mocking smile? Or the passion for acting a part that sometimes makes us do things finer than we are? Or, perhaps, all these things? And why was the stain larger than before? It seemed to have crept like a dreadful disease over the wrinkled fingers. There was blood on the painted feet, as though it had dripped down—blood even on the hand that had not held the knife. Confess? Did it mean that he should confess? Give himself up, and be put to death? He laughed. He felt that the idea was monstrous. Besides, even if he did confess, who would believe him? There was no trace of the murdered man anywhere. Everything belonging to him had been destroyed. He had burned what had been below stairs himself. People would simply say he was mad. They would shut him up if he persisted in his story... Yet it was his duty to confess, to suffer public shame, to make public atonement. There was God, and He required confession before men as well as before Heaven. He could do nothing that would cleanse him till he had told his own sin. His sin? He shrugged his shoulders. The death of Basil Hallward seemed very little to him. He was thinking of Hetty Merton. For it was an unjust mirror, this mirror of his soul that he was looking at. Pride? Curiosity? Hypocrisy? Had there been nothing more in his renunciation than that? There had been something more. At least he thought so. But who could say?... No. There had been nothing more. It was pride that had made him spare her. It was hypocrisy that had made him wear the mask of goodness. It was curiosity that had made him seek to deny himself. He recognized that now.
tr_translation: He entered the room silently. As was his habit, he locked the door behind him, then pulled the purple cover off the portrait. A cry of anger and pain escaped from his lips. He could see no change. There was only an expression of cunning in the eyes and a line of hypocrisy on the mouth. The portrait was still disgusting – even more disgusting than before – the crimson dew drops that stained his hand looked more vivid than before, resembling freshly spilled blood even more. Dorian began to tremble. Had his pride made him commit the only good deed of his life? Perhaps, as Lord Henry had mockingly hinted, a search for a new excitement. Perhaps the desire to play a role that sometimes makes us perform nobler deeds than we are. Perhaps all of these. Could it be? And the red stain. Why had it expanded? It seemed to have spread over those wrinkled fingers like a vile disease. There was blood on the feet in the picture too, as if it had dripped and oozed between the toes; even the hand that had not held the knife was bloody. A confession perhaps? Was this indicating that he should confess everything? Surrender, go to the gallows? Dorian laughed. That was impossible. Besides, even if he confessed, who would believe his words? There was no trace left of the murdered man. Everything had been disposed of. Dorian himself had burned those downstairs. Everyone would look at him as if he were mad. If he insisted on his words, they would lock him up in an asylum... Gene de suçunu itiraf etmek, ele güne karşı mahcup olmak, cezasını çekmek de boynunun borcuydu. İnsanların günahlarının hesabını yalnızca öbür dünyada değil, bu dünyada da vermesini isteyen bir tanrı vardı. Günahını açığa vurmadıkça ne yaparsa yapsın, hiçbir şey onu arındıramazdı. Günahı mı? Dorian omuz silkti. Basil Hallward’ın ölümü pek umurunda değildi aslında. O Hetty Merton’u düşünüyordu, çünkü şu karşısındaki ayna, ruhunun aynası, ona haksızlık etmiyor muydu? Kibir ha? Merak? İkiyüzlülük? Bunlardan öte bir şey yok muydu, Hetty’den vazgeçmesinde? Olmaz olur muydu? Vardı; en azından o olduğunu sanıyordu. Ama kim bilebilirdi?.. Hayır. Başkaca hiçbir şey yoktu! Dorian kibri yüzünden kızı esirgemişti. İkiyüzlü olduğu için iyilik maskesi takmıştı. Merak uğruna fedakârlığı denemişti. Bunları şimdi kabul ediyordu. Now, about that murder...
es_translation: He entered without making the slightest noise, locking the door again as was his custom, and removed the purple cloth that covered the painting. A cry of pain and indignation escaped his lips. There was no noticeable change, except for a gleam of cunning in the eyes and the sinuous wrinkles of hypocrisy around the mouth. The canvas was as hateful as ever, even more so, if that were possible; and the scarlet dew that stained the hand seemed brighter, more like freshly spilled blood. Dorian Gray then began to tremble. Had vanity alone driven him to carry out his only good deed? Or had it been the desire for a new sensation, as Lord Henry had suggested with his mocking laugh? Or perhaps the passionate desire to play a role that pushes us to do better things than we are naturally inclined to? Or maybe all of it at once? But why was the red stain larger? It seemed to have spread like a horrible disease over the wrinkled fingers. There was blood on the painted feet, as if that thing had dripped..., blood even on the hand that had not wielded the knife. A confession? Did that mean he was going to confess his crime? That he was going to turn himself in to be executed? He laughed. The idea seemed monstrous to him. Besides, even if he confessed, who would believe him? There was no trace anywhere of the murdered painter. All his belongings had been destroyed. He himself had burned the suitcase and coat. The world would simply say he was crazy. They would lock him up in an asylum if he insisted on repeating the same story... However, it was his duty to confess, to publicly endure the shame and expiate the guilt in an equally public manner. There was a God who demanded that humans confess their sins on earth as well as in heaven. Nothing he did would purify him if he didn't confess his sin. His sin? He shrugged. The death of Basil Hallward seemed very insignificant to him. He thought of Hetty Merton. Because that mirror of his soul he was gazing at was an unjust mirror. Vanity? Curiosity? Hypocrisy? Was there nothing more than that in his renunciation? There had been something more. At least that's what he believed. But how to know...? No. There was nothing more. He had only renounced the girl out of vanity. Hypocrisy had led him to don the mask of goodness. He had practiced self-denial out of curiosity. Now he acknowledged it.

en: But this murder—was it to dog him all his life? Was he always to be burdened by his past? Was he really to confess? Never. There was only one bit of evidence left against him. The picture itself—that was evidence. He would destroy it. Why had he kept it so long? Once it had given him pleasure to watch it changing and growing old. Of late he had felt no such pleasure. It had kept him awake at night. When he had been away, he had been filled with terror lest other eyes should look upon it. It had brought melancholy across his passions. Its mere memory had marred many moments of joy. It had been like conscience to him. Yes, it had been conscience. He would destroy it.
vi: Nhưng tội giết người này — chẳng lẽ nó cứ bám sát gót cậu cả đời? Chẳng lẽ cậu lúc nào cũng phải chịu gánh nặng quá khứ? Chẳng lẽ cậu phải thú tội thật sao? Không hề. Chỉ còn một mảnh bằng chứng chống lại cậu. Chính bức tranh — đó là bằng chứng. Cậu sẽ phá hủy nó. Sao cậu lại giữ nó lâu như vậy? Trước kia nó từng cho cậu niềm vui khi theo dõi nó thay đổi và già đi. Gần đây cậu không thấy niềm vui như vậy nữa. Nó cứ bắt cậu tỉnh dậy giữa đêm. Khi ở xa, cậu cứ sợ là những con mắt khác có thể ngắm nhìn nó. Nó phủ bóng sầu lên các đam mê của cậu. Chỉ cần nhớ đến nó thôi đã là hỏng mất nhiều khoảnh khắc vui sướng. Với cậu, nó giống như lương tâm. Đúng, nó là lương tâm. Cậu phải phá hủy nó.
tr: Ömür boyu yakasına yapışıp kalacak mıydı? Dorian ömür boyu geçmişinin yükünü mü taşıyacaktı? Gerçekten itiraf edecek miydi suçunu? Asla. Ona karşı kullanılabilecek tek bir kanıt kalmıştı: portrenin kendisi; tek kanıt. Dorian ortadan kaldıracaktı onu. Bunca zaman ne diye saklamıştı sanki? Bir zamanlar resmin değişip yaşlanmasını gözlemek ona keyif verirdi. Son zamanlarda bu keyif de kalmamıştı. Geceleri bu resim yüzünden uyuyamamıştı. Evinden uzaklaştığı zaman başka gözler resmi görecek diye dehşete kapılmıştı. Ateşli duygularının üstüne hüzün çökmüştü bu resim yüzünden. Bu resmin salt anısı bile nice keyifli dakikanın tadını kaçırmıştı. Portresi başına vicdan kesilmişti sanki. Evet, vicdanı olmuştu onun. Dorian portreyi ortadan kaldırmalıydı.
es: Pero aquel asesinato..., ¿iba a perseguirlo toda su vida? ¿Siempre tendría que soportar el peso de su pasado? ¿Tendría que confesar? Nunca. No había más que una prueba en contra suya. El cuadro mismo: ésa era la prueba. Lo destruiría. ¿Por qué lo había conservado tanto tiempo? Años atrás le proporcionaba el placer de contemplar cómo cambiaba y se hacía viejo. En los últimos tiempos ese placer había desaparecido. El cuadro le impedía dormir. Cuando salía de viaje, le horrorizaba la posibilidad de que lo contemplasen otros ojos. Teñía de melancolía sus pasiones. Su simple recuerdo echaba a perder muchos momentos de alegría. Había sido para él algo así como su conciencia. Sí. Había sido su conciencia. Lo destruiría.
vi_translation: But this murder — will it follow you all your life? Will you always have to bear the burden of the past? Will you really have to confess? No. There is only one piece of evidence left against you. The painting itself — that is the evidence. You will destroy it. Why have you kept it for so long? It once gave you joy to watch it change and age. Recently, you no longer find such joy. It keeps waking you up in the middle of the night. When you are away, you fear that other eyes might gaze upon it. It casts a shadow of sorrow over your passions. Just thinking about it has ruined many moments of joy. To you, it is like a conscience. Yes, it is a conscience. You must destroy it.
tr_translation: Would it cling to him for life? Would Dorian carry the burden of his past for life? Would he really confess his crime? Never. There was only one piece of evidence left against him: the portrait itself; the only evidence. Dorian would get rid of it. Why had he kept it for so long anyway? Once, he used to take pleasure in watching the picture change and age. Lately, even that pleasure was gone. He couldn't sleep at night because of this picture. When he was away from home, he was terrified that other eyes would see the picture. His fiery emotions were overshadowed by sadness because of this picture. The mere memory of this picture had spoiled many pleasant moments. It was as if the portrait had become his conscience. Yes, it had become his conscience. Dorian had to get rid of the portrait.
es_translation: But that murder..., was it going to haunt him all his life? Would he always have to bear the weight of his past? Should he confess? Never. There was only one piece of evidence against him. The painting itself: that was the evidence. He would destroy it. Why had he kept it for so long? Years ago, it gave him the pleasure of watching it change and grow old. In recent times, that pleasure had disappeared. The painting kept him from sleeping. When he traveled, he was horrified at the possibility of others seeing it. It tinged his passions with melancholy. Its mere memory spoiled many moments of joy. It had been something like his conscience. Yes. It had been his conscience. He would destroy it.

en: He looked round and saw the knife that had stabbed Basil Hallward. He had cleaned it many times, till there was no stain left upon it. It was bright, and glistened. As it had killed the painter, so it would kill the painter’s work, and all that that meant. It would kill the past, and when that was dead, he would be free. It would kill this monstrous soul-life, and without its hideous warnings, he would be at peace. He seized the thing, and stabbed the picture with it.
vi: Cậu nhìn quanh và thấy con dao đã từng đâm Basil Hallward. Cậu đã lau sạch nó nhiều lần, cho tới khi không còn vết bẩn nào. Nó sáng lấp lánh. Do nó đã giết họa sỹ, nên nó sẽ giết luôn tác phẩm của họa sỹ, và tất cả những gì mà cái thứ ấy có liên quan. Nó sẽ giết quá khứ, và khi cái quá khứ ấy chết thì cậu sẽ tự do. Nó sẽ giết hồn-sống quái dị này, và, khi không có các cảnh báo gớm guốc từ thứ đó, cậu sẽ được thanh thản. Cậu nắm lấy món đồ ấy và đâm nó vào bức tranh.
tr: Çevresine bakınca Basil Hallward’ı öldüren bıçağı gördü. Kaç kez temizlemişti bu bıçağı, üzerinde hiç leke bırakmamıştı. Bıçak pırıl pırıldı, ışıldıyordu. Ressamı nasıl öldürmüşse ressamın yapıtını da, bu yapıtın olanca anlamını da öyle öldürecekti. Geçmişin canını alacaktı; geçmiş öldüğü zaman da Dorian özgür kalacaktı. Bıçak şu iğrenç, şu ürkünç ruhun yaşantısını sona erdirecekti; portrenin uyarıları kesildiği zaman da Dorian dirliğe kavuşacaktı. Bıçağı aldı, resme sapladı.
es: Miró a su alrededor, y vio el cuchillo con el que apuñaló a Basil Hallward. Lo había limpiado muchas veces, hasta que desaparecieron todas las manchas. Brillaba, lanzaba destellos. De la misma manera que había matado al pintor, mataría su obra y todo lo que significaba. Mataría el pasado y, cuando estuviera muerto, él recobraría la libertad. Acabaría con aquella monstruosa vida del alma y, sin sus odiosas advertencias, recobraría la paz. Empuñó el arma y con ella apuñaló el retrato.
vi_translation: He looked around and saw the knife that had once stabbed Basil Hallward. He had cleaned it many times, until there was no stain left. It gleamed brightly. Since it had killed the artist, it would also kill the artist's creation, and everything associated with it. It would kill the past, and when that past was dead, he would be free. It would kill this monstrous soul, and, without its ghastly warnings, he would be at peace. He grabbed the object and stabbed it into the painting.
tr_translation: When he looked around, he saw the knife that killed Basil Hallward. How many times had he cleaned this knife, leaving no stain on it. The knife was sparkling, it was shining. Just as he had killed the painter, he would kill the painter's work and all its meaning. He would take the life of the past; when the past was dead, Dorian would be free. The knife would end the life of that disgusting, terrifying soul; when the portrait's warnings ceased, Dorian would find peace. He took the knife and stabbed the painting.
es_translation: He looked around and saw the knife with which he had stabbed Basil Hallward. He had cleaned it many times, until all the stains disappeared. It shone, it sparkled. In the same way he had killed the painter, he would kill his work and everything it meant. He would kill the past and, when it was dead, he would regain his freedom. He would end that monstrous life of the soul and, without its hateful warnings, he would regain peace. He wielded the weapon and with it stabbed the portrait.

en: There was a cry heard, and a crash. The cry was so horrible in its agony that the frightened servants woke and crept out of their rooms. Two gentlemen, who were passing in the square below, stopped and looked up at the great house. They walked on till they met a policeman and brought him back. The man rang the bell several times, but there was no answer. Except for a light in one of the top windows, the house was all dark. After a time, he went away and stood in an adjoining portico and watched.
vi: Nghe thấy một tiếng hét và một tiếng đổ vỡ rầm rầm. Tiếng hét trong cơn hấp hối khủng khiếp đến nỗi làm cho các gia nhân hoảng hồn thức dậy, rón rén ra khỏi phòng họ. Hai quý ông, đang đi qua quảng trường bên dưới, dừng lại, nhìn lên ngôi nhà khổng lồ. Họ đi tiếp cho đến khi gặp một viên cảnh sát và đưa y quay lại. Y rung chuông vài lần, nhưng không thấy đáp lại. Ngoài một ánh đèn trên một trong những cửa sổ tầng thượng, còn thì ngôi nhà tối om. Một lúc sau, y bước ra xa và đứng trong cái cổng bên cạnh để quan sát.
tr: Bir haykırış duyuldu, bir patırtı. Haykırış öyle korkunç bir azapla doluydu ki hizmetçiler ödleri koparak uyandılar, usulca odalarından çıktılar. Aşağıdaki meydandan geçmekte olan iki bey başlarını kaldırıp büyük eve baktılar. İlerleyip bir polis buldular, polisi alıp getirdiler. Polis kapı çıngırağını kaç kez çaldıysa da yanıt veren olmadı. Üst kat pencerelerinden birindeki ışığın dışında bütün ev karanlıktı. Polis bir süre sonra yürüdü, yan evlerden birinin sundurmasına çıkıp evi oradan gözlemeye koyuldu.
es: Se oyó un grito y el golpe de una caída. El grito puso de manifiesto un sufrimiento tan espantoso que los criados despertaron asustados y salieron en silencio de sus habitaciones. Dos caballeros que pasaban por la plaza se detuvieron y alzaron los ojos hacia la gran casa. Luego siguieron caminando hasta encontrar a un policía y regresar con él. Llamaron varias veces al timbre, pero sin recibir respuesta. Con la excepción de una luz en uno de los balcones del piso alto, todo estaba a oscuras. Al cabo de un rato, el policía se trasladó hasta un portal vecino para contemplar desde allí el edificio.
vi_translation: Hearing a scream and a loud crash. The scream in the terrible throes of death was so horrifying that it woke the servants, who crept out of their rooms. Two gentlemen, passing through the square below, stopped and looked up at the enormous house. They continued until they met a policeman and brought him back. He rang the bell several times, but there was no response. Except for a light in one of the top-floor windows, the house was completely dark. After a while, he stepped back and stood in the adjacent gate to observe.
tr_translation: A shout was heard, a commotion. The shout was so filled with terrible agony that the servants woke up in fright, and quietly came out of their rooms. Two gentlemen passing through the square below looked up at the large house. They went ahead and found a policeman, and brought him back. No matter how many times the policeman rang the doorbell, there was no response. Except for the light in one of the upper floor windows, the whole house was dark. After a while, the policeman walked away, went up to the porch of one of the neighboring houses, and started observing the house from there.
es_translation: A scream was heard and the sound of a fall. The scream revealed such dreadful suffering that the servants woke up frightened and quietly left their rooms. Two gentlemen who were passing through the square stopped and looked up at the large house. Then they continued walking until they found a policeman and returned with him. They rang the bell several times, but received no response. Except for a light on one of the balconies of the upper floor, everything was dark. After a while, the policeman moved to a neighboring doorway to observe the building from there.

en: “Whose house is that, Constable?” asked the elder of the two gentlemen.
vi: “Nhà ai đấy, anh cảnh sát?” người già hơn trong hai quý ông hỏi.
tr: İki beyden, daha yaşlıca olanı, “Kimin evi bu, memur bey?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Quién vive en esa casa? —le preguntó el caballero de más edad.
vi_translation: "Whose house is that, officer?" the older of the two gentlemen asked.
tr_translation: The older of the two gentlemen asked, "Whose house is this, officer?"
es_translation: —Who lives in that house? —the older gentleman asked him.

en: “Mr. Dorian Gray’s, sir,” answered the policeman.
vi: “Của mít-tơ Dorian Gray, thưa ngài,” viên cảnh sát trả lời.
tr: Adam, “mr Dorian Gray’in, efendim,” dedi.
es: —El señor Dorian Gray—respondió el policía.
vi_translation: "Mr. Dorian Gray's, sir," the policeman replied.
tr_translation: Adam said, "Mr. Dorian Gray, sir."
es_translation: —Mr. Dorian Gray—replied the policeman.

en: They looked at each other, as they walked away, and sneered. One of them was Sir Henry Ashton’s uncle.
vi: Họ nhìn nhau lúc họ bước đi và cười khinh bỉ. Một trong hai người là chú của ngài Henry Ashton.
tr: Beyler bakıştılar, dudaklarını bir küçümsemeyle bükerek oradan uzaklaştılar. İçlerinden biri Sir Henry Ashton’un akrabasıydı.
es: Las dos personas que le escuchaban intercambiaron una mirada de inteligencia y, mientras se alejaban, había en su rostro una mueca de desprecio. Uno de ellos era tío de sir Henry Ashton.
vi_translation: They looked at each other as they walked and laughed scornfully. One of the two was Sir Henry Ashton's uncle.
tr_translation: The gentlemen exchanged glances, curling their lips in disdain as they walked away. One of them was a relative of Sir Henry Ashton.
es_translation: The two people who were listening to him exchanged a knowing glance and, as they walked away, there was a sneer of contempt on their faces. One of them was Sir Henry Ashton's uncle.

en: Inside, in the servants’ part of the house, the half-clad domestics were talking in low whispers to each other. Old Mrs. Leaf was crying and wringing her hands. Francis was as pale as death.
vi: Bên trong, ở khu vực của gia nhân trong nhà, những người hầu ăn mặc dở dang đang thì thào bàn tán với nhau. Bà già Leaf khóc và siết chặt tay. Francis tái nhợt như chết.
tr: İçeride, evin hizmetçi bölümünde, yarı çıplak hizmetçiler fısıldayarak konuşmaktaydılar. İhtiyar ms Leaf ellerini ovuşturarak ağlıyordu. Francis ölü gibi sapsarıydı.
es: Dentro de la casa, en la zona donde vivía la servidumbre, los criados a medio vestir hablaban en voz baja. La anciana señora Leaf lloraba y se retorcía las manos. Francis estaba tan pálido como un muerto.
vi_translation: Inside, in the servants' quarters of the house, the half-dressed servants were whispering to each other. Old Mrs. Leaf was crying and clenching her hands tightly. Francis was as pale as death.
tr_translation: Inside, in the servants' quarters of the house, half-naked maids were whispering to each other. Old Ms. Leaf was crying, rubbing her hands together. Francis was as pale as a corpse.
es_translation: Inside the house, in the area where the servants lived, the half-dressed servants spoke in low voices. The elderly Mrs. Leaf cried and wrung her hands. Francis was as pale as a dead man.

en: After about a quarter of an hour, he got the coachman and one of the footmen and crept upstairs. They knocked, but there was no reply. They called out. Everything was still. Finally, after vainly trying to force the door, they got on the roof and dropped down on to the balcony. The windows yielded easily—their bolts were old.
vi: Sau độ một phần tư giờ, hắn gọi xà ích và một người hầu rồi rón rén lên gác. Họ gõ cửa, nhưng không có tiếng trả lời. Họ gọi to. Mọi vật lặng như tờ. Cuối cùng, sau khi cố phá cửa không được, họ leo lên mái, rồi tụt xuống ban-công. Các cửa sổ dễ dàng chịu thua; chốt của chúng đã cũ.
tr: On-on beş dakika sonra arabacıyla erkek uşaklardan birini alıp sessizce üst kata çıktılar. Kapıya vurdularsa da yanıt alamadılar. Seslendiler. Ne bir ses vardı ne de bir soluk. Kapıyı açmaya boş yere çalıştıktan sonra, en sonunda, dama çıkıp oradan balkona atladılar. Balkonun camlı kapısı kolayca açıldı; sürgüsü eskimişti.
es: Transcurrido un cuarto de hora aproximadamente, el ayuda de cámara tomó consigo al cochero y a uno de los lacayos y subió en silencio las escaleras. Los golpes en la puerta no obtuvieron contestación. Y todo siguió en silencio cuando llamaron a su amo de viva voz. Finalmente, después de tratar en vano de forzar la puerta, salieron al tejado y descendieron hasta el balcón. Una vez allí entraron sin dificultad: los pestillos eran muy antiguos.
vi_translation: After about a quarter of an hour, he called the coachman and a servant, then stealthily went upstairs. They knocked on the door, but there was no response. They called out loudly. Everything was as silent as the grave. Finally, after failing to break the door open, they climbed onto the roof and then descended to the balcony. The windows easily gave way; their latches were old.
tr_translation: Fifteen minutes later, they took the coachman and one of the male servants and quietly went upstairs. They knocked on the door but received no answer. They called out. There was neither a sound nor a breath. After trying in vain to open the door, they finally climbed up to the roof and jumped onto the balcony from there. The glass door of the balcony opened easily; its bolt was worn out.
es_translation: After approximately a quarter of an hour had passed, the valet took the coachman and one of the footmen with him and silently went up the stairs. The knocks on the door received no response. And everything remained silent when they called out to their master aloud. Finally, after trying in vain to force the door, they went out onto the roof and descended to the balcony. Once there, they entered without difficulty: the bolts were very old.

en: When they entered, they found hanging upon the wall a splendid portrait of their master as they had last seen him, in all the wonder of his exquisite youth and beauty. Lying on the floor was a dead man, in evening dress, with a knife in his heart. He was withered, wrinkled, and loathsome of visage. It was not till they had examined the rings that they recognized who it was.
vi: Khi họ vào được rồi thì họ thấy trên tường treo bức chân dung lộng lẫy của ông chủ như họ đã thấy ông lần cuối, cùng tất cả sự diệu kỳ xuân sắc tuyệt vời. Nằm trên sàn là một người chết, mặc dạ phục, với một con dao trong tim. Mặt ông ta tàn tạ, nhăn nheo, ghê tởm. Mãi đến khi xem kỹ những chiếc nhẫn thì họ mới nhận ra ông ta là ai.
tr: İçeri girince duvarda efendilerinin şahane bir portresini buldular: Tıpkı onu en son gördükleri zamanki gibi, benzersiz gençliği ve güzelliğiyle göz kamaştırıyor, soluk kesiyordu. Yerde smokin giymiş, yüreğine bıçak saplanmış ölü bir adam yatmaktaydı. Yüzü buruş buruş, çökük, son derece iğrençti. Ancak yüzüklerini gözden geçirdikleri zaman onun kim olduğunu tanıyabildiler.
es: En el interior encontraron, colgado de la pared, un espléndido retrato de su señor tal como lo habían visto por última vez, en todo el esplendor de su juventud y singular belleza. En el suelo, vestido de etiqueta, y con un cuchillo clavado en el corazón, hallaron el cadáver de un hombre mayor, muy consumido, lleno de arrugas y con un rostro repugnante. Sólo lo reconocieron cuando examinaron las sortijas que llevaba en los dedos.
vi_translation: When they got in, they saw a magnificent portrait of the master hanging on the wall, just as they had seen him last, with all the wonderful springtime beauty. Lying on the floor was a dead man, dressed in evening clothes, with a knife in his heart. His face was haggard, wrinkled, and repulsive. It was not until they examined the rings closely that they recognized who he was.
tr_translation: When they entered, they found a magnificent portrait of their master on the wall: Just as they had last seen him, dazzling with his unique youth and beauty, breathtaking. On the floor lay a man in a tuxedo, with a knife plunged into his heart. His face was wrinkled, sunken, extremely repulsive. It was only when they examined his rings that they could identify who he was.
es_translation: Inside they found, hanging on the wall, a splendid portrait of their lord as they had last seen him, in all the splendor of his youth and singular beauty. On the floor, dressed in formal attire, and with a knife stuck in his heart, they found the corpse of an older man, very emaciated, full of wrinkles, and with a repugnant face. They only recognized him when they examined the rings he wore on his fingers.
